title: Yeats Country
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 WEAPONS FACING CAPITOL QUESTIONS
description: Two major weapons proposed by President Reagan, the MX missile in hardened silos and the B-1 bomber, are in jeopardy in Congress, according to Congressional, Reagan Administration and defense industry officials.

title: Matrimony
description: To the Editor:

title: BUMPHUS OUTPOINTS RODRIGUEZ FOR TITLE
description: Johnny Bumphus, who pretended that he was a slugger in the early rounds, settled down and scored a unanimous decision over Willie (Fireball) Rodriguez today, becoming the first of ''Tomorrow's Champions'' to make tomorrow today.

title: No Headline
description: HARVARD ROUTS BROWN BY 41-7

title: Travel Advisory; EXPLORERS, ANGELS AND GLADIATORS; Angel Aides to The Rescue in Mexico City; The ''Green Angels'' civilian Samaritans, who have been patrolling the highways in and around Mexico City for several years aiding motorists in distress have been joined by a new squad, the ''Silver Angels,'' composed of specially selected members of the Police Department
description: The urban corps of Silver Angels, distinguished by their silvertoned Jeeps and silver-white uniforms, have received special training and instruction, and all speak at least one foreign language. For several years, Mexico City's ''Green Angels'' have patroled the highways in green trucks looking for motorists who need help changing a tire or replacing a broken fan belt. The two patrols' functions are complementary, according to an official of the Mexican National Tourist Council. The Green Angels are equipped to perform minor auto repairs and are trained to provide first-aid if required. The Silver Angels,''who provide protection and assistance,'' the tourist council said, deal with more serious problems like accidents, illness and lost property. He also conceded that the new squad might serve as a deterrent to thieves preying on tourists. A visitor who needs help from either of the patrols should telephone 588-51-00. Seagoing Spa On the QE2 With all those choices of steak and chicken, souffles and casseroles and rich desserts - not to mention between-meal treats and, of course, alcohol - cruise passengers often question whether it is possible to avoid putting on weight during a voyage.

title: Comment; IN DEFENSE OF EX-IM
description: A T the very time that United States unemployment is growing, companies that provide millions of American jobs are being squeezed out of the international marketplace by foreign governments.

title: TUGMASTER DEFENDS TESTIMONY IN DROWNINGS
description: A tugboat captain, cross-examined about his earlier testimony, has continued to maintain that he was unaware until the next morning of the sinking of a 36-foot cabin cruiser in Long Island Sound last August.

title: Saving Energy
description: To the Business Editor: The cost of energy is, to be sure, a powerful stimulus to conserve. But to claim that price alone is the only cause of reduced energy consumption ignores the realities of consumer behavior in the marketplace.

title: LEAR, SHAKESPEARE'S 'IMPOSSIBLE' ROLE, ANIMATES A NEW PLAY
description: Near the beginning of Ronald Harwood's new play ''The Dresser,'' a small crisis erupts between an aging actor played by Paul Rogers, and his valet, a fussy young man played by Tom Courtenay. Ill, distracted, and weary of performing, night after night, year after year, the old actor, who is referred to only as ''Sir,'' is reluctant to go on stage again. It is England in January of 1942, and outside the theater, the distant rumblings of German air-raids are heard.

title: Jayne Edna Farrell, Boston Paralegal, To Be Bride in May of William Hasler
description: John L. Farrell Jr. of White Plains and Joanne Gorman Farrell of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jayne Edna Farrell, to William Roger Hasler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Francis Hasler of Cheshire, Conn. The wedding is planned for May.

title: Patricia E. Gitt Is the Bride Of Lee A. Edwards on L.I.
description: Patricia E. Gitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Gitt of Kings Point, L.I., was married there yesterday to Lee A. Edwards, son of Drina Edwards of Eastanollee, Ga. The nondenominational ceremony was performed outdoors at the home of Mrs. Herman Brickman, a friend of the couple, by the Rev. Gary E. Maier of All Saints Episcopal Church in Great Neck, L.I.

title: 58 Food Outlets Given Summonses on Health
description: The New York City Department of Health released the names of 58 food establishments last week that it found in violation of the city health code.

title: WHY ROBERT FRIPP RESURRECTED KING CRIMSON
description: What's in a name? Consider the curious case of King Crimson, the name of a succession of rock bands that were put together by the guitarist Robert Fripp between 1969 and 1974. During those years, King Crimson was more a revolving door than a band. The only musician who played in every edition of King Crimson was Mr. Fripp, and the changes in style and substance that marked the various King Crimson albums were a testament to both the fertility and restlessness of his imagination.

title: New Jersey Housing; WHAT GOES ON IN HOUSING COURT
description: JERSEY CITY AS Judge Elaine Davis sees it, the reason this city has a Housing Court is relatively simple: To give tenants a better place to live. In the two years since the court was established, it has been the central source for resolving local housing-related complaints or Housing Code violations.

title: Around the World
description: A 1,100-pound beluga whale that was being trained by the United States Navy to recover torpedoes was freed from its pen yesterday, and the environmentalist Greenpeace Foundation said it was responsible. Today, the Navy announced that the whale had returned to captivity on its own.

title: School Forfeits Games
description: Southwestern Oklahoma State will forfeit the eight football games it has played because a starting offensive lineman has been found academically ineligible, officials said today. The Bulldogs of the Oklahoma Intercollegiate Conference had a 6-2 record.

title: The Long Ordeal of James Brady
description: I found Dr. Richard Cytowic's article interesting and informative. However, I was surprised that no mention was made of clinical neuropsychology, the speciality concerned with diagnostic examination of cortical functions (abstraction, memory, intelligence, visual perception, etc.)

title: GOVERNOR
description: James J. Florio, D

title: Dance View; THE JOFFREY BALLET'S ECLECTIC FLAIR
description: There are unquestionably three major American ballet companies although one leaves to the wisdom of Solomon a determination of who is number one. By common consent, the Joffrey is number three. Or, as its current 25th anniversary season at the City Center reminds us, should the Joffrey finally be recognized as being in a category by itself? Repeatedly, the Joffrey, in its open outlook and wide-ranging repertory, tells us that ballet does not begin and end with one esthetic, that there is room for a company with a difference.

title: Carlos Alberto, Rockets Talk
description: Carlos Alberto, the ageless Brazilian sweeper, may return to the Meadowlands, this time with the New Jersey Rockets, the newest entry in the Major Indoor Soccer League.

title: Practical Traveler; WHEN YOUR AGENT CAN HELP
description: N o matter how far away you may be when a vacation is marred, your travel agent at home may prove extremely helpful in turning wrong into right and making the remainder of your trip go smoothly. There is no guarantee of this, but it may be worthwhile to make an international telephone call and rouse your agent - even at his or her home in the middle of the night - if you encounter a situation like the following:

title: IN TIBET, A TRAIL OF SMASHED TEMPLES
description: A group of Indian pilgrims who for the first time in 22 years were permitted to visit a lake sacred to Hindus in southwestern Tibet have returned with descriptions of monasteries that were destroyed in China's Cultural Revolution.

title: PROSECUTOR RECALLS HIS DAYS ON COURT
description: Seventeen years ago, Edward A. McDonald made the freshman basketball team at Boston College after having played varsity ball at Xaverian High School in Brooklyn. But after two preseason games on the bench, he realized he would never be more than the ninth or 10th man on the team, so he quit to concentrate on other school activities. It was, he thought, the end of his involvement with B.C. basketball.

title: ATLANTIC CITY TO VOTE ON MAYOR-COUNCIL RULE
description: Voters here will decide Tuesday whether to scrap their 70-year-old commission form of government in favor of a mayorcouncil form.

title: Millard Fillmore
description: To the Editor:

title: 6-0 Hempstead Rallies to Top Lynbrook
description: Hempstead rallied from a 14-6 halftime deficit and defeated Lynbrook yesterday, 24-14, for its sixth victory without a loss, including four in Conference III-A. The defeat was the first of the season for Lynbrook after five triumphs. The Owls fell into a tie for second place with New Hyde Park, which beat Carey, 18-0, for a 3-1 record.

title: Columbia Settles Case In Death of Girl in '79
description: Columbia University has agreed to pay $153,000 to the parents of a Barnard College freshman killed in 1979 when she was struck on the head by a piece of masonry that fell from a building it owned.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: ''RIGHT across there,'' says Bill Davenport, gesticulating at a row of comfortable houses surrounded by tall trees and shrubbery, ''we grew corn 10 feet tall. That was prime land.''

title: Sunday Observer; By Russell Baker
description: Delights of the Time Warp It is 2 A.M., but you can forget about the hot chocolate and bedtime for me, folks, because Kirk Douglas and the aircraft carrier Nimitz have just slipped through a time warp, and when people slip through time warps it takes wild horses to drag me away from the television set.

title: PIANIST: ROBERT TAUB'S DEBUT
description: In a program favoring lean idioms and abstract passions, there is always the danger of failing to impress one's audience with the volcanic potency of one's playing. That was a risk Robert Taub, a pianist trained at Juilliard and Princeton, seemed not to mind as he made his New York debut Thursday night in Alice Tully Hall, playing Leon Kirchner's restlessly involute Sonata (1948), Beethoven's Sonata in C minor (Op. 111), and the ''Davidsbundlertanze'' of Robert Schumann.

title: CANARSIE DEFEATS ERASMUS, 44-0, FOR SEVENTH STRAIGHT VICTORY
description: Canarsie remained undefeated in P.S.A.L. Brooklyn B division play with a 44-0 rout of Erasmus yesterday. Ron (The Snake) McLaughlin ran for 141 yards on 20 carries, and scored the first two touchdowns for the Chiefs. He now has 853 yards in seven games, and 11 touchdowns.

title: FRESH SEAFOOD IN BEFITTING SETTING
description: FRESH seafood is the stock in trade at Sam's Restaurant in Rockville Centre. This small, stylishly attractive marine blue restaurant is connected to the fish market of the same name next door. Fish made of fluorescent lights cast a welcoming glow in the window.

title: HOUSE CURBS ITS OWN SPECIAL INTEREST GROUPS
description: The House of Representatives has established a set of rules governing the behavior of special interest caucuses on Capitol Hill -groups of lawmakers who band together to promote the cause of mushrooms and steel, New England and the Sun Belt, women and blacks.

title: New York Times Magazine November 1, 1981
description: William Safire 10 On Language The Great Out There Russell Baker 19 Sunday Observer Delights of the Time Warp Hedrick Smith 24 How Many Billions for Defense? Henry Leifermann 28 Herschel Walker's Run to Glory Morton Hunt 42 A Fraud That Shook the World of Science Maurice Carroll 60 Reagan's Stake in New Jersey's Election Suzanne Slesin 80 Design Drama on a Small Stage 84 Fashion Galanos Defines Evenings in Black Craig Claiborne 86 Food with Pierre Franey Unorthodox Variations on Chili 101 Puzzles Answers, Page 108 110 Letters Cover: Photograph by David Burnett/Contact Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: THE LONG BLACK MOVEMENT TOWARD JUSTICE
description: THERE IS A RIVER The Black Struggle for Freedom in America. By Vincent Harding. Illustrated. 416 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95. By ERIC FONER

title: Theater; BEHIND THE HOOPLA AT GOODSPEED
description: ''BLOOMER GIRL,'' at the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam through Nov. 22, dates back only to 1944, which makes it a youngish musical in terms of the way things are done at the Goodspeed. But it is set in the year 1861, and that has caused some problems for the folks at the restored Goodspeed, whose narrow halls, stairways and doors work just fine for actresses in the slender costumes of the 1920's and 30's but are treacherous for hoop skirts.

title: Miss Cooney Plans Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Cooney of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Lynn Cooney, to Judson Hugh Thuerk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh D. Thuerk of Easton, Conn.

title: Children's Books
description: THE MAGIC BOAT By Tom Seidmann-Freud. Illustrated. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow Books. $5.95. (Ages 3 to 5) By GEORGE A.WOODS

title: DIGITAL DISKMAKING CASTS ITS SPELL ON 'THE MAGIC FLUTE'
description: When it comes to recordings, some operas are blessed and some operas are cursed. Among Mozart's operas alone, ''Don Giovanni'' is an example of the curse - there have been no really superlative recordings, ever. And ''Die Zauberflote,'' or ''The Magic Flute,'' has been blessed, and not just by Mozart himself: he blessed ''Don Giovanni'' too, after all, which has not solved its problems in the recording studio.

title: NOW TO FIT THE AWACS INTO WIDER DIPLOMACY
description: In the tense days after the assassination of Anwar el-Sadat and during the debate that led last week to approval of the sale of Awacs planes to Saudi Arabia, the Reagan Administration has, in effect, proclaimed a new, wide-ranging commitment to protect all friendly states in the Middle East against outside aggression.

title: A CLOSE MATCH: GIANTS' DEFENSE AGAINST JETS' OFFENSE
description: Football players know what to watch for in a game - and it isn't necessarily the quarterback throwing to a receiver. So there will be half a dozen battles, skirmishes, and holding actions going on at once at Giants Stadium today during every play as the Jets and Giants go at each other.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: TODAY'S IMMIGRANTS, THEIR STORIES A New Look at the Newest Americans. By Thomas Kessner and Betty Boyd Caroli. 317 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $16.95.

title: QUEENS CONTESTS LACKING SUSPENSE
description: The victory parties will not start in Queens until after the polls close at 9 P.M. next Tuesday, but that is more out of respect for tradition than doubt about the outcome.

title: Critics' Choices
description: JAZZ Sonny Rollins, who will be at the Bottom Line on Friday and Saturday nights, is the most inventive improvisor and the most awesome technician presently playing jazz on the tenor saxophone. Like several other musicians who are capable of sculpturing improvisations as coherent and complete as works that result from the long, agonizing labors of the finest composers, Mr. Rollins does not seem to be able to fake a performance. If he does not happen to feel like playing, he will begin and end tunes and let his accompanists take care of the improvising. But most of the time, especially lately, Mr. Rollins has felt like playing. When he feels like playing, he does not need accompanists, and these occasions are among the most satisfying experiences one can derive from listening to jazz. For more information, call 228-6300.

title: A Mutt's Heroism Rewarded
description: It was Christmas Eve, five years ago, when Howard and Fern Carlson returned to their home in Granite Falls, Wash., and found a young, unwanted, injured, whimpering dog, who had been left on their grounds.

title: BOW SEASON OPENS AMID DEER DEBATE
description: SOMERS IN these bucolic northern Westchester precincts, where the oaks and maples are losing their multicolored mantles and frost may cover unharvested pumpkins, deer will have to exercise more than their usual caution starting this morning.

title: DOUBLE FEATURE IN IRVINGTON FRIDAY
description: IRVINGTON IRVINGTON is celebrating a double premiere this Friday evening when the first showing of the film ''Suburban Visions: Westchester Architecture,'' produced by the Film and Video Workshop of Westchester, opens in the newly restored Town Hall Playhouse here.

title: Fathers Get Maternity Leave
description: Fathers as well as mothers may take up to six months of unpaid leave after the births of babies under a revised maternity policy at The Minneapolis Star and Tribune Company. The company, announcing the decision Wednesday, said it was naming the new benefit ''parenting leave.''

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: 1980), a complex, enigmatic man who, as a law professor and a U.S. Supreme Court justice for 36 years, worked ardently for liberal, humanitarian causes, but in his personal life was irascible and often hardly humane. Our reviewer Alan M. Dershowitz called this study by a New York Law School professor ''excellent ... probing yet balanced.''

title: ZAMBIAN UNIONIST OPPOSING KAUNDA
description: Shortly before he was detained last summer, Frederick Chiluba, Zambia's most prominent labor leader, sought increased contacts with Western diplomats here and invited them to compare his movement to the Solidarity union in Poland.

title: PAPER IN DISPUTE OVER A CIVIC ROLE
description: The Minneapolis Star has sought in recent articles to show that its coverage of planning and construction of the city's nearly completed domed stadium was not tainted because the paper's top executive had promoted the sports arena.

title: Thai Troops Search 2 Homes After Rumors of a Coup Plot
description: Thai troops, on full military alert after rumors of a possible coup attempt, searched the homes today of two former army officers involved in an attempted takeover in April.

title: HOME BRINGS TIME THE BACON
description: L IKE Henry R. Luce, Time Inc.'s long-time editor in chief, James O. Heyworth is a lanky graduate of Hotchkiss and Yale with an Ivy League mandarin manner.

title: Chess; YOUTHFUL CHAMPION
description: Ognjen Cvitan of Yugoslavia captured the World Junior Championship in Mexico City with a 10 1/2-2 1/2 score in a Swiss-system field of 46 players, none of whom would have had his 20th birthday until after the tournament.

title: Millard Fillmore
description: To the Editor:

title: ELECTRICITY PLAN UPSETS NON-LILCO USERS
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE THE ''piggy's share'' of hydroelectric power produced by New York State, the nation's cheapest power, is being gobbled up by only 2 percent of the state's residential customers, according to the State Power Authority chairman, John S. Dyson. He proposes to change all that, much to the dismay of those few Long Islanders who now benefit.

title: The Week in Business; THE FED CUTS THE DISCOUNT RATE
description: The discount rate, which is charged by the Federal Reserve for borrowing by members banks, was cut to 13 percent from 14 percent. It was the first significant easing of the Fed's grip on the nations's credit in over a year. Separately, the Fed said the money supply increased $1 billion in the latest reporting week.

title: BRINGING EDITH WHARTON'S WORLD TO TV
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Steve Lawson is freelance writer with a special interest in television adaptation. By STEVE LAWSON

title: DECIDING HOW TO STOP HAITIANS- AND WHY
description: There was a wretched symmetry to it: While lifeless Haitian bodies washed up on a Florida beach Monday morning, live Haitian bodies plucked from another foundering boat by the United States Coast Guard were being hauled back to the island they tried to flee.

title: 'They Want to Be Babied Themselves'
description: Births to unwed females in the United States went up 50 percent in the 1970's: a shocking figure. It encompasses realities that are even more so.

title: Pamela Carney Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Franklin W. Carney of Melrose, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Carney, to Rowland B. Bates, son of Mr. and Mrs. Barstow Bates of Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: LARGE TURNOUT EXPECTED TUESDAY
description: DESPITE public-opinion surveys showing that voters are having a difficult time clearly separating the major-party candidates for Governor, an unusually large turnout is expected at the polls on Tuesday.

title: A TASTE OF CHINA IN AMMAN
description: CHRISTOPHER S. WREN is chief of the Times bureau in Peking. By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN

title: RX FOR SAFE SKIING
description: GEOFF KALISH, M.D., who is group director of clinical research for a pharmaceutical company in Nanuet, N.Y., writes on health topics. By GEOFF KALISH, M.D.

title: Bridge; AN UPDATE ON BIDDING WEAK FOUR-CARD SUITS
description: If you brought to a presentday tournament a player who last played the game half a century ago, he would be considerably surprised by many aspects of modern bidding. One of them would be the general tendency of most experts to bid weak four-card suits.

title: COMPLAINTS RISE OVER NOISE AT KENNEDY
description: CEDARHURST PEOPLE in the Five Towns and neighboring communities have increased their complaints about noise from aircraft flying in and out of Kennedy International Airport since the beginning of the air-traffic controllers' strike in August.

title: Business Conditions; FOREIGN FARMERS
description: The concern about foreign ownership of American agricultural land may not be warranted, recent Agriculture Department statistics indicate.

title: PROSPECTORS WARNED OF MERCURY HAZARDS IF HEATED TO A VAPOR
description: Amateur prospectors driven by the high price of gold are smelting ore with mercury on the kitchen stove and thereby risking being poisoned, a specialist says.

title: VIETNAMESE PILOTS EXPLAIN DEFECTION TO CHINA
description: A month ago, 10 Vietnamese squeezed into an American made Vietnamese Air Force helicopter and flew across the border into China's Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, explaining to surprised Chinese frontier guards that they were unhappy with life at home.

title: Other World Events; One Job After Another
description: When Parliament rejected his first choice for Prime Minister, an American-educated pediatrician, Iran's clergyman President, Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, had a hard time coming up with a new nominee. Assassinations and purges had eliminated many possible candidates - the President himself almost died in a bomb explosion in June - and few survivors could meet the strict religious and political qualifications set by Iran's fundamentalist-run Parliament.

title: HAUTE CUISINE IN CASINOLAND
description: ATLANTIC CITY THIS resort has been called many things, but never, even in the pre-gambling casino era, had it ever been called, a gourmet capital. Now, however, a few residents have formed a chapter of the Chaine des Rotisseurs, the Paris-based society that caters to some of the world's most cultivated taste buds.

title: VIRTUOSOS PLAY NEW INSTRUMENTS, TOO
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Ellen S. Freilich is a freelance writer with a special interest in music. By ELLEN S. FREILICH

title: NEW YORK STATE DECLARED FREE OF LEADING LIVESTOCK DISEASE
description: For the first time since records have been kept, state officials say New York is free of brucellosis, an infectious animal disease that is the leading health problem in the livestock industry of the United States.

title: The World; Namibia Talks Make Progress, In Principle
description: Namibia negotiators gained new ground last week amid continuing skepticism that they would arrive at their destination - internationally recognized independence for the South Africancontrolled territory -by the end of next year.

title: 2 VILLAGES CONSIDER SELF-RULE
description: AT the junction of the Island's forks, residents of an economic dead spot encompassing the hamlets of Flanders and Northampton are considering whether they can afford to take their destiny into their own hands.

title: BAYSIDE'S HARMON BROTHERS CONTINUE A TRADITION
description: In the 10 years that the Public Schools Athletic League has had championship playoffs in A division football, Bayside has won five times. The Commodores, currently in quest of a third straight city title, owe a lot of their recent success to the Harmon family.

title: HOW MANY BILLIONS FOR DEFENSE?
description: The mood in Congress had already turned wary by the time Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger brought the revised military budget to Capitol Hill this fall. Even though he was actually snipping a little bit off the Reagan Administration's colossal, five-year $1.5 trillion defense buildup, Republicans as well as Democrats were balking. For while Congress, like the public at large, generally backs a boost for defense, more and more members have questioned whether President Reagan was overdoing it and was using ever-deeper cuts in domestic programs to finance huge increases in military spending beyond those already proposed by Jimmy Carter.

title: Rescue Bid Cost 193 Million
description: The abortive effort to rescue American hostages in Iran last year cost $193 million, Pentagon officials told Congress in testimony released yesterday. A 90-man force flew into the Iranian desert on April 24, 1980, but the mission was called off after three of eight helicopters broke down. Eight men were killed when a helicopter collided with a transport plane while taking off from the desert.

title: FINDING THE PERFECT SLOPE
description: DAVID BIRD is a reporter for the The New York Times. By DAVID BIRD

title: MUSEUM EXHIBITS APPALACHIAN ART
description: A two-month exhibition of paintings and sculpture by Appalachian artists opened today in the marble halls of the National Museum of American Art. The exhibition, ''More Than Land or Sky,'' is the first such prominent showing ever staged of the work of contemporary Appalachian artists.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: A SPECIAL PROBLEM OF A SPECIAL SESSION
description: That sinking feeling weak students have before an important exam settled on the Capitol during the Legislature's renewed session. The bill that brought the Legislature back - property-tax assessment - was due for a vote, and many lawmakers said they hadn't a clue what the 18-page document really meant for homeowners.

title: Stage View; THESE PLAYS REFLECT THEIR DIRECTOR'S WEAKNESS
description: Istill think of Robert Altman as a smoke-filled room, perhaps because the fogbound hangover I acquired while watching his film ''McCabe and Mrs. Miller'' has never entirely left me. I had admired ''M*A*S*H'' enormously. Then I went to the McCabe opus and sat in stunned disbelief as the director carefully drew veil over veil across whatever it was I was trying hard to see and hear. I was, in fact, trying to see and hear the principals. Mr. Altman had developed a habit of placing any two characters who were talking to each other deep in a corner of a rough-hewn room. He then rushed into camera range some 15 or 20 extras in whose existence no one was interested and scattered them about between the two characters and the camera lens (us), urging them to whoop and holler to their hearts' content. He then filled whatever was left of the visible area with smoke. I am exaggerating, but not much.

title: EDUCATORS ASSAIL STUDENT AID CUTS
description: Educators and college financial aid officers have sharply criticized the Reagan Administration's proposal to reduce funds for the largest Federal aid program for needy college students.

title: TRIUMPHANT 'DA' IN MADISON, DREADFUL 'U.S.O.' IN MONTCLAIR
description: MADISON ''OLOVE is the crooked thing,'' wrote William Butler Yeats. Moreover, the winding paths that divide or unite a father and son are beautifully trod in Hugh Leonard's ''Da,'' now being triumphantly presented by the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival at Drew University.

title: Around the Nation; Ranger Crewman Guilty Of Mistreatment Charges
description: A Navy petty officer convicted of assault and maltreatment of sailors aboard the aircraft carrier Ranger was sentenced today to 30 days at hard labor.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Free Cars
description: General Motors was stuck with hundreds of homes that it had bought from transferred employees around the country. The company also was having trouble selling new cars.

title: No Headline
description: Around the World; New Iranian Premier Is Formally Appointed

title: Antiques; MARITIME EXHIBIT COVERS EARLY TRADE
description: NEW HAVEN AS early as the turn of the 18th century, local merchants dreamed of the time when New Haven would be an important mercantile center and Connecticut-built ships would be sent out to sea on long and profitable voyages to Europe and the Far East.

title: U.S. PICKS UP A REPAIR BILL FOR 2 BRIDGES
description: In 1978, Congress voted to finance the rehabilitation of several major bridges in New York City. But early this year, the Reagan Administration raised a question: What about the portion of the bridges over which subway trains travel - should that cost also be borne by the Federal Government?

title: Art View; ARE THE STANDARDS TOO LOW FOR AMERICAN ART?; WASHINGTON
description: Certain exhibitions, while not especially noteworthy for the quality of the objects they contain, are nonetheless interesting for the way they illuminate the contemporary cultural scene. The show called ''An American Perspective,'' which is currently on view at the National Gallery of Art (through Jan. 31), is an event of this sort. It is not an exhibition of much interest, frankly, to anyone on the lookout for a vivid or transcendent esthetic experience. The art in it - 100 examples of 19th-century American painting, drawing and sculpture from the collection of Jo Ann and Julian Ganz Jr. - is mostly pretty dull. But as evidence of the runaway boom that has lately elevated even the most modest accomplishments of 19th-century American art to a position of unprecedented prominence, the show has an important story to tell.

title: INDEPENDENTS: BUFFOONS--OR VOX POPULI?
description: THE 10 independent candidates for Governor this year have not quite captured the public's attention the way the late Henry Krajewski used to. Mr. Krajewski, a pig farmer from Secaucus and a perennial candidate for both President and Governor, ran on the slogan:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''With the country in dire straits, this is no time for work stoppages and protests.'' - A resolution approved by the Polish Parliament. (20:1.)

title: CORA E.M. CRANE
description: Cora Ellen Miller Crane, mother of two Congressmen from Illinois and the wife of a newspaper columnist, will be buried tomorrow.

title: Parents Fighting Drugs, Alcohol in Eastchester
description: We read with great interest the article by Virginia Satkowski entitled ''Parents Initiate Drug-Abuse Program'' (Oct. 4). It is so good to know that there is a real effort under way countywide to combat the problems of drinking and drugs that seem to be on the increase among our teen-agers and in some cases elementary school children.

title: TV View; BUSINESS NEWS IS GOOD NEWS
description: Economics may be the dismal science, but the subject of business is sparkling these days on television. Suddenly, it seems, the home screen is overflowing with talk about ''CDs'' and Treasury-bill auction rates. The daily report that used to be limited to some brief graphics indicating whether the stock market went up or down has now been expanded to special segments and, in some instances, full halfhours focused on nothing but business news. In addition to the granddaddy of all these shows, ''Wall Street Week,'' there is ''The Nightly Business Report,'' also on public television, ''Louis Rukeyser's Business Jounral'' on WCBS-TV and ''Moneyline'' on the Cable News Network. Dow-Jones, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, is supplying short reports to television and radio stations. Elsewhere on cable, there is ''This Week on Wall Street,'' carried on the Christian Broadcasting Network, and Home Box Office, the paycable operation, has launched ''Money Matters,'' based on Money magazine.

title: MURDER FORGOTTEN
description: PEOPLE VERSUS KIRK By Robert Traver. 279 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $12.95.

title: 150 GRAINGER SCORES
description: Percy Grainger, the noted Australian composer, onetime society pianist and protege of Edvard Grieg, was best known for lilting English-style folk pieces such as ''Country Gardens'' and ''Molly on the Shore,'' rather than the avant-garde ''free music'' he wrote sub rosa in graph form.

title: Rye Wins Battle of Unbeatens
description: Undefeated Rye made it six victories in a row by routing previously unbeaten Eastchester, 31-8, yesterday. Bob Flood and B.J. Surhoff led the way for the Garnets, Flood scoring a pair of touchdowns, with Surhoff scoring once and running 55 yards to set up another touchdown.

title: Suspect in Student's Slaying Held to Face Trial in Arizona
description: A Tucson man has been held for trial in the 1980 slaying of a University of Arizona student, Laura Lynn Webster, from Hamburg, N.Y.

title: November 1, 1981
description: NONFICTION THE BEST OF DEAR ABBY. By Abigail Van Buren. 12 A BINTEL BRIEF: Volume II. Letters to the Jewish Daily Forward 1950-80. Edited by Isaac Metzker. 12 CHRISTINA ROSSETTI: A Divided Life. By Georgina Battiscombe. 16 LADIES OF THE LEISURE CLASS: The Bourgeoises of Northern France in the 19th Century. By Bonnie G. Smith. 13 THE MISMEASURE OF MAN. By Stephen Jay Gould. 11 TERRAINS OF THE HEART AND OTHER ESSAYS ON HOME. By Willie Morris. 16 THERE IS A RIVER: The Black Struggle for Freedom in America. By Vincent Harding. 7 TODAY'S IMMIGRANTS, THEIR STORIES: A New Look at the Newest Americans. By Thomas Kessner and Betty Boyd Caroli. 13 TOO MANY SONGS BY TOM LEHRER: With Not Enough Drawings by Ronald Searle. 13 THE TRANSATLANTIC SLAVE TRADE: A History. By James A. Rawley. 7 VAN WYCK BROOKS: A WRITER'S LIFE. By Raymond Nelson. 9 VICHY FRANCE AND THE JEWS. By Michael R. Marrus and Robert O. Paxton. 1 WALDO EMERSON: A Biography. By Gay Wilson Allen. 9 FICTION AND POETRY ANGEL EYES. By Loren D. Estleman. 41 THE BOOK OF REVELATIONS. By Rob Swigart. 14 THE CARIBBEAN ACCOUNT. By Alan Furst. 42 THE CASE OF THE SLIDING POOL. title: FUN DOLPHIN, SMART WHALE
description: EASY TRAVEL TO OTHER PLANETS By Ted Mooney. 278 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95. THE BOOK OF REVELATIONS By Rob Swigart. 278 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $13.50.

title: DANCE: MISS DEAN, COMPOSER
description: If Laura Dean were not a choreographer - and the composer of the scores for her own dances, as well - she could be a designer of kaleidoscopes, for her works are kaleidoscopic in character. Like those often mesmerizing toys, her dances consist of tiny bits of material that can be rearranged in apparently infinite combinations. Everything is always the same, yet everything is always different.

title: CARPENTER GETS A CHANCE TO ROLL
description: 24, here two months ago in an exhibition game, the Giants' running game was lethargic. The team gained 75 yards that night, and when the regular season began two weeks later, it started going from bad to the worst in the National Football League.

title: A STONECUTTER FACE-LIFTS YALE'S TOWER
description: NEW HAVEN THE view from Harkness Memorial Tower, nearly 200 feet above the Yale University campus, inspires a calm perspective. Below are the Gothic-style university buildings, beyond is the dwarfed city skyline and farther out lies the blurred autumn countryside.

title: Cecile Doelger Is Wed To David A. Newberg
description: The marriage of Cecile Marie Doelger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank G. Doelger of New Canaan, Conn., to David Allen Newberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Newberg of Brightwaters, L.I., took place yesterday. Civil Court Judge John A.K. Bradley performed the ceremony at the Burden Mansion in Manhattan.

title: Monte L. McQueen Married to Kevin F. Bransfield
description: Monte Louise McQueen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. McQueen of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Kevin F. Bransfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Bransfield of Lynn and West Dennis, Mass. The Rev. Kenyon J. Wildrick performed the ceremony at the Community Congregational Church.

title: C.P.I. Finger, Inflation Soup
description: The Consumer Price Index has long been like the cook's finger: when dipped in to test the temperature, it changes the taste of the soup. Now, at last, Washington is going do something about it.

title: The Region; Up to There in Tax Tangles
description: For years, New York State's system of property tax assessment has been criticized as confusing, inequitable and, quite possibly, illegal. Such might also be said of the Legislature's attempt last week to reform it.

title: Herring
description: To the Editor:

title: PAGEANTRY IN LONDON'S CITY
description: If you missed the Royal Wedding, the annual Lord Mayor's Procession through the City of London, always held on the second Saturday in November, is the ideal opportunity to witness the pageantry that Britain alone does so well.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: Business Conditions; NEW YORK INCOMES UP
description: Helped by lower inflation and a general improvement in economic conditions, personal incomes for New York State residents showed renewed strength last year.

title: STATE WILL RESUME TESTS FOR HAIRDRESSERS
description: HARTFORD PROTESTS by hairdressers, barbers and cosmetologists evidently prompted action last week when the state's Department of Health Services announced that a test for aspiring hairdressers would be given next month.

title: YALE 24-3 WINNER OVER DARTMOUTH
description: Yale's undefeated football team made Dartmouth victim No. 7 today, 24-3, and four exceptional offensive players had a lot to do with it. They were the quarterback, John Rogan; the running back, Rich Diana; the wide receiver, Curt Grieve, and the kicker, Tony Jones.

title: Pamela Crombie Married To Michael Harry Calman
description: Pamela Anne Crombie, daughter of Mrs. David J. Crombie of New Canaan, Conn., and Michael Harry Calman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert I. Calman of Mamaroneck, N.Y., were married yesterday.

title: Navy Tops Recruiting Goals; Pay and Housing Gains Cited
description: For the second consecutive year the Navy has exceeded its recruiting goals while gaining people with higher intelligence and exceeding its requirements for doctors, according to the Navy Recruiting Command said.

title: Santa Fe Rescue
description: To the Editor:

title: HORSE MEDICATION IS VOLATILE ISSUE
description: OVER the last 10 years, New York horsemen could watch with detachment as the issue of medicating race horses has vexed almost every other racing state in the country. New York and Arkansas were the only states never to initiate so-called ''permissive medication'' programs that later backfired when taken advantage of by unscrupulous trainers.

title: Joanne Douglas And Brent Olsson, Lawyer, Are Wed
description: Joanne Moment Douglas and Brent Kristian Olsson were married yesterday in the Trinity Episcopal Church in Newport, R.I. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. D. Loren Coyle.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Packagers. What do these books, now in the bookstores or soon to arrive, have in common?

title: REFLECTIONS OF AN INEXPERT TRAVELER
description: Style.'' By QUENTIN CRISP

title: POP SINGER: SUSANNAH MCCORKLE
description: Although Susannah McCorkle's early influences as a singer came from the jazz world, she is most comfortable and most effective in her programs at Michael's Pub, where she will be singing through Nov. 14, when she gets away from songs that lend themselves to jazz treatment.

title: Gina Lorini Lemon Is Married to Gregory Martino
description: The marriage of Gina Lorini Lemon of Brooklyn and Gregory Marcel Martino of Mount Vernon, N. Y., took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of SS. Peter and Paul in Mount Vernon. Msgr.

title: Stuart A. Irvine Will Marry Elizabeth McK. Tobie
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Alan F. Tobie of Lancaster, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth McKenrick Tobie, to Stuart Andrew Irvine, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander R. Irvine of Los Angeles. A December wedding is planned.

title: PARLIAMENT BIDS POLISH WORKERS STOP ALL STRIKES
description: Parliament today acceded to the wishes of Poland's Communist Party leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, and passed a resolution appealing for an immediate halt of all strikes.

title: Comparing the '82 Models
description: a horde of '82 models, maybe 50 of them, so new they aren't even in the showrooms yet, freshly minted and smelling that way. Keys dangle from each ignition, and the road awaits; just help yourself.

title: Around the World; British Leyland Accord Fails to Avert a Stoppage
description: Last-ditch talks by management and unions of British Leyland, the huge state-owned auto manufacturer, produced a tentative settlement late yesterday, but it came too late to avert a strike that began at midnight.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION: AN ABUSIVE SYSTEM
description: NEW JERSEY'S unemployment compensation program is among the worst in the nation. The system needs a complete overhaul. Employers and the unemployed are being cheated by the abuses of the program.

title: RCTV
description: To the Business Editor: It is inaccurate to refer to ''NBC's Entertainment Channel.'' The Entertainment Channel, a new pay cable program service, is a joint venture of Rockefeller Center Inc. and the RCA Corporation. There is no affiliation with the National Broadcasting Company. HOWARD BURKAT Vice President Advertising and Promotion The Entertainment Channel New York, N.Y., Oct. 27, 1981

title: MARY CODD'S HOUSING VIEWS
description: Mary T. Codd, the Liberal Party candidate for Mayor, was asked by The New York Times for her views on major issues confronting the city. Following is her reply on housing. The views of the other mayoral candidates were published earlier.

title: Numismatics; SPECIALTY: PRISON MONEY
description: Mention the word ''bars'' to most numismatists and they will think of gold and silver bars or ingots. But mention the same word to Jerry Zara of Point Pleasant, N.J., and he thinks of something quite different: the prison bars that separate inmates from their freedom.

title: Leisure; ROSEMARY, THE HERB OF MANY USES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Richard M. Bacon has written several books on gardening. By RICHARD M. BACON

title: Child Loans
description: To the Business Editor: In ''College on an Interest-Free Loan,'' (Oct. 11), you tried to improve on something that is already too good to be true. The Internal Revenue Service will undoubtedly be delighted if your readers follow your advice.

title: U.N. Team in Thailand
description: A United Nations team arrived here today to investigate allegations that Vietnamese troops are using toxic chemicals against guerrillas in Cambodia. In their one-week visit, they are to interview Cambodian refugees along the Thai-Cambodian border.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE Nassau Republican organization, which is run like the goodsized business it is, has relocated from a modern office building in downtown Hempstead to a four-story former Knights of Columbus hall on Post Avenue in the heart of Westbury.

title: DANIEL L. DYER JR. FIANCE OF CATHERINE LYNN OLSON
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Olson Jr. of Chatham, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Lynn Olson, to Daniel L. Dyer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dyer of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: TEXT OF 8 QUESTIONS ON TUESDAY'S BALLOT
description: Following are the public questions that will be put to the voters on Tuesday. They are taken verbatim from a sample ballot mailed to registered voters in the Seventh District in the Township of South Orange Village. Public Question No.1: Water Supply Bond Issue

title: Three Wounded in Hebron
description: An Israeli was stabbed and two Arabs were shot in an incident in Israeli-occupied Hebron this evening, and the military government subsequently imposed a curfew on the center of the town.

title: Marine Corps Marathon Draws Field of 10,000
description: The largest field in the race's history, nearly 10,000 men and women, is expected for tomorrow's Marine Corps Marathon.

title: P.O.W. DEATHS LAID TO GERM-WAR TESTS BY JAPAN
description: American prisoners of war were among 3,000 people who died as a result of germ-warfare tests and medical experiments conducted by Japan during World War II, according to a published report.

title: Environews
description: IT MAY be decided soon whether hunters or animal lovers get 212 acres in West Milford Township in Passaic County. Both interests might even benefit.

title: Essay; ISRAEL AFTER AWACS
description: Exactly one day after its triumph in the U.S. Senate, Saudi Arabia raised the price of its oil by $2 a barrel and delighted the Libyans by curtailing production to keep world oil prices up. The U.S. motorist suddenly discovered who would be paying for the missiles, bomb racks and Awacs in the greatest arms sale in history.

title: CAN A WOMAN CONCEIVE UNDER WATER
description: THE BEST OF DEAR ABBY By Abigail Van Buren. 252 pp. Kansas City: Andrews and McMeel. $9.95TREADING ''The Best of Dear Abby'' is like opening a jar of peanuts. Who can read just one letter? Once you start, say, with the woman who let her ex-husband and his wife live with her and her new husband because they (couple number one) were broke, and is giving them a baby shower to boot, your appetite is whetted for what's to come. Will it be the one about how Indian men are better lovers than palefaces because of ''closely guarded tribal secrets on how to please a woman''? Or the missive from the lady who wanted to find a foam rubber derriere? Or the anguished cry from the man who has been kissed to exhaustion by his girlfriend: ''Last night we sat on her sofa kissing from midnight until 2 A.M., and I hardly managed to get my own lips together once in those two hours. If my nose had been stopped up, I would have suffocated. All this time she was glued to my face, wearing me out.''

title: Economic Affairs; THE PROBLEM'S NOT THE DEFICIT
description: T O Members of Congress: As this session of Congress draws to a close, you face a time of increasingly difficult budgetary choices. On the one hand, the Administration is pressing you to slash another $13 billion from the 1982 budget. At the same time, the economy is poised for a nosedive into the depths of a recession - a time at which budget cutting hardly seems the most urgent task.

title: AMID POMP, ANTIGUA GAINS ITS INDEPENDENCE
description: ST. JOHN'S, Antigua, Sunday, Nov. 1 (AP) - This Caribbean island and nearby Barbuda became an independent nation last midnight, ending nearly 350 years of British rule.

title: Lew Jenkins Is Dead at 64; Held Lighweight Title in 1940
description: Verlin Lew Jenkins, who became lightweight boxing champion of the world in 1940, died yesterday at the Oakland Naval Regional Medical Center after a long illness. He was 64 years old.

title: Connecticut Housing; PARLEY CONSIDERS ALTERNATIVES
description: BECAUSE of record-high mortgage interest rates, virtually no new construction and a shrinking rental market, the state's Annual Housing Conference chose this year to focus on possible remedies that participants said might have been overlooked in the past because they had been considered politically unacceptable.

title: Hannah M. Sexton Is the Bride of John Entwistle
description: Hannah M. Sexton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Patrick Sexton of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and Point Lookout, L.I., was married yesterday to John Craig Entwistle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jean E. Entwistle of New York. The Rev. W. Laurence O'Neill performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Family in Flushing, Queens.

title: Mailbox; Uproar in Stands Appalls Young
description: To the Sports Editor: I sincerely hope that Paul Gardella's article (''After 39 Years: Goodbye Rangers, I Hate to See Me Go,'' The New York Times, Sept. 27), describing the ''quality of contemporary hockey fans,'' at Madison Square Garden, was read by the pitiful hierarchy that claims to be in charge of controlling this ''sporting'' arena. Until this time, there has been no talk of the deteriorating inhumane conditions a fan must put up with, while desperately trying to enjoy a New York Rangers hockey game.

title: Crafts
description: LINCROFT AFEELING that the outdoors has moved inside prevails around ''Natural Basketry,'' an exhibition of the works of Carol Grant Hart. The display of about 30 pieces - it will continue in the Galleryin-the-Loft at Brookdale Community College through Nov. 13 - offers visitors an opportunity to view the largest group of this nationally known basketmaker's works ever assembled for one show.

title: STATE WARNED OF REPURCUSSIONS IF IT CONTINUES TO IMPORT ELECTRICITY
description: NEWARK NEW JERSEY may be subject to intervention by other states if it continues to rely on out-of-state generating facilities, according to an executive of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.

title: COUNTDOWN PREPARATIONS GO WELL FOR 2D LAUNCHING OF THE COLUMBIA
description: The countdown for the second flight of the space shuttle Columbia began early today and was running smoothly and slightly ahead of schedule for a planned launching 7:30 A.M. Wednesday.

title: NEW YORK PURSUES SALES-TAX ACCORD
description: PURCHASING items in New York State and having them shipped home has for years been a popular and legal way for Connecticut shoppers to avoid paying sales taxes. But New York, in coming to terms with Massachussetts last week, now has agreements with three of its five bordering states prohibiting the practice, and talks involving similar agreements are continuing with its two remaining neighbors: Connecticut and New Jersey.

title: COLORS DRAW THE YOUNG TO PEKING CLOTHES FAIR
description: A throng of young Chinese jostled around the outdoor stand where down-filled parkas, previously made for export, were selling for the equivalent of $22, a bargain.

title: GASTINEAU IS LEADING CHEERS
description: NEW YORK, NEW YORK? Shucks. It used to get Mark Gastineau really annoyed. Everything about the Big Apple was just ... well, it wasn't like back home on the ranch. But now, he says, ''I feel like a native New Yorker.'' And he has been thinking about today's game. He doesn't care whether some of the Giants think he's a ''hot dog'' if he starts to whirl in the air - a recent innovation - after he sacks a quarterback. He is, he explains, proud to be a New York Jet. And these are, after all, the Giants his team is playing.

title: ACCORD REACHED IN SUIT OVER CHRISTIANS' ADS
description: The publisher of The Christian Yellow Pages, a business directory for ''born-again'' Christians, has agreed to a court-approved settlement of a suit brought on behalf of two Jewish businessmen who contended that a policy of excluding them from the directory was contrary to state laws barring discriminatory business practices.

title: POP FUNK: BROTHERS JOHNSON
description: Discovered in the late 1970's by the noted Hollywood producer Quincy Jones, the Brothers Johnson, who appeared at the Savoy on Thursday, became one of the first and most successful West Coast funk acts, with four consecutive million-copy albums. But their latest album, ''Winners,'' hasn't done nearly so well, probably because it was produced by the Brothers Johnson themselves and not by Mr. Jones, who used the pounding, thumping bass lines of Louis Johnson and the stinging electric guitar of George Johnson as the basis for a high gloss pop-funk sound that was as polished as it was propulsive.

title: A Pennsylvania Justice Battles for Re-election
description: Ordinarily, State Supreme Court Justice Robert N.C. Nix Jr. would have no trouble winning another 10-year term on Pennsylvania's highest court, which will be up to the voters Tuesday.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Ernest Hills Presents Rare Lute Music
description: The New York debut Saturday night of Ernest Hills, a Canadian lute player, brought a good deal of little-known music to Carnegie Recital Hall, along with a few more familiar selections drawn from the vast repertory that belonged to the pre-eminent ''gentleman's'' instrument of the 16th through mid-18th centuries.

title: BRUINS TOP RANGERS BROOKS ANGERED
description: The Rangers combined all their faults - weak goaltending, sloppy defense, and sporadic offense - tonight and were trounced, 7-3 by the Bruins at Boston Garden.

title: NOBEL PLAYED NO PART IN PROF. TOBIN'S PRIZE
description: To the Editor:

title: VICHY FRANCE AND THE JEWS By Michael R. Marrus and Robert O. Paxton.  432 pp. New York: Basic Books New York. $20.95.
description: FORTY-ONE years after the fall of France, no period in modern French history remains more painful and controversial than the Vichy regime set up by Marshal Petain in the summer of 1940; no subject is more delicate than the behavior of the French during the four years of German occupation and Vichy rule. The postwar French political leaders - of the early Fifth as well as of the Fourth Republic - had, on the whole, come out of the Resistance; they had no reason to encourage explorations of the darker side of French wartime attitudes and policies. French archives were closed to scholars. It was only after 1970 that Marcel Ophuls's searing movie ''The Sorrow and the Pity'' began to challenge heroic myths and prudent silence. Nevertheless, when Robert Paxton's ''Vichy France'' appeared in a French translation in 1973, his stark and devastating description of Vichy collaborationism (which he based on German and American archives) was rather badly received in France, where many critics accused this scrupulous and thoughtful young historian either of misinterpreting the Vichy leaders' motives or of lacking compassion.

title: THE DISABLED SEEK PUBLIC AWARENESS
description: The United Nations has proclaimed 1981 the International Year of Disabled Persons, and a dinner Thursday night at the New York Academy of Medicine was expected to draw crowds for a program called ''The Disabled in Society.''

title: Mailbox; Series Not Merely A Show for Best
description: To the Sports Editor: Regarding John B. Holway's article (''Making a Pitch for a More Realistic World Series,'' The New York Times, Oct. 11). The World Series is not necessarily a showcase for a team's depth as Mr. Holway asserted.

title: POP SINGER: ROBERTA FLACK
description: There isn't another pop-soul singer around with the versatility and refinement of Roberta Flack, who turned in a glowing performance at Carnegie Hall on Friday. Backed by an excellent six-piece band, Miss Flack played several different musical roles, from cabaret chanteuse to gospel belter, all with consummate skill.

title: NOT TOO LATE TO MAKE A FRUITCAKE
description: MANY people who never use their kitchens for anything other than making instant coffee insist on re-creating the family's old fruitcake recipe each fall, feeling an obligation to keep alive the Christmas traditions they grew up with.

title: The Cruel Rodeos
description: It is unfortunate that in his article, ''Rodeo Is Riding High Again'' (Sept. 20), Scott Eyman did not turn over the coin and talk of the cruelty involved in these exhibitions. He never tells why the broncs and bulls ''erupt snorting in fury, leaping, bucking, spinning, twisting and careening.''

title: A SPARKLING 'PRIVATE LIVES'
description: HERRICKS ''NOBODY writes plays like this anymore'' and ''It's a period piece'' were two of the comments most often overheard during the intermissions of ''Private Lives'' at the Nassau Repertory Theater last Sunday afternoon.

title: DUAL GOAL SEEN FOR EXTENDING DAYLIGHT TIME
description: The dual goals of saving fuel and slowing the rising crime rate are behind a move in Congress to extend daylight saving time around the nation.

title: Jonathan W. Skipp Is Fiance of Catharine Collins
description: Kitty Hyatt Collins and Paul H. Collins, both of Coconut Grove, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catharine Thorpe Collins, to Jonathan William Skipp, son of Francis Skipp and Marjorie LaPorte Skipp, both of Miami. The wedding is planned for April.

title: BY ELLEN RAND
description: As of two weeks ago, all of the ''hereontofores'' and ''thereuntos'' were to have been banished from apartment leases, home sale contracts and other types of consumer contracts in New Jersey. But the move has been postponed, at least for a while.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. ENVOY BACK IN ROME AFTER PLOT REPORT

title: Representation For the People
description: The more things change, apparently, the more they remain the same. Ten years ago, an independent Democrat, Allard Lowenstein, lost his seat in Congress through the gerrymandering of his district by the Nassau Republican machine.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Mastodon Hunt
description: The news report from Santa Cruz, Calif., in March 1980 said that Jim Stanton, a high school student, had found ''the complete skull of what scientists here describe as a four-million-year-old mastodon - a rare find for the Santa Cruz Mountains.''

title: Nets' Walker Proving a Point
description: When the Knicks and the Nets met last night in the first National Basketball Association regularseason game to be played in the new Byrne Arena, several players had something to prove.

title: TEANECK CAPTURES 6TH GAME IN A ROW
description: Euford Cooper bolted 5 yards for the tiebreaking touchdown with 5 minutes 55 seconds left to give undefeated Teaneck its sixth victory, a 21-14 defeat of Passaic Valley in Little Falls.

title: HOW MY BOOK WENT HOLLYWOOD
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lynne McTaggart is an author and investigative journalist. By LYNNE McTAGGART

title: RAIN SENDS MOST RESEVOIRS TO WELL ABOVE 1980 LEVELS
description: The runoff from recent rainfall has replenished reservoirs in the New York metropolitan area to levels well above last year's, though still somewhat below normal.

title: Music; 2 ORCHESTRAS FEATURE YOUTHFUL PERFORMERS
description: THE Oct. 17 performance of the Ridgefield Orchestra was impressive but disconcerting. It was a happy surprise to hear a community symphony achieve sound so resonant, almost sumptuous, and a pleasure to hear music shaped by so vigorously decisive a conducting personality as Beatrice Brown, Ridgefield's music director.

title: WESTFIELD TURNS BACK UNION BY 17-14
description: Paul Leifer and Mike Giacone each ran for a touchdown, and Kevin Lasher kicked a field goal as Westfield downed archrival Union yesterday, 17-14, in Westfield.

title: 9TH AVE. BUILDING COLLAPSE LAID TO OLD MORTAR
description: Age and water that gradually eroded lime in old-fashioned mortar between bricks were among contributing factors in a midtown West Side building collapse on Aug. 31, according to a report by the city's Buildings Department.

title: Pollution Suit Is Filed
description: The State Attorney General has filed a suit against Jameco Industries, a Wyandanch plumbing-supply manufacturer. The Attorney General, Robert Abrams, accused the company of contaminating the ground around its factory with cyanide, copper, lead, nickel and chromium. Michael Lipman, president of Jameco, declined to comment on the suit.

title: SECURITY PUTS OFF A BRINK'S HEARING
description: Citing inadequate security in weekend court, a Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday postponed until Monday the arraignment of an avowed black nationalist on charges of conspiracy in the $1.6 million Brink's robbery that left three people dead in Rockland County 12 days ago.

title: SMITH BACKS VOTING RIGHTS ACT WITH CHANGES
description: Attorney General William French Smith has told President Reagan that there is still a serious need for the Voting Rights Act in some states but that he opposes the legislation favored by a broad coalition of civil rights groups.

title: DETROIT'S SYMBOL OF PRIDE IS IN THE RED
description: The Renaissance Center, the soaring, $357 million centerpiece of this city's struggle to rebuild its decaying center, is being crippled by the economic forces it was supposed to overcome.

title: Miss Honan Wed To Samuel Bird
description: Kathleen Frances Honan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen F. Honan of Concord, Mass., was married there yesterday to Samuel Bird, son of Robert Bird of Orange, N.J., and Jane Whittemore Harrison of Contoocook, N.H., and Albufeira, Portugal.

title: Speaking Personally; WHERE ARE THE NOSTRUMS OF YESTERYEAR?
description: NOT long ago, Washington decided to ban sweet spirits of nitre, described as ''an old-time nostrum used to treat fevers.'' The Food and Drug Administration has prohibited 39 companies from distributing any more of this compound, which also is known as potassium or sodium nitrate - and which was one of my mother's favorite remedies.

title: A FRAUD THAT SHOOK THE WORLD OF SCIENCE
description: Morton Hunt writes frequently about science and psychology; his latest book, ''The Universe Within: A New Science Explores the Human Mind,'' will be published in February by Simon & Schuster. By Morton Hunt

title: John Fetterman Fiance Of Carolyn Perlmuth
description: Mr. and Mrs. William A. Perlmuth of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn Eve Perlmuth, to John Sykes Fetterman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy A. Fetterman of Fort Washington, Pa. The couple plan to be married on March 21 at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: This Could Be a Habit
description: The Chicago Cubs will be the Cincinnati Reds' opponent in the 1982 major league baseball season opener April 5 in Riverfront Stadium. The Reds have opened the season in Cincinnati 96 times and the Cubs have been the opponent 29 times.

title: THEATER: FIERSTEIN'S 'TORCH SONG'
description: Arnold Beckoff, the lonely but far-from-forlorn hero of Harvey Fierstein's ''Torch Song Trilogy,'' is a diehard romantic who takes his heart, soul and fatalism from the 1920's ballads that give the work its title and its tone. At the end of a long, infinitely rewarding evening in the company of Arnold and his family and friends, he confesses with a sigh that he has always wanted exactly the life that his mother has had - ''with certain minor alterations.''

title: Music: Debuts in Review; David Russell, Guitarist, In Albeniz and Regondi
description: It was Hector Berlioz who supposedly said, ''The only thing more pleasant than the sound of one guitar is the sound of two.'' Berlioz notwithstanding, one guitar sounded quite splendid by itself last Sunday night in the hands of David Russell, a young Scottish guitarist who made his New York debut at the Merkin Concert Hall as the first performer in a series titled ''N.Y. Guitar 81/82.''

title: DISPUTES GROWING IN U.N. ATOM PANEL
description: Reagan Administration officials have become disturbed by increasing confrontations between industrial and developing nations in the International Atomic Energy Agency, which tries to prevent the diversion of nuclear technology to military uses.

title: U.S. HORTICULTURE IS ROOTED IN ENGLAND
description: RECENTLY I spend an afternoon with four distinguished horticulturists: T.H. Everett, senior horticulture specialist from the New York Botanical Garden and the author of its new 10-volume Illustrated Cyclopedia of Horticulture; Harold Epstien, Rye, N.Y., noted plantsman and horticultural tour guide; Gordon Jones, director of the Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay, L.I., and Ian Beyer, assistant curator of living plants at the Royal Botanic Garden, Kew, England, who was visiting this country to study our horticultural institutions.

title: THE 'GYPSY MOTHS' FOLLOW THEIR OWN LIGHTS
description: THIS summer, Congressional Republicans united behind President Reagan's tax and budget cuts. This fall, as they confront President Reagan's request for new tax revenues and more spending cuts to help keep the Federal deficit down, they are in disarray. A key factor in the current battle of the budget is the disaffection of the 25 moderates from the Northeast and Middle West who dub themselves the ''gypsy moths.'' They supported the Administration's first round of cuts in return for protection of programs important to their districts, and feel betrayed by many of the new proposals.

title: RUMANIA DETERMINED TO AVOID POLAND'S PLIGHT
description: Every day, Rumanians, like the people of Poland, have to stand in long lines for food and often cannot find cooking oil, sugar, dairy products, fresh meat or eggs.

title: The Region; It's Back to the Drawing Board For City Council
description: In its zeal to reapportion election districts in a way that preserved ''safe'' seats for incumbents, the New York City Council apparently didn't know where to draw the line. When the Council passed its plan in May, civil rights groups charged that it illegally diluted minority voter strength, and last week the Justice Department agreed.

title: KOCH REPLIES TO U.S. CHARGES INVOLVING FOOD-STAMP FRAUD
description: Mayor Koch has responded directly to charges by Federal officials that the city seriously mismanaged the food stamp program. In a letter, Mr. Koch said the city ''has implemented major administrative changes in the food stamp program to reduce its vulnerability to fraud.''

title: LATEST TRENDS: RACING, SNOWGUNS
description: STANLEY CARR is assistant to the editor of Travel. By STANLEY CARR

title: Children's Books
description: OUT OF THE BUG JAR By Kathleen Thomas. Illustrated by Tom O'Sullivan. 125 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Co. $7.95. (Ages 8 to 11) By DORIS ORGEL

title: Merchant Marine Ends 19-Loss Skid
description: With Mike Giambrone scoring a pair of first-half touchdowns, the United States Merchant Marine Academy routed Hofstra, 31-14, yesterday at Tomb Memorial Field in Kings Point, L.I., to snap a 19-game losing streak

title: Children's Books
description: RAMONA QUIMBY, AGE 8 By Beverly Cleary. Illustrated by Alan Tiegreen. 190 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $7.95. (Ages 8 to 11) By NATALIE BABBITT

title: Nancy Messner Is Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Messner of Great Neck, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Louise Messner, to Joel Richard Franklin, son of Mrs. Helene F. Farmer of Fort Lee, N.J., and of Henry Franklin of Yonkers. The wedding is planned for June. Miss Messner and her fiance graduated from Oberlin College.

title: ENTREES THAT CAN FUEL THE APPETITE
description: ALTHOUGH the price of fuel has made the casual Sunday afternoon drive almost extinct except, perhaps, for the ritual excursion to preview autumn foliage before it dazzles Our Town, Westchester residents still travel north throughout the year to deposit offspring at colleges, to hear music, to ski mountains, to scout fairs. If circumstances take the traveler to the Poughkeepsie area and dictate a very good, leisurely dinner, Le Pavillon, five minutes north off Routes 44/ 55, is a restaurant well worth remembering.

title: Ideas and Trends; A Familiar Drug Shows Promise For Heart Attacks
description: Of the 350,000 Americans who survived a first heart attack last year, about 35,000 may die of another attack before the end of next year. At least 6,500 of these heart patients could be saved if treated with the drug propanolol, researchers at the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute said last week as they called off further clinical trials.
To the Editor:

title: MAN WITH A DREAM GETS SOMEONE TO LISTEN
description: THE night before he was to go to Washington, D.C., as a participant in the Connecticut Senior Intern Program, 62-year-old Charlie Halbach of Hampton slept fitfully.

title: Derailment in Buffalo Suburb Routs Hundreds From Homes
description: Hundreds of people were ordered to leave their homes today in this Buffalo suburb after a freight train derailed, rupturing a tank car carrying a toxic chemical, authorities said.

title: PITT STAYS UNBEATEN AFTER 29-24 SCARE
description: The Pittsburgh Panthers had each warned themselves, and they also had warned one another, not to take their unranked opponent too lightly. A sloppy, uninspired victory over Syracuse a week ago had been their lesson, they said, and so from the final gun last week until the kickoff against Boston College this afternoon, the Panthers had repeated their vow: It won't happen again.

title: SIGNIFICANT SHIFTS FOUND IN STATE EMPLOYMENT
description: ''Significant shifts'' have been discerned recently in the focal points of employment strength and weakness in New York State, according to Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Florida Prisons to Hear Grievances of Inmates
description: In an experimental program, Florida prisons plan to invite volunteer lawyers to hear a wide range of inmates' grievances, state officials say.

title: RICHARD YATES AND HIS UNHAPPY PEOPLE
description: LIARS IN LOVE By Richard Yates. 272 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $14.95. By ROBERT TOWERS

title: KARPOV AND KORCHNOI PLAY TO ANOTHER DRAW
description: Anatoly Karpov, the world chess champion, and Viktor Korchnoi drew the 11th game of their title match here in the Kurzentrum playing hall tonight.

title: A LESSON FOR ELITE OF COLLEGE SPORTS
description: WITH all the attention and well-deserved criticism focused recently on intercollegiate athletics, I'd like to call attention to an unsullied area of college sports - Division III.

title: Behind the Best Sellers
description: Ralph Nader, as might be imagined, is loathe to hand out kudos to anybody. His forte is attack. Yet on the jacket of the best-selling ''Keep It Simple,'' he calls the book by Marian Burros an ''irresistible alternative to the giant industries of factory-prepared food such as T.V. dinners.'' He describes her chapter ''The Politics of Food'' as a ''gripping introductory tour of food fraud in the marketplace'' and then reminds readers that Mrs. Burros will help them to prepare 30-minute meals at home that are ''cheaper, safer, quicker to fix, better, more abundant, and more tasty.''

title: IN NORTHERN COUNTY, REPUBLICANS HAVE FOUND THEIR ROOST
description: BACK in the early 1960's, the North Salem Town Board enjoyed a distinction close to unique in the 10 towns of Northern Westchester: One of its members was a Democrat. How Dr. Henry Junemann gained elective office in that staunchly Republican town is a mystery. Having managed it, however, he took his opposition role seriously, and board proceedings were often acrimonious in consequence. The bickering may have helped to convince North Salem voters that twoparty government was a mistake; in any case, they waited another 10 years before repeating the experiment.

title: The Region; A Case Against Family Court
description: An extensive study released by the Community Service Society last week reports that New York City's Family Court system is not as bad off as many people suppose it to be, but worse.

title: Connecticut Guide; ON A JEWISH THEME
description: A cultural compendium that should interest art lovers of any religious persuasion will unfold throughout the week beginning Saturday at the Hartford Jewish Community Center, 335 Bloomfield Avenue.

title: 'ABORTION IS A QUESTION OF RIGHT AND LAW'
description: To the Editor:

title: SOMALIA'S DOUBLE TROUBLE AS A CLIENT STATE
description: The Somali word for ''comrade'' is ''jaalle'' and there was a time when the propaganda posters here depicted a trinity of them: Jaalle Marx, Jaalle Lenin and Jaalle Siad. Only one of the trio has survived the realignment of power in the Horn of Africa which has dramatically affected this country of more than three million people. Jaalle Marx and Jaalle Lenin are gone. The posters now show only one comrade - President Mohammed Siad Barre.

title: The Region; In Hot Pursuit Of More Holdups
description: Though last month's armored-car robbery in Nanuet, N.Y. was a spectacular and bloody failure, police last week said the radical gang charged with committing it may have had plenty of practice.

title: FLEMISH PARTY FAVORED AS BELGIAN VOTE NEARS
description: Coalition cabinets rise and fall in Belgium, but one political party seems to tower above the rest. The Flemish Social Christian Party, which is based in the north of the country, has been in the driver's seat of countless coalitions since its formation in 1945. It has presided over the virtual redrawing of Belgium's economic map as the industrial center has shifted to its own power base in predominantly Catholic Flanders.

title: Antiques; LAMBERTVILLE ADDS ANTIQUES SHOPS
description: LAMBERTVILLE EACH new year seems to bring changes to this quaint Hunterdon County town. Old houses are being done over, a small, bright restaurant or two added. Two antiques stores have opened in the last year, making for more than a half-dozen.

title: Antiques; THE HAUNTED WORLD OF THE MARTIN BROTHERS
description: The first major show in America of the weird and astounding ceramic art of the Martin Brothers opened most appropriately last night while goblins and grotesques were abroad in the land. The Halloween preview of ''Boobies, Boojums and Snarks'' at Jordan Volpe gallery, 457 West Broadway, was in a two-room space in which the Martins' London shop with its wooden showcases is re-created and a Gothicarched stone-walled fantasy setting beyond. The latter suggests the tortured minds of these men by the use of eerie sounds, dripping water in a darkened pool, gnarled trees, live moss and mood lighting.

title: 2 HELD BY FELLOW INMATES ARE FREED IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: Twenty-seven inmates have gained release here from a band of convicts who had held them captive along with six prison employees for nearly four days, state officials said today.

title: CITY AUDIT ASSAILS SUPERVISION OF PROBATIONERS
description: A survey of 274 persons on probation has found that most of them failed, some as many as 11 times, to report to their probation officers, according to an audit by the New York City Comptroller's office.

title: Melbourne
description: To the Editor:

title: IDYLL, $21, TAKES STUYVESANT
description: Two years ago, Tartan Farm had several promising 2-year-olds, including two colts named Idyll and Codex. In the fall of that year, Tartan was more impressed with Idyll, so he was nominated to the Kentucky Derby and Codex was not.

title: A RETROSPECTIVE LOOK AT WHAT 'SOLIDARITY DAY' MEANT
description: ON SEPT. 19, I joined 260,000 other Americans from throughout the nation in the great Solidarity Day march on Washington. Although I was New Jersey's Acting Governor, I was anonymous in the crowd, and rightly so. It was a protest of America's working men and women, not a rally for its political leaders.

title: Brooklyn Getting Indonesian Art
description: Approximately 100 traditional art works by the Archaic Indonesians will go on display at the Brooklyn Museum from next Saturday through Jan. 31.

title: 36 Arrested on Drug Charges
description: Sheriff's deputies from five counties in central New York arrested 35 adults and a 15-year-old on drug charges, authorities said.

title: 'HEAD SHOP' BAN FACING LEGAL HURDLES
description: ALTHOUGH Nassau County has adopted an ordinance to outlaw ''head shops,'' and Suffolk County is considering a similar measure, the constitutionality of barring the sale of drug paraphernalia remains in doubt.

title: Q and A
description: Question:My family and I would like to plan a ski vacation to Europe this Christmas. I would appreciate any information that you may have regarding the usual ski conditions this time of year in France, Switzerland and Austria. - S.M.L., Cherry Hill, N.J. Answer:French Alpine ski resorts with slopes at elevations above 4,000 feet - such as the villages of Chamonix and Val d' Isere and the newer resorts of Flaine and Avoriaz in the Savoie region - generally guarantee snow at Christmas time. From mid-December through March you may call the French Government Tourist Office (212-757-1125) for weekly snow reports from the resort areas.

title: No Headline
description: 76ERS EDGE HAWKS; ERVING SCORES 22

title: AREA REACTS TO ROCKEFELLER GIFT
description: POCANTICO HILLS is probably the most exclusive hamlet in Westchester, even though houses were sold there for as little as $12,000 only nine years ago. To live in the cluster of old farm houses along Bedford Road or the larger masonary and clapboard houses on the side roads, a family has to ''know somebody.'' They either have to know a Rockefeller, a Rockefeller staff member, or somebody who does.

title: ON THE IMPORTANCE OF LATTER-DAY CELESTIAL GODS
description: To the Editor:

title: WASHINGTON
description: Numerous regulators oversee the automobile companies, but the most irksome, in the industry's view, has been a branch of the Department of Transportation with a mouthful of a name - the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. And in the brief 10 months since Ronald Reagan's inauguration, probably none has changed its tune as much.

title: Sports of The Times; Just Say Goodbye to Lem and Reggie)
description: JUDGING by the semaphore code of George Steinbrenner's syntax, Bob Lemon soon will receive an honorable discharge as the Yankee manager, to be succeeded by Dick Williams, and Reggie Jackson will be permitted to take his act to another theater.

title: The World; Back to Work In Philadelphia
description: ''I'm not interested in shutting the city down,'' Edward Toohey, president of the Philadelphia A.F.L.-C.I.O. council, said last week as unions planned a one-day general strike in support of a 50-day-old teachers' walkout. Nor, as it turned out, was the three-member Commonwealth Court interested in contemplating a shut-down Philadelphia.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN DUBLIN
description: WILLIAM BORDERS is a correspondent in London for The New York Times. By WILLIAM BORDERS

title: NOT TO WRITE WAS NOT TO BE ALIVE
description: VAN WYCK BROOKS: A WRITER'S LIFE By Raymond Nelson. Illustrated. 332 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $21.75.

title: Crime
description: About a year ago Loren D. Estleman delivered himself of a novel featuring Amos Walker, a private eye who works out of Detroit. ''Motor City Blue'' turned out to be a competent composite - and the word is used advisedly - of the stereotypes of the hard-boiled species. Now comes ANGEL EYES (Houghton Mifflin, $11.95), and Amos Walker rides again.

title: SELLERS LEARNING HOW PRIVATE MORTGAGES CAN FAIL
description: Desperate to sell their $85,000 home in Mamaroneck, N.Y., a couple preparing to retire last fall decided to offer a buyer a private mortgage of $55,000. Having made a commitment on a Florida condominium, they were afraid that otherwise they would be in debt over their heads.
