Today they are seeking legal advice because the people who bought their house have been consistently late in making mortgage payments.

title: STRATEGY OF AVOIDANCE FAILS TO MEET PUBLIC NEEDS
description: WHEN Governor O'Neill made his closing address to the General Assembly this spring, his favorable comments were for the most part limited to the legislature's achievements of avoidance - primarily its refusal to raise certain taxes and to impose other taxes, and its passage of a state budget which, for a fleeting moment, did not involve a projected deficit. He praised the means the legislature had chosen without ever examining the real goals it should have been trying to reach. It was like a military commander praising a particular campaign for its low losses in men and material without ever looking to see what, if anything, the campaign had accomplished.

title: No Headline
description: OHIO STATE TURNS BACK PURDUE, 45-33, AS ANDERSON EXCELS

title: HERSCHEL WALKER'S RUN TO GLORY
description: Copyright c 1981 by Henry P. Leifermann Henry Leifermann is a freelance writer. By Henry Leifermann

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: REAGAN'S STAKE IN NEW JERSEY'S ELECTION
description: Maurice Carroll is a reporter on the metropolitan desk of The New York Times. By Maurice Carroll o state in the union serves as the butt of so many jokes as New Jersey. Humorists from Mark Twain to Woody Allen have found that the mere mention of any town - from Hackensack to Ho-Ho-Kus - is good for a laugh. Now, however, New Jersey is enjoying a moment of national attention for a more dignifed reason: Next week's New Jersey election for Governor will serve as the first opportunity to test the popularity of the Republican Administration in Washington and, more specifically, the public's attitude toward Reaganomics. And while there is little to suggest that most New Jerseyans view their election in this light, a number of influential personalities clearly do. ''The whole country is watching,'' said President Reagan, who was in New Jersey campaigning for the Republican ticket. ''New Jersey is being offered a clear-cut choice between those who think Government spending and taxes are the solution to our problems and those ... who understand that Government spending and overtaxation are the problem.'' And Vice President George Bush, on another campaign stop in the state, agreed that a Republican victory would be ''a national symbol.''

title: SALE TO SAUDIS JUST GOT BY, BUT IT DIDN'T JUST HAPPEN
description: During the controversy over the sale of Awacs planes to Saudi Arabia, senator after senator expressed doubt about the wisdom of the policy. But many added that once it had ''got this far,'' the consequences of rejection seemed too grave to risk. How did it get so far?

title: JERSEY LEGISLATIVE RACE FEATURES NO 'COATTAILS'
description: Although overshadowed by the race for Governor and concerns about the national economy, candidates for 120 seats in the New Jersey Legislature are waging more costly and sophisticated campaigns this year to offset the ''coattail'' effect that has been evident during recent gubernatorial election years.

title: THE BIG STATE BOND ISSUES: IT'S WATER IN NEW JERSEY...
description: $350 million. And the state engineers and planners who mastermind New Jersey's complex water delivery systems say it's the most important. If that borrowing is authorized, they say, it will buy enough new supplies and pipelines to make recurrences of the 1980-81 water shortage highly improbable.

title: 17 MUSLIMS REFUSE DEFENSE IN A ROBBERY TRIAL
description: Members of a Muslim sect who are accused of stealing more than $317,000 in a series of armed robberies have refused to defend themselves against the charges, on grounds of religious persecution.

title: Joan Carol Welton Married
description: Joan Carol Welton and John Gray Faron 3d, both of Baltimore, were married yesterday at the United States Coast Guard Academy Chapel in New London, Conn. The Rev. David W. DeRevere, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Tentative Contract Reached By Volkswagen and U.A.W.
description: A tentative contract has been reached between Volkswagen and Local 2055 of the United Automobile Workers, the company said today.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: ALTERNATIVE/ONE, a methadone maintenance clinic in Saddle Brook, may soon no longer be an alternative for former heroin addicts. The Mayor and Council have been battling the clinic in local and county courts since it moved into town last May, and both sides are awaiting a decision by the Appellate Division of Superior Court as to whether it will have to close.

title: Andrea Bienstock Is Engaged to Nathan A. Bicks
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Bienstock of Fort Lee, N. J., and Quogue, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Bienstock, to Nathan Allan Bicks, son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Bicks of Memphis.

title: A CHEAP HIDE-OUT FOR WRITERS
description: Montana is cold, lonely, vulgar. In addition to these three points of merit it has others, all recommending it as a home and hide-out for writers of a certain bent. Inspirational scenic vistas, of course; clocks that move more slowly and tick more quietly than elsewhere; most of America's best trout fishing. Novelist Max Crawford (''A Waltz Across Texas''), transplanted once from Texas to San Francisco and now up here on a long visa, cites one further consideration: ''You know why writers live in Montana? The same reason they used to live in Paris. It's cheap. The exchange rate. Cheap places sustain good writers.'' For whatever reasons, although there is no great Montana Renaissance afoot, the state does seem to sustain considerably more than its share.

title: KNICKS ARE BEATEN BY PACERS, 106-99
description: There were new faces but many of the same problems last night for the Knicks, who lost to the Indiana Pacers in their National Basketball Association home opener at Madison Square Garden, 106-99.

title: The World; Help Is Never Far Off in Chad
description: Chad's ethnic divisions and strategic location, like Lebanon's, have long invited foreign meddling. Last week, France sent light arms and ammunition to prop up President Goukouni Oueddei, who was installed with Libyan backing last December but has angered Col. Muammer el-Qaddafi by refusing a Libya-Chad merger.

title: Caldwell Rolls, 30-6
description: Caldwell, off to its best start in recent years, romped to its sixth victory without a loss as it beat Nutley yesterday, 30-6, in Nutley. Caldwell was led by Tom Martin and Tom Bryant, two outstanding backs.

title: Ups and Downs On OPEC Oil
description: ''Rumors about OPEC's death were exaggerated,'' Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, the Kuwaiti oil minister, boasted last week in Geneva as cartel members settled price and output disputes after 32 months of disarray. Under pressure from Saudi Arabia, whose high production and moderate prices had siphoned off nearly half of OPEC's steeply declining sales, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries voted to restore price unity at $34 a barrel.

title: MILITARY IS PUSHING ITS SHUTTLE PROGRAM AMID RISING DEBATE
description: Military officials are pushing ahead with the construction of a $2 billion complex here for the launching of space shuttles designed to place clandestine military satellites in orbit.

title: Elyse Rothaus Is Fiancee Of Howard Joseph Butnick
description: The engagement of Elyse F. Rothaus to Howard Joseph Butnick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Butnick of Forest Hills, Queens, has been announced by the bride-to-be's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Rothaus of Manhattan.

title: BOSTON BALLOT ISSUE CHALLENGES REAGAN ECONOMICS
description: On a blustery gray afternoon this week, as the wind blew the trash down Dudley Street and across Columbia Road in Boston's tough Dorchester section, a young man and woman stood on opposite curbs, stopping people to tell them about an economic question that will be on the municipal ballot here Tuesday. It is a question that has begun to assume some national importance.

title: Chaminade 19-0 Winner
description: John Stalzer scored two touchdowns to lead Chaminade of Mineola to a 19-0 Catholic High Schools Football League victory over Holy Family of South Huntington yesterday.

title: AMERICAN'S HELP CALLED KEY TO LIBYANS' MOVE INTO CHAD
description: Libya would have had difficulty sustaining its intervention in Chad last year without the support of a former American intelligence agent, according to pilots and technicians who recently returned from Libya.

title: THE SCOREBOARD ON HEISMAN WINNERS
description: Until the 1970's, winning the Heisman Trophy was far from a guarantee of future success. The first winner (in 1935), Jay Berwanger, a halfback from the University of Chicago, never even played professional football and other winners such as Gary Beban of U.C.L.A., John Huarte of Notre Dame and Steve Spurrier of Florida, quarterbacks who played in the mid-1960's, failed to gain winning reputations in the National Football League. The situation is very different now. The last five trophy winners, all running backs, are starters in the N.F.L., and four of the five are among the leading rushers in the league. Jim Plunkett culminated a decade in the National Football League when he led the Oakland Raiders to the Super Bowl title earlier this year. After winning the Heisman Trophy while at Stanford University, the quarterback was drafted by the Boston Patriots, who later changed their name to New England. In his first seven seasons as a pro, only one of his teams had a winning record. After leading the University of Alabama, Pat Sullivan, a quarterback, became the lowest choice of Heisman Trophy winners in the N.F.L. draft (late in the second round) since the Cowboys made Roger Staubach (the 1963 winner) a 10th-round pick in 1963. Sullivan was drafted by the Atlanta Falcons and was with the team from 1972 through 1975 as a backup quarterback. After winning the trophy as an all-purpose back for the University of Nebraska, Johnny Rodgers bypassed the offers of the N.F.L. San Diego Chargers and reportedly became the highest paid player in the Canadian Football League.

title: Business Conditions; ANOTHER ALTERNATIVE TO THE C.P.I.
description: The Consumer Price Index is the nation's most closely watched indicator for inflationary trends, but the index's weighting system continues to draw criticism on the grounds that it overinflates inflation. For a more accurate gauge of price movements, many analysts look to the personal consumption price deflator.

title: Aide Defends Methods In Adult Education
description: In ''The Changing Course of Adult Education'' (Oct. 11), Charles E. Rodgers made several inaccurate and misleading statements that I want to correct.

title: THRILLS IN HIGH PLACES
description: FEAR ITSELF By Stefan Kanfer. 215 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $12.95. RED OMEGA By John Kruse. 372 pp. New York: Random House. $14.50. DEATH BEAM By Robert Moss. 408 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $13.95.

title: Man and Woman Found Slain In Chelsea Section Apartment
description: A 20-year-old Long Island woman and a 39-year-old Manhattan man were found slain in the man's apartment in the Chelsea section last night, the police said.

title: 100,000 IN MILAN PEACE MARCH
description: More than 100,000 people marched here today for peace and disarmament, the second protest in Italy against United States and Soviet policies in a week.

title: DRAMA ON A SMALL SCALE
description: he apartment was not appealing by any means, even if it was situated at the top of the Dakota, one of New York's most prestigious apartment buildings. It was cramped -just 750 square feet with two rooms on one level and a pitch-roofed storage room on the floor above. And the previous tenant had fought the idiosyncratic nature of the rooms by filling in the niches and obliterating the charming quirks that are typical of apartments in this venerable, late-19thcentury building. ''A disaster,'' said Joseph Paul D'Urso, the wellknown minimalist designer whose most recent projects have tended to be large-scale experiments with the spatial possibilities of extravagantly proportioned rooms.

title: Sound; IN TURNTABLE DESIGN SILENCE IS GOLDEN
description: According to Keats, ''Heard melodies are sweet but unheard ones are sweeter.'' Turntable designers would amend this line to the effect that what remains unheard sweetens the melody. Paradoxically, it is a turntable's silence that makes the most of the music. The notorious rumbling of inferior turntables, which sounds somewhat like a soft growl from a large dog, makes an unwelcome accompaniment to any music. Even in its subtlest forms, rumble strips the dramatic hush from wispy pianissimi and coarsens the texture of diaphanous orchestrations. It becomes all the more obtrusive with good loudspeakers capable of rendering the deeper reaches of the frequency range, which are the natural domain of turntable rumble.

title: Refugee Center Is Approved
description: The Valley County Board of Commissioners has approved a plan, negotiated with Federal officials, to establish a refugee center at an abandoned Air Force base 20 miles north of here. The center will house about 2,000 aliens, including 500 Cubans now at Fort Chaffee, Ark.

title: WHO'S BEHIND THE CANDIDATE? A GOOD MAN
description: In the packed Community Hall behind the fire station on a quiet residential street in Stamford, Conn., Samuel Laitman listened attentively as his wife, Lyn, the Democratic candidate for Mayor, addressed the crowd.

title: Television Week
description: Loving Women Linda Gray, the star of ''Dallas,'' claims that a television special on female sexuality that she will participate in this week is ''a first for television.'' The program is ''The Body Human: The Loving Process - Women,'' to be broadcast on CBS on Wednesday and Thursday, from 1:30 to 2 P.M. For it, three women from Santa Fe, N.M., and Miss Gray met to converse and ''share our feelings about our sexuality.''

title: PEACE CORPS SEEKS A REVIEW OF CUTS
description: The Peace Corps, with its modest $105 million budget cut this year to $83.6 million, has appealed to the Administration for reconsideration.

title: PENN STATE UPSET BY MIAMI, 17-14
description: The top ranking in college football appears too hot to handle this season. Penn State was the fifth team rated No. 1 in the wire service polls this fall, and today it became the fifth team to suffer its first defeat soon after having reached the top spot.

title: Camera; HOW TO MAKE COPIES OF THOSE OLD PHOTOGRAPHS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Bruce Habegger is a freelance writer who also teaches photography at City College and at the Educational Alliance.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: A.B. Waugh, Miss Knutson Are Engaged
description: Anne Burdett Knutson, a legal assistant with the New York law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, will be married in April to Alexander Butler Waugh, an accountant with the New York firm of Coopers & Lybrand. Their engagement has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bruce Knutson of Pittsburgh. Mr. Waugh is a son of Mrs. Robert Martin Greaney of Naples, Fla., and James Champlain Waugh of Lawrenceville, N.J.

title: SOME ELDERLY AND HANDICAPPED BEING ABANDONED AT HOSPITALS
description: LONG ISLAND hospitals, according to their administrators increasingly used as receptacles for too many of the community's problems, are now faced with another challenge: the abandonment of the elderly and handicapped in parking lots and emergency rooms.

title: RUSSELL HOBAN, REINVENTING ENGLISH
description: ''After a certain point, the straight English began to ring forced,'' explained Russell Hoban in his light, twinkly voice. ''Little by little the proper English crumbled and fell away, and little by little the vernacular rose up.''

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1981
description: International Israel's total rejection of the Saudi Arabian peace plan for the Middle East was reaffirmed by Ambassador Ephraim Evron at a meeting with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. at the State Department, an Israeli spokesman said. The Ambassador officially protested to the United States over its recent statements portaying the Saudi plan as containing some positive approaches toward a Middle East peace settlement. The Israeli spokesman said that Mr. Evron told the Secretary of State that any show of American backing for the Saudi plan would be seen as a weakening of American backing for the Camp David accords, which Saudi Arabia rejected. (Page 1, Column 6.) An end to all strikes in Poland immediately was called for in a resolution passed by Parliament, which acted in response to a request by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelsi, the Prime Minister. The resolution was backed by the threat of firmer action if it was ignored. Parliament said it would then consider ''providing the Government with such legal means as are required by the situation.'' An outright ban against strikes was implicit. (1:5.)

title: A Correction
description: Pictures of a greenhouse and flower that appeared on Page 1 of last week's Long Island Weekly were incorrectly credited. They were taken by Nik Kleinberg.

title: Millard Fillmore
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: VOTERS IN TUNISIA OFFERED A CHOICE
description: Traveling in a 21-car caravan, Prime Minister Mohammed Mzali came to this seaside town the other day to campaign for tomorrow's legislative elections in which opposition groups are being allowed to take part for the first time.

title: TANAKA SUFFERS SETBACK IN THE LOCKHEED CASE
description: Former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka is believed to have suffered a setback in his five-year struggle to defend himself in court against charges that he received $2.17 million in bribes from the Lockheed Corporation.

title: Clemson Rolls By 82-24
description: Chuck McSwain ran for 90 yards and three touchdowns today as unbeaten Clemson defeated Wake Forest, 82-24. Clemson won its eighth game and scored more points than any other team in Atlantic Coast Conference history; the previous record was set in 1954 when Maryland beat Missouri, 74-13.

title: Troubled Waters Of Our Lakes
description: Roger Swain's article, ''The Troubled Waters of Our Lakes'' (Sept. 20), is an excellent and scientifically accurate summary of the state of our nation's lakes.

title: Ideas and Trends; A Case Against Family Court
description: If statistics count for anything, an increasing number of American women are saying that men not husbands, compatability not marriage are the prerequisites for bearing children. Unfortunately, the numbers also indicate that among teen-age women there is often no prerequisite at all: Pregnancy is simply the result of ignorance and misinformation.

title: Nancy A. Gumley Engaged to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Gumley of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Ann Gumley, to Thomas Richard Comer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Comer of Clark, N.J.

title: Cora Yamamoto Affianced to Jeffrey Mark Lepon
description: The engagement of Cora Jean Emiko Yamamoto to Jeffrey Mark Lepon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Lepon of Avon Lake, Ohio, has been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Hideo Yamamoto of Honolulu. An early January wedding is planned.

title: G.O.P. GRIP ON TOP POSTS SEEMS SOLID IN 2 COUNTIES
description: REPUBLICAN domination of Nassau and Suffolk county and town governments is not likely to be seriously threatened in Tuesday's election, Democratic and Republican politicians generally agreed in the final days before the vote.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Paul Stern, Guitarist, Plays Giuliani, Henze
description: Ever since Andres Segovia transcribed his music for the modern guitar, Bach has been the musical measure of a guitarist - as he is the musical measure of most other instrumentalists. There are no easy ways into Bach; either the music is understood - with its contrapuntal lines, harmonic architecture and dancing rhythms - or it is heard as skittish patter.

title: FARM STANDS IRK SOME ON EAST END
description: FARM stands are under attack again on the East End, where some of the East Hampton Village trustees are planning to ban them if they are ruled to be a nuisance and are not on private property.

title: The Demons Beneath the Awacs
description: A sordid matter lingers from the Awacs fight. It was poignantly raised by Senator William Cohen, who opposed the deal but finally voted for it. The Maine Republican, a Unitarian with a Jewish father, said it was better that American Jews lose the contest than suffer the consequences of winning.

title: OPENING THE DOOR A BIT TO WOMAN'S MOST INTIMATE MOMENT
description: GREENVALE WHEN modern woman is glimpsed in her intimate moments of domestic leisure, more often than not we find her taking 10 over a mug of instant coffee in the breakfast nook or glued to her favorite television soap opera. Perhaps she is slumped on the living room sofa, disabled by a headache, but never, never is she seen in her boudoir, languidly passing the hours in idle contemplation.

title: A MIND IS NOT DESCRIBED BY NUMBERS
description: THE MISMEASURE OF MAN By Stephen Jay Gould. Illustrated. 352 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $14.95.

title: Four Hurt as 50 Cars Crash
description: A total of 50 cars crashed in several pileups on a rain-slick freeway here early today, injuring only four persons but clogging traffic for about two hours, the police said. Marilyn Hay, a spokesman for the police, said the first wreck involved 10 cars traveling south on North Central Expressway at 1 A.M. Fifteen more cars traveling south and 15 traveling north parallel to the first accident were involved in a second, simultaneous wreck, and five more cars were involved in a pileup farther south, she said.

title: SCOTTO SINGS 3 ROLES IN PUCCINI'S 'IL TRITTICO'
description: The Metropolitan Opera brought back Puccini's ''Il Trittico'' Friday night with Renata Scotto singing all three major soprano roles. Each part of this tryptich is far from the other in time, place and mood, but they fit together like the movements in a classical sonata - first the grim intensity of ''Il Tabarro,'' then the dreamy leisure of ''Suor Angelica'' and then, all serious business having been disposed of, the broad humor and quick step of ''Gianni Schicchi.''

title: Singapore Party Loses Vote
description: The ruling People's Action Party lost its 13-year domination of the Singapore Parliament today when the secretary general of the opposition Workers' Party, J.B. Jeyaretnam, won a by-election here. Mr. Jeyaretnam defeated Pang Kim Hin by 650 votes, giving the opposition its first seat in the 75-member Parliament since 1968.

title: BISHOP MOORE TO REVIEW ST. BART'S TOWER PLAN
description: The Episcopal Bishop of New York plans to conduct a full review of the proposal to build an office tower next to St. Bartholomew's Church on Park Avenue.

title: Tremor Shakes Greek Island
description: A strong earth tremor shook the Greek island of Cephalonia today, the Athens Seismological Institute said. There were no immediate reports of damage or casualties. The quake measured 5.0 on the open-ended Richter scale.

title: S.R. Kellert Weds Miss Whiteman
description: The marriage of Priscilla Morrow Whiteman to Stephen Robert Kellert took place yesterday at the Marquand Chapel of Yale University. The Rev. James Carse, professor of philosophy and religion at New York University, performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: MAIN STREET IN COLD SPRING LOOKS MORE LIKE ANTIQUES ROW
description: An old merry-go-round horse stands in what used to be a plumbing and hardware store. Baskets of antique tools and stationery fill an old saloon. Oriental antiques have taken over a haberdashery.

title: Art; THE VIEW FROM WITHIN
description: FAIR LAWN WE SCRUTINIZE most paintings as if we were on the outside looking in. We become voyeurs as we examine the interiors, both figurative and abstract, of artists.

title: The Long Ordeal Of James Brady
description: Dr. Richard Cytowic's detailed article describing James Brady's injury and extended treatment made a difficult subject readily understandable (''The Long Ordeal of James Brady,'' Sept. 27).

title: MCGUIRE BASE SALUTING ACE FOR WHOM IT'S NAMED
description: WRIGHTSTOWN AS Col. Larry D. Wright, the wing commander, recalls, the elderly man standing alongside the World War II fighter plane refused to move when asked to during an Open House celebration at McGuire Air Force Base last May.

title: MANHASSET BAY OPERA
description: With three Metropolitan Opera audition national finalists in the cast, the Manhasset Bay Opera opens its seventh season today with Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor.'' And though the production of this tale of murder and madness is a revival of a 1979 version - Deborah Truxal, coloratura, starred then, too - there is a new element; two, in fact: the company will be appearing at C.W. Post's Concert Theater in Brookville this year and is also expanding its horizons with performances out east at the Shoreham-Wading River High School.

title: Mailbox; Baseball Dunk: A New Weapon?
description: To the Sports Editor: In case no one's noticed, baseball has evolved its own version of the dunk shot -the dunk catch. Just as 6-foot-6-inch and 7-foot cagers were destined eventually to soar over the rim to sink their baskets, we now see the 6-6 superman Dave Winfield leaping over tall fences and down into the seats to burglarize home run balls.

title: The World; The 33 Who Didn't Make It
description: For residents of Hillsboro Beach, Fla. the sight of swollen, nearnaked corpses scattered across the town's condominium-lined beach was perhaps as bizarre a scene as it was tragic. The victims, 33 Haitian refugees, had drowned before dawn when a sailboat capsized about a mile out.

title: Future Events Gardens, Galleries, Gandhi
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated: The Healing Art Nov. 2 - An art preview to aid St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center will combine two collections - the Julien Levy and the Anne Burnett Tandy - at Sotheby Parke Bernet, 980 Madison Avenue, during which viewers may sip cocktails and enjoy snacks by Glorious Foods. A 9 P.M. dinner will be served at the Carlyle, 35 East 76th Street. Cocktail reception-preview tickets are $50 and dinner tickets $50, from 554-7147. The Red Mill Nov. 4 - Members of the Light Opera of Manhattan will present Victor Herbert's ''The Red Mill,'' followed by a champagne and pastries reception, when the audience will be invited to ballroom dancing on the stage. The 13-year-old company will benefit from the gala at the Eastside Playhouse, 334 East 74th Street. Tickets are $40, from 861-2287.

title: THE TREASURE OF LANGUEDOC
description: MacDONALD HARRIS is the author of nine novels, among them ''The Treasure of Sainte Foy.'' The most recent is ''Herma,'' published by Atheneum. By MacDONALD HARRIS

title: LARGER HAULS RAISE FEARS OF DEPLETION
description: MONTAUK HERE in Montauk, home of Long Island's highly profitable fishing industry, marine biologists are closely watching the area's fish stocks to see if they are being hurt by overfishing. Because fishermen are fishing more heavily than ever before, the biologists are unsure whether certain fish can survive the strain. Last year, Montauk's commercial fishermen caught 40 million pounds of fish and, if the trend of the last five years continues, that figure will be 6 percent higher this year.

title: The World; A Disarming Rumanian
description: West European peace demonstrators who doubt a Soviet nuclear edge exists in Central Europe were contradicted last week by someone who should know. President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania, a Warsaw Pact member, called on Moscow to withdraw the SS-20 missiles it has targeted on Western Europe.

title: Joe Henderson in Sextet In Jazz at Public Series
description: Joe Henderson, the tenor saxophonist, will perform with a sextet at the Public Theater next Thursday and Friday.

title: BACKING ONESELF INTO A CLOSET OF FEARS
description: TO my inexperienced eyes, the vault room of the bank was straight out of a horror movie: polished steel walls, ceiling and floor; steel that reflected the guard who entered the room to remove my newly rented vault box. The walls, made of steel file drawers, provided chopped up distortions of the guard: arms, legs, pieces of his face. A scene of torture, a scene of hell.

title: God and Mr. Trevor At Millbrook
description: In speaking of Frank Trevor, William Buckley appears to derive immoderate enjoyment in having the last word with a man who had a short way with buffoons and smart alecks (''God and Boys at Millbrook,'' Oct. 4).

title: TRAUMAS OF BEING DISMISSED OUTLINED IN A NEW HANDBOOK
description: One of the most frightening and shattering edicts in the business world is the blunt phrase ''You're fired,'' or some more kindly variation such as: ''We're sorry, but with sales slipping we've got to make some changes. I'm afraid we'll have to let you go.''

title: POST-MODERN DANCE FAVORS DISPLAY IN LIEU OF DEFINITION
description: Modern dance exists. No dancegoer would doubt that. Yet it has always been next to impossible to formulate a succinct definition of just what modern dance is. To complicate matters further, some dancers and critics are now talking of post-modern dance. And that term is proving even harder to define.

title: PRESCRIPTION FOR AN AILING POLITICAL SYSTEM
description: IF VOTER turnout is an index of the health of a democracy, American politics - and New Jersey politics in particular -are pretty sick. Only 53 percent of the nation's registered voters went to the polls in last November's Presidential election; last June, only 28 percent of New Jersey's registered electorate voted in the gubernatorial primary. In contrast, European democracies routinely turn out more than 75 percent of their eligible voters.

title: No Headline
description: NOTRE DAME STOPS NAVY, 38-0

title: Other Business; A BANK CARD FOR FOOD STAMPS
description: In an experiment that will introduce 13,000 welfare recipients to the magic of electronically transferred funds, New York City's Income Maintenance Department is trying to phase out the present clumsy methods of mailing welfare checks and authorizing food stamps.

title: Egyptian Arms Show Opens
description: An exhibition of Western-made weapons and military equipment opened here today. More than 100 companies from 11 countries are taking part in the four-day show at Artillery House.

title: State Hospitals Did Have a Purpose
description: Recently, the Long Island Weekly did a piece about empty buildings on state hospital grounds on Long Island. That week, I went into the city on business. I was approached for money by two gruff, unshaven men. I saw three women asleep on the floor in Penn Station. I watched as a man, apparently hallucinating, made his unsteady way against a light across Lexington Avenue.

title: JETS' WOES STEM FROM PAST, NOT PRESENT
description: AFTER last week's inept performance against the Seattle Seahawks, the bonfires of skepticism that have surrounded Shea Stadium's football denizens -the Jets - in recent years burn brightly once again. Hailed for the performances against the Patriots and the Bills only weeks ago, we wonder anew whether Walt Michaels possesses the coaching acumen of a Chuck Noll or a Don Shula.

title: CLINCHER FOR NO. ROCKLAND
description: North Rockland defeated Tappan Zee, 28-6, yesterday to clinch its first Rockland County P.S.A.L. championship since 1977.

title: PORT DIRECTOR IN MILWAUKEE
description: Harry C. Brockel, a longtime Milwaukee port director who advocated expanding shipping on the Great Lakes, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, at the age of 73.

title: IN TECHNOLOGY AND IN INDUSTRY, THE ISLAND ATTRACTS A VARIED CLIENTELE AND KEEPS APACE
description: THE organization I represent is involved in spreading the Long Island technological message in a clear and consistent way, so that our identity is representative of our capabilities.

title: Around the Nation; Ministers' Worry Leads To Nuclear Arms Forum
description: An effort by two Episcopal priests who wanted to do more than worry about nuclear disarmament has led to the scheduling of a face-to-face meeting here between Soviet and American officials.

title: C.D. Kirby Fiance Of Judith Martin
description: The engagement of Judith Anne Martin, daughter of David T. Martin of Lake George, N.Y., to Christopher D. Kirby, son of C. John Kirby and Mrs. Miriam Kirby, both of New York, has been announced by the future bride's father.

title: BARBARA ALLEN ASHLEY FIANCEE OF LIEUTENANT
description: Dr. and Mrs. Charles Allen Ashley of Cooperstown, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Allen Ashley, to Second Lieut. Harry Augustus Griffith 3rd, U.S.A, son of Lieut. Gen. Harry A. Griffith, U.S.A., of McLean, Va., formerly of Boonton, N. J.

title: The World; Atlanta Split Favors Young
description: Andrew Young was of course glad to have been elected Mayor of Atlanta last week. But he also acknowledged that there may have been a price.

title: TEACHER TENURE: IS IT AN ASSET OR A LIABILITY?
description: LATE this winter, the New Jersey League of Women Voters is expected to take a stand on the issue of tenure in public education. Its position will be based on a 16-month study that was completed last month.

title: POSTAL-CLOSURE PLAN STIRRING RIVERHEAD
description: THE Riverhead Post Office annex, which handles and distributes mail for the East End communities, may be facing a shutdown next spring. The Regional District office on Long Island is putting together a report on the feasibility of closing the facility. One of the options proposed in the study is to transport all the mail from the East End to either the Smithtown facility or the main mailprocessing center in Hicksville.

title: STATE AUDIT ASSAILS BATTERY PARK CITY AGENCY
description: Between 1968 and last year, the Battery Park City Authority awarded more than $8 million in consulting contracts without competitive bidding and in many cases failed to analyze the consultants' bills to see if their rates were justified, according to an audit by the State Comptroller.

title: Miss Hollyday, Nursing Student, Will Be Married
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Virginia Carroll Hollyday, daughter of Elizabeth Carroll Hollyday and Guy T. Hollyday of Baltimore, to Iredell Waddell Iglehart 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Iglehart of New York.

title: L.I. Sound Races Growing in Stature
description: In grand prix ocean racing, few things remain constant, as evidenced by the high-powered fleet that gathered on Long Island Sound last weekend for the Manhasset Bay Invitational. One of them, though, is Ted Hood's ability to win.

title: 1-MAN PLAY EVOKES GEORGE S. KAUFMAN
description: ''KAUFMAN AT LARGE'' is among those theatrical productions that one thinks of as annuity plays. They are created to serve an actor in search of income and work. Each is designed for one performer; each involves minimal scenery and props, or scenery easily built and props easily collected, so that the show can be booked across the country at colleges and universities.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: * Rates restricted by state usury laws

title: SOME PRACTICAL METHODS FOR PLANING THE EDGES OF DOORS
description: WHEN a door tends to rub along most of its vertical length as you try to close it, chances are that the wood has swelled a little. Sometimes it will shrink back as dries out, but all too often it doesn't. The only way to eliminate the problem is to plane a little off that edge. However, even though the rubbing occurs along the edge where the lock is mounted, planing this can be a problem.

title: ...AND PRISONS IN NEW YORK
description: More than 50 years have passed since New Yorkers voted on whether to build new prisons. This week, with the state's jails brimming over, they will have the chance.

title: NOT TOO LATE TO MAKE FRUITCAKE
description: MANY people who never use their kitchens for anything other than making instant coffee insist on re-creating the family's old fruitcake recipe each fall, feeling an obligation to keep alive the Christmas traditions they grew up with.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THE practice of redlining, usually associated with mortgage-lending institutions, is also being practiced by insurance companies that refuse to write policies in areas where incidents of arson and car thefts are frequent, according to a state official. The practice, he said, has spread from New York City to sections of Westchester and Nassau Counties.

title: Personal Finance; HOW TO CUT YOUR 1981 TAXES
description: I NTERESTED in investing in ''4,'' a low-budget version of the movie ''10''? There's still time to get in on it before the end of the year, and you can claim a $60,000 tax loss on a $30,000 investment.

title: FIVE WHO EXCELLED PAUSE FOR CPTV
description: FROM a farm dotted with maple trees in the rolling western hills to a small, free pediatric clinic in Danbury, from memories of movies to visions of England and the romance of America with the automobile, the television cameras of ''Connecticut Profiles'' have roamed, searching for people from Connecticut whose lives and experiences are meant to inspire.

title: SURPLUS IN BUDGET FOR NEW YORK CITY TOTALS $128 MILLION
description: A final accounting of New York City's 1981 fiscal year disclosed yesterday a sizable budget surplus that was fed by sharp rises in revenues from business taxes and from inflation-swollen income and sales taxes.

title: The World; Soviet Navy Gets Its Comeuppance
description: Running aground is mortifying in anybody's navy, but piling up a 250-ton Russian espionage submarine in mud within neutral Sweden's waters is something else, a Soviet Navy captain learned last week.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: AS far as environmental observers in the state are concerned, today is the end of two years of drought and the start of a third year. Since Nov. 1, 1979, rainfall has been almost 30 percent below normal, according to officials at the National Weather Service office in Windsor Locks, who noted that last August was the driest ever, with the state getting only about one-eighth of its normal rainfall.

title: FOR SOUTH AFRICA'S BLACKS, SOME RELIEF IN COURTS
description: For the second time in little more than a year, South Africa's first and only public interest law firm has won a crucial test case against a part of the labyrinthine bureaucracy that exists to tell blacks where they can live and work and whether they can live with their families.

title: Navy Radar Planes Reported In Hunt for Drug Smugglers
description: The Navy has reportedly begun using sophisticated radar planes against drug smugglers.

title: Topics; Seasons' Meetings
description: Presidential Questions

title: The Region; And the Score Is Unchanged
description: Their party outnumbered two-to-one in the Connecticut Congressional delegation, Republicans in the General Assembly fought Democrats to a standstill in July in hopes of reapportioning the state's Congressional districts in a way that would even things up. Faced with an Oct. 30 deadline, a bipartisan Reapportionment Commission settled the issue last week, but it left the Republicans no better off than before.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: In a news article of Oct. 20, ''La-sers, X-Rays and Quantum Mechanics Prominent in Nobels,'' Walter Sullivan says the award of a Nobel Prize to Kai Siegbahn of Sweden's Upsala University represents the fourth time ''a parent and offspring have both been so honored.''

title: A TERRIBLE NEED FOR ONE MAN LIKE HIM
description: WALDO EMERSON A Biography. By Gay Wilson Allen. Illustrated. 751 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $25. By PAUL ZWEIG

title: A LOOK BACK AT THOSE CROSSTOWN RIVALRIES
description: THE Giants tried to downplay the Jets game the first time they met, that summer of 1969. It seemed silly at the time, but Allie Sherman knew what he was doing.

title: CORNING, ALBANY'S MAYOR FOR 40 YEARS, IS FACING A STIFF CHALLENGE
description: Eight years ago, the longest-running big-city Mayor in the nation, Erastus Corning 2d of Albany, had his closest call in 10 mayoral elections when he defeated Carl Tuohey, a wealthy businessman, by 3,500 votes.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: GREENBURGH THE lights snake through the woods, bright spots on a dark, winding trail. From a distance, the scene is eerie, reminiscent of a candlelight vigil commemorating a death, or it is like some mysterious nighttime parade. The luminescent circles bob up and down, seemingly disembodied.

title: JOINING HER FATHER IN THE LITERARY LIFE
description: ON an autumn day in 1977, Mary Sheldon was seated in a rocking chair in a room in Cambridge, Mass., doing needlepoint and watching the news on television while the man who was to become her husband was studying law.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL CITES AWACS PLAN
description: Benjamin Welles, a spokesman for the department, said that no formal agreement had been discussed with the Saudis and that the United States hopes were still in the formative stage.

title: 132 MUNICIPALITIES TO ELECT CHIEF EXECUTIVES
description: THE candidates' signs have sprouted among the fallen leaves in front yards across the state. The candidates are ringing doorbells and the volunteers are making the last rounds of telephone calls from the temporary storefront headquarters.

title: GREENWICH, TRUMBULL GAIN
description: Greenwich and Trumbull took giant strides towards berths in the Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference's Thanksgiving Day championship game by defeating their nearest division rivals yesterday to remain unbeaten after seven weeks of play.

title: NEW JERSEY'S LAME DUCKS CAN STILL GET UP AND RUN
description: In electing a governor and a legislature this week, voters in New Jersey will do more than choose a new state government. They also will decide what the old one will do in a potentially crucial lame duck session.

title: A SCARED NEW WORLD OF THIRD WORLD ENERGY
description: For developing countries at least, there was a scrap of good news from Geneva last week. At the same time the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to increase world oil prices, it decided to freeze its basic price for a year, thus protecting poorer countries from unexpected and unmanageable increases.

title: THE SELLING GETS TOUGHER FOR LIQUID SOAPS
description: ''R EJOICE,'' declares the advertisement. What has commerce wrought to inspire this summons to celebrate? ''Rejoice,'' it seems, is the name of the newest liquid soap. ''It's what soap should have been in the first place,'' the advertisement states.

title: 36th Election Day Fair Shapes Up in Scarsdale
description: A tradition for 35 years, the Scarsdale Congregational Church Election Day Fair draws crowds from well beyond the village. Some business people come regularly for the corn chowder, turkey salad, sandwiches, lasagne, hot dogs, cake or pie and go back to work after lunch is served between 11:30 A.M. and 1 P.M. in Dyckman Hall of the Parish House.

title: The Fictive Voice
description: To the Editor:

title: 1,600 DETAINED IN NEW YORK JAILS AWAIT TRIAL FOR 6 MONTHS OR MORE
description: Nearly 1,600 people have been awaiting trial in New York City's jails for six months or longer, officials say, worsening the problem of overcrowding.

title: UNORTHODOX VARIATIONS ON CHILI
description: We have often voiced the opinion that chili con carne, rather than apple pie, might well be America's favorite dish. It is one of the tastiest - and easiest -of dishes to make, and anybody, regardless of age or ethnic background, can qualify as a chili expert, one who could declare that his, above all, is the greatest chili on earth.

title: Dining Out; IT MAY BE AN EVENING OUT, BUT--
description: RESTAURANTS serve many purposes. Some people go to them to sample special, or at least well-prepared, dishes that they might not prepare at home. Others choose to dine out because they are feeling festive and want to be pampered by a well-trained staff in an attractive atmosphere. Another group of diners simply wants to have an evening out without spending an arm and a leg.

title: Saving Energy
description: To the Business Editor: In his analysis, ''Winning the War on Energy'' (Oct. 11), Robert D. Hershey Jr. contends that the United States was on the verge of regaining control of its energy destiny. Unfortunately, a glance at America's oil import situation strongly refutes this claim.

title: HOLY CROSS TURNS BACK COLUMBIA, 14-7
description: Holy Cross, which numbered Harvard, Dartmouth and Brown among its previous victims this season, had to battle much harder this afternoon on Fitton Field and even had to change quarterbacks before subduing a gritty Columbia team, 14-7.

title: PANEL URGES SHIFT IN HOUSING POLICY
description: A Presidential commission today recommended a fundamental shift in national housing policy, saying that Federal housing subsidies should go directly to low-income families, not to developers of low-cost housing.

title: WHY THE RUSSIANS CAN'T GROW GRAIN
description: Roy A. Medvedev is a Marxist historian who believes Leninism is compatible with democracy and a multiparty system within the Soviet Union. He was expelled from the Communist Party in 1969 and is now the most prominent dissident in Moscow since the exile early last year of Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist.

title: THREE NOVELS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lore Dickstein is a freelance writer based in New York City. JAIMIE An Autobiographical Novel in Short Stories. By John Becker. 176 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $10. SOLOMON'S DAUGHTER By C. E. Poverman. 268 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $12.95.

title: ISOLATED ALBANIA OPENS PARTY CONGRESS TODAY
description: Albania, the poorest and most isolated country in Europe, opens its eighth Communist Party congress tomorrow to chart its first five-year period without foreign aid or allies.

title: HOW THE RACES LOOK FOR VOTE ON TUESDAY
description: THERE was a time, four years ago, when Democrats on the County Board of Legislators nourished the hope of reversing a narrow 9-to-8 Republican majority and taking control. A Democrat, Alfred B. DelBello, was in the County Executive's office, and control of both branches of government was a possibility.

title: Miss Carroll Sets Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Willis Carroll of Newtown Square, Pa., and Ocean City, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lindsay Carroll, to William Joseph Farrell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Gaillard Farrell of Whitestone, Queens.

title: FETTUCINE- A DISH FIT FOR A DUCHESS
description: Foreigners visiting Rome still ask for fettuccine Alfredo, and some restaurants with a lot of tourist business keep listing the dish that way, but local people prefer to call it by its old name, fettuccine alla Romana. It is one of the most tempting and at the same time simplest pasta specialties.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 7 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with an eccentric family. 2 3 2 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 3 2 12 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 4 4 26 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A British-Chinese struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 5 7 4 THE LEGACY, by Howard Fast. (Houghton Mifflin, $14.95.) The Lavette family of ''The Immigrants'' and ''The Establishment'' reaches the turbulent 60's. 6 5 14 THE THIRD DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam's, $13.95.) On the trail of the elusive killer of o ut-oftown businessmen visiting New York. 7 6 19 THE CARDINAL SINS, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner/Bernard Geis, $12.95.) The triumphs and tragedies of two Chicago boys as priests in the Catholic Church.

title: Colonel Backs Barring Women From Marines
description: The capability of the Marine Corps to deploy units quickly in emergencies has been undermined by the presence of women in the ranks, a marine officer contends in an article released Thursday.

title: Autonomy Talks to Resume
description: Egypt and Israel will resume negotiations on Palestinian autonomy on Nov. 11 in Cairo, a top official said today. Foreign Minister Boutros Ghali told reporters that the new date was proposed by Israel and approved by Egypt provided it was agreeable to the United States, the third party to the talks.

title: No Headline
description: VAN PATTEN TOPPLES MCENROE BY 6-3, 7-5

title: A REVERED COACH IS HONORED
description: ENGLEWOOD IT WAS only one small part of the Homecoming Day program at Dwight-Englewood School, but for many people dedication of the Carlos Henriquez Fitness Center was a highlight not to be missed.

title: THE CLARINET PLAYS A HARMONIOUS ROLE
description: MASSAPEQUA SHE started playing the clarinet at the age of 8, because ''we had one at home and it seemed economically sound.'' He began at 10, when ''during the Benny Goodman craze my parents must have liked the clarinet and bought me one.''

title: HOMAGE TO A LEGEND CALLED ASPEN
description: JAMES SALTER is a writer who lived in Aspen for 10 years. His novels include ''A Sport and a Pastime'' and ''Light Years.'' He also wrote the script for the film ''Downhill Racer.'' His latest novel is ''Solo Faces.'' By JAMES SALTER

title: States News Service
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. DESPITE pressure from the White House, the Egyptian Government and the United Technologies Corporation, Connecticut's Congressional delegation held out to the last against the sale of Awacs surveillance planes to Saudi Arabia.

title: Headliners; The French Branch
description: The rules of the game have changed in Socialist France and Baron Guy de Rothschild, for one, won't play. Last week, faced with the nationalization of much of his financial empire, the Baron publicly relinquished his role as banker and industrialist. ''A Jew under Petain, an outcast under Mitterrand - for me it is enough,'' Mr. Rothschild said, in a statement published by the Paris newspaper, Le Monde. ''I am forced into retirement. I wish I could go on strike.'' In the spirit of more resigned detachment, he added, ''It is clear that the nationalization of the banks does not have the Rothschilds as a specific target. We have been caught up in it as if in a hunting accident, caused by the men whom the French people had the weakness to give the guns to for a time.''

title: ISRAELIS PROTEST ANY U.S. SUPPORT FOR SAUDIS' PLAN
description: Israel has protested to the United States over recent American statements portraying a Sau i Arabian plan as containing some positive approaches toward a Middle East peace settlement, an Israeli Embassy spokesman said today.

title: TIDAL LANDS QUESTION IS THORNIEST ON THE BALLOT
description: THE most confusing, misunderstood and controversial public question on Tuesday's ballot is a proposed constitutional amendment on tidelands in the state. The amendment - Public Question No. 7 - has confounded politicians, pollsters and the public alike.

title: WEATHERED WELL
John Barton Fiance of Pamela Morton
description: The engagement of Pamela Mary Morton to John Whipple Barton has been announced by the future bride's parents, the Very Rev. James Parks Morton, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, and Mrs. Morton. The wedding is planned for the early summer.

title: SOMEONE IS TRYING TO FIRE DR. WALDHEIM
description: Until this week, Kurt Waldheim, the elegant Austrian diplomat who has made a career of avoiding offense to the superpowers or third world nations, appeared assured of an unprecedented third term as Secretary General of the United Nations. But after two days and six futile ballots in the Security Council, there is increasing gloom among the small corps of officials whose jobs depend on Mr. Waldheim's holding his $158,340-a-year post.

title: CONTROVERSY INTENSIFIES ON PRISON BOND ISSUE
description: As Tuesday's election approaches, debate over the $500 million state prison bond issue has intensified, with New York officials trying to win public support for the measure.

title: RIDING THAT HELPS HANDICAPPED
description: STAMFORD IN some ways, the horse show in the spacious barn at Cedar Lodge Farm here last Sunday could have been duplicated at a lot of places in Connecticut and Westchester County where riders and their horses compete on fall weekends.

title: WHERE NO PARENT CAN GO IT ALONE
description: WHEN I moved to the suburbs, I thought I knew what I was getting into. I had been a suburban child, after all. A house in a good neighborhood, it seemed to me, came with effortless entitlements: dancing school and band concerts, Junior Life Saving and Little League games.

title: Washington; ECHOES OF THE 1930'S?
description: In the last few weeks, there have been massive demonstrations in Europe against the emplacement of U.S. nuclear arms in the NATO countries to counter the Soviet SS-20 missiles, now targeted on every Western European capital.

title: THE RATIONAL CONSUMER MAY BE JUST A DEREGULATOR'S DREAM
description: ''Free enterprise is becoming far less free in the name of something called consumerism,'' President Reagan said during his election campaign. Last week, James C. Miller 3d, in his first news conference as chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, suggested freeing up the system by halting programs that protect consumers against defective products and unsubstantiated advertising claims.

title: HOUDINI- THE GREATEST SHOWMAN OF ALL?
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Daniel E. Harmon is a freelance writer with a special interest in magic and magicians. By DANIEL E. HARMON

title: NEW PROBLEM PLAGUES INDIAN POINT 3 NUCLEAR PLANT
description: The Power Authority of the State of New York disclosed this week that tests had detected a new problem at its Indian Point 3 nuclear plant - pitting on the tubes inside the plant's steam generators.

title: MAYORAL RACES ARE FOCUS OF CONNECTICUT'S VOTERS
description: Incumbent Mayors are seeking re-election in four of Connecticut's five largest cities on Tuesday and at least two of the Mayors - in Bridgeport and Stamford - are facing unusually strong opposition.

title: RACIAL ISSUE RAISED IN BRONX CAMPAIGN
description: The issue of minority representation on the Board of Estimate, which has figured prominently in the race for Manhattan Borough President, is a factor to a lesser degree in Tuesday's race for the borough presidency of the Bronx.

title: A SMALL VILLAGE CELEBRATES 2
description: ANNIVERSARIES By J.C. BARDEN TUCKAHOE MANY of the 6,700 residents of this southern Westchester village are full swing into a year of celebrating two school anniversaries. It is the 50th anniversary of the Tuckahoe High School and the 25th anniversary of the village's William E. Cottle Elementary School, and it doesn't bother the celebrants one bit that neither school is actually in Tuckahoe.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Floating Museum
description: She patrolled the seas in World War II, destroying 80 enemy ships and 600 aircraft. Three times she was hit by Japanese kamikaze bombers off Okinawa.

title: No Headline
description: ALABAMA WINS ON KICK, 13-10

title: BRUINS TOP RANGERS CANADIENS HALTED
description: The Islanders' spell over Montreal lived on tonight, and as a result, the Canadiens' unbeaten streak did not. For the eighth time in their last 11 meetings, the Islanders came out with a victory, this time by a score of 2-1. Two of those 11 games were ties.

title: DANCE: LIZ PASQUALE'S 'WE ARE ALL JUNKIES'
description: Liz Pasquale has impersonated a wistful middle-class gogo dancer and a tough and sad little street kid and made them live. On Friday at the White Dog Theater, where she'll be through tonight, she took on the character of Natalie, the junkie, in a 45-minute piece - or 75 if you count the half hour it took Miss Pasquale to get going - called ''We Are All Junkies.''

title: STATE TO USE ARTS TO LURE TOURISTS
description: HARTFORD THE State Commission on the Arts and the State Department of Economic Development have begun a collaborative effort to promote tourism in the state.

title: Miss Eccker, C.D. Lidstone Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Lawrence Eccker of Winnetka, Ill., and Holland, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sandra Louise Eccker, to Christopher Drake Lidstone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herrick Kenley Lidstone of Broomfield, Colo.

title: Around the Nation; 3d Stage of Rescue Plan For Detroit Is Approved
description: The Internal Revenue Service has formally approved the final part of a financial survival plan for Detroit that involves the sale of $56.5 million in municipal bonds to the police and fire departments' pension funds.

title: TOKYO, CALIF.
description: SAN JOSE, Calif. O FTEN vilified for copying American technology, bringing it home and then sending it back to haunt the American companies that developed it, the Japanese have become established, if not entirely appreciated, residents of the semiconductor capital of America, California's Silicon Valley.

title: SPORTS COMPLEX PROPOSED FOR A SITE IN QUEENS
description: A sports and harness-racing complex in Queens that would encompass an enlarged and domed Shea Stadium has been proposed in a statecommissioned report on troubled professional sports in New York City and Westchester and Nassau Counties.

title: SUIT SEEKS TO TAX 4 EXEMPTED GROUPS
description: OSSINING SCORES of wooded acres here, exempt from real estate taxes for religious, historic and environmental reasons, have become the focus of a law suit aimed at adding them to the town of Ossining's tax rolls.

title: The Long Ordeal Of James Brady
description: I was struck by the third sentence in Richard Cytowic's article: ''When a single hospital administrator drops his reptilian doze and shows signs of life ... .'' I knew that I had forfeited all hope of glory or eminence when I abandoned my youthful ambitions for a career in hospital administration, but I did not realize how far I had fallen until Dr. Cytowic pulled the scales from my antediluvian eyes. PETER BAIDA Administrator Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center New York City

title: POLICE REWARD FUND IS SET UP
description: Acting on the suggestion of a 74-year-old Brooklyn businessman who said he was ''horrified by the senseless murder-mania in our city, especially the murder of policemen,'' the New York City Police Foundation will offer rewards for information leading to the arrest and conviction of anyone who kills an on-duty city police officer.

title: Editors' Choice
description: BORGES: A READER, by Jorge Luis Borges. (E.P. Dutton. Cloth, $16.50; paper, $10.)

title: U.S.C. CRUSHES WASHINGTON STATE, 41-17
description: Washington State's dreams of an undefeated season collapsed in the heat and smog of the Coliseum today with a loss to Southern California that also dimmed the Cougars' hopes of going to the Rose Bowl for the first time in 51 seasons.

title: IN MAHOPAC, FOCUS ON A PHOTOGRAPHER
description: MAHOPAC PHOTOGRAPHS by the late Ursula Wolff Schneider are in the collections of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, the Metropolitan Museum, Columbia and Harvard Universities and various other institutions. Also, Miss Wolff, who was married to Karl Schneider, a Bauhaus architect, exhibited in both her native Germany and Chicago. Readers of Chicago Magazine may recall a 1978 spread devoted to her. But as far as Eastern audiences are concerned, she is a new name whose black and white prints are now on view at the Belle Levine Art Center and Gallery in Mahopac (through Nov. 15). Situated on Kennicut Hill Road off Route 6, these premises, which also are the seat of the Putnam Arts Council, served once as the studio of the creator of the Mutt and Jeff cartoon, Bud Fisher, and are open Tuesday through Friday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Saturday and Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M.

title: Fashion
description: GALANOS DEFINES EVENINGS IN BLACK early every woman longs to find the perfect black evening ensemble. James Galanos, to many the premier American designer, may end that quest with his current collection - at least for those women with infinite dollars.

title: Dr. Catherine Kierney to Wed in May
description: The engagement of Dr. Catherine Mary Patricia Kierney of Manhattan to Dr. Gustavus Henry Zimmerman 3d of Wheaton, Ill., son of Gustavus H. Zimmerman Jr. of Garden City, L. I., and the late Isabelle Nelmes Zimmerman, has been announced by Mrs. John F. Kierney of Largs, Scotland, mother of the future bride.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Jin-Kyung Koo Offers Twist in Violin Program
description: Jin-Kyung Koo, a Korean-born violinist, played works of Beethoven, Bach, Chausson, and Brahms in her New York debut Friday night, camoflaging a Carnegie Recital Hall program devoted to the three B's by transposing their order and dropping in a fin de siecle Frenchman. She also stepped outside the conventional violin-piano pairing, for her Bach selection was the Sonata No. 1 in G minor for unaccompanied violin, and her Brahms was the Trio No. 2 in C (Op. 87) for violin, cello and piano.

title: TERRAIN DESCRIPTIONS, APRES-SKI TIPS AND MORE FOR 42 AMERICAN AND EUROPEAN RESORTS
description: The following selective listing was compiled to indicate the variety of resorts available to a ski vactioner in the coming season. It includes well-known destinations and those less renowned, but with features of interest to skiers.

title: Bettye Blatman, Banker, Fiancee
description: Dr. and Mrs. Saul Blatman of Hanover, N.H., and Lynchburg, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bettye Ann Blatman, to Thomas George Manuel, son of George Thomas Manuel of Garden City, L.I., and the late Mrs. Manuel.

title: Other Business; MAGIC IN BUSINESS
description: It's a novelty item that has made a wish come true for Laura Chatain, it's originator. Mrs. Chatain sells magic wands - thin, 14-inch clear acrylic rods with an acrylic sphere enclosed by an acrylic star on top. This fall, sales of the $5 wands hit 100,000. She says she is shipping up to 500 wands daily from the headquarters of her business, an abandoned laundromat in Harbor Springs, Mich.

title: STAGE: ODETS'S 'AWAKE AND SING!'
description: If there is any show that is difficult to make electric in revival, it is ''Awake and Sing!'', that Clifford Odets drama-poem of the Bronx that established so many cliches of dialogue for succeeding playwrights that it might seem to parody itself. For all that, the Jewish Repertory Theater, which frequently sets currents pulsing in its modest East 14th Street house, has done it again with a production of this fine old chestnut that makes one awake and sing.

title: Music View; MUST EVERYBODY WORSHIP WAGNER?
description: Strange, isn't it, how the Wagner question refuses to die. No other composer raises temperatures so high or sets off such awful rows and vendettas, even among people whose interest in music is otherwise close to nil. That, of course, is because no other composer's music is so permeated with his political and social beliefs, so dominated by his view of the world. Strange, again, that such a composer should have arisen in and come to stand for Germany, which had established itself as the guardian of the idea of music as a branch of abstract thought. Bach's fugues (not the cantatas or the passions, of course) epitomize this concept of musical purity. Then Beethoven came along to strain that mold, and Wagner shattered it. Music and philosophy became intertwined throughout Europe in the 19th century and have never come untangled.

title: New Jersey Guide; PIANO CONCERT TODAY
description: Bella Davidovich, the highly acclaimed Soviet pianist who won the Chopin Competition in Warsaw in 1949 and emigrated to this country in 1979, will give a concert in Montclair this afternoon.

title: GETTING RE-ELECTED MAY BE KOCH'S SMALLEST PROBLEM
description: No one can say that the seven candidates in Tuesday's mayoral election have avoided talking about some of the problems or suggesting solutions. But the most original ideas seem to have little connection with political reality.

title: RAIL OFFICIALS HOPE TO TURN OLD STATIONS INTO NEW ASSETS
description: AT THE turn of the century, trolley companies laying tracks through many American cities often built special attractions at the end of their lines -like amusement parks - as a way of increasing ridership.

title: HUMAN MERCHANDISE WAS BIG BUSINESS
description: THE TRANSATLANTIC SLAVE TRADE A History. By James A. Rawley. Illustrated. 452 pp. New York: W. W. Norton. $24.95.

title: INDIA'S ROYAL GHOST TOWN
description: A couple of years ago, while I was in a hospital in New York, my then-11-year-old daughter wrote me from our home in India describing her first visit to Agra. In an attempt to cheer me up, she wrote: ''When you tell people you've been to Agra, of course, they ask you about the Taj Mahal. It's always the Taj this and the Taj that. Now don't get me wrong, the Taj is really quite nice, it's okey dokey, but there's a lot of other stuff around Agra and the most fun is this terrific old city called Fatehpur Sikri.''

title: JONATHAN LOGAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $17 million charge from costs and expenses related to closing of the company's textile manufacturing operations in Spartanburg, S.C.-...C-Net income

title: How Deep Can Poland Plunge?
description: Poland's wildcat strikes and deteriorating economy made for a surprising, if limited, partnership last week between Solidarity leader, Lech Walesa, and Gen. Wojciech Jarzuelski, the Prime Minister and new Communist party chief.

title: Shopper's World; A CUSTOM SUIT IN LONDON FASHION
description: STEVEN RATTNER is a Times correspondent in London. By STEVEN RATTNER

title: Two Means Togetherness
description: After reading ''The Perils of a Two-Income Family'' (by Didi Moore, Sept. 27), I felt that most of these double earners were neurotic, insecure and, in one word, selfish.

title: Stamps; U.N. AND U.S. ISSUES
description: As the United Nations closes out the year with a clutch of six commemoratives, the United States is coming up with a barrage of higher-rate issues, many of which will probably be issued by the end of this year.

title: Yeats Country
description: To the Editor:

title: CREMATION WARNING
description: WASHINGTON DEAD bodies usually play a more prominent role in horror movies than in Congressional legislation. However, a member of Congress has introduced a bill that would provide safeguards against heart pacemakers, which explode during a cremation.

title: AT NASA, ALL THAT'S UP IS THE SHUTTLE COLUMBIA
description: Officials at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration once consoled themselves by saying that when the space shuttle got off the ground, they would turn the corner to find, if not prosperity, at least relief from a decade of hard times. Then there would be room in the budget to reinvigorate space research and exploration programs, which had suffered because of the shuttle's expense.

title: Charleston Police Chief Dead; Praised in '69 Hospital Strike
description: Police Chief John F. Conroy, who earned nationwide respect for his handling of a violent hospital workers strike in 1969, died Wednesday of an apparently selfinflicted gunshot wound, officials said.

title: Investing; SHOULD YOU LEND THE U.S. $8.5 BILLION?
description: G IVEN the state of the stock and bond markets, the plan that the Government announced last week to auction $8.75 billion of new Treasury securities is certain to get a lot of attention from investors - particularly those residing in high-tax states like New York, where the interest earned on Treasury securities is exempt from state income taxes.
To the Editor:

title: The Nation; Pucker Up, Kiss Goodbye to That Balanced Budget
description: For Jimmy Carter, feeling warm about a balanced budget finally meant having to say he was sorry. The Reagan Administration, even more deeply attached, was inching in that same direction last week.

title: TUESDAY, REAGAN AGAIN WILL BE COUNTING THE VOTE
description: While Ronald Reagan was campaigning in Virginia Tuesday night for Marshall Coleman, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, Kyle Tapscott was here arranging to have telephone calls made for Henry Boevers, a Republican running to replace a corrupt Democratic commissioner in Canadian County. Both efforts were paid for by the party's national committee, which is making an all-out push to win any election it can find a Republican running in.

title: OUR REDS, AND THEIRS
description: Devotees of yoga recommend standing on one's head a f ew minutes every day. They say it provides a refreshing new view of t he world. One way to defuse the holy-war spirit welling up around usi s to stand on our heads and take an upside-down view of the s ocalled East-West struggle.

title: STOCKED TO SUIT YOUR FANCY
description: HUNTINGTON EXCEPT that there is a large parking lot conveniently situated at its rear entrance, Jonathan's, a new food shop in Huntington, would not be out of place in Manhattan, on the upper East Side or in SoHo. And it is a welcome addition to the Island.

title: Higher Postage Rates In Effect as of Today
description: New postage rates become effective tomorrow, with first-class letter rates increasing from 18 cents to 20 cents, the United States Postal Service said today.

title: Giant Scoreboard for Mets
description: The Mets announced yesterday that on opening day at Shea Stadium next season they will unveil the world's largest full-color video screen scoreboard. Nelson Doubleday, the chairman of the board, said that the 24- by 36-foot screen would be placed in left-center field, replacing the former auxillary scoreboard.

title: Troubled Waters Of Our Lakes
description: Roger Swain's article was timely because of the impending Federal budget cuts.

title: Ideas and Trends; Scientists Seek Their Safety Net
description: There's nothing like a threatened budget cut to create unity out of discord, even among scientists. Answering the call of the National Academy of Sciences, nearly 100 leading scientists from academia, industry and national laboratories convened in Washington last week to respond to new Federal austerity proposals.

title: Dr. Jay Jensen Fiance of Sarah Meeker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Carpenter Meeker of Washington, have announced the engagement of Mr. Meeker's daughter, Sarah Louise Meeker, to Dr. Jay Arthur Jensen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jay Monroe Jensen of Salt Lake City. A Dec. 5 wedding is planned.

title: Margaret Ferrara Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur V. Ferrara of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Mary Ferrara, to John A. Brescia Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brescia of White Plains. Miss Ferrara and her fiance were graduated from Iona College. She is a corporate banking representative with the Bank of New York and Mr. Brescia is a member of the professional staff of Price Waterhouse & Company.

title: Congress v. The Court
description: I want to congratulate Judge Irving Kaufman on his article, ''Congress v. the Court'' (Sept. 20). While the withdrawal-ofjurisdiction bills, intended to restrict the Supreme Court's ability to hear cases of a specific nature, may be sponsored by liberals or conservatives, Democrats or Republicans, it is the very intent of these bills that must be defeated.

title: God and Mr. Trevor at Millbrook
description: I have never attended a boarding school for boys, but were I to do so, Millbrook would seem a most felicitous choice. Thank you for a lovely article, Mr. Buckley. MARY L. BOARDMAN Philadelphia

title: Prospects
description: Thrifts Face More Losses

title: U.S. PROMOTING STRONGER SAUDI ROLE AMONG ARABS
description: A new diplomatic relationship appears to be emerging in the post-Sadat Arab world, drawing the United States and Saudi Arabia into closer cooperation.

title: No Noho
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics; SEASONS' MEETINGS OCTOBER
description: Sometimes, a friend of ours reports, the early mornings are a bit too chilly for her cardigan and she is glad of the heat on the uptown bus. But by noon the sweater seems too much and she walks the lunchhour streets without it, ice cream cone in hand.

title: Miss Mirkil Wed To H.W. Taylor
description: Sandra Irwin Mirkil, daughter of William I. Mirkil Jr. of Newtown Square, Pa., and the late Mrs. Charles Hollerith Jr. of New York and Harbor Springs, Mich., was married yesterday in Malvern, Pa., to Harrison William Taylor. He is a son of Mrs. Mary Morehead Taylor of Charlottesville, Va., and Harry William Taylor of Tucson, Ariz.

title: Other World Events; Off on the Rights Foot
description: The first target of criticism of Elliott Abrams, nominated last week as Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, was his own Government. The Reagan Administration, he said, had ''done a very bad job of explaining the importance we attach to human rights.'' Mr. Abrams, a 33-year-old lawyer and currently Assistant Secretary for International Organization Affairs, is the second choice for the rights post. In June, the White House withdrew Ernest W. Lefever's nomination after senators questioned the funding of his institute and his reluctance to criticize right-wing regimes. Mr. Abrams, a neoconservative Democrat-turned-Republican who has worked for Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and Henry M. Jackson of Washington, said he would not rule out public criticism of rightist governments but that ''with rare exception, any non-Communist regime is preferable to a Communist regime.''

title: WILLIAMSON TRADE (6-1) SETS BACK 4-1-1 LAWRENCEVILLE BY 14-0
description: It was Parents Weekend at Lawrenceville and the largest crowd of the season was at the New Jersey school's field to cheer on its unbeaten team yesterday. But little cheering was done as Williamson Trade (6-1) of Media, Pa., handed the Larries a 14-0 defeat. The home team, which is now 4-1-1, had been unscored upon in three previous games on its field.

title: Toscanini Photos To Be Displayed
description: Wave Hill, the estate preserved as a cultural institution in Riverdale, the Bronx, is assembling an archive of recordings and memorabilia of Arturo Toscanini. To begin the project, it will open a photographic exhibition about the conductor Nov. 10.

title: PERILS OF PLANNING AN OPERA SEASON
description: The following is an excerpt from Sir Rudolf Bing's new book, ''A Knight at the Opera.'' Sir Rudolf was general manager of the Metropolitan Opera from 1950 to 1972. By SIR RUDOLF BING

title: Follow-Up on the News; Baby Lobbying
description: Before their infant sons became gravely ill, neither Carol Laskin of Washington nor Lynne Pilot of Arlington, Va., was unusually active in Government affairs. They became lobbyists for America's babies in 1979 after their children's sickness had been traced to a diet deficiency in two commercial baby formulas.

title: The Last Day
description: LEMPSTER, N.H. UNLIKE Gerard Manley Hopkins's Margaret, we did not grieve as we drove to Long Pond through Goldengrove unleaving. It was the last day of the New Hampshire trout fishing season, to be sure, but the weather was ideal. For three days a cold northerly wind had come down from Canada, twisting and rattling the leaves of the oaks and maples and birches, leaves that had already lost their scarlet and were gold and brown, tattered, fading pennants that no longer brought hordes of tourists into the high country. Then the wind died and was reborn from the south, soft and gentle, and on the first afternoon of that wind we arrived at Long Pond with three good hours left to flyfish for the brook trout and splake it holds.

title: BRINK'S INQUIRY MARKED BY CLOSE COOPERATION OF LAW AGENCIES
description: Federal agents pursuing suspected terrorists in the Brink's armored-car robbery are feeding the many strands of information gathered in the sprawling investigation into a computer system in their lower Manhattan office and linked to one in Washington.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART In the art of Edvard Munch, the great Norwegian modernist, the principal subject is often some variation on the theme of ''Woman.'' It is rarely, if ever, a very happy theme.

title: A ONE-TIME DIVIDEND ON A HIGH-RISK INVESTMENT
description: WASHINGTON LIKE most other politicians in this city, President Reagan spent much of Wednesday waiting for the Senate vote on his plan to sell five Awacs radar surveillance planes to Saudi Arabia. His triumph, by a 52 to 48 vote brought Mr. Reagan to a crest of power that was notable even by the standards of an Administration that has shown great skill in bending Congress to its will.

title: THE LAST WORD ON QUEEN'S ENGLISH
description: The British Broadcasting Corporation, which takes very seriously the task of teaching the English how to speak, has just published a 40-page guide to pronunciation, diction and grammar.

title: JAMES J. FLORIO - Democrat
description: ECONOMY Says New Jersey's economy is stronger than his opponent has portrayed it. Expresses more concern over state's ability to balance its budget without major cuts in state services in light of cuts in Federal aid. Attacks Kean program as cutting revenues to the state at a time it will most need them. Proposes a more modest tax-cut program, aimed at new businesses and small businesses wanting to create new jobs. Has not ruled out an increase in the income tax during his term, but says he believes he will be able to balance next year's budget without one. Says he hopes to cut costs by eliminating duplication of government services among departments and increasing efficiency and by strengthening the coordination of the budget process in the Governor's office. ENVIRONMENT Successfully sponsored "superfund" legislation in Congress that is intended to provide money for the cleanup of toxic waste sites through an excise tax on chemicals. Supports the bond issues related to water supply, toxic waste cleanup and farmland preservation. Sponsored legislation in the House of Representatives to preserve the South Jersey Pinelands and has urged that the state's Pinelands Protection Act of 1979 not be tampered with. Says that nuclear plants under construction should be completed, but that no new plants are necessary at this time. Has the support of state's leading environmental groups.

title: WHAT DEREGULATION MEANS FOR G.M.
