description: ROGER B. SMITH, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation, has an extra $500,000 a day to spend on new cars now, thanks to the Federal Government, which two weeks ago decided not to require air bags or other passive restraints on 1983 model cars.

title: The World; Finland Loses Master's Touch
description: Finland's longtime President, Urho Kekkonen, 81, who resigned last week because of illness, made a specialty of getting close to Soviet leaders. He frequented their hunting dachas and talked international politics with Nikita Khrushchev and other Soviet leaders in the clothes-off informality of the presidential sauna.

title: THE REAGAN HOAX
description: Ronald Reagan is proving every day that his bite is worse than his bark.

title: 'POST-PIONEER' ARRIVALS KEEP PARK SLOPE IN FLUX
description: Post-gentrification has arrived at Park Slope, the scene of a much-heralded ''renaissance'' in the early 1970's. The young professionals who bought and restored Victorian houses and brownstones there then are now feeling displaced by newer arrivals - developers and Manhattanites willing to pay $200,000 or more for a house.

title: FREEING UP THE BASKETBALL COURTS OF NEW YORK
description: THE flyer in the vestibule of my apartment building demanded attention. It read: ''Attention Basketball Players,'' and went on to say that a private school in the neighborhood had opened a ''large modern gym'' that was available for basketball for two hours an evening during the week at $5 a session.

title: Film View; TIRED BLOOD CLAIMS THE HORROR FILM AS A FRESH VICTIM
description: The scene: a beautiful New England town, immaculate and plain. Does it summon up thoughts of honest labor, simple rewards, and happy families at Christmastime? Or does it remind you -as such places can't help but remind me - of something sinister? Can this be the village to which a plucky young stewardess/schoolteacher/babysitter has come to settle, moving into a cavernous old house that has ghosts in the attic/rats in the basement/peepers at the window? Will she be skewered in the kitchen, or merely strangled in the shower? Will her boyfriend wind up impaled on a thresher or inhabited by the ghost of a prior tenant? Have we all been seeing too many horror movies?

title: Other World Events; They'll Take NATO
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization has its detractors these days, but Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo of Spain is not one of them. In a debate last week before the lower house of Parliament voted 186 to 146 to seek admission to the Western alliance, Mr. Calvo Sotelo declared: ''As long as there is a wall in Berlin, the Government and the Government party know on which side of it they want to be.'' Beyond affirming its geopolitical identity, Madrid hopes NATO membership, which must be ratified by the other allies, will give Spanish generals something to occupy them other than coupplotting, that it will strengthen Spain's hand in renegotiating a bases treaty with Washington and help get the British out of Gibralter.

title: DEFIANT YOUTH OF EUROPE MAINLY DEFY STEREOTYPE
description: It was impossible to talk about youth in general terms, the professor insisted, because there were too many currents, too many contradictions. He tried anyway. When he finished, what little youth there was at the seminar in Essen on young people's problems said they barely understood what he had in mind.

title: Reading and Writing; THE LITERATURE OF DEATH (II)
description: While books have always tried to show us how to live, they are trying now to teach us how to die. The fascination with nothingness that we find in contemporary philosophy, fiction and painting seems to have been extended to the nothingness beyond death, and we have developed a literature that tries to soften the impact of that impending nothingness.

title: Helen L. DuBose To Wed Dec. 19
description: The engagement of Helen Louise DuBose, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Rembert DuBose of Atlanta, to Geoffrey de Rohan, son of Mrs. John Van Rensselaer Strong of Far Hills, N. J., and Charles Louis de Rohan of Cincinnati, has been announced by her parents.

title: GOVERNOR'S TENURE IS KEY ISSUE IN KENTUCKY
description: A proposed state constitutional amendment that would allow the governor to seek re-election for a second term will be on the ballot in Kentucky Tuesday.

title: Lawrence's Accomplishments
description: To the Editor:

title: WILDCATS TIE LOSS MARK
description: Northwestern suffered its 28th straight defeat today, tying the major-college football record.

title: ANIMAL INVENTORY IS AN INTERNATIONAL MATCHMAKER
description: In a cramped little office on the grounds of the Minnesota Zoological Garden, computers keep track of vital statistics for 50,000 animals and birds on three continents. The aim is matchmaking.

title: Dining Out; SETTING A NEW HIGH, ITALIAN STYLE
description: NEW HAVEN IN looks alone, L'Avventura sets new standards for Italian restaurants in New Haven; in fact, perhaps for the entire state. Located in an old brick building on the corner of Elm and State Streets, the premises once served as a drugstore and most recently as another restaurant, Curious Jane's. But L'Avventura has changed more than the decor. The entire configuration is different and stunning.

title: HOW HE BECAME HOLLYWOOD'S HOT WRITER
description: LOS ANGELES Ascreenwriter's tools are simple ones, which may be why Hollywood - intoxicated from the beginning with huge machinery -treats screenwriters with an uneven mixture of envy and contempt. A script is the necessary evil, the 125-page, Xeroxed platform form on which can be erected those fragmented, triplicated, spliced-together images that are so much more fun.

title: WEST ISLIP ENDS EAST ISLIP STREAK
description: In a game between undefeated neighborhood powers yesterday, West Islip defeated East Islip, the defending Rutgers Cup champions, 26-7. West Islip snapped the Redmen's 16-game winning streak, including five straight season. West Islip (6-0) has a 14-game unbeaten and an eight-game winning streak. Last year the teams played to a scoreless tie.

title: Critics' Choices
description: OPERA The much-heralded New York City premiere of ''Satyagraha,'' an opera by Philip Glass, takes place on Friday at 8 P.M. at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. For those interested in contemporary trends in music and theater, it promises to be one of the major events of the season.

party congress today 5 Antigua and Barbuda becoming independent of Britain 6 Pacific island angry at U.S. stand on missile site 8 Peace Corps seeks review of budget cuts 9 U.S. Ambassador, back in ''We Are All Junkies'' 77 Roberta Flack sings in pop recital at Carnegie Hall 77 Susannah McCorkle, pop singer, at Michael's Pub 78 Reviews of debuts by young musi- cians 79

title: CINEMA PLAN IN LEGAL TANGLE
description: NEW HYDE PARK A DEVELOPER's plan to construct a six-auditorium movie theater complex here has resulted in a tangle of litigation. Among the legal actions is a $10 million lawsuit against five opponents of the project, including the leaders of three local civic groups, a neighboring resident and a Town of North Hempstead Councilwoman.

title: A FORCE BEHIND THE SYMPHONY
description: CLIFTON AMONG the many assets of Jean Hooper, the 56-year-old president of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra League, are her forthright manner, a seemingly endless supply of optimism and good humor - qualities the symphony needs to thread its way through its present crisis.

title: Benjamin Kittredge, 81, Dies; Restored Southern Plantation
description: Benjamin Rufus Kittredge, who restored Cypress Gardens, a plantation near Charleston, S.C., that he gave to the city in 1964, died yesterday in a hospital in Montreux, Switzerland, where he was vacationing. He was 81 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Tucson, Ariz.

title: On Language; By William Safire
description: The Great Out There In Vienna, Alan Levy has been clipping certain New York Times Service stories out of the International Herald Tribune. The common denominator is ''out there.''

title: CLINTON CITES 48-YEAR LINK
description: For 48 years, Bernie Sherman has been on a chain gang, and yesterday he was rewarded for his efforts by his alma mater, DeWitt Clinton, in the Bronx.

title: No Headline
description: 4 Goals by Gretzky As Oilers Win, 11-4

title: Brick Routs Central Regional
description: Pete Panuska ran for three touchdowns yesterday to spark undefeated Brick to its sixth victory, a 42-0 rout of Central Regional in Bayville. Panuska sprinted 18, 30 and 13 yards for first-quarter touchdowns.

title: Eric Hirschhorn Weds Leah Wortham
description: Leah Wortham and Eric L. Hirschhorn were married yesterday at the Newton White Mansion in Mitchellville, Md., by the Rev. William R. Murry of the River Road Unitarian Church in Bethesda.

title: Ex-British Intelligence Officer Admits He Spied for Moscow
description: A former British intelligence officer has admitted that he supplied important military secrets to the Soviet Union in World War II and later escaped prosecution despite the exposure of his espionage ring, The Sunday Times reported.

title: EAGLES, COWBOYS PLAY FOR THE TOP
description: The National Football League's 28 teams get into the second half of the season today with the standings in the six divisions in customary knots and two significant games within divisions on the schedule: Kansas City at San Diego and Dallas at Philadelphia.

title: STONY BROOK AREA OVER BOAT
description: A PLAN by the Museums at Stony Brook to donate a 24-foot wooden boat, once used on Arctic expeditions, to the Mystic Seaport Museum has stirred concern among civic leaders who would like to see the boat remain on Long Island.

title: MASTER OF NAMESMANSHIP
description: T HE Allied Chemical Corporation becomes the Allied Corporation. United Aircraft becomes United Technologies. The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company becomes Chemical Bank. Who's responsible for all this?

title: Helen Bertles Bride of Richard Pearce
description: Helen Starr Bertles, daughter of Mrs. Nancy Spring Bertles of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late William M. Bertles Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Richard Anthony Pearce, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Pearce of Finchley, London. Archdeacon James Cattell performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Bailey's Bay, Bermuda.

title: ELI 11 HOLD THE LINE ON RECOGNITION
description: NEW HAVEN IN the afterglow of the Yale football team's upset victory over Navy on Oct. 3, John Rogan, the Elis' outstanding quarterback, saw a particular significance in the 23-19 triumph. ''Tomorrow, people in Kansas are going to pick up the newspaper and see 'Yale stuns Navy' and realize that we've got a pretty good football team.''

title: Wende S. Swartz To Be June Bride
description: Dr. and Mrs. Charles J. Swartz of Easton, Conn. and Weirs, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wende Susan Swartz, to Bruce Scott Bennett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan E. Bennett of River Vale, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: 8-1 Snow Plow Takes Selima by 2 1/4 Lengths
description: Jack Kaenel, a 16-year-old jockey, guided Snow Plow to a 2 1/4-length victory in a field of six 2-yearold fillies today in the $218,335 Selima Stakes at Laurel Race Course.

title: BELGRADE AND U.S. CELEBRATE 100-YEAR LINKS
description: It started with plums and kerosene, $1 million worth of the succulent fruits of Serbia being shipped to America, and, in return, America shipping half a million dollars worth of the fuel here.

title: Workers' Protest
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S NEW IN EQUIPMENT
description: RUTH ROBINSON is a reporter for the Style section of The Times. By RUTH ROBINSON

title: SONGS THAT TEACHER TAUGHT US
description: TOO MANY SONGS BY TOM LEHRER: With Not Enough Drawings by Ronald Searle (Pantheon, Cloth, $16.50. Paper, $8.95) can boast an implausible title and honest subtitle. For anyone who measured the 1950's and 60's in the rhythms of Tom Lehrer's ''The Old Dope Peddler,'' ''I Hold Your Hand in Mine'' or ''The Vatican Rag,'' 34 songs (with piano accompaniment and guitar chords) by the master of musical satire could never be ''too many.'' However, five wicked cartoons by Ronald Searle are clearly ''not enough.''

title: How to Stimulate Nighttime Students
description: Your article, ''The Changing Course of Adult Education'' (Oct. 11), implied, and rightly so, that a teacher's expectations from his adult student body must be different from that of a college-age student body.

title: NEW COMMISSIONER SEEKS TO 'BALANCE' STATE TRANSPORTATION
description: HARTFORD IN his first policy pronouncement after being sworn in last week as the new State Commissioner of Transportation, J. William Burns said his top priority would be to maintain a ''balanced'' transportation system for Connecticut.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Ingrid Stjernloef Sings A Contralto Program
description: Ingrid Stjernloef is a contralto from Sweden who puts thought and emotional intensity behind everything she sings. When her music does not stray too far from the warm and communicative middle range she commands so well, Miss Stjernloef makes quite a success of her music.

title: WEINBERGER'S TWISTED HISTORY OF THE 1930'S
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation; Early Warning on Nuclear Spending
description: Congress last week gave its first formal response to the Administration's plan for putting elevator shoes under the nation's nuclear triad. It was underwhelming.

title: Mailbox; Give the Games Back to Youths
description: To the Sports Editor: Fred F. Paulenich's article, ''Sports and the Curse of Violence'' (The New York Times, Oct. 18), is helping me make a case against the hard slide employed in breaking up the double play.
To the Editor:

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL URGES 'JUDICIAL RESTRAINT'
description: ''THE groundswell of conservatism evidenced by the 1980 election makes this an especially appropriate time to urge upon the courts more principled bases that would diminish judicial activism,'' Attorney General William French Smith told a group of Government lawyers last week. Mr. Smith referred to judicial restraint - in matters such as abortion and school desegregation - for which President Reagan campaigned and, Mr. Smith said, his department will now work. He did not specify actions to be taken. Excerpts of his speech follow.

title: Queens to Dedicate Copland Music School
description: Aaron Copland will be present when the Aaron Copland School of Music at Queens College is dedicated next Thursday at 8:30 P.M. The ceremony will be held before an invited audience in the Queens College Theater, Kissena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway.
To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation; 10 Drowned Haitians To Be Buried in U.S.
description: Federal and local officials said today that 10 of the 33 Haitian refugees who drowned in the surf off Hillsboro Beach, Fla., would be buried in this country.

title: Death Threats Cited By Belgrade Dissident
description: Milovan Djilas, a prominent dissident, said today that he had received anonymous death threats accusing him of anti-Yugoslav activities.

title: GARDEN LANES ECHOING TO WORLD CUP BOWLING
description: The Federation Internationale des Quilleurs is in town this weekend, creating no stir at all for most New Yorkers, but mounting excitement among the metropolitan area's quarter-million devotees of bowling.

title: Photography View; O'SULLIVAN'S MODERNITY; PHILADELPHIA
description: Overlooked in the excitement created by the Museum of Modern Art's Eugene Atget exhibition is a major exhibition of work by a photographer of no less importance, Timothy H. O'Sullivan. O'Sullivan (1840-82) was as fluent as Atget (1857-1927) in the straightforward, seemingly uninflected documentary style for which the turn-of-thecentury Frenchman is held in such esteem, and he is at least as influential on today's photographers. Insofar as O'Sullivan's subjects were American, ranging from the Civil War to the exploration and first exploitation of the West, he may be even more of an exemplar than Atget. Moreover, his landscapes mark a watershed between a 19th-century view of nature as essentially sympathetic to, and defined by, man, and the more modern view of nature as alien, overwhelming and indifferent.

title: Business Forum; THE MEMORIES OF A CHASE BANKER
description: A FTER working at the State Department, the author was a vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank and chief of staff to its former chairman, David Rockefeller. Following Mr. Rockefeller's retirement in April, Mr. Reed became senior adviser to Willard C. Butcher, who curently is chairman of Chase. In September, Mr. Reed was appointed Ambassador to the Kingdom of Morocco. Before leaving, he pulled together some recollections of his career at Chase and published them in a brochure that he sent to some of his former colleagues. Following are excerpts:

title: Patricia Palmieri Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gene F. Palmieri of Scarsdale, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Jane Palmieri, to John D. Dadakis, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Dadakis of Harrison, N.Y. A spring wedding is planned. Mr. Dadakis is an associate with the New York law firm of Reavis & McGrath.

title: KELLY PACES CHATHAM BOROUGH ROMP
description: Doug Kelly, a senior halfback, carried 10 times for 142 yards and three touchdowns yesterday to lift undefeated Chatham Borough over Mountain Lakes, 44-0, in Mountain Lakes. It was Chatham Borough's sixth victory.

title: Other Business; NEW MAN, OLD PATCH
description: He has returned. The same, yet different. Mysterious, but gentler. Authoritative, but a family man. He is the man with the eyepatch - the man in the Hathaway shirt ad. ''A man's man,'' explains Hathaway's vice president of marketing, Albert J. DiMarco.

title: Ann Jones Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Ann Holmes Jones to Donald Henry Koch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Koch of Livingston, N.J., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Ridgely Jones of Sykesville, Md., parents of the future bride. The wedding will take place on Jan. 2. Miss Jones is an energy planner with the Colorado Office of Energy Conservation. Mr. Koch is a senior engineer with Hittman Associates in Englewood, Colo., an energy and environmental consulting concern.

title: GIANTS VS. JETS: A NEW MEANING
description: THE Giants and the Jets, New York's two professional football teams, collide today before the usual sellout crowd of more than 76,000 at Giants Stadium. Exciting? Yes, but not as it once was, and the reasons for the excitement are different.

title: Around the World; Salvadorans Extending Martial Law for 30 Days
description: The junta announced yesterday that it was extending martial law for another 30 days, but said it was exempting seven right-wing and centrist parties from bans on freedom of the press and expression.

title: IS THERE A TIE-UP? THE SHADOW KNOWS
description: UNION TRAFFIC is down to a crawl on the New Jersey Turnpike. One lane is closed by a jack-knifed truck, and there is a half-hour wait at the Holland Tunnel.

title: POSTSCRIPTS TO THE SAUDI AWACS DEAL
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: WASHINGTON DEFEATS STANFORD

title: No Headline
description: SWEDEN MAINTAINS ITS TOUGH STANCE ON SOVIET SUB

title: LIVING THE ECONOMICAL LIFE DOESN'T SEEM EASY ANYMORE
description: ''I WENT to the woods,'' Thoreau said, ''because I wished to live deliberately, to front only the essentials of life, and see if I could not learn what it had to teach, and not, when I came to die, discover that I had not lived.''

title: CHURCH CELEBRATES ITS RESTORED ORGAN
description: NEW ROCHELLE ''THE music is both fire and shining gold,'' the Rev. Donald V. Roberts was saying. ''It is an ineffable, awesome something, impossible to describe.''

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE Two new works this week look to the rituals of modern day and distant cultures. At City Center, the Joffrey Ballet will present Gerald Arpino's ''Light Rain,'' the world premiere of this 25th-anniversary season.

title: The County Executive And Sensitive Positions
description: Paul Feiner's letter of October 25 ignores the causes of the costly administrative hearings and why certain sensitive positions, like Budget Director, Commissioner of Health and Commissioner/Sheriff, are exempted from serving at the pleasure of the County Executive.

title: Ideas and Trends; High Stakes at St. Bart's Church
description: Whether seen as a conflict between tradition and real estate, pressure and esthetics or God and Mammon, the dispute over St. Bartholomew's Church in New York seems likely to provide a lot of work for lawyers. The Episcopal church's leaders last week accepted a plan to lease some of its valuable Park Avenue land to a British developer, Howard P. Ronson, as the site of a 59-story office tower.

title: Reagan Wins on Awacs With a Little to Spare
description: Averting what could have been a disastrous foreign policy crash, the Reagan Administration last week maneuvered its wobbly Awacs proposal to a safe landing - and made it look easy.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Matti Raekallo Plays Liszt Piano Sonata
description: A polished and relaxed pianistic technique, capable of incisive precision and extravagant energy, is a double-edged sword. It immediately slices through all instrumental difficulties, but it can also cut into the music, turning its hard-earned, sensuous tensions into overly neat, matter-of-fact articulations.

title: KVETCHING ABOUT THE HUMAN CONDITION
description: A BINTEL BRIEF Volume II. Letters to the Jewish Daily Forward 1950-80. Compiled and Edited by Isaac Metzker. Translated by Bella S. Metzker and Diana Shalet Levy, Under the Supervision of Isaac Metzker. 167 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $10.95.

title: POOR, STARVING SCIENCE
description: The mandarins of American science frequently p ortray their profession as a starvling, a victim of parsimony that i s squandering an indispensable national asset. Yet in recent weeks, A merican scientists continued their long domination of the most s everely judged symbol of scientific prowess, the Nobel Prize. Five w ere among eight researchers sharing the 1981 prizes in physics, c hemistry, and physiology or medicine. Every year since 1950, A mericans have shared or exclusively received at least one of the s cience prizes; in seven of the last 20 years, Americans were winnersi n all three categories.

title: A LESSON LEARNED AT POCANTICO HILLS
description: INEVER met the man in my life. My feeling about all his money and power was inarticulate awe. I wondered often what he was like as a small boy, what he was told about who we are and why we're here and where we're going that is different from what I am now telling my own boys. I felt sorry for him twice: when he was snookered out of the Republican Presidential nomination and when he made a lewd gesture at a heckler. I coveted his property at Pocantico Hills and still do. I am not certain how I feel about the way he died, though I am inclined to believe the most scandalous. I do know that I miss Nelson Rockefeller.

title: PACIFIC ISLE ANGRY AT U.S. STAND ON MISSILE SITE
description: Landowners of Kwajalein Atoll, whose property has been used by the United States for missile tests for nearly 20 years, have been told by a Washington consultant that the Department of Defense may continue using the test site for the next decade or two.

title: Editor Weds Janet Graham
description: Janet Graham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Graham of Wantagh, L.I., was married yesterday to Martin Gottlieb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Gottlieb of New York. Criminal Court Judge Jay Gold performed the ceremony in a private apartment in Manhattan. The bride, a freelance documentary film researcher, is a former special assistant to the commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development of New York. Mr. Gottleib is editor of the Manhattan section of The Daily News.

title: SECURITIES GROUP NOMINATES LEADER
description: The Securities Industry Association has nominated Edgar D. Jannotta, the 50-year-old managing partner of Chicago-based William Blair & Company, as its chairman for 1982. In the association, the major trade group of the brokerge and investment banking business, the nomination is tantamount to election, which will be held in December at the annual convention in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: LIST OF CANDIDATES IN THE CITY AND ITS NEW YORK STATE SUBURBS
description: Following are abbreviations used for party designations in the accompanying tables. Asterisk denotes incumbent. D-Democrat. R-Republican. C-Conservative. RTL-Right to Life. L-Liberal. U-Unity. LP-Libertarian. FL-Free Libertarian. SW-Socialist Workers. Ind-Independent. Coa-Coalition. CS-Common Sense. NP-Nonpartisan. IT-Independent Taxpayers. TP-Taxpayers. VI-Voters Independent. NEW YORK CITY

title: Waltrip Is Winner In American 500
description: Darrell Waltrip beat Bobby Allison by a car length in the $196,400 American 500 Nascar Grand National race at the North Carolina Motor Speedway today.

title: 49ERS TOP STEELERS FOR 6 IN ROW, 17-14
description: Joe Montana, a victim of two costly interceptions, led the decisive touchdown drive in the fourth quarter today as the San Francisco 49ers won their sixth straight game, by 17-14 over the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: INQUIRY ON JAIL DEATH OF BLACK ATHLETE WIDENS DIVISIONS IN CALIFORNIA TOWN
description: Until a black college student, a football star with no previous police record, was found hanging dead in a jail cell here, this tiny oil town was virtually unknown to the thousands of people who stream through it commuting between Los Angeles and Long Beach.

title: FOR SPAIN, 'GUERNICA' STIRS MEMORY AND AWE
description: MADRID THE silence in the presence of Pablo Picasso's ''Guernica'' in the Prado Annex is impressive. Spaniards are given to chattering and exclaiming in museums, but, confronted with the stark mural and its shrieking victims, they are hushed, as if in church. Old men take off their berets and hold them at their sides.

title: JAMEELA WINS BY 6 LENGTHS AT AQUEDUCT
description: Jameela, who finished seven lengths behind the front-running Love Sign in the Beldame Stakes three weeks ago, yesterday went after Love Sign early, wore her down and pulled away to a six-length triumph in the $110,400 Ladies Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: Zimbabwe Rallies Banned
description: The Government banned three rallies today as part of its crackdown on opposition political parties. At the same time, it granted permission for a rally by Prime Minister Robeert Mugabe's own party, the Zimbabwe African National Union.

title: TV SPECIAL LISTS ELIZABETH TAYLOR
description: Elizabeth Taylor will appear in the cast of ''Night of 100 Stars,'' a three-hour television special to be broadcast in March as part of the centennial celebration of the Actors' Fund of America.

title: Bruins 4, Whalers 1
description: BOSTON (UPI) - Rick Middleton had two goals and an assist and a rookie Boston goalie, Marco Baron, missed his first National Hockey League shutout by one second.

title: KEAN AND FLORIO RACE TO THE WIRE WITH BUSH AND BRADLEY ON HAND
description: Both major party candidates for Governor of New Jersey made lastminute appeals for votes yesterday, with the Republican, Thomas H. Kean, receiving a visit from Vice President Bush and the Democrat, Representative James J. Florio, accompanied on campaign stops by Senator Bill Bradley.

title: GROUND THE F-18 PROGRAM
description: The Navy's proposed F-18 jet aircraft is an unnecessary addition to America's arsenal.

title: Ohio Steelworkers Make Concessions to Get Plant
description: By a margin of better than 10 to 1, steelworkers at the Timken Steel Company have agreed to contract concessions in return for a new $500 million mill, union officials announced today.

title: Welsh Party Now Seeks An Independent Nation
description: The Welsh Nationalist Party has voted to seek a Welsh Socialist state independent of Britain, discarding its previous goal of self-government within the United Kingdom.

title: BILLS, LED BY CRIBBS, BEAT BROWNS, 22-13
description: Many National Football League observers regard Joe Cribbs, the second-year running back for the Buffalo Bills, as one of the most versatile and valuable offensive threats in the league. Cribbs, a 5-foot-11-inch 190-pound back from Auburn, proved his value as a rookie last year with 1,185 yards gained rushing and 415 yards as a pass receiver, scoring 11 touchdowns on the ground and one on a reception.

title: PIANO RECITAL: HOROWITZ PLAYS SCARLATTI SONATAS
description: WHEN Vladimir Horowitz stepped out on the Metropolitan Opera House stage Sunday afternoon in his cutaway he looked like a magician right out of a Fellini movie. He beamed his famous toothy smile of reassurance and spread his hands to the audience as if to say, ''You see, I have nothing up either sleeve.'' But in a moment the 77-yearold pianist was up to his old tricks, and what tricks they still are: for sheer prestidigitation this recital was a stunner from start to finish. Mr. Fingers is not ready to give up his title.

title: TRIAL NEAR FOR MAN CHARGED IN SHOOTING LIBYAN
description: The trial of Eugene Tafoya, the former Green Beret charged in the shooting of a Libyan student last year, opens tomorrow in Fort Collins, Colo., with Mr. Tafoya's attorneys planning a lastditch attempt to have the trial moved to another city.

title: A RUSSIAN SECT CANONIZES NICHOLAS II
description: In a religious ceremony with political overtones, Czar Nicholas II, his family and tens of thousands of others killed since the outbreak of the Russian Revolution in 1917 were canonized as saints at a Manhattan church over the weekend.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BACKGROUNDERS

title: Francine Kaczmarek Bride Of Martin Andrew Siederer
description: Francine Kaczmarek, a research analyst trainee with the Continental Insurance Company in Piscataway, N.J., was married yesterday to Martin Andrew Siederer, an assistant director of public education and information in the national headquarters of the Leukemia Society of America in New York.

title: Elizabeth Kaplow Wed to Evan Jacobs
description: Elizabeth Amy Kaplow and Evan B. Jacobs were married yesterday at Temple Israel. Rabbi Martin J. Zion performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Irving Kaplow of Putnam Valley, N.Y., and New York and Mrs. Neil McCluskey of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Chester Jacobs of Jericho, L.I.

title: Bomb Hits Salvador Bridge
description: A bomb destroyed a bridge today on a main road linking El Salvador's capital with provincial towns, th police said. No one was injured.

title: SHOOTING VICTIMS HONORED IN RITES
description: Eighty relatives, friends and supporters of five leftists fatally wounded two years ago by Ku Klux Klansmen and American Nazis gathered this afternoon in a cemetery where four of the leftists are buried.

title: IF PARENTS WERE ARBITERS OF SCHOOL INTEGRATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Indiana Rolls On
description: Pat McGauley scored two first-half goals, his 15th and 16th of the season, as Indiana, the nation's topranked soccer team, defeated Evansville today, 4-0. Indiana is now 17-2, having won 11 in a row. Armando Betancourt got his 22d goal of the season for the winners.

title: TUNISIAN VOTE FRAUD IS CHARGED
description: Tunisians voted today for a new 136-seat National Assembly in the first contested election in 25 years, but opposition groups charged tonight that officials of the ruling party prevented many of the opposition's supporters from casting their ballots.

title: SSC&B Adds Scannon To Its Mennen Billings
description: SSC&B, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is adding to its billings from the Mennen Company.

title: TV: THE NEW YORK OF EDITH WHARTON
description: YEARS in the financing, Edith Wharton's ''The House of Mirth'' comes to public television this evening, at 8 on WNET, Channel 13, courtesy of the National Endowment for the Humanities, Exxon, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and the system's stations. Apart from Geraldine Chaplin and William Atherton, the cast has been recruited from Rhode Island's outstanding Trinity Square Repertory Company, which has Adrian Hall as artistic director. Mr. Hall directed and is co-author of the script with Richard Cumming.

title: MUSIC: MODERN JAZZ QUARTET PLAYS BENEFIT
description: SINCE the celebrated Modern Jazz Quartet broke up in 1974 after having played together for 22 years, it has reunited on a few occasions in one-shot situations in which the innate musicianship of the four musicians and their long-term instincts enabled them to recreate some of their best-known numbers. On Friday, however, the quartet arrived at Avery Fisher Hall to play a benefit for Jazzmobile after a tour of Japan, and we received the benefits of the tour.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Rock Hudson will undergo heart bypass surgery this morning at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. The 55-year-old actor was admitted to the hospital for tests on Thursday, two weeks after he began experiencing chest pains and shortness of breath while filming episodes for a new NBC television series, ''The Devlin Connection.''

title: SOCCER NOT FOREIGN TO L.I.U.
description: THEY were playing up North a few weeks ago, at one of the better schools in the country, when the taunting came from a few people in the stands.

title: Bucs 20, Bears 10
description: Jimmie Giles caught Doug Williams's pass and ran 60 yards on an 81-yard scoring play for Tampa Bay. Williams added a 51-yard scoring pass to Kevin House, and Bill Capece kicked field goals of 46 and 30 yards, the second one set up by a Bear fumble in the waning moments.

title: SAUDIS PLAN PRAYERS FOR RAIN
description: King Khalid has declared tomorrow a school holiday so that teachers and students can ''pray for rain,'' the state-run Riyadh radio announced today. Saudi Arabia's annual rainfall averages between 4 and 8 inches, depending upon the region.

title: AUSTRALIA, UNDER NEW POLICY, IS SEEKING SKILLED AMERICANS
description: Australia, under a new immigration policy due to go into effect next April, is actively seeking more Americans with business and technical skills.

title: Index; International
description: A ''colored'' South African fights for better schools A2 In the Sudan, 200 miles can last forever A3 Canada's premiers gather for a last meeting on constitution A3 French Socialist test: taxing wealth A5 Around the World A7 Australia is actively seeking skilled Americans A10 Fifty percent cut in Asia's popula- tion growth rate urged A13 Private health care is a booming business in Britain A14 Government/Politics Racial issue emerges in cam- paign for governor of Virginia A21 Top U.S. prosecutor in Manhattan focusing on organized crime B2 Nassau County Executive race has generally been low key B7 Democrats see a chance to gain in Suffolk County Legislature B7 Washington Talk Briefing A20 Unlikely duo works into White House position of power A20 White House does far more than guess who's coming to dinner A20 The Calendar A20 Energy Oil dealers say trucked-in heating fuel violates standards B1 General Around the Nation A16 Leftists' allies meet in Greens- boro to mark '79 killings A17 Health/Science Foster-care agencies faulted in review by New York City B3 Religion Disagreements again arise at forum of Christians and Jews A17 SportsMonday Baseball: George Bamberger confident of himself and Mets C1 Basketball: Isiah Thomas gives Pistons hope for revival C8 Columns: Dave Anderson on Jets' Bruce Harper C4

title: BL'S FUTURE IS CLOUDED BY STRIKE
description: The future of Britain's only domestic auto maker was thrown into doubt today when employees of BL Ltd. went on strike for larger wage increases despite a threat that the company would be liquidated in the event of a walkout.

title: TREASURY PLANS HEAVY BORROWING
description: Despite the success of last week's offerings, large corporations and their investment bankers have not scheduled any bond offerings this week in deference to the $8.75 billion of Treasury notes and bonds to be auctioned.

title: ASIA URGED TO END POPULATION SURGE
description: Legislators from 19 Asian countries have concluded a United Nations-sponsored conference on population problems by proposing that their governments work to hold Asia's annual population growth rate to 1 percent by the end of the century.

title: Blue Cross Predicts a Deficit Without a 31% Rise in Jersey
description: Blue Cross officials say they will run up a $2.5 million deficit unless the company is granted a 31 percent rate increase.

title: NEW-WAVE ROCK: DEVO FROM OHIO
description: wave quintet from Akron, Ohio, are media satirists whose theatricality is at least as important as their music. The group, whose premise is that the human race is in a process of ''devolution,'' actually markets its fashions, which include rubber pompadour hairpieces in red and black, quasi-astronaut uniforms, 3-D glasses and ''energy dome'' hats.

title: CANADIAN PREMIERS GATHER FOR PARLEY
description: Canada's 10 provincial premiers gathered here today for what is expected to be the last attempt to settle the country's long constitutional crisis by consensus.

title: DELAY IN TAX RISES TILL'83-'84 BACKED BY REAGAN AND DOLE
description: The top tax officials in the Reagan Administration and the Senate agreed today that any tax increases to help cut future Government budget deficits should be put off until 1983 and 1984.

title: THE G.O.P. ALTERNATIVE FOR THREE KEY OFFICES
description: To the Editor:

title: Greene's Act, Part II
description: Television viewers who two years ago enjoyed the Coca-Cola commercial in which Mean Joe Greene of the Pittsburgh Steelers appeared may want to watch a one-hour movie on Nov. 15. NBC will present ''The Steeler and the Pittsburgh Kid,'' a spinoff from the commercial that won a Clio award, the advertising business equivalent of an Ocsar.

title: Song-and-Dance Role Beckons Richard Thomas
description: Richard Thomas said goodbye to Broadway yesterday, but only for a while. Before his final appearance in ''Fifth of July,'' the 30-yearold actor said he planned to return to the New York stage next year - in a musical.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt ELVIS. By Albert Goldman. 598 pages. Il- lustrated. McGraw-Hill. $14.95.

title: Creighton's Coach
description: The large, strong fingers which a decade ago lofted delicate jump shots and tipped rebounds for the New York Knicks are now wrapped around a pen, writing the name Willis Reed hundreds of times daily at his job at Creighton University in Omaha.

title: No Headline
description: ANTIGUA GAINS INDEPENDENCE: Princess Margaret of Britain attending ceremony Sunday in St. John's marking the creation of the new Caribbean nation of An-tigua and Barbuda. With her is Prime Minister Vere Bird. Britain, which ruled the two islands for nearly 350 years, has pledged $18 million in assistance until 1991.

title: Bridge: Pakistan's Team Is Called World Play's Top Surprise
description: For many of the participants and spectators, the most exciting feature of the world team championship that ended Friday in Port Chester, N.Y., was the remarkable performance of the Cinderella team from Pakistan. This was Pakistan's first appearance in the Bermuda Bowl event, and many observers predicted a last-place finish.

title: Commodities; Sugar Bill Called Aid To Fructose
description: IN a bizarre turn of events, domestic beet and cane sugar producers are expected to attain a hard-fought legislative victory in Washington this week that will only help their chief competitors - the makers of corn-based sweeteners - gain an even greater share of the market.

title: Packers 34 Seahawks 24
description: AT GREEN BAY, Wis. - David Whitehurst, playing for the injured Lynn Dickey, threw three touchdown passes and ran for a score.

title: Airlines Mark 2 Years Without a Fatal Crash
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said domestic airlines yesterday completed 24 months without a fatal accident involving a large passenger jet.

title: Advertising; Following A Trend in Drug Field
description: JUST as consumer goods ad agencies sometimes diversify into prescription pharmaceuticals advertising in order to beat the conflict problem that impedes their growth, so Sudley & Hennessey, the world's largest health-care ad agency is moving into consumer goods advertising. But only for over-the-counter consumer drugs.

title: Amber Light on Foreign Aid
description: The Senate added two useful riders when it approved the Administration's $6.7 billion foreign aid package. As requested by President Reagan, it removed long-standing restrictions on aid to Chile and Pakistan. But without asking, the President also got what he needs: an amber warning that Congress will not forget Chile's human rights abuses or Pakistan's nuclear ambitions. That is a minimal signal for an amnesia-prone Administration.

title: DANCE: LES BALLETS JAZZ DE MONTREAL IN THE BRONX
description: LES Ballets Jazz de Montreal, which made its only local appearance of the year on Saturday at the Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts, is just what its name suggests. Versed in classical-ballet technique, this company in its style blends the taut limbs and isolations of body parts of jazz dance with the sleek propulsion and attention to long, tapering line identified with ballet. And it is danced by 13 young dancers - many of them of French Canadian descent - whose bright good looks have a Gallic piquancy to them.

title: 'COLORED' SOUTH AFRICAN FIGHTS FOR BETTER SCHOOLS
description: If it is possible for a disenfranchised nonwhite who is morally committed in his opposition to every aspect of the country's racial system to be a member of the South African establishment, then Franklin Sonn might be called an establishment figure.

title: SHIFT ON SIX-MONTH RATE
description: Starting today, a change in the formula for determining the interest rate on six-month savings certificates will allow banks and savings institutions to choose between a rate based on the average of the last four auctions of six-month Treasury bills or continue to use the results of the last auction.

title: Sabres Turn Back Flyers, 6-2
description: Tony McKegney scored two power-play goals for Buffalo tonight as the Sabres defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 6-2.

title: KOCH SEEKS SWEEP TOMORROW
description: Mayor Koch, running on both the Democratic and Republican lines, is strongly favored to win a second term tomorrow and lead a Democratic sweep of municipal and judicial offices in the city - the most visible of local elections across the state.

title: THE SAVINGS BANKS CUSHION
description: Although experiencing heavy losses, most of New York City's savings banks are not in danger of immediate failure, and many have enough surplus reserves to sustain current losses for five years or more.

title: Thomas Starts With a Bang for Pistons
description: Phil Hubbard, the Detroit Piston forward, has nicknamed Isiah Thomas Zeke. Coach Scotty Robertson calls him I. George Andrews, Thomas's lawyer, refers to him as Pocket Magic, a takeoff on Earvin (Magic) Johnson of the Los Angeles Lakers. To Mary Thomas, Thomas's mother, he is just Junior.
