title: News Analysis
description: The unified oil price that OPEC members agreed on last week can be viewed as a peace treaty between Saudi Arabia and the group's 12 other members. But the new peace may be fragile, largely because of pressures in the marketplace and lingering animosities caused by the previous 10 months of sometimes bitter dissension over prices. The members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries achieved the consensus that had eluded them in two previous meetings here this year by setting a common base price of $34 a barrel - replacing a system that had permitted Saudi Arabia to use a $32 base while other members used $36. The 13 thus displayed a sense of common purpose that had been lacking for more than two years.

title: U.S. PROSECUTOR STRESSES FIGHT ON ORGANIZED CRIME
description: Efforts to combat organized crime were stressed in a 77-page report issued yesterday by the chief Federal prosecutor in Manhattan. The prosecutor, John S. Martin Jr., reported on his first 16 months in office as the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. He observed that ''organized crime continues to be a major focus of the work of this office.''

title: New York Seascape
description: An exhibition illustrating New York's maritime history since the 17th century will be on view through March 14 at the Seaport Gallery of the South Street Seaport Museum, 213 Water Street.

title: News Analysis
description: The Koch administration and the union representing New York City's police officers both say they want many patrol cars to carry one officer instead of two. But both sides also hint that their failure to reach an agreement on the subject after 10 months of talks could mean that the differences separating them are insurmountable.

title: MILITARY OUTLAYS EXPECTED TO HELP IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Major military contractors in the New York metropolitan area expect long-term gains in revenues and jobs from the Reagan Administration's increase in military spending, but the impact has yet to be felt, according to most company officials.

title: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1981; The Economy
description: Top White House and Senate tax officials agreed that any tax increases to reduce budget deficits would be put off until 1983 and 1984. But the officials, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and the Senate Finance Committee's chairman, Bob Dole, disagreed on how large the future tax rises should be. (Page A1.)

title: JUDGE REJECTS FINDINGS OF FAMILY COURT STUDY
description: Responding to a report critical of New York City's Family Court system, the judge in charge of the courts asserted that, despite staff shortages, many problems have been corrected and the courts today are working ''quite efficiently.''

title: SUFFOLK G.O.P. CONSOLIDATION BID REGARDED AS HELPFUL TO DEMOCRATS
description: Efforts by the Suffolk County Executive to consolidate his control over the county's Republican Party have given Democrats an opportunity to increase their numbers in the Republican-led County Legislature.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Auction column in Weekend on Friday listed the wrong days for the Impressionist and modern art sales at Sotheby Parke Barnet. They will be held on Wednesday and Thursday.

title: Spy to Be Witness at Trial
description: Christopher Boyce, the convicted spy who was arrested in August after escaping from a Federal prison, is expected to appear as a defense witness in the trial of a woman charged with harboring him last summer. The trial of Gloria Ann White, who is said to have harbored Mr. Boyce in her summer home near Bonners Ferry, Idaho, begins Dec. 2.

title: Bengals 34, Oilers 21
description: Ken Anderson's passing triggered a 24-point Bengal scoring spree in the second quarter. Anderson tossed three touchdown passes - two of them in the second quarter - as the Bengals (6-3) snapped the Oilers' six-game winning streak against Cincinnati. Anderson, who completed 21 of 30 passes for 281 yards, threw touchdown passes of 8 yards to Dan Ross and 18 yards to Cris Collinsworth before the half, then hooked up with Ross on a 14-yarder in the third quarter as Cincinnati built a 34-7 lead over Houston (4-5).

title: MIAMI ENHANCES REPUTATION
description: The University of Miami may have finally reached the status of a major football power, a status that can enhance recruiting, sell tickets and make for continuing success. That was the impression that Miami's coach, Howard Schnellenberger, had after the Hurricanes upset Penn State, 17-14, in the Orange Bowl Saturday, to knock the Nittany Lions out of first place in the national rankings.

title: 27 EXPERTS GIVE PRESCRIPTIONS FOR PRESIDENCY'S ILLS
description: Twenty-seven men, most of them distinguished lawyers and historians, gathered in Manhattan over the weekend to discuss whether constitutional changes might be needed to let a President govern effectively.

title: APPROVAL OF BAR DENIED TO MANY IN JUDICIAL BIDS
description: Nearly 40 percent of the candidates seeking judgeships in the Supreme, Civil or Surrogate Court in tomorrow's citywide elections have not been approved for office by the City Bar Association.

title: MT. SINAI TRUSTEES PLAN A RENOVATION
description: Mount Sinai Medical Center is planning a $425 million renovation of its patient care facilities. The redevelopment of the medical complex, under a design by I. M. Pei, would be one of the most extensive reconstructions of existing medical facilities in this country.

title: BRIEFING
description: S ENATE Republicans who have been trying to diminish the power of the Federal Election Commission, the agency that serves as watchdog over politicians' campaign spending, are pushing for an accommodation this week from Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the majority leader. The Tennessee Republican hopes to move the Postal Service and Treasury appropriations bill before Friday, but 16 Republicans led by Roger W. Jepsen of Iowa have indicated they'll hold up the measure if necessary to block its F.E.C. funding and force the issue.

title: Phoenix Seeking N.F.L. Franchise
description: Gov. Bruce Babbitt says he has met with Pete Rozelle, the National Football League commissioner, to discuss the possibility of obtaining a franchise for Phoenix.

title: John Warburton, 78, Actor On Broadway and in Movies
description: John Warburton, a stage and screen actor, died of cancer at his home in suburban Sherman Oaks on Tuesday. He was 78 years old.

title: Out at Home?
description: While doing research for a book he hopes to publish in 1983, ''The Future of the Olympic Games,'' Dr. John A. Lucas of Pennsylvania State University attended the meetings of the Olympic Congress in Baden-Baden, West Germany, last month. Before and during the meetings, he interviewed 59 of the 84 members of the International Olympic Committee and came home with some alarming news.

title: WASHINGTON'S CHAMPIONS OF THE ARTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Bright Outlook For Furniture
description: THERE'S no mystery on Wall Street about the current state of the nation's housing market. A combination of high mortgage rates, rising home prices and the shriveling availablity of mortgage funds adds up to a situation that one brokerage firm describes as ''grim indeed.''

title: Halloween Wedding Manages to Be Outlandish
description: The wedding dress was white, but that was the only concession to tradition Saturday night when Barbara Kocur and Gary Ostler were married at the bridegroom's home in Waterbury Center, Vt.

title: PROFITS OFF MANY COMPANIES
description: The dollar's international strength, high interest rates and the persistently sluggish American economy combined to depress earnings at many of the nation's companies in the third quarter, a compilation by The New York Times of 286 major corporations shows. Many others, however, fared better than had been expected.

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration has found itself in a new dispute with Israel that raises questions about Washington's ability to encourage both a continuing Saudi Arabian involvement in Middle East diplomacy and an early resolution of the Egyptian-Israeli negotiations on Palestinian self-rule. President Reagan and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. insist that they are solidly behind the ''Camp David process,'' the Administration's term for the talks on Palestinian autonomy and the fulfillment of terms of the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty.

title: Red Smith; Harold Patrick Reiser
description: DURING the World Series, Harold Patrick Reiser died in Palm Springs, Calif. Pete Reiser, called Pistol Pete, was 62 years old and had suffered heart trouble off and on for 25 years. Pete may have been born to be the best baseball player that ever lived but there never was a park big enough to contain his effort. He was a man of immeasurable skills and unconquerable spirit who played the only way he knew how - hitting, running, sliding, crashing into outfield walls, until he had literally broken his magnificent body to bits.

title: Jet Owner Gets Game Ball
description: ''The season's at stake. If you don't win this game, it'll be all loused up.'' That was the advice given to the Jets today, but it did not come in an impassioned locker-room speech by Coach Walt Michaels.

title: Saudis Reduce Oil Production
description: Abdul Hadi Taher, governor of Saudi Arabia's General Petroleum and Mineral Organization, was quoted yesterday as saying Saudi oil output would be cut by 800,000 barrels a day, to 8.5 million, following last week's OPEC conference.

title: SOCIALIST TEST: TAXING RICHES OF THE FRENCH
description: ''The opposition should at least be consistent,'' Budget Minister Laurent Fabius said, looking haggard after spending a hard week in the National Assembly over the Government's proposed wealth tax. ''First they attack us for making it too harsh. When we amend it, they say it is ineffectual.''

title: COWBOYS TRIUMPH OVER EAGLES, 17-14
description: There were 136 plays in the game between the Dallas Cowboys and the Philadelphia Eagles today, but one stood out above all the rest for the 72,111 spectators. It was a field-goal attempt 34 yards in distance, which Tony Franklin, the Eagles' barefooted kicker from Texas, missed with 1 minute 51 seconds left.

title: DISCORD RE-EMERGES AT INTERFAITH WORKSHOP
description: Despite expanding Christian-Jewish dialogues, religious and political disagreements are still complicating relations between the two faiths and occasionally shaking the foundation of good will built up in the past decade.

title: JETS' ROOKIE FINDS WRONG MAN ON LINE
description: It didn't matter at all today that the Jets' Ben Rudolph had practiced all week to face the wrong Giants' offensive lineman. Rudolph, a rookie defensive right tackle, recorded a sack, anyway, among nine the Jets made as their defensive line punished Phil Simms and embarrassed his protectors in a 26-7 victory.

title: Showing Off on Secret Agents
description: Should Congress decree that information in the public domain may not be publicly repeated? The very idea represents a radical departure from the American tradition of free speech and press. Yet Congress is seriously considering a bill to make publishing names of covert intelligence agents, even on the basis of publicly available knowledge, a crime. The House passed such a measure last month and a similar bill, almost as objectionable, awaits a vote by the Senate. The Senate should bring Congress to its senses and reject this proposal.

title: Dolphins 27, Colts 10
description: David Woodley ran for one touchdown and threw for two more as Miami (6-2-1) handed Baltimore its eighth consecutive defeat after a season-opening victory.

title: H.S. Kritzer Weds Dr. Janis Halpern
description: Dr. Janis S. Halpern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Halpern of North Bellmore, L.I., was married yesterday to Howard S. Kritzer, son of Muriel Kritzer of Lynbrook, L.I., and Allan Kritzer of Franklin Square, L.I. Rabbi Harvey L. Goldscheider performed the ceremony at Temple B'nai Sholom in Rockville Centre, L.I. Cantor David B. Hiesiger assisted.

title: GOING NORTH FOR GROUSE
description: WENTWORTH LOCATION, N.H. NORTHWEST of the White Mountains in Groveton, N.H., I stopped for a cup of coffee and was pleased to see an inch of snow on the roofs of two of the cars parked in front of the diner.

title: 470 Fishermen Missing As Hurricane Hits India
description: At least 470 fishermen were missing today in a hurricane that lashed the western Indian coast with tidal waves and 90 miles per hour winds, the United News of India reported.

title: RACE ISSUE ERUPTS IN VIRGINIA GOVERNOR RACE
description: Charges of an appeal to racial prejudice are erupting in the closing days of a rapidly narrowing Virginia gubernatorial campaign.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We had something to prove to us and to the New York fans.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Computer Associates International filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 500,000 shares, at $13 to $15 a share, to be sold through an Alex Brown & Sons group.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Sushi at the Harvard Club
description: In Times Square, the huge signs used to flash Camel (with a puff of smoke), and Planters Peanuts, and Maxwell House. Look at them now: Panasonic, Sony and JVC electronics, Seiko and Casio watches, Midori liqueur, Canon cameras, Fuji film. You have to look around before spotting non-Japanese names like Coca-Cola and Castro Convertibles.

title: Gail Lynne Berry, Designer, Is Bride of Bruce Pollekoff
description: Gail Lynne Berry, a fashion designer, was married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El to Bruce Pollekoff, an accountant with the Convention Center Development, a subsidiary of the New York State Urban Development Corporation. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony.

title: Judyth Bernstein Wed To Reuben Gutoff
description: Judyth Bernstein was married yesterday at the Harmonie Club to Reuben Gutoff. The ceremony was performed by Family Court Justice Shirley Kram.

title: REVIVAL FOR ONE-SHOT ROCKETS
description: Even if the second flight of the space shuttle Columbia this week is as successful as the first, concern over how soon the new spaceships could assume the burden of carrying most satellites into orbit is forcing potential commercial, scientific and military users to make or consider alternate plans.

title: IN SUDAN, 220 MILES CAN LAST FOREVER
description: A visitor was explaining to a Sudanese Army officer the other day how he had come to this place on Sudan's border with Chad whose name, in Arabic, means garden.

title: Traffic Is Reduced to 4 Lanes For Part of Hudson Parkway
description: Beginning today and continuing for the next 32 months, traffic on the Henry Hudson Parkway between 125th Street and 145th Street will be restricted to two lanes in each direction, instead of the normal three lanes, the State Department of Transportation announced yesterday.

title: David Heidecorn Marries Deborah J. Stern in Jersey
description: The marriage of Deborah Joan Stern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney L. Stern of Perth Amboy, N.J., to David Heidecorn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Monroe Heidecorn of Scarsdale, N.Y., took place yesterday. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J.

title: HOOVER, ROOSEVELT AND THE 'MESS' REAGAN HAS TO DEAL WITH
description: To the Editor:

title: Drs. Joanne Wible and Steven Kant Wed
description: Dr. Joanne Wible, a member of the faculty at the University of Michigan Medical School in Ann Arbor, Mich., was married yesterday at the Tappan Hill Restaurant in Tarrytown, N.Y., to Dr. Steven M. Kant, a fellow in child psychiatry at the same institution.

title: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1981
description: National A delay in deficit-cutting tax increases until 1983 and 1984 has been backed by top tax officials in the Administration and in the Senate. But Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and Bob Dole, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, disagreed on how large the increases would have to be. Mr. Regan, who is reluctant to raise taxes, wants major spending cuts to reduce budget deficits. Mr. Dole believes that a large tax increase would have to be part of any effort to achieve a balanced budget by 1984, which is President Reagan's aim. (Page A1, Column 6.) 12 demands by the captors of hostages remaining at the state prison in Graterford, Pa., after 29 others were released over the weekend, were made in talks with a Philadelphia columnist who acted as an intermediary. He described the demands as ''reasonable, not extravagant.'' (A16:1-2.) Eugene Tafoya's lawyers attempted up to the last minute to have his trial on charges of shooting a Libyan student in Colorado last year moved from Fort Collins, Colo., to another place. The trial was scheduled to begin today. One of two Denver attorneys representing Mr. Tafoya, a former Green Beret, said he would renew a motion for change of venue. (B10:1-4.)

title: UNLIKELY TEAM WINS PLAY FOR POWER
description: Nothing is so rare in the White House as a true symbiotic relationship. Yet that is what Craig S. Fuller and Richard G. Darman say they have established in the very nerve center of that palace of rivalries.

title: No Headline
description: Dave Anderson The Seventh Jet Dimension

title: CHARGERS BEAT CHIEFS ON KICK
description: After Rolf Benirschke won a battle with an intestinal disorder that kept him sidelined for most of the 1979 season, he was voted ''Hero of the Year'' last season by the Players Association for his comeback.

title: AGE CATCHING UP WITH RASMUSSEN
description: In a game with more emotional overtones than most, Randy Rasmussen also discovered today that his career as a Jet is being slowly wound down.

title: PILOT SAYS LIBYA OUSTED HIM FOR REFUSING MISSION TO CHAD
description: When John Anthony Stubbs, a British civilian pilot, signed on in London late last year to fly transport planes in the Libyan desert, he expected a comfortable salary of $48,000 a year and hardly any adventure.

title: Mexico Raises Oil Price by $1
description: Mexico has raised the price of its top-quality crude oil by one dollar a barrel, the Minister for Industrial Development, Jose Andres de Oteyza announced today. He said the new prices set last week by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had strenghtened the market for oil exporters.

title: Medieval Manuscript Brings Record $225,000
description: A record American auction price for a medieval manuscript was set Friday when Hans Kraus, a New York rare-book dealer, paid $225,000 for a 15th-century Northern Italian handbook on good health practices entitled ''The Tacuinum Sanitatis.''

title: 23 Drowning Victims Are Sent Back to Haiti
description: Memorial services were held today for the 33 Haitians who drowned off Florida last week, and the bodies of 23 were flown back to the land they died trying to flee.

title: Roger Gilbert, 76, Dies; Oil Industry Executive
description: Roger Gilbert, an oil industry executive, died Saturday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. Mr. Gilbert, who lived in Greenwich, was 76 years old.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: Frances Milliken Wed to Peter Balsam
description: Frances Johnstone Milliken and Dr. Peter Balsam were married yesterday at the Terrace Garden of Butler Hall at Columbia University. Walter Lawton, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society in New York, performed the ceremony.

title: PENNSYLVANIA INMATES GIVE COLUMNIST LIST OF DEMANDS
description: A Philadelphia newspaper columnist, acting as an intermediary, brought new hope into the standoff at the state prison here tonight, but after 45 minutes of face-to-face talks with prisoners holding six prison employees captive, he said:

title: SMITH ANGERED BY PORTRAYALS
description: Although this may be the year that Billy Smith of the Islanders gains acclaim as the best goaltender in the National Hockey League, it may also be the year he is recognized as the most controversial.

title: STUDY BY CITY FAULTS AGENCIES ON FOSTER CARE
description: Many foster-care agencies under contract to New York City are keeping children in institutions and with foster families for years after they are supposed to be returned to their parents, according to a review by the city.

title: EX-JUSTICE AIDE, 79
description: George Cochran Doub, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's civil division during President Eisenhower's second term, died Friday at his home in Owings Mills, Md. He was 79 years old.

title: Clash Reported in Lebanon
description: Lebanese leftists fired rockets and automatic weapons at Dutch and Irish soldiers in the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon today, a spokesman for the world body said. No casualties were reported.

title: A SLAYING CASE AND A POLYGRAPH TEST
description: Three days after Renee Walker was stabbed to death, her body was found in her modest apartment in the Inwood section of upper Manhattan.

title: PRESIDENT IS APPOINTED AT FIELDCREST
description: Francis X. Larkin, 54, has been named president and chief operating officer of Fieldcrest Mills Inc., a manufacturer of home furnishings textiles based in Eden, N.C. He succeeds as president Willim C. Battle, 61, who retains the position of chief executive officer. Albert B. Hunt, the 71-year-old chairman and chairman of the Amoskeag Company, which owns 40 percent of Fieldcrest, continues in those posts.

title: OPERA: 'ANOUSH,' CLASSIC OF ARMENIA, IN DETROIT
description: If David DiChiera and his Michigan Opera Theater are any guide, opera companies have found a new source for novelties. As a rule, companies seek fresh repertory from the past because audiences have rejected the present. But now Mr. DiChiera, who actually has a pretty good record when it comes to conservative contemporary operas, has hit upon the idea of introducing the favorite national operas of countries outside the operatic mainstream. This provides a potentially fertile new supply of repertory. And, as the entire page of the ''Special Support Fund'' listed in last night's program indicated - a page consisting almost exclusively of names ending in ''ian'' - local ethnic communities can form a new source of financial support.

title: THE CORPORATE LAWYER AT HYATT CLARK'S HELM
description: When the recently established Hyatt Clark Industries last Friday acquired the Hyatt bearing plant in Clark, N.J., that General Motors did not want, Alan V. Lowenstein was not particularly moved.

title: THE THEATER: 'JOE EGG' REVIVED AT LONG WHARF
description: NEW HAVEN IN recent seasons, there's been no shortage of plays about the chronically disabled and the terminally ill. But not one of them has equaled ''A Day in the Death of Joe Egg,'' the comedy that introduced us to the British playwright Peter Nichols in the late 1960's. Unlike many of his peers, this writer brings fierce wit and theatrical iconoclasm, as well as sorrow and guilt, to his subject. ''Joe Egg,'' the story of two parents whose daughter is a brain-damaged ''vegetable,'' doesn't settle for sending us home with easy sermons on human dignity. Mr. Nichols makes the audience truly uncomfortable - he implicates us in the pain of his characters.

title: Goodyear Layoffs
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said it would lay off 102 production workers by Friday, bringing to 270 the number idled by the company here. The plant normally employs about 1,500. Goodyear officials attributed the layoffs to continuing slumps in the automobile and agricultural implement industries and to Goodyear's market for industrial belts.

title: Military Analysis
description: The overall defense strategy of the Administration is expected in time to force the Soviet Union to re-examine and perhaps revise its strategic and conventional military policy.

title: Louis Metcalf, 76, Trumpeter With the Ellington Orchestra
description: Louis Metcalf, a jazz trumpet player who was a member of the Duke Ellington Orchestra that opened the Cotton Club in Harlem in 1927, died Tuesday at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica, Queens. He was 76 years old and lived in Queens.

title: SOVIET SUB SPENDS SIXTH DAY GROUNDED ON SWEDISH COAST
description: A Soviet submarine spent a sixth day today stranded off the coast of southern Sweden without any sign of a break in what has become a diplomatic standoff between Moscow and Stockholm.

title: ALBANIAN CAUTIONS YUGOSLAVIA
description: Enver Hoxha, the Albanian Communist leader, was reported today to have warned that unrest among the ethnic majority in Yugoslavia's Kosovo Province will spread if Yugoslav authorities ''keep a valiant people like the Albanians under the threat of tanks and bayonets.''

title: May in November
description: When Scott May entered the National Basketball Association with the Chicago Bulls in 1976, he had ''can't-miss'' credentials in abundance. He had helped Indiana to the national title earlier that year with a 23.5 scoring average, was voted the College Player of the Year and was the second player selected in the pro draft.

title: MEHTA GETS LIFE POST IN ISRAEL
description: The Israel Philharmonic Orchestra has named the conductor Zubin Mehta its musical director for life, saying the act was a response to his critics, who have condemned him for attempting to conduct Wagner's music in Israel.

title: ST. JOHN KICK BRINGS VICTORY
description: A 32-yard field goal by John Kennedy with 2 minutes 2 seconds left gave St. John the Baptist of West Islip a 10-9 victory over Holy Cross yesterday on the loser's field in Flushing, Queens. The triumph created a three-way tie for first place in the Long Island Division of the Catholic High Schools Football League. St. John, Holy Cross and Chaminade of Mineola all are 4-1.

title: It's Horse Show Time
description: Early today, 10 hours after the ice used for last night's hockey game was melted and plowed away, a convoy of dump trucks was to start rolling into Madison Square Garden to drop the 500 tons of dirt needed for the National Horse Show.

title: MET OPERA: FIRST 'TOSCA'
description: GRAND flourishes are needed to give the stabbing, shooting, suicide, desire, deceit, oppression, torture and sacraments of ''Tosca'' any sort of dramatic power. In the first performance this season at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday night, several of the principals had a certain restrained flair for such matters, but it was not sufficient.

title: Competition Narrows For Hallmark Cards
description: The competition for the $12 million-to-$15 million Hallmark Cards account has now been narrowed to Foote, Cone & Belding of Chicago, the incumbent; the Leo Burnett Company, also of Chicago, and Young & Rubicam and Ogilvy & Mather, both of New York.

title: MUBARAK TRYING TO PENETRATE EGYPTIAN RED TAPE
description: President Hosni Mubarak clearly intends to imprint his own management style on the Egyptian bureaucracy, which, if it takes hold, will mark a distinct departure from the Sadat era.

title: JETS STAGGER GIANTS, 26 TO 7, SACKING SIMMS 9 TIMES
description: It was a blowout. The Jets routed the Giants, 26-7, today by putting constant pressure on the Giants' passing game, and the Giants compounded their problems with holding penalties, dropped passes, nine sacks by the Jets and big plays that did not quite make it.

title: POLICE SEEK MOTIVE IN DEATHS OF STUDENT AND A PHOTOGRAPHER
description: Detectives were still uncertain early this morning as to the motive behind the slayings of a Smith College student and a photographer in the photographer's apartment in the Chelsea section of Manhattan on Saturday.

title: SOLIDARITY CHAPTERS IN POLAND TO CONTINUE STRIKES
description: Local officials of Poland's independent union movement said today that they were going ahead with plans for new strikes this week despite efforts by the national Solidarity leadership and the Government to end them.

title: STATES, PRESSED BY INFLATION AND CUTS, TRY TO HOLD LINE ON WELFARE
description: BENEFITS By ADAM CLYMER

title: CONCOCTING A STATE DINNER GUEST LIST
description: Late tomorrow afternoon, hours before the limousines begin arriving at the North Portico, the White House will release a list of 96 guests who will attend the state dinner in honor of King Hussein and Queen Noor of Jordan.

title: BAMBERGER IS SURE OF HIMSELF, METS
description: before the season even started.

title: Car Kills 3 Pedestrians; Driver, a Minister, Held
description: Three pedestrians were were killed and a motorist was injured in Harlem yesterday afternoon when a car ran through a red light and into a group of people crossing a street, the police said. The driver of the car, a minister on his way home from church, was charged with manslaughter.

title: Avis Flower Settlement Awarded Doyle Dane
description: Last week in Federal court here, Doyle Dane Bernbach was awarded $126,730 for services rendered from Avis Flowers, an account it had resigned at the request of a more famous client, Avis Rent-A-Car.

title: Diplomats Discuss Arms At 'Grass-Roots' Session
description: At a ''grass-roots'' peace meeting organized by two Episcopal priests, two Soviet diplomats sat down today with 250 clergymen and a State Department official for a quiet conversation about the threat of nuclear war.

title: THE NEW SEPARATES IN FASHION
description: Kasper called it the contradictions that attract. He was referring to the fashion trend, especially pronounced in sportswear, that plays off colors and patterns and the shapes of clothes themselves against one another. The resulting tension is stimulating not only to the designer but also to the wearer, he explained to the audience attending the opening of his J.L. Sport collection last week.

title: NASSAU EXECUTIVE RACE SEEMS RELATIVELY QUIET
description: The well-financed campaign drive of Francis T. Purcell, the 63-year-old Republican who is seeking a second term as Nassau County Executive, has been low key - just enough to keep his name in the minds of voters - and separate from the stamp of Joseph Margiotta.

title: Still Cutting School Lunch Corners
description: In a perfect world, aid would go directly to those who needed it, and only to them. In the real world, there is waste, inefficiency and dishonesty. Not everyone who needs help gets it, nor does everyone who gets it need it. There is easy consolation for such imperfection, however: if the benefits far outweigh the flaws, one learns to live with the fallibility of human institutions.

title: OH WOULD SOME POWER
description: When Soviet spokesmen say United States policy is militaristic or threatening, most Americans dismiss the comments as propaganda. We know that we do not want war with the Soviet Union. We see the threat to peace in its arms buildup, its invasion of Afghanistan, its proxy forces in the third world.

title: OPERA: 5 ARE NEW IN 'BOHEME'
description: WHOLESALE cast changes did little Saturday afternoon to dilute the effectiveness of the City Opera's ''La Boheme'' in its fifth performance this season at the New York State Theater. In fact, the principals, five of whom were singing their roles for the first time with the company, got along as if they had been doing the show together for weeks. Additionally, the efforts of several of the new arrivals were first-rate.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 2, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: PROPAGANDA VS. SKILL
description: Surprisingly, the U.S. Mission in Havana has spoken up in opposition to the plan for a special U.S. radio service to Cuba.

title: HOUSTON ACCEPTS NEW POLITICAL FORCE
description: Frank Mann was one of the first politicians, but far from the last, to discover that the Gay Political Caucus has very quickly become a major political force in this city, whose image is so often associated with the Wild West.

title: No Headline
description: VAN PATTEN TAKES FINAL

title: WHAT THE VOTE ON PRISON BONDS WILL DETERMINE
description: To the Editor:

title: IMPROVING THE SELF-IMAGE OF OLDER WOMEN
description: Women over the age of 40 were urged over the weekend to become less invisible and more political, as a means of restoring their selfesteem in a society that often regards them as over the hill.

title: People
description: Spencer Plavoukos, an executive vice president, has been elected to the board of SSC&B.

title: Devine Considered For Booster Post
description: Dan Devine, the former Notre Dame football coach, could be returning to a college campus next year, but not in a coaching capacity.

title: Washington Watch; Aid Weighed On Thrift Units
description: WASHINGTON CONGRESS will probably do something soon for the mutual savings banks of New York and other distressed thrift institutions. The regulators' bill that cleared the House of Representatives last week and has been taken up by the Senate along with the broader issues of enlarging the earnings base of thrifts and commercial banks has fires under it now that the troubles of the Greenwich Savings Bank have become public.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Brezhnev Sees U.S. Plot To Wreck Arms Talks

title: LOW YIELD LEVELS BEING QUESTIONED
description: Interest rates declined precipitiously late last week, but by the time the smoke cleared, many analysts were uncertain if the lower yields could be sustained this week when the Treasury sells $8.75 billion of notes and bonds.

title: A LOOK AT RECORD FOR CONNECTICUT'S U.S. ATTORNEY
description: In his first major trial as the chief Government prosecutor in Connecticut, Richard Blumenthal was in essence placed in evidence as Exhibit A for the defense. His opposing lawyer in the case assailed him as a ''politically ambitious United States Attorney'' and suggested the case had been brought to the state purely for reasons of publicity.

title: Queen to Conquer Wins on Coast
description: Queen to Conquer made a late rush to win the $300,000 Yellow Ribbon Stakes for fillies and mares on the turf at Santa Anita today. Ridden by Marco Castaneda and carrying 123 pounds, Queen to Conquer covered the mile-and-a-quarter distance in a stakes record 1:58 3/5. The previous best was 1:59 1/5.

title: CONFLICT OVER POST IN O.E.C.D.
description: A diplomatic row is brewing between Western Europe and the Reagan Administration over who will be the next Secretary General of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development when Emile Van Lennep retires from the post next March.

title: REAGAN'S HUMAN NATURE
description: President Reagan has a tendency to talk to us about human nature.

title: Newmont Stake
description: Consolidated Gold Fields Ltd., which is based in London, said it had raised its stake in the Newmont Mining Corporation to 16.5 percent and now held 4.3 million common shares, including 415,100 shares purchased for $19.1 million between Oct. 23 and Oct. 28.

title: Rule in the West Bank Transferred to Civilian
description: A university professor today took over responsibility for the civil administration of the Israeli-occupied West Bank. Local Arabs demonstrated against the change and denounced it as a step toward imposing Palestinian autonomy in the area.

title: Curtailment Of Mortgages
description: In order to aid the savings and loan industry, Congress should curtail the ability of homeowners to pass on their low-interest mortgages to new owners, the chief Federal regulator of the thrift institutions has said.

title: Britons Take to Shelters In Vast Air-Raid Drill
description: Eight-thousand Britons went underground today, swarming into 872 fallout shelters in a nine-hour nationwide civil defense drill.

title: PRIVATE HEALTH CARE MAKING NEW INROADS IN BRITAIN
description: The elegant Harley Street Clinic, on Weymouth Street, is privately owned. So are the Wellington Private Hospital near Regents Park and, over in Chelsea, the Charter Clinic and the Cromwell Hospital.

title: FAMILY THERAPY IS COMING OF AGE
description: For all the dire alarums about the state of the American family, the gathering here of 1,300 family therapists was a genial and festive occasion. ''The American family isn't going to hell in a hand basket,'' said Dr. William C. Nichols, president of the American Association for Marriage and Family Therapy. ''It's adapting and ever-changing, and we're trying to keep up with it.''

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: During a recent round of golf, my drive split the fairway, but a seagull picked up the ball and flew away with it. I dropped another ball at the spot of the theft, instead of driving a second ball from the tee. I did not take a penalty stroke, because my contention is that a seagull is an outside agency. Am I correct?

title: WEEKS, AS GOALIE, HELPS RANGERS WIN
description: It was not a thing of beauty, the Rangers' 4-2 victory over the Calgary Flames last night at Madison Square Garden. But it was a reasonably well-crafted work, unbotched by the unskilled labor that had given the team a 3-8 record before the Flames came to town with a 2-7-2 record.

title: Alexander's Option
description: Alexander's Inc. said in its annual report that it had an option agreement to acquire the leasehold interest on property adjacent to its Manhattan store at 59th Street and Lexington Avenue.

title: OIL DEALERS SAY TRUCKED-IN FUEL VIOLATES A LAW
description: An association of New York heating oil dealers charged yesterday that heavy oil whose burning violated air-pollution standards was being trucked into New York City from southern New Jersey for delivery to apartment houses for use as fuel. The group said the oil was being sold at 20 to 25 percent below regular prices.

title: TO HINDER DISSEMINATION OF RESEARCH DATA
description: To the Editor:

title: G.N.C. EXPANDING AT A ROBUST PACE BY MOVING TO MALLS
description: Nearly 50 years ago, David B. Shakarian, then a young man with an idea, opened a health food store named Lackzoom in downtown Pittsburgh. The first day, sales reached $35 - an astounding figure for those Depression times.

title: SHUTTLE'S LAUNCHING PREPARATIONS PROCEEDING BETTER THAN EXPECTED
description: The wind blew in gusts, clouds came and went with brief downpours, but through it all, sometime with a rainbow gracing the seaside launching pad, technicans ministered to the space shuttle Columbia today and kept ahead of schedule in preparations for the winged spaceship's return to orbit.

title: ADVERTISING
description: The word from Los Angeles is that after a relationship with Young & Rubicam of over 30 years, Armour Foods, part of the Greyhound Corporation, is looking for a new agency.

title: WORLD WAR II INTERNMENT IS DEFENDED
description: A former Army official said today that the World War II internment of 120,000 Japanese-Americans was necessary because of the ''very real and present danger'' of a Japanese invasion of the West Coast.

title: Physician Is Slain In Holdup Attempt
description: A young physician died shortly after being shot twice during a robbery attempt as he left the grounds of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in upper Manhattan last night, the police said.

title: U.S. AIDE DEFENDS SALE OF F-16'S TO PAKISTAN
description: The Reagan Administration said yesterday that it would be able to overcome any Congressional attempts to block the sale of 40 Americanbuilt F-16 fighter planes to Pakistan.

title: U.S. Planning Move on Steel
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today that the Government expected to file an antidumping complaint in the next six weeks against European and possibly other steelmakers, charging them with exporting steel to the United States at unfairly low prices.

title: Pills to Be Distributed In Nuclear Plant Area
description: Tennessee plans to distribute pills to about 7,000 families living near the Sequoyah nuclear plant to protect them in case of a release of radioactive iodine in a nuclear accident.

title: Clyde Petroleum Sets 2 Purchases
description: Clyde Petroleum Ltd. said it had agreed to acquire the City Exploration Company and City Petroleum Company, both active in North Sea exploration and production, from the City Investing Company for $45 million in cash. Clyde said it financed the acquisition with a syndicated bank loan.

title: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LONGER-TERM RATES DECLINING
description: The steep decline in short-term interest rates appeared to be spreading yesterday to the intermediate and long-term bond markets, despite a heavy supply of new note and bond issues.

title: Rams' Controversy
description: It dates from Bob Waterfield and Norm Van Brocklin more than 30 years ago. Now, once again, the Los Angeles Rams have a quarterback controversy, and it is worthy of Roman Gabriel-Billy Munson or John Hadl-James Harris or Pat Haden-Joe Namath-Vince Ferragamo.

title: CAREY SAYS HE EXPECTS NO TAX INCREASES FOR '82
description: Governor Carey said today that he probably would not recommend to the State Legislature in January an increase in taxes in the 1982-83 budget.

title: Court Stays Execution Of Convicted Murderer
description: A Federal appeals court today stayed the execution set for this week of a convicted murderer, Colin Clark, and ordered more hearings to determine whether he was sane because he has said he wanted to be executed even though he maintained he was not guilty.

title: SENATE REAFFIRMS ITS OPPOSITION TO TAXING SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS
description: The Senate reaffirmed unanimously today its opposition to any taxation of Social Security benefits after the Democratic leadership charged that Republican members of the Budget Committee were contemplating such a move.

title: BAYSWATER REALTY & CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to July 31
description: B-Including $3,750,199 or $3.60 a shr nonrecurring net gain on the sale of real estate equity and investments

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In the quarterly profits table in Busi- ness Day yesterday, the name and sales figures for Kidde Inc. were incor- rect. The company had sales of $740,- 048,000 in the quarter ended Sept. 30, 1981, up 14 percent from the previous year.

title: Accounts
description: * Avalon Industries, a toy company, to Dick Levy & Associates.

title: A Prince of a Godfather at a Christening
description: It was just a simple christening ceremony in the south of England, but thousands of well-wishers lined the roads on Sunday when Nicholas Louis Charles Norton Knatchbull was taken from his home to nearby Romsey Abbey.

title: TURNER CONSTRUCTION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $1,312,000 extraordinary gain

title: U.S. STARTS DEPLOYING TROOPS FOR MANEUVERS IN FOUR MIDEAST NATIONS
description: The United States has begun to deploy 5,000 soldiers in a Rapid Deployment Force exercise covering Egypt, the Sudan, Somalia and Oman, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Upjohn Drug Gets F.D.A. Approval
description: The Upjohn Company announced that its new anti-anxiety drug, Xanax, had been approved by the Federal Drug Administration.

title: EDUCATION
description: year-old student at Evander Childs High School in the Bronx, is in her fifth year of high school and is determined to get a diploma no matter how long it takes. She is one of many students around the country who do not finish high school in the customary four years, taking an extra semester or an additional year or longer to graduate. Often, such young people are 19 or 20 years old before they get their diplomas.

title: GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PURITAN-BENNETT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HALLIBURTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ROLE OF AMERICANS IN LIBYAN WARFARE CONFIRMED BY U.S.
description: The United States today confirmed that Americans had been involved in military support activities in Libya and called the involvement ''reprehensible.''

title: Officer Is Exonerated In a Shooting in IND
description: A Manhattan grand jury cleared a Transit Authority police officer yesterday of charges that he had needlessly shot a man in a scuffle in a train station.

title: ROYAL BUSINESS FORMS (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gold Output Falls
description: South African gold production in September fell to 1.77 million ounces from 1.8 million ounces in August and 1.8 million ounces in September 1980, the Chamber of Mines reported today. Gold output in the first nine months of this year totaled 15.89 million ounces, down from 16.38 million ounces in the similar period of last year.

title: DOWNEY SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
News Summary; TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1981
description: International The U.S. stressed the Camp David approach to a Middle East peace. President Reagan also told King Hussein of Jordan that it was imperative to cooperate in seeking an overall settlement in the region. But there was no indication of any change in Jordan's refusal to take part in negotiations arising from the Egyptian-Israeli accords, and later the monarch publicly endorsed Saudi Arabia's plan for regional peace. (Page A1, Column 6.) Creation of a P.L.O.-governed state is essential to the Middle East peace plan proposed by Saudi Arabia, according to Crown Prince Fahd. In expressing support for the Palestine Liberation Organization, the Saudi leader asserted that the Camp David accords were ''a dead end.'' (A8:1.)

title: REAGAN, RECEIVING HUSSEIN, ENDORSES CAMP DAVID PACT
description: President Reagan told King Hussein of Jordan today that the United States stood by the Camp David approach to a Middle East peace and that it was imperative to cooperate in seeking a settlement.

title: Canada's Charter Talks Make Little Progress
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and the Premiers of Canada's 10 provinces tried today in private to resolve their differences on a new constitution after publicly setting out what seemed to be irreconcilable positions.

title: EDO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been restated for a 10 percent stock divd paid June 30, 1981

title: CONCERT: YOUTHFUL CHARM OF EARLY AMERICAN SONGS
description: FOR 200 years Americans have had a reputation for being energetic innocent folk, unburdened by the freight and weight of European history; the youthful culture has made up for its thinness with cocky charm and ambition. That was the musical impression as well, on Sunday afternoon, listening to early American songs at Corpus Christi Church.

title: ASHLEY JOINING LINCOLN CENTER BOARD
description: Ted Ashley, former talent agent and television and motion-picture executive, has been elected a director of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, it was announced by Martin E. Segal, the center's chairman.

title: ND RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PRIME LOWERED TO 17 1/2%
description: Most of the nation's major banks lowered their prime lending rates yesterday by one-half of 1 percentage point, to 17 1/2 percent, and some economists said that the prime was likely to continue to fall in the next few months.

title: Fire in a Camden Warehouse Sparks Propane Explosions
description: A three-alarm fire in a warehouse raged out of control for more than an hour today, sparking several small explosions in propane tanks.

title: Record Is Set by Binns In IC4A Cross-Country
description: Stephen Binns, a freshman from Providence College, captured the IC4A championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday with a meet-record time of 23 minutes 52.5 seconds for the five-mile cross-country race.

title: CITY CANDIDATES HIT THE SIDEWALK ON ELECTION EVE
description: The election campaign wound down yesterday with Mayor Koch and other municipal candidates engaging in traditional day-beforeelection debates and sidewalk appeals.

title: EX-CHIEF IN KEARNY GUILTY OF BRIBERY
description: The suspended police chief of Kearny and two former police officers were convicted yesterday of accepting $1,300 in bribes to protect a numbers operation in Kearny.

title: Seton Hall Coach Quits
description: Bill Raftery, the basketball coach at Seton Hall the last 10 seasons, will announce his resignation tomorrow, a school official said tonight.

title: JAPAN'S BARRIER ON ALUMINUM
description: Japan, which has been strongly criticized for its growing exports and big trade surplus with Europe and the United States, would presumably be the last to use barriers against imports from abroad.

title: CALLON PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including $630,000 income from the cumulative effect of an accounting adjustment

title: VALLEY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EUROPE'S JUSTIFIED NUCLEAR FEARS
description: To the Editor:

title: Seattle Paper Hearings
description: A public hearing on merging the business and production facilities of Seattle's two daily newspapers, The Post-Intelligencer and The Seattle Times, opened today.

title: North and South Korea Fight 23-Minute Battle
description: North and South Korean forces fought a 23-minute machine-gun battle in the sixth border clash this year, the Defense Ministry said today.

title: Creative Media Plans Newspaper Ad Service
description: In a speech to the New England Newspaper Association in Providence, R.I., Thursday, Douglas K. Burch, president of Creative Media Services, Wilton, Conn., will announce a new service, the Newsprint Network.

title: 200 Flee Leaking Chemical
description: A forklift punctured a drum containing thionyl chloride, a toxic chemical, during a loading operation at the Maislin Transport terminal early today, forcing the evacuation of nearly 200 people for three hours.

title: Venezuelan Oil Output
description: Venezuelan oil production for the 10 months through Oct. 28 averaged 2.075 million barrels a day, down slightly from an output of 2.168 million barrels a day in the same period of 1980, the Energy and Mines Ministry said today.

title: RULING PARTY IN TUNISIA APPERARS TO BE HEADED FOR ELECTORAL SWEEP
description: President Habib Bourguiba was told by aides here today that his ruling party and its ally, a trade union, had swept nearly every constituency in yesterday's elections for the National Assembly.

title: A WHITE HOUSE DINNER FOR JORDAN'S KING AND QUEEN
description: A glittering state dinner was held this evening at the White House in honor of the visiting King Hussein and Queen Noor of Jordan.

title: SALEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: 1981 results include foreign tax relief credits of $532,000 or 32 cents a shr and foreign statement translation loss of $166,000 or 10 cents a shr and $545,000 or 34 cents a shr respectively...B-Net income

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 3, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: TV: 'FATHER MURPHY,' A WESTERN SERIES
description: ''FATHER MURPHY,'' a weekly series that will be shown Tuesdays at 8 on NBC-TV, has a special two-hour premiere tonight. Any resemblance between its calculated wholesomeness and the family-entertainment terrain of ''Little House on the Prarie'' is purely intentional. ''Father Murphy'' has been created by Michael Landon, who is also executive producer of the series and the writer of this evening's debut. Mr. Landon is, of course, the idealized father in ''Little House,'' in addition to being a fixture on commercials selling photographic equipment.

title: AUGAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GAME 12 OF CHESS MATCH ADJOURNED
description: Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland struggled into adjournment tonight down a pawn against Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, the world chess champion, in the 12th game of their title match. Bishops of opposite color give the challenger a strong chance to attain a draw when play is resumed tomorrow at 5 P.M. here in the Kurzentrum playing hall.

title: JEFFERSON-PILOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONROY INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
Kaiser to Close Aluminum Potline
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it would shut a third aluminum-producing potline at its Ravenswood, W.Va., works and would restructure operations in the fabrication plant, idling some 950 employees.

title: Young Astronomer Gets Halloween Night Treat
description: While other 13-year-olds were having Halloween fun Saturday night, Anthony M. Sarkis Jr., an amateur astronomer, was adjusting his telescope in his front yard in North Adams, Mass.

title: TINSLEY LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MIAMI MAY PICK MOSTLY LATIN COUNCIL
description: For the first time, Latins make up the largest group in the Miami electorate, and tomorrow, when the municipal primary is held, the city may get its first governing body composed mostly of Hispanic members.

title: Index; International
description: Polish workers heed Walesa's appeal to end strike A3 U.S. aide defends sale of 40 F-16's to Pakistan A3 New Iranian Premier announces Cabinet A4 Around the World A5 Pentagon denies report of U.S.- Saudi accord A7 Washington Talk Briefing B10 Representative Whitten to make 40 years on the Hill B10 The Clean Air Act is increasingly entangled in politics B10 The political rumor is an art form in the nation's capital B10 ELECTION DAY Today is Election Day. It is a state holiday in New York and New Jersey. It is not a holiday in Connecticut. Parking - Alternate-side regulations suspended in New York City; all other rules in effect. Sanitation - No collection, no street cleaning in New York City. State and municipal offices - Closed in New York and New Jersey, open in Connecticut. State courts - Closed in New York, New Jersey, open in Connecticut. Federal offices - Open. Postal service - Regular schedule. Banks - Federal Reserve and most banks in New York and New Jersey, closed. Connecticut banks, open. Stock and commodity markets -Open. Transportation - Normal schedules for subways, buses and trains. Libraries - Closed in New York City. Many closed in New Jersey. Open in Connecticut. Public schools - Closed in New York City. Many closed in New Jersey and Connectiuct.

title: DIGITAL PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $41,047 for the qr and $36,494 for the 6 mos; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations; yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for 100 percent stock divd paid in Jan 1981 and June 1981

title: FEDERAL BUDGET CUTS IMPERIL CHANCES OF MANY POOR FOR COLLEGE EDUCATION
description: Uncertainty abounds these days at community colleges and hundreds of other institutions where the vast majority of students come from families that earn less than $12,000 a year and rely almost entirely on Federal assistance for tuition and living expenses.

title: 2 Japanese Climb Annapurna
description: Two Japanese men became the first climbers to scale the south face of Annapurna I in the Himalaya mountains and reach its 26,700-foot peak, the Nepalese Ministry of Tourism announced today. A spokesman said the two reached the summit Thursday without using oxygen. They were identified as Yukigiro Yanagisawa, 26 years old, and Hiroshi Aota, 23.

title: DISPUTE IN WESTCHESTER ON DEAF CHILD ACCEPTED
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether public school systems may be required, under the terms of a 1975 Federal law, to provide sign-languate interpreters to assist deaf children in the classroom.

title: MAUI LAND & PINEAPPLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes tax credits of $708,000 for the qr and a $2,157,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net income

title: 2d CONCERN SEEKS STAKE IN JARTRAN
description: Frank B. Hall & Company, a large insurance brokerage firm, said that it had been informed that another party is interested in acquiring a stake in Jartran Inc., a Miami-based truck leasing concern, which Hall agreed to acquire last month for about $20 million in cash and securities.

title: ADAGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: Shr earnings have been restated for a 3-for-2 stock split in Feb 1981

title: GENERAL BINDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1981 qr and 9 mos results include a loss of 5 cents a shr for a special provision on the phase-out of the floor model folder business recorded in the third qr and a gain of 4 cents a shr on the sale of land recorded in the second qr; the 1980 9 mos includes a gain of 19 cents a shr on sale of the company's Pho-tronics subsidiary and the provision of 15 cents a shr from losses anticipated in the disposition of certain foreign assets; all 1980 results are restated to reflec tax benefits

title: NESTLE-LE MUR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Footnote Is Added to Gershwin Memorabilia
description: The company's Bureau of Inspection and Revision found that the 22-year-old applicant came from a ''modestly and neatly furnished home'' at 520 West 144th Street, that its ''environmental and sanitary conditions,'' were good, that the applicant and his family enjoyed good health, that the applicant's father had been doing well as the treasurer of a restaurant, and that the applicant was of good character and made ''around $40 a week easily.''

title: STATES LAG ON REDISTRICTING FOR CONGRESS
description: Congressional redistricting is coming like a chill fall wind to the politically most explosive states in the nation, those that will lose Congressional districts because the 1980 census found that they had lost population or recorded only small gains.

title: Saskatchewan Bond
description: The province of Saskatchewan is raising $100 million (United States) through a seven-year Eurobond, the lead manager, Credit Suisse/First Boston Ltd., said here today. The issue, which has flexible terms, has a 16.25 percent coupon with pricing to be fixed on Thursday. The bond is callable in 1987 at par.

title: SAUDI CALLS P.L.O. VITAL TO HIS PLAN
description: Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia said today that the establishment of a state governed by the Palestine Liberation Organization was essential to the success of his Middle East peace plan.

title: New Technique Aids Treatment Of Eye Ailments
description: Scientists at the Los Alamos National Laboratory say they have developed a more precise technique to interpret measurements of the human cornea to help doctors treat eye problems and disease.

title: Agent Admits To Selling Data
description: TRENTON (AP) - A state tax investigator pleaded guilty to selling confidential information to the natural parents of an adopted child.

title: An Owner's Promise
description: The Baltimore Colts have lost a team-record eight straight games and, at 1-8, have the worst record in the National Football League. But Coach Mike McCormack, who has a season and a half remaining on his three-year contract, received a vote of confidence from the club's owner, Robert Irsay. ''Mike McCormack will be my coach next week, next year,'' said Irsay, who delivered the message personally to the coach a half-hour after the Colts' 27-10 loss to the Dolphins Sunday.

title: Brezhnev to Extend His Visit To West Germany by 2 Days
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, will extend his visit to Bonn later this month to allow him more time to rest and to keep the timetable flexible, a West German Government spokesman, Kurt Becker, said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept
NEW IRAN PREMIER NAMES CABINET AND GAINS PARLIAMENT'S APPROVAL
description: Iran's new Prime Minister presented a 21-member Cabinet to Parliament today and received its approval soon afterward, the state radio reported.

title: JOURNALIST AND MEDIATOR
description: He has been a Congressional aide, a political strategist, a radio and television commentator, a teacher, the author of three books, a leader of black organizations and a newspaper reporter, editor and columnist.

title: COME BACK, RICHARD
description: The Republican Party is dying in New York City and nobody seems to care.

title: New Nation Seeks U.N. Seat
description: Antigua and Barbuda, which gained its independence from Britain yesterday, applied for membership in the United Nations today. It would become the 157th member.

title: Ovaltine Spot Builds On Chocolate Craving
description: Ovaltine Products Inc. U.S.A., a subsidiary of the Swiss Sandoz organization, has a penchant for agencies with highly creative reputations. That slot is currently filled by Smith/ Greenland, where the pride of the moment is the stop-action photography triumph of a TV commercial that it created for Ovaltine, the enriched, chocolate-flavored milk additive.

title: VAN DUSEN AIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results restated to reflect Aug 31, 1981 acqusition of G & N Aircraft Inc

title: WASHINGTON PUBLISHING: FLURRY OF POLICY PAPERS
description: A few hundred fellows and scholars at major public policy research organizations here have made Washington a publishing town.

title: Siberian Oil Increase
description: Oil production in western Siberia, the main Soviet producing area, will increase about 15 percent by 1985, a high-ranking official predicted today.

title: Bridge: New York Event Winners Have International Flavor
description: One winning partnership in the Swiss team championship at the Metropolitan championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association on Sunday included a player from London and a player from Sydney, Australia. This will stand as a record for far-flung partnerships until Buenos Aires and Hong Kong or Cape Town and Honolulu score a victory.

title: PLANT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $2,916,000 gain for both periods on the sale of the company's Canadian operations and $1,090,000 tax credit for both periods...C-Includes $1,807,000 pretax non- recurring gain for the qr and $141,000 pretax nonrecurring charge for the 9 mos and $350,000 gain from discontinued operations for the qr and $455,000 loss from discontinued operations for the 9 mos...D-Net loss

title: Ozawa and Von Karajan On Gala Tours of Japan
description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra and the Berlin Philharmonic are celebrating their 100th anniversaries here in friendly musical rivalry.

title: Tombstone Pizza To Campbell-Mithun
description: Campbell-Mithun, the Minneapolis-based subsidiary of Ted Bates & Company, is the new agency for the Tombstone Pizza Company of Medford, Wis.

title: Islanders Call Up Wing
description: The Islanders called up Neil Hawryliw, a left wing, from their Indianapolis farm team of the Central League today. Hawryliw, 26 years old, had five goals and six assists in 11 games with the Checkers.

title: WITNESS TELLS OF BRIBE
description: Jim Sweeney, a co-captain of the Boston College basketball team of 1978-79, testified for the Government yesterday that he had once accepted $500 from Rick Kuhn, a teammate, as a payoff for helping to shave points in games that season.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on the Style page Saturday about new devices for the disabled gave misleading information on prices. The Arroya sled for paraplegics costs $980. A bicyclelike vehicle propelled by arms is not yet on the market.

title: Penn Central Vote Result Is Delayed
description: The outcome of a vote by shareholders on the Penn Central Corporation's $1.4 billion bid to acquire Colt Industries will not be announced until tomorrow at the earliest, the chairman of Penn Central said.

title: STAGE: A VIEW OF JACK LONDON, RADICAL
description: JACK LONDON once described his adolescence, his life as a seaman, buccaneer and hobo, as a time when he was ''raw and naked, wild and free.'' When he transformed himself into a writer, it was the untamed side of his nature that won his widest audience, but beyond his popular fiction - ''The Call of the Wild'' and ''The Sea Wolf'' - he was a committed radical and socialist.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: PORNOGRAPHERS and the anti-sin lobby have succeeded in making sex the only dirty three-letter word. This may explain why sex education is persistently under fire as something like the devil's manual for the subversion of America's youth. Whenever right-wing critics of the public schools regroup for renewed attacks, sex education emerges as a favorite target.

title: SEPARATING TERRORISM FROM RADICALISM
description: After the attempted robbery of a Brink's truck Oct. 20 in Nyack, N.Y., the murder of two policemen and an armoredcar guard, and capture of some underground radicals from the 1960's, law-enforcement officials promptly claimed that the holdup was part of a ''terrorist conspiracy'' aimed at establishing ''a socialist state'' and abolishing the Government ''as we know it.''

title: RECITAL: ROBERT STARER'S SONATA PLAYED IN DUO PROGRAM BY THE GRUNSCHLAGS
description: TONI and Rosi Grunschlag, Viennese-born duo-pianists, presented a program Sunday night at the 92d Street Y that was, even by two-piano standards, unusual. The centerpiece was a one-movement sonata for two pianos by Robert Starer, fellow Viennese, written for the sisters this year and which received its world premiere in their performance.

title: GULF UNITED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GF BUSINESS EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JETS ARE PERPLEXED OVER INCONSISTENCY
description: Despite the Jets' emotional, convincing victory over the Giants yesterday and their 4-1-1 record over the last six games, their season took on this perspective today for Darrol Ray: ''All the good we did, it just got us back to even.''

title: BLASS: DESIGN IS THE POINT
description: Bill Blass opened the second week of spring showings yesterday morning with an upbeat collection that had the audience beaming. ''They're wearable, inventive and women will love them,'' observed Kalman Ruttenstein, vice president of Bloomingdale's. ''Good clothes for spring - not just for summer,'' said Ellin Saltzman, fashion director of Saks Fifth Avenue, referring to a frequent complaint about last week's shows: that there were plenty of hot weather clothes, but little for the milder weather.

title: IMS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Current 9 mos net includes a nonrecurring charge of $713,000 or 7 cents a shr

title: Rare Telemann Opera At 92d St. Y on Nov. 28
description: A performance of ''Pimpinone,'' a rarely heard chamber opera by Telemann, will be performed at the 92d Street Y on Nov. 28 at 8 P.M. in the Y Chamber Symphony Goes Baroque series.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Re-Insurance Co. has appointed Ronald E. Compton executive vice president.

title: Election Day Choices
description: Only the election of New York's City Council has been put off by challenges under the Voting Rights Act. For all other races, the promise of that act will be wasted today unless citizens vote.

title: DISSECTING A VINTAGE EXAMPLE OF A POLITICAL RUMOR
description: In the right hands at the right time, the strategically placed political rumor is perhaps the most subtle and lethal weapon in the arsenal of the Washington bureaucrat.

title: LAND OF CHEAP ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING
description: J AMES S. BRADY, who was wounded last March in the assassination attempt on President Reagan, is expected to leave George Washington University Medical Center this month and return to his home in Virginia for further recuperation.

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: Radwaste: A Reporter's Investigation of a Growing Nuclear Menace By Fred C. Shapiro. 272 pages. Random House, New York. $14.50. Mr. Shapiro, a staff writer for The New Yorker magazine, has written an unemotional, ordered book about an emotional, disordered problem -America's growing piles of nuclear waste - a problem whose solution continues to elude both the Government and the private sector.

title: MILLIPORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Data on Malaysian Prisoners
description: Malaysia is holding 513 people in prison without trial under the Government's internal security act, Deputy Prime Minister Musa Hitam, said today. The act, aimed at combating Communist guerrilla activities and other threats to national security, authorizes the Government to arrest and imprison people indefinitely without pressing charges.

title: U.S. Aide Sees Hope For Progress on Namibia
description: Assistant Secretary of State Chester A. Crocker said today that five Western nations hoped to begin carrying out an independence plan for South-West Africa within a few months.

title: Art Directors Club Honors Five Designers
description: Last week at the Pierre Hotel, the Art Directors Club inducted the five newest members of its nine-year-old Hall of Fame, bringing the total to 43.

title: CENTRAL SECURITIES CORP reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets

title: Mead Establishes Official Hierarchy
description: At the beginning of 1980, the Mead Corporation, a major paper maker with headquarters in Dayton, Ohio, was shocked by the sudden resignation of Warren L. Batts as president and chief executive officer. As a result, there was a shuffling of titles in the upper echelon that year, and again early in 1981 to provide the necessary management continuity.

TOBACCO PRICE SUPPORTS VS. SMOKING

title: Matz and Jenkins Head U.S. Horsemen at Show
description: Michael Matz and Rodney Jenkins head the United States team for the National Horse Show, which begins a six-day run at Madison Square Garden tonight.

title: MILITIAS IN BEIRUT OBSERVE BAN ON ARMS
description: The uniformed militiamen of predominantly Moslem West Beirut disappeared from the streets today as a new disarmament effort began in the hope of returning security duties to the police.

title: 100,000 IN POLAND END THEIR STRIKE
description: A 10-day wildcat strike by more than 100,000 workers ended in southern Poland today after an appeal from Lech Walesa, the leader of the independent union Solidarity.

title: Loews Purchase
description: The Loews Corporation said it had acquired 2,582,800 shares, or 5.2 percent, of the common stock of the General Foods Corporation for investment purposes.

title: Justice, Reaganized
description: The independent Federal judiciary is one of the glories of American government, but that doesn't impress Attorney General William French Smith. He wishes to press the election returns on the Federal courts. ''The Department of Justice intends to play an active role in effecting the principles upon which Ronald Reagan campaigned,'' he said in a policy address last week. That means turning the courts away from their ''constitutionally dubious and unwise intrusions'' onto legislative turf.

Market Place; Why Seagram Is So Alluring
description: MEMBERS of the Bronfman family must be relieved, now that the Mobil Corporation has announced an unfriendly bid for the Marathon Oil Company. This takeover effort appears to eliminate Mobil as a threat to the Seagram Company, though other huge corporations might covet the world's largest distiller.

description: To the Editor:

BRONCOS DEFEAT VIKINGS, 19-17
description: Rob Lytle's 5-yard touchdown run and Craig Morton's 15-yard scoring pass to Steve Watson within two minutes in the fourth quarter gave the Denver Broncos a 19-17 victory over the Minnesota Vikings tonight.

title: MARATHON, IN COURT, SLOWS MOBIL BID
description: The Marathon Oil Company, responding swiftly to an unwelcome $5 billion takeover attempt by the Mobil Corporation, filed an antitrust suit against Mobil yesterday and obtained a temporary restraining order halting the giant oil company's tender offer until next Tuesday.

Article 077160 -- No Title
description: Bail of $250,000 was set in Manhattan yesterday for Cynthia Boston, a suspect arrested in Mississippi last week on a Federal conspiracy charge involving the Oct. 20 armored-car robbery in Rockland County.

title: Hudson Has Surgery
description: A follow-up: He was on the operating table for six and a half hours, and his surgeons found they had to perform five separate heart bypasses, but Rock Hudson came through the ordeal yesterday.

title: SIX HOSTAGES FREED UNHURT AFTER 5 DAYS OF PRISONERS' SIEGE
description: A band of seven prisoners tonight released six hostages they had held in a wing of the Eastern State Correctional Institution here since Wednesday.

title: Allstate Refund Grows in Jersey
description: TRENTON (AP) - Allstate Insurance Company policyholders will share in $1,164,559 more in auto insurance refunds for improperly imposed rate increases, Insurance Commissioner James J. Sheeran announced.

description: By John Leonard THE MONKEY GRAMMARIAN. By Octa- vio Paz. Translated from the Spanish by Helen R. Lane. Illustrated. 162 pages. Seaver Books. Hard cover, $14.95; paper, $7.95.

title: Morgan Guaranty Loss On Bank Loans Possible
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company stands to lose up to $70 million in loans that it has outstanding to three deeply troubled New York City savings banks, banking sources said yesterday.

description: Yr-ago revs figures have been reclassified
