Soccer Player From Rumania Is Denied Asylum in Australia
description: A Rumanian soccer player lost his bid for political asylum in Australia and left for home today after receiving assurances that he would not be punished in Rumania, his lawyer said.

title: Smart Chimpanzees
description: Experiments with chimpanzees suggest that the adults can achieve high scores in tests that require an understanding of numbers and proportion. The scores of less mature animals were far lower.

title: PIANO: EARL WILD PRESENTS 'THE ART OF THE TRANSCRIPTION'
description: LISTENING to Earl Wild play piano transcriptions at Carnegie Hall Sunday afternoon was a little like being turned loose in a candy store. This was a celebration of the hyphen - Gluck-Sgambati, Rossini-Thalberg, Chopin-Liszt, Tchaikovsky-Wild - and for most of the afternoon, what came after the hyphen held sway over what came before.

title: Alexander Kevitz Dead at 79; Played for U.S. Chess Team
description: Alexander Kevitz, a chess master who played on the United States chess team against the Soviet Union in 1946 and 1955, died Oct. 24 at the Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Rabbi Kahane Arrested After Speech in Canada
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane, the founder and leader of the Jewish Defense League, was released from custody today after his arrest for failing to obtain an entry permit into Canada.

title: GUARANTEE FINANCIAL OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; the current qr and 9 mos losses include extraordinary gains resulting from repurchase of mortgage backed bonds amounting to $389,000 for the qr and $1,463,000 for the 9 mos

title: SEPTEMBER FACTORY ORDERS OFF
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - Orders for new manufactured goods fell ninetenths of 1 percent in September, the second consecutive monthly decline after having risen steadily since January, the Commerce Department said today.

title: UTILITY SETBACKS ON THE COAST
description: Cheap electrical power has been an article of faith in the Pacific Northwest, where hydropower has been so plentiful that, in the 1930's, the Bonneville Power Administration even hired the folk singer Woody Guthrie to promote electrical use in song. And, until recently, many utility officials would meet annually to decide how to lower rates.

title: Justices Clash on Issue Of Executing Juveniles
description: Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court expressed skepticism today after a fellow Justice suggested that saving money might serve as a rationale for the death penalty.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BIC PEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHICAGO RIVET & MACHINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2,000 Arab Students Battle With Israeli Troops in 6 Towns
description: More than 2,000 Arab high school and university students in the Israeli-occupied West Bank clashed with Israeli soldiers today, hurling stones and setting tires ablaze in the streets in six towns.

title: CENTRAL PARK HOST TO STARS OF HORSE SET
description: Some working-class Central Park horses got a glimpse yesterday of how their jet-traveling, polo-playing other half lives. A splendid sampling of animals from the National Horse Show turned up to demonstrate their specialties on the Great Lawn, getting a little outdoor exercise amid the bright foliage and the autumn sunshine.

title: COURT TO HEAR ELECTION PLEA BY UNION ON 'SOVEREIGNTY'
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether labor unions can prohibit candidates for union office from accepting campaign contributions from nonmembers of the union.

title: DATA I-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: 1981 results include interest income of $303,000 for the qr and $578,000 for the 9 mos; shrs outstndg are fully diluted

title: The Time to Pay for Prisons
description: Should New York State build 4,000 new prison cells? The question, which is at the heart of debate over the $500 million bond issue on today's ballot, misses the point. The real issue is how to pay for cells that will have to be built one way or another. That's why voters should approve the prison bond.

title: WAS POCKET BOOKS FOUNDER
description: Robert F. de Graff, a founder and former president of Pocket Books, died Sunday at his home in Mill Neck, L.I. He was 86 years old. Before the remarkable success of the 10 paperback reprints initially offered by Pocket Books in 1939, publishers insisted that the American public would not buy paperbound books.

title: Financial Federation's New Chief
description: William J. Popejoy, a former head of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, and a recognized expert in real estate financing, will join Financial Federation Inc., a leading savings and loan association holding company, as president and chief executive officer early next month.

title: PEOPLES ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
20 People Are Seized in Sicily On Drug-Smuggling Charges
description: Authorities charged 20 people today with involvement in international drug smuggling, including the shipping of cocaine and heroin to the United States hidden inside household furniture.

title: Auto Makers Trim Output
description: United States automobile manufacturers have again cut production plans for the present quarter because of the continuing sales slump, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

title: Q&A
description: Q. If all the cells in our bodies are constantly replaced, why do we grow old?

title: POP: REINCARNATION OF THE INK SPOTS OF 1932
description: THE Ink Spots - a black singing quartet founded in 1932, famous in 1939, nostalgia by 1945 - have lived on since then through numerous groups using the name. The Ink Spots that were singing last week at Sweet Basil were led by Jim Nabbie, who replaced Bill Kenny as the high tenor in the Spots in 1945.

title: PACO PHARMACEUTICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 29
FOOD PRICE RISE SEEN OF 5% TO 8%
description: With large supplies of feed grains and most livestock assured for next year, the rise in retail food prices should be held to between 5 and 8 percent in 1982, the Agriculture Department predicted today.

title: Patient Accused In Nurse's Killing
description: A patient in the Kingsboro Psychiatric Center in Brooklyn's Crown Heights section was arrested early this morning and charged with the murder of a registered nurse at the facility over the weekend, the police said.

title: ELECTION DAY: WHO, WHEN, WHERE
description: Today is Election Day. The polls will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. in New York State, from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. in New Jersey and from 6 A.M. to 8 P.M. in Connecticut.

title: 2d L.I. Trial Starts In Officer's Killing
description: Jury selection began in the second trial of a man accused of slaying a Nassau County police officer.

IRVIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: ASTRONAUTS ARRIVE AT CAPE AS COUNTDOWN ADVANCES SMOOTHLY
description: The astronauts who will pilot the space shuttle Columbia for its second mission arrived here this afternoon as countdown preparations continued at a leisurely pace surprisingly free of glitches and gremlins.

BELL, W, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: B-Reflects 20 percent stock divd paid in Dec 1980

title: Consumer Groups Urge Rehiring of Controllers
description: Several consumer and labor groups, citing concerns over a possible strain on the air traffic control system, today urged President Reagan to rehire dismissed controllers.

title: MILLER TECHNOLOGY & COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
KLAN VERDICT POLARIZES VOTERS IN CAROLINA CITY
description: Partisans on both sides of Greensboro's municipal election campaign, which has divided business interests on the one hand and a newly unified black community on the other, are speaking of tomorrow's vote in somewhat apocalyptic terms.

title: MEM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHORAL: NEW YORK SOCIETY OFFERS DVORAK'S REQUIEM
description: ANTONIN DVORAK'S Requiem got lost in the shuffle of 19th-century choral music some time ago, and still has difficulty working itself out of the shadow of more imposing settings by Berlioz, Brahms and Verdi, to name but three. Yet the piece is typical of its composer, in that it brings to bear on the subject an earthy sincerity and psychological straightforwardness, without avoiding the projection of sentiment.

title: Drug Link Is Seen In Chelsea Killings
description: Detectives investigating the slayings Saturday night of a photographer and a Smith College student in the photographer's Chelsea apartment said they believed the killings might have resulted from a ''drug-oriented robbery.'' Both victims had been shot in the head.

title: Sears's Stake In Coldwell
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company announced that 1.4 million shares, or 28 percent, of the shares outstanding of Coldwell, Banker & Company's common stock had been tendered under its offer of $42 a share.

title: PLAYOFFS OR PIPE DREAMS?
description: IN evaluating the fantasy that either the Jets or the Giants, or both, will qualify for the National Football League playoffs this season, consider the reality that each team now must do what it has not been able to do - win the games it's supposed to win.

title: G.O.P. CHIEFS REDUCING PROPOSALS ON THE BUDGET
description: Senate and House Republican leaders today gave the White House an informal, scaled-down version of budget cuts and new taxes that would give President Reagan about half the $16 billion package that he has been seeking for the fiscal year 1982.

title: Orion Gains Pact With Ahmanson
description: The Orion Capital Corporation, an insurance holding company, said that it had reached agreement with H.F. Ahmanson & Company on revised terms for the $109 million purchase by Ahmanson of Bankers National Life Insurance Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of Orion.

title: Harrelson a Met Coach
description: Bud Harrelson, shortstop for the Mets for 13 years and a leader of their National League championship teams of 1969 and 1973, was named their first-base coach yesterday.

title: NLI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-There are no yr-ago results since NLI Corp was organized on Dec 31, 1980 as a wholly owned subsidiary of TIME-DC Inc... C-Includes pretax gain on the sale of property of $1,311,000 for the qr and $2,449,000 for the 9 mos

title: AMERICAN FAMILY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NOTES ON FASHION
description: T HE surprise of the week was the American collections for spring, which proved that American fashion design has come of age and that its vocabulary is more diverse and extensive than ever before. The shows of Calvin Klein and Perry Ellis were triumphs, each typifying distinctly different emerging trends.

title: MCI-AMERICAN EXPRESS PACT
description: MCI Communications Inc., a Washingtonbased company that competes with the Bell System for long-distance telephone business, said today that it had signed a marketing agreement with the American Express Company giving it access to more than nine million holders of American Express cards.

title: Amoco Lifts Oil Prices
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) yesterday became the first United States oil company to raise its prices in reaction to the price accord reached last week in Geneva by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: News Analysis
description: By all indications, an attempt on the political life of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt - a move toward the jugular that was expected by some after he received a heart pacemaker on Oct. 12 - is not taking place.

title: Marshal Accused Of Grand Larceny
description: A city marshal was arrested after auditors found only $69 in an account in his trust that should have held $30,000, according to District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx.

title: INTEGRITY ENTERTAINMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BOSTON STUDENTS SEEK ACCESS TO SCHOOL POLICE DATA
description: Editors of two student newspapers at Boston area colleges are engaged in court battles with college administrators, seeking to compel private campus police forces to open their records to the public.

title: Vic DeLucia Binns Wins IC4A Cross-Country Run
description: Stephen Binns, right, from Providence College, approaching finish line yesterday in Van Cortlandt Park to win the IC4A championships for five-mile cross-country.

title: LANCASTER COLONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PLANNING RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HALLIBURTON SOARS; GREYHOUND UP
description: The Halliburton Company reported yesterday that net income in the third quarter soared 48.3 percent as revenues increased 23.1 percent. Halliburton, a leader in oil well services, said that net income in the latest three months climbed to $191.5 million, or $1.62 a share, from $129.1 million, or $1.09 a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1980. Revenues increased to $2.24 billion from $1.82 billion.

title: 31 Arms and Poison Caches Are Found in West Germany
description: The police said today that they had discovered huge quantities of arms, explosives and poisons in 31 buried caches that had been described in a register kept by a neo-Nazi.

title: SPRINKBOK'S TOBIAS ON SPOT
description: A white woman who was teaching an extension course on ''The Scarlet Letter'' in Cape Town, where her students were mostly drawn from the mixed-race population group that is officially classifed as colored, recently asked whether any of them could think of a current situation in which a person might be ostracized as severely as Hawthorne's heroine.

title: Korvettes Lease
description: Korvettes Inc., the defunct discount chain now operating under Chapter 11 provisions, said it had agreed to sell the lease of the Richmond Avenue Shopping Center on Staten Island to Pergament Inc., the home improvement retailer, for $1.75 million. About $2.5 million in existing mortgages would be taken over by the purchaser, Korvettes said.

title: WASHINGTON POST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BALLET: JOFFREY TAKES A LOOK AT YOUTH
description: THE Joffrey Ballet, which has always been a youthful company, placed an accent on youth and youth culture at some well-danced weekend performances.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PARKS WITHIN PARKS

title: A Jackpot of $63,680 Paid by Slot Machine
description: A New Jersey man took home $63,680, the biggest payoff ever on a progressive-link slot machine at the Playboy Hotel Casino, a spokesman for the casino said today.

title: DEPENDABLE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Padres Hold Out
description: The world champion Los Angeles Dodgers may want Ozzie Smith, the San Diego shortstop, but a Padre official said they weren't going to get him in an even exchange for Pedro Guerrero.

title: NETS GET ELMORE FROM BUCKS
description: When the Milwaukee Bucks played an exhibiton game at Madison Square Garden last month, Larry Brown, the coach of the Nets, was envious of the Bucks' depth at center.

title: OEA INC reports earnings for Yr to July 11
FRIEDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STATES ACT WARILY ON BLOCK GRANTS
description: The states have moved with surprising rapidity -New York and California being notable exceptions - to take over 57 Federal programs that Congress placed under block grants as the beginning of President Reagan's policy to reduce Washington's authority in the domestic area.

title: ADVEST GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SEAGULL PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MAMELODI, South Africa
description: DESPITE the strenuous efforts of South African lawmakers to dig deep moats around every racial and ethnic group in a diverse population, it now and then happens that people escape from enforced social and cultural isolation to try on a new style, even a new identity, that is proudly and assertively hybrid.

title: G.M. Declares 60 Dividend
description: The General Motors Corporation declared its regular quarterly dividend of 60 cents, a sign analysts said indicated the big auto company is trying to communicate to investors it is still financially healthy. The dividend is payable Dec. 10 to holders of record Nov. 12.

title: TANDEM COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect 3-for-1 stock split effective June 30

title: CROWNAMERICA INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: B-After $229,509 loss from discontinued operations; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations 1981 results reflect a change to the LIFO method of inventory valuation

title: HIGH AIDE TO CUOMO RESIGNS POST AMID CHARGES OF PAYROLL PADDING
description: A high aide to Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo resigned yesterday at Mr. Cuomo's request amid reports that the aide had been accused of putting five nonexistent employees on his payroll and cashing their checks.

title: JACKSON DECLARES AGAIN FOR STATUS AS FREE AGENT
description: Reggie Jackson declared himself a free agent yesterday for the second time in his career. His first venture into the free agent market produced what was then a record baseball contract of $2.5 million for five years. What this second experience may bring is not so clear.

title: 'NONSENSE' IN GENE IS PROMPTING NEW THOUGHT ON MAN'S ORIGIN
description: IN 1977 two teams of scientists made the startling discovery that genes - the blueprints of heredity in all living things - sometimes contain large segments of nonsense interrupting the real hereditary message. In the brief time since that discovery at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, the phenomenon of ''split genes'' has been found to be widespread, and in the genes of animals and humans, it is almost universal. Furthermore, some hitherto unsuspected footprints of evolution are becoming visible in the nonsense portions of genes.

title: A PRINCIPAL SHARES VIEWS OF APPAREL CONCERN
description: Marvin Blumenfeld, one of the principals in last week's merger of three companies in the men's apparel industry into a corporation with annual sales of $100 million, summarized yesterday how the deal was born.

title: LINDAL CEDAR HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PACIFIC POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Shuttle's Cork From Portugal
description: The space shuttle Columbia's huge external fuel tank is partly insulated by 497 pounds of cork taken from the bark of 225 cork oak trees in Portugal.

title: MENTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONCERT: COLLEGIATE CHORALE
description: THE chorus is a rhythmic and coloristic instrument in Carl Orff's often tedious ''Carmina Burana.'' It bites out Latin syllables with pulsing senselessness; it toys with sinuous melodies.

title: BUCKHORN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $150,000 for the qr and $490,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss

title: SOVIET-CHINA TALK STILL IN DEADLOCK
description: Within the walls of the large Soviet Embassy compound in northeast Peking, a skeleton staff of negotiators has been waiting for the opportunity to resume talks with China on disputed boundaries .

title: ITT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: ITT Financial is a subsidiary of International Telephone & Telegraph

title: MANHATTAN LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ACCURAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago net income for the qr and 9 mos have been restated to reflect the accrual of vacation pay for exempt employees

title: HINES, EDWARD, LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Haagen-Dazs National Ads
description: Haagen-Dazs ice cream, produced in Woodbridge, N.J., will begin its first national advertising program tomorrow when its commercial begins its 10-time run on the syndicated ''Merv Griffin Show.''

title: GREYHOUND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Current qr includes a gain or settlement of litigation amounting to $8.1 million or 18 cents a shr after taxes

title: BLOOD AND TAXES
description: To the Editor:

title: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1981; Companies
description: The Catawba Corporation, a company founded by the late oilman William F. Buckley Sr., was ordered, along with some associates, to make payments and relinquish royalties totaling more than $800,000. An agreed-upon consent decree stemmed from S.E.C. charges about transactions involving companies they controlled. (Page A1.)

title: IRT PROPERTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Talking Business with Muriel Siebert, Bank Superintendent;  Thrift Units: What's Ahead
description: Last week, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced that it was seeking a merger partner for the Greenwich Savings Bank of New York. It was the first time the agency had confirmed reports about an ailing thrift institution.

title: Doing Something Right
description: In his first collegiate start, 10 days ago, Greg Allen, Florida State's 18-year-old freshman tailback, ran for 202 yards.

title: Climber Marooned
description: Well, nobody is perfect. When Daniel D. Goodwin, a 26-year-old stuntman, set out to climb the Sears Tower, the world's tallest building, last Memorial Day, he scaled the skyscraper with seeming ease.

title: TV: 'PRINCESS AND THE CABBIE,' A SICK POOR LITTLE RICH GIRL
description: SOMEBODY had the bright idea of combining one of yesteryear's poor-little-rich-girl stories with the currently popular exoticmalady genre. So here is ''The Princess and the Cabbie,'' an oldfashioned fable about a girl with a newfangled ailment. It can be seen tonight on CBS-TV at 9 o'clock. It stars Valerie Bertinelli, whose kittenish presence is this television movie's only touch of anything appealing.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The situation is one that we are convinced, and convinced that the Saudis are convinced, that given certain contingencies as they occur in Southwest Asia, particularly including the Soviet Union, that literally the only force that could meet the military requirements to deter and or defend the region, has to be the forces of the United States.

title: MODERN DANCE: INSPIRED BY OLD MEXICAN RITUALS
description: AMERICAN modern dance's fascination with the ancient Indian cultures of Mexico dates back at least to the 1920's, with Denishawn's ''Aztec'' spectacular ''Xochitl,'' starring the young Martha Graham and Ted Shawn.

title: THE HAPLESS 2 PERCENT OF INSURED MOTORISTS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. MEDICAL AID UP IN NEW YORK STATE
description: Because it has become poorer in a census ranking than 10 other states, New York has regained more than double what it lost in Federal Medicaid cuts, Federal health officials reported yesterday.

title: City Agency Corrects Figure In Foster Children Statistics
description: The city's Human Resources Administration said yesterday that because of a typographical error in its review of the Cardinal McCloskey School and Home for Children in White Plains it erroneously reported that 50 percent of the children placed in foster homes by the McCloskey program were on psychotropic medicine to control their behavior.

title: Giants Still Counting on Gray
description: Earnest Gray has had brilliant days in his three years with the Giants. In last year's opener against the St. Louis Cardinals, his four touchdown receptions set a club record. Against the Cardinals this year, his stabbing, one-handed catch in the end zone was memorable.

title: Court Takes Japanese Job Suit
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether American subsidiaries of foreign corporations are required to abide by the Federal law that forbids discrimination in employment, despite trade treaties that appear to give the companies discretion in hiring.

title: SOUTHWEST FOREST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Wage Settlements Key Issue for British Industry
description: Plagued by a lack of competitiveness in world markets, Britain's principal business group has made wages the key issue at its annual conference, which opened this morning to wide attention.

title: BUCKLEY GROUP TO PAY $800,000 IN S.E.C. SUIT
description: The company founded by the late oilman William F. Buckley Sr. was ordered today, along with some associates, to make payments and relinquish royalties totaling more than $800,000.

title: POLITICS CLOUDS CLEAN AIR ACT DEBATE
description: Until recently clean air and clean water legislation tended to breeze through Capitol Hill in a climate of pristine bipartisanship.

title: Comings and Goings
description: As expected, Matthew Saad Muhammad signed to defend the World Boxing Council's light-heavyweight championship against Dwight Braxton of Camden, N.J., who recently knocked out Mike Rossman and outpointed James Scott. The bout will be held, said the promoter Murad Muhammad, Dec. 19 in Atlantic City. ... The State Racing and Wagering Board suspended the license of Henry Villar Jr., a jockey who is charged with having had an illegal ''battery,'' a prodding device, in his possession during the ninth race Saturday at the Finger Lakes track.

title: WASHINGTON NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHAIRMAN OF VOLKSWAGEN TO RESIGN
description: Volkswagen, West Germany's biggest auto maker, announced today that its chairman and chief executive officer would resign for health reasons.

title: SPEX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $208,022 loss from discontinued operations; 1980 results reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in Mar 1981

title: WTC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $373,000 for the qr and $2,259,000 for the 9 mos; 1980 results restated to inclu the company's 10 percent equity in earnings of WTC Rand

title: PENTAGON DENIES REPORT ON SAUDIS
description: Defense Department officials described today as ''totally unfounded'' a report that the United States had reached agreements with Saudi Arabia for the stockpiling of United States military supplies or for American use of Saudi bases.

title: STANLEY HOME PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HIGH ACIDITY IS FOUND IN MANY NEW YORK STREAMS
description: Forty percent of the Adirondack Mountain streams sampled during and after the 1980 snows melted showed ''critical'' or ''endangered'' levels of acidity, according to a state report released today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Acton Corp. said it had sold its International Food Service-Miami to C.F.S. Continental Inc. for more than $4 million in cash and notes.

title: HONEYWELL CLOSING UNIT AND ENDING 400 JOBS
description: Honeywell Inc. said yesterday that it would close a Massachusetts manufacturing plant and dismiss 400 employees because of slow orders for the company's minicomputers and terminals.

title: NATIONAL BERYLLIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jersey A-Plant Is Restarted
description: The turbine engine generator of the Oyster Creek nuclear station was returned to service today, officials of the General Public Utilities Corporation said. Startup procedures began yesterday after a three-day shutdown for minor repairs to equipment in the turbine building. The plant is expected to reach maximum output later this week.

title: NEWCOURT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $564,000 for the qr and $548,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net income including gains from discontinued operations of $56,000 for the qr and $12,000 for the 9 mos

title: TRI-STATE MOTOR TRANSIT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Included $3.6 million gain from tax benefit from writeoff of operations...C-Net losses after losses from writeoff of operating rights of $9,827,000

title: Trenton Times Lays Off 60
description: The new owners of The Trenton Times laid off 60 employees in an attempt to cut costs. at A spokesman said The Times was ''strongly overstaffed.''

title: New Haven Line Given U.S. Funds
description: WHITE PLAINS (AP) - The Federal Government has approved a $25 million grant to improve power on Conrail's New Haven line, according to the office of Representative Richard L. Ottinger.

title: DYNASCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MARSH SUPERMARKETS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 10
Advertising; RCA's Videodisk Campaign
description: THE RCA Corporation yesterday began the first independent advertising for its videodisks, a $1 million, six-week investment on five radio networks that will promote them as ideal Christmas gifts.

title: DEVON GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $11,000 loss for the qr and $203,000 income for the 6 mos from discontinued operations and $663,000 gain for the qr and 6 mos from the sale of a subsidiary

title: ALUMNI LEAD RENAISSANCE OF OLD CLUBS
description: Today's young college graduates, new New Yorkers who came to the city to seek their fortunes, have revived one of the city's oldest traditions - its university clubs.

title: FLORIO AND KEAN CONFIDENT AS JERSEY CAMPAIGN CLOSES
description: Thomas H. Kean, the Republican candidate for Governor, wrapped up his campaign today with a flurry of handshakes and predictions of victory.

title: THE WRONG ANSWER
description: Well-intentioned New Yorkers face a tough choice today on the proposed $500 million bond issue for new prisons and jails. Most will want to relieve the self-evident evil of overcrowding in these institutions; but to many, as to me, the evidence will suggest that a big new construction program is the wrong way to go about it.

title: THE GLEN COVE HUSTINGS
description: Howard Tulchin says he cannot afford a campaign consultant, which is probably just as well, since a consultant would almost certainly tell him to lose 50 pounds to improve his image.

title: NATIONAL CITY LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $2,226,000 tax benefit

title: Liquor Deliveries Curbed by Strike
description: About 1,500 liquor salesmen went on strike against five large distributors, affecting deliveries to liquor stores in most of the New York metropolitan area.

title: BARNES ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOVIET CAPTAIN IS INTERROGATED IN SUB INCIDENT
description: The commander of a Soviet submarine that has been aground in a restricted Swedish naval zone near here for a week left his vessel today and submitted to questioning by Swedish authorities.

title: CONSTRUCTION OUTLAY IS LOWEST IN A YEAR
description: Construction spending by American builders, declining all year under the weight of high interest rates, fell four-tenths

title: 7 Congressmen Urge Court To Bar Nixon's Immunity Bid
description: Seven members of Congress, in a bipartisan action, have urged the Supreme Court to reject Richard M. Nixon's contention that he cannot be sued for money damages for actions taken while he was President.

title: Commission Orders Thumbless Gloves
description: Jack Prenderville, the chairman of the State Athletic Commission, announced yesterday that gloves used in fights in New York would be thumbless, starting Jan. 15.

title: INTERCRAFT INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
BIRDS OF PREY DEMONSTRATE STRATEGIES OF ATTACK
description: loaded net trap that lay in front of the blind. The pigeon, protected by a leather vest, suddenly flapped its wings. The hawk dove toward it. As it landed on the pigeon's back, a researcher in the blind sprung the trap and the netting closed over the two birds.

title: TECHNODYNE INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 1
VORNADO TO INCREASE STORE CLOSINGS BY 18 UNITS
description: In a move that points to its intent to sharply limit its retailing activities, Vornado Inc., operator of the Two Guys discount store chain, said yesterday that its board had approved the closing soon of an additional 18 stores. The loss-ridden company two weeks ago said it planned to close 12 other stores.

title: FLORIDA CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After provision for losses of $178,000 related to discontinued operations in the qr and 9 mos

title: DIAGNOSTIC RETRIEVAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GOVERNOR RACES WATCHED FOR U.S. CLUES
description: As campaigning in elections across the country drew to a close, Republicans looked to today's two gubernatorial elections for votes of confidence on national policy while two Democratic Governors with apparent Presidential ambitions sought votes of confidence in their own states.

title: A STATE DEPT. PURGE
description: Robert White, the former ambassador to El Salvador, recently accused the Administration of purging the State Department's Latin American bureau. Senior officials who normally would have received ambassador-level appointments are being passed over for promotion or forced to retire.

title: U.S. Court Upsets Antitrust Ruling
description: Toshiba America Inc. won a legal victory when a Federal appeals court upset a lower court finding that it had violated antitrust laws in dealings with a former distributor of its copying machines.

title: DOW IS UP BY 14.27 AS RATES EASE
description: Falling interest rates sent stock prices sharply higher yesterday in extremely heavy trading as the market scored its second big advance in succession. Energy, technology and railroad issues ranked among the better gainers.

title: KEMPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHEN A DEFENDANT TRIES TO GET EVEN
description: To the Editor:

title: A 40TH ANNIVERSARY
description: When Jamie L. Whitten was first elected to Congress 40 years ago this Wednesday, 84 members of the current House of Representatives had not been born and a goodly number of others were still toddlers.

title: BABY'S CRY, IT TURNS OUT, CAN SPEAK VOLUMES
description: EACH generation of new parents painfully confronts the old dilemma that the crying baby presents. Should they pick up the infant, and thus risk ''spoiling'' the child, or should they sometimes leave him alone and ignore his cries?

title: UNION REJECTS WAGE CONCESSIONS AT FAILING PLANT IN ALABAMA
description: A proposal by the financially troubled Ford Motor Company to salvage its parts plant here and the jobs of nearly 1,000 hourly and salaried workers has stirred a major controversy.

title: FOXBORO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NAVCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OPPOSITION IN ISRAEL JOINS IN DENOUNCING SAUDIS' PEACE PLAN
description: The parliamentary opposition joined the Begin Government today in denouncing the Saudi Arabian Middle East peace plan but warned that the Government's failure to achieve self-rule for the Palestinians was increasing world support for the Saudi plan.

title: ALBA-WALDENSIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CENSUS SHOWS INCREASE IN NEED FOR WELFARE AID
description: The Census Bureau, noting ''large increases in poverty'' in the United States, reported today that the number of families receiving food stamps increased 12 percent last year, over 1979, while the number of families living in public or subsidized housing rose by 8 percent.

title: MOOD OF FLORIO'S SUPPORTERS TURNS FROM EALRY OPTIMISM
description: In the heart of his political base here in South Jersey, Representative James J. Florio waited patiently tonight for results of the gubernatorial contest. Early optimism turned to caution as the early tallies came in and swung against him.

title: Arthur Dixon Is Dead at 57; Headed State C.P.A. Group
description: Arthur J. Dixon, managing partner of Oppenheim, Appel, Dixon & Company, certified public accountants, died Monday at his home in Roslyn, L.I., after a brief illness. He was 57 years old.

title: Advertising; A Booming Boston Agency
description: JOHN M. Connors JR., 39 years old, is feeling his oats these days. He has been president of his own agency since he was 25 and has seen it grow into an international enterprise. Of course, it is Bostonbased, but he doesn't think that's a major handicap.

title: GUARDS 'SHAKE DOWN' GRATERFORD PRISON FOR ARMS
description: Guards searched cell by cell and in every corner of the vast Eastern State Correctional Institution here today, looking for any weapons that, like those used by convicts in a fiveday hostage standoff just ended, might have penetrated the security system.

title: YOUNG DEMOCRATS ON RISE IN HOUSE
description: They are hardly household names beyond the beltway, but on Capitol Hill in this session of Congress a new generation of Democratic leaders has begun to emerge.

title: Some Old Business Returns to Dancer
description: Two years ago, Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, the national agency for Toyota Motor Sales USA and for most of its dealer associations, lost the Greater New York Dealers Association to Altschiller Reitzfeld Solin/ NCK. Well, yesterday D.F.S. got that business back and it is reportedly now billing $4 million.

title: OLD-TIME CRACKERS BOUNCE BACK
description: Two years ago Cross Crackers, the thick white crackers that filled American cracker barrels for over a century, seemed headed for oblivion as surely as beer in a bucket. The Cross Baking Company, which was in business for 151 years in Vermont and later in New Hampshire, went bankrupt, and its machinery was sold at auction.

title: EJECTION FROM SPACE SHUTTLE ON GROUND COULD BE PERILOUS
description: Nobody has ever pulled the D ring, and space agency officials frankly fear the consequences if Col. Joe H. Engle of the Air Force and Capt. Richard H. Truly of the Navy must eject from the Columbia in the event of an accident on the launching pad.

title: Deputy Minister Heads Field for Young America
description: Deputy Minister, whose eight victories in nine career starts include the Youthful and the Laurel Futurity, drew Post 7 and was made the early 2-1 favorite among 14 2-year-olds entered yesterday for the $282,750 Young America Stakes at the Meadowlands tomorrow night.

title: KEYSTONE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MICHIGAN ENERGY RESOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DELBELLO THE APPARENT WINNER IN WESTCHESTER
description: County Executive Alfred B. DelBello appeared early today to have won re-election to a third four-year term, defeating his Republican-Conservative challenger, State Senator Joseph R. Pisani of New Rochelle.

title: HARVEST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STRAVINSKY ARCHIVES MAY GO TO U.C.L.A. MUSIC LIBRARY
description: Igor Stravinsky's archives may soon find a final resting place at the University of California at Los Angeles. The collection of scores, sketches, letters and documents at the Stravinsky apartment on Fifth Avenue has been central to a 10-year dispute over Stravinsky's estate between his wife, Vera, and his three children by an earlier marriage. The division of the estate was settled two years ago, but the disposition of the archives has remained undecided.

title: SAV-A-STOP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
No Headline
description: HIGHWAY ROUNDUP: A cow being roped in the middle of the Golden State Freeway, near Sun Valley, Calif., after a semitrailer truck overturned, let-ting loose about 20 head of cattle. Highway traffic was tied up for hours while the animals were rounded up; some had to be shot to speed up the process.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt SELECTED LETTERS OF JAMES THUR- BER. Edited by Helen Thurber and Ed- ward Weeks. 274 pages. Illustrated With Thurber Drawings. Atlantic-Little, Brown. $15.

title: ANDERSON CLAYTON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'BULLET TRAIN' SERVICE IN U.S. URGED IN REPORT
description: The Joint Economic Committee of Congress, in a bipartisan move, called today for development of high-speed rail lines like the Japanese Bullet Train to bolster the national transportation system.

title: EMOTIONS SEESAW AT GATHERING OF KEAN'S BACKERS
description: The tension in the Regency Room of the Holiday Inn here, where Thomas H. Kean's supporters were gathered, ebbed and flowed this morning with the election returns dribbling from the television screens.

title: Dr. Bernard Alpers, Teacher And Neurology Text Author
description: Bernard J. Alpers, emeritus professor of neurology of Jefferson Medical College of Thomas Jefferson University in Philadelphia, died Monday at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital. Dr. Alpers, who lived in Merion, Pa., was 81 years old.

title: NEW YORK LAW PUTS NURSE PRACTITIONERS IN LIMBO
description: When a medical emergency arises on the ward for elderly and chronically ill patients at the City Hospital Center at Elmhurst, Queens, the patient frequently requires immediate medication. But under New York State law, only physicians are allowed to prescribe - and there is not always a doctor on the ward.

title: Euphrosyne, Ghazwan Win on Aqueduct Turf
description: Richard Migliore, the top apprentice jockey in the country, and Constantino Hernandez, a promising apprentice just beginning a career in this country, rode long shots to victory in the split Knickerbocker Handicap on the turf yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: WEINBERGER CALLS NUCLEAR ARMS BUILDUP PREREQUISITE TO TALKS
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger asserted today that the refurbishing of the nation's nuclear arsenal was ''a necessary prerequisite'' to negotiations with the Soviet Union on reducing strategic arms.

title: MITTERRAND TELLS THE AFRICANS FRANCE WILL KEEP UP ITS AID
description: President Francois Mitterrand promised today that France would continue the active role it has traditionally played in its former African colonies, but with a difference.

title: ADVERTISING
description: In its third-quarter earnings statement issued yesterday, Ogilvy & Mather International reported that its net income rose 40 percent, to $2.8 million, or 67 cents a share, compared with $2 million, or 49 cents a share.

title: MIDLAND SOUTHWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Florence Fabricant
description: ''YOU will find that cooking with wine is as easy as opening a bottle and taking a sip.'' That encouragement is offered by the British food authority and restaurateur Robert Carrier in his new book, ''Cooking With Carrier.'' Whether or not one is inclined to share the wine with the stewpot, wines selected for cooking should be worth sipping.

title: MURDOCH OFFERS TO BUY TROUBLED SEATTLE PAPER
description: Rupert Murdoch, the owner of The New York Post and several other publications, has offered to buy The Seattle Post-Intelligencer if a joint operating agreement with The Seattle Times is rejected by the Justice Department, an attorney for the Hearst Corporation said today.

title: AN OLD FACE IN A NEW PLACE
description: Even as a player, he was uncompromising, which is perhaps why Kevin Loughery, the sometimes volatile coach, is no longer with the Nets. For almost five lackluster seasons, Loughery was the franchise's sole link to those years when the Nets were champions of the American Basketball Association - 1974 and 1976. He was a puzzling sort. One minute he would be shouting and pacing along the sidelines, and a few minutes later, off the court, he would calmly prop his feet up and light a cigar.

title: ILL-CONCEIVED ATTACKS ON A ROBESON TRIBUTE
description: To the Editor:

Nuclear Agency Orders Studies of Coast Plant
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission staff today ordered the owners of the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant near San Luis Obispo, Calif., to arrange for three independent studies of the plant's design before it can be fully licensed.

title: RETIREMENT SAVINGS STIR BANKS' CONCERN
description: The American Bankers Association, representing commercial banks, has signaled in a letter to President Reagan sharp differences with the thrift industry regarding deregulation of interest rates in retirement savings accounts.

title: EMERSON ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ISLANDERS TIED BY FLAMES, 2-2
description: The Islanders, coming off a big victory over previously unbeaten Montreal, suffered a letdown tonight, and the Calgary Flames, struggling to shake off the worst start in their history, managed to salvage a 2-2 tie at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: BRAZILIAN'S BEQUEST SETS OFF $12 BILLION SCRAMBLE
description: Though there is every evidence that Domingos Faustino Correa was anything but a good family man, thousands of South Americans are earnestly trying to prove they were related to him.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE TEXT OF KOCH VICTORY SPEECH
description: Following are excerpts from the text of a victory speech by Mayor Koch last night at the Sheraton Centre in Manhattan:

title: TO CASH IN ON A SPARK OF CHINA'S 1911 UPHEAVAL
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1981
description: The Elections The New Jersey gubernatorial contest was the closest one since 1961, with Representative James J. Florio, the Democratic candidate, and Thomas H. Kean, the Republican, running neck and neck. The relatively large turnout showed that Mr. Kean had attracted most of the independent voters, who have been responsible for wide swings in previous Jersey elections. (Page A1, Column 6.) Mayor Koch won a second term in a landslide victory as Democrats swept citywide and boroughwide offices. Mr. Koch, who had both the Democratic and Republican endorsements, and his Democratic running mates, City Council President Carol Bellamy and Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, overwhelmed their opponents. (A1:3.)

title: A FORMER POLICEMAN LEARNS A NEW BEAT
description: THE egg-shaped wedges of zucchini and the tiny barrel-shaped chunks of carrot were in the pots on the stove, under bubbling water, butter and sugar, cooking and acquiring a suitable glaze.

title: HAIG CHARGES A REAGAN AIDE IS UNDERMINIG HIM
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., irritated by articles suggesting that he was in disfavor with President Reagan, charged today that a senior White House aide had been waging ''guerrilla warfare'' against him.

title: SIFCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Family Confirms Son Did Not Desert in '72
description: Norman and Lillian Barnes, who for nine years challenged the Army's contention that their son Kenneth had deserted, have finally received official word that he died nine years ago.

title: HENRY HUDSON SNARLED AT START OF REPAIR WEEK
description: Southbound traffic on the Henry Hudson Parkway was snarled most of yesterday as road work forced autos coming from New Jersey, Westchester and other points into two lanes and then into one lane.

title: BELDING HEMINWAY CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Affiliated Publications, Boston, has named William O. Taylor chairman of the company and of The Boston Globe, succeeding William Davis Taylor, who is retiring, and has also named John P. Guiggio president and chief operating officer of the company and president of The Globe.

title: HINTS FOR LENS WEARERS
description: Little things can markedly influence your success in wearing contact lenses. Experts recommend the following precautions:

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT
description: GOOD cooking is a symphony of nuances. Virtually every aspect of the work has its techniques, the small touches that lead to a successful dish instead of a mediocre one.

title: REAGAN'S QUARREL WITH SEPARATION OF POWERS
description: To the Editor:

title: 1. Toy Works of Art
description: Few children will be able to resist the quartet of endearing hand puppets that recently arrived from Switzerland to dwell in the book store of the Museum of Modern Art. The work of Cordula von Tettau and Manfred Zipfel, the puppets represent a seal, a frog, a fox and a hare, done in bright-colored cotton with amusing painted faces. The museum says they're washable and virtually indestructible. The puppets are $6 each.

title: Halfway Home for the Humanities
description: The arts and the humanities, like everything else, are going to have to do with a lot less Government money. But the recent report to the Reagan Administration from the Presidential Task Force on the Arts and Humanities should quiet fears for the National Endowments.

title: ATLAS CONSOLIDATED MINING & DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sep
CENTRAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating earnings...C-Net income; operating losses for the latest qr and 9 mos include $4,674,000 writeoff of goodwill and deferred expenses related to non-bank affiliates

title: U.S. SEEKS RETRIAL IN GUYANA DEATHS
description: The Government moved today to retry Larry Layton, 35 years old, on charges growing out of the attack at a remote airstrip in Guyana against a party led by United States Representative Leo Ryan of California, one of five persons shot to death.

title: AMICOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $424,000 extraordinary charge from the writeoff of unamortized discount on debt refunded

title: CODY BANK SUBPOENAS REPORTED
description: A Federal grand jury has subpoenaed financial records from five banks in a widening investigation of the finances of John Cardinal Cody, The Chicago Sun-Times reported today.

title: MONOCLONAL ANTIBODIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 20
HEARTY FARE OF FRANCE'S SOUTHWEST
description: FRANCE still has regions where one can drive for hours and not pass another vehicle. That is true of Quercy, in the southwest, where gently rolling hills are dotted with brilliant fields of sunflowers and where the only signs of life are, as often as not, a few waddling geese or a stray cat. There are few restaurants, and no one has ever heard of a fast-food croissant shop.

title: Columbia Film Net Off 38.3%
description: Columbia Pictures Industries Inc. said yesterday that earnings for the quarter ended Sept. 26 fell 38.3 percent from a year ago. The company blamed high interest rates and a loss from its pinball machine subsidiary.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.** Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.N.A. Not available because markets closed for Election Day.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MODULINE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes tax credits of $88,800 for the qr and $135,000 for the 6 mos

title: PROCURING THE ESSENTIALS
description: The essentials of sausage making and the preparation of pates and terrines are relatively simple and easy to procure at hardware and housewares stores and by mail.

title: Pitcher Misses a Turn
description: Fernando Valenzuela, the rookie pitching sensation of the Los Angeles Dodgers, missed the victory celebration that drew a throng of 300,000 in Los Angeles last Friday, and, because he is so popular, his absence put a damper on the proceedings. He apologized to his public, saying that he was ill but that he would have tried to make it, anyway, had he known how much he would be missed.

title: MUSIC: ZAGREB PHILHARMONIC ENDS U.S. TOUR AT CARNEGIE
description: CARNEGIE HALL is the principal New York home for visiting orchestras, and has heard most of the best. This season, there is a slightly smaller proportion of premier national and international ensembles, and a larger proportion of orchestras from more exotic spots. An example is the Zagreb Philharmonic Orchestra, which ended its first American tour there Monday night.

title: SURGEON'S SLAYING STUNS UPPER WEST SIDE
description: Two muggers who fatally shot a young resident surgeon just a block from Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center were the object yesterday of a wide police search.

title: 'Ballot Security' Signs Stir a Jersey Squabble
description: Democrats and Republicans squabbled today over signs the G.O.P. said it had posted warning that the ''National Ballot Security Task Force'' was patrolling polling areas to find election-law violators.

title: Mathieu, Gerfen Loses Perrier Account
description: Mathieu, Gerfen & Bresner has been dismissed from the Perrier account, it announced yesterday.

title: Canadian Parley Reaches 'Make-or-Break' Stage
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and Canadian provincial premiers opposed to his plans for a new constitution moved today into the ''make-or-break'' stage in negotiations aimed at a compromise solution, one of the premiers said.

title: STEIN IS RE-ELECTED, 2 TO 1, IN CONTEST AGAINST DINKINS
description: Andrew J. Stein was re-elected Borough President of Manhattan yesterday. He promised - after a campaign in which blacks failed to recapture the seat, the only one they ever held at the top of the New York City government -to ''fight for all areas of Manhattan.''

title: COLUMBIA GAS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Commonwealth Natural Resources

title: Wang Presents Audio System
description: Wang Laboratories, a leading maker of computers and word processing equipment based in Lowell, Mass., took a step yesterday toward an industry goal of producing a machine that can automatically type spoken English.

title: ORION RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NATIONAL EDUCATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GENERAL NUTRITION CORP reports earnings for 12 weeks to Oct 10
TESTS ABROAD CRAFT AIM TO UNVEIL EARTH'S SECRETS
description: To set the stage for ambitious Earth-scanning roles envisioned for future space missions, the Columbia's cargo bay carries five scientific experiments, including a high-performance mapping radar with a 30-foot-long antenna. All are designed to test the feasibility of novel observing techniques from space.

title: Index; The Elections
description: DelBello and Pisani in close race in Westchester B6 Purcell wins by landslide in Nas- sau B6 Milner elected in Hartford; re- count seen in Bridgeport B6 Henry seems winner as District Attorney in Suffolk B6 Democrats win decisive victories in four upstate cities B7 International Brazilian's bequest sets off a $12 Billion Scramble A2 Government party and allied group sweep Tunisian election A4 Weinberger says arms buildup is necessary A6 Sweden presses interrogation of Soviet submarine commander A8 West German says neutralism threaten nation A9 Possible Chinese shift on Wald- heim is hinted A10 Egyptian official calls security situation reassuring A14 Washington Talk Briefing A20 A new generation of Democratic leaders emerges in the House A20 President Reagan is a favorite of White House photographers A20 General Council of Churches seeks new vitality and purpose A16 Around the Nation A18 Newspaper says 5 banks subpoe- naed in Cody investigation A18 ''Bullet train'' service urged for U.S. A25 Suspect in Brink's case is moved to a jail in Manhattan B2 Obituaries Arthur A. Leff, professor at Yale Law School A26 Ed Libov, advertising executive active in Jewish groups A26 Living Section Food Hearty fare of France's South- west C1

title: U.S. Golfers Bow
description: Japan defeated the United States today in the Pioneer Cup women's professional golf match by a three-day total of 18 strokes. In the individual event, Hisako Higuchi beat Michiko Okada in an all-Japan playoff. Pat Bradley finished third.

title: CANADIAN CAPTURES JUMPOFF
description: Mark Laskin, a Canadian, won a seven-horse jumpoff last night but the United States team moved into a commanding lead as the National Horse Show opened at Madison Square Garden.

title: TEEN-AGE, GOOD AGE
description: I am often made to feel that my liking for teen-age company is a depraved taste. When I admit to being the mother of a 16-year-old boy, a 17-yearold girl, people look at me with commiseration and begin quite gratuitously to reassure me that it's natural to find children of this age difficult, aggressive, withdrawn, boring, noisy, rude. I listen politely, wondering if they can be referring to the same chatty, charming people I know and love so well.

title: AVATAR HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-The company said that earnings of GAC Corp as Avatar was formerly known, prior to its reorganization on Oct 1, 1980 for the respective periods in 1980 are not being represented because provisions of the reorganization plan resulted in the elimination of certain liabilities, transfer of certain assets and the restructuring of debt and equity which brought about a new entity not comparable with GAC

title: U.S. STARTS 'PROJECT TRUTH' IN BID TO COUNTER SOVIET
description: The United States International Communication Agency, responding to a Reagan Administration desire to counter Soviet propaganda, has begun a new effort of its own called ''Project Truth.''

title: MDC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
description: BLAZERS TOP LAKERS BY 102-100

title: G.M. Plant Opening Is Delayed; Company Cites Product Shifts
description: The General Motors Corporation, the No.1 domestic auto maker, said today that it would delay opening a new $500 million assembly plant being built in Detroit and adjacent Hamtramck.

title: MAJORITY LEADER IN JERSEY SENATE RETAINS HIS SEAT
description: The majority leader in the New Jersey Senate, Carmen Orechio, retained his Essex County seat last night despite a strong Republican effort to oust him.

title: Max Scherr, Radical Founder Of The Berkeley Barb in 60's
description: Max Scherr, radical founder and editor of The Berkeley Barb, which was a leading underground newspaper in the 1960's, has died of cancer less than a year after the tabloid ceased publication. He was 47 years old.

title: KIRKLAND FOR CORRUPTION CURB
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.- C.I.O., today backed legislation endorsed by the Reagan Administration to stiffen criminal penalties for union corruption, saying, ''The morals of the marketplace will not suffice.''

title: TROUBLE-FREE PREPARATIONS ELATE CREW FOR 2D SHUTTLE FLIGHT TODAY
description: The second flight of the shuttle Columbia is about to mark the first critical test of the reuse of a spaceship for scores of trips to and from the orbital frontier.

title: KANSAS CITY LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HEIST, C H, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
SPACE STUDIES ON SEEDLINGS AN EARLY STEP
description: Among the baggage scheduled to be placed aboard the space shuttle Columbia for its liftoff was an aluminum container resembling a suitcase that could hold the key to agriculture in space.

title: 'THE FIRST' DELAYS OPENING TO NOV. 17
description: Yet another Broadway show in the new season has postponed its opening. ''The First,'' a musical about Jackie Robinson, the first black baseball player in the major leagues, now in previews at the Martin Beck Theater, will open Nov. 17 instead of Nov. 12.

title: HARD CHOICE GIVEN REAGAN ON BUDGET
description: President Reagan is being told that he must accept either higher budget deficits over the next three years or ask Congress to adopt tax increases that would raise billions of dollars in that period, White House spokesmen said today.

title: REID PROVIDENT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PIONEER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ontario Hydro Bond
description: Ontario Hydro is raising $150 million through a 10-year Eurobond with a 16 percent interest-rate coupon and par pricing, bond market sources said here today. Deutsche Bank is the lead manager of the issue, which is callable after seven years at 101 1/2.

title: Loan for Peru
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York said today that it had been asked to arrange a $300 million international loan for Peru. The interest rate will be three-fourths of a percentage point above the London interbank rate.

title: REDM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $18,000 extraordinary charge

title: FLORIDA STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in Mar 1981; Net income for the latest periods was increased by 20 cents a shr for the qr and 56 cents a shr for the yr from the capitalization of interest

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny International Inc. said its Alsub Corp. subsidiary had accepted for payment 7.5 million shares of Sunbeam Corp. common stock under Allegheny's tender offer.

title: WHY MARATHON RUNNERS LOVE NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: VIRGINIA SCHONBERG
description: Virginia Schonberg, a former member of the faculty of the Graduate School of the Bank Street College of Education in Greenwich Village, where she taught social studies, died Monday in a hospital in Kennebunk, Me.

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration's plans to control illegal immigration include several little-noticed legislative proposals designed to restrict the power of the Federal courts in immigration and asylum cases.

title: SWEDEN PRESSES INTERROGATION OF SUB CAPTAIN
description: The Swedish Defense Ministry said today that the interrogation of the commander of the Soviet submarine that ran aground near a Swedish naval base a week ago would continue until he gave a satisfactory explanation of why he was there.

description: B-Includes tax credits of $195,000 for the qr and $250,000 for the 9 mos ...C-Net loss

title: DUAL-LITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INTERNORTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HUNTING AFOOT BEHIND THE CHATHAM BEAGLES
description: It was a left-footed rabbit, and it hopped from the wild-cherry thicket right out into the alfalfa field. Far in the background were the russet and gold hills of Columbia County. In the foreground, eyeing the cottontail, were 46 men, women and children, a number of them wearing black velvet caps and green and yellow hunt livery agleam with brass buttons.

title: ED LIBOV, FOUNDER OF AN AD COMPANY
description: Ed Libov, an advertising executive and a leader in Jewish charitable and civic activities, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 51 years old.

title: Late Entrance on Voting Rights
description: President Reagan, who has been in no hurry to educate himself about the need to extend the 1965 Voting Rights Act, turns to that subject at a Cabinet meeting today. It's about time. The House already has overwhelmingly approved a praiseworthy voting rights bill, and the Senate must soon consider its own version.

title: KOCH, AFTER 4 YEARS AS MAYOR, IS SEEKING NEW PATHS TO GOALS
description: As he prepares for four more years at City Hall, Mayor Koch says that key people will soon leave his administration, several of them involuntarily.

title: TIMBERLAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $141,000 gain from discontinued operations... C-After losses from discontinued operations of $21,000 for the qr and $424,000 for the 9 mos...D-Net loss

title: WORKERS VOTE TO ACCEPT BL OFFER
description: The threat of immediate and permanent closure lifted at BL Ltd. when 58,000 striking workers voted today to accept the auto maker's offer of a 3.8 percent increase in base pay.

title: AMERICAN FINANCIAL ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-The company was formed in August 1980 so there are no comparable figures...C-Including $25,740,000 extraordinary gain

title: Harvester Planning U.S.-Canada Cuts
description: The financially troubled International Harvester Company, a leading manufacturer of farm equipment, heavy-duty trucks and construction equipment, announced today that it plans to temporarily suspend manufacturing operations next month at 16 United States plants and three in Canada, idling more than 20,000 employees.

title: 12TH KARPOV-KORCHNOI GAME DRAWN
description: Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, the world chess champion, and Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland drew the 12th game of their title match at the 47th move tonight.

title: THE CHALLENGE ON DONATIONS
description: Many large corporations plan to increase their philanthropy next year, but corporate executives say that business cannot replace the billions of dollars that will be cut from the Federal budget for education, social welfare and the arts, according to a survey and interviews with business leaders.

title: Benedict to Challenge Byrd
description: Representative Cleve Benedict announced today that he would try to unseat Robert C. Byrd, the Senate minority leader, and become the first Republican Senator from West Virginia in more than 20 years.

title: Economic Scene; Will History Repeat Itself?
description: COULD another Great Depression like that of the 1930's happen now? Many economists think it was the worldwide liquidity crisis of 1931 that turned the recession of 1929-30 into the worst depression in history.

title: NO HUM BUT HO HUM
description: Let's run through it one more time to make sure I've got it right. ''O.K. One, you call for a big tax cut to get business humming again. That's called ...'' I know: supply-side economics. Now I go to the Congress and ask for the tax cut and the Democrats say no dice. What do I do next? ''You round up the votes for a big victory by offering even bigger tax cuts to Southern Democrats who are called ...'' Don't tell me, I know: the Cotton Bowls. ''Close, but no cigar. They are called the Boll Weevils. To win over the Boll Weevils you offer some really dandy tax cuts and win what in Congress?''

title: STANLEY HOME PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dr. Edward Ignall, 43, Engineering Professor
description: Dr. Edward J. Ignall, chairman of the industrial engineering department at the Columbia University School of Engineering and Applied Science, died of leukemia Friday at the M. D. Anderson Hospital in Houston. He was 43 years old and lived in Leonia, N.J.

title: DRINKING AGE TIED TO FALL IN CRASHES
description: Raising the legal drinking ages in Michigan and Maine were directly responsible for a sharp drop in automobile accidents attributed to intoxication among young drivers in those states, according to a University of Michigan study released today.

title: MOBIL LOSES ROUND IN MARATHON BID
description: The Mobil Corporation yesterday lost its petition to upset a Federal court order, granted on Monday, that restrained its $5 billion takeover bid for the Marathon Oil Company until next Tuesday. Judge Frank A. Battisti, ruling in the Federal District Court in Cleveland after a three-hour hearing, denied Mobil's request and extended the order instead to cover Marathon as well.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THERE is one combination of foods that the average cook seems to find irresistible, namely chicken in a light cream or other sauce, served with noodles. These two dishes can be prepared in a virtually endless number of variations. They can, for instance, be combined and baked with a sprinkling of cheese on top or served separately but eaten together.

title: INSTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income and after an extraordinary gain of $68,000 in the 9 mos; a change in Britain's tax laws relating to inventories resulted in an income tax benefit in the third qr of 1981 of $674,000

title: UNR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $10,560,258 gain for both periods on the sale of CATV Systems and $259,640 gain from discontinued operations. C-Net loss including gains from discontinued operations of $117,599 for the qr and $285,049 for the 9 mos

title: Market Place; Turnaround At Conair
description: IN 1978, the Conair Corporation lost Wall Street support as sales of hand-held blow dryers slowed. At the time, Conair held 25 percent of that market and its shares had done well on the company's soaring profits. But Conair's earnings plunged to 2 cents a share in the first quarter of 1978 from 29 cents in 1977's first quarter.

title: British Reserves Fall
description: Britain's gold and foreign currency reserves fell by $380 million in October, to $23.32 billion, the lowest level since December 1979, from $23.7 billion in September and $28.03 billion in October last year, the Treasury said today.

title: NATIONAL CHURCH COUNCIL SEEKING NEW VITALITY ON ECUMENICAL GOAL
description: Weakened by staff dissension, unsure of its goals and plagued by broad indifference among member churches, the National Council of Churches has scheduled four days of activity, beginning tomorrow, that council officials hope will pump new vitality into the nation's largest ecumenical agency.

title: Involving Liver
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: VICTORY MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DODGERS, ANGELS WARY ON JACKSON
description: If he were to leave the Yankees, Reggie Jackson indicated recently, his first two choices as his new team would be the Los Angeles Dodgers and the California Angels. Neither, however, seems eager to sign him as a free agent.

title: REAGAN'S QUARREL WITH SEPARATION OF POWERS
description: To the Editor:

title: ASNER VOTED PRESIDENT OF SCREEN ACTORS GUILD
description: Edward Asner, seven-time Emmy Award-winning star of the ''Lou Grant'' television series, has been elected president of the Screen Actors Guild, despite charges that he lacked the time and background necessary to head the 50,000-member union.

title: STAGE: 'CROSSING NIAGARA' ON A ROPE
description: IT isn't until very late that we realize why the Manhatttan Theater Club has chosen to open its new season with a play as ordinary as ''Crossing Niagara.'' The light dawns in the final scene, when we find ourselves transported, quite literally, to heaven.

title: Rosen to Play at Carnegie
description: L'Orchestre de la Suisse Romande, conducted by Horst Stein, will perform at Carnegie Hall on Nov. 12 at 8 P.M. Nathaniel Rosen, 1978 winner of the Tchaikovsky International Competition, will be soloist in the Dvorak Cello Concerto. The program will include the New York premiere of ''Erinerungen an Orpheus'' by Rudolf Kelterborn, a Swiss composer, and Sibelius's Symphony No. 2.

title: MAJOR BOND ISSUE AND FARMLAND PRESERVATION PROPOSAL WINNING APPROVAL IN JERSEY
description: Major bond issues to finance more water supplies, a cleanup of toxic waste sites and the start of farmland preservation were winning wide acceptance from New Jersey voters early today.

title: Ford Ailing
description: A light touch of bronchial pneumonia has forced former President Gerald R. Ford to cancel a public appearance and take to his bed. Mr. Ford had been scheduled to appear today and Friday at the University of Charleston in West Virginia as a visiting scholar, but when he became ill, his doctors ordered him to cancel his travel plans and get some rest, a spokesman said.

title: PHOTOGRAPHERS FINDING REAGAN PICTURE PERFECT
description: Earlier this year, while President Reagan was posing for cameras in the Oval Office just minutes before he was to address the nation on his economic plans, one of the photographers told Mr. Reagan he needed a two-column picture.

title: STERLING ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: B-Net income including tax credits of $20,253 for the qr and $121,665 for the 6 mos

title: 'ALL SAVERS': NO PANACEA YET
description: The sale of tax-exempt savings certificates, one of the more controversial features of President Reagan's tax package, is not living up to expectations as the program moves into its second month.

title: BURNS INTERNATIONAL SECURITY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept
description: B-Including gains from discontinued operations of $621,000 for the qr and $861,000 for the 9 mos

title: ARAFAT AND TOP SAUDIS CONFER
description: Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, met in Riyadh today with the three ranking members of the Saudi royal family to discuss Crown Prince Fahd's Middle East peace plan.

title: KOCH RE-ELECTED IN LANDSLIDE; ROBB IS THE WINNER IN VIRGINIA
description: Mayor Koch, carrying Democratic and Republican endorsements, won a second term in a landslide yesterday as Democrats swept citywide and boroughwide offices.

title: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1981; Companies
description: Florida National Banks selected New York's Chemical Bank as its merger partner. But two rejected suitors of the much-sought-after bank-holding company, Marine Midland of New York and Southeast Banking of Miami, immediately served notice that they might move to upset the deal. (Page D1.)

title: HUSSEIN OPTIMISTIC AFTER SEEING REAGAN
description: King Hussein of Jordan concluded two days of talks with President Reagan today and said that he was more confident about the future than after any of his many other visits to Washington.

title: RECOUNT IS EXPECTED IN BRIDGEPORT
description: State Representative Thirman L. Milner, who had to fight two primary election campaigns to win the Democratic nomination, was elected Mayor of Hartford yesterday as voters across Connecticut chose their municipal officials.

title: BRITISH CASINO SALE BY PLAYBOY
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc., threatened with the loss of gambling licenses for two of its three London casinos, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to sell its British gambling operations.

title: Business People; GOLD COIN TRADING: CHAIRMAN IS NAMED
description: About three years ago Walter H. Liebman, a well-known figure in the securities business and long active in the Securities Industry Association, came to the American Stock Exchange as executive assistant to the chairman in what he intended to be a one-year leave of absence from his firm. But, as Mr. Liebman noted yesterday, ''I liked it - and then the gold coin program came along.''

title: Stocks Gain; Dow Adds 1.90
description: Stock prices edged higher yesterday after two sessions of spectacular gains in response to falling interest rates. After showing small losses earlier, the Dow Jones industrial average finished at 868.72, up 1.90 points. Its combined advance on Friday and Monday came to nearly 34 points.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: She looked good. That was what they had come for, really - not to hear about how Cecil B. De Mille had called her ''young fellow,'' or how Rudolph Valentino got to be her leading man, but to see how time, which had passed over all of them just as surely, had treated her.

title: A KITCHEN SOLOIST'S HOMEMADE SAUSAGE
description: IT is fascinating how often the goings-on in a fine professional kitchen are compared to the art of dance. When several chefs work to prepare one elaborate feast or another, someone invariably notes that their movements in cutting, slicing and interchanging roles are balletlike. Similarly, a professional kitchen has been compared to an orchestra, with the executive chef as conductor and the underchefs - those who specialize in sauces, roasts, pastries and so on - working in the same harmony as do violinists or oboists in an ensemble.

title: COMPUTER ENTRY SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BEENE'S FASHIONS: FLUIDITY AND FREEDOM
description: THE giant fans that decorated the showroom and the music from ''Madame Butterfly'' were mementos of Geoffrey Beene's recent trip to Japan. The clothes, too, reflected the Orient. There were water lilies and sashes (mostly placed at the hips rather than the waist) and kimono sleeves, but the main influence was the serenity that pervaded the collection.

title: PESSIMISTIC BORROWERS
description: To the Editor:

title: ROBB OUTPOLLS COLEMAN FOR VIRGINIA GOVERNOR
description: Lieut. Gov. Charles S. Robb, son-inlaw of the late Lyndon B. Johnson, last night was elected the first Democratic Governor of Virginia in 12 years. Mr. Robb defeated State Attorney General Marshall Coleman, who had staked his campaign to maintain Republican control of the governorship here on a strong identification with President Reagan.

title: DEVELOPMENT GROUP GETS FINANCIAL AID FOR JAMAICA
description: All over the city, entities known as local development corporations have sprouted in neighborhood commercial districts. Nobody knows exactly how many there are, but 45 are taking part in governmentassisted commercial revitalization programs, the city's Office of Economic Development says.

title: A FITTING SYMBOL
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: As you will note, the health column has been caught cohabitating with Hermes, prince of knaves, rather than with Aesculapius, a well respected physician. VICTOR GOLDIN, M.D. Beth Israel Medical Center Manhattan

title: OGILVY & MATHER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After foreign currency losses of $700,000 for the qr and $2,940,000 for the 9 mos and $735,000 tax credit from the new Britain tax legislation...C-After foreign currency losses of $222,000 for the qr and $73,000 for the 9 mos and $1,308,000 refund under U.S. Britain tax treaty

title: COST AND INDIANS' OPPOSITION MAY HALT ARIZONA DAM PLAN
description: A proposal for a mammoth Arizona dam, torpedoed in the Carter Administration, has gained new life in recent years, but it may finally be blocked by its price tag and the opposition of a tiny Indian tribe.

title: CUTTER TO KEEP ZONE CLEAR OF SOVIET SHIPS WHEN ROCKETS DROP
description: The Coast Guard cutter Steadfast will try tomorrow to ''screen'' Soviet trawlers that may be in the area where the space shuttle's spent solid-fuel booster rockets are expected to fall into the Atlantic.

title: STORER BROADCASTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Casting a Vote for Resourcefulness
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato went to some pains, and some expense, to vote in yesterday's election. He had intended to spend the day in his hometown of Island Park, L.I., but had to fly to Washington late Monday for some important Senate votes, notably a transportation appropriations bill up for consideration yesterday.

title: PROFESSOR AT YALE LAW SCHOOL
description: Arthur A. Leff, who taught contracts, evidence and ethics to scores of students at the Yale Law School in the last 13 years, died of cancer Monday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 46 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGE

title: ARROW AUTOMOTIVE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
FRIENDSHIP ENDS IN THE RING
description: In the solitude of their training camps, Vonzell Johnson would sing his old Columbus, Ohio, ghetto song for Leon Spinks: ''Our neighborhood is classy, we have rats as big as Lassie.''

title: REPLACING CAMP DAVID
description: If Anwar el-Sadat were alive, he would soon find that the Camp David accords were becoming a mirage - in the Sinai only less ominously than in the West Bank and Gaza. We must wonder how he might have felt privately about Saudi Arabia's peace plan.

title: PRISON BOND VOTING ISSUE IS CLOSE
description: New York State's voters yesterday approved a constitutional amendment to expand the ability of the state's Job Development Authority to make low-interest loans to businesses.

title: A Fitting Symbol
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Displayed on page C1 of the Oct. 21 issue of The Living Section was the caduceus. It was used, as it often has been in the past, to signify an article on health or medicine.

title: Business People; HECTIC DAYS FOR T.W.A.'S FARE EXPERT
description: Neil M.
