Effman, the senior vice president of Trans World Airlines responsible for the carrier's pricing and marketing strategy, gestured at a full-page Air Florida advertisement that ran last week offering a one-way fare of $114 to Miami, Fort Lauderdale and West Palm Beach. That same day, he and his staff worked out T.W.A's response: It would meet Air Florida's lower fares for the high season between Nov. 16 and Jan. 31 to Miami and Fort Lauderdale but would keep its $135 fare to West Palm Beach.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 4, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: PURCELL WINS BY LANDSLIDE IN NASSAU ELECTION
description: Francis T. Purcell, a Republican, won a second term last night as Nassau County Executive in a landslide victory over his Democratic opponent, John W. Matthews, and the Right to Life candidate, Raymond J. Voulo.

title: No Headline
description: Miami Is Barred From Bowls Because of Recruiting Abuses

title: Soviet Food Pact Studied
description: The Reagan Administration is considering a proposal to include processed grain and other food items in a new long-term agreement with the Soviet Union, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday on Congressional redistricting incorrectly stated the change in Ohio's House seats start- ing in 1983. Now 23, it will be 21.

title: OUSTED CUOMO AIDE ADMITS SCHEME TO PAD STATE PAYROLL
description: A former high aide to Lieut. Gov. Mario Cuomo said yesterday that he had placed the names of nonexistent people on Mr. Cuomo's payroll and had cashed the checks made out to them.

title: Soviet's New Threat
description: Aleksandr Sizonenko looks like a good prospect for the Soviet Olympic basketball team. He is 7 feet 9 1/4 inches, the tallest player in Soviet basketball history, and weighs 286 pounds.

title: SUBURBAN PROPANE GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Plea on Debts By Rumania
description: Rumania, burdened with huge foreign debts, is asking Western companies to postpone their demands for repayment, Western experts said today.

title: Senate Panel Restricts Busing for Integration
description: A Senate subcommittee voted today to prohibit Federal judges from using busing as a tool for desegregating public schools.

title: LIQUID AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The yr-ago 9 mos net and shr earnings include a gain of $2 mill or 19 cents a shr from sale of certain industrial gas assets an related business in 1980

title: GTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
T.V. RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, Oct. 26, to Sunday, Nov. 1), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: Hilton and Agency Plan Hotel 'Videoguide'
description: A joint venture of the Creative Factor of Hollywood and the Hilton Hotels Corporation will be creating 96 hours of original programming that will be used on a network of closed-circuit television sets in 48 hotels owned or managed by Hilton starting Feb. 1.

title: More Kicks?
description: The deadline for the Minnesota Kicks of the North American Soccer League to find a new owner or surrender the franchise has been extended further because Rod Burwell, a local businessman, has offered to go halfway in rescuing the franchise. Burwell said he would be interested if another partner could be found. Commissioner Phil Woosnam has been here to aid in negotiations to save the financially troubled club, which carries a $450,000 debt.

title: SELAS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes tax credits of $28,000 for the qr and $69,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net income

title: REHEARING DENIED ON PLYWOOD
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit today denied an application for rehearing in a classaction case against three manufacturers that were found guilty three years ago of conspiracy in the pricing of plywood.

title: U.N. ASIANS SAY CHINA HINTS IT MAY ABSTAIN ON WALDHEIM
description: Asian diplomats said today that China had begun to hint that it might drop its veto of Secretary General Kurt Waldheim's bid for a third five-year term if the stalemate persisted in the Security Council. Chinese diplomats said they had received no instructions to shift course.

title: HOUSTON MAYOR DEFEATED
description: Voters rejected a series of key ballot issues yesterday, turning down tuition tax credits in Washington, D.C., an amendment allowing second terms for governors in Kentucky, highway bonds in West Virginia and computerized redistricting in Ohio.

title: PUGET SOUND POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
5 Voters Visit Polls In Town in Montana
description: The results of yesterday's election in this eastern Montana town, the smallest incorporated community in the state, are in.

title: BRIEFING
description: A FTER weeks of rumor and anxiety, the first personnel changes have been made at the Voice of America - two transfers that Administration officials describe as ''normal,'' but that career workers widely consider to be part of the attempt to put a new political caste on the agency's operation.

title: DOME REPORTS POTENTIALLY BIG FIND
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said tonight that initial evaluations of drilling in the Beaufort Sea ''give positive confirmation of major oil potential on Dome interest lands.''

title: EXCERPTS FROM BREZHNEV'S REPLIES TO QUESTIONS ON EAST-WEST ARMS ISSUES
description: Following are excerpts from questions submitted by Der Spiegel, the West German news magazine, to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, and his written answers as published Monday by Der Spiegel and translated by The New York Times from the German:

title: TO RID LOANS OF THE INFLATION RISK
description: To the Editor:

title: MANY DRUGS THROWN OUT, PRESLEY DOCTOR TESTIFIES
description: Dr. George Nichopoulos testified under crossexamination here today that more than half the narcotics, stimulants and sedatives he prescribed for Elvis Presley in the last three years of the singer's life were either thrown away or substituted with placebos.

title: VW Plant Closing
description: Volkswagen of America said that it will shut down its Westmoreland County assembly plant for three weeks beginning Nov. 16 because of lagging car sales, idling 4,600 workers. Although the plant will be closed, hourly employees will receive pay for three regularly scheduled holidays during the shutdown, VW said in a statement. The shutdown is the first complete production curtailment since the plant began production more than two years ago.

title: What Does the 'S' in NASA Mean?
description: In his movie comedy ''Tillie and Gus,'' W.C. Fields tries to help a young couple win a steamboat race by serving as their stoker. Discovering in mid-race that there is no more firewood, he starts chopping up the ship and feeding the pieces into the firebox. By the time the race is run he has sacrificed much of the old ship - just to keep it going.

title: DEMOCRATS WIN BIG VICTORIES IN 4 UPSTATE NEW YORK CITIES
description: Democratic Party candidates swept to decisive victories last night in municipal elections in Albany, Syracuse, Buffalo and Rochester. The longest-serving big-city mayor in the United States, Erastus Corning 2d of Albany, defeated his opponent by more than 2 to 1 in his bid for an unprecedented 11th term.

title: Arizona Bowler Takes Final and World Cup
description: Robert Worrall, a 24-year-old graduate of Northern Arizona University, won the 1981 Bowling World Cup at Madison Square Garden yesterday, defeating Manny Magno of the Philippines in the final match, 221-179.

title: Opportunity Knocks
description: Citing the opportunity to enter private business, Bill Raftery, the basketball coach at Seton Hall since 1970, announced his resignation. ''I regret leaving Seton Hall and basketball, but this is for the betterment of my family,'' he said. Under Raftery, who is 39 years old, the Pirates won 156 games and lost 140.

title: TUNISIAN REGIME SWEEPS ELECTION
description: The Tunisian Government announced today that no opposition member was elected to the new National Assembly on Sunday in the nation's first multiparty elections in 25 years of independence.

title: 25% of Draft-Age Men Have Not Yet Registered
description: About 25 percent of all young men required to register with the Selective Service have not done so, according to the agency. The Government and an antidraft leader differ over what the figure means.

title: Death Precedes Election
description: Mayor Frank DiMaio, who was unopposed for re-election on the ballot here today, died yesterday of cancer. He was 60 years old. Mr. DiMaio, a Republican, was employed by the Scott Paper Company plant in Chester.

title: Lowell Mayor Injured At a Campaign Stop
description: Mayor Robert Maguire followed the city election returns from a hospital bed today after he broke a leg while doing some last-minute campaigning.

title: Polish Union Closes Its Office in New York
description: The New York office of the independent Polish trade union Solidarity was closed Friday, less than two months after it opened, according to a statement issued by the office's director.

title: ROCKETS DEFEAT KNICKS
description: The Houston Rockets, a team that relies on tough inside play and ball control, used both tactics effectively tonight in defeating the Knicks, 101-98. The physical aspect of the game was underscored by the 66 personal fouls that sent the Rockets to the free-throw line for 47 shots and the Knicks for 37.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Avantek Inc. announced that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission on a proposed public offering of one million shares of common stock, to be underwritten by a Kidder, Peabody group.

title: AMBASSADOR GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHY MARATHON RUNNERS LOVE NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATORS WEIGHING CLEAN AIR ACT HINT MAJOR CHANGES ARE UNLIKELY
description: The Senate Environment and Public Works Committee began drafting its amendments to the Clean Air Act today by unanimously agreeing to leave unchanged the health standards on which the national air quality rules are based.

title: Jets Defeat Rockies, 5-3, As DeBlois Scores Two
description: Lucien DeBlois scored two goals tonight to help the Winnipeg Jets defeat the Colorado Rockies, 5-3.

title: FOOTLOOSE IN MANHATTAN (IN SNEAKERS)
description: ''GOOD grief, Michaele!'' said my mother, who was visiting from Boston. ''Is that the way you dress for work?'' I can't help it. Walking to work and home again - five miles round trip - has turned me into the kind of woman, the scourge of mothers, who wears sneakers all day long in midtown Manhattan.

title: HARRIMAN AT 90
description: Averell Harriman, former Governor of New York, Secretary of Commerce, Ambassador to London and Moscow, among many other things, will be 90 in a few days, and he reminds us not of how old he is but of how young this Republic is.

title: IOWA PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CABINET IN EGYPT GIVEN REASSURANCE
description: Egypt's Interior Minister, who is in charge of the investigation into the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat, told the Cabinet today that the country's security situation was ''extremely reassuring.''

title: MILL TO BE RESTRUCTURED
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to restructure its main steel mill and that its president and chief executive officer, Roland A. Kjelland, had voluntarily resigned.

title: INTERNATIONAL FLAVORS & FRAGRANCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LAKE SHORE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: Martin Willsted points out that Foo Chow, a restaurant on Third Avenue near 73d Street, has a Sunday-brunch sign in its window, offering ''WANTON SOUP.''

title: When Robert Redford's Asleep, He's Asleep
description: Robert Redford was asleep early yesterday morning when two burglars climbed up a fire escape and slipped into his Fifth Avenue apartment through a bathroom window.

title: CONSOLIDATED NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss; net income for the latest 9 mos includes a gain equal to 75 cents a shr from the sale in the second qr of Canadian gas and oil properties

title: Taking Off on Wings of Nuptial Bliss
description: The first time Gerd Burla saw Manhattan was four years ago when he flew in on a plane from Chicago. ''It was 4 in the afternoon and the setting sun was behind us,'' he recalled yesterday.

title: SUSPECT IN BRINK'S CASE IS MOVED TO FEDERAL JAIL
description: The only person charged in the armoredcar robbery and slayings Oct. 20 in Rockland County who was not in a Federal jail was transferred today from the Rockland County Jail in a heavily guarded police convoy to the Metropolitan Correctional Facility on Foley Square in Manhattan.

title: WEST GERMAN CONSERVATIVE WARNS OF NEUTRALISM
description: Helmut Kohl, the chairman of the Christian Democratic Party, told its national convention today that the future of West Germany was threatened by neutralism and nationalism that could eventually lead to the destruction of the Atlantic alliance.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You bet your life we are ready. Everything's looking beautiful.'' -Col. Joe H. Engle, space shuttle astronaut.

title: 43 STORE CLOSINGS AT A. & P. EXPECTED
description: The loss-ridden Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company is reported to be planning another major round of store closings, but its plan to use surplus funds from its pension program to offset the costs has drawn a lawsuit from a former senior company executive.

title: AMERICAN INDIAN ART GOING TO CHINA
description: A show that combines American painting of the Old West and Indian artifacts of the Americas, the first such exhibition sent to China, will open Nov. 19 at the Museum of Chinese History in Peking. The exhibition, comprising 80 historical paintings of the American West and nearly 600 objects from the Indian cultures of North and South America, is a combined venture of the Museum of the American Indian in New York and the Anschutz Collection of Denver.

title: TAX-EXEMPT PRICES ADVANCE
description: The Election Day holiday interrupted a busy financing week for the United States Treasury yesterday, with the closing of the New York Federal Reserve Bank halting trading in Treasury securities and money market instruments.

title: Business People; DEVELOPMENT ASSISTANCE UNIT AT O.E.C.D. GETS CHAIRMAN
description: Rutherford M. Poats, 59, a specialist in economic aid, has been elected chairman of the development assistance committee of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, effective Jan. 1. He will succeed John P. Lewis, 60, at the Paris-based organization.

title: Columbia, L.I.U. Tie In Soccer Overtime, 1-1
description: Columbia and Long Island University played to a 1-1 overtime tie yesterday at the Blackbirds' field in Brooklyn.

title: DELINQUENT YOUTHS' DELINQUENT PARENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Dennis E. Rich has been appointed vice president of sales and marketing at Kurlash/Diamon Deb Ltd.

title: MICHIGAN SCHOOL DISTRICT REOPENS WITHOUT BUSES
description: About one-third of the students in the Alpena school district stayed home in an apparent protest over lack of bus service when classes resumed today for the first time in more than two weeks.

title: AFGHAN REBEL LOSSES REPORTED
description: Western diplomats here quoted Afghan informants today as having said that overconfidence and sloppy security measures by guerrillas had been responsible for recent rebel setbacks.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN, the tennis pro Eddie Dibbs and the actress Carol Channing are among the more than 14 million Americans who have turned to contact lenses to improve their vision without obscuring their visages with a second pair of ''eyes.''

title: CONTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BEST BUYS
description: THIS fall, fruits and vegetables are of better quality and in many cases cheaper than a year ago. ''The weather conditions both locally and in Florida have been ideal,'' said Michael Pflueger, a Hunts Point spokesman. ''Last year was unusually dry but this year there has been adequate moisture for local crops and there have been no severe freezing temperatures in growing areas. Meanwhile, the Florida crop is ahead of schedule because they have not had the normal amount of tropical storms that often cause heavy losses.''

title: 2 Posing as Police Rob Salesman in Brooklyn
description: Two men posing as police officers and riding in what appeared to be a police car stole 16 jackets and 144 sweaters worth about $2,000 from a clothing salesman in Brooklyn yesterday, the police said.

title: HAUSERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
News Analysis
description: The latest wobbling in American Middle East policy points up the difficulty Washington has in simultaneously supporting Israel and seeking influence with moderate Arab countries.

title: A Cougar Showdown
description: When Gifford Nielsen wrote all the passing records as Brigham Young's quarterback during his senior year, Marc Wilson was a freshman waiting for his chance. What Wilson did the next season might not have made Cougar fans forget Nielsen, but it did leave many wondering who was better. Sunday the fans may get a chance to compare.

title: Sgt. Lew Jenkins
description: IT takes a special talent to be a disgrace to boxing, and it is utterly inconceivable that such a man could wind up in a hero's grave in Arlington National Cemetery, but Lew Jenkins was equal to both challenges.

title: Bridge: Rebidding Five-Card Suit Requires Show of Support
description: A basic rule of bidding, belonging in Lesson three of a beginners course, is regularly fractured, for no good reason, by a very high percentage of relatively experienced players. It is this: Never rebid a five-card suit unless partner has indicated some support.

title: Turkish Court Sentences Ex-Premier to Jail
description: Bulent Ecevit, a former Prime Minister and the chairman of the defunct Republican Peoples' Party, was sentenced to four months in jail today by an Ankara military court for criticizing the military Government.

title: JOHN O'REILLY
description: John (Tex) O'Reilly, who reported nature and animal stories for The New York Herald Tribune and served as a war and foreign correspondent, died last Saturday at Sibley Hospital in Washington.

title: Careers
description: THE regulatory proliferation under the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, the Toxic Substances Control Act, the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, the Clean Air Act, the Consumer Product Safety Act and numerous state laws may have created a host of complications for businessmen and corporate executives. But they have opened up new opportunities for trained personnel in the health field.

title: DELTA DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss; shr earnings are fully diuted

title: Boeing Plans More Layoffs
description: The Boeing Company, the world's leading producer of commercial aircraft, said it expects to furlough an additional 1,300 employees by the end of the year because of a slowdown in airline orders.

title: Applied Devices' Debt Restructure
description: The Applied Devices Corporation said that it had agreed with three of its lenders on a plan to restructure the company's bank debt.

title: ATLANTIC CITY RUSHING TO MOVE WELLS
description: While residents of nearby Farmington fly white flags to signal their need to have water delivered, this casino resort is rushing to relocate its municipal well field.

title: Regan Plans Trip to China
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan will visit China in mid-November for an economic meeting and for talks on wide-ranging topics with Chinese officials, Treasury officials said today.

title: West Germans Protest New Frankfurt Runway
description: Thousands of demonstrators marched in five German cities today to protest the construction of a third runway at Frankfurt's international airport.

title: TV: 'OTHER VICTIM,' EFFECTS OF RAPE
description: TELEVISION has long had a special fondness for rape stories. Television movies wrapped in pious motivations have featured the horrifying violations of housewives, divorcees, swinging singles, teen-age runaways and female and male prisoners. Tonight at 9 o'clock, CBS-TV manages to find a new angle for the subject in ''The Other Victim,'' who turns out to be the husband of the suburban mother who is raped.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE GOOD WORD

title: Comings and Goings
description: Normand Leveille, a left wing who was the Boston Bruins' No. 1 draft choice last spring, will be lost to the team about a month because of strained knee ligaments. ... Mary T. Meagher, who broke her world records in the 100- and 200-meter butterfly in 1981, has been named American swimmer of the year by United States Swimming, the national governing body. ... Manager Earl Weaver of the Baltimore Orioles, who was arrested on drunken-driving charges several weeks ago, has lost his license for 60 days.

title: GATT Seeks Trade Accord
description: The United States and three European countries - France, Belgium and the Netherlands - moved today to drop charges over export subsidies at a meeting of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The two sides indicated they would accept a 1976 ruling by a GATT panel that said they had broken international trade rules by giving tax concessions to exporters.

title: Joseph Fountain, 82, Witness To Coolidge's Oath of Office
description: Former Mayor Joseph Fountain, one of six witnesses to the swearing-in ceremony of Calvin Coolidge as President 58 years ago, died Sunday in Eustis, Fla.

title: Excerpts from statement, page A6.
description: Soviet newspapers published a statement today by Leonid I. Brezhnev rejecting the idea that Moscow might launch a preventive nuclear strike and disclosing unusual details about Soviet deployment of medium-range missiles in Europe.

title: AGRA INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Yr to July 31
description: B-Including special gains of $2,587,973 for the latest yr and $149,093 for the previous yr

title: EMERSON AND INTERNORTH POST NET GAINS
description: The Emerson Electric Company reported yesterday that its earnings in the fourth quarter of the fiscal year 1981, ended Sept. 30, increased 22.8 percent as sales climbed 17.1 percent.

title: MOTION TO DISMISS SHAVE CHARGE AGAINST EX-PLAYER DENIED
description: A motion for dismissal of the Government's indictment against Rick Kuhn, one of five defendants in the Boston College point-shaving case, was quickly turned down yesterday by the judge who is presiding over the trial at United States District Court in Brooklyn.

title: LIBYA CALLED READY TO QUIT CHAD
description: President Goukouni Oueddei of Chad said today that Libyan troops would leave Chad as he had requested, the French news agency reported. He did not indicate a departure date.

title: UP-RIGHT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ASTREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fingers Cy Young Winner
description: Rollie Fingers, the 35-year-old relief ace of the Milwaukee Brewers who led the major leagues in saves with 28, was named the American League's Cy Young Award winner yesterday.

title: The Talk of Cape Canaveral
description: Down an oyster shell road in a tubercular Model T came William B. Lewis with a pocketful of dreams. It was his design, then in the winter of 1922, to raise tomatoes on a sandy knuckle called canaveral, from the Spanish word for canebrake. That he did, until the Federal Government bought him out in 1950, and began hurling missiles off his patch.

title: THE STONES ROLL ON, REFUSING TO BECOME SHOW-BUSINESS SLICK
description: THE Rolling Stones visited Atlanta for about five hours last week - just enough time to land their chartered jet, race into town to the Fox Theater, play a two-hour set, race back to the airport and take off for Houston, the next stop on their 1981 American tour. The tour is expected to be the most profitable in the history of rock-androll; its sheer size has been staggering. It began with the group's having to add a second show in Philadelphia's immense John F. Kennedy Stadium, which seats about 92,000, and will probably end with two shows at the New Orleans Superdome. The band's five shows in the New York area, which begin tomorrow night at the Brendan T. Byrne Sports Arena in New Jersey's Meadowlands, will accommodate a total of nearly 150,000. That looks like an impressive figure, but ticket requests for these shows ran into the millions.

title: SPECTRA-PHYSICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AROUND THE NATION
description: Move, the self-styled revolutionary movement, is not a religion, and one of its members is not entitled to a special diet in prison because of his beliefs, a three-judge appeals panel has ruled.

title: EX-AIDE CALLS JAPANESE INTERNMENT 'HUMANE'
description: John J. McCloy, former Assistant Secretary of War, today defended the internment of Japanese-Americans in World War II as ''reasonably undertaken and thoughtfully and humanely conducted.''

title: Sedco Ends Stake
description: Sedco Inc., a leading offshore driller, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had sold 556,400 shares of the Delhi International Oil Company to Patson Investments Ltd. for $78 a share, or a total of $43.4 million, and no longer owns any shares of Delhi.

title: TOP PROSECUTOR IN SUFFOLK TAKES A STRONG LEAD
description: The Suffolk County District Attorney, Patrick Henry, appeared early today to have won an easy victory over his Democratic challenger, Paul Giannelli.

title: WASHINGTON FOLLOW-UP
description: At first, Samuel Dash was reluctant to listen to the Watergate tapes. He didn't want anybody to think he was ''a vulture picking over the bones.''

title: KEY RATE LIST CHANGE
description: Beginning today, the Key Rates box will list the highest permissible rate for six-month savings certificates. The maximum rate will continue to change weekly according to results of the latest auction of six-month Treasury bills. The published rate is the higher of either one-quarter percentage point more than the average sixmonth bill rate, or one-quarter percentage point more than the average of the last four auctions of six-month Treasury bills.

title: Justice Dept. Challenges Phone Ruling by F.C.C.
description: The Justice Department has joined several trade groups in challenging the Federal Communications Commission's landmark deregulation ruling that would permit the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to enter new and unregulated fields.

title: SUSQUEHANNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $532,000 extraordinary gain...C-Net loss including $1,050,000 extraordinary gain for the 9 mos

title: STRUGGLING FOKKER PLANS BIG PROJECT
description: The Fokker Aircraft Company has been feeling the pressure lately. Its civil aircraft production has not been large enough to increase profits, and its military output - Fokker makes F-16 fighters under license - is scheduled to taper off in the mid-1980's.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Something has puzzled me for a good many years: why some restaurants advertise their fare as ''continental cuisine.'' Can you tell me what continental cuisine consists of?

title: CHEMICAL IS CHOSEN FOR MERGER
description: The management of Florida National Banks of Florida Inc., the much-sought-after bank-holding company, announced yesterday that it had chosen New York's Chemical Bank as its merger partner.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard A BETTER CLASS OF PERSON. An Auto- biography. By John Osborne. 285 pages. Dutton. $13.75.

title: Transit Report Cites Overtime
description: Major subway repairs, employee vacancies and poor training have caused overtime costs to soar at the Transit Authority, according to a report issued by the agency yesterday.

title: CANADA'S ADVANCES ON ENERGY CONTROL
description: Canada's controversial national energy program is a year old, and the country has moved considerably closer to its goal of attaining 50 percent Canadian ownership of the oil and gas industry by 1990.

title: Excerpts from memo, page A10.
description: The State Department has outlined a need for a strong human rights policy in foreign affairs after a period of inaction on the matter.

title: ROCK-JAZZ: FRANK ZAPPA
description: THE last of five Frank Zappa Halloween concerts at the Palladium on Sunday proved to be an unexpectedly magnificent mixture of rock-jazz surrealism and social satire. Mr. Zappa and his eight-piece band wove together some 20 Zappa songs into a sprawling, unstructured oratorio - two hours of uninterrupted music - that offered a musical rollercoaster ride through a dozen styles, including rap, reggae, heavy metal and television-incidental.

title: Home Improvement; MAINTAINING AND REPAIRING TILE FLOORS OF SLATE
description: ALTHOUGH slate and quarry tile are considered primarily a paving material for walks and terraces, they are also quite popular for floors in entrance halls, kitchens and bathrooms, as well as for fireplace hearths. Much of this appeal is because of the attractive, luxurious appearance, but another reason is that many people mistakenly expect such floors to be virtually maintenance-free.

title: New York Tax Burden Is $1,495 Per Person
description: New York continues to outstrip every state except Alaska in the average amount of taxes its residents pay, according to a statewide taxpayer research group.

title: PROSECUTION OUTLINES ITS CASE IN TRIAL ON 'FREEWAY KILLINGS'
description: Prosecutors said today that William Bonin, a sex offender, carefully planned the torture slayings of 12 young men and boys, and drove out on southern California freeways in a ''death van'' searching for hitchhikers.

title: CRISS GETS 20 AS HAWKS TO NETS, 95-86
description: The program lists him at 5 feet 8 inches tall. And Charlie Criss, an Atlanta Hawks reserve, seems even smaller than that as he weaves among the redwoods that dominate a basketball court. Tonight, however, he dazzled the frustrated Nets, scoring 20 points to tie his teammate, Dan Roundfield, for game-high honors as the Hawks defeated the Nets, 95-86, before a crowd of 12,260 at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: RECOUNT IS SET FOR TOMORROW IN BRIDGEPORT'S MAYORAL RACE
description: Election officials in Bridgeport, Conn., scheduled a recount for tomorrow after the three-term Democratic Mayor was apparently unseated by his Republican challenger.

title: CHEAP, UNRELIABLE AND TRIUMPHANT
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Patco Decertification Vote Is Switched From 2-1 to 3-0
description: The Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization suffered a new rebuff when the vote of a Federal agency stripping it of its status was changed, from 2 to 1 to 3 to 0.

title: 2 ON A SEESAW: A LONG NIGHT IN NEW JERSEY
description: ''We're not calling on Florio to concede, but we are not making a victory speech either,'' Thomas H. Kean's campaign manager, Roger Bodman, told reporters at 1 A.M. this morning at the Holiday Inn in Livingston. ''It will be a long night.''

title: U.S. DROPS ARAB SATELLITE PLANS
description: Stung by Congressional criticism, the Reagan Administration today withdrew a plan to sell communications satellite equipment to an Arab consortium that includes Libya and the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Credits for Mexico
description: Mexico's state industrial development bank, Nacional Financiera, is seeking a $250 million Eurocredit and special drawing rights of the same amount, a Mexican Finance Ministry spokesman said today. The spokesman said the eightyear credit deal would be lead-managed by the Chemical Bank, with four years of grace, at an interest rate of five-eighths of 1 percent above London interbank offered rates.

title: Jazz: Thelonious Monk Performed by 4 Pianists
description: THELONIOUS MONK has not been heard playing his distinctively edgy compositions since the mid-1970's and, although his material is played fairly frequently by other musicians, primarily ''Round Midnight,'' it has not received the attention that a composer of his originality deserves.

title: Screening for TB Begun At Prison in Michigan
description: Corrections officials began tuberculosis tests today on 5,200 inmates and 700 guards at Michigan's largest prison after a dozen cases of the disease were detected among prisoners in the last year.

title: BIG 3 AUTO SALES DOWN 19.7% FOR END OF OCTOBER
description: The nation's Big Three auto makers said today that sales of new cars fell 19.7 percent in the last 10 days of October and 27.2 percent for the month, to the lowest October selling rate since 1958, despite rebates and other incentive programs.

title: Critic's Notebook; SEPARATING CONCRETE FROM ABSTRACT
description: WHEN Peter Capone, president of the architectural office of Edward Durell Stone, described his firm's design for a tower that the developer Howard Ronson has proposed to build over the community house of St. Bartholomew's Church on Park Avenue, he spoke in terms of ''an appropriate and harmonious element in the urban fabric.'' Mr. Capone called the glass tower ''crystal-like and faceted'' and said it would ''reflect the church dome and the neighboring buildings and the blue of the sky'' for an ''ever-changing'' appearance.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: Trudeau Proposes a Vote On Bill of Rights
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, faced with the imminent failure of his latest attempt to gain wide provincial support for constitutional change, proposed to the 10 provincial premiers today that the issue be voted on in a national referendum in two years.

title: Phelps Dodge Mine
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the nation's largest copper producer, said it would suspend operations at its Tyrone copper mine from Dec. 23 through Jan. 1, idling nearly 900 employees without pay, in a move to cut inventories. The shutdown, the second Phelps Dodge cutback this year in New Mexico, was attributed to lower prices for copper, which has fallen to about 81 cents a pound.

title: HAIG IS SAID TO PRESS FOR MILITARY OPTIONS FOR SALVADOR ACTION
description: A consensus has developed in the Reagan Administration that the civil war in El Salvador has reached a stalemate that will eventually cause the defeat of the Government unless the United States takes decisive action soon, according to key Administration officials.

title: An Appraisal
description: It was completed in 1913, before most of the people who work in it today were born, and its $13.5 million cost was paid for, immediately, in cash. It has never had a mortgage, it has almost always been fully rented and it has never changed hands. The Woolworth Building is still owned by the F. W. Woolworth

title: Two Canadian Nuns in Brazil Are Given Police Protection
description: Two Canadian Roman Catholic nuns were granted police protection to continue their work after being threatened with expulsion from a poor northeastern village, the Canadian Embassy said today.

title: No Headline
description: 3 STASTNYS LEAD NORDIQUES, 6-2

title: Solar Energy Homes
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: It is truly unfortunate that Paul Goldberger equates energy conservation with spareness and limitation (''Assessing Solar House Architecture,'' Oct. 15) when he suggests that ''our esthetic leadership has, in a sense, made a conscious decision to render energy concerns less than crucial.'' His orderly and abstract villas of richness and plenty represent elitist profligacy and waste, often ignoring human needs for warmth, nature, comfort and convenience.

title: Husband Defeats Wife
description: It was a gently fought race, and when it was over yesterday, G. Ferril Heaton had scored a five-vote mayoral victory over Dorothy Heaton, his wife. Mr. Heaton, a high school teacher, received 10 votes, Town Clerk Orval K. Palmer 8 and Mrs. Heaton 5. The town has 71 people. Each Heaton had endorsed the other.

title: Since Budapest
description: The reason people routinely ask whether the Soviet Union will invade Poland is 25 years old this week. The reason is Hungary, 1956.

title: AM International Gains Loan Delay
description: AM International Inc. said that the 19 United States banks participating in its $106 million revolving credit agreement had waived for 45 days their right to declare the company in loan default.

title: Penn Central-Colt Vote Not Ready
description: For the third time in a week, the Penn Central Corporation has reconvened and adjourned a special shareholders meeting regarding its proposed acquisition of Colt Industries ''because the vote count is not yet completed.''

title: Jersey Trotting Under Inquiry
description: Federal prosecutors have subpoenaed records from this year's harness racing meeting at the Meadowlands as part of a reported investigation into possible race-fixing by drivers at that track and perhaps at Freehold Raceway, also in New Jersey.

title: 'ODD MARRIAGES' IN A STORE'S MODEL ROOM
description: ''THIS is not a collection for me,'' said the interior designer Andree Putman, in her husky, accented English. ''It is a series of love affairs. I met these pieces as one meets people. At first we were strangers, but now we are like old and dear friends.''

title: Celtics 115, Bulls 93
description: BOSTON (UPI) - Larry Bird and Kevin McHale combined for 47 points to pace Boston. Bird collected 26 points, all in the first and third quarters, and McHale, scoring in the second and fourth periods, added 21. The Celtics (2-1) downed the Bulls (1-3) for the 10th time in their last 11 meetings. Reggie Theus led Chicago with 26. Boston took command with a 17-3 spurt in the first quarter. After the score had gone to 25-13, Chicago began to close the gap, and it was 27-21 at the end of the period.The Celtics moved to a 53-46 halftime lead, and began the third quarter with a 7-0 burst that made the score 60-46. Boston shot 56 percent in the third quarter to Chicago's 23. The lead soared to 24 points once.

title: Notes on People; Deceptive Appearances and Unexpected Largess
description: William Morse lived like a pauper, so it seemed only natural that when he fell down some hotel stairs in Minneapolis a while back, he would not spend very much for someone to take care of him.

title: Vietnam Veteran Takes 6 Captive at Newspaper
description: A Vietnam War veteran took six newspaper employees hostage at gunpoint today, saying he was angry over continued news media attention to the former American hostages in Iran while his fellow veterans were ignored.

title: CENSUS STUDY FINDS BLACKS' DIVORCE RATE IS RISING
description: WASHINGTON (UPI) - Divorced American men are remarrying more often than divorced women, and the divorce rate for both black men and black women is soaring, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: BALANCE SHEET
description: Florida National Banks followed such conservative strategies under the stewardship of Edward W. Ball, the late financier, that it has the lowest return on assets of any major bank in Florida and a limited presence in some fast-growing areas, according to banking analysts.

title: SWEDES DENY BACKING OFF IN SUB AFFAIR
description: The Swedish Government denied today that it was backing off in its negotiations with the Soviet Union over the Soviet submarine that ran aground in a military zone.

title: Common Market Reprimands Turkey on Jailing Ex-Premier
description: The Common Market today denounced the Turkish military junta for having jailed former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit and said aid to Turkey might be cut off unless democracy was restored.

title: BRINGING SHAKER-STYLE FURNITURE BACK TO LIFE
description: THE scenario goes something like this: A furniture craftsman with little or no experience sees a piece of Shaker furniture in a museum or antique shop or perhaps even in a book. The simplicity of the design encourages him to try his hand at copying it. Whether the task turns out to be as simple as the style or not, he is hooked on Shaker.

title: MOST STATE BOND ISSUES WIN VOTER APPROVAL
description: Voters appear to have approved most of the more than $3 billion in tax-exempt bond issues on ballots in seven states in Tuesday's elections.

title: TREASURES RE-CREATED
description: ''ICONSIDER that decanter and stopper the quintessential designs that you would think had already existed, but they didn't,'' said John Loring, executive vice president and design director of Tiffany & Company. ''I've never seen a stopper like that - it's like a diamond. And the decanter is simple and perfectly proportioned.''

title: New York Air Cuts Boston Run Dec. 1
description: New York Air, blaming effects of the air traffic controllers' strike, said it would suspend its New York-to-Boston service effective Dec. 1.

title: House Votes Center Funds
description: Legislation authorizing up to $3 million for the Carl Albert Congressional Research and Studies Center was passed by voice vote today in the House.

title: Cold Males, Neo-females
description: Audubon magazine reports that nesting temperatures on the beach help determine the sex of hatchling sea turtles. Warmer nests produce females; cooler nests, baby males. We were reminded that jack-in-thepulpit plants tend to become male in years when undernourishment has left them weak, but female when local conditions have infused the same flower with renewed strength.

title: JETS' TODD ROUGHS UP REPORTER
description: Richard Todd, the Jets' quarterback, injured a reporter for The New York Post today by shoving him into a locker and then to the floor during the pre-practice time allotted for interviews at the team's camp here.

title: HEADS OF PARTY, UNION AND CHURCH CONFER IN POLAND
description: The heads of the Polish Communist Party, the Solidarity labor union and the Roman Catholic Church met today for the first time to discuss setting up a permanent body to try to resolve the nation's difficulties.

title: Hers
description: KENNEDY to Frankfurt, Frankfurt to Geneva, Geneva to Nice: everything on schedule, each transfer smooth as tissue paper. Time after time I checked the contents of my purse, ticked them off like staples on a grocery list: tickets, baggage claim checks, passport, travelers' checks, address book. Sophisticated world traveler, 50 years old, and off to France for three months, away from husband, children, home ... on my own.

title: AUCTION AND EXHIBITION POINT UP SHAKER POPULARITY
description: THROUGHOUT the 1970's interest quickened in the Shakers, the celibate religious sect that flourished from the late 18th century through the early 20th. At the height of the communal organization's influence, between 1830 and 1860, members produced superbly crafted furnishings for their own use and to sell to others. These designs, although based on existing styles, seemed distinctively different because the Shakers were masters at refining details and disdained surface ornament.

title: Formal Medical Report On President Is Issued
description: The formal report on the results of President Reagan's recent medical examinaton says that he appears to be in ''excellent health'' and has no specific medical complaints except for a cold that has been rapidly improving.

title: NEW YORK-AREA ARENAS GIRD FOR ROLLING STONES
description: The Rolling Stones are about to hit the New York area and officials at the buildings they will play in are talking about barricades and guards and secret ''options.''

title: SUN BELT RISE IN WAGES AIDS NEW YORK IN BUSINESS BATTLE
description: In a trend that could help New York and other Northern cities become more competitive, the salaries and benefits of municipal workers in the Sun Belt have begun catching up with those of their Northern counterparts.

title: Warde B. Ogden, 77; Accounting Executive
description: Warde B. Ogden, a former partner in Price Waterhouse & Company, the accounting concern, died Saturday at his home in Sedona, Ariz. He was 77 years old and a former resident of Manhattan.

title: JACKSON STUNNED BY DEAL
description: George Steinbrenner, the aggressive Yankee owner who says that he believes in perfection, showed again yesterday that he also believes in persistence.

title: A Democrat Is Elected As Sheriff in Rockland
description: Rockland County has elected Thomas J. Goldrick, an educator in the criminal justice field and a former New York City police officer, as its next Sheriff. He defeated the 74-year-old Raymond A. Lindemann, who has held the job since 1966.

title: AMERICAN RIDERS TAKE NATIONS CUP AT GARDEN
description: With perfect rides by three of its four members, the United States team won the Nations Cup in the international jumping competition yesterday at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden.

title: News Anaylsis
description: Despite predictably partisan differences in explaining the immediate meaning of Tuesday's elections around the country, professionals in both parties found at least two important messages in the results, and each of them contained a warning for the Republicans.

title: Lukens Layoffs
description: The Lukens Steel Company, a specialty steelmaker, said that it had laid off 107 more workers because of reduced orders.

title: Power Failure in El Salvador Blacks Out a Third of Country
description: A power failure that the authorities suspect was a result of sabotage blacked out eastern El Salvador today.

title: A CHANGE DUE IN GOVERNMENT IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: Voter approval of a proposal to change the municipal government here from the present commission form to a mayor-council system will force new elections in May for control of City Hall.

title: Moderate Quake Jolts Reno
description: A moderate earthquake jolted this city in western Nevada early today, shaking residents in their beds while gamblers in downtown casinos shook dice and played the slots, apparently unaware of the temblor. The quake, which struck at 3:47 A.M., measured 3.8 on the Richter scale, the University of Nevada-Reno Seismological Laboratory reported.

title: Columbia Names Engineering Dean
description: Columbia University has appointed Prof. Robert A. Gross as the 12th dean of the School of Engineering and Applied Science. Dr. Gross, who is 54 years old and is the chairman of the Department of Applied Physics and Nuclear Engineering, has been a professor at Columbia since 1960. He succeeds Peter W. Linkins, who was appointed provost for the professional schools more than a year ago.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 5, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets at 3 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: JERSEY ELECTION POSED PROBLEMS FOR TV NEWS UNITS
description: The chief of polling operations for CBS News said yesterday that ''I sure made a mistake somewhere.'' That mistake led WCBS-TV to announce incorrectly at 8 P.M. Tuesday that Representative James J. Florio had been elected Governor of New Jersey.

title: COMPLAINTS ON IMPORTS OF STEEL
description: A year-old truce over steel imports is ending, raising the specter of another major trade confrontation as the United States and major steel exporting countries struggle to preserve jobs as economies weaken.

title: No Headline
description: ACTION ON TAXES AND RIGHTS REJECTED BY NATION'S VOTERS

title: Braniff Trims Fare Structure
description: In a back-to-basics move, Braniff Airways said that it was reducing the number of fares on its domestic flights to 15 from the current 582 and eliminating distinctions between first-class and coach service.

title: Circulations Bureau Names New President
description: M. David Keil, a 50-year-old former ad agency man, is the new president and managing director of the Audit Bureau of Circulations, an organization made up of 5,000 media, ad agencies and advertisers. The Audit Bureau of Circulations has the critically important function of verifying circulation claims of print publications.

title: Ansel Adams to Receive $20,000 Photo Award
description: Ansel Adams, the photographer, will receive the 1981 Hasselblad gold medal and $20,000 for his work as a teacher and ''master of photographic technique'' in a ceremony Nov. 18 at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: TECHNOLOGY
description: BOTH the telephone system and cable television are vying to provide electronic home information services that will allow consumers to read news reports on their television screens or to shop or bank at home. Now, in a new twist, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is trying to interest cable companies in a joint venture that would use both sets of wires.

title: RANGER LAPSES HELP PENGUINS WIN, 6-3
description: The Rangers did most of the things tonight that Coach Herb Brooks has been telling them not to do, and the result was a 6-3 loss to the Pittsburgh Penguins at the Civic Arena.

title: U.N. Still in Deadlock On Secretary General
description: The United States and China continued to veto each other's candidates tonight, prolonging the Security Council's effort to choose a Secretary General.

title: EXCERPTS FROM STATE DEPARTMENT MEMO ON HUMAN RIGHTS
description: Following are excerpts from a memorandum to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. from Deputy Secretary of State William P. Clark and Richard T. Kennedy, Under Secretary of State for Management, on human rights policy:

title: New Chief To Diversify At Giddings
description: Giddings & Lewis Inc., a leading machine tool manufacturer based in Fond du Lac, Wis., has named a new president and chief executive officer who intends to take the company more heavily into the industrial products field.

title: Gardening; END-OF-SEASON CHORES FOR CITY DWELLERS
description: THE leaves have let go of the trees, signaling the onset of winter dormancy and the plants' period of rest, but vital chores remain before the garden door is closed for the year.

title: 250 SEIZED IN DISCO DRUG RAID
description: Narcotics investigators and uniformed policemen raided a crowded midtown discoteque early this morning and arrested 250 people they found inside on charges ranging from loitering to the sale of narcotics.

title: THE DANCE: MARY OVERLIE
description: EVERYTHING about Mary Overlie's 90-minute dance piece, ''Adam and Eve'' Tuesday night suggested a fine intelligence at work. Yet when the evening was over at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, it all looked like pretty thin stuff.

title: Rally in Bonds Is Unabated
description: Investor demand for notes and bonds blossomed yesterday, and was so strong that prices rose sharply even as underwriters were selling $2.25 billion of 10-year Treasury notes, as well as several corporate issues that were hurriedly brought to market.

title: Corpair's New Service
description: Ronald N. Dubin, a 47-year-old businessman, has long been interested in aviation in general and helicopters in particular. ''I've been a private pilot for 14 years, and when I was an Air Force officer in Korea, I was commander of an island and got back and forth each day by helicopter,'' he said yesterday.

title: ROBB VICTORY TIED TO BLACK SUPPORT
description: ''Mills Godwin gave this to us, right here in this same hall,'' was one terse analysis of Charles S. Robb's gubernatorial election victory early this morning.

title: Ralston Purina Net Down 17%
description: The Ralston Purina Company reported yesterday that net income in the third quarter of 1981 dropped 17 percent, to $32.3 million, or 30 cents a share, from $38.9 million, or 36 cents a share, in 1980.

title: ISRAEL SHUTS WEST BANK UNIVERSITY AFTER PALESTINIAN DEMONSTRATIONS
description: The Israeli military authorities closed down the major Palestinian university in the occupied West Bank today in retaliation for several days of anti-Israeli demonstrations by students.

title: EUROPE'S SANE VIEW OF THE NUCLEAR PERIL
description: To the Editor:

title: MAYOR
description: Election District; EDR - Election District Reporting; ESP - Esposito; DOM - Dominquez; BARB - Barbaro ED EDR KOCH ESP DOM CODD BARB A.D. BRONX 75. Mott Haven, Melrose 54 54 5,886 315 1,113 451 1,611 76. Highbridge, Middle Concourse 64 64 4,453 277 606 308 1,421 77. Port Morris, South Bronx 50 50 3,710 195 917 211 852 78. Morrisania 45 45 3,515 210 399 318 944 79. West Farms, Soundview 41 41 3,460 224 685 286 969 80. Throgs Neck, Pelham Bay 80 80 18,014 1,655 668 354 1,626 81. Pelham Parkway, Co-op City 132 132 27,499 1,150 549 1,120 4,514 82. Morris Heights, Tremont, Fordham 71 71 5,962 285 722 300 987 83. Kingsbridge Heights, Bedford Park 89 89 15,560 894 745 601 1,830 84. Riverdale, Kingsbridge 90 90 16,866 625 484 827 2,098 85. Park Chester 90 90 14,081 917 1,480 689 2,708 86. Woodlawn, Wakefield 79 79 14,080 1,264 683 662 2,515 Total 885 885 183,086 8,011 9,051 6,127 22,069

title: Anne Tyler Wins Prize
description: Anne Tyler, author of ''Morgan's Passing,'' has won the sixth Janet Heidinger Kafka prize for fiction written by an American woman. Honorable mentions went to Mary Lee Settle for ''The Scapegoat'' and Hilma Wolitzer for ''Hearts.'' The award is given by the University of Rochester's writers' workshop and English department through an endowment created by the family and friends of the late Miss Kafka, who had been an editor at Random House.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alliance Capital Corp. has named Paula Brown a senior vice president and director of marketing, Anthony D. Bune and Joseph C. Williams vice presidents of the corporation and of Alliance Capital Management International, Alexander Laird 3d vice president and fixed-income portfolio manager and Charles Taylor vice president and research analyst.

title: G.O.P. KEEPS SUFFOLK LEGISLATURE AND WINS A BIG VICTORY IN NASSAU
description: Republicans retained control of the Suffolk County Legislature in yesterday's elections and won what the party described as its greatest victory in the history of Nassau County.

title: KOCH PLANS TO NAME AN ADVISORY COUNCIL FOR MINORITY AFFAIRS
description: Mayor Koch is planning to appoint an advisory council on minority affairs to ''reach out'' to New York City's black and Hispanic residents.

title: TO STRIKE A BLOW AGAINST GERRYMANDERING
description: To the Editor:

title: KOCH SAYS PROBLEMS OF MASS TRANSIT WILL BE A MAJOR CONCERN IN 2D TERM
description: Fresh from his landslide re-election victory, Mayor Koch said yesterday that he had shifted his priorities and intended in his second term to play a ''much closer role'' in seeking better subway and bus service.

title: VIRGIN ISLANDS RESOUNDINGLY REJECT FOURTH DRAFT OF A CONSTITUTION
description: The United States Virgin Islands, purchased from Denmark in 1917, have been a territory in search of a constitution since 1964. Yesterday, a fourth draft went before the voters with the strong backing of the Governor, legislators and civic groups - and was rejected by a ratio of nearly 3 to 2.

title: TRADE GAP WIDENED IN 3D QUARTER
description: The nation's trade deficit grew to $7.2 billion during the third quarter despite a big reduction in imports of oil, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ivan Lendl is the first player to qualify, on the basis of tour points, for the $400,000 Volvo Masters tennis tournament, scheduled for Jan. 13-17 at Madison Square Garden. ... Ken Linseman of the Philadelphia Flyers was fined $200 by the National Hockey League for attempting to kick Robert Picard of Montreal during a scuffle between the two teams in a game Oct. 27. The referee didn't see the attempt, but it was picked up on videotape, the league said. Thomas Edward Simmons, 27, who once held the world record for speed skiing, was sentenced in San Francisco to three years in Federal prison for smuggling 2 pounds of heroin into the country by starching it into his clothing.

title: H.C. WESTERMANN, SCULPTOR, IS DEAD
description: H.C. Westermann, a sculptor known for the humorous, folkloric quality of his assemblages, died Tuesday evening at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He had suffered a heart attack several days ago. Mr. Westermann was 58 years old and lived in Brookfield Center, Conn.

title: Dow Off 1.90; Volume Heavy
description: Strength in the brokerage, transportation and natural resource sectors appeared in the stock market yesterday, while minicomputer issues were hit by selling.

title: Design Notebook; IS THE TIME RIGHT FOR CLASSICISM?
description: ''GREEK, Sir, is like lace. Every man gets as much of it as he can.'' What Greek was to Dr. Samuel Johnson, classicism and its derivatives are to the postmodern architects of today. They are the indispensable element, the mandatory attributes of which ''every man gets as much as he can.''

title: CREDIBLE CHOICE
description: Margaret Thatcher had a two-year head start on Ronald Reagan in applying right-wing ideology to a troubled economy. The policies have been roughly parallel, and the results make grim reading for American conservatives: deep recession, continuing inflation. The latest forecasts say that by 1984 the British inflation rate will be at 11 percent, unemployment over 12 percent.

title: Hays Wins Ohio Seat On Education Board
description: Wayne L. Hays, the former Ohio Congressman who resigned from the House after a sex scandal, won a seat on the Belmont County Board of Education in yesterday's election.

title: Senator Holds Up Vote On a Surgeon General
description: The nomination of C. Everett Koop, a pediatric surgeon who opposes abortion, to become United States Surgeon General has hit another roadblock. A ''hold'' has been placed on the nomination by Senator Charles Mathias, Republican of Maryland.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * A.H. Belo Corp., which owns and operates The Dallas Morning News, WFFA-TV of Dallas, and other newspapers and radio stations, said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 2 million common shares, to be sold through a Goldman, Sachs & Co. group.

title: Gold Found By Pennzoil
description: The Pennzoil Company said yesterday that it had discovered 2.4 million ounces of gold and 9.2 million ounces of silver in Battle Mountain, Nev.

title: SWEDISH GLASSWARE SHINES IN HISTORICAL EXHIBITION
description: In the first significant New York showing of Orrefors glassware since the 1940's, the Heller Gallery of Glass Art has mounted an exhibition of more than 50 pieces, highlighting the history of the famous Swedish-made glass.

title: 'REDS': A MOVIE AFLOAT ON RUMORS
description: It's way over budget. It won't be screened until the very last minute. There are more editors splicing it together than there are elves in Santa's workshop. Yet it has already been previewed, and audiences have booed.

title: Canada Trade Surplus
description: Canada's September trade surplus fell to $65 million (Canadian) from August's upward-revised figure of $372 million and last September's $553 million, Statistics Canada said today. The federal agency said that seasonally adjusted September exports totaled $6.96 billion, up from $6.95 billion in August and $6.04 billion last September, while imports totaled $6.90 billion, up from $6.58 billion in August and $5.49 billion in September 1980.

title: Joblessness Shows Slight Rise in City
description: The unemployment rate increased slightly in New York City in September but showed little change in the New York metropolitan area as a whole, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported.

title: Woman, 82, Dies in a Blaze And 3 Other Persons Are Hurt
description: An 82-year-old woman died and three others persons were injured in a smoky fire that swept through a three-story building in Long Island City, Queens, last night the police said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: '' 'Human rights' is not something we tack on to our foreign policy but is its very purpose: the defense and promotion of freedom in the world.'' -State Department memorandum. (A10:3.)

title: Helpful Hardware; AIDS FOR THE HOBBYIST
description: SOME very handy aids are available for the hobbyist or craftsman from specialty stores that generally sell to professionals and trades people but will also sell to the general public.

title: Grace Ends Talks With Dutch Group
description: W. R. Grace & Company and Vroom & Dreesmann, the Dutch holding company, said that they had ended by mutual consent negotiations under which the Dutch concern would have acquired a substantial interest in Grace's retailing operations. No reasons were given for the termination of the talks.

title: DE LA RENTA: IN TOP FORM FOR SPRING
description: DISTILLING the best fashion ideas from the last half century or so, and adding to them his own special alchemy, Oscar de la Renta has produced one of the most impressive spring collections of the season. Certainly this designer has never been at a loss for drama. He has always had a flair for the spectacular - sometimes, perhaps, making too much of a good thing.

title: BLACK CANDIDATES LOSE IN KEY TESTS
description: Race and ethnic preference emerged as decisive factors in several local elections across the nation yesterday.

title: JAPAN AND A-WEAPONS
description: The Japanese public's attitude toward nuclear weapons is changing significantly. The findings of recent opinion polls probably startled outsiders accustomed to hearing of the ''nuclear allergy'' - the national aversion to nuclear arms - which Japan's news media have depicted as very nearly a permanent fixture.

title: THE THEATER: BETH HENLEY'S 'CRIMES OF THE HEART'
description: BETH HENLEY'S ''Crimes of the Heart'' ends with its three heroines - the MaGrath sisters of Hazelhurst, Miss. -helping themselves to brick-sized hunks of a chocolate birthday cake. The cake, a ''super deluxe'' extravaganza from the local bakery, is as big as the kitchen table, and the sisters laugh their heads off as they dig in. The scene is the perfect capper for an evening of antic laughter - yet it's by no means the sum of ''Crimes of the Heart.'' While this play overflows with infectious high spirits, it is also, unmistakably, the tale of a very troubled family. Such is Miss Henley's prodigious talent that she can serve us pain as though it were a piece of cake.

title: THE SELLING OF AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: COLLEAGUES AND PROTEGES HONOR GEORGE LONDON
description: Some of opera's brightest lights gathered at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts this evening to pay tribute to George London, the bass-baritone. Mr. London's career was cut short in 1967 by the paralysis of a vocal cord and four years ago he suffered a severe cardiac arrest that has left him incapacitated.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Part of the roof on my house is covered with copper. The rain gutters are also copper. All of this is about 15 years old and none of the copper has ever been painted. In order to preserve the metal is it necessary to paint the copper, and if so, is there some special kind of paint that will not cover up the color of the copper metal? - -M.A., Swarthmore, Pa.

title: FAULTY PART SIMILAR TO AUTO OIL FILTER, BUT TOUGHER TO REPLACE
description: The offending part looks and acts much like the oil filter in an everyday, down-to-earth automobile. In this case, it filters the oil that lubricates the gears that drive the hydraulic system that operates the control surfaces and maneuvering rockets of the space shuttle Columbia.

title: PRESLEY'S DOCTOR ACQUITTED ON ALL PRESCRIPTION CHARGES
description: Dr. George Nichopoulos was acquitted today of 11 counts of criminally overprescribing addictive drugs to Elvis Presley, the country-western singer Jerry Lee Lewis and seven other patients.

title: LINGERING QUESTIONS ABOUT THE AWACS SALE
description: To the Editor:

title: PROBLEMS TURN UP WITH SOLAR HOUSES
description: MOST people who have bought passive solar houses in the last few years are finding that fuel savings live up to expectations. But those same people report that they are running into unanticipated difficulties as well, including the impracticality of manually operated systems and condensation buildup.

title: Home Beat; TWO NEW SHOPS, UPTOWN, DOWNTOWN
description: THEY are at opposite ends of town and at different sides of the design spectrum, but two new shops have one thing in common: each is run by an enthusiastic and entrepreneurial woman. ''My idea was of a French country cottage filled with special things that you won't see all over town,'' said Peaches Gore of Mabel's, at 1046 Madison Avenue, between 79th and 80th Streets.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS
description: Gardens and Groves, Pierpont Mor- gan Library, 29 East 36th Street.

title: PRIVATE INDUSTRY ON CAMPUS
description: About a year ago, on the fifth floor of what was then a rundown humanities and science building on the campus of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, two 22-year-old former R.P.I. research associates started a computer graphics company called Raster Technologies.

title: TENTATIVE NEW DISTRICT LINES DRAWN TO FOLLOW U.S. ORDER
description: Officials of New York's City Council said yesterday they had tentatively redrawn the disputed district lines. The new approach abandons the principle of protecting all incumbents in favor of lines that would give minority candidates a better chance of being elected in several districts.

title: U.S. Orders Bolts Inspected After Fatal Beechcraft Crash
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday it had ordered that the wing bolts of 2,600 Beechcraft King Air and Queen Air planes be inspected before the craft were flown again.

title: Notes on People; Nancy Reagan Dress Becomes a Museum Piece
description: ''I feel like Cinderella,'' Nancy Reagan said yesterday. Mrs. Reagan made the comment as she presented her white satin inaugural ball gown to the Smithsonian Institution.

title: ECUMENICAL GROUP NAMES NEW LEADER
description: Bishop James Armstrong, the leader of the United Methodist Church in Indiana, was elected president of the National Council of Churches today.

title: WASHINGTON - At the midpoint between elections, Congress is always furthest from the voters. Not surprisingly, that is when the public is threatened with the worst economic policy.
description: A year ago, the American people thought that they had voted to reduce tax rates, restrain spending, strengthen defense, and restore a sound dollar. Now some senators recall voters' demanding defense cuts and increased tax rates, among other things.

title: INVENTOR DOES BATTLE WITH THE ARMY
description: Loebe Julie, a 60-year-old New York inventor who is the son of Polish immigrants, was traveling happily down the path of the American Dream until he tried doing business with the United States Army.

title: Upset by Brooklyn
description: Brooklyn College, a Division III team, upset St. Francis in soccer yesterday, 1-0. St. Francis is ranked among the nation's top 20 in Division I. Charles Caruso scored from 15 yards on a pass from Dominick Demonte in the 60th minute. Brooklyn improved its record to 12-1-2; St. Francis fell to 10-3-1.

title: Index; The Elections
description: Close Jersey election posed prob- lems for news organizations B11 Republicans win in Nassau and Suffolk Counties B16 Recount scheduled in Bridgeport mayoral race B16 Washington state voters approve curb on nuclear reactors B17 Robb in Virginia victory tied to blcak surport B18 International Shadow of dead leader lies over Trinidad election A2 Swedish Government denies it is retreating on sub issue A3 Heads of party, union and church meet in Poland A3 Around the World A5 King Hussein affirms Soviet arms deal A6 Indians boycott South African election A7 Israel closes university in West Bank after demonstrations A12 Government/Politics House panel cancels inquiry into cult deaths at Jonestown A18 Senators warn Reagan C.I.A. could be hurt by domestic role A19 Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway survives a close vote A20 House committee rejects plan for Social Security finances A21 Reagan defending his nominee to lead E.E.O.C. A22 Atlantic City prepares to set up new government B11 Virgin Islanders reject fourth draft of a constitution B19 Washington Talk Briefing A24 Agriculture conference sees re- sults of eyes in the sky A24 An inventor takes on the United States Army A24 Impromptu bill-writing per- formed in the Senate A24 Home Section Home Bringing Shaker-style furniture back to life C1

title: ISRAEL'S ENVOY TO U.S. IS RESIGNING
description: Ephraim Evron, the Israeli Ambassador in Washington, will leave his post in January and is expected to be succeeded by Moshe Arens, a hard-line political appointee.

title: What the Election Shows
description: Haruspicy, the ancients called it - interpreting the world by examining the entrails of sacrificial animals. When it comes to the modern political equivalent, sometimes it's no trick at all. Last year, for instance, all the signs seemed to point, in neon, in one direction: less government, taxes, inflation. There is no such electric lesson this year. If anything, the results suggest that American politics is in fact more ambiguous than the neon of 1980. Consider a few contradictory examples.

title: HUMAN RIGHTS VICTORY
description: SafireWASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -The Reagan Administration intends to take the human rights issue seriously.

title: U.S. Military Team Arrives in Morocco
description: A United States military delegation arrived here today to discuss the conflict in the Western Sahara and other regional security issues with Moroccan military and civilian leaders, officials said.

title: Sony Opens Lab In New Jersey
description: The Sony Corporation said its United States subsidiary, the Sony Corporation of America, had opened a consumer electronics research laboratory in Paramus, N.J.

title: THEATER: 'THE LAST BURNING'
description: DOUBLE, double toil and trouble in Patrick Galvin's ''The Last Burning.'' In this Irish play, the subject is witchery. There are four witches and a fifth under suspicion. This makes a full house, a quintet of a coven. On the dimly lit stage of the No Smoking Playhouse, the four accredited witches carry candles, which gives the audience eyestrain (to say nothing about mind strain). The evening is long and murky.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION: We at Jersey Devil find ourselves in a bit of a dilemma re Mr.  Goldberger's article. While Mr. Goldberger perhaps unconsciously borrowed the theme for his article from Steve Badanes's abstract and presentation at the American section of the International Solar Energy Society conference, he repays this debt by ranking a selected portion of our work as bad, calling it ''tiresome'' and ''gimmickyry.''
description: Those, of course, are fighting words. If he had stopped at ranking our work as bad, we would have written it off as good press, considering the source, but no one calls us ''tiresome'' and gets away with it.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Directors of the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company today recommended that the company's minority shareholders accept a merger proposal, valued at more than $1 billion, announced last night by the company's 52.9 percent owner, Dome Petroleum Ltd., of Calgary, Alberta.

title: Who Cares for the Mentally Ill?
description: New York state and city officials will attempt today to settle yet another clash in their protracted struggle over the care of the mentally ill. The dispute arose when a state official arranged surprise inspections of city hospital psychiatric wings, then ordered them to relieve overcrowding, perhaps by using empty beds in other wards.

title: HOUSTON CONTROLLER FAVORED IN MAYORALTY RUNOFF NOV. 17
description: City Controller Kathryn J. Whitmire made by far the strongest showing of any candidate in an election in which Mayor Jim McConn went down to defeat yesterday. She is the early favorite to win a runoff on Nov. 17 and thereby become Houston's first woman Mayor.

title: 2 YOUTHS SOUGHT IN BRONX KILLING OF A TEEN-AGER
description: Two youngsters who shot and killed a 15-year-old Bronx student after a brief shouting match were being sought by the police yesterday.

title: PUBLIC WORKS PROJECTS SQUEAK THROUGH IN SENATE
description: The Senate narrowly defeated attempts today to block two of the nation's costliest and most controversial public works projects: the Tennesee-Tombigbee Waterway in Alabama and Mississippi and the Clinch River Breeder Reactor in Tennessee.

title: Congressman's Son Loses
description: Ronald Mottl Jr., the 19-year-old son of United States Representative Ronald M. Mottl, lost his bid for City Council president yesterday in this Cleveland suburb. He was defeated by a margin of 2 to 1 by the incumbent, Kenneth G. Kuczma.

title: AD AGENCIES RETREATING TO 'MADISON AVE. SOUTH'
description: Madison Avenue has not been Madison Avenue for a long time, according to some advertising executives. In fact, ''Madison Avenue'' - the words that conjure up a world of slickly dressed ad men, glib talk and high-priced models - has included Third Avenue and Lexington Avenue and even the Avenue of the Americas since about the mid-1960's.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1981
description: The Elections Doubt over New Jersey's election for Governor continued after a chaotic day of checking and rechecking figures. Governor Byrne ordered all voting machines and paper ballots impounded and placed under a round-the-clock police guard in preparation for a recount. Unofficial tallies showed Thomas H. Kean, the Republican, leading Representative James J. Florio, the Democrat, by 1,158 votes out of more than 2.28 million cast. Neither candidate declared victory or conceded defeat. (Page A1, Column 6.) Democratic legislators held control of both chambers of the New Jersey Legislature, but by the slimmest margins of their eight years in power. In Tuesday's balloting, the Republicans gained five seats in the Senate and one seat in the Assembly. (B12:1-3.)

title: Pastorini to Start
description: Coach Ray Malavasi has made his decision in the latest chapter of the quarterback controversy among the Los Angeles Rams: Dan Pastorini, the former Houston star, gets the start in Sunday's game against New Orleans. ''Haden has done good things for us,'' Malavasi said of Pat Haden, who previously started, ''but we have not been putting enough points on the board.''

title: News of Music; COMPUTERS FACE THE MUSIC IN TEXAS
description: DURING the last few decades, computers have become an increasingly important part of musical life, influencing techniques of composition, performance and recording. Musical needs have, in turn, led to advances in computer design and programming.

title: U.S. Receives Bids For Silver
description: Bids for slightly more than three million ounces of silver were received today in the Government's fourth weekly auction of surplus silver from the country's stockpile, the General Services Administration said today.

title: Spanish Regime Hurt As 15 Legislators Quit
description: The coalition Government of Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo was threatened today by the resignation of 15 of his Social Democratic supporters in Parliament.

title: MUSIC: SOME CONTEMPORARIES
description: HEARD repeatedly at the 92d St. Y on Monday night was the admission ''everybody's here,'' intoned with delight and disbelief. The ''everybody'' in question was everybody from Elliott Carter to the still-under-30 composers just beginning to feel like part of the contemporary music establishment. The occasion was a program by the Group for Contemporary Music, now a venerable 20-year-old institution whose artistic directors, Harvey Sollberger and Charles Wuorinen, were students, like many in the audience, when they founded it.

title: Going Out Guide
description: PENMANSHIP

title: 6 GUARDS ARE HURT AS PRISONERS BRAWL IN CONNECTICUT JAIL
description: Inmates held a guard captive for three and a half hours tonight at Connecticut's only maximum-security prison after a fight in which six guards were slightly hurt.

title: GREENWICH ACQUISITION CONCLUDED
description: In one of the biggest rescue operations in its history, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation last night approved the takeover of the failing Greenwich Savings Bank by the Metropolitan Savings Bank.

title: WNCN Offering Series Of Recorded Concerts
description: FM will record performances by well-known artists this season and broadcast them soon after they occur, on Friday nights at 9. ''New York Concerts'' will begin tomorrow with Eugene Fodor, the violinist, at Lehman College. The concert, which was given on Oct. 24, includes Brahms's Sonata in D minor (Op. 101).

title: QUICK WITHDRAWAL FROM CHAD VOWED
description: The commander of Libya's troops in Chad said tonight that all his forces would leave the central African country within seven days.

title: A NEW TEST FOR IMPERIAL OIL
description: On a brisk fall day 101 autumns ago, a handful of Ontario businessmen each invested $25,000 to form the Imperial Oil Company, a concern founded to combat the invasion of American oil interests.

title: Rare Telemann Opera At 92d St. Y on Nov. 28
description: A performance of ''Pimpinone,'' a rarely heard chamber opera by Telemann, will be performed at the 92d Street Y on Nov. 28 at 8 P.M. in the Y Chamber Symphony Goes Baroque series.

title: Step Up Pays Off
description: Pete Ranzany, ranked fifth as a welterweight contender by the World Boxing Association and seventh by the World Boxing Council, stepped up to the junior middleweight division. He did so impressively, stopping Greg Stephens in the fifth round in Sacramento Tuesday night.

title: ANDERSON FIRM IS FOUND GUILTY OF FRAUD
description: A Federal Court jury in Manhattan yesterday found that Arthur Andersen & Company, one of the nation's biggest accounting firms, had committed fraud against a mutual fund called the Fund of Funds in the late 1960's.

title: RECITAL: CHRISTOPHER O'RILEY, PIANIST
description: IN many of life's arenas, the magic letter is A, or even A-plus. Here and there, an E for Excellent is the one to shoot at. But for musicians, the alphabet sometimes seems to begin and end with T: their careers depend on how well they deal with the ever-evolving problems of technique, taste and temperament. Pianists, furthermore, must break down technique into a thousand little Tinker Toy parts bearing such labels as tone, touch or tension, not to forget for a moment the important techniques involved in touring. So you can see that the question of what makes one pianist different from another, let alone better, is altogether a ticklish one.

title: Manson Denied Parole For 4th Year in a Row
description: The imprisoned mass murderer Charles M. Manson was denied parole today for the fourth year in a row.

title: CABARET: BESSIE SMITH
description: THAT Carrie Smith is a singer with something special to offer has been evident for a long time.
