Robert Shelton noted this fact in a review in The New York Times when she made her concert debut as a gospel singer at Town Hall 20 years ago. In her various guises since then - as a band singer with Big Tiny Little and Al Hirt, as a cabaret performer at Michael's Pub and particularly in her recreation of Bessie Smith songs for a New York Jazz Repertory Company program at Carnegie Hall - the special gleam in her singing was apparent. But there always seemed to be a little distance between herself and her audience that inhibited the emergence of the fullbodied talent that was moving inside her.

title: NEW YORK PRISON BONDS WIN
description: Party professionals studied the impact of money and the black vote on the results of Tuesday's voting nationwide. News analysis, page B18. By RICHARD J. MEISLIN

title: FIX WITNESS TELLS OF THREAT
description: A woman who said she lived with Rick Kuhn during Boston College's 1978-79 basketball season testified yesterday that Mr. Kuhn had threatened to kill her if she told what she knew about a pointshaving scheme for which he and four co-defendants are on trial.

title: NEW JERSEY PROPOSITIONS
HUSSEIN AFFIRMS MOSCOW DEAL
description: King Hussein of Jordan said here today that he was going through with plans to purchase air defense equipment from the Soviet Union because ''the door was closed to me'' by the Carter Administration when he first sought to buy the equipment from the United States.

title: TV: PROWLING REPORTER MAKES DEBUT
description: FOR several seasons, CBS-TV has been providing a home for ''Lou Grant'' and his newspaper. Now, on Thursdays at 10 P.M., the network is offering a television newsroom to ''Jessica Novak.'' Jessica is a ''human interest'' television reporter who is determined to bring in important, not to mention flashy, stories. As the ads put it, ''She goes for the headline, but she leads with her heart!''

title: THE THAI WAY IN THE METROPOLIS: TEMPLE TO HOME
description: LAST Sunday morning, even though they had been up very late the night before to attend a ball that raised funds for one of the charities of Queen Sirikit of Thailand, Vichan and Yupadee Chu chaitayakul rose from bed and drove from their Bronx apartment to the tiny Buddhist temple of Vajiradhammapadip off Burnside Avenue in the West Bronx, just as they do every Sunday.

title: OPERA: HENRY LEWIS IN DEBUT
description: THE ''Rigoletto'' production now on display at the New York City Opera dates back to 1969, and was last seen at the New York State Theater in the fall of 1979. Its revival this fall has been staged by Jay Lesenger.

title: ABUNDANT HARVEST IN CORN BELT DEPRESSING PRICES
description: There is a time when farmers should be ''adventurous and expanding,'' Bob Baur was saying the other day, and a time when they should ''contract and reorganize.''

title: READING THE HANDWRITING ON THE BILL
description: Those who care for the law and sausage, the saying goes, may be well advised not to watch either being made. Theorists who regard legislating as a precise and formal discipline could have been startled by events on the Senate floor Monday when Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts persuaded the Republican majority to preserve the ''meals on wheels'' program for elderly shut-ins.

title: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1981; Companies
description: A takeover of Greenwich Savings Bank by Metropolitan Savings was approved by the F.D.I.C. Helping the bank cover the losses of Greenwich will cost the agency an estimated $400 million to $500 million. Metropolitan had previously arranged a December merger with the Brooklyn Savings Bank. The three-bank combination would create the largest savings bank in New York State. (D1.)

title: Notes on People; Cagney to Be Honored by Journalists
description: His first job was as a copy boy on The New York Sun, he's made half a dozen appearances as a newspaper reporter over the years and now James Cagney will finally get a press card.

title: NORTHWEST REACTORS' FUTURE IS CLOUDED BY VOTE ON BONDS
description: Voters in the state of Washington yesterday approved a ballot proposition that limits the right of municipalities to issue revenue bonds for power plants without voter approval. Their decision, which faces a legal challenge, has clouded the future of one of the nation's most ambitious nuclear power developments, and one of its most disputed.

title: Bridge: British Women Overcame Obstacles on Road to Title
description: The victory of the British women's team over the United States in the final of the world championship in Port Chester, N.Y., a week ago was a shock for most Americans but was no surprise to the European contingent.

title: PHILADELPHIAN OPENS HOME TO EX-GANG MEMBERS
description: Curtis Jones Jr. is alive and doing well, and, like hundreds of other young men here, he gives thanks on that account to a woman who has spread a warm and gentle influence through the toughest sections of a city once notorious for the violence of its youth gangs.

title: Market Place; Color Tile's Uneven Path
description: FOR a time, Color Tile Inc. appeared to be another Radio Shack - a retailer with exceptional prospects. Now the picture may have dimmed a bit. Color Tile offers a broad assortment of quarry, ceramic and wooden floor and wall tiles, and it caters to the do-it-yourself trade.

title: REAGAN URGED TO ACCEPT BIG 1984 BUDGET DEFICIT
description: George P. Shultz, the former Treasury Secretary, and three other senior Republican advisers counseled President Reagan today to accept a 1984 budget deficit of tens of billions of dollars rather than ask Congress to raise such sums in new taxes.

title: Testing Companies Ask No Regulation by U.S.
description: Testing companies today urged Congress not to regulate the industry, arguing that they already have answered most students' concerns about the secrecy of college admissions tests.

title: French Joblessness Up
description: French seasonally adjusted unemployment is estimated to have risen to 1.82 million in October from 1.81 million in September, the Labor Ministry said today.

title: Thousands in Teheran Join Anti-U.S. March
description: Thousands of demonstrators chanting ''death to America'' marched to the closed and deserted United States Embassy in Teheran today to mark the second anniversary of its takeover and the start of the 14-month hostage crisis.

title: FROM WORKING MOTHERS TO WELFARE MOTHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING
description: T HE White House is losing one of its most staunch Congressional allies until early next year. Senator Barry Goldwater has quietly returned to his home in Scottsdale, Ariz., for a hip operation this weekend. Mr. Goldwater is expected to remain away from Washington nearly two months. ''He'll just have to miss some votes, that's all there is to it,'' said one Goldwater aide.

title: Offers for Kelser
description: Newspaper reports in Detroit say that Greg Kelser, the former Michigan State star now with the Pistons, could be playing soon for either Chicago or Los Angeles, where Kelser, a small forward, would be rejoining his college teammate, Magic Johnson. Detroit has reportedly offered Kelser and a draft choice to Chicago for the rights to Orlando Woolridge, a power forward from Notre Dame who has balked at accepting a contract. But the Lakers also need a small forward to back up Jamaal Wilkes and, the reports said, want to trade for Kelser.

title: Sports of The Times; Now, Introducing, Mr. November
description: WITH a Yankee banner as a backdrop, Ken Griffey put on a Yankee cap, smiled for the photographers and turned to confront his first Stadium interrogation. When the questions began, Griffey, the 30-year-old outfielder who had worn No. 30 for the Cincinnati Reds for eight seasons, was asked what number he would wear next season on his Yankee pinstripes.

title: Phils Tap Corrales
description: The Philadelphia Phillies announced their choice of a new manager yesterday. He is 40-year-old Pat Corrales, former manager of the Texas Rangers and a onetime backup catcher for Philadelphia, who had been reported in recent weeks to be the strongest candidate for the job.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Comtex Scientific Corp. said Capital Cities Communications had purchased an option to acquire 20.1 percent of the common stock of Comtex for $350,000.

title: LA PRENSA'S LISTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Grey and STP Have Change in Relationship
description: There will be no announcement on it since neither STP nor its agency considers it a big deal, but there has been a change in their relationship, which began last February, when Grey replaced Henderson Advertising.

title: President of CBI To Add Two Posts
description: William A. Pogue, the 54-year-old president of CBI Industries, has been elected to the additional posts of chairman and chief executive officer, effective Jan.1. He will succeed Marvin G. Mitchell, 64, who is to retire.

title: JONESTOWN INQUIRY CANCELED BY HOUSE PANEL
description: Citing legal complications, a House subcommittee today canceled its plans to hold a public inquiry into the performance of State Department officials in connection with the mass murders and suicides three years ago in Jonestown, Guyana.

title: JERSEY G.O.P. CUTS DEMOCRATS' EDGE TO 4 SENATE SEATS AND 6 IN ASSEMBLY
description: Republicans gained five seats in the New Jersey Senate and one in the Assembly Tuesday, but the Democrats retained their eight-year hold on both houses of the Legislature.

title: INDIANS BOYCOTT SOUTH AFRICA VOTE
description: Twenty minutes after the polls opened this morning at the largest of the three polling stations in this Indian community outside Johannesburg, a total of four voters had cast their ballots in what the Government had promoted as the first general election ever held for South Africa's Indians.

title: Hungary Seeks To Join I.M.F.
description: Hungary has applied to become the third East European nation in the International Monetary Fund, joining Rumania and Yugoslavia, the 143-member organization said today. The fund was founded after World War II to stabilize international finance by making short-term loans to economically troubled governments.

title: 3 SENATORS WARN PRESIDENT ON C.I.A.
description: Three members of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence have privately warned President Reagan that authorizing the Central Intelligence Agency to infiltrate and influence American organizations could damage the agency.

title: Waring & LaRosa Gets Perrier Account
description: Well, that didn't take long. On Tuesday when it was announced that Mathieu, Gerfen & Bresner had been dropped from the Perrier account, it looked like the client had an agency search ahead of it. Yesterday Great Waters of France, the company based in Greenwich, Conn., that markets the sparkling water, was ready to announce the business is going to Waring & LaRosa.

title: A Correction
description: A recipe for French garlic sausages in The Living Section yesterday gave an incorrect diameter for the sausage casing. The correct diameter is 40 to 43 millimeters.

title: Massachusetts to Help Curb Anti-Semitic Acts in Boston
description: The Massachusetts Attorney General's office has agreed to help investigate increasing reports of anti-Semitic vandalism and assaults in the Boston area, the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith said today.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION
description: Paul Goldberger's article tells us that solar house design is often ridiculously flamboyant or just plain ugly. On the other hand, Goldberger condemns the Brookhaven House as ''competent'' but ''dull'' - in design terms not much better than a conventional tract house.

title: PLAN FOR PENSIONS LOST IN HOUSE UNIT
description: An amendment sponsored by Representative J.J. Pickle, Democrat of Texas, that would have increased revenue to the retirement fund by an average of $20 billion a year for 75 years was voted down, 18 to 14, with most of the Democrats on the panel in opposition.

title: 5 Ex-Policemen in Texas Indicted in Rights Case
description: A Federal grand jury indicted five former McAllen policemen today on charges that they violated the civil rights of prisoners who were beaten, kicked and abused.

title: BIG TEST FOR DEPUTY MINISTER
description: John Tammaro stared intently at a slice of cream pie before him as someone asked if he already dreaded putting Deputy Minister, the outstanding 2-year-old colt he trains, through the glare and grind of the countdown to the Kentucky Derby and the Triple Crown next spring.

title: SHADOW OF DEAD LEADER LIES OVER TRINIDAD VOTE
description: OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, Oct. 31 - He was, for 25 years, at the absolute center of his society, a brilliant anticolonial father figure growing more eccentric and secretive as the years passed, running what his critics called a ''doc-tatorship.'' Now that Dr. Eric Williams is dead, his ghost is still the most compelling presence in the campaign to elect a new government for Trinidad and Tobago on Nov. 9.

title: Profit Expected By VW in U.S.
description: Despite continuing weakness in the United States auto market, Volkswagen of America has a chance of making a small profit for 1981, a company official said.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.** Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: NEW SHUTTLE SHOT DELAYED FOR WEEK
description: Impairment of the auxiliary power units that operate the space shuttle Columbia's oil hydraulic system forced postponement today of the craft's second flight. The launching was delayed for a week, possibly longer.

title: Allen Reaffirms U.S. Support For Camp David Agreements
description: Richard V. Allen, President Reagan's national security adviser, last night reaffirmed American support for the Camp David accords, saying they ''epitomize the fundamental exchange of peace for territory, a transaction that underlies the United Nations Security Council Resolution 242.''

title: POST MAY SELL SPORTS MAGAZINE
description: The Washington Post Company announced yesterday that it was discussing with prospective buyers the sale of its money-losing sports magazine, Inside Sports.

title: Advertising; Ad Stand At F.T.C.  Questioned
description: IF a question period follows the address of James C. Miller, new chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, to the annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers, then next Tuesday's session is due to go into overtime.

title: DELBELLO TAKES VICTORY AS A VOTE OF CONFIDENCE
description: Alfred B. DelBello said today that his reelection yesterday as Westchester County Executive represented ''confidence in the way we run the government, and we will not be making any changes.''

title: KEY TO SYMBOLS
description: Asterisk (*) denotes incumbent where appropriate (the New Jersey State Senate and Assembly have been reapportioned); dagger (+) denotes incomplete result. The results of some minor-party candidates were not immediately tabulated and will be certified at a later date.

title: Man Killed, Girl Raped By Gunman in Queens
description: A 28-year-old man was shot and killed and his female companion was raped at gunpoint by a man who opened fire without warning as they sat in a car parked in a secluded section of a park in Ridgewood, Queens, the police said.

title: CHILDREN WHO SHOULD NOT BEAR CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: ALLIED CONTINGENCY PLAN ENVISIONS A WARNING ATOM BLAST, HAIG SAYS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that contingency plans in the event of a conventional war in Europe included the exploding of a nuclear warhead as a ''demonstration'' to deter the Soviet Union from trying to overrun Western Europe.

title: REAGAN DEFENDING NOMINEE TO LEAD JOB FAIRNESS AGENCY
description: A White House spokesman said today that President Reagan was sticking by his nomination of a black businessman from Detroit to head the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission despite growing opposition in the Senate and among civil rights groups.

title: Canada-Egypt Contract
description: The Dehavilland Aircraft Company of Canada, a state-owned aircraft manufacturer, has been awarded a contract worth more than $100 million (Canadian) to supply Egypt with 10 Buffalo aircraft, spare parts and training assistance, the Trade Ministry said here today.

title: BANKERS TRUST GETS OFFER FOR VISA CARD
description: The First National Bank of Chicago, in a move that would nearly double its bank card business overnight, said yesterday that it was negotiating to buy the 1.1 million Visa accounts operated by the Bankers Trust New York Corporation.

title: EYES IN THE SKY GLEAN DATA ON EXPORTS
description: The Agriculture Department has mobilized its vast agrarian intelligence network this week for the Agriculture Outlook Conference, an annual gathering to which anyone involved in producing or eating food is invited to come and hear the good, or bad, news about farmers in 1982.

title: FEWER CONSUMERS ASK CONVERSION TO GAS HEAT
description: Fewer consumers in New York State are asking that their home heating oil systems be converted to natural gas. Officials are not certain, however, whether that decline is a result of fear of deregulation, the cost of conversion or the fact that conversions have reached a saturation point.

title: SIMMS EXPECTS TO PLAY
description: Last year, because of a bruised right shoulder, Phil Simms missed the Giants' last three games. Except for that lapse, Simms, the starting quarterback, had not missed a practice in three years.

title: Conviction Upheld In Sindona Case
description: A Federal appeals court upheld the conviction of Michele Sindona, the Italian financier, on charges that he jumped bail and staged a bogus kidnapping to conceal a mysterious 11-week trip to Europe before his scheduled fraud trial in 1979.

title: Advertising; State Sets Business To Music
description: NEW YORK STATE, which increased tourism revenues $20 billion since 1977 with the help of the ''I Love New York'' campaign, is now turning the power of advertising toward industrial development.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Princeton's track and field coach, Larry Ellis, has been named coach of the United States men's track and field squad for the 1984 Summer Olympic Games in Los Angeles. His selection, made by a staff screening committee of The Athletics Congress, is pending approval by that organization's national convention during the first week of December. ... The Minnesota Kicks have closed their offices in Bloomington, Minn., but Commissioner Phil Woosnam of the North American Soccer League insists that new ownership will be found for the financially troubled franchise. ... Eamonn Coghlan of Ireland, the indoor record-holder for the mile, has entered the second international cross-country meet Nov. 21 at Belmont Park.

title: PIANO RECITAL: AMIRAM RIGAI AT Y
description: IT was in the most trivial music that Amiram Rigai was most successful in his recital at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday night. The Israeli pianist, who has played here regularly over the last 20 years, gave three short works by Louis Gottschalk a spirited and flashy sense of play.

title: PURSUING DETENTE AND DETERRENCE
description: Since the end of World War II, Europe's view of United States policy toward the Soviet Union has almost always been profoundly ambiguous. Today's view is no exception.

title: AMERICAN AGGREGATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Recognition Factor
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt, speech to the Associated Press Managing Editors: For those of you who do not read Doonesbury, I am Jim Watt. Yes, the face you are looking at has launched a thousand cartoons.

title: REGIONAL BANDS IN NATIONAL SPOTLIGHT
description: ''I WON'T quit till I'm a star on Broadway,'' the hero of ''On Broadway,'' an early-1960's rock-and-roll hit of the Drifters, vowed. He didn't want to be a star in his own hometown; that wasn't being a star at all. He wanted to see his name in lights on the Great White Way. He may have been a rock-and-roll musician, but he grew up watching the same movies and television shows everyone else watched, and those movies and television shows told him that if he was ambitious, if he thought he had star quality, then he belonged in New York City or Hollywood or possibly swinging London. If he could make it there, he could make it anywhere.

title: HOUSE-SENATE CONFEREES RESTORE SUGAR SUPPORTS
description: Sugar price support loans, which would raise consumer prices at least 2 cents a pound this year, were accepted today by a House-Senate conference committee struggling to agree on a new farm bill.

title: Labor Tries to Unfly a Kite
description: Labor is embarked on a shortsighted campaign against high interest rates. In September, unions mustered a huge army of marchers to protest the President's economic program, but they offered no credible plan to take its place. Now Howard Samuel, director of the industrial union department of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., says interest rates are ''the number one issue in the country'' - evidently surpassing such secondary matters as inflation and stagnation. The A.F.L.- C.I.O. unions therefore have joined public utilities, farmers, contractors and mayors in a National Council for Low Interest Rates.

title: 'MODEST' BUT CRUCIAL U.S. AID PROJECTS
description: To the Editor:

title: KEMP IS EXPECTED TO DECLARE HE WON'T RUN FOR GOVERNOR
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp is expected to announce tomorrow that he will not seek the Republican gubernatorial nomination that would probably be his for the asking next year.

title: MEDEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results reflect 4-for-3 stock split paid Sept 1981

title: Garden 'Doo Wopp'
description: A reunion of some of the original members of Frankie Lymon and the Teen-agers, a doo wopp group from the 1950's, will highlight ''Doo Wopp at the Garden, Vol.

title: BRIEFING
description: I N the toughest attempt yet to combat the National Rifle Association's proven lobbying powers, the antigun lobby has zeroed in on Congressional beneficiaries of N.R.A. campaign funds with mass mailings to constituents.

title: Mayor Koch's New Diplomacy
description: A lot of the talk about Mayor Koch's bad relations with New York's blacks and Hispanics has been superficial. Widespread poverty breeds anger and discontent, and nothing that City Hall can do, particularly in a time of austerity, can still all the complaints of the poor and their leaders. Some minority group spokesmen, hardly naive, will persist in blaming the Mayor, even for problems he cannot possibly solve.

title: Dutch Coalition Mends Rift and Takes Power
description: The three-party Netherlands' coalition was back in power today after patching up differences that led to its resignation Oct. 16.

title: France Says the Libyans Have Quit Chad Capital
description: French officials, who have been virtually silent about reports of a Libyan military withdrawal from Chad, said today that Libyan armored cars and troops had been flown out of Ndjamena, capital of the central African nation.

title: ECONOMICS LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOMALIA IS READY TO MOVE TOWARD PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Hunters Asphyxiated
description: Three hunters died of asphyxiation in their tent Tuesday, apparently because they burned two gasoline lanterns throughout the night, the authorities said. The victims were identified as Raymond Carlton, 45 years old, of Falls River Mill, Calif., and Peter Popp, 40, and Nickolas Popp, 38, both of Portland.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; GANDHI OPERA IN BROOKLYN
description: ''Satyagraha,'' an opera by Philip Glass, will have its New York City premiere tonight at 8 in the Opera House of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, using the same principal singers and huge set and costumes as it had when presented in its successful world premiere a year ago by the Netherlands Opera in Rotterdam. The opera is based on the life of Mohandas K. Gandhi during his years in South Africa (1893-1914), when the father of Indian independence first used the tactics of nonviolent civil disobedience to fight racial discrimination. The libretto, by Constance De Jong, is in Sanskrit, and the entire performance takes place behind a scrim. The music, with full orchestra, is described as softer and more lyrical than most of the other works of the avant-garde composer. Christopher Keene will conduct the Brooklyn Philharmonia, and Douglas Perry will sing the role of Gandhi. The staging is by Hans Nieuwenhuis. Tickets are $10 to $20 (benefit tickets for Monday night, at $100 each, which includes a party, are also available). Reservations only through Chargit: 944-9300. Box office information: 636-4100.

title: EXCERPTS FROM JERSEY'S RULES REGARDING RECOUNTS OF DISPUTED ELECTIONS
description: Following are excerpts from the portions of the New Jersey statutes governing election recounts: Application for Recount

title: KEAN AND FLORIO PLAN COURT FIGHT
description: With the winner of the race for Governor of New Jersey still in doubt, representatives of the Republican and Democratic candidates began preparing yesterday for potential court action on a recount while trading increasingly bitter accusations.

title: DUGUAY SCORES 3
description: The Rangers played their finest game of the National Hockey League season tonight, as Ron Duguay scored three goals to lead a 6-2 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers at the Spectrum.

title: GUITAR RECITAL: JULIAN BREAM
description: THERE must have been a few score different ways Julian Bream produced sounds from his guitar Monday night in Avery Fisher Hall. Just by locating the point of plucking the string, he gave each note a decisive shape and shade.

title: Satellite Challenge By a Warner Unit
description: The Warner Amex Satellite Entertainment Company has mounted a legal challenge to an auction of satellite transponders planned for Monday by an RCA unit.

title: Milton Smith, Taught Drama at Columbia
description: Milton Smith, former director of the School of Dramatic Arts at Columbia University, died Wednesday in Red Bank, N.J. He was 91 years old.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Bracken Exploration Co. is selling 400,000 shares of common stock at $13 a share, to be offered through a Rotan Mosle Inc. group.

title: SIGMOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A LIFE OF SHARING WITH WOMEN OF THIRD WORLD
description: Picture the scene. Perdita Huston, a strapping, stunning, greeneyed woman from Maine, is sitting in the back room of a rural health clinic on a dusty road north of Cairo. Gazing back at Miss Huston from over a black veil is another beautiful woman, Zohila. Her eyes are dull with malnutrition and overwork. She is only 20 years old, and has come to the clinic with her fifth child, who is sick. The two women talk in country Arabic.

title: Clinch River Reactor Survives Senate Vote
description: Opponents of the Clinch River nuclear breeder reactor today failed for a second time to persuade the Senate to cut Federal financing for the $3.2 billion project.

title: NLT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SIMMS OUT, BRUNNER TO START
description: Scott Brunner will replace Phil Simms as the Giants' quarterback Sunday against the Green Bay Packers in Milwaukee, because Simms is restricted by a strained groin muscle. Coach Ray Perkins told both quarterbacks last night, and Simms was kept out of practice yesterday and today. He will not practice tomorrow, either.

title: HARWYN INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes interest and divd income of $137,670 in latest qr and $11,130 in yr-ago period...C-Includes interest and divd income of $217,258 and discount on a settlement terminatin a joint venture of $348,722...D-Includes interest and divd income of $46,230; the shr earnings and shrs outstndg reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Oct 14, 1980

title: NEW ATTORNEY FOR NEW YORK
description: As a youngster, Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr. had the ambition of most New York boys, to play for the Yankees. He was not good enough. He was good enough years later, however, to win a case against the Yankees when, representing the magazine Sports Illustrated, he forced the team to open its locker room to female reporters. With the exception of that early dream, ''Fritz'' Schwarz, as he is known, has had a remarkably varied career and, according to professional colleagues, has been eminently successful.

title: Index; International
description: Mubarak works to untangle Egypt's economic plight A2 U.S. protests to Britain on support for Saudi peace plan A3 Lord Carrington calls Saudi peace plan ''serious'' A3 Oman asks the U.S. to reduce the size of war games A4 Around the World A5 West German opposition party fights old-fashioned image A7 Tokyo court hands out first prison sentence in Lockheed scandal A8 Alarmed Mexico spends heavily to improve farming A10 Government/Politics Nancy Reagan is turning to humor in self-defense A17 Governors tell Senators of budget cut plight A18 Conferees decide to close National Acquarium in capital Secretary of State is in the middle of N.J.'s election problems B2 A18 Kemp is not expected to seek nomination for Governor B3 Washington Talk Briefing A16 Many pause at the Bernard Baruch Bench of Inspiration A16 Gamesmanship is rampant in scramble to avoid budget cuts A16 Required reading A16 General Around the Nation A14 Detroit News jumps gun on space shuttle ''launching'' A14 Dealer losing service station after rent dispute A14 Retired city detective finds his parents murdered B1 The City B3 17 members of Muslim sect found guilty of bank robberies B4 Trial opening in $21.3 million theft from Wells Fargo bank B5 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 Shipwrecked treasure on view at Queens museum C11 Theater: Broadway C2

title: 'CLOUD 9,' AS VIEWED BY THOSE FLOATING ON IT
description: It's an hour or so before curtain. The cast has gathered at the Theater De Lys to discuss Caryl Churchill's ''Cloud 9,'' a dark horse of an English play that has developed into one of the Off Broadway season's most talked-about hits. Soon the actors will spill out onto the stage as a typically Victorian family circle: a pukka sahib intent on ruling the jungle and his family in the British colonial Africa of the 1880's, his timid wife and her ferocious mother, his effeminate son, his good little rag-doll of a daughter, the whipflicking woman neighbor with whom he is having an affair, the maid who would like to have an affair with the wife, the visiting explorer who would like to have an affair with everyone and the obsequious little manservant who sees - and tells - all.

title: Padres Court Williams
description: Dick Williams, a focus of speculation as to future Yankee managers, is being sought by the San Diego Padres. ''Dick says he's interested,'' said Jack McKeon, the general manager, who added that he would be speaking further with Williams soon.

title: Art People
description: THOUGH it has moved only a few blocks west, down 125th Street from Fifth Avenue to the block between Seventh and Lenox Avenues, the Studio Museum in Harlem has come a long way. The old address, where the museum lived for 13 years since its founding in 1968, was a leased loft above a luncheonette and a liquor store; the new address, 144 West 125th Street - right across from the new Harlem State Office Building - is a handsome old edifice that is the Studio Museum's very own, a gift from the New York Bank for Savings. Ensconced there since August, the museum is now renovating three floors and the basement for its own use (the top three floors are rented out), with plans for a big opening next spring.

title: HAIG SAYS U.S. AID TO SALVADOR JUNTA MUST BE INCREASED
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that more American aid for El Salvador was needed and indicated that the Administration was examining ways to combat the flow of external military support to leftist guerrillas there.

title: Apuna Sues School
description: Ben Apuna, formerly a linebacker at Arizona State, filed a $2 million lawsuit in Phoenix, charging university officials with negligence for having him sign up for an extension course that he did not attend. Apuna played briefly for St. Louis and the Giants last season and is now with Toronto of the Canadian Football League.

title: HAIG IS DISPUTED BY WEINBERGER ON A-BLAST PLAN
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger contradicted Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today by saying that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization did not have a plan to use a nuclear explosion as a warning to the Soviet Union in the event of a war in Europe.

title: FORD TO SELL TAX CREDITS TO I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation will pay the Ford Motor Company $100 million to $200 million for the right to use Ford's investment tax credits and depreciation deductions on almost $1 billion worth of machinery that the troubled auto maker has purchased this year, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: KORCHNOI VICTORY SEEN
description: Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland adjourned the 13th game of the world championship chess match here tonight with a great advantage against the titleholder, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union: There is no question that Korchnoi sealed 42 QxN, giving himself the advantage of a queen for a rook and two pawns.

title: JOFFREY BALLET: 'LIGHT RAIN' ARPINO AT HIS SLICKEST
description: GERALD ARPINO'S newest sexy ballet is pure hard-core corn. ''Light Rain,'' a big belly-dance of a ballet that had its world premiere with the Joffrey Ballet at the City Center Wednesday night, is one of Mr. Arpino's slickest efforts in the pop-erotic genre and it is mighty good slick.

title: Capital Shake-Up
description: When the Washington Capitals won in their second game this season, Gary Green set a record for most victories by a coach in the franchise's eight-year history: 50. But since then the Capitals have lost 11 straight, a streak that caused the owner, Abe Pollin, to dismiss not only Green but also Max McNab, the general manager, yesterday.

title: SNIPES STILL EXPECTING TO BEAT HOLMES
description: Renaldo Snipes stood by his Chevy van, the one he said he was driving to the heavyweight championship, and planned his return trip from Pittsburgh.

title: Dow Falls 7.71; Volume Drops
description: With such recent favorites as energy, railroad and brokerage issues generally in retreat, stock prices declined yesterday amid profittaking.

title: Restaurants; Sushi at its best, simplicity in steak.
description: food noodle restaurant, Kurumazushi has a simple sign that could easily be missed. To enter the restaurant, on Madison Avenue, between 48th and 49th Streets, you must first walk into the Dosanko, climb the stairs and slide open a more or less Japanese wood-and-glass door, all of which might cause you to suspect you are in the wrong place. The interior is equally uninspiring, with its big bar, small sushi counter and a few tatami alcoves lined up against the front window. But the crush of Japanese customers eating sushi and sashimi is testimony to the superiority of this establishment, especially when one realizes they are paying $30 to $40 a person for the privilege, especially at dinner. Nowhere in New York have we found sushi so well-made and so delicately balanced in texture, temperature and flavor.

title: LUPINETTI OF ITALY TAKES PUISSANCE AT THE GARDEN
description: Puissance means strength, or might, and Uberto Lupinetti showed just enough strength with Twilight last night to capture the grueling wall-jumping event in the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.

title: KEY AIDE TO WILSON IN LIBYA DESCRIBED
description: The American pilots and mechanics who are maintaining helicopters for the Libyan Air Force and training Libyan airmen are being directed by a former covert employee of the Central Intelligence Agency, according to intelligence officials and Americans who worked in Libya.

title: G.M. House Plan In New York Area
description: The General Motors Corporation extended its ''Buy a House - Get a Car'' campaign to the threestate metropolitan area around New York City. Under the program, identical to one just completed in Detroit, residents of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut who buy 42 houses the auto maker has acquired from transferred employees will receive a free car, or the cash value of the car.

title: FRIONA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results include equity in net earnings of affiliates of $38,000 for the latest first qr and $50,000 for the previous first qr

title: DELIGHTED DIANA EXPECTS BABY IN JUNE
description: The Princess of Wales is expecting a baby next June, Buckingham Palace announced today. The former Lady Diana Spencer, who was married to Prince Charles on July 29 in a ceremony of pomp and grandeur seen on television by hundreds of millions of people, emerged from the @semiseclusion of a three-month honeymoon only last month. She and her husband made a triumphal tour of Wales last week, and several people wept with excitement when she stopped to chat with them.

title: U.S. PROSTESTS TO BRITAIN ON SAUDI PLAN
description: The United States has protested to Britain about statements made in recent days by its Foreign Secretary, Lord Carrington, endorsing Saudi Arabia's Middle East peace plan. His remarks have produced a threat in Israel not to accept European participation in the Sinai peacekeeping force.

title: A PLANNED TOWN GOING UP AT PROJECT
description: In the shadow of two majestic Rocky Mountain peaks, Battlement Mesa, a subdivision of Parachute, is being built from scratch by sponsors of the Colony shale oil project. It is expected eventually to have a population of 25,000.

title: GOVERNORS COMPLAIN ON BUDGET CUTS
description: Three leading Governors said today that Federal spending cuts were hurting state budgets and threatening President Reagan's economic program.

title: AMERICAN WATER WORKS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
description: SHARON VISITS ISRAELI SETTLEMENTS: Ariel Sharon, at left, the Israeli Defense Minister, being greeted by Jewish settlers yesterday in Bet Hadassah in central Hebron. Earlier during his visit to the Occupied West Bank, Mr. Sharon said, ''Our answer to the eight points of the Saudi plan is eight Israeli settlements.''

title: LOSING IS NO JOKE AT NORTHWESTERN
description: The fall afternoon, growing chillier, was quickly coming to a close. Although the darkening sky was still blue and streaked with orange, a half-moon, white and prominent, had appeared above the black bare branches of the trees at the south end of Dyche Stadium. The lights for the parking lot had been turned on. Down on the field, the Northwestern University football team was in the final stages of the day's practice.

title: G.M.A.C. Profit Up
description: The General Motors Corporation's financing arm, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, said today that its earnings in the third quarter rose to $108.5 million from $72.5 million a year before.

title: GENERAL HYDROCARBONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LIFE AT THE CENTER OF JERSEY VOTE TALLYING
description: New Jersey's Secretary of State, who is also the state's chief election officer, was about to begin a paper-plate lunch of cottage cheese and salad at his desk today when the phone rang.

title: NOVAR ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONROY INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
CONCORD FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $310,000, or 17 cents a shr for the qr and $740,000 or 52 cents a shr for the yr... C-Net loss

title: LINCOLN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRAIN HEADING NOWHERE SIDETRACKS 500
description: A Long Island Rail Road train carrying 500 Manhattan-bound commuters got lost yesterday morning, and it was an hour before it got back on the right track.

title: PUT THE MX WHERE THE PEOPLE ARE
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Coca Cola Co. said that it had purchased Coke Investors Inc., a bottler holding company, from AEA Investors of New York and other owners.

title: AMEND THE CLEAN AIR ACT
description: The Clean Air Act has become a double-edged sword. One edge is the act's laudable objective of protecting public health from the effects of excessive air pollution. Unhappily, the other is the use, at times, of the incredible complexity of the 185-page law to impose Federal controls that retard economic development, industrial productivity, and the achievement of clean air.

title: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1981; The Economy
description: The Government will institute a trade action for the first time next week, accusing foreign governments of unfairly subsidizing steel exports to this country, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige announced. The move was viewed as increasing the dangers of a trade war. The countries that are expected to be cited are France, Belgium, Luxembourg, Rumania and South Africa. (Page A1.)

title: Georgia Officials Held In Drug Smuggling Case
description: Two Atlanta area law-enforcement officers, a probate judge and a former county commissioner have been arrested on drug smuggling charges as the result of a covert operation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Drug Enforcement Administration.

title: Carnegie-Mellon Artists To Present 3 Concerts
description: Three evenings of music by musicians affiliated with the Carnegie-Mellon University are planned this weekend at Carnegie Recital Hall, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street.

title: PIANO VIRTUOSOS HOLD CENTER STAGE
description: THE renowned pianist Abbey Simon, whose recital tonight at 8 in Carnegie Hall comes as part of his 60th birthday celebration, is convinced that the solo performance remains the ultimate test of any artist.

title: GERTRUDE YOST DOBSON
description: Gertrude Yost Dobson, the mother of Senatory Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, has died at the age of 81, a statement from the Senator's office said. Mrs. Dobson died Tuesday after a long illness. Her son is assistant Senate majority leader.

title: MORSE SHOE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Latest qr and 9 mos reflect change to LIFO method of accounting

title: COMBINED COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POLITICAL 'BUDDY SYSTEM' LIVES IN NIXON-HAIG TIES
description: When Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. telephones ''Mr. President'' to discuss foreign affairs these days, the man on the other end of the line is not always Ronald Reagan.

title: PUBLISHING: A FULL-SCALE BIOGRAPHY OF PASTERNAK
description: WORN down by the campaign of vilification waged against him by Soviet authorities after he won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1958, Boris Pasternak began carrying a fatal dose of poison with him, and he suggested to his longtime mistress that they die together as ''a slap in the face'' of their persecutors.

title: NEIGHBORS TRIED TO OPPOSE DISCO RAIDED BY POLICE
description: A Manhattan discotheque in which the police arrested 380 persons Wednesday night had long been the object of complaints by neighborhood residents. And the city's Consumer Affairs Department had been frustrated in its two-month-long effort to close it.

title: MOORE PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Serby Charges Todd
description: Richard Todd, the Jet quarterback, was formally charged with assault yesterday by Steve Serby, the New York Post reporter whom Todd had injured the day before by shoving him into a locker and then to the ground.

title: NEW YORK INVENTOR WINS A CONCESSION IN BATTLE WITH ARMY
description: Army officials misled Congress with ''inaccurate, unproven and inconsistent'' information about their refusal to do business with a New York City company, Pentagon officials said at a Senate hearing today.

title: WELBILT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: B-After foreign currency losses equal to 18 cents a shr for the qr and 48 cents a shr for the qr and 48 cents a shr for the 9 mos and $394,000 extraordinary gain for the 9 mos... C-After foreign currency gains equal to 4 cents a shr for the qr and 6 cents a shr for the 9 mos and extraordinary credits of $229,000 for the qr and $451,000 for the 9 mos

title: Mobil-Marathon Hearing Nov.17
description: A Federal judge has set Nov.17 as the date for a hearing on the preliminary injunction in the Marathon Oil Company's antitrust complaint against the Mobil Corporation's attempt to buy a controlling $3.4 billion interest.

title: RELIANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes gains on investments of $5,645,000 for the qr and $27,047,000 for the 9 mos...C-Includes gains on investment of $5,998,000 for the qr and $17,073,000 for the 9 mos

title: EDISON BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CP NATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $793,000 or 47 cents a shr from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting

title: F.C.C. ASKS COMMENT ON EASING CABLE LIMITS
description: By a unanimous vote, the Federal Communications Commission put out for public comment today a staff report that recommends the removal of all restrictions on cable television ownership.

title: Illustrators at Met
description: The illustrators Alice and Martin Provensen, whose work has appeared in many children's books, will greet readers and sign autographs tomorrow from 1:30 to 2:30 P.M. at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, at the third in a meet-the-illustrators series.

title: Senate Votes to Delay Funds For B-1 Bomber and the MX
description: The Senate gave voice-vote approval tonight to a compromise $130.7 billion Defense Department authorization bill that would put a temporary hold on building the B-1 bomber and basing the MX missile.

title: GRUMMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Grumman said that the third qr earnings were lower because of a $13 million increase in the operating loss of the Flxible bus program and a $9.5 million rise in interest charges; the qr also includes a gain of about $3 million from the sale of a manufacturing facility; the company added that the 9 mos results were depressed by a $36 million increase in its Flxible Corp's operating loss and a $28 million drop in bus sales

title: Disney Net Down 7.1%
description: Walt Disney Productions announced yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of fiscal year 1981 fell by 7.1 percent, to $37.7 million, or $1.15 a share, from $40.6 million, or $1.25 a share, in the corresponding quarter in 1980. Revenues in the quarter, which ended on Sept. 30, advanced by 16.2 percent, to $308.4 million, from $265.5 million. The company said the decline was due to disappointing domestic results from several movies.

title: BRINK'S SUSPECT RELEASED AFTER F.B.I. CHECKS ALIBI
description: A conspiracy charge against Cynthia Boston, a suspect in the Rockland County armored-car robbery, was dismissed yesterday because a ''reliable witness'' had seen her in New Orleans at the time Federal authorities believed she was in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: Continental Air Reports Loss
description: Continental Air Lines today reported a third-quarter loss of $12.2 million on operating revenues of $305 million, bringing its loss for the first nine months of the year to $50 million.

title: 30-YEAR BONDS TO YIELD 14.10%
description: The Treasury sold $2 billion of 30-year 14 percent bonds yesterday at an average yield of 14.10 percent, to complete a heavy week of financing that included auctions of three- and six-month bills, three-year notes, 10-year notes and 30-year bonds.

title: PAIN AND ANGER ARE SHARED AT SERVICE FOR SLAIN SURGEON
description: More than 500 mourners attended a memorial service here today for Dr. John Chase Wood Jr., who was shot to death Monday night near Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan.

title: Israeli Cabinet Official To Be Tried for Larceny
description: Israel's Supreme Court ruled today that a Cabinet minister, Aharon Abuhazira, must stand trial on larceny charges. Mr. Abuhazira, who has responsibility for labor, social welfare and immigrantion policies, had argued that he was immune from prosecution because he is a newly elected Member of Parliament.

title: TO NATHAN MILSTEIN, THE EX-CHILD PRODIGY AT 77, LIFE IS MUSIC
description: The violinist Nathan Milstein rushes to the piano in his hotel suite, stands over the keyboard, glances enthusiastically at a visitor and plays the opening phrases of the first Bach solo violin Sonata. The violinist remains standing as he plays, as if the grand piano were just another portable string instrument; the melodic line is delicately articulated, supple and breathing, arriving and departing from its nodal points with a controlled freedom.

title: Books of the Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt POPPA JOHN. By Larry Woiwode. 203 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95.

title: SHALE OIL IS COMING OF AGE
description: Six months ago this dusty, western Colorado town, 17 miles from the nearest motel room and an hour's drive from a hospital, had only 300 residents, most of whom maintained a weary cynicism about yet another series of reports of impending economic boom.

title: ALEXANDER J. BAILIE
description: Alexander J. Bailie, an executive vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died Wednesday at his home in Stamford, Conn.

title: THE NAME OF THE GAME IS DUCKING THE BUDGET AX
description: Budget makers here have long noticed a peculiar phenomenon involving the United States Geological Survey. It seems that each time the agency's spending comes up for review, there is an almost immediate rise in predictions of earthquake activity. Scientists are baffled.

title: A World to Feed 13th article of a series appearing periodically
description: Seemingly hypnotized by its extraordinary oil discoveries and the resulting industrial boom of the late 1970's, Mexico barely noticed when it joined those oil-exporting countries that depend on imported grains to feed their population. The social and economic implications of this development were serious, yet even deteriorating nutritional standards, rising food prices and accelerated peasant migration from the depressed countryside were insufficient to break the trance.

title: MCDERMOTT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
11 Arrested for Hunting Rabbits as a Food
description: Eleven South Side men and youths, most of them unemployed, have been arrested for killing wild rabbits near Lake Michigan for food.

title: Benton Harbor Mayor Faces Charges in Handling of Funds
description: The Mayor and City Attorney of Benton Harbor, Mich., have been indicted on charges of embezzlement and bribery in connection with a city housing program, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: RETIRED CITY DETECTIVE FINDS HIS PARENTS SLAIN IN QUEENS
description: Just a few weeks ago, John Alberga, 81 years old, and his wife, Jinny, 75, signed themselves out of a hospital -they were both patients - so they could attend the wedding of a grandchild, a daughter of their son, James. They were also celebrating their 55th wedding anniversary.

title: 16-BILLION HOME LOAN SUPPORT AMONG CUTS REAGAN ORDERED
description: The White House disclosed today that President Reagan had made a $16 billion cut in Federal support for loans to purchase homes as the centerpiece of a larger effort to curb the Government's appetite for credit.

title: FINDS SIGNS OF NUCLEAR ARMS
description: Sweden said today that it believed there were nuclear torpedo warheads aboard the Soviet submarine that has been stranded for 10 days near a Swedish naval base. But it said the vessel and its crew of 56 would be released ''as soon as weather permits.''

title: U.S. ASKED TO TRIM WAR GAMES
description: Oman has ordered the United States to reduce the size and scope of a United States Marine landing exercise in the Arabian Sea-Persian Gulf area, Reagan Administration sources said today.

title: No Headline
description: DANTLEY'S 43 PACE JAZZ VICTORY

title: DR. SAMUEL ROSEN, EAR-SURGERY PIONEER, DIES AT 84
description: Dr. Samuel Rosen, an ear surgeon who gained worldwide acclaim for developing the ''Rosen stapes'' operation to restore hearing to partly deaf people, died yesterday in Peking. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: JUMPING THE GUN ON A SHUTTLE SHOT
description: The Detroit News went a little too far ahead in its coverage of the Columbia space shuttle mission Wednesday morning. The time to start the presses for the first edition of the afternoon newspaper is 7:45 A.M. That was also the moment the space shuttle was to have lifted off from its launching pad at Cape Canaveral, Fla., after delays late in the countdown.

title: DIBRELL BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ESQUIRE RADIO & ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Secretaries of State; Disarming
description: It should have remained a military secret, but now that it's not, the Reagan Administration deserves its due: its war strategy seems to be the most imaginative ever devised by any atomic-age Government of the U.S.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I do hope that it will be a son because that is what every English man and woman want.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 6, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: KALVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: B-Includes tax credits of $143,000 in the latest qr and $106,000 in 1980...C-Includes tax credits of $234,000 in the latest period and $153,000 in 1980 6 mos

title: TANAKA ALLY LOSES IN LOCKHEED CASE
description: A Tokyo court today handed down the first prison sentence in the 1976 Lockheed bribery scandal that led to the indictment of former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka.

title: STRAWBRIDGE & CLOTHIER HAS SUCCESSION PLAN
description: Strawbridge & Clothier, a leading Philadelphia-area department store group, has announced a management succession plan. Next Feb. 1, Winthrop deV. Schwab, 63, will succeed Randall E. Copeland, 72, as chairman. And a year later, Mr. Schwab will retire to become a financial consultant to the store and will be succeeded by Francis R. Strawbridge 3d, 43, who will hold the rank of vice chairman for the next year.

title: Market Place; Utility Spinoff To Save Cash
description: CENTRAL LOUISIANA ENERGY is spinning off its electric utility to become an aggressive regional energy company this month. That is a marked departure. For years, the utility earned modest profits on its gas-fed power plants. The company, critics say, was operated as if that gas, which it bought from outside sources, would always be cheap and plentiful.

title: DANT & RUSSELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange

title: Broadway; A musical hitched to high school days due early in '82.
description: ''IS THERE LIFE AFTER HIGH SCHOOL?'' The answer is yes, at least on Broadway. This perky question is the title of a new musical comedy due to open after the first of the year. The show will be directed by Melvin Bernhardt, who has just staged the newest Broadway hit, ''Crimes of the Heart.''

title: SPANISH GOLD MAKES PORT IN QUEENS
description: Gold, $10 million worth of it - in gleaming doubloons, pieces of eight, bullion, jewelry and seven-foot-long chains - forms the centerpiece of ''Shipwrecked 1622,'' an exhibition on view at the Queens Museum in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park through Nov. 29.

title: PENGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Economic Scene; Finding a Path To Stability
description: HOW can national economic policy aimed at curing ''stagflation'' avoid, on one side, the danger of pushing the economy into a depression and, on the other, regenerating higher inflation? The problem is exacerbated today by the overstrained debt positions of many companies, as indicated by liquidity ratios calculated by the Bank of New York.

title: THE STAGE: 'L'ATELIER,' IN POSTWAR EUROPE
description: Jean-Claude Grumberg's ''L'Atelier'' (or ''The Workroom'') is a quiet but resonant play about the aftermath of the Holocaust, the way people try to excuse the complicity of silence by claiming ignorance. The play, in its East Coast premiere at the Trinity Square Repertory Company, also deals with the shortness of memory and the quickness of history. As one character observes, the movement from ''postwar'' to another state of ''prewar'' is almost imperceptible. Before time escapes, Mr. Grumberg wants us to remember the victims and also the victimizers.

title: DIXICO NAMES PRESIDENT AND CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: William N. Kassen, 46, has been elected president and chief executive officer of Dixico Inc., a manufacturer of packaging and plastic materials primarily for the snack food industry, with headquarters in Dallas. He succeeds Louis T. Kimple, 60, who will become chairman.

title: Auto Output Off in Month
description: Domestic car and truck production last month fell to the lowest level of any October since 1970, a trade publication reported today.

title: Camacho Outpoints Murray in 10-Rounder
description: Hector Camacho, a 19-year-old high school student from Spanish Harlem who stuffed himself with soda, ice cream and cake for two days to put on weight, scored a one-sided 10-round decision over Anthony Murray of Nashville last night at the Felt Forum in a lightweight bout.

title: MYERS, L E, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PRESIDENT STILL RESISTS TAX RISES
description: President Reagan was described today as leaning against making any significant revisions in his economic package, despite continuing advice from some aides and Republicans in Congress that he accept the idea of tax increases to balance the Federal budget.

title: ALLEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: 26% Increase Sought In Malpractice Rates
description: The Medical Liability Mutual Insurance Company, which underwrites most of the malpractice coverage for New York physicians, has accepted the recommendation of the State Superintendent of Insurance and applied for a 26.3 percent increase in premium rates, a spokesman for the company said yesterday.

title: BEVERLY HILLS SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DRAMATIC END TO SPRING SHOWS
description: Two intense weeks of spring fashion openings ended on a theatrical note yesterday as Mary McFadden presented her pre-Columbian collection in the marble Astor Hall of the New York Public Library. Her models moved with a slow, regal air suggesting Indian princesses in her pleated Grecian columnar dresses and quilted coats.

title: Auctions
description: THE auction season in New York is off to a mixed start with some categories of sales registering brisk bidding and many records, and with disappointing results for sellers in others. Sales of modern and Impressionist art at Christie's last Tuesday night and at Sotheby Parke Bernet on Wednesday night are a cases in point. The first session of Christie's two-part sale totaled $530,000 instead of the low estimate of $1.6 million, and the second part realized $4.1 million, where at least $6.9 million had been estimated. However, some art works sold at their highest estimates, for instance two Picassos, which were the most important works in the sale, ''Bottle of Anis del Mono, Compote, Dish, Pipe,'' which brought $500,000, and ''Fair Booth at Kermis,'' $450,000. And some others dramatically surpassed expectations, for example, another Picasso, ''Female Nude and Bird and Flutist,'' $190,000, and Henri Fantin-Latour's ''White Roses,'' $120,000.

title: REAGAN CUTS OFF HAIG DISPUTE
description: President Reagan today ordered Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Richard V. Allen, the White House national security adviser, to end the feuding that Mr. Reagan believes to be disrupting the Administration's foreign policy operations.

title: HANOVER INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ART: BENEATH THE CHARM, THE GRAVITY OF BONNARD
description: PAINTERS whose work offers the eye an instant and irresistible sensation of pleasure often run the risk of being misunderstood. The very pleasure we take in their pictures may have the paradoxical effect of blinding us, if only temporarily, to the seriousness of the thought that has been invested in them. With art that is obviously abrasive or otherwise ''difficult,'' we are probably more inclined to search out an inner meaning - to decode, as it were, the ideas that animate the offending attributes. To art that captures our immediate response, we tend to submit without reflection and then make the mistake of declaring the art to be thin or devoid of ideas.

title: Conferees Vote to Sell Washington Aquarium
description: Congressional conference committee has voted to close the National Aquarium in Washington and auction its fish, ending a long battle to rescue the tourist attraction from budget cuts by the Reagan Administration.

title: Golf Rabbit to Be Extinct
description: The rabbit of the professional golf tour is about to go the way of the dinosaur and the dodo. Beginning in 1983, Monday qualifying will no longer be required for tournaments.

title: LANE WOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $495,000 for the qr and $670,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including extraordinary tax credits of $257,000 for the qr and $412,000 for the 9 mos

title: Notes on People; Patricia Neal's Advice: Don't Give Up
description: ''The first thing you have to do after suffering a stroke is to tell yourself you won't give up, that you don't want to die, or be cared for like a baby the rest of your life,'' Patricia Neal was saying yesterday.

title: TRIAL OPENING IN $21.3 MILLION WELLS FARGO THEFTS
description: Harold Rossfields Smith, once one of the nation's most powerful boxing promoters, and an associate, Sammie Marshall, went on trial trial on charges that they stole $21.3 million from the Wells Fargo National Bank.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: L ITTLE Orphan Annie has never grown up, but Andrea McArdle, the original Broadway ''Annie,'' has. She turned 18 yesterday and celebrated with a party at the St. Regis Hotel, where she's singing in a revue. Wearing a suede pants outfit trimmed with lizard and a topaz bracelet (a birthday present from Peter Gennaro, the choreographer), she cut a giant cake, fed some to her former co-star, Sandy, (who licked off the icing) and was ceremoniously offered a glass of Champagne to mark her coming of age.

title: CATHOLIC BISHOPS FOR AMENDMENT ALLOWING STATES TO BAN ABORTIONS
description: The National Conference of Catholic Bishops today endorsed a constitutional amendment that would empower Congress and individual states to adopt laws regulating and banning abortion.

title: BLUE BELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV Weekend; RIPLEY, SERIES FOR KIDS, 'ALICE' FINALE
description: LONG before ''That's Incredible!'' and other such television concoctions, there was ''Ripley's Believe It or Not!'' a syndicated newspaper feature purporting to prove conclusively that truth is stranger than fiction. The Ripley confection even pops up on television occasionally, and tonight at 8:30, it is being given another electronic whirl on ABC-TV.

title: YANKS PLAN TO SHUN FREE AGENT DRAFT
description: George Steinbrenner, who has been an object of criticism by other owners because of the free agent contracts he has negotiated, announced yesterday that the Yankees' ''present intention is to not participate'' in the free agent draft next Friday.

title: PISTONS DEFEAT NETS BY 6
description: With the Detroit Pistons, convincing winners of their first two regular-season games, nursing a 94-89 lead late in their game against the New Jersey Nets tonight, a woman near the court at the Silverdome shouted, ''Hey, where's the team we had last week?''

title: Chicago Catholics Bid Cody Respond on Funds
description: A group of Roman Catholics said today they would ask John Cardinal Cody to respond to charges that he diverted church funds to a friend.

title: SIERRA PACIFIC POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
17 IN MUSLIM SECT CONVICTED OF ROBBING BANKS
description: Seventeen members of a Muslim sect were found guilty today of robbing banks to raise money for their religion. They had refused to defend themselves against Federal racketeering charges on the ground that they were victims of religious persecution.

title: T.C.U. on Probation For Recruiting Abuse
description: Texas Christian's basketball program was placed on one-year probation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association today for what the association called the improper recruiting of one player. No other sanctions were imposed.

title: FOX-STANLEY PHOTO PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PATERNITY SUIT FOCUSES ON FEMINISM AND FREEDOM
description: Frank Serpico and Karen DeCrow would be an unlikely team in any court of law, but the scene in Family Court in Manhattan yesterday was even more improbable.

title: GENERAL DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A FORCE, NOT A TIDE
description: It's all too easily forgotten and sometimes never understood that politics is an unfolding drama, a play that never ends, with each act inevitably affecting those yet to come. Just when the curtain falling on one election may seem to bring the action to a close, new actors with new lines are always moving toward the stage. You can depend upon it.

title: A FRESH WAY TO FINANCE REHABILITATION
description: One of the more promising developments in an otherwise uninspiring housing scene is the continuing expansion of efforts to upgrade older occupied apartment buildings in moderate-income neighborhoods. Nowhere is this more important than in New York City, with its inventory of about a million privately owned apartments more than half a century old.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Five jurists - representatives of Britain, France, India, Senegal and Argentina - were elected to nineyear terms today on the International Court of Justice, the judicial arm of the United Nations.

title: ROYAL INSURANCE MAKES U.S. CHANGES
description: The American subsidiary of Britain's Royal Insurance Company has named George W. Ansbro, 53 years old, as president and chief operating officer, effective next Jan. 1. He will succeed William C. Simpson, 63, who will retire from the New York-based organization. J. Roy Nicholas, a 59-year-old executive of the American company, continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Impressive Strides on Namibia
description: There is a hardheaded reason why South Africa may finally be ready to resolve the protracted conflict over Namibia. Its white rulers know that Ronald Reagan is the most sympathetic American President they are ever likely to confront in the negotiations. This is the time, in other words, to get the best available terms for granting genuine independence to the vast and mineral-rich territory that South Africa has been holding illegally. And if that appeal works, Mr. Reagan will have confounded many doubters - us among them.

title: Moody's Lowers RCA Debt Rating
description: Moody's Investors Service lowered its rating on the RCA Corporation's senior unsecured debt and industrial development bonds to BAA from A. Moody's also lowered its ratings on the company's preferred stock and convertible debentures to BA from BAA.

title: QUEBEC IS OPPOSED
description: The Canadian Government and the country's nine predominantly English-speaking provinces reached agreement today on a new Canadian constitution.

title: CONSOLIDATED REFINING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FRENCH FILMS REDISCOVERED IN FESTIVAL AT THE MODERN
description: THE mention of ''French films'' usually conjures up images of tortuous love triangles, rainy Parisian nights and the sounds of mournful saxophones. Yet these popular conceptions may be subtly altered by an ambitious festival of French films distinguished by lavish indoor sets, couples unambiguously in love and happy endings.

title: RAMPART GENERAL INC reports earnings for Yr to Mar 30
Panasonic Expands With Grey Advertising
description: After 16 years using only the Ted Bates Advertising agency for consumer advertising, the Panasonic Company, a division of the Matsushita Electric Corporation of America, has decided to enlarge its agency list. Grey Advertising is the beneficiary of that decision.

title: Dayton-Hudson Plans Expansion
description: The Dayton-Hudson Corporation, the nation's eighth-largest retailer, and one of the most diversified, said yesterday that it planned to expand by more than 750 stores over the next five years. The expansion plan is one of the most ambitious ever announced by a United States retailer.

title: ERNST, E C, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss...C-Including $11,802,000 or $3.30 a shr extraordinary income; revs figures represent contract income

title: NATIONAL SILVER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IT WAS A VICTORY PARTY FOR 'CRIMES OF THE HEART'
description: Opening-night parties for hits are all alike; opening-night parties for turkeys are dismal each in their own way. ''Crimes of the Heart,'' which opened Wednesday night at the John Golden Theater, is a hit. Therefore, at the party for ''Crimes of the Heart'' on Wednesday night, its myriad producers smiled; one of the stars called her mother; the director said he couldn't have done it without the cast, and people kept talking to the author while she tried to eat dinner. This is the way it was supposed to be.

title: DISNEY, WALT, PRODUCTIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRITON CALLS SAUDI PROPOSAL 'SERIOUS' AND 'POSITIVE'
description: Lord Carrington, the British Foreign Secretary, said today that Saudi Arabia's Middle East peace plan had common ground with the Common Market's declaration on the Arab-Israeli conflict.

title: OFFSHORE LOGISTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $1.8 million loss from discontinued operations

title: St. Luke's Church Begins to Rebuild
description: Work on the reconstruction of St. Luke in the Fields Episcopal Church in Greenwich Village began yesterday as Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of New York dedicated the materials to be used in the rebuilding.

title: DEL LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results include $4.5 million pretax proceeds from business interruption insurance, net of settlement costs and specified fire-related expenses but with no adjustment for other direct or indirect costs attributable to the fire

title: OVERSEAS SHIPHOLDING GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $2,472,000 foreign currency loss for the qr and $1,196,000 foreign currency gain for the 9 mos and $6,858,000 gain for both periods representing the recovery of prior yrs deferred credits related to a British subsidiary and $3,228,000 gain for the 9 mos on the sale of a vessel...C-After foreign currency losses of $223,000 for the qr and $983,000 for the 9 m and $2,858,000 gain from the sale of 50 percent interest in a v

title: Phone Calls Are Listed in Point-Shaving Case
description: About 200 telephone calls made from hotels or from the homes of the defendants in the Boston College baskeball point-shaving case were placed in evidence yesterday by the prosecutor, Edward A. McDonald, at Brooklyn Federal court. The calls were made during the 1978-79 season in which the defendants were said to have conspired to shave points in six games in order to profit by gambling.

title: Soviet Bank Financing
description: The Soviet Union relied heavily on its foreign bank deposits for its financing needs in the first half of this year, the Bank for International Settlements said today.

title: U.S. Courts And France
description: American courts are likely to accept France's right to nationalize banks and industrial companies and will probably deem adequate the compensation it is offering shareholders, according to a study prepared for the French authorities by a major American law firm.

title: Notes on People
description: Cuts at C.A.B.'s When Marvin S. Cohen took over as chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board three years ago, he did so with the understanding that he would continue the policy set by his predecessor, Alfred Kahn, to carry out deregulation of the airline industry and put the agency out of business.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 17.00-17.50.** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.+ Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CRIB DEATHS LINKED TO HORMONE LEVELS IN AN AUTOPSY STUDY
description: The discovery of unusually high hormone levels in babies stricken by sudden infant death syndrome may pave the way for a simple blood test to identify infants in danger of crib death, according to researchers.

title: Schwartz Appointed Sports Commissioner
description: Allen G. Schwartz, who is leaving his post as Corporation Counsel of New York City , was appointed by Mayor Koch yesterday to the new position of Sports Commissioner.

title: MRS. REAGAN TURNS ATTACKS INTO JESTS
description: Nancy Reagan, who ranks lower in popularity polls than some recent Presidents' wives, is using ''Queen Nancy'' postcards and First Family paper dolls to her advantage.

title: News Analysis
description: The struggle within the Reagan Administration for the President's favor on economic policy is pitting the budget balancers against the supply-side advocates. Regardless of the outcome, the all-out debate has already provoked doubts, even within the Administration's highest councils, over whether the Reagan economic program can work. In pushing for tax increases of about $80 billion over three years, David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget and an advocate of balancing the Federal budget, is implicitly acknowledging that the original Reagan economic program cannot work. This program assumed that, with large domestic spending cuts, there could be at the same time big military spending increases, large tax cuts, a balanced budget by 1984 and strong economic growth.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1981
description: International A constitutional accord in Canada was reached by the federal Government and the nine English-speaking provinces against the opposition of Quebec. The majority achieved a compromise that would allow Canada to gain control of its constitution from Britain and become fully independent after years of debate. (Page A1, Column 6.) Differences on NATO war planning in the Reagan Administration were indicated in Senate testimony by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger. He said that NATO did not have a plan to use a nuclear explosion as a warning to Moscow in the event of a war in Europe, as Secretary of State Alexander Mr. Haig Jr. had testified. (A1:5.)

title: News Analysis
description: The acquittal of Elvis Presley's doctor today followed a month of testimony touching on issues significant far beyond the confines of a small, modern courtroom in Memphis.

title: ACMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RARE BILLS-COWBOYS GAME SPICES N.F.L.
description: Buffalo's Joe Cribbs, the halfback who runs, blocks, catches passes and scores touchdowns as well as anyone in the National Football League, and Tony Dorsett of Dallas, who has similar skills, will be in the spotlight Monday night at Dallas the Bills play the Cowboys (Channel 7 in New York, 9 P.M.).

title: At the Movies; Films that don't move, but do work.
description: ACCORDING to Louis Malle, the French-born director of ''Murmur of the Heart,'' ''Lacombe, Lucien'' and ''Atlantic City,'' Darryl Zanuck used to tell film makers, ''If you're in trouble, cut to the chase.''

title: THE FOLLY OF SELLING ALASKA NORTH SLOPE OIL TO JAPAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Grumman Off 17.2%; McDermott Doubles
description: The Grumman Corporation reported yesterday that earnings for the third quarter totaled $5.3 million, or 37 cents a share, down 17.2 percent from earnings of $6.4 million, or 44 cents a share, for the third quarter last year.

title: JOSEPH E. BECK
description: Joseph E. Beck, former executive director of the National Refugee Service, died yesterday in Palo Alto. He was 77 years old.

title: A TUNEUP FOR LARRY HOLMES
description: AWAY back in the dark ages of 1951, Ezzard Charles, the heavyweight champion of the world, was encountered on a train, which was a popular form of travel in those times. Asked about his immediate future, he said he was booked to fight Jersey Joe Walcott for the Dapper Dan Club in Pittsburgh. He had already whipped Walcott twice, winning in 15 uneventful rounds when they met for the title left vacant by Joe Louis's retirement and again on points in a rematch, when a left hook in a late round left him with a right ear the size of a softball.

title: Emigre Orchestra in Hunter Series
description: The Soviet Emigre Orchestra, with the pianist Boris Bloch, will open the People's Symphony Concert Festival series Sunday at 2:30 P.M. at Hunter College, 69th Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues. The orchestra comprises recent Soviet emigres and young American musicians.

title: FASTEN YOUR SEAT BELTS
description: To the Editor:

title: 'TIME BANDITS,' A LARK THROUGH THE EONS
description: ''TIME BANDITS'' is a cheerfully irreverent lark - part fairy tale, part science fiction and part comedy. It's a fantastic though wobbly flight through history and legend in the company of a small boy named Kevin and six dwarfs named Randall, Fidgit, Wally, Og, Stutter and Vermin. These are not your ordinary, run-of-the-mill little people. They're more like the angry, liberated ids of the crowd Snow White hung out with.

title: Bridge: Goren Award by Writers Is Given to Deng Xiaoping
description: A highlight of the world championship play in Port Chester, N.Y., last week had nothing to do with the play or the players. For the first time ever, a bridge award was given to a leader of one of the world's great powers. It was the Charles Goren Award for the bridge personality of the year, given under the auspices of the International Bridge Press Association.

title: U.S. Delegation Tours West Sahara War Zone
description: A United States military delegation headed by Francis J. West Jr., Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs, arrived here yesterday and spent today touring the Western Sahara war zone, Moroccan military sources reported.

title: DANGERS IN OVERSTATING UNDERNUTRITION
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. PLANS DIRECT COMPLAINTS TO NATIONS SUBSIDIZING STEEL
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige announced today that the Government, for the first time, would bring official complaints accusing foreign governments of unfairly subsidizing steel exports to this country.

title: A HOMECOMING FOR JORDAN'S QUEEN
description: Gone are the long hair and dungarees. The love beads have given way to diamonds and gold. She has changed her name and even speaks with a different accent.
