title: COASTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $76 million extraordinary charge for the qr and 9 mos for expected losses on future disposition of two crude oil tankers...C-Net income

title: DEPUTY MINISTER WINS BY 3 LENGTHS
description: Deputy Minister made one devastating move round the final turn to pull away from 13 challengers and romp home a three-length winner in the $282,750 Young America Stakes tonight at the Meadowlands.

title: OPERATOR PROUD OF LOST FIGHT OVER SERVICE STATION
description: At midnight tomorrow, Bob Wilson's Exxon here will no longer be Robert J. Wilson's. The broadshouldered, soft-spoken service station operator is sorry about that, but he voices no regrets about the fight over rental rates that has cost him his business.

title: GERMAN OPPOSTION TRYING ON A NEW IMAGE
description: The Christian Democratic Party concluded a national convention today, convinced that it had taken steps to shed an image that it feared was one of babbit@try, inspirationless and old-fashioned.

title: U.S. Silver Output Down
description: The United States Interior Department's Bureau of Mines said yesterday that United States mine production of silver fell 8.2 percent in August, to 2.996 million troy ounces, from 3.262 million in July.

title: Ford of Mexico In Credit Pact
description: Ford of Mexico announced it had signed a syndicated credit agreement for $280 million, the largest ever arranged for a Mexican private corporation.

title: CELLU-CRAFT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $70,000 for the qr and $212,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including income from discontinu operations of $35,000 for the qr and $57,000 for the 9 mos and extraordinary credits of $88,000 for the qr and $264,000 for the 9 mos

title: A PAUSE AT BERNARD BARUCH'S BENCH
description: Bernard Baruch called it his Bench of Inspiration, a spot where, as an old man with dreams still to dream, he often sat to drowse in the warming sun or to watch the comings and goings at the White House across the way.

title: NOVUS PROPERTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sears Accepts Dean Witter Stock
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said that 4,255,988 shares of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. common stock had been tendered and not withdrawn by midnight Tuesday.

title: PALM BEACH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $52,000 for the qr and $394,000 for the 9 mos...C-After $110,000 loss from discontinued operations for the qr and $40,000 gain from discontinued operations for the 9 mos

title: TROUBLESHOOTERS EXAMINE SHUTTLE IN BID TO SOLVE PRESSURE PROBLEMS
description: Technicians entered the aft compartment of the space shuttle Columbia this afternoon to begin troubleshooting the oil pressure problem that has forced an indefinite postponement of the spaceship's launching.

title: AMEDCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RECITAL: ALISON DEANE, RICHARD LOCKER
description: RICHARD LOCKER and Alison Deane gave a duo recital of cello and piano music Monday night at the Abraham Goodman House. Mr. Locker's personal feelings about his instrument and music in general were made quite clear in the Bach Unaccompanied Suite in E flat. His passionate broad-gestured style and his willingness to push and pull at melodic lines in order to wring the most feeling from them may have seemed a little heavy-handed in Boccherini's more delicate Sonata in A for cello and piano, but in the Bach and in Bloch's ''Nigun,'' the approach worked very well.

title: GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: B-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $1,582,000 for the qr and $40,000 for the 9 mos and extraordinary gains of $3,852,000 for the qr and $8,328,000 for the 9 mos

title: STECHER-TRAUNG-SCHMIDT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SAMURAI MUSICAL OPENS AT LA MAMA TOMORROW
description: Yutaka Higashi brings a major new Japanese musical to New York for the first time in seven years Saturday, when ''Shiro'' opens at La Mama Annex. For Mr. Higashi, the 35-year-old leader of the Tokyo Kid Brothers theatrical troupe, this is a big test after more than a decade in theater, a culminating point in a career that blossomed when his musical ''Golden Bat'' opened to wide praise at La Mama in 1970.

title: FASTEN YOUR SEAT BELTS
description: To the Editor:

title: IMPELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Youth, 15, Is Held In Bronx Slaying
description: A 15-year-old high school student was arrested and charged with the fatal shooting of another 15-year-old youth after a brief shouting match on a Bronx street on Tuesday. The suspect, Edward McPherson, a 10th-grade student at James Monroe High School in the Bronx, was taken into custody at his apartment at 1151 East 165th Street.

title: FOREIGNERS RETREAT FROM JAPAN STOCKS
description: A few days ago, over a course of black mushroom soup at an elegant restaurant here, Howard Stein, president of the Dreyfus Corporation, said, ''We've been cutting back our investment in Japanese stocks substantially.''

title: CHEMICAL CUTS PRIME TO 17%
description: The Chemical Bank cut its prime rate yesterday for the second time this week, lowering it one-half percentage point, to 17 percent. This matched the lowest level of the year, set last March.

title: PORTA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $158,000 tax credit for both periods and $245,000 interest income for the 9 mos...C-Includes tax credits of $14,000 for the qr and $155,000 for the 9 mos and $125,000 interest income for the 9 mos; 1980 shr earnings reflect 2-for- stock split paid in May 1981

title: ART: JEAN HELION IN STEP WITH TIME
description: THE French painter Jean Helion has been in and out of the best dealers' galleries all over the world for the last 49 years, and in and out of the best art magazines, too. But it is one thing to call the roll of those galleries and those magazines, and quite another to have any one firm idea of what Helion has done. We would need a major museum exhibition for that. But meanwhile ''Jean Helion: Paintings and Drawings from the years 1939-60'' at the Robert Miller Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, will do very well.

title: 'OLYMPIAD: MOSCOW 1980'
description: ''XXII OLYMPIAD: Moscow 1980,'' which opens today at the Embassy 72d Street Theater, is an official Soviet look at the event of the title, which makes it one of those documentaries that reveal at least as much through omission as any other way. Determinedly cheerful, it neglects to say much about the boycott that undermined the Olympics last year, and insteads devotes lavish attention to Misha the Bear.

title: NATIONWIDE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pop Jazz; HUGH SHANNON SLIDES BEHIND THE KEYBOARD AT THE CARLYLE
description: AFTER 13 years as resident pianist and singer at the Cafe Carlyle, Bobby Short has gone off to widen his horizons and Hugh Shannon has moved in to take his place. It's true that Mr. Short will be back at the cafe for the month of December but it will be Hugh Shannon who will be singing and playing the piano there from January through March.

title: Notes on People; A Costly Habit
description: Michael Howard, a grandson of a founder of the Scripps-Howard newspaper chain, has disclosed that a $6,000-a-week cocaine habit cost him his job as a Denver newspaper editor and led to a series of suicide attempts.

title: MUBARAK WORKS TO UNTANGLE EGYPT'S FISCAL PLIGHT
description: At the end of a recent interview, Egypt's new President, Hosni Mubarak, said, after a long discussion on foreign relations, that his primary task was to tackle this impoverished nation's intricate internal problems.

title: THE SOURING OF FRANCE
description: The French political climate has suddenly soured.

title: KENCOPE ENERGY COS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fund Assets Rise Slightly
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $443.2 million in the week ended Wednesday, to $169.9 billion, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. It was the 23d consecutive weekly increase but the slimmest gain since May.

title: Notes on People; Celebrating Television's Golden Age
description: It was, give or take a season, the silver anniversary of the ''golden age of television,'' and that called for a champagne celebration by the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences.

title: MINNESOTA RECALLS LEGISLATURE ON MONEY
description: Last spring state economists drew up a budget based on projections that the nation's economy would show an upturn by 1982. Instead, the national economy is in a recession and Minnesota is faced with a deficit of $600 million to $700 million, partly as a result of its error. Another source of the problem was a tax cut accomplished mainly by linking tax rates to the Consumer Price Index, a process known as indexing.

title: COURT TOLD OF ERRATIC POINT SPREADS
description: A professional oddsmaker from Las Vegas, Nev., testifying for the Government in the Boston College point-shaving case, said yesterday that the point spreads on several of the college's basketball games during the 1978-79 season had fluctuated erratically. The cause of such fluctuation, he said under direct examination, could have been that ''either the games were fixed or someone thought they were.''

title: AN UNCORRECTED ERROR ON TUITION ASSISTANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: The City; New Restrictions On Henry Hudson
description: The State Department of Transportation has extended to 158th Street the section of the Henry Hudson Parkway that will be be partly closed during a 32-month, $30 million repair project, a spokesman for the department's New York City office announced.

title: Sports People; Coach Defends Action
description: Lambert Reed, coach of the football team at tiny Morris Brown College in Atlanta, has been suspended pending further investigation of the circumstances under which he struck a player, Ben Scott, with an ax handle. The incident began, Reed said, when he questioned Scott on players' smoking marijuana on a trip to Alabama.

title: KNICKS BEAT MAVERICKS, 104-95
description: For three games Campy Russell had struggled through a 9-for-28 shooting slump that included forced shots and resulted in injured pride when he was benched.

title: No Headline
description: In the Broadway column in Weekend yesterday, an item about musicals that have delayed their openings listed the status of ''Oh, Brother'' incorrectly. It will open on schedule at the ANTA Theater Tuesday.

title: Briefing
description: THE White House press office, obviously worried that rumpled journalists might turn up in inappropriate outfits, instituted an unusual dress code for President Reagan's speech last night before the American-Irish Historical Society at the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan. All men were required to wear dark suits, and women were to be ''appropriately attired.'' Or else. It is the first edict in memory where guests were told what to wear outside 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: The Region; Connecticut Gets New Chief Justice
description: John A. Speziale, who supervised the reorganization of Connecticut's state court system and presided over one of the state's most sensational murder trials, was sworn in yesterday as the 47th Chief Justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court.

title: The Region; Oil Tanks Erupt; Hundreds Flee
description: Hundreds of people were removed from their homes because of a fire and explosions at a petroleum tank farm in this village 15 miles east of Buffalo.

title: The Region; 2 Found Guilty In Double Slaying
description: A Rockland County jury yesterday convicted a man and a woman of slaying the woman's parents during a robbery. The defendants, Sheryl Sohn and Belton Brims, face a maximum of 25 years when sentenced later this month. Miss Sohn, 23 years old, and Mr. Brims, 26, both of Spring Valley, were charged with murder, robbery, burglary and grand larceny in connection with the slayings of Miss Sohn's parents Dec. 28, 1980.

title: Four-Week Navy Drill Is Begun in Caribbean
description: The United States Navy has begun four weeks of manuevers in the Caribbean, Pentagon officials said today. However, they stressed that the manuevers, which began Oct. 30, were planned long ago and were only coincidentally related to a request from Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to the Defense Department to examine the military options growing out of Washington's concern about arms shipments to rebels in El Salvador.

title: Asbestos Trading Halted in Toronto
description: Trading in shares of Asbestos Corporation Ltd. was halted on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges today.

title: METHODS OF TESTING FOR CANCER DRUGS ARE CRITICIZED
description: The Government is jeopardizing the lives of cancer patients by lax supervision of drug experiments, the head of a Presidential commission testified today at a Senate hearing.

title: Your Money; How F.D.I.C.  Backs Savings
description: WITH many savings institutions teetering on the brink of insolvency, and the Metropolitan Savings Bank's takeover of the failing Greenwich Savings Bank of New York earlier this week, many consumers have a more than casual interest in learning how the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's protection program works.

title: Going Out Guide
description: Like almost all hard times in mankind's history, the Depression-World War II era gave rise to great art that commented on the world that inspired it. A new exhibition, ''Social Art in America: 1930-45'' has just opened at ACA Galleries, 21 East 67th Street (628-2440) in honor of the gallery's 50th anniversary.

title: Sports People; Camarillo Finds Niche
description: The New England Patriots have had 17 punters in 22 seasons, and in only four seasons have those punters averaged more than 40 yards. Now the club has one who may last.

title: Sports People; Andretti Protests
description: Mario Andretti, who was credited successively with second place, first place and second place in this year's Indianapolis 500, is contesting the United States Auto Club's most recent ruling. Andretti is arguing, among other points, that USAC did not have jurisdiction. He says the race was sanctioned by the Federation Internationale de l'Automobile and that the proper forum is therefore the Automobile Competition Committee of the United States, the American arm of F.I.A.

title: Around the World; 5 Western Envoys End Talks Over Namibia
description: Five Western diplomats seeking an independence plan for South-West Africa ended an African tour today, saying they want definitive replies to their proposals in the next few weeks.

title: Sports of The Times; The Gentleman
description: OVER pasta and espresso the other night, 11 friends enviously listened to Michael Burke describe his new life in the old country. At the age of 62, he is taking his memories of running the Yankees and the Knicks and the Rangers with him to County Galway ''while I can still put a shovel in the ground.''

title: CLEMSON BASKING WITH 8-0 RECORD
description: The five youthful Danny Ford ''lookalikes'' stood on the stage of Clemson University's outdoor Amphitheater in bright orange jackets and caps, their mouths bulging from slugs of tobacco.

title: JERSEY JUDGE ACCUSED OF TAKING $12,000 BRIBE
description: A New Jersey Superior Court judge was arrested in front of the Camden County Courthouse yesterday morning and charged with accepting a $12,000 bribe from a defendant who was scheduled to be sentenced by the judge later in the morning.

title: CURTAIN UP IN THE CAPITAL: 'LA BOHEME'
description: For the last decade, the nation's capital has been emerging from what had been its universally agreed status as a cultural backwater. First, the Kennedy Center opened.

title: WHAT SADAT DID FOR THE ARAB WORLD
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 ARE KILLED IN BROOKLYN BY FUMES TIED TO INADEQUATE HEATING VENTS
description: A young man and woman and their 7-month-old son were killed and 36 other persons were overcome early yesterday by fumes that spread through a four-story building in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: JOINS SOVIET FLOTILLA
description: A Soviet submarine that ran aground in a secret Swedish military zone 11 days ago left Swedish waters today, joining a flotilla of Soviet Navy ships that had been waiting for it.

title: Sears Acceptance Gains
description: The Sears Roebuck Acceptance Corporation reported yesterday that its net income in the three months ended Sept. 30 soared 85.7 percent, to $67.4 million from $36.3 million in the quarter a year earlier.

title: HAIG SEES A 3-1 SOVIET EDGE IN NUCLEAR FORCES IN EUROPE
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., disputing Leonid I. Brezhnev's assertions of ''approximate parity'' in nuclear forces in Europe, has said that the Soviet Union has roughly a 3-to-1 advantage over the United States in missiles and aircraft.

title: Editors Will Visit Nicaragua Over Closings of Newspaper
description: A group of editors and publishers, led by Charles Scripps, president of the Inter-American Press Association and chairman of Scripps-Howard newspapers, will visit Nicaragua next week.

title: TEXT OF PRESIDENT'S STATEMENT
description: Following is the text of a statement by President Reagan today on the extension of the Voting Rights Act: Several months ago in a speech, I said that voting was the most sacred right of free men and women. I pledged that as long as I am in a position to uphold the Constitution no barrier would ever come between a secret ballot and the citizen's right to cast one. Today I am reaffirming that commitment.

title: A Long, Wrong Realty Tax Bill
description: For more than a century, New York State law has required tax assessors to appraise all real estate at full market price. Most have consistently ignored that law, overvaluing some properties and undervaluing others. The courts declared the practice illegal in 1975, and the Legislature has tried ever since to write a new tax code that would satisfy the court without shifting the tax burden from business properties to private homes.

title: AT F.A.O. SCHWARZ, ANNEXATION MEANS MORE TOYS
description: The kids who'll be coming to feast their eyes on the toys and games and stuffed animals on the shelves, floor and even the ceiling of F.A.O. Schwarz's newly constructed City of Toys won't remember, or even care, that the site was previously associated with food. First there was Reuben's, followed by the Factoria, and most recently there was Nathan's. But now the space has been annexed by Schwarz and the specialty of the day, every day, will be fun and games.

title: U.S. NUCLEAR RIFT DISTURBS LONDON
description: British anxieties about American nuclear policy have been deepened by the confusing and seemingly contradictory statements made this week by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger.

title: Patents; New Porous Membrane For Artificial Pancreas
description: An artificial pancreas for use in transplant surgery can be made of a new porous membrane that was patented this week after research in the laboratories of Columbia University and the National Patent Development Corporation, New York. A chamber made of the membrane may hold living pancreatic tissue from a human or animal source.

title: TRAURIG WINS JUMPOFF WITH A FLAWLESS RIDE
description: Bernie Traurig was the last rider in a six-horse jumpoff for the Devereux Challenge Trophy and World Cup points at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night. He knew what he had to do, for the only woman finalist, Leslie Burr, had just posted the fastest time ahead of him.

title: SARAH LAWRENCE INSTALLS DR. ILCHMAN AS PRESIDENT
description: Dr. Alice Stone Ilchman was installed today as the eighth president of Sarah Lawrence College, which she said adhered to a philosophy that opposes the kind of decisions on education being made in Washington.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is inconceivable why the Soviet military authorities could jeopardize friendly neighboring relations by an action that was sure to outrage the entire Swedish people. The grounded, most likely nuclear-armed sub is a frightening reminder of how close we are to the precipice, how great the risk is for a nuclear war.'' - Former Prime Minister Olaf Palme of Sweden. (3:4.)

title: Managua Paper Names 13 as C.I.A. Members
description: A pro-Sandinist newspaper today published the names of 13 people who it said were Central Intelligence Agency members now attached to the United States Embassy here, prompting a strong protest from the Reagan Administration.

title: New York; SAVING THE 'GARDEN'; by Sydney H. Schanberg
description: Ever since the new Madison Square Garden opened in 1968, we have heard tales of its financial woes. And reports that the Garden's centerpieces - the Knicks and the Rangers - might leave for greener sports arenas have cropped up so regularly that everyone assumed it was an annual wolf-crying ritual aimed at extracting some money from the city.

title: The City; Cocaine and 3 Men Seized in Queens
description: Twelve pounds of cocaine was seized and three men were arrested in Richmond Hill, Queens, in what the police described as a Colombiabased cocaine ring.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON DIARY SUPPORTS
description: A new dairy price support plan that will bring a slight increase in retail milk prices next October was accepted today by members of a House-Senate conference committee that has struggled for the last three days to agree on a new farm bill.

title: WILLIAM W. SCHOTT
description: William W. Schott, a retired Foreign Service officer who specialized in European relations and spent extensive time in United States embassies in Europe and elsewhere, died Monday at his home in Bad Godesberg, a suburb of Bonn.

title: RARE GOLD OF THE AVARS TO BE SOLD AT AUCTION
description: More than 1,400 years ago, a people known as the Avars migrated from Asia, probably from Inner Mongolia, to an area of present-day Hungary known as Pannonia. It was the time of the barbarian surge across Europe, and the ferocious Avars came to dominate the region east of the Elbe, building settlements consisting of strongholds surrounded by circular earthworks reaching out 100 miles.

title: Count Basie Orchestra At Queens College Gala
description: Count Basie and his orchestra, the Queens Symphony Orchestra, a champagne reception and a photographic exhibition are all part of a gala concert tomorrow, sponsored by the symphony at Colden Center, on the campus of Queens College, at Kissena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway.

title: A PENSION MANAGER MAKES A COMEBACK
description: For years Alliance Capital Management had the resources to dwarf most of its competitors. Alliance had more assets, more offices and more accounts than all but a few Wall Street pension management firms. It seemed that the company could deliver everything a client could want, its competitors scoffed, but first-rate investment results.

title: VOTERS REJECT REAGAN BUDGET
description: A ballot question challenging the economic priorities of the Reagan Administration seems to have won a substantial victory here.

title: Interferon Used in Bid To Save Rabies Victim
description: For the first time in the United States, interferon has been used in an attempt to save the life of a man bitten by a rabid dog, the national Centers for Disease Control reported today.

title: Sports People; Grich Remains an Angel
description: Bobby Grich, the California Angels' second baseman who had filed for free agency, re-signed with the club last night. Grich, 32 years old, signed a four-year pact.

title: JOFFREY BALLET: 'THE GREEN TABLE'
description: If you are planning to see just one ballet this year, make sure it is the Joffrey Ballet's revival of Kurt Jooss's ''The Green Table.'' Thursday night at the City Center, this powerful and humanist work was seen for the first time this season and with an absolutely splendid debut by Philip Jerry in the leading role of Death.

title: OUSTED CUOMO AIDE PLEADS GUILTY TO 3 COUNTS
description: William D. Cabin, who resigned Monday as Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's chief of staff, pleaded guilty today in Albany County Court to three counts of a 20-count indictment. He was charged with misappropriating about $175,000 in state funds through a payroll-padding scheme.

title: Less Is Not More at E.P.A.
description: If President Reagan has his way, the Environmental Protection Agency will soon be unable to do its job. While Congress is increasing the agency's responsibilities, stretching its resources to the limit, the Administration is proposing savage cuts in its personnel and research budgets. Even the E.P.A.'s more thoughtful critics in industry are disturbed, for without a strong Federal presence, business could find itself at the mercy of conflicting state and local regulators.

title: Jonestown Hearing Delayed
description: A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee will wait until all criminal and civil cases are completed before holding a hearing on the State Department's performance in connection with the mass murders and suicides three years ago in Jonestown, Guyana, a committee aide said today. The hearing, which was to have been held yesterday, was called off at the last minute because of concern about unresolved legal matters stemming from the deaths of more than 900 members of the People's Temple.

title: CONNECTICUT ASSEMBLY TO CONVENE ON NOV.19 TO BALANCE THE BUDGET
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill today ordered the General Assembly to convene on Nov. 19 for a special session to balance the budget, which may require program cuts and tax increases totaling $147 million.

title: GROUNDED SPACE SHUTTLE GETS CHANGE OF OIL AND A CHECKUP
description: Technicians changed the dirty oil in the contaminated auxiliary power units of the space shuttle Columbia today as officials expressed the hope that nothing more stood in the way of the spaceship's second test flight, postponed Wednesday just 31 seconds before the scheduled liftoff.

title: Patents; New Preparations Aid In Cancer Detection
description: Dr. Samuel Bogoch, a New York physician who is also associate research professor of biochemistry at the Boston University School of Medicine, received this week another of his series of patents in the field of cancer detection.

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times The Sad Young Man By ANATOLE BROYARD SOME SORT OF EPIC GRANDEUR: The Life of F. Scott Fitzgerald. By Matthew J. Bruccoli. Illustrated. 624 pages. Har- court Brace Jovanovich. $25.

title: MISS WEINSTEIN TO HEAD M-G-M UNIT
description: In the latest shuffling of executive posts at the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Corporation, Paula Weinstein has been named president of the motion picture division of the United Artists Corporation.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes On People; Family of Achievers Is Twice Rewarded
description: Two of this year's winners of the American Jewish Congress Stephen S. Wise Awards happen to be married to each other. They are Joan Ganz Cooney, president of the Children's Television Workshop, which produces ''Sesame Street'' and other programs for youngsters, and Peter G. Peterson, a former Secretary of Commerce who is chairman of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., the investment banking firm.

title: 1,000 FACE LAYOFF AT POLAROID
description: Blaming adverse economic conditions and predicting that they would persist, the Polaroid Corporation said yesterday that it would trim 1,000 employees from its 17,000-member work force early next year.

title: FERRET, FEARED EXTINCT, IS FOUND IN WYOMING
description: The black-footed ferret lives. The Department of the Interior announced today that biologists in its Fish and Wildlife Service had captured the only positively known living member of the species in a prairie dog colony in Wyoming.

title: HARNESS INVESTIGATION WIDENS
description: A Federal investigation of possible race fixing this year at two harness tracks in New Jersey has uncovered links between organizedcrime figures and 10 to 15 leading drivers, according to New Jersey law enforcement sources. As many as 30 races at Meadowlands Race Track and Freehold Raceway are believed to have been involved, the sources said.

title: Birdsong Possible Tonight
description: After receiving a cortisone shot yesterday to alleviate the pain of a sore right kneecap, Otis Birdsong joined his Net teammates here this morning for tomorrow night's game against the Chicago Bulls. Birdsong has yet to play this season because of recent knee pain.

title: Phone Link Set By 2 Exchange- s
description: The Chicago Board of Trade and the New York Futures Exchange have agreed to establish a telephone link between their trading floors, it was announced yesterday.

title: KORCHNOI VICTORY CUTS KARPOV'S MARGIN TO 4-2
description: Anatoly Karpov, the world chess champion, resigned the 13th game of his title match with Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland this afternoon without resuming play. His written capitulation was delivered to Paul Klein of Ecuador, the chief referee, who made the formal announcement.

title: IRVING J. POZEN
description: Irving Joseph Pozen, a former official of the Job Corps, died Thursday at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. at the age of 80. Mr. Pozen, who spent most of his life in New York City, lived in Kensington, Md. He served as director of procurement for the Job Corps from 1961 to 1968. Before that, he was an executive for the B.V.D. Corporation and International Ship Suppliers of Hoboken, N.J.

title: Bridge: Novices Must Learn Risk Of Being Busy on Defense
description: Inexperienced players tend to be too busy in defense. When the situation calls for passivity, they flit from suit to suit like butterflies, giving welcome assistance to struggling declarers.

title: The City; Fight on Vandals
description: A City Council committee urged the State Legislature to make vandalism at religious institutions a felony rather than a misdemeanor.

title: SWISS BANK FACES U.S. COURT ORDER
description: In a legal decision intended to penetrate Swiss secrecy laws, Judge Milton Pollack disclosed in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday that he would sign an order requested by the Securities and Exchange Commission requiring a Swiss bank to identify specific clients or face court sanctions.

title: REAGAN ORDER ON COST-BENEFIT ANALYSIS STIRS ECONOMIC AND POLITICAL DEBATE
description: When President Reagan signed Executive Order 12291 on Feb. 17, he transformed with a stroke of his pen what had been a useful economic tool into an imperative of Federal decision making.

title: Mayor in Jersey Faces Charges on Campaign
description: State officials today accused Mayor Gerald McCann of Jersey City of 11 campaign violations during his election drive earlier this year.

title: SOVIET SAYS U.S. STATEMENTS ON NUCLEAR WAR ARE A 'SERIOUS' DANGER
description: The Soviet Defense Minister said today that statements by members of the Reagan Administration on the feasibility of a limited nuclear exchange posed a ''particularly serious'' danger.

title: Key Rates
description: Split rate, 17.00-17.50.** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: U.S. AND PRAGUE IN PACT ON WAR GOLD
description: The United States and Czechoslovakia completed negotiations today on an agreement that would allow Prague to recover 18.4 tons of gold seized by the Nazis in return for settlement of financial claims held by more than 2,500 Americans.

title: Italy to Free 14,000 Convicts
description: About 14,000 prisoners will be freed from Italy's overcrowded jails under an amnesty pardoning minor crimes that was approved by the Senate's Justice Commission last night, an Italian official said today. About 36,000 people are being held in Italian jails, which were built to hold a maximum of 22,000 prisoners, the official said.

title: CHILDREN'S PARTIES: PARENTS NEEDN'T DO IT THEMSELVES
description: Jessica Chinitz was 6 years old the other day and her 14 party guests had a marvelous time. So did her parents, Shelley and Martin Chinitz, who didn't lift a finger except to snap pictures of the festivities. The children, wearing chef's toques and wrapped in aprons, baked the birthday cake and somebody else did the cleaning up.

title: 9 WORLD WAR I ACES LEAVE FOR REUNION IN PARIS
description: Nine youthful octogenarians flew to Paris last night for a reunion next week on what most Americans call Veterans' Day. To them, however, it is still Armistice Day, the end of World War I, in which they became the first American flying aces by downing at least five enemy airplanes each.

title: Around the Nation; Jews Allowed on JuryIn Bombing Plot Trial
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that blacks and Jews cannot be barred from the jury in the trial of three suspected Ku Klux Klan members accused of conspiring to bomb a Jewish temple.

title: About New York; A HOSPITAL CONFRONTS ANOTHER KIND OF DEATH
description: Murder strikes right at the heart of the city, like pointed metal to the nerve of a tooth. It shakes a block, or a neighborhood, so that everyone talks about it, thinks about it, looks over the shoulder warily for a time.

title: No Headline
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday incorrectly reported the rate at which the General Electric Foundation received requests for philanthropic grants. William A. Orme, its secretary, said requests arrived once every 26 minutes.

title: SCHWEIKER TO REVIEW RULES ON WHITE HOUSE PARLEY ON AGING
description: Richard S. Schweiker, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, agreed today to review procedures governing the White House Conference on Aging to see if the 2,200 delegates would be allowed to adopt their own rules when they meet here later this month.

title: MILITARY LIAISONS: HELPING HANDS FOR CONGRESSMEN
description: Senator Barry Goldwater, a Republican, returning to his home state of Arizona for an operation on his hip, wanted to stop in Fort Worth first to test-fly a new tilt-rotor helicopter.

title: INSTALLMENT DEBT RISES SHARPLY
description: American consumers borrowed $2.82 billion more in installment debt than they paid off in September, mostly because of borrowing to finance auto purchases, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Notes On People; New Barnum Faces an Opening and 32 Relatives
description: As Mike Burstyn prepared to step onstage in the title role of ''Barnum'' on Broadway last night, he said, ''I'll face the toughest critics and most demanding audience in my life - 32 aunts, uncles and cousins.''

title: SUSPECT FREED IN BRINK'S CASE CHARGES PERSECUTION
description: Cynthia Boston, who was freed Thursday after Federal officials dropped their charges that she conspired in last month's Rockland County armored-car robbery, attacked the Government yesterday at a news conference in Harlem for what she said was its continued ''persecution.''

title: MAINE SENATOR ASSAILS SMITH'S VIEW OF COURTS
description: Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, a former Federal district judge, took the Senate floor today to accuse Attorney General William French Smith of seeking to undermine ''the independence of the judiciary.''

title: MIDTOWN HOTEL GUARD SLAIN SEEKING PROWLER
description: An unarmed security guard for one of Manhattan's newest hotels was shot and killed last night when he went to the 15th floor to investigate reports of a prowler, the police said.

title: Consumer Saturday; COUPLES WITH A CONTRACT
description: ''T HE time to agree to disagree is when there is love in your heart and a smile on your lips,'' said Cecile C. Weich the other day to women gathered at the Chase Exchange to hear her talk about premarital and pre-living-together agreements. Such agreements are becoming more common these days, she says, because women have more tangible assets than they used to.

title: OVER- AND UNDERSHADOWING ST. BART'S
description: To the Editor:

title: General Dynamics Net
description: The General Dynamics Corporation announced yesterday that its third-quarter earnings declined to $36.9 million, or 67 cents a common share, from $51.7 million, or 95 cents, for 1980's third quarter. Sales during this year's quarter rose to $1.3 billion from $1.2 billion. This year's third-quarter earnings reflected tax credits of $6.5 million compared with tax credits of $16.5 million during the 1980 quarter.

title: Dow Down By 6.66; Volume Off; Merger Stocks Rise Sharply
description: Takeover situations produced strong gains for some stocks yesterday, but prices generally extended their recent decline amid profit-taking pressures.

title: MICHAEL S. ADLER
description: Michael S. Adler, the last city editor of The New York Mirror, which ceased publication in 1963, died Wednesday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: More Banks Cut Prime
description: Several of the nation's major banks, led by the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, the seventh largest, yesterday joined the move to lower their prime lending rate to 17 percent, the lowest level since last March.

title: Sharp to Market Video Still Camera
description: The Sharp Corporation, a leading Japanese manufacturer of consumer electronics and cameras, said it plans to market by the end of 1983 a video still camera that uses a magnetic disk in place of conventional film.

title: by Norman Rosten
description: I have been hoping for some kind of uprising since the announcement that a postage stamp would cost 20 cents for first-class mail. But Nov. 1, the day the cost went up two cents, has come and gone -without a sound, not a bang, not even a whimper. How to account for this silence in the face of postal tyranny?

title: EDITOR AND AN AIDE TO 2 PRESIDENTS
description: Jonathan Daniels, the former editor of The Raleigh (N.C.) News and Observer who served as press secretary to President Franklin D. Roosevelt and was an adviser to President Truman, died yesterday in Hilton Head Island, S.C., after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Sports People; Dickey to Face Giants
description: While the Giants were deciding that an injury would keep Phil Simms, their No.1 quarterback, from starting against Green Bay tomorrow, the Packers were deciding that Lynn Dickey, their No.1, was now healthy enough after sitting out a week. So Dickey, injured on a tackle two weeks ago, gets the start even though his backup, David Whitehurst, played well in leading the Packers to a 34-24 victory over Seattle last Sunday.

title: Saturday News Quiz; by Linda Amster
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 12.

title: RETRENCHMENT BY INVSCO
description: The American Invsco Corporation, a multifaceted real estate company noted for its large condominium conversions, said yesterday it was paring its nationwide operations and renegotiating loans to ease a cash drain.

title: Notes On People; Pistol-Packing Judge Shoots at Fleeing Burglars
description: Many judges in New York City are licensed to carry guns under their judicial robes, presumably to protect themselves from violent offenders brought before them.

title: Around the Nation; Weapons Search EndedAt Pennsylvania Prison
description: Inmates at Graterford State Prison were allowed out of their cells for meals today for the first time in nine days after the authorities ended a shakedown stemming from a five-day hostage siege, state officials said.

title: Bid for Leasco, Reliance Raised
description: Saul P. Steinberg, chairman and president of Reliance Group Inc., said that he and his family had agreed to increase their offer to acquire the Reliance Group and Leasco Corporation securities in connection with a proposed settlement of litigation that challenged their earlier proposal.

title: Inland Steel Plans To Shut a Mill
description: Inland Steel, a maker of sheet, plate and bar steel, said crippling interest rates that cut car and appliance sales would force it to shut down a hot strip rolling mill here, idling 115 employees. Inland already has 616 people laid off at the plant, which normally employs 24,000.

title: News Analysis
description: Canada's basic constitutional problem is back where it began - in French-speaking Quebec. For more than two centuries, the country has been wrestling with the seemingly intractable problem of how to accommodate its Frenchspeaking and English-speaking peoples under one roof. Yesterday a deal was struck on a new constitution that, instead of promoting unity, left Quebec out in the cold and once again made a breakup of the country possible.

title: BEATRICE TO BUY NORTHWEST DRINK UNIT
description: The Beatrice Foods Company yesterday announced an agreement to buy, for $600 million, the beverages industry segment of Northwest Industries, which includes the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Los Angeles and the Buckingham Corporation, an importer of various spirits.

title: Observer; HAIGS AND PAINS; by Russell Baker
description: I got to the office late and hung-over and started to make a pass at the bourbon and my secretary. ''Slow down, Shamus,'' she said. ''You've got fancy company waiting inside. Al Haig.''

title: REAGAN BACKS VOTING RIGHTS ACT BUT WANTS TO EASE REQUIREMENTS
description: President Reagan declared today that the Voting Rights Act should be extended for 10 years, but he qualified his position by saying that he would support amendments making it easier for states and counties to be released from certain requirements of the law.

title: Howard Reilly Dies in Paris; Former Envoy, Aide to C.A.B.
description: Howard Barclay Reilly, a diplomat at the United States Embassy here in the years after World War II, died Wednesday after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

title: JOBLESSNESS RISES IN NEW YORK AND JERSEY
description: Unemployment rose in both New York State and New Jersey last month, but the jobless rate in both states remained well below the national figure of 8 percent, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Storm Lashes the Bahamas
description: Tropical Storm Katrina swept into the Bahamas today after losing its hurricane punch over Cuba, where it reportedly caused two deaths and forced the evacuation of 150,000 people. Forecasters at the National Hurricane Center here said the storm was regaining some force as it moved northwest at 14 miles an hour, with top winds of 50 miles an hour.

title: DISMISSED WORKERS CALL MEAT PLANT SALE A 'SHAM'
description: With 27 years on the job, Wilbur J. Martinez was earning $10.44 an hour as a ham boner at the Cudahy meat packing plant here. Last August the plant changed management, and Mr. Martinez and some 200 other members of Local P-85 of the United Food and Commercial Workers found themselves on the street.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error, a dispatch from Los Angeles in some copies yesterday erroneously charac- terized Harold Rossfields Smith, a boxing promoter, and Sammie Mar- shall, an associate. They are on trial on charges of having stolen $21.3 mil- lion from the Wells Fargo National Bank.

title: REAGAN ABANDONS AIM OF BALANCING THE BUDGET BY '84
description: President Reagan, struggling to adjust his fiscal policies to adverse political and economic conditions, today abandoned his long-stated goal of a balanced budget by the 1984 fiscal year.

title: NEW RISES SEEN
description: The nation's unemployment rate leaped to 8 percent in October, the highest level in almost six years, and Reagan Administration economists said today that they expected the rate to continue to climb as the economy kept declining.

title: I.B.M. Case Delay Is Set
description: The schedule for post-trial proceedings in the Government's 12-year-old antitrust suit against the International Business Machines Corporation was amended yesterday to give William F. Baxter, an Assistant Attorney General, more time to review the case.

title: KOCH'S TOP AIDES TO RECEIVE SUBSTANTIAL INCREASES IN PAY
description: Mayor Koch has decided to give his top aides substantial raises early next year, city officials said yesterday. They said the increases might be as much as $7,000 and would probably be given to about 65 people, including the three Deputy Mayors and the heads of about 45 agencies.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1981
description: International Participation in the Sinai peace force by Britain, France, Italy and the Netherlands has encountered obstacles. Reagan Administration officials said that the European Economic Community had planned to issue a statement this week opening the way for the four countries to take part in the peacekeeping force. But the statement, which outlined their desires for a broader peace settlement that would take into consideration the rights of the Palestinians, was regarded as so offensive to Israel that the United States persuaded the Europeans not to issue it and to review their position. (Page 1, Column 1.) Britain's leaders are more worried about United States nuclear policy since the confusing and contradictory statements this week by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger. Senior American officials in London said many British political leaders, including members of the Prime Minister's Cabinet, had been disturbed by the new controversy caused by Mr. Haig's statement that one NATO contingency plan for an attack on Europe by conventional Soviet forces included the possible detonation of a nuclear weapon as a warning. Mr. Weinberger said Thursday that there was no such plan. (1:2.)

title: JERSEY CONTROVERSY WIDENS OVER G.O.P. PATROLS AT POLLS
description: As the vote tally in New Jersey's election for Governor continued to change and the victor remained undetermined, controversy broadened yesterday over the activities of a group of people who patrolled and posted warning signs on Election Day at polling places in some areas of the state.

title: Too Little for Schools. Also Too Late?
description: Poorer Districts Need Help Now

title: EXPANSION AT GOLD FIELDS LTD.
description: Cecil Rhodes, the late 19th-century explorer and entrepreneur, viewed the fortune he made after founding Consolidated Gold Fields Ltd. as a means of extending the boundaries of the British Empire. Rudolph Agnew, the current chief executive of the diversified London-based mining company, has a more modest aim: He simply wants to extend the boundaries of Consolidated Gold Fields.

title: Smithsonian Project Authorized by Senate
description: The Senate passed and sent to the House today a bill authorizing $1 million to plan an expansion of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.

title: Patents; Fee Rise Asked for Patents
description: WASHINGTON THE cost of getting and maintaining patents and trademarks is likely to be substantially increased. Gerald J. Mossinghoff, Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks, told a meeting of attorneys this week that proposals will be made to adopt charges in the fiscal year 1983 that are several times as high as current rates.

title: Index; International
description: The State Dept. says El Salvador's junta is getting stronger 3 Around the World 4 Head of southern Lebanon enclave says he has resigned 4 Britain and Ireland to set up a council to work for closer ties 5 Haig says Soviet has a 3-to-1 edge in nuclear arms in Europe 6 Soviet criticizes U.S. over comments on nuclear war 6 Government/Politics Aides to Mayor Koch will get substantial raises next year 26 O'Neill orders special Assembly session, to balance budget 26 Democrats look at rules for Presidential nominating process 30 Panel questions Schweiker about White House parley on aging 48 Washington Talk Briefing 13 Military liaison offices provide assistance to Congressmen 13 Curtain to rise on ''La Boheme'' in Washington 13 General Around the Nation 7 Army resumes bayonet training in bid to improve morale 7 Black-footed ferret, feared extinct, is found in Wyoming 24 Cynthia Boston accuses Government of ''persecution'' 26 Three killed and 36 overcome by fumes in an apartment house 27 Health/Science Grounded space shuttle gets oil change 31 Education/Welfare Sarah Lawrence's new head condemns cuts in education aid 26 News Analysis Henry Giniger on Canadian constitutional issue 2 Arts/Entertainment Gold of the Avars to be auctioned in London 8 Joffrey Ballet's revives Jooss's ''Green Table'' 8 ''Fantasies,'' Bo Derek's first movie, opens 8 Stones open series of appearances in New York City area 9 Bruccoli biography of F. Scott Fitzgerald is reviewed 12 Industry/Labor Replacement of workers at meat plant stirs labor dispute 7 Unemployment shows rise in New York State and Jersey 28 Style Consumer Saturday 29 Children's parties: Parents needn't do it themselves 29 De Gustibus: Solutions to tea and tea-bag problems 29 At F.A.O. Schwarz, Annexation Means More Toys 29 Obituaries Anton H. Rice, an investment banker 31 Sports Inquiry into Jersey harness rac- ing widens 32 Oddsmaker tells of erratic Boston College point spreads 32 Holmes stops Snipes in 11th to retain title 33 2 owners say Rangers may move to Meadowlands in 1982 33 Knicks beat Mavericks, 104-95 33 Clemson basking in 8-0 record and No.2 ranking 33 Dokes oupoints Chaplin and stays undefeated 34 George Vecsey on Gentleman Mike Burke 35 Traurig wins jumpoff at National Horse Show 35 Features/Notes Man in the News: James Armstrong, head of church council 7 Going Out Guide 10 Saturday News Quiz 11 Notes on People 12 About New York 25 Sports People 32 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22

title: No Headline
description: PRESS GROUPS IN 19 COUNTRIES JOIN TO SET UP AN ASIAN NEWS NETWORK

title: HOLMES, KNOCKED DOWN IN 7TH, STOPS SNIPES IN 11TH
description: Larry Holmes, looking ahead to his 12th defense and the $10 million purse against Gerry Cooney, tonight forgot to watch out for Renaldo Snipes's wild overhand rights and had to get up off the canvas in the seventh round to defend his World Boxing Council heavyweight championship successfully for the 11th time.

title: Pittsburgh Is Wary Despite Top Rating
description: Inspired by a No. 1 ranking that has suddenly made the less challenging part of its schedule more significant, the University of Pittsburgh will try to avoid the potholes that five other college football teams have discovered this season.

title: A SENIOR EXECUTIVE IN SHEARSON CONCERN
description: Anton H. Rice Jr., an investment banker who founded the research and institutional sales departments of Spencer Trask & Company, died Thursday of a heart attack in Maui,, Hawaii. He was on a business trip for the Shearson/ American Express Company, of which he was a senior vice president.

title: No Headline
description: Around the World; Union Says It Will Meet Poland Halfway in Talks

title: ARMY RESUMES BAYONET TRAINING
description: After a lapse of nearly a decade, the Army is again teaching bayonet fighting to infantry recruits. Today the first of two new bayonet training courses, constructed at a cost of $50,000, was opened at this sprawling Army post in westcentral Georgia. Over the next year about 33,000 infantry soldiers are expected to be trained to use the weapon.

title: by Charles Gati
description: It's 25 years ago this week that Soviet tanks brought the Hungarian Revolution to a sudden, brutal end. Those 150,000 Hungarians who then left for the West - the Class of '56 - still wonder if it could have turned out differently.

title: Reagan Asks $37 Million Cut In Public Broadcasting Funds
description: President Reagan proposed today to rescind $37 million in funds provided by Congress for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting for the fiscal years 1983 and 1984.

title: 2 N.H.L. OWNERS SAY RANGERS MAY MOVE TO NEW JERSEY IN '82
description: The head of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority said yesterday that, after recent discussions with teams including the New York Rangers and the Colorado Rockies, he expected a National Hockey League club to move into the new Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford next season.

title: CAPT. OWEN BOYHAN
description: Capt. Owen Boyhan, who was said to have been the New York Fire Department's last link with the horse-drawn era, died yesterday in Princess Bay, S.I. He was 97 years old.

title: Ex-Denver Newspaper Editor Says Cocaine Led to Job Loss
description: Michael B. Howard, the former editor of The Rocky Mountain News, says his dismissal from the Denver morning newspaper last year was linked to his addiction to cocaine, but he says that he is recovering from the addiction.

title: Around the World; New Greek Government Appoints 10 Envoys
description: The Greek Government announced the appointments tonight of 10 new ambassadors, including the envoy to Washington and at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization headquarters in Brussels.

title: Around the Nation; Oakland Schools' Policy On Contracts Is Upheld
description: The Oakland Unified School District's policy of giving at least 25 percent of major construction work to minority-owned businesses was upheld today by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

title: Gillette to Shut Unit in Germany
description: The Gillette Company said that its subsidiary, Braun A.G., planned to close its plant in Munich, West Germany that makes movie cameras and equipment. About 450 employees would be dismissed, the company said. Braun previously agreed to sell the movie camera business to Robert Bosch G.m.b.H.

title: The Region; Power Authority Considers Moving
description: The Power Authority of the State of New York said it was considering moving part of its headquarters staff from New York City to White Plains.

title: NCC AND SIMPLICITY END MERGER TALKS
description: NCC Energy Ltd. of London and the Simplicity Pattern Company, the nation's largest producer of sewing patterns, announced jointly yesterday that they had agreed to terminate plans for an earlier announced $85 million merger because of ''current circumstances.''

title: Around the Nation; Students at Brown Guilty In Protest on Casey
description: A Brown University disciplinary board today found 13 students ''guilty of infringement on the rights of others to participate in a university function,'' but no penalty was imposed.

title: PAOLETTA NAMED MAYOR-ELECT AFTER A RECOUNT IN BRIDGEPORT
description: By 64 votes out of nearly 36,000 cast, Leonard S. Paoletta, a Republican lawyer and former State Representative, was declared the Mayor-elect of Bridgeport today after a recount of last Tuesday's election results.
To the Editor:

title: Diamond Stock Up Sharply
description: Stock in the Diamond International Corporation jumped 21.7 percent on the New York Stock Exchange following the company's announcement on Thursday that it was talking to a British financier about his purchase of all the company's stock.

title: LEADERS OF BRITIAN AND IRELAND TO FORM PANEL ON CLOSER TIES
description: The Prime Ministers of Britain and Ireland, in a friendly five-hour meeting here today, agreed to set up a joint ''intergovernmental council'' to work toward closer links between their two countries.

title: Turk Sees Greek Premier
description: The Turkish Ambassador to Athens called today on Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou for the second time in a week, apparently to express his Government's concern over recent critical statements about Turkey by the new Greek leader. The two men, however, declared that a message conveyed to Mr. Papandreou from the Turkish leadership expressed optimism for the development of good relations between the two countries.

title: IF THE PRESSURE VESSEL OF A REACTOR CRACKS
description: To the Editor:

title: REBUILDING SECOND-HAND 727'S
description: Bill Elliott, chairman of International Executive Aircraft, holds the opinion that the price of a top-of-the-line corporate jet - the Gulfstream III - is so prohibitive at $17 million that corporations are better off buying used commercial airliners.

title: Candy-Store Manager Kills One of 3 Robbers
description: The manager of a Bronx candy store shot three men who tried to rob him and his store last night, killing one and wounding the other two, the police said.

title: LARGER DEMOCRATIC DELEGATION
description: Officials of organized labor told the Democratic Party today that it should dramatically increase the number of elected officials serving as delegates to Presidential nominating conventions but should not abandon the principle of having equal numbers of men and women as delegates.

title: House Bond Interest Cut
description: The states of Hawaii and New York, both of which are coming to market with new issues of housing revenue bonds, have devised new financing techniques to cut their interest costs.

title: UNDEFEATED DOKES OUTPOINTS CHAPLIN
description: Michael Dokes, the No. 2-ranked heavyweight, remained undefeated tonight by scoring a unanimous decision over George Chaplin of Baltimore in their 10-round bout.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF
description: Short- and long-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday as a steep decline in the nation's money supply and an increase in the unemployment rate to 8 percent in October provided more evidence of the economy's slide into a recession.

title: LEADER OF ENCLAVE IN LEBANON QUITS
description: Maj. Saad Haddad, the former Lebanese Army officer whose Israeli-backed militia has ruled an enclave along the Israeli border for the last five years, announced today that he had resigned.

title: Notes On People; Brady to Return, Briefly, to White House
description: For the first time since March 30, when he was shot in the head in the assassination attempt on President Reagan, James S. Brady, the Presidential press secretary, plans to return Monday to the White House for an official appearance.

title: A REVISION IN TALLY ON PRISON BOND VOTE PUTS RESULT IN DOUBT
description: A revised tally yesterday left in doubt whether voters had approved a $500 million bond issue to build and improve prisons in New York State.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1981; The Economy
description: President Reagan abandoned his long-stated goal of achieving a balanced budget by the 1984 fiscal year. He said he would stick to his plan, announced Sept. 24, to seek $13 billion in budget cuts in addition to the $37 billion he recommended last spring. Mr. Reagan ruled out new tax increases for the 1982 fiscal year, but said he would consider imposing new taxes in the following two years. (Page 1.)

title: POP: THE STONES AT PLAY
description: For people who have seen the Rolling Stones often before, it must be terribly tempting to regard them today as geriatric hacks. Compared with the thrilling impact they exerted on popular consciousness a decade ago, when Mick Jagger and Keith Richards were widely and seriously believed to have some sort of tangible sympathy with the Devil, their shows today can seem like pandering to a teenage audience a generation younger than they.

title: by Eric Foner
description: During the civil rights revolution of the 1960's, it became a commonplace among American historians that the nation was experiencing its ''Second Reconstruction.'' In the original Reconstruction following the Civil War, blacks were accorded political equality and the Federal Government sought to impose interracial democracy upon the South.

title: YOUNG BO DEREK IN 'FANTASIES'
description: ''Fanatasies'' is a curiosity - Bo Derek's first movie, before she wore her hair in cornrows, before she swung through the jungle, before she was even Bo Derek. She was Cathy Collins, and all that other stuff was yet to come. John Derek was around, however, and ''Fantasies'' shows that already he was thinking big. The movie, which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, is very solemn. It is also very badly done. It celebrates its star's adolescence.

title: LIBERAL ACTIVIST AND PREACHER
description: Bishop James Armstrong of Indiana, the newly elected president of the National Council of Churches, has touched off considerable controversy with his outspoken liberal social views. At the same time, he has shown remarkable ability to retain the support of a broad spectrum of church people.

title: E.E.C. Assails Suits on Steel
description: The European Economic Community today denounced a plan, announced yesterday by the United States, to file suits against European steelmakers believed to subsidize steel exports.

title: U.S. REPORTS SNAGS ON EUROPEAN ROLE IN THE SINAI
description: Administration officials said today that unexpected problems had developed in efforts to secure British and other European participation in the Sinai peacekeeping force.

title: REAGAN VISITS CITY TO HELP STATE'S G.O.P. RAISE FUNDS
description: President Reagan flew here last night to help his party raise money and to be lauded as an Irish-American who has made it. The President was the principal attraction at a $1,000-a-person reception sponsored by the Republican State Committee at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, with the proceeds earmarked for party preparations to challenge Governor Carey next year. The Democratic Governor is expected to be a chief target of the Republicans in next year's elections.

title: No Headline
description: BULLETS WIN FIRST BY TOPPING PISTONS

title: De Gustibus; HANDY SOLUTIONS TO TEA AND TEA-BAG PROBLEMS
description: The subject of tea bags apparently stirs up intense feelings both pro and con. After some comments about the use and quality of tea bags that appeared here two weeks ago, readers sent in suggestions for making better use of the convenient if unsightly bags, and several sent samples of empty bags that can be filled with bulk leaves of one's choosing.

title: THE PROMISE OF TIMES SQUARE 'INNS OF COURT'
description: To the Editor:

title: EL SALVADOR'S JUNTA IS GETTING STRONGER, U.S. SAYS
description: The State Department said today that the military abilities of El Salvador were improving and that the Government of Jose Napoleon Duarte was stronger now than at the beginning of the year.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 11. 1. Richard V. Allen, the national security adviser, denied that he was the unidentified senior White House aide who Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said had been ''waging guerrilla warfare'' against him. Articles suggesting that he was in disfavor with the President had prompted Mr. Haig's charge.

title: Miss Thomas Plans Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Thomas Jr. of Morristown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Benner Thomas, to Kenneth E. Pariseau, son of Mrs. Alex Snitko of Gorham, N.H., and the late Paul R. Pariseau of Burlington, Vt.

title: CHAD: AN O.A.U.-SPONSORED SETBACK FOR QADDAFI
description: To the Editor:

title: Staten Island Teams Star
description: Staten Island schools won three of four city championship crosscountry meets yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. Susan Wagner and Tottenville took the boys' and girls' titles, respectively, in the Public Schools Athletic League championships, and Monsignor Farrell won the Catholic High School Athletic Association boys' crown. St. Francis Prep of Queens, winner of the Catholic girls' race, was the only non-Staten Island champion.

title: COURT BARS EXCLUDING UNBELIEVER ADVERTISERS
description: A Los Angeles court has ruled that the publisher of the Christian Yellow Pages business directory cannot limit advertising to those willing to declare that they are ''bornagain Christians.''

title: The Region in Summary; Koch Promises To Mend Fences, Repair Rails
description: It seems no easy matter for Mayor Koch to bury the hatchet, even under a record landslide in which he won 75 percent of the citywide vote. In pledging last week to blunt the accusations of racial polarization that had emerged during his re-election campaign, the Mayor made it clear that his ''obligation to reach out'' to disaffected minorities did not extend to certain of their politicians.

title: RIO NUMBERS GAME MAY GO ON STRIKE
description: In a sequence of events that could be mistaken for a Damon Runyon story, operators of the widespread numbers racket in Rio de Janeiro have threatened to go on strike to protest a police crackdown, and the city's law enforcement chief has charged that such a strike would be unpatriotic.

title: About Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS '' 'THE CALM,' '' Anne Pellowski read. '' 'Dry the living springs of tears that fill your children's eyes. Console them with stories, those sweet thieves of wretched make-believe.' ''

title: Connecticut Guide; RIBICOFF HONORED
description: Abraham A. Ribicoff, former judge, Governor and United States Senator, has been named the first recipient of the Raymond E. Baldwin Award, to be bestowed annually by the University of Bridgeport on Connecticut residents who have distinguished themselves in law and public service.

title: PIANIST: NINA LELCHUK GIVES RECITAL
description: Nina Lelchuk, the Soviet-emigre pianist who came to this country two years ago, devoted the first half of her Carnegie Hall recital on Thursday evening to music by three of her countrymen, two of whom were among the first artists to leave the Soviet Union after the Revolution. It was clear from the way Miss Lelchuk immersed herself in her playing that the music of these three - Nikolai Medtner, who left in 1921, Sergei Rachmaninoff, who left in 1917, and Alexander Scriabin, who died in 1915 - had considerable meaning for her. It was also clear, from the ease with which she negotiated one difficult passage after another, that she based her accounts on the surest of technical foundations.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: AUCTIONS: A LOW VOLUME BUT A HIGH YIELD
description: The auction market for Impressionist and modern art ranged from selective to highly selective last week in the first major sales of the season at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, and Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street. Although the percentage of art works that did not find buyers was greater than in last season's sales, many works sold for prices exceeding the galleries' most optimistic expectations.

title: THE ART OF BARNEGAT BAY CARVERS GOES ON DISPLAY
description: TOMS RIVER WATERFOWL decoys made by Barnegat Bay carvers around the turn of the century and earlier are on display at the Ocean County Historical Museum.

title: MOSCOW AND WAR
description: The Soviet Union does not exclude the possibility of nuclear war. It prepares very seriously to fight one. Even Leonid I. Brezhnev, in his recent statement that the Soviet Union would not launch a preventive nuclear strike, did not deny this. The Kremlin also believes that a shift in the strategic nuclear balance in its favor provides greater freedom of geopolitical maneuvering. But Moscow does not feel that it can fight and win a nuclear war. On the contrary, its prevailing assumption is that a nuclear exchange cannot be reliably controlled and is inherently unwinnable.

title: THE GAMES OLYMPIC ATHLETES MUST PLAY FOR MONEY
description: ALBERTO SALAZAR, winner of the 1981 New York City Marathon, has said: ''I make no bones about it. I make my living off running.'' Under-the-table prizes for top finishers in last month's marathon have been reported at $14,000 to the winner and $8,000 to the first woman across the line.

title: FOR 'VOLGA GERMANS,' BREZHNEV TRIP AUGURS WELL
description: When Leonid I. Brezhnev travels to Bonn later this month, his visit will be attentively studied by politicians and policy makers for signs of shifts on critical East-West issues. The visit will also be followed avidly by clusters of ethnic Germans scattered across the Soviet Union, but for different, more personal reasons.

title: CONGRESS BRACES FOR AN ASSAULT ON DEFENSE
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. came up with a startling suggestion last week -the creation of a national trust fund, along the lines of the Social Security fund, to finance future defense needs.

title: INQUIRY ON 'MESS' AT HOSPITAL PUTS EDITOR IN COURT
description: It started with an anonymous tip scribbled on a postcard: ''Why don't you check the mess in the hospital?''

title: ACCESSIBILITY A GOAL OF NEW CHIEF JUDGE
description: HARTFORD LAST week, more than three decades after he heard his first case as a 26-year-old judge on the Torrington Municipal Court, John A. Speziale became the 32d Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court.

title: Major News in Summary; Tea Leaves in State Capitals
description: Democracy, for all its virtues, often frustrates those who seek a clear and consistent meaning in its expression. So it was last week when gubernatorial elections in New Jersey and Virginia produced a surprisingly large Democratic victory in a Republican state and a razor-thin Republican victory in a Democratic one.

title: England-Ulster Ferry Halted
description: England's only passenger sea link with Northern Ireland was stopped today when the two ferryboats were commandeered by their crews. The sit-in aboard the Ulster Queen and the Ulster Prince in Liverpool harbor was a last attempt to prevent the planned closing of the money-losing service next Wednesday, Seamen's Union spokesmen said.

title: LILCO ACCORD LIMITS SUFFOLK
description: HAUPPAUGE SUFFOLK'S county legislators are considering an agreement with the Long Island Lighting Company that would limit the county's role in the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's licensing hearing for the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Stamps; 'NATIONAL '81' OPENS AT THE COLISEUM NEXT WEEK
description: The philatelic highlight of the fall season is the annual National Postage Stamp Show which will be held Nov. 19 through Nov. 22 at the New York Coliseum. National '81, which proclaims itself, without apparent challenge, as the ''largest and greatest'' philatelic show in the United States, is presenting a glistening array of dealers to warm the hearts of collectors seeking to buy or sell stamps. The number of dealers, from all over the country and abroad, totals more than 175, but the show also offers various other divertissements.

title: Poetry Society Names 3 Winners of Awards
description: The Poetry Society of America has named Brewster Ghiselin winner of the 1981 William Carlos Williams Award for his ''Windrose: Poems: 1929-79,'' published by the University of Utah Press. The judges, James Dickey, Gerald Stern and Robert Penn Warren, described Mr. Ghiselin's poetry as ''long neglected but always profoundly imaginative and built to last.''

title: Sir Lionel Heald, 84, Is Dead; Churchill's Attorney General
description: Air Commodore Sir Lionel Heald, who was Attorney General in Sir Winston Churchill's Cabinet from 1951 to 1954, died today at his home in suburban Guildford, his family announced.

title: The Region in Summary; It's Lonely At the Top
description: Among friends, Governor Carey and Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo have had few nice things to say about each other. Last week they met, and apparently they didn't have many nice things to say to each other, either.

title: Jacqueline Kay Is the Bride of Edward M. Brown
description: Jacqueline Kay, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stuart Andrew Kay of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church to Edward Mackintosh Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mackintosh Brown of Denver. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers performed the ceremony.

title: New Zealand
description: To the Editor:

title: Long Island Housing; RADIANT SYSTEMS OFFER AN ALTERNATIVE FOR HEATING
description: TWO years ago, Richard and Harriet Herman paid $2,000 to heat their 50-year-old, nine-room Colonial house in Merrick with oil. In addition, their heating system was so antiquated that they were always chilly.

title: The Week in Business; THE UNEMPLOYMENT RANKS GROW
description: The unemployment rate soared to 8 percent of the work force in October from 7.5 percent the month before, the Labor Department said. The figure means that more than 8.5 million people were out of work.

title: Essay; WHO'S BLOWING SMOKE?
description: In two recent instances, President Reagan has removed himself from reality. He has denied the truth by blaming others for misinterpreting or misreporting what he and his closest aides have been saying.

title: Landmarks Group Names Award Winner
description: The 1981 Chairman's Award, given annually by the New York Landmarks Conservancy for excellence in building restorations, will go to the United States Trust Company for its headquarters at 9-11 West 54th Street.

title: Westchester Journal
description: WESTCHESTER COUNTY spent $50,000 last week to help the Board of Elections improve the reporting of election results, but when it was all over early Wednesday morning, there were indications that more work was needed.

title: IN MOSAIC OF SOUTHEAST ASIA, WAR, POVERTY AND PROSPERITY
description: Southeast Asia has been a focus of war, of violent changes of regime and of direct and indirect involvement of outside powers. Yet despite the convulsions that followed the temporary end of the Indochina wars in 1975, a correspondent who has spent most of the last 12 years in this region leaves impressed with a constant amid the turmoil.

title: New Jersey Guide; by Martha G. Wilson; HERE COMES PILOBOLUS
description: The Pilobolus Dance Theater -whose marrying of gymnastic feats and eclectic sources with dance has a tendency to startle at first glimpse, and then to delight - is seen all too rarely in the New York area. As might be expected from a group named after a fungus, Pilobolus is also known for wit, sophisticated sight gags and innovation. Its movements, a critic said, ''can be startlingly beautiful or wickedly funny.''

title: Around the Nation; Paper Fights Exclusion From Family Court
description: The Newport Daily News is challenging a judge's order that barred the newspaper from the murder trial of a juvenile because it published the youth's name. The newspaper told the state Supreme Court yesterday that the ban, imposed by Judge William R. Goldberg of Family Court, was a punishment.

title: FROM FLORIDA ORANGES, THEY'VE SQUEEZED MILLIONS
description: FOR years now, the giants of packaged foods have been sweeping into the Florida orange business. Coca-

title: THE DRAMATIC LIVES OF TWO PLAYWRIGHTS
description: A BETTER CLASS OF PERSON An Autobiography. By John Osborne. 285 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $13.75.

title: No Headline
description: Around the World; Polish Leader Hails Talk With Union and Church

title: Fordham Prep Triumphs
description: Brendan Dolan passed for one touchdown and scored the game-winner with 6 1/2 minutes left to give Fordham Prep a 16-12 victory over Christ the King yesterday in a Catholic High Schools Football League game. The winning score was a 1-yard plunge that was set up by a 38-yard pass from Dolan to Simon Walsh.

title: Fashion
description: The Big Spill of Fall Fur In a fall fashion season of unusual opulence, it stands to reason that some of the most extravagant clothes of the year should be long, full coats made of furs that are luxurious to the sight and to the touch. Yet, while such volume makes these generous wraps expensive, experts report that they are selling well -sometimes, more than one to a customer.

title: A HOME OF ONE'S OWN
description: THE MAKING OF MODERN ZIONISM The Intellectual Origins of the Jewish State. By Shlomo Avineri. 244 pp. New York: Basic Books. $15.50. By WERNER J. DANNHAUSER

title: RANGERS OVERCOME CAPITAL HOME EDGE AND TRIUMPH BY 3-1
description: The Rangers ended a three-game road trip with a 3-1 victory tonight over the Washington Capitals. The victory, on goals by Mike Rogers, Eddie Johnstone and Ron Duguay and almost-flawless goaltending by Steve Weeks, gave the Rangers a 6-9 record. They played an arduous schedule of five games in the last eight days, including four road games. They won three of the five, including two on the road. Tonight's victory also marked the first time this season the Rangers had won two games consecutively.

title: Holmes Terms Fight a 'Good Workout'
description: The winner called it a workout. The loser was distraught over the result. The chairman of the state commission called it the right move, but the loser's trainer disagreed.

title: The World in Summary; White Hats Have A Practical Use
description: ''A human rights policy means trouble'' a State Department memorandum confessed last week, but perhaps a lot less trouble than the alternative. The department ought to know.

title: No Headline
description: The article about roots in the community has been on my mind since I read it. I wonder how many ''Carols'' realize that they may be setting a very poor example for their own children in not contributing and participating in their communities.

title: Setting Down Roots In the Suburbs
description: Hooray for Thelma Sokoloff in the Long Island Weekly (''A Moment of Realization in a Place Close to Home,'' Opinion Page). A person who lives in the suburbs without ever putting down roots is like the person who can't see the trees for the forest. How lucky we are who live where green things can grow. TAMARA SCHROEDER Bayside

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; The Poor Get More Numerous
description: In the view of at least one Reagan Administration official, the war on poverty has been won; by this logic, growth in ''entitlement'' programs is attributed to lax enforcement, abuse by beneficiaries and similar moral lapses. Last week, the Census Bureau reported that the number of families receiving Federal benefits in the United States has indeed increased.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Arturo Ciompi Plays A Clarinet Program
description: Arturo Ciompi's solo debut in Merkin Hall on Tuesday night was that of a disciplined, well-trained clarinetist who seemed quite comfortable as a participant in Mozart's Clarinet Quintet in A (K.581) but less so, perhaps, as recitalist in Gade's Fantasy Pieces, Honegger's Sonatine, Poulenc's Sonata and shorter works by Koechlin, Faure and others.

title: EASY LINES
description: RUMOR VERIFIED Poems 1979-1980 By Robert Penn Warren. 97 pp. New York: Random House. Cloth, $9.95. Paper, $5.95. By DONALD HALL

title: MADELEINE WEIGEL ENGAGED TO MARRY
description: Announcement has been made by Francis P. Weigel of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and William F. Weigel of New York of the engagement of their daughter Madeleine Weigel to Thomas Hibbard Ludlow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman H. Ludlow Jr. of Rochester. A January wedding is planned.

title: MAYOR GOES THE 'FUSION' TRADITION ONE BETTER
description: ''M Y re-election as Mayor would mean just this: The patronage of the city shall not be used by or for any party.'' Thus spake the Mayor of New York, asking for a second term. No, it wasn't Edward I. Koch. It wasn't Fiorello H. La Guardia, either. It was Seth Low, the portly, amiable civic idealist who became the city's first ''fusion'' mayor in 1901.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Mozart and Donizetti Sung by Carol Joy
