description: Carol Joy brought her light, agile soprano voice Sunday evening to Alice Tully Hall. Miss Joy whipped through the coloratura of Mozart's ''Schon lacht der holde Fruhling'' and ''O Luce di quest'anima'' from Donizetti's ''Linda di Chamounix'' with only rare loss of rhythmic balance.

title: No Headline
description: Fathers, Sons And Chess In ''Cold War in the World of Chess'' (Sept. 27), Harold Schonberg cites the paucity of information on the psychology of the chess genius. Yet, he might have mentioned the work of Reuben Fine (a practicing psychologist and a former world-class chess player). Mr. Fine's book, ''The Psychology of the Chess Player,'' postulates that the avid chess player visualizes the opponent's king as his absent or weak father.

title: IN THESE PARTS, FRIENDSHIP IS A THREE WAY STREET
description: A French diplomat was musing once on a reporter's question about the scope of an African war. Had there been any big battles? the reporter asked. The Frenchman sighed and shrugged a Gallic shrug and said, ''Mon cher, in Africa, there are never any big battles.'' The generalization does not hold true for every African wa ?in recent times, but it does characterize the sputterings in the continent's northeast where surrogates are enacting a confrontation in miniature between East and West, and where alliances of convenience shift with sometimes surprising haste.

title: About Long Island
description: WESTBURY WHERE do those box tops go when you send away for a ''free for two box tops'' promotion? And do they really look at the cash register tape you send as proof of purchase when you clip out a magazine refund coupon?

title: Around the Nation; Inmates Injure 9 Guards At South Dakota Prison
description: A small group of convicts armed with clubs, chains and homemade knives attacked and injured nine guards at the South Dakota State Penitentiary today, the authorities said.

title: 'WE CAN'T AFFORD A HOME'
description: SOMEWHERE along the way, attitudes toward us have changed. Or maybe we have changed. We have ''progressed'' from ''those young people who get what they deserve'' to ''those poor young people who can't get ahead today.''

title: RECESSION IS SEEN GROWING SHARPER
description: Many leading private economists say that the long-predicted recession has taken hold of the economy so strongly in the last month that they have begun to doubt whether President Reagan's recovery program will ever get off the ground.

title: THANKSGIVING WITH MUSCLE
description: JOAN COOK is a reporter for The Times. By JOAN COOK

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1981
description: International The West and China were rebuked in Moscow at the observance of the Soviet Union's 64th anniversary, whose key element was the traditional display of Soviet military power on Red Square. In a speech from atop the Lenin Mausoleum, Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov said the Soviet Union would never allow another country to achieve military superiority. He accused the West and China of ''lunatic imperialist reaction'' and said Russia gave ''unremitting attention to its defenses.'' (Page 1, Columns 1-3.)

title: SURVEY SHOWS MORE DRIVERS PREFER LARGE OR MIDSIZE CARS
description: America's hunger for small cars may be abating, according to a study showing a far greater preference for large and midsize models than was evident a year ago.

title: New York Times Magazine November 8, 1981
description: William Safire 16 On Language Shlepper and Bungie Russell Baker 32 Sunday Observer In the Teeth of Fanatics Robert Lacey 35 How Stable Are the Saudis? Donal Henahan 40 A School for Smart Strokes Walter F. Mondale 67 The Re-education of Walter Mondale Paul Goldberger 68 The New American Skyscraper Patrick Huyghe 98 Diary Writing Turns a New Leaf Roger Starr 122 The Case for Nuclear Energy Ron Winslow 132 A Nation of Doctors in Debt? Bill Kurtis 142 A Worldwide Scramble for the Rarest Rubies Lesley Nonkin 148 Fashion The Big Spill of Fall Fur Craig Claiborne 151 Food with Pierre Franey Clams Off the Half Shell Marilyn Bethany 152 Design True to the 18th Century 156 Puzzles Answers, Page 159 166 Letters Cover: Photograph by Evelyn Hofer Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: ROUGHING IT AT GOLF SCHOOL
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex. P LAYING conditions were miserable that entire Saturday. Rain and cold penetrated sweaters and slacks down to the skin. It was impossible to keep the grips of the golf clubs dry, however thoroughly they were wiped. Players soaked up three and four towels and exhausted their supplies of dry gloves. A few times the clubs flew, or nearly flew, from the hands of players, including Skip Dunaway's. His visor did not fully protect his eyeglasses; constantly he had to wipe them with his handkerchief. Dunaway was fighting a cold, and he carried a bottle of Coricidin in the ball pocket of his golf bag.

title: Joseph Kanarek Fiance Of Robin C. Bennett
description: Mr. and Mrs. Carl Bennett of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Cheryl Bennett, to Joseph Kanarek, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Kanarek of Tel Aviv. A Dec. 6 wedding is planned at Temple Agudath Sholom in Stamford.

title: Majority in a British Survey Oppose U.S. Nuclear Stands
description: In a national survey of 1,000 people by The Sunday Observer, 53 percent of the people polled said they thought that American nuclear weapons should be removed from Britain and 57 percent said they thought that President Reagan was making nuclear war more likely, the newspaper reported.

title: McMahon Sets Offense Record
description: Jim McMahon threw seven touchdown passes and gained 538 yards in the air en route to becoming the nation's record-holder for total offense today as Brigham Young routed Colorado State, 63-14, in the Western Athletic Conference.

title: Stage View; DURANG'S 'SISTER' IS MALICIOUS FUN
description: Christopher Durang does not yet seem to me to be a playwright who can establish a comic level and stick with it until his work is done. Nonetheless, it's got to be said that his ''Sister Mary Ignatius Explains It All For You,'' which has now extended its run at Playwrights Horizons until New Year's, is a startlingly funny piece of work. What I find most curious about it is that it is startlingly funny for precisely so long as it clings stubbornly and passionately to the record, inventing almost nothing.

title: 3 Killed by Shotguns in Italy
description: Gunmen using sawed-off shotguns killed three members of a family in what appeared to be a gangland slaying, the police said today. The killings were apparently the result of a feud between rival gangs trying to control organized crime here, according to the authorities.

title: 5 Children Lost in Floods
description: Flash floods washed five children out to sea, wrecked 150 homes and caused a new bridge to collapse here after two days of heavy rain, officials said today. Up to 900 people were made homeless by floods from the Dumaca River, which runs through this city 60 miles southeast of Manila.

title: Leisure; PROLIFEROUS HOUSE PLANTS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Wallace S. Lipton teaches French at Brooklyn College. By WALLACE S. LIPTON

title: Miss Butler Plans Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Linwood C. Butler of Pittsburgh have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Griffin Butler, to John F. Rogers 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Rogers Jr. of Macon, Ga. A June wedding is planned.

title: Clare A. Cantrill And Law Student To Wed June 12
description: Dr. and Mrs. James Egbert Cantrill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Clare Agnes Cantrill, to Arie Johannes van den Blink 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. van den Blink. Both families are of Princeton, N.J. A June 12 wedding is planned.

title: Cornell Stopped By Yale
description: Cornell, which had lost five games this season, led unbeaten Yale, 17-7, going into the final period of their Ivy League game today. But a fumble and two poor punts led to two touchdowns and a safety for Yale that enabled the Elis to win, 23-17.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Catholic Bishops Act on Abortion
description: Even cherished convictions must sometimes bow to pragmatism, the National Conference of Bishops seems to have decided. The group has generally favored, though never endorsed, constitutional amendments banning abortions outright.

title: WINFIELD PACT MAY END ERA
description: None of the players in Friday's free-agent draft can expect to receive as much money as Dave Winfield will earn from his historic free-agent contract.

title: 5-2 RED BANK WINS BY 14-6
description: Dan Murphy returned an interception for a touchdown and Dwayne Smith scored on a short run to give Red Bank a 14-6 victory over Freehold Borough yesterday in Freehold.

title: Mailbox; At Least, Yanks Didn't Skip Town
description: To the Sports Editor: It strikes me as ironic the way George Steinbrenner has been criticized and compared so unfavorably with the O'Malley ownership of the Dodgers. The O'Malleys wrested control of the Brooklyn Dodgers in the early 50's; by the end of the decade, they had moved baseball's most beloved team to the West Coast.

title: OAK GETS CAPITOL SITE
description: STATE officials are determined to keep alive the spirit of Connecticut's historic Charter Oak on the grounds of the State Capitol. A few weeks ago, they disclosed that a seedling descended from the Charter Oak and planted last August on the Capitol lawn had vanished, apparently after it had been trampled to death by children playing football.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: PERSONAL INCOME RISES IN ALL BUT TWO STATES
description: Americans in all but two states saw their average income grow last spring, with total income rising at least as fast as inflation in a majority of states, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Food; L.I.'S WILD EDIBLES ON GOURMET MENU
description: WHILE many chefs fly in Dover sole from England, wild mushrooms from Italy and goat cheese from France to enhance their menus, Lawrence Forgione has created a bill of fare using American products -many of which he finds right here on the Island.

title: Around the World; El Salvador Insurgents Press Drive in East
description: A three-week-old rebel drive against Government forces in eastern El Salvador continued today with raids on army garrisons in San Miguel, the region's economic and trade center.

title: COMMISSARS OF CULTURE DON'T RELAX VERY OFTEN
description: Western reviewers of cultural events in the Soviet Union are often wont to see them as harbingers of a trend - a shift in Soviet esthetics away from strict Socialist realism, a relaxation of rigid control over culture, a yielding to tolerance, flexibility, maybe even to taste. Such, in recent months, were the staging of ''Perchance,'' a rock opera by Andrei Voznesensky and Aleksei Rybnikov blending ancient Russian chants with Western rhythms, or the Moscow-Paris art exhibition with its wealth of hitherto hidden revolutionary Russian art, or the first festival of contemporary music in June, or the screening at the Moscow film festival of a movie about the monk Rasputin.

title: Carol J. Wise Is Bride Of John R. Hammett
description: Carol J. Wise of Campbell, Calif., and John R. Hammett of Rowayton, Conn., were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in San Rafael, Calif. The Rev. Thomas L. Wise, brother of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Listing of Ingredients For Drinkers Rejected
description: The Reagan Administration has killed a proposal that would have allowed beer, liquor and wine drinkers to find out exactly what ingredients were in the products they consumed.

title: TV View; IS CABLE TV DOING ENOUGH IN MANHATTAN?
description: Apattern is emerging in cable television service across the United States. Large companies that own cable systems, eager to win franchises in unwired cities, are quite willing to spend hundreds of millions of dollars to build modern systems. At the same time, they give much lower priority to rebuilding their older systems in areas where there are no competitive reasons to offer the more lavish services.

title: Encephalitis Kills 323 People In a Gold-Mining City in India
description: At least 323 people, most of them children, have died of encephalitis in the last two weeks in the southern city of Kolar, the United News of India said today.

title: ARABS AND JEWS ASSAIL TEL AVIV MOSQUE PLAN
description: Arab and Jewish volunteers cleared 33 years of accumulated rubbish and debris from the crumbling Hassan Bek Mosque here recently and a prayer meeting was held in the ruins last week to protest a city-approved plan to rebuild the area as a tourist shopping center.

title: VOTE GIVES TEXANS LAND TITLE AFTER 50 YEARS
description: Jessie and Malissi Johnson have lived on their 120-acre farm in east Texas for more than 50 years, but it took a statewide election to give them clear title.

title: Dance View; WHEN A BALLET IS FILMED
description: ''= Blood Wedding,'' a Spanish movie directed by Carlos Saura, is ostensibly a film treatment of Antonio Gades's flamenco ballet based on Federico Garcia Lorca's play of the same title. Mr. Gades's live dance version of ''Blood Wedding'' had its own New York premiere with Alicia Alonso's National Ballet of Cuba in 1978 and in that theatrical presentation, it was deservedly a success.

title: DANCE: 'PIANO QUARTET' WTH BRAHMS SCORE
description: Hannah Kahn is a choreographer with a special sensitivity toward music. And her recent ''Piano Quartet in A, Opus 26,'' seen on Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church, is the exhilarating product of that sensitivity. One hears the music freshly and sees it before one on the stage. Each gesture and step seems to develop from the Brahms score, intrinsic to its rhythms and sonorities yet bearing the mark of Miss Kahn's intelligence and the impressive gifts of her dancers.

title: U. S. and Saudis Seek Date for Prince's Visit
description: The United States and Saudi Arabia are discussing the date of Crown Prince Fahd's visit to Washington, the State Department said today.

title: New York Political Notes
description: Governor Carey's remark the other day that he wished Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo would be more positive about his administration came after a considerably sharper critique of the Lieutenant Governor aboard the Governor's state airplane.

title: Headliners; Jonestown Revisited
description: Responsibility for most of the 918 deaths in and around the Guyana camp of the People's Temple in 1978 probably cannot be laid to anyone now living. But last week, the Federal prosecutors moved to try Larry Layton for the second time on charges of involvement in one of them, that of United States Representative Leo Ryan. Mr. Layton, who was released from custody after his first trial ended in a hung jury Sept. 27, was charged with taking part in a shooting attack at a remote airstrip in which Representative Ryan and four others died.

title: CONSTRUCTION BIDS LOWERING FOR CITY
description: New York City officials and contracting companies say that a drop in construction and contracting work in the suburbs has spurred many companies to submit bids on city-financed jobs. And as the number of bidders has increased, they say, more bids are coming in far below the estimated costs.

title: Antiques; A JUMBLE OF BRASS AND BEDS
description: RED BANK IT'S NOT a stylish shop. At first glance, it seems to have junk piled atop junk. But there is more than meets the eye at Blue Cow Antiques, at 2 Riverside Drive here.

title: RAPID DEPLOYMENT FORCE NEEDS A LIFT ABOUT NOW
description: As the Reagan Administration expands security commitments in Southwest Asia, unease is growing among those in the Pentagon who might have to back up those pledges. The weakest link in the United States global strategy is in facilities to transport troops and supplies.

title: PASSAIC TOPS CLIFTON FOR A PLAYOFF BERTH
description: Passaic, unbeaten in seven games, secured a Group 4 state playoff berth yesterday with a 20-3 victory over Clifton in Clifton. Mike Volpe led the way with two touchdown passes against a team that previous to yesterday's game had given up only 10 points and scored five shutouts.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; SHEL SILVERSTEIN
description: ''We're not selling the book, the books are flying out of here,'' said Janis Irvine, co-owner of the Book Bin Inc. in Northbrook, Ill. The book she referred to is not this season's blockbuster novel but ''A Light in the Attic,'' the latest collection of poems and drawings by Shel Silverstein. The book is No. 2 on this week's nonfiction best-seller list, and while it was published as a children's book it is, by all accounts, enjoying much the same popularity among adults as such other recent ''children's books'' as Kit Williams's ''Masquerade'' and ''Miss Piggy's Guide to Life.''

title: Long Island Journal
description: WITHOUT getting elected - or even running -members of the Senior Citizens Pops Orchestra of Long Island are going to Washington. The 85 musicians, led by their director, Albert A. Rauscher, will open the 1981 White House Conference on Aging at the Sheraton Center on Nov. 29.

title: Gallery View; THE PERVASIVE PRESENCE OF WILLIAM COLDSTREAM; NEW HAVEN
description: You would have to look hard, long and far to find an exhibition that is farther from current American taste than the one that has just opened at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven. Curated with all possible commitment by Andrew Forge, Dean of the Yale Art School, it can be seen through Jan. 3.

title: A SYMBOLIC CAREER
description: GEORGE WASHINGTON CARVER Scientist and Symbol. By Linda O. McMurry. Illustrated. 367 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $25.

title: WAGNER (8-1) TOPS SPRINGFIELD, 16-14
description: Local Colleges

title: SEPARATE AGENCY SOUGHT FOR L.I.R.R.
description: FRUSTRATION over service on the Long Island Rail Road has led a bipartisan group of state legislators to press for a law that would create a separate state authority to oversee the operation of the beleaguered commuter line.

title: Westchester Guide; VERSATILE COMPANION
description: Each year the promotion department of Neiman-Marcus, the Dallasbased department store that took over Bergdorf-Goodman's former location in White Plains, comes up with an unusual his-and-her Christmas gift for people who are presumed to have almost everything else. One year it was a Jaguar automobile for him, a jaguar coat for her.

title: No Headline
description: MIAMI TURNS BACK FLORIDA STATE, 27-19

title: Careful Shopper; Sports Outlet Paring Grand Opening Prices
description: For this month, Sports Barn in Yorktown is offering grand opening discounts to celebrate its move from a small area of a former chicken coop to more spacious quarters in a disused dairy barn. For the moment, the sports catered to are lacrosse, soccer, racquetball, football, basketball, baseball, softball and swimming. The hayloft may house cross-country skis eventually and the horse barn is headquarters for the American Youth Soccer Organization. The management has provided a baseball and softball field for shared community use and plans an additional area to accommodate soccer team expansion.

title: AIR CONTROLLERS, STILL DEFIANT, COMPETE FOR JOBS IN TIGHT MARKET
description: The nation's 11,500 striking air controllers are looking for work, in many cases at lower wages, and are finding the task difficult. While adept in their sophisticated task of guiding aircraft, the controllers are workers with few skills transferrable to other occupations. Moreover, they are looking for work in a difficult economic period. Competition for jobs is stiff and unemployment stands at 8 percent.

title: Theater; BEHIND THE COSTUMING FOR A NEW 'BLOOMER GIRL'
description: ''BLOOMER GIRL,'' at the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn., through Nov. 22, dates back only to 1944, which makes it a youngish musical in terms of the way things are done at the Goodspeed. But it is set in 1861, and that has caused some problems for the folks at the restored Goodspeed, whose narrow halls, stairways and doors work just fine for actresses in the slender costumes of the 1920's and 30's but are treacherous for hoop skirts.

title: Sharon Readhimer Engaged to Robert D. Kimball
description: James M. Readhimer of Houston has announced the engagement of his daughter, Sharon Elaine Readhimer, to Robert D. Kimball, both of New York. A March wedding is planned at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour.

title: Alan Sussna, Brenda Bock Are Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. George W. Bock of Plattsburgh, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Brenda Diane Bock, to Alan Frost Sussna, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen Sussna of Lawrenceville, N.J. A spring wedding is planned.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART The reputation of the French painter Andre Masson has taken a long time to settle down, here as elsewhere. Even in Paris, where he has lived for most of his life, it is difficult to find any two people who agree as to how he will be judged by posterity.

title: Food; KITCHEN FANTASIES TAKE WING WITH THE FLAVORFUL PHEASANT
description: Pheasant is a small and exquisitely flavored bird. It is available fresh in many markets these days and makes a delicious feast for two, prepared without much bother. Elizabeth David has called it the bird that inspires fantasies in the kitchen. Indeed, pheasant responds to all sorts of flavorings, especially those that hint of autumn. Cranberries, juniper berries and chestnuts go wonderfully, as does that sublime fall luxury that comes in fresh from Italy - white truffles. Roast pheasant can be served with vegetables such as brussels sprouts, celeriac, braised celery of roast potatoes flavored with rosemary.

title: FOR MANY CANDIDATES, PARTY LABELS ARE FLAGS OF CONVENIENCE
description: In Manhattan last week, a Republican district leader asked Republicans to reject the G.O.P. candidate for Borough President as a sure loser, and vote for the Democratic incumbent running on the Democratic line and not for a Democrat running on the Liberal Party line.

title: Around the Nation; Judge Allows 2 Bands To Join New Year Parade
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that two additional groups of participants have a constitutional right to march up Broad Street on New Year's Day wearing sequins and strumming banjos.

title: MORE BEREAVED SEEK COUNSELING
description: When someone you love dies, you have a feeling of numbness. You feel so alone, and loneliness is one of the biggest problems of grief.

title: Q&A
description: Question:Can I take a ship one way from the United States to any of the southern European ports? - C.M., Charleston, S.C. Answer:Two shipping lines that offer such a possibility are Norwegian American Cruises (29 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10006, 212-422-3900) and the Royal Viking Line (One Embarcadero Center, San Francisco, Calif. 94111, 415-398-8000). Norwegian American's 650-passenger Vistafjord will leave Port Everglades, Fla., March 20 for a 15-night voyage to Genoa. Its ports of call include St. Thomas, the Canary Islands, Tangier, Gibraltar and Corsica. (Fares range from $1,940 to $3,870.)

title: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: THEATER The movie director Robert Altman would not seem a likely recruit for the theater. His best films, such as ''M*A*S*H'' and ''Nashville,'' rely heavily on improvisatory, free-wheeling cinematic techniques that have no real stage equivalents.

title: Bridge; CALCULATING THE RISKS OF SETTLING FOR A SMALL SLAM
description: Asimple question to which there is no simple answer is this: When should a partnership attempt a grand slam? The scoring is an obvious factor. In rubber bridge, in theory, one needs about two chances in three to justify risking the loss of a sure small slam. In team play, one can be more aggressive: The break-even point is about 57 percent.

title: L.I.E. RAMP PLANS
description: A SERIES of proposed alterations in exits off the Long Island Expressway in the Jericho, Old Westbury and Roslyn areas have touched off concern among local residents. They fear increased traffic congestion and, in the case of Roslyn, possible danger to schoolchildren as a result.

title: Austin Votes to Sell Shares In Long-Delayed Atom Plant
description: Residents voted this week to sell the city's 16 percent share of the long-delayed South Texas Nuclear Project, but officials say it will take more than a year to complete the sale.

title: Airline Club
description: To the Editor:

title: PARENTS FIGHTING TO RETAIN SCHOOL FLEA MARKET
description: For the last two years, residents near Public School 183 on East 67th Street have flocked to the school on Saturdays in search of bargains in everything from radishes to rhinestones at the green market and flea bazaar sponsored by the Parent-Teacher Association.

title: Other Business; FORECAST FOR NEW YEAR'S EVE: A RISING SUN
description: Times Square is as American as, well, sushi. At least, it's the Japanese who are lighting it up. The Fuji Film Company has wrapped a huge, $500,000 green and white, neon-lighted billboard around the corner of a building at 43d Street and Broadway, outshining the next brightest sign in the square, one erected by Sony that uses 7,000 incandescent light bulbs.

title: MAN THE ATHLETES SEEK FOR PROWESS
description: PORT CHESTER THE telephone rattles the walls in the house on King Street: - ''Person-to-person for Mr. Marks from Mr. Billy Johnson in Montreal.''

title: FREEHOLDER PONDERS PROSPECT OF BEING A MINORITY OF ONE
description: HACKENSACK ''IT'S beginning to feel very, very lonely,'' confided Doris Mahalick as she assessed the results of last Tuesday's election. Mrs. Mahalick, a member and former director of the Bergen County Board of Chosen Freeholders, won re-election last year and was not a candidate this year.

title: EX-UNITED PILOT WINS $17,500 IN SUIT OVER RELIGIOUS BIAS
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that United Airlines discriminated against a former pilot who refused to fly on weekends because his religion forbade it.

title: MISSTEP ABROAD
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRESPONDENT'S CHOICE
description: R.W. APPLE Jr. is chief of the London bureau of The Times. By R.W.APPLE Jr.

title: No Headline
description: ARCHIBALD PACES A 129-88 ROUT

title: One Tax Fable Was Enough
description: High interest rates and the recession they induced have also created a healthy crisis for Reaganomics. The Administration can cut taxes and increase military spending, but it cannot then shrink the deficit enough to let the Federal Reserve relent on interest rates. The current deficit is climbing toward $100 billion. What's worse, even after the recession lifts, the deficits are destined to grow rather than disappear, as promised, by 1984.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER: 'SEESAW' IS REVIVED
description: When Cy Coleman, Dorothy Fields and Michael Bennett (with an uncredited assist on the libretto from Neil Simon), attempted to turn William Gibson's play ''Two For the Seesaw'' into a musical in 1973, they came up with a show that was less a musical than a play, less a play than a musical, and not enough of either.

title: 20 ON STUDENT PAPER QUIT IN POLICY CLASH
description: Twenty members of the University of Texas student newspaper staff have resigned in a dispute with the editor.

title: DETECTIVES STUDY SLAYING AT HOTEL
description: Detectives investigating the fatal shooting of a security guard at the Harley of New York, a new luxury hotel in midtown Manhattan, yesterday were ''continuing their police work but with no progress to report at this time,'' according to a police spokesman.

title: Dining Out; FIRST DUNELLEN, NOW LIVINGSTON
description: CHAN'S GARDEN in Dunellen has been popular with devotees of Chinese food for many years. It is so popular, in fact, that eight months ago Hai Kan Chan, the owner, decided to open another restaurant of the same name in Livingston.

title: HOBOKEN: FEAR OF FIRE HAUNTS MANY
description: HOBOKEN FOR MOST people who live on the clean, tree-lined streets of Hoboken's brownstone revival neighborhoods, life is comfortable. The homes are well kept and an air of a community is on the rise.

title: Politics; BEHIND THE HAIR-THIN MARGINS
description: WHILE the winner of the election for Governor remains unclear - a remarkable fact, five days after the polls closed - the reasons for the closeness of the race are somewhat more understandable.

title: Film View; 'MOMMIE'- A GUILT-EDGED CARICATURE
description: No wonder florists do such a booming business on Mother's Day, even though the reason clearly is less often love than guilt. A lot of this may be inspired by high-powered advertising campaigns, but a certain amount must be native to what Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, on his radio show sponsored by International Telephone and Telegraph, cherishes as ''the American character.'' If our films offer any clue to the true nature of our feelings toward mom, it is apparent that we regard her with mixed emotions. That is, with impatience, fury, resentment, dependency, loathing and fear. Poor mom. Poor kids.

title: RECORDS SHOW WILSON MADE MILLIONS ON C.I.A. EXPERIENCE
description: Edwin P. Wilson used the techniques and contacts he developed as an intelligence agent to assemble a multimillion-dollar business empire, according to former associates and financial records.

title: Gardening; TUCKING IN THE GARDEN FOR THE WINTER
description: NOW that most tender plants have been killed by frost and those that are hardy have been hardened off, it is time to put the garden to bed for winter.

title: MIRACLES ASIDE, REAGAN HAS FEW FISCAL OPTIONS
description: Like the events on a soap opera, the dismal economic choices confronting President Reagan last week had a familiar look. They were, in fact, the same choices of what to cut in the budget that he faced upon election exactly a year ago. The twist is that, this time, Mr. Reagan is handicapped by division among his advisers and allies over what to do.

title: DORMANT DEPOSITS VEX BANKS
description: THIS month and last, all New Jersey banks are required by law to advertise their unclaimed 5- and 10-year-old dormant accounts in local newspapers.

title: SLIM CHANCE SEEN FOR MISS REAGAN
description: Maureen Reagan, the eldest daughter of President Reagan, has begun a campaign for a seat in the United States Senate with a strategy seeking to stress, at once, her closeness to the President and her independence from him.

title: SOCCER FOR GIRLS A POPULAR GAME
description: For the last 10 years, girls soccer in the area has prospered for a variety of reasons - from Title IX to the decline in interest in field hockey -but on Long Island, some of the credit for the sport's rising popularity belongs to Gordon Bradley.

title: A Gripping 'Iguana' At the McCarter
description: PRINCETON The time is 1940, and the setting is the veranda of a Mexican hotel run by a slim underdressed widow. A reptile tied to a rope within the jungle foliage will be freed by the machete of the former Reverand Shannon.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. INQUIRY ASKED OVER VOTING RIGHTS IN JERSEY'S ELECTION
description: The chairman of the Democratic National Committee called on the Justice Department today to investigate whether the Voting Rights Act was violated by what he called intimidation of black voters in the New Jersey gubernatorial race.

title: Three Children Killed In Bridgeton, N.J., Fire
description: Three children were killed early today in a fire that was probably ignited by an electric space heater, authorities said.

title: THE POWER OF WASHINGTON'S ISRAEL LOBBY
description: To the Editor:

title: JEWISH Y RE-EMPHASIZING RELIGIOUS PROGRAMS
description: Just before the Jewish High Holy Days, three rabbis earnestly debated scriptural interpretations while several hundred people followed the text in Hebrew and English. The complex religious discussion took place not at a synagogue, but at the 92d Street Young Men and Young Women's Hebrew Association.

title: THE NEW AMERICAN SKYSCRAPER
description: Paul Goldberger, the architecture critic of The Times, adapted this article from his book ''The Skyscraper,'' to be published this month. By Paul Goldberger

title: Trapp Lodge Sued by Widow Over Husband's Death in Fire
description: A $5 million lawsuit has been filed by the widow of an Illinois man who was killed when fire destroyed the famous Trapp Family Lodge in Stowe.

title: HAIG TAKES OFFENSE, AND MAKES IT PUBLIC
description: W ASHINGTON FOR Haigiographers, it was one of the four most memorable weeks since President Reagan appointed Alexander M. Haig Jr. as Secretary of State.

title: co,inf Campo's Princelet Captures Discovery
description: Princelet, a son of Stage Door Johnny, won the $55,400 Discovery Handicap for 3-year-olds by a neck yesterday at Aqueduct. But Johnny Campo wasn't around to see it.

title: HOLES IN RE G N M CS
description: Reaganomics is based upon the assumption that society is nothing but a statistical aggregation of private economic actors. From the Reagan perspective, whatever the level of government and whatever the program (with the exception of defense), the public sector should shrink. A completely private economy with minimal government would be a better society, from this point of view.

title: KETCHAM DEFEATED
description: North Rockland's already-crowned county P.S.A.L. champions, seeking their first undefeated season since 1972, won their eighth game yesterday, scoring a 28-14 victory over R.C. Ketcham in a non-league game.

title: CHINA SEAS AND TIN SOILDERS; Discovering A New Route To China
description: Xiamen and the remnants of a 14th-century fortress; Shanghai, a trading port nine centuries old; Qingdao, a picturesque, museumfilled city; Dalian, China's third largest port, and Xingang, a carpet-weaving and art center that is the port of Tianjin: These exotic ports of call are offered on a China cruise aboard the Pearl of Scandinavia, a ship being put back in service next May by a new company, Pearl Cruises of Scandinavia. The sailings are planned out of Hong Kong and Kobe; later next year the ship will also sail out of Singapore to Indonesia.

title: Freehold Bans 8 Drivers
description: Eight harness drivers, including Herve Filion, the 11-time national champion, were suspended today for 30 days by the Freehold Raceway judges for performances ''detrimental to the sport'' and ''deliberately inconsistent driving.''

title: 400 Protestants Assail British-Irish Agreement
description: Four hundred masked Protestants occupied two Northern Ireland villages for about an hour early today as a protest against yesterday's agreement by Prime Ministers Margaret Thatcher of Britain and Garret FitzGerald of Ireland to set up an intergovernmental council to try to improve relations.

title: Realty News; A Buy in Brooklyn
description: With interest rates as low as 8 percent, there should be great interest among prospective homebuyers in 450 Federally-assisted, two-story dwellings to be built soon in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn.

title: TENANTS WIN SUIT OVER OUSTER
description: A Civil Court judge in Manhattan has ruled that tenants of buildings bought from the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority two years ago could not be dispossessed because the new owner does not really hold title to the property.

title: Economic Affairs; THE ELEGANCE OF DOING NOTHING
description: W HEN confronted with a complex public policy problem, it has always been difficult to sell what is often the most elegant and sophisticated policy option. That is, to do absolutely nothing.

title: Prospects
description: Slower Growth Ahead

title: Crafts; by Patricia Malarcher
description: APORTRAIT of the artist as an endangered species is being drawn as research testifies to the lethal potential of numerous materials that painters, potters, sculptors, printmakers, textile artists and photographers use.

title: Hope Scott Bride Of T.O. Rogers Jr.
description: Hope Tyler Scott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Montgomery Scott of Wayne, Pa., was married there yesterday to Theodore Otto Rogers Jr., son of Judge Theodore O. Rogers of West Chester, Pa., and the late Mrs. Rogers. The Rev. Richard W. Hess performed the ceremony in St. David's Episcopal Church.

title: Georgette Pasisis Wed in Suburbs
description: Georgette Pasisis and John Richardson Heerwagen, were married yesterday at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church in New Rochelle, N.Y. The Rev. Peter W. Kyriakos performed the ceremony.

title: The World in Summary; Trudeau Victory Moves Canada to New Federalism
description: After more than 50 years of trying, English-speaking Canada finally agreed last week on constitutional reforms that gave Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau a significant compromise victory. But paradoxically, instead of raising hopes for strengthening national unity, the outcome endangered it.

title: Swedes Mock Soviet On Atom-Free Zone
description: Four hundred demonstrators, some carrying a cardboard submarine and posters mocking Soviet proposals for a nuclear-free Nordic zone, converged today on the Soviet Embassy here.

title: Realty News; Advertising for Trouble
description: New York State Attorney General Robert Abrams last week filed suit against 11 real estate developers charging they offered out-of-state properties for sale to New York residents through local newspaper advertisements without first filing offering plans as required by law.

title: The Region in Summary; Eight-to-Five They Find It
description: There is already enough to gamble on, Atlantic City officials have decided, without including the drinking water. Discovering traces of toxic chemicals near wells providing the city's supply, they hired a consultant last week to help them find a new water source and draw plans to tap it.

title: Deborah McNair Fiancee Of Roger William Thomas
description: The engagement of Deborah Anne McNair to Roger William Thomas has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm McNair of Locust Valley, L.I., parents of the future bride. Mr. Thomas is a son of Mrs. Arthur Thomas of Muttontown, L.I., and the late Mr. Thomas.

title: CHURCHES PRESSED TO RENEW ACTIVISM
description: Bishop James Armstrong, in his first address as president of the National Council of Churches, urged churches today to attack poverty and injustice but to avoid a ''doctrinaire approach'' that might align them too closely with the political left or right.

title: ART MIRRORS LIFE IN TWO SHOWS HEADED FOR BROADWAY A MUSICAL CELEBRATES AN ATHLETE
description: Jackie Robinson, young and jittery, sits in the office of Branch Rickey, who runs the Brooklyn Dodgers, and is told he is being considered for promotion from the minor leagues to the ''big club.'' It is 1947.

title: Kyoto
description: To the Editor:

title: Art; A SLIM, BUT WELCOME, GROSZ SHOW
description: MADISON GEORGE GROSZ was born in Berlin in 1893 and he died there (in the western part) 66 years later. Having left Germany during the 30's as a ''degenerate artist,'' he had returned a few years before his death as a highly respected figure, fit to be elected Extraordinary Member of the Berlin Academy of Art.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: * Maximum rate payable at savings institutions+ Rates restricted by state usury laws

title: IN THE MIDDLE OF THE ROAD
description: EUGENE J. McCARTHY is a former United States Senator from Minnesota. By EUGENE J. McCARTHY

title: Mailbox; Rangers Should Take the Hint
description: To the Editor:

title: On Language By William Safire Shlepper and Bungie
description: I have a favorite old suitcase covered with stickers from faraway places and tags from forgotten Presidential summits (''Formal Wear - Offload Iran Only''). But carrying the big bag around gives me a backache, and I look with envy at people who breeze through airports with designer luggage (when did a suitcase stop being called a ''grip''?) that rolls on built-in wheels.

title: Topics; Computer Braille
description: The computer punch card, as Time magazine notes, is disappearing; now New York Telephone has started sending out bills without them. For a generation, the punch card was a primary way to feed data into computers, but also a symbol.

title: 'English Miniatures' Opens Dec. 16 at Yale
description: ''The English Miniature,'' an exhibition that includes 114 miniature portraits from the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, will open Dec. 16 at the Yale Center for British Art.

title: SIDES CALLED 'DEADLOCKED' IN LAY TEACHERS' STRIKE
description: The two sides in the eight-week-old teachers' strike at Christ the King Regional High School in Middle Village, Queens, are ''hopelessly deadlocked,'' according to a state mediator. He said they should submit the dispute to binding arbitration,

title: IN ARGENTINA, 10,000 PROTEST THE LACK OF JOBS
description: A crowd of more than 10,000 attended a mass at the rear of a small church today to protest unemployment and continued military rule in Argentina.

title: No Headline
description: An inaccuracy in ''The New Black Conservatives'' was that I am a ''favored spokesman'' for the Reagan Administration. How can someone who steadfastly refused to talk to the press for months be a ''spokesman'' for anybody? My first public words on this Administration were uttered recently on ''Meet the Press'': ''I am not now, nor have I ever been, a spokesman for the Reagan Administration.'' Mr. Daniels is apparently one of those reporters who reports his own preconceptions and calls it news.

title: The World in Summary; Blowing Hot On El Salvador
description: When the Reagan Administration set out with much fanfare early this year to help defeat the leftist insurgency in El Salvador, it seemed confident that a quick infusion of military advisers and economic aid would turn the tide. Not so, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. admitted last week.

title: Camp David Finished, A British Envoy Asserts
description: Ambassador David Roberts of Britain was quoted today as having said that the United Statessponsored Camp David peace process between Israel and Egypt was ''finished, more or less.''

title: The Greenwich
description: To the Business Editor: I maintain that the woes of the Greenwich Savings Bank had nothing to do with low mortgage financing and lower interest rates, at least not at first.

title: Arrow Coach Likes How Team Looks
description: Coach Don Popovic of the New York Arrows kept peeking out the window of his office. He was looking at the carpeted arena of the team's training facility, which was occupied by 20 players. Some were playing a small game of tennis using a soccer ball and no racquets, some were juggling with a soccer ball, and others were playing a soccer game with four players on a side.

title: WHY ARE WE SO FASCINATED BY THE HARRIS CASE?
description: WHEN Jean S. Harris pulled the trigger of her .32 in the Scarsdale bedroom of Dr. Herman Tarnower, I was on vacation. I had just brought to a close five years of research and writing on ''Women Who Kill.'' Jean Harris, as it turned out, had brought to a close almost everything she cared about.

title: Emirates Leader Re-elected
description: Sheik Zayed bin Sultan al-Nahiyan, the ruler of Abu Dhabi, was re-elected unanimously today to a second five-year term as President of the United Arab Emirates, according to the official Emirates press agency.

title: Chess; OLD-FASHIONED ATTACK SERVES BELYAVSKY WELL
description: Alexander Belyavsky of the Soviet Union won the all-grandmaster Interpolis International Tournament in Tilburg, The Netherlands with a 7 1/2-3 1/2 score. Final Standings Player Pts. Belyavsky 7 1/2 Petrosian 7 Portisch 6 1/2 Timman 6 1/2 Ljubojevich 6 Andersson 5 1/2 Player Pts. Kasparov 5 1/2 Spassky 5 1/2 Larsen 4 1/2 Sosonko 4 1/2 Huebner 4 Miles 3

title: DELBELLO REFLECTS ON A 'TOUGH' VICTORY
description: LAST Sunday, at the Rye Town Hilton, 400 to 500 friends and associates of Alfred B. DelBello gathered for a birthday party that was also the last fund-raising event of an exhausting re-election campaign. They paid $47 a couple, the figure representing the County Executive's age.

title: MISSTEP ABROAD
description: To the Editor:

title: Life Sentence for 2d Brother
description: A man convicted of conspiring with his brother to have their father's throat slit has been sentenced to life in prison. Larry Baublitz, 21 years old, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Rex Martin of Lenawee County Circuit Court.

title: THE RE-EDUCATION OF WALTER MONDALE
description: Walter F. Mondale, former Vice President of the United States, is of counsel to the law firm of Winston & Strawn and a visiting professor at three universities in Minnesota. By Walter F. Mondale It's been about a year now since my previous employer informed me that my contract would not be renewed. In that year, I've had the opportunity to do a number of things that nationally elected leaders too rarely have the chance to do: to engage in extended discussions with people who are not regular visitors to the White House, to read extensively, to explore long-term issues without the pressures of day-to-day crisis management. This year has meant more to me than simply moving from the West Wing of the White House to a law office on Washington's M Street and new teaching positions in my state of Minnesota. It's meant a chance to refresh myself spiritually and restock the shelves intellectually. And I'm eagerly taking advantage of this opportunity.

title: WESTERN STATES SEEK NEW LEVIES AS U.S. CUTS THREATEN VARIETY OF PROJECTS
description: Projected cutbacks in Federal assistance to state and local governments for capital development projects, including waste water treatment plants and new highways, are causing growing alarm in the Rocky Mountain region, where rapid population growth and the drive to develop energy resources have already put a severe strain on public services.

title: The New Black Conservatives
description: ''The New Black Conservatives'' (by Lee A. Daniels, Oct. 4) are clearly a heterogeneous group. Moderate and extreme positions contrast sharply under the all-inclusive label ''conservative.''

title: LEADERSHIP BATTLES LOOM IN LEGISLATURE
description: ALTHOUGH they did not know who the next Governor would be, leaders in both houses of the Legislature last week began preparing for crucial legislative battles that could dominate the last two months of this legislative session and, to a large extent, shape the leadership structure of the coming session.

title: Around the Nation; Oregon District Closes Schools as 3d Vote Fails
description: Schools closed at the end of classes this week, giving 2,500 students a ''forced vacation,'' because voters have refused to approve school taxes.

title: CAMP DAVID OR BUST?
description: JERUSALEM FOUR years since Anwar el-Sadat journeyed to Jerusalem, Israelis are having difficulty recalling the exhilaration of that time. The joy has faded into apprehension. The peace process the Egyptian leader initiated - still the region's solitary structure of accord - seems a flimsy shelter of sanity, requiring zealous and passionate protection.

title: Dining Out; FISH SHOP AND RESTAURANT IN ONE
description: the name resounds with the real business of the sea, the promise of a direct link between seafood in the water and seafood in the pan. One enters the restaurant's capacious dining room - decorated in the obligatory life preserver, fishing net, rusty anchor spool - through a fish shop displaying a live lobster tank and bins of shaved ice studded with iridescent sea creatures. To be sure, Westchester Trawler, awaiting its Tuesday delivery, had little to offer on one Monday evening, when most fish restaurants and stores are closed. However, later in the week superbly fresh fish were in plentiful supply.

title: Paperback Talk
description: The crazes of '81. The Cube. Cats. Preppies. Eleven of the paperbacks on the best-seller lists above deal with those currently raging fads.

title: POEMS AND EXCITEMENT
description: SELECTED POEMS 1958-1980 By Gilbert Sorrentino. 268 pp. Santa Barbara: Black Sparrow Press. Cloth, $20. Paper, $7.50.

title: BETH BARON TO BE BRIDE OF JEFFREY A. SCHREIBER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Baron of Jericho, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beth Lori Baron, to Jeffrey Alan Schreiber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Schreiber of Sands Point, L.I.

title: Headliners Feeling Better, Thanks
description: He may not have been the best doctor for a drug addict, but in prescribing more than 19,000 doses of narcotics, sedatives and stimulants for Elvis Presley over 32 months, Dr. George Nichopoulos was a ''good samaritan,'' his lawyer argued in Memphis last week. Standing trial on charges of overprescribing addictive drugs for Mr. Presley and 10 other patients, Dr. Nichopoulos was acquitted, largely because the defense was able to establish that there is no universally accepted treatment for prescription drug addicts. Dr. Nichopoulos said he prescribed the drugs in hope of becoming his patients' only source and then weaning them from their dependency. Drug experts said they wished the case would focus attention on the plight of physicians who feel duty bound to treat the growing number of such cases, but lack the necessary training.

title: OKLAHOMA POLICE CARS CONVERT TO NATURAL GAS
description: Police cars and other city vehicles are bypassing the gasoline pumps in an effort to save $50,000 to $70,000 a year in energy costs.

title: Stephanie Doering Wed To Michael David Soffer
description: Stephanie Lowell Doering, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul E. Doering of Wayne, Pa., was married yesterday to Michael David Soffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Soffer of Havertown, Pa., and Ventnor, N.J. Criminal Court Judge Robert Gawthrop of West Chester, Pa., performed the ceremony at the Merion (Pa.) Tribute House.

title: 20,000 Marchers in Frankfurt Protest New Airport Runway
description: About 20,000 people opposed to the construction of a new runway at Frankfurt's international airport staged a protest march at the site today.

title: No Headline
description: The explanation that Jews stayed in Kiev because ''they knew nothing of Adolf Hitler's vow to annihilate the Jews of Europe'' is questionable.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Trouble Under The Hood Delays Columbia's Trip
description: Something there is that doesn't like an on-time, trouble-free launching of the space shuttle Columbia. Its first liftoff in April came two days late thanks to a communications mixup by onboard computers. Last week, the spacecraft's second flight came down to the wire - 31 seconds left in the countdown - before it, too, was scrubbed. The culprit this time: clogged oil filters, which delayed the launch at least a week, until Wednesday at the earliest.

title: No Headline
description: Allen Breaks Rush Mark as U.S.C. Wins

title: The World in Summary; Bilateral Effort For Ulster Peace
description: Turning a deaf ear to the hard-liners and haters, the Prime Ministers of Britain and Ireland agreed last week to create an intergovernmental council to seek to ''diminish the divisions between the two sections of the community in Northern Ireland.'' Margaret Thatcher and Garret FitzGerald immediately ordered studies on economic and energy cooperation.

title: MISSTEP IN FRANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: A LIBERAL ANTECEDENT TO NIXON'S CHINA FEAT
description: To the Editor:

title: Tropical Storm Dissipates
description: Tropical Storm Katrina dissipated over the western Atlantic today, leaving behind two dead in Cuba and some crop damage in the Bahamas. In its final advisory on the storm, the National Hurricane Center reported that the remains of the storm were about 600 miles east of the northern Bahamas and speeding eastnortheastward at 35 miles an hour.

title: The Nation in Summary; Across the Land, The Levers Fall Where They May
description: Putting an ear to the ground during off-year elections sometimes yields a sense of where the nation is coming from, or galloping off to. More often it's just another way to get an earache. True to form, last week's voting in a scattering of states and cities seemed to show hestitancy toward black politicians, a tendency to re-elect familiar faces and a reluctance to spend money - but there were the usual notable exceptions.

title: WESTFIELD DEFEATS NUTLEY, 35-6, IMPROVING ITS RECORD TO 6-1
description: Westfield, a strong contender for the state Group 4 title, gained its sixth victory against one setback yesterday by beating Nutley, 35-6, in Westfield.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Career Man Over the years, Robert Stack has portrayed Linc Evers, the Los Angeles police captain in ''Most Wanted,'' the G-man Eliot Ness in ''The Untouchables'' and Dan Farrell, an F.B.I. agent-turned-reporter, in ''The Name of the Game.'' Mr. Stack is now playing Captain Frank Murphy in ''Strike Force,'' an adventure series that will have its premiere Friday on ABC at 9:30 P.M. Also in the cast are Dorian Harewood, Richard Romanus, Michael Goodwin, Trisha Noble and Herb Edelman.

title: No Headline
description: CUEVAS IS UPSET BY STAFFORD

title: Air-Fare Bargain?
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: RACHEL HARMS'S 'GROUND'
description: The Rachel Harms Dance Company gave its audience an inside look at dance Friday at the Jan Hus Church, where the modern-dance group is based. It was an unusual form of entertainment. But Miss Harms is as assured and thoughtful a speaker as she is a choreographer, and she has a very personable company.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Hero and Worship
description: Not many applicants enter the United States Military Academy at West Point by Presidential endorsement. Colin P. Kelly 3d did - but after first taking, at his insistence, a qualifying examination and passing it.

title: Around the World; Rebels Reportedly Storm City in Northwest Iran
description: The Teheran radio said today that Kurdish rebels and leftist guerrillas stormed into the northwestern Iranian city of Bukan last night and shot scores of people in the streets, public baths, cafes and bakeries.

title: LESSON NO. 1: IMAGE, IMAGE
description: It's called a school, though there are no classes or instruction. It is in fact a two-day series of seminars in which the professionals who have just earned their touring cards learn what they can expect to find on the tour - and what is expected of them.

title: Other Business; GOODWILL INDUSTRIES: IT APPROVES THE REAGAN BUDGET
description: As unpopular as Reagonomics may be among agencies that help the poor, there is at least one that's not complaining. Goodwill Industries, a $264-million-a-year corporation that hires and trains handicapped people for industrial jobs, endorses the Administration's policies, including its cuts in social programs.

title: Broadway Stars to Give A 'New Moon' Benefit
description: Broadway performers, including Estelle Parsons, John Reardon, Meg Bussert and Debbie Shapiro, will head the cast of ''The New Moon,'' the 1928 operetta hit by Sigmund Romberg and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, on Nov. 23 at 8:30 P.M. in Town Hall.

title: A WORLDWIDE SCRAMBLE FOR THE RAREST RUBIES
description: Bill Kurtis is a reporter and anchor man for WBBM-TV in Chicago. By Bill Kurtis In the tropical forests of Thailand, where the border with Cambodia touches the sea, two pistol-toting mine owners - in a scene out of the Old West - stand guard over laborers aiming a high-pressure hose against a hillside. The spray of water cuts into red earth, sending mud and gravel spilling 20 yards below into a sluice box that is pumping up and down. Farther below, where a muddy stream fans into a small alluvial delta, an old woman squats under a sloping hat, chewing betel nuts as she sifts gravel in a bamboo tray. She searches the pebbles for something far more valuable than gold and 40 times rarer than diamonds. She looks for rubies.

title: Navy Cruise Missile Fails
description: A Tomahawk cruise missile aimed for a Nevada test site splashed down in the Pacific today, apparently because of an engine failure, a Navy spokesman said.

title: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: CONTEMPORARY MUSIC

title: COMMON MARKET DREAMS WEAR THIN
description: Worried that Europe's commitment to free trade and economic integration may not survive the world recession, the continent's leaders will meet in London later this month to try to inject new vitality into the Common Market's flagging quest for ''an ever closer union of the European peoples.''

title: BAD NEWS AT THE FINANCIAL TIMES
description: LONDON L ESS than a month ago, the Financial Times, perhaps best known for its distinctive salmon-pink paper, closed World Business Weekly, an American offshoot introduced on a shoestring in 1978 that had nonetheless piled up losses estimated in the millions.

title: Susan Friedman Betrothed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Ross N. Friedman of Spring Valley, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Susan Amy Friedman, to Steven William Hirsch, son of Dr. and Mrs. Norbert Hirsch of Yonkers.

title: Music; A MUSICAL BONANZA: THREE NEW GROUPS
description: WITHIN the next two weeks, Connecticut will celebrate the birth of a chamber ensemble, a professional music theater and a symphony orchestra.

title: HOW STABLE ARE THE SAUDIS?
description: Robert Lacey is the author of ''The Kingdom,'' from which this article is adapted. The book will be published next spring by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. By Robert Lacey

title: GETTING DOWN TO BASICS ON WHAT AILS THE U.S. ECONOMY
description: EVEN Pollyanna would have been daunted by last week's economic statistics. The nation's unemployment rate leapt to 8 percent in October, the highest level in almost six years; for blacks, it hit a record. One million more people are out of work now than in July, and the recession that put them there - the second in as many years - is only expected to grow deeper. Not only were orders for new manufacturing goods down 0.9 percent in September; the biggest month-to-month rise in inventories since February was reported. In American industry's crippled bellwether, autos, sales were down 27.2 percent, for the lowest October since 1958.

title: A FLOWER STAND ENLISTS IN BATTLE FOR BRYANT PARK
description: In the gentlest of aggressions against the drug dealers and derelicts of Bryant Park, chrysanthemums and roses and carnations and daisies have established a gallant little beachhead outside the park's seedy northwest entrance at 42d Street and the Avenue of the Americas.

title: Business Conditions; A BIG YEAR FOR OPIC
description: These are heady days for the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, a Government entity that sells political risk insurance and financial services to American companies entering markets in developing countries. Backed by a pro-investment Administration and a more aggressive marketing approach, it is writing more policies than ever.

title: PLAYWRIGHTS WILL GET AWARDS
description: Harold Pinter and Tennessee Williams will receive the third annual Common Wealth Awards for Distinguished Service in Dramatic Arts Nov. 19 at the Shubert Theater. Each playwright will receive $11,000 and a commemorative sculpture.

title: ARTIST, 82, SAVORS TIE WITH YOUTHS
description: WALLACE PUTNAM, the painter, is 82 years old and lives here in a converted ice house, an impeccably maintained, four-room wooden structure half-hidden by trees at the end of a long dirt road.

title: TENURE: ARE ALL ENTITLED TO IT?
description: NO ASPECT of tenure has come under attack as frequently as that for district superintendents, the chief administrators of district school systems.

title: Long Islanders; HIS FILM-PRODUCING VENTURE BEGAN WITH A SONG
description: ''INEVER knew what I wanted to do,'' said William Blake of Woodmere. ''I still don't.'' As a result, the 38-year-old Mr. Blake, known as Billy, has found himself in a variety of businesses -founder of Aquarius Transfer, a New York City sound studio for film and video producers; founder of Can Carriers Messenger Service, a delivery service for people in the creative arts, and founder and co-publisher of Millimeter, a magazine for those in film production.

title: A SCHOOL FOR SMART STROKES
description: Donal Henahan, the chief music critic of The Times, made it to the finals of Wimbledon twice- but not as a player. By Donal Henahan

title: No Headline
description: LEXICOGRAPHER TAKES STRICTLY AMERICAN VIEW

title: BEYOND CANCUN
description: With the Cancun summit meeting behind us, the United States will be under pressure from both its industrialized allies and the developing countries to move promptly into global negotiations on such North-South issues as trade, development, finance, food, raw materials, and energy. But such negotiations cannot occur until there is a compromise on the procedural question of where and how the North-South dialogue is to proceed.

title: Around the World; Supreme Court Blocks All Executions in India
description: India's Supreme Court effectively postponed all executions today by issuing a stay of execution for two men who had been scheduled to die tomorrow morning for the murder of two teenagers.

title: Steinbrenner Faces Surgery
description: A hospital appointment will keep George Steinbrenner from speaking at Purdue University's ''Old Masters'' program, a Yankee spokesman, Irv Kaze, said today.

title: Food; CLAMS OFF THE HALF SHELL
description: Over the years, we often have been both enlightened and amused by A.J. McClane's ''The Encyclopedia of Fish Cookery'' (Holt, Rinehart & Winston, 1977). Recently, when reading up on clams, we were fascinated by his observation that the shells of the hard clam once served as a form of currency in America. ''Black wampum,'' made from the heart of the large quahog shell, was strung into bands or belts and ''served for money in the eastern colonies until the end of the 17th century.'' (Quahog, by the way, is the Algonquin Indian name for all the hard-shell clams, including littlenecks, cherrystones and chowder clams.)

title: VOTING RIGHTS BACKERS ASSAIL REAGAN'S STAND
description: Dozens of organizations that support extension of the Voting Rights Act said today that changes proposed by President Reagan would threaten the rights of millions of minority voters.

title: PRAYERS BURDENED WITH EARTHLY MISSIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation in Summary; A Soft Landing On Voting Rights
description: President Reagan finally took a stand on the Voting Rights Act last week, and his views were hailed as either surprisingly flexible or unacceptably insensitive. Calling the right to vote ''the crown jewel of American liberties,'' Mr. Reagan said he could accept a renewal of the current law or a toned-down version of a bill adopted by the House last month.

title: The Controversial Mrs. Carey
description: Mrs. Carey is not Governor and her personal style and list of previous husbands should have little influence on a voter's decision in next year's gubernatorial election (''The Careys of Albany,'' by Richard Meislin, Oct. 4).

title: Follow-Up on the News; 'New' Mammoth
description: The mammoths of Siberia are believed to have become extinct 10,000 years ago, but the Soviet Academy of Science was reported confident in March 1980 that it had a good chance of creating live specimens of the beast.

title: Local Officials And Foreign Affairs
description: The use of Nassau District Attorney Denis Dillon's public office as a podium for urging boycott and picketing of the Coldstream Guards Scotch Band and Bagpipes visit to the Nassau Coliseum is, to say the least, irresponsible, in bad taste and nauseating to the majority of law-abiding citizens in Nassau County.

title: 2 VILLAGES STYMIE BROOKHAVEN ON AID
description: BROOKHAVEN TOWN will lose more than $600,000 in Federal funds in the next three years because the incorporated villages of Old Field and Belle Terre will not accept a portion of the funds for community improvements, according to Edward Romaine, director of the Town of Brookhaven Community Development Agency.

title: Westchester Housing; BUYING, SELLING: TEACHING THE ROPES
description: BUYING and selling a house has become so complicated that there are now classes in how to go about it. Westchester Residential Opportunities, a nonprofit organization, recently held a four-hour ''homebuyer's class'' that attracted 75 people. The Westchester County Board of Realtors gave a two-hour class last spring and filled a ballroom at the White Plains Hotel. Several Westchester real estate agents now hold classes regularly in their offices.

title: STATE SEEKS RULES FOR 'HARD R' CABLE TV
description: SECAUCUS CONCERNED about the spread of ''adult'' entertainment on cable television, the state is considering regulating programming of the so-called ''hard R'' shows.

title: Glenn Tops Bayport, 43-0
description: Jim Malloy scored three touchdowns on runs of 10, 2 and 59 yards yesterday to give John Glenn of Huntington a 43-0 victory over Bayport, its seventh straight triumph this season.

title: Header Card Captures $240,650 Coast Feature
description: Header Card became the champion 2-year-old filly of the 1981 Oak Tree meeting at Santa Anita today with a 1 1/2-length victory over A Kiss for Luck in the $240,650 Oak Leaf Stakes.

title: CHOPPING THE FEDERAL WORK FORCE
description: WASHINGTON T HERE is an eerie hush on the fifth floor of the downtown office building that, only six weeks ago, was the headquarters of the Community Services Administration. Only a handful of people slip between the desks, tables, chairs and typewriters that are piled in the corridor. The walls are full of graffiti, mostly the giant signatures of the people who ran the nation's antipoverty program until it closed Sept. 30. The fish swimming in the tank outside the administrator's office are, as one former employee put it, ''the only signs around here that life goes on.''

title: NORTHWESTERN FALLS INTO RECORD BOOK
description: It was a great moment. Northwestern, the underdog hoping against Michigan State to prevent a 29th straight loss today that would give it the major-college record, worked a beautiful sideline pass play, and scored.

title: Police Reject Story on Killing And Charge Man Who Gave It
description: The manager of a South Bronx social club was arrested yesterday and charged with the fatal shooting of one man and the wounding of two others in a scuffle that apparently involved drugs, the police said.

title: The Week in Business; A NEW CHIEF FOR VW
description: Volkswagen, struggling to revive sales and profits, tapped a new chairman last week. He is Carl H. Hahn (right), 55 years old, who now runs West Germany's biggest rubber company, Continental Gummiwerke. Mr. Hahn won the recommendation of a committee of VW's board to succeed Toni Schmucker, 60, who suffered a heart attack last June and who had asked to be relieved of his post. Mr. Schmucker revived VW after the oil price rises and auto slumps of the early 70's. The company has again fallen on difficult times with problems in the American auto operation and at its office-machine subsidiary.

title: Washington; HAIG'S ENDLESS PROBLEMS
description: Secretary of State Haig is regarded here as the most experienced member of the Reagan Administration in the conduct of foreign affairs, which is no great compliment, but he is in deep trouble.

title: STAGE: KITCHEN EXERCISE
description: The title character in ''Selma'' (at the Theater for the New City) has just turned 50, and she and four friends are preparing a celebratory dinner. In this short but seemingly long one-course play, the first to be written by the actress Shami Chaikin, we learn various culinary skills, such as how to prepare string beans and how to make carrot juice (scrape with a knife, slice and push hard into a blender). In that sense, ''Selma'' is useful. But as a play it is simply an overstuffed appetizer.

title: Elizabeth Groves Lawyer's Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Freeman Groves of Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Groves, to John William Campo Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Campo of Greenwich, Conn.; Hyannis Port, Mass., and Boynton Beach, Fla. The wedding will take place next month.

title: Misstep Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: After Prisons, What?
description: The debate over New York's $500 million prison bond issue pitted those who want more cells against those who want to solve crowding with better management. The vote approving the bond was so close that victory is still not certain - and officials who campaigned vigorously for it should read the slim majority as a mixed mandate: yes, build urgently needed cells, but do something about management, too.

title: IRISH AID EFFORTS IN U.S. STILL STRONG
description: Support for the Irish republican cause in the United States has remained strong since the hunger strike in Northern Ireland ended, according to an official of a New York-based organization that the Justice Department says is an agent of the Irish Republican Army's Provisional wing.

title: Military Analysis
description: The balance of military power in the Middle East, especially in terms of air strength, is likely to be significantly affected by the scheduled completion of the Israeli withdrawal from Sinai in April.

title: COMPUTER POINTS TO SINGLE AUTHOR FOR GENESIS
description: A computer analysis of the Old Testament Book of Genesis has yielded evidence to support a common Christian and Jewish religious belief that the work was written by one author.

title: 25% MORE WORKERS TO CROWD MIDTOWN IN 80'S
description: Construction in midtown Manhattan over the next decade will add 150,000 office workers to the crowded heart of the city, a 25 percent increase over the present number, according to a city study examining the likely environmental consequences of such growth.

title: SOUTH LEBANESE MILITIA CHIEF DECIDES TO STAY
description: Maj. Saad Haddad, the former Lebanese Army officer who quit yesterday as leader of an Israeli-backed militia in southern Lebanon, withdrew his resignation today, the Israeli radio said.

title: UPSTATE CEMENT PROJECT BURNS HAZARDOUS WASTE
description: A new method of disposing of hazardous wastes - by burning them as a fuel in the manufacture of cement - is being demonstrated here on the banks of the Hudson River, and its advocates hope it will prove both safe and profitable.

title: Headliners; The Royal Family Way
description: Attending her first major ceremonial function last week, Diana, the Princess of Wales was, the Times of London gushed, ''a glamorous concoction almost beyond description, shimmering from head to toe.'' Apparently it was the glow of impending motherhood.

title: SEED FUEL'S DAY MAY NEVER COME, BUT JUST IN CASE...
description: When Hugh Whitted, an engineer and farmer in East Bend, N.C., heard from a friend that the Chinese ran their buses on soybean oil during World War II, he could hardly wait to pour a bottle of corn oil into his tractor. That was in 1968.

title: BRAIN SCANNING TECHNIQUE PRAISED AT PARLEY
description: A conference of medical experts has given a sweeping vote of confidence to the use of computer-assisted X-ray scanning of the brain, asserting that the technique is saving lives and money.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: KING OF THE CONFESSORS By Thomas Hoving. Illustrated. 365 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: Kathryn B. Tracy To Be Wed Jan. 2
description: Kathryn Bayard Tracy, a consultant in gerontology in Syracuse, and Dr. William Nicholas Wanck, a resident in psychiatry at the State University of New York in Syracuse, plan to be married Jan. 2 at the Erwin Methodist Church in Syracuse.

title: Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: DIFFERENT WARS DIVIDE VETERANS
description: HOLBROOK WITH the annual observance of Veterans Day three days away, Vietnam veterans on the Island have adopted a more aggressive approach in their decade-long struggle to obtain recognition, jobs and medical care for their colleagues who fought in an unpopular war and then faced ostracism when they returned home.

title: EX-CLERKS TO HONOR JUDGE KAUFMAN
description: Former law clerks for Judge Irving R. Kaufman will hold a dinner tomorrow in honor of his 20 years on the Federal appeals court in Manhattan.

title: STORY OF PFC. WILLIAM JAMES, WAR HERO FOUR DECADES LATER
description: HIS toes were frozen white, yet his fingers were scorched from the heat of gunfire. His valor was part of a battle that helped change the course of World War II, but for nearly four decades those deeds went unhonored and virtually unremembered.

title: Recordings; POP STYLISTS EMBRACE BALLADS
description: Is torch singing coming back? As the rock generation approaches middle age, many singers who made their names in rock are looking back to the 30's, 40's and 50's for inspiration. Although Carly Simon, Diana Ross and Bernadette Peters are vastly dissimilar pop stylists, their latest albums all propose a post-rock ballad tradition with strong ties to the past.

title: G.O.P. FINDS STRENGTH IN FAIRFIELD COUNTY
description: AS they were looking over the returns from Connecticut's municipal elections in Hartford last Tuesday night, state Democratic leaders were discounting any sweeping generalities.

title: A PRIMITIVE EXPLAINS HERSELF
description: NISA The Life and Words of a !Kung Woman. By Marjorie Shostak. Illustrated. 402 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $20. By LISA PEATTIE

title: Study Favors Reducing Use of Heart Operation
description: Victims of coronary artery disease may not need cardiac surgery to avoid heart attack and sudden death. Researchers at Harvard University say that drugs, proper diet and exercise may be all that is necessary in most cases.

title: A FILM OFFER 'DONS' COULDN'T REFUSE
description: A line of actors and would-be actors, waiting in the cold yesterday to get into B. Dalton's bookstore on Fifth Avenue, stretched around the corner of East 52d Street like a sort of costume party.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Yves Rault, Pianist, Plays Debussy Preludes
description: Yves Rault, a young pianist from France, made an impressive debut at Carnegie Recital Hall Wednesday evening. His virtues began with his program, which included six Debussy Preludes, Webern's Variations (Op. 27) and ''Eritana'' from Albeniz's ''Iberia.''

title: Speaking Personally; HEADING FOR THE NORTH WOODS... BY MAIL
description: THE catalogue king of the Northeast, L.L. Bean, not only has tamed the bitter Maine weather, but also has charmed one closet woodsman living in the wilds of suburban New Jersey.

title: OFFICIALS TOLD TO MAKE FLOOD ALERTS SPECIFIC
description: A weather expert, calling for a new approach to flood warnings, says people would react more quickly and lives would be saved if details about the threat were made available.

title: JUDGE'S COUNSELING OFFERS DEFENDANTS A 2D CHANCE
description: Judge Jerome Hornblass of Criminal Court passes a note to a defendant who has come before him for sentencing - a note that typically begins, ''You are invited to meet the judge.. . .''

title: Follow-Up on the News; 'Injuring' Corpses
description: To learn how the front of a car might be modified to reduce pedestrian injuries, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration approved a $380,000 study that called for using human cadavers. The news report from Columbus, Ohio, last Oct. 10 began:

title: COMPUTERS: THE ACTION'S IN SOFTWARE
description: I T can turn a scruffy youngster with a bright idea into a millionaire, and a gigantic scientific project like the space shuttle into a failure. People working at home can produce it, as can highpaid employees of giant corporations, providing they can bring both artistic creativity and detailed, logical drudgery to the task. It is part product, part service - an unusual enough combination that governments haven't figured out how to tax it.

title: DUTY SHIFTS TO STRENGTHEN CITY DETECTIVE UNIT
description: More than 400 police officers and uniformed specialists will be shifted to investigative duties beginning tomorrow, in a major strengthening of the New York City Police Department's detective bureau.

title: POINTS OF VIEW FROM A ROOFTOP
description: EACH day John Higgins of Rocky Point climbs to the roof of his restaurant, Charly 5's Surf and Turf, to put up messages that have been variously described as witty, heartwarming and outrageous.

title: Harriet Moore Is Wed To George Patterson
description: The marriage of Harriet Hamilton Moore of Gulfstream, Fla., widow of David Channing Moore, to George Doremus Patterson of Wilmington, Del., a widower, took place in Princeton, N.J., yesterday.

title: WILDCLIFF MUSEUM FIGHTS TO QUASH DEBTS
description: NEW ROCHELLE THE art displays are gone from the walls of the stone mansion overlooking Long Island Sound. The blue and white truck that delivered Wildcliff's ''petting zoo'' to curious youngsters in daycare centers stands unused in the front yard here.

title: SPINKS KEEPS TITLE, STOPPING JOHNSON
description: With what he shyly but proudly admitted was ''a sneaky punch,'' Michael Spinks, the only undefeated professional among this country's five 1976 Olympic champions, knocked down Vonzell Johnson in the seventh round today and scored a knockout moments later in the first defense of his World Boxing Association light-heavyweight title.

title: Strong Quake Jars Chile
description: A strong earthquake jolted a wide area of central Chile early today, sending hundreds of people into the streets in panic. The police said they had no immediate reports of deaths.

title: CITY OPERA: JUNE ANDERSON IN 'LUCIA'
description: As the opera world in general cries poverty over its dimished vocal resources, the New York City Opera gives occasional sly displays of hidden wealth. Friday night's revival of Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' offered three principal singers that might have made the City Opera's more august next-door neighbor at Lincoln Center squirm with envy.

title: The Region in Summary; In Medicaid, Is Less More?
description: Being rich is better, of course, but poor has its advantages, too. Because New York fell from 5th to 12th in per capita income among states in the 1980 census, Federal officials said last week, the state's share of Medicaid matching funds was raised from 50 percent to 50.88 percent, increasing the amount Washington will send Albany for the health and hospital program by $53 million.

title: Laissez-Faire
description: To the Business Editor: Senator Bill Bradley's ''Laissez-Faire on Oil'' (Oct. 25), has some valid points on the useful allocation effects of rising prices during an oil shortage, but in other economic respects, it is seriously flawed. Oil markets may not ''crumble under stress,'' but as the last two crises have shown, the unregulated spot market does go into a frenzy once the panic bidding for crude oil begins.

title: No Headline
description: BRUINS TROUNCE QUEBEC

title: Headliners; An Account Since Closed
description: His relationship with an airline stewardess two years ago was ''purely sexual''; he was not only ''used as a sperm bank,'' Frank Serpico said last week, but fraudulently so.
