He told the story in his defense in Manhattan Family Court, where the stewardess, identified as L. Pamela P., has sued him for support of the toddler she says was conceived during their affair.

title: CRITICAL VIEWING IS BEING ADDED TO THE THREE R'S
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Alexis Greene is a freelance writer who frequently reports on children's television. By ALEXIS GREENE

title: WHY WERE THE YANKEES SORROWFUL IN DEFEAT?
description: NOW that the Series is over and the Yankees have said they're sorry, showing their class in praise of the Dodgers, who, they say, deserved to win and are the true champs, let's set the record straight. A few more rainouts or Yankee victories and they would have been playing hardball on Halloween though as it was many observers insisted that the Fall-less-than-Classic was a sorry masquerade. (Who was that dressed up as Dave Winfield?)

title: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: JAZZ Two of the most reserved performers in the sometimes flamboyant world of jazz, John Lewis and Hank Jones, will join together for an evening of two piano performances at City College's Aaron Davis Hall (Theater A) on Thursday at 8 P.M. They will bring to this concert another quality that they have in common in addition to their conservative appearance: They are two of the most polished, thoughtful and subtle pianists in the jazz world. Since the Modern Jazz Quartet broke up in 1974, Mr. Lewis, who was the pianist and musical director of the group, has been teaching at City College. Mr. Jones, who spent many years as a staff musician for the Columbia Broadcasting System and later was Ella Fitzgerald's accompanist, has most recently been playing Fats Waller's music in the Broadway show, ''Ain't Misbehavin' .'' Mr. Jones and Mr. Lewis first played together at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington shortly after the Modern Jazz Quartet disbanded and later were members of a jazz troupe on a tour of Japan which gave them an opportunity to play duets. Since then they have played together frequently enough to develop a small repertory of two-piano arrangements that reflect their individual personalities. John S. Wilson

title: HOW TO READ THE ECONOMY
description: WASHINGTON P EOPLE might feel it in their paychecks and the supermarket. But there's only one way most folks really know how the economy is doing, and that's by watching the reports that the Government's statisticians keep cranking out, month by month, quarter by quarter. These indicators produce more than a picture of the economy. They also form the basis for economic policy decisions and signal whether policies then in effect are working.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Too Many Youths Will Be Served
description: A little impediment can go a long way toward reducing the highway accident rate of young people, according to a University of Michigan study released last week.

title: RETURN OF WOLVES TO A NATIONAL PARK SOUGHT
description: Wildlife researchers are seeking to re-establish a wolf population in Glacier National Park by creating an environment that will lure the wolves across the Canadian border.

title: Providential II Wins Laurel International
description: Providential II, a 4-year-old colt bred but later sold off by Bert Firestone, charged through the stretch past April Run, a 3-year-old filly owned by Firestone's wife, Diana, and won the $250,000 Washington International on the grass today at Laurel Race Course.

title: Art; WORKS IN MINIATURE CHALLENGE THE POWER OF PERCEPTION
description: HUNTINGTON THE scale of a work of art is one of those fundamental attributes that we often take for granted but that must be carefully considered in evaluating the success or failure of the work as a whole.

title: A NEW PRESIDENT AT SARAH LAWRENCE
description: BRONXVILLE WHEN students at Sarah Lawrence College invited their presidentelect to deliver a ''fantasy lecture'' earlier this year in their coffee house, Alice Stone Ilchman responded with a speech entitled, ''The Role of Public Diplomacy in the Conduct of United States Foreign Relations.''

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: out-of-print autobiographical volumes - ''Happy Days,'' ''Newspaper Days,'' ''Heathen Days'' - that the editor-curmudgeon H.L. Mencken (1880-1956) wrote during the afternoon of his life. Our reviewer Justin Kaplan described this collection as ''an unadulterated 180-proof delight, the chronicle of a lifelong romance with the printed word, daily journalism, politics, humor and Baltimore.''

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 8 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with an eccentric family. 2 2 3 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 3 3 13 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 4 5 5 THE LEGACY, by Howard Fast. (Houghton Mifflin, $14.95.) The Lavette family of ''The Immigrants'' and ''The Establishment'' reaches the turbulent 60's. 5 4 27 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A British-Chinese struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 6 7 20 THE CARDINAL SINS, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner/Bernard Geis, $12.95.) The triumphs and tragedies of two Chicago boys as priests in the Catholic Church. 7 6 15 THE THIRD DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam's, $13.95.) On the trail of the elusive killer of o ut-oftown businessmen visiting New York.

title: DANCE: PADOW INTERPLAY IN 'DESIRES'
description: In its first moments, Friday night's dance concert by the Judy Padow Dance Company at the Bessie Schonberg Theater threatened a rather hermetic evening.

title: Albanian Leader Re-elected
description: Enver Hoxha was re-elected head of the Albanian Communist Party today at the end of the eighth party congress. Mr. Hoxha, who is 73 years old, has been in power since World War II and is the longest-ruling leader of a Communist nation.

title: Business Conditions; THE BRAKE ON TRUCKS
description: Much attention has been focused on depressed auto sales, but conditions in the truck market are little better. Truck sales are well into their third straight year of decline as prime residential construction and agricultural markets continue to sag and other businesses delay buying equipment.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Plutonium Spill
description: Eighteen workers in a metallurgy area at the Los Alamos National Laboratory were nearing the end of their shift last Oct. 14 when a supervisor discovered the accidental release of highly radioactive plutonium.

title: F.H.A.'S FUTURE UNDER DEBATE
description: Soon after the Federal Housing Administration was created in 1934, the long-term fixed-rate mortgage became the mainstay of housing finance. Now, with fixed-rate loans rapidly becoming history, Federal policy makers are debating whether the F.H.A., too, is a thing of the past.

title: GREAT EMANCIPATOR AND MASTER OF TIMING
description: To the Editor:

title: Bonita Abdelnour Married to Nicholas Verbitsky
description: Bonita Ann Abdelnour and Nicholas J. Verbitsky, president of the United Stations, a satellite radio network broadcasting from New York, were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Paul Schneirla of St. Mary's Eastern Orthodox Church in Brooklyn performed the ceremony.

title: Business Conditions; CURRENCY DEMAND DIPS
description: Since the beginning of the year, according to Federal Reserve statistics, growth of currency in circulation, the major component of the monetary base, has slowed considerably.

title: Cogan Does a Turnaround
description: Just nine months ago Kevin Cogan thought about quitting auto racing. But the 25-year-old driver will instead replace Bobby Unser next season in Roger Penske's Indy car, Norton Spirit.

title: Food; KITCHEN FANTASIES TAKE WING WITH THE FLAVORFUL PHEASANT
description: Pheasant is a small and exquisitely flavored bird. It is available fresh in many markets these days and makes a delicious feast for two, prepared without much bother. Elizabeth David has called it the bird that inspires fantasies in the kitchen. Indeed, pheasant responds to all sorts of flavorings, expecially those that hint of autumn. Cranberries, juniper berries and chestnuts go wonderfully, as does that sublime fall luxury that comes in fresh from Italy - white truffles. Roast pheasant can be served with vegetables such as brussels sprouts or roast potatoes flavored with rosemary.

title: ECUMENICISM SEEKS TO RENEW PROMISE
description: During the 1960's and 1970's, Christians had their Camelot - a vision of a united church, its theological differences reconciled and proclaiming the one gospel of Jesus Christ. In those decades, the ecumenical movement commanded a great deal of energy and commitment from various denominations who shared a broad consensus on the Biblical basis for unity. But as the year 2000 approaches, there are questions of how a still-divided Christendom can celebrate the third millenium of the Christian era. In recent years, ecumenicism has foundered on persistent doctrinal disagreements, confusion over the way Christian unity can express itself and its own low morale.

title: BRUNNER, PITTMAN IN KEY GIANT ROLES
description: The Giants, with Scott Brunner at quarter and Danny Pittman back at wide receiver, will try to regain their winning form tomorrow when they play the Green Bay Packers in County Stadium. (Channel 2, 1 P.M.)

title: Sunday Observer By Russell Baker In the Teeth of Fanatics Patrick McDonnell
description: Mrs. Delia Odorra of Little Rock, Ark., wants someone to straighten her out about fundamentalists, extremists and fanatics. ''The news is filled nowadays with fundamentalists, extremists and fanatics, but the papers seem to use the words interchangeably,'' she writes. ''Am I wrong in thinking that fundamentalists, extremists and fanatics are actually three different breeds of cat?''

title: UNITED WAY ASSAILED AS MONOPOLISTIC CHARITY
description: Robert O. Bothwell, executive director of the National Committee for Responsive Philanthropy, criticized United Way, the nation's dominant volunteer charity, yesterday as a monopolistic organization.

title: ECONOMIES ARE THREATENING DIVORCE COURT
description: THE emphasis in Washington today is to balance the budget, even at the expense of some essential programs. This new focus will have a profound impact upon services traditionally provided at the state and local levels.

title: Denise Williams to Be Married May 8
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward David Williams of Franklin Lakes and Avalon, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Denise Daria Williams, to Kenneth Bradish Kunhardt Jr., son of Edith Woodruff Kunhardt of New York, and Kenneth B. Kunhardt of Cambridge, Mass.

title: HOBOKEN: CHANGE BRINGING PROBLEMS
description: HOBOKEN EFREYN and Carmen Ramos pay $108 a month for a four-room, coldwater railroad apartment on lower Willow Avenue here. Recently, they and their nine fellow tenants received rent-increase notices. After certain improvements are made, the notice said, the Ramoses' rent would be $360.

title: School to Get Oswald Papers
description: Marguerite Oswald's personal collection of books and information on the assassination of President Kennedy has been donated to Texas Christian University, the school announced this week. Mrs. Oswald, the mother of the Presidential assassin, Lee Harvey Oswald, died in January.

title: INVENTORY OF VACANT HOME LOTS IS UP NATIONWIDE
description: In Houston these days, the deer and the antelope could find plenty of room to play on the more than 70,000 empty building lots baking in the Texas sun. The lots are a testament to the city's status as one of the strongest housing markets in America until high interest rates finally caught up with it.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Just about every major economic indicator is now confirming that economic activity fell off a cliff in September, and the magnitude of the drop is much larger than anyone anticipated.'' - Edward Yardeni, chief economist for E.F. Hutton & Company. (1:6.)

title: TWO WRITERS LAMENT A 'LOSS OF COMMUNITY'
description: story writer, essayist, winner of the National Book Award for a work of nonfiction and Mr. Warren's wife of 30 years, is, according to him, ''as Yankee as they get.''

title: EXPATRIATES ARE HIS SUBJECT, ICONOCLASM IS HIS HOMELAND
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Annette Insdorf, an associate professor at Yale, is writing a book on film and the Holocaust. By ANNETTE INSDORF

title: Photography View; IS THE NEW COLOR WORK SO DIFFERENT FROM THE OLD?
description: ''The New Color'' is a very useful exhibition in the sense that it enables the viewer to get an overall view of a development that, up to now, has been visible only in bits and pieces. It is a survey of the kind of color photographs that have been shown in art galleries and museums during the past decade, and it can be seen at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue at 94th Street, through Wednesday.

title: No Headline
description: The Broker's View To the Editor: In response to your letter of Oct. 4, I must say that it is time for the public to hear the broker's point of view. Your reader, who cited the article (''House Sales Slowest in 6 Years,'' Sept. 13) failed to see an important point.

title: F.A.A. REPORTS 50% FAILURE RATE FOR FIRST AIR TRAFFIC CONTROLLERS'
description: Mark Weaver, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration's training academy in Oklahoma City, said Friday that while the figure was "unusual," it had been matched once or twice in recent years.

title: WOECKENER PACES 43-7 ROUT
description: Brian Woeckener ran for two touchdowns and passed for two more yesterday as unbeaten Pleasantville defeated Irvington, 43-7. Woeckener scored on runs of 62 and 10 yards, and combined with Jamie Mills for a 24-yard score and Rob Curran for a 50-yard score. Lou Hughes ran for touchdowns of 42 and 21 yards.

title: Art; 2 SHOWS CONTRAST SOCIAL REALISM AND CONCEPTUALISM
description: HARTFORD THE current juxtaposition at Wadsworth Atheneum might give even the most jaded connoisseur of modernism pause. On the one hand, is the continuing exhibition of Sol LeWitt's disposable wall drawings. On the other hand, there is the new Matrix show of color photographs, blueprints and drawings depicting the ''Great Wall of Los Angeles,'' a Social Realist mural-in-progress masterminded by Judith Baca (through Jan. 17).

title: The Suggestion Box; DOWN WITH LAWYERS AND M.B.A.'S
description: W HAT executive does not, now and then, ponder giving the boss a piece of his mind? And when the corporate ship starts to list, what executive doesn't conjure up ways of getting it moving again? The author, writing under a pseudonym, was a senior executive and division manager at a major, family-controlled industrial corporation, which he calls Smasco. He wrote some memos, most of which were addressed to Smasco's chairman, ''R.V. Sloane,'' and president, ''R.A. Gardner.'' The executive never actually sent the memos, but he pulled them together in a new book, ''The Confidential Memos of I.M. Vested.'' The following are excerpts.

title: A DUTCH TREAT
description: MARYLIN BENDER, a New York writer, is the author of a book on Pan American World Airways to be published next spring. By MARYLIN BENDER My love affair with the Netherlands dates back to a honeymoon trip that began in the sedately romantic city of The Hague. Like all such enduring liaisons - this one has lasted for more than two decades - it has grown beyond starry-eyed sentiment to exciting discoveries and nuances of feeling. My latest discovery was the Netherlands' oldest and southernmost city, Maastricht.

title: Ann Driscoll Wed To an Accountant, E.W. Marshall Jr.
description: Ann Elizabeth Driscoll and Edward John Marshall Jr. were married yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in New Monmouth, N.J. Msgr. Herman L. Heide, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Art Sampler; by David Shirey
description: THE conflict in art between expressive freedom and esthetic order seems to be as old as the struggles between Adam and Eve. At different times in the history of art, painters and sculptors have either leaned more toward one or the other or tried to strike a balance between the two. Often our judgment of an art work is shaped by how well we think an artist has handled this conflict.

title: JOE DELANY, ROOKIE RUNNER, STEPS IN AND STARS FOR THE CHIEFS
description: The two longest runs from scrimmage in the National Football League this season have been made by rookies, Joe Delaney of the Kansas City Chiefs and George Rogers of the New Orleans Saints. Those runs for touchdowns, 82 yards for Delaney against Denver and 79 for Rogers against Cleveland, were spectacular plays that brought added attention to two of the 46 first-year players making marks as regulars.

title: Long Island Guide; PORTER REPRISE
description: When it comes to the music of Cole Porter, familiarity does not breed contempt. If anything, it's cause for rejoicing. And today devotees of the sophisticated composer-lyricist can wallow in ''Cole Porter Revisited'' at the Bryant Library in Roslyn at 2:30 P.M. With Ben Bagley, producer (a popularizer of the ''composer-revisited'' school of nostalgia); Helen Halpin, vocalist, and Arthur Siegel, songwriter (he wrote Eartha Kitt's ''Monotonous''), holding forth, the free production will explore Porter's private life and his music. The library is on Paper Mill Road. SHAW REVISITED

title: Kathleen Bovers And Robert Bitter Will Be Married
description: Mrs. Donald P. Bovers of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Kathleen McCabe Bovers, to Robert Franco Bitter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwain Ward Bitter of Locust Valley, L.I. A February wedding is planned.

title: UNFINISHED CASINO REPRIEVED
description: ATLANTIC CITY THE Dunes Hotel-Casino here nearly was sold at a sheriff's sale last month to pay off $1.78 million in debts for materials and labor. The sale was scheduled to take place Oct. 15, but attorneys for the Dunes were able to obtain a delay until Nov. 12 and then, last week, indefinitely.

title: Food; KITCHEN FANTASIES TAKE WING WITH THE FLAVORFUL PHEASANT
description: Pheasant is a small and exquisitely flavored bird. It is available fresh in many markets these days and makes a delicious feast for two, prepared without much bother. Elizabeth David has called it the bird that inspires fantasies in the kitchen. Indeed, pheasant responds to all sorts of flavorings, especially those that hint of autumn. Cranberries, juniper berries and chestnuts go wonderfully, as does that sublime fall luxury that comes in fresh from Italy - white truffles. Roast pheasant can be served with vegetables such as brussel sprouts, celeriac, braised celery or roast potatoes flavored with rosemary.

title: Intellectuals And Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: LEARNING TO LIVE NEXT DOOR TO A JAIL
description: HACKENSACK DESPITE the commotion outside, it was business as usual for Pete and Maria Lepera. They were at their luncheonette, which they have operated since 1959, before dawn to prepare their hot plate special.

title: Reader Comment; FOR THE BELL BILL
description: P AUL MacAVOY'S opposition to the Telecommunications Competition and Deregulation Act of 1981 (''Why Reagan Should Veto the Bell Bill,'' Oct. 25) should be entitled ''Stop the World, I Want to Get Off.''

title: MIDWOOD, BAYSIDE GAIN P.S.A.L. SEMIFINALS
description: Bayside and Midwood took steps toward toward their third straight Public Schools Athletic League championships yesterday. The Commodores, winners of the Bronx-Queens A division, beat Lafayette, the wildcard team from Brooklyn, 20-0, and Midwood, the Brooklyn B champion, won from Adlai Stevenson, the Bronx-Manhattan B runner-up, 23-6.

title: Maryanne Kentz Married to Cory Sea
description: Maryanne Kentz, daughter of New Jersey Superior Court Judge Frederick C. Kentz Jr. and Mrs. Kentz of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday in Ann Arbor, Mich., to Cory Mullen Sea, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert F. Mullen of Ann Arbor. The Rev. Vincent D. Mathews, a Roman Catholic priest and chairman of the sociology department of Trinity College in Washington, performed the ceremony at the Quaker Meeting House.

title: Article 084836 -- No Title
description: IT was like a story in a detective magazine: A lone armed bandit made off with more than $60,000 in payroll funds from an armored car in 1957. Two weeks later, the suspected robber, Francis Kolakowski, commited suicide after allegedly killing an F.B.I. agent, Richard P. Horan, in a police stakeout at the home of the suspect's sister in Suffield. And now, 24 years later, what is believed to be the payroll money has been found buried in a wooded area near a major highway.

title: A HARDSHIP ON DEPOSIT
description: IT was last winter, and I was at a party. After finishing a bottle of beer, I turned to the hostess and asked, ''Where do I put this?'' ''Just throw it out,'' was the offhand reply.

title: PAINTED LIFE
description: CHARLOTTE: LIFE OR THEATER? An Autobiographical Play. By Charlotte Salomon. Introduction by Judith Herzberg. Translated by Leila Vennewitz. Illustrated. 784 pp. New York: A Studio Book/The Viking Press. $75.

title: ARTIS ASKS PAROLE IN TRIPLE MURDER
description: John Artis, convicted twice with Rubin (Hurricane) Carter of a triple murder in Paterson, N.J., and sentenced to a maximum term of life imprisonment, has applied for parole.

title: NASSAU DEMOCRATS: WHICH WAY IS UP?
description: IN a post-mortem on the election returns, leading Nassau Democrats agree that the Democratic Party in Nassau County is in bad shape. A virtual Republican sweep of the county and town elections last Tuesday has left the party with fewer than a dozen elected public officials outside of the judiciary and no Democrat likely to move beyond the Nassau level of government in the near future.

title: WOMEN'S SOCCER SCORES FAST
description: LIKE mother, like daughter. What began as an annual game between girl soccer players and their mothers in 1976 in North Babylon has grown into two adult women's leagues on the Island with more than 50 teams and over a thousand participants.

title: Liars and Cheats
description: How much do Americans cheat in daily life? A lot, to judge by a report in Psychology Today on a survey that attracted 24,100 replies, the largest response the magazine has ever received.

title: KYOTO
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DRAMATIC LIVE OF TWO PLAYWRIGHTS
description: CLIFFORD ODETS American Playwright. The Years From 1906 to 1940. By Margaret Brenman-Gibson. Illustrated. 748 pp. New York: Atheneum. $30.THE playwright Clifford Odets was born in Philadelphia in 1906 and reborn, as someone scribbled on a wall, in 1932. He had lived through the 20's - that ''high plateau of permanent prosperity'' - but the young Odets was no part of that happy high decade. He felt he belonged to nothing, to nobody; he had succeeded at nothing, completed nothing. Without enthusiasm he tried suicide. He was a very obscure actor in summer stock, and on the larger stage of the world wholly invisible. ''To be sure,'' Margaret Brenman-Gibson, a psychoanalyst and his perfect biographer, writes, ''there was some substance in ... his secret writing, but it would take the cataclysm of the Great Depression, with its vast wake of stranded people, to provide his spiritual salvation. He could become a voice for a disinherited generation only when it appeared. His own conflicts could become creative when history opened the door.''

title: A CHILDBIRTH EXPERIENCE IS SET TO MUSIC
description: AMUSICAL comedy about childbirth may sound like an unlikely notion, but to Joan Swirsky, who has written such a work, it couldn't be more natural.

title: NEW YORK'S EXPERIMENTAL MUSIC SOUNDS FAMILIAR NOTES
description: Just a few years ago, ''new music'' in New York meant fiercely austere, densely chromatic efforts by such composers as Milton Babbitt, Charles Wuorinen and Elliott Carter. But now the pendulum seems to be swinging toward a more open, accessible yet experimental spirit.

title: Mailbox; Steinbrenner's Influence Hurt
description: To the Sports Editor: The New York Yankees lost the 1981 World Series. Or did they? Certainly they did not take the field with the intention of losing.

title: ISLANDERS SUFFER 2D LOSS, 6-2
description: For the first 38 seconds, when they scored a goal, the Islanders were the best team on the Nassau Coliseum ice. But then the Buffalo Sabres scored six times, five on the power play, and skated off with a 6-2 triumph.

title: Connecticut Housing; NURSING-HOME SHORTAGE PERSISTS
description: THE scene, though grim, is not unfamiliar. An elderly relative becomes seriously ill, and the family is faced with a discomforting prospect of permanent nursing-home care.

title: THE YOUNG JEWELERS OF MAMARONECK
description: THE children's eyes sparkle and their jaws drop in amazement. They have just been told that they will leave their first jewelry-making class with a completed project - a pendant or a key chain, constructed from sterling. Most of them have never seen a jeweler's bench, let alone held a saw in their inexperienced hands. They expect that some type of alchemy is about to occur here in the basement of Felice Isreeli's house in Mamaroneck.

title: POTKUL PACES ROUT OF MONROE
description: Jamie Potkul, a senior halfback who was the first this season in New Jersey to break the 100-point mark, increased his total to 122 today with three touchdown runs and helped unbeaten Green Brook gain a 38-0 rout of Monroe in Green Brook. Potkul scored in the first, second and fourth quarters on runs of 8, 5 and 12 yards.

title: WHAT CAN HARTFORD'S NEW MAYOR REALLY DO?
description: HARTFORD'S new Mayor will take office next month with more potential power than any mayor since the city's Charter was last changed in 1967. The sources of that potential, however, will be the Mayor's ability to use the momentum of his election, not the legal or structural role of a mayor in our government.

title: Future Events The Festive Season Begins
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated: Studio Party Nov. 8 - A gala evening to aid the New York Theater Studio will provide theater buffs with the opportunity to sip wines, nibble on crudites and visit with Joanne Woodward and Jane Curtin from 6:45 to 8 P.M., when the premiere of two one-act plays will be given at the Actors and Directors Theater, 410 West 42d Street. Tickets are $16 from 496-7833. Music, Music, Music Nov. 8 - Count Basie and His Band, David Katz and the Queens Symphony Orchestra will share a musical evening, champagne reception and buffet supper to aid the symphony. Mercer Ellington will present Count Basie with an Upbeat award at the festivities, which begin at 7:30 P.M. in the Colden Center for the Performing Arts at Queens College. Tickets are $50 from 275-5000.

title: The World in Summary; Soviet Sub Gets A Cold Send-Off
description: The diplomatic incident Swedes referred to as ''whiskey on the rocks'' ended last week when a Soviet submarine that had gone aground in restricted Swedish waters was escorted back to sea. But Soviet officials may be scraping egg from their faces for some time to come.

title: No Headline
description: In response to Lee Daniels's excellent article, the immediate problem is that the Republican Party is not receptive, or has not been receptive to black participation in the past. The Republican national chairman, Richard Richards, said recently, in Atlanta, that the Republican Party was ''discounting black leaders ... .'' During the Congressional Black Caucus (Sept. 25-26), the Nation's Capital Republican Club sponsored a national press conference in general support of Republican policies and offered Mr. Richards a chance to resolve this impression of uninterest in the black voter. Mr. Richards neither responded nor showed up.

title: Motorcycle Light Bill Signed
description: Gov. Lee S. Dreyfus signed into law this week a bill permitting flickering headlights on motorcycles. The law will allow motorcycles, motor bikes and mopeds to be equipped with devices that change the headlight from high to low beam at a rate of more than 200 changes a minute. The modulating lights are designed to make the vehicles more visible.

title: THE FINE ITALIAN HANDS OF FLORENCE
description: PAUL HOFMANN, a former Times corrrespondent, lives in Rome. By PAUL HOFMANN

title: AUSTRALIA AID TO ABORIGINES MISSING MARK
description: No one knows just how many people live in the two dozen houses that make up Mount Nancy, a camp established for aborigines on a slight rise in the red desert of central Australia.

title: MEXICO'S REFUGEES FEAR CLAMPDOWN
description: The arrest of five Argentine leftist exiles on kidnapping charges here last week has awakened fears of a general clampdown against the thousands of Latin American political refugees who have sought asylum in Mexico in recent years.

title: TEACHING NONVIOLENCE BEHIND BARS
description: WE WERE seated in a circle with 11 inmates and the warden in an undersized gymnasium in the Hudson County Jail and Penitentiary in Jersey City, struggling to explain an experience that at times seemed unexplainable.

title: Opera in Review; THE SITE OUTSHINES SOUND IN 'LUCIA'
description: BROOKVILLE EVER more expansive, the Manhasset Bay Opera opened its seventh season last Sunday with Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' at C.W. Post's Concert Theater. The opera's next two performances will take place in high schools on the South Shore and the East End - the company's first ventures beyond the North Shore.

title: BREWER-LED SPURS BEAT KNICKS, 103-96
description: Ron Brewer, operating behind bruising picks set by the San Antonio front line, scored a career-high 40 points tonight as the Spurs beat the Knicks, 103-96, at the HemisFair.

title: REAGAN AIDES MAP PROPOSALS TO CUT HEALTH CARE COSTS
description: Reagan Administration officials want to make fundamental changes in the Medicaid and Medicare programs as part of their effort to control Federal spending on domestic social programs that pay guaranteed benefits to millions of Americans.

title: TACOMA POLLUTION ON '10 WORST' LIST
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency's recent listing of Tacoma's Commencement Bay as one of the 10 worst toxic waste sites in the country was greeted with surprise here. People were aware, however, that scientists had discovered liver cancer and other diseases in bottom fish in the bay, and the public health authorities had cautioned against eating the fish.

title: KYOTO
description: To the Editor:

title: CZECHOSLOVAKIA, THE EAST'S NEW ECONOMIC CASUALTY
description: Czechoslovakia, whose Government was boasting only 10 months ago of rising national prosperity, has joined Poland and Rumania among Eastern Europe's economic casualties, according to a speech by Prime Minister Lubomir Strougal.

title: Antiques; A GOLDMINE OF AMERICAN FOLK ART
description: The extraordinary folk-art collection of Jean and Howard Lipman will be auctioned in two sessions Saturday at Sotheby Park Bernet's York Avenue galleries (at 72d Street). The Lipmans, pioneer collectors in this field, acquired about 450 selections over 40 years and earlier this year sold the assemblage to the Museum of American Folk Art for $1 million. They did this so that the museum would be able to select the examples it wished for its permanent collection and sell the rest, possibly at a profit. Thirty-two pieces were retained by the museum and the rest will be auctioned.

title: AMID STORMY DEBATES, A LOW-KEY STYLE
description: WASHINGTON U NLIKE previous chairmen of the Council of Economic Advisers, Murray L. Weidenbaum seems to be content to play a low-key, even self-effacing role within the Administration. Mr. Weidenbaum advises a President who receives a steady stream of economic advice from such prominent outsiders as the ''four wise men'' who went to the Oval Office last week -former Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz, two former C.E.A. chiefs, Alan Greenspan and Paul McCracken, and Walter B. Wriston, the New York banker.

title: WRITING THE GOOD LIFE
description: BIOGRAPHERS are on a better-than-first-name basis with their subjects. They tolerate their idiosyncrasies, admire their style, second-guess their reactions, indulge their faults. If this resembles a great and good friendship evolved over a long term, it should; for writing a carefully researched biography routinely takes up a large portion of an author's life. The ties binding biographer and subject have been likened to a near-parasitic affair, in which the biographer is nurtured through the life of his subject; but ''symbiotic'' might be a truer characterization. A successful biographer somehow transcends his own being in order to comprehend the life of his subject and illuminate it as if from within. In fact, some biographers become so obsessed with their subjects that their lives are overrun by the persons they are examining. That the relationship is invariably close cannot be ignored; the feeling of ''living with'' their subjects appears to be the standard description offered when biographers discuss their work.

title: Dining Out; COMBINING JAPAN'S OLD AND NEW
description: SUMA of Tokyo, recently installed in Great Neck, offers a menu that should please novices as well as those who are familiar with Japanese food. It combines the showy hibachi grill dinners with traditional Japanese dishes. And unlike some of the hibachi-style restaurants that have added more authentic specialties, diners are not segregated according to their level of sophistication with the traditional food available in only one section. At Suma of Tokyo, it is possible to order from both sides of the menu at the same table.

title: MYSTIC TO BE THE HOST TO A CELEBRITY ANIMAL
description: MYSTIC CHAMPAGNE will be served and a group of local and state officials are expected to be on hand tomorrow to welcome a 20-year-old celebrity seal who plans to winter in this seaport town.

title: MET OPERA: 'ZAUBERFL"OTE'
description: The Metropolitan has been accused - with some justification - of staging operas without singers, or at least with voices that the audience barely notices. Thursday's ''Die Zauberflote,'' on the other hand, was for the most part cleverly cast and ardently sung, and yet at the end it never really amounted to the sum of its admirable parts.

title: PITT AND CLEMSON STILL UNBEATEN KNIGHTS BOW
description: For the first time this autumn, the football players from the University of Pittsburgh could raise their index fingers triumphantly at the end of a Saturday afternoon. By the time the fingers went up near the end of a 47-3 victory over Rutgers today, Pitt's frustrating first half was already a distant, if unpleasant, memory.

title: PITT AND CLEMSON STILL UNBEATEN TAR HEELS FALL
description: Clemson's defense, which shut down Herschel Walker earlier in the season, protected the Tigers' unbeaten record again today in a 10-8 victory over North Carolina.

title: Around the Nation; Cancer Society to Seek New Cigarette Warning
description: By United Press International The American Cancer Society board voted yesterday to join the Federal Trade Commission in a search for bigger, better and more numerous health hazard warnings on cigarette packages.

title: NANCY FREEDMAN TO WED IN WINTER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Freedman of Riverside, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Robin Freedman, to Steven M. Peters, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest S. Peters of Longboat Key, Fla., formerly of New York.

title: Sound; RADICAL DESIGNS RESHAPE TONEARMS
description: Edna St. Vincent Millay, who often celebrated the sensual, also had an ear for austerity: ''Euclid alone has looked on beauty bare,'' she declared in one of her poems.

title: 3 British Riders Score Sweep
description: The British team, led by John Greenwood on Ballyouskill Boy, scored a 1-2-3 sweep of the National Horse Show Challenge Trophy last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: METS OWNER A BIG-LEAGUE BUILDER
description: As a boy growing up in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, Fred Wilpon played high school baseball with Sandy Koufax, worshipped Gil Hodges and Carl Erskine of the old Dodgers and wondered why New York City's skyscrapers did not sway in the wind.

title: Julie Balaban Affianced
description: Dr. and Mrs. Alvin B. Balaban of Great Neck, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julie Ellen Balaban, to Alan Craig Garber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Garber of Monsey, N.Y. A May wedding is planned. Miss Balaban, a graduate of Harvard University, is a third-year student at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, where Mr. Garber, a graduate of Amherst College, is in hisfourth year.

title: TAOS: A SKIER'S MARTINI
description: DONAL HENAHAN is the chief music critic of The Times. By DONAL HENAHAN

title: MEXICAN SACRIFICE
description: THE WHITE RAINBOW By Alan Harrington. 379 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $14.95.

title: FOR SPAIN'S COMMUNISTS, DIVISIONS ARE DEEP
description: The Communist Party of Spain, which led the resistance to the dictatorship of Francisco Franco and then emerged as the boldest exponent of an independent form of West European Communism, is in disarray.

title: JURORS' CONDUCT AT MURDER TRIAL TO BE STUDIED
description: A Brooklyn judge has ordered a hearing to determine if assertions of misconduct against sequestered jurors and a court officer should cause dismissal of a conviction in a case involving three ganglandstyle slayings and a shootout with a police officer.

title: THE VOICE OF THE NEW YORKER
description: POEMS AND SKETCHES OF E.B.WHITE 217 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $13.50.

title: Fire Dept. Will Inspect All High-Rise Buildings
description: The Fire Department will begin inspecting all 1,070 high-rise buildings in New York City tomorrow for compliance with fire and safety regulations.

title: Cynthia Jean Flood Is Bride
description: Cynthia Jean Flood, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene T. Flood Jr. of Plainfield, N.J., was married there yesterday to James Frederick Almand, son of Mr. and Mrs. Iverson H. Almand of Arlington, Va. The ceremony was performed in St. Bernard's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. John W. Flesey and the Rev. Jack S. Austin of the First Christian Church in Falls Church, Va.

title: BUSINESS, WOMEN MEETING ON JOBS
description: THE large numbers of women in the county who must work and the many employers who are looking for skilled personnel will be brought together through a new program, ''Operation Talent Bank,'' a cooperative venture of the county's Office for Women and the Women's Bureau of the United States Department of Labor. The project has received a starting grant from the Employment and Training Administration of the Labor Department and will focus especially on helping women who have been enrolled in public service employment programs.

title: KETTERING FOUNDATION TRUSTEE
description: Robert G. Chollar, chairman of the board of trustees of the Charles F. Kettering Foundation and a former vice president and director of the National Cash Register Company, died of cancer yesterday at the Kettering Medical Center in Dayton, Ohio. He was 67 years old.

title: WHEN PROFESSIONALS LOSE THEIR JOBS
description: JOEL SOLOW describes his eight months out of work earlier this year simply: ''The whole period was absolute misery. It's very difficult to get across to somebody who's not in that position the humiliation involved.''

title: Sports of The Times; MISTAKEN SNIPES AT THE REFEREE
description: ONE punch. One punch had Larry Holmes spinning like the Las Vegas roulette wheels that must have stopped in shock Friday night, when the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion's anticipated $50 million showdown there in March with Gerry Cooney was momentarily in jeopardy. One punch, a roundhouse right that Renaldo Snipes threw from somewhere in Yonkers, almost created the biggest upset in boxing history. Almost. But before and after that one punch in the seventh round, Larry Holmes was in command. And when Referee Rudy Ortega stopped the fight in the 11th, he acted wisely and mercifully.

title: THE CASE FOR NUCLEAR ENERGY
description: Roger Starr, a member of The Times's Editorial Board, writes extensively on urban and industrial problems. By Roger Starr I write of nuclear power as a self-confessed coward in the face of all massive concentrations of energy. Lightning frightens me. A surge in the wind's strength makes me uneasy in an airplane. And I cannot stand at the base of a 200-foot dam without thinking of the force of gravity stored up behind it, waiting to sweep everything before it.

title: SAFE IN THE WARM EMBRACE OF GRANDMOTHER AND A TREE
description: ''I HAVE a little shadow that goes in and out with me ...'' There is a large, thick book, a massive green tree, its dark needles folding into mesh and enveloping its cover. I am littler than this foreboding giant, spread before me on pages too cumbersome to hold. But I am not afraid.

title: DIARY WRITING TURNS A NEW LEAF
description: Patrick Huyghe, a journal keeper himself, worked in the field of social psychology before he turned to writing. By Patrick Huyghe Things are getting very secretive here now. Mr. Kugler was afraid that they might come here to search for hidden bicycles and for that reason he wanted to have the door leading to our place camouflaged. They have done that now in such a way that it looks like a wall cabinet with books. - ANNE FRANK, from the unpublished portion of her diary, Aug. 21, 1942.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: A NATION OF DOCTORS IN DEBT?
description: Ron Winslow teaches journalism at the University of New Hampshire. By Ron Winslow

title: Sharon L. Kratz, Realtor, Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Kratz Jr. of West Rockhill, Bucks County, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sharon Leigh Kratz, to John Kendall Thornburgh of Bryn Mawr, Pa. He is a son of Gov. Richard L. Thornburgh of Pennsylvania and Mrs. Thornburgh of Harrisburg.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Mary Stanton, Pianist, Offers Liszt, Schubert
description: A lot of unlovely piano sound emanates from Carnegie Recital Hall, and frequenters of this much-used facility often blame its resident instrument. Last Saturday evening Mary Stanton proved us wrong.

title: IT'S TEXAS VS. THE FIRE ANTS, 'AND THE ANTS ARE WINNING'
description: Fire ants, trying to escape from soil made sodden by recent torrential rains in Texas, are building their foothigh nests above ground. And that, officials say, makes it easy for people to stumble into them, with painful and possibly lethal results.

title: Major News in Summary; Fortunately, Words Are Not Rockets
description: Talk of nuclear options reverberated across an already jittery Europe last week, sketching contingencies that had been regarded as ''unthinkable'' in a bygone era and publicly unmentionable in this one.

title: JERSEY VOTE CONTROVERSY MOVES FURTHER IN COURTS
description: As Republicans and Democrats continued to trade charges of voter intimidation, the battle over who would be New Jersey's next Governor moved further into the courts yesterday.

title: B-1 DECISION HINGES ON QUESTIONS OF TIMING
description: A decision by Congress on President Reagan's proposal to spend $20 billion to $30 billion to build a fleet of 100 B-1 long-range bombers appears to turn on a series of dates in the 1980's and 1990's.

title: HILLARY LINSKY ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Ronald Linsky of East Williston, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Hillary Jane Linsky, to Alan Harvie Hudesman, son of Mr. and Mrs Bernard Hudesman of Woodmere, L.I. A spring wedding is planned. Miss Linsky is a fashion designer and her fiance is executive vice president of the Empire Shirt Trimming Company and the Aluma-Form Corporation. Dr. Linsky is assistant clinical professor of surgery at the Cornell University Medical College.

title: R.C. Miller Weds Katharine Teale
description: Katharine Brown Teale and Richard Cross Miller were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church. The Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins and the Rev. Charles Underwood Quinn of the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour performed the ceremony.

title: REAVEY LEADS 27-7 VICTORY
description: Pete Reavey, a senior quarterback, threw two touchdown passes and ran for a score in the second half to lead undefeated Seton Hall Prep to a 27-7 victory over Belleville before 6,000 fans yesterday in Belleville.

title: Food; KITCHEN FANTASIES TAKE WING WITH THE FLAVORFUL PHEASANT
description: Pheasant is a small and exquisitely flavored bird. It is available fresh in many markets these days and makes a delicious feast for two, prepared without much bother. Elizabeth David has called it the bird that inspires fantasies in the kitchen. Indeed, pheasant responds to all sorts of flavorings, especially those that hint of autumn. Cranberries, juniper berries and chestnuts go wonderfully, as does that sublime fall luxury that comes in fresh from Italy - white truffles. Roast pheasant can be served with vegetables such as brussels sprouts, celeriac, braised celery or roast potatoes flavored with rosemary.

title: MAKAVEJEV'S 'MONTENEGRO,' SET IN SWEDEN
description: Dusan Makavejev, the Yugoslav director who has been working outside Yugoslavia since his ''W.R.: Mysteries of the Organism'' (1971), has a maddening talent. As you watch his films, he can convince you that he's a man of intelligence, wit, irony and skepticism, a person with unexpected insights into all manner of things, though the film that carries this information may be almost unbearably foolish, like his latest, ''Montenegro.''

title: HORSEBACK RIDING AID TO HANDICAPPED
description: ON Monday afternoons at the Boulder Brook Stables in Scarsdale, a group of disabled 5- to 21-year-old people are doing something they and their parents probably never dreamed would be possible. They are learning to ride horseback in a program called Unicorn. The program, the first of its kind in southern Westchester, is part of a growing nationwide therapeutic-riding movement aimed at providing the disabled with an experience that combines education, recreation and therapy.

title: Antiques; SMALL-SIZE FURNITURE IN SOUTHPORT SHOW
description: SOUTHPORT VERY often in the opinion of collectors of antiques less really does equal more. So it would seem, at any rate, if today's increasing interest in buying and selling small versions of traditional fullsize pieces of furniture is any indicator. These are not true miniatures, nor are they toys, but furniture and accessories that were made specifically for use by boys and girls in the 18th and early 19th centuries. One reason such furniture is popular with adults now is that many new homes also are scaled down from the size of houses built generations ago and some small antiques more easily fit into contemporary decorating schemes.

title: Topics; BLINDLY TO AND FRO; Death at an Early Age
description: By now it's a familiar refrain: if juvenile crime is on the rise, don't fool around with goody-goody programs for youthful offenders; prosecute them as adults.

title: No Headline
description: Lucy Dawidowicz's article can only provide grist for the mill of the Soviet anti-Semitism she so rightly condemns.

title: O'Connor Seeks No. 4
description: Dan O'Connor of Westminster, Calif., will try tomorrow for his fourth title in four years in The Athletics Congress 40-kilometer national race-walking championship. Susan Liers-Westerfield of Smithtown, L.I., is the women's favorite.

title: ''Nickleby'' Notes
description: To the Editor:$

title: U.S. CANCELS AFRICA TOUR BY CRITIC OF ITS POLICY
description: The United States International Communication Agency has canceled an American scholar's Government-sponsored lecture tour in Africa because he has written an article critical of Administration policy.

title: BACKSTAGE AND OFFSTAGE WITH THREE YOUNG BALLET DANCERS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Barbara Harris is a freelance writer with a special interest in dance. By BARBARA HARRIS

title: Dining Out; PEKING DISHES THAT DON'T SATISFY
description: NEW HAVEN BLESSINGS, a Chinese restaurant in New Haven, has for many years commanded a loyal following. But despite its reputation, we have found, on visits over the years, that it is almost impossible to get a uniformly satisfying meal here.

title: Environews; by Leo H. Carney
description: THE New Jersey Institute of Technology is getting more and more heavily involved in environmental matters. Officials of the Newark school confirmed last week that they had received $700,000 in private grants toward the new Institute for Hazardous and Toxic Wastes and that the institute would open its doors to graduate students next fall.

title: INGREDIENTS ARE SHIFTING IN MELTING POT
description: WHEN I was growing up in an apartment on Chicago's North Side nobody moved. Month after month, the rent was collected. Cash was the usual commodity, although the more affluent used checking accounts while the less trusting bought money orders. No one earned enough to need tax shelters and building equity was never mentioned. Although acquiring a nest egg was devoutly wished for, that was more a dream than a reality. Along with what was politely called ''modest circumstances'' was stability - no one could afford the luxury of upward mobility.

title: Home Clinic; NEW PRODUCTS MAKE IT EASIER TO CUT HEAT LOSS AT WINDOWS
description: IN many homes and apartments, loose-fitting windows are one of the greatest sources of cold-air infiltration and heat waste during the winter. The cheapest and most effective method for minimizing this is to make certain each window is tightly sealed with weatherstripping.

title: Katharine Sednaoui Wed to Physician
description: Katharine Hale Sednaoui, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael C. Sednaoui of New Haven, Vt., was married yesterday in Shelburne, Vt., to Dr. Peter Maclean Hoagland, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald W. Hoagland of Denver.

title: LAISSEZ-FAIRE
description: To the Business Editor: Senator Bradley is quite right that new legislation is needed to replace the Emergency Petroleum Allocation Act, which expired on Sept. 30. Without new legislation, it is unclear how the Administration would be able to deal effectively with supply interruptions such as those resulting from turmoil in the Persian Gulf.

title: New Jersey Housing; A 'NO FRILLS' BUILDING INSPECTOR
description: ''IT ISN'T all glamour,'' said Catherine Aratow-Harding as she trudged up a muddy slope to inspect the foundation of a house. Mrs. Harding, as she is known, is the Construction Official of Chester Township, a job she has held for the last four years. She is one of the few women building inspectors in the state.

title: WHEN OWNERS BECOME RENTERS
description: IN my dream life, I am rolling in dough, or as they say in financial circles, I am ''very liquid.'' I'm a snob and very materialistic. I want to move to a larger home, demonstrating in concrete terms my upward mobility - or my rapid spiral into greater debt, depending upon how one looks at such things. For me, in my dream life, there's no getting caught in the mortgage crunch when you're looking for a $500,000 house. Easy Street, that's my address.

title: Dartmouth Defeats Columbia
description: Dartmouth, with a vigorous and hard-working offense, defeated Columbia, 21-7, yesterday in a wind-blown and chilled game at Baker Field.

title: BAR CRITICIZES PLANS TO ROTATE ACTING JUSTICES
description: A plan to screen and rotate the 97 Criminal and Civil Court judges now serving as acting Supreme Court justices in New York City has drawn criticism from the bar, the city's District Attorneys and the Legal Aid Society.

title: AT 75, HIS TENNIS IS ON THE UPSWING
description: PORT WASHINGTON THEY call him the Grand Old Man of Long Island tennis, but he says he doesn't feel old and he wouldn't think of putting on airs. At the age of 75, Sam Shore says ''I'm growing younger,'' and to prove it he has gone out and won three national doubles titles this year, just missing a grand slam. When the new rankings come out soon, he expects to be No. 1 in doubles with his partner, Buddy Goeltz of Maryland, and in the top 10 in singles.

title: Auto and Truck Travel Up
description: The Highway Users Federation said this week that travel by automobiles and trucks over the first eight months of this year increased 2.5 percent over the same period in 1980.

title: Realty News; TIP OF ORIENT POINT IS SOLD
description: Six Manhattan investors have bought the tip of Orient Point on Long Island's North Fork and are considering demolishing the once-elegant Orient Point Inn, where Walt Whitman wrote poetry and Daniel Webster and President Grover Cleveland vacationed, to make way for condominiums.

title: No Headline
description: Colgate Sets Back Bucknell by 24-6

title: The Region in Summary; Suburban Cheer For Republicans
description: Westchester County Executive Alfred B. DelBello celebrated his reelection against a Republican ''minitide'' last week, but many of his fellow suburban Democrats found the currents a good deal stronger. Republicans retained most of what they had in Westchester, Suffolk and Nassau Counties and took much of what they had not.

title: Other Business; DETROIT: 26 WAYS TO NAME A CAR
description: What will they do when they run out of letters? General Motors had the ''X'' cars and the ''J'' cars. Chrysler claimed the ''K.'' Early next year, G.M. plans to start selling its new ''A'' cars and sporty ''F'' models.

title: Politics; A TRADE-OFF SETTLES NEW DISTRICTS
description: THE five-month struggle to redraw Connecticut's Congressional districts provided some graphic illustrations of how the two major parties try to gain the edge - or blunt the other party's edge - by political mapmaking.

title: RIPARIAN RIGHTS CHANGE MAY AID ATLANTIC CITY
description: An amendment to the New Jersey Constitution approved by the state electorate Tuesday could produce a new spurt in casino hotel and housing construction here.

title: New Caledonia Riots Linked To Independence Movement
description: Scores of youths rioted today here in the capital of this French island in the southwest Pacific, breaking windows and looting shops in the town center.

title: No Headline
description: I was membership chairman of New York CORE during the late 1950's and early 1960's. I remember how much trouble we had trying to ''integrate'' our picket lines because most of our members were white.

title: No Headline
description: Maine Overcomes Princeton by 55-44

title: Pamela Pearce Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan Thompson Pearce of Short Hills, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Durkin Pearce, to Donald Collins Carey, son of Governor Carey and the late Helen Owen Carey.

title: SENATE BILL BUOYS COAST GUARD CENTER
description: THE Coast Guard Research and Development Center in Groton would continue to operate for at least another year under a Transportation Department appropriations bill approved by last week by the United States Senate. But because a version of the bill passed by the House of Representatives Sept. 10 contained no mention of the center, the issue will go to a conference committee.

title: Beth Hirsch Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan R. Hirsch of Verona, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beth Hirsch, to Jacob Berman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Berman of Rutherford, N.J. A wedding in late May is planned. Miss Hirsch and her fiance are graduates of Johns Hopkins University. She is a second-year student at the University of Pennsylvania School of Law. Mr. Berman is a third-year student at the Rutgers University Medical School.

title: CHORAL: MUSICA SACRA
description: Musica Sacra generally devotes itself to the performance of established choral works, but at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night it offered a relatively recent piece by David Diamond in a program that began with Mozart and ended with Handel.

title: No Headline
description: Babi Yar's Legacy Lucy Dawidowicz's superb and heartbreaking article, ''Babi Yar's Legacy'' (Sept. 27), should be read by all people who are dedicated to the elimination of anti-Semitism and genocide. We owe it to future generations. RAE MORROCK Brooklyn, N.Y. ------

title: No Headline
description: GEORGIA OUTLASTS FLORIDA

title: Down Memory Lane
description: To the Editor:

title: Mailbox; Reiser Did Job For Little Pay
description: To the Sports Editor: While watching the fourth game of the World Series, I reminisced on the career of Pete Reiser, shortened by his willingness to hurtle his body against outfield fences. I was saddened to read on the following Tuesday, Oct. 27, that Pistol Pete had died the night of the fifth Series game.

title: MASTER MOVES
description: The photographs and printing are clear, the paper is of superior quality - but A PICTURE HISTORY OF CHESS (Dover. Paper, $8.95) is more than a handsome book about chess. Thanks to the generous running commentary, the book is also an accurate, lively, concise history of chess. Fred Wilson, the editor, is clearly a chess buff, and he responds to the magic names of Morphy, Pillsbury, Capablanca, Alekhine, Fischer and Karpov much as an opera lover responds when the names of Malibran, Melba, Caruso, Melchior or Flagstad are mentioned. The pulse races a little faster, the eyes sparkle, memory runs riot.

title: by Leo H. Carney
description: NEW JERSEY'S crops of lettuce, spinach, soybeans and some other vegetables will be seriously damaged in coming years if the state remains exposed to current levels of acid rain, according to Dr. Jorg Manring, a toxicologist with the National Wildlife Federation.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Liechtenstein
description: To the Editor:

title: Kay Wilson Strickler Wed to Randolph Post
description: Kay Wilson Strickler and Randolph H. Post were married yesterday at Mr. Post's country home in Pound Ridge, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Daniel Miner, rector of St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: OTTAWA GOES SLOW ON CHARTER ACTION
description: The federal Government is not rushing to carry out the accord it signed Thursday with nine of the 10 provinces on a new constitution because of its hope of obtaining the agreement of Quebec, the only holdout.

title: WHEN SPORTS MOVES INTO THE THEATER
description: The challenge of depicting sports on stage has been met with varying degrees of success over the years. More often than not, writers and directors have chosen to make the sports setting of a drama or musical implicit.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN DENVER
description: WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT is chief of the Denver bureau of The Times. By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT

title: HOUSTON CRACKS DOWN ON ILLEGAL DOGFIGHTING
description: Behind a ramshackle house in a densely wooded neighborhood, 19 people in ragged clothes lined a small pit, lit only by a bulb dangling from a wire above, and watched as two husky bulldogs with spiked collars snarled from opposite ends of the pit.

title: Provost Leaving Columbia U.  To Become Lehigh President
description: Columbia University's provost for the professional schools, Dr. Peter W. Likins, has been appointed the 11th president of Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pa.

title: MOSCOW OFFICIAL VOWS TO MATCH BUILDUP IN ARMS
description: The Soviet Union celebrated the 64th anniversary of its revolution today with the traditional display of military might in Red Square. From atop the Lenin Mausoleum, Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov said the country would never allow another to achieve military superiority.

title: MR. NICE GUY- HIS DULL ACT TRIUMPHS IN HOLLYWOOD
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Stephen Farber is a freelance writer based in Los Angeles. By STEPHEN FARBER

title: BULGARIA IS ZEALOUSLY MARKING ITS 1,300 BIRTHDAY
description: There is a rush to finish construction by the end of the year on the National Palace of Culture, an arts center that will have an auditorium that seats more than 10,000 people and contain works by more than 100 of Bulgaria's best artists.

title: DESPITE VETOES, TANZANIAN STILL HOPES FOR U.N. JOB
description: The United States has told him no eight times, but Salim A. Salim of Tanzania still hopes to persuade Washington that he is neither too radical nor too much the African nationalist to lead the United Nations.

title: PRIVATE AID OPENING DOORS FOR UNEMPLOYED
description: A group of New York City businessmen, determined to be ''pioneers'' in the area of job training, has been finding employment for those who have had little or no success in the job market.

title: Betty Cook Plans To Keep Winning
description: ''I have pneumonia,'' said Betty Cook. ''The doctor said I need a vacation, go lie down somewhere and read books. I said: 'Yes, sir. What else?' He said to take these antibiotics. O.K., I'll do that. The rest, forget it for a while. I haven't got time.''

title: Personal Finance; SHOULD A PENSION BE A TAKEOVER TOOL?
description: H OW safe are the assets in your pension fund? The decision of the Grumman Corporation pension plan trustees to use the plan's holdings of Grumman stock to foil a takeover attempt by the LTV Corporation raises fundamental questions about the fiduciary responsibilities of pension fund managers and how much control companies can exert over the funds they contribute to the plans.

title: California Court Invalidates Limits on Abortions for Poor
description: New restrictions on state payments for abortions for poor women in California are unconstitutional, the state Court of Appeal ruled yesterday.

title: WHEN TEACHERS GET TOGETHER
description: ''AS CONVENTIONS go,'' says Lillian Mortimer, a veteran of 30 years of teaching, ''you can't beat the N.J.E.A. conference in Atlantic City. It's got something for everyone.''

title: HEAD OF ARAB LEAGUE SEEKING TO ENHANCE ITS EFFECTIVENESS
description: The headquarters of the Arab League here is quietly pushing for a change in the organization's charter to enable it to become more effective politically and administratively.

title: No Headline
description: WISCONSIN AND MICHIGAN TRIUMPH TO TIE FOR LEAD IN BIG TEN

title: Ramona Lenora Grey Wed To Bentley Whitfield
description: Ramona Lenora Grey, daughter of Acting State Supreme Court Justice Maurice W. Grey and Mrs. Grey of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married at her parents' home yesterday to Bentley Whitfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Whitfield of New York. The Rev. Dr. John H. Johnson of St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Manhattan performed the ceremony.

title: RAY, ON JETS DEFENSE, MAKES HIS POINTS
description: In only his second season as a New York Jet, Darrol Ray has become the most dangerous receiver in pro football: every time he snares a pass he averages more than 30 yards running with it.

title: Cynthia Irvin to Wed Dec. 5
description: Mr. and Mrs. Tinsley H. Irvin of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Gaye Irvin, to Ron William Aivalotis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry William Aivalotis of Wheeling, W. Va. The wedding will take place on Dec. 5 at the Peachtree Road Lutheran Church in Atlanta.

title: Camera; PHOTOGRAPHING MINIATURE WORLDS ON A TABLETOP
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Robert J. Salgado is a freelance writer and photographer. Camera enthusiasts who get involved in tabletop photography can create miniature worlds of their own on almost any flat surface of moderate size. The environments created can be entirely artificial, or they can include pieces of nature, such as small plants or insects that gain pictorial impact being by pictured as larger-than-life in size. And, like model makers, tabletop photographers can also bring such unwieldy pieces of reality as trains and ships into a basement workshop or family room to be included in their miniature settings.

title: PENN STATE PULLS OUT VICTORY
description: By GORDON S. WHITE Jr.

title: No Headline
description: Someone once said when told of the Young Republicans political organization, ''There is no such thing as a young Republican.'' I say, there is no such thing as a black conservative. ROMAN ZAHARCHUK, Boyertown, Pa.

title: Keith Meyers
description: MIAMI FUNERAL FOR DROWNED HAITIANS: The coffins of 10 Haitians being blessed yesterday at Our Lady of Mercy Cemetery in Miami. The dead were 10 of the 33 refugees who drowned late Oct. 26 when their small boat capsized off the Florida coast. The others were returned to Haiti where they were buried Friday.

title: Design; TRUE TO THE 18TH CENTURY
description: clecticism in furnishing is dead,'' says Karl Lagerfeld, the Parisian couturier. And when Karl Lagerfeld speaks, le petit monde listens, no matter how whimsical or ill-founded his proclamations may sound. Over the years, too many have been proved correct.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL LAWS SHIFTING
description: NEW JERSEY appears to be undergoing a major change in the way it safeguards its environment, a change resulting from the shifting of responsibilities from the Federal to the state and local levels. The transition is expected to continue, with considerable debate, for years.

title: DEMOCRATS MAY DROP 'FAITHFUL DELEGATE' RULE
description: Members of a Democratic panel considering revisions in the party's rules appeared to be in agreement today on guaranteeing women half the seats at Democratic national conventions and throwing out the ''faithful delegate'' rule that split the convention last year.

title: Investing; USING STOCK OPTIONS TO CUT TAXES
description: O N Jan. 1, 1982, the maximum tax rate on short-term capital gains plunges to 50 percent from 70 percent. The message is obvious: If you've been lucky enough to realize a profit in common stocks or other investments, you'd be better off having that profit taxed at 1982's lower rates. But how?

title: JOANNA BROECKL AFFIANCED
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Joanna Pearl Broeckl, daughter of Thomas E. Broeckl of Chicago, and the late Joan Buckingham Broeckl, to Everett Burton Miller 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Miller Jr. of Stuart, Fla. A January wedding is planned. Miss Broeckl is a business planner with Pepsico Inc. in Purchase, N.Y. Her fiance is an assistant manager of real estate investment with the Travelers Insurance Company in White Plains.

title: NANCY JOY LESTER TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack M. Lester of Clifton, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Joy Lester, to Michael Robert Elitzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hillard X. Elitzer of East Greenbush, N.Y. An August wedding is planned. Miss Lester is an official assistant in the commercial banking group of the Bankers Trust Company in New York. Her fiance is a senior at Harvard University's joint program in law and business and expects to receive his J.D. and M.B.A. degrees in June.

title: No Headline
description: November 8, 1981 NONFICTION A BETTER CLASS OF PERSON: An Autobiography. By John Osborne. 1 THE BIROBIDZHAN AFFAIR: A Yiddish Writer in Siberia. By Israel Emiot. 16 CHARLOTTE: Life or Theatre? An Autobiographical Play. By Charlotte Salomon. 14 CLIFFORD ODETS: American Playwright. The Years From 1906 to 1940. By Margaret Brenman-Gibson. 1 GEORGE WASHINGTON CARVER: Scientist and Symbol. By Linda O. McMurry. 11 THE INNER AMERICAN: A Self-Portrait From 1957 to 1976. By Joseph Veroff, Elizabeth Douvan and Richard A. Kulka. 7 KING OF THE CONFESSORS. By Thomas Hoving. 16 THE MAKING OF MODERN ZIONISM: The Intellectual Origins of the Jewish State. By Shlomo Avineri. 14 MENTAL HEALTH IN AMERICA: Patterns of Help-Seeking From 1957 to 1976. By Joseph Veroff, Richard A. Kulka and Elizabeth Douvan. 7 NISA: The Life and Words of a !Kung Woman. By Marjorie Shostak. 9 A PICTURE HISTORY OF CHESS. Edited by Fred Wilson. 15 PORTRAIT OF AN ELECTION: The 1980 Presidential Campaign. By Elizabeth Drew. 20 SELECTED LETTERS OF JAMES THURBER. Edited by Helen Thurber and Edward Weeks. 3 WARRIORS AT SUEZ: Eisenhower Takes America Into the Middle East. By Donald Neff. 18 FICTION AND POETRY MAZES AND MONSTERS. By Rona Jaffe. 12 POEMS AND SKETCHES OF E.B. WHITE. 3 RUMOR VERIFIED: Poems 1979-1980. By Robert Penn Warren. 13 SELECTED POEMS: 1958-1980. By Gilbert Sorrentino. 13 TRIPLETS. By Joyce Rebeta-Burditt. 12 THE WHITE RAINBOW. By Alan Harrington. 12 FEATURES WRITING THE GOOD LIFE.

title: SHUTTLE'S LIFTOFF SET FOR THURSDAY AFTER INSPECTION
description: The second flight of the space shuttle Columbia was rescheduled for launching next Thursday morning after engineers determined yesterday that all the craft needed was a change of oil and filters, not the replacement of its power units for maneuvering in ascent and re-entry.

title: EAST AFRICA'S WAY WITH PRAWNS
description: It is not a subtle dish, more a palatable bombardment of garlic and chiles and the flavor of the ocean, to be attacked with exuberance after a morning on a sun-struck coral beach or snorkeling on the reef, when the salt taste lingers and there is a dazzle to everything.

title: GUARDING AGAINST LOSS
description: S o much baggage insurance is available these days that it is important to understand the options and to assess carefully your own needs. Otherwise, you may depend on coverage that does not apply in your case or buy too little or too much insurance.

title: LAWRENCE RALLIES TO SET BACK MEPHAM BY 24-14
description: Lawrence rallied from a 6-0 halftime deficit and defeated Mepham, 24-14, yesterday, to extend its winning streak to seven games, including six in Conference I-B.

title: CONSUMERS DIALING FOR HELP
description: WHAT'S on the minds of New Jersey consumers as the economy worsens? If response to the state's Tel-Consumer program is any measure, it's using small claims court, buying new or used cars, and having autos repaired.

title: MCBURNEY TOPS MINEOLA BY 30-0, FINISHES UNBEATEN
description: McBurney, a team without a field, ended its season yesterday undefeated in eight games when it trounced Mineola, 30-0. ''Playing all of our games away isn't easy for our students, the players and the staff,'' said Joe Puggelli, co-head coach of McBurney along with Rick Starace, ''but it does show the spirit and determination that pervails at our school that we can produce outstanding teams such as the one we had this year.''

title: FAMILY AFFAIRS
description: TRIPLETS By Joyce Rebeta-Burditt. 495 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $15.95. MAZES AND MONSTERS By Rona Jaffe. 329 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $13.95.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Sharon Hamilton Sings 4 Lieder by Schubert
description: With a program that offered selections from the German lied, Italian opera, English oratorio and French cantata, all on its first half, Sharon Hamilton, a Chicago-born soprano, made her New York debut Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall. She was at her best in four lieder by Schubert, where her interpretive ideas suited the music and the range of the settings suited her voice.

title: Margaret Grady Married to Francis Kidder, Writer
description: Margaret Ann Grady, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Grady of Andover, N.J., and Francis Key Kidder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome H.T. Kidder of Cockeysville, Md., were married yesterday at the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation in Baltimore. The Rev. Lawrence Mills performed the ceremony.

title: A NEW LEASE FOR OLD THEATERS
description: ''WE bombed in New Haven,'' the familiar phrase that once relegated a new show to oblivion, has passed into history with the out-of-town tryout and cheap transportation. But the Shubert Theater, where tryouts for Broadway productions created a theatrical legend, has a new lease on life after being vacant for six years.

title: New Jersey Journal; by Anthony DePalma
description: ALTHOUGH the New Jersey Supreme Court has reversed its earlier decision requiring the State Public Television Network to air the views of every candidate in the gubernatorial election, the candidate who brought the suit - Richard B. McGlynn - considers the court's decision a victory for all candidates.

title: No Headline
description: The article on Babi Yar confuses two different books. Although the title of both is ''The Black Book,'' they have nothing in common.

title: WOMEN GIVE UP CAREERS TO CRUSADE FOR EQUALITY
description: HELP WANTED: Equal Rights Amendment missionaries - Immediate openings for volunteers. No experience necessary. Training available. Work in unratified states in challenging environment. Lots of public contact. Excellent benefits. Send resume to E.R.A. Countdown Campaign, an equal opportunity campaign.

title: HOW THE 'SAINTS' CAME TOGETHER IN PARIS
description: The night he turned 25, in 1921, Virgil Thomson found himself walking the streets of Paris alone, his birthday uncelebrated. He had arrived there during the summer with the Harvard Glee Club, staying on to study with the late Nadia Boulanger. The experience of reaching so important an anniversary in solitude sent him back to his apartment, where he poured out his feelings by composing a prelude for piano.

title: RED SMITH  Sports of The Times
description: FRIDAY brought one of the most enjoyable afternoons experienced in a long time. It took only a couple of hours to read and relish ''Only the Ring Was Square,'' Teddy Brenner's memoirs of his years as a boxing matchmaker, as told to Barney Nagler (Prentice-Hall Inc., $10.95).

title: GREENWICH HALTED, 14-7
description: Greenwich High School, the state's top-ranked scholastic team, committed eight turnovers, including six interceptions, and fell to Westhill yesterday, 14-7, in a Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference game in Greenwich.

title: 24 Food Places Given Summonses on Health
description: The New York City Department of Health released the names of 24 food establishments last week that it found in violation of the city health code.

title: New Jerseyians
description: THE state's biggest city is better than many think, says Judith Brodsky, whose optimistic view of the downtown Newark of today, as well as her vision of its future, does not square with the bleak view of many others.-It is Mrs. Brodsky's job - carried on with cyclonic energy - to help make sure that current reality is appreciated and future hopes achieved.

title: A TOUCH OF THURBER
description: SELECTED LETTERS OF JAMES THURBER Edited by Helen Thurber and Edward Weeks. Illustrated. 274 pp. Boston: Atlantic-Little, Brown. $15.

title: Philadelphia Orchestra In 26-Week Radio Series
description: Recorded concerts by the Philadelphia Orchestra are being broadcast in a 26-week radio series sponsored by the INA Corporation. In New York, the series will be on WQXR on Fridays at 9:05 P.M. The first, broadcast last night, was a preseason gala performed in September with Eugene Ormandy, conductor laureate, and Rudolph Serkin, the pianist, in an all-Beethoven program.

title: Editors' Choice
description: BORGES: A READER, by Jorge Luis Borges. (E.P. Dutton. Cloth, $16.50; paper, $10.)

title: Reading and Writing; COURT OF LOVE
description: Diana Trilling's book on the Harris-Tarnower case is reminiscent of the medieval Courts of Love, in which the proper conduct of love was argued by two opposing parties before an appointed judge. The verdicts handed down by these courts were as much literary as ''legal,'' based on esthetics as much as on ethics.

title: INSURER IS WARNED TO CURB EXPENSES
description: New York State's Superintendent of Insurance has taken the unusual step of warning the directors of Group Health Inc., the oldest nonprofit medical insurance organization in the Northeast, that expenses are getting out of hand.

title: THE FAR-REACHING 'CONSCIENCE' OF HASTINGS CENTER
description: ON-HUDSON LAST year, the United States Senate asked the Hastings Center for help in revising its code of ethics; the model code provided by the center is now under Senate consideration. With the growth of cults and the trials of Patti Hearst and others in mind, the center's staff is studying the process of coercive persuasion, or brainwashing, and whether victims of severe psychological deprivation should be held morally accountable.

title: Eugenie Maechling to Be Bride Dec. 5
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Maechling Jr. of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eugenie Elisabeth Maechling, to David Buchan, son of Mrs. Alastair Buchan of Brill, Buckinghamshire, England, and the late Professor Buchan. The wedding will take place Dec. 5 in Washington.

title: ART MIRRORS LIFE IN TWO SHOWS HEADED FOR BROADWAY A DRAMA RECALLS A PLAYWRIGHT
description: His was a sad and remarkable story. While still at Harvard, Edward Sheldon wrote ''Salvation Nell,'' a play that not only became the Broadway hit of 1908 but also helped usher in a whole new era of realism on stage. His work was admired by Eugene O'Neill and Thornton Wilder, and his advice would help shape the careers of such actresses as Mrs. Patrick Campbell, Helen Hayes and Katharine Cornell. Gifted, charming and handsome, he was, at 22, ''the Wonder Boy of Broadway.'' Within a decade, however, he would become a permanent shut-in, afflicted by a rare form of arthritis that turned him into a kind of living statue, paralyzed and blind.

title: COAST LAWYER REPORTED AS LEGAL AID CHOICE
description: The White House has tentatively chosen Ronald A. Zumbrun, a conservative Republican, to be chairman of the board of the Legal Services Corporation, according to sources in the White House and the legal aid community. The agency distributes Federal funds to provide legal aid for poor people.

title: Numismatics; 'KING OF U.S. COINS' BRINGS A PRINCELY SUM
description: The 1804 silver dollar, long acclaimed as the ''King of American Coins,'' gained new glitter last month when one of the 15 known specimens went for $280,000 at a Stack's public auction sale on Oct. 23 in New York.

title: THE MOOD OF AMERICANS TODAY
description: THE INNER AMERICAN A Self-Portrait From 1957 to 1976. By Joseph Veroff, Elizabeth Douvan and Richard A. Kulka. 637 pp. New York: Basic Books. $36. MENTAL HEALTH IN AMERICA Patterns of Help-Seeking from 1957 to 1976. By Joseph Veroff, Richard A. Kulka and Elizabeth Douvan. 352 pp. New York: Basic Books. $30. By KENNETH KENISTON

title: KARPOV GETS A POSTPONEMENT IN CHESS MATCH
description: Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, the world chess champion, today postponed the 14th game of his title match with Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland, which was to have been played here this afternoon. The game was rescheduled for 5 P.M. Monday.

title: GRAND HOTELS, L.A. STYLE
