description: ALJEAN HARMETZ, the Hollywood correspondent for The Times, is the author of ''The Making of the Wizard of Oz,'' a book about the movie industry in the 1930's and 1940's. By ALJEAN HARMETZ

title: BANKS JOIN TO STEM ROBBERIES
description: CONCERN over an increase in bank robberies in the state and a decrease in solved cases has prompted Connecticut banks to jointly set up a new program to assist law-enforcement officials through monetary contributions.

title: B. W. Cart, Sarah Austell Are Married
description: Sarah Austell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rhett Austell Jr. of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Benjamin Whaley Cart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Whaley Cart of Pamplico, S.C. The Rev. Robert W. Hare performed the ceremony in the Scarborough (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church.

title: BULLS SEND NETS TO 4TH DEFEAT
description: The damage had been done. The Chicago Bulls had routed the Nets with a 31-16 burst in the second half on their way to a 118-105 victory and David Greenwood, a starting forward for Chicago, was lounging amid the victorious celebrants near his locker.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: ''THE umbrella doesn't quite cover us anymore,'' was the way David Hays, founder of the National Theater of the Deaf, described the decision to break away from the O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford to ''pursue our separate fortunes.''

title: Music View; IT'S A BEASTLY WAY TO STEAL THE SHOW
description: Something really must be done about animals. They are all right in their place, of course. Some of my best friends are animals. No one objects to coming upon animals in zoos, parks or the ferny and woodsy wild. But what is it that impels opera directors to fill their stages with creatures that crawl, prance, flap or otherwise distract my attention from what should be the point of an evening at the opera, the music and/or the drama? In several recent productions, events have taken such a zoological turn that the only reasonable addition to the cast would have been Marlin Perkins.

title: Music; UPPER AREA OF THE COUNTY IS READYING FOR SEVERAL TREATS
description: WHILE it may be true that the lower half of Westchester has the upper hand in the number and diversity of cultural events, there are many significant cultural oases in the north. Today, for instance, one can choose between two splendid ensembles: Music for a While, opening the fifth year of concerts sponsored by the Pleasantville Chamber Music Society, and Musica Reservata, singing its own season opener at the Seven Springs Center in Mount Kisco. On Saturday, the Concert Society of Putnam and Northern Westchester begins its 10th anniversary season in Shrub Oak and a week from today, the Shrub Oak-based Singer's Theater takes up its new operatic residence at the historic Music Hall in Tarrytown.

title: Major News in Summary; Triumvirate Of Concern
description: Poland's day of reckoning may yet come, when mere chaos turns into total collapse. Remarkably, it hasn't happened, thanks largely to a shared capacity for conciliation at pivotal moments by the leaders of the three institutions that count - the Communist Party, the Roman Catholic Church and the Solidarity union.

title: ARAB GROUP TRYING TO STOP ARMS FLOW TO LEBANON
description: A committee of Arab ministers announced measures today to try to stop the unauthorized flow of arms to rival Lebanese factions and Palestinian guerrillas.

title: SALVADOR ASSERTS U.S. IS MISLED
description: The head of the Democratic Revolutionary Front, a coalition of leftists opposed to the United States-backed junta in El Salvador, has accused the Reagan Administration of misleading the American public about the civil war in his country in order to gain support for increased military aid.

title: No Headline
description: Bruins' Winning Streak Ends

title: Waring & LaRosa Get AMF Voit Inc.
description: The people at Waring & LaRosa, still doing a victory dance inspired by the Perrier account, will extend their dancing now in behalf of AMF Voit Inc., a unit of the AMF Corporation, the country's largest maker of inflatable balls for sporting activity, racquetball equipment and swimming gear.

title: Jorene R. Frenkl Wed To Gerald Alan Robbie
description: Jorene Roslyn Frenkl, a lawyer specializing in trusts and estates, was married yesterday to Gerald Alan Robbie, a member of the law firm of Kreindler & Kreindler.

title: Letter: On Nuclear Disarmament No Hostages to Superpower Bullying
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect in Unionist's Killing Faces an Extradition Hearing
description: A man accused of having killed a Philadelphia union leader with organized crime ties last week faces a hearing on his refusal to be extradited to Pennsylvania.

title: Vikings Set Back Buccaneers, 25-10
description: For a change, Tommy Kramer, the quarterback of the Minnesota Vikings, was not called upon for any last-minute heroics yesterday. Since replacing Fran Tarkenton as the passing master of the Vikings two and a half seasons ago, Kramer has pulled out at least half a dozen victories with offensive charges late in the game.

title: Economic Analysis
description: There were bruised feelings on both sides last week in the policy struggle between Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and David A. Stockman, the budget director.

title: Bengals 40, Chargers 17
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Louis Breeden, the Bengal cornerback, ran 102 yards with an intercepted pass to tie an N.F.L. record, and the quarterback Ken Anderson's passing paced a 31-point first half against the mistake-prone Chargers.

title: SALVADOR BRIDGE: ITS LOSS IS SERIOUS
description: The steel and reinforced concrete pylons and asphalt surface that were half of the longest and most important bridge in El Salvador lie submerged beneath the Lempa, the country's most important river.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: MONDAY The nation's growing economic problems top the Washington agenda again this week. There's little scheduled that is cause for optimism.

title: F.H.A. Lowers Ceiling on Rate
description: The Government is lowering the interestrate ceiling for another federally insured home loan program, bringing the limit on graduated-payment mortgages into line with other loans for single-family homes.

title: NUCLEAR NUTSHELL
description: To the Editor:

title: RELATIONSHIPS
description: B ecause the abortion question is decided ''between a woman and her doctor,'' an estimated one million men a year are left on the emotional periphery of this most difficult problem. Not only are many powerless to voice their opinions in the decision-making process, but they are also typically neglected by abortion-clinic counseling services and prohibited from being with their partners during the abortion procedure or in the recovery room.

title: Academic Coach
description: Everyone interested in college football knows that the University of Nebraska almost every year is one of the nation's top-ranked teams, and usually a contender for the Big Eight title.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1981
description: International Guidelines for Egypt's future were given by President Hosni Mubarak in his first major address since taking office in early October. He called for economic improvement at home for all Egyptians, and he affirmed Egypt's commitment to a foreign policy of nonalignment, while supporting the Camp David peace process with Israel. (Page A1, Column 6.) The American aid program for Haiti will be reshaped, according to Administration aides and Haitian Cabinet ministers who met in Washington last week. The United States will also support Haiti's request for a World Bank development study that is intended to bring Haitian needs to the attention of donor nations and private investors. The actions are part of a larger Carribean initiative announced in July by the United States, Canada, Mexico and Venezuela. The cost of the American program was not announced. The United States provides Haiti with $26 million a year in food and development funds and $750,000 in military assistance. (A1:4-5.)

title: Santa Yamani and the OPEC Elves
description: ''This is exactly the dream of everybody,'' gushed Sheik Ahmed Yamani, the Saudi oil minister. ''It will make everybody very happy.'' He meant the OPEC oil cartel's new unified price policy.

title: LET THEM OBSERVE U.S. DEMOCRACY IN ACTION
description: To the Editor:

title: A Night of Memories for Miss Hayes
description: A biographical work about the late playwright Edward Sheldon and the actor John Barrymore, ''Ned and Jack'' - which opened last night at the Little Theater - is a story about friendship in the theater, and for some members of the audience it was also an emotional evening of much nostalgia.

title: EX-AGENT REPORTS HE PAID U.S. AIDES
description: Frank E. Terpil, a fugitive former agent for the Central Intelligence Agency, asserted in a recorded television interview broadcast tonight that he had made payoffs involving a State Department employee and certain military and intelligence officials.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny Power System has elected Franklin L. Morgal president of the Penn Power Co., a subsidiary.

title: FOR MEXICO'S LEFT, NEW DISCORD AND OLD DIALECTIC
description: Long accustomed to the sight of local Marxists squabbling among themselves, Mexico's political establishment was taken aback in mid-August when five leftist parties announced plans to unite behind a single candidate in next July's presidential elections.

title: BRIEFING
description: T IGHTER housekeeping rules set by Congress are forcing the Black Congressional Caucus to give up free office space on Capitol Hill and pay for new shelter elsewhere. A half dozen other caucus-style organizations relied on by lawmakers for research and advice must also decide whether to cut off all outside funding as the price of keeping free Congressional office space. One of them, the Northeast-Midwest Institute, has already decided that it cannot survive well without outside aid and so will move and pay its own rent elsewhere.

title: Marsteller Wins Investors Account
description: Marsteller, Chicago, a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam, has been named national ad agency for Investors Diversified Services, a subsidiary of the Alleghany Corporation.

title: MERGER-NOTICE LAW SAID TO WORK WELL
description: Five years ago, when legislation was being considered to force companies to give the Government 30 days' notice before consummating mergers, opponents argued heatedly that such a delay would prevent many legitimate corporate marriages from taking place.

title: Wyse Advertising Acquires Jane Maas
description: Wyse Advertising has acquired Jane Maas Inc., a six-month-old agency billing about $1 million. Actually, it will be just Miss Maas that Wyse is acquiring, because none of the agency's other four employees is moving to Wyse.

title: Trail Blazers Top Nuggets, 120-116
description: Calvin Natt and Billy Ray Bates combined for 26 points in the fourth quarter as the Portland Trail Blazers came from behind tonight and beat the Denver Nuggets, 120-116.

title: HALLIBURTON ELECTS NEW PRESIDENT
description: Thomas H. Cruikshank has been elected president of the Halliburton Company, a major service concern in the oil and gas industry that has expanded into construction, specialty products and insurance. Mr. Cruikshank, 50, succeeds John P. Harbin, 64, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the Dallas-based company.

title: BUSINESS COMES TO AID OF BLIGHTED AREA OF TOLEDO
description: Two years ago this winter the wreckers came to the Warren-Sherman district here, tearing down block after block of houses in the name of urban renewal, and promising a new life for the old inner-city neighborhood.

title: Listen to the C.I.A. Watchmen
description: Point: The United States cannot be secure if our spies can't use their covert methods on the home front as well as abroad.

title: 10 OFFICERS SUSPENDED IN BEATINGS OF BLACKS
description: Ten police officers have been suspended with pay after black residents of a hotel charged that white off-duty officers waving a Confederate flag, beat tenants and yelled racial epithets.

title: THRIFT UNITS EXPECTING LITTLE RELIEF
description: The recent drop in interest rates will bring little near-term relief to many of the nation's beleaguered savings and loan associations, according to delegates attending the annual convention of the United States League of Savings Associations.

title: Launching Pad Closed For Columbia Refueling
description: The space shuttle Columbia's launching pad was closed to all but essential workers today while the power units that delayed last week's mission launching were refueled for another attempt at a second launching Thursday.

title: 22 Members of Congress Ask Ban on Soviet Truck Imports
description: A group of 9 Senators and 13 members of the House of Representatives from auto-producing states have asked President Reagan in a letter to block the importation of a Sovietmade four-wheel-drive truck.

title: Lois Stempel, an Ad Aide, Bride of Melvin Diamond
description: Lois Stempel, an account executive with Michael J. Motto Advertising in Mountainside, N.J., and Melvin N. Diamond, president of Diamond Pools, a retail swimming pool chain based in South Amboy, N.J., were married yesterday.

title: POLITICAL ACTIVISM ON CAMPUS IS NOWHERE NEAR DEATH
description: To the Editor:

title: D.N. Berman Weds Marcia Wishinsky
description: Marcia Wishinsky, a psychotherapist with Youth Consultation Services, a community mental-health clinic in Jersey City, was married yesterday to Dennis Neil Berman, an associate with the law firm of Reavis & McGrath in New York. Rabbi Seymour Baumrind performed the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: 'TAXI HUSTLERS' PREY ON VISITORS AS OFFICIALS ARGUE
description: A continuing dispute over who is responsible for law enforcement at the East Side Terminal is enabling an organized team of ''taxi hustlers'' stationed there every weekday night to systematically overcharge visitors to New York City, officials say.

title: Oilers 17, Raiders 16
description: HOUSTON (AP) - John Reaves threw a 25-yard touchdown pass to Mike Barber on fourth down with 7 minutes 20 seconds remaining to give Houston (5-5) the victory. The score offset an outstanding secondhalf passing effort by Marc Wilson, the Oakland quarterback.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In some articles in Business Day in the past two weeks, the ranking of the Greenwich Savings Bank was incor- rectly stated. It was the 9th-largest in total assets in New York State, accord- ing to the State Banking Department, and the 16th in size nationally in total deposits, according to the National As- sociation of Mutual Savings Banks.

title: Weapons Search Called After Uprising at Prison
description: Warden Herman Solem ordered a cell-to-cell search of the South Dakota State Penitentiary today after a brief uprising in which a handful of convicts with clubs, chains and homemade knives injured 11 guards.

title: 49ERS TOP FALCONS FOR 7TH IN A ROW
description: Joe Montana threw two touchdown passes for San Francisco, and Dwight Hicks intercepted a Steve Bartkowski pass with one minute left in the game as the 49ers posted their seventh straight victory, a 17-14 decision over the Atlanta Falcons today.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Medical International filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering the proposed public offering of $80 million principal amount of convertible subordinated debentures due 2001, to be sold through a Goldman, Sachs group.

title: FEW ISSUES SET SO FAR THIS WEEK
description: Few corporations have scheduled new note or bond issues this week, but investment bankers say many more will come to market if yields continue to decline or even stay at their levels of late Friday.

title: U.S. TO REDESIGN ITS AID PROGRAM FOR HAITI DESPITE RIGHTS PROBLEM
description: The United States is reported to have indicated that it will redesign its aid program for Haiti and help the Government of President Jean-Claude Duvalier strengthen its trade and investment program.

title: Bears 16, Chiefs 13
description: John Roveto kicked a 22-yard field goal with 1:53 left in overtime for the victory. The Bears started the winning drive when Al Harris fell on a fumble by Steve Fuller at the Chiefs' 37 with 7:30 left.

title: CIGARETTE TAX RAIDERS SEIZE THREE WITH 44,000 CARTONS
description: State tax authorities said yesterday that three persons and 44,000 cartons of stolen, unstamped cigarettes had been seized in western New York, culminating a two-month investigation into the largest tax-stamp counterfeiting operation ever uncovered in the state.

title: AUTHOR OF 'CIVILIZATION' SERIES
description: Will Durant, a historian and philosopher who won a Pulitzer Prize with his wife, Ariel, for a volume of their ''Story of Civilization,'' died late yesterday. He was 96 years old.

title: Broncos 23, Browns 20
description: DENVER (AP) - Fred Steinfort got a 30-yard field goal at 4:10 of the overtime session to lift Denver.

title: MET MUSEUM AIMING TO TAP REAL-ESTATE INDUSTRY
description: THE recent $10-million gift from Harold D. Uris, the real-estate executive, to the Metropolitan Museum of Art for educational purposes, has given that financially troubled institution a new idea about where to turn for money -to the city's booming real-estate industry. To tap a potential source of funding that it had in the past overlooked, the museum has set up a Real Estate Council composed of prominent persons in the field ''to organize the realestate interests of New York City in support of the Metropolitan.''

title: CONNIE FRANCIS: COMEBACK TRAIL AFTER 7 LOST YEARS
description: ''Every face seemed to be that face - for many months, many years,'' the singer Connie Francis said. ''They never found him.'' It has been seven dark years since Miss Francis was raped at knife point by an intruder in a Howard Johnson's motel in Westbury, L.I. Now, at age 42, she is returning Thursday to make her comeback at the Westbury Music Fair, telling herself: ''O.K., let's see what kind of guts you've got, girl.''

title: TINY, GOSSAMER CRAFT TAKE TO LIBRARY'S QUIET AIR
description: Watched by the likes of Euripides, Demosthenes and Sophocles in marble - as well as a portrait pantheon of Columbia University's presidents - men at play flew their tiny airplanes yesterday under the 105-foot dome of Low Memorial Library.

title: A NEW DEAL PRODUCT RE-PROVES ITS WORTH
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTO RALLY STIRS UP FADINGTOWN'S ECONOMY
description: There are 50 people milling around the intersection of two dirt roads deep in Ottawa National Forest near here. It is dark and cold, and most either huddle by a small fire or clap their hands and stamp as they wait.

title: Out of the Game
description: Bill Raftery, the blithe spirit who has coached the Seton Hall basketball team since 1970, tendered his resignation last week. One of the most popular coaches in the metropolitan area, he quipped his way to 156 victories over 11 seasons with the Pirates.

title: PLAYER HAYES HIT HAUNTED BY INCIDENT
description: The visitor to the Keowee Key Country Club could see that the stocky-shouldered maitre d'hotel looked bigger and stronger than most dining-room hosts.

title: LIBERAL-CONSERVATIVES FIGHT LOOMS OVER INCENTIVE ZONES FOR INDUSTRY
description: A fight between liberals and conservatives is shaping up over the idea of luring business into cities through special investment and tax policies, which President Reagan has called the keystone of his urban policy.

title: TV: EDITH WHARTON'S 'SUMMER'
description: TONIGHT'S 90-minute version of Edith Wharton's ''Summer,'' beginning at 8 on WNET-TV, demands patience, much more than it finally deserves. But hang in there. Immediately following that presentation, Channel 13 is offering a half-hour film called ''Close Harmony,'' which has already won a CINE Golden Eagle Award and will undoubtedly collect a good many other recognition trophies. Produced and directed by Nigel Noble, ''Close Harmony'' is the kind of production that whizzes by dazzlingly, leaving the audience drenched in smiles and tears and hoping for just a bit more.

title: What's a Family?
description: Most countries have a vision of the perfect family. England's, for instance, is best encapsulated in those big Victorian paintings of a father, mother, seven children, spinster sister, aged grandfather and, in the doorway's shadow, a maid with a tea cart.

title: The Talk of Tompkins County
description: The weather headlines hereabouts were emphatic: ''Floods Sweep Area - Governor Declares Disaster - Cost in Millions.'' Yet residents of Tompkins County seem more interested in the omens of winter in the sky than the piles of debris on the ground.

title: CONVICTION GROWS ON LOWER RATES
description: Accompanying the decline in short-and long-term interest rates last week was the growing conviction among some analysts that the drop would not be a temporary one followed by a surge in rates to record levels.

title: TALLY TODAY COULD LEAD TO JERSEY VOTE RECOUNT
description: After a weekend of legal maneuvering in the still unsettled election for Governor of New Jersey, the unofficial tallies for both major candidates were to be certified at noon today by the state's Board of Canvassers, paving the way for a probable recount.

title: Saints 21, Rams 13
description: George Rogers scored three touchdowns and became the N.F.L.'s leading rusher today as he led New Orleans to a surprising victory over Los Angeles.

title: TIMING IS THE KEY IN DEER HUNTING
description: IN many areas of the nation -and New York State is a prime example of this - the timing of one's deer hunt may be more critical to success than the skills one brings to the endeavor.

title: Practice Is Perfect, Fire Dept. Finds
description: Just one day after the Fire Department practiced a new concept - automatically responding with many men and a lot of equipment to fires at high-rise buildings - the department applied the concept to confine a potentially serious fire to an 11th-floor advertising office at 575 Madison Avenue, at 56th Street.

title: First Golf Victory For Patty Sheehan
description: Patty Sheehan of the United States won her first professional golf tournament today, shooting a threeunder-par 71 to capture the $200,000 Mazda Japan Classic.

title: PURCHASERS SEE A FALL IN INDUSTRY
description: The economy turned sharply lower in October, with output, new orders and employment declining at a faster pace than the month before, according to the latest report on business conditions compiled by the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: TIME TO STOP LAUGHING
description: The conduct of foreign affairs in the Reagan Administration has reached the level of a national joke. Cabinet members making offhand statements about nuclear weapons, publicly correcting each other, denouncing ''guerrillas'' in the White House: if a satirist had invented such stuff, he would have been chided for going too far.

title: SERGEANT-AT-ARMS HAS KEY TO 1,213 SENATE JOBS
description: A Southern Democratic Senator tried to find a chauffeur's job for a young constituent who settled for work as a clerk. A Middle Western Republican Senator secured a managerial position for a middle-aged woman, while a Republican Senator from the Great Plains obtained a doorkeeper's job for the protege of a defeated colleague.

title: AS COLLEGES SCRAMBLE FOR NO. 1, PITT HOLDS LINE
description: FROM the day that Johnny Majors became the head football coach at Pittsburgh, Dec. 19, 1972, until mid-August, 1973, he and his new staff scoured the nation for as many football recruits as they could find. They signed 76 newcomers and 67 of them showed up at preseason training camp, according to Jackie Sherrill, who was an assistant to Majors then and became the Pitt head coach when Majors left for Tennessee in 1977.

title: Mayers in Final; Connors Is Upset
description: Sandy Mayer upset top-seeded Jimmy Connors, 6-3, 6-3, tonight to set up a final with his younger brother Gene in the $200,000 Stockholm Open Tennis Championships.

title: 'INTENT': CRUX OF DEBATE ON MANY BILLS
description: A slippery legal concept called ''intent,'' mentioned by President Reagan in his statement last week on extending the Voting Rights Act of 1965, lies at the heart of current legislative debates on other issues ranging from protection of intelligence secrets to bribery of foreign officials.

title: GRUMMAN LAGGING IN BRINGING BUSES BACK TO NEW YORK
description: With less than eight weeks remaining before a deadline for the return of 837 Grumman Flxible buses to the streets of New York, only 99 have been returned, and company and transit officials said yesterday that the deadline would not be met.

title: Gen. Avraham Orly; Led Israeli Paratroops
description: Maj. Gen. Avraham Orly, the former chief administrator of the Israeli-occupied Arab territories and one of the first paratroopers in the Israel Army, died at a hospital here today. He was 51 years old.

title: 2 Left-Wing Guerrillas in Italy Report Receiving Arab Guns
description: Two members of the leftist Red Brigades who have turned state's witness say they received a shipment of submachine guns and hand grenades from Palestinian guerrillas in Italy, according to court records.

title: A World to Feed 14th article of a series appearing periodically
description: The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, the oldest and largest of the four world hunger relief agencies based here, is facing the most serious challenge to its activities since its founding in 1945. The major industrialized countries, which contribute more than 70 percent of the agency's budget, are becoming increasingly skeptical about its approach to the problem of world hunger. And the United States in particular is more reluctant to finance F.A.O. activities.

title: OFFICIALS AT UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO CLOSE DOORS IN LATEST STUDENT STRIKE
description: For the fourth time this school year, the University of Puerto Rico today closed its doors to allow crews to repair damage from the student strike that has convulsed the campus since August.

title: Renaissance Band Plans Twice-a-Month Series
description: Calliope: A Renaissance Band, a chamber-music ensemble, will present medieval, Renaissance, Baroque and contemporary American chamber music in a series of free, twice-a-month, noontime concerts at Christ United Methodist Church.

title: Oneida Takeover
description: Stockholders at the Oneida National Bank and Trust Company of Central New York have approved the acquisition of their bank by United Bank of New York.

title: The Candidate
description: ''I'll be holding my breath,'' said Alvin Reynolds, a 200-pound linebacker for Indiana State, looking forward to the Heisman Trophy ceremony on Dec. 5.

title: THEATER: 'COWBOY MOUTH' RETURNS
description: SAM SHEPARD and Patti Smith wrote ''Cowboy Mouth'' as a duel with dialogue, shooting words and music back and forth as if engaged in a fun fight at the R & R Corral. The battle was hand-stitched for the co-authors, who played the roles - approximations of themselves - in the work's first New York production in 1971 at the American Place Theater. Mr. Shepard was the lanky cowboy Slim, ''a cat who looks like a coyote,'' and Miss Smith was the urchin Cavale, ''a chick who looks like a crow.''

title: Washington Watch; Europe-U.S.  Energy Rift
description: WASHINGTON THE UNITED STATES is getting a polite rebuff from Western Europe on the energy alternatives it is offering in last ditch efforts to dissuade the Europeans from increasing their reliance on Soviet natural gas.

title: Centrowitz Excels In Cross-Country
description: Matt Centrowitz set a meet record of 31 minutes 9.3 seconds in leading the New York Athletic Club to the team title in the Metropolitan Athletic Congress senior cross-country championships yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Broad Street Author
description: The man who personified the aggressive, brawling style of play that the Philadelphia Flyers made their trademark in the early and mid-1970's was Dave Schultz, 190-pound left wing who led the National Hockey League in total penalty minutes for four straight seasons, beginning in 1972-73. Although he was lionized by the fans of the ''Broad Street Bullies,'' he represented to advocates of pure hockey a hooligan distorting the sport.

title: ITALIAN RIDER WINS GRAND PRIX OF N.Y.
description: The National Horse Show closed with a decided Italian accent last night as Filippo Moyersoen proved that his horse, Adam, was a legitimate threat to world honors.

title: IN ARGENTINA, AN ELITE CALLS BRITAIN HOME
description: The air was full of the scent of freshly cut grass and the sounds of polo - the thudding hooves, the crack of mallet on ball, and the polite applause of the spectators. After the match, the onlookers wandered across the cricket field to the Tudorstyle clubhouse for tea and cakes.

title: AS TALK OF A 'GREAT' QUAKE CONTINUES, CALIFORNIANS PLAY A WAITING GAME
description: The newspapers and television stations here, as they tend to do periodically, have been paying renewed attention recently to geologists' warnings that southern California is likely to be struck by a crippling earthquake in the next two decades or so.

title: Panama Editor Arrested For Attack on President
description: The editor of the newspaper La Prensa has been arrested on a charge of accusing President Aristedes Royo of instigating an armed assault on the newspaper's office.

title: Eagles 52, Cardinals 10
description: ST. LOUIS (AP) - Ron Jaworski of Philadelphia (8-2) threw four touchdown passes, two of them to Harold Carmichael in the second half to break open a tight game.

title: A Place in the Sun for the Brothers Reagan
description: Since his kid brother became President, 73-year-old Neil Reagan has kept his distance from the White House, and there's a reason. ''Washington,'' Mr. Reagan explained ''is a stinking city weatherwise.'' Mr. Reagan, who lives in Rancho Fe, Calif., noted in an interview last week that he had seen his brother only twice since he took office - at the inauguration and at a birthday party a week later.

title: 'ALL SAVERS' DEPOSITS BOLSTER THRIFT UNITS
description: Fed by an influx of funds from the sale of tax-exempt savings certificates, deposits at savings and loan associations exceeded withdrawals last month for the first time since February, according to an industry official.

title: Income Is Up Slightly At Foote, Cone
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications reported Friday that its third-quarter net income rose 1.7 percent, to $1.7 million from $1.6 million.

title: BUILD F-18'S
description: Since 1975, the Navy and Marine Corps have advocated, developed, tested, and started production of a new airplane, the F/A-18 Hornet. If the program is fully approved, 1,366 Hornets will be produced for the United States; already more than 200 have been purchased by Canada and Australia. This aircraft has generated lengthy debate in the news media and the Congress, a debate that still goes on. However, seldom do I see anything written by the one person who ''pays'' for the good or bad features of a new plane - the pilot, the guy who must fly it every day.

title: BELGIAN VOTE AIDS THE LEFT AND RIGHT
description: The left and the right wings advanced at the expense of the center in yesterday's general election, Belgium's third in less than five years.

title: AUCTION BY RCA UNIT IS CLOUDED
description: The Federal Communications Commission has cast a legal cloud over an unusual auction of communications satellite facilities that is scheduled for today.

title: Sports World Specials; Safety First
description: A five-year battle by Floyd Patterson, the former heavyweight champion who is now a member of the three-man New York State Athletic Commission, to make manadatory a thumbless boxing glove in New York will become a reality early next year. Jack Prenderville, the commission chairman, announced last week that the Everlast Eyesaver will be used for all bouts in New York, except for championship matches, after Jan. 15.

title: FAR-REACHING EFFECTS FORESEEN IN FUTURE TIE
description: The Chicago Board of Trade's decision to join forces with the tiny and moribund New York Futures Exchange could have a far-reaching effect on the commodity futures industry, according to market participants.

title: FATIGUE AND FRUSTRATION FILL THE HALLS
description: The Pentagon is a somewhat dispirited place these days. It begins at the top with the Secretary of Defense, Caspar W. Weinberger, who is usually a peppy man with a quick wit. But he seems tired and his public appearances lack the zip they had only a few weeks ago.

title: MIGLIORE RIDES FOUR WINNERS
description: Richard Migliore, the 17-year-old who is the leading apprentice in the country, rode four winners yesterday, including Island Charm in the $56,200 First Flight Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: Corrections
description: The caption under a photograph of a group of pianists in Weekend on Friday incorrectly identified Alicia de Larrocha and Bella Davidovich. Miss de Larrocha was on the left and Miss Davidovich on the right.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A man was shot in the chest and killed as he stood on a Brooklyn street.

title: CRIME AT AN EARLY AGE: THE VIOLENT STREETS OF LUIS GUZMAN
description: Avenue D on the Lower East Side of Manhattan is only 12 blocks long. But it is one of the meanest streets in America, a narrow corridor of poverty and violence running north from Houston Street, parallel to the East River and just across town from the leafy tranquillity of Greenwich Village.

title: FREUD ARCHIVES RESEARCH CHIEF REMOVED IN DISPUTE OVER YALE TALK
description: A Berkeley scholar entrusted with private papers of Sigmund Freud has been removed as research director of the Sigmund Freud Archives in New York City after indirectly blaming Freud for ''the present-day sterility of psychoanalysis throughout the world.''

title: Ballesteros Takes Australian PGA
description: Severiano Ballesteros of Spain shot a three-under-par 69 today and scored a three-stroke victory in the $150,000 Australian PGA Championship.

title: Seahawks 24 Steelers 21
description: SEATTLE (AP) - Theotis Brown of Seattle scored on two 1-yard runs in the fourth quarter, and David Trout of Pittsburgh missed a 22-yard field goal with 19 seconds left as the Seahawks overcame a 21-3 first-half deficit.

title: King Hussein Forsees A Key Role for Egypt
description: King Hussein of Jordan said today that Egypt had an important part to play in Arab affairs but that it was too early to say when that nation might be able ''to resume its place in the Arab family.''

title: OPERA: 'SATYAGRAHA,' TALE OF GHANDI, IN BROOKLYN
description: ''SATYAGRAHA,'' the opera by Philip Glass that had its New York City premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday evening, ought to be considered for inclusion in the Guinness Book of Records. Has there ever been an opera that went so far on so few musical ideas? If music without frills is your ideal, ''Satyagraha'' is your opera. Mr. Glass has purposely cut down his options in this work, like a man who has decided to see whether he can wallpaper a room with one hand tied behind his back.

title: PLAN FOR MARKET BENEATH BRIDGE REVIVED BY CITY
description: The Koch administration has resurrected plans to build an open-air market beneath the Manhattan end of the Queensboro Bridge - setting the stage for a new version of the battle that killed the project at the last minute three years ago.

title: West Bank Mayors Set Back
description: The Defense Ministry has rejected an appeal by two expelled Palestinian Mayors to return to the occupied West Bank, Israel radio reported today. Mayors Fahad Kawasmeh of Hebron and Mohammed Milhem of Halhoul were expelled in May 1980. They were accused of creating the climate for a Palestinian attack on Jewish worshipers in Hebron in which 16 Jews were killed.

title: U.N. Aide Reported on Hunger Strike in Poland
description: Alicja Wesolowska, the United Nations secretary who was arrested during a vacation visit to her native Poland in 1979, has been on a hunger strike since Sept. 21 and is in ''extremely serious condition,'' according to friends in New York.

title: OLIVER D. WILLIAMS, JUSTICE WHO SERVED STATE SUPREME COURT
description: Oliver D. Williams, a retired justice of the New York State Supreme Court, died Saturday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 83 years old. Justice Williams was the first black elected to the State Supreme Court from the Second Judicial Conference, comprising Brooklyn and Staten Island. He was elected in November 1963 on the Democratic ticket to a full 14-year term, but had served only five years when he reached the statutory retirement age in 1968. He received three twoyear extensions, permitted under the law, and retired in December 1974.

title: SALLY H. CLARK
description: Sally H. Clark, known for her sculptures of animals and busts, died Nov. 1 at her home on the Upper East Side.

title: GIANTS BEATEN BY 26-24
description: At first, it was a nightmare for the Giants. They suffered disasters on their first five possessions and fell behind the Green Bay Packers, 20-0, in the first quarter today. Then they came back and took a 24-23 lead midway through the last quarter, only to lose by 26-24 on Jan Stenerud's fourth field goal in four attempts.

title: CARTWRIGHT RETURNS TO KNICKS' LINEUP
description: All through training camp and for the five games the Knicks have played in the regular season, they have been in a period of adjustment. First it was the introduction of Mike Newlin and Randy Smith at guard. Then came the addition of Maurice Lucas, the power foward.

title: TV: 'FOR LADIES ONLY,' MALE STRIPPER'S STORY
description: WHEN John Phillips (Gregory Harrison) first takes up stripping, it doesn't seem such a bad idea. At the start of ''For Ladies Only,'' a television movie to be shown tonight at 9 on NBC, John has come to New York to look for work as an actor, but he doesn't have much luck. One casting call finds him lining up with dozens of other aspirants to read the line, ''The hell with you, lady.'' A man in front of him does so well he is hired on the spot; John doesn't even get a chance.

title: People
description: * Thomas R. Miller has been named executive vice president and chief operating officer for Ketchum New York.

title: Manhattan Bows
description: Alan DeLisle threw two touchdown passes and ran 1 yard for a score to lead St. John Fisher of Rochester to a 26-20 victory over Manhattan College in an Atlantic Conference football game yesterday at Kennedy High School in the Bronx. The victory was the sixth in six league games for the Cardinals, who completed their regular season with an 8-2 record. Kevin Care threw touchdown passes to Gerry Murphy and Bart Gallagher for Manhattan (4-4).

title: Bridge: Big Lie Slips From Favor, But a Small Fib Is Helpful
description: Big lies, in the form of outright psychic bids, have long been out of favor among experts. The Roth-Stone system in its original form a quarter of a century ago embodied a stylized opening psychic with a hand containing about 3 to 6 points concentrated in the suit bid.

title: STAYING UNBEATEN GETS TOUGHER
description: Sixteen major college football teams have gone through a regular season undefeated and untied in the seven complete campaigns since the first part of the 95-30 rule took effect (1974-1980). There were 22 teams with perfect regular-season records in the seven years immediately preceding the 95-30 rule.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE ART OF MARRIAGE

title: Hudson Vitamins Assigned to Venet
description: Venet Advertising has become agency for Hudson Vitamins, a unit of the Hudson Pharmaceutical Corporation, which in turn is a unit of the Cadence Industries Corporation.

title: NEW YORK STORES' SALES RISE ONLY 3.9%
description: New York City's seven largest department stores recorded their smallest sales gain in 18 months in October. A spot-check found that the stores had an average sales rise of only 3.9 percent from October 1980, half the inflation rate in general retail merchandise. This meant that the retailers had a decline in the volume of sales last month.

title: Florence Lomuscio, Buyer, Is Wed to Juan E. Metzger
description: Florence A. Lomuscio, a doll buyer for F.A.O. Schwarz, was married yesterday at the Church Center for the United Nations to Juan E. Metzger, founder and former chairman of the Dannon Company, the yogurt producer.

title: COCA-COLA BOTTLER NAMES A PRESIDENT
description: The Coca-Cola Bottling Company of New York has named Edward F. O'@Reilly, the 43-year-old president of its soft-drink division, as president of the corporation. He succeeds Charles E.F. Millard, 49, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Mugabe Vows to Expel All 'Racist' Whites
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe has vowed to expel white racists who he said continued to ''insult'' Zimbabwe's black majority.

title: Addenda
description: * Fortune magazine increasing its advertising rates 10 percent effective with the Jan.11 issue.

title: REAGAN RIGHTS POLICY CONFIRMED
description: The Administration said today that President Reagan had approved a State Department memorandum outlining the need for a strong human rights policy in foreign affairs.

title: WORKERS VOW TO SAVE GEAR FACTORY
description: Factory work starts early, varies little. It is reassuring in its routine. At 7:30 each morning, Bill Ashcroft is at work in the Paragon Gears Company's plant here, standing over his machines. For 80 years, the plant has made marine transmissions for small motor yachts and pleasure boats, and Mr. Ashcroft has worked here for half that time.

title: AUSTRIAN CHANCELLOR AND ECONOMY ARE AILING
description: Chancellor Bruno Kreisky and the Austrian economy are ailing these days - not gravely, but enough to prompt renewed speculation here about a governmental succession or change.

title: 'I Just Kept Winging'
description: IN the beginning, Scott Brunner had just about everything happen to him that could possibly happen. Everything bad. On the Giants' first series, he had a delay-of-game penalty when he didn't get the play off in the allotted 30 seconds. Then he had an interception run back for the Green Bay Packers' first touchdown. Another interception positioned a field goal, then his fumble set up another field goal as the Packers took a 20-0 lead. But when the game ended, with the Packers winning, 26-24, on Jan Stenerud's fourth field goal after the Giants had led, 24-23, midway in the final quarter, Scott Brunner had emerged as a quarterback that some Giant followers surely will adopt.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bass Family Real Estate Developers said it and an investment group had acquired 7.3 percent of the Northwest Energy Co.'s cumulative preferred stock series A. The concern said it held 220,400 Northwest Energy Preferred shares, purchased for $4.3 million.

title: Society May Close 3 Animal Shelters
description: The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals says it will close its shelters in the Bronx, Queens and Staten Island if the state does not increase fees for dog licenses by Jan. 31.

title: THE WASHINGTON OPERA: 'LA BOHEME'
description: THE Washington Opera opened its new season at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts on Saturday with just a touch of lobbying in the air. The confrontation was piquant, if perhaps unintentional - President Reagan, a committed cutter of Federal cultural subsidies, in the audience and, on stage, Puccini's ''La Boheme,'' a story of impoverished artists. At the side of Mr. and Mrs. Reagan was Beverly Sills, the country's most visible supporter of the arts, and one could imagine her whispering into the Presidential ear: ''See, Mr. President, what happens when you deprive poets, painters, musicians and philosophers of their commissions and matching grants. They end up selling their overcoats, behaving badly at outdoor cafes and finally developing consumption.'' A reproachful glance toward the Reagan box from the stage could almost be detected as the shivering Colline intoned ''Vecchia zimarra senti.''

title: ALLEN WARNS OF THREAT TO ALLIANCE
description: West European critics of President Reagan's hard-line policies toward the Soviet Union are contributing to the ''disruption'' of the Atlantic alliance, according to an article published today by Richard V. Allen, the President's national security adviser.

title: Georgia Pulls Out Another
description: Georgia was on its own 5-yard line, trailing Florida by a point with 10 minutes 16 seconds remaining in the game at Jacksonville, Fla., Saturday. The Bulldogs pulled it out, winning by 26-21.

title: REAGAN SALON RENOVATED
description: Nancy Reagan has had the White House beauty salon renovated with thousands of dollars worth of furnishings, fabrics and cosmetics donated by the beauty industry.

title: Contract for ITT Unit
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said Friday that its Spanish subsidiary, Standard Electrica, had obtained a $96 million contract to modernize and expand Venezuela's telephone system.

title: Ed Libov Elections
description: The board of directors of Ed Libov Associates, following the death last Monday of its 51-year-old founder and owner, elected new officers Friday. They are Carmine Cicchino, chief executive officer; Avram Buttensky, chief operating officer; Jack Gracian, chief administrative officer, and Sam Selig, chief financial officer. The company is a media-buying service that works largely for toy companies and bills some $150 million.

title: TITLES SWITCH AT CLABIR
description: The chairman and the president of the Clabir Corporation, a holding company for two operating companies, have changed titles. Henry D. Clarke Jr., 47, who had been president, will become chairman, while Ralph R.M. Ehrmann, 56, who had been chairman, will become president. Mr. Clarke, however, continues as chief executive officer.

title: METALS SEEM READY FOR A RISE
description: The market for metals may be languishing in recession, but the road back to higher prices - especially for copper, lead and zinc - is not expected to be as arduous as it was after the sharp business downturn of 1974-75. In fact, many analysts contend that even a slight increase in demand could send prices soaring.

title: CITY'S PAYROLL FALLS BELOW BUDGET PLAN BY 6,000 POSITIONS
description: Despite plans to hire more teachers, police officers, firefighters and sanitation workers, there were nearly 6,000 vacant positions in the New York City payroll in September, officials said yesterday.

title: BLUES SINGER: JOE TURNER, AT 70, IS BACK
description: BIG JOE TURNER, the Kansas City blues shouter whose booming voice first blasted through New York more than 40 years ago when, after making his debut at a Carnegie Hall concert he moved to Cafe Society in Greenwich Village for a run of almost four years, is on another long-term New York engagement, at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street.

title: UNBEATEN FARRELL CAPTURES CITY TITLE
description: Tony LoPresti scored three touchdowns, two on passes from Jack Valinoti, as Monsignor Farrell of Staten Island defeated St. Francis Prep of Fresh Meadows, 22-7, yesterday to win the Catholic High Schools Football League City Division championship at St. John's University in Jamaica, Queens. It was the seventh victory for undefeated Farrell, including six in the City Division.

title: STUDY ON SPECIAL-PROSECUTOR LAW
description: A Senate subcommittee called today for legislation to make it easier for the Justice Department to drop criminal charges against high-level Federal officials, without an investigation by an independent special prosecutor.

title: MAYOR OF BRIMINGHAM ASSAILED FOR RUNOFF ROLE
description: When Richard Arrington was elected two years ago as Birmingham's first black mayor, jubilation swept much of the city. To many blacks, and the whites who voted for him, Mr. Arrington's election symbolized the burial of the city's 1960's image as a bastion of racial bigotry and violence.

title: Question BoxS. Lee Kanner
description: QUESTION: In a game of touch football, played under National Football League rules, I took a pitchout around the left side, but was forced to cut back. Trapped 15 yards behind the line of scrimmage, I lateraled the ball to the other running back, who was ahead of me, but still back of the line. Was that illegal? What would the ruling have been if my teammate had dropped the ball?

title: Abdul-Jabbar 3d On Scoring List
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 15 points tonight and became the third-leading scorer in National Basketball Association history as he helped the Los Angeles Lakers to defeat the Dallas Mavericks, 121-111.

title: Nets Get First Victory
description: It was 5 A.M. in Chicago, and the Nets were awaiting their boarding call for the flight home. After four games this season, the Nets were the only team in the National Basketball Association without a victory, but Buck Williams said there was a feeling that tonight would be different.

title: Liquor Prices Up in Hungary
description: Hungarians will have to pay about 20 percent more tomorrow for cigarettes and liquor, the official press agency announced today. A pint of rum will cost the equivalent of $2.29 under the new prices. Cigarettes will range from 19 cents to 34 cents a pack.

title: NEW VATICAN CODE IS CALLED FLEXIBLE
description: The new code of canon law drafted by the Roman Catholic Church to replace one that was published in 1917 represents ''a clarification of what has been in place for some time,'' according to an American archbishop who participated in its preparation.

title: Bonnett Is Narrow Winner in Atlanta 500
description: Neil Bonnett barely held off challenges by Darrell Waltrip and Cale Yarborough on the last lap to win the Atlanta Journal 500 Grand National stock car race today.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 9, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: Press Notes
description: The Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press is preparing for substantial battles against a variety of Reagan Administration proposals, including new restrictions on obtaining Government documents and on identifying foreign agents. But battles cost money, so the committee was pleased when Columbia Pictures offered it the proceeds from a benefit premiere next Sunday at Washington's Kennedy Center of a new movie about the press, ''Absence of Malice.''

title: Critics Say Rivalries Hurt Work of Food Groups
description: This city has become the home of the international food bureaucracy. The four intergovernmental agencies specifically established to deal with global hunger are based here - the Food and Agriculture Organization, the World Food Council, the International Fund for Agricultural Development and the World Food Program.

title: Shaffer One-Act Plays To Open York's Season
description: ''The Private Ear'' and ''The Public Eye,'' two one-act comedies by Peter Shaffer, will open the 13th season of the York Players Company on Nov. 20 at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th Street. Mr. Shaffer is the author of ''Amadeus,'' ''Equus'' and other works.

title: Rolls-Royce Gains
description: Rolls-Royce Motors Inc., the United States marketing unit of the British auto maker, said it had sold 894 cars in the United States between April 1 and Oct. 24, up 30 percent from the 628 sold in the similar period last year. The new Rolls-Royce Silver Spirit sells for $109,000 and the Silver Spur for $117,000.

title: DECISION COMING ON WHETHER TO REQUIRE DRUG DATA LEAFLET
description: Any day now, the Reagan Administration will decide whether consumers will receive, with some prescription drugs, a leaflet describing the medicine's effects, possible side effects and dangers of misuse, and telling the user what to do in case of an adverse reaction.

title: AN AMERICAN VISITOR
description: A visitor from Washington, gathering information to advise the Government on how to present its policy, said the impression now was that Europeans ''are no longer anti-Communist.''

title: HOME VIDEOTAPING HURTS NO COPYRIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Redskins 33, Lions 31
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - Mark Moseley's fourth field goal, a 44-yarder with 43 seconds remaining, won the game for Washington (4-6). Moseley's winning kick followed a 50-yard field goal by Ed Murray of Detroit (4-6) with 1:50 left.

title: Shula Wins 200th
description: Uwe von Schamann's third field goal of the afternoon came with 7 minutes 52 seconds remaining in overtime and did more than give the Miami Dolphins a 30-27 triumph over the New England Patriots yesterday.

title: FOR TORONTO, A LANDMARK HAPPILY FALLS
description: Canada's largest city lost a landmark here last week, to the dismay of virtually no one. Blow by blow, a 6,000-pound wrecker's ball, painted like a smiling jack-o'-lantern, razed the Hampton Park Apartments 28 years after they were conceived during a Toronto building boom. Politicians, developers, wreckers and even the owners smiled during the destruction.

title: Solidarity Is Optimistic Strikes Can Be Ended
description: Despite earlier pessimistic statements, strike leaders in Zielona Gora Province said today that they were hopeful that a new round of talks with the Government could end Poland's most extensive series of strikes since the Solidarity union movement emerged last year.

title: Liberia Giving Up Its Only Jet
description: The Liberian Government has decided to sell its only jet plane, a Boeing 737, as part of a drive to cut costs. President Samuel K. Doe said that the jet would be replaced by a smaller aircraft.

title: Corrections
description: In a table of third-quarter earnings in Business Day last Monday, the results for the A.E. Staley Manufacturing Company were incorrectly reported. The company's revenue was $456,298,000 and net income $20,721,000.

title: Diver Drowns in Seaweed
description: A scuba diver looking for lobster died early today when he became tangled in a bed of seaweed, officials said. The body of John Steven Fulcher of El Segundo, Calif., 26 years old, was retrieved at 2:45 A.M.

title: MUBARAK PLEDGES TO IMPROVE LIVING FOR ALL EGYPTIANS
description: In his first major address since taking office, President Hosni Mubarak called today for economic changes to better the lot of the average Egyptian and affirmed that Egypt was committed to a policy of nonalignment in foreign affairs.

title: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1981; The Economy
description: Falling interest rates will not bring fast near-term relief to thrift institutions, delegates at their annual convention said, because they still must work off deposits acquired at high rates. It could take them months or even years for these deposits to mature. (D1.)

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard NOBODY HERE BUT US CHICKENS. By Marvin Mudrick. 299 pages. Ticknor & Fields. $16.95.

title: BULGARIANS TRY TO STEER CLEAR OF THE POLES' DIFFICULT ROUTE
description: Many Bulgarian officials and private citizens alike believe that the Poles have made some basic errors in industry and agriculture, and hope that moderation will prevail in resolving the crisis there.

title: 3 Lifters Penalized For Use of Drugs
description: Three competitors in the world power-lifting championships, including an American, were stripped of their medals today and disqualified for a year on charges of having taken drugs intended to help them better their performances.

title: WHY LONG-TERM MARRIGES CAN SUCCEED
description: The discussion was about researchers' efforts to study mature marriages, and two of the test subjects were speaking. ''When you've been married to someone for 50 years, you have to ask yourself some questions,'' said Viola Berton, 73 years old, to her husband, Jim, 81, who was seated at her side. ''Why should I stay together with a man just because of the years I've invested? Shall I take a risk and move away? Do I love him enough to put up with his foibles?''

title: Clampett Helps U.S. Beat Japan
description: Bobby Clampett led the United States to a 35-stroke victory over Japan today for the first American victory in seven years in the nations' men's professional golf series.

title: Advertising; Brooke Shields Is A Real Doll
description: ''B ROOKE SHIELDS. She's a real living doll,'' will be the advertising theme that will introduce a new citizen to the little world where Barbie is queen.

title: Market Place; Group Focus And Robotics
description: IF Unimation's initial public offering later this month parallels that of Genentech a year ago, the robot maker's debut may popularize other robotics shares as investors focus on the favored group.

title: BIG DRUG SUPPLY AND NINE SEIZED IN HARLEM RAID
description: A raid on a Harlem social club early yesterday resulted in the seizure of more than $2 million worth of drugs, drug-cutting and packaging paraphernalia, $200,000 in cash and a small arsenal of weapons. Nine persons were arrested and charged with drug and weapons possession.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The peace for which Egypt strives is not partial or limited, but a just and comprehensive peace for the whole of the Middle East.

title: Index; International
description: Mexico's Left is in disarray again after unity attempt A2 Destruction of Golden Bridge has cut a key road in El Salvador A3 Reagan rights policy confirmed A4 Around the World A5 U.S. expects Japan to press ahead on arms buildup A7 Bulgarians say Poles erred in in- dustry and agriculture A8 Austria's leader and economy are ailing A9 Arab group trying to stop arms flow into Lebanon A11 To an Argentine elite, aping the English is a way of life A12 In Toronto, some ghosts and pi- geons lose a home A13 Allen says West European critics of Reagan endanger alliance A14 Government/Politics Birmingham mayor at center of racial and political dispute B15 Washington Talk Briefing B8 Calendar B8 The Pentagon and its boss appear a bit dispirited B8 Patronage still part of job for Sen- ate sergeant-at-arms B8 General Around the Nation A16 Boston University's president marks 10 years at helm A16 Auto rally churns up economic benefit for Michigan town A19 Three seized upstate with 44,000 cartons of stolen cigarettes B2 Police seize $2 million in narcotics and arrest nine in Harlem B3 Businesses helping a neighorhood in Toledo, Ohio, to rebuild B11 Press Notes: Movie premiere re- ceipts to go to aid press group B14 Industry/Labor Union vows to save gear factory in Massachusetts B15 SportsMonday Auto Racing: Bonnett wins At- lanta Journal 500 C10 Basketball: Brewer of Spurs daz- zles Knicks with 40 points C3

title: Begin Cites Conditions For Sinai Peace Force
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that Israel would disqualify any European country from the Sinai peacekeeping force if that country's announcement of participation mentioned any documents other than those related to the Camp David accords.

title: Alfred Ford Takes a Turn to the Spiritual
description: His great-grandfather achieved the greatest of worldly success, but Alfred Brush Ford says he plans to renounce the world and immerse himself in the spiritual Hare Krishna movement in India.

title: Red Smith Quarterback And Outfielder
description: IT was the start of the football season of 1935, a few weeks more than 46 years ago. Til Ferdenzi was a candidate for quarterback at Boston College but Til isn't a big guy and competition for the assignment was lively. However, on the eve of the opening game a sports page in Boston carried the banner headline: ''Ferdenzi to Start at Q.B. for B.C.''

title: John Henry Wins $300,000 Oak Tree
description: John Henry, overtaken by Spence Bay late in the stretch, surged back in the final strides to win the $300,000 Oak Tree Invitational on the turf at Santa Anita today.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Peking Accuses Moscow Of Nuclear Duplicity

title: An Open Door Leads Police To $3.3-Million in Marijuana
description: Two police officers responding to a report of an open door at a Brooklyn warehouse last night found nearly two tons of marijuana with a street value of $3.3 million.

title: U.S. EXPECTS JAPAN TO PRESS AHEAD ON ARMS
description: A high official of the National Security Council said last week that the United States was ''not publicly applying pressure to the Japanese'' for a military buildup and that decisions on how Japan should deal with threats to its security should be made ''in Tokyo, not Washington.''

title: LTV Shuts Steel Mill
description: The LTV Corporation announced Friday that it was temporarily shutting down the Brier Hill cold finished bar mill of its Jones & Laughlin Steel division at Youngstown, Ohio, idling 100 workers, because of weak demand.

title: EUROPEAN UNIONISTS
description: West European trade unions have been badly shaken by this past year's dramatic rise in unemployment and continuing stagflation, and by pessimistic projections for economic recovery. Increasingly-radical policies are being propounded by union leaders who in the past usually helped stabilize and restrain others on the left. Faced now with economic instability, as well as declining membership and bargaining power, leaders of predominantly Socialist unions are seeking a new, more-assertive role in national politics - both inside and outside the parliamentary systems.

title: G.O.P. TO EXPAND TO OTHER STATES 'BALLOT SECURITY' IT USED IN JERSEY
description: Republican National Committee officials, insisting that their workers had not intimidated any New Jersey voters, said today they considered their ''ballot security'' effort in last week's gubernatorial election a success. Further, they said that it would be repeated in other states.

title: Nancy Herschberg Is Married to Mitchell Muntner
description: Nancy Herschberg, a speech pathologist at St. Vincent's Hospital, was married yesterday to Mitchell Muntner, president of Troika Textiles Ltd., an exporter and sales agency representing textile mills in New York. Rabbi Myron Fenster performed the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I.

title: THEATER: 'NED AND JACK,' A BARRYMORE FANTASY, MOVES UPTOWN
description: WHEN life imitates art, the results are not always salutary. Sheldon Rosen's play ''Ned and Jack,'' which opened at the refurbished Little Theater last night, is the story of two legendary theater friends, the playwright Edward (Ned) Sheldon and the actor John (Jack) Barrymore, who rose to the heights only to slide, steadily and inexorably, into doom during the last two decades of their lives. What happened to these men, I'm sorry to report, has also happened to the play that contains them. In its Off Broadway production last spring at the Hudson Guild, ''Ned and Jack'' was a spirited and touching, if small and unformed, work that brought its two quixotic heroes to life. In the Broadway version, the spark has dimmed.

title: TODD LEADS JETS OVER COLTS, 41-14
description: Was it only last September that others did to the Jets what the Jets did today to the Colts? The resurgent New Yorkers relentlessly hammered the dispirited Colts, 41-14, in a game of many dramas, major and minor. But for the Jets' fans, whose heroes have missed every playoff since 1969, this victory was especially important: It put the team over .500 with a 5-4-1 record. It was the Jets' fifth victory in their last seven games, including a tie.

title: Wendy Turnbull Captures Final
description: Top-seeded Wendy Turnbull of Australia won the Seiko Classic for the second year in a row with a 6-3, 6-0 victory over Sabina Simmonds of Italy today.

title: BOSTON UNIVERSITY HEAD MARKS 10 STORMY YEARS
description: When John R. Silber came up from Texas 10 years ago to become president of Boston University, the nation's fourth largest private university, he told the board of trustees that he had been called in very late. ''The patient is already on the operating table and could be moribund,'' the former philosophy professor warned at the time.

title: VIOLIN: MILSTEIN DISPLAYS VIRTUOSITY OF SIMPLICITY
description: IT is not a gift to be simple; it is an achievement. And simplicity was Nathan Milstein's accomplishment when he gave a recital in Carnegie Hall on Saturday night. The 77-year-old violinist did not need to impose any effect or rubato on the music; he did not resort to sentiment or nostalgia; he did not make the violin quiver with emotion; he even looked askance at what is called ''expression.'' No such temporal, earth-bound indulgence here.

title: THE BENEFITS OF PRIVATE AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: COST OF 100 B-1 BOMBERS FIGURED AT DOUBLE THE AIR FORCE ESTIMATE
description: The 100 B-1 bombers President Reagan wants to buy would cost $39.8 billion, Congressional analysts said today.

title: FIE, COMRADE NIKOLAEV
description: On Sept. 30, the Soviet weekly Literaturnaya Gazeta carried an article by one A. Nikolaev titled ''Riff-Raff Fair.'' A. Nikolaev's article described the Moscow Book Fair reception in exile, which was held in the New York Public Library at 42d Street and Fifth Avenue Sept. 14. One of the sponsors of the event, Robert Bernstein of Random House publishers, is a constant target of Literaturnaya Gazeta's attacks, since he is a founder of the American Helsinki Watch Committee. Comrade A. Nikolaev tells us that readers of the journal ''indignantly condemn'' Mr. Bernstein for his activities. One reader, in fact, a certain Vladimir Veselok of the desert coal-mining center of Ekibastuz, in Kazakhstan, has even proposed bringing suit against Bernstein for his ''unprecedented outrages'' against ''millions of honest people.''

title: KMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $77,000 tax credit...C-Net income including $268,000 tax credit; 1981 results include operations of Comsl Inc since May 4, 1981

title: U.S. Debt Slips Below Trillion
description: Two weeks after surging past the $1 trillion mark for the first time, the national debt has quietly slipped back into a mere 12 digits - about $998,782,000,000, Treasury Department officials said today. But the slippage is hardly the start of a trend, they said.

title: THE CELLAR HAS A BIRTHDAY
description: Fashions in food can be as fickle as those in clothes or manners, and during the last five years New Yorkers' preferences for fancy food have undergone major changes. Italian imports are acquiring the cachet formerly accorded only to French labels; fresh, bulk products now have more appeal than packaged goods, no matter how elaborate the wrapping, and consumers have become far more adventurous eaters.

title: Coal Terminal May Be Built
description: The Patrick Petroleum Corporation said that it would build a coal terminal in Hampton Roads, Va., the country's No.1 port for coal exports, if it could secure financing.

title: EDUCATION
description: ONLY a few years ago, Mark Uberman recalls, the primary aim of the social studies course in economics that he teaches at Norman Thomas High School in Manhattan was to prepare students to become discerning consumers.

title: Reagan News Session on TV
description: President Reagan will hold a nationally televised news conference today beginning at 2 P.M. It will be carried live by the CBS, NBC and ABC television networks and some radio stations.

title: U.S. SEIZES COCAINE IN WESTERN FLORIDA WORTH $36 MILLION
description: The United States Customs Service seized 500 pounds of cocaine last night from an airplane that landed on a deserted roadway in the Florida Panhandle after a four-hour, 400-mile chase off the coast.

title: SEIS PROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WILLIAMS LETTER URGES COLLEAGUES NOT TO EXPEL HIM FROM THE SENATE
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. sent a letter to all 99 of his colleagues today, urging them not to expel him on the ground that his Abscam bribery conviction was brought about by ''Government agent provocateurs.''

title: CONNECTICUT GENERAL, INA TO MERGE
description: The Connecticut General Corporation and the INA Corporation, two of the nation's most prominent insurers, said yesterday that they would merge into a new company named the North American General Corporation.

title: Sports of The Times; Patron Saint of the Sideline
description: WHEN he celebrated his 100th birthday, the football coach Amos Alonzo Stagg was asked how long he expected to live. ''Very few people die after 100,'' the sturdy, white-haired man said with a smile, ''so I guess now I'll live forever.'' Amos Alonzo Stagg died at 102 in 1965, but his memory is alive again. If Alabama defeats Penn State Saturday at University Park, Pa., the victory will be engraved as the 314th in Paul (Bear) Bryant's coaching career, tying the record established by Amos Alonzo Stagg, the patron saint of the sideline.

title: MUSIC: MOURA LYMPANY, FAMILIAR ENGLISH PIANIST
description: FOR a good proportion of the audience at Carnegie Hall last evening, Moura Lympany's appearance to begin her piano recital must have set the nostalgia glands to pumping. The English pianist, who made her American debut in 1948 and last played here 16 years ago, came of age artistically shortly before World War II, and in the years immediately afterward she caught the musical public's fancy both for her elegant playing and in particular for the records she made in the dawn of the high-fidelity phonograph age. In the dim light of memory, at least, Miss Lympany will never lose her stature as a significant artist.

title: QUEBEC, GENERAL DYNAMICS SET PACT ON ASBESTOS CONTROL
description: The Quebec government yesterday moved closer to its long-range goal of nationalizing the Montreal-based Asbestos Corporation Ltd. with an agreement to purchase voting control of the company from its American owner, the General Dynamics Corporation of St. Louis, for $16 million in Canadian currency.

title: SONESTA INTERNATIONAL HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
General Electric Computer Venture
description: The General Electric Company said that it was entering the computer-aided engineering field by acquiring 48 percent of the Structural Dynamics Research Corporation of Cincinnati for $9.1 million.

title: PLANNED DEER HUNT SPURS VOLLEYS OF PROTEST
description: Plans for a three-week deer-hunting season in the rustic hills of Harriman State Park - the first in the park's 70-year history - have encountered a lawsuit and a storm of protest from wildlife-preservation groups and local residents.

title: Billy Graham and All in the Family
description: Like many chief executives approaching retirement age, the 63-year-old head of the $30 million enterprise had been thinking about a successor, and in Houston over the weekend, the Rev. Billy Graham said he might have found just the man - his son, William Franklin Graham 3d.

title: Sayers' Treat TO SCIENCE TIMES:
description: As reported in your article ''Dorothy Sayers' Poison Is a Treat for Chemists'' (Oct. 13), Dorothy Sayers, in her book ''The Documents in the Case,'' did not, as she believed, commit a ''first-class howler.'' The structure of naturally occurring muscarine was proven by its synthesis in the 1950's.

title: N.A.A.C.P. PLEA ON BOYCOTT PENALTY FACES REVIEW
description: The Supreme Court set the stage today for an important constitutional test of the uses and consequences of organized boycotts as tools to achieve political and social change.

title: MATHEMATICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1980 revs restated

title: Wasowski Presents Schumann and Chopin
description: Seemingly a pianist who would rather delight the ear than dazzle it, Andrzej Wasowski devoted the bulk of his Carnegie Hall recital Sunday evening to a tour of the literature's more intimate regions, which he penetrated with uncommon skill and sensitivity. Featured on the first half of his program were the idyllic pages of Schumann's ''Kinderscenen,'' and on the second, two of Chopin's most delicate essays, the Barcarolle (Op. 60) and Berceuse (Op. 57).

title: SOUTH AFRICANS DOWN A MIG OVER ANGOLA 'IN SELF-DEFENSE'
description: South African Air Force fighters shot down an Angolan MIG-21, believed to have been piloted by Cubans, over Angolan territory on Friday, a spokesman for the Defense Forces acknowledged today.

title: KENTUCKY CENTRAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COURIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
SPACE SHUTTLE IS CLEARED FOR ANOTHER COUNTDOWN
description: THE power units that caused last week's mission-delaying problems for the space shuttle Columbia have been cleaned, filled with fresh oil and fitted with new filters. Their tanks have also been refilled with hydrazine fuel. Everything, therefore, appeared set for the countdown to resume at 8 A.M. today for launching the shuttle's second flight Thursday morning.

title: AERO-FLOW DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
21 Afghan Soldiers Defect to Pakistan
description: Twenty-one Afghan soldiers, including an army brigadier who said atrocities were being committed in his country, defected to Pakistan today, Pakistani government sources said.

title: MCM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRADY JOINS PRESIDENT AT REOPENING OF PRESS ROOM
description: James S. Brady, the President's press secretary, joined Ronald Reagan today at the ribbon-cutting for the redecorated press room in the West Wing of the White House. It was Mr. Brady's first prolonged public appearance since he was wounded in the assassination attempt against the President last March.

title: BRASCAN LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is also listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges

title: Oct. 31 Car Inventories A Record
description: Inventories of United States automobile makers, swollen by stiffening consumer resistance to higher prices, surged to a 1,480,600-car, 81-day supply on Oct. 31, a record for that date, an industry journal said today.

title: City Opera Presents 'La Clemenza di Tito'
description: The black sheep of Mozart's mature stage works has long been ''La Clemenza di Tito,'' written in 1791 for the coronation of the Hapsburg emperor, Leopold II, as King of Bohemia. Based on Caterino Mazzola's reworking of what was by then an antiquated libretto by Metastasio, and composed with purposeful allusions to archaic style, among which is the use of high tessitura in two of the male roles, the piece is, all in all, a curious throwback to opera seria that can strike modern listeners as breathtakingly static.

title: TENNEY ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1980 shr earnings reflect 4-for-3 stock split paid June 19, 1981

title: Not a Nice Day
description: Cliff Stoudt, Pittsburgh's second-string quarterback, broke his right arm at a Seattle restaurant after the Steelers' 24-21 loss to the Seahawks and will be out indefinitely, possibly for the rest of the season. A team spokesman first said that Stoudt suffered the injury on a mechanical horse, adding that the jerking motion of the machine snapped the right ulna, the bone between the wrist and the elbow.

title: A PUZZLEMENT OVER A BAKERY RUMOR
description: At the Star Market in Porter Square, where Harvard and Tufts students shop the bakery shelves alongside the working class customers of Cambridge, Blanche Ahern noticed that sales of the fancy cakes and pastries made by Entenmann's were slowing.

title: Pan Am Realigns Top Management
description: Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it had realigned its top management in order to conform with its present structure as an airline, rather than a holding company.

title: 14TH GAME IS ADJOURNED WITH KARPOV WINNING
description: Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, the world chess champion, adjourned the 14th game of his title match here in a winning position against the challenger, Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland.

title: Advertising; Iacocca's Ideas for Budget Aid
description: Lee A. Iacocca, chairman and chief executive officer of the Chrysler Corporation, called today for a short-term Federal Government surcharge on gasoline as a way of balancing the budget.

title: BEEHIVE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $313,473 tax credit

title: Nuclear Panel to Discuss Steps on Coast Reactor
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission agreed today to discuss possible actions that it might take against the operator of the troubled Diablo Canyon power plant in California. However, it held off ordering specific studies that are expected before the plant can be licensed to generate power.

title: Talking Business with Schmiedeskamp of Gallup; Reagan Policy: Public's View
description: A large part of the success of the Reagan economic program depends on how the American public responds to it. With the economy declining, the public's response in recent surveys has been less enthusiastic than it was just months ago. Indeed, Jay Schmiedeskamp, director of economic surveys for the Gallup Organization, believes that the public could turn against the President very quickly. Mr. Schmiedeskamp, an economist, is concerned that people will save more but spend less, leaving a stagnant economy without means for recovery.

title: PETROLANE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1980 shrs earnings and shrs outstndg restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in Mar 1981

title: MCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $12,275,000 or 52 cents a shr extraordinary income

title: SUPREME COURT WILL DECIDE CASE ON BANKRUPTCY TRIBUNALS
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the new Federal bankruptcy courts that Congress established under the Bankruptcy Reform Act are constitutional.

title: GENERAL GROWTH PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The yr-ago results include operating results for 6 mos from ten shopping centers which were sold Mar 31, 1980 for $69,462,000

title: Costly Fight
description: The National Basketball Association imposed a total of $2,750 in fines against the guards Calvin Murphy of the Houston Rockets and Norm Nixon of the Los Angeles Lakers for their fight in the clubs' opener on Oct. 30. Joe Axelson, a league vice president, reported Murphy's fine was $1,750 and Nixon's $1,000. The fight occurred while Murphy and Nixon were away from the ball under the Rocket basket.

title: SEARS ROEBUCK ACCEPTANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cadet Is Suspended
description: A senior cadet at Texas A & M was suspended today for the remainder of the fall semester for brandishing his saber threateningly at a Southern Methodist cheerleader during a football game. Greg Hood, the cadet, emerged from a 3 1/2-hour hearing and said that he had been suspended for the remainder of the semester. The incident occurred Oct. 31 when S.M.U.'s male cheerleaders ran onto the Astroturf at Kyle Field after their team scored a touchdown.

title: LEVESQUE ASSAILS CONSTITUTION ACCORD
