description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $208,000 for the qr and $905,000 for the 9 mos...C-After losses of $3,618,00 from discontinued operations and $8,987,000 from divestiture of magazine and film operations and $8,841,000 gain on the sale of investment in Western Broadcasting; shr earnings reflect 3-for- stock split last Dec

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Aluminum Company of America's $300 million of new seven percent, 15-year debentures were tentatively priced for offering at 53.864 to yield 14.70 percent. The bonds will be sold through a group of underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: MR. TIMERMAN'S REPLY
description: To the Editor:

title: BOARD TO GIVE CRIME VICTIM $20,000
description: ''Well, it doesn't make me rich,'' Robert Barrett said yesterday. Then again, the former bank manager from Brooklyn added, he feels better that he is getting the money and that it is not going to the man he considers responsible for his troubles.

title: WINE TALK
description: IT is vintage time in the vineyards of the Northern Hemisphere, the period when the grapes have just been harvested and their juice is bubbling and gurgling in the fermentation that will result in wine. It is also the time when the first evaluations of the current vintage are made and when decisions are reached about restocking the cellar or simply accumulating a supply for the fall and winter seasons.

title: CENTRONICS DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
PHILIP MORRIS AND THE ARTS
description: In recent months Philip Morris Inc. helped bring an Edward Hopper exhibition to the Whitney Museum of American Art and a show on German Expressionism to the Guggenheim Museum. Next year it will help bring works by Kandinsky to the Guggenheim and manuscripts of Lewis Carroll to the Morgan Library.

title: Yvonne de C. Richardson Wed to Robert L. Edgell
description: Yvonne de Clairmont Richardson and Robert Louis Edgell were married yesterday at Calvary Presbyterian Church in San Francisco.

title: WHY PALESTINIANS ARE NOT HOMELESS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE STAGE: 'OH, BROTHER!,' A MUSICAL
description: ''OH, BROTHER!,'' the new musical at the ANTA, desperately wants to be ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum.'' It also wouldn't mind being ''The Boys From Syracuse,'' the musical version of ''Two Gentlemen of Verona'' or maybe even ''Milk and Honey.'' In the end - or, for that matter, in the beginning - it has to settle for being a spectacularly silly Las Vegas floor show. But ''Oh, Brother!'' tries. Oh, brother, does it try.

title: OLD WINES WILL BE AUCTIONED IN CHICAGO
description: One of the nation's most valuable collections of old wines will be sold next Tuesday in Chicago, when Sotheby Parke Bernet auctions off the 6,000-bottle inventory of Vintage Imports Inc., a wholesaler based in Miami that is going out of business. In recent years the company has been one of the few purveyors of old wines.

title: Interest-Sensitive Issues Rise; Dow Off
description: The stock market spotlight continued to focus yesterday on interest-sensitive issues and possible takeover candidates, with a small gain over all.

title: Court Declares Church Subject to Trust Laws
description: A Federal appeals court, ruling in a case involving Roman Catholic reading materials, declared today that religious groups were not automatically exempt from antitrust laws.

title: New Property-Tax Bill Is Criticized by Carey
description: In his strongest public statement since the Legislature approved a bill revising the state's property-tax assessment system, Governor Carey said yesterday that he would not ''settle for a real-propertytax reform that ducks the issues involved and sloughs the problems off to local governments.''

title: PRODUCERS' PRICES CONTINUE TO SHOW INFLATION SLOWING
description: Three indexes that measure prices at various levels of production indicated a continued easing of inflation during October.

title: Grand Union Told To Sell Colonial Inc.
description: The Grand Union Company, a supermarket chain based in Elmwood Park, N.J., must sell Colonial Stores Inc., a chain it acquired in 1978 for about $114 million, because the merger hurt competition in the retail food industry in parts of the Southeast, a Federal Trade Commission administrative law judge ruled yesterday.

title: NICKLOS OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Flames Trade Vail
description: Eric Vail, a left wing who was the National Hockey League's rookie of the year in 1974-1975, was traded to Detroit by the Calgary Flames yesterday for the right wing Gary McAdam and a fourth-round choice in each of the next two drafts. Vail, who reportedly feuded with Coach Al MacNeil, had been sent to the minors by the Flames, but he is expected to play for the Red Wings at Chicago tonight. ... The N.H.L. fined Dale Hunter of Quebec $500 and Mark Hardy of Los Angeles $300 for an incident two weeks ago in which they swung their sticks at each other.

title: CAREY CITES FUND LIMITS ON EXPANDING PRISONS
description: Governor Carey, reacting to the apparent defeat of the $500 million prison bond issue, said yesterday that the state could not use operating funds for prison expansion.

title: Rockwell Receives 144 U.S. Contracts
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said that it received 144 Federal contracts totaling more than $436 million in the five-week period ended Oct. 30. Among the contracts were awards from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the Air Force and the Army.

title: Rail Rates Under Fire
description: Deregulation of the nation's railroads is having a disastrous effect on coal companies and other bulk shippers forced to pay higher rates, industry representatives told Congress today.

title: Del Webb Sale Of Units Studied
description: The Del Webb Corporation, which has $200 million in debt, has approached Hilton Hotel officials about selling Del Webb's Sahara hotels in Reno and Las Vegas, a Hilton official said.

title: CENCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Madagascar Reports Peace After 2 Days of Civil Disorder
description: Security forces have restored order in Madagascar's capital after two days of looting and vandalism, Radio Madagascar reported today.

title: JACLYN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DIM OUTLOOK FOR RETAIL SALES
description: The lackluster pace of retail sales in October and expectations of sharply lower third-quarter earnings for the nation's big chain stores are leading to some unusually pessimistic forecasts for the coming Christmas season.

title: INTERNATIONAL ALUMINUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DANCE: ED DI LELLO'S GROUP
description: THEY danced. They sang. They played musical instruments. But most of all the members of the Ed Di Lello Group asked esthetic questions. Mr. Di Lello is both a choreographer and a composer, and his Monday night program at the Merce Cunningham Studio explored relationships between dance and music.

title: Mets Appoint Frey As Batting Coach
description: A year ago he was smarting from a six-game World Series defeat as manager of the Kansas City Royals. Yesterday he was at Shea Stadium getting ready to try to teach the Mets how to hit.

title: DOYLE DANE BERNBACH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'82 Rise Seen In Home Sales
description: Sales of existing homes will jump 20 percent in 1982, to 2,875,000 units, as mortgage rates fall below 14 percent, according to a forecast being released today by Multi-List McGraw-Hill. It also predicts that the average home selling price will increase 7 percent, to $84,100, from $78,400 this year.

title: TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PHOTOGRAPHIC SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $31,620 tax benefit

title: Index; International
description: Soviet says Swedish has elec- tronic listening post A3 China taunts Soviet over strand- ing of submarine A3 Industrial unrest continues in Po- land A3 Around the World A5 Top Afghan military officials said to study in Moscow A8 Gulf states main challenge Oman's role in U.S. maneuvers A9 Libya is opposing Saudi peace proposals A10 West Bank university, closed by Israel, starts drive to reopen A11 Egyptian aide says nation's poli- cies have not changed A12 Tunisia reported worried over fundamentalist gains A13 Government/Politics Miami's mayor gains black sup- port to win re-election in runoff A16 Officials warn cutbacks are harming public housing in U.S. A29 VETERANS DAY Today is Veterans Day. Following are holiday schedules: Parade - Begins 10 A.M., Fifth Avenue and 39th Street; moves south to 24th Street; ends at noon. Parking - Alternate-side regulations suspended; all other rules in effect. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Federal, state and municipal offices -Closed. Post offices - Closed; only special delivery and express mail delivered. Banks - Closing optional in New York; banks closed in Connecticut and New Jersey. Stock and commodity markets -Open. Transportation - Regular schedules. Libraries - Closed. Schools - Closed.

title: THE '84 FEVER CLAIMED FIRST VICTIMS
description: It is a disease that can strike early. When it does, its devastated victims often go into strange public paroxysms.

title: DEWEY ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GULF RESOURCES & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $1.1 million income for the qr and $8.3 million loss for 9 mos from discontinued operations and $82.2 million loss for the qr and 9 mos from the closure of the Bunker Hill Co unit...C-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $7 million for the qr and $16.1 million for the 9 mos; yr-ago results have been restated

title: PUPILS' PARENTS URGED TO FILL IN FORM ON LUNCH
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy yesterday joined the New York City Board of Education in urging parents to complete new and far more detailed applications to determine whether their children are eligible for free or reduced-cost school lunches.

title: A LES BLANK TRIO, FROM GARLIC TO TATTOOS
description: LES BLANK, known mainly for his films about regional music and musicians, continues to discover America in three delightful short films that open today at the Film Forum - ''Garlic Is Good as 10 Mothers'' (51 minutes), a cinematic song in praise of the glories of garlic; ''Werner Herzog Eats His Shoe'' (20 minutes), in which the noted West German film maker (''Aguirre, the Wrath of God'' and ''Stroszek,'' among others), eats his shoe, lovingly cooked beforehand, and ''Stoney Knows How'' (30 minutes), a portrait of Leonard St. Clair, nicknamed Stoney, a paraplegic dwarf, a carnival sword-swallower as a child and best known as a tattoo artist.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: In the summer of 1965, when Richard Shapiro was 10 years old, Mark Neston was a baby, James Walsh was 20 and Mick Jagger was pushing 23, the No. 1 song in America was a single by the Rolling Stones entitled ''(I can't get no) Satisfaction.''

title: BLASIUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Net loss after $614,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: BRIEFING
description: A FTER dealing with Cabinet-level fractiousness last week, President Reagan has turned to the less melodramatic but, some emphasize, no less important problem of the morale of key sub-Cabinet officials. These are the ranking Deputy and Assistant Secretaries who must carry out policy changes without benefit of ego-soothing publicity. The President met privately Monday with 200 sub-Cabinet workers, gave them a pep talk, and posed for pictures with them.

title: ENSOURCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-The company is less than a yr old so no comparable figures for the 1980 are available

title: Doyle Dane Bernbach Posts 16% Profit Rise
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach International yesterday announced record third-quarter results. Net income rose 16 percent, to $764,000, or 14 cents a share, up from $656,000, or 12 cents a share, in the comparable 1980 period.

title: Boy Killed, Brother Wounded; Police Accuse Their Mother
description: A Bronx woman fatally stabbed her 6-year-old son and seriously wounded his older brother last night because she feared the the city's child welfare agency was going to take them away, the police reported.

title: MIAMI MAYOR RUNOFF WITH STRONG BLACK SUPPORT
description: Black voters went to the polls in record numbers here today to keep a black representative on the City Commission and to defeat the most formidable mayoral candidate the Latin community has ever put forth.

title: AND THE REICH GOES ON
description: To children of the 1930's World War I, though it had ended only 15 or 20 years earlier, already belonged to ancient history. I marveled that my parents had been alive when it was fought. It made them seem very, very old.

title: Playboy's Net Down 19.1%
description: Citing a decline in profit of its gaming operations, Playboy Enterprises said today that its net earnings for the first quarter of the 1982 fiscal year fell 19.1 percent, a drop of more than $1.2 million from the same period a year ago.

title: POLYSAR LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Careers; Mobile Technical Training
description: VISUALIZE two giant trailers parked side by side at the campus of a technical college in South Carolina, with double doors flung open to provide more space. Inside are large, highly complex machines - possibly robots, lathes or micro-electronic devices.

title: TV SWEEPS: TIME TO BREAK OUT THE STEAMY SHOWS
description: THIS is the month when commercial television puts aside any loftier intentions and gets down to its real business: News Analysis delivering the largest possible audience to advertisers. Out go any pretenses that prime-time television is an artistic forum or that local newscasts conscientiously deliver the news. Suddenly, made-for-television movies and the endless ''investigative'' series and ''special reports'' on local newscasts often seem indistinguishable - the serious moments buried in a blur of sex and crime, the high life and the low lifes, pestilence and resurrection.

title: U.S. Says Food Agency Must Tighten Belt
description: The United States said today that the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization must hold down its spending and reduce administrative costs in line with other international agencies.

title: JULIET LIT STERN
description: Juliet Lit Stern, a newspaperwoman, died Monday at her home in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Advertising; Combating Generic Brands
description: Some supermarket operators, believing that their best opportunity for profits lies with branded products, have proposed that the manufacturers defend their brands with a variety of promotions, but not necessarily with advertising.

title: 20 COUNTY TALLIES CERTIFIED
description: With the latest count giving him a lead of 1,677 votes, Thomas H. Kean, the Republican candidate for Governor of New Jersey, claimed victory today over Representative James J. Florio, his Democratic opponent.

title: Economic Scene; A Steep Slide Into Recession
description: THE economy is sliding into what could become the worst recession of the postwar period. Unemployment in September climbed to a seasonally adjusted 8 percent of the labor force, and is likely to go on rising well into 1982. Since the steep part of the slide has just begun, it is conceivable that the jobless rate could get up above 10 percent before the recession is over.

title: LIEBERT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Loomis to Leave S.E.C.  In the Next Six Months
description: It was in 1954 that Philip A. Loomis Jr. took a temporary job as a consultant at the Securities and Exchange Commission. He became so interested in the work there, however, that he stayed on, moving from consultant to director of trading to general counsel, and finally, in 1971, to commissioner.

title: VAGABOND HOTELS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HELMERICH & PAYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1980 shr earnings adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid Oct 14, 1980

title: Poison Toll in Spain Is 187
description: Poisoned cooking oil in Spain claimed two more victims today, raising the death toll to 187 since the first death six months ago. The Health Ministry said a 52-year-old woman died in Leon in central Spain and a 16-year-old boy died in Madrid from rapeseed oil imported for industrial use, illegally treated for human consumption and sold illegally on the streets as cooking oil.

title: HOUSING OFFICIALS FEAR HARM FROM CUTBACKS
description: Housing officials from around the country warned today that public housing units were falling into disrepair and would deteriorate rapidly because of reductions being made in Federal housing subsidies.

title: NEIL BOGART SEES VITAL NEW BEAT IN '84
description: RINGO STARR'S new album is on the relatively new Boardwalk label, which was started by Neil Bogart. Mr. Bogart was the founder of Casablanca Records, the company that made Donna Summer one of the brightest pop stars of the 70's and did more to make disco an international phenomenon than any other label. Before that, in the late 60's, he was president of Buddah Records and the man responsible for unleashing Bubblegum pop (the sugary, mindless stuff purveyed by Buddah groups like the Ohio Express and the 1910 Fruitgum Company) on American teen-agers.

title: Blues 7, Flames 0
description: Mike Liut stopped 33 shots as St. Louis crushed Calgary. The shutout was the first of the season for Liut, a 25-year-old goaltender, and the Blues won their first road game of the season after five losses and two ties.

title: TO KEEP MIDEAST SURVEILLANCE EVENHANDED
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMISSION FORMALLY REJECTS 71ST. TOWER
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission formally rejected yesterday a proposal to build a 15-story tower near the corner of 71st Street and Madison Avenue in the heart of the Upper East Side Historic District. The vote was 6 to 5.

title: MOR-FLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Giants' Clack Clears Waivers
description: Jim Clack, called out of retirement yesterday by the Giants, cleared waivers today and will start practicing tomorrow.

title: Kaiser to Add Stock of Filtrol
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the stock of a restructured Filtrol Corporation for about $92 million.

title: Houseman Wins Award for Work in Theater
description: A veteran man-about-the-theater, John Houseman, will receive the second annual John F. Wharton Theater Award on Dec. 3. Mr. Houseman, who has spent nearly half a century in the theater in such diverse roles as actor, producer, director, playwright and teacher, will be honored in recognition of his ''creative contributions to the producing of theater.''

title: HONORING VETERANS OF WAR, AND ANTI-WAR
description: To the Editor:

description: Shr earnings figures are per partnership unit

title: MERCURY DROPS, COMPLAINTS RISE ON LACK OF HEAT
description: The heat emergency number to call with complaints is 960-4800. The number may be called at any hour. By LEE A. DANIELS

title: HANDY & HARMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Aid Official in Honduras Escapes From 2 Kidnappers
description: A United States aid official was kidnapped by two armed men in Honduras today but escaped seven hours later when they were involved in a car crash, the police said.

title: TEXAS OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
APPLIED POWER INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
'A VERY HAPPY GROUP' IN THE REAGAN FOLD
description: In the fifth news conference of his nearly 10 months in the White House, President Reagan defended his foreign policy and made some astonishing remarks:

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON KEEPING PEANUT SUPPORTS
description: The South rose again today and managed to salvage vital parts of Government subsidies and controls on peanuts. After nearly two hours of dispute over the peanut section of a new four-year farm bill, House and Senate conferees agreed to abolish planting restrictions on peanuts but to retain limits on how much of the crop may be sold for domestic use. The compromise would also require the Agriculture Secretary to raise the Government price support loan level on the 1982 peanut crop by about 25 percent, to $580 a ton from $455.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GUEST SHOT

title: Warning Labels Ordered On California Drugs
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. has ordered that drugs sold over the counter next year bear labels warning pregnant women and nursing mothers to consult a physician or pharmacist before using the product.

title: DIONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $59,100 for the qr and $181,600 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss; yr-ago shrs outstndg have been restated to show the effect of a 5-for-4 stock split, effective June 29, 1981

title: MARATHON GETS FUNDS FOR FIGHT
description: In a move to give itself more flexibility in fighting off the Mobil Corporation's takeover bid, the Marathon Oil Company said yesterday that a $5 billion bank credit arranged last summer had been modified to enable the company to purchase up to $2 billion of its own stock.

title: U.S. Beats South Korea
description: Chris Evert Lloyd and Andrea Jaeger led the United States to a 3-0 victory over South Korea today in the opening round of the 32-nation Federation Cup tennis championship.

title: WASHINGTON FOLLOW-UP; Priesthood for Women
description: Sister Mary Theresa Kane is still waiting for what she once called ''further dialogue with the Holy Father'' over the issue of priesthood for women.

title: U.S. FINDS CHEMICAL WARFARE TOXINS IN INDOCHINA
description: The State Department said today that it had evidence, in the form of new samples of rocks, leaves and water from Southeast Asia, that chemical warfare agents had been used in Cambodia and Laos.

title: PENTRON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV: VIETNAM VETERAN RECOUNTS HIS TRAVAILS
description: ''THE Vietnam Veteran: A Matter of Life and Death,'' a two-hour Veterans Day special packaged by Boston station WGBH and being carried on WNET-TV tonight at 9, got a publicity boost recently when the national offices of the Veterans of Foreign Wars and the American Legion publicly protested the inclusion of one segment. ''Frank: A Portrait of a Vietnam Veteran,'' a documentary by Fred Simon, had already been shown in the Boston area and elicited what Lawrence K. Grossman, president of the Public Broadcasting Service, called ''an extraordinarily positive viewer response.'' However, the veterans' organizations found the portrayal of Frank to be entirely negative and, in the words of one letter, ''potentially damaging.''

title: CLASSIFIED FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
First, End the Recession
description: President Reagan was quick to admit that recession is upon us. Why is he so slow to abandon policies that will prolong it?

title: FEAR OF ELDERLY ABOUT CRIME FOUND EXAGGERATED
description: The fears of older people that they are more likely than other people to become victims of crime are not supported by national statistics, a study commissioned by the Department of Justice reported today.

title: DORSEY RICHARDSON, ADVISER TO 2 PRESIDENTS ON ECONOMY
description: Dorsey Richardson, a retired investment banker and former State Department official, died Sunday at the Merwick unit of the Medical Center of Princeton, N.J. He was 85 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: INDIA TAKES A LOOK AT ITSELF AND FINDS A BRIGHT SIDE
description: The Government poster being circulated to Indian missions abroad carries the caption ''India among the nations of the world'' and goes on to proclaim proudly that this country is ''among the 10 most industrialized nations, among the only seven countries which have launched their own earth satellites, and among the three countries which have the world's largest pools of technically trained manpower.''

title: CLARA STERN
description: Clara Stern, a civic leader in Bridgeport, Conn., and a sister of Golda Meir, the late Israeli Prime Minister, died Monday of a heart attack at her home in Bridgeport.

title: AFGHAN MILITARY AIDES SAID TO STUDY IN SOVIET
description: A Western diplomat here said today that four officials of the Afghan Defense Ministry were attending a military training course in Moscow while the Moslem insurgency in Afghanistan continued unabated.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of New York has elected Raymond G. Hart Jr. and Rochelle Siegel vice presidents.

title: ACME-CLEVELAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE RIGHT PLACE TO GO IN MISSISSIPPI
description: During my recent visit to Mississippi I ate in what might be the best catfish restaurant in the state and therefore, the nation. Called the Cock of the Walk, it is in Madison, a suburb of Jackson, the state capital, about a half-hour drive from the heart of Jackson.

title: BIRD OF MYTH REPORTED SEEN
description: While walking through a tangle of fallen trees and vines in the mountains of New Guinea, the ornithologist Jared Diamond says, he heard a strange birdcall, a sound like someone shoveling gravel. He suspected at once that he might be hearing a rare bird known for decades to exist but never before seen by any scientist.

title: United Brands May Sell A &W
description: The United Brands Company announced that it was negotiating the sale of its A & W Restaurants subsidiary to a corporation headed by Alfred Taubman, one of its company directors.

title: Lockheed Corp.'s Tristar Review
description: The chairman of the Lockheed Corporation, Roy Anderson, said the company was not near a decision on whether to scrap its costly L-1011 Tristar commercial airliner project.

title: PINIELLA, 38, GIVEN A 3-YEAR CONTRACT
description: George Steinbrenner, who generally gets his man, tied up Lou Piniella yesterday, but he was not prepared to do the same with Reggie Jackson before Friday's free agent draft.

title: ATLAS VAN LINES INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary gain of $1,322,484 from the writeoff of operating rights

title: Lawyer for Accused Spy Quickly Rests His Case
description: The attorney for an accused Polish spy charged with conspiring to sell American military secrets to the Communists rested his case today without calling a single witness.

title: RUTGERS SENIOR PRESSES FIGHT TO ABOLISH MANDATORY FEE TO ADVOCACY GROUP
description: When Joseph P. Galda, a member of the conservative Young Americans for Freedom and of Consumer Alert, enrolled as a Rutgers University freshman here, he was appalled to learn that mandatory fees include $2.50 a semester to support the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group.

title: Comings and Goings
description: James Tulley of Rockford, Ill., was so disenchanted with the Chicago Bears after a 24-7 loss to Washington early in the season that he sued the club for $58 - the cost of tickets, gasoline, tolls and a babysitter - on the ground that the Bears had misrepresented themselves as a professional team. But Judge Craig Peterson observed that fumbles and intercepted passes did not qualify as misrepresentation.

title: Westway Is Among Golden Fleece Winners
description: For his November Golden Fleece Award for the waste and mismanagement of taxpayer money, Senator William Proxmire yesterday chose the Federal Highway Administration and two of its programs, the Westway in New York City and the Glenwood Canyon project in Colorado.

title: Tin Prices Reach Record
description: The price of tin reached a record in London today as dealers speculated that a mystery buyer of large quantities of the metal would stay in the market.

title: GARFINKEL CHIEF RESIGNS HIS POSITION
description: As expected, David R. Waters, chairman and chief executive officer of Garfinckel, Brooks Brothers, Miller & Rhoads Inc., has resigned. The action came yesterday as the Allied Stores Corporation, which had acquired 92 percent of the Washington-based Garfinckel, completed the purchase following a vote of Garfinckel's stockholders.

title: President Asks Press to Reflect
description: President Reagan has suggested for the second time in a week that reporters consider whether news reports critical of his Administration are going to help or hinder its foreign policy efforts.

title: SMD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: B-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $225,752 for the qr and $558,481 for the 6 mos

title: QUEBEC ASBESTOS BID SPURS INVESTOR STOCK SALES
description: Investors rushed to sell their shares of the Asbestos Corporation today after an announcement that the Quebec government would assume effective control of the company under an agreement with the majority shareholder, the General Dynamics Corporation.

title: KEARNEY-NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said that figures for the 1981 third qr and 9 mos include results of Wabash Inc acquired in Jan 1981

title: If Queens Gets 107 Channels ...
description: It doesn't always pay to be first. As Tony Schwartz explained in the Arts and Leisure section Sunday, cable TV companies are now bidding for the right to wire every town with a zip code. People in Pittsburgh, Cincinnati and Boston are offered scores of channels for pennies a day. Yet Manhattan, one of the first big urban areas to get cable, is stuck with third-rate service and premium prices.

title: CATFISH, LONG A SOUTHERN DELICACY, BRANCHES OUT
description: LIKE most Southerners I adore catfish. I remember that half a century and more ago my family would drive to the banks of Four Mile Lake near here and unload a picnic hamper. Gliding about on the water were small pleasure boats, many of whose passengers dangled fishing lines from cane poles, hoping a catfish would nibble.

title: Williams Has a Price
description: Dick Williams, who has won three division championships and two World Series in 14 seasons, said that he had received job offers as manager from four major league teams but that his choice was the San Diego Padres. ''If they want me,'' he said, ''if they feel I haven't overpriced myself, I'll come.''

title: Handy & Harman Net
description: Handy & Harman, Inc., a New York-based processor and marketer of precious metals, reported yesterday that it earned $5.6 million, or 41 cents a share, in the third quarter, up 2.7 percent from $5.5 million, or 40 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues fell 6.9 percent, to $149.3 million, from $160.4 million last year. The concern's president, Richard M. Daniel, said depressed prices of silver and gold compared with a year ago were the main causes of the weak sales.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Brooke Shields Loses Case A New York judge ruled against Brooke Shields yesterday in her fight to block further distribution of nude photographs she posed for when she was 10 years old.

title: FAMILY DOLLAR STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Oct 15

title: Hawks 94, Bucks 83
description: ATLANTA (AP) - Three baskets by Rory Sparrow in the final 63 seconds of the third period broke a tie and sent Atlanta on to victory.

title: DID RINGO STARR ALONE ESCAPE TRAP OF BEATLES?
description: RINGO STARR'S most recent album was released two and one half years ago, but the world has not exactly been holding its breath waiting for the follow-up. Saying so isn't a slight on Mr. Starr's talents; in fact, it could be construed as a compliment. He was the only Beatle who remained immune to the expectations of cosmic significance that were hung like millstones on the other three. At times, especially when John Lennon grew snappish and tired of living the Myth, Ringo seemed to be the only Beatle who had held on to his sense of humor. He certainly was the only one who could get away with singing cheerful nonsense songs of no great consequence; when the others tried it, they were accused of selling out. Ringo was free to be a pop star, pure and simple, and to exercise his comic talents in a series of film roles. Of all the Beatles, only Ringo translated the exceptionally promising notices the group got for its film debut into a continuing acting career.

title: King Hussein and Queen Noor In Texas Hospital for Checkup
description: HOUSTON. Nov. 10 (AP) - King Hussein of Jordan has checked into Methodist Hospital for a physical examination by Dr. Michael E. DeBakey, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: MORTON SHOE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: B-After $687,541 loss from discontinued operations

title: WHEN LAST A PRISON CONSTRUCTION PROPOSAL WAS DEFEATED
description: To the Editor:

title: 76ers 95, Pistons 93
description: Julius Erving scored 28 points and put in the game-winning basket with 37 seconds left. Detroit had tied the game at 93-93 with 50 seconds remaining after scoring 6 straight points, 4 of them by the rookie Isiah Thomas. Philadelphia then set up Erving, who hit a jumper from the foul line.

title: GEOSOURCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes after-tax gain of $721,000 or 5 cents a shr relating to discontinued product lines...C-Includes an after-tax gain of $2,137,000 or 15 cents a shr; the 1980 figures restated to include operations of companies acquired during 1981 on a pooling of interest basis

title: LINDAL CEDAR HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $60,000 for the qr and $110,450 for the 9 mos...C-Net income

title: ELEMENTARY PUPILS LEARN ILLS OF ALCOHOL
description: Extremely encouraging results have been reported from a pilot program aimed at teaching elementary school pupils the dangers of alcohol.

title: LIBYA TRIES TO PREVENT CONSENSUS FAVORING SAUDI'S PEACE PROPOSALS
description: Libya is trying to prevent the development of an Arab consensus in favor of a Saudi Arabian plan for a Middle East peace settlement.

title: The Sakharovs Plan A Hunger Strike
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and human rights leader exiled to the city of Gorky, and his wife, Yelena Bonner, are planning to start a hunger strike on Nov. 22 to press for the emigration of a young woman engaged to marry Miss Bonner's son, friends of the family said today.

title: VICON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Panasonic Offers Hand Computer
description: Panasonic, the consumer electronics unit of Japan's giant Matsushita Electric Industrial Company Ltd., introduced a hand-held computer that the company said could be packed into a briefcase.

title: Life in the Minors: Dreams and Despair
description: With the Rangers showing a bit of improvement recently but still struggling to hit their stride under Coach Herb Brooks, some attention is being focused on the Springfield Indians, the Rangers' new affiliate in the American Hockey League.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1. A Dancer's Fashion

title: THE U.S. AND VIETNAM
description: The United States should stop trying to overthrow the regime that Vietnam installed in Cambodia, and focus its policy on a more important American interest: reversing the increasing Soviet military presence in Vietnam. The policy of supporting China's military pressure on Vietnam and its arming of anti-Vietnamese forces in Cambodia, and the economic and diplomatic isolation of Vietnam, is not working. The only winners are Moscow and Peking, each of which exploits the conflict in Indochina to become more deeply involved in Southeast Asia.

title: OWNERS OPTIMISTIC ABOUT MOVIE THEATERS' FUTURE
description: The 1981 convention of the National Association of Theater Owners opened here today in an atmosphere of surprising optimism about the future of movie theaters. There was also an unusual semblance of peace between the makers of movies and the exhibitors, who are their principal customers.

title: SITARIST: MAHMUD MIRZA, UNACCOMPANIED
description: SOME music reaches out to humanity at large; other music is by its very nature refined, aristocratic, even hermetic. Mahmud Mirza, a sitarist from New Delhi who appears often in London but who had not given a recital in a major New York hall since 1971, appeared Monday night at the Abraham Goodman House and offered a musical experience that was most definitely on the refined end of the spectrum.

title: Protest Planned in Bonn
description: The Christian Democratic Union, West Germany's major opposition party, called on its members today to demonstrate ''for peace and human rights'' on Nov. 22, the day Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, arrives here for an official visit.

title: FARMERS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Blazers 117, Mavericks 95
description: Portland, the only unbeaten team in the league, improved its record to 7-0.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Anatole Broyard THE ALLEYS OF EDEN. By Robert Olen Butler. 256 pages. Horizon Press. $12.95.

title: The Communist Party's ruling
description: Politburo endorsed a plan today by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the party leader, to include the Solidarity union in a new Communist-run popular-front organization to be known as the Front of National Accord.

title: ECONOMIC GROWTH'S ILLUSIONS
description: As recent squabbles within the Administration illustrate, the Republican Party is being torn apart by the same conundrum that destroyed the Democrats under Jimmy Carter: a futile quest for economic growth in an economy that can no longer provide it.

title: BOWL AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
SCIENCE MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes foreign tax benefits of $21,000 for the qr and $88,000 for the 9 mos

title: INTERNATIONAL PROTEINS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1980 figures reclassified to conform with yr-end presentation

title: Bridge: Neutral Signals Are Useful If a Partner Gets Message
description: Some subtle possibilities are available to the defenders in making their first discard. There are obvious ways to show enthusiasm or lack of it for a particular suit, but it is also possible in some cases to give a neutral signal and allow partner to work out the reason for this message.

title: TAX RULES ON LEASING AMENDED
description: The Treasury Department today amended its regulations governing the sale of corporate tax benefits so that companies in need of cash, such as the Chrysler Corporation, may sell the benefits from new investment to profitable companies that can use the benefits.

title: INNOVATIVE DIRECTOR OF 'NAPOLEON'
description: Abel Gance, the cinematic pioneer whose 1927 classic ''Napoleon'' is still acclaimed by audiences around the world, died tonight at his Paris apartment, friends of the family reported. He was 92.

title: HIGHER COSTS TAKING A TOLL ON 2 FAMILIES
description: The Roses and Kusulases live next door to each other in Woodside, Queens, in compact apartments that would be identical except that the room layouts are reversed and the furnishings reflect the contrasting tastes and priorities of different generations.

title: People
description: * Bruce Meyers elected a senior vice president of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn Inc.

title: THEIR SHINING EARLY HOURS
description: DAWN breaks in New York, and zzzzzzzzz - most people are still sleeping. And they will probably stay snuggled under the covers until the alarm clock rings, when they leap out of bed and start the mad dash to the office. To them the early-morning hours are not to be savored; they are to be slept through.

title: MONDALE CALLS FOR DEFERRING 1982-83 TAX CUTS
description: In a wide-ranging criticism of President Reagan's economic policies, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale said yesterday that the Administration should defer part of its scheduled cuts in personal income tax in 1982 and 1983, an action that he said would enable the Federal Reserve Board to push down interest rates.

title: New Strike At BL Ltd.
description: A week after the end of a strike over pay that threatened to close state-owned BL Ltd., production of its Austin Mini and Metro cars was halted today by a walkout over tea breaks.

title: VARIAN ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,083,000 for the qr and $5,724,000 for the yr and $9,960,000 nonrecurrin after tax charge for the qr and yr relating to reducing the level of manufacturing personnel terminations and discontinuanc and restructuring of product lines...C-Net income including gai from discontinued operations of $1,397,000 for the qr and $498, for the yr

title: SUPREME COURT; EARLY HISTORY: LOST AND FOUND
description: To all appearances, the Supreme Court must be the best documented of American institutions. Its decisions, filling 448 volumes of a series called United States Reports that goes back to the Court's earliest days, take up shelf after shelf in all but the smallest law offices. The written word is the Supreme Court's currency, its legacy, in many ways its identity.

title: GUERRILLAS IN COLOMBIA QUITS CITIES TO OPEN A JUNGLE OFFENSIVE
description: Guerrillas of the April 19 Movement have begun an offensive in Colombia's southeastern jungles and for the first time seem to have the Government seriously worried.

title: How to Remember Vietnam
description: On Veterans Day, consider the nation's newest war memorial: instead of white, the color of glory, its walls are black, the color of death. Instead of soaring to the sky, it drops into a trench. In almost every aspect, it is depressing rather than uplifting. Is that an appropriate way to remember those who gave their lives in war?

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I HAVE a friend who has a theory that several generations back, when the chefs of France were labeling dishes such as tournedos Rossini, toast Melba, salade Ni,coise and so on, they tended to label the simplest foods ''a l'anglaise'' largely as a commentary on or a rebuff to the English kitchen.

title: KENNINGTON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COST PRESIDENT CITED FOR GIRL'S TREATMENT IS DESCRIBED AS 'LOW'
description: The hospitalization costs for Katie Beckett, the 3-year-old Iowa girl whose case President Reagan referred to in yesterday's news conference as an example of overregulation by the Government, have actually been $10,000 to $12,000 a month, or about twice the amount stated by Mr. Reagan, according to a spokesman for St. Luke's Hospital in Cedar Rapids.

title: Chevron Oil Tests
description: Chevron U.S.A. Inc., the United States petroleum subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of California, said today that it had discovered an offshore oil field in the western part of the Santa Barbara Channel.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Every so often a sauce with eggs curdles. It is heartbreaking to have to throw away all those expensive ingredients and start all over. Is there any way to reconstitute a curdled sauce?

title: DANCE: MA DANSE RITUEL OF PARIS IN U.S. DEBUT
description: The name of the Ma Danse Rituel Theatre, a Paris-based theaterdance company that made its American debut last week at Japan Society, may be read in two quite different ways. Both readings - whether the French possessive pronoun or the Japanese concept of Ma, a relationship of time and space - would be pertinent, for the group is engaged in a highly personal exploration of Japanese classical theater and dance forms as well as ancient ritual. ''Riviere Sumida/ Folie,'' seen on Nov. 3, is a 1976 piece by the company's founder, Hideyuki Yano, that is based on a Kabuki tragedy but also draws on African ritual movement.

title: RESEARCHING THE ROOTS OF GASTRONOMY
description: RARE leather-bound cookbooks from the 17th and 18th centuries line the living room walls, computer printouts of ancient recipes are stacked in the bedroom and early food advertisements decorate the dining room of Mary and Philip Hymans' fourth-floor apartment in the historic Marais section of Paris.

title: COMMERCIAL CENTER AT BATTERY PARK CITY GETS ITS FIRST TENANT
description: The Olympia & York Equity Corporation, developer of the planned commercial center at Battery Park City, announced yesterday that it had found its first tenant.

title: ARAB SCHOOL, SHUT BY ISRAEL, SEEKS TO REOPEN
description: Nov. 10 - Bir Zeit University, which was closed last week by the Israeli military authorities, announced today that it had begun a campaign in Israel and abroad to have the institution reopened.

title: NORTH AMERICAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOUTHWEST GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our goal remains the same; we recognize now that the likelihood of meeting it on the 1984 date has become an unlikelihood because of unforeseen changes.'' - President Reagan, on balancing the budget. (A1:6.)

title: The Days When Men Were Men
description: Add to the chorus of baseball's ancients crying out against the 'softness' of modern baseball the voice of Jack Zalusky, star catcher for the New York Yankees and Chicago Cubs 30 years ago.

title: Cut in London Transit Fares Ruled Illegal by Appeals Court
description: The Court of Appeals ruled today that the Greater London Council, which is controlled by the opposition Labor Party, illegally reduced subway and bus fares by 25 percent last month and raised property taxes the same amount.

title: Sunbeam Net Down
description: The Sunbeam Corporation said today that it earned $12.4 million, or 82 cents a share, in its third quarter ended Sept.30, down 10.8 percent from the $13.9 million, or 92 cents a share, it earned in the comparable period a year ago. Revenues dropped 1.3 percent, to $349.9 million, from $354.5 million. The company said that third-quarter profit was slashed 30 cents a share by foreign currency translation losses and 11 cents a share by higher interest charges.

title: LINCOLN INCOME LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The U.N. Today; Nov. 11, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: F.T.C. CHIEF HOLDS INDUSTRY CAN REGULATE AD CLAIMS ITSELF
description: A company's reputation, the threat of lawsuits and industry self-regulation would create enough pressure for most corporations to maintain their substantiation programs for advertising claims even if the Federal Trade Commission ended its requirement, the new chairman of the commission, James C. Miller 3d, said here today.

title: DELAWARE JOBS-FOR-YOUTH PLAN GAINS
description: Brian Newman, surrounded by toys and Christmas shoppers, beamed a smile as bright as his white shirt and answered with an explosive ''Yeh!'' when asked if he liked his job.

title: TRANSWAY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago 9 mos net includes a writedown from Transway International's discontinued cruise ship operation resulting in a first qr 1980 loss provision of $10,520,000

title: PLAYBOY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Aircraft Shipments Off
description: The value of general aviation aircraft shipped during October fell to $227.4 million, down 7.7 percent from billings of $246.3 million in October 1980, the General Aviation Manufacturers Association reported yesterday.

title: LOOKING BEYOND THE GAME
description: Neal Walk has always been stubborn. As far back as the eighth grade at Nautilus Junior High School in Miami Beach, when the basketball coach told him to forget jump shots and stick to the band, Walk had other ideas.

title: INTERNATIONAL POWER MACHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Car Dealerships Show a Decline
description: The number of United States auto dealerships handling domestic makes fell to 21,187 during the 1981 model year, down 758 from 21,945 at the end of the previous year, according to an industry journal.

title: FIFTH AVENUE CARDS INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
On the Way Up, and Down
description: It came as something of a surprise to James Kushner, who was just 12 years old last April when he opened in ''March of the Falsettos,'' an all-music musical that drew immediate critical interest.

title: RELIANCE FINANCIAL SERVICES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Reliance Financial Services is a unit of Reliance Group Inc

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE problem with the Beverly Hills Diet is not only that it has been so soundly criticized by nutritional experts in these pages, but also that it has given such national attention to Los Angeles. Lewis Burke Frumkes of Manhattan proposes a few alternative diets that might be more appropriate to those in our own metropolis: THE FIFTH AVENUE DIET

title: KNICKS TIP NETS, 111-99, AS RICHARDSON EXCELS
description: After struggling through the first half, the bigger and stronger Knicks unleashed a second-half running game that dominated the New Jersey Nets and led New York to a 111-99 victory last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Mobil Oil Canada
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Nov. 10 (UPI) - Mobil Oil Canada said that it had confirmed ''a significant extension'' of the Hibernia oilfield, 196 nautical miles southeast of here, and planned to drill another exploratory well in the area. A Mobil spokesman said that tests at step-out well K-18, the fifth drilled at Hibernia since the field was discovered in 1979, indicated a flow rate of 4,642 barrels a day.

title: DOWNEY SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Cable to Aim at Family
description: Walt Disney Productions and Westinghouse Broadcasting have announced a 16-hour-a-day cable television service. They say they would spend $100 million in the next four years to acquire programming.

title: COURT RULES STATES MAY NOT INTERFERE IN G.I.'S CHOICE OF BENEFICIARY
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that members of the armed services can designate any beneficiary for their military life insurance policies, regardless of prior state court decrees awarding the benefits to a former spouse or to children of a dissolved marriage.

title: PRESIDENT PLEDGES HE WILL STAY FIRM ON SPENDING CUTS
description: President Reagan declared today that his Administration would ''stiffen its spine and not throw in the towel'' on spending cuts, but he said he would defer until next year a proposal that he had made six weeks ago to reduce Federal benefit programs.

title: ISLANDERS WIN, 5-3, AS BOSSY SCORES 2
description: Two goals by Mike Bossy, inspired goaltending by Roland Melanson and the return to form of their penalty-killers helped the Islanders defeat the Winnipeg Jets, 5-3, tonight. New York has yet to lose in seven road games this season.

title: U.N. TALLIES SALVADOR DEATHS
description: A United Nations report estimates that there were 9,250 political murders in El Salvador in the first six months of this year, more than the total estimated by the State Department for all of last year.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1981
description: International U.S. praise for a Saudi peace plan for the Middle East was renewed by President Reagan at a news conference. Israel has totally rejected the proposal as imperiling its existence. (Page A1, Columns 3-4.) No plans to send troops to El Salvador to combat leftist insurgents have been developed by the Administration, according to President Reagan. At his news conference, he reaffirmed his belief that the use of tactical nuclear weapons would not necessarily lead to an all-out nuclear war. (A25:2-4.)

title: AMERICAN BAKERIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $4.5 million estimated costs and losses for the qr and 9 mos associated with disposal of the company's three main non-baking units, $192,000 loss for the 9 mos from operations to be disposed of, estimated net costs for the 9 mos of $1,296, for the company's recent proxy fight and $2,878,000 for the 9 m representing the cumulative effect of an accounting change... C-Including $183,000 income from operations to be disposed of.. D-Net income after $142,000 loss from operations to be disposed of; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect accounting requirements and stock divds

title: INDUSTRIAL UNREST PERSISTS IN POLAND
description: Industrial unrest continued today in parts of Poland, including Sosnowiec where five coal miners started an underground sit-in.

title: Sampson Hobbling
description: Ralph Sampson, perhaps the top player in college basketball, has suffered a hip injury that may keep him out of Virginia's opener Nov. 21 against Brigham Young. Sampson, a 7-foot-4-inch center, pulled a flexor muscle in his right leg while practicing with the Cavaliers two weeks ago and aggravated it over the weekend, again in practice.

title: FREED SUSPECT IN BRINK'S HOLDUP WON'T TESTIFY
description: A lawyer for Cynthia Boston, a released suspect in the Rockland County armored-car robbery, said yesterday that she would refuse to appear before a grand jury until a dispute was resolved about a lawyer who has been barred from representing her.

title: Defense Gains Recess In Point-Shaving Trial
description: Attorneys for five men accused of conspiring to shave points in Boston College basketball games yesterday obtained a recess in the trial until Monday morning.

title: METRO-GOLDWYN-MAYER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: 1981 fourgh-qr results include one month of operations of United Artists Corp acquired July 28, 1981

title: JUDGE WITHDRAWS DECISION AGAINST CASEY IN SUIT
description: A Federal district judge has withdrawn his finding that William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, knowingly participated in an investment offering that ''omitted and misrepresented facts.''

title: SETTLEMENTS BANK TO GET NEW LEADER
description: Fritz Leutwiler, the 57-year-old president of the Swiss National Bank in Zurich, has been elected chairman and president of the Bank for International Settlements, effective Jan. 1. He will succeed Jelle Zijlstra, 63, president of the Netherlands Bank, who announced yesterday at a meeting of the settlement bank's board his intention to retire at the end of this year from the post he has held for 14 years.

title: FT. DRUM MADE A DETENTION SITE FOR ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: The White House announced today that the Fort Drum Army base in upstate New York would become an interim detention center for Haitians, Cubans and other aliens who had entered the United States illegally.

title: Loews Reports Lower Net
description: The Loews Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the third quarter of 1981 ended Sept. 30 dropped 22.9 percent, to $43.8 million, or $3.44 a share, from $56.8 million, or $4.59 a share, in the third quarter of 1980. Revenues remained at $1.16 billion.

title: U.S. Productivity Panel
description: President Reagan today established an advisory committee on productivity and named former Treasury Secretary William E. Simon to head the group. The panel, consisting of 33 members, most of them business executives, is to study ways the Government affects productivity and to advise the Reagan Administration on how it can encourage growth.

title: REAGAN AGAIN PRAISES SAUDI PLAN, SAYS IT SHOWS WILLINGNESS TO TALK
description: President Reagan renewed his praise today for aspects of a Saudi peace plan that Israel has already totally rejected as imperiling its existence.

title: A RETIRED EXECUTIVE IS BELIEVED A SUICIDE IN BOATING INCIDENT
description: A 73-year-old retired textile executive and yachtsman is missing and is believed to have committed suicide, the Stamford police reported today after his 50-foot power boat was found anchored in Long Island Sound with no one aboard.

title: CASTRO CHARGES U.S. WITH LIES
description: President Fidel Castro has complained that reports of Cuban troops in Nicaragua are part of ''a campaign of lies'' by the United States Government ''aimed at setting the stage'' for aggressive United States action against Cuba.

title: ISRAELI, IN U.S., ASSERTS SAUDI PLAN IS A 'LITTLE' STEP 'IN OUR DIRECTION'
description: The leader of an Israeli parliamentary delegation sent here to argue against a Saudi Arabian peace plan said unexpectedly today that the Saudis had gone ''a little way in our direction,'' though they were still ''a long way'' from becoming part of the Middle East peace process.

title: SOVIET REJECTS SWEDISH PROTEST IN SUBMARINE AFFAIR
description: The Soviet Government today rejected Sweden's complaint that a Soviet submarine recently stranded in Swedish waters had been conducting ''impermissible activities.''

title: SYNALLOY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $15,924 gain from discontinued operations... C-Includes $278,881 gain from discontinued operations; yr-ago shr earnings adjusted for 5-for-4 stock split

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A caption in the Business People col- umn of Business Day on Wednesday incorrectly identified the executive pictured. He is Robert G. Vandemark, vice chairman of Garfinckel, Brooks Brothers, Miller & Rhoads Inc.

title: Nader and Labor Heads Suing Over Controllers
description: Labor leaders and Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, announced today that they would file suit to force the Reagan Administration to rehire the air traffic controllers who were dismissed for striking.

title: GET THE GOVERNMENT BACK ON OUR BACKS
description: To the Editor:

title: ROCKIES ADJUSTING TO A YOUTH BOOM
description: The Rocky Mountain region, holding the promise of a booming job market and unspoiled recreation, is riding the greatest wave of youthful immigration in the country.

title: Lau Leaves Yanks
description: Charlie Lau, widely considered major league baseball's preeminent batting coach, has left the Yankees after three years to join the Chicago White Sox, who gave him a six-year contract yesterday.

title: OF REAGAN AND RIGHTS
description: According to a State Department policy memo recently approved by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., ''Human rights is at the core of our foreign policy.'' Public disclosure of this memo seems to have ruffled feathers elsewhere in the Administration. James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, dealt with the matter on a television program by attempting to downgrade the memo, saying it did not constitute ''any significant change in policy.''

title: Judge Arraigned On Bribe Charge
description: A Superior Court judge was arraigned in his hospital room on charges he took a $12,000 cash bribe in exchange for promising a convicted arsonist he would not go to jail.

title: 8 WIN PUBLIC SERVICE AWARDS
description: Eight men and women have been honored with $10,000 Rockefeller Public Service Awards for their contributions toward solving important problems facing the nation.

title: PERSIAN GULF NATIONS, AT RIYADH, BACK SAUDI PLAN
description: A six-nation meeting of Persian Gulf countries agreed tonight to back Saudi Arabia's Middle East peace plan at an Arab League meeting this month.

title: Books of the Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE BREAKS OF THE GAME. By David Halberstam. 362 pages. Knopf. $15.

title: Gardening; PLANTINGS FOR THE 'ROOF' OF PARK AVENUE
description: FEW New Yorkers realize it, but a five-acre community ''rooftop garden'' is located in the middle of Park Avenue. It is divided, as community gardens are, into individual plots. In this case they are called malls, especially by those who hope the word will inspire lofty garden thoughts - an idyllic European promenade, perhaps.

title: G, AS IN GIELGUD
description: Sir John Gielgud, in New York for a whirlwind visit, had some unsettling reports yesterday for those who love the stage, including two of his most famous co-stars, Lillian Gish and Irene Worth. The actresses had joined him for lunch at the Four Seasons.

title: READING ANALYSIS IS CALLED LACKING
description: A federally financed study has concluded that while American schoolchildren are learning to read a wide range of materials, the vast majority do not develop adequate thinking skills or the ability to interpret what they read beyond a superficial level.

title: Heffernan Resigns Post As N.Y.R.A. President
description: Saying that he was ''confirming a rumor that has been going around for four years,'' James P. Heffernan resigned yesterday as president of the New York Racing Association, effective Jan. 1, to accept a higher-paying job in the private sector.

title: ALL AMERICAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE PHILADELPHIA CRAFT SHOW, WHERE ARTISTS LIKE TO EXHIBIT
description: PHILADELPHIA THE Philadelphia Craft Show, which runs tomorrow through Sunday, is only in its fifth year but has already endeared itself to the artists who exhibit in it. ''This fair is the nicest one,'' said Nancy Clearwater Herman, a quilter whose work has been in shows and galleries all over the country. ''It's not that big, so you feel important to get into it. Also, this place is the nicest.''

title: Canucks 6, Nordiques 5
description: Per-Olov Brasar had a goal and three assists for Vancouver. Brasar, who had only two goals and three assists going into the game, scored at 12:13 of the first period, and assisted on goals by Curt Fraser, Ron Delorme and Stan Smyl. The Canucks opened a 5-1 lead by 4:10 of the second period but squandered the lead by surrendering three straight power-play goals in a span of 3:03 in the second period.

title: Technology; Quality Check For Welding
description: IF you want to make anything much more complicated than a paper clip out of metal, there's a good chance you will have to resort to welding. Thousands of welds go into cars and airplanes. Tens of thousands strengthen the metal skeletons of skyscrapers and stitch together oil pipelines.

title: Hers
description: FLANNERY O'Connor has a wonderful short story, ''A Temple of the Holy Ghost,'' in which the protagonist, a child of 12, hears about the half-man, half-woman at the county fair and cannot understand how such a creature can exist if it doesn't have two heads. My seventh-graders thought the child woefully immature and spoke about the ''old days'' when parents didn't talk to children about such things. One of their classmates proceeded to speak so knowledgeably about hermaphrodites and sex-change operations that my head swam.

title: Reagan's View of War Is Absurd, Moscow Says
description: The Soviet Union, responding to President Reagan's reiteration of his view that it might be possible to limit the extent of a nuclear war, said today that Mr. Reagan's theory was ''absurd'' and ''extremely dangerous.''

title: G.M. May Offer A 'Basic' Chevrolet
description: The General Motors Corporation is considering introducing a lower-priced, stripped-down version of its Chevrolet Cavalier in a bid to increase the car's lagging sales, a Chevrolet spokesman said today.

title: G.M. FINDS HIGH CANCER RATE
description: A yearlong study has determined that workers in General Motors Corporation's model shop developed colon and rectal cancers at nearly three times the national rate, the company said today.

title: MOLSON COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $2 million investment writeoff; the company is listed on the Montreal and Toronto stock exchanges

title: CHINA WARNS U.S. ON SALE OF ARMS TO TAIWAN
description: China said again today that it objected to any sale of American arms to Taiwan, calling the issue ''a litmus test'' of American respect for Chinese sovereignty.

title: G.O.P. CLOCKS DIFFER ON TIMING OF BUDGET MOVES
description: The venerable political maxim ''Where you stand depends on where you sit'' goes a long way in explaining the confusion and conflicting statements that have surrounded President Reagan's efforts to impose a second round of Federal budget cuts.

title: BARCO OF CALIFORNIA (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
7 in Family Suffocate In House in Louisiana
description: Seven members of a young family suffocated today in the gas heat of their unventilated frame house, the police said.

title: Home Improvement; REUSABLE WEATHER STRIPS AND OTHER NEW PRODUCTS
description: ANEW type of synthetic rubber tubular weatherstripping, ideal for temporary use around windows and doors that normally are not opened in winter, has just been put on the market by the 3M Company, Household and Hardware Products Division, 3M Center, St. Paul, Minn. 55144.

title: TEXAS INTERNATIONAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Antigua Joins the U.N.
description: Antigua and Barbuda, the Caribbean nation that attained independence from Britain on Nov. 1, has become the 157th member of the United Nations.

title: ON INDIA'S CAMPUSES, POLITICS BREEDS VIOLENCE
description: A university dean was shot to death recently in the northeastern Indian city of Shillong. The police arrested two professors and the college librarian while questioning student leaders in connection with the slaying, which apparently had its roots in campus politics.

title: POLAND REHABILITATES A DATE, CELEBRATING ITS 1918 REBIRTH
description: Today was Nov. 11 and all across Poland the redand-white flags were flying in the cold autumn breeze. The graves of beloved war heroes were piled high with flowers.

title: Change at Siemens
description: Siemens A.G. today accepted the resignation of Friedrich Baur, head of its components division. The electrical, engineering and technology company said the division's profitability had eroded. Mr. Baur's successor is Ulrich Haier, head of the technology division.

title: SOURCES FOR ACRYLIC PLASTICS
description: In 1957, a House of Tomorrow was opened at Disneyland and was completely furnished and decorated with products made of Lucite, Plexiglas and other acrylic plastics.

title: THIS IS THE BUILDING THAT THE SENATE BUILT, BARELY
description: The workers are using gypsum board instead of plaster for many interior finishes, they will be installing thin, hollow metal door frames instead of wood frames and they are reducing the size of the ceiling light fixtures. Even so, the new Philip A. Hart Senate Office Building will cost nearly three times its original projected price by the time its first tenants begin to move in shortly after the midterm elections.

title: Balloon Passes a Mark On Flight Over Pacific
description: The giant helium-filled balloon Double Eagle V, soaring from a night of storms into clear weather, crossed the international dateline today and approached the halfway mark of its flight across the Pacific Ocean.

title: Du Pont Project
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said it would modernize its Newport, Del., plant and increase capacity by 50 percent to produce chromium dioxide magnetic particles.

title: RACISM IS CHARGED IN FORT DRUM PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration's decision to send 2,500 Haitian and Cuban refugees to Fort Drum in upstate New York has brought charges of racism from the newly re-elected Mayor of Miami, attorneys for the Haitians and local Haitian leaders, as well as from civil rights groups here and in New York.

title: Stabler Faces Fine
description: Ken Stabler, recovering from a wrist injury and now finding himself in a battle with John Reaves for the No. 1 quarterback job with the Houston Oilers, failed to attend practice yesterday, and Coach Ed Biles said he would be fined. But Biles said the absence would not be a factor in his deciding whom to start Sunday against Kansas City. ... But one decision on who starts at quarterback has been made. Coach Jim Hanifan, whose St. Louis Cardinals suffered a 52-10 rout at the hands of Philadelphia last Sunday, said the veteran Jim Hart would be benched in favor of Neil Lomax.

title: TAX LEASE DEADLINE SPURS RUSH
description: Corporations seeking to reduce their tax bills are rushing to meet tomorrow's deadline for completing special tax leasing deals that could cost the Treasury billions of dollars in lost revenue.

title: British Aide Delays U.S. Trip
description: Britain postponed at the last minute today a visit to the United States by a junior Government minister to discuss differing approaches on the Middle East. British officials said the delay in the visit of Douglas Hurd, Minister of State at the Foreign Office, was not for political reasons but to allow him to take part in an important parliamentary vote on local government powers.

title: RABBIT HUNTERS' ARRESTS STIR CHICAGO
description: Early last Wednesday, 11 men gathered out back of Timothy Thigpen's apartment at the Altgeld Gardens public housing complex. They stuffed themselves, 11 eager dogs and a supply of heavy hardwood sticks into several automobiles and set out to stalk rabbits in wooded areas of the city.

title: Addenda
description: * Newsweek magazine increasing its national ad rates 10.5 percent, effective with the Jan. 4 issue.

title: DO LATINS MAKE LOUSY LEADERS?; Latin America - that region of great nations and banana republics, sleeping giants and vast resources, tinhorn dictators and Communist zealots, ancient cultures and a tradition of law - has at long last a chance to make a symbolic impact on the international scene.
description: The United Nations has reached a stalemate on the choice of Secretary General. Kurt Waldheim, seeking an unprecedented third term in a position once graced by Dag Hammarskjold, is deservedly getting a compromiser's comeuppance: a veto from China, the only third-world nation with a veto power, which wants a person from the third world to head the Secretariat of the world body.

title: N, as in No and Never
description: At first it was an annoyance, something to be brushed away like a fly buzzing his courtroom bench. But as the offense has become a vexing constant in his life, Federal Judge Mark A. Costantino has decided to take action.

title: ARREST OF 375 IN DRUG SWEEP AT DISCOTHEQUE RAISES QUESTION OF DUE
description: PROCESS By MARCIA CHAMBERS News Analysis

title: NATIONAL PUBLIC RADIO SEEKS FUNDS FROM PRIVATE SOURCES
description: National Public Radio, facing a sharp reduction in Federal financing over the next five years, today began a campaign to raise more private money and make profits from nonbroadcasting operations.

title: HARPER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GREECE SAYS IT WANTS TO BAN U.S. NUCLEAR ARMS ON ITS SOIL
description: Greece said today that it wanted to ban American nuclear warheads from the country. ''The removal of the nuclear warheads will be one of our first demands in the negotiations on the American bases,'' Dimitrios Maroudas, the Government spokesman, said at a news conference.

title: BERG ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $71,250 or 5 cents a shr income from a reduction of liability in connection with the sale of a subsidiary in an earlier yr; yr-ago net income has been restated to reflect an increase of $29,341 or 2 cents a shr due to an accounting change

title: New Capital Coach
description: The Washington Capitals had considered several candidates from outside the organization, including Don Cherry, Fred Shero and reportedly Phil Esposito, but in the end they decided on one of their own. Bryan Murray, the team announced yesterday, is the new coach, replacing Gary Green, who was removed with Max McNab, the general manager, last week after the Capitals had lost 11 straight games.

title: POPE EVANS & ROBBINS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Chrysler Closing
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it had shut down production at its Newark plant and furloughed 3,800 workers for two weeks to balance production and inventories. About 880 Chrysler ''K'' cars are assembled daily at the Newark plant.

title: UNMARRIED COUPLE WIN FIGHT AGAINST RENT RISE
description: This time it was a question of both love and money. New York City's Commission on Human Rights has come down on the side of love. In a ruling earlier this week, the commission found that it was a form of marital discrimination for a landlord to require a higher rent when the lover of a lease-holding tenant moved into the partner's apartment.

title: POLLOCK PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
News Analysis
description: West Germany is in the process of deciding how seriously to take a new kind of leftist nationalism whose existence, initially denied, has increasingly become a subject of political discussion.

title: CONCERT: GUTIERREZ PLAYS WITH SUISSE ROMANDE
description: GREAT Performers are no rarity; Lincoln Center has an entire series devoted exclusively to them. But great performances are not so common that the phenomena can be institutionalized.

title: CAPITAL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: 1981 results include the acquisition of National Liberty Corp in Jan 1981

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have been debating the advisability of insulating the ceiling of the basement crawl space in my country home. Some local workmen have advised against this, but I have read that this is one way to conserve heat. I have also thought of just stapling up plastic sheets on the crawl space ceiling. What is your opinion of these ideas? - B.H., Jericho, N.Y.

title: Shotgun Offense
description: Ken Simon, Alabama's starting fullback, was charged with a felony on a complaint by a law student at the university that Simon fired a shotgun at him and another student during a quarrel last week. Simon was freed on $2,000 bond, pending a hearing.

title: TRADING SLOWS
description: Stock prices closed slightly higher yesterday in slower trading, with transportation issues posting the best gains. The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a very narrow range throughout the session, rose 3.14 points, to 857.12. Advances on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered declines, 771 to 720.

title: DONALD J. KRINTZMAN
description: Donald J. Krintzman, director of marketing for the Joffrey Ballet, died at University Hospital on Tuesday after a brief illness.

title: CINCINNATI MILACRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After foreign currency translation losses of $7,502,000 for the qr and $11,532,000 for the 40 weeks and $3,346,000 or 15 cents a shr gain for the qr and 40 weeks for the forgiveness of deferred taxes on inventories of Milacron's British subsidiary...C-Including foreign currency translation gains of $1,906,000 or 8 cents a shr for the qr and $2,972,000 or 12 cents a shr for the 40 weeks and $23,203,000 income for the 40 weeks from discontinued operations, which includes $22,596,000 from the sale of Cincinnati Milacron Chemical Inc; Yr-ago 40 weeks sales figure is restated to reflect the sale of the chemicals company

title: Moscow Denies Charge On Chemical Warfare
description: The Soviet Union today denied an accusation by a United States official that Soviet-backed governments in Asia were using lethal chemical weapons.

title: Bridge: Five Harter Team Victors Ineligible to Defend Crown
description: Some odd features become evident if one studies the list of players who recently won the Harter double knockout team championship in New York: Judy Rich, Janet de Grazia, Mark Cohen, Barry Goren, Rajat Basu and Arjun Ray, all of New York.

title: THE GAP COUNTERS RETAIL RETRENCHMENT
description: While most other retailers are cutting back expansion and also reducing the size of their new stores, The Gap Stores Inc. is doing just the opposite. It will be opening larger units next year, each three or four times the average size of its present 500 stores, while increasing its rate of new store space.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: 2 SLAIN ON SAME BLOCK LAST WEEK
description: It is a quiet homeowner block, 104th Street from 97th Avenue to 101st Avenue at the south end of Richmond Hill, Queens. Early yesterday, for the second time in a week there, an elderly couple were attacked inside their home.

title: RICHARD E. THOMAS
description: Richard E. Thomas, former vice president and a senior credit officer of the First National City Bank of New York, died Monday at his home in Hilton Head Island, S.C. He was 67 years old.

title: END OF TAXI SURCHARGE FORECAST BY PANEL CHIEF
description: The chairman of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission predicted yesterday that the 50-cent surcharge on cab rides at night and on Sundays would be discontinued at the end of the year.

title: MICROS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
KIRBY EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes earnings from discontinued operations of $200,000... C-Includes earnings of $9,163,850 from continuing operations and a gain of $2,259,740 on the sale of discontinued operations in the latest 9 mos and earninns of $8.8 million from continuin operations and $700,000 from discontinued operations; the 1980 results have been restated to reflect the Barge Yard division as a discontinued operations sold Jan 28, 1981; the shr earning for both periods adjusted for 10-for-1 stock split paid Apr 22,

title: RANGERS ROMP OVER SABRES, 7-3
description: Slowly but unmistakably, the Rangers seem to be losing their mediocre ways. After nearly a month of desultory play, they are now the happy possessors of a three-game winning streak, the third victory achieved last night as they defeated the Buffalo Sabres, 7-3, at Madison Square Garden.

title: LSB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MIDLAND RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes credits from utilization of net operating loss of $683,000 for the qr and $1,859,000 for the 9 mos... C-Includes credits of $255,000 for the qr and $751,000 for the 9 mos and $599,000 after tax gain for the 9 mos from the sale of interest in five of the company's total properties

title: Bonn Raising Fees on Fuels
description: Energy companies will have to pay a royalty of 32 percent on oil and gas produced in West Germany from Jan.1, up from the current 22 percent, the Lower Saxony state government announced today.

title: WAXMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rebuff to Champion
description: Alexis Arguello, the World Boxing Council lightweight champion, has a title defense coming up in nine days against Roberto Elizondo in Las Vegas, Nev. Arguello has been getting ready, or trying to.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bill Raftery, who resigned recently as Seton Hall basketball coach, has joined the broadcasting team for televised Big East games Monday nights. ... Ilie Nastase, defeated by Britain's Richard Lewis at Wembley in the first round, was fined $400 for using indecent language. ... Isiah Thomas, Detroit's rookie guard, was reprimanded and fined an undisclosed sum when he arrived 20 minutes late for the game with Philadelphia. Thomas said he did not have a players' pass to the parking lot and the attendants would not let him enter the area. Of their failure to recognize him, he said, ''I was kind of surprised.''

title: Former Albuquerque Mayor Is Elected to Another Term
description: Harry Kinney, elected yesterday to his second nonconsecutive term as Mayor, pledged that he would try to build a ''more responsive city government.''

title: Scandinavian Airlines, Scali, McCabe Part
description: Scandinavian Airlines System and its advertising agency since 1975, Scali, McCabe & Sloves, have agreed to mutually terminate their relationship.
