title: New Product Introductions Off
description: According to New Product News, published by Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, new product introductions for the month of October were off 16.5 percent, to 102, a sharp drop from the 121 reported in October 1980.

title: CHARLES RITZ, 90, EX-HEAD OF MINNEAPOLIS FOOD CONCERN
description: Charles Ritz, a former chairman of the board of the International Multifoods Corporation in Minneapolis, died yesterday at Abbott-Northwestern Hospital in Minneapolis. He was 90 years old and had lived in Minneapolis.

title: Genstar Net Off; Rockwell Up
description: The Genstar Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in the third quarter of 1981 plunged 65 percent, as revenues dropped 10.1 percent.

title: REDISTRICTING PLANS IN SOUTH THWART BLACKS' HOPES
description: Blacks in the Deep South, who had hoped to make significant political gains in legislative seats as a result of redistricting, are being bitterly disappointed by the results.

title: LOUISIANA GENERAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $1,687,221 net gain from the sale of property; 1980 results have been adjusted to reflect a 50 percent stock divd paid in July 1981 and a 4 percent stock divd paid in Aug 1981

title: MURRAY MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COLOMBIA SEEKS CREDIT
description: Colombia, which is seeking a $200 million Eurocredit, will likely receive terms to match those on a recently priced transaction for the state coal company, banking sources said here today. That 10-year loan carried an interetst rate spread of half a percentage point over London interbank rates for the first three years, rising to five-eighths of a percentage point for the final seven years. Chemical Bank and Chase Manhattan are heading one group bidding on the loan, the sources added, while two other groups are led by Lloyds Bank International and Credit Lyonnais.

title: Apple Expands Its Top System
description: Apple Computer Inc. introduced a mass data storage system and software for its Apple III computer in an apparent effort to stimulate flat sales of its top-of-the-line model and counter the entry into the market of the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: JONES & VINING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
Helpful Hardware; HOME FROM THE SEA
description: MARINE supply stores carry two made-for-boating items that can be put to several ingenious uses at home. A cleat, used for holding line in place on a boat, can be used for storing Venetian blind cords neatly next to the window.

title: VETERANS FINDING NO AUSTERITY
description: These may be days of austerity for cities, symphonies and school children, but the pinch has not yet come for veterans who look to Washington for a helping hand.

title: Unhappy Mariner
description: Tom Paciorek, the Seattle Mariner outfielder who finished second in the American League batting race with a .326 average, has formally notified the Major League Baseball Players Association that he is demanding a trade. The Mariners, who had refused his demand for a three-year guaranteed contract worth $1 million, now have until March 15 to trade him or he will be able to negotiate a deal with any team.... Jerry Morales, the Chicago Cub outfielder, re-signed for two years instead of going through tomorrow's re-entry draft.

title: GENERAL EMPLOYMENT ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Design Notebook; AN HONORABLE U.S. TRADITION OF SUBURBAN PLANNING
description: THE suburb is, to most architecturally minded observers, the quintessence of banality. Dreary, unimaginative houses, scattered across the landscape with little concern for much of anything except carving up the earth in a way to give every one of those disjointed structures its little sliver of backyard, its closed-off, private piece of nature. The prevailing notion seems not so much community as separation - as a village whose physical layout seems to symbolize keeping apart, not joining together.

title: KOCH REJECTS PROPOSAL TO ACCEPT PENALTIES FOR WELFARE INEFFICIENCY
description: Mayor Koch yesterday disavowed a suggestion by his welfare commissioner that the city might find it less expensive to lose tens of millions of dollars in Federal aid as a result of penalties for inefficiency than to take sufficient corrective action.

title: U.S. IS CONSIDERING LOGISTICAL SUPPORT FOR FORCE IN CHAD
description: The United States is actively considering a request by Nigeria to provide transport and supplies for part of a 5,000-member African peacekeeping force that will be sent to Chad to replace departing Libyan troops, Administration officials said today.

title: 2 NEW FINDS EASE TUNISIA'S OIL WORRIES
description: Discovery of two major oil deposits here is easing Tunisia's worry that the rapid depletion of existing resources would force it to import rather than export oil within the next three years.

title: BYRNE ARENA: NEW BRUSH ON RING CANVAS
description: Bobby Czyz was watching the St. Peter's College basketball team work out today, trying to put the first boxing card at Byrne Meadowlands Arena in historic perspective.

title: TEMPERENCE HILL IN FAREWELL RACE
description: The bay colt in Barn 8 at the Meadowlands is handsome, rich and famous but probably the least popular or respected four-legged millionaire in thoroughbred racing history.

title: MANES BIDS TO END HIS FEUD WITH L.I. BUSINESS LEADERS
description: Borough President Donald Manes of Queens, who has accused business leaders in Nassau and Suffolk Counties of pirating businesses from his county, has proposed that the three counties end their long feud and work together to attract new companies from outside the state.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

'SOMETHING IS HAPPENING'; BOSTON, Nov. 11 - A generation of Americans has grown up now with the fact of nuclear weapons: thinking little about them, putting their potential horror out of mind. We have truly been a silent generation. The nuclear armory has swollen in numbers and sophistication and danger with hardly a murmer of American public protest.
description: The years of silence make what occurred on Veterans Day 1981 extraordinary. On campuses across the United States people gathered to take part in a national teach-in on the threat of nuclear war. They heard what the weapons will do to civilization if they are ever used. They heard about the compulsions of the arms race. And in large numbers they said they were ready to join in efforts to reduce the nuclear threat.

title: COMDISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income of $1,355,000 for the qr and $4,488,000 for the yr from accounting changes

title: 5 Arrested in Raid Linked to Robbery
description: Five persons were booked following a raid on a suspected fencing operation in Washington Heights, where the police said they found huge quantities of the loot from a $100,000 appliance store robbery in Yonkers on Monday.

title: BUILDERS INVESTMENT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income...C-Including extraordinary credits of $4,889,000 for the latest yr and $1,831,000 for the previous yr

title: Volkswagen Brazil Loss
description: Volkswagen do Brasil, the Brazilian subsidiary of the West German auto maker, is expected to post a loss equivalent to more than $49.5 million this year compared with a 1980 loss of $25.2 million, a spokesman for the parent company said here today. The subsidiary's deliveries to clients fell 42.1 percent in the first nine months of 1981, to 190,600 units, while deliveries in September dropped 53.3 percent from September of 1980, to 21,800. At the same time, the Brazilian unit's share of the domestic market declined to 46 percent in the first eight months of 1981 from 47.2 percent in the 1980 period.

title: Oil Use Fell 5% Last Year, Output by 4%
description: World oil consumption fell an estimated 5 percent in 1980 to its lowest level in four years, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the major international trade supervision body, reported today.

title: Looting Seen At Stix & Co.
description: Three officers and two clients of Stix & Company, a brokerage house that was declared insolvent earlier this week, systematically looted private accounts, taking amounts as high as $100,000 at one time, according to an affidavit by the Internal Revenue Service made public today.

title: Pupil's LSD Fells Teacher
description: A pupil angry at being reprimanded for throwing paper airplanes in class slipped LSD into the coffee cup of his 61-year-old teacher and the woman began hallucinating, the police said. Antoinette Indovina, a teacher at Notre Dame School on the South Side, was reported in good condition yesterday by hospital attendants. The 13-year-old student was being held in the juvenile detention center.

title: Going Out Guide
description: FROM OKINAWA

title: SCHMIDT FACES LABOR PROTESTS
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany is working to calm unrest among labor unions and in his own Social Democratic Party over the deteriorating economy. The unrest has been straining the ties that bind together his coalition Government.

title: MIRIAM W. HALBERSTADT
description: Miriam W. Halberstadt, president of the board of trustees of the Daughters of Jacob Geriatric Center in the Bronx, was killed Sunday when the car she was driving ran off the Taconic State Parkway in Mount Pleasant, N.Y. She was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: COMBINED INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WETTERAU INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
CO-FOUNDER OF JET PROPULSION LAB
description: Frank J. Malina, an aerospace pioneer whose work helped the United States put the first man on the moon, is dead at the age of 69, the United States Embassy here said yesterday. A spokesman said that Mr. Malina died of a heart attack Monday at his Paris home.

title: CHEMPLAST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
LION COUNTRY SAFARI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bomb Explodes in San Juan
description: A bomb exploded today in a power substation in the Condado tourist section, causing damage but no interruption in electricity. A spokesman for the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority expressed concern that incidents of sabotage were continuing despite last week's settlement of a three-month strike by 6,600 electricity workers.

title: U.N. CONDEMNS ISRAELI RAID ON REACTOR
description: Over protests by the United States, Iraq won a condemnation of Israel today in an otherwise routine resolution dealing with the International Atomic Energy Agency.

title: John J. Ansbro, Vicar General Of the Archdiocese of Newark
description: Msgr. John J. Ansbro, vicar general of the Archdiocese of Newark, died Monday at St. Mary's Hospital in Orange, N.J. He was 69 years old.

title: Tosco to Borrow For Shale Project
description: The Tosco Corporation said it had arranged to borrow an initial $82 million under its recently negotiated $1.1 billion Federal loan guarantee program to finance its 40 percent share in the Colony shale oil project in northwestern Colorado.

title: Quaker May Sell Its Restaurants
description: The Quaker Oats Company said it was studying inquiries about the possible sale of all or part of its restaurant division. William D. Smithburg, Quaker's president and chief executive officer, told shareholders at the company's annual meeting in Chicago that the company's restaurants are ''not a profitable business and we are continuing to review and reduce our investment by closing weaker stores.''

title: News of Music; 44 CENTURIES OF FEMALE COMPOSERS
description: THE word ''woman'' has become an ethnic adjective in recent decades, used - as in ''woman composer'' - much the same way the words ''American'' or ''black'' are. But the International Encyclopedia of Women Composers by Aaron I. Cohen, just published by R.R. Bowker, is the first extensive reference book of interest to anyone concerned with the history of female musical composition.

title: 1 Killed, 15 Hurt In Y.M.C.A. Fire
description: One man was killed and 15 others hurt in a fire yesterday that destroyed the top two floors of a five-story Y.M.C.A. in this city's business district, the police said.

title: MAKERS OF GIFT WRAP REPORT ITS LEAD CONTENT IS REDUCED
description: Potentially dangerous levels of lead contamination in Christmas gift wrap have been substantially reduced, an industry group said today.

title: MY SON, THE ARCHITECT: HOUSES FOR PARENTS
description: IN the beginning there is nepotism. It is hard enough for an experienced architect to get work today. What does a young designer do to get his first cornerstone laid? Build a house for relatives.

title: DANCE: WALLACE-LARKIN RECITAL OF DUETS
description: CHERYL WALLACE and William Larkin are engaging young performers, and their ''Duets: Solo Dance/Solo Piano,'' seen Saturday at Eden's Expressway, reflected that. If neither plumbed great artistic depths - or even small ones - they clearly have a solid collaboration going and their pleasure in it is infectious.

title: FRANCIS R. O'NEIL
description: Francis R. O'Neil , a retired investment manager and analyst, died of cancer yesterday at the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital.

title: M-G-M Suing Transamerica
description: The Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company has accused the Transamerica Corporation of fraud and deception in the $380 million sale of Transamerica's United Artists unit to M-G-M earlier this year.

title: FAIR LANES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: 1981 figures reflect the acquisition of Treedway Companies effective July 1981

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.** Maximum rate payable by savings institutes.N.A. Not available today because the markets closed for the Veteran's day holiday. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: DISPUTE OVER FINANCES IS SNARLING PLAN TO EXPAND QUEENS AIRPORT
description: Nearly eight months after the Koch administration and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey thought they had struck a deal, a dispute over finances continues to stall an agreement that would clear the way for a $500 million development program at Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports.

title: Atom Test Blast in Nevada
description: One nuclear weapons test was conducted today at the Nevada test site and another was postponed until tomorrow, the Department of Energy said. A spokesman, Dave Miller, said that the test was detonated 1,460 feet beneath Yucca Flats, 90 miles north of here. He said that the yield was 20 to 150 kilotons.

title: Raytheon Will Cut Staff of Data Unit
description: The Raytheon Company said that it would reduce the work force at its Raytheon Data Systems Company division by about 250, or approximately 5 percent of its 4,400 employees.

title: Advertising; Industry Week Is Moving Up
description: ''B USINESS WEEK and The Wall Street Journal own the hard news and Fortune does pretty well on the issues; finance is covered by Forbes, The Journal, Dun's Review and the others, but we frequently hear from our readers, 'Industry Week catches me right where I'm living,' '' said Patrick B. Keefe, in from Cleveland and talking about his favorite magazine.

title: Suspect Injures 2 Police Officers
description: Two police officers suffered powder burns when a suspect they were trying to subdue grabbed one of their revolvers and fired a single shot, authorities said.

title: Isabelle Rogers Finch Dead; Posed in World War I Poster
description: Isabelle Rogers Finch, who was in a World War I recruiting poster for the Navy, died Monday in a Long Island nursing home.

title: CPS CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW YORK CITY TESTING A BUS WITH A GALLIC TWIST
description: New Yorkers traveling on two city bus routes were treated to travel with yet another accent - French. As the Transit Authority's search for the perfect bus for New York City grows global in scope, the city's fleet of buses is becoming ever more varied.

title: A BORN ENVOY, ECHOES OF HOME AND MAIL CALL
description: Haiti's Georges Nicolas Leger is an ambassador literally born to the job. His maternal great-grandfather, Ernest Roumain, opened the Republic of Haiti's first legation in Washington in 1860. His paternal grandfather, Jacques Nicolas Leger, was ambassador here for more than a decade at the turn of the century, serving as dean of the diplomatic corps on the eve of World War I. Another Jacques, the present Ambassador's cousin, was Haiti's envoy here in the 1950's.

title: ASSUMABLE MORTGAGES: BILL WOULD BAR TRANSFER
description: The Senate Banking Committee is considering a proposal that would pre-empt many state laws that allow homeowners to transfer old, low-interest mortgages to purchasers when they sell their homes.

title: MEMBERS CHALLENGE FUTURES TIE
description: The plan to link the trading floors of the mighty Chicago Board of Trade and the foundering New York Futures Exchange has stirred up a storm of protest among members of the Chicago exchange.

title: 2 BILLS ON SEWERS GO TO CONFERENCE
description: The fate of the heavily criticized, multibillion dollar Federal sewer construction program may soon be decided as House and Senate conferees meet tomorrow to try to iron out sharp differences over changing the program.

title: FILLING THE HOURS AFTER SCHOOL ENDS
description: IN response to the needs of parents and children, a growing number of private and public schools are expanding their role in their students' lives. Of New York City's 80 or so private schools, 30 percent offer after-school programs that are attended by 30 to 70 percent of their younger students. Most of the city's public elementary schools provide after-schood programs at least two afternoons a week, with some having as many as five.

title: Israeli Fever, Camp David Cure
description: President Reagan cannot understand why Israelis don't appreciate Saudi Arabia's ''implicit'' recognition of their right to exist, and why they resent his saying this implies a ''willingness to negotiate.'' A senior Washington official told The Times's Bernard Gwertzman that he could not remember ''when the Israelis have been so excitable and so sensitive about everything; I can't rule out the possibility that they might do anything.''

title: NO-SHINE COMBAT BOOT IS FAILING ARMY TESTS
description: The Army's proposed no-shine combat boot has run into trouble. Instead of planning to buy as many as 2.5 million pairs of the rough-finish boot by 1983, as anticipated, the authorities are backtracking.

title: GENSTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results are reported in Canadian dollars

title: FREMONT GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHIEF DEMOCRAT IN BERGEN CITED IN BRIBE SCHEME
description: The Bergen County Democratic chairman and a state police sergeant were charged today along with five other men in a conspiracy to bribe a state trooper.

title: Critic's Notebook; HOW MUCH OUGHT A CRITIC TO KNOW?
description: WHAT happens is this: the crazed reviewer disappears into the book. He has been gobbled up. He knows not where he is - lungs, pancreas, urinary tract, big toe. A novel like Robert Stone's ''A Flag for Sunrise,'' for example, is so consuming because it is ''about'' everything from the ''moral fascination'' of Vietnam to revolution in Central America to communications theory to the death of God. If Mr. Stone goes all the way, shouldn't the reviewer plunge after him, sink or swim? Perhaps not.

title: THOUSANDS AT COLLEGES JOIN DRIVE AGAINST ATOMIC ARMS
description: Thousands of students and faculty members at 151 college campuses around the country staged a teach-in today on the threat of nuclear war, opening what is planned as a continuing national education program to generate popular demands for multinational nuclear arms reduction.

title: UNIONIST SAYS OUSTER OF CONTROLLERS INFLUENCED RAILWAY PACT
description: Economic conditions and the Reagan Administration's treatment of the strikers in the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization played a role in contract negotiations in the railroad industry.

title: Valenzuela Gets Young Award
description: Fernando Valenzuela, the Los Angeles Dodgers' rookie left-hander, was named the National League's Cy Young Award winner yesterday, narrowly defeating Tom Seaver of the Cincinnati Reds.

title: ARGENTINES FLOCK ABROAD AS DREAMS OF RICHES DIE
description: It was the promised land in South America, and for more than a century immigrants from Europe flowed here just as they did to the United States.

title: RECOTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Warner Gives $15,000 To Mount 3 Musicals
description: Warner Communications has given the Performing Arts Repertory Theater a $15,000 grant to produce three original musicals designed for family audiences.

title: THEY GAMBLE ON FILMS, POPCORN, SODA AND CRAPS
description: The juxtaposition of Las Vegas and the National Association of Theater Owners is no mixed metaphor. The Columbia Pictures vice president sliding his silver dollars hopefully into a slot machine last night and the theater owner from Pennsylvania making eight the hard way at the craps table this morning are only bringing to their play the gambling that is an everyday part of their work.

title: State Names Consumer Aide
description: A former assistant counsel to Governor Carey has been named director of the new Consumer Services Division within the Department of Public Service. The $46,850-a-year post will be taken over by Lisa Rosenblum. Her parent agency helps consumers with utility billing and service complaints.

title: CAREY VETOES A KEY BILL REVISING STATE'S ILLEGAL PROPERTY TAX SYSTEM
description: Governor Carey yesterday vetoed a bill that would have revised the state's complicated property tax assessment system, six years after the system was ruled illegal by the courts, his aides said.

title: GARAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
Dr. Milton L. Berliner, Eye Surgery Specialist
description: Dr. Milton L. Berliner, surgeon director of ophthalmology at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary and director of ophthalmology at Beth Israel Hospital, died last Friday at his Manhattan home. He was 88 years old.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1981
description: International Support for African troops in Chad by the United States is under active consideration, according to Reagan Administration officials. They said that Washington was weighing a request by Nigeria to transport and supply part of a 5,000-member peacekeeping force that will be sent to Chad to replace departing Libyan troops. Washington has also been asked to provide economic aid to the strife-torn country now that Libya is halting all support. (Page A1, Column 6.) Peace proposals by Saudi Arabia prompted an unexpected comment from the leader of an Israeli parliamentary delegation sent to Washington to argue against the plan. The legislator, Moshe Arens, said that the Saudis had ''gone a little way in our direction,'' but that they still had ''a long way to go to become part of the Mideast peace process.'' (A1:4-5.)

title: MARATHON IN SEARCH OF MERGER PARTNER
description: Representatives of the Marathon Oil Company have been inviting industrial corporations to rescue the company from an unwanted takeover bid by the Mobil Corporation, Wall Street sources disclosed yesterday.

title: GENESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After an extraordinary tax credit of $2,570,000... C-After $700,000 operating loss from discontinued operations and provision for future losses of $480,000 from discontinued operations; the qr also showed an extraordinary tax credit of $1,552,000; the figures for 1980 have been reclassified to give effect to the retroactive adoption of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No 13

title: Cunningham & Walsh Expands Dallas Office
description: The small Dallas office set up by Cunningham & Walsh last September to handle the then newly acquired Lennox Industries and La Quinta Motor Inns account, has been expanded into a full service office to be headed by Harve Chapman as president and general manager.

title: E, AS IN E.R.A.
description: San Francisco's Mayor, Dianne Feinstein, made it to the U.S. Mayor's Conference in Chicago yesterday after smoothing over some ruffled feathers on her own Board of Supervisors.

title: Playboy Bird
description: The bowerbirds of Australia and New Guinea are in the news this week after an ornithologist spied a rare member of the species. Rare or not, the males are remarkable birds.

title: Fujitsu Sees U.S. Bid Bias
description: Japan has formally asked the United States to investigate a case of reported discrimination against a Japanese computer company, a Foreign Ministry official said today.

title: WHEN A BLOOD DONOR NEEDS HIS BLOOD
description: To the Editor:

title: NUCORP ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: 1980 shr earnings adjusted for 3-for-2 stock split

title: PHYSICIANS DEPLORE THE ABORTING OF ONE TWIN
description: An operation in which a fetus suffering a genetic disorder was aborted seven months before its twin was born naturally has aroused protests from doctors in the United States and Canada.

title: Syrian Communists Lose All Parliamentary Seats
description: Parliamentary election results announced today showed that Syria's Communist Party lost all eight seats it held in the previous Parliament, while President Hafez al-Assad's ruling Socialist Baath Party won at least 60 percent of the seats.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny International Inc. said a subsidiary had completed its previously announced cash offer for 7.5 million shares of common stock of Sunbeam Corp. at $41 a share.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF CHOOSING TO WORK AFTER 65
description: To the Editor:

title: BRONX WOMAN ACCUSED OF KILLING ONE SON AND WOUNDING ANOTHER
description: A Bronx woman who the police said fatally stabbed her 6-year-old son and critically wounded his 12-year-old brother was arraigned yesterday on charges of murder and attempted murder.

title: U.S. Judge Under Inquiry Says He Won't Testify
description: Federal District Judge Alcee Hastings said yesterday he would not testify before a grand jury investigating charges he solicited payoffs.

title: TV Ad Bureau Head
description: At the annual meeting yesterday of the Television Bureau of Advertising in Miami Beach, David E. Henderson, president of Outlet Broadcasting in Providence, R.I., was elected chairman. He succeeds Thomas B. Cookerly, president-broadcast division of Allbritton Communications in Washington, D.C., who held the post for the past two years.

title: WHILE AWAITING MERGER, INA REALIGNS DUTIES
description: Following Monday's announcement that the INA Corporation and the Connecticut General Corporation plan to merge, forming what would be the nation's sixth-largest insurance company, INA has named a new chief operating officer to handle its day-to-day operations. John R. Cox, 49, INA's senior executive vice president, will assume the additional title on Nov. 25.

title: NATIONAL PATENT DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFING
description: Q UIETLY and without too much notice, an influx of French businessmen and their families has slipped into Washington and begun buying expensive homes. One Frenchwoman just purchased a home (sight unseen, according to a real estate broker) for $800,000 on 31st Street in Georgetown, and other French citizens with plenty of cash have signed agreements for condominiums in the area. One real estate broker said the stream of Frenchmen into Washington began even before the Socialist government of Francois Mitterrand took over in Paris. And now, with the onset of bank nationalization and other threatened government takeovers, the exodus has accelerated.

title: POTENTIAL FREE AGENTS PROSPER
description: Baseball's club owners, almost as a chorus, have said in recent weeks that they would not pay free agents the kind of money they have in the past. But some of the owners have already given potential free agents even more lucrative contracts than most free agents have received.

title: GEORESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
News Analysis
description: When Miet Jan Faber, leader of the Dutch peace movement, wrote to rally similar groups around Europe earlier this year, every country answered him except France.

title: MIME: NIEDZIALKOWSKI TALKS AND ACTS
description: BECAUSE mimes can be brainy theoreticians as well as nimble movers, Stefan Niedzialkowski's lecture-demonstration on mime at the Ohio Performance Space on Nov. 4 could have provided valuable insights into the art. But too many opportunities for illumination were missed.

title: CHAMBER: CLARINET AND PIANO IN BRITISH MUSIC OF THE 40'S
description: IF British music remains an obscure item on New York programs, this month may see a corrective. There will be three all-British concerts by the Pittsburgh Symphony and an all-Britten program from the New York Philharmonic. And on Nov. 4 at the Abraham Goodman House, under the auspices of the Society for British Music, there was a clarinetand-piano program focusing on British music of the 1940's. Improbably enough, it was charming.

title: EGYPT AND ISRAEL RENEW DISCUSSIONS
description: Egypt and Israel resumed talks on Palestinian autonomy today and Israeli officials said they were anxious to resolve the long impasse over the issue quickly because of growing concern in Israel that the Camp David accords might dissolve after the death of Anwar el-Sadat.

title: No Headline
description: Arnold B. Dibble Dies at 65; Ex-Correspondent for U.P.I.

title: MUSIC: OLD FACES, NEW NAME
description: THE National Orchestral Association, which has served so well for so long as a trainer of symphony orchestra players, apparently decided that 50 years of operation under that name was enough and is now calling itself the National Orchestra of New York.

title: Prelate Leading Appeal For Indicted Unionists
description: Msgr. Galliano J. Cavallaro is leading a fund-raising drive to help pay legal expenses for officials of the Laborers International Union who were indicted in Miami on racketeering charges.

title: G.O.P. RELIEVES SECURITY OFFICIAL IN JERSEY VOTING
description: John A. Kelly, the Republican National Committee official who was in charge of the party's controversial National Ballot Security Task Force in the New Jersey gubernatorial election, was suspended from his duties yesterday.

title: Schweiker Warns Cuts May Curb Doctors' Aid
description: The Secretary of Health and Human Services says that Federal budget cuts will cost the Government the services of 200 doctors it put through school and could jeopardize health and safety programs.

title: JAPAN'S SHOCK-PROOF PORTFOLIOS
description: Plying the bond markets of the globe is a rather arcane art, as its practitioners puzzle over variables whose names and meanings are grasped only by the initiated -yield curves, swaps, ratings and coupons.

title: IN A WORD, SUCCESSFUL
description: It may seem odd to be celebrating the 50th anniversary of a board game just 33 years after it came on the market, but Alfred Butts, who has been doing just that, has an explanation.

title: A.M.C. BIDS FOR WAGE CONCESSION
description: The American Motors Corporation has asked its employees to forgo future salary and benefit increases amounting to about 10 percent of their current compensation to help the company through its financial difficulties.

title: C.I.A. WON'T PUBLISH STUDIES
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has decided to stop publishing analyses for consumption by the general public because they take too much time to prepare and draw too much attention to the agency, a spokesman said Tuesday.

title: Oil Data Delayed
description: The weekly statistics of the American Petroleum Institute do not appear today because of the Veterans Day holiday yesterday. The statistics will appear in tomorrow's issue.

title: KALLESTAD LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ISLANDERS WIN, 4-3, ON NYSTROM'S GOAL
description: The Islanders' dominance over the Toronto Maple Leafs here, and their unbeaten record on the road were in jeopardy tonight with a little more than 10 minutes to play.

title: Pakistani Asks Study of Plan Made by Iran for Afghanistan
description: Pakistan said today that new Iranian peace proposals for Afghanistan deserved attention.

title: Iraq Says It Downed Iranian Jet in Dogfight
description: Iraq said it shot down an Iranian F-14 fighter plane today in a dogfight over the southern sector of the Persian Gulf war battlefront.

title: Clack Looks Sharp in Practice
description: It was Monday morning, and Jim Clack was leaving his home in Rocky Mount, N.C., on an errand when the phone rang.

title: Article 089706 -- No Title
description: An investigating committee says about $35,000 was funneled through a secret slush fund to the University of Arizona Athletic Department from 1971 to 1977, when it was discontinued.

title: EX-DEMOCRATIC CHIEF CLEARED IN PLANE FRAUD
description: A Federal prosecutor said yesterday that no charges would be filed against John C. White, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, in a case involving Libyan efforts to obtain military transport planes from the United States.

title: Alexander Lindey, 85, Lawyer And an Author of Textbooks
description: Alexander Lindey, a lawyer and author of textbooks on copyright, censorship and plagiarism, died Tuesday at St. Clare's Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: FURTHER TROUBLE DELAYS LAUNCHING OF SPACE SHUTTLE
description: Trouble with a data signal processing unit aboard the space shuttle Columbia interrupted countdown preparations yesterday and forced a delay in the planned launching.

title: The President and the Little Girl
description: With feeling, President Reagan told an affecting story at his news conference Tuesday about mindless regulations and a little girl in the hospital. The girl, a 3-year-old from Iowa named Katie Beckett, has been in the hospital with viral encephalitis since she was four months old. It costs $6,000 a month to keep her there, Mr. Reagan said, but she would be better off at home. That would cost only $1,000 a month, yet if she went home her parents would lose Federal Medicaid payments. Since they can't afford $1,000 a month, she stays in the hospital.

title: North Stars Score 15 Goals
description: The Minnesota North Stars routed the Winnipeg Jets, 15-2, tonight, falling one short of the National Hockey League record for most goals in a game.

title: M.T.A. to Issue Reports on Transit
description: Transit officials will begin a regular series of reports to the public on the performance of buses and subways, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: MacMillan Bloedel To Trim Logging
description: MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., Canada's largest forest products company, said it planned to curtail logging operations because of weak lumber markets.

title: FIRST TRIDENT SUB IS COMMISSIONED IN CONNECTICUT
description: With flags and pennants flying and a ceremonial guard of 30 sword-carrying officers in black uniforms and gold braid standing above the missile tubes, the first Trident ballistic-missile submarine was commissioned here this morning.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article on the discovery of a rare New Guinea bird in yesterday's Times, the affiliation of Dr. Donald Bruning was incorrectly reported. He is curator of birds, Department of Ornithology, the New York Zoological Society.

title: ISRAEL'S ORTHODOX COMMUNITY: TO CORRECT A ONE-SIDED PORTRAYAL
description: To the Editor:

title: 11th Officer Suspended In Texas Racial Incident
description: The authorities have suspended an 11th police officer in an investigation of charges that off-duty officers beat and harassed black residents of an apartment hotel.

title: STOCKMAN'S VIEWS TOUCH OFF FUROR
description: David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, became the focus of a major controversy today because of what Democrats termed a ''devastating admission'' that he never had much faith in the Reagan Administration's economic theories and projections.

title: INTERNATIONAL CONTROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1980 figures restated to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in Jan 1981

title: Canadiens 7, Rockies 0
description: DENVER (AP) - Chris Nilan scored his first two goals of the season in a 31-second span of the first period for Montreal, and Doug Jarvis scored three goals in the third period. Nilan, a right wing in his third season, had played in only five of the Canadiens' first 15 games. After Keith Acton opened the scoring at 11:46 on a rebound, Nilan put a 20-footer from the right side past the Colorado goalie Glenn Resch, who was screened on the play, at 13:44. Then Larry Robinson set up Nilan on a 2-on-1 break at 14:15.

title: 'Oh, Brother!' Closes
description: ''Oh, Brother!,'' a musical based loosely on Shakespeare's ''The Comedy of Errors,'' closed last night after its third performance at the Anta Theater. The show, which had book, lyrics, choreography and direction by Donald Driver and music by Michael Valenti, played 13 previews.

title: Boston Backs Jobs Proposal
description: Bostonians voted overwhelmingly to urge Congress to spend more on jobs than on nuclear weapons and military programs for foreign nations, according to results of a nonbindng referendum that were released yesterday. The vote was 42,910 to 16,397 in favor of jobs, with 38,191 voters not marking their ballots on the question. About 36 percent of the city's registered voters went to the polls.

title: WAYS TO PREVENT MAIL-ORDER DELAYS
description: THAT thump you hear against your door may very well be the sound of a mail-order catalogue, for this is their season. Ordering merchandise from your favorite armchair may sound like the perfect way to avoid lines, traffic and the crush of shoppers, but it does have its drawbacks.

title: Cost of Rearing Child Said to Be $134,000
description: A child born now may cost at least $100,000 more to rear to the age of 18 than a child born in 1960, the Agriculture Department says.

title: ROCKWELL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Holiday Trading Curb
description: Because of the Veterans Day holiday, there was no trading yesterday in foreign exchange or in Treasury notes, bills and bonds.

title: FRENCH NATIONALIZATIONS
description: Tensions in France have deepened over the Government's decision to expropriate five major industrial conglomerates and 36 banks, in the largest wave of nationalization in Europe since 1945. This policy would bring 95 percent of French bank deposits and up to 17 percent of production under Government control. When even Chancellor Helmut Schmidt is cutting budgets, why has the Mitterrand Government chosen a policy so boldly at odds with conservative strategies in fashion in the West?

title: Third St. Music School Honors Schuman, Segal
description: William Schuman, the composer, and Martin E. Segal, chairman of Lincoln Center, received the 1981 awards for distinguished achievement in music and the arts given by the Third Street Music School Settlement on Tuesday.

title: Market Place; Large Assets At Low Value
description: NOT since the bear market of 1974 have so many quality companies sold at share prices so low that takeovers could be financed with their liquid assets.

title: Japan Lists Trade Figures
description: Japan's exports last month totaled $12.253 billion, unchanged from the year before, while imports dropped 3.2 percent, to $10.02 billion, officials said today.

title: WHY MANHATTAN'S 6TH DISTRICT WAS RESHAPED
description: To the Editor:

title: AHMANSON, H F, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $34.1 million gain for the qr and 9 mos from the sale of real estate and gains of $2.1 million for the qr and $10 million for the 9 mos from the repurchase of mortgage backed bonds...C-Net income including $3.6 million gain from the repurchase of bonds

title: Weinberger Says Titans Will Be Removed in '82
description: A Defense Department letter to Representative Dan Glickman, Democrat of Kansas, has outlined plans to remove aging Titan II nuclear missiles from underground silos in three states beginning next fall.

title: ANDREW CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CALENDAR OF EVENTS: COLONIAL AMERICANA
description: The Colonial Revival in America, Winterthur Museum, Winterthur, Del.

title: GREAT SOUTHWEST INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Great Southwest had no operational activities in 1980; Net income figures represent interest from investments; yr-ago results include $50,226 or 2 cents a shr extraordinary tax credit

title: ONE OF THOSE QUITE FASHIONABLE BENEFITS
description: IT may come as a surprise, but all charity benefits are not equal. There are worthy causes and there are fashionable worthy causes. That a hospital is fashionable (would you believe it?) does not mean that it is more worthwhile than others, and a fashionable cultural event is not automatically better than others. The term simply indicates that the people who have taken them up are well known, social or rich, and that they then get their equally well-known, social or rich friends to contribute large sums and appear at their fund-raising parties.

title: RANCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After foreign currency losses of $523,000 for the qr and $2,665,000 for the yr...C-Includes foreign currency gains of $1,098,000 for the qr and $1,194,000 for the yr

title: BOND SPRINGS STATION, Australia
description: THE red heart of central Australia extends for hundreds of miles. Hot, rocky and dusty, the Outback of its Northern Territory is the kind of pioneering challenge that can break the strongest will.

title: G.P.U. Postpones Coal-Fired Plant
description: Citing problems from the cost of cleanup at its Three Mile Island nuclear generating plant and other factors, the General Public Utilities Corporation ruled out near-term construction of a proposed $1 billion coal-fired power plant in western Pennsylvania.

title: Butz Talks of Recovery
description: Former Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said today that he was ''coming along O.K.,'' as he recuperates from emergency surgery last Saturday. ''I'm supposed to be released tomorrow,'' Mr. Butz said by telephone from his hospital room. ''The doctor tells me I can go home a week from today.'' Mr. Butz and his wife were vacationing with some other friends from Indiana on nearby Longboat Key when he was stricken with severe stomach pains.

title: JEFFERSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After income from discontinued operations of a life insurance subsidiary of $2,363...C-After losses from discontinued operati of $99,706 in the qr and $85,980 in the 6 mos...D-After a loss discontinued operations of $155,470

title: Changing Partners in Chad
description: Chad, like many African colonies, became a country before it was really a nation. The 20 years since it gained independence from France have been years of strife between the Moslem nomads of the Saharan north and the Christian and animist tribes of the more arable south. So far, geography has not relieved the tensions; Chad is landlocked, poor and surrounded by wary neighbors. But it may be sitting atop a form of salvation - petroleum, uranium and gold.

title: Ethnic Melees Reported In Caucasus Region
description: Soviet authorities sent extra security forces and imposed a curfew in a southern mountain city late last month after disorders among two ethnic groups, according to unofficial reports reaching Moscow. No official reports of the incident have appeared here.

title: Former Police Chief Arrested On Drug Charges in Florida
description: A former police chief who recently ran unsuccessfully for sheriff of Sarasota County was arrested yesterday on a charge conspiring to deliver more than four tons of marijuana to state undercover agents.

title: Brazil Oil Output Up
description: Brazil's oil production averaged 231,257 barrels a day in October, up 33.2 percent from a year earlier, the state oil company announced today. Offshore production jumped 85.8 percent, to nearly 110,000 barrels a day; onshore production rose 6.1 percent, to 121,141 barrels daily. the first nine months of 1981, to 190,600 units, while deliveries in

title: WIDER HOUSE ROLE IN A.T.&T. DEBATE
description: Every branch of government seems to be getting in on the act of reshaping the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and, in the process, national policy in telecommunications.

title: BAR LEADER FEARS CRISIS OVER CURBS ON COURTS
description: The president of the American Bar Association warned tonight that attacks being mounted in Congress against the Federal courts may lead to ''a possible constitutional crisis that could prove the most serious since our great Civil War.''

title: Sports of The Times; The Next General Manager
description: I N all the commotion over whether the Yankees will retain Reggie Jackson and Ron Guidry after tomorrow's re-entry draft, George Steinbrenner has quietly rehired Jeff Torborg, who may influence the team's future more than either of those two expensive free agents. Jeff Torborg has agreed to return as a coach next season, but, within the span of his new seven-year contract, look for him to emerge as the general manager, perhaps in the next two or three years.

title: STAGE: 2-PART 'PEER GYNT' OPENS AT C.S.C. REPERTORY
description: ''PEER GYNT'' and ''Brand'' are Ibsen's twin dark towers - soaring pinnacles, both dramatic and metaphysical, in which man undertakes an obsessional search for the meaning of life and the meaning of self. While Brand is the soul-burning believer, Peer is the heretical rogue, whom Shaw characterized as ''the pushing, competitive, success-craving man,'' ''the hero of the modern world.'' Peer's Odyssean adventure is among the most challenging in dramatic literature, which is, of course, why the play is often studied and so rarely staged.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Bancshares Inc., Houston, has elected W.C. Hatfield vice chairman of the holding company and vice chairman of its Allied Bank of Texas.

title: BL-Honda Auto Venture Reported
description: BL Ltd., Britain's struggling stateowned auto maker, said it would build a new car in Britain in partnership with the Honda Motor Company of Japan.

title: News Analysis
description: Twice in the last two weeks, President Reagan has said that published reports of conflicts among his foreign policy advisers were inaccurate and that they had injured the nation's ability to conduct international affairs. In his news conference Tuesday the President advised the press to ''reflect'' on whether such articles would ''aid in what we're trying to do in bringing peace to trouble spots like the Middle East and - or whether it's going to set us back.''

title: BUCKS SEND NETS TO 6TH LOSS IN 7 GAMES
description: About 30 minutes after the Nets were defeated by the Milwaukee Bucks, 100-88, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight, Larry Brown, the Nets' coach, was still trying to find an explanation.

title: P, AS IN PRINCE AND PAINT
description: He has his duties as the Duke of Edinburgh, but Britain's Prince Philip manages to find time for some amateur painting. And now 36 of his works are going on display in London to stir interest in a charity auction.

title: Article 089666 -- No Title
description: The golden leaves are falling, and the brilliant Indian summer days are over, but there is nothing sad about Prospect Park these days. It is, in fact, thriving.

title: UNUSUAL VOTING PATTERN FOUND IN COUNTY IN JERSEY
description: Approximately 20,000 more votes were cast in Middlesex County for Governor of New Jersey than for individual countywide races on Nov. 3.

title: TERENCE SMITH TO BE WASHINGTON TALK EDITOR
description: Terence Smith has been appointed editor of the Washington Talk page of The New York Times, A.M. Rosenthal, executive editor, announced yesterday. Mr. Smith, who has been acting editor in the introduction of Washington Talk, will report to Bill Kovach, Washington editor of The Times.

title: MONUMENT ENERGY SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Reagan Going to Texas
description: President Reagan will fly to Texas on Friday for a three-day weekend in Houston and San Antonio, the White House announced yesterday. On Friday night, Mr. Reagan will attend a dinner in Houston honoring his chief of staff, James A. Baker 3d, and other Presidential appointees from Texas. Mr. Reagan will fly to San Antonio on Saturday and stay overnight at Mr. Baker's ranch. The President will return to Washington Sunday.

title: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1981; The Economy
description: Budget director David A. Stockman is embroiled in a major controversy. In an interview in the December issue of The Atlantic Monthly, Mr. Stockman said he had never had much faith in the Reagan Administration's economic theories and projections. The admission was called ''devastating'' by Democrats and caused anger and dismay among senior White House aides. But the aides said Mr. Stockman was too valuable to be dismissed. A spokesman for Mr. Stockman did not disavow the quotations but said that Mr. Stockman thought his remarks were off the record. (Page A1.)

title: E.E.C. Appeal Lost by I.B.M.
description: The European Court of Justice today rejected a challenge by the International Business Machines Corporation to an antitrust investigation that the European Economic Community had begun into I.B.M.'s competitive practices in Europe.

title: HE'S the image of the international interior decorator - suave and sophisticated, with a coterie of clients, and projects in progress in several countries. Right now, he's restoring a huge neo-classical villa in Athens and has just swung through New York on his way from Washington, where he's working on renovation plans for the ballroom at the British Embassy. But John Stefanidis does not want to be called a decorator. ''That word is just not applicable,'' said the Alexandria-born Greek who has a staff of 10 people in his London office. ''What we do is about practicality - the closet space, the kitchen, and most of our real design work cannot be seen.'' What isn't is charming - and full of Stefanidis trademarks - a mix of materials, a breathtaking swimming pool, a well-landscaped garden, trellises and the furniture and fabrics that he designs. But who are his clients? ''The discreet elite,'' he said. ''The aristocracy in England, the creme
description: Above: Four ice cream dishes and saucers, $32.50 at Home Base, 2335 Broadway, at 84th Street. Below: Easy to read Seca scale, $140 at Lee Bailey at Henri Bendel. HOMEBEAT CUTLINE-RIGHT-C3

title: GARAN, APPAREL MAKER, NAMES OPERATING HEAD
description: Jerald Kamiel, 38, has been elected president and chief operating officer of Garan Inc., a major branded and unbranded manufacturer of apparel for men and children with headquarters in New York. He succeeds Seymour Lichtenstein, 55, who was named chairman of the executive committee and remains chief executive officer.

title: MACMILLAN AFFIRMS GIBBS SCHOOL POST
description: Six months ago Eleanor P. Vreeland was named acting president of the Katharine Gibbs School, the business training organization owned by Macmillan Inc., following the sudden resignation of Lynn D. Salvage. Now the ''acting'' has been dropped, and Mrs. Vreeland is the full-fledged president and chief executive officer of the sevenbranch, 4,000-student operation.

title: Cosmos Name Werblin's Son
description: The Cosmos appointed Thomas D. Werblin as general manager yesterday, hours after Krikor Yepremian, vice president and general manager, and Peppe Pinton, a vice president, resigned.

title: Emmet Andrews, 65; Headed Postal Union
description: Emmet Andrews, a former president of the American Postal Workers Union, died of a stroke Sunday at John Muir Hospital in Walnut Creek, Calif. He was 65 years old and lived in Walnut Creek.

title: Index; International
description: Argentines flock abroad as dreams of riches die A2 Egypt and Israel renew Palestin- ian autonomy talks A3 Castro accuses the U.S. of ''a campaign of lies'' A4 Persian Gulf nations, at Riyadh, back Saudi peace plan A5 Chinese reiterate objections to a U.S. arms sale to Taiwan A8 Greece says it will have U.S. nu- clear weapons withdrawn A12 Soviet rejects Swedish complaint over submarine A12 On India's campuses, politics breeds violence A16 Washington Talk Briefing A26 New Senate office building, not yet open, stirs controversy A26 A family of envoys, touches of home and questions A26 General Around the Nation A18 Rabbit hunt arrests stir protest in Chicago A18 Proposed no-shine combat boot is failing Army tests A23 Disputes snarls Queens airports' expansion program B3 A 2d elderly couple attacked in their home in Richmond Hill B6 Health/Science Abortion of one twin is deplored by physicians A13 News Analysis Richard Eder explores France's quiescent peace movement A10 John Vinocur examines Germa- ny's left-nationalism A10 Jonathan Friendly on Reagan and the role of the press A25 Martin Tolchin looks at the con- flicts that shape the budget A26 Marcia Chambers discusses legality of mass drug arrests B15 Home Section Home My son, the architect: Houses for parents C1

title: THEATER: 'FIGHTING BOB,' LA FOLLETTE AND ROOSEVELT
description: ROBERT M. La FOLLETTE (1855-1925) was an authentic maverick in American politics. The ''Wisconsin Idea,'' as realized by La Follette during his many years as Governor and Senator, turned his state into what Theodore Roosevelt called a laboratory of democracy, and instituted Populist reforms that remain a cornerstone of grassroots liberalism. Tom Cole's play about La Follette, ''Fighting Bob,'' which is playing at the Astor Place Theater, was originally commissioned by the Milwaukee Repertory Theater as a work to celebrate a pivotal moment in Progressive government.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 12, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A jewelry salesman was abducted at gunpoint and robbed of more than $200,000 in gold cases and watch works outside his office at the Jardinary Company, at 155 Avenue of the Americas, at 9 A.M. The salesman, Max Addar, 48 years old, of Wantagh, L.I., was released unharmed when the two gunmen abandoned their stolen car in downtown Brooklyn. ... Thurmond Richards, 33, was found stabbed to death in his basement apartment at 88-11 208th Street in Queens Village by firemen who arrived to put out a small blaze at 5:20 A.M. ... The owner of a grocery at 1291 Clay Avenue in the South Bronx was shot in the head and critically wounded when he refused to turn over his money to a robber at 8:05 A.M. The assailant fled empty-handed. The grocer, Nelson Perez, 40, was taken to Bronx Lebanon Hospital with a bullet in his brain.

title: SALVADOR'S INQUIRY INTO NUNS' SLAYING STALLED
description: Investigations by the Salvadoran Government into the murders of four Roman Catholic missionaries last December are dormant and there is insufficient evidence at this time to charge anyone with the crimes, according to Salvadoran and United States officials.

title: REPUBLICAN SENATORS ON BUDGET UNIT DEFY REAGAN
description: Defying President Reagan, Senate Republicans on the Budget Committee began an effort today to cut Federal benefit programs in this fiscal year and balance the budget by 1984.

title: APL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HARPER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
F.B.I. CHIEF BACKS INFORMATION CURB
description: William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that details of the bureau's investigations into foreign counterintelligence, organized crime and terrorism should be released only to members of Congress and not to the public.

title: CHINA JAILS WOMAN FOR AFFAIR WITH FRENCHMAN
description: The Chinese Government has been trying to justify to the West the sentence it imposed on a Chinese woman who was arrested after she began living with a French diplomat in a compound for foreigners here.

title: IMMIGRATION POST LOSES ITS NOMINEE
description: Norman Braman, President Reagan's nominee for Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, withdrew his name from consideration today, saying that he wanted to devote himself to his automobile business in Florida.

title: BECTON DICKINSON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
All Souls Church Fair
description: A tradition that dates back more than 150 years continues tomorrow with the annual church fair of the Unitarian Church of All Souls, on Lexington Avenue and 80th Street.

title: Gas From Heater Is Blamed For Seven Louisiana Deaths
description: Investigators today blamed carbon monoxide gas from a space heater for the asphyxiation of a young couple and five children found sprawled throughout their unventilated home yesterday.

title: POP JAZZ
description: THE electric guitar is the most potent instrument in pop music's arsenal. Its prominence in music doesn't just have to do with the way it sounds; the way it looks is important, too. Would-be rockers practice wielding imaginary instruments in front of their bedroom mirrors, and rock's guitar stars hold and move their instruments as distinctively as they play them. Some crouch low and sweep the audience with their guitar neck as if it were a machine gun; others telegraph the forward thrust of their rhythms with expressive body English.

title: Steel Company To Modernize
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, said that it would spend $187 million in the next year and a half on a modernization program in a bid to ''move ahead and be competitive in the world market,'' .

title: 15TH CHESS GAME ADJOURNED, WITH A DRAW LIKELY
description: Anatoly Karpov, the world chess champion, adjourned the 15th game of his title defense against Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland in a drawish position. The 30-year-old Soviet champion was a pawn down, but there was no chance that he would lose the lifeless bishops-of-opposite-color ending.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: In reprinting the Saudi ''peace plan'' on Oct. 31, The Times did not take account of the full statement made by Crown Prince Fahd when he put forth the plan last August. Appended to the eight ''principles'' were three conditions upon which the plan is predicated.

title: Notes on People; Judge in Chicago Grounds a High Achiever
description: He may be becoming something of a hero to people impressed by his feats of derring-do, but Daniel Goodwin, who wears a ''Spiderman'' comic strip outfit when he climbs tall buildings, failed yesterday to impress a judge in Chicago.

title: WOODS PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $7,675,000 gain from the sale of oil and gas properties

title: QUICKPRINT OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the yr-ago qr are not available since the company was acquired Aug 6, 1981

title: LAKE SUPERIOR DISTRICT POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RETAIL SALES DOWN 1.5% IN OCTOBER
description: In a discouraging prelude to the usually brisk Christmas selling season, the Government reported today that retail sales fell 1.5 percent last month. The decline, to $87.2 billion, was the largest since April.

title: Japan to Discuss Plane With Boeing
description: Japanese aerospace officials plan to travel to Seattle next week to discuss a possible joint venture with the Boeing Company for development of a 150-seat aircraft, Boeing officials said.

title: A PECULIAR U.S. READING OF THE SAUDI PEACE PLAN
description: To the Editor:

title: ALLEGHENY BEVERAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: 1981 results include operations of Macke Co on an equity basis prior to its acquisition on Jan 30 on a consolidated basis; yr-ago results have been restated to LIFO accounting

title: Advertising; New Network Offers Ad Time
description: A new advertising vehicle of special interest to those seeking the consumer with more money to spend will have its debut Nov. 30. Called the Financial News Network, it will run on broadcast television stations in 13 markets with a potential audience of 21 million.

title: Money Funds Add $2.8 Billion
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds climbed $2.8 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to $172.7 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. It was the 25th consecutive weekly increase and the largest since Sept.23.

title: BEST PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
NETS GET LACEY FOR WOODSON
description: Coach Cotton Fitzsimmons of the Kansas City Kings once said of Sam Lacey: ''He'll be my starting center until the day someone rips the jersey off his back.''

title: Transactions
description: AUTO RACING

title: WILLCOX & GIBBS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes tax credits of $274,000 for the qr and $794,000 for the 9 mos...C-Includes tax credits of $251,000 for the qr and $601,000 for the 9 mos

title: HAIG SAYS U.S. ASKS CONSTRUCTIVE TIES WITH THE RUSSIANS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that American foreign policy sought to build a constructive relationship with Moscow while renewing traditional alliances. He also called for restoring American economic and military strength and promoting peaceful development in the third world.

title: CANADA REAFFIRMS FUELS PLAN
description: The Government tonight reaffirmed its national energy program as ''a great Canadian undertaking,'' but added that the special measures being employed to achieve more Canadian ownership of the oil and gas companies would not be extended to other sectors.

title: 20,000 FLOCK TO GARDEN FOR ROLLING STONES SHOW
description: Two decades after they began, the Rolling Stones played last night before a tumultuous, whistling, screaming, stomping crowd of 20,000 mostly teen-age fans at Madison Square Garden.

title: Canada Bank Rate Falls
description: The Bank of Canada's closely watched bank rate declined today by 1.49 percent, to 16.13 percent, its lowest level in 11 months. The central bank rate -the benchmark in determining the rate chartered banks charge their most creditworthy customers - fell to 17.62 percent last week. This week's decline extended a steady drop since August, when the rate peaked at a record 21.24 percent.

title: CFS CONTINENTAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for a change in accounting for compensated absences

title: Briefing
description: A S if the Office of Management and Budget doesn't have enough on its agenda with budget deficits, tax cuts and the uproar over the director's own confessional disclosures, the office is now being criticized by Congress for lagging in putting into effect the new paper-work reduction law. The law, one of the most ambitious Federal reform attempts in years, gave the budget office extensive powers to force the bureaucracy to reduce by 25 percent in two years' time the information collected and stored by the Government. This is no small dent in a massive problem that annually costs the Government and public an estimated $100 billion for storage and retrieval.

title: U.S. Envoy to U.N. in Hospital After Suffering Chest Pains
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, suffered severe chest pains on a flight from Washington, D.C., to New York last night and was rushed on arrival to New York Hospital, where she was admitted for several days of tests.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in Business Day on Wednesday incorrectly listed 1980 third-quarter earnings per share for Miller-Wohl, a clothing chain. The correct figure is 79 cents.

title: PLAN FOR DOMESTIC SPYING SAID TO BE MODIFIED
description: The Reagan Administration was reported tonight to have discarded its plan to allow the Central Intelligence Agency to infiltrate and influence domestic organizations.

title: CHASTENED TEAM PLAYER
description: For the first time in a year of virtuoso performances, David A. Stockman was on the defensive. Contrite and visibly shaken, the director of the Office of Management and Budget appeared before the television cameras in the White House briefing room to say that President Reagan had offered him a ''second chance'' and that he was gratefully accepting it. He would stay on in his $70,900-a-year job because the President wanted him ''on the team.''

title: NORTHWESTERN STEEL & WIRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Robin Ann Rost Married To James H. Fairclough
description: Robin Ann Rost and James Henry Fairclough, who are equestrians, were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Newton, N.J. The Rev. Ralph Nelson performed the ceremony.

title: FASHION TWO TWENTY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KELLY REPORTED ON REAGAN'S APPOINTEES
description: An official of the Republican National Committee who has been suspended pending inquiries into his background sent reports to the White House on the political backgrounds of Presidential appointees, an assistant to President Reagan said today.

title: Dean Carpenter Dead at 79; Former Hilton Vice President
description: Dean Carpenter, a former vice president of Hilton International Corporation, died Monday at his home in Little Compton, R.I. He was 79 years old and was a former resident of Manhattan.

title: STOCKMAN ARTICLE POSES JOURNALISTIC QUESTIONS
description: Senior editors of The Washington Post said yesterday that they had approved in advance an agreement under which an assistant managing editor repeatedly interviewed David A. Stockman, and wrote about the interviews in The Atlantic Monthly.

title: Burroughs Price Rises
description: The Burroughs Corporation said today that it would increase the lease and purchase price of its information processing equipment by 5 percent, effective Jan. 1. The company added that prices on selected products would be increased by up to 10 percent.

title: 3 BANKS CUT PRIME RATE TO 16 1 2%
description: Three major banks lowered their prime lending rates yesterday by half a percentage point, to 16 1/2 percent, the lowest level of the past year.

title: Thatcher Wins Party Vote
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was formally re-elected today as leader of the governing Conservative Party. Mrs. Thatcher, Prime Minister since May 1979, was re-elected unanimously.

title: Notes on People; Getty,25, Reported Ill
description: He was born to a life of ease, but life has been far from easy for J. Paul Getty 3d, a 25-year-old grandson of the late oil billionaire. In 1973, at the age of 16, he was abducted in Rome by kidnappers who cut off his right ear and held him for six months before releasing him for a $2.8 million ransom.

title: MINA H. HEIDENSON
description: Mina Hager Heidenson, a mezzo soprano who championed contemporary music between the wars, died on Saturday in La Grange Park, Ill.

title: John Cale in TriBeCa
description: The avant-garde composer and pianist John Cale will give two solo performances this weekend at Stilwende, 225 West Broadway, between White and Franklin Street in the TriBeCa section.

title: MONOGRAM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes gain equal to 7 cents a shr from the sale of an excess manufacturing facility and $327,000 after tax reserve in connection with the company's real estate operations

title: Biology Teacher Held In Excessive Lesson
description: A teacher was charged with contributing to the delinquency of a minor after one of his students tried to dig up human remains for a class contest, the state police said today.

title: HOW THE WEATHERMAN FACTION WAS BORN
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Associates Corp. of North America amended its pending offer of $100 million of senior notes. The issue is now set to mature on Feb. 1, 1990.

title: BIG THEATER-BUFF BAZAAR RETURNS
description: As the technology of home entertainment lurches forward to microcassettes and home-video recorders, there are still those who thrill to the sound and the look of an old 78 rpm recording. For yearners after old records and old movies and old plays, there is opportunity this weekend at the Library of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. It is the library's 10th annual Giant Bazaar on Sunday from 10:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Admission is $2.

title: VERDEROSA ENLIVENS MEADOWLANDS SHOW
description: Johnny Verderosa, who says he retires before every fight, ''but then I realize I have to pay the rent,'' saved the first boxing show at the sparkling new Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight.

title: Notes on People; Judicial Benchmarks
description: As one new judge joined the Federal District Court in Manhattan this week, another observed his 30th anniversary on the court. Judge John E. Sprizzo became the court's newest member when he was sworn in Tuesday in the United States Court House in Foley Square.

title: TEXAS CITIES LEAD U.S. IN THE RATE OF DIVORCES
description: Dallas-Fort Worth and Houston, economic magnets for restless, uprooted young opportunity-seekers from everywhere, have become the divorce co-capitals of metropolitan America.

title: AMERICAN BANKERS INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating loss...C-Net loss; 1980 results have been restated

title: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHAD'S LEADER ACCUSES THE SUDAN OF INVADING AS LIBYANS WITHDRAW
description: The President of Chad, Goukouni Oueddei, said today that his country had been invaded by Sudanese troops and Chadian rebels after Libyan forces began withdrawing.

title: SPAIN IN NATO
description: It is taken for granted that Spain's parliamentary vote to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is a positive development and should be welcomed in Washington. After all, NATO is an organization under American military leadership and it follows that we should be pleased to have one more applicant at the door, especially since Greece is talking of resigning.

title: Topics Performance Tests; After the Veto
description: Governor Carey's veto of the complicated New York real estate tax reform is the right second step. He now promises to propose a fairer, more comprehensible tax policy.

title: KAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including gains of $3.7 million for the qr and $4,550,000 for the 9 mos on the sale of PVO assets...C-Including $4,023,00 gain on the sale of PVO assets...D-Net income including $4,877, gain on the sale of PVO assets; yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 15 percent stock divd in Feb 1981

title: STRONG BOND RALLY CONTINUES
description: The strongest bond market rally of 1981 rolled into its third week yesterday, spearheaded by higher prices for Government securities. The Government market, after halting Wednesday for the Veterans Day holiday, benefited from the spillover effect of surging prices for corporate bonds that were traded Wednesday. Yesterday, corporates displayed small gains.

title: BRASS: AMERICAN QUINTET
description: THE American Brass Quintet celebrated its 20th anniversary last year, yet it appears to have come nowhere near exhausting the literature in that time, let alone the possibilities for putting more than five players on the stage.

title: Tax Leasing Deals Mount
description: More companies yesterday took advantage of the chance to complete retroactive tax leasing deals before tonight's deadline. In such transactions, corporations in effect sell tax credits and depreciation deductions they cannot use to corporations seeking tax shelters.

title: INSURERS SUPPORT BUMPER STANDARDS
description: The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, an industry-sponsored research group, today made public a study indicating that most Americans are willing to pay for automobile bumpers that can sustain a 5-mile-an-hour crash without damage.

title: BAN LIFTED ON SALE OF DETERGENTS IN SUFFOLK COUNTY
description: Residents of Suffolk County will no longer have to fight ring-around-the-collar without the pow-pow-power of their favorite laundry detergents.

title: Grumman Credit
description: The Grumman Corporation said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had reached agreement with eight banks for a $200 million credit.

title: N.F.L. TEST 40 ON INJURED LISTS
description: The National Football League has put 40 players through independent physical examinations in New York since the start of the season to determine if they had injuries that justified their being placed on the injured-reserve list by their teams.

title: BIOMEDICAL REFERENCE LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for a pooling acquisition; yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for 3-for-2 stock splits in Oct 1980 and June 1981

title: AMID JOY AT LAUNCHING, WHISPERS OF DOUBT RISE
description: The lapidary work done, as if on a damaged diamond, the first secondhand rose of America's space age got aloft at last today. Time - overtime, rather, at a cost of between $1.5 million and $2 million for the latest delay -and tinkering made for a momentous encore of the space shuttle Columbia.

title: THE NEW POTENTIAL AT CROCKER
description: The Crocker National Corporation, by all accounts, is bursting with potential. A $500 million investment by Midland Bank Ltd. of Britain for a 51 percent stake in Crocker could catapult California's fifth-largest bank holding company, with current assets of $20.8 billion, into a banking giant with assets of more than $30 billion.

title: Quartet in Brooklyn
description: Chamber music at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, continues this weekend with performances by the quartet of Paula Robison, flutist; Daniel Phillips, violinist; Alexander Heller, bassoonist, and Kenneth Cooper, harpsichordist.

title: Giants Running Short of Healthy Backs
description: The Giants had so many running backs two days ago that they could afford to waive Bo Matthews, a fullback, when they brought back Jim Clack to play center. Today they put Doug Kotar on injured reserve and found themselves down to three healthy running backs - Louis Jackson, Leon Bright and Leon Perry.

title: MAL WALDRON BACK IN A SOLO CONCERT
description: MAL WALDRON, the jazz pianist who settled in Europe 15 years ago, is best known for his work as Billie Holiday's accompanist during the last two years of her life and for his association with Charles Mingus, Eric Dolphy and Booker Little. His playing with Miss Holiday represented a period in his musical life when he was playing what he called ''in'' music - music that follows established forms and has harmonic variations and melodic and rhythmic forms that are generally accepted. His work with Mr. Mingus, Mr. Dolphy and Mr. Little was the beginning of his involvement with ''free'' music, which has no limitations or rules.

title: WITH 11 STRAIGHT, LEAHY NEARS FIELD-GOAL MARK
description: ''What's new today?'' Pat Leahy asked a visitor at the Jets' camp. ''I've got an interesting statistic,'' the visitor told Leahy. ''Oh, good. What is it?'' ''It's about you.'' ''I don't want to hear about it,'' Leahy said. And he knocked on his locker, which is made of wood. Small wonder. Leahy has gone from the American Conference's leading scorer in 1978, to an erratic kicker in 1979, to one who was threatened with loss of his job in 1980.

title: Index; International
description: Britain's ''Ban the Bomb'' movement gains new strength A2 France moves to close jet sale to India A3 200,000 Poles end wildcat strike, but other protests go on A3 Israeli official seems to retreat from remarks on Saudi plan A4 Around the World A5 Israelis shoot Palestinian student A6 Salvador's investigation of nuns' slaying stalled A11 Government/Politics Rights nominee not well known back home A20 Reagan tells black reporters he backs Voting Rights Act A21 F.B.I. chief backs information curb A25 White House considering further cuts in food stamp program A26 Text of Carey's message vetoing bill on tax assessments B3 Washington Talk Briefing A28 Clare Booth Luce is back in town, as peppery as ever A28 Legal Services Corporation struggles to survive A28 General Around the Nation A12 U.S. rests case in espionage trial of Polish citizen A15 Study finds higher incidence of toxic shock A19 Lease sale would permit oil drilling near New York shores B2 Health/Science Artificial genetic material used to create polio virus A12 Doubts emerge amid jubilance at second shuttle launching A31 News Analysis Hedrick Smith on David Stockman's budget remarks A1 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 An odyssey to Greek Astoria C1 Theater: Broadway C2

title: M-A-COM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $33,000 for the qr and $595,000 for the 9 mos...C-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $856,000 for the qr and $1.1 million for the 9 mos

title: O'NEILL SEEKING $83 MILLION RISE IN TAX REVENUE
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill said tonight that he would ask the General Assembly to approve $83 million in increased taxes during the special session that convenes next Thursday. He also said that 665 state workers would be laid off to help close a budget gap of $121 million in the present fiscal year.

title: NABISCO BRANDS TO BUY LIFE SAVERS
description: Nabisco Brands Inc., formed earlier this year by the merger of Nabisco Inc. and Standard Brands, said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase Life Savers Inc. from the Squibb Corporation for approximately $250 million in cash and notes and the assumption of certain Life Saver liabilities.

title: Bill to Bar Arm Band At Polls Is Introduced
description: A bill that would prohibit the wearing of arm bands and the carrying of weapons by anyone but on-duty police officers within 200 feet of a polling place was introduced in the New Jersey Senate today under the sponsorship of several Democratic lawmakers.

title: TRULY: GRANDFATHER, 44, HAS A BIRTHDAY IN SPACE
description: Capt. Richard Harrison Truly of the Navy yesterday became the first grandfather, so far as is known in this country, to enter space. And he is a young grandfather: Because of previous delays in the second flight of the space shuttle Columbia, Captain Truly's liftoff occurred on his 44th birthday.

title: In the Nation; A TROJAN HORSE INDEED
description: David Stockman now says that he should not have called President Reagan's ''supply-side'' reduction in practically everybody's tax rates ''a Trojan horse to bring down'' the top rate on the wealthiest Americans. But the phrase is apt; and state and municipal governments are finding out that it's applicable to the Reagan program in more ways than one.

title: Art, too, gets used up.
description: ARS LONGA, vita breva, they say, but some art objects last longa than others.
