A billboard painted by Alex Katz in 1977, a 24 foot by 20 foot frieze of women's faces atop the building at 1481 Broadway, was painted over last week with a garish advertisement for ''Mafia Kingpin,'' a book about prison life by Sonny Gibson. And at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, the bookstore redesigned by Red Grooms in 1979 as a takeoff on the Pierpont Morgan Library and the Mendoza Bookstore downtown, has been diminished somewhat in the interests of sales efficiency. A few of the shiny vinyl pieces created by Mr. Grooms to flesh out his painted environment have been removed from a sales island, where they interfered with the visibility of the stock.

title: TRANS-LUX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago gain includes gain equal to 15 cents a shr from the sale of a theater leasehold in Huntsville, Ala.

title: UNIVERSAL FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: 1980 results restated to include the acquisition of Major Brands Inc in July 1980

title: Rockets Open Tonight
description: The New Jersey Rockets will inaugurate indoor soccer at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight by opening the Major Indoor Soccer League season with a game against the defending champion New York Arrows.

title: Fiasco on the Farm
description: House and Senate conferees are still dotting the ''i'' 's and crossing the ''$'' 's on a new farm bill, but the outlines are clear enough. Not surprisingly, price supports for grains and dairy products are less generous than farmers wished, but considerably more generous than taxpayers and consumers might have hoped.

title: MYRON L. MAYER
description: Myron L. Mayer, president of Korn, Mayer & Klein, real estate managers, died Wednesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: G.E. Gets Queries On Flatiron Plant
description: At least eight groups, including one formed by employees, have indicated an interest in buying the General Electric Company's flatiron plant here that is scheduled for closing in February, a G.E. spokesman said.

title: Writer and a Convicted Spy Hope to Be Married on Jan. 2
description: A freelance writer says she and Andrew Daulton Lee, a convicted spy, plan to marry on his 30th birthday in the Federal Correctional Institute at Lompoc, Calif.

title: ART: SMALL UNIVERSES IN BILL JENSEN PAINTINGS
description: IN a period that has been dominated by the big picture - by paintings that cover entire walls and fill the eye with highly simplified forms and immense ''fields'' of color - the re-emergence of the small painting that concentrates a great deal of pictorial energy in a very circumscribed space was bound to come as something of a shock. It required, at the very least, a certain adjustment in the mechanism of esthetic response. The change of scale called for a shift in the kind of attention the viewer brought to the object under scrutiny.

title: MGM GRAND MOTELS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Revs for the latest periods include insurance proceeds of $13.3 million for the qr and $62.8 million for the yr from the business interuption caused by fire at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas

title: Debbie Boone due in 'Seven Brides,' from film musical.
description: STAR glitter from Hollywood is falling on Broadway. Raquel Welch is in rehearsal to replace Lauren Bacall in ''Woman of the Year'' for two weeks, starting Dec. 1. Cher will open after the first of the year in ''Come Back to the 5 and Dime, Jimmy Dean, Jimmy Dean,'' Ed Graczyk's new play, which will be directed by Robert Altman. Now comes word that Debby Boone is going to make her debut on Broadway debut, too.

title: Around the World; Danish Cabinet Falls; Election Set for Dec. 8
description: Denmark's minority Social Democratic Government was toppled today as Parliament voted down an economic program that Prime Minister Anker Jorgensen had termed vital to revive the nation's stagnant economy. Mr. Jorgensen thereupon announced that special elections would be held Dec. 8.

title: BRAVES SAY THEY WANT JACKSON
description: George Steinbrenner and Ted Turner can usually be relied on to stir up interest in the free agent market, and they have come through again this year: Steinbrenner because he has not signed Ron Guidry and Reggie Jackson, Turner because he is eager to sign Jackson.

title: 'TICKET TO HEAVEN,' A SLEEPER ABOUT CULTS
description: ''TICKET TO HEAVEN'' is an absorbing, frightening, entirely believable movie, which is particularly amazing in view of its subject matter. This is the story of a young man who is seduced into joining a religious cult, and it presents the group's indoctrination process in terms that are graphic, terrifyingly plausible and all too easy to understand. It is also the story of his friends and relatives' efforts to get him back, after he has become a near-zombie with close-cropped hair and a fierce but automatic dedication to the cult's leader. A credit at the end of the movie says this is fiction. That credit is the one thing about ''Ticket to Heaven'' that is genuinely funny.

title: U.S. ENVOY UNHURT IN ATTACK IN PARIS
description: A gunman fired six shots at the top-ranking American diplomat in Paris as he was leaving his home this morning, but the envoy escaped unhurt.

title: Turnbull Goes to Kings
description: The third major hockey trade in 72 hours saw the Toronto Maple Leafs sending the defenseman Ian Turnbull to the Los Angeles Kings for Billy Harris, a right wing who formerly played for the Islanders, and John Gibson, a defenseman. Turnbull had long been at odds with Toronto management and had asked before the season to be traded.

title: HUNTINGTON HEALTH SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
PENNSYLVANIA ENGINEERING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STUDY FINDS A HIGHER FREQUENCY OF TOXIC SHOCK
description: Medical researchers in Minnesota suspect that toxic shock syndrome, a sometimes fatal but apparently rare disease occurring mostly in menstruating women who use tampons, occurs more frequently but is less often fatal than previously thought.

title: LIFE AT AN ASHRAM, SEARCH FOR INNER PEACE
description: AT the start of ''Ashram,'' a title announces that this film has been condemned by the followers of Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, even though Wolfgang Dobrowolny, who wrote and directed ''Ashram,'' was a Rajneesh disciple at the time the film was made. Mr. Dobrowolny may not have intended any treachery, but it's understandable that the Rajneesh organization would be upset by even a straightforward, unbiased film record of its activities. That is largely what ''Ashram,'' which opens today at the Waverly theater, appears to be.

title: FLORIO ASKS FOR RECOUNT OF ALL VOTES
description: Representative James J. Florio, the Democratic candidate for Governor of New Jersey, petitioned today for a recount of all the votes cast on Nov. 3. The request was likely to be granted tomorrow morning.

title: Foreign Affairs; BACK TO MIDEAST BASICS; Paris, Nov. 12 - The Middle East is sharply dividing the West again, showing once more the lack of coherent policy. There is a danger now that the Sinai peace force - to move in when the Israelis are due to move out - is falling apart even before it takes shape.
description: The immediate squabble is that Britain's Lord Carrington has come out in favor of Saudi Arabia's plan for a Palestinian state, and Israel says it won't accept troops from any country that takes that stand.

title: CAMPO'S PRINCELET SCORES IN AN UPSET
description: Princelet, a little 3-year-old colt that John Campo bought for $5,500 at a used-horse sale three months ago, prevailed in a long stretch duel to win the $336,800 Meadowlands Cup tonight at Meadowlands Race Track.

title: CHANGING AT THE OFFICE: INSTANT ELEGANCE
description: A couple of hours at the beauty salon, a little nap, a leisurely bath, clothes laid out neatly, and off to the party. It's all wishful thinking for thousands of career women. Their schedule reads meetings, telephone calls, appointments, interviews, a dash into the ladies' room and 15 minutes later, abracadabra, a new woman, possibly harried and exhausted but to all outward appearances fresh and sparkling.

title: Around the Nation; 10 Policemen Indicted In Chicago Drugs Case
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted 10 police officers for narcotics racketeering, extortion and civil rights violations, and prosecutors said further indictments might be returned.

title: Israel to Continue Flights
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon said tonight that Israel would continue its aerial reconnaissance patrols over Saudi Arabia. Saudi Arabia said that it had chased Israeli planes out of its northern airspace on Monday. Mr. Sharon, replying to questions on his return from Palestinian autonomy talks in Cairo, said the question of the overflights had not been discussed. He added it was clear to the countries of the region, as it was to the United States, that Israel would defend itself.

title: NORTHWESTERN NATIONAL INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Books
description: The Worm's Tale By Jane E. Brody NEW GUINEA TAPEWORMS AND JEW- ISH GRANDMOTHERS. Tales of Para- sites and People. By Robert S. Desowitz. 224 pages. W.W. Norton. $12.95.

title: cThe Atlantic Monthly (Reprinted by permission.)
description: The following quotations from David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, appeared in an article by William Greider in the December issue of The Atlantic Monthly. The elisions were made by Mr. Greider.

title: COLONIAL COMMERCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IN PURSUIT OF THE HIJACKER WHO LEAPED TO FAME
description: TEN years ago this month, a young man calling himself D.B. Cooper, dressed in a business suit, carrying a briefcase, wearing two parachutes and $200,000 richer than when he boarded the plane, bailed out of a 727 jet cruising 10,000 feet over the state of Washington. In this fashion ended one of the most successful hijackings in airline history, and one of the nation's most unsuccessful manhunts was begun. To this date no trace of the high-flying extortioner has been found.

title: WORLD OF HOMOSEXUALS
description: TONIGHT at 9:30, ABC-TV wins the violence award for a new series with the special 90-minute premiere of ''Strike Force,'' the Aaron Spelling-Douglas Cramer production that brings back Robert Stack to the gangbusters arena of television. This time around, Mr. Stack is playing a Los Angeles police captain named Frank Murphy, not to be confused with NBC's ''Father Murphy,'' played by Merlin Olsen.

title: DRILLING FOR OIL PROPOSED NEAR NEW YORK SHORES
description: Exploratory drilling for gas and oil as close as three miles from the shores of New York, New Jersey and five other mid-Atlantic states would be permitted in a lease sale proposed by the Reagan Administration.

title: VERNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Geoffrey Horne Joins 'Merrily' Cast; Geoffrey Horne Joins 'Merrily We Roll Along'
description: Geoffrey Horne, the stage and screen actor who had a major role as a young commando in the film ''The Bridge on the River Kwai,'' is a late addition to the cast of the new Broadway musical ''Merrily We Roll Along.'' He entered the show last Tuesday night in a featured role.

title: No Headline
description: 200,000 POLES END 22-DAY WILDCAT STRIKE BUT OTHER PROTESTS GO ON

title: M-G-M PICKS PRESIDENT TO SUCCEED BEGELMAN
description: Donald Sipes, 53, has joined the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company as president and chief operating officer. His appointment comes less than two months after David Begelman, the 59-year-old motion picture executive, left those M-G-M posts to become chairman and chief executive officer of its United Artists Corporation subsidiary.

title: FUND DELEGATE EXPLAINS U.S. POSITION ON INDIA
description: Since the International Monetary Fund approved on Monday a $5.8 billion loan to India, the largest single outlay ever made by the 143-nation agency, questions have been raised about why the United States abstained from voting. Speaking by telephone from his Washington office yesterday, Richard D. Erb, 40, the American representative on the governing board of the fund, explained the action.

title: SHELLER-GLOBE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $1,284,000 gain from discontinued operations... C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations; of $19,668,000 for the qr and $22,083,000 for the yr

title: JURY TOLD OF ATTACK ON LIBYAN
description: Eugene A. Tafoya's lawyer said today that Mr. Tafoya, a former Green Beret, believed that he was working for the Central Intelligence Agency and acted in self-defense when he shot and partly blinded a dissident Libyan who is a student in the United States.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split Rate, 16.50-17.00** Rates before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.+ Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.N.A. Not available because markets were closed for the Veterans Day holiday.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: The Lambert Incident
description: A confessed racketeer cooperating with a Government investigation of contract slayings testified that a scuffle involving Jack Lambert, the Pittsburgh Steeler linebacker, might have been a factor in the killing of a man. The incident was described by Charles (Monster) Kellington at a hearing in Allegheny County Common Pleas Court for Miles Gabler, one of three men charged in the killing of Thomas Sacco. Partly because of the Lambert incident, Mr. Kellington said, there were hard feelings between the victim and another man involved in the case, William (Eggy) Prosdocimo of Pittsburgh. Mr. Prosdocimo is charged with paying Mr. Gabler $600 to kill Mr. Sacco. Mr. Kellington said that Mr. Sacco ''was mad because Eggy didn't jump in to help'' during an assault on Lambert, which, the witness said, occurred in a Pittsburgh discotheque in May 1979.

title: Flea Market Wins Reprieve
description: The neighborhood flea market and green market sponsored by the Parent-Teacher Association of Public School 183 on East 67th Street in Manhattan, has won a reprieve from a threat by the Board of Education to close it down. It will be open tomorrow as usual.

title: PIZZA INN (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
Notes on People; Move for Carey Aide
description: Thomas P. Regan, who recently resigned as administrative assistant to Governor Carey, has been named vice president for governmental affairs at the Battery Park City Authority, a subagency of the state's Urban Development Corporation.

title: Sambo's Closings In 8 States
description: Sambo's Restaurants Inc., confirming earlier reports, said that it had closed down some of its outlets in eight states in a ''store-by-store evaluation'' to weed out unprofitable operations.

title: WOOLWORTH SLIDES IN QUARTER
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company reported yesterday that its earnings in the third fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31 plunged, while sales slipped one-half of 1 percent.

title: About Real Estate; CO-OP CONVERSIONS: THE PITFALLS OF NONEVICTION PLANS
description: It was in the hope of reducing renters' anxieties in cooperative conversions in the early 1970's that the state Attorney General's office began to encourage the so-called noneviction route to building conversions. This gave the sponsor, or seller, the option of selling the property to a cooperative corporation without the requirement of achieving sales to the tenants in 35 percent of the apartments.

title: SANTA FE TO N.Y. BY HAND
description: Now there is a Santa Fe on Fifth Avenue as well as one in New Mexico. The one in New York is a shop selling crafts by artisans from New Mexico, and it opened this week on the second floor of Saks Fifth Avenue.

title: EMF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credit

title: OLYMPIA BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN SOLAR KING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CENTRAL SAVINGS BANK
description: The Manhattan Savings Bank said yesterday that it had made a bid to acquire the ailing Central Savings Bank, the 24th-largest savings bank in New York City.

title: PUBLISHING: ANATOMY OF AN AUTHOR
description: ALMOST 25 years ago a 1,000-page manuscript that had made the rounds of New York publishers came into St. Martin's Press. It was read by Sherman Baker, a veteran editor who was not terribly enthusiastic about the endless descriptions of trout fishing but who reported that buried in the manuscript was a teriffic courtroom drama.

title: Search of Prisoner Linked to Rioting
description: HARTFORD (AP) - A search of an inmate for contraband led to the violent outbreak on Nov. 4 that injured six guards at the Somers state prison, according to State Correction Commissioner John R. Manson. But Mr. Manson said he had no evidence to show the incident had been drug-related, as reported by guards after the incident.

title: ISRAELI SOLDIERS SHOOT PALESTINIAN STUDENT IN WEST BANK MELEE
description: Israeli soldiers in the occupied West Bank shot and wounded a 15-year-old student in the leg today after he had brandished a knife, military sources reported.

title: TEXT OF CAREY MESSAGE VETOING BILL TO CHANGE PROPERTY TAXES
description: Following is the text of Governor Carey's message vetoing changes in the property-tax assessment system: This bill would amend the real-property tax law by changing the existing statewide standard of assessments, prescribing a classification system for New York City and Nassau County, authorizing other assessing units to preserve homestead-class tax shares and to provide a transition period in cases where such assessing units complete revaluations, requiring the establishment of class ratios in New York City and Nassau County, and making changes in the admissibility of evidence in real-property tax-review proceedings.

title: Turning out a 'Moby-Dick' of a kids' film.
description: ''TIME BANDITS,'' which opened at the Loews State, Loews Orpheum and other theaters last week, was the inspiration of Terry Gilliam, one of the ''Monty Python'' Gang of Six. (The others are John Cleese, Eric Idle, Terry Jones, Graham Chapman and Michael Palin.) The Pythons act, write, direct. They produce books, films and television shows. Sometimes they all do a project together, sometimes two or three of them do a project, sometimes one of them goes off and does a project on his own.

title: ANACOMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect acquisitions on a pooling of interests basis; yr-ago net income has been adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split distributed June 1981

title: CADENCE INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $82,000 for the qr and $303,000 for the 9 mos and $4,337,000 pretax loss for the 9 mos from the revaluation of certain intangibles...C-Including $121,000 tax credit...D-Net income including $323,000 tax credit and $1,171,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: BRIEFS
description: * Compuscan Inc. said that Olivetti Realty, an affiliate of the Olivetti group of Italy, had exercised a warrant to purchase 500,000 shares of Compuscan common stock at $3 a share.

title: FAILURE OF A POWER DEVICE LED TO A FEAR OF EXPLOSION
description: The space shuttle Columbia was betrayed today by a piece of equipment that has been standard on almost every manned space flight made by Americans during the last 16 years. It is the fuel cell, which, through the chemical reaction of oxygen and hydrogen, produces all electrical power for the spacecraft.

title: Around the World; Ulster Policeman Wounded by Car Bomb
description: Irish guerrillas kept up their attacks on the British province's security forces today, critically wounding a policeman with a bomb that they placed in his car.

title: Free Rent in Houston?
description: Lonnell Phea, a wide receiver for the University of Houston, was quoted in a Fort Worth, Tex., newspaper as saying that a downtown Houston hotel provided rent-free lodging for 12 players on the football team last summer so that they could attend unofficial workouts frequently attended by Coach Bill Yeoman and several assistants. A spokesman for the National Collegiate Athletic Association said that free lodging could violate the N.C.A.A.'s extra-benefit rules, and that the coaches might have violated rules governing outof-season workouts if they attended the practices.

title: Government Sues to Recover Money Paid in; Abscam Case
description: The Federal Government filed a civil suit today in an attempt to recover $61,900 paid by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as bribes to four men who were later charged as part of the Abscam inquiry into political corruption.

title: Coney Whale Dies
description: A female whale born on Aug. 24 at the New York Aquarium at Coney Island died on Oct. 18 of a massive internal infection, aquarium officials said yesterday.

title: EXXON TO END ITS OIL AND GAS OUTPUT IN LIBYA
description: The Exxon Corporation, America's largest oil company, said yesterday that it had decided to withdraw from all of its oil and gas production operations in Libya

title: F.T.C. NEAR DEADLINE ON MOBIL BID
description: Staff lawyers for the Federal Trade Commission may recommend a two-part plan that would enable the Mobil Corporation to go ahead with a $5 billion takeover bid for the Marathon Oil Company, sources close to the Government agency said yesterday.

title: ORMAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IN RIYADH, THE LUCKY NUMBER IS 8 1/2
description: To the Editor:

title: ENGLE: FROM CHILDHOOD HE PLANNED TO BE A PILOT
description: Rarely, if ever, does Col. Joe Henry Engle of the Air Force show any sign of becoming satiated with flying, any kind of flying. He has flown 135 kinds of aircraft in his more than two decades as a pilot, logging more than 8,350 hours of flight time, of which 6,000 hours was in jets. He has piloted some of the most sophisticated equipment this country has produced, including the X-15 research rocket plane early in the 1960's. Yesterday he took off in the space shuttle Columbia.

title: LUCK OFTEN DECISIVE ON RESEARCH FUNDS, SCIENCE STUDY FINDS
description: Luck plays as big a role as merit in determining which scientists get research grants from the National Science Foundation, according to a major study being published today.

title: JUPITER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Topics; PERFORMANCE TESTS; Loyalty
description: Trojan horses being what they are, it may be time for the Reagan Adminis-tration to adopt a 1979 innovation of the Carter Administration: tests to evaluate the competence and loyalty of Government officials.. Not many test questions are really necessary; the answers to just a few could prove greatly revealing.

title: Mary Magdalene Show
description: ''Mary M: A Visit With the Magdalene,'' a one-woman show written and performed by Mary Betten, will be presented at no charge this weekend at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street.

title: TRIP MAY BE CUT SHORT
description: Two American astronauts rode the space shuttle Columbia into an orbit of earth today with hopes for a five-day mission, only to have a malfunctioning electric power unit threaten them with a premature return home. They were told that they might have to come back almost three days early, on Saturday afternoon.

title: OLIVER SCHAFFER, 62, PROFESSOR OF SCIENCE SUPERVISED RESEARCH
description: Dr. Oliver A. Schaeffer, who had been chairman of the earth and space sciences department at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L.I., died Wednesday at Mather Hospital in Port Jefferson, L.I. Dr. Schaeffer, who lived in Old Field, L.I., was 62 years old.

title: G.M. PLANS A LAYOFF OF 13,000
description: The General Motors Corporation, which has suffered sagging sales, today announced the layoffs of 13,000 workers at three plants producing subcompact ''J'' cars and at a New Jersey factory making full-sized cars.

title: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1981; The Economy
description: David A. Stockman offered his resignation as budget director, conceding ''poor judgment and loose talk'' in his controversial Atlantic Monthly interview, but President Reagan declined to accept it. Mr. Stockman's remarks in the interview, indicating a lack of faith in the Administration's economic theories and projections, were said to have infuriated Mr. Reagan, though he considered the 35-year-old official too important to let go. (Page A1.) Editors at The Washington Post said they had approved in advance an agreement for the Stockman article to appear in The Atlantic Monthly. (D17.)

title: THEATER: 'MASS APPEAL' COMES TO BROADWAY
description: ''LOVE goes its own course,'' says one of the two characters in Bill C. Davis's ''Mass Appeal.'' The same might be said of good writing. In this modest, winning play, Mr. Davis has taken a seemingly stock situation - rebellious young seminarian confronts conservative middle-aged priest - and has insisted on letting it go its own passionate course. The result is a work that happily defies our pat expectations. ''Mass Appeal,'' it turns out, is not preoccupied with generational or theological conflict; nor is it exclusively about the Roman Catholic Church. By letting his characters grow and change, Mr. Davis has written a play that lives up to the promise of its title - a tender comedy about the meaning and power of both secular and religious love.

title: RICHARD W. GOSS
description: Richard W. Goss, who was sales manager of the aluminum division of the Scovill Manufacturing Company of Waterbury, Conn., died Wednesday in Sanibel, Fla., after a long illness.

title: ATLAS VAN LINES INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $1,322,484 tax gain for the qr and 9 mos from the writeoff of operating rights

title: RYAN INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BL, HONDA EXPLAIN LUXURY CAR PLANS
description: The joint development of a new luxury car line by the Honda Motor Company and BL Ltd. is expected to strengthen each company's prospects of prospering in the increasingly competitive global auto market.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF STOCKMAN'S STATEMENT AND HIS NEWS CONFERENCE
description: Following is a transcript of the statement and news conference by David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times, through the facilities of ABC News: OPENING STATEMENT

title: ORGAN: GRIMES PLAYS BACH
description: NEARLY all the best organs in New York City lurk in churches. Thus a music-lover in search of organ music as an artistic experience must usually seek it out in an environment that lacks some of the niceties of secular concertgoing.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Group W Satellite Communications, a recently formed division of Westinghouse Broadcasting, to Slater, Hanft, Martin Inc.

title: BOOMERANG TEAM AIMS AT AUSTRALIA
description: The real aboriginal Australian boomerang, it develops, does not return to the hand of the thrower. ''It's a weapon, actually,'' observed L. Gerard Sellars, standing like a refugee from the Coldstream Guards on a misty sward in Golden Gate Park and brandishing a handsome, yardlong boomerang carved out of native Australian mulga wood.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Niki Lauda of Austria, the former world driving champion, confirmed that he would return to Formula One auto racing next season as a member of the McLaren team. Lauda, who was nearly killed in a racing accident in 1976, had retired before the 1981 season. ... Tom Pridemore, Atlanta Falcon safety and a member of the West Virginia Legislature, was arrested in Atlanta on charges of drunken driving and freed on bond. ... Jose-Luis Clerc and Guillermo Vilas were named to play singles for the Argentine team that will meet the United States in the Davis Cup final at Cincinnati next month. The American team has not yet been named, but its singles players are expected to be John McEnroe and either Jimmy Connors or Roscoe Tanner.

title: Place Where Polo Reigns Supreme
description: WHEN Tommy Hitchcock Sr. was still the patron saint of American polo, Frank Graham sought to compare other games, like baseball, football, basketball, hockey and boxing, which punish the legs unmercifully, with a game whose players take their exercise sitting down.

title: Haig Sees No Way to Prevent Americans From Aiding Libya
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that while the United States was ''profoundly opposed'' to Americans' working for the Government of Libya, this is a ''free society'' and there appeared to be no way the practice could be stopped.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By John Leonard WHO KILLED KAREN SILKWOOD? By Howard Kohn. Illustrated. 462 pages. Summit. Hard cover, $16.95; paper, $8.95.

title: French Offices Hit in Beirut
description: Bombs planted at two French offices went off in predominantly Moslem west Beirut tonight, causing extensive damage but no casualties. Security sources said one bomb exploded at an Air France office and the other went off at the French Cultural Center.

title: AUCTIONS
description: World War II art next week at New York's two leading auction houses. Christie's, at Park Avenue and 59th Street, will hold sessions at 7 P.M. on Wednesday night and 10 A.M. on Thursday morning, and Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, will have its sale Thursday night at 7 P.M.

title: Economic Scene; A Severe Blow For Reagan
description: WHAT remains of ''supply-side'' economics in the light of the published confessions of a supply-side champion, David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget? Mr. Stockman has, in a series of interviews reported in the The Atlantic Monthly, said that supply-side economics is just a disguised version of the old ''trickle-down'' theory, long-favored by conservative Republicans. The old theory in new garb was a ''Trojan horse'' to aid the rich under the guise of giving a break to everyone.

title: JACOB ROSENTHAL, 75, IS DEAD, A FOOD AND WINE AUTHORITY
description: Jacob Rosenthal, a food and wine expert and former president of the Culinary Institute of America, died Wednesday at Presbyterian Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 75 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Ship Building Co., Lorain, Ohio, has appointed Joseph M. LaNasa vice president and general manager of the Amship division.

title: APPLIED POWER INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 30
description: B-After $6.4 million net loss from the disposal of businesses

title: Around the World; Flemish Liberal to Look For a Belgian Coalition
description: King Baudouin today asked Herman Vanderpoorten, a member of the Flemish Liberal Party, to consult political leaders to try to find the basis for a new coalition government.

title: LA POINTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CARRYING ON THE LIEDER TRADITION, CHRISTA LUDWIG SINGS SCHUBERT
description: When Birgit Nilsson sang the Dyer's Wife in ''Die Frau ohne Schatten'' last month, a recurring murmur sounded among New York's opera fans: ''Brilliant - a wonderful voice, but ah, remember Christa Ludwig!'' It was she who sang the role in 1966 and sang it, many think, as the Metropolitan Opera has never heard it before or since.

title: DIVERS TO SEARCH L.I. SOUND FOR BODY OF YACHTSMAN
description: The police said today that scuba divers were scheduled to start searching Long Island Sound tomorrow for the body of a 72-year-old retired textile executive and yachtsman who disappeared from his 50-foot power boat on Monday.

title: EGYPT INDICTS 24 MEN IN THE ASSASSINATION OF SADAT
description: Egypt's military prosecutor general indicted four men today for the murder of President Anwar el-Sadat, and accused 20 others of complicity in the assassination.

title: Around the Nation; Ohio Stores Agree to Pay $20 Million in Food Credit
description: Three supermarkets must give a million consumers coupons or food worth $20 million in the next five years, under a tentative agreement reached today in Federal District Court.

title: TO PROSECUTE QADDAFI'S AMERICAN MERCENARIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Auditors Fault Jersey Agency
description: NEWARK (AP) - New Jersey's Department of Energy failed to monitor the spending of $305,505 of a total of $3.6 million in Federal grants, the Division of State Auditors reported yesterday.

title: VIATECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes gains on disposal of subsidiary of $15,980 for the qr and $91,052 for the 9 mos...C-Includes gains on disposal of subsidiary of $51,949 for the qr and $126,881 for the 9 mos and $57,638 pretax gain for the 9 mos on disposition of fixed asset

title: COORS, ADOLPH, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sun Unit Selling Its Retail Assets
description: The Sun Company said that its Sun Gas Liquids Inc. marketing subsidiary had reached a definitive agreement to sell its retail assets to Synergy Group Inc. for an undisclosed amount.

title: Advertising; Keeping An Eye on Cable TV
description: ''T HERE'S too much being said for what's going on,'' was the comment on cable television delivered by James Alberts, vice president and director of advertising services at the Glenbrook Laboratories division of Sterling Drugs. He was among the 300 persons of similar persuasion who attended the annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers earlier this week in San Francisco.

title: Oilers Fine Stabler
description: The quarterback Ken Stabler was fined $500 by the Houston Oilers when he showed up at practice yesterday, having missed the practice session the day before.

title: Around the Nation; Balloon Lands on Coast, First to Cross the Pacific
description: The Double Eagle 5 came down with a bump tonight after crossing a wave-swept beach about 170 miles north of here. Its crew of four thus became the first people ever to soar across the Pacific Ocean in a balloon.

title: CONNECTICUT NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STOCKMAN OFFERS REAGAN 'REGRETS' AND KEEPS HIS JOB
description: David A. Stockman acknowledged today that ''my poor judgment and loose talk'' had damaged President Reagan's economic program and said that he had offered his resignation. But Mr. Reagan declined to accept it, concluding, according to aides, that the budget director was ''too indispensable.''

title: Counterattack in Bryant Park
description: If some New York City parks and plazas have turned into shopping malls for drug dealers, it is partly because they look as if they'd been designed for the purpose. These are not places in which to stroll or sit; they are grim, graceless, inhospitable -wastelands.

title: WOOLWORTH, F W, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-The company said that it broke even for the qr; after foreign currency losses of $5 million for the qr and $20 million for the 9 mos and $16 million gain for the 9 mos from stock relief tax benefits and $13 million after tax gain from the sale of 51 percent of the equity in a Mexican subsidiary...C-Includes foreign currency gains of $2 million for the qr and $3 million for the 9 mos and $20 million refund for the 9 mos of advance corporation tax

title: ONE YOUTH SLAIN AND 2D WOUNDED IN AFTERMATH OF A BROOKLYN PRANK
description: One youth was killed and another was critically wounded early yesterday when what the police described as a prank involving a bicycle erupted into gunfire in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.

title: Notes on People; Building a Tradition Around a Master Builder
description: To honor the memory of New York's ''master builder,'' the Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York gave its new Robert Moses Special Achievement Award last night to a public servant who said he had often tried to emulate the late Mr. Moses.

title: PARK TOUR IN EVERY BOROUGH
description: The natural resources of the parks in all five boroughs will be tapped this weekend in a series of free walking tours led by the Urban Park Rangers. The rangers, employed by the Parks Department for the last two years, also conduct first-aid workshops and patrol the parks to discourage vandalism.

title: ROADWAY EXPRESS APPOINTS CHAIRMAN
description: Charles F. Zodrow, 59 years old, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of Roadway Express Inc., a major trucking line based in Akron, Ohio, and Richard M. Hoss, 43, has been named president, effective Jan. 1. The appointments follow the decision of William F. Spitznagel, Roadway Express's 55-year-old chairman and president, to retire and become a consultant to the corporation.

title: The Evening Hours
description: T HE Countess Emanuela Castelbarco had flown into town from Milan, Italy, to hear her uncle play the piano. But she thought it would be nice to see her grandfather's old house, she said, particularly since it was to become a museum of music. She stayed over for the party, drank some apple juice-and-ginger-ale punch, and kept telling everybody how much she remembered the house called Wave Hill, which is in Riverdale.

title: THE FOLLY OF FOCUSING ON HANDGUN MURDERS
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELI SEEMS TO RETREAT ON SAUDIS
description: An Israeli official who was quoted yesterday as saying that Saudi Arabia had gone ''a little way in our direction'' with certain aspects of its peace plan appeared to repudiate his remarks today.

title: Energy Watch
description: NOV. 6, 1981 Crude oil stocks jumped to 373.8 million barrels.

title: ARMSTRONG RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $375,000 or 19 cents a shr for the qr and $750,000 or 40 cents a shr for the yr...C-Net loss Results for the 1981 qr and yr include the consolidation of Copolymer Rubber & Chemical Corp since Jan 1, 1981

title: MOXIE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $73,000 for the qr and $343,000 for the 9 mos

title: U.S. RESTS CASE IN TRIAL OF POLE IN ESPIONAGE PLOT
description: A Government prosecutor told a Federal District Court jury today that it took not only a cunning personality but also professional training in espionage to enable a young Pole to draw a former Hughes Aircraft engineer into an espionage plot.

title: Racial and Religious Violence Is Termed a Growing Menace
description: Racial and religious violence is a growing menace that ''hate groups such as the Ku Klux Klan and Nazitype organizations seem committed to keep alive,'' the nation's civil rights enforcement chief told a House Judiciary subcommittee today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A United Press International dispatch published yesterday incorrectly reported the time at which a fetus diagnosed as having Down's syndrome was destroyed in the womb. The operation was done 20 weeks into the pregnancy.

KAPLAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CENTENNIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $120,000 tax credit...C-Net loss

title: REAGAN JOB RIGHTS NOMINEE AROUSES DISPUTE
description: Few people outside Detroit's tiny Republican Party knew of William M. Bell, a local businessman and frequent unsuccessful political candidate, when President Reagan named him last June to head the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: NOBEL FAMILY NO. 6
description: To the Editor:

title: CAGLE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: B-Net income; results for the latest periods were for 14 and 27 weeks

title: Dow Adds 3.42 on Rate Drop
description: The stock market, buoyed by another decline in interest rates, rose moderately yesterday in accelerated trading, with some transportation issues again registering the best gains.

title: Around the World; Brazil's Chief Resumes Job After Heart Attack
description: Joao Baptista Figueiredo reassumed the Presidency of Brazil today after 53 days spent out of office recuperating from a heart attack.

title: REAGAN BACKS MODIFIED PLAN ON RIGHTS BILL
description: President Reagan told a group of black reporters today that he continued to support an extension of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, but ''with a couple of modifications.''

title: PANTASOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 9
description: B-Includes foreign currency gains of $555,000 for the qr and $1,699,000 for the 9 mos...C-After $59,000 foreign currency loss for the qr and $124,000 foreign currency gain for the 9 mos and charges of $425,000 for the qr and $1,501,000 for the 9 mos from the closing of plants in London, Ohio and Escondido, Calif

title: HARKEN OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss...C-Net income

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I hesitate to use metaphors after the bad luck that I've had in recent days, but I grew up on a farm and I might say, therefore, that my visit to the Oval Office for lunch with the President was more in the nature of a visit to the woodshed after supper.'' -David A. Stockman, budget director. (D16:1.)

title: Bucyrus-Soviet Deal
description: The Bucyrus-Erie Company said today that it had a preliminary agreement to sell drilling equipment worth $35 million to $40 million to the Soviet Union's Bureau of Mines. The company said that it expected to complete a final contract within several weeks and to deliver the equipment in 1982. Bucyrus-Erie said the agreement had been arranged through a New York export concern, the Foreign Transaction Corporation.

title: Bridge: The 'Captaincy Principle' May Have Its Drawbacks
description: Some married couples have a ''captaincy principle'' that determines who is entitled to make the final decision on important occasions. If they are bridge players, they should observe the same captaincy principle as everyone else: The partner of the no-trump bidder should make the final decision and should not be overruled.

title: GOVERNOR EXPLAINS VETO AS LEADERS PLAN A FIGHT
description: Governor Carey said yesterday that he had vetoed a bill changing the state's methods of assessing property taxes because it would have continued an ''inequitable, chaotic and haphazard'' system.

title: 'BAN THE BOMB' MOVEMENT IS BOUNCING BACK IN BRITAIN
description: Two years ago the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament seemed as anachronistic as the @miniskirt, another quaint relic from the optimistic, extroverted Britain of the 1960's.

title: EXCERPTS FROM HAIG'S REVIEW OF FOREIGN POLICY PRESENTED TO A HOUSE P ANEL
description: Following are excerpts from the text of a statement made today before the House Foreign Affairs Committee by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Oct. 21 about a bomb ex- plosion in Antwerp gave an incorrect estimate for the city's Jewish popula- tion. The correct figure is closer to 13,000.

title: MAGNETICS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REAGAN WEIGHS PLANS TO CUT FOOD STAMPS FUND EVEN MORE
description: As House-Senate conferees put the final touches on legislation today that would prune back the food stamp program in the current fiscal year, Reagan Administration officials were advancing new proposals to slash the program even more deeply in the future.

title: Penn Central Tally On Colt Uncertain
description: The Penn Central Corporation said that it was still awaiting the completion of a count of shareholders' ballots on the company's proposed $1.4 billion acquisition of Colt Industries. Penn Central said that it had been advised by the election judges that the tabulation was unfinished and a shareholders meeting was adjourned until next Thursday.

title: Bankruptcies in Japan
description: About 17,600 Japanese companies with debts totaling $11 billion are likely to close this year, the Tokyo Commerce and Industry Research Company said today. The private research company, whose figures are used by the Bank of Japan, said the 1981 figures would be the third-highest annual total of bankruptcies, after 1977 and 1980.

title: A good kitchen that travels well.
description: BROOKLYN'S loss is Manhattan's gain. In July, Hubert's, the charming and very good restaurant that was in Boerum Hill, moved to 22d Street just east of Park Avenue South, in the premises formerly occupied by E.F. Barrett. The new restaurant, still operated by Karen Hubert and Len Allison, the partners who share kitchen and dining room chores, is already up to the two-star performance of the original. Despite the kitchen's consistency in Brooklyn, the location was too remote to attract a steady following.

title: MRS. LUCE IS BACK, PEPPERY AS EVER
description: Are there any attractive, interesting, eligible men loose in Washington? If so, please tell Clare Boothe Luce. She would like to meet them.

title: Market Place; An Offering With Risks
description: ROONEY, PACE INC. marketed a million units of Inteleplex Corporation on Wednesday and in doing so may have brought back the concept of public offerings for unseasoned companies.

title: The Cat's Still Out of the Bag
description: As melodrama, it has warmth, even poignance. Bright brash young David recklessly spilled the big family secret so the President took him out to the woodshed and gave him a proper whuppin'. Then, manfully, David apologized, thanked the President for giving him a second chance and insisted he is still a true believer. Thus proceeds ''the education of David Stockman.''

title: WILSON BROTHERS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $364,000 gain from the sale of discontinued operatio

title: CRAFT'S MECHANICAL ARM FACES FIRST TEST IN SPACE
description: A 50-foot, many-jointed mechanical arm aboard the Columbia is to unlimber itself tomorrow morning under astronaut control. It will then reach out into the void in the first test of a device on which the space shuttle's future usefulness depends.

title: AN ODYSSEY BY SUBWAY TO GREEK ASTROIA
description: THE nearest Greek island for you to visit lies on the east bank of the East River, in the Astoria neighborhood of Queens. It is not only the nearest Greek island but, in terms of population, also one of the largest. Almost any weekend you can sense the throb of Mediterranean life, modified by the American experience, as it pulses through streets that are clean and safe at almost any hour.

title: POLITICAL RISK BY PRESIDENT; News Analysis
description: Washington, Nov. 12 - President Reagan's decision to keep David A. S tockman as Director of the Office of Management and Budget after hise mbarrassing admissions of doubt about the Reagan economic program isa political gamble. Before Congress, Mr. Stockman has been the p rincipal advocate and architect of the Reagan budget. But over the p ast 48 hours Republicans as well as Democrats have been questioning w hether he will ever again be a truly persuasive exponent of the P resident's program or whether his usefulness has been irreparably d amaged.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1981
description: International The aims of American foreign policy were reviewed by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. in Congressional testimony. He said the Reagan Administration sought to encourage constructive relations with Moscow while renewing traditional alliances, restoring American economic and military strength and promoting peaceful development in the third world. During questioning, Mr. Haig refused to rule out a possible blockade of Nicaragua. (Page A1, Column 3.) Exxon is withdrawing from Libya after 26 years of pumping crude oil there. Spokesmen for Exxon, the largest American oil company, declined repeated requests to explain whether the decision was taken because of a dispute with Libya over oil production or prices or because of political or security reasons. (A1:2-4.)

title: U.S. ISSUES 3 LEASES FOR OIL EXPLORATION IN WILDERNESS AREA
description: The Interior Department's Bureau of Land Management has issued the first leases that will allow energy companies to explore for oil in a wilderness area.

title: Article 091192 -- No Title
description: A $10,000 offer to a state trooper to falsify his complaint about an assault on him by the son of a reputed underworld leader was disclosed in court papers today as the key factor in a bribery scheme said to involve the Bergen County Democratic Party chairman.

title: No Headline
description: Blazers Lose First

title: LEGAL SERVICES AGENCY STRUGGLES FOR ITS SURVIVAL
description: Rejected by Ronald Reagan, mauled by Edwin Meese 3d, scorned by David A. Stockman, vilified by Richard Viguerie, the Legal Services Corporation continued its battle against the Administration this week, temporarily kept alive by Congress but not exactly well.

title: ALCO STANDARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AWARD TO GO TO THE SHUBERTS
description: The first annual humanitarian award of Hospital Audiences Inc. will be given to Gerald Schoenfeld and Bernard B. Jacobs of the Shubert Organization on Dec. 8 at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

title: Expos Rehire Fanning
description: Jim Fanning will be back for another year as manager of the Montreal Expos, having signed a one-year contract yesterday. There had been speculation that Fanning would return next season to the Montreal front office, which he left when Dick Williams was dismissed as manager in September.

title: RIBLET PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TANDON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LIMITED STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
No Headline
description: NO PROGRESS ON PALESTINIAN AUTONOMY: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, center, in Cairo with Interior Minister Yosef Burg, left, and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel.

title: ARMADA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $385,000 for the qr and $377,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net income

title: 2 TASTES OF TRADITIONAL DANCE FROM THE FAR EAST
description: In a world that seems geared to rapid obsolescence, the ancient arts, handed down from generation to generation, may be in special danger. But they do endure. This weekend in New York, two groups of Far Eastern performers will present the faithfully preserved traditional dance and music of their countries.

title: SCRIPTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EGYPT AND ISRAEL STILL AT ODDS ON PALESTINIANS
description: Two days of Egyptian-Israeli talks on Palestinian autonomy ended tonight with no sign of progress. On arrival yesterday, Israeli officials said they were pressing for a quick resolution of the long-stalled effort to arrive at a definition of ''autonomy'' so that the Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin could report some progress.

title: POLIO VIRUS MADE WITH ARTIFICIAL GENETIC MATERIAL
description: Artificially fabricated genetic material has been used for the first time to produce an active, infectious polio virus in the laboratory, according to scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: EQUITABLE OF IOWA COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ON SINAI, THERE'S NO ECONOMICS
description: Economics is an unpredictable art and an unreliable science. As such, it should be treated with the utmost caution while, at the same time, being favored with further resources for study so that it may improve on its undoubted unreliability.

title: Friday; '4 SAINTS' ON 57TH ST.
description: To wish Virgil Thomson a happy 85th birthday, the opera that brought the composer fame will be given a concert performance tonight at 9 in Carnegie Hall. ''Four Saints in Three Acts'' - his collaboration with Gertrude Stein - will be performed by a distinguished cast that includes Betty Allen, making her New York farewell appearance, and Clamma Dale, and the Orchestra of Our Time, a 30-piece chamber ensemble, conducted by Joel Thome, which specializes in 20th-century music. John Houseman, who directed the original 1934 production of ''Four Saints,'' will be the host. Tickets are $6 to $17.50; to charge, call 247-7459. For tickets starting at $125, to benefit the orchestra and including a birthday celebration afterward at the Parker Meridien Hotel, call 924-2692. 50 YEARS OF ORKIN PHOTOS

title: ART: MUNCH IN PRINTS AND ALMOST IN THE FLESH
description: IT is easy to have the illusion that we know all there is to know about the prints of Edvard Munch. Is there not, after all, something in back of that illusion? Munch's prints turn up all the time in reproduction. Some of them - ''The Scream,'' for one - are among the most famous images of the last 100 years. ''The Scream'' evokes to perfection the state of helpless dread that has been the lot of many millions of people in our century. Who is to say that we do not know it backwards?

title: N.F.L.'S TOP 7 TEAMS FACE A COMMON FOE-COMPLACENCY
description: The National Football League has seven first-place teams among its six division races - Dallas and Philadelphia are tied in the National Conference East - and not one of them will play an opponent with a winning record Sunday.

title: People Express
description: People Express Airlines, a carrier based in Newark, said that it would suspend two daily flights from Indianapolis to Newark International Airport, effective Nov. 30. The airline, which offers cut-rate fares and no-frills service, said that the suspension was necessary because of cutbacks ordered at Newark by the Civil Aeronautics Board. The cutback will reduce from 48 to 36 the number of People Express flights to Newark.

title: Paroled Inmate Held in 4 Robberies
description: NEWARK (UPI) - A paroled convict who had helped form a group that was the subject of an award-winning documentary, ''Scared Straight,'' was held without bail on a charge of committing four armed robberies in eight days. The suspect, Russell Watson, 31 years old, of Newark, was arraigned and jailed to await grand jury action, according to Lieut. Armando Fontoura of the Newark police.

title: PARIS SEEKING TO CLOSE INDIAN JET DEAL
description: France's Socialist Government hopes to conclude its first major foreign-arms deal, a $3.3 billion sale of advanced Mirage fighter-bombers to India, during a 3-day official visit begun here today by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: GUARANTEE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income...C-Operating earnings

title: HARRY THE OPERATIC HAWK NOW STARS IN LEGAL BATTLE
description: A hawk named Harry that had a bit part in the New York City Opera production of ''Der Freischutz'' was seized by conservation officers last week a few hours before curtain time and has become a leading character in a wildlife legal battle.

title: INTEGRATED RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COUNTRY-POP: TILLIS AT LONE STAR
description: based country-pop singer and songwriter who made a rare appearance at the Lone Star Cafe on Tuesday, is an engaging performer who straddles the line between country and pop without any apparent discomfort. And on Tuesday, this 25-year veteran of Nashville's Music Row, delivered his two best-known compositions, ''Detroit City'' and ''Ruby, Don't Take Your Love to Town,'' in offhanded versions that treated them as though they were in the public domain.

title: INSULATION'S FUMES, HEALTH RISK, FOUND TO LINGER FOR YEARS
description: The cancer risk from foam insulation may be slightly lower than previously thought, but the formaldehyde fumes believed to cause the problem may last for years, Government safety investigators said today.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 13, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10.30 A.M.

title: BAR OPPOSES CHANGE IN ILLEGAL EVIDENCE RULE
description: The American Bar Association today reaffirmed its strong opposition to proposals to eliminate or weaken a rule that prevents the use of illegally seized evidence in criminal trials.

title: Aluminum Price at Low
description: The price of aluminum fell to a record low today under the impact of recent heavy selling by two major producing companies trying to cut their losses during the world recession, traders reported.

title: LIFESURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After capital losses of $10,000 and a tax credit of $280,000. C-After capital gains of $13,000 and tax credit of $280,000

title: GIRL TO BE TREATED AT HOME
description: The White House announced today that it had found a way for Katie Beckett to go home from a hospital in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, without losing Medicaid coverage to pay the bills for her disease.

title: CONSOLES TO COCKPIT: ALL WELL, BUT THEN...
description: Following are excerpts from conversations the astronauts had yesterday with Shuttle Launch Control in Cape Canaveral, Fla., and with Mission Control in Houston, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: The Police Blotter
description: Three Manhattan teen-agers were arrested at 12:30 A.M. after they tried to hold up a taxi driver on a dead-end street in Harlem. The police said they were investigating the possibility that the youths - Anthony Lyons, 17 years old, of 260 West 131st Street; Andre Taylor, 16, of 410 St. Nicholas Avenue, and Lee Bennett, 17, of 256 West 132d Street - were part of a gang preying on taxi drivers. ... Two teenagers, both under 16, were arrested for grand larceny and menacing in the Flushing section of Queens at 8 P.M. at 141st Street and 72d Road after pointing a revolver at police officers and fleeing in a stolen car. ... Julio Acevido, 24, of 341 East 94th Street, was shot in the torso shortly before noon by one of two prowlers he encountered on the roof of his apartment building.

title: HELIX TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss...C-After $4.5 million loss from discontinued operations

title: Small Quake on Coast
description: A small earthquake today rattled homes in the metropolitan Seattle and Everett areas, but apparently caused no serious damage. The temblor, registering 3.7 on the Richter scale, was centered near Lynnwood in southwestern Snohomish County and midway between Seattle and Everett, according to the United States Geological Survey center in Golden, Colo.

title: Required Reading; Bits of Pork
description: Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, speaking in support of an amendment to kill the Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway Project, which was later defeated 48 to 46:

title: Quebec Limits Asbestos Stock
description: The province of Quebec has no intention of buying any shares of the Asbestos Corporation beyond the 54.6 percent stake held by the General Dynamics Corporation, Jacques Parizeau, the province's finance minister, said.

title: STATEMENT BY WHITE HOUSE
description: Following is the text of a statement by the deputy press secretary of the White House, Larry Speakes, which he read to reporters today:

title: ON THE SMALL STAGES, THE SEASON IS OFF TO A ROUSING START
description: CELEBRATING the 20th anniversary of La Mama, Ellen Stewart is reaffirming her company as a home for an expansively eclectic outpouring of theater of every tradition, sensibility and nationality. That vibrant spirit of productivity is being felt this season not only at La Mama, but all through the kaleidoscopic world of Off and Off Off Broadway. With the definite exception of ''Nicholas Nickleby'' and the recently opened ''Crimes of the Heart'' and ''The Dresser,'' Broadway has barely left the starting gate. But away from Broadway, in small but very legitimate playhouses covering the length of Manhattan, the new season already is marked by a panoply of outstanding theater. The range runs from a perfect two-character one-act play, Shirley Lauro's ''Open Admissions'' at the Ensemble Studio Theater to a stage-sweeping four-and-one-halfhour, two-part epic ''Peer Gynt'' at the C.S.C. Repertory.

title: HITTMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes extraordinary legal expenses of $27,700 or 3 cents a shr in the qr and $83,000 or 8 cents a shr in the 9 mos

title: 19 ACCUSED IN CASINO THEFTS
description: Nineteen persons, including three casino officials, have been indicted on charges of stealing $644,000 from three Atlantic City casinos through a complicated credit scheme, Attorney General James R. Zazzali announced today.

title: IN ITALY, THE BOMB'S A POLITICAL ISSUE FOR FIRST TIME
description: In all, perhaps a half-million demonstrators have marched this fall in Rome, Milan, Venice and many smaller cities against the stationing of nuclear weapons in Italy.

title: WINSTON MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a tax loss carryforward credit of $7,000...C-Net income and after a tax credit of $7,000 and a refund of $108,000 from over payment of Chapter 11 administrative expenses

title: VOICE OF AMERICA ANNOUNCERS MAY GET MORE CHOICE IN NEWS
description: The director of the Voice of America has told his staff that he is considering allowing the network's foreignlanguage broadcasters more leeway in selecting and interpreting the news provided them by the agency's central news division.

title: Notes on People; Cooper Union Honors a Favorite Architect
description: He already has a building named after him, the 56-story Chanin Building, a classic example of the Art Deco buildings he constructed in 1929. Now Irwin S. Chanin has a school named for him, too.

title: Around the World
description: Three Nicaraguan soldiers were killed today in an exchange of fire across the border between rightist-ruled Honduras and leftist Nicaragua, witnesses said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bass Brothers Enterprises said it had acquired a stake in Crown Zellerbach Corp. of 125,700 shares of the $4.625 cumulative convertible preferred stock, series A (no par value), or 5 percent, at a net purchase price of $6.3 million.

title: Reagan Picks Comptroller
description: President Reagan announced today the nomination of C.T. Conover, a San Francisco lawyer, as Comptroller of the Currency, the agency that regulates nationally chartered commercial banks.

title: REPORT OF THE $1,000 PAYMENT COMES FROM JAPANESE PAPER
description: A Japanese magazine paid $1,000 to an American official to arrange an interview with Nancy Reagan, according to a Japanese journalist who acted as an intermediary.

title: COURT BACKS GRUMMAN IN LTV FIGHT
description: The Grumman Corporation won a major victory yesterday in its fight to block the LTV Corporation's $450 million tender offer when the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upheld Grumman's assertion that an LTV takeover would violate Federal antitrust laws.

title: MCFARLAND ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: the 1980 shr earnings adjusted for 10 percent stock divd paid in Apr

title: POLICEMAN ARRESTED IN THEFT OF A TICKET FOR STONES CONCERT
description: A 23-year-old police officer who has been on the force less than 10 months was arrested last night on charges of robbing a man at gunpoint of a ticket to Thursday night's Rolling Stones concert at Madison Square Garden, the police reported.

title: WORKER FOR CITY HELD FOR ASKING BRIBE FROM A 2D
description: It went, New York City officials said, considerably further than the familiar exchange of a quart of Scotch to expedite a matter. This time, they said, one city employee told another city employee that if he wanted a job done he would have to come up with $2,600. As a result, a Sanitation Department superintendent in the Bronx was under arrest yesterday, charged with demanding a bribe from a worker with the Public Development Corporation, a city agency that seeks to spur economic growth.

title: FOES OF PENN CENTRAL-COLT MERGER LEADING IN VOTE
description: With nearly 400,000 votes still to be tallied, stockholders of the Penn Central Corporation apparently have narrowly rejected a proposal to acquire Colt Industries, Penn Central announced yesterday.

title: AFTER SIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $341,800 loss from discontinued operations... C-Net income including $295,700 gain from discontinued operations

title: FLEXI-VAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,006,000 for the qr and $19,773,000 for the 9 mos...C-After $4,955,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: LOS ANGELES CRIME FALLS AS POLICE CUT BACK AND PUBLIC STEPS IN
description: Last year a crime wave put Los Angeles well ahead of the national increase in reported violent crimes and stirred a major outcry.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. The rotunda of Columbia University's Low Library, where members of the Columbia Indoor Miniature Aircraft Society held a warmup for a model airplane endurance competition Nov. 22.

title: U.S. CALLS STEEL EXPORTS BY FIVE NATIONS 'UNFAIR'
description: The Commerce Department today accused France, Belgium, South Africa, Rumania and Brazil of ''unfair competition'' in selling steel in the United States and filed complaints that could lead to sharply higher tariffs on steel imported from those countries.

title: News Analysis
description: Global negotiation to aid the poorer nations, a topic everyone here talks about and nobody does much about, has surfaced briefly again after the meeting of rich and poor nations in Cancun.

title: BIRDSBORO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including equity in net earnings of affiliates of $101,000 for the qr and $231,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including equity in net earnings of affiliates of $135,000 for the qr and $327,000 for the 9 mos; yr-ago results have been restated to account for the cost of certain employee compensated absences in accordance with F.A.S.B. Statement No 43

title: Briefing
description: T O the visiting Israeli parliamentary delegation, sent to Washington to argue against a Saudi Arabian peace plan, divisions within Senate conservative ranks over Middle East policy are especially troublesome because right-wingers in recent years have been some of Israel's strongest supporters.

title: EDWARDS BASE ON ALERT FOR COLUMBIA LANDING
description: Although the shuttle is designed to land here tomorrow under the control of ground-based electronics, the possibility exists that the astronauts will have to land the craft themselves.

title: The Talk of Kansas City
description: This is a city where curiosity about the weather goes a lot deeper than whether to take an umbrella to work. Here, lots of people keep track of the weather with the same fastidiousness that people in Detroit reserve for automobile production statistics. Here, the classic conversational topic of American strangers is elevated from the category of idle talk.

title: RECALL 'PRUDENT,' NASA SAYS
description: The astronauts flying the space shuttle Columbia were ordered today to cut short their mission and prepare to bring the troubled craft back to a landing tomorrow afternoon in the desert of California.

title: BEKER INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Around the World; Pope Says Rich Nations Have Duty to Poor Ones
description: Pope John Paul II said today that rich countries had a duty to help others and should not cite selfreliance as an excuse for cutting aid to poor nations.

title: WELLCO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: B-Includes $65,000 tax credit...C-Includes $28,000 tax credit

title: PAVAROTTI OPERA DRAWS SCALPERS
description: Tickets to a new production of ''Aida,'' with Luciano Pavarotti singing his first Radames and with Margaret Price and Stefania Toczyska, are being sold by scalpers for many times the original price.

title: SCHOLAR CHOSEN AS HUMANITIES CHIEF
description: The Reagan Administration has decided against appointing a conservative political theorist from Texas to head the National Endowment for the Humanities. It has chosen instead the president of a scholarly research center in North Carolina.

title: KOCH URGES OUTSIDE REPAIR WORK FOR M.T.A.
description: Mayor Koch said today that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority should consider hiring private companies to do routine repair work on New York City's subways and buses.

title: A WARNING BY L.I.R.R. ON WINTER
description: The new president of the Long Island Rail Road said yesterday that he would have ''no compunction'' about temporarily shutting down the entire system if winter weather conditions were so bad that running the trains ''would be unsafe'' for commuters and harmful to the equipment.

title: PIC 'N' SAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The yr-ago results have been restated for a 3-for-1 stock split in June

title: ARGONAUT ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE WRITER BEHIND 'THE DRESSER'
description: On his 47th birthday Monday, Ronald Harwood paced the mezzanine bar of the Brooks Atkinson Theater, listening to the opening night performance of ''The Dresser'' but not daring to watch it. His play had been a hit in London but this was Mr. Harwood's United States debut, and ''in New York it's sudden death, isn't it?'' he said. The playwright had heard awesome things about the power of critics here.

title: DRIVER-HARRIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After nonrecurring charges of $2,157,000 related to severance payments and other costs associated with the shutdown of a department of a British subsidiary...C-Net income

title: LABOR LEADERS PREDICT REAGAN PLAN WILL FAIL
description: Top leaders of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations called yesterday for a reversal of Reagan Administration economic policies. They charged those policies were destroying vital social programs and threatening the jobs and living standards of workers.

title: Beneficial Corp.  In Reorganization
description: The Beneficial Corporation has announced a sweeping reorganization that will consolidate all deposit and consumer services to prepare for interstate banking.

title: Notes on People; Piano Needs Home
description: Musicians go through a lot caring for their precious instruments. Cellists, for example, have been known to buy first-class airplane tickets for their bulky instruments.

description: B-Including $164,000 extraordinary tax credit

title: CARNATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest periods reflect foreign currency translation losses of $10.7 million for the qr and $20.5 million for the 9 mos

title: Lakers 119, Blazers 115
description: Earvin (Magic) Johnson ignited a fourthquarter rally to lead Los Angeles over Portland, which dropped its second straight after having won its first seven games.

title: BALTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $604,587 for the qr and 9 mos and tax credits of $384,700 for the qr and $532,890 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $276,403 for the qr and $494,174 for the 9 mos

title: Hinkle Leads in Japan
description: Lon Hinkle of the United States shot a course-record 65 today to take a one-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the $300,000 Toshiba Masters golf tournament.

title: Sports of The Times; The Prisoner of Baseball
description: DANNY AINGE drove the 40 minutes from Provo to Salt Lake City to see a pro basketball game the other night. It made him realize more than ever that this could be a very long winter for him.

title: GLASROCK MEDICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including gains of $478,000 for the qr and $3,047,000 for the 6 mos from the sale of stock in a subsidiary and $747,000 loss for the 6 mos on disposal of a subsidiary... C-Including income from discontinued operations of $76,000 for the qr and $141,000 for the 6 mos; the yr-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations

title: BAN SOUGHT ON FOOD AS WEAPON
description: A House-Senate conference committee adopted a clause in the new farm bill today that would virtually eliminate the use of American food as a diplomatic weapon.

title: EX-IM BANK DEFERS LAKER'S LOAN DATE
description: The Export-Import Bank today gave Sir Freddie Laker, the British entrepreneur, an extra year to make repayments on a portion of the $228 million loan package he used to start his low-fare trans-Atlantic airline.

title: WHITE HOUSE LIMITS PUBLICITY ON REDO
description: Nancy Reagan's aides have refused to permit the press and television to distribute photographs of her $1 million White House redecoration after allowing an architectural magazine to present a broad treatment of it.

title: 85 COMPANIES REFUSED TO HELP
description: To the Editor:

title: ORION CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: the results for the 9 mos periods include $330,000 charge for the latest 9 mos and $83,000 or 1 cent a shr gain for the yr-ago 9 mos from foreign currency adjustments and $1 million or 13 cents a shr net gain for the yr-ago 9 mos on the sale of Metropolitan Fire Assurance Co during the second qr of 1980

title: News Analysis
description: The proposal by the leaders of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church on Park Avenue to allow the construction of an office building over its Community House has raised the question of what the purpose of a church is, particularly when its Christian mission collides with outside interests.

title: CONTROL TO CREW: GOOD AND BAD NEWS
description: Following are excerpts from converstations the astronauts had with Mission Control in Houston on the second day of the space shuttle's flight, as recorded by The New York Times and The Associated Press. ''Sally'' is Dr. Sally Ride, an astronaut who served yesterday as capsule communicator.

title: KYLE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
MAYORS COMPLAIN OF REAGAN POLICIES
description: Mayors from many of the nation's largest cities complained bitterly here today about the Reagan Administration's budget reductions and urban policy, but they were unable to find the unanimity needed to draw a solid line against further cuts.

title: MUSIC: PIANO RECITAL BY PAUL JACOBS
description: Paul Jacobs brought a scrupulous sensitivity to his piano recital at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday night, performing an interpretive artist's most valuable service. He took something new, difficult and unfamiliar and so thoroughly absorbed it into his own experience that he revealed it to be part of ours as well. Under his hands, the New York premiere of Elliott Carter's formidable recent work ''Night Fantasies'' fixed the listener's ears with its often unsettling tale.

title: British Inflation Up
description: Britain's annual inflation rate last month reached its highest levels since May, rising to 11.7 percent from 11.4 percent in September, the Government said today. Supplementary local taxes raised the inflation rate, and people also had to pay more for meat, beer and wine. Analysts predicted the rate would exceed 12 percent by the end of the year.

title: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY UP A BIT; MORE FED EASING SEEN
description: The Federal Reserve System yesterday reported very modest increases in several measures of the nation's money supply, causing some economists to predict that the central bank would ease monetary policy and allow interest rates to decline further.

title: LABORITE LEADER DENOUNCES TONY BENN
description: Michael Foot, the leader of the Labor Party, abandoned his effort to conciliate Tony Benn, the leader of its left wing, and bitterly denounced him today.

title: BIO-RESPONSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are not of interest income

title: Columbia Wins Title
description: Kazbek Tambi scored an unassisted goal midway through the first half tonight as the undefeated Columbia soccer team posted a 1-0 victory over Cornell and won the Ivy league championship. The victory assured the Lions a position in the National Collegiate Athletic Association playoffs.

title: Mugabe Arrives in Rumania
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, after a stopover in Yugoslavia, arrived here today for an ''official visit of friendship'' and was greeted at the airport by President Nicolae Ceausescu, the official press agency reported. Mr. Mugabe told reporters before leaving Belgrade that he had reached agreement with officials there on military cooperation and on assistance in road construction, farming, mining and other projects in Zimbabwe.

title: Kodak Dividends
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said that it would pay a record $245.8 million wage ''dividend'' to 93,000 of its employees in the United States.

title: BIOSPHERICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including investment gains of $282,969 for the qr and $1,552,885 for the 9 mos...C-Including investment gains of $41,145 for the qr and $192,415 for the 9 mos

title: Observer; THE EYEBALL GAMBIT
description: I know I ought to be rooting for Viktor Korchnoi to beat Anatoly Karpov, but I'm not. I don't care which one wins, even if they are playing for the chess championship of the world.

title: Sports People; Colts' Dispute Deepens
description: The split between Bert Jones and Curtis Dickey, the latest problem in a problem-filled season for the Baltimore Colts has widened with Dickey's assertion that racial matters are at the heart of the dispute. Racial difficulties among the Colts, who have lost nine of 10 games, have ''probably been around all along,'' Dickey, who is black, said in an interview with The Baltimore Sun.

title: 7 CLAIM JACKSON
description: The room was filled with those who believed that Ron Guidry would remain with the Yankees, but that did not stop 17 other teams yesterday from making him the most popular player in the six-year history of the free agent draft.

title: McEnroe and Connors Advance at Wembley
description: John McEnroe, the defending champion, and Jimmy Connors, the No. 2 seeded player, scored straightset victories today to move into the semifinals of the $175,000 Benson and Hedges tennis tournament at the Wembley Arena.

title: Transactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: VISHAY INTERTECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Business Digest; SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1981; The Economy
description: Industrial output fell 1.5 percent in October, the steepest drop in 16 months, the Federal Reserve Board reported. The biggest declines were in the production of cars, building materials and big consumer items usually bought on credit. Analysts said the new figures indicated that the economy was seriously weakening. (Page 29.)

title: F.T.C. SEEKS MORE DATA IN MOBIL'S MARATHON BID
description: The Federal Trade Commission, which is investigating antitrust issues in the Mobil Corporation's $5 billion takeover bid for the Marathon Oil Company, yesterday asked both companies to supply extensive data for the agency to study.

title: PLENUM PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company recognized unrealized losses on securities of $502,460 in the latest qr and $48,707 in the 1980 period; in the latest 9 mos the company recognized losses on securities of $329,797 and reversed previously unrealized but recognized losses on securities to make them gains of $196,709

title: About New York; MISS MOLT'S BOYS TURN BACK THE CLOCK
