description: Backward, turn backward, Oh time in your flight, Make me a boy again Just for tonight. P.S.109 Alumni Association motto

title: Around the Nation; Three-State Waste Site Called Nation's Worst
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today declared an old Oklahoma mining area that reaches into Kansas and Missouri the most dangerous hazardous waste site in the nation.

title: REAGAN CRITICS CALLED 'LIMITED'
description: A top Republican Party official today assailed critics of the Reagan Administration as people with a ''limited mentality'' and as that ''same raunchy bunch'' who are out to destroy the country with socialism.

title: ROCK: ROLLING STONES
description: Rock bands that perform in arenas the size of Madison Square Garden often resort to making broad visual points to make up for the distance between the stage and the fans in the back rows. But arena shows stand or fall on the quality of the music and the sound, and while Thursday's Rolling Stones show at the Garden had plenty of arresting moments visually, it was the music and especially the crystal-clear, intelligently balanced sound that made it special.

title: Sports People; Connors on Blacklist
description: Jimmy Connors, playing in a tournament at Wembley, attacked the United Nations-backed blacklist of athletes with sporting ties to South Africa and said he would play in Johannesburg later this month. ''I'm a sportsman,'' Connors said, ''not a politician.''

title: SANTA FE INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes a gain of $17.2 million from sale of a construction vessel and a foreign currency exchange gain of $7.6 million

title: 34 JUDGES GET A TASTE OF PRISON
description: Thirty-four Federal judges went to prison this morning, but their sentences were short and lenient: a tour of the Federal correctional institution here, followed by lunch and a discussion with some of the inmates.

title: Around the World; Lebanese Truce Is Over, Militia Leader Says
description: Maj. Saad Haddad, speaking hours after three of his men were killed by a land mine, said today that he had called off a four-month-old cease-fire with Palestinian guerrillas.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1981
description: International A payment of $1,000 in cash by a Japanese magazine to Richard V. Allen, President Reagan's adviser on national security, is being investigated by the Justice Department, the White House said. The payment reportedly had been made after the magazine's interview with Nancy Reagan on Jan. 21. (Page 1, Columns 4-5.) Archeological discoveries in Kenya appear to push back by almost a million years the first use of fire by the ancestors of modern humans. Until the Kenyan discoveries, the earliest strong evidence of fire was found in a very few sites, such as that at Choukoutien, China, dated about 500,000 years ago. The new finds in Kenya are estimated to be about 1,400,000 years old. (1:5.)

title: SKEWED PROMISE OF FREE TRADE
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation; Legal Heirs Win Round In Hughes Estate Case
description: A probate judge signed papers today moving 19 legal heirs to the estate of Howard R. Hughes one step closer to receiving shares of his millions, but lawyers said it would be years before the money was actually in their hands.

title: INVENTORY-SALES RATIO HITS A 12-MONTH HIGH
description: Inventories held by American companies rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in September despite apparent efforts to keep stockpiles down in a time of national economic weakness, Commerce Department officials said today.

title: BECK-ARNLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $182,000 tax credit...C-Net loss after $952,345 loss from discontinued operations

title: Around the World; I.R.A. Bomb Explodes At Home of British Aide
description: A bomb exploded tonight at the home of the British Attorney General, Sir Michael Havers, slightly injuring four police officers.

title: INTERTEC DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AT BUDGET OFFICE, WORK TO DO
description: It was supposed to be business as usual at the Office of Management and Budget today following David A. Stockman's visit, as he put it, to President Reagan's woodshed for a verbal spanking yesterday.

title: TAXICABS DESIGNED FOR THE HANDICAPPED
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Money; SOCIAL SECURITY LAGGING BADLY ON PAY RECORDS
description: The Social Security Administration has fallen badly behind in recording the earnings of millions of workers since 1978. The lag has raised the possibility that at least some workers may lose retirement benefits because they have not been fully credited for their earnings.

title: MIDLAND GLASS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes tax benefits of $2,034,000 for the qr and $3,325,000 for the yr...C-Net income and includes charges of $53,000 for t qr and $1,209,000 for the yr; the 1980 qr and yr shr earnings restated to reflect 3 percent stock divd paid Mar 1981

title: OTHERS SKEPTICAL
description: Thirty-two Republican senators today rallied to the support of David A. Stockman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget. But many other legislators expressed a belief that his effectiveness in presenting the President's economic recovery program had been permanently impaired by the publication of remarks in which Mr. Stockman cast doubts on parts of the program.

title: Patents; G.I. Training Simulator Helps Identify Armor
description: A patent was granted for an Army training simulator meant to teach troops to identify enemy armor vehicles operating at night. Patent 4,299,575, obtained this week by William W. Carrow and Joseph R. Moulton for the Army Training Command, covers lights to be put on United States tanks to make them look like those used by the Soviet Army.

title: DEPOSIT INSURANCE WAS NOT F.D.R.'S THING
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE OF VISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including losses from discontinued operations of $103,000 for the qr and $122,000 for the 9 mos which included estimated gains on sales C-Including gains from discontinued operations of $218,000 for the qr and $419,000 for the 9 mos and $101,000 gain for the 9 mos from an accounting change

title: Liver Donor Is Found For a Jersey Girl, 2 1/2
description: A donor who can supply the liver needed to try to save a 2 1/2-year-old Kinnelon girl's life has been located in Wisconsin, officials at Beth Israel Medical Center here said today.

title: Three Jockeys Injured In Churchill Downs Spill
description: Three jockeys were injured and a horse was destroyed after a spill on the backstretch just before the turn in today's fifth race at Churchill Downs.

title: DESPITE PERILS, BALLOON SETS MARK
description: In its 6,000-mile Pacific crossing, the balloon Double Eagle 5 hovered near disaster and narrowly avoided crashing into a street of homes in Ukiah, Calif., just minutes before a desperate landing on a mountain ridge, the captain said tonight.

title: Sports People; Ongais Starts Back
description: Danny Ongais, who was badly injured in a crash during the Indianapolis 500 last May, may resume his racing career later this month at Daytona International Speedway. Ongais plans to test the Interscope team's Turbo Porsche 935 on Nov. 25 in hopes for participating in the Camel GT 250 sports car race at Daytona on Nov. 29.

title: NOV. 1-10 CAR SALES BY BIG 3 OFF 13.9%
description: New-car sales by the three major domestic automobile manufacturers declined 13.9 percent in the first 10 days of this month, continuing the slump that under way since the 1982 model year began Oct. 1.

title: GNC ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
American Wins
description: Norman Dello Joio of the United States captured the opening event of the nine-day Royal Horse Show tonight. Dello Joio rode Grand Lieu to a 42.62-second clocking in a faultless ride to finish ahead of Ian Millar of Canada, aboard Stardust Mel, and another American, Anne Kursinski, aboard Unique, in the Rolex International Welcome competition. Teams from the United States, Britain, Italy and Canada are entered in the international jumping events.

title: THE GHOSTS OF AUTUMN ARE BACK
description: It is the season of the frosts now, and I am having trouble with ghosts again.

title: The Mount Rushmore Problem
description: There was a story told about President Kennedy just before his death that may be apocryphal but that bears a useful moral for the present.

title: Sports People; Kicking Star Suspended
description: Barry Childers, the place-kicker for Marshall University in Huntington, W. Va., has been suspended by Coach Sonny Randle for his team's final two games after having been arrested on a publicintoxication charge. Last season, Childers set a national collegiate record by kicking a field goal of 59 yards, the longest ever by a freshman. ... Vince Dooley, coach of the Georgia Bulldogs, says, ''If a dog makes a good play, you throw him a bone, right?'' So, next season those star-shaped helmet decals used to reward Georgia players for making big plays will be replaced by bone-shaped decals, which have already been ordered. ... Larry Kelley and Clint Frank, who won Heisman Trophies as players for Yale in 1936 and 1937, respectively, are donating the trophies to the university. A. Bartlett Giamatti, Yale's president, will accept the awards in a ceremony on the New Haven campus next Friday, the day before the Harvard game.

title: OIL OUTPUT IN LIBYA BY MOBIL HALTS
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation said yesterday that its oil production in Libya had been halted Nov. 1 and that it was reviewing its operations there. The disclosure came one day after the Exxon Corporation announced that it was withdrawing from Libya.

title: ADAMS RESOURCES & ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXPRESS BUS FARES FROM S.I. AND BRONX TO RISE TO $2.50
description: Express-bus fares to Manhattan from the Bronx and from Staten Island will rise to $2.50 on Monday, the Board of Estimate decided yesterday.

title: NVF CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The shr earnings have been adjusted for aggregate stock distributions declared through Oct 1981

title: Amoco to End Some Operations
description: The Amoco Oil Company, a unit of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), said it will cease dealer and jobber branded gasoline and distillate marketing operations in 11 states by Oct. 1, 1982.

title: SHARON STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a loss on sales of securities of $1 million... C-Net loss...D-Includes gains of sales of securities of $23.6 million

title: Patents; Invention Licenses To I.B.M.
description: WASHINGTON A VERY productive inventor, who received a patent this week for a patient-monitoring device, announced that he had just licensed the International Business Machines Corporation to use more than a score of his earlier inventions that concern information handling.

title: MATAGORDA DRILLING & EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Santa Fe Net Climbs
description: The Santa Fe International Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the third quarter soared 79.7 percent, to $44.2 million, or 90 cents a share, from $24.6 million, or 52 cents, in the corresponding quarter of 1980. Revenues rose 19.5 percent, to $403.7 million from $337.9 million. E.L. Shannon Jr., chairman of the international oil and gas drilling, engineering and construction company, said Santa Fe had achieved the earnings gain despite lower revenues and operating profits from its oil and gas division.

title: COMPUTER NETWORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Cloud Over 'Governor' Kean
description: Republicans take a curious position toward the complaints about their New Jersey ''Ballot Security Task Force.'' Unless effectively answered, they could well taint Thomas Kean's apparent winning of the governorship.

title: SENATORS ENCOURAGED BY REVISIONS IN C.I.A. ORDER
description: Several members of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence said today that they were heartened by the Reagan Administration's apparent willingness to adopt several revisions to a draft executive order governing intelligence activities.

title: STATE JUDGE REFUSES TO BAR HUNTING SET FOR HARRIMAN PARK
description: A State Supreme Court justice refused today to interfere with plans of the Palisades Interstate Park Commission to open Harriman State Park to deer hunting beginning Monday.

title: No Headline
description: JOBLESSNESS GROWS AS SLUMP SPREADS

title: MAGIC CIRCLE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: the company became publicly held in Aug 1980; the yr-ago figures are pro forma for the privately held companies that were consolidated into the public company

title: 76ers 105, Kings 85
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP) - Lionel Hollins scored 25 points and Darryl Dawkins had a career-high 19 rebounds as Philadelphia improved its record to 7-1. The 76ers scored 12 straight points in the first quarter for a 16-6 lead and finished the quarter ahead by 31-14.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This gives me a sense of what I'm doing to people. It helps us to reflect on life as it really is and to explain prison to people we sentence so that it's less devastating when they arrive.'' -Judge Jack B. Weinstein, touring a New York prison. (25:2.)

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 16.50 - 17.00 ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers + Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: JERSEY INQUIRY IS PLANNED ON VOTE SECURITY FORCE
description: The Essex County Prosecutor said today that he would coordinate a statewide investigation to determine whether any irregularities were committed in a Republican-backed ballot-security program during the New Jersey gubernatorial election Nov. 3.

title: THE IMMUNIZATION LAW IS WORKABLE BUT IT TAKES PLANNING
description: To the Editor:

title: PANEL OF JUDGES ORDERS RECOUNT OF JERSEY VOTES
description: A statewide recount of the votes for Governor of New Jersey will begin Wednesday morning, a three-judge panel ruled today.

title: DELTA DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $29,750,000 extraordinary net loss...C-Net income

title: U.S. Reaches Finals In Federation Cup Play
description: Chris Evert Lloyd and Andrea Jaeger led the top-seeded United States team past Switzerland today and into the finals of the Federation Cup tennis tournament.

title: Congress; DISTRICT LINES: HOT TOPIC ON THE HILL
description: Representative Gillis Long was brimming with joviality as he bounced through the halls of the Capitol. ''My district's O.K.,'' he called out to anyone within range of his good cheer. ''My district's O.K.''

title: SYSTEM ENABLES SPACESHIP TO LAND WITHOUT PILOT
description: Last April, to great cheering and the sound of its own sonic booms, the space shuttle Columbia returned from its first orbital flight and glided to a landing about a mile beyond its target point.

title: Patents; Avoiding Closed Eyes As Photos Are Taken
description: An engineer for the Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester, has found a way to avoid poor photographs of people who shut their eyes. Before the exposure begins, a flash of light is released to cause the subject to blink.

title: IN BANGLADESH ELECTION, THE AURA OF TWO DEAD LEADERS IS PERVASIVE
description: Despite the lively participation of 26 candidates, the Bangladesh presidential election campaign that ended here today has been dominated almost entirely by the auras of two dead adversaries.

title: PRESIDENT ORDERS RICKOVER TO LEAVE NAVY ATOMIC POST
description: Adm. Hyman G. Rickover will leave his post as the Navy's chief nuclear officer in January, on the orders of President Reagan, ending a 63-year career in which he brought a sometimes reluctant Navy into the nuclear age.

title: Going Out Guide
description: THE INQUIRING PHOTOGRAPHER

title: Letter: On Municipal Bonds Tax Exemption Is Not a Subsidy
description: To the Editor:

title: F.C.C. JUDGE BARS TV LICENSE
description: A Federal Communications Commission administrative law judge has refused to renew the license of a television and radio station in Lansing, Mich., because of ''misrepresentation and fraud'' in advertising and programming practices.

title: LAST OF TAX LEASE DEALS
description: A last-minute rush of tax leasing arrangements that would save corporations millions of dollars in Federal taxes was announced yesterday before a midnight deadline.

title: HELM RESOURCES (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $2,000 loss from discontinued operations... C-Net loss after $204,000 loss from discontinued operations; results exclude tax credits of $175,000 and $430,000 for the latest third qr and 9 mos and $63,000 for the yr-ago third qr which were earned but credited directly to capital surplus

title: Warriors 102, Rockets 100
description: HOUSTON (AP) - Sonny Parker hit a layup at the buzzer to give Golden State the victory. Parker rebounded a shot by his teammate, Lloyd Free, with two seconds left and put in a reverse layup. Houston (2-6) led by 10 points, 81-71, in the opening minute of the final quarter, but Joe Hassett scored 7 points and Parker added 6 as the Warriors (3-4) caught Houston with 3:15 left and took a 92-91 lead on a Parker layup.

title: ELECTRO-NUCLEONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sports People; Penalized Again
description: Last Sunday, the veteran guard Conrad Dobler of Buffalo was called for three major penalties in the Bills' loss against Dallas. Saying ''I felt it was time for a change,'' Coach Chuck Knox announced that Dobler would be replaced by Jim Ritcher for tomorrow's game against St. Louis. ... David Whitehurst will be the Green Bay Packers' starting quarterback against the Chicago Bears tomorrow, playing in place of Lynn Dickey. Whitehurst has played well once as a starter and twice in relief of Dickey the past three weeks.

title: Bridge Top New York Players Get A Night Away From Strife
description: When New York's most famous players meet at the card table it is usually with the firm intention of beating each other's brains out. Once a year, however, they gather in harmony and discuss old battles.

title: DELLWOOD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $430,100 extraordinary gain from the settlement of litigation

title: BONN LEGISLATORS ASSAIL SOVIET
description: Some 50 leftist legislators in West Germany's ruling Social Democratic Party have written to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, criticizing Moscow's military policies.

title: Cooney-Bugner Bout Canceled
description: A back injury suffered by Gerry Cooney in training has forced cancellation of his scheduled interim fight Dec. 5 against Joe Bugner. The cancellation means that Cooney, the undefeated top-ranked challenger, will go into his heavyweight title bout against Larry Holmes next March with only 3 minutes 43 seconds of actual ring work in almost two years.

title: RECESSION FEARS CUT DOW BY 4.66
description: The stock market fell moderately yesterday with some of the technology and recently strong railroad stocks posting the biggest losses.

title: Big Steel Tries Again
description: Barely a year after Big Steel pushed the Carter Administration to give it more protection against imports, the industry is back asking for more. But this time it's pounding on the door of an Administration pledged to free-market competition.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about Clare Boothe Luce on the Washington Talk page yester- day incorrectly reported the year of a visit by Ronald Reagan to Mrs. Luce and her husband before Mr. Reagan ran for office. The visit was in 1966.

title: FOR CHAD, THE LIBYAN PULLOUT IS CREATING A PERILOUS VACUUM
description: There is a poster in La Tchadienne hotel here that shows three people atop a camel and tells the visitor that this is a land of contrasts, folklore and hunting. After the word hunting, someone has penciled in ''for humans.''

title: STATE SET TO AWARD $5 MILLION IN ITS LOTTO DRAWING TONIGHT
description: A jackpot of $5 million - said by New York State Lottery officials to be the largest ever in a public gambling venture - may be awarded tonight to one or more persons who have bought $1 Lotto tickets this week.

title: FOREST OFFICE BACKS DRILLING IN SECOND WILDERNESS AREA
description: The United States Forest Service proposed yesterday that oil and gas drilling be allowed on more than 89,000 acres of the Washakie Wilderness, a rugged 687,000-acre preserve in northwestern Wyoming that is among the last remaining habitats of the grizzly bear and bighorn sheep.

title: British Leyland Increases Layoffs
description: A five-day-old strike over tea breaks caused British Leyland to lay off 2,000 more workers at its giant Longbridge plant outside Birmingham, with all car production at a standstill.

title: Judge Delays Hinckley Trial
description: A Federal District judge today delayed the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr., charged with shooting President Reagan and three others on March 30, until Jan. 4. Betty Flynn, court clerk, said Judge Barrington Parker postponed the trial, originally set for Nov. 30, because he felt it would be difficult to impanel a jury over the holidays.

title: Unhappy Jets' Past Recalled
description: The New York Jets have a 5-1-1 record in their last seven games, the best mark in the American Conference over that stretch. The New England Patriots have lost their last three games and have a 2-8 record this season, including a loss to the Jets.

title: UNIVERSAL VOLTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; the shr earnings and shrs outstndg give retroactive effect to a 2-for-1 stock split effective July 20, 1981

title: SOUTH AFRICA SECRETLY OBTAINS URANIUM FUEL, FRENCH ASSERT
description: French officials said tonight that South Africa had succeeded in buying enriched uranium in Western Europe to start up its French-built nuclear power plant despite American efforts to deny it the fuel.

title: ORWELL'S AHEAD SO FAR ON THE SHAPE OF 1984
description: To the Editor:

title: RANGERS, SABRES PLAY 3-3 TIE
description: Grinding is the word the Rangers use to describe themselves when they play hockey diligently. So tonight they may be said to have ground the Buffalo Sabres into accepting a 3-3 tie after Buffalo had taken the lead twice. The Ranger grinding took the form of indefatigable harassment of the Sabres until one of them made a mistake, by not checking a Ranger shooter, not clearing a rebound or not being able to move Ron Duguay out of the goal area.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48.

title: IMPERIAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BERKEY PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $2,164,000 for the qr and $2,227,000 for the 9 mos and $1,344,000 extraordinary tax credit for the qr and 9 mos...C-Including extraordinary tax credits of $1 million for the qr and $1,760,000 for the 9 mos and $180,000 income from discontinued operations for the 9 mos

title: CHARITIES DOUBTFUL THEY WILL BE ABLE TO OFFSET AID CUTS
description: Leaders of private charities say they will not be able to meet President Reagan's challenge to raise enough money for the needy and provide enough volunteers to offset cuts in Federal social programs - at least, not any time soon.

title: The City; Phone Problem At Bronx Hospital
description: Telephones at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx were knocked out of service late Thursday night, temporarily cutting off communications between the hospital and outside callers, officials said.

title: Cessna Aircraft Plans Layoffs
description: The Cessna Aircraft Company said it would begin laying off 1,295 workers and reduce its production rate on all types of aircraft.

title: THEATER: 'LADY LESTER'
description: The tenor saxophonist Lester Young was a legendary pioneer of modern jazz, an individualist who was unable to compromise either in his music or in his attitude toward those who could control his destiny. The story of Young, the ''Prez'' - the president of saxophonists - is the provocative subject of OyamO's play ''The Resurrection of Lady Lester,'' which opened last night at the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: Around the Nation; 5 Ex-Officials Admit Guilt in Oklahoma
description: Five more former county commissioners pleaded guilty to mail fraud and tax evasion charges today, a day after six others pleaded guilty to similar charges that grew out of a Federal inquiry into taking kickbacks.

title: CARING FOR THE ELDERLY
description: Current concern over the Social Security system affords an opportunity to consider not just the smaller question of whether to encourage later retirement but also the larger issue of basic strategies for responding to the needs of the elderly.

title: JUNIPER PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Consumer Saturday; CITY BAN APPLIES TO KEROSENE HEATERS
description: I T often seems that many of the city's problems become more burdensome in the colder months. Fuel complaints multiply, demands on city and state services increase, illnesses spread more quickly and their seriousness becomes magnified.

title: The City; The Police Blotter
description: A Queens man already in custody on charges of robbery and sodomy was charged with the sexual assault and strangulation of a bank worker last month. The suspect, Chris Aniades, 23 years old, was in the Queens House of Detention when he was charged with abducting Doreen Vitale on Oct. 15 and killing her.

title: SEGA ENTERPRISES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After foreign currency translation, losses of $896,000 for the latest first qr and $347,000 for the previous first qr

title: CELTICS DEFEAT NETS
description: After almost every one of the Nets' baskets during their 111-97 loss to the Boston Celtics tonight, the most audible voice in the Civic Center came from New Jersey's bench. But it did not belong to Larry Brown, the head coach.

title: OPTIMUM HOLDING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including investment gains of $3,000 for the qr and $9,000 for the 9 mos; prior to July 1, 1980 the company's operations consisted of the investment of its contributed capital

title: Sports People; Eddie Johnson's Battle
description: The Atlanta Hawks' Eddie Johnson, who has been fighting emotional problems, will begin practicing with the club again on Monday. Johnson was suspended during training camp and has been undergoing physical and psychological therapy.

title: Athens Court Rules Journalist Need Not Reveal His Sources
description: An Athens court has ruled that a journalist is not obliged to reveal his sources but rather ''has a duty to protect them.''

title: BANK-BROKERAGE THAW?
description: The longstanding feud between the banking and securities industries has taken an unexpected turn with a major securities association endorsing a proposal to allow banks to move into the lucrative business of underwriting municipal revenues bonds - an area that securities firms have always regarded as theirs exclusively.

title: RADIO SESSION VOTES TO KEEP CURRENT FREQUENCIES FOR AM
description: The United States, gaining its first negotiating victory at an international radio conference, has persuaded the nations of the Western Hemisphere to keep the current arrangement for spacing radio stations on the AM dial.

title: BRYANT GOING FOR STAGG'S VICTORY MARK
description: John David Crow, the only Heisman Trophy winner from a team coached by Paul (Bear) Bryant, said: ''It is no surprise to me that Coach Bryant is going to win this many games and set the record. Heck, I always felt like he would win them all.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Avco Financial Services filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a sale of $125 million of zero-coupon junior subordinated notes due in 1990, through a group of underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody.

title: Books of The Times
description: Doomed to Enlighten By Anatole Broyard JOHN RUSKIN: THE PASSIONATE MORALIST. By Joan Abse. Illustrated. 363 pages. Knopf. $18.50.

title: Around the Nation; Court Settlements Paid In Deaths at Hyatt Hotel
description: More than $600,000 has been paid in out-of-court settlements in lawsuits stemming from the July 17 walkway collapse at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in which 113 people were killed and 186 were injured, according to court documents.

title: De Gustibus; UPS AND DOWNS OF SUNNY SIDE UP
description: For an apparently simple dish, fried eggs provoke a good deal of argument, first over how they should be cooked and then how they should be eaten.

title: Notes on People; Fake Cowboy Takes Act Too Far
description: A shaken deputy sheriff said yesterday that he came near to shooting a 14-year-old boy who looked like he was acting out a typical climactic scene from a Hollywood Western.

title: DUPONT AND STEELWORKERS FACE VOTE
description: For months, the United Steelworkers of America and E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company have been engaged in a war of words over the union's longstanding campaign to recruit workers at 16 Du Pont plants.

title: KARPOV AND KORCHNOI DRAW THEIR 15TH GAME
description: Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union and Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland today agreed to a draw in the adjourned 15th game of their world chess championship match here without resuming play.

title: BOND DEALERS CONVENE IN AN OPTIMISTIC MOOD
description: After 10 months of high and volatile interest rates that kept profits low or nonexistent, the recent sharp rate declines have brought smiles to securities dealers gathered here at the annual convention of the Public Securities Association.

title: Jazz 131, Nuggets 124
description: SALT LAKE CITY (AP) - Adrian Dantley scored 38 points, including 14 in the final quarter, for Utah as Denver lost its fourth straight. Dantley scored 20 points in the first half, but sat out the third quarter after getting into foul trouble. He returned and scored six field goals.

title: SHAPELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOUTHWEST LEASING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1980 figures include revs generated from the sale of corporate property of $1,764,000 which increased net income by $1,012,000 or 60 cents a shr

title: HARRIET PHIPPS, FORMER HEAD OF GIRL SCOUT COUNCIL, IS DEAD
description: Harriet Phipps, who was president of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York from 1942 to 1973 and continued as honorary president, died yesterday at Nassau Hospital in Mineola, L.I. She was 80 years old and a resident of Old Westbury, L.I.

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT DROPS 1.5%
description: With the economy plunging into a recession, the nation's industrial production fell 1.5 percent in October, the sharpest drop in 16 months, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: 17,625 SEE ROCKETS LOSE DEBUT
description: The New Jersey Rockets rallied from a four-goal deficit only to lose, 7-6, to the New York Arrows before a crowd of 17,625 tonight in the innaugural indoor soccer game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: New York; WALKING A MOTHBALLED ELEPHANT
description: The budget-makers may still be wearing frowns under their green eyeshades, but what the president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation told the agency's board on Thursday is good news: Woodhull Hospital - the innovative and very costly city institution that, despite its completion three years ago, has been in mothballs out of fear of what it could cost to open and run it - will indeed begin to open in phases starting next spring.

title: EXPRESS BUSES HAVE IT ALL OVER THE M.T.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK TERMED 'HUB' OF FOREIGN SPIES IN U.S.
description: From the Soviet residence in the Bronx, where rooftop equipment permits surveillance of telephones throughout the Northeast, to Russian emigre communities in Brooklyn, where the F.B.I. fears that Soviet agents live in disguise, American and Russian agents are competing for information.

title: LOAN GUARANTEES PROVIDED TO CITY
description: After weeks of debate within the Treasury Department, the Reagan Administration yesterday approved $300 million in Federal loan guarantees intended to assist New York City in its fiscal recovery.

title: Notes on People; A Medal for Mrs. Astor
description: Nobody has given more to the New York Public Library than Brooke Astor, and few library trustees have been as diligent as she has in attending library events.

title: Rawson, Wade To Be Part of Scribner's
description: Effective Jan. 1, Rawson, Wade Publishers will become a division of the Scribner Book Companies, which presently includes Charles Scribner's Sons and Atheneum Publishers. The new division will be known as Rawson Associates, of which Kennett L. Rawson will be president and Eleanor S. Rawson executive vice president.

title: ADAMS-RUSSELL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONTINUING PROBLEMS IN GETTING CREDIT DATA
description: Two Federal laws passed in the 1970's greatly improved a consumer's right to obtain credit and gain access to credit reports, but problems ave remained.

title: LOUIS B. RESNICK
description: Louis B. Resnick, a senior partner in the law firm of Paskus, Gordon & Hyman in Manhattan and the Mayor of Flower Hill, L.I., died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in Manhasset, L.I. He was 60 years old.

title: Senate Rejects Reagan Plan To Curtail Legal Aid for Poor
description: The Senate today rejected, 61 to 21, the Reagan Administration's proposal to eliminate direct Federal financing for legal aid for the poor.

title: U.N. ASSAILS ISRAEL FOR 3D TIME OVER ATTACK ON IRAQI REACTOR
description: For the second time in three days and the third time since June, the United Nations has rebuked Israel for destroying an Iraqi nuclear reactor.

title: WORK GOING ON AROUND THE CLOCK ON QUEENS SUBWAY LINK
description: Since early September, construction crews have been working around the clock burrowing 40 feet under the Van Wyck Expressway in Queens to create two 1,400-foot tunnels as part of the Archer Avenue subway extension project.

title: The City; Asia Society Off Tax Rolls
description: A judge restored the tax-exempt status of the Asia Society yesterday, saying that the society, which owns property in Manhattan assessed at millions of dollars, was an educational organization.

title: MEENAN OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BLACK-TIE SAFARI TO RESCUE RHINO
description: They journeyed, 200 strong, to East 70th Street, wearing, as requested, formal attire or safari clothes - in some instances both - to rescue the rhinos.

title: BUTTES GAS & OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A CATHOLIC REVOLUTION
description: Something is stirring in the Roman Catholic Church in the United States that portends an explosion between church and state that will make the abortion issue, the school-aid controversy, and the tax-exempt status of churches look like a child's sparkler on the Fourth of July.

title: Sports People; Boyer Gets Post
description: Ken Boyer, who managed the St. Louis Cardinals from 1978-80, was named manager of the Louisville Redbirds, the Cards' American Association farm team. The Redbirds have switched to Louisville from Springfield, Ill. Boyer, 50 years old, had been working as a scout and consultant for the Cardinal organization.

title: TELLER SHOT IN UNION SQ. ROBBERY
description: A teller was shot yesterday during an attempted bank robbery in the Union Square area just hours after another teller was briefly taken hostage but not harmed by a gunman who held up a bank in Herald Square.

title: A VISIT TO A SALVADORAN VILLAGE AT WAR
description: Shredded strips of the blue and white Salvadoran flag flutter at the top of a 50-foot-high bamboo pole in front of the gutted shell of what was the village's municipal building.

title: FIRST USE OF FIRE PUT MILLION YEARS EARLIER THAN WAS ESTIMATED
description: New discoveries at an archeological site in Kenya appear to push back by almost a million years the first use of fire by the ancestors of modern humans.

title: U.S. EXAMINES JAPANESE PAYMENT GIVEN TO REAGAN SECURITY ADVISER
description: The White House said today that the Justice Department was investigating a $1,000 cash payment received by President Reagan's national security adviser, Richard V. Allen, from a Japanese magazine that interviewed Nancy Reagan on Jan. 21.

title: SUPRADUR MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CAMBRIDGE ROYALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dining Out; SUNDAY BRUNCH IN COS COB
description: COS COB IF you're looking for a low-key, informal Sunday brunch, the best value around - at least in Fairfield County - might well be the Hunt Breakfast Buffet recently inaugurated at Tumbledown Dick's on the Post Road in Cos Cob.

title: Betsy King Shares Lead
description: Betsy King of the United States shot a six-under-par 68 for a second-round total of 142, and shared the lead with Japan's Yuko Moriguchi today in the $87,000 Itsuki women's golf tournament.

title: A VILLAGE ECHOS CHOPIN'S THEMES
description: PAUL LEWIS is a correspondent in Paris for The New York Times. By PAUL LEWIS

title: HAIG SEES TROUBLE IN TIES WITH CHINA OVER TAIWAN ARMS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that relations with the Chinese Communists faced ''a very worrisome specter'' over the question of American military sales to Taiwan.

title: Soviet Exile a French Citizen
description: Leonid Plyoushch, a mathematician who spent three years in a Soviet psychiatric hospital before being expelled to the West in 1976, has been granted French citizenship, the Government journal said today. Mr. Plyoushch, a human rights activist until his arrest, has lived in France since being expelled.

title: The Gold-Headed Cane
description: In 1909 a Boston newspaper distributed 700 gold-headed canes throughout New England to be awarded by local newspapers to their towns' oldest citizens. After each recipient's death, the cane was to be reclaimed and passed on.

title: Union Wins, Led by Smith
description: Albert Smith, a senior tailback, rushed for 212 yards on 24 carries and scored two touchdowns to help Union gain a 21-0 victory over Montclair yesterday. The victory gave Union a berth in the North Jersey, Section 2, Group 4 playoffs.

title: Television Week
description: More Mileage ''Norma Rae,'' the movie, gave Sally Field an opportunity that she made the most of, winning an Oscar for her portrayal of the mill hand who helped to bring the union into her factory. Now, ''Norma Rae'' has been made into what NBC calls a ''sequential television project.'' Translation: a potential series for which this one-hour drama, to be shown Saturday from 10 to 11 P.M., serves as a pilot.

title: WILL HE GO FROM 'RAGTIME' TO RICHES?
description: What Howard E. Rollins Jr. remembers best was the moment when he came in for the second screen test and met O.J. Simpson coming out. He had already passed through three auditions at director Milos Forman's apartment, two readings with other actors, and an initial test for the part of Coalhouse Walker Jr., a part which is to the movie version of ''Ragtime,'' which opens Friday at the Coronet, what a mainspring is to a watch. And all the time he knew, deep in his gut, that the role of the fiery black turn-of-the-century piano player who is willing to kill and to die to retain his dignity was going to go to somebody else, because Howard Rollins was nobody at all, except for maybe ''Who was that guy who was so good in that Off Off Broadway thing we saw a couple years ago?''

title: CORRESPONDENT'S CHOICE
description: Since I'm probably one of the few persons in the world who could stake a claim to having seen Niagara Falls and Victoria Falls within a span of about 12 hours, I'm prepared to pose as a connoisseur of waterfalls and to declare that if you've seen one waterfall you haven't seen them all, unless you've walked the promontory above the Zambezi River George in Zimbabwe.

title: CHINA'S LEAP TO AMERICAN CAMPUSES
description: Jan Wong lived in Peking for six years and worked as a news assistant for The Times's Peking bureau. She is currently a reporter for The Gazette in Montreal. By Jan Wong

title: COLUMBIA COULD HELP UNSCRAMBLE A DATA GLUT
description: When man-made instruments were first launched into Earth orbit almost a quarter century ago, revolutionary improvements in understanding Earth and inventorying its resources on land and at sea seemed in prospect. Spectacular performances by satellites such as the Landsats and the short-lived Seasat in the late 1970's led many scientists to believe these achievements were at hand.

title: MAKING A DREAM COME TRUE, AND WATCHING IT FADE AWAY
description: The phone call that came last Wednesday confirmed what I had contemplated and begrudgingly come to accept: I was officially unemployed - the Women's Pro Basketball League had folded.

title: Mary Vanderwoude Wed To Lee Gross, Executive
description: Mary Celeste Vanderwoude, a fashion editor and coordinator at Popular Services Inc., a catalogue merchandising company in Passaic, N.J., was married yesterday at the Church Center for the United Nations to Lee Harlan Gross. He is controller of BCI Casting & Talent Payments and IDC Data Services divisions of IDC Services Inc., a talent casting company, in New York.

title: Politics; THE THIRD-PARTY INFLUENCE
description: LAST year, when John B. Anderson was running for President as an independent and most of the pre-election polls were projecting a close race between Ronald Reagan and Jimmy Carter, political analysts began dusting off their history books.

title: FOR ARGENTINE YOUNG, AN AGED LITERARY HERO
description: More than 100 young authors crammed into the dining room of the Writers' Association one night here recently, perspiring but attentive.

title: BABAR AT 50, PINOCCHIO AT 100
description: BABAR'S ANNIVERSARY ALBUM Six Favorite Stories. By Jean and Laurent de Brunhoff. Introduction by Maurice Sendak. 144 pp. New York: Random House. $12.95.

title: St. Joseph's Gains Playoff
description: Playoff berths for the three football conferences in Fairfield County have been decided. Greenwich and Trumbull posted victories Friday evening to set up a Thanksgiving Day Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference championship game. St. Joseph's and Fairfield Prep will meet for the Metropolitan Bridgeport Interscholastic Athletic Conference title, and Newton and New Fairfield are set to vie for the Western Connecticut Conference crown.

title: Mailbox; How the Yankees Could Have Won
description: To the Sports Editor: As a Dodger fan (but very objective), I would like to apologize to the Yankees and their fans. Based on the World Series post-mortems I have read or heard, I fully realize that my beloved Dodgers had no right to allow the best team in baseball to lose the World Series.

title: New Jersey Housing; VERNON TOWNSHIP'S GROWING PAINS
description: timers.''

title: A PLACE TO ENSHRINE RELIGIOUS TOLERANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THEY have been riding Conrail trains to work for 22 years or more, six county residents who now have a new chance to make the voice of the rider heard in Albany and New York City.

title: HELP WANTED: A 'BIG 5' MUSIC DIRECTOR
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Judith Karp writes frequently about music. By JUDITH KARP

title: New Jersey Guide; RE: GERTRUDE STEIN
description: When Pat Carroll, the actress and television personality, was recuperating from knee surgery in 1976, she had a lot of time to consider subjects for a one-woman show. Becoming fascinated with Gertrude Stein, the controversial author and literary and artistic patron, she commissioned a Texas playwright, Marty Martin, to write a script.

title: TUNISIANS WORRIED ABOUT SUCCESSION
description: With Tunisia's 80-year-old President reported to be seriously ill with an undisclosed illness, politicians are increasingly concerned with the problems of succession.

title: More Child Loans
description: To the Business Editor: Peter Huber's letter on Nov. 1 states with undue certainty that a ''parent who makes a demand loan to a trust will be taxed.'' With equal certainty, at least as unwarranted, Julian S. Bush responds in the Editor's Note that ''at no time does an interest-free loan create any liability for income taxes on the part of the lender.''

title: Patricia Morrissey Married
description: Patricia Ann Morrissey, a medical social worker at the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, was married yesterday to David V. Repko, a personnel relations lawyer with the J.C. Penney Company in New York. The ceremony was performed in St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City, L. I., by the Rev. Patrick Whitney. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas G. Morrissey of Garden City. Mr. Repko, a former city councilman in Duquesne, Pa., is a son of Mrs. Joseph F. Repko of Duquesne and the late Mr. Repko.

title: STAGE: 'JAPANESQUE' SAMURAI MUSICAL
description: Two lovers share an idyllic pas de deux to the tune of undulating soft rock. They are surrounded by a chorus carrying puffballs, which, when tossed into the air, turn into clouds of confetti. The ''snow'' falls onto long roads of bright ribbon, which are rhythmically raised and lowered so that the sky is filled with a replenishing Milky Way of dancing particles. The moment is both ingenuous and inspired, and if all of ''Shiro'' were on this level, the evening would be as captivating as ''The Golden Bat.''

title: CITIES NOW LEARN ARTFUL FRUGALITY
description: The nation's cities have been so short of money in recent months that they have become something of a collective laboratory in the art of penny-pinching.

title: ISRAEL REJECTS MOSQUE PLAN OPPOSED BY ARABS
description: A dispute over an Israeli project to incorporate the ruins of a mosque into a tourist shopping complex here ended this week with the announcement that the proposal was invalid because the land involved was Government-owned.

title: Ann Carhart Is Married
description: Anne McDonnell Carhart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Carhart of East Northport, L.I., was married there yesterday to Jesse Carl Downing 3d, son of Dora Downing of Washington and the late Mr. Downing Jr.

title: GUARDIANS OF GAME DESERVE BETTER FATE
description: IT is time to praise obscure men. In a world filled with corruption, avarice and unscrupulousness, sports has always been an arena of purity -the purity of physical achievement for its own sake. True, it has become more business-like and Hollywood, yet one vestige of its raw innocense remains: the sports official. In the light of college recruitment violations, athletic point-shavings, professional athlete's betting scandals, politicalization of the Olympic Games, use of drugs for human and animal athletes, constant litigation among teams, players, owners and host cities, how often has a hint of wrong-doing been connected with the lowest-paid and most-watched (and second-guessed) participant on the field?

title: 2 Die in Pretoria Jet Crash
description: A Lear executive jet crashed and burst into flames last night at South Africa's Waterkloof Air Force base outside Pretoria, killing the aircraft's two crewmen, the South African radio reported today. It identified the crewmen as James Burre, a Lear representative from Tucson, Ariz., and Boet Preller of Johannesburg.

title: New York Times Magazine November 15, 1981
description: William Safire 16 On Language Zapped Again Russell Baker 30 Sunday Observer Reviving the Shotgun Wedding John Vinocur 40 The German Malaise Wayne Biddle 46 Neutron Bomb: An Explosive Issue Susan Goodman 64 The Legend of the Golden Hare Jennifer Dunning 66 Exchanging the Bow for the Baton Jan Wong 82 China's Leap to American Campuses Anthony Burgess 102 Creating a Language for Primitive Man Isadore Rosenfeld 126 A Doctor Defends His Calling Elizabeth B. Moynihan 136 Mail Call on Capitol Hill Carrie Donovan 140 Fashion The Success of Luxury Jani Wooldridge 142 Beauty A Nose for Making Scents Suzanne Slesin 144 Design Cement Silos Recast for Living Craig Claiborne 148 Food with Pierre Franey A Lift Up for Leftovers 154 Puzzles Answers, Page 158 166 Letters Cover: Photograph by Regie Bossu/Sygma Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: PORTRAIT OF THE HUDSON RIVER
description: IN a book recently published by the Sleepy Hollow Press of Tarrytown, about 150 vintage photographs from historical societies, museums and private collections portray what life was like along the Hudson River many years ago. ''The Hudson River: 1850-1918'' ($29.95) is a photographic portrait by Jeffrey Simpson, a social historian, that includes detailed captions and a descriptive text.

title: No Headline
description: Spurs Topple Sonics as Gervin Scores 47

title: NEW TITLE I FASHIONED OUT OF CONTROVERSY
description: DESPITE efforts by the Reagan Administration to eliminate Title I as a distinct program, the nation now has a new, streamlined version of the much-acclaimed compensatory-education system.

title: PHILIPPINES IS HARNESSING POWER OF VOLCANOES
description: Guarding the southern flank of this vast metropolis are two graceful, green-clad mountains wreathed with white smoke, emissions from a potent reservoir of volcanic steam.

title: George Walsh, Reporter, Fiance of Diane Farewell
description: Mrs. Vila Farewell of Harrison, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Diane Catherine Farewell, to George Morrell Walsh, son of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Walsh of Garden City, L.I. The wedding is planned for Jan. 2.

title: STUDIES BUDGET CUTS
description: NEWARK THE board of directors of NJ Transit, the state's mass-transit corporation, is scheduled to vote in two weeks on whether to impose another round of fare increases and service reductions on all its bus and rail lines this year.

title: Future Events A Faire, a First and Fashions
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated: Ye Olde British Faire Nov. 16 - The 61st Ye Olde British Faire sponsored by the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York will open at 10 A.M. at the Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue. Refreshments will be available, and the opportunity to do Christmas shopping for British foods antiques and other gifts will also aid the Victoria Home for Retired Men and Women in Ossining, N.Y. Call 838-0808. Fashion Fun Nov. 16 - The Fourth Tribute to the Black Designer, a festive evening of dancing, dessert, Diahann Carroll and Gregory Hines and a music and fashion revue, will aid the Scholarship Fund of the Educational Foundation for the Fashion Industries of the Fashion Institute of Technology. Geraldine Stutz, president and owner of Henri Bendel, and Lionel Hampton are co-chairmen of the sponsors' committee. The institute and Harveys of Bristol are the sponsors of the event at 227 West 27th Street. Tickets are $50 from 760-7641.

title: SECOND FLIGHT YIELDS RICH HARVEST OF SPACE DATA
description: Even with a shortened flight, all indications are that the space shuttle Columbia brought home a far richer harvest of scientific and engineering data than it did on its first mission last April.

title: 778 HAITIANS SEE NO END TO ODYSSEY
description: On the perimeter of Fort Allen, where the inexorable tropical vegetation tries to take back its own, vines ease over the barbed wire and thick vegetation hides the old military installation from view. Grass grows knee-high in the shady gardens of the abandoned officers' quarters, and there is a certain lushness in the midst of the isolation and decay.

title: DAVID DIGGS, MUSICIAN, TO WED GRACE MEADE
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Winthrop Sibley of New York have made known the engagement of Mrs. Sibley's daughter, Grace Louise Meade, to David Diggs. Miss Meade is a daughter also of the late Harry Allen Meade. Mr. Diggs is a son of Bill Diggs and Adele Diggs, both of Oklahoma City.

title: THE GERMAN MALAISE
description: John Vinocur is chief of The New York Times bureau in Bonn. By John Vinocur

title: DEVELOPERS EYE LAND ON FRICK ESTATE
description: ROSLYN HARBOR In 1969, Nassau County acquired 145 acres of land here for $3.5 million and termed it the William Cullen Bryant Preserve, since it was near Cedarmere, the Long Island home of the widely respected newspaper editor, essayist and poet. Five years later, in a 25-room brick Georgian mansion on the property, the county established the Museum of Fine Art, where today it presents large art and sculpture exhibitions.

title: Mishaps Plaguing Falcons, Steelers
description: Leeman Bennett and Chuck Noll are two pro coaches who have been reminded lately that much can go wrong in a football game. Bennett's Falcons take on Noll's Pittsburgh Steelers today in Atlanta, each team with a 5-5 record and diminishing playoff chances.

title: BOAT-RAMP PLAN STIRS DEBATE
description: KINGS PARK A PROPOSAL by the Long Island State Park Commission to build a new public boat launching ramp on the Nissequogue River - providing for the first time public access to Long Island Sound to boaters from around the state - has raised concern among civic leaders and boat owners in some North Shore communities.

title: BALLET: SCHAUFFUS VERSION OF 'NAPOLI'
description: The National Ballet of Canada celebrated its 30th anniversary last night with a gala at the O'Keefe Center that included a birthday cake, an unusual array of guest stars and, most important, a spectacular new production by Peter Schaufuss of ''Napoli,'' the 19th-century classic by the Danish choreographer August Bournonville.

title: LASER LIGHT GIVES MAPLE NO. 5
description: Laser Light, who suggested he was a top 2-year-old when he finished second to Deputy Minister in the Laurel Futurity and Young America Stakes, confirmed that opinion yesterday with a five-length victory in the $172,500 Remsen Stakes at Aqueduct.

title: Music; A BARTOK FESTIVAL SET FOR PRINCETON
description: THE story of a composer who spends his last days in poverty and embitterment, only to be acclaimed after his death, would seem to belong to the distant past - to the legend of a Mozart or Schubert.

title: Leifer, Giacone Lead 17-6 Westfield Victory
description: Paul Leifer and Mike Giacone, senior running backs, both scored on 1-yard runs to boost Westfield to a 17-6 victory over Linden yesterday. Westfield (7-1) will be the second-seeded team in the North Jersey, Section 2, Group 4 playoffs.

title: No Headline
description: The idea that overweight is due primarily to pressures of ''society ... culture ... fashion'' is destructive to many.

title: No Headline
description: FETAL SURGERY OUTSIDE WOMB CALLED A SUCCESS

title: U.S. DRIVE PAYS OFF ON LOAN DEFAULTERS
description: COLLEGES and universities around the nation have tightened collection procedures on student loans in the last few years. But there may be renewed trouble, loan officials say, because the uncertain state of the economy means fewer good jobs for those expected to repay the loans in the years ahead.

title: ISRAELI 'THIN LINE,' TOUCHING FAMILY STORY
description: ''The Thin Line'' chronicles the decline of an Israeli woman into madness, to the dismay of her two young daughters and her devoted husband. It is the second film written and directed by the actress Michal Bat Adam, and it's a great improvement over ''Each Other,'' her first.

title: DAMS LABELED AS UNSAFE REMAIN UNREPAIRED
description: More than 200 dams in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have been classified by the Army Corps of Engineers over the last four years as unsafe, and only a small number of them have been repaired, according to environmental officials in the three states.

title: A BIRTHDAY PARTY FOR A BRIDGE
description: A TIARA of lights 325 feet above the roadway of the Bayonne Bridge glowed majestically last night as the 1,675-foot-long span marked its golden anniversary. But the official celebration - partially eclipsed, perhaps, by the hooplah that accompanied the George Washington Bridge's 50th birthday on Oct. 25 - will not be held until tomorrow.

title: A MOVIE ON THE PRESS STIRS A DEBATE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jonathan Friendly is the press reporter for The Times. By JONATHAN FRIENDLY

title: CHICAGO
description: ATREMOR of anticipation rippled through the audience of 350 young children sitting cross-legged on the floor of the Chippewa Elementary School's gym in suburban Bensenville. Suddenly, almost magically, two black men wearing colorful African costumes and playing strangelooking flutes, appeared from behind a closed door.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE AGE OF SURVEILLANCE, by Frank J. Donner. (Vintage, $7.95.) From the Red Scare of World War I through the Watergate scandals of the 70's, intense clandestine campaigns were mounted against American citizens by such Government organizations as the F.B.I., military intelligence, the C.I.A., the I.R.S., Presidential agencies and Congressional committees, all in the name of ''political intelligence'' and ''surveillance,'' but actually to restrict political dissent and movements for social change. Such is the thesis of this sprawling, chilling indictment by a civil liberties lawyer.

title: THE SURGE IN BUSINESS FAILURES
description: FINALLY, the high cost of money is sending tens of thousands of the businesses that borrowed it down the road that so many of the experts said it would to a cleaner called bankruptcy court. All it took to send them there was a recession.

title: A DAY WITH A LIVE-IN CAMPUS COMPUTER
description: IN the fall of 1980, Richard Cyert, the president of Carnegie-Mellon University, announced that the university planned to provide a personal computer terminal for each student, starting in 1986. The technology for the project is available. All that is needed is a commitment to the belief that a personalized computing environment will actually enhance education - and substantial amounts of money, effort and good design.

title: A PRODUCER OF THE PROVOCATIVE
description: Herbert Brodkin has been producing television dramas for 30 years, from programs for ''Playhouse 90,'' ''Studio One,'' ''The Motorola TV Hour'' and ''The Alcoa-Goodyear Playhouse'' during television's socalled Golden Age of the 50's, to ''The Defenders'' series, ''Pueblo,'' ''The Missiles of October'' and, more recently, ''F.D.R. - The Last Year'' and ''Holocaust.'' His nearly 600 shows have dealt with substantive and often provocative subjects. Generally, they have also garnered critical praise as well as high ratings.

title: Paperback Talk
description: The challenge of the children. What is the most challenging problem now facing paperback publishers? When he was asked that question recently, Lou Wolfe, chairman of Bantam Books, had a ready answer: ''Getting the kids interested in books as a form of entertainment as well as a means of learning. If we get them into the book habit early, we have them for life.''

title: 400-MILE WALL CHANGING WAR IN WESTERN SAHARA
description: From a Moroccan hilltop artillery position, a long line of bulldozer-turned earth can be seen forming a raised scar across the low mountains and desiccated plain of the Western Sahara.

title: OIL FUELS THE LAMPS OF LEARNING IN SOUTHWEST
description: SAN ANTONIO FOR a university that has bounced around three different towns and whose current campus did not exist 30 years ago, Trinity University of San Antonio would have to be considered a remarkable success story. But it - and numerous other schools, in varying degree - can thank the oil industry for relative financial independence.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: ALAW designed to protect elderly and disabled tenants from eviction in apartment house conversions to condominiums is being tested in the courts because landlords are arguing that the regulations are not applicable if plans were announced before the statute became binding.

title: Gallery View; CONTRASTS IN THE LIFE AND ART OF ANDRE DERAIN
description: One of the most curious careers in 20th-century art - and one of the most poignant, also - is commemorated in the exhibition of paintings, drawings and sculptures by Andre Derain at the Theo Waddington Gallery, 1044 Madison Avenue at 80th Street.

title: A NOAH'S ARK OF TOYS
description: SUSAN GOODMAN is a London-based writer. By SUSAN GOODMAN

title: Why Send Haitians to Siberia?
description: Why is the Reagan Administration so intent on giving itself one hotfoot after another concerning the Haitians?

title: READING, PA., WORKERS TESTED IN CANCER STUDY
description: Stanley Schweitzer worked his way up in the Reading Company from trucker to helper to machinist. He put in 38 years at the locomotive construction and maintenance facility that the now-defunct railroad once operated here.

title: MAESTRO TO HONOR OLD FRIEND AT HARTT
description: ''HARTFORD has a very deep place in my heart,'' said Mstislav Rostropovich, the noted Russian cellist and conductor. In a recent telephone interview, the director of Washington's National Symphony talked about his appearance at 3 P.M. today in Lincoln Theater in Hartford with the Hartt Symphony Orchestra.

title: Kenyan Driver Is First In Himalayan Car Rally
description: The second Himalayan Car Rally ended today with only 13 of 59 starting cars surviving the week of dust, rain, snow and rocks - including some hurled by anti-rally demonstrators.

title: Lisa Rogovin, Gary Marx, Lawyers, Wed in Capital
description: Lisa Shea Rogovin, a lawyer in Washington, was married there yesterday to Gary Samuel Marx, an associate in Washington law firm of Arent, Fox, Kitner, Plotkin & Kahn. Rabbi James Glazier of South Burlington, Vt., performed the ceremony at the Congressional Club.

title: LABOR CHIEFS SEEK ORGANIZING AND POLITICAL FUNDS
description: Leaders of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations yesterday recommended increases in per capita dues for the labor organization that would bring in close to $14 million in additional funds in the next two years for expanded organizational activities, political education and other programs.

title: NORTH EDGECOMB, Me.
description: BILL BURLESON gazed out the living room window at the Sheepscot River and the painter's easel foliage that covered the surrounding hills here only a few miles from the Atlantic Ocean. It was one of those utterly brilliant autumn days, and the hills shimmered. Then the bell rang, and class started.

title: 6 QUESTIONS APPROVED BY VOTERS FACE DELAYS
description: TRENTON THE easy passage of all eight public questions on the Nov. 3 ballot does not mean instant change in the issues they addressed. Indeed, additional work and uncertainty, including at least one lawsuit, stand in the way of quick implementation of six of the eight. The hurdles are as follows:

title: A FELLOW PAINTER'S VIEW OF GIORGIO MORANDI
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Wayne Thiebaud is a painter and teacher at the University of California at Davis. By WAYNE THIEBAUD

title: North Rockland Tops Nyack
description: North Rockland trounced Nyack, 28-0, yesterday to finish its first undefeated season since 1972 in the Rockland County P.S.A.L. Greg Erdle, the league's leading scorer, had three touchdowns for the Red Raiders, who won their ninth straight game. Juan Moranda had the other touchdown.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Purloined Papers
description: Documents signed by Lafayette, Brahms and Lincoln, among others, were stolen two years ago from the Sheraton Centre hotel in Manhattan, where the Antiquarian Booksellers Association of America was holding its annual spring fair.

title: States News Service
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. NEW ENGLAND Congressmen are becoming more optimistic that they can save energy tax credits from the Federal budget ax. The Reagan Administration insists it still may try to cut or eliminate the credits, which are available to individuals and businesses to help defray the costs of installing insulation or alternative energy sources. But some members of the New England Congressional Caucus are beginning to doubt the cuts will be made. The Administration may be stalling, they say, or it may even have dropped its plans to impose the cuts.

title: Protest for Soviet Germans
description: About 1,000 people marched here today demanding that the Soviet Union allow ethnic Germans to emigrate.

title: Around the World; 100,000 Rumanians Call For East-West Arms Cut
description: About 100,000 people demanding disarmament by both the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Soviet Union marched here today in what officials called the largest peace demonstration in this Soviet-bloc nation.

title: Business Conditions; THE VALUE OF EXPORTS
description: As America's second recession in as many years spreads beyond the housing and automotive industries, economists and international trade specialists are worried that protectionist pressures may mount both here and abroad. However, recent Commerce Department statistics show that such an effort could prove self-defeating: In the last decade, exports have become an increasingly important component of gross national product.

title: 11 Aswan Buildings Damaged In 3 Quakes but No One Dies
description: Three strong earthquakes damaged 11 buildings in Aswan yesterday and today but there were no reports of deaths, the Middle East News Agency said.

title: 'DEMONSTRATION' BOMBS AND OTHER THREATS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CAMPUS VISIT: WHAT TO LOOK FOR
description: THERE were 12 in the group - high school students and the parents of some of them - as it wound over the grassy slopes and tree-shaded lawns of the Wesleyan University campus in Middletown, Conn. ''Is there close contact between students and professors?'' one of the youngsters asked Steven Levere, an undergraduate leading the group. ''Because the classes are small, there's a lot of contact with the professors,'' he replied.

title: EXCHANGING THE BOW FOR THE BATON
description: Jennifer Dunning is on the culture staff of The Times. By Jennifer Dunning he St. Paul Chamber Orchestra tunes up for its first concert of the season in Minneapolis. The conductor trudges out, glancing toward the crowd. ''Ahhhh,'' the audience breathes before breaking into applause. Maestro Pinchas Zukerman has returned for a second year, 35 pounds lighter and without his familiar beard. ''Look! He has such cute dimples,'' a teen-age girl murmurs.

title: By Theodore W. Libbey; Music: Debuts in Review; Laurentian Strings Offer Singer Work's Premiere
description: The Laurentian String Quartet, winner of the chamber-music award in the 1981 Artists International young musicians auditions, made its New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday evening with a program that included the first New York performance of Andre Singer's String Quartet No. 5.

title: CALVIN COOLIDGE INSISTED, THE STORY GOES
description: IPHIGENE Memoirs of Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger of The New York Times Family. As Told to Her Granddaughter Susan W. Dryfoos. Foreword by Barbara W. Tuchman. Illustrated. 312 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Co. $14.95

title: THE LEGEND OF THE GOLDEN HARE
description: Susan Goodman is an English writer living in Dorset, the setting of her forthcoming novel ''Dancing Ledge.'' By Susan Goodman

title: Long Island Guide; CHILDREN'S BOOK WEEK
description: Since youngsters cannot live by television alone, the Island's libraries are celebrating Children's Book Week -and some of them are using books and writers to mark the event. Take, for example, the Half Hollow Hills Community Library at 55 Vanderbilt Parkway in Dix Hills, which will offer a ''Meet the Author Program'' at 2 P.M. today that will introduce visitors to Lee Ames (''Make 25 Crayon Drawings of the Circus''), Jeannette Caines (''Abby''), Johanna Hurwitz (''Aldo Ice Cream'') and Boche Kaplan (''The Make-It, Play-It, Show-It Time Book'').

title: Essay; FIRST SYMBIOSIS FUROR
description: Furors and scandals, in the past, have been caused by all sorts of illicit relationships among men and women. David Stockman, whiz-kid turned was-kid, has presented us with the first furor based on the new symbiotic relationship between government and press.

title: Elizabeth anne Yeiser is engaged to marry Douglas Dean Molash
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Yeiser of West Nyack, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Anne Yeiser, to Douglas Dean Molash, son of Barbara J. Molash of St. Louis Park, Minn., and the late Walter W. Molash.

title: WOMEN IN CLERGY SHOW MORE GAINS
description: Women have been entering the ranks of the Protestant clergy in growing numbers and with increasing success, according to a study sponsored by the Ford Foundation. It was the first major national examination of the attitudes of an expanding group that has begun to reshape the ordained ministry, particualarly over the last decade.

title: NEW YORK'S USE OF ENERGY IS LOWER, BUT AT HIGHER COST THAN REST OF U.S.
description: New York City consumes energy at half the rate of the rest of the nation, but pays substantially more for it and will face runaway energy costs in the 1980's unless sweeping measures are taken, a major study of the city's energy patterns has found.

title: FAIR DRAFT BOARDS A GOAL IN MICHIGAN
description: Gov. William G. Milliken is completing a program he pioneered to make sure Michigan's revived local draft boards are not biased in favor of the military if they are called on to consider requests for deferments.

title: 2 MAESTROS, PUPIL AND SENSEI, IN JAPAN
description: In Japan, one defers. In a formal society in which rank is honored, the Japanese esteem their sensei, or ''teachers,'' whether college professors, noted artists or physicians. To address someone as sensei is to defer.

title: BALTIMORE
description: ''WHEN I first started teaching population education,'' said silver-haired Caroline Cochran, ''I'd tell them, 'Too bad, kids, I'm not the sex lady.' ''

title: Mailbox; Vulnerability In College Sports
description: To the Sports Editor: In the article ''A Lesson for Elite of College Sports'' (The New York Times, Nov. 1, 1981), we are given the impression that, in general, Division I college athletic programs are dishonest, hypocritical and immoral professional franchises. According to the author, these programs will continue to prevail because their supporters endorse the win-at-all-costs philosophy.

title: AGAINST THE BUDGET CUTS
description: I KNOW that business executives are not supposed to disapprove of the Administration's spending program. Polls show support among us hovering around 90 percent. That's a phenomenal vote of confidence. I support the new policies that promote growth, new investment and greater productivity.

title: CHICAGO
description: THE philosopher Mortimer Adler reminds you of Henny Youngman, a furniture salesman and your favorite uncle. He's funny, insistent and so downright likable and full of ideas that you've just got to sit down and listen to him.

title: MAN HAS YET TO MASTER SHUTTLE'S SOPHISTICATION
description: One major reason the space shuttle's mission had to be curtailed is that those who operate the craft are not yet fully confident of their ability to handle it. They concede, in fact, that they have created a machine whose complexity and sophistication so far present more than they can comfortably deal with: a machine they say they may not master for some flights to come.

title: Article 093698 -- No Title
description: The 16 leading contenders for Presidential nominations in 1980 raised a combined total of $131.2 million and spent $129.1 million in their campaigns, the Federal Election Commission said in a final report today.

title: Dining Out; ECLECTICISM AMID VICTORIAN CHIC
description: HANDSOME is as handsome does, and so it is especially gratifying to find that The Brownstone Cafe in Mount Kisco has at last a kitchen worthy of its stylish decor. From the anteroom's crewel couch and Oriental runner to the dining area's wicker screens and pretty hanging lamps, the long, narrow restaurant has renovation-Victorian chic. Arabesques of oak grain soften the railroad-style room arrangement: the wood crosses walls, frames windows and mirrors, lines up in vertical louvers and blossoms into highly polished tables. From its eclectic new menu, The Brownstone Cafe offers diners some interesting and effective dishes.

title: Jean Harris
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DAME DOESN'T WANE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Selma G. Lanes is the author of ''The Art of Maurice Sendak.'' By SELMA G.LANES

title: Elizabeth Anne Mudd Fiancee of Marc Rosen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney P. Mudd of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Anne Mudd, to Marc Rosen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Myer Rosen of Los Angeles. The wedding will take place next month.

title: Wharton Misnomer
description: To the Editor:

title: THOUGHT-PROVOKING WORK AT THE HUDSON
description: YONKERS AT the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, the legacy of its brilliant and innovative former director, Richard Koshalek, continues to unfold in an exhibition of the work of the sculptor Yuri Schwebler entitled ''The Studio,'' which will remain on view through Jan. 10.

title: Speaking Personally; DEEP EMOTION, SUBTLY EXPRESSED
description: IOPEN the door to my consultation room and observe a thin, elderly man with sharp features and industrious eyes whose gray hair matches his conservative three-piece suit.

title: Amy Sue Hofberg is engaged to marry Thomas Patrick Carter
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Amy Sue Hofberg, daughter of Lita Kobalkin Hofberg of Great Neck, L.I., and Victor Hofberg of Lido Beach, L.I., to Thomas Patrick Carter, son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Carter of Ukiah, Calif.

title: THE ONLY SURE OUTCOME IN SALVADOR IS MORE DEATH
description: The civil war in El Salvador is stalemated, according to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. ''Not true,'' President Jose Napoleon Duarte countered last week, contending that the Salvadoran Army was getting stronger and the guerrillas weaker. The country's Minister of Defense, Colonel Jose Guillermo Garcia, was more categorical. In Washington, he asserted that his army was in complete control of El Salvador and that reports of a stalemate were ''propaganda'' spread by ''subversives.''

title: Marie Ashton and Peter Werner Will Wed Dec. 26
description: Marie Elizabeth Ashton of Santa Monica, Calif., a film maker, and Peter Henry Werner, also of Santa Monica, a director of television and feature films, plan to be married in New York on Dec. 26.

title: LIBYAN WITHDRAWAL FROM CHAD IS CONTINUING
description: Libyan troops today continued an evacuation from Chad that seems to represent a reverse for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader.

title: No Headline
description: McEnroe-Connors Showdown

title: LABOR FACES UNMET GOALS AND NEW CHALLENGE
description: Twenty-six years ago, Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, addressed the merger convention of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations in New York and laid out major goals for the labor movement.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1981
description: International Relations With Peking may sour over the issue of possible American military sales to Taiwan, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. told an audience in Palm Beach, Fla. The Chinese Communists have warned that relations with the United States may deteriorate if it upgrades the fighter plane arsenal of the Chinese Nationalists in Taiwan. Peking has delayed sending a military mission of its own to Washington pending resolution of the arms sales issue. (Page 1, Col. 3.) Richard V. Allen was involved in arranging an interview with Nancy Reagan by a Japanese magazine, the magazine Shufu-no-tomo said in the article written about the interview. Mr. Allen, President Reagan's national security adviser, said that he had not set up the interview and that he was present while it took place only because he acted frequently as liaison with foreign journalists. The White House said Friday that the Justice Department was investigating a $1,000 cash payment received by Mr. Allen from the magazine. (1:2.)

title: F.A.A. TROUBLED BY CONCORDE TIRE BLOWOUTS
description: The National Transportation Safety Board, voicing ''serious concern'' about four incidents in which Air France Concorde supersonic airliners blew out tires on takeoff, has urged the French Government to make it mandatory that pilots refrain from pulling up the landing gear in such cases.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Article 093769 -- No Title
description: Atlantic City's casino-hotel industry has topped the $2 billion mark in winnings, helped by an October take of $101.9 million - off slightly from September.

title: 'PROVISIONAL' PERSONNEL UP 78% UNDER KOCH
description: The number of city workers who hold their jobs without having taken competitive examinations has increased by 78 percent, to more than 16,000, since Mayor Koch took office four years ago. At that time, the Mayor said the number was too high.

title: CHURCH VS. STATE: WHO DECIDES WHAT TO TEACH
description: A NEBRASKA sheriff padlocked the doors of Faith Baptist School in Louisville in September, drawing attention to a growing number of disputes between sponsors of religious schools and state authorities. The school was closed after years of negotiation with the state department of education, and following a decision by the United States Supreme Court not to act on an appeal by the church, because its three teachers are not accredited.

title: ABALONE: TASTY INDULGENCE
description: WALLACE TURNER is chief of the San Francisco bureau of The New York Times. By WALLACE TURNER

title: FACING UP TO THE PROBLEM OF DRUG ABUSE
description: service workshops and mandating 10 hours of drug education a year for all students in Grades 7 through 12.

title: TEACHING HOW TO SOLICIT GIFTS
description: HILLSDALE ''IAM the most knowledgeable person in church funding in the world,'' says Dr. Raymond B. Knudsen, a Presbyterian pastor and president of a nonprofit corporation called National Consultations on Financial Development.

title: Washington; REAGAN: SENSE OR NONSENSE?
description: Judging by the noise around here, you would think the big question about the Reagan Administration these days was not whether it had a nuclear policy, but whether it had a magazine policy.

title: FORMER STANFORD STUDENTS TRANSLATE COLLEGE LIFE INTO A GAME
