description: Two former Stanford University students have made it quick and easy to get through college. They have reduced the Stanford campus to a map on a board and replaced studying and social activities with rolls of the dice. Even if a student is chosen for the ''life cycle of a nerd'' photo layout in the campus magazine, he can still find success.

title: The Nation; Eager Beavers Meet Smokey
description: To assure its greatness, Interior Secretary James G. Watt is fond of saying, America must take stock of and develop its natural resources. Last week it became clear that how purposeful is the plan.

title: Personal Finance; THE HAZARDS OF TIME SHARING
description: T HE sales brochure was seductive and the sun-starved Chicagoan thought he was buying the right to vacation for a week every winter in a posh new $120,000 high-rise condominium overlooking Hawaii's Waikiki Beach. But as it turned out, 80 percent of the units in the brochure weren't even in Hawaii, and the buyer had just a one-in-five chance of getting Waikiki Beach. In four years out of five he was relegated instead to a $15,000 unit in a 20-year-old complex in Ocean Shores, a sleepy town on Washington State's cold and rainy southern coast.

title: UNCLEAR AND PRESENT DANGERS IN EUROPE
description: The next stage in the long argument over the role of nuclear weapons in the Atlantic Alliance is about to start, with Soviet-American negotiations scheduled this month on limiting theater nuclear forces. The talks were pledged in the 1979 NATO decision to deploy new American missiles in Western Europe that could reach the Soviet homeland. But even before they begin, an evolution of attitudes has provoked new American-European strains, leaving Western aims in confusion. Last week, President Reagan again spoke of alliance doctrine countenancing the ''possibility'' of limiting a nuclear exchange to Europe, a concept many Europeans find abhorrent.

title: R. E. Culbertson Jr. to Wed Sarah Hall
description: Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Perry Hall of Newton Centre and Nahant, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Appleton Hall, to Robert E. Culbertson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Culbertson of Miami, formerly of Washington. A wedding is planned next August.

title: RIVER PLAN VOTE STIRS DEBATE
description: THE resounding defeat earlier this month of a referendum on a plan to divert water from the Farmington River to the Greater Hartford area has opponents of the project hailing the vote as the beginning of a pro-environment trend even as water authority officials are insisting that they will put the project to a vote again next November.

title: CAN U.S. LABOR PROGRAM ITSELF FOR THE FUTURE?
description: ''I essentially hoped to shuffle off to a quiet demise,'' Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said recently, ''without ever having learned what a computer is all about or the intricacies of microwave transmission or low-frequency transmission or cable TV and satellite TV and all of those things. But I am aware that a revolution is going on.''

title: REVEALING SOME ROCK SECRETS
description: STONY BROOK WITH an extraordinary scanning electron microscope and the ordinary silicone materials used today to fashion dentures, two professors at the State University's Dental School here are shedding light on how ancient man transformed stones into works of art and instruments of commerce.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Philippe Bianconi, Pianist From France
description: There have been times when being a French pianist meant being taken, or mistaken, for a specialist in French music. Admittedly, it has always been possible for the French to play an occasional Beethoven sonata without being accused of intruding on repertory sacred to the Germans, but the stereotype of French musicians as champions of French composers has survived, in spite of the universality of musical interest France has nurtured.

title: ALCOHOLISM FILM ACCLAIMED
description: MONTCLAIR ''IT'S MORE socially acceptable to be crazy than to be drunk,'' says Sandy, who in the film, ''The Last to Know,'' describes herself as an ''upper-middle-class lady with children.''

title: The Marathon as Good Will
description: To the Sports Editor: I have been visiting New York City since I was a child, but rarely, if ever, did I experience the warmth, community involvement, civic pride and spirit of the city as was experienced during the weekend of the New York Marathon, particularly on the day of the race.

title: HAZELTINE'S BEST DEFENSE
description: story factory - not by a company with a household name like Boeing or Grumman, but by one of the hundreds of smaller subcontractors that get little notice when the Pentagon writes a major contract.

title: NEW DIRECTOR FOR LINCOLN HALL
description: ''IT takes quite a while to get settled,'' said Max Brand, the new executive director of Lincoln Hall, a minimum security juvenile treatment center in Somers. He was referring to his family's move from Idaho to their home on the grounds of Lincoln Hall, but he could have just as easily been speaking about his new post.

title: COUNTY SEEKS TAX-ASSESSMENT BILL CHANGES
description: WHITE PLAINS ANEWLY passed property-tax assessment bill, which had been repeatedly criticized by Westchester County's 13-member state legislative delegation and by the Board of Legislators as ''unwieldy'' and ''deficient,'' was vetoed by Governor Carey last week.

title: The Nation; Rickover Accepts His Retirement And Honors
description: For almost 30 years, Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, who launched and built the nuclear Navy, ran it in his own independent, sometimes brilliant, irascible way.

title: Mexico City Crash Kills 8
description: A freight train crashed into a bus at a grade crossing last night on the northern edge of the Mexican capital, killing 8 people and injuring 42.

title: Art; SHOW OF CONTEMPORARY PAINTERS EMPHASIZES DIVERSITY
description: STAMFORD SURVEYS of recent art present one almost insoluble problem: The art of our day is extremely various, and no single style or point of view is dominant. Thus ''The American Landscape: Recent Developments'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art in Stamford (through Dec. 9) almost of necessity lacks focus.

title: MORAL FICTION
description: Aesop's biography has been a disputed subject since at least the 14th century, although it is generally accepted that he was born in 620 B.C. and was a slave who became a protege of Lydia's great ruler, Croesus. While on an official mission to Delphi, so the story goes, he ran into a spot of trouble and was tossed to his death off a cliff.

title: Fashion; THE SUCCESS OF LUXURY
description: One recent Saturday afternoon, the owner of Martha, a posh Park Avenue boutique, unpacked her newest cache of James Galanos dresses (his designs are among the most expensive and best-made ready-to-wear in America). By the end of the day, $101,000 worth of merchandise from that shipment had been sold.

title: A RHYME IS A CHIME
description: IN his verse for children, as in his public face, Shel Silverstein displays a certain startling quirkiness. On the dust jacket of his new collection of poems and drawings, A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC (Harper & Row, $10.95), he is depicted as a cheerily triumphant-looking Fu Manchu with bristling beard and shaven pate - not exactly the Mister Rogers type. We have to think twice to identify this formidable figure with the author-illustrator of that delicate picture book ''The Giving Tree'' and of ''Where the Sidewalk Ends,'' that previous, immensely popular verse collection that included, besides much hilarious stuff, much that is wistful and sensitive.

title: TESTIMONY GRAPHIC IN 'FREEWAY KILLINGS' CASE
description: Each weekday morning these days, lawyers, jurors and spectators gather in a courtroom here to focus on a drama of grisly images, even for a city with a history of grisly murders.

title: WOMEN'S WORK
description: THE WOMAN THAT NEVER EVOLVED By Sarah Blaffer Hrdy. Illustrated. 256 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $17.50.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: * Rates restricted by state usury laws

title: M.H. TANENBAUM, GEORGETTE BENNETT WILL BE MARRIED
description: Sidonie Bennett of Kew Gardens, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Georgette F. Bennett, to Dr. Marc H. Tanenbaum, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Tanenbaum of Baltimore.

title: Amherst Wins Little 3 Title
description: Amherst beat Williams today, 21-17, to win the Little Three championship for the first time since 1968. The first touchdown, played at Weston Field before a homecoming crowd of 8,700, was scored on a 92-yard punt return in the first period by Jan Ostendarp, a sophomore and son of the Amherst coach, James Ostendarp.

title: HUNT FOR CONDUCTORS UNDER WAY HERE
description: IT'S conductor-hunting time in the county, so audiences at the season openers of the Westchester and White Plains Symphony Orchestras knew that they were witnessing public auditions of music-director candidates. Both programs showed that subsequent directors would have a high standard to match.

title: ELECTION LAW'S WEAK SPOTS IN SPOTLIGHT
description: TRENTON THE close contest for Governor of New Jersey, which will not be resolved until after a ballot recount, has pointed up some weaknesses in the way election returns are handled in the state's 21 counties and could lead to some revisions in the election law.

title: SCHOOL SPECIAL, FUTURE UNCLEAR
description: JERSEY CITY ONE OF the most specialized schools for handicapped children in New Jersey, the A. Harry Moore School, is celebrating its 50th anniversary this year, but staff, parents and present and former students fear it may not survive to celebrate its 51st.

title: Dining Out; FULL FARE WITH A 1950'S TOUCH
description: IN some respects, the Charred Oak Manor in New Hyde Park is a restaurant straight out of the 1950's, a place for fancy Sunday dinners before casual brunches became so popular. The menu, a complete dinner that includes appetizer, soup, salad, entree, dessert and coffee, fits that model. The Charred Oak Manor clings to certain outdated practices that better restaurants have begun to discard, such as packaged crackers in the bread basket and mint jelly with the lamb.

title: OPERA: 'FOUR SAINTS' BY THOMSON IN CONCERT
description: For an opera that nearly threw the worlds of music, art and literature out of orbit in 1934 because of its audacity and offcenter wit, ''Four Saints in Three Acts'' has found it surprisingly difficult to find and keep an audience. In recent times, Manhattan has seen the Virgil Thomson-Gertrude Stein work staged almost too intimately by the Mini-Met in 1973 and as a concert piece at the Beacon Theater in 1977. Slim pickings, indeed.

title: BANKSVILLE MANSION IS WILLED TO COUNTY
description: BANKSVILLE RESIDENTS of this small Westchester community, which dates from the late 1600's and at one time had its mail delivered by stagecoach, are angry about a recent decision of the Postal Service to change the routing of mail destined for Banksville.

title: MISS HOLTZMAN SEEKING STAFF OF TOP LEGAL TALENT
description: Elizabeth Holtzman says she is working to ''recruit top legal talent'' for the Brooklyn District Attorney's office, which she takes over Jan. 1, but adds that there will be no wholesale sweeping-out of supervisors and assistant prosecutors who have served under the retiring District Attorney, Eugene Gold.

title: TEXT OF A STATEMENT BY ALLEN
description: Following is the text of a statement made public today at the White House by Richard V. Allen, the national security adviser to President Reagan:

title: Chinese Literature
description: To the Editor:

title: MALLS KEEP LEAFLET LIMITS
description: SHOPPING mall managers in Nassau and Suffolk, undaunted by a pending lawsuit filed by an antinuclear group against the Smith Haven Mall, are continuing their policies prohibiting the distribution of leaflets, despite questions of possible unconstitutionality.

title: Virginia Townsend Derby Is Bride of Ingersoll Jordan
description: Virginia Townsend Derby and Ingersoll Jordan were married on Oct. 31 at the Trinity Episcopal Church in New Orleans.

title: Camera; WHEN SOME OF THE RULES SHOULD BE BROKEN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Robert S. Winkler is a freelance writer and photographer. Like every discipline, photography has rules that include a long list of do's and don'ts, and right at the top are two rules that most photographers will obey without question: One is the rule which states that a picture must be properly exposed; the other is the rule which states that a picture must be sharp or accurately focused.

title: NEUTRON BOMB: AN EXPLOSIVE ISSUE
description: Wayne Biddle writes frequently about science and public issues. By Wayne Biddle

title: SOMETHING HAPPENED AT THE OFFICE
description: MAYBE it was the recession. But for Jim, Bob and Murray, it seemed more than just that. They each lived in a different town on the Island. They each worked in the metropolitan area, in a different industry. Their stories are true, but their names and various details of their experiences have been changed.

title: SOFIA MELDING RELICS OF PAST INTO DAILY LIFE
description: Five years ago the Bulgarian Government made the defense of national monuments official policy and declared the entire historical center of Sofia an archeological site.

title: 'DEMONSTRATION' BOMBS AND OTHER THREATS
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All this meditation is too peaceful and entirely opposite to a chess game. Viktor is too relaxed to fight.'' - Petra Leeuwerik, manager of Viktor Korchnoi, the challenger in the world chess match. (45:2.)

title: Gardening; OFFICE PLANTINGS RISE IN CORPORATE WORLD
description: IN recent years, the use of plants in offices, hotels, stores and other public buildings has grown phenomenally. And gone is the day when the secretary cared for plants by giving them a little water each day from a coffee cup. Too much is at stake both in investment and appearance. A concern's image can be enhanced by plants with a healthy appearance and it can be damaged by a seedy-looking one.

title: HOUSTON AND COLUMBIA: TALK ON THE WAY HOME
description: Following are excerpts from conversations the astronauts had with Mission Control in Houston on the third and last day of the space shuttle's flight, as recorded by The New York Times. ''Rick'' is Comdr. Frederick H. Hauck of the Navy, an astronaut, navy aviator and test pilot, who served as capsule communicator yesterday. Shuttle Control is the public affairs commentary of Mission Control.

title: Connecticut Housing; HOME NURSING CARE FINDS TAKERS
description: A GENTLE rain had been falling all day on the tiny, red shingle cabin in the Silvermine section of Norwalk. Elizabeth Laychak, an 87-year-old former landscape artist who lives alone, decided to curl up in bed and wait for a staff coordinator from Connecticut Community Care Inc.

title: Researcher Finds Fossil Of World's Oldest Bird
description: The scientist who found the remains of the world's two largest dinosaurs in a Colorado quarry says he has discovered a fossil of the world's oldest known bird in the same area.

title: SPACE CONSTRUCTION IS BEING EXAMINED
description: Researchers at the space agency's Langley Research Center are looking toward future shuttle flights and large-scale construction in space.

title: Numismatics; ELONGATED COINS
description: With prices for so many items having declined, some observers worry that the coin market isn't in very good shape - but people who collect elongated coins don't let such considerations bother them. First of all, market value isn't their main concern; and secondly, the coins they collect are never in very good shape - at least not when judged by normal numismatic standards.

title: City Hall Notes
description: One of the bigger tenants in New York City is the city itself, which rents 18 million square feet of space for various agencies in privately owned buildings.

title: St. John Wins by 24-7 In Playoff Semifinal
description: St. John the Baptist of West Islip, defending Catholic High Schools Football League champion, defeated St. Francis Prep of Fresh Meadows, 24-7, yesterday in the semifinal round of the league playoffs. The Cougars will meet the winner of today's game between Monsignor Farrell of Staten Island and Holy Cross of Flushing for the league title.

title: Rumanian Crop-Burner Jailed
description: A court in eastern Rumania has sentenced a state farm manager to two years in prison for burning his unharvested crops, a Bucharest newspaper reported. Reports circulating in Bucharest recently said some farm managers had burned corps that could not be harvested before the Government-set deadline so they could report harvesting all crops on schedule.

title: Around the Nation; Students Felled by Weed Bought as Hallucinogen
description: More than 30 high school students were taken to a hospital after being mildly poisoned by jimson weed seeds they bought from a fellow student, school officials said.

title: YESHIVA U., ONCE ALMOST BANKRUPT, EAGERLY AWAITS FINAL DEBT PAYMENT
description: Dr. Norman Lamm, the rabbi who is president of Yeshiva University, sees himself in one of the tales told by the legendary wise men of Chelm.

title: IMPACT OF CUTBACKS ON HEALTH-CARE SITES
description: ANTICIPATING Federal and county cutbacks in health-care allocations, leaders of Westchester's four community health-care centers recently held a public meeting to dramatize their need for support.

title: LEGISLATORS LOOK TO DEC. 15 TO HAVE GARBAGE PROJECT IN PLACE
description: WHEN a token shovelful of earth was turned at a riverside site in Peekskill a month ago, it was described as the start of the ''construction stage'' of Westchester County's ambitious plan to turn garbage into energy. Last week, the Board of Legislators started what could be considered the ''taxing stage'' of the project.

title: Strength and Compromise at the U.N.
description: Walter Hoffmann argues for the need of a ''stronger Secretary General'' at the United Nations (Letters, Oct. 25, in response to ''The U.N.'s Man in the Middle,'' by Jane Rosen, Sept. 13).

title: Comment; ANTITRUST TRAVESTY
description: OF all the abuses of law in our society, the game with the highest stakes is currently in the field of Federal antitrust law. The travesty of justice being played out here would have stirred the wrath of even that great trustbuster, Teddy Roosevelt.

title: THE 49ERS MAKE A LONG-AWAITED RUSH
description: PAUL HOFER, a San Francisco 49er running back, was having trouble concentrating. His team was beating its Western Division rival, Atlanta, 17-14, and suddenly the delirious fans in Candlestick Park took up a chant.

title: IN BRIDGEPORT, AN IMAGE OF CHANGE
description: BRIDGEPORT AT Dolan's Cafe here, where a glass of beer is 35 cents and the house speciality, an Angus burger, is 70 cents, more attention was being paid to the Monday night football game than the festivities up the block at City Hall, where a new Mayor was being sworn into office.

title: OBSCURE LAW CASTS SHADOW ON CONTEST
description: POLITICAL ambitions and a little-used state law could collide in Hartford next January if the office of the Secretary of the State becomes vacant. Quiet contests are already heating up, involving several potential candidates.

title: 60% in Poll Back Shuttle Program
description: Sixty percent of Americans believe the space shuttle program is a good investment for the United States, according to an Associated Press/NBC News poll.

title: HARVARD TROUNCES PENN, STAYS IN RACE
description: Harvard, tuning up for its key game with Yale next Saturday, swept past Pennsylvania, 45-7, before 10,500 chilled spectators at Harvard Stadium today.

title: BALLET: U.S. TERPSICHORE PERFORMS
description: Little ballet companies can sometimes accomplish big things by preserving offbeat works and encouraging young choreographers. And they can also give young dancers valuable training in standard repertory.

title: Reading and Writing; KAFKA AND PRAGUE IN N.Y.
description: Of the 169 photographs in the Kafka-Prague exhibit now at the Jewish Museum, the one that impressed me most shows the window of Kafka's study, which, unless this is an optical illusion, looks directly into the interior of Tyn Church. A caption under the picture says that the window ''had been built by a former religious tenant who wanted a view to the church.'' Elsewhere I read that the house the Kafkas lived in was built ''against'' the church, so perhaps they did share a common wall. In very old cities, such things are possible.

title: BAYSIDE, LINCOLN WILL PLAY FOR P.S.A.L. TITLE THIRD TITLE ON THE LINE
description: Bayside will play Lincoln for the Public Schools Athletic League championship Saturday. Bayside defeated Jefferson, 28-12, and Lincoln beat Port Richmond, 34-8, yesterday.

title: Other Business; PUBLISHING: ASSESSING THE EXECUTIVE DIARIES
description: The first was the Economist Diary, a World War II creation of the publishers of the British news magazine. Bound in lush, fire-engine red leather, embossed in gold, the Economist Diary became one of the prerequisites of the status-wary executive desk. John F. Kennedy had two, says the Economist's president, Clive L. Greaves. One was for the Oval Office and one for travel.

title: Law Provides a 'Court' On Home Assessments
description: Homeowners who feel their property assessment for tax purposes is too high in comparison to other assessments in the same locality can now take a complaint to a type of small claims court under a bill signed by Governor Carey.

title: CAMPERS DIET
description: To the Editor:

title: A VILLAIN IN THE SENATE
description: POINT OF ORDER A Profile of Senator Joe McCarthy. By Robert P. Ingalls. Illustrated with Photographs. 159 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $9.95. (Ages 12 to 16)

title: Long Island Journal
description: BEFORE most people even get a crack at the four-day work week, about 20 Nassau Police Department mechanics are trying a three-day week as a pilot project. The mechanics will work three 12-hour shifts a week with an additional eight-hour shift one week every month to make an average 38-hour work week, including lunch breaks.

title: ONE MORE GRANT IN FINANCIAL SERVICES
description: PHILADELPHIA R ALPH S. SAUL, 59 years old, the chairman of the INA Corporation, has worked for nine organizations since he left the Navy at the end of World War II. He has been a Foreign Service officer at the United States Embassy in Prague, a lawyer in a law firm, a staff attorney at RCA and an aide to Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York. He has also been director of the trading and market division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, vice president of Investors Diversified Services Inc., chairman of the First Boston Corporation's management committee and president of the American Stock Exchange.

title: THANKSGIVING PARADE
description: Sixteen marching bands, 14 floats keyed to an American heritage theme, color guards, clowns, costumed Pilgrims and Indians will join in a Thanksgiving parade for the 20th consecutive year down North Avenue in New Rochelle starting at 10 A.M. Saturday. The step-off point is New Rochelle High School.

title: POACHERS IMPERILING WILDLIFE IN BRAZIL
description: The 80,000-square-mile inland delta that fans out just south of this frontier city has the most varied and profuse animal life in all the Americas, but poachers are turning it into a vast killing ground.

title: MANY OFFICES BUT TOO FEW SECRETARIES
description: FOR the last three months, the 10-member staff of Cosmepak, a Stamford supplier of domestic plastic products, has been without a full-time secretary. Telephones go unanswered. There is no one to greet visitors. Letters must wait until the day when temporary help comes in to catch up on the backlog.

title: 24 Food-Handling Concerns
description: Cited for Health Violations

title: Margo S. Weaker Bride Of Benjamin Suckewer
description: Margo Susan Weaker, was married yesterday at the Royal Orleans Hotel in New Orleans to Benjamin Suckewer, a lawyer with Stroock & Stroock & Lavan in New York. Rabbi David Goldstein performed the ceremony.

title: White House and Congress Wrestle With the Economy
description: ''I must confess,'' Senator Jim Sasser said last week, ''to some degree of bewilderment.'' The Tennessee Democrat had plenty of company. There was the Republican White House, backing off from the $3 billion in new taxes and the $2.6 billion in social spending cuts it had asked Congress for in September. There was the majority on the Republican Senate Budget Committee, working on billions more than that in taxes and cuts to balance the budget in 1984 - a goal President Reagan last week formally abandoned. And there were the House Democrats, running as fast as they could from the opportunity to make capital on the confusion.

title: IS A POWER AUTHORITY NECESSARY?
description: INCREASINGLY, we hear that public power is the answer to the state's electricity production problems. There is even a chance that, in the Legislature's lame-duck session, Governor Byrne will push for a bill creating a state power authority.

title: PITT, LED BY MARINO, CRUSHES ARMY, 48-0
description: The unbeaten, No. 1-ranked Pitt Panthers routed Army, 48-0,today in a game in which the school record book took almost as sound a beating as the Cadet football team.

title: THE SINAI'S ENDURING SOLITUDE
description: DAVID K. SHIPLER is chief of the Times bureau in Jerusalem. By DAVID K. SHIPLER

title: SUNLIGHT IN GLOOM OF BRONX
description: AFTER teaching at Columbia for 40 years, I now also teach in the South Bronx. At the university my students range in age from 18 to 60. In the South Bronx they are 12 and 13 years old. The experience of teaching these youngsters is overwhelming.

title: Alanka Remec Bride of Peter O'Connor
description: Alanka Cecilia Remec, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Peter P. Remec of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter Joseph O'Connor, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. John O'Connor of Rochester. The Rev. Bernard J. Dooley, president of Gonzaga High School in Washington and an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Fordham University Church in the Bronx.

title: COPING WITH COSTS: FOUR FAMILY PROFILES
description: Soaring college costs in the last few years have forced parents of prospective students to consider several unaccustomed methods of raising money. Long since obliged to trim personal spending, many are now making their first attempt at demonstrating need for financial aid or low-cost loans, and others are moonlighting to increase their income or turning to relatives for help. Here are four examples of the way families are dealing with the mounting cost of higher education.

title: Antiques; ANTIQUE JEWELRY FOR THE HOLIDAYS
description: MORRIS PLAINS THE Rehabilitation Center for the Handicapped on Route 53 may seem like an odd place to look for fine antique jewelry. Even so, it might be just the place for holiday shopping.

title: Q&A
description: Question:I am planning a trip to the Yucatan, where I would like to make rubbings of Mayan stelae. Is this allowed by the Mexican Government and, if so, are any permits required? - E.B., Centereach, N.Y. Answer:A representative of the Mexican Government tourism office says: ''The making of rubbings of Mayan stelae is prohibited in Mexico. The carvings are of such a fragile nature and the preservation of most archeological sites in Mexico of such cultural significance that visitation activities to the sites are strictly controlled.''

title: SPECIAL SESSION: CURTAIN RISING AND PLAYING ENTER DOUBTING
description: HARTFORD THE special session of the General Assembly, which convenes here next Thursday morning, will be a little like the Broadway show that is opening too soon.

title: LACEY TO FACE HIS OLD TEAM
description: With almost eight minutes gone in the game between the Boston Celtics and the New Jersey Nets at the Hartford Civic Center Friday night, Sam Lacey, the Nets' new center, walked to the scorer's table and prepared to check in. After more than 11 seasons in the National Basketball Association, all with one franchise, Lacey was about to play his first minute as a Net.

title: ASSAULTS PROMPT PROGRAM
description: MADISON A SERIES of rapes and attempted rapes around this small, coastal town have prompted officials at the Dr. Robert H. Brown Middle School to initiate a program designed to prepare young people to cope with crisis situations.

title: Mirrors and Mr. Reagan
description: The political and economic history of the last two years can be acidly summarized in the answer to one question. It was asked in January 1980 during the first Republican debate of the campaign: ''How can any President curb inflation, cut taxes, increase defense spending and balance the budget all at the same time?''

title: STATE IS MONITORING NASSAU COLLEGE
description: GARDEN CITY IN the wake of criminal indictments against five top administrators at Nassau Community College, state education officials are keeping a closer watch on the 23,000-student school than ever before. While the state officials emphasize that they have no reason to believe that educational quality has been affected by the indictments or the continuing investigations of financial arrangements set up by some of the college's administrators, they have for the first time assigned state staff members to attend college board meetings regularly.

title: Seoul Sentences 3 Students
description: The Seoul district court has sentenced three students to jail terms ranging from eight months to one year for selling seditious books and staging illegal demonstrations, authorities said today.

title: Linda E. Laufer Wed To Lance Gotthoffer
description: Linda Ellen Laufer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Laufer of Kenmore, N.Y., was married yesterday to Lance Gotthoffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel S. Gotthoffer of Delray Beach, Fla. Rabbi Martin L. Goldberg performed the ceremony in the Plaza Suite in Buffalo.

title: CLOUDS FOR BREAKFAST
description: A VISIT TO WILLIAM BLAKE'S INN Poems for Innocent and Experienced Travelers. By Nancy Willard. Illustrated by Alice and Martin Provensen. 45 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $10.95. (Ages 6 and Up)

title: YALE STREAK HALTED BY PRINCETON, 35-31
description: Princeton scrambled the Ivy League race today by rallying to beat Yale, 35-31, at Palmer Stadium. Bob Holly, Princeton's quarterback, who threw for an Ivy record of 501 yards, scored the winning touchdown from the 1-yard line with four seconds remaining.

title: The Gallic Geezer
description: As I inexorably approach geezerhood, I take word processor in hand to offer a wordsmith a possible substitute for ''old geezer'' (''Geezer Power,'' by William Safire, On Language, Sept. 27).

title: Follow-Up on the News; Threat to Liberty
description: Soon after political protesters scaled the Statue of Liberty in May 1980, a team of specialists inspected the monument, fearing serious damage to its copper skin.

title: Food; A LIFT UP FOR LEFTOVERS
description: EVEN over the years, we have been asked endless times to provide recipes for cooked leftovers, foods such as fish, shellfish, chicken, lamb, pork, beef and vegetables. To our minds, there is no recipe so universally fitting that request as croquettes, which can be an exceptionally tasty appetizer or main course.

title: Crafts
description: CAROL WESTFALL of Nutley, a fiber artist and college teacher, is still assimilating the experiences of her recent sabbatical year in India. But, she affirms, it was good to return not only to her textile classes at Montclair State College, but also to having Hellman's mayonnaise in the refrigerator.

title: Topics; ZEALOTS, LARGE AND SMALL; Fee Frustration
description: Rutgers University has been collecting $2.50 from students at 11 colleges to support the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group. Joseph Galda, a senior at the Camden campus, is ask-ing a court to stop the practice.

title: FINDING THE PROPER PLACE, AND PRICE, FOR ARSENALS
description: ACKNOWLEDGING mounting concern about the East-West nuclear weapons buildup in Europe, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. last week reaffirmed that the Administration is ''serious'' about arms-control talks with the Soviet Union scheduled to start in Geneva on Nov. 30. The peace demonstrations do ''not mean that our European allies are going 'neutral,' '' he also told the House Foreign Affairs Committee. ''The invasion of neutral Afghanistan and the violation of neutral Sweden's territory by a Soviet submarine should dispel the illusion that neutrality confers immunity.''

title: AS FEDERAL CUTS TRICKLE DOWN, STATES ARE AWASH
description: Most of the nation's 50 states, after several years of relative prosperity and expansion, have found themselves spending more money than they are taking in, and their reserves are fast dwindling. They are caught between the reduction in revenues from the Federal Government and the citizens' tax revolt that began in the 1970's and has not yet spent its fury. The fiscal predicament was predictable but came faster than most analysts had expected.

title: WHO IT TAKES TO TANGO
description: From various quarters - some earnest, others suspect - the proposition is being put forward that the nation's economic malaise requires greater cooperation between labor and management. Immediately, trade unionists who are expected to participate must raise two questions: What is meant by cooperation? What has to be done before any union will agree to cooperate?

title: RUSSIAN GIVES CLASSES IN CHARACTER DANCING AN EXPERT TOUCH
description: PELHAM IN a skylighted storefront dance studio here, the Russian emigre dancer Mark Litvak conducts a character-dance class each Saturday morning with four sixth graders. Mr. Litvak, an award-winning character dancer, teacher and choreographer, left the Soviet Union two years ago with his wife and daughter. He has been on the faculty of the Westchester Dance Center in Pelham since September.

title: 'GUERNICA' STANDS OUT, BUT DOES IT STAND UP?
description: THE MEANINGS OF MODERN ART By John Russell. Illustrated. 430 pp. New York: The Museum of Modern Art/ Harper & Row. $35.

title: Headliners Higher and Higher
description: It wasn't a fear of heights that nearly did in Dan Goodwin as he climbed Chicago's 100-story John Hancock Center last week. It was a fear of water. When he reached the 38th floor, fire fighters began spraying the building in an effort to render ineffective the suction cups which the daredevil had used in conquering the Sears Tower earlier this year. ''If anyone else besides me had been on the side of that building, they would have been washed off,'' said Mr. Goodwin, who, as it turned out, wasn't using cups but clamps. He made it to the top, and also to court the next day, where he was found guilty of contempt and got a lecture from the judge for signing autographs on the witness stand.

title: Design; CEMENT SILOS RECAST FOR LIVING
description: he conversion of warehouses and office buildings, hotels and factories for residential use has been a growing international design pursuit. But few projects, either here or abroad, are as striking in both scale and design as the Taller de Arquitectura Bofill, an architectural office and residence in Sant Just D'Esvern, a suburb of Barcelona.

title: Hilary Chittenden Plans Summer Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Chittenden Jr. of Clinton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hilary Bradley Chittenden, to Dirck Barhydt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Barhydt of Middlebury, Conn. The wedding is planned for next summer.

title: McAulay Ties Mark
description: Don McAulay kicked a 53-yard field goal yesterday to tie the New York State scholastic record and added seven extra points as East Islip defeated Deer Park, 65-0, in a League II game.

title: CONCERN RISES ON AUTO BOMBINGS IN ST. LOUIS
description: The police here are expressing growing concern over violence that they say is linked to construction union racketeering. The violence has gone on intermittently for about 20 years but has increased recently and in the last two years has resulted in four automobile explosions, with three deaths, and two ambush shootings.

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE Over at Riverside Church this week, two contrasting and recentlyformed companies are in the spotlight -Ballet Today and the Danny Buraczeski Concert Jazz Dance Company.

title: Liza Smith To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Graham Wood Smith of Orchard Park, N.Y., and Gulfstream, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Elizabeth Smith, to Charles Schuyler Morehouse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis Bradley Morehouse of Rumson, N.J.

title: Business Conditions; SLOWDOWN IN FEDERAL REVENUES
description: From the outset, critics of the Administration's economic plan contended that Mr. Reagan's program of large tax cuts, smaller budget cuts and restrictive monetary policy would lead to a sharp reduction in Federal tax revenues and ever-larger budget deficits. In the near term, at least, that view may prove correct because the stagnant economy is causing Federal revenue receipts to lag.

title: THE SWEET 16 PARTY
description: THE music of Bruce Springsteen and Billy Joel has taken the place long held by Johnny Mathis, and the sugar cube corsage on a bouffant party dress has been replaced by tennis outfits and disco wear. Yet the Sweet Sixteen party remains a special event and is flourishing in Westchester.

title: ANTHONY DAVIS- BEYOND JAZZ
description: Anthony Davis had already been singled out by several critics as the most accomplished and impressive young pianist in jazz when he moved to New York City from New Haven, Conn., in 1977. As he has continued to demonstrate, most recently in a program of Thelonious Monk's compositions at Columbia University, he retains a formidable grasp of the varied resources available to jazz pianists, from the earliest styles to the most modern.

title: A FRACAS OVER FUNDS ROILS M.I.T.
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. O N Wednesday, for the third and perhaps last time, the faculty of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology will convene to try to resolve one of the most divisive conflicts ever to befall it. A wealthy businessman wants to finance, with more than $100 million, a biomedical research institute that would have a novel affiliation with the eminent college of arts and sciences. It would bear his name, share faculty with M.I.T. and be governed by a board that would include his three children.

title: IS PUBLIC EDUCATION A CASUALTY OF REAGANOMICS
description: AS the price of Reaganomics becomes clear, Americans are becoming edgy. Teachers are downright nervous. We who are the true believers in public education are nearly frantic. In the big budget fight of 1980 we saw the President strive for a 30 percent reduction in Federal aid to education, but were heartened as Congress pared the cut to a less painful 10 percent. We attributed the President's zeal to wayward economics.

title: Art; THE URBAN LEGACY OF LOUIS LOZOWICK
description: REPUTATIONS in the art world are sometimes more fickle than teenage love. Many of the 19th-century artists who were both admired and venerated in their day have been forgotten in ours. Others who were coldly snubbed then have been enshrined today in the pantheon of art, and still others have enjoyed great fame and suffered oblivion during their lifetimes.

title: Mailbox; Sellout Season For Baseball
description: To the Sports Editor: With the close of the 1981 World Series comes the realization that all things, no matter how strange, do come to an end. Don't worry, baseball lords, this is not just another irate letter from a spectator. Actually, you probably don't worry anyway. You certainly do whatever you please with schedules, people, championships. The truth is, you know you have a hold on people like me. You see, I love baseball, but now it's time to admit it: our romance has problems.

title: THE PLAY-SCHOOL-AT-HOME 'UNDERGROUND'
description: ''IHAVE a long waiting list for only seven places, and yet I'm always hiding from the Health Department,'' said the director of an unlicensed in-home play group for toddlers in New York City who asked to remain anonymous. The play school meets in her three-room apartment five days a week, at hours convenient for working parents.

title: SUDDENLY THE TALKIES COULD SING
description: HOLLYWOOD MUSICALS By Ted Sennett. Illustrated. 384 pp. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $50. THE HOLLYWOOD MUSICAL By Clive Hirschhorn. Illustrated. 456 pp. New York: Crown Publishing. $30. THE HOLLYWOOD MUSICAL By Ethan Mordden. Illustrated. 261 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $15.95. ENCYCLOPAEDIA OF THE MUSICAL FILM By Stanley Green. 344 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $25.

title: The Nation; Uncertain Flight Plan for the B-1
description: If the B-1 bomber ever gets off the ground, it may well be in spite of the Pentagon's Capitol Hill pitchmen. Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, though no rookie in the Congressional trenches, had said in recent testimony that by the end of the decade the bomber would be no match for Soviet air defenses.

title: A MAN WHO BECAME HIS OWN GRANDFATHER
description: POPPA JOHN By Larry Woiwode. 204 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95.

title: No Headline
description: Pryor Stops Rival

title: Stage View; OFFBEAT- BUT A BEAT TOO FAR
description: Beth Henley's ''Crimes of the Heart,'' now at the Golden after winning virtually every prize going during its run at the Manhattan Theater Club, is loaded and perhaps overloaded with quirky, casually outrageous, Mississippi-Gothic misbehavior. As I watched the three MaGrath sisters reassemble for the 30th birthday of one and for the impending death of the grandfather who'd long cared for them, I found myself often grinning at what might have been gruesome, sometimes cocking my head sharply to catch a rueful inflection before it turned into a comic one, and always, always admiring the actresses involved. I also found myself, rather too often and in spite of everything, disbelieving - simply and flatly disbelieving. Since this is scarcely the prevailing opinion, I'd best be specific.

title: PRINCE: 'THERE WERE MORE CHANGES THAN I'M USED TO'
description: Harold Prince, the producer-director whose last hit show, ''Evita,'' won him a 15th Tony Award, swept into a midtown restaurant on a recent Saturday afternoon, looking frazzled but smiling just the same. He had spent the early part of the afternoon watching a preview matinee of his new Broadway musical, ''Merrily We Roll Along,'' to which he had added four new scenes the night before. He said he thought the changes had helped ''clarify'' the show for the audience. At least, he noted, members of the audience were no longer walking out after the first act, as they had during the first two weeks of previews.

title: RISE IN COST OF MEDICAID HELD THREAT TO BUDGET
description: WHILE preparing for the release of Westchester's 1982 budget, which county Legislators receive tonight, government leaders last week blamed the New York State-mandated Medicaid program for a dramatic increase in local costs that will require the county to increase taxes for the first time in four years.

title: MOVABLE FEAST
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Astronaut Says He's Not Envious
description: Wally Schirra, one of the seven original astronauts, said yesterday that he was glad to be resting comfortably on Earth instead of orbiting the planet aboard the Columbia.

title: QUINN TWINS SPARK EXETER
description: Season records don't always count when long-time rivals meet, as Andover, Choate and Hotchkiss found out yesterday. Andover, headed for its first unbeaten season since 1970 going into its 101st meeting with Exeter, came out instead with its first defeat in eight games as the home team scored in the final minutes for a l2-7 victory. Exeter closed its season at 4-3 and made the series record between the two schools, the oldest prep rivalry in the country, 52 victories for Andover to 41 for Exeter with eight games ending in ties.

title: Pamela Ann Warburton is engaged to marry lieut (jg) Robert Allen Mirick, U S N
description: Dr. and Mrs. Richard H. Warburton of South Dartmouth, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Ann Warburton, to Lieut. (jg.)

title: The Sutro File
description: To the Business Editor: That changes in the ratio of consumer goods to capital goods produced by industry is found to be a leading economic indicator, ''The Sutro Forecast'' (Oct. 25), this seems significant even beyond the fact that when this ratio declined it forecast the past several recessions.

title: BRYANT TIES COACHING MARK AS ALABAMA WINS, 31-16
description: Paul William (Bear) Bryant, 68 years old, achieved his 314th victory as a college head football coach today and tied Amos Alonzo Stagg's career record when Alabama decisively beat Penn State, 31-16.

title: MISSISSIPPI IN THE THIRTIES
description: LET THE CIRCLE BE UNBROKEN By Mildred D. Taylor. 394 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $11.95. (Ages 11 and Up)

title: MARINO CANDIDACY LIKENED TO D'AMATO'S
description: HOPING that lightning will strike twice, State Senator Ralph J. Marino of Muttontown has started running for the Republican gubernatorial nomination with the support of the powerful Nassau Republican organization, which can produce a larger Republican primary vote than any county in the state.

title: ACCORDING TO STOCKMAN
description: Budget Director David A. Stockman (right), chastened after what he termed a visit to President Reagan's woodshed, says he'll stay on the Administration team, but will supply-side economics ever be the same? Mr. Stockman, 35, in a series of remarkable statements attributed to him in an Atlantic Monthly article, called the philosophical underpinnings of the Reagan economic program just the old ''trickledown'' theory and a ''Trojan horse'' to sneak in aid to the rich under the guise of helping everyone. Of the budget process, Mr. Stockman is reported to have said: ''None of us really understands what's going on with all these numbers.''

title: AWAY FOR THE HOLIDAYS
description: For most of us, Christmas is a time for home, family and close friends. But for others it can be an especially rewarding time to travel. Many options designed to help travelers enjoy the ritual and traditions of the season are available at Christmastime. They range from the very modest to the extremely posh. Some are particularly attractive to singles; others to couples and traditional family groups who want a different sort of Christmas.

title: WHY OUR GOVERNMENT DOESN'T WORK BETTER
description: AMERICAN POLITICS: THE PROMISE OF DISHARMONY By Samuel P. Huntington. 303 pp. Cambridge, Mass: The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press. $15.

title: LONDON
description: IT takes more than $41,000 to earn an undergraduate degree at Yale, but a Briton can get a degree of comparable value at Oxford for virtually no cost at all. The disparity exists because Britain is one of many European countries that offer higher learning cheaply through heavy Government subsidies.

title: Lancia Zagato: Full of Pizazz
description: THE car is standing in the driveway, red as a ribbon and wrapped in pizazz. It is a Lancia Zagato, a different sort of automobile, and it works well - both on its own terms and as a symbol.

title: CONVICTED SLAYER IN CAROLINA WINS ACQUITTAL AFTER RETRIAL
description: When Michael Linder was convicted of killing a highway patrolman and sentenced to die, he says, a pastor went to his cell and told him that in two years he would be free.

title: TWO SOLID WAYS TO BUILD A COLLEGE NEST EGG
description: WHEN it comes to accumulating a fund for their children's college education, most parents procrastinate. But by failing to act while their youngster is still in elementary school, they are losing out on one of the most effective techniques available to build a college nest egg - short-term trust funds and parent loans to children.

title: Arrows Still Tops in M.I.S.L.
description: The Major Indoor Soccer league opened its fourth season Friday night with a schedule extended by two months into late May and with new teams in New Jersey, Kansas City and Memphis.

title: WHATEVER HAPPENED TO ALTERNATIVE SCHOOLS?
description: WHEN 150 students abandoned their classes in Philadelphia public high schools in 1969 to study their communities and use the city as their classroom, few thought that such an alternative to traditional public education would last.

title: CONCERT: RUDOLF KELTERBORN
description: For its second and last concert this week at Carnegie Hall, on Thursday evening, the Orchestre de la Suisse Romande introduced a work by one of Switzerland's leading composers, Rudolf Kelterborn, who was born in Basle in 1931.

title: Seven Killed as Tanker Truck Explodes on Road in Colorado
description: A tanker truck exploded on a highway near here early today, killing at least seven persons and injuring more than half a dozen others, the Colorado State Patrol said.

title: COAST HISPANIC COLLEGE FIGHTS TO SURVIVE
description: Colegio Cesar Chavez was born eight troubled years ago as the first college run for and by Hispanic Americans. Now the school is insolvent and under attack from the local Mexican-American community that gave it life.

title: PUTTING IT ALL TOGETHER, CRITICS SPELL 'BIG BROTHER'
description: The Reagan Administration abondoned last week some of the proposals in its draft executive order governing intelligence activities that had triggered the loudest howls of outrage from Congressional critics.

title: Sports of The Times; 'His Record Will Stand
description: THE deep lines in his wonderful face resemble the hard cracks in the dirt where an old river had dried up. Those deep lines had been dug by 37 years as a college football coach. But he has not dried up. Wearing his familiar hound's-tooth hat and a gray topcoat over his red plaid jacket, Paul (Bear) Bryant was out there in front of the Alabama bench yesterday during his 314th victory, tying the record total established by Amos Alonzo Stagg over nearly six decades. But the enormousness of the occasion had best been put into perspective by Joe Paterno, the Penn State coach whose team was unable to postpone the Bear's appointment with history.

title: Music View; SHOULD SCHOLARS DIG UP DISCARDS?
description: Do you remember the last important letter you had to write? The one to the president of the appliance company, maybe, complaining about the dishwasher that poured water into your shoes whenever it was turned on? Did you throw your thoughts on paper in one feverish sweep and pop them right in the mail? Probably not, unless you are one of those miraculously pure creative types who do everything right the first time. Instead, you first may have produced several versions of the document that did not quite say what you meant, in the way you wanted. There were erasures, false starts, cross-outs, crumpled pages - in other words, the whole detrius of creativity, major or minor.

title: The World; For India, $5.8 Billion
description: The International Monetary Fund last week overruled Reagan Administration objections and approved a record $5.8 billion loan to India, which is among the world's most advanced countries but at the same time, among the poorest. Washington objected that the loan, ostensibly intended to ease New Delhi's multibillion dollar burden for importing oil, would be used to develop oil and steel industries.

title: Kelleher Scores Twice
description: Middletown North, en route to the Central Jersey, Group 4 playoffs, beat New Providence, 21-13, yesterday.

title: Investing; A WAY TO SPOT A TAKEOVER TARGET
description: A BOUT the only way to score in the stock market today is by spotting takeover targets - and spotting them may not be so hard as it seems. One approach is to seek out companies that already hold a stake in other companies. If they've bought their stock, the thinking goes, they might someday buy them out.

title: Ideas and Trends; Freud's Legacy: Totem and Taboo
description: The issues may not have been strictly theological, but it could be said that Jeffrey Moussiaeff Masson, the projects director of the Sigmund Freud Archives, was fired for heresy.

title: Sensible Standards For 'No Fault' Divorce
description: Ruth Dreyfus's article on divorce and its unfortunate effect on women (''Divorce: A Standard for Measuring Losses,'' Oct. 18) was unchallengeable but, inevitably, by its nature it was only part of the story. The other side of the coin is rather important, too.

title: The World; Poland Looks to The West and to Its Own History
description: Poland last week took a portentous Westward step, applying to resume membership in international lending agencies it had quit 30 years ago on Stalin's orders. This time, Moscow looked the other way as Warsaw, desperately fighting off economic collapse, sought increased loan-getting potential by asking to rejoin the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

title: Manville Hands Green Brook First Loss, 20-0
description: Manville contained previously unbeaten Green Brook and the state's leading individual scorer and recorded a 20-0 upset victory yesterday.

title: Economic Affairs; RELAX, SOCIAL SECURITY IS DOING ITS JOB
description: I F one believes the detractors of Social Security, the public pension system of this country is almost bankrupt, gives out benefits that are improvidently generous and has reduced savings among our citizens, thus robbing our economy of vital capital. This adds up to a harsh indictment. The truth is, however, that not one of these accusations deserves to be taken seriously.

title: Theater in Review; STUDENTS STAGING A FOLK LEGEND
description: PORT JEFFERSON WITH a more than threefold increase in subscriptions since last season -from 400 to 1,400 - and turn-away business on Saturday nights, Theater Three seems settled into a period of prosperous growth. And with Jules Feiffer's ''Little Murders,'' the theater's executive director, Bradlee Bing, has chosen a play that could prove unsettling to the most complacent suburban audiences.

title: No Headline
description: Kim Chernin's vague invocation of what she suggests are historical trends in fashion is misleading: ''Our grandmothers were permitted to wear flowing clothes.'' By whom? She ignores the cultural and ethical preconditions to this statement.

title: The Week in Business; RATES AND INFLATION EASE AS RECESSION BITES
description: The prime rate dropped to its lowest level in almost a year. Several major banks cut the key lending rate to 16 1/2 percent from 17 percent. Bankers and economists predicted further declines.

title: DESPITE LOCKHEED CASE, TANAKA IS POWERFUL
description: Japanese politics is a glacier. The pace of change is infinitesimal. Surprises are few; major departures, virtually unheard of.

title: FILLING IN A GAPING HOLE DURING A SUNDAY BRUNCH
description: I DID something one morning for the first time, and not without some difficulty - I purchased one bagel. The line in the bakery consisted of several early risers out to purchase the makings of brunch for a dozen or more of their most intimate friends. They called out commands to a plump little woman behind the counter, whose standard white uniform bore flecks of chocolate frosting here and there. ''A dozen rolls, a dozen jelly doughnuts, a large rye, extra seeds, more sugar,'' she echoed as her customers made their demands.

title: I.R.A. GUNMEN SLAY A PROTESTANT M.P.
description: The Rev. Robert J. Bradford, a Unionist Member of the British Parliament, was killed by Irish Republican Army gunmen this morning as he sat talking with constituents in a Belfast community center.

title: Ideas and Trends; A Life List Grows Longer, More Notable
description: Look! On the ground! Was it a yellow-bellied sap sucker? Was it a blue-footed boobie? No, said Dr. Jared Diamond, a reknowned ornithologist newly returned from the wilds of New Guinea. It was the mysterious yellow-fronted gardener bowerbird he heard, then saw, in those hills.

title: A Cram Course For Columbia
description: It was a beautiful liftoff; ''picture perfect,'' observers exclaimed as the space shuttle Columbia, for the second time, climbed into the bright blue Florida sky last week. Even astronaut Richard H. Truly, a Navy captain who happened to be celebrating his 44th birthday, remarked ''We've really been having a lot of fun.''

title: PRIVATELY FINANCED TUITION PLANS ARE TAKING ON NEW IMPORTANCE
description: WHEN Alison Mack was admitted to Cornell University in the fall of 1977, her parents, both faculty members at Pennsylvania State University, felt that they could pay her tuition without taking out Guaranteed Student Loans. At the same time, however, they wanted to avoid making large payments at the beginning of each semester. Cornell put them in touch with Academic Management Services of Rhode Island, which offers an insured plan designed to break down large tuition payments into smaller bills paid over the course of the year.

title: NEW YORK ASSAILS WASHINGTON PLAN ON PUBLIC HOUSING
description: A Reagan Administration plan that would reduce Federal aid for public housing, coupled with rent increases for all 600,000 tenants of the New York City Housing Authority, will have ''a traumatic and devastating effect,'' the agency's two top officials charge.

title: Art View; SOCIAL ART AND THE POLLOCK KRASNER CONNECTION
description: For anyone attempting to chart the course of American art in the 1930's and 40's, two current exhibitions have much to offer us in the way of instruction and illumination. One is the show that Linda Hyman has organized at the ACA Galleries, 21 East 67th Street, under the title ''Social Art in America, 1930-1945'' (through Nov. 28). The other is the show that Barbara Rose has organized at New York University's Grey Art Gallery, 33 Washington Place in Washington Square, under the title ''Krasner/Pollock: A Working Relationship'' (through Dec. 12). Each in its own very different way is an interesting event in itself, yet both acquire an additional interest when seen in relation to the other. For the whole attitude toward art that is upheld in the ''Social Art in America'' exhibition is categorically rejected in most of the work we see in the Lee Krasner/Jackson Pollock exhibition at N.Y.U.

title: PIANO: ANNE VERBIT RECITAL
description: A remarkable program of late-19th-and early-20th-century music, most of it well off the beaten track, was given sharp focus Wednesday by the insightful and involved playing of Martha Anne Verbit, pianist, in a recital at the Merkin Concert Hall. Among the surprises was Miss Verbit's offering of four Arabesques (Op. 42) and the Sonata No. 4 of Leo Ornstein, a Russian-born prodigy who, for a short time prior to 1920, was regarded as this country's leading futurist composer.

title: SUSAN BRAZILL SETS JANUARY WEDDING
description: Dr. and Mrs. George F. Brazill of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Brazill, to Dr. Thomas Andrew Kelly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Kelly of North Brunswick, N.J. and Stella C. Kelly of Clark, N.J. The wedding is planned for January.

title: THE HEROINE FINDS A WAY
description: STORIES with female protagonists that are aimed at young teen-agers are customarily either spiked with romance or soaked in it. But in at least four recently published novels, the boy-girl interest is lowkeyed, weaving in and out of such family traumas as often make the headlines: Identical Twins Meet for First Time; Boy Attempts Suicide; Father Kidnaps Daughter; Local Grocer Shot and Killed.

title: Vadnais, Near 1,000th Game, Is the Vintage Ranger
description: AS a New York Ranger, Carol Vadnais is different for a number of reasons. At 36, he is the oldest Ranger. By conservative haberdashery standards, his vested pinstripes make him the best-dressed. He is the only smoker of cigars - long, fat, $2 zeppelins, debonair in a hotel lobby, provocative on a bus. He is also the only native speaker of French on the team, and the only known collector of oil paintings. He is also the slowest Ranger on ice, and the defenseman who nearly lost his job two months ago, partly because younger, faster defensemen were available, partly because Coach Herb Brooks doubted Vadnais's dedication to what Brooks calls the work-ethic.

title: IT TAKES TIME AND MONEY TO GROW NOBEL LAUREATES
description: To the Editor:

title: Holly Puritz Sets Wedding in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Puritz of Lakewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Holly Suzanne Puritz, to Stephen David Wohlgemuth, son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Wohlgemuth of Waterbury, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Ideas and Trends; How Lucky Are Some Scientists
description: The humanities, so runs the preconception, are the subjective disciplines; in the sciences, reason and objectivity reign. Not by a long shot, said a study published last week in Science, if one analyzes scientists' judgments of each other's research.

title: Florida Quarantine Lifted
description: The Mediterranean fruit fly ''has been eradicated from Florida'' and all quarantine restrictions are lifted, effective immediately, according to the Agriculture Department. A department statement said yesterday that the action released from quarantine a 52-square-mile area of Tampa in Hillsborough County where five of the flies were found in August. The pests attack more than 200 kinds of fruit and vegetables.

title: BARS GET WARNING ON 'LADIES NIGHTS'
description: ''LADIES' NIGHT'' at the local pub has fallen victim to equal rights. Unless the neighborhood tavern offers a like number of ''Gentlemen's Nights,'' special promotions only for women are illegal.

title: LOCAL UNITS FACING NEW RESPONSIBILITY
description: STARTING Jan. 1, some 130 municipal and county health departments will be required by law to assume many of the functions that have been performed in the last decade by the state's Department of Environmental Protection.

title: No Headline
description: Eric Gottgetreu, 78, Reported 3 Middle East Wars for A.P.

title: The Nation; Miami's Black Vote Decisive
description: Despite the growing Latin dominance of Miami that leaders in Little Havana like to call ''evolution, not revolution,'' the results of last week's election for mayor and City Commission made the city's new tri-ethnic politics look a lot like good old-fashioned bloc voting.

title: PRELIMINARY BOUT COMING FOR '82 CONNECTICUT FIGHT
description: It will be almost a year before Connecticut elects its next Governor, but as a practical matter the 1982 gubernatorial campaign will start Thursday, when the General Assembly begins a special session to deal with the state's worsening fiscal condition.

title: HEAVY SEAS HINDER RECOVERY OF BOOSTERS OFF COAST OF FLORIDA
description: It will be sometime tomorrow before the space shuttle Columbia's twin solid rocket boosters are returned to shore.

title: Around the Nation; Storms Batter Coasts, Leaving Dead, Missing
description: By The Associated Press Winds reported to be gusting to 100 miles an hour blew down a dozen redwood trees yesterday and whipped the Pacific Coast in the second major storm in two days, while parts of the lower East Coast were battered by gales and high tides.

title: Centennial for Labor Argued by Historians
description: The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations is calling its meeting the centennial convention of the federation. It is also suggesting that the convention will mark the centennial of the American labor movement, saying the labor movement is entering its ''second century.''

title: A LONG HUDDLE, AND 'I'VE GOT IT!' THUS DO BUILDINGS GET THEIR NAMES
description: To the mailman, it is 1080 Madison Avenue - the address just after the funeral home at 1076, just before the bookstore at 1082. To the developers, however, it is ''1080 - The Residence on Madison,'' a designation they hope will make a gilt-edged impression. Was the name the product of some marketing strategy, like designer jeans or the car named Le Car? ''You might not believe this,'' said T'ing C. Pei, one of the building's principals, ''but we did not do anything scientific - no computer analysis, no surveys or any of that.''

title: THE 'BLOSSOMING' OF ENGLISH MUSIC
description: The Germans used to call England ''Das Land ohne Musik'' - ''the land without music.'' In the 19th century, that was true, if by ''music'' we mean the work of internationally recognzed composers.

title: John Glenn's Candidacy
description: Eugene Kennedy has done an admirable job in discerning whether Senator John Glenn could become the Democratic candidate in the Presidential election of 1984 (''John Glenn's Presidential Countdown,'' Oct. 11). While much of the article is devoted to an analysis of the degree of national recognition Senator Glenn enjoys and the experience of his political advisers, less is said about the Senator's position on the major domestic and international issues of the day, and about whether the Senator is qualified to be President.

title: THE GIFTED CAN'T WEIGH THAT GIRAFFE
description: THE turbojet descends from 32,000 feet into the purple air and the rainy-wintry Vancouver morning left far behind is transformed magically into spring. On the freeway the cars wear yellow and blue license plates reading KING NI and M. BENZ and HOT TUBS and you know you are in Southern California.

title: No Headline
description: Kim Chernin overlooks one important development which has reshaped formerly rounded bodies into rather slender ones - the fitness movement.

title: SINGAPORE SHARPLY RESTRICTS ACTION BY UNIONS
description: The Singapore Government has made major changes in its labor laws that in effect will ban almost all forms of industrial action by the country's trade unions.

title: Theater; 'BLOOMER GIRL' OFFERS AN ENGAGING TIME
description: IN 1943, ''Oklahoma!'' marked a revolution in musical comedy, and in 1944 ''Bloomer Girl'' consolidated the innovations that ''Oklahoma!'' brought to the theater. No longer would any nonsense story line serve to hold a show together; music would no longer be an interruption but a way of advancing the plot; and dancing meant just that, not merely a chance to show off the legs of chorus girls.

title: CATHOLICS IN U.S. PLAN SATELLITE TV NETWORK
description: The Roman Catholic Church is completing plans for a satellite television network that would link the 171 dioceses in the United States, provide a variety of programming and perhaps even save the church almost $90 million a year in telephone costs.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in the Arts and Lei- sure section today incorrectly identi- fies the concert hall where Kyung-Wha Chung will perform with the Pitts- burgh Symphony on Wednesday night. It is Carnegie Hall.

title: LOCAL MENTAL CARE IS LAGGING, STUDY ASSERTS
description: In a new study, a statewide civic group says that the need for mental-health services based in communities ''far exceeds'' the ability of localities to provide that care.

title: SAVE THE GARAGE
description: ONLINESS. By Dave Smith. 262 pp. Baton Rouge, La.: Louisiana State University Press. $12.95 By TOM O'BRIEN

title: Other Business; VIDEO GAMES: A GLUTTON FOR GLOBS...AND QUARTERS
description: There are no fire buttons, warp buttons or hyperspace buttons. Bombers, fighter planes, mutants, asteroids and space invaders are nowhere to be seen.

title: Prospects
description: Tumbling Interest Rates

title: IT TAKES TIME AND MONEY TO GROW NOBEL LAUREATES
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT'S 'HAPPY GROUP' IS STRICKEN BY DISARRAY
description: WASHINGTON DESPITE their determination to steer a constant course, it has long been obvious that some of the officers piped aboard President Reagan's ship on Jan. 20 were carrying their own sealed orders. In the last ten days, however, the outsized personalities in senior policy positions pressed their conflicting agendas in an embarrassingly public way - and, by White House lights - at a terrible time. The President's foreign policies are encountering major obstacles in Israel and with the European allies, and the news on the economy is grim enough for Mr. Reagan himself to say, in his press conference last week, that ''we're going to have some hard times for the next few months.''

title: Best Sellers
description: Jx FICTION 1 2 4 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 2 1 9 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with an eccentric family. 3 3 14 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 4 5 28 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A British-Chinese struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 5 4 6 THE LEGACY, by Howard Fast. (Houghton Mifflin, $14.95.) The Lavette family of ''The Immigrants'' and ''The Establishment'' reaches the turbulent 60's. 6 11 4 RABBIT IS RICH, by John Updike. (Knopf, $13.95.) Harry Angstrom of ''Rabbit, Run'' returns in the chips but unfulfilled. 7 6 21 THE CARDINAL SINS, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner/Bernard Geis, $12.95.) The triumphs and tragedies of two Chicago boys as priests in the Catholic Church.

title: No Headline
description: Nebraska a Winner; Oklahoma Is Upset

title: WILD RICE: PREPARING THE FILET MIGNON OF GRAINS
description: WILD rice is not rice and most of it isn't wild anymore. It is an exotic, crunchy and nutty grain or seed, the major portion of which is cultivated now in paddies. To distinguish the cultivated rice from the rice that does grow wild in lakes and rivers, the former is called paddy rice.

title: THE HERO COMES OF AGE
description: THERE is no more enduring theme in literature than that of the passage of a young man from adolescence to maturity. Four fine new novels for young teen-agers treat this hardy perennial of a subject this fall.

title: 800 U.S. PARATROOPERS OPEN WAR GAMES IN EGYPT
description: More than 800 American paratroopers, many of whom had flown nonstop from Fort Bragg, N.C., bailed out over the Egyptian desert here today as the largest American military exercise in the Middle East since World War II got under way.

title: FROM GORE TO GARLIC: READER'S HOLIDAY FARE
description: A TIMELY feast of books about New Jersey for almost every taste in print - about murders, mergers, history, art, nature, preservation or fun and food -is being offered to readers this holiday season. Following is a sampling of the fare:

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART The map of German art since World War II has yet to be drawn. Even the Germans are not quite sure how it should look, and for most other people the area in question is a matter of bog and swamp, wasteland and vacancy, with hardly a landmark to steer by.

title: Art; BLITHE SPIRITS IN THE ANIMAL KINGDOM
description: assurance of royalty on pedestals in the foyer, only a few feet apart. Even though they are of bronze, their bodies appear capable of springing into immediate and decisive action.

title: WINDOWS ON THE WORLD
description: MIMI SHERATON is the food and restaurant critic of The New York Times. By MIMI SHERATON

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Cynthia Raim, Pianist, Plays Many Styles
description: Cynthia Raim is a young pianist from Detroit who has skirted the mainstream of pianistic fame and fortune for the last few years and who decided last Sunday to take a plunge into New York's recital world. Miss Raim bears first prizes from Switzerland's Clara Haskil Competition and from the Three Rivers Competition in Pittsburgh, and this appearance at the 92d Street Y was a debut only in the technical sense of the term.

title: Hoboken Community Groups Rally Against Arson for Profit
description: About 2,500 people chanting, ''Stop the war against the poor'' marched through the streets of Hoboken today to a City Hall rally protesting arson for profit.

title: G.O.P. Found Unlikely To Win House in 1982
description: The Republican Party's chances of winning a majority of seats in the House of Representatives in the 1982 elections showed little improvement in recent weeks, according to the two latest nationwide Gallup polls.

title: WALKER IS BACK AMONG ELITE RECEIVERS
description: They have been Jets' teammates since 1977, but Richard Todd and Wesley Walker found each other only this season.

title: NAVY, ELECTRIC BOAT ENJOY A RENEWED PARTNERSHIP
description: GROTON THE commissioning of the Trident submarine here last Wednesday was a milestone for the builder, the Electric Boat division of the General Dynamics Corporation. But its construction was only one of the shipyard's accomplishments this year. Another was a reconciliation with its only customer, the Navy.

title: POTVIN RETURNS TO ICE
description: How much better can the Islanders get? The answer was expected to come at Nassau Coliseum tonight, when Denis Potvin, their all-star defenseman and captain, returns after missing the first 15 games of the season with a torn groin muscle.

title: THE U.S., SALVADOR, NICARAGUA
description: The Administration is debating expanded military measures to deal with the stalemate in El Salvador. President Reagan, at his news conference Tuesday, sought to allay fears that United States combat forces would be sent to Central America, but he said nothing about reported planning for other kinds of actions, including a blockade of Nicaragua and Cuba to stifle what the Adminstration says is a flow of arms to the Salvadoran rebels.

title: Antiques; MANSION ROOMS PROVIDE STAGE FOR SHOW
description: NORWALK SET against what has to be Connecticut's most elegant backdrop for such an event, the fourth annual Lockwood-Mathews antiques show will be staged here next Saturday and Sunday in the downstairs reception room of a grandiose Victorian home built in emulation of European castles.

title: BUGGING AT SAN QUENTIN RAISES RIGHTS ISSUES
description: A disclosure that the authorities bugged some inmates' conversations at San Quentin prison has prompted charges that the privacy of attorney-client meetings was violated. State officials assert, however, that they did not eavesdrop on lawyers.

title: FOR GOOD SPANISH AND GOOD BEER
description: MOLLY IVINS is a reporter for The New York Times. By MOLLY IVINS

title: BRATTLEBORO, Vt.
description: AT a mountaintop campus here, a new breed of development specialists is laying plans for a project in Zimbabwe meant to help that new African nation survive the exodus of its skilled white workers.

title: FEDERAL COURT OF APPEALS GETS A NEW MEMBER
description: Judge Richard J. Cardamone has joined the Federal appeals court in Manhattan, leaving three vacancies on the court. At his swearing-in ceremony on Friday, Judge Cardamone was given the oath of office by Judge Wilfred Feinberg, who heads the court. The chief judge expressed hope that the three vacancies would be filled soon.

title: The Region; Putting Limit on Right to Counsel
description: Subpoenaed to appear before a grand jury investigating last month's Rockland County armored-car robbery, Fulani Sunni Ali, who is also known as Cynthia P. Boston, had as her attorney Chokwe Lumumba, with whom she has politics and organizational ties in common. In a disputed ruling last week, a Federal District Court judge in Manhattan barred the attorney from representing her, citing just those politics and ties.

title: Stoke City 2-1 Winner
description: Stoke City defeated West Bromwich Albion, 2-1, in one of only two English League First Division soccer matches played today. In the other match, Middlesbrough and Sunderland tied 0-0.

title: A STOUT CONSTITUTION
description: SO PROUDLY SHE SAILED Tales of Old Ironsides. By Olga Cabral. Illustrated. 170 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin. $8.95. (Ages 10 to 14)

title: ROBOTS BUILD A NEW RENAULT
description: heads bob and weave, biting six or seven times amid a hissing cascade of golden sparks.

title: ENVIRONMENT GROUP PROGRESSES IN ACQUIRING LAND
description: An ambitious program by the Nature Conservancy to protect rare ecosystems by acquiring 22,000 acres at 11 California sites is about a third of the way toward its goal of raising $15 million by the end of 1982.

title: SEARCH FOR URANIUM DEPOSITS DIVIDES VIRGINIANS
description: The first major exploratory drilling east of the Mississippi River for uranium ore to fuel the nation's nuclear power industry is dividing rural Virginians. In the southern part of the state, the preliminary core drilling seems to be generally accepted. To the north, residents concerned about low-level radiation are pitted against landowners who are leasing property to a uranium company.

title: Ellen Brenton is engaged to marry Donald H McAllister Jr
description: Mr. and Mrs. William G. Brenton of Kingston, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Brenton, to Donald H. McAllister Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McAllister of Greenwich, Conn. The wedding is planned for January. Miss Brenton and her fiance are with the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

title: Deconstructionists
description: To the Editor:

title: SYRACUSE JUDGE, INDICTED IN TRESPASS, RESIGNS
description: The chief judge of City Court here has resigned after admitting that he illegally entered another judge's chambers to gather evidence of what he believed to be judicial misconduct.

title: On Language By William Safire Zapped Again Kimble Mead
description: When you push somebody out of a window, how would you describe the sound the person makes as he heads for the asphalt 40 stories below? The answer, as any reader of old comic books will quickly tell you, is ''Aieeeee!'' -sometimes spelled ''Aiiieeeee!'' It is the nearest written approximation of a scream -not perfect, but an improvement over ''Eek!,'' which is now used exclusively by people leaping on chairs to escape mice. A strangled scream is spelled ''Arrgh!''

title: Katherine J. Hall Married to Dr. Ronald Gurney
description: Katherine Jane Hall was married yesterday to Dr. Ronald Edward Gurney. The Rev. Gary Pinder performed the ceremony at the Lewisville Presbyterian Church in McLean, Va.

title: FOLK RECORD COMPANY CAPTURES SOUND NEAR AND FAR
description: SHARON WHEN the Library of Congress started doing documentary field recordings of traditional folk singers in the Depression years of the 1930's, Sandy and Caroline Paton were children. While growing up, those records were ''great sources of songs and knowledge about the tradition for us,'' said Mr. Paton.

title: Gearhart, Pro Bowler, Killed in Auto Mishap
description: Benjamin (Butch) Gearhart, who spent 11 years on the Professional Bowlers Association tour before he decided to quit because he was tired of the travel, was killed yesterday when his car overturned on Florida's Turnpike, the Florida Highway Patrol said. He was 36 years old

title: Council Committees To Meet This Week
