description: The following meetings of City Council committees have been scheduled for this week at City Hall and elsewhere: MONDAY - Subcommittee on the Status of Women, 10 A.M.; Committee on Governmental Operations, 1:30 P.M. TUESDAY - Committee on Consumer Affairs, 10 A.M.; Committee on Environmental Protection, 1:30 P.M. WEDNESDAY - Committee on Public Safety inspects alternative sentencing facilities, leaves at 10 A.M.; Committee on Youth Services, 1:30 P.M.

title: STORIED MANSION IS WILLED TO COUNTY
description: BEDFORD IT once required a butler, a lady's maid and six other indoor servants to keep Merestead, a 26-room Georgian mansion, and its family in elegant style. Even today, it takes a live-in couple. But what worried the current lady of the house, Margaret Sloane Patterson, who was born in an upstairs bedroom, was that a day would come when nobody would be able to keep it up, and the house would be ''knocked down or go to pieces or be turned into condominiums.''

title: Seller Financing Defended
description: To the Editor:

title: DISABLED: PARIAHS NO MORE
description: year-old cerebral-palsied son, rides to school in a wheelchair van, has an instructional aide, and receives daily help from his learning-disabilities teacher. Through this marvelous collection of educational responsiveness, he is able to attend a regular second-grade class at the Davenport Ridge School in Stamford, Conn., with other neighborhood children.

title: AVANT-GARDE RUSSIAN STYLE WITH A 1920'S FLAVOR
description: The styles may have been from the 1920's, but there was nothing nostalgic about the fashion show at the Guggenheim Museum the other night. For one thing most of the 250 spectators were not born in the 20's. For another the clothes were not made then either. On display were clothing and costume designs by avant-garde Soviet artists and, except for one dress, they never went further than the sketchbook stage.

title: Margaret D. Hanes, Sculptor, Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Gordon Hanes Jr. of Winston-Salem, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Drewry Hanes, to Christoph Nostitz-Rieneck, son of Count and Countess Christof Nostitz-Rieneck of Vienna.

title: Miss Ferko, T. C. Darling Will Be Wed
description: Adrienne Elizabeth Ferko and Thomas Christopher Darling plan to be married July 10 at the Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J. Miss Ferko is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen G. Ferko of Awosting, N.J. She attended the Northfield Mount Hermon School in Northfield, Mass.; the Persc School in Cambridge, England, and the Osnabruck Gymnasium in Osnabruck, West Germany, and graduated from Smith College. She is a special projects assistant in the media department of Young & Rubicam Inc. Her father, who is retired, is a former biology teacher in Bayonne, N.J., and was on the faculty of Fairleigh Dickinson University in Teaneck, N.J.

title: HOSPITAL GARAGE FEE DEBATED
description: NEW HYDE PARK WHAT had been perceived as the solution - the construction of a three-level garage by the Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center for staff and visitors, alleviating clogged streets - is seen by community leaders as part of the problem. Residents, contending that the hospital broke a 1977 promise to charge no more than 50 cents, say the hospital's recent decision to charge up to $3.50 will only worsen the present situation of cars clogging streets and blocking driveways.

title: ETHICS TEST RAISES ITS OWN
description: QUESTIONS By DAVID MARGOLICK

title: GUSTY WINDS CAUSE A LAST-MINUTE REASSIGNMENT OF RUNWAY FOR THE SHUTTLE
description: A rapid freshening of the wind from the southwest, with gusts to 28 miles per hour, led to a last-minute reassignment of the runway for today's landing of the space shuttle Columbia.

title: BALLET: AN ARPINO DREAM
description: Gerald Arpino's ''Secret Places,'' which re-entered the repertory of the Joffrey Ballet last Wednesday at the City Center after a fouryear absence, is a pas de deux about young love in its most private, dreamlike moments. In this dream, the man is all ardor and the woman mysterious allure.

title: COAST RIDERS WIN A REPRIEVE
description: AFINAL decision on whether to discontinue through train service between Bay Head and New York City has been delayed by NJ Transit for at least four months because of unexpected problems in completing electrification of the line between South Amboy and Matawan.

title: Ideas and Trends; Prometheus Gets Much Older Now
description: With fire came warmth, light, new foods and tools, nurturing early man's brain and behavior. Previous evidence suggested that hominids first controlled the use of fire some 500,000 years ago.

title: Reviving the Shotgun Wedding
description: Patrick McDonnell

title: Credit Controls
description: To the Business Editor William Nordhaus's article, ''The Problem's Not the Deficit'' (Nov. 1), was a fairly good analysis of some of our economic woes and a rather sensible remedy, suspension of tax cuts. But there is a better one that may not be as fiercely resisted by most businessmen - the application of selective credit controls.

title: MOVABLE FEAST
description: To the Editor:

title: MOST OF ITS TESTS COMPLETED
description: The shortened flight of the space shuttle Columbia came to a safe conclusion here today as two American astronauts steered the winged spaceship through cloudy skies and stiff winds to a graceful touchdown.

title: PHILADELPHIA BATTLES NONRESIDENT ON JOB TAX
description: For 28 years William Gould refused to pay Philadelphia's wage tax, contending it was ''taxation without representation.''

title: PRESIDENT'S PROCLAMATION
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's Thanksgiving Day proclamation: The White House By the President of the United States of America A Proclamation

title: WHAT STATES ARE DOING TO TAKE UP THE SLACK
description: AS student financial aid becomes increasingly scarce on the Federal level, students and independent colleges are turning for help to state legislatures. But according to aid specialists, the states will have trouble making up the difference.

title: Rome Daily American Offered For Sale in Bankruptcy Court
description: Italy's oldest English-language newspaper, The Daily American, went up for sale in a Rome bankruptcy court today, but no buyers appeared, court officials said.

title: The Lively Arts; 'LITTLE MURDERS': VICTIM OF CIRCUMSTANCE
description: GLEN HEAD A DIRECTOR who is disenchanted with the level of local theater is determined to prove that high school students can do it better, and he has chosen a folk play with an enchanted theme, full of witches, conjurers, country songs and spooky effects, to prove his point.

title: 'My Fair Lady' to Close Nov. 29 After 124 Shows
description: The final curtain of the 25th anniversary production of ''My Fair Lady'' will come down after the performance of Nov. 29 at the Uris Theater.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: NORTHEAST UTILITIES will test the emergency plans for the Connecticut Yankee nuclear plant on Feb. 6, and for the Millstone nuclear complex on March 18, with state and local officials going along with the drill, while Federal emergency workers take notes and make suggestions.

title: LUIGI BARZINI'S ITALY
description: Veteran foreign travelers usually bring their own Italy with them; they stubbornly see, taste, experience and remember uniquely the country of their wishes. There is therefore almost no point in giving them any advice or illustrating the multiform possibilities of the voyage.

title: The Region; N.Y. Jail Bonds Do Not Pass Go
description: Since when is crime a pocketbook issue? Since last week, when late returns indicated that upstate voters in New York defeated a $500 million bond issue for prison construction in the Nov. 3 election by 3,400 votes.

title: HEADS IT'S FLORIO, TAILS, KEAN
description: IMAGINE the following experiment: On Nov. 3, 1981, a total of 2.28 million voters go to the polls in New Jersey. Each voter flips a fair coin with ''Florio'' on one side and ''Kean'' on the other.

title: THEATER: ARLEN AND HARBURG'S 'BLOOMER GIRL'
description: ''Bloomer Girl'' doesn't belong entirely to Harold Arlen; E.Y. Harburg had something to do with it, too. The difference is that you can hum the music Mr. Arlen wrote for ''Bloomer Girl.'' You've been hearing it for years, and it stays in your head. Mr. Harburg's lyrics, however, you probably remember only in bits and pieces. Therefore, it's good of the Goodspeed Opera House to revive ''Bloomer Girl'' and let us have a lot of Mr. Harburg's words once again all in a piece. God forbid they should ever get lost.

title: MANY MANHATTAN CRIME SUSPECTS ARE TRANSIENTS
description: About half the criminal defendants indicted in Manhattan come from outside the borough, according to the Manhattan District Attorney's office.

title: Sewanhaka Wins in I-B, Sets Back Lawrence, 7-0
description: Sewanhaka of Floral Park defeated Lawrence, 7-0, yesterday, to win the Conference I-B championship for the fourth consecutive year. It was the first loss of the season for the Golden Tornado after seven victories, including six in the conference. Sewanhaka has a 6-0 league record and is 6-1 over all.

title: Chris Curtin Paces Mepham
description: Chris Curtin broke the girls' 5,000-meter course record yesterday at Sunken Meadow State Park and led Mepham to victory in the eighth New York State Cross-Country Federation meet.

title: AT POCANTICO HILLS, A QUESTION OF TAXES
description: NEW YORK STATE and its citizens are to be enriched soon by a gift of 1,500 acres of incomparable woods and pasture land. The proposed park represents about 40 percent of the 3,500-acre Rockefeller holdings in Pocantico Hills; eventually, the family plans to add a further 1,000 acres. And to crown the benefaction, the main house, Kykuit, is scheduled to join Sunnyside, Philipse Manor Hall and the Van Cortlandt Manor House as a feature of the Sleepy Hollow Restoration.

title: The World; A Nuclear-Free Balkan Zone?
description: The intrusion into Swedish waters of a Soviet submarine suspected of carrying nuclear weapons has torpedoed talk of a nuclear-free zone in Scandinavia. But the election of a Socialist Government in Greece has given new life to a similar proposal for the Balkans.

title: Antiques; INDIANS ARTISTRY
description: American Indian art has been collected seriously for at least a century. The blankets, beadwork, silver jewelry, pottery, masks, baskets and totems were acquired when they were new and as period works by enthusiasts who recognized the superior craft skills of native Americans and were as interested in the sociological and esthetic statements these wares conveyed. Collecting has increased astoundingly in the last decade, in part as a result of the general boom in acquiring all art and antiques.

title: No Headline
description: Bravo for Kim Chernin! Her article is a voice in the wilderness of diet ads and unrealistically thin models that whittle down women's morale. STEVEN LEVENKRON, (Author, ''The Best Little Girl in the World''), New York City

title: Two Urge Trade Commission To Back Imports of Casein
description: A Harvard Medical School professor and a corporate nutritionist say that casein imports should be allowed for medical reasons, despite milk industry objections to the substitute for dairy products.

title: GOVERNOR PRESUMPTIVE CAN PRESUME LITTLE
description: Seven uncertain days after voters went to the polls, former Assembly Speaker Thomas H. Kean stepped forward last week to declare himself the next Governor of New Jersey and accept the cheers of his Republican supporters. Even though his lead of only 1,681 votes (out of more than 2.3 million cast on November 3) will be rechecked and re-examined in the most careful post-election recount in the state's history, Mr. Kean was confident this first hurrah would not be his last.

title: Around the World; France Plans Expansion Of Its Nuclear Forces
description: Defense Minister Charles Hernu announced today in Parliament that France would develop a new tactical missile system and build a seventh nuclear submarine. The program will increase military spending by 17.8 percent.

title: JERSEY TO JOFFREY: A TALE OF 5 COMMUTERS
description: WHEN the curtain goes up Tuesday on the final week of the Joffrey Ballet's 25th anniversary season at Manhattan's City Center, audiences will see three dancers - Jerel Hilding, Krystyna Jurkowski and Beatriz Rodriguez - who commute from New Jersey, along with Diane Orio, the ballet mistress, and Alan Gerberg, the stage manager.

title: THE FISH STORY: IT'S A CHINESE TRADITION, TOO
description: He had just plopped down on the grass, wrapped the line around his big toe and popped the cap off a cool bottle of Peking Five Star beer, when the fish hit.

title: A MINI-SERIES' GENESIS
description: To the Editor:

title: Peace Plan Makes For More Tension
description: Even the Saudis may be surprised by all the waves their not-so-very new peace proposals have suddenly made. When Crown Prince Fahd first put forth his eight-point plan in August, nobody paid much attention. That was before Anwar el-Sadat was killed and the Senate let the Awacs sale to the Saudis go through, partly swayed by the Administration argument that Riyadh, in turn, would be a more willing partner for peace.

title: White Plains Prevails, 31-10
description: Wayne Anderson scored two touchdowns in the fourth quarter to power White Plains to a 31-10 victory over New Rochelle yesterday. Anderson's touchdowns broke open a surprisingly close 10-10 game. The victory assured Coach Brant Wintersteen's Tigers the Conference A, Division 1 championship and gave them a 7-1 regular-season record. White Plains must now await a Section 1 postseason bowl invitation.

title: PARTISAN SHIBBOLETHS
description: To the Editor:

title: Molly P. Bowen To Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. George D. Bayley Jr. of Pleasantville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Bayley's daughter, Molly Patricia Bowen, to Michael H. Ames of Canton, N.Y.

title: Around the World; Dairy Workers in Poland Call Off Planned Strike
description: The Polish Government agreed today to meet the wage demands of dairy workers, and the workers canceled a strike planned for Nov. 23.

title: WAGNER TAKES 9TH STRAIGHT
description: Wagner College's hopes for a second straight invitation to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III playoffs grew slimmer yesterday although the Seahawks defeated Kean, 13-10, at Fischer Field, Staten Island. It was Wagner's ninth straight victory after a season-opening loss to Montclair State but that defeat may have cost the Seahawks a playoff invitation.

title: NEW CHURCH GROUP ASSAILS SUPPORT FOR LEFT
description: A new organization of theologians and church leaders has charged that Christian activists in the United States ignore the benefits of democracy in favor of social revolution that leans to the left.

title: November 15, 1981
description: NONFICTION AMERICAN POLITICS: THE PROMISE OF DISHARMONY. By Samuel P. Huntington. 3 CHESS MYSTERIES OF THE ARABIAN KNIGHTS. By Raymond Smullyan. 16 EASY STREET: True Story of a Mob Family. By Susan Berman. 16 ECONOMIC DIPLOMACY AND THE ORIGINS OF THE SECOND WORLD WAR: Germany, Britain, France and Eastern Europe, 1930-1939. By David E. Kaiser. 18 ENCYCLOPAEDIA OF THE MUSICAL FILM. By Stanley Green. 13 THE HOLLYWOOD MUSICAL. By Clive Hirschhorn. 13 THE HOLLYWOOD MUSICAL. By Ethan Mordden. 13 HOLLYWOOD MUSICALS. Edited by Humphrey Carpenter with the assistance of Christopher Tolkien. 7 THE MEANINGS OF MODERN ART. By John Russell. 12 THE MINDS OF BILLY MILLIGAN. By Daniel Keyes. 9 SELECTED LETTERS OF RAYMOND CHANDLER. Edited by Frank MacShane. 7 SHAW'S MUSIC. By Bernard Shaw. 1 THE WOMAN THAT NEVER EVOLVED. By Sarah Blaffer Hrdy. 9 FICTION DANGER ON CUE. By Rebecca Holland. 34 DEATH IN THE PAST. By Richard A. Moore. 34 DRILLING FOR DEATH. By John Wolfe. 34 ECHOES OF ZERO. By Ross H. Spencer. 35 A FRAGRANT DEATH. By Christina Blake. 34 ILLUMINATIONS.

title: IT TAKES TIME AND MONEY TO GROW NOBEL LAUREATES
description: To the Editor:

title: Dutch Yacht Leads In Whitbread Race
description: At the bottom of the world on the fringes of Antarctica, the Dutch yacht Flyer is reported leading the 26-boat fleet on elapsed time in the 27,000-mile Whitbread Round the World race.

title: Topics Zealots, Large and Small; Legal Fever
description: John Martin, the United States Attorney for Manhattan, is trying to prevent a Detroit lawyer and black nationalist named Chokwe Lumumba from representing Cynthia Boston, a witness and until recently a suspect in the case of the Brink's holdup in Rockland County. What a peculiar position for a Federal prosecutor.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Caryl Thomas, Harpist, Offers Varied Program
description: There is considerable pressure on gifted young performers these days to raise the roof in their debut recitals. So it comes as a pleasant surprise whenever one evinces a concern for musical interest and variety of style, and devotes a program to works in which the element of display, if it is present at all, is subordinated to content.

title: Elizabeth Flood To Be June Bride
description: Dr. and Mrs. John A. Flood Jr. of Trenton and Loveladies, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Susan Flood, to Michael James McNamara, son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. McNamara of Memphis.

title: A DOCTOR DEFENDS HIS CALLING
description: Isadore Rosenfeld, M.D., is a clinical professor of medicine at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center and the author of ''Second Opinion.'' By Isadore Rosenfeld

title: CUBAN THEATER IS THRIVING- IN MIAMI
description: MIAMI Every Friday and Saturday night and twice on Sunday the silver screen at the Teatro La Comedia I comes down and the curtain rises for what has been one of the most popular evenings of original language theater in Miami.

title: UNREST IN MILITARY REPORTED IN SPAIN
description: In the last two days, Madrid has been swept by reports of unrest and anger in the military hierarchy and petitions to King Juan Carlos from senior officers that a general be put at the head of the Government.

title: Long Islanders; ENTERTAINING IDEAS IN TELEVISION LAND
description: ''I TEND to be in new developments,'' said Giraud Chester. So it is not surprising that at the age of 59, Mr. Chester can tick off such innovative projects as founding a university in the Navy after World War II and writing books that break fresh ground.

title: WHY NOT A DOMESTIC CIVIL AWACS PROGRAM?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE YEAR'S BEST ILLUSTRATED BOOKS
description: The illustrations on these pages have been taken from the Book Review's choices of the 10 best illustrated children's books of 1981. Judges who participated in this 30th annual selection were Karla Kuskin, author and illustrator of some 40 books for children; Selma G. Lanes, author of ''Down the Rabbit Hole'' and ''The Art of Maurice Sendak''; and George A. Woods, children's book editor of The New York Times.

title: OFFICE TENANTS FACE NEW RISKS IN LEASES
description: Our latest market studies show commercial rentals setting new records monthly, with $50 per square foot being quoted on a regular basis for prime midtown properties, and the few postwar financial district buildings with space available renting in the $30 to $40 a square foot range. Real estate values are also reaching new heights. The record $177 a square foot for the Pan American building last year has already been eclipsed, with 350 Park Avenue having fetched $331 a square foot. New construction is proceeding at a pace we have not experienced in more than a decade.

title: 2 AUTHORS REVIVE DISPUTE OVER PEARL HARBOR
description: Forty years after the Japanese air attack on Pearl Harbor, on Dec. 7, 1941, writers and researchers are still arguing over whether Washington had advance knowledge of that Sunday morning attack, which plunged the United States into World War II.

title: BROOKLYN WOMAN, SON, 8, AND NEPHEW SHOT DEAD
description: A Brooklyn woman, her 8-year-old son and a nephew were shot to death Friday afternoon in the gray-shingled house where the woman and her husband had operated a $150,000 credit card fraud scheme, according to the police.

title: ALLEN SAYS HE GOT REQUEST AND PASSED IT ON
description: Richard V. Allen, the national security adviser to President Reagan, reaffirmed today that he had not arranged for a Japanese magazine to interview Nancy Reagan last January. But he acknowledged that he had received and passed along the ''initial request'' for the interview.

title: William S. King to Marry Miss McMahon in Summer
description: Acting Court of Claims Judge Daniel F. McMahon of the State Supreme Court and Mrs. McMahon of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nuala M. McMahon, to William S. King of Stamford, Conn.

title: Sarah Mleczko, Gallery Aide, Fiancee Of John Knowles Jr., Business Student
description: Mrs. Stanley Samuel Mleczko of Hanover, N.H., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Sarah Elizabeth Mleczko, to John Hilton Knowles Jr., son of Mrs. Lewis Stackpole Dabney of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and the late Mr. Knowles. A June wedding is planned.

title: Beauty; A NOSE FOR MAKING SCENTS
description: here are those who earn their living by the pen, those who earn it by the sword, those who earn it with their hands and even those who earn it with their noses.

title: ARABS TRYING TO AVERT CONFRONTATION ON SAUDI PLAN
description: Arab nations and the Palestinian guerrilla movement are trying to avoid an open confrontation over a plan put forward by Saudi Arabia for a Middle East settlement.

title: CONFERENCE EXPLORES INCEST
description: INCEST, sometimes called the last taboo, is so rarely a subject of study that when the Mental Health Association of Westchester County decided that it was time for some attention on this form of sexual abuse, 200 professionals in the human services field signed up from Westchester, Rockland, Ulster and Putnam Counties as well as from New York City.

title: PROPOSAL TO SPEED WAR CRIMES CASES STUDIED
description: The United States and West Germany are considering a proposal to allow Americans accused of Nazi war crimes to be extradited to Germany to stand trial without forcing the United States first to go through the long procedure of stripping them of their American citizenship.

title: JEWS IN ETHIOPIA REPORTED BEATEN
description: Jews in a northern province of Ethiopia are being arrested and tortured and their villages deprived of educational and other Government services, according to a group of 13 Americans and Canadians who recently visited the country.

title: Around the Nation; Oklahoma Won't Pursue Liability in Pollution Case
description: Companies that may have contributed to environmental damage at the abandoned Tar Creek lead and zinc mines along the Oklahoma-Kansas border will probably not be liable, an aide to Gov. George Nigh said today.

title: F.B.I.'S FILES COMBINED SERIOUS WITH TRIVIAL
description: The first thorough assessment of Federal Bureau of Investigation files by outsiders shows that the bureau has carefully stored records on 25 million investigations ranging from the serious to the trivial.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Brooks de Wetter-Smith Plays Flute Program
description: Brooks de Wetter-Smith, a flutist who made his New York debut Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, may have avoided the routine by programming works of Hummel, Pierne and Boulez, among others, but he paid a higher price than he needed to. There are better ways to lift one's program out of the ordinary than wholesale dipping into the second rate.

title: Dining Out; A TASTE OF OLD MEXICO IN ORANGE
description: DECENT Mexican and Tex-Mex restaurants are few and far between in New Jersey, and so it is good news for aficionados that El Bandito has opened in Orange. Mexican food is at once earthy and festive, and this friendly young restaurant captures these qualities.

title: COLLEGES SCURRYING TO EASE AID PINCH
description: FURMAN UNIVERSITY in Greenville, S.C., has created an office to find part-time and summer jobs for all of its undergraduates - anywhere in the country and without regard to their financial need. It is also helping to develop a regional manual to advise students on how to make their money go further, and it has set up a computerized system to match students with foundations and corporations offering special grants and employment.

title: DAWKINS IS PLAYING UNDER MORE CONTROL
description: Ever since Darryl Dawkins joined the Philadelphia 76ers in 1975, fresh from Maynard Evans High School in Orlando, Fla., countless predictions have been made that some day he would blossom into his full potential.

title: IN A TURN TO FARMING, COUPLE SEEK SELF-SUFFICIENCY
description: MONTAUK IN Montauk, just a few blocks from Main Street, behind a sign bearing the name Ocean View Farm, stands the house that John and Carla Craft moved to the site in 1973. At the time, subdivision papers for the 20-acre parcel surrounding it were already on file and Mr. Craft, then in the real-estate business and a builder as well, was in an ideal position to profit handsomely by carving it up for development.

title: DANCE: TRADITIONAL OKINAWAN WORKS
description: Geographically, Okinawa has been an Asian crossroads. And the cultures of China, Japan, Korea and Indonesia have left their marks on that of Okinawa. So it wasn't surprising that a sense of fusion and assimilation characterized a program by the Court Dance Theater and Music of Okinawa company Thursday at the Asia Society's Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium. But there could be no mistaking of Okinawan dance for anything other than itself: an art of simplicity, handsome stylization and earthy humor, performed with irresistible warmth.

title: ASTRONAUT'S FATHER ELATED
description: ''I was wiping my eyes when it landed,'' James Truly said today after his son returned safely to earth aboard the space shuttle Columbia.

title: Safety, Legal Abortion Are Not Synonymous
description: Susan Schneider's article ''Antiabortion Plan: Where Is Justice?'' (Sept. 20) and Polly Rothstein's letter concerning that article (Oct. 4) require a response to serve the cause of justice.

title: Cuban Classrooms
description: I appreciated Jo Thomas's article about foreign students on the Isle of Youth (''Cuba's School for Exporting Marxism,'' Oct. 4). Cuba's program of junior high schools in the countryside, which combines half days of study and farm work, has been a useful model in many places.

title: Sheila Davidson Wed to Peter Leokum
description: Sheila B. Davidson, a senior supervisor with the Children's Aid Society of Pennsylvania, was married yesterday in New York to Peter J. Leokum, Philadelphia and Pittsburgh branch manager for the Filmways Pictures Corporation. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Haskel Lookstein and Cantor Avrum Davis at Temple Kehilath Jeshurun.

title: Summer of Striper Records
description: ALTHOUGH most anglers and fisheries biologists are in accord that the East Coast's striped bass, a highly prized, saltwater food and game fish, is in trouble because of both over-harvesting and pollution of its spawning grounds, the second striper over 70 pounds has been caught in the region this season.

title: The World; End of Another Trial Marriage
description: The urge to merge that has stampeded Libya's Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi into embarrassingly brief liaisons with half a dozen Arab and African countries was thwarted anew last week. Correspondents counted 30 daily planeloads of Libyans departing from Ndjamena, the capital of Chad, just 10 months after Libya had announced a ''merger'' with its sprawling, uranium-rich southern neighbor.

title: Sarah Schlesinger To Wed in August
description: Edward S. Schlesinger of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Renee C. Schlesinger of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Jane Schlesinger, to Stanley R. Frankel, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Frankel of Evanston, Ill.

title: 'BLOOMER GIRL' OFFERS AN ENGAGING TIME
description: IN 1943, ''Oklahoma!'' marked a revolution in musical comedy, and in 1944 ''Bloomer Girl'' consolidated the innovations that ''Oklahoma!'' brought to the theater. No longer would any nonsense story line serve to hold a show together; music would no longer be an interruption but a way of advancing the plot; and dancing meant just that, not merely a chance to show off the legs of chorus girls.

title: TURKEY SHOOTING OFFERS A RESPITE FOR REAGAN
description: President Reagan sought respite from White House personnel troubles here today by stalking the elusive wild turkey on a hunting trip in the south Texas brush country.

title: Draft Registration Foes Seek Reagan's Support
description: Anti-draft leaders, charging that Selective Service registration has not worked, have called on President Reagan to end the process.

title: Critics' Choices
description: THEATER Right now the Public Theater is making it incredibly easy for audiences to follow, step by exciting step, the development of an important new American playwright. The writer is 24-year-old David Henry Hwang, whose second and third plays, ''The Dance and the Railroad'' and ''Family Devotions,'' are playing concurrently on two of the Public's stages.

title: No Headline
description: CLEMSON (10-0) SINKS MARYLAND TO WIN A.C.C. TITLE

title: Kalule Takes Decision Against Odell Leonard
description: Ayub Kalule of Uganda, the former World Boxing Association junior middleweight champion, won a unanimous eight-round decision from Odell Leonard of the United States tonight.

title: Around the Nation; Jersey Child Receives A Transplanted Liver
description: Surgeons transplanted a liver today into a 2-year-old girl dying of cancer. The child, Lauren Toohey of Kinnelon, N.J., was listed as ''critical'' in an intensive care unit at Children's Hospital,

title: Stamps; EUROPAS SHOW FOLKLORE
description: The annual ''Europa'' omnibus issue for this year has been devoted to the theme of national folklore - customs, legends, rituals and superstitions - and it has turned out to be a lively topic as more than half of the countries participating chose to translate folklore into national dances.

title: R.N. Ryan Fiance Of Sara Ballantine
description: Mr. and Mrs. Percy H. Ballantine of Andover, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sara Streit Riker Ballantine, to Roderick Newbold Ryan, son of William A.K. Ryan of Easton, Md., and Mrs. Martin Richards of New York and Southampton, L.I.

title: A SPECIAL REMEMBRANCE
description: MY family and I celebrated Veterans Day this year in a special way. We all went to the cemetery first, with public memories and private tears, to remember the past and make promises for the future.

title: Patsy Gassel Sets February Bridal
description: The engagement of Patsy Louise Gassel to Edward Ira Handelman has been announced. Miss Gassel is a daughter of Lillian Lehrer of Skokie, Ill., and Seymour Gassel of Glenview, Ill. Mr. Handelman is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Handelman of New York and Westhampton, L. I.

title: Russia's Grain
description: To the Business Editor: When I read ''Why the Russians Can't Grow Grain'' (Nov. 1), I was reminded of a question and answer session that Intourist offered to us when we toured Moscow, Leningrad and Odessa three summers ago.

title: Charles E. Dunbar, 68, Dead; Securities Concern's Ex-Head
description: Charles E. Dunbar, retired chairman of the Discount Corporation of New York, suffered a fatal heart attack Friday night while driving near Chatham, N.J. Mr. Dunbar, a resident of New Vernon, N.J., was pronounced dead at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 68 years old.

title: 'VACATIONING' KOCH TAKES TIME OFF FOR PARTY
description: This small, sun-baked town threw a party today in honor of a returning native son and the big-city Mayor who came home with him.

title: YOUR NAME IS MURPHY? HERE'S A SCHOLARSHIP
description: THE University of Miami offers a scholarship to Armenian students, Stanford gives one to Eagle Scouts from the 12th scouting region, and New York University pays full tuition for a graduate of a Yonkers public high school.

title: Business Conditions; WEAKNESS IN POWER
description: Cooler weather across the nation prompted a rise in electricity generation last month, but continuing conservation and a slumping economy have dampened demand for the year so far.

title: Home Clinic; A SIMPLE METHOD FOR TRIMMING PANELING AND FLOOR TILES
description: THERE are many do-it-yourself projects around the home that call for trimming the edge of a panel or sheet - or the end of a piece of wood trim -to a specific contour so that it will fit snugly against an irregular or uneven surface.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: MAMARONECK MORE than anything else, the smells bring back memories. The musty odors of tempera paint and thick white paste; the damp, earthy scent of clay - these can envelop a person at the Children's Art Workshop of Westchester, can send a visitor years back to elementary school or to that first day of kindergarten.

title: ARTHUR, RAGEN, ALLEN ET AL.
description: THE MINDS OF BILLY MILLIGAN By Daniel Keyes. Illustrated. 374 pp. New York: Random House. $15.50.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; France de Guise Plays Three Etudes by Liszt
description: There was a rhapsodic kind of lyricism to France de Guise's piano playing at the Abraham Goodman House Thursday evening. Her big, fullcolor technique often muddled Beethoven's ''Waldstein'' Sonata, but three Transcendental Etudes of Liszt - especially the Etude in F minor - had a wonderful sweeping musicality.

title: No Headline
description: U.S.C. ELIMINATED FROM ROSE BID, 13-3

title: Chess; HERE COMES KASPAROV
description: None of yesterday's younger generation - with the single exception of West Germany's Robert Huebner -has gotten into the Candidates Matches for the world championship. And now they are all 30 years old, or close to it.

title: No Headline
description: Michigan Beats Purdue, 28-10

title: Food; TURKEY WITH A DASH OF DIFFERENCE
description: ''MANY students take this class more than once,'' said Roslyn Wasserstrom, who, for the last 12 years, has been teaching a threehour class early in November on how to prepare a Thanksgiving dinner. Recently, when 20 women arrived in her well-equipped kitchen, more than half had attended a previous class here.

title: GIANTS OF THE EARTH
description: DINOSAURS By Mary Packard. Illustrated by Christopher Santoro. Unpaged. New York: Little Simon/Simon & Schuster. $6.95. (Ages 4 to 8) DINOSAURS OF NORTH AMERICA By Helen Roney Sattler. Introduction by Dr. John H. Ostrum. Illustrated by Anthony Rao. 151 pp. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard. $10.95. (Ages 9 to 14)

title: No Headline
description: Experience with patients has indicated that compulsive dieting is a female mechanism which simplifies life by restricting and controlling behavior.

title: No Headline
description: This Week:

title: No Headline
description: Dartmouth Routs Brown on Polsinello's Passing

title: The Region; Keane Is Still Ahead As N.J. Recount Begins
description: Politics may not obey the laws of probability, but they are what Representative James J. Florio is counting on after the final tally last week indicated his Republican opponent, Thomas H. Kean, had won the Nov. 3 gubernatorial election in New Jersey.

title: Robert Cerf, Miss Weintz To Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Frederick Weintz Jr. of Riverside, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Hunt Weintz, to Robert Alan Cerf, son of Prof. and Mrs. Alan Cerf of Piedmont, Calif. The wedding will take place next month at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: BRAVURA OPINIONS
description: SHAW'S MUSIC By Bernard Shaw. The Complete Musical Criticism in Three Volumes. Edited by Dan H. Laurence. Volume I, 1876-1890. 958 pp. Volume II, 1890-1893. 986 pp. Volume III, 1893-1950. 911 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Co. Boxed, $150.

title: PBS OFFERING CREDITS FOR COLLEGE ON TV
description: THE Public Broadcasting Service has joined the ranks of television learning systems, turning living rooms across the country into classrooms where the housebound, the disabled, people with odd working hours and mothers with small children can earn college credit by flicking the ''on'' switch.

title: HUNTING MONSTERS
description: RED DRAGON By Thomas Harris. 348 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $13.95. By THOMAS FLEMING

title: Marjorie Holland, Nurse, Fiancee of Indraneel Paul
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Holland of Middletown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Ann Holland, to Indraneel Paul, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anil K. Paul of Calcutta, India. The wedding is planned for Jan. 23.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Cambridge Players Joined by a Singer
description: The debut of Boston's Cambridge Chamber Players on Wednesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall was an occasion for beautiful singing by D'Anna Fortunato of Ravel's ''Chansons Madecasses'' and John Harbison's ''Book of Hours and Seasons,'' but the concert as a whole was uneven and inconclusive at best.

title: Sound; JUDGING TURNTABLE VALUES
description: Having delved - or at least dipped - into the theoretical squabbles of turntable designers in recent columns, we're ready to leap from theory to practice to cast a critical look at current hardware. A definite pattern of design and marketing is clearly evident: in economy models, the emphasis is on holding the price line while assuring good basic performance. Midprice models tend to appropriate refinements formerly confined to the upper brackets. And deluxe designs push the technical frontiers but occasionally become sidetracked into extravagant and capricious innovation.

title: CONTROLLED FICTION AND RECKLESS ENDINGS
description: IN THE GARDEN OF THE NORTH AMERICAN MARTYRS By Tobias Wolff. 175 pp. New York: Ecco Press. $10.95.

title: Lafayette Triumphs As Brown Excels
description: Larry Brown, a senior halfback, starred on offense and defense as Lafayette defeated Tottenville, 16-12, yesterday. Brown scored on a 1-yard plunge in the first quarter and a 2-yard run in the fourth quarter, and carried 27 times for 120 yards.

title: Diane Adreon Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Adreon of St. Louis have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Adreon, to Lawrence Gillman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Gillman of Teaneck, N.J.

title: Environews
description: THE United States Fish and Wildlife Service has extended the hunting season for the snow goose at the Brigantine National Wildlife Refuge after having increased the daily bag limit last year from two to four birds.

title: Tightening the Computer Belt
description: In reference to Myron Berger's article, ''Enter the Computer'' (Home Design, Sept. 27), it occurred to me that when families are lowering the thermostat because of excessive heating costs (and finding that a few extra layers of clothing suffice to keep them warm), when people are sponge-bathing at the sink because it wastes less water, isn't it ironic that, with our abundant technological advances, we have entered an age of scarcity so that it is not the home computer that has become our newest luxury, but the very things it was designed to monitor. DEANNE ABEDON, Danbury, Conn.

title: 200,000 AT AIR BASE CHEER 2D RETURN OF THE SHUTTLE
description: They spent the night on mattresses and sleeping bags spread on the desert floor, strumming guitars, singing around campfires and enjoying cook-outs. By dawn, about 100,000 people had converged on Edwards Air Force Base to catch a glimpse of the Columbia space shuttle for the few minutes that it would be visible to them as it made its second return to earth.

title: 'DEMONSTRATION' BOMBS AND OTHER THREATS
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Kastenbaum, Cindie Meyerson To Wed May 27
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Monroe R. Meyerson of New York and Weston, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Cindie Donna Meyerson, to Dr. Donald Mark Kastenbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Kastenbaum of Lawrence, L.I. The wedding is planned for May 27.

title: A Fiesta of Fabrics At Modest Prices
description: For nearly 36 years, first quality yardgoods have been supplied by The Westchester Fabrics Company in Mount Vernon - not only to institutions, corporations and ambassadorial residences but also to tailors, dressmakers, belly dancers, choristers and costumers for drama groups. Quantity discounts apply on the larger orders, but ''there are no gimmicks or sales because everything goes on sale the day it comes in,'' according to Milton Goldstein, who with his brother, Jack, is the store's owner. There are no irregulars or seconds, although there are closeouts and overruns.

title: JERSEY DEMANDS CAESARS WORLD OUST FOUNDER
description: The Casino Control Commission asserted in papers filed with the New Jersey Supreme Court yesterday that Clifford S. Perlman should be barred from any position with Caesars World, not only the parent company and its New Jersey subsidiary but also its Nevada subsidiary.

title: Motorists at Stoplights Lure Chicago Thieves
description: It usually happens when a woman is alone in an automobile, stopped for a light. Suddenly, a brick smashes the window, a hand reaches in and grabs her purse.

title: RAFFLES A CHANCY THING FOR HOMEOWNERS
description: As the popularity of house raffles has increased, so has the vigilance of law enforcement agencies in states where they are prohibited.

title: IS PUBLIC EDUCATION A CASUALTY OF REAGONOMICS?
description: AT the outset, I must state unequivocally that I believe in American education. I always have. As the product of a public school system and a parent who has sent four children to public schools in various states, I stand proudly in the tradition of

title: GLUM REALITY OF BORROWING FOR A BRIGHT FUTURE
description: EDUCATIONAL debt began innocently enough for Michael DiGregorio. As a second-year student at the School of Dentistry of the University of California at Los Angeles in 1974, he borrowed $5,000 in federally insured student loans. In 1976 he changed careers and was admitted to the U.C.L.A. School of Medicine. For the next four years he financed his education through the Guaranteed Student Loan program, along with loans from the university, a foundation and a commercial bank. When his internship ended in 1981, Dr. DiGregorio found himself $40,000 in debt, with monthly payments of $400 and $300 more a month expected to begin falling due the following April.

title: YUGOSLAVIA IS SHOWING STRAIN AT ITS MANY SEAMS
description: A Yugoslav Foreign Ministry official, musing aloud to a visitor from the United States, remarked recently: ''On every single occasion your officials talk to us or make public statements they repeat the formula that your Government supports our territorial integrity, independence and unity. Are you trying to tell us something? Do you think we're falling apart?''

title: MINORITY COMPANIES SEE TOUGHER SLEDDING AHEAD
description: In the wake of an increase in commercial construction activity in the New York metropolitan area, a small number of black and Hispanic real estate professionals are making inroads into the traditional real estate brokerage, management and development establishment. Most minority companies, however, are still trading in poorer neighborhoods where housing and construction are often subsidized by governmental agencies and they are worried about the future as President Reagan plans to cut programs.

title: Leisure; CONSIDER LILIES FOR INDOOR CHEER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lynn Lewis Monroe is a freelance writer. By LYNN LEWIS MONROE

title: BAYSIDE, LINCOLN WILL PLAY FOR P.S.A.L. TITLE MIDWOOD, CANARSIE GAIN
description: uf89 By AL HARVIN

title: MAIL CALL ON CAPITOL HILL
description: Frequently exhorted to ''write your Senator,'' an astonishing number of Americans respond, with an average of three million pieces of mail a month. A few hours past midnight every workday, a United States Postal Service truck lumbers up Capitol Hill and heads for the Dirksen Senate Office Building to make the first of a dozen daily deliv-eries. At about 3:30 A.M., a small mountain of mail is dropped at the loading-dock entrance to the United States Senate Post Office to await the arrival an hour later of the clerks who will sort and bundle it for delivery in carts that will roll through underground passages beneath and between the two Senate office buildings and up and down still empty corridors. By 6:30 A.M., piles of mail will have been deposited in each of the 100 senators' offices.

title: CAN FINANCIAL-AID SEARCHERS FIND YOU MONEY?
description: ONE way to find out about the thousands of scholarships, loans and grants available in the United States each year is to buy the services of companies that compile extensive computer files on sources of financial aid. The companies, for a fee, match a student's background, interests and abilities with requirements for sometimes obscure, privately financed scholarships.

title: 'FAIR' SYSTEM OF PROPERTY TAX REFORM ELUDES ALBANY
description: It has been six years since the State Court of Appeals ruled that New York's property tax system was illegal because it did not comply with a 200-year-old law requiring all property to be assessed at its full market value. The decision left homeowners quaking in fear of new assessments and an end to the long-standing practice of valuing homes at lower rates than commercial property.

title: 2 TRIBES WANT U.S. TO END OIL LEASES
description: Charging that the Amoco Production Company had repeatedly violated Federal regulations, attorneys for the Shoshone and Arapaho tribes in Wyoming said today that they would ask the Interior Department to cancel oil-producing leases held by the company on Indian land.

title: LEGISLATORS FACING MINORITY ISSUE IN REDISTRICTING
description: With the New York City Council's reapportionment experience as a warning, state legislative leaders hope to redraw Assembly district lines next month so that minority-group legislators will not be affected by an expected loss of four Assemblymen in the city.

title: TENNESSEE WILLIAMS GALA TO AID FELLOWSHIPS
description: A salute to Tennessee Williams marking the playwright's 70th birthday will be held Dec. 2 at 8 P.M. in Avery Fisher Hall. Stars, including Warren Beatty, Helen Hayes, Maureen Stapleton, Meryl Streep, Sally Struthers, Eli Wallach and Irene Worth, will take part in the event, which will include scenes from Mr. Williams's awardwinning plays as well as music, poetry and dance.

title: The Industry's Side On Overfishing
description: I would like to respond to the recent article ''Larger Hauls Raise Fears of Depletion.'' I and others in the commercial fishing industry are upset that the article was so poorly informed and biased.

title: Lorraine M. Pirog Engaged to Christopher D. Starr
description: The engagement of Lorraine Marie Pirog to Christopher Daniel Starr has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Martin Pirog of West Hempstead, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Starr of Garden City, L.I.

title: Recordings; PLACIDO DOMINGO TESTS HIS RANGE
description: What do new recordings of Verdi's ''Un Ballo in Maschera,'' the Berlioz and Verdi Requiems, three collections of operatic arias and one of popular songs involving John Denver have in common? Aside from the fact that they are all in the vocal category, they all have Placido Domingo as a soloist or featured singer. The plethora of releases with his name on them is an indication of his popularity and status.

title: AFTER THE FEDERAL CUTBACKS, A NEW ERA IN PAYING FOR COLLEGE
description: THE success of the Reagan Administration in trimming Federal aid to college students has led to a new era in the financing of a college education - both for millions of potential college students and the institutions they seek to attend.

title: CONCERNING HOBBITS AND PHILIP MARLOWE
description: THE LETTERS OF J.R.R.TOLKIEN Selected and edited by Humphrey Carpenter, with the assistance of Christopher Tolkien. 463 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $16.95.

title: CREATING A LANGUAGE FOR PRIMITIVE MAN
description: Anthony Burgess is an author, critic and historian who once devised a glossary of the future for his novel ''Clockwork Orange.'' By Anthony Burgess You will, I hope, go to see a new movie sometime this winter called ''Quest for Fire.'' The title tells you what it's all about - a primitive human society, which discovers fire, has its most treasured possession stolen by an enemy tribe and must set out to regain it. In the old days of the cinema, it was possible to dramatize such a subject in fairly fanciful terms. There was no need to pay heed to prehistoric fact or probability. But nowadays many of us fancy ourselves amateur anthropologists and expect to find, even in the most extravagant reconstruction of the remote past, a substructure of scholarship.

title: WEST SHORE LINE: GOOD NEWS
description: DUMONT ALMOST since the last northbound passenger train left this Bergen County town 22 years ago, commuters, public officials and railroad enthusiasts here and in other populous communities along the West Shore Railroad have sought a resumption of passenger service.

title: WASTE IS THE CHALLENGE
description: THE proper management of solid, hazardous and nuclear waste is one of the greatest health and environmental challenges of this decade. At present, most efforts to manage these wastes are either shortsighted, ineffective or not responsible, and will not improve unless we, as a society, are willing to recognize the existence and severity of waste management problems and to accept responsibility for managing the wastes we produce.

title: DICKENS, A BIRTHDAY AND MIGRATING BIRDS; A Week for Waterfowl In Virginia
description: It is early morning, and the autumn sky is cloudless and deep blue. Breakers thunder onto the beaches, a cold wind sighs over dunes cloaked with scrub pine. Suddenly, the vanguard of the migrating flocks appears in the distance, dark against the sky, moving swiftly south in V-formation, fluttering softly overhead, then down the beachfront, moving away, honking the pale song of late November.

title: Film View; HOW ART TRIUMPHS OVER SOCIAL REPRESSION
description: The critical and popular success (in New York, anyway) of ''Taxi zum Klo'' (''Taxi to the Toilet''), Frank Ripploh's ferociously indiscreet autobiographical German film, is prompting a lot of talk about the freedom of motion pictures. One of my colleagues has enthusiastically described it as ''a big step toward liberating the screen'' and, to the extent that it's the first nonpornographic film to include sequences that in other circumstances would be judged pornographic, he is right.

title: THE BLIND DENTIST
description: ILLUMINATIONS By Tamas Aczel. 375 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $15.50. By D.M.THOMAS

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: CHESS MYSTERIES OF THE ARABIAN KNIGHTS By Raymond Smullyan. Illustrated. 192 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $13.50. Paper, $6.95.

title: VENICE IN WINTER
description: To the Editor:

title: HEPBURN: 'I HAD A CORNER ON THE RICH, ARROGANT GIRL'
description: Once upon a time, there was a kind of film that featured what my father called ''good, smart talk.'' It usually starred Katharine Hepburn or Margaret Sullavan, and he was infatuated with both. I preferred Katharine Hepburn, and, writing to a cousin in Scotland whom I was safe from ever meeting, told her I was skinny, highcheekboned, 5 feet 7 1/2 inches tall and red-haired. Skinny was true and so was the stuff about the cheekbones; everything else was a lie. But in childhood I lived in a world where all the girls wanted to look like Katharine Hepburn, and in middle age I still do.

title: The Nation; O'Hare Airport's Junior Jet-Set
description: At city halls all over the country, fiscal hard times have made old-style patronage jobs harder to come by. But Chicago officials, displaying an almost magical knack for business as usual, have simply pulled an O'Hare out of their hats.

title: CAREY SIGNS A BILL REDUCING WELFARE BENEFITS
description: About 50,000 New York families will have their welfare benefits eliminated or reduced under legislation signed by Governor Carey.

title: Sneezing in the Draft
description: DURING the baseball strike, Ray Grebey, the one and only spokesman for the club owners' player relations committee, had a line he found occasion to drop in with a sneer. ''Well,'' he would say, ''now we have a strike over three players.'' He meant that if the owners won their demand for professional compensation for free agents, only three players would have to be paid for with other players out of major league organizations.

title: WORK, A FIRST-OFFENDER OPTION
description: IN 1978, William Shockley, Assistant State's Attorney in Norwalk, was experimenting with several alternative programs for first offenders. In one, defendants were asked to donate to charity. ''That was fine until we began to figure out that the parents were paying,'' he said. Then he struck on the idea of volunteer service.

title: Redskin Comeback A Threat to Giants
description: Fans counting on an easy victory when the Giants play the Washington Redskins tomorrow should heed a warning.

title: Anne Maciag to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John A. Maciag of Pelham Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Marie Maciag, to Patrick Joseph Kaiser, son of Mrs. Katherine C. Kaiser of Portland, Ore.

title: TOXIC DUCKS WORRY HUNTERS
description: FOR thousands of years, the Island's quaint ponds, gentle streams and broad-leaved forests provided a hunting paradise for Indians who stalked game for food and clothing. In recent times, however, the pursuit of wildlife has been harmed by industrial expansion, the flow of urbanization and environmental errors.

title: ELECTRONIC GAMES: DO THEY HELP?
description: THE miniature computer has a keyboard, musical sound effects and an animated viewing screen with built-in modes for musicians, artists and authors. The getting of this wisdom - without extra software - costs some $125. The end-users? Six to 11-year-olds.

title: Critics' Choices
description: POP MUSIC The apparently indestructible Jerry Lee Lewis is scheduled to return to the Ritz, 11th Street between Third and Fourth Avenues, on Thursday night. A few months ago, Mr. Lewis was seriously ill and confined to a hospital bed.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Urban Renewal
description: On Aug. 25, 1980, the Henry Rincker house, the second oldest house in Chicago, was demolished in 10 minutes by a bulldozer. The wooden landmark structure, built about 1852 and incorporating details of the Gothic revival style, was on a tract intended for condominiums.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Swept Away
description: As leaves piled up around City Hall last November, Mayor Koch introduced an innovation discovered on his tour of China: Shanghai sweepers.

title: YOUNG DANCERS DEFINE THE JOFFREY STYLE
description: You can tell an American Ballet Theater dancer, they say, by the way he paces the stage, pointing imperiously to swans and noble folk alike. And, as the joke goes, the New York City Ballet roster is full of pin heads with endlessly attenuated bodies. But what is a Joffrey dancer?

title: Connecticut Guide; A SYMPHONY IS BORN
description: Beatrice Brown, conductor of the Ridgefield Symphony Orchestra since 1970, has also taken on the directorial chores for the new 81-member Western Connecticut Symphony Orchestra. An inaugural concert will take place at 8:15 P.M. Saturday in Ives Hall, Western Connecticut State College, Danbury. Two more concerts are scheduled for February and May.

title: Dance View; DANCE HISTORY IN ITS CULTURAL CONTEXT
description: Because dance is regarded so traditionally as an art of the fleeting moment, there is a strong tendency to look at even its history in isolation. In the theater, dance's antecedents seem less important than the actual live performance in front of us and how it affects us at the time. Viewing a manifestation of an art form bereft of context seems more common to dance than to the other arts. A viewer who is startled by an industrial-style metallic abstract sculpture suddenly plunked down in his village square, is startled precisely because he has a prior reference frame - the statue in honor of the Civil War dead or the neo-classic draped nude in the local squire's garden. A dance viewer, on the other hand is usually seized by the immediate impact and worries less about what came before.

title: S. Mississippi Still Unbeaten
description: Undefeated but once-tied, Southern Mississippi scored the first seven times it had the ball and overwhelmed Florida State today, 58-14.

title: The Region; Well, It Was Just a Thought
description: Bureaucracy may be prone to err, but it need not admit prostration. Such was Mayor Koch's argument when he overruled the head of New York City's welfare agency last week and said the city would indeed attempt to improve welfare efficiency rather than risk losing many millions in Federal contributions.

title: Bridge; THE AUSTRALIANS WERE NOT AMUSED
description: If there had been an award in the recent 1981 World Team Championships for the most error-free performance, most observers would probably have voted for Jeff Meckstroth of Columbus, Ohio, and Eric Rodwell of West Lafayette, Ind., the anchor pair of the American team that won the title.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ATLANTA
description: REGINALD STUART is the chief of the Atlanta bureau of The Times. By REGINALD STUART

title: SAUDI ENVOY SAYS PEACE PLAN RECOGNIZES ISRAEL
description: Saudi Arabia's ranking diplomat here has said that his Government's Middle East peace plan recognizes Israel.

title: KARPOV AND KORCHNOI ADJOURN 16TH TITLE CHESS GAME
description: The 16th game of the world chess championship was adjourned today with the champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, holding the advantage over Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland, who sealed his 41st move.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: Nothing Can Go Wrong By Capt. John H. Kilpack with John D. MacDonald. 305 pages. Harper and Row. $15.95.

title: Diet, Fitness And Feminism
description: Kim Chernin's interesting and compassionate article has made me more accepting of myself (''How Women's Diets Reflect Fear of Power,'' Oct. 11). If I do decide to diet, it will be far easier to do so because I am more relaxed about my weight - and about myself! ROBERTA JOHNSON, New York City

title: Crime
description: Among the more convincing private eyes of recent years have been Albert Sampson, out of Indianapolis, and John Denson, who works in Seattle. The Sampson series is the senior; it started in 1971 with ''Ask the Right Question.'' The first Denson book, ''Decoys,'' was published only last January. Now both are back - respectively, in MISSING WOMAN (Knopf, $10.95), by Michael Z. Lewin, and 30 FOR A HARRY (Evans, $8.95), by Richard Hoyt.

title: WINNING IN THE PACIFIC
description: THE BATTLE OFF MIDWAY ISLAND By Theodore Taylor. Illustrated by Andrew Glass. 141 pp. New York: Avon/Flare. Paper, $2.25. (Ages 12 and Up)

title: MISS KETCHAM FIANCEE OF LLOYD H. COFFIN 3D
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Bonbright Ketcham of Lawrence, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Long Ketcham, to Lloyd Hibbert Coffin 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Coffin Jr. of Stratham, N.H., and Naples, Fla.

title: WHAT'S PLAYING AT THE MOVIES IN WESTCHESTER--AND WHY
description: ON a recent weekend ''Paternity,'' starring Burt Reynolds, opened at six Westchester theaters. Two other films - ''Southern Comfort'' with Keith Carradine and ''All the Marbles'' with Peter Falk - each opened at five other theaters. Moviegoers who were willing to travel around the county could choose from 20 other features, including some of last summer's hits and, untypically, three foreign films.

title: Around the World; Nicaragua Recalls Envoy As U.S. Ties Deteriorate
description: The Government called its Ambassador to the United States home today for consultations amid deteriorating relations with Washington.

title: LIGHT OPERA: HERBERT'S 'RED MILL'
description: While some art forms defy the passage of time, musical comedy tends to age along with its original audiences. Victor Herbert's ''The Red Mill,'' resurrected by the Light Opera of Manhattan and running at the Eastside Playhouse through Nov. 29, is 75 years old this fall, and though Friday evening it showed its wrinkles early on, it managed at the end to recapture some of its youth.

title: SHUTTLE'S PAD IS CLEANED UP FOR 3D LIFTOFF
description: Thousands of spectators flocked to this desert air base today to watch the Columbia make its historic second return from space.

title: JAPANESE MAGAZINE DESCRIBES ALLEN ROLE IN DISPUTED ARTICLE
description: The article published in a Japanese magazine after an interview with Nancy Reagan at the White House says that Richard V. Allen, President Reagan's national security adviser, was involved in the arrangements for the interview.

title: The World; Two-Part Land, Three-Way Split
description: Belgian elections last weekend that were intended to clear the air may have only made the country's future more murky. The centrist Christian Democrats lost 21 seats in Parliament, their worst showing since World War II.

title: About Long Island
description: THE houseguest season never ends, a friend of mine who lives in Syosset and feels that it is always open season on his bed and board observed the other day in the most dour fashion. I have disguised his identity, which is not difficult to do since he is very much of a piece with his community, but he dearly loves people, except when they are sleeping in his house, and he would not want to get the reputation among his friends of being one who doesn't really want to see them.

title: T.W.U. VOTE MAY INFLUENCE TRANSIT TALKS
description: The union representing most of the city's bus and subway workers is embroiled in an election battle that could once again, as it did two years ago, have important repercussions in next year's transit negotiations.

title: Ideas and Trends; Reinventing a Polio Virus
description: Off-the-shelf chemicals are seldom the stuff of which genetic material is made. But scientists at Massachusetts Institute of Technology used just that to manufacture the genetic core of a polio virus.

title: Susan Davis to Be Wed Jan. 2
description: Dr. and Mrs. John Staige Davis 4th of Charlottesville, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Abbott Davis, to, Richard Bradford Bailey, son of Mrs. Irving H. Chase of Lincoln, Mass., and Richard Briggs Bailey of Woodstock, Vt., and Boston. A Jan. 2 wedding is planned.

title: PROJECT PAYS DIVIDENDS TO THE CITY'S MINORITIES
description: APILOT project that began a couple of years ago in 35 New York City schools with dominantly minority enrollments has been credited with bringing about a marked improvement in student performance, a rise in both teacher and student attendance, and a sharp decrease in classroom disruption.

title: THE ART OF PICTURE BOOKS
description: VLADIMIR NABOKOV remembered his father ''reading to us aloud, on rainy evenings in the country'' near St. Petersburg. In Vermont, a relative of Rudyard Kipling's recalls hearing ''The Just-So Stories'' delivered in ''Cousin Ruddy's deep unhesitating voice ... each phrase having its special intonation ... without which the stories are dried husks.'' Those were the days when a channel was simply a deep waterway, sesame was only a seed and people read aloud for entertainment. It was a wonderful pastime. It still is. Many a grown bibliophile owes a lifelong love of books to childhood's compelling duo: a voice and a tale.

title: GOATS DO JOB CLEARING LAND HARD TO TAME
description: For five years Helen and Thomas Buckholtz tried to clear their hillside yard of blackberry brambles and poison oak vines using conventional methods, but nothing worked until they called Dick Otterstad and rented some of his goats to do the job.

title: Clifton Triumphs And Gains Playoffs
description: Rich Noonan scored the winning touchdown in the third quarter as Clifton defeated Teaneck, 13-7, yesterday. It was the first loss for Teaneck (7-1), which has secured a berth in the North Jersey, Section 1, Group 4 playoffs.

title: TV View; MIKE WALLACE TURNS TO 'PROFILES'
description: Devotees of television in the wee hours, anytime between 2 A.M. and 6 A.M., are probably familiar with a series called ''Biography.'' Produced some 20 years ago by David Wolper, who later snared a niche in the history books of television with ''Roots,'' the half-hours use archival film footage to devise portraits of world leaders, prominent personalities and assorted celebrities. Lending an extra dimension of interest to these essays, which still pop up on the schedule with surprising persistence, is the fact that the narrator, the man delivering the wraparound comments, is Mike Wallace, the tough guy of the ratings-winning ''60 Minutes'' team.

title: FATEHPUR SIKRI
description: To the Editor:

title: Laura J. Torrisi Is Married to James A. Goldsmith
description: Laura J. Torrisi, a designer with Bruce Withers Graphic Design, and James A. Goldsmith, a real-estate broker with Collins Tuttle & Company Inc., were married yesterday at the Ridgeway Country Club in White Plains. Rabbi Irwin Loewenheim performed the ceremony.

title: BILLS ON DIVORCE CHALLENGE COURT
description: Legislation to undo a Supreme Court ruling that divorced people are not entitled to share in military pensions is gaining wide support in Congress.

title: JOYS OF FLEEING THE CORPORATE STABLE
description: IF the 1980's are the era of colossal multibillion-dollar mergers, it is also a time of a contrary trend - the uncoupling of the conglomerates pieced together during the corporate building days of the 1960's. Many of these corporate giants are now spinning off the businesses they acquired then and turning them back to their managers, who think they can can do a better job running the companies once they are free of the conglomerate headquarters.

title: Rangers Use Grinding Tactics
description: Grinding is the word the Rangers use to describe themselves when they play hockey diligently. So Friday night they might be said to have ground the Buffalo Sabres into accepting a 3-3 tie after Buffalo had taken the lead twice. The grinding took the form of indefatigable harassment until a Sabre made a mistake - by not checking a Ranger shooter, not clearing a rebound or not moving Ron Duguay out of the goal area.

title: Advertising; Measuring Cable TV Audiences
description: NEITHER cable system operators nor local television station managements appear eager to compile data on the audiences of cable television, despite the clamoring of advertisers for this information.

title: INDUSTRIAL BONDS IRK DEALERS
description: Securities firms that sell tax-exempt notes and bonds issued by states and municipalities are worried that this market is being threatened by a flood of tax-exempt securities that are really thinly disguised borrowings of private corporations.

title: A SOVIET REPUBLIC TOASTS A VINTAGE HARVEST
description: While Soviet farmers brood over grain crops severely hit by this year's drought, the wine connoisseurs of Moldavia are raising their glasses to a bumper grape harvest.

title: Nudists Attack Possible Ban
description: A national nudist group, the Naturalists, has gone to Federal court to prevent the Fish and Wildlife Service from barring nude sunbathing on Moonstone Beach in South Kingstown, R.I. Last week the Rhode Island Audubon Society gave 115 acres, including Moonstone Beach, to the Fish and Wildlife Service. A spokesman for the service said the Government would crack down on the nude sunbathing that has become popular at one end of the beach.

title: WHITE HOUSE WAITS AS ALLEN INQUIRY GOES ON
description: The White House has no plans to ask Richard V. Allen, President Reagan's national security adviser, to step down during the Federal investigation of his acceptance of $1,000 from a Japanese magazine, Administration officials said today. But, they said, its position could change if a special prosecutor is appointed.

title: MUSIC: CHRISTA LUDWIG SINGS
description: SCHUBERT provides ample recompense for the sense of loss that suffuses the lines of his lieder. The sensuous beauty of the melody itself is a reminder that something is held in reserve, out of the reach of passing time.

title: SONG RECITAL: TERESA BERGANZA
description: THE transition from operatic stage to recital hall requires delicate shiftings of vocal and stylistic gears, which few singers learn to manipulate. Teresa Berganza, the Spanish mezzo-soprano, gave an evening of songs to a small but adoring audience at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night, but her sense of the stage was manifest in every one of them.

title: EXCERPTS FROM AN INTERVIEW WITH LANE KIRKLAND
description: Following are excerpts from an interview by William Serrin with Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. COPE refers to the labor federation's Committee on Political Education.

title: KORCHNOI GAINS CHESS DRAW WITH SUPRISE MOVE
description: With a sealed move that astonished expert onlookers here, Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland preserved a draw today in a game that many of the experts thought would be his last.

title: Senegal and Gambia Become Senegambia
description: Sir Dawda Jawara, the President of Gambia, has formally united his small West African nation with Senegal, it was announced last night.

title: GETTING TO THE TOP IN FASHION AND BEAUTY INDUSTRIES
description: More than 1,500 women - and a sprinkling of men - spent all day Saturday at Hunter College hearing about and discussing opportunities and challenges for women in the fashion and beauty industries.

title: Linda Ann Halpern Wed To Joseph S. Ort., C.P.A.
description: Linda Ann Halpern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Halpern of Convent Station, N.J., was married at the Cedar Hill Country Club in Livingston, N.J., yesterday to Joseph Stephen Ort, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel H. Ort of Glenside, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Steven Price of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church and Rabbi Roy Rosenberg of the Temple of Universal Judaism, both of New York.

title: THE REGION
description: It took 60 firemen about four hours to put out a brush fire along a mile stretch of Conrail tracks here.

title: DOES THE EMPEROR KNOW?
description: In the storm over William Greider's brilliant article in The Atlantic Monthly, Washington has been debating the future of David Stockman. I think the more interesting question is the effect on the future of Ronald Reagan.

title: QUTDOORS: IN PURSUIT OF THE STRIPED BASS
description: CHILMARK, Mass. HAVING gone all fall without savoring the sweet, white flesh of a striped bass, I wept on Kib Bramhall's shoulder and asked if he could remedy my plight.

title: CITY POLICE OFFICER HELD UP
description: Three armed youths held up four subway passengers on an earlymorning Lexington Avenue train in Manhattan yesterday and shot one of them point-blank when he seemed to resist, the Transit Authority police reported.

title: MASSACHUSETTS TOWNS REFLECT ANTAGONISM AT TRIAL
description: On State Road 20, along the western rim of Massachusetts, where the gentle Taconic Mountains rumple the border with New York, a single modest road sign separates the towns of Lee and Lenox. One face of the sign announces ''Lenox.'' The other side says ''Lee.''

title: STARRED IN FIRST TARZAN FILM
description: Enid Markey, the actress who created the role of Jane in the first Tarzan movie, in 1918, died yesterday in South Side Hospital, Bay Shore, L.I. Her age was listed as 91.

title: Pure Science and Pure Profit
description: Sounds of strange anguish continue to be heard on the campus as molecular biologists try to come to terms with the wealth that genetic engineering is bringing to them and their universities.

title: COLLEGES ARE UNEASY OVER FACULTIES' OUTSIDE JOBS
description: Three days a week Otto Eckstein lectures to the biggest course at Harvard, the introductory class in economics. Other days, he goes to suburban Lexington, to his orange-carpeted office at one of the nation's most successful economic forecasting companies, Data Resources Inc., of which he is chairman. Two years ago, Mr. Eckstein sold Data Resources to McGraw-Hill Inc. for $103 million. He and his family owned 20 percent of the company's stock.

title: Ailing Campbell Bars Medication
description: Scott Campbell, defenseman of the St. Louis Blues, will leave the team rather than take medication prescribed for his recurring headaches, the Blues said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photograph accompanying an ar- ticle on New York State Assembly redistricting in the main section of yesterday's Times was identified as Assemblywoman Rhoda S. Jacobs. It was actually Assemblywoman Gail S. Shaffer.

title: 'Ox-Strong, Cat-Quick'
description: WET and weary, Mark Gastineau was plodding toward the Jet trainers' room when Marvin Powell glanced at him. ''How many sacks?'' Marvin Powell asked. ''Eight altogether,'' Mark Gastineau said. For the season, the Jets are leading the National Football League with 46 sacks. Joe Klecko, the right end who is 6 feet 3 inches tall and weighs 272 pounds, is the N.F.L. individual leader with 15 1/2, including three in yesterday's 17-6 triumph over the New England Patriots. Mark Gastineau, the defensive left end who is 6 feet 3 and 276 pounds, is second in the league with 14 sacks, including three yesterday.

title: THE POOR? WHO ARE THEY?
description: Thirty years into the American-led assault on global poverty, we still know very little about the very poor. The reasons for this lack of knowledge speak to the nature of the poverty problem itself. The wretched and the dispossessed do not generate information about themselves. Frequently, they do not even register the birth -or death - of their children. Living beyond the limited reach of their countries' social agencies, their very rhythms of life are largely unknown to their own governments.

title: SAG IN HOME PRICES MAY AFFECT FAMILIES' INVESTING
description: After more than a decade of steady increases, prices of homes in the United States have begun to level off, and in many areas they have begun to decline.

title: 'SILENCE' MOTIVE IS BEING STUDIED IN THREE DEATHS
description: City detectives said yesterday that they were looking into the possibility that a Brooklyn woman was slain, along with her son and nephew, to keep her or her husband from cooperating in government investigations.

title: Barbara Fanning Is Bride of Spiro Marousis, Artist
description: At St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn, L.I., yesterday, Barbara Ann Fanning, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Fanning of Roslyn Heights, L.I., was married to Spiro Marousis, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Marousis of Manhasset, L.I. The Rev. Stephen P. Morris performed the ceremony.

title: LABOR, AUTO INDUSTRY DEBATE REACTION TO ADVERSITY
description: Thirty-six years ago today, the United Automobile Workers began a bitter 113-day strike against the General Motors Corporation. It was the first of the great postwar industrial strikes and the experience so unnerved the automobile company that when a new round of contract talks began in 1948, G.M. avoided the wage issue by relating pay increases to productivity gains, with adjustments for cost-of-living increases.

title: JETS TRIUMPH
description: The Giants lost in overtime today in a game they appeared to have won in the final minute of regulation time. They also lost their quarterback, Phil Simms, probably for the season, with a separated right shoulder.

title: CITY'S BOOKSTORES OFFER SOLACE FOR A RAINY SUNDAY
description: It was was a great day yesterday for browsing in the bookstores of Manhattan. From France and Italy, Montreal and Denver, Hoboken and Brooklyn, people were drawn to New York City's popular Sunday activity. What better way to spend a dank and drizzly day than in the narrow, warm aisles of Rizzoli or Books and Company? Energetic early Christmas shoppers with baskets on their arms meandered through the mazes of paperbacks and hardcovers at Fifth Avenue's Barnes & Noble and B. Dalton.

title: The Toll of the Bells
description: Twyford is a small town in rural England 35 miles west of London, and when Colin Tompson moved there six years ago he apparently figured he could count on some peace and quiet.

title: Cargill Pleads Guilty on Taxes
description: Cargill Inc., a major grain dealer, has pleaded guilty to two charges of failing to report all its income for two years.

title: CHARLES C. PARLIN, LED A CHURCH UNIT
description: Charles C. Parlin, a former senior partner in the law firm of Shearman & Sterling and a past president of the World Council of Churches and the World Methodist Council, died yesterday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Red Smith The Classic Gimpy Back
description: SPARRING with Duane Bonds, Gerry Cooney went into a weave and felt a stab of pain high in the back above the rib cage. He went to his corner, where Victor Valle rubbed the back. Sparring again, Gerry started a punch and the pain lashed back. They consulted Dr. Jeffrey Minkoff, who recommended rest, with no sparring, calisthenics or running.

title: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1981; Markets
description: A flood of tax-exempt industrial development bond issues worries securities firms that deal in tax-exempt bonds and notes issued by municipalities and states. They feel say some tax-exempts are actually disguised borrowings by private corporations. (Page D1.)

title: The Pop-Soul Baritone Of Luther Vandross
description: Although Maze Featuring Frankie Beverly, a popular pop-funk group from Los Angeles, headlined at the Palladium on Saturday, it was apparent from the audience response at the first of two shows, that the second-billed Luther Vandross, a New York singer with a smash-hit debut album riding the charts, was the chief box-office attraction. A portly, wide-eyed entertainer, with a flouncing, good-humored stage manner, Mr. Vandross combined the light-hearted theatrics of an oldtime band leader with one of the most impressive pop-soul baritones this listener has heard in a while.

title: Transactions; FOOTBALL JETS (AFC) - Activated Freeman McNeil, running back, and Mickey Shuler, tight end. Placed John Woodring, line- backer, on the injured reserve list.  Released Ralph DeLoach, defensive line- man.
description: SAN DIEGO (AFC) - Released Billy B rooks, wide receiver. COLLEGE WASHINGTON STATE - Signed Jim Walden football coach, to a four-year con- tract.

title: 45 Killed in Accident At a Rally in Mexico
description: At least 45 people were killed today at a political meeting in a bullring when a wall collapsed under the weight of a crowd trying to climb it and get inside, the Mexican Red Cross said.

title: Railroad Film Studios In Hoboken Get Aid
