description: A proposal to build a film and television production center in the refurbished Erie Lackawanna Railway Terminal here has cleared its final hurdle with the receipt of a $1,375,000 grant from the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: THE VICIOUS CYCLE OF RENT CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: Andrea Nadel Is Married to John Griffin, Banker
description: The marriage of Andrea Hope Nadel, a portfolio manager with Advanced International Income, to John C. Griffin, a banking officer in the specialized industries division of the National Bank of North America, took place last evening. Rabbi Burt Siegel performed the ceremony at the Tavern on the Green.

title: SILENCE ON A NOISY SUBMARINE
description: Scandinavia was appalled by the nuclear weaponsbearing Soviet submarine that poked into Sweden. But the incident has been treated with peculiar insouciance by the rest of the West, as though it were enough to giggle at the Russians slipping on their own banana peel.

title: Canucks 7, Flames 4
description: The Vancouver victory was led by Ivan Boldirev, who scored three goals and assisted on two others.

title: TRANSIT OUTLAYS AND STAFF GREW AS SERVICES FELL
description: Despite a widely noted deterioration of subway and bus service in New York City, municipal researchers have found that since 1970 the work force and spending power of the Transit Authority, alone among major services, have actually increased.

title: HOLY CROSS UPSETS FARRELL IN SEMIFINAL, 6-0
description: A 14-yard touchdown pass from the junior quarterback Ralph Scarano to the wide receiver John Finnegan with 2 minutes 1 second left in the first half gave Holy Cross a 6-0 upset victory over Monsignor Farrell yesterday in the semifinals of the Catholic High Schools Football League playoffs. The Knights will meet St. John the Baptist of West Islip, L.I., defending champion, for the title next Sunday.

title: BRIEFING
description: D ESPITE President Reagan's retention of David A. Stockman as his budget director, some of the President's strongest political allies are already looking hopefully for some other employment for Mr. Stockman, and they say Michigan isn't too far away for the embarrassingly garrulous aide. Republican strategists are speculating, with considerable wishfulness, that Mr. Stockman, a former Michigan Congressman, may choose to go home and run for Governor or, more likely, Senator next year.

title: THE SUPPLY-SIDERS RESPOND
description: Supply-side economists who advocated the big tax cuts that have formed the basis of President Reagan's economic policy are rallying to defend their ideas against those who say that David A. Stockman has effectively discredited them.

title: Greek Diplomat in Australia Found Slain in His Residence
description: The Greek Consul General in Sydney was found stabbed to death in his official residence today, the police said.

title: ABORTION: FACING THE BASIC QUESTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Siemens Sets Layoffs
description: Siemens plans to cut its work force by between 5 percent and 7 percent in the financial year ending Sept. 30, 1982, West German newspaper reports said today.

title: Durable Isley Brothers Play Date at the Savoy
description: The Isley Brothers have endured as one of the country's most successful pop-soul acts for some 20 years by virtue of their ability to assimilate styles and to change with the times. Both Ronald and Ernie Isley, lead singer and lead guitarist of the family-oriented sextet, are naturally eclectic talents, and on the second night of a four-night stand at the Savoy on Friday, their sextet, augmented to 11 musicians, ran through half a dozen different styles, including hard funk, disco and lush erotic ballads.

title: Index; International
description: Report sees gross deficiences in global nuclear safeguards A2 U.S. commander urges review of advisers' role in Salvador A2 Uprising of 1973 is marked in Athens A4 Around the World A5 Acting President piles up big lead in Bangladesh election A7 Uzbeks are demanding a bigger piece of the Soviet pie A8 Soviet republic of Moldavia toasts a vintage harvest A8 Thousands disrupt traffic in Frankfurt airport protest A10 Trudeau and Levesque trade insults A12 Government/Politics Miami Beach installs TV cameras to discourage criminals A17 Group in Jersey seeking voter intimidation evidence B1 Supporters of George Wallace urge him to run for Governor B10 Efforts are being pressed in Congress to pass an antibusing bill B17 Reagan flys back to Washington aboard command center B17 More than 900 publications will be dropped to save money B17 Washington Talk Briefing A20 Reagan's pollster keeps his finger on nation's pulse A20 A new breed emerges in capital: political husbands A20 General Around the Nation A14 Manslaughter trial further divides two Massachusetts towns A14 Brooklyn's Red Hook section undergoes renaissance B1 Link is sought between Brooklyn murders and fraud scheme B6 Outside employment of college teachers raises questions B11 Excerpts from interview with Lane Kirkland of A.F.L.-C.I.O. B12 SportsMonday Basketball: Knicks lose on another second-half collapse C3 Boxing: Alexis Arguello is wandering into history C1 Columns: Dave Anderson on Jets' front four C7

title: Asbestos Deal Is Scrutinized
description: Securities regulators in Ontario say they are looking into the purchase by the government of Quebec of a controlling interest in the Asbestos Corporation because of the possibility that Ontario law might require Quebec to make an offer to minority shareholders.

title: DIANA TRILLING, PATHFINDER IN MORALITY
description: IN all her work, Diana Trilling has been interested in the relationship between esthetics, morality and society, and in her recently published book, ''Mrs. Harris,'' an account of the trial of Jean Harris for the murder of Dr. Herman Tarnower, she declares that an individual's ''moral style'' can be adduced from his style of life. Dr. Tarnower's Westchester house, for instance, strikes her as an ugly manifestation of the doctor's mistaken belief that money ''was class, and that class conferred moral stature,'' and she writes that the Madeira School for girls in Greenway, Va., where Mrs. Harris was headmistress, sounds like ''a patrician zoo.''

title: AUSTRALIAN MOVIES SEEK U.S. BACKING
description: Los Angeles is a 15 1/2-hour flight from here, but that is where Filmco Ltd., Australia's only publicly traded film company, is trying to make deals these days.

title: CALDER MOBILE CONDUCTS A WORK BY EARLE BROWN
description: At the State University campus at Purchase on Saturday afternoon, the conductor of the East Coast premier of a percussion piece by Earie Brown was a mobile by Alexander Calder.

title: BEVERLY HILLS DIET IS CRITICIZED
description: The Beverly Hills Diet, the latest rage in reducing plans, is full of medical ''inaccuracies'' that could harm people who follow the diet, a report in The Journal of the American Medical Association said recently.

title: Roy Wins Account Of Coca-Cola of Detroit
description: Ross Roy Inc., of Detroit, has become the agency for the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Detroit, which is under new ownership and is consolidating all of the products previously handled by McCann-Erickson and Stone & Simons, both in Detroit.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE KLEBER FLIGHT. By Hans Koning. 214 pages. Atheneum. $12.95. THE LAST SCAM. By David Harris. 364 pages. Delacorte/Seymour Lawrence. $13.95.

title: CAN WE INDEX OUR WAY OUT OF INFLATION?
description: T o the Editor: Professors Robert Heilbroner and Adolph Lowe do not seem to have taken account of the full implications of their proposal to index loan contracts to an appropriate price index (letter Nov. 4).

title: SOVIET JEWS FOUND TO BE DOING WELL IN U.S.
description: Three-quarters of the Soviet Jews who emigrated to the United States say that their overall standard of living and their incomes are better here, but only 15 percent say their social status is better and only 20 percent say they have a better cultural life, according to the preliminary summary of a yearlong study.

title: Married Couples Show More Decline in Nation
description: For the first time, less than 60 percent of American households have a married couple, according to Census Bureau statistics released today.

title: City Opera 'Freischutz' Casts 2 New Principals
description: The fifth and sixth performances of the City Opera's new production of ''Der Freischutz'' took place Tuesday evening and Saturday afternoon and featured a new Agathe, sung by Heather Thomson, and a new Caspar, Richard Cross.

title: No Headline
description: CONNORS DEFEATS MCENROE IN FIVE SETS

title: Clack Returns
description: Jim Clack was satisfied with almost everything about his return to pro football competition today except for the outcome of the game.

title: Papers' Revenues Up
description: Newspaper ad revenues rose 15.6 percent in September from the year before, to $1.5 billion, according to the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, which used data from Media Records Inc. The biggest gain was in retail advertising, which gained 20.7 percent, while national rose 13.3 percent and classified 8.2 percent.

title: Theater Piece Studies Children of Immigrants
description: Howard Da Silva, Pearl Lang, Rita Karin, Eve Merriam, Joseph Papp, Zvee Scooler and the Klemzer ensemble, Kapelye and others will participate in a theatrical exploration of the lives of the children of Jewish immigrants in a bilingual performance called ''Children in a New Land.''

title: LATE KICK BY BAHR ENDS 49ERS' STREAK
description: Matt Bahr, who had been with the San Francisco 49ers when their seven-game winning streak began, ended it today by kicking a 24-yard field goal in the last minute to give the Cleveland Browns a 15-12 victory.

title: BERTHE M. COSTIKYAN
description: Berthe M. Costikyan, who taught French at the Horace Mann School in Riverdale and other schools for 63 years, died yesterday at the Amsterdam House nursing home in Manhattan. She was 96 years old.

title: TV: KATHLEEN WIDDOES AS EDITH WHARTON AT 60
description: THE trilogy on the life and works of Edith Wharton on WNET-TV, Channel 13, began promisingly with a flawed but imaginative adaptation of ''The House of Mirth'' and then, last week, stumbled badly with a lifeless version of ''Summer.'' Tonight it closes with an unfortunate thud as ''Looking Back'' attempts to compress Mrs. Wharton's fascinating biography into an awkwardly structured hour.

title: Jack Wenarsky, Lawyer, Marries Randy S. Phillips
description: Randy Susan Phillips, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Phillips of Cranford, N.J., was married in Livingston, N.J., yesterday to Jack Edward Wenarsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Wenarsky of Morristown, N.J. Rabbi Ronald Hoffberg performed the ceremony at the Crystal Plaza.

title: G.O.P. KEEPS TABS ON NATION'S MOOD
description: The calls go out every night, randomly, 150 or more to homes scattered from coast to coast. For half an hour or so, interviewers ask the anonymous respondents at the other end of the line a stream of questions about the state of the nation, the world, the Republican Party and, most important of all, the state of Ronald Reagan's presidency.

title: Addenda
description: * Sports Illustrated increasing its advertising rates 9.5 percent, effective with the Jan. 11 issue.

title: London Paper Says Judge Has Held Up Spy Article
description: A High Court judge has issued an injunction preventing The Sunday Times from publishing new allegations concerning members of a Soviet spy ring controlled by Anthony Blunt, the former art adviser to Queen Elizabeth II, the paper reported today.

title: Lakers 124, Pacers 123
description: LOS ANGELES (AP) - A free throw by Kareem Abdul-Jabbar with eight seconds remaining in the second overtime period gave Los Angeles the victory over Indiana.

title: REAGAN, FACING ALLEN ISSUE, RETURNS TO THE CAPITAL
description: President Reagan, after an unsuccessful morning of hunting turkeys in the Texas brush country, arrived back in Washington today aboard the so-called doomsday plane that is designed to serve as an airborne command post in the event of a nuclear attack.

title: ACTING BANGLADESH PRESIDENT GAINS BIG VOTE LEAD
description: Acting President Abdus Sattar was on his way to a sweeping election victory tonight over his chief rival, who charged that results were being manufactured and that they were ''laughable.''

title: POLLS IN HOUSTON FAVOR CONTROLLER
description: As the campaign for Mayor of Houston moved into its final hours today, City Controller Kathryn J. Whitmire was generally favored to defeat Sheriff Jack Heard of Harris County in a runoff on Tuesday.

title: STRANGE EQUATION ON THE WEST BANK
description: To the Editor:

title: CAN WE INDEX OUR WAY OUT OF INFLATION?
description: To the Editor:

title: Armenians Threaten To Destroy French Plane
description: Armenian extremists, seeking the release of one of their number from a French prison, threatened to blow up an Air France plane in flight today.

title: SECURITIES GROUP ELECTS A CHAIRMAN
description: Larry F. Clyde, a 39-year-old executive vice president of the Crocker National Bank in San Francisco, has been elected chairman of the Public Securities Association, the trade group of banks and brokers that underwrite and trade municipal and Federal Government securities.

title: HARVARD IS GIVEN 7.5 MILLION
description: Harvard University said yesterday that it had received a $7.5 million gift that would permanently endow 15 chairs for its junior faculty.

title: KNICKS' LATEST LOSS FOLLOWS A PATTERN
description: Rival National Basketball Association coaches and scouts frequently bring back glowing reports of the Knicks' talent, but their 3-5 record hardly inspires awe. Two of the victories have been against the New Jersey Nets and the other against the Dallas Mavericks, who have the worst record in the league.
To the Editor:

title: 9th Audelco Awards To Be Given Tonight
description: Three musicals, five dramas and more than 60 individuals have been nominated for Audelco Recognition Awards, which will be presented tonight to winners in 15 categories of theater arts.

title: HEATING OIL PRICES EDGE UP ALTHOUGH SUPPLY IS PLENTIFUL
description: The average price of heating oil used in small homes in New York City is edging up again, although oil-industry leaders report that supplies are plentiful and that nationwide inventories are even being held down.

title: 'My Fair Lady' to Close Nov. 29 After 124 Shows
description: The final curtain of the 25th anniversary production of ''My Fair Lady'' will come down after the performance of Nov. 29 at the Uris Theater.

title: Norway Lifts Price of Crude
description: Statoil, the Norwegian state oil company, has informed its customers of a $1.50-a-barrel increase in the price of its North Sea crude oil, a spokesman said.

title: Chiefs 23, Oilers 10
description: Joe Delaney, Kansas City's quick-starting rookie, rushed for a team-record 193 yards and Nick Lowery kicked three field goals.

title: RELATIONSHIPS
description: T HERE'S this problem with envy. It's very different from the six other scoundrels in that hall of human dishonor, the seven deadly sins. ''Envy is curious because each of the other sins points to an end or a goal that is not in itself evil,'' said Dr. Maury Silver, an assistant professor of psychology at Johns Hopkins University. ''For example, gluttony is a sin, and yet no one would advocate that we not eat. Lust may be sinful, yet we are also enjoined to be fruitful and multiply. So too with greed, sloth, pride and wrath. These involve virtuous goals that have been done to excess, or inappropriately.''

title: Pope Defends Workers' Right To Seek Jobs in Other Nations
description: Pope John Paul II said today that workers had the right to travel to other countries to seek jobs and that their host countries should grant them equal rights.

title: People
description: * William F. Abrams and John J. Grogan have been elected senior vice presidents at SSC&B Inc.

title: REVIEW OF ROLE IN SALVADOR URGED
description: The commander of all United States troops in Central and South America said in an interview yesterday that ''someone is going to have to rethink'' regulations preventing United States advisers from going into the field if the military situation in El Salvador worsens.

title: MIAMI BEACH TO USE CAMERAS TO DETER CRIME
description: In an effort to deter rising crime and quiet the fears of residents, the city of Miami Beach is installing televison cameras to monitor its streets.

title: SOVIET MOSLEMS DEMAND A BIGGER PIECE OF THE PIE
description: The Uzbek chairman of the big cotton-growing Madaniyat collective farm spoke proudly of the fertility of his land and its Moslem women.

title: Bucks 98, Cavaliers 96
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Sidney Moncrief scored 12 of his game-high 28 points in the fourth quarter as Milwaukee rallied. After trailing by 7 points entering the final quarter, the Bucks took a 97-93 lead on a jump shot by Quinn Buckner with 1 minute 15 seconds to play. But Bobby Wilkerson scored on a 20-foot shot that brought the Cavaliers to within 2 points, 97-95, with 1:01 left.

title: Letter: On Human Rights Chile Doesn't Deserve U.S. Military Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Grain Woes Persist
description: The Soviet Union is continuing to import large quantities of grain and improvise in other ways to protect its domestic livestock industry, the Agriculture Department said Friday.

title: TRAFFIC ON ROADS IS DISRUPTED IN FRANKFURT AIRPORT PROTEST
description: Thousands of people opposing construction of a third runway at Frankfurt International Airport disrupted automobile traffic near the airport today and forced airport officials to partially close the airport, which is Europe's second-largest.

title: TRUDEAU AND LEVESQUE EXCHANGE TAUNTS AND INSULTS ON CHARTER PLAN
description: Premier Rene Levesque of Quebec and Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau traded taunts and insults over a distance of 150 miles yesterday and in the end showed that they are a world apart on a new Canadian constitution.

title: NJ Transit Plans New Bus Garage
description: NEWARK (AP) - NJ Transit, the state's mass-transit agency, says it plans to build a new bus garage near Freehold that is expected to save the agency $1 million a year.

title: Stock Table Unavailable
description: Because of transmission problems, the table of most active stocks for the week of Friday, Nov.13, does not appear today.

title: ARAFAT SAYS ISRAEL WILL RAID LEBANON
description: The Palestinian guerrilla leader, Yasir Arafat, said yesterday that he had ordered a mobilization of his troops in Lebanon in anticipation of what he called an imminent Israeli attack.

title: Loan to Quebec
description: The National Bank of Canada and a group of 48 Canadian and international financial institutions have made a 12-year loan of $500 million (in Canadian currency) and $250 million (United States currency) to the Province of Quebec. The Canadian funds carry interest at the prime rate for the first five years, the prime plus an eighth of a point for the next five and the prime plus a quarter of a point for the last two years. The United States funds carry interest at the London inter-bank offered rate plus three-eighths of a point for the first five years, with premiums of half a point for the next five years and five-eighths of a point for the final two years.

title: Lions 27, Cowboys 24
description: Ed Murray kicked a 47-yard field goal on the last play of the game to give Detroit (5-6) an upset victory. The field goal was Murray's 17th in 23 attempts this season.

title: SABRES CONQUER BRUINS
description: Yvon Lambert and Jim Schoenfeld each scored in the third period and lifted the Buffalo Sabres to a 3-1 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight.

title: News Analysis
description: The guessing game surrounding the peace plan of Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Fahd -would he or would he not recognize Israel? - has been generating considerable impatience here, mainly because Israelis think they know the answer very well. Optimism comes hard to a country besieged, vilified and repeatedly attacked by hostile neighbors over the decades. The impulse is to hear the Arab voices of extremism and to dismiss those of moderation, to see radicalism as reality and conciliation as duplicity.

title: Hecht & Partners
description: The 14-year-old Hecht, Higgins & Petterson today will become Arthur Hecht & Partners, which is sensible because Walter Higgins and Lewis Petterson are elsewhere. The agency, with $8 million in billings, specializes in making cable television ads. The agency has also formed three subsidiaries, two of which produce programs for cable and radio and a third that will publish advertising-supported books on sports and other leisure activities.

title: DILUTING VOTING RIGHTS
description: When is an endorsement not an endorsement? The answer is: when President Reagan backs extension of the Voting Rights Act of 1965. The President's ''endorsement'' of extending the act, which expires in 1982, was qualified with backing for amendments that would weaken the act.

title: THE 'MYTH' OF MOTHER LOVE IS CHALLENGED
description: Once in a blue moon, somebody comes along who touches a deep nerve in almost everyone. Such a person is Elisabeth Badinter, the 37-yearold wife of France's Minister of Justice and the mother of three children. She has written a book challenging the widespread, deeply held conviction that mother instinct is inborn and universal, arousing a storm of controversy in France.

title: FEDERAL FINANCING FOR STATE'S PARKS CUT FROM BUDGET
description: All $15.4 million in Federal funds for New York State parks has been eliminated as part of the Reagan Administration's budget cuts, according to the State Parks and Recreation Commissioner.

title: WALLACE URGED TO TRY '82 ALABAMA GOVERNOR RACE
description: Three or four dozen supporters of former Gov. George C. Wallace were busy last week urging him to return to the political wars next year and seek a fourth term as Governor, but, in what may have been a sign of changing times and political forces in this bastion of Deep South conservatism, few people seemed to care.

title: ARGUELLO WANDERS INTO RING HISTORY
description: TUCSON, Ariz. THE police officers arrived while Alexis Arguello was cooling off in the center of the ring. The world lightweight champion was wearing the striped robe that made him look like a hooded Bedouin, a modern wanderer, when the officers came through the door. Take everything down, they ordered. The punching bags, the corner pads, the weights. The gym was reserved for Police Athletic League amateurs, not the champion of the world. Everybody out on the street. No time for showers. Out.

title: EAGLES SEND COLTS TO 10TH STRAIGHT DEFEAT
description: The Eagles defeated the Baltimore Colts, 38-13, yesterday in Philadelphia, handing the Colts their 10th straight defeat and rendering false any accusations of complacency on the part of the Eagles.
To the Editor:

title: BIG MADRID RALLY OPPOSES NATO ENTRY
description: Tens of thousands of Spaniards marched today in one of the biggest demonstrations since the death of Francisco Franco. The march, organized by the Socialist Workers Party, was to press for a national referendum on the Government's plan for Spain to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Commodities; Amex's Push Into Options
description: WHEN the American Stock Exchange sought permission last week to open an options market in certificates of deposit, the move signaled more than an attempt by the Amex to participate in the fast-growing market for these 90-day domestic-bank debt instruments. It also was a move by the Amex to offer new products and become an ''investment supermarket.''

title: Navy Reports Errant Missile Was Destroyed by an Officer
description: A Trident missile fired from a submerged submarine in a test veered off course today and had to be destroyed by a range safety officer, the Navy said.

title: Five Ad Challenges End in Withdrawals
description: The National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus has reported that of the 11 challenges to national advertising claims settled in October, five were resolved when the advertisers either changed the claim or dropped the advertising.

title: New Raboy Account
description: The first packaged-goods account for Epstein Raboy Advertising has just come through the door: the E.T. Bowne Drug Company of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., maker of the Palmer's line of Cocoa Butter Formula Moisturizing cream and soap, Hair Success Treatment and Skin Success soaps. The account, previously with the Howard Goldstein Organization, has been billing about $50,000, according to Leading National Advertisers, but the client said it would spend more than $1 million next year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of Montreal has named George E. Neal executive vice president and treasurer; William B. Bateman general manager, world corporate banking group, and Carson G. Stratton general manager, North American corporate banking group. * Cordis Dow Corp., a joint venture of the Dow Chemical Co. and the Cordis Corp., has named Robert E. Monica president and chief executive officer.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It sure did disappoint us because we were just beginning to get the hang of it.'' - Capt. Richard H. Truly, whose space shuttle mission was cut short. (A1:4.)

title: Question BoxS. Lee Kanner
description: QUESTION: How does the speed and impact of a baseball that strikes a batter at 94 miles an hour compare with that of a punch thrown by a heavyweight fighter?

title: U.S. AGENCIES VARY ON RIGHTS POLICY
description: The three Federal agencies that enforce the nation's civil rights laws are pursuing markedly different policies toward affirmative action, in which employers take steps to increase opportunities for women and minority groups.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A LA GREC

title: HELP FOR THE MENTALLY ILL, EVEN DESPITE THE LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DANCE: PETER SPARLING
description: dance makers who'd try a solo about Vincent van Gogh or a dance for four voluptuously impassioned muses. Peter Sparling did, and brought it off, in a concert by his company on Friday at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: ABORTION: FACING THE BASIC QUESTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Cardinals 24, Bills 0
description: ST. LOUIS (AP) - Ottis Anderson pounded for two touchdowns on a rushing performance of 177 yards in leading the Cardinals to an upset.

title: Bridge: Negative Double Can Ruin An Opportunity for Penalty
description: Virtually all American experts use negative doubles when an opponent overcalls an opening bid of one of a suit. This solves many problems for the opener's partner, but it does sometimes permit a juicy penalty to remain unplucked.

title: COUGARS CAN WIN BOWL BID
description: Washington State beat California, 19-0, Saturday, and became the Pacific-10 Conference team to control its own destiny when its archrival, Washington, upset Southern California, 13-3, in stormy weather at Seattle.

title: W.B. Doner Sues 3 Former Employees
description: W.B. Doner & Company filed suit last week in the Circuit Court of Baltimore against three former employees and a former client's employee who have set up an ad agency and are doing business with two former Doner clients.

title: RANGERS LOSE, 5-3
description: It took more than Wayne Gretzky for the Edmonton Oilers to defeat the Rangers, 5-3, last night at Madison Square Garden. It took superb goaltending, and the Oilers had that, too, as Grant Fuhr, a 19-year-old rookie, turned back an admirable but unavailing Ranger attack late in the third period to preserve the lead that Gretzky helped to build.

title: Record Maruzen Loss
description: The Maruzen Oil Company posted a loss of 73.8 billion yen ($327 million) in the first half of its fiscal year, ended Sept. 30, the largest six-month loss ever reported by a company listed on Japan's stock exchanges. The refiner, which relies heavily on relatively higher-priced non-Saudi Arabian crude oil, had a 23.7 billion yen loss in the year ended last March.

title: De La Rose, Silveyville Win
description: De La Rose, the odds-on favorite and the only filly in the race, captured the first section of the Hollywood Derby by a neck today, and the longest shot in the second division, Silveyville, was also a winner.

title: TAX LAW SPURS GIVING IN '81
description: A major donor to the University of Miami's School of Medicine recently took steps to take advantage of the new tax law. Rather than spread a sizable gift over several years, as originally planned, he arranged to pay off the entire pledge in the final months of 1981.

title: Raiders 33, Dolphins 17
description: MIAMI (AP) - Marc Wilson threw three touchdown passes, all in the first half, when Oakland (4-6) built a 21-3 lead. With less than two minutes gone, Wilson, a second-year pro from Brigham Young, threw a 13-yard scoring pass to Todd Christensen.

title: Big Textile Deficit Seen
description: The United States will have a $5.4 billion textile and apparel trade deficit this year, its largest in history, according to Robert E. Coleman, president of the American Textile Manufacturers Institute.

title: MICHAEL J. PETERSEN
description: Michael Joseph Petersen, a free-lance photographer, died early yesterday of cardiac arrest at New York Hospital. He was 28 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: OVER 900 FEDERAL PUBLICATIONS HALTED
description: In complying with the Reagan Administration's order to eliminate unnecessary spending on publications, Federal agencies have canceled more than 900 periodicals and recurring pamphlets, and more cuts are expected next year.

title: ANALYSTS SAY RALLY WILL LAST
description: CREDIT-MARKETS By VARTANIG G. VARTAN

title: 12 SHOTS FIRED INTO L.I. RESIDENCE OF SOVIET ENVOY TO UNITED NATIONS
description: Twelve shots were fired through window panes of the Long Island mansion of the Soviet delegate to the United Nations Saturday evening, according to the Nassau County police.

title: BLUE CHIPS ON MARGIN
description: MARKET PLACE By ROBERT METZ

title: Margiotta Retrial Begins Today
description: Joseph Margiotta, leader of the Nassau County Republican organization, returns to Federal District Court today for a retrial on charges that he used his office to benefit his party financially.

title: Private Colleges Report Drop in Total Freshmen
description: Freshman enrollment at private colleges and universities fell 2 percent this fall, largely because of cuts in Federal student aid, the National Institute of Independent Colleges and Universities said today.

title: RED HOOK SURVIVES HARD TIMES INTO NEW ERA
description: Red Hook, Brooklyn's legendary waterfront, survived generations of poor immigrants, brawling workers and union corruption, only to be nearly destroyed by government decisions. It is now beginning a renaissance, this time aided by government.

title: RECOVERY OF BOOSTERS FROM SHUTTLE STALLED BY BROKEN TOW LINE
description: A tow line that snapped in rough seas today became the latest problem to stall the recovery of the two empty booster rockets that helped push the space shuttle Columbia into orbit last week.

title: Pan Am Will Resume Its Flights at Newark
description: Pan American World Airways, which suspended service at Newark Airport last month, is planning to restore service to and from the airport by February, its officials said today.

title: A DURABLE WINNER
description: On the first series of plays against Penn State Saturday, Alabama had a fourth down and less than a yard to go at its 45-yard line. It never considered punting. After a timeout for consultation with Coach Bear Bryant, the quarterback Alan Gray set the team in a tight wishbone. It seemed apparent to Penn State that Alabama would try a dive play for the first down. Suddenly Gray backpedaled before the snap from center, and the three running backs took a step toward the line. It was a legal shift, and it drew the entire Penn State defensive front offside, resulting in a 5-yard penalty and a first down. The cunning tactic had been used many times by Bryant.

title: ESKIMOS BEAT LIONS, ADVANCE TO GREY CUP
description: Warren Moon threw a 33-yard touchdown pass to Brian Kelly with a little more than five minutes left in the game today to give the Edmonton Eskimos a 22-16 victory over the British Columbia Lions in the Canadian Football League Western Division final.

title: DANCE: DIANE GERMAINE TROUPE AT RIVERSIDE
description: DIANE GERMAINE assembled a good-looking company for Thursday night's performance by Diane Germaine and Dancers at the Theater of the Riverside Church. But, possibly to indicate that she had more than prettiness on her mind, she subtitled her dances ''antipoems.'' And these antipoems always turned violent.

title: STOCK LIST REVAMPED BY NASDAQ
description: The Nasdaq national list of over-the-counter stock quotations is being revised because of changes in the criteria that companies must meet to qualify for the list. The over-the-counter tables in The New York Times will reflect this change in tomorrow's issue.

title: SOVIET GAIN IN POLAND'S I.M.F. LINK
description: The Soviet Union, looking at what could be large costs it would have to bear if the Polish economy collapsed, acquiesced to Polish membership in the International Monetary Fund to limit future drains on the Soviet economy and open the door to more Western assistance, American and European analysts believe.

title: Polish Union Challenging Electoral Procedures
description: In a challenge to existing electoral procedures, Solidarity leaders in the industrial region of Silesia have called on their members to begin selecting candidates for local government councils.

title: REPORT ON A-BOMB SAFEGUARDS: GROSS DEFICIENCIES
description: A report to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has concluded that the international system of safeguards intended to stop the diversion of uranium and plutonium from peaceful nuclear programs to atomic weapons has gross deficiencies.

title: MANY NEW FINANCINGS ON THE WEEK'S CALENDAR
description: A huge supply of new issues is set to reach the public market this week as corporations take advantage of the recent sharp decline in borrowing costs. Today alone, more than $900 million in notes, debentures and bonds are on the calendar for public sale.

title: Boston Power Is Back
description: A 31-hour blackout ended this morning as power was restored to the last of 6,500 affected customers.

title: T.V.A. Nuclear Reactor Suffers a Rod Problem
description: One of 50 control rods in a new reactor at the Sequoyah nuclear plant failed to seat properly last night, the Tennessee Valley Authority said.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 16, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: HINCKLEY ATTEMPTS TO HANG HIMSELF IN CELL AT FORT MEADE
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., the 26-year-old drifter accused of attempting to assassinate President Reagan on March 30, tried to hang himself in his cell today at nearby Fort Meade, Md., but was quickly cut down by Federal marshals, the Justice Department said.

title: Jersey's Senate To Elect Officers
description: TRENTON (AP) - Democrats in the State Senate have agreed to name Carmen A. Orechio of Nutley as Senate President and Steven P. Perskie of Margate as majority leader, Senator Orechio said yesterday.

title: Washington Watch; Textiles: New Test for Brock
description: WASHINGTON THE threat of a breakdown in negotiations aimed at setting new rules for international trade in textiles presents another major test for Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, who was criticized by White House aides after the automobile settlement with Japan.

title: Was the Cap Blue?
description: Cindy Blasier knew something was wrong as soon as she got home from the hospital. When she started to change her new baby's diaper, she realized that it was a girl she had taken home.

title: Trials of Juvenile Justice
description: No one should be surprised that the New York Community Service Society has found considerable mismanagement and inefficiency in the agencies that comprise the juvenile justice system. The Family Court, the Corporation Counsel's office and the Probation Department perform a thankless mission on pinch-penny budgets. But they also suffer from a deeper problem: a scarcity of options for dealing with troubled children.

title: Judith R. London Wed to Eli N. Evans
description: Judith Rachel London, an advisory officer with the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association/College Retirement Equities Fund, was married at the St. Moritz yesterday to Eli N. Evans, president of the Charles H. Revson Foundation. Rabbi Malcolm H. Stern performed the ceremony.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1981
description: International A vote on Spain's joining NATO is sought by the Socialist Workers Party, which organized one of the biggest demonstrations since the death of Franco to support its demand for the vote. Tens of thousands of people marched in Madrid. The party leader, in a keynote speech, said, ''What will the allied countries of NATO say when they see that half a million people have gathered in Madrid to say that they do not want to go into NATO without a referendum?'' (Page A3:4-6.) Mobilization of the P.L.O.'s troops in Lebanon was ordered by Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian guerrilla leader, in anticipation of what he said was an imminent attack Israeli attack. He made the announcement in a speech to Palestinian students, who form part of the military ranks of the Palestine Liberation Organization. He said he had told the Arab League that the P.L.O. would accept no curbs on guerrilla armament and that he had informed the United Nations that he had rejected a proposal for an increase in the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon. (A3:1-3.)

title: Highlights in Jazz Series Features Red Norvo
description: The ''Soft Swinging Sounds'' that provided the title for the Highlights in Jazz concert at the Loeb Auditorium on Thursday evening also provided this long-running jazz series with one of its best and best-balanced programs.

title: TV: 'GOLIATH AWAITS,' UNDERSEA YARN
description: EVEN if you have never discovered a long-submerged submarine carrying 337 mysterious survivors - and, let's face it, you probably haven't - you can imagine how it might go. Or at least how it goes in ''Goliath Awaits,'' a bland television movie with plenty of skindiving sequences but few surprises. A two-hour installment of ''Goliath Awaits'' will be shown tonight at 8 on WPIX, Channel 11, with a second installment next week. That isn't long to wait for the rest of the story, in view of the fact that half of its characters have been waiting for 40 years.

title: A World to Feed 15th article of a series appearing; periodically.
description: The roads leading out of the capital north toward the tiny towns in the Nile delta bump past neat, square fields of cotton and rice, occasional processions of camels and buffaloes turning waterwheels in the shade of huge billboards for Pepsi and Toyotas. Like the well-stocked produce markets in Cairo, the rural scene conveys an impression of abundance. But in fact the Egyptian fellaheen, or peasants, produce only a little more than half the food consumed in the country. Egyptians, more than almost any other people in the developing world, are dependent upon foreign countries and food aid for their daily bread.

title: HEAD OF LARK LUGGAGE
description: Matt D. Chamlin, 42 years old, who will join the New York-based Lark Luggage Company on Dec. 1 as president, knows pretty well what he will be facing in his new slot. "I'm going to be focusing on finding a long-term strategic direction for the company, with particular emphasis on broadening the base," he said.

title: Handicapped Horse
description: Will America's hard-bitten rail birds accept a horse in the Kentucky Derby who has only one eye and suffers from claustrophobia? They may have to.

title: Teamster Vote Voided
description: An election by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in the nation's largest teamster local has been voided by regional directors, who decided that the members may have avoided voting because ballots were not secret. Ballots for the September election in the 12,000-member Local 748 were numbered and the same number and the member's name appeared on return envelopes.

title: Snow Plow First at Aqueduct
description: It was a perfect day at the races yesterday - chilly, sleeting and depressingly gray - for a daughter of Royal Ski named Snow Plow to win the Demoiselle Stakes at Aqueduct.

title: BENGALS WIN NO. 8, BEATING RAMS, 24-10
description: Off to their best start since 1976, when they won nine of their first 11 games, the Cincinnati Bengals tenaciously held onto their two-game lead in the American Conference's Central Division yesterday with a 24-10 victory over the Los Angeles Rams in Cincinnati.

title: SHUTTLE WEATHERS ITS SECOND MISSION WITH LESS DAMAGE
description: After a preliminary inspection, space agency officials said today that the space shuttle Columbia suffered ''considerably less'' visible wear and tear on its second flight than on its first. They said it should be ready for another trip in March.

title: THE CALENDER
description: Monday

title: News Analysis
description: When Mayor Koch talks these days of improving mass transit, he stops short of the ultimate weapon - a city takeover of the troubled subway and bus system that each day carries 3.5 million passengers.

title: COALITION IN JERSEY SEEKS EVIDENCE OF VOTER FEARS
description: Democratic Party officials in New Jersey, aided by labor unions, church groups and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, organized a network of volunteers this weekend to find examples of intimidation at the polls by the National Ballot Security Task Force.

title: No Headline
description: WEIDENBAUM SEES MORE JOBLESSNESS

title: BRITISH AIDE CALLS FOR CALM AFTER SLAYING BY I.R.A.
description: The British Cabinet member responsible for Northern Ireland went on the radio today to make an urgent appeal for calm after the Irish Republican Army's killing of a Unionist Member of Parliament in Belfast yesterday.

title: LABOR CHIEF SEEKS INVESTMENT POWER
description: Control over pension, welfare and other funds is a far more effective tool for labor unions than participation on boards of directors, according to Lane Kirkland, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations. Excerpts from interview, page B12.

title: DOWN, 3-0, FLYERS BEAT ISLANDERS, 5-4
description: The largest crowd to see a hockey game in the Spectrum, 17,092, and 18 Philadelphia Flyers presented too great a barrier for the Islanders tonight, and New York's unbeaten road streak ended in a 5-4 loss.

title: Libya Criticizes Exxon Move
description: Libya accused The Exxon Corporation of breaching its contract and Libyan law by relinquishing its concessions in Libya, but its national oil company said the dispute might be resolved through negotiations.

title: Players Lift Barrier
description: ''As usual,'' Dorothy Stickney was saying yesterday afternoon, ''I'm a little terrified.'' Butterflies in the stomach are a familiar opening night hazard, but what was making Miss Stickney nervous wasn't a new play, but an unusual honor - her own ''pipe night'' at The Players.

title: Steelers 34, Falcons 20
description: ATLANTA (AP) - Pittsburgh's Terry Bradshaw threw five touchdown passes, a personal record for his 13-year career. Bradshaw, who completed 14 of 22 attempts for 253 yards, threw scoring passes of 6 and 19 yards to John Stallworth, 18 yards to Bennie Cunningham, 14 to Randy Grossman, and 22 yards to Lynn Swann.

title: STAGE: 'CAMELOT' IS BACK WITH RICHARD HARRIS
description: MAYBE there can be ''Camelot'' without Richard Burton, but it didn't happen in the revival that opened at the Winter Garden last night. While this is, in broad outline, the same production that Mr. Burton brought to the New York State Theater 17 months ago, it is now ruled by Richard Harris as King Arthur. Mr. Harris is by no means an abject pretender to the throne - in fact, he previously occupied it in the Hollywood version of the Alan Jay Lerner-Frederick Loewe musical - but his performance is at odds with the very essence of the show's appeal.

title: COLUMBIA ASTRONAUTS TELL BUSH OF MISSION LETDOWN
description: Joe H. Engle and Richard H. Truly, the shuttle astronauts, told Vice President Bush today that they were disappointed by the early ending of the Columbia's mission ''because we were just getting the hang of it.''

title: U.S. Post in Taiwan Filled
description: James R. Lilley, a career intelligence officer with the Central Intelligence Agency, has been appointed director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan, it was announced today. The institute was established under the Taiwan Relations Act as the vehicle for dealings with the Nationalist Government after President Jimmy Carter broke diplomatic relations with Taiwan in January 1979. Mr. Lilley replaces Charles T. Cross, who has resigned.

title: PENNSYLVANIA BLACKS' LIFE ILLUMINATED
description: With obvious pleasure, two museum officials contemplated a portrait of Abraham Lincoln standing against a desk. It was unframed and grimy from years of neglect.

title: WILLAMETTE PROMOTION
description: William Swindells Jr., the 51-year-old president of Willamette Industries, a wood and paper products producer, has been named to the additional position of chief executive officer, effective Jan 1. He will succeed Gene D. Hnudson, who will be 65 and will continue as chairman of the company, which has its headquarters in Portland, Ore.

title: Crimea Battered by Storm
description: A storm caused serious damage to hundreds of homes, factories and farms on the Crimean coast last week. The trade-union newspaper Trud said today that a hurricane hit the Black Sea peninsula with such force Tuesday that a 5,000-ton cargo ship was thrown ashore at the port of Yevpatoria. There were no fatalities, the newspaper said.

title: Vikings 20, Saints 10
description: Tommy Kramer surpassed 10,000 yards in career passing, throwing for 287 and a touchdown. Ted Brown ran for another Viking score.

title: Ohio Raises Sales Taxes, Covers Labor Charges
description: The largest tax increase in Ohio history went into effect today, raising the sales tax and adding taxes to such things as automobile repairs and installation of cable television.

title: ACTION ON ANTIBUSING BILL PRESSED IN CONGRESS
description: Efforts are gathering steam in Congress to pass legislation that would virtually ban busing as a way of desegregating public schools.

title: More Foxes for the Chicken Coops
description: Somebody is still trying to sabotage the Reagan Administration from within. It's probably the person the President accused of creating the impression of heartless foolishness by defining ketchup as a school-lunch vegetable. Instead of firing the culprit, they must have transferred him/her to Personnel.

title: Pahlevis Inquire About New England Schools
description: Princess Farahnaz, the 18-year-old daughter of the late Shah of Iran, has made inquiries about enrolling in Bennington College in Vermont and representatives of her family have also been looking into schools nearby for another family member.

title: '73 UPRISING IS MARKED IN ATHENS
description: A crowd estimated at 100,000 marched on the United States Embassy today to commemorate the 1973 uprising against the Greek military dictatorship.

title: THE POLITICAL HUSBAND IS A RARITY NO LONGER
description: At the age of 51, John J. O'Connor 3d found himself looking for a job. His wife, Sandra Day O'Connor, had been appointed to the Supreme Court, a lifetime job, and unless he planned to spend the rest of his days commuting back to Phoenix where he was a partner in a prestigious corporate law firm, it meant relocating.

title: Broadway Stars to Give A 'New Moon' Benefit
description: Broadway performers, including Estelle Parsons, John Reardon, Meg Bussert and Debbie Shapiro, will head the cast of ''The New Moon,'' the 1928 operetta hit by Sigmund Romberg and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, next Monday at 8:30 P.M. in Town Hall.

title: BAY STATE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nassau Drops Todd Case
description: Denis Dillon, the Nassau County District Attorney, has decided not to act on the criminal-assault charges filed against the Jets' Richard Todd by Steve Serby, a reporter for The New York Post.

title: BISHOPS DEBATE STRATEGY ON ABORTION BATTLE
description: An unexpected debate over strategies to combat legalized abortion erupted at today's opening session of the annual meeting of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops.

title: Belgium Budget Deficit
description: Belgium is heading for a 1982 budget current account deficit of about $111.8 billion compared with a target ceiling of about $74 billion, Prime Minister Mark Eyskens said in an interview in the newspaper De Standard.

title: VAN DYK RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard BISMARCK. By Edward Crankshaw. Illus- trated. 451 pages. Viking. $19.95.

title: Advertising; 'Life Style' Magazines Prospering
description: THE happiest publishers in town appear to be the ones running the four major fashion magazines, although some of them no longer like that designation. ''Life style'' magazine is the label they prefer.

title: INTERNATIONAL GAME TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
QUOTATIONS OF THE DAY
description: ''Rather than allow freedom of religion, they'd forbid any religion whatsoever.'' - Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, supporting the amendment. (A22:4.)

title: Lawmakers to Weigh Carey's Tax-Bill Veto
description: The State Legislature will return to the capital on Dec. 3 and may attempt to override Governor Carey's veto of a bill to reform the state's property-tax assessment laws, legislative aides confirmed today.

title: THREE MORE COAST DEATHS LINKED TO OVERDOSES OF A HEART DRUG
description: The authorities investigating the deaths of 27 aged patients at two rural hospitals near Los Angeles have linked three more of the deaths to overdoses of a heart drug, lidocaine. This raises the number of deaths attributed to overdoses of the drug to 12, or nearly half of the cases under investigation.

title: REGAN OPENS TALKS IN CHINA
description: A high-level American delegation led by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan opened discussions today with Chinese officials on a full range of economic and commercial issues affecting China and the United States.

title: Baldrige Sees Near-Term Economic Lag
description: Recovery from the nation's recession is still months away, with ''a tough first quarter'' of 1982 likely to follow an even worse final quarter of 1981 before the economy picks up, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today.

title: CANADA APPROVES HARVESTER UNIT SALE
description: The Canadian Government said yesterday that it had approved the sale of the International Harvester Corporation's Solar Turbines Canada division to a Canadian unit of the Caterpillar Tractor Company.

title: SHUTTLE'S RETURN TO FLORIDA IS BEHIND SCHEDULE
description: Preparations to move the space shuttle Columbia back to its launching base in Florida fell behind schedule today largely because ground crews were not ready for the spaceship's early return to Earth, the space agency said.

title: OPEC Panel Sets Meeting
description: The oil strategy committee of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet this weekend in Vienna to discuss future approaches to supply and pricing, the Austrian news agency said today.

title: Talking Business with Jones of Northrop; The Business Of Defense
description: The Defense Department recently selected the Northrop Corporation as prime contractor for the initial development of the Stealth bomber, known as the advanced technology bomber. During the mid-1970's, the company underwent Congressional scrutiny over questionable overseas payments. Here, Thomas V. Jones, Northrop's chairman and chief executive, discusses the effect of that inquiry within the company, as well as the problems of dealing with the Federal Government.

title: Chemical Bank Has Gold Card
description: The Chemical Bank will begin marketing a new, ''upscale'' MasterCard later this week, according to Wilbert Primosch, vice president.

title: TV: 'SKOKIE,' NAZIS MARCH IN ILLINOIS
description: TONIGHT'S two-and-a-half-hour television movie on CBS, beginning at 8 o'clock, is ''Skokie,'' a dramatization of what happened in a Chicago suburb in 1977-78 when a small group of American Nazis threatened to hold a public demonstration. Skokie had special significance as the planned site. Of its 70,000 residents, about 30,000 are Jewish, and many of them are Holocaust survivors. The inevitable confrontations generated national headlines.

title: NICARAGUA'S ODD CELLMATES REFLECT BATTLE FOR MINDS
description: In a former industrial park outside Managua, where large warehouses have been turned into improvised prisons, three of Nicaragua's leading businessmen and a score of prominent Communists are sharing a clean but overcrowded cell.

title: Indian Point 3 Back on Line After Two-Month Shutdown
description: The State Power Authority announced today that its Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant in Buchanan had been returned to service after a shutdown of more than two months.

title: ELSCINT LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Exxon Completes Georges Bank Well
description: The Exxon Corporation has finished drilling a 14,000-foot-deep exploratory well in the Georges Bank fishing grounds off Cape Cod, but company officials said it would be several weeks before they announced whether they had found any oil or natural gas.

title: IMPERIALE CALLED A CHIEF IN G.O.P. POLL 'SECURITY'
description: The Essex County Prosecutor said today that Assemblyman Anthony Imperiale had been identified as having been in charge of ''street operations'' for a Republican ballot-security task force in Newark on Election Day.

title: SUNDANCE OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN PLAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $59,000 for the qr and $481,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including extraordinary credits of $132,000 for the qr and $280,000 for the 9 mos

title: NEW CHIEF FOR CORADIAN
description: State Senator Joseph L. Bruno of New York, a 51-year-old co-founder of the Coradian Corporation, has been elected chairman of its executive committee and chief executive officer.

title: WEINBERGER GIVES PLEDGE ON ISRAEL
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger declared last night that the United States would try to find ''bits and pieces for agreement'' in any plan for peace in the Middle East, but that it would insist on formal explicit recognition of Israel's right to exist.

title: DIGITAL RECORDING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including interest income of $12,253 for the qr and $158,279 for the 9 mos...C-There were no revs in the yr-ago periods

title: INDIANA STANDARD APPOINTS PRESIDENT OF CANADIAN UNIT
description: Norman J. Rubash, 49, has been named president of the Amoco Canada Petroleum Company, based in Calgary, Alberta, effective Dec. 15. The company is the Canadian subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana). Mr. Rubash will succeed Fraser H. Allen, 63, who is retiring after more than 41 years with the Indiana Standard organization.

title: Columbia to Face L.I.U.  In First N.C.A.A. Game
description: Columbia will visit Long Island University on Sunday in a first-round game of the Division I soccer championships, the National Collegiate Athletic Association announced today.t

title: More Zairian Troops Are Flown to Chad
description: Several hundred more Zairian soldiers arrived in this capital today, bringing the strength of the Pan-African peacekeeping force for Chad to 700, military sources said.

title: LEATHER: LUXURY FOR ALL SEASONS
description: The leather juggernaut is moving along. So many designers presented leather styles in their spring collections and so attractive were their suggestions that it seems likely few women will be able to resist adding at least one piece of leather clothing to their wardrobes in the months ahead. And the chances are they will go on wearing it through the summer.

title: Fugitive Turns Up In Persico Case
description: Andrew Russo, a reputed mobster who disappeared early this year and was believed by Federal authorities to have been slain, appeared in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday and pleaded not guilty in a bribery case involving his cousin, Carmine Persico.

title: ASSAD ASSERTS SYRIA IS SEEKING 'PEACE WITH JUSTICE'
description: President Hafaz al-Assad of Syria said today that his Government wanted peace based on justice in the Middle East and not on what he described as Israeli terms backed by the United States.

title: Liver Replaced, Girl, 2 1/2, Improves
description: PITTSBURGH (AP) - A 2 1/2-year-old girl whose diseased liver was replaced with that of a little boy is ''improving as expected,'' according to a spokesman for Children's Hospital.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Armco Inc. said it filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed public offering of $100 million in notes due in 1986, to be sold through a Smith Barney, Harris Upham group.

title: TRILLING 'INVITATION' CHARGE DENIED BY LILLIAN HELLMAN
description: Lillian Hellman yesterday denied an assertion by Diana Trilling that ''anyone who entertains me on Martha's Vineyard is never again invited to Lillian Hellman's house.'' Mrs. Trilling made the statemnt while discussing her long-standing political differences with Miss Hellman in an interview published yesterday in The New York Times.

title: WILLIAMS AND HIS STAFF AWAIT SENATE'S VERDICT
description: Outwardly, it seems like any other Senate office. The telephones jangle, tourists stop by for free Senate gallery passes and a Hazeltine computer churns out letters on the recent Awacs vote.

title: No Headline
description: ROZELLE ADMITS SCALPING WOES

title: MOST BANKS CUT PRIME RATE TO 16 1/2%
description: This autumn's steady easing of interest rates gathered new momentum yesterday as most of the nation's major banks lowered their prime lending rate to 16 1/2 percent from 17 percent and the Crocker National Bank of San Francisco cut its rate a full percentage point, to 16 percent.

title: REAGAN PROMISED TOO MUCH
description: Ronald Reagan appears to be falling victim to dashed expectations - the self-inflicted wound that may be the nemesis of modern Presidents.

title: 6-Week Walkout Ends at Legal Aid
description: Staff workers at the Legal Aid Society voted 233 to 57 to return to work after a strike that lasted nearly six weeks. The workers are members of District 1199 of the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees, A.F.L.-C.I.O. They include secretaries, messengers, translators, paralegals, social workers and educational consultants.

title: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A SAFEGUARD IN A LAW ON LIABILITY INSURANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERTHERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
BRIEFING
description: T HE Madison Group, a network of conservative Congressional aides who are hawks in foreign policy and the military field, is quietly seeking to organize support for the appointment of the Marine Corps commandant, Gen. Robert H. Barrow, as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. The current chairman, Gen. David C. Jones of the Air Force, will probably retire sometime next year. If appointed, General Barrow would be the first Marine ever named to the post.

title: KIRKLAND ASSAILS REAGAN'S POLICIES
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., sharply attacked the Reagan Administration yesterday, saying that the promised economic boom had turned out to be ''a bust.''

title: Cunningham 'Events' Set
description: The Merce Cunningham Dance Company will present a series of ''events'' at the Merce Cunningham Dance Studio, 55 Bethune Street, 11th Floor, starting tonight and running through Sunday.

title: Associated Press; SIXTY-TWO PROTESTERS ARRESTED AT PENTAGON:
description: AN officer stepping over some of the 2,000 demonstrators who nearly encircled the Pentagon yesterday. The protesters, most of them women, represented several causes

title: BOLAR PHARMACEUTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Quotations of the Day
description: ''All we'd be doing is inviting the states and local governments to produce all sorts of unconstitutional prayer programs.'' - Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut, opposing voluntaryprayer legislation. (A22:4.)

title: Illinois High Court Bars Service Tax for Transit
description: A 1 percent service tax imposed by the Chicago City Council last summer to help provide money for the city's mass transit system was ruled unconstitutional today by the Illinois Supreme Court.

title: ALTMAN SIGNS SIX ACTRESSES
description: Robert Altman, known for imaginative casting as a film director, is carrying on in the same spirit for his Broadway debut as a stage director. He has signed an impressive group of actresses - Sandy Dennis, Cher, Karen Black, Sudie Bond, Kathy Bates and Marta Heflin - to star in Ed Graczyk's new play, ''Come Back to the 5 and Dime, Jimmy Dean, Jimmy Dean.'' The production will go into rehearsal on Dec. 28 and open on Feb. 18.

title: CHAMPION PARTS REBUILDERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; net losses for the latest qr and 6 mos reflect $462,000 in expenses from plant closing and relocation

title: Johnson Works Out
description: Eddie Johnson, the Atlanta Hawks' star guard, practiced with the team for the first time in six weeks and said it would be ''only a matter of time'' before he was ready to play. Johnson had not practiced since Oct. 5 and was suspended indefinitely Oct. 29 following psychiatric care at an Atlanta hospital.

title: Williams, Padres Will Meet
description: Dick Williams, whose name is often associated with the Yankees' managing job, plans to travel today to San Diego, where he very likely will be offered the Padres' managing job. ''If we chatted with him once and he's coming back, there must be a reason,'' Ballard Smith, president of the Padres, said yesterday.

title: Outdoor Fence Art
description: Good fences might have made good neighbors to Robert Frost, but to the sculptor Susannah Hardaway, fences of screen, barbed wire and feather constitute an art exhibition called ''Fences and Gates.'' It is on view at eight outdoor display cases on Eighth Avenue, between 53d and 54th Streets. The 10 sculptures, which include a solid wall, a fence with jagged edges and another that blends gray tones, can be seen free any hour of the day or night through Saturday.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: I T was a week of unveilings, not the least of which was that by Victor Edelstein, the British fashion designer, who presented his spring collection in the apartment that once belonged to George Gershwin. Mr. Edelstein is very tall and thin and wears bow ties. The vaulted ceilings, old paintings and chintz-covered furniture were perfect foils for his sparkling evening clothes. Mr. Edelstein, despite the English economy and the European socialists, is not about, he said, to give up on royalist finery. The best of his gowns were pleated in the manner of Fortuny. While many may be tired of that style, much misused by those who execute it in scratchy polyester, Mr. Edelstein's gowns are made of the creamiest silk. He has sculptured it into body-hugging tubes with triangular aprons and bodices that erupt at the shoulder into tendrils of fabric. Like the best fashion, Mr. Edelstein's gowns complement the body rather than obscure it. They will be at Bergdorf Goodman for around $1,000.

title: ADAMS DRUG CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated

title: Market Place; James River Deal Brewing
description: THE James River Paper Corporation, the nation's largest independent producer of specialty papers, may be ready to make its second major acquisition in just a little over a year. People in the financial community are betting that James River will buy the forest products division of the American Can Corporation.

title: Jeff-Boat Layoffs
description: Jeff-Boat Inc., the nation's largest inland boat works, will lay off 600 employees at the end of November, company officials said.

title: HELPING BUSINESS JAPANESE STYLE
description: His manner is reserved, almost stolid, and his dress is conservative - navy blue suit, french cuffs and the metal-framed glasses worn by so many Japanese businessmen. Yet Isao Nakauchi, the 59-year-old president of Daiei Inc., this nation's largest retailer, has been a kind of revolutionary in Japanese industry.

title: VIRCO MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 9
AMERICAN ISRAEL PAPER MILLS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the average exchange rate was 12.54 Israeli shekeis equals $1 for the latest second qr and 5.417 Israeli shkeis equals $1 for the yr-ago second qr

title: Broadcast Museum Showing TV Musicals
description: ''Music, Music, Music,'' a collection of television specials from the 1950's and 60's, featuring the music of Noel Coward, the Beatles, the Rolling Stones and others, will be shown over the next few months at the Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street.

title: Bonn Industry Orders
description: The growth of West German industry's orders from abroad is likely to slow in the next few months because of the rising value of the mark, the German Institute for Economic Research said. Exports will continue to underpin the economy while imports, supported by their cheaper prices, will decline slightly, the report said. Domestic orders have declined significantly in recent months and will remain low until the end of the year, it said.

title: NEW I.C.C. CHIEF FOCUS OF CRITICISM
description: Amid the deregulatory fervor in Washington these days, Reese H. Taylor Jr., the Reagan Administration's appointee as chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, has drawn criticism from Congressional leaders, and even senior Administration officials, for his lack of enthusiasm.

title: CAGNEY, 82, IS EMBARRASSED ANEW AT BEING A 'STAR'
description: JAMES CAGNEY came out of a 21-year-long retirement to play Police Commissioner Waldo in the movie ''Ragtime,'' and the world has responded by going Cagney-crazy.

title: SOVIET AIRLINE FLIGHTS HALTED BY U.S. FOR WEEK
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board suspended flights into the United States by the Soviet airline Aeroflot for a week today as a penalty for flying over ''sensitive areas'' in New England.

title: Moran Energy Discovers Gas
description: Moran Energy Inc. said it had discovered gas at its Darrington State Farm No. 1-A well in Brazoria County, Tex.

title: AIR EXPRESS INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NORTHGATE EXPLORATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; revs is metal production rev

title: SUNSTATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $313,000 for the qr and $662,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss

title: REPORT BY EL SALVADOR CRITICIZED
description: A Salvadoran Government report prepared for the families of four American churchwomen murdered in El Salvador last year was described today by Representative Mary Rose Oakar as disappointing, out of date and devoid of reliable sources.

title: Keenan's Chairman Joining Chester Gore
description: Michael E. Keenan, 47-year-old chairman and president of Keenan & McLaughlin, which is in the process of being disolved, has joined the 26-year-old Chester Gore Company as president. That means that the founder, Chester Gore, will step up to chairman and chief executive of the shop.

title: Israel Demolishes 3 Homes Of Arabs After Bomb Attacks
description: Israeli troops today blew up the homes of three Palestinian families of Arab teen-agers suspected of having thrown fire bombs at mobile patrols in the Bethlehem area.

title: BRIEFS
description: * African Coast Diamond and Minerals Ltd. and T.O.N.M. Oil and Gas Exploration Corp. said they had signed an agreement whereby T.O.N.M. will acquire a 50 percent interest in African Coast Diamond for about $11 million.

title: PUSH THAT NUCLEAR BUTTON-AND-DIE
description: To the Editor:

title: DEATH TOLL REACHES 48 IN MEXICO
description: The death toll in the collapse of a wall at a rally in a bullring where a politician was promising free stoves and refrigerators climbed to 48 today.

title: Fed Drops Surcharge on Bank Loans
description: The Federal Reserve Board today dropped the special two percentage point surcharge on loans that the Fed makes to frequent bank borrowers. The change, effective tomorrow, leaves the discount rate at 13 percent.

title: STEVE MACKO
description: Steve Macko, an infielder for the Chicago Cubs, died yesterday of cancer. He was 27 years old. Macko, a native of Burlington, Iowa, played briefly with the Cubs in 1979 and 1980, and had a .250 batting average.

title: Doctors Held in Dispute With Paramedic Aides
description: Two doctors have been arrested on charges of interfering with paramedics who were treating a heart attack victim at a hotel, officials say. The doctors say they were roughed up by the police.

title: The Right Response to $1,000
description: The special-prosecutor law, which the Reagan Administration finds an annoyance, is again proving its worth. When news broke last Friday that Richard Allen, the national security adviser, had received $1,000 from a Japanese magazine in connection with an interview with Nancy Reagan, the White House was ready to declare Mr. Allen exonerated - before most Americans had any idea what the charge might be.

title: WICHITA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock distribution on Nov 2, 1981

title: DUNLAP & ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Inquiry Opens in Sinking Of a Dutch Cruise Ship
description: An official inquiry into the sinking of the Dutch cruise ship Prinsendam opened today with a tribute to the 319 passengers who left the burning vessel at night aboard lifeboats in the storm-tossed Gulf of Alaska last year.

title: DEPRESSION: ELDERLY AND SINGLES SHOW UNEXPECTED STRENGTH
description: WITH depression the most widespread emotional illness in the United States, the National Institute of Mental Health began a series of collaborative studies of thousands of people in the early 1970's to understand its basic nature and compare the many methods used to treat it. Although these research efforts will continue at least through the middle of this decade at university centers around the country, some startling findings have already emerged.

title: SELECTION OF JURY BEGINS IN 2D TRIAL OF MARGIOTTA
description: Joseph M. Margiotta, the chairman of the Republican Party in Nassau County, went on trial today for the second time on Federal charges of fraud and extortion involving insurance commissions for county property.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Federated Will Scrap Division
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., the nation's largest department store chain, is discontinuing its Gold Triangle hard-goods specialty store division at the end of January, the company said.

title: Off With Their Heads
description: Maybe he didn't mean it. He was probably just upset. It was the day Mayor Koch learned that the voters had narrowly defeated something he had fought for - the proposed $500 million bond issue to build more prisons and, in his disappointment, he let fly: ''The people who led the fight against that bond issue have to have on their heads the crimes committed while those (criminals) are out of jail.''

title: FORD FUND GIVES $848,052 TO 23 WRITERS AND SCHOLARS
description: The Ford Foundation has awarded a total of $848,052 to 23 scholars and writers to support their writing of analytic books dealing with major issues and trends in contemporary society.

title: PENNEY, J C, CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $5 million in the qr and $15 million for the 9 mos

title: Some Cracks in Woody Allen's Celluloid Curtain
description: When Woody Allen makes a movie, he goes to great lengths to shroud it in mystery almost until the moment it is released, refusing to say what it is about or even to divulge its title.

title: An Idaho Insurer Agrees to Merger
description: The Continental Life and Accident Company has reached an agreement in principle to merge with the John Alden Life Insurance Company of Minnesota.

title: Stock Test Threatened; S.E.C. May Scrap Stock Market Test
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, faced by budget cuts, may have to scrap a highly touted experimental stock trading monitoring system, the commission's chairman, John S.R. Shad, said today.

title: AGS COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-1 stock split on Sept 15, 1981

title: GENERAL SERVICES HEAD IS EXPECTED TO ANNOUNCE RESIGNATION TODAY
description: James F. Capalino, head of New York City's purchasing and housekeeping agency, the Department of General Services, is expected to announce today that he will leave the Koch administration.

title: HORIZONS RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $3,599 for the qr and $40,942 for the 9 mos...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $6,000 for the qr and $59,300 for the 9 mos

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1981
description: International A U.S. negotiating position on arms will be formally announced by President Reagan in a few days, according to high Administration officials. They said that Mr. Reagan would make public proposals to Moscow for eliminating or reducing medium-range missiles in Europe to show American support for arms control and to counter antinuclear campaigns in Western Europe. (Page A1, Columns 2-3.) The primary Soviet problem is food, Leonid I. Brezhnev told leaders of the Soviet Communist Party. Acknowledging that a third year of drought had caused great harm to the economy, the Soviet leader pledged to develop a comprehensive program to improve the entire system of food production and distribution. (A1:1.)

title: A PRESIDENTIAL MEAL IN THE NEW FAMILY QUARTERS:
description: President Reagan and his wife,Nancy, in the White House study, which was recently redecorated under the supervision of Mrs. Reagan.

title: ASSOCIATED MADISON COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including realized gains of $123,000 for the qr and $676,000 for the 9 mos, $75,000 gain from discontinued operations for the qr and $472,000 loss from discontinued operations for the 9 mos...C-Including realized gains of $674,000 for the qr and $629,000 for the 9 mos and losses from discontinued operations of $39,000 for the qr and $84,000 for the 9 mos

title: IN MICHIGAN, 'BUCK FEVER' IS NO SURPRISE
description: Only two of the Buick engine assembly lines were running in Flint today. The people who work on the third one were here in the North Woods with a few hundred thousand others like them, sitting in the silent forest waiting for a buck to walk by.

title: 11 Die in Storms Along the Pacific Coast
description: By The Associated Press Heavy rain and winds pounded the northern Pacific Coast yesterday, continuing a storm pattern that has caused an estimated $9.8 million damage in Washington state and Oregon.

title: Georgia, Pitt Reported To Be Sugar Bowl Foes
description: The Sugar Bowl has chosen Georgia over Alabama as the host team against No.1-ranked Pittsburgh on New Year's Day, The Associated Press reported last night.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on the Washington Talk page Nov. 4 about emerging Democratic leaders incorrectly stated the positions of two Representatives on oil deregulation. Tim Wirth of Colorado opposes deregulation; Toby Moffett of Connecticut supports it.

title: Bridge: 'Bluffing Finesse' Is Useful When Declarer Has a Void
description: A player in a suit contract with a void in his hand opposite a king-queen combination in dummy usually takes a ruffing finesse, hoping that the ace is on his right. A version of this might better be called the bluffing finesse.

title: AIR FLORIDA SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $109,000 for the qr and $315,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including $10.2 million gain on the sales of securities and aircraft

title: HOUSE PANEL ADDS MONEY TO BUILD MX
description: The House Appropriations Committee voted by a slender margin tonight to provide funds for the MX intercontinental ballistics missile as proposed by President Reagan.

title: SAUDIS DISAVOW ENVOY'S COMMENT ON STATUS OF ISRAEL IN PEACE PLAN
description: Saudi Arabia said today that its acting delegate to the United Nations had not been authorized to interpret its peace plan for the Middle East.

title: Turkish Authorities Seize 72 Suspected of Being Leftists
description: The Turkish police arrested 72 people today, charging them with five murders and with setting up businesses as fronts to make money for an outlawed leftist group.

title: POLE ON COAST IS CONVICTED IN AN ESPIONAGE CONSPIRACY
description: After two days of jury deliberations, Marian Zacharski, a Polish national, was convicted of espionage today for conspiring with an American aerospace engineer to deliver United States military secrets to the Soviet bloc.

title: TAX LEASE AIDING BIGGER COMPANIES
description: Under the Reagan Administration's new tax-leasing program, smaller companies and those that are financially weak have so far been less active sellers of unneeded tax benefits than larger and more profitable companies with excess tax shelters.

title: DEMOCRATS HOPE TO ORGANIZE AMERICANS LIVING OVERSEAS
description: Democrats, exploring every possibility for votes and money after their losses in the 1980 elections, are now looking to Americans abroad.

title: Norway Pipeline Study
description: Statoil, the Norwegian state oil company, said today that it had agreed with Vattenfall, a state-owned Swedish energy concern, to study the feasibility of constructing a pipeline to transport natural gas from northern Norway through Sweden to Western Europe. A Statoil spokesman, Willy Olsen, said the technical and economic study would be completed by July 1, 1983.

title: CHEMINEER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
SENATE CONFIRMS KOOP, 68-24
description: The Senate today confirmed Dr. C. Everett Koop, a pediatric surgeon who is a prominent foe of abortion, to be United States Surgeon General and director of the Public Health Service.
