title: Groups Ask U.S. to Bar Mobil's Bid
description: A coalition of small business, consumer and union groups today urged the Reagan Administration to block the Mobil Corporation's bid for the Marathon Oil Company, calling the proposed merger clearly illegal.

title: Polish Debt Meeting Set
description: Representatives of Poland and its 15 main Western creditors are to meet in Paris on Wednesday and Thursday to discuss the rescheduling of debts falling due in 1982, banking sources said today. Without a revised schedule, Poland would have to come up with $5.7 billion next year to meet its debts.

title: MAKE 994. (Q. WHY?)
description: "Productivity" has become an economic rallying cry, without enough agreement on what it means, how to measure it, what to do about it - or whether it is, in fact, the central issue in economic recovery. The term has been elevated into a slogan that few dare or bother to challenge. ''Productivity'' has become so imbued with positive meaning that it serves not merely as a measure but as a goal of performance. It is taken as signifying not a level of output but basic worth itself: ''productive'' means ''zealous.''

title: HYATT INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BANGLADESH LEADER SAID TO THWART ARMY PLOT
description: Abdus Sattar, the 75-year-old judge elected President of Bangladesh yesterday, reportedly thwarted a plan by army officers during the campaign to install him as the civilian head of a military regime.

title: High Court to Examine Insurance 'Peer Review'
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the practice of ''peer review,'' commonly used by the insurance industry to evaluate claims for reimbursement of medical expenses, could lead to antitrust liability on the part of the insurance companies and doctors who participate.

title: PROTEST IS STAGED BY SOVIET GERMANS
description: A small group of Soviet Germans tried to unfurl banners in Red Square today to publicize their quest for emigration to West Germany. Soviet plainclothesmen and uniformed police seized the protesters, pushed them into vehicles and took them away.

title: FUND TO SELL AM STAKE
description: The Madison Fund Inc., acknowledging what appeared to be a major investment miscalculation, said yesterday that it would attempt to sell its 16 percent stake in ailing AM International Inc., the moneylosing maker of engineering graphics and information processing systems.

title: Dr. HENRY T. YOST Jr.
description: Dr. Henry T. Yost, Jr., president of the American Association of University Professors and Rufus Tyler Lincoln Professor of Biology at Amherst College, died Sunday at the Cooley Dickinson Hospital in Northampton, Mass.

title: CHARTER MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including special credit of approximately $880,000 or 12 cents a shr related to the company's incentive compen- sation plans

title: RED BARBER ON BROADWAY
description: RED BARBER was the best baseball broadcaster of his time, to many the best of any time. And tonight his soft Southern voice will be heard again in the opening of ''The First,'' a Broadway musical about Jackie Robinson's rookie season with the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1947 as the major league's first black player.

title: INVESTOR IN ST. JOE IDENTIFIED
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday identified Guiseppe Tome, an Italian citizen living in Switzerland and a close friend of Edgar M. Bronfman, head of the Seagram Company, as the purchaser of securities in the St. Joe Minerals Corporation in advance of an attempted takeover of St. Joe by Seagram last March.

title: WEST GERMAN BANK HEAD CLEARED OF FRAUD IN KEY TRIAL
description: The troubled banks controlled by West Germany's 10 states received some relief today when a former leader of one of them was cleared of charges of having engaged in fraud, bribery and breach of trust.

title: Too Quick on Yellow Rain
description: There's a serious gap between the weight of the evidence and the weight of the charges made by the State Department in the ''yellow rain'' affair.

title: G.M. PRESSES CAMPAIGN TO HOLD DOWN WAGES
description: The General Motors Corporation has started an unusual campaign to convince its 499,000 employees of the ''hard realities that may be required for survival'' of the company, according to a private G.M. memorandum obtained yesterday.

title: BIG FIELD FOR WILD-CARD BERTH
description: Of the National Football Conference's seven teams with 5-6 records, all trying for the fifth and last conference wild-card position, the Giants have by far the most difficult path to the playoffs. They must play the Philadelphia Eagles, the San Francisco 49ers and the Dallas Cowboys, the teams with the best records in the conference; they have only two of their remaining five games at home, against the Los Angeles Rams and Dallas, and they play only one of those other 5-6 contenders, the Rams.

title: S.E.C. TO REVIEW ENFORCEMENT POLICY
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun a study into whether it provides adequate legal protection for people suspected of securities law violations, John M. Fedders, director of the enforcement division, said yesterday.

title: FOREMAN FIGHTS FROM THE PULPIT
description: Once George Foreman stood in a boxing ring in the nation of Zaire and saw countless faces stretching to the horizon. Now he stands in a makeshift chapel in the scrub-pine woods of Houston and he can count the missing as easily as the present.

title: SHUTTLE'S CRITICS CALL FOR A BROAD REASSESSMENT
description: THE technical failures that disrupted the space shuttle Columbia's second mission are considered the least of its problems by an increasingly vociferous band of critics. As many of them see it, the shuttle has been a costly mistake that gobbles up scarce billions yet offers few significant advantages in space beyond what can be accomplished with expendable rockets. Some are calling for a reassessment before additional billions are spent to develop related systems to make the shuttle more useful.

title: LAW CLOSING TESTIMONY IN SEX CASE FACES TEST
description: The Supreme Court set the stage today for the third significant test since 1979 of the right of the public and the press to attend courtroom proceedings.

title: U.S. Fishing Fee Rise
description: The United States Commerce Department has notified Japan that it plans to increase by 50 percent fees for foreign boats fishing within the United States 200-mile zone, a Fisheries Agency spokesman said today. The proposed increase, to take effect next year, would add some $12.5 million to the current $25 million a year that the United States receives from nations that fish its waters.

title: REAGAN DISMISSES CIVIL RIGHTS CHIEF, BUSING SUPPORTER
description: President Reagan today dismissed Arthur S. Flemming as chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights and appointed Clarence M. Pendleton, a conservative black Republican, to replace him.

title: Index; International
description: Nicaragua's unresolved conflict: battle for minds A2 French link Armenian terrorist to bombing of synagogue A3 Death toll reaches 48 in collapse of a bullring wall in Mexico A4 Assad tells Parliament that Syria seeks ''peace with justice'' A6 Doubts arise about India's plans to buy planes from France A8 New Bangladesh leader said to have spurned army plot A9 Ethnic German protest in Mos- cow quickly suppressed A11 Government/Politics Senate confirms Koop as Surgeon General, 68-24 A14 Supreme Court Roundup A18 House panel restores $1.9 billion for MX missile A24 Supreme Court to rule on ban of sexual films on children B2 Capalino expected to resign as General Services head B2 Governor Carey talked about money in Harlem B5 Washington Talk Briefing A28 Despite uncertainty, Senator Wil- liams's staff carries on A28 Working profile of Thomas John Campbell of the F.T.C. A28 Odessa Ferguson is an institution at the Longworth Cafeteria A28 General Around the Nation A12 California panel to reconsider Sir- han's parole date A13 Kirkland calls Reagan economic plan ''a bust'' A25 A private health clinic in the Bronx fights to keep U.S. funds B3 Hinckley suffered some injuries in attempting suicide B10 Religion Bishops conference debates strat- egy on abortion fight A20 Science Times After 50 years, radio astronomy looks toward new frontier C1 Education: Princeton in a Su- preme Court battle C1 Science Watch C2 Shuttle's critics call for a broad reassessment C3 Ferrying of Columbia to Florida runs behind schedule C3 Science Q&A C3 Hipparion, a prehistoric horse, is still elusive C4 About Education: Fulbright fel- lowships are in danger C5 Arts/Entertainment Sondheim's musical ''Merrily We Roll Along'' opens at Alvin C9 Audelco bestows 15 theatrical awards at City College C9 Jimmy Cagney, at 82, revels in his comeback C11 Edward Crankshaw's biography ''Bismarck'' is reviewed C12 Lillian Hellman denies socially outlawing Diana Trilling C17 ''Skokie,'' on CBS-TV tonight, dramatizes 1977-78 Nazi case C19 Style Notes on Fashion: Edelstein's spring collection C6 Leather: Luxury for all seasons C6 A new facade on 57th Street C6 Obituaries Horace Brock, former pilot for Pan Am B10 Maurice Sievan, landscape artist and teacher B10 Sports Giants' Simms lost for season; Olander recalled C13 Todd's broken rib jeopardizes his chances to face Dolphins C13 Lions had 12 men on field for win- ning kick against Cowboys C13 Williams to meet with Padres about manager's post C13 George Foreman is now punching from the pulpit C13 Despite suspension, McEnroe is safe for Davis Cup final C13 Dave Anderson on the return of Red Barber C16 * Writer testifies as point-shaving trial resumes C16 Features/Notes Notes on People B6 Sports People C15 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials A30

title: Farm Fuel Costs Rise
description: Fuel prices continue to be among the top gainers on farmers' costs lists, the Agriculture Department says.

title: JUDGE RULES AGAINST L.I. PRINCIPAL IN SUSPENDING PUPIL DURING STRIKE
description: A State Supreme Court justice has determined in a ruling made public yesterday that the principal of Holy Family High School in South Huntington, L.I., acted in an ''arbitrary and capricious'' manner when he suspended the school's 17-year-old student president from classes for breaking his rule against speaking to striking lay teachers.

title: GETTING CUBA
description: Though the Ad- ministration has repeatedly threatened to contain the crisis in El Salvador by ''going to the source,'' President Reagan will find, as have six Presidents before him, that the military options available for use against Cuba are severely limited.

title: Petro-Lewis Sets Oil Acquisition
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation said it had agreed to acquire nearly all of the American Express Company's oil and gas assets for about $76.9 million.

title: HINCKLEY TERMED SERIOUSLY ILL
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., accused of trying to kill President Reagan, suffered neck injuries when he tried to hang himself in his cell yesterday but is slowly improving, the Justice Department said today.

title: USR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $10,486 loss for the qr and $94,054 income for the 9 mos from discontinued operations, $36,300 extraordinary charge for the qr and $36,700 extraordinary gain for the 9 mos C-Including income from discontinued operations of $60,189 for the qr and $147,014 for the 9 mos...D-Net loss

title: No Token Ride for a Mayor
description: Mayor Koch asks to be included among the millions who know how not to run a subway. New York's problem, however, is to find people who do.

title: Rome Planning to Ban Autos On 440 Miles of City Streets
description: The city announced plans today to ban private traffic on 440 miles of city streets to allow public buses and trams to travel faster.

title: Rangers Bring Up Two; Nethery Sent to Minors
description: The Rangers called up the left wing Claude Larose and the right wing Tom Younghans from the Spingfield Indians of the American Hockey League yesterday and assigned Lance Nethery, a center, to Springfield.

title: NEW CABLE TO COVER HEALTH AND SCIENCE
description: Plans for a 24-hour cable network devoted to health, science and consumer information were announced yesterday by Viacom International Inc. The company owns a 50 percent interest in the movie-oriented Showtime cable network.

title: LAKERS' COACH IS REBOUNDING
description: With National Basketball Association owners getting more involved in the day-to-day operations of their teams, pressures mount on their coaches to win.

title: STATE COURT PROHIBITS MEETING AT ST. BART'S ON ITS LEASE PLAN
description: The officials of St. Bartholomew's Church were barred last night by a State Supreme Court justice from holding a meeting this morning at which the congregation was to vote on whether to lease a portion of the church's midtown property for the construction of a 59-story office tower.

title: OXFORD FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $97,481 for the qr and $323,905 for the 9 mos...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $11.8 million for the qr and $12 million for the 9 mos and tax credits of $977,500 for the qr and $1.5 million for the 9 mos

title: AMERICAN BILTRITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $2.4 million income from discontinued operations for the qr and 9 mos and extraordinary tax credits of $1.5 mill for the qr and $2.1 million for the 9 mos...C-Net loss after lo from discontinued operations of $5.3 million for the qr and $6. million for the 9 mos and charges for a plant shutdown and rear ment expenses of $10.7 million for the qr and $12 million for t

title: U.S. ENVOY TO CONGO NAMED
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate Kenneth L. Brown, a Foreign Service officer, as Ambassador to Congo. Mr. Brown, 45 years old, is director of the State Department's Office of Central African Affairs

title: FOR SALVADOR VICTIMS, MACABRE FATE
description: An expanse of jagged lava rock known as El Playon is the sepulcher for an unknown number of slaughtered Salvadoran civilians.

title: LTV ENDS ITS BID FOR GRUMMAN
description: The LTV Corporation yesterday abandoned its $450 million bid to take over the Grumman Corporation, deciding that further litigation to overcome Grumman's antitrust charges would take too long and cost too much.

title: BARUCH-FOSTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
12 MEN ON FIELD FOR LIONS' WINNING KICK
description: Game films show that the Detroit Lions had 12 players on the field yesterday when Eddie Murray frantically kicked a 47-yard field goal as time expired to give the Lions a 27-24 victory over the Dallas Cowboys at the Pontiac Silverdome. But Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League, despite the complaints of the Cowboys, said today that the result was final.

title: AMERICAN SCIENCE & ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $53,000 net gain from discontinued operations... C-Including $123,000 tax credit; yr-ago shr earnings and shrs outstnding have been restated to reflect a 5 percent stock divd issued in Aug 1981

title: COLLAGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BENEFICIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $40.4 million for the qr and $41.2 million for the 9 mos and interest expense of $1.3 million for the qr and $4.5 million for the 9 mos...C-N income including $900,000 gain for the qr and $3.7 million loss for the 9 mos from discontinued operations and interest expense of $1.3 million for the qr and $3.7 million for the 9 mos

title: MOBILE HOME INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Net income including $116,000 tax credit

title: SHORT TERM RATES FALL SHARPLY
description: Short-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday amid widespread indications that rates would continue to decline. The outlook for a further drop was strengthened late in the day when the Federal Reserve eliminated the surcharge of two percentage points it has levied on large banks that borrow frequently at the Fed discount window. The basic discount rate was unchanged at 13 percent, but analysts said it would fall in coming weeks. (Page D16.)

title: POLITICS AND FEEDING THE HUNGRY DON'T MIX
description: To the Editor:

title: Ally & Gargano Gets Scandinavian Airlines
description: Ally & Gargano, which as Carl Ally Inc. was the Scandinavian Airlines Systems agency from 1963 to 1967, has just got the account back with its $1.8 million.

title: G.& W. STAKE
description: Gulf and Western Industries has increased its stake in the Libbey-Owens-Ford Company to 2,382,520 shares, or 21,48 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Gulf and Western said this amount included 161,000 shares bought on the New York Stock Exchange between Oct. 15 and Nov. 11 for $4,270,243. The company said that the purchase, made from general corporate funds, was for investment.

title: Air Florida Net Up 10.5%
description: Air Florida System Inc., said that its thirdquarter profit was $2.1 million, up 10.5 percent from $1.9 million a year ago.

title: EDUCATION
description: CAN a private university - in the name of ''academic freedom'' - keep outsiders from expressing their political views on campus? Princeton University says ''yes,'' and last week it found itself arguing this ironic, if not self-contradictory, position before the Supreme Court of the United States. For excellent reasons, the case is being watched closely, not only by civil libertarians but also by faculty members and officials of private colleges across the country.

title: Factory Utilization Off 1.5% in October
description: The utilization of the nation's factories slipped 1.5 percent in October, to 76.9 percent of capacity, the lowest level since August 1980 at the end of last year's recession, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: MUCH ADO ABOUT A CONFERENCE ON AGING
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Selection Begins In Hillside Strangler Case
description: The trial of Angelo Buono, who is accused of murdering 10 women in the so-called hillside strangler case, began today after years of legal dispute and doubt concerning the testimony of his co-defendant, Kenneth Bianchi, who has changed his account of the killings several times.

title: Bank of America Credit-Card Fees
description: The Bank of America said it would increase the annual percentage rate and change the late charge on its bank card accounts beginning in February 1982.

title: WAINOCO OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; the latest periods include a $7.4 million writeoff from cost of an unsuccessful exploratory well drilled in Columbia, South America

title: THE PRIME OPPORTUNITY OF ST. BARTHOLOMEW'S
description: To the Editor:

title: 15 RECEIVE 9TH AUDELCO STAGE AWARDS
description: ''When the Chickens Came Home to Roost'' by Laurence Holder won the 1981 Audelco Recognition Award for drama Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway last night. ''Bessie Smith, Empress of the Blues'' by Ed Shockley was named best musical.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OPENING

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: AMERICA'S educational and cultural presence on the world scene is in danger of being snuffed out - not by this country's adversaries, who often decry that presence as cultural imperialism, but by the Reagan Administration's exchange program managers.

title: CHARLES OPPENHEIM, MANHATTAN RETAILER AND A CIVIC LEADER
description: Charles Jay Oppenheim Jr., a retailer and civic leader who founded the Jay Thorpe specialty stores in 1920, died last night at his home in Manhattan. He was 91 years old.

title: COGNITRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $70,000 or 4 cents a shr for the qr and $178,000 or 11 cents a shr for the 9 mos

title: ENERGY MINERALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss including $312,000 pretax gain from the sale of undeveloped oil and gas acreage

title: EXCEL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SUPREME COURT TO RULE ON FILMS SHOWING SEXUAL ACTIVITY OF CHILDREN
description: The United States Supreme Court agreed today to rule on the constitutionality of a New York law that prohibits the use of children in films, photographs and performances that depict sexual activity but are not necessarily obscene in the legal sense.

title: ATCO INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $71,000 for the qr and $589,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net income including gains from discontinued operations of $355,000 for the qr and $400,000 for the 9 mos and $29,000 tax credit for the qr

title: CALIFORNIA PANEL WILL REVIEW A 1984 PAROLE DATE FOR SIRHAN
description: The California Board of Prison Terms voted unanimously today to consider rescinding a 1984 parole release date for Sirhan B. Sirhan, who assassinated Senator Robert F. Kennedy of New York in 1968.

title: Andretti Appeal Denied
description: The United States Auto Club has denied an appeal by Mario Andretti over the result of last May's controversial Indianapolis 500. Bobby Unser finished first in the race last May 24, but the next day he was penalized one lap by USAC for passing cars during a yellow caution light and Andretti, who crossed the finish line second, was declared the winner.

title: ANTITRUST JOB WILL TEST 'MR. NICE GUY' IMAGE
description: James C. Miller 3d, the new Federal Trade Commission chairman, who says the agency should no longer ''explore the frontiers of antitrust law,'' may have unknowingly hired an explorer to run the agency's antitrust division. That, perhaps, is the risk the Administration took in hiring a certified whiz kid.

title: House Crossover Votes On Move to Recommit
description: Following is a partial tally of votes by which the House today defeated, 201-189, an effort to make further cuts in a stopgap budget resolution. In the key vote, House Democrats halted an effort by Republicans to send the resolution back to committee with instructions to make the cuts.

title: WESTCHESTER BUDGET PLAN SEEKS 17% TAX RISE
description: Westchester County residents learned today, with the release of the proposed 1982 budget, that their county property taxes might increase by 17 percent, the sharpest rise in five years. The budget also calls for decreasing government services in such areas as public health, recreation and transportation.

title: WINKELMAN STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Baltimore Brouhaha
description: Coach Mike McCormack of the Baltimore Colts refused to discuss reports that Robert Irsay, the owner, took over his job Sunday during the Colts' 10th straight loss, a 38-13 rout at the hands of Philadelphia. But McCormack did say that he had considered quitting after the game. Irsay sat in the assistant coaches' box in the stands wearing a head phone during the second half of the game, and several players indicated later that it had been the owner's decision to pull the quarterback Bert Jones off the field and replace him with Greg Landry in a fourth-period shuffle.

title: COMMODORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $169,000 gain from the sale of an idle manufacturin facility in Cotton, Calif; shr earnings are fully diluted

title: Soviet Aid to India
description: The Soviet Union has agreed to grant credits totaling $245 million to India to help it build a large steel plant. The credits will be used to purchase Soviet materials and equipment for the plant, an official statement said. The plant will start production in 1985 and be in full operation by 1987, the statement added.

title: WAS CALLED 'ARTIST LAUREATE OF SUBURBS'
description: Maurice Sievan, an artist and teacher known for his landscapes of various Queens neighborhoods, died at St. Luke's Hospital on Sunday. He was 82 years old.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A 40-year-old dentist was accidentally shot by a colleague during a confrontation with a former patient armed with a gun and a knife in their Harlem office, the police reported. The wounded dentist, Dr. Richard Sepe, was reported in fair condition at Metropolitan Hospital with a bullet wound in a shoulder.

title: Beware Pink Peppercorns
description: An ''exotic'' imported spice that is being gobbled up by fans of nouvelle cuisine is nothing more than a common weed related to poison ivy and capable of causing severe toxic reactions, according to botanical experts.

title: DEMOCRATS DEFEAT AN ATTEMPT TO CUT SPENDING MEASURES
description: The House today defeated a Reagan Administration effort to make further reductions in a $440 billion stopgap spending bill intended to keep the Government running through next September. The 201-to-189 vote gave the Democrats their first major fiscal victory of the year.

title: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1981; Markets
description: Short-term interest rates fell sharply amid widespread prospects of further drops. In Treasury bill auctions, new three-month and sixmonth issues averaged 10.693 percent and 10.972 percent, respectively. Long-term bond prices rose as yields eased. (Page D1.)

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Abex Corporation has elected Arthur A. Borin vice presidentresearch and engineering.

title: U.S. Farm Aid Up in 1981
description: Government payments under various farm programs this year will total about $1.5 billion, up from $1.3 billion in 1980, according to economists in the Agriculture Department.

title: COUNCIL MAPS A NEW PROPOSAL ON VOTING LINES
description: Officials of New York's City Council said yesterday that they were attempting to redraw the disputed district lines in a way that would create 12 districts in which minority candidates would have good chances of winning election.

title: Article 095942 -- No Title
description: A buyer of a $1 Lotto ticket in last week's New York State Lottery has won $5 million, believed to be the biggest jackpot ever in a game of chance, lottery officials said.

title: FIRSTMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $25,000 charge for the qr from reversal of a tax credit and $345,000 tax credit for the 9 mos... C-After $150,000 charge for the qr from reversal of a tax credit and $160,000 tax credit for the 9 mos

title: CHURCHES PRESS DISARMAMENT DRIVE
description: Fear of nuclear war is prompting more Americans to turn to their churches for help in halting the arms race, according to many of the 700 participants in a conference on disarmament sponsored by the Riverside Church.

title: FERROFLUIDICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WASHINGTON REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
description: The shrs outstndg and shr earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid Mar 1981

title: McEnroe Suspended; Still in Cup
description: John McEnroe began a three-week suspension from Grand Prix tennis tournaments yesterday. He is still eligible for next month's Davis Cup final and the Volvo Masters at Madison Square Garden in January.

title: KEEP SOCIAL PROGRAMS, CAREY TOLD IN HARLEM
description: Governor Carey held the second of a series of what he called ''prebudget hearings'' yesterday, this time in Harlem, to ask his constituents how to spend the state's money.

title: Secret Service Chief Leaving; Plans to Study Border Patrol
description: The director of the Secret Service, H. Stuart Knight, will leave his post Dec. 1 to conduct a three-month study of how to improve the Border Patrol and will then retire, the Treasury Department announced today.

title: DUNES HOTELS & CASINOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After net losses from discontinued operations of $378,000 for the qr and $738,000 for the 9 mos

title: A New Name for an Off Broadway Theater
description: It was a man named Bill de Lys who converted an old Christopher Street movie house into a legitimate theater and called it the Theater de Lys, but it was Lucille Lortel who made it famous as one of New York's leading Off Broadway theaters. And last night, 26 years after she took over the playhouse, it was finally renamed the Lucille Lortel Theater.

title: DOUBTS ARISE ABOUT INDIA'S PLANS TO BUY JET FIGHTERS FROM FRANCE
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi returned from Europe today with the future of the purchase of advanced Mirage fighter-bombers from France clouded by seemingly contradictory statements.

title: Rise Seen in Tree Cost
description: Christmas tree prices will increase only slightly this year, according to the National Christmas Tree Association.

title: COURT ORDER STOPS DEER HUNTERS IN HARRIMAN PARK
description: Deer hunters were barred by court order from Harriman State Park yesterday after opponents of the hunt won an injunction they had failed to get from a lower court Friday.

title: Stabler No. 1 Again
description: The Oilers' Ken Stabler, fined $500 last week for missing a workout and intercepted twice in a reserve role against the Kansas City Chiefs on Sunday, has regained his starting job.

title: The Editorial Notebook;  Who's That Hog in the Bond Market?
description: Short-term interest rates are apparently dropping back to earth. Why, then, are long-term rates - the cost of money that is borrowed for a decade or more - still stuck up in the ionosphere?

title: COMMONWEALTH OIL REFINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $2 million provision for personnel severance costs associated with the temporary closing of the company's Aromatic facilities in October; Commonwealth Oil Refining is listed on the Pacific and Philadelphia stock exchanges...C-After $5 milli provision for impairment of investment in joint ventures and $41.7 million extraordinary loss...D-Including $7.3 million extraordinary gain

title: Margin Narrows On Prison Vote
description: The margin by which New York State voters apparently rejected the $500 million bond issue for prison construction narrowed to 1,985 votes as New York City and Monroe County released their official figures, the News Election Service reported.

title: BODARD WINS GONCOURT FOR BOOK 'ANNE-MARIE'
description: Lucien Bodard won the Goncourt Prize for Literature today for "Anne-Marie," a reminiscence about his mother and his childhood in China.

title: THE HIPPARION IS STILLL AN ELUSIVE HORSE
description: WHEREVER one looked in the low-ceilinged room in the American Museum of Natural History, there were ancient bones - bones atop desks, on chairs, in cabinets, on shelves, in alcoves, on the floor. In the room 14 internationally known fossil experts had come to sit around a table covered with whitened craniums, limbs and spines, and to expand their knowledge of Hipparion, the three-toed precursor of the modern single-toed horse.

title: FIRST EXECUTIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
I.T.T. to Retail Phone Service
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Company said that it would sell subscriptions to its long-distance telephone service at 21 Sears, Roebuck & Company outlets in Washington, D.C., and Miami. I.T.T. said it was the first time long-distance service would be sold over the retail counter.

title: Monbouquette Goes Up
description: Bill Monbouquette, a coach in the Mets' minor league system the last five years, was promoted to pitching coach of the parent club yesterday, a move that added to what has become a decidedly American League flavor in the transformation of the team's leadership in recent weeks. The appointment of the 45-year-old Monbouquette, who pitched a no-hitter for Boston in 1962 and spent virtually all his major league career with the Red Sox, the Detroit Tigers and the Yankees, follows the appointments in recent weeks of Manager George Bamberger, formerly of Milwaukee, and Jim Frey, the batting coach, who formerly managed at Kansas City.

title: THE GOLD IN GARAGES
description: ''This has been the greatest season in garage-sale history,'' Deborah Wilson proclaimed as she stood in a driveway here, giving serious consideration to a used basket of polyethylene fruit.

title: KEEPING ORDER ON THE EGG LINE
description: John F. Kennedy liked his eggs over light. So did Gerald R. Ford. Odessa Ferguson knows, because for more than 30 years she has been frying and scrambling for a long procession of clients ranging from pages to Presidents.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 17, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: TELECOM EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HORACE BROCK, 73, AN EX-PILOT FOR PAN AM ON FLYING BOATS
description: Horace Brock, an early flying-boat pilot who became an airline historian and held high posts at Pan American and three other airlines, died yesterday at New York Hospital after suffering a stroke. He was 73 years old and lived in Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Billie Jean King and Mrs. Graham Tie in Poll Who are the most influential women in the United States? According to a poll conducted by the World Almanac, they are Billie Jean King and Katharine Graham.

title: One-Day No-Smoking Campaign On Tomorrow
description: The fifth annual Great American Smokeout, an attempt to get 18 million to 20 million Americans to give up cigarette smoking for 24 hours, begins tomorrow at midnight. Larry Hagman, a vehement exsmoker, is the Smokeout leader.

title: A NEW FACADE ON 57TH STREET
description: She had said two weeks ago that if the renovation of the facade was not finished by mid-November she could kiss the Christmas shopping season goodbye. But at noon yesterday, Geraldine Stutz, the president of Henri Bendel, wasn't kissing anything but her friends and well-wishers.

title: TACOMA BOATBUILDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings have been restated for a 50 percent stock divd effective July 7

title: RADIO ASTRONOMY, 50 YEARS OLD, MOVES TOWARD A NEW FRONTIER
description: IN 1931 Karl Jansky, a researcher for Bell Telephone Laboratories, was assigned to track down static interfering with long-distance communications.

title: INDICTED PAIR LOSE BID FOR TV OUTTAKES
description: Two men facing criminal charges for their roles in a restaurant-franchising business failed today in the Supreme Court to get film "outtakes" from the "60 Minutes" television program.

title: TEXAS GENERAL RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SENATE RESTRICTS SUITS ON PRAYERS IN THE SCHOOLS
description: The Senate voted today to endorse ''programs of voluntary prayer'' in public schools. Opponents of the legislation immediately announced that they would stage a filibuster against them.

title: STAGE: A NEW SONDHEIM, 'MERRILY WE ROLL ALONG'
description: AS we all should probably have learned by now, to be a Stephen Sondheim fan is to have one's heart broken at regular intervals. Usually the heartbreak comes from Mr. Sondheim's songs -for his music can tear through us with an emotional force as moving as Gershwin's. And sometimes the pain is compounded by another factor - for some of Mr. Sondheim's most powerful work turns up in shows (''Anyone Can Whistle,'' ''Pacific Overtures'') that fail. Suffice it to say that both kinds of pain are abundant in ''Merrily We Roll Along,'' the new Sondheim-Harold Prince-George Furth musical that opened at the Alvin last night. Mr. Sondheim has given this evening a half-dozen songs that are crushing and beautiful - that soar and linger and hurt. But the show that contains them is a shambles.

title: CLARK EQUIPMENT HIRES G.M. OFFICER
description: James R. Rinehart, 50 years old, resigned yesterday as president of General Motors of Canada Ltd. to become president and chief executive officer of the Clark Equipment Company, a manufacturer of material-handling equipment, construction equipment, axles and transmissions. At Clark he succeeds Bert E. Phillips, 62, who remains chairman.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Oct. 31 on Elliott Abrams's nomination as Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights incorrectly identified the father of his wife, Rachel. She is the daughter of Moshe Decter, editor of Near East Re- port, and the stepdaughter of Norman Podhoretz, editor of Commentary.

title: SHORTAGE OF FOOD WORRIES BREZHNEV
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev said today that the production and distribution of food was the greatest economic and political problem facing the Soviet Union.

title: Koch Calls Kahane 'Disgrace to Jews'
description: Mayor Koch denounced Rabbi Meir Kahane, leader of the Jewish Defense League, as ''a disgrace to Jews.'' The Mayor called Rabbi Kahane ''another Arafat,'' referring to Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Bouquet for a Rose
description: Pete Rose, the National League's leading career hitter, was named athlete of the decade by the American Cancer Society. Also honored, posthumously, was William Jennings, president of the New York Rangers, for his efforts in raising funds to fight cancer.

title: POLITICS AND FEEDING THE HUNGRY DON'T MIX
description: To the Editor:

title: ARMENIAN LINKED TO SYNAGOGUE RAID
description: French investigators have linked an Armenian terrorist who was arrested, released and rear@rested here last week with the bombing of a Paris synagogue in October 1980 in which four persons died.

title: People
description: * Theodore F. Newlin has been elected an executive vice president, and Alfred R. Sanno and Alan Goldin senior vice presidents of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn Inc.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What causes a person to snore?

title: South African Contracts
description: Combustion Engineering Inc. of Stamford, Conn., has been awarded a contract to supply power station boilers to the South African Electricity Supply Commission. Combustion will supply six 600-megawatt boilers worth $800 million. Another contract was awarded to a French-West German consortium of Stein Industrie of France and Energie und Verfahrenstechnik G.m.b.H. of West Germany to supply six 600-megawatt boilers for the Matimba power station in the northern Transvaal.

title: K MART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
825Strawberry Shortcake To Dancer Fitzgerald
description: America's current darling, Strawberry Shortcake, and all of her involvements, will be touched by the promotion brush of Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, one of the nation's leading ad agencies.

title: Another British M.P. Leaves Laborites to Join New Party
description: John Grant, a Member of Parliament representing a north London constituency, announced today that he was leaving the Labor Party and joining the centrist Social Democrats, an 8-month-old party that has already drawn 22 other Labor Members of Parliament.

title: CALIFORNIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
description: B-After $200,000 charge for the qr and 9 mos from the writedown of carrying value of the company's investment in a bond fund to its market value and gains of $310,000 for the qr and $300,000 for the 9 mos on the sale of real estate

title: Dutch Deficit Figures
description: The 1982 Dutch financing deficit could rise to about 7 percent of national income from a planned 6.5 percent, and compared with an estimated 7.5 percent to 8 percent this year, the finance ministry said today. Financing deficit is defined as the Government's total borrowing requirement, less the redemption of fixed debts. The deficit increase was partly attributed to major reductions in gas revenues.

title: CONFLICTS RAISED IN FIX TRIAL
description: Douglas S. Looney, the author of a Sports Illustrated article dealing with charges of a Boston College point-shaving scheme, testified at a Federal trial yesterday that the article was in keeping with information supplied him by Henry Hill, a key Government witness.

title: More Steel Suits Seen
description: The Government will file another series of lawsuits against foreign steel-exporting countries this week or next, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today.

title: PACIFIC TIN CONSOLIDATED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DELMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $44,000 for the qr and $110,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss

title: Connecticut Bond Rise
description: The Connecticut Housing Finance Authority's issue of serial and term mortgage revenue bonds, series B, has been increased to $200 million from $100 million, for sale through a Salomon Brothers group.

title: Lawyer Disrupts Sessions in Jersey
description: TRENTON (UPI) - An Atlantic City lawyer, shouting that the Mafia was after him, disrupted a session of the State Legislature and oral arguments before the State Supreme Court.

title: PENNEY GAINS 59.2%
description: The K mart Corporation, the country's second-largest retailer of general merchandise after Sears, Roebuck & Company, reported yesterday that increased expenditures helped depress earnings by 54.2 percent in the third fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31.

title: KARPOV AND KORCHNOI PLAY TO A DRAW IN 23 MOVES
description: The world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, and his challenger, Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland, drew the 17th game of their title match here in 23 quiet moves tonight.

description: * Split rate, 16.00-17.00 ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. + Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SIMMS OF GIANTS IS OUT FOR SEASON
description: Richard Todd, whose play at quarterback helped transform the Jets into a contender, has a fractured rib that jeopardizes his chance to play next Sunday when New York faces the Miami Dolphins, with first place in the American Conference East at stake.

title: DOW PLUNGES 10.85 ON RECESSION FEARS
description: Stock market prices plunged yesterday, mainly because of growing apprehension among investors over the deepening recession. The Dow Jones industrial average, which lost ground throughout the session, closed down 10.85 points, at 845.03, its biggest daily loss since Oct.14, when it fell 14.93 points.

title: VACCINE FOR HEPATITIS B, JUDGED HIGHLY EFFECTIVE, IS APPROVED BY F.D.A.
description: THE Food and Drug Administration yesterday announced approval of the first vaccine against hepatitis to be licensed for use in the United States.

title: A BRONX HEALTH CENTER BATTLING FOR U.S. FUNDS
description: News of a possibly shrinking future for the health center at 1175 Morris Park Avenue in the Bronx had spread among its clients as rapidly as a bad cold. Yesterday, however, it appeared that the situation might not be terminal.

title: BEACON PHOTO SERVICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
House of Commons Suspends 3 Ulster M.P.'s
description: Three Protestant Members of Parliament from Northern Ireland were suspended indefinitely today after they shouted abuse during a Government statement in the House of Commons on the continuing guerrilla violence in their province.

title: Commercial Paper
description: Commercial paper outstanding in the United States rose a record $8.26 billion in September to a seasonally adjusted record $165.38 billion, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said. Last year, commercial paper outstanding totaled $119.78 billion. Financial company paper rose $4.94 billion in September, to $113.52 billion, while nonfinancial company paper rose $3.32 billion, to $51.86 billion.

title: WON OSCAR FOR 'STALAG 17'
description: William Holden, the film star who won an Oscar in 1953 for his role in ''Stalag 17'' and who represented the manly, straightforward, romantic figure during a career of more than 40 years, was found dead yesterday in his apartment in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: SENIOR OFFICIALS FEAR THAT SHIELDING AIDES COULD HURT REAGAN
description: Despite an outward show of firmly weathering the latest embarrassing revelations about two top Presidential aides, some senior Administration officials are privately fearful that President Reagan's political and policy interests are being mistakenly sacrificed to protect the two men under fire.

title: REAGAN TO PROPOSE MISSILE TERMS FOR EUROPE AHEAD OF SOVIET TALKS
description: President Reagan will take the unusual step of announcing a proposal to the Soviet Union in the next few days for eliminating medium-range missiles in Europe or, failing that, for reducing them, high-ranking Administration officials said today.

title: Massey-Ferguson
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. said it would temporarily shut down its combine harvester and supporting operations in Brantford, Ontario, and Toronto from Nov. 20 until February, laying off about 1,750 employees. Massey announced earlier this month that it was reducing its Brantford combine plant from two shifts a day to one shift. It said that forecasts for the rest of this year offer no prospect of improvement.

title: TRIAD SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SEAHAWKS WIN BY 44-23
description: Dan Doornink scored two touchdowns and Sherman Smith ran for another on a fake field-goal attempt to lead the Seattle Seahawks to a 44-23 victory over the San Diego Chargers tonight.

title: Steel Exports Of Japan Fall
description: Japan's steel exports in the six months ended Sept. 30 fell 3.8 percent in tonnage from a year earlier, but the value rose 5.6 percent because of price increases, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said today.

title: Connors Withdraws
description: The South African Press Association has reported the withdrawal of Jimmy Connors from the Sigma tennis tournament in Johannesburg next week, citing death threats against Connors and his wife.

title: NOW YOU TAKE ONE TURKEY...
description: To roast a stuffed turkey, the following method is recommended: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Sprinkle the center cavity and the inside of the crop with pepper and, if desired, salt.

title: AVERY COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Husky Oil Net Down by 79.3%
description: Husky Oil Ltd. reported yesterday that its net income in the third quarter dropped 79.3 percent, to $9.1 million from $44 million a year earlier.

title: CABLE TV IN FOUR BOROUGHS TAKES ANOTHER STEP TONIGHT
description: The final decisions will not be made for months and the last switch will not be turned to the ''on'' position for years. But by tonight, the people of Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island will finally be a substantial step closer to getting what Manhattan has had for a decade - cable television.

title: U.S. BARBED WIRE FOR U.S. CITIZINS
description: To the Editor:

description: If he is confirmed as chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, says Clarence M. Pendleton Jr., he would like to see that agency turn its efforts to such issues as making it financially possible for more women and members of minority groups to own taxi medallions in New York City.

title: KHOMEINI RULES OUT SAUDIS' PEACE TERMS AS CONTRARY TO ISLAM
description: Iran has denounced the Saudi Arabian plan for a Middle Eastern settlement as ''inconsistent with Islam.'' The statement, made by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, followed a Teheran newspaper attack on Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, because he called the Saudi proposals a good basis for negotiations.

title: Electrician Gets $1.3 Million Award
description: JERSEY CITY (UPI) - An electrician who became a quadriplegic about three years ago when a scaffold collapsed as he was repairing a Marcal Paper Products roof sign has accepted a $1.3 million settlement, his attorney announced.

description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been restated for a 5-for-4 stock split in Dec 1980

title: INVENTOR'S I.B.M. DEAL
description: Jerome H. Lemelson, a 58-year-old inventor who last week announced the licensing of a group of his patents for information-handling equipment to the International Business Machines Corporation, believes that ''my persistence'' has been one of his major assets. It was this persistence, he said, that helped him receive more than 350 patents as well as large royalties over the years for inventions in such fields as industrial robots, communications and magnetic recording.

title: Market Place; The Quandary In Bond Rally
description: THE current rally in bonds after the worst bear market in history puts investors in fixed-interest securities in a quandary. Should they cash in their money market fund shares to lock in high yields on long bonds or sit tight - accepting reduced yields as interest rates retreat?

title: Letter: On Population Balance People Against Resources
description: To the Editor: Your editorial marking the observance of the first world Food Day (''Malthus and Marx,'' Oct. 16) confused the need for a balance between population and resources with the impact in the Eastern bloc of low levels of agricultural productivity on the spread of Marxism.

title: THINNESS LINKED TO A LONG LIFE
description: Skinny people who don't smoke much or at all live the longest, a new study contends. ''If you show me a thin person who isn't a heavy cigarette smoker, I'll show you the person who does the best - the lowest death rate, the lowest stroke rate, heart attack rate, the whole bit,'' said Dr. William Castelli, director of the Framingham Heart Study.

title: Pope Honors Dead Prelates
description: Pope John Paul II led 24 cardinals and 300 other prelates and church officials today in a special mass for Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, who died May 28 in Poland, and Egidio Cardinal Vagnozzi, a Vatican official who died Dec. 26. A new feature of the annual ceremony was that prayers were also said for all Roman Catholic bishops who died since last November.

description: Assemblyman Anthony Imperiale acknowledged today that he was in charge of a Republican ballot-security program in Newark on Election Day. But he said that charges of voter intimidation by Democratic Party leaders were ''sour grapes.''

description: To the Editor:

REAGAN AND BREZHNEV
description: Before his meeting with Chancellor Schmidt in West Germany this coming weekend, Leonid Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, sent a private letter to President Reagan suggesting that U.S.-Soviet relations were getting out of hand and implying that maybe they should get together and discuss the problem.

title: CORADIAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Limited Colt Trading Set
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it would allow limited trading of Colt Industries shares pending resolution of a dispute over whether Colt will be merged into the Penn Central Corporation.

title: QUO VADIS RESTAURANT CHANGING HANDS
description: Quo Vadis, one of New York's most fashionable Continental restaurants for the last 38 years, will be under new management by the middle of next January, pending approval of the transfer of a liquor license. A contract for the sale has been signed by Gino Robusti and Bruno Caravaggi, the founders and partners of Quo Vadis, and the purchasers, Romeo Mattiusi and Bernard Norget, who also own La Folie in the Carlton House.

title: Former Boxer Charged
description: Jose Stable, a former boxer who in 1965 lost to Emile Griffith in a bout for the world welterweight championship, was arrested in Miami on charges of trying to kill a police officer. Stable was accused of attempted first-degree murder in the wounding of a police officer who had gone to his home with a court order to apprehend him on a concealed-weapon charge. A bullet grazed the head of the officer, Robert Diers, who was reported in stable condition. ... Claude Noel of Trinidad will make the first defense of his World Boxing Association lightweight championship against Gonzalo Montellano of Bakersfield, Calif., Dec. 5 in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: K-TEL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE 50'S FAMILY AND TODAY'S
description: Are we returning to the 1950's-style family? When people discuss recent changes in family life in the United States, they often take the 50's as their point of reference. Many of us were either growing up or rearing children then, so that decade is a natural standard to use. Scholarly and popular commentators on the family frequently note that since the 50's, the divorce rate has more than doubled, the birth rate has dropped sharply, and the average age at marriage his risen.

title: 'JANE AUSTIN'
description: ''JANE AUSTEN in Manhattan,'' which opens today at the Art Theater, begins on an enticingly mysterious note. There are glimpses of an 18th-century kidnapping, an auction at Sotheby, a commune in SoHo, a grand, aging actress and a charismatic drama teacher, with no explanation of what these elements have to do with one another.

title: LEHIGH VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $108,000 for the qr and $216,000 for the 9 mos and tax credits of $421,000 for the qr and $1,502,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including tax credits of $319,000 for the qr and $483,000 for the 9 mos

title: THE SAUDI TEXT
description: Nobody does Israel any service by proclaiming its ''right to exist.'' It is disturbing to find so many people well-disposed to Israel giving currency to this contemptuous formulation. Israel's right to exist, like that of the United States, Saudi Arabia, and 152 other states, is axiomatic and unreserved. Israel's legitimacy is not suspended in midair awaiting acknowledgement by the royal house in Riyadh. Nor does a group such as the Palestine Liberation Organization have any juridical competence to accord recognition to states, or withhold it.

title: PRELATE APPEALS FOR ARMS CURBS AND AID TO POOR
description: Archibishop John R. Roach, president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, urged the bishops today to spearhead a campaign for social justice that advocated a halt to the arms race, a ban on abortion and more aid for the poor.

title: ROPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net loss after $23,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: AMERICAN AIR ASKS A 5% PAY CUT
description: American Airlines today announced a second cost-cutting move in as many weeks, this time asking its 35,000 employees to accept a 5 percent pay cut for the first three months of 1982, and a wage freeze for the rest of that year.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Vince Bartimo, president and general manager of Louisiana Downs, filed a $15 million lawsuit against a horsemen's union magazine, The Racing Journal, which had referred to him as ''an alleged Mafia lieutenant.'' The dispute between Bartimo and the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association stemmed from Bartimo's barring some union members from the track on the ground that they were undesirables. ... Ivan Lendl clinched first place in the season's Grand Prix point standing, a result that makes him the top-seeded player in the $400,000 Masters tournament at Madison Square Garden in January. ... Claudia Kohde of West Germany and Jimmy Arias of Grand Island, N.Y., were named the Tennis Magazine/Rolex rookies of the year. The Golf Digest/ Rolex rookie awards went to Mark O'Meara of Palm Springs, Calif., and Kyle O'Brien of Indianapolis. ... The International Tennis Federation named Kurt Nielsen of Denmark, a Wimbledon finalist in 1953 and 1955, as referee for the Davis Cup final, between the United States and Argentina, next month in Cincinnati.

title: JUSTICE MARSHALL DENIES PLAN TO RETIRE FROM HIGH COURT
description: Justice Thurgood Marshall today denied broadcast reports that he was considering retiring from the United States Supreme Court.

title: American Invsco Loses On a Co-op Challenge
description: The State Attorney General has rejected a challenge by the American Invsco Corporation concerning the eligibility of nearly 100 elderly and handicapped tenants who claim to be legally exempt from a cooperative conversion plan for an East Side building.

title: Former Embassy Burns
description: A fire today shortly after midnight at the former Nicaraguan Embassy caused damage estimated at over a million dollars, a fire department spokesman said. He said the possibility of arson was being investigated.

title: LABOR DISPUTE ADMITTED AT SOVIET AUTO PLANT
description: Officials at the Togliatti auto works have acknowledged that there was a labor dispute last year, but they denied that there was a strike.

title: COMPUTER INVESTORS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WIDE STUDY FINDS THE FRENCH DRINK LESS WINE THAN BEFORE
description: An extensive study, just made public, shows that what the French suspected is not only true but even worse. The annual per capita consumption of wine has dropped since 1964 from 120 liters (just under 32 gallons) a year to 90 liters. People under 35 drink nearly a sixth as much wine as their elders did at the same age, and they insist that what they do drink is good.

title: Leader of O.A.U. Force Said to Arrive in Chad
description: The commander of an African peacekeeping force arrived today and met President Goukouni Oueddei to discuss its deployment, military sources said.

title: THE CITY
description: A maintenance worker at Fordham University was struck by a car and killed on a private service road on the school's Bronx campus last night, the police reported.

LEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After capital gains of $4,950,000

title: Herzog Plotting Again
description: Whitey Herzog, manager and general manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, said he was considering trading Garry Templeton and Sixto Lezcano in a package deal. Herzog, who orchestrated some of the biggest trades involving some of baseball's top players at last year's winter meetings, characterized a possible Templeton-Lezcano package as a ''barnburner that might make an expansion club a contender.''

title: HARD TIMES AHEAD FOR CIVIL RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN SAYS HE'LL MEET CONGRESS HALFWAY ON STOPGAP SPENDING BILL
description: President Reagan said today that he was willing to meet Congress halfway in a dispute over how much spending would be allowed in a stopgap money bill needed to keep the Government operating beyond midnight Friday.

title: SPECIAL U.S. ENVOY PLANS TO RETURN TO MIDEAST SOON
description: President Reagan's Middle East envoy plans to return to that region shortly after Thanksgiving to try to strengthen the four-month old cease-fire in Lebanon and to ease Israeli concerns about American policies, Administration officials said today.

title: MONENCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The third qr rev figures were not available

title: CHANCELLOR TO RUN SCHOOL FOR FIRSTHAND VIEW
description: Frank J. Macchiarola, the city's Schools Chancellor, announced yesterday that he would become acting interim principal of Jamaica High School in Queens to get a first-hand view of day-to-day life in the school system.

title: 3 Are Slain in Wichita; 25-Year-Old Arrested
description: A young boy, his mother and a teenaged girl were fatally shot and another woman was critically wounded in an attack at their home before dawn today, the police said.

title: Economic Scene; Despite Furor, Little Change
description: THE charges of confusion and cynicism at the heart of the Reagan economic program by David A. Stockman are still reverberating within the Administration.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE other day I was wandering through the park when I noticed a large green tropical parrot trailing me through the woods at an altitude of about 15 feet. We made small talk, but the bird had nothing to say.

title: INVESTORS SOAK UP BOND FLOOD
description: Corporations flooded the bond market with more than $1 billion of new issues yesterday, but investor demand was strong enough so that the heavy supply caused prices of outstanding issues to decline only slightly.

title: Fear Assailed as Factor In Hearings on A-Plant
description: Lawyers representing the nuclear power industry and the Government contended in a hearing at an appeals court here today that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission had no statutory responsibility to consider the ''psychological fear'' of residents near the crippled Three Mile Island reactor in deciding whether to reopen the unit's sister plant.

title: Advertising; Compton Gets New Logotype
description: AT a pep rally in the Plaza Hotel yesterday, the management of Compton Advertising, which expects to hit the $1 billion-in-billings mark next year, displayed a new logotype: an appropriately aggressive-looking ''C'' that is about to take a healthy bite out the world.

title: BRAZIL TAKES OVER TOWN RACKED BY A BLOOD FEUD
description: The military police have been ordered to assume control of Exu, a town in Brazil's interior where a longtime political vendetta involving three families has just claimed its 37th and 38th victims.

title: HISPANIC BUSINESS WORRIED
description: Hispanic businessmen, most of whom supported President Reagan's election, are expressing criticism of the Administration's economic policy, with some saying that it has eroded gains of minority-owned businesses.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE AIDES NOW DOUBTING GOAL OF BIWEEKLY LIFTOFF
description: Now that two orbital tests have demonstrated that the space shuttle can fly and land as designed, space agency officials are still left with a disturbing problem: They doubt that the shuttle will ever be able to be serviced and returned to space as rapidly as originally hoped.

title: The Top Officials Need a Raise
description: In the parlance of the moment, Congress ought to get off the backs of senior Government officials. It needs once and for all to eliminate the link between their salaries and its own.

HEITMAN MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: President Reagan's scheduled speech at the National Press Club today will be carried live by the CBS, NBC and ABC television networks and by WOR Radio beginning at 10 A.M.

But because of the controversy surrounding the new map, the plan may be destined to join three proposals for Congressional redistricting in the Chicago area in court.

title: DANCE: BETH SOLL AND TROUPE PRESENT HER 'PAGEANT'
description: PAGEANTS can be about all sorts of things: the settling of the West, the fall of the Roman Empire, the history of a Masonic lodge or of a women's club. Whatever their theme, however, pageants tend to be large-scale attractions.

description: THE Khmer Classical Dancers, based in Maryland, are Cambodian refugees who are successfully attempting to maintain the classical dance and music traditions of their homeland.

He has been doing strictly financial work and, he said, he wants to get back to doing advertising, the work he enjoys.

CRISIS DENOUNCEMENT, CANADIAN STYLE
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A sports article in some copies yesterday gave an incorrect location for a soccer playoff game scheduled Sunday between Columbia and Long Island University. It is Baker Field.

title: Houses Votes Banking Bill
description: The House tonight approved by voice vote a bill that would free banks from having to charge Federal insurance fees on deposits attracted to special international accounts that are to go into effect on Dec. 3.

title: Bearded Bus Driver Wins Discrimination Suit
description: A black bus driver who followed his doctor's advice to grow a beard and lost his job as a result has won a discrimination suit against the Trailways Bus System, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said today.

description: Even for Brazil, where national leaders like to think big, the project now getting under way at this Amazon site is immense.

Principal and Test Scores Tell the Story
description: According to her high school principal at Sacred Heart Academy in Hempstead, L.I., 17-year-old Laura Clark is a ''very quiet, intense, charming, altruistic person.''

title: Firestone to Begin A Tender Offer
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said it would begin a tender offer on Monday for up to 10 million of its common shares at $11.50 each, and reserved the right to buy an additional five million shares at the same price if tendered.

title: Man Tied to Mafia Sentenced in Plot
description: Russell A. Bufalino, a reputed Pennsylvania Mafia figure, was sentenced to 10 years and fined $15,000 for plotting unsuccessfully to kill a witness against him in a 1977 extortion trial.

title: PRESIDENT GETS REVISED PROPOSALS FOR STANDARDS ON SCHOOL LUNCHES
description: President Reagan has received revised proposals for school lunch standards, including one that would let children decide whether they wanted small or full-size portions of food, Administration officials said today.

title: COVINGTON TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VOTE ON LEASE PLAN IS SCRAPPED
description: Bowing to a court order, lawyers for St. Bartholomew's Church agreed yesterday to discard a completed parish vote on whether to lease a portion of the church's midtown property for construction of an office tower next to the landmark building. The church tentatively set a new vote for Dec. 15.

title: PROBLEMS GROW IN SHELTERING HOMELESS IN CITY
description: New York City officials say that the rapidly growing number of homeless people seeking shelter has forced them to seek new housing space quietly and move people in quickly, before community opposition has a chance to develop.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE WHOLE CLOTH

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on the Style page Satur- day, about contracts signed by couples before they marry or live together, in- correctly described New Jersey law. The state does not have a community- property law but since 1971 has had an equitable-distribution statute.

title: County Jury Hears Brink's Evidence
description: A grand jury in Rockland County has begun hearing evidence against five persons charged in the $1.6 million Brinks armored-car holdup in Nanuet Oct. 20, officials said.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: OTHER than wisdom teeth, I have lost one permanent tooth, and I have shoddy dentistry and myself to blame for it. I was camping in the wilderness out West when the tooth began to throb. The California dentist I finally saw shook his head in dismay: the tooth had decayed so extensively beneath a crown that it could not be saved. The crown had been made some years earlier by a neighboorhood dentist who functioned more like a short-order cook than a careful health professional. He ''worked'' at least three patients at a time, frenetically flitting from one treatment room to another, doing a little bit on one patient, then another, while a full waiting room kept on the pressure for speed. It was hardly the setting for careful dentistry. But it was close to home and swift, the fees were moderate and the dentist kept up a friendly chatter that took your mind off the inevitable discomfort. The price I paid for this convenience - besides the pain, a fixed bridge with two crowns to support it, requiring many weeks of treatment and hundreds of dollars - was hardly worth it.Even more than with medicine, consumers of dental care are hard put to evaluate the competence of the practitioner. A medical patient who does not get well or suffers frequent recurrences or mishaps from treatment may get suspicious about a doctor. But the hallmarks of careless dentistry are rarely obvious to the patient, at least not immediately.

title: Hours That Shine
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Regarding ''Their Shining Early Hours,'' (Nov. 11) by Judy Klemesrud: I am a schoolteacher.

title: THE TRAIL OF THE RUMOR ON BLAIR HOUSE'S 'BUG'
description: The rumor that Blair House was bugged by Jimmy Carter's Administration soared and crashed last month, strewing embarrassment and chagrin from The Washington Post, which printed and then retracted the report, to the White House, where the tale first entered the city's rumor circulatory system.

title: ROUSE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHITE HOUSE SAYS REAGAN KNEW IN SEPTEMBER ABOUT ALLEN INQUIRY
description: President Reagan has known since mid-September that his national security adviser, Richard V. Allen, received a $1,000 cash payment from a Japanese journalist, a White House spokesman said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bristol-Myers Company has elected John W. Melton a vice president.

title: Careers; Baby Boom Children in Job Squeeze
description: ARE you a child of the baby boom? If so, you might face a career problem. People born during the baby boom years of 1948 to 1962 are 19 to 33 years old today. They constitute an army of some 60 million people, according to the Census Bureau. And among them there are too many with education and ambition who are seeking to rise at the same time. The result is a bottleneck.

title: Giuseppe Roncalli, 87, Dies; A Brother of Pope John XXIII
description: Giuseppe Roncalli, the last surviving brother of Pope John XXIII, died at his home today of a stomach tumor, family members said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The right of religious organizations, of varying views, to speak must be defended by all who understand the meaning of religious liberty and the social role of religion.

title: BURGER BARS C.I.A. DISCLOSURE
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger refused today to allow the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church to gain access to sensitive spy data in the files of the Central Intelligency Agency.

title: Bridge: Take a Dummy-Play Test: Cover Hands of East-West
description: Those who like to test their skill in dummy play should cover the East-West hands on the diagramed deal and plan their moves in a contract of four spades. The opposing bidding should be taken into account: West has opened the bidding with one heart and subsequently bid clubs; East has responded one no-trump.

title: County to Pay Family Of Victim $1 Million
description: The Dade County Commissioners voted today to award $1 million to the family of a black insurance man, Arthur McDuffie, whose death after a beating by police officers led to three days of rioting here in May 1980.

OHIO PASSES LAW BLOCKING BID BY MOBIL
description: The Ohio Legislature gave final approval today to a bill that would block the Mobil Corporation's $5.1 billion takeover bid for Marathon Oil Corporation.

description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Coca-Cola Unit In Sale Accord
description: Allied-Lyons PLC, the British parent company of Tetley Inc., said it had reached agreement to buy the coffee, tea and related businesses of the Coca-Cola Company's Tenco division in the United States and Britain.

description: B-After pretax foreign currency translation losses of $130,000 for the qr and $490,000 for the 6 mos...C-After pretax foreign currency translation losses of $91,000 for the qr and $39,000 for the 6 mos

title: Jets Sued on Death As Result of Show
description: A $10 million damage suit was filed in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday in the death of a man who was struck by a radiocontrolled model airplane that was being flown as part of a halftime show at a New York Jets football game on Dec. 9, 1979.

title: Brooklyn Academy Gets $30,000 Clark Grant
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music has been awarded a grant of $30,000 by the Edna McConnell Clark Foundation. The annual award recognizes an arts organization in the greater New York area that demonstrates both the artistic excellence and sound business management.

title: Survey Research For Cosmetics Sales
description: Marketers who sell through supermarkets and drugstores are aided in their competitive wars by having available syndicated market share data that will let them know just where they stand relative to the others in their category - whether that dip in sales is everyone's problem or just theirs.

title: SELECTING THE RIGHT BIRD
description: THE turkey grandmother used to serve does not bear much resemblance to the average bird today. Most have been frozen and filled with ingredients no self-respecting turkey should contain. Some have had their appendages lopped off, the remaining breast meat rolled and, frequently, pressed into something that remembles a football with its ends slightly flattened. They have also been seasoned with an assortment of chemicals.

title: AGENCY'S PLAN TO QUIT CITY TAKES A PERSONAL TWIST
description: The New York State Power Authority, confronted by a doubling of its rent and a lack of space at its present headquarters at 10 Columbus Circle in Manhattan, has proposed moving about 70 percent of its operation out of New York City.

title: Tennessee-Wisconsin Seen for Garden State
description: Tennessee will face Wisconsin in the fourth Garden State Bowl, which will be played for the first time without a football team from the Northeast, The Associated Press reported Tuesday.

title: Shah's Son, 16, to Attend Massachusetts School
description: A follow-up: Ali Pahlevi, the 16-year-old son of the late Shah of Iran, was enrolled yesterday as a sophomore at Mount Greylock Regional High School in Williamstown, Mass.

title: FINDING READY-MADE FEASTS
description: WITH Christmas catalogues arriving before the end of October, Thanksgiving may be somewhat overshadowed. For those who have not been able to plan or prepare for the feast, suppliers in New York City can provide an entire Thanksgiving meal or some of the accompaniments, both traditional and original, even at the last minute.
