title: George Bragalini, 76; Ex-Tax Commissioner
description: George M. Bragalini, former New York State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance and Acting Postmaster of New York, died Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: MUSIC: BEETHOVEN 'EROICA' CONDUCTED BY TENNSTEDT
description: THERE are phenomena that should be experienced only occasionally if they are to make their most powerful effect. Riverside residents in India, that is to say, must be less impressed than tourists by moonlight on the Ganges. Doctors, in time, become less astounded than parents by the miracle of birth. That's the way it is, unfortunately, with great music, too. Who would not want to be going to hear the ''Eroica'' for the first or second or third time? We can wear out music by incessant use just as surely as dripping water can wear away a stone. For that reason, the people who see to it that the ''Eroica'' and a few other stupendous works come at us daily out of car radios and waiting-room loudspeakers should be subject to citizen's arrest and put away until they reform.

title: Marshall Field Ends Halle Link
description: Marshall Field & Company, the Chicago-based retailer, said it had agreed to sell the 16 Cleveland-area stores of its Halle division to a unit of Schottenstein Bros., a Columbus, Ohio, retailer and retail liquidator, for an undisclosed cash price. The sale does not include the real estate held by Halle's downtown Cleveland store, Marshall Field said.

title: WHAT RENT VOUCHERS CAN DO TOHOUSING PROJECTS
description: To the Editor:

title: WAY CLEAR FOR CAPITOL DEBATE ON B-1 AND MX
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee approved funds today for the B-1 bomber and the MX missile, thus clearing the way for a vigorous Congressional floor debate on the most disputed parts of President Reagan's nuclear deterrent program.

title: DAVID LIEB
description: David Lieb, general manager of the Knox Construction Company of West Orange, N.J., died Saturday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived in West Orange.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1981
description: International President Reagan has known for two months that his national security adviser, Richard V. Allen, received a $1,000 cash payment from a Japanese journalist who interviewed Mrs. Reagan one day after the Inauguration, the White House spokesman said. He also said, that in the 60 days in which the secret inquiry has been under way, the White House had made no decision on whether the matter would ever be made public. (Page A1, Columns 3-4.) A new Middle East peace initiative was reported by Reagan Administration officials. They said that Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's special envoy, planned to return to the region late this month to try to strengthen the cease-fire in Lebanon. (A1:1.)

title: MRS. WHITMORE WINS EASILY IN HOUSTON MAYORAL RUNOFF
description: Kathryn J. Whitmire, the City Controller, was easily elected today in a runoff for Mayor of Houston. She is the first woman elected to the post.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE ocean was slate green under an overcast morning sky as we put out from the dock in a small powerboat and headed into the chill wind of the Great South Bay off Long Island with two scallop dredges aboard. We were contemplating a harvest feast, the kind of repast typical of Thanksgivings long past, although we were a few weeks early.

title: New Chief Set At Foote, Cone
description: The board of directors of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications met in Chicago yesterday and decided that Norman W. Brown, president and chief operating officer since May, would get the chief executive's mantle when Arthur W. Schultz, chairman of the executive committee, turns 60 and retires in January.

title: A 'NO-GROWTH' TOWN FINDS ITSELF UNDER SIEGE
description: Stuart is a tough little town, tough on developers who would make it a big town, tough on anyone with visions of towering modernity. That resolve has given the place a problem: people, especially South Floridians fed up with crime, find Stuart attractive and move here.

title: PIANO RECITAL: GENA RAPS AND STRING PLAYERS
description: The 50-cent concert ticket existed at a prehistoric time for many of us. But at Gena Raps's recital Sunday night in Alice Tully Hall, the cheap ticket made a brief comeback - coincidentally, a few days after the New York City Opera reduced its ticket prices.

title: SOVIET FIRM ON GOALS OF 5-YEAR PLAN
description: Soviet planners today reported a poor start on the current five-year plan and a sizable reduction in projected capital investment. But they still asserted that they planned to stick with most economic goals set by the Communist Party through 1985.

title: I.C.C. Chief Assailed
description: A bipartisan panel of regulatory experts today assailed Reese H. Taylor Jr., chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, and his agency's application of the new trucking bill.

title: PEKING CELEBRATES VOLLYBALL SWEEP
description: Chinese young people this week have been seized by a fervor that involves not politics but volleyball. Defying a recent ban on unauthorized gatherings in Tian An Men Square, tens of thousands of Chinese converged on that vast downtown area last night for boisterous celebrations that prompted the police to rush in reinforcements and seal off some adjacent streets.

title: HOUSTON ENTREPRENEUR RNOVATES OFFICES DOWNTOWN
description: In Houston, John J. McMullen is best known as the owner of the Houston Astros. In maritime circles, he is best known as the man who runs John J. McMullen Associates, a naval architecture and marine engineering firm with 650 employees. He started it after he retired from the Navy as a captain in 1954.

title: NATIONAL SECURITIES & RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JENSEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMMONWEALTH NATIONAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HINDERLITER ENERGY EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 17
LOW-FLYING COPTER STARTLES RUSSIANS IN GLWN COVE MANSION
description: With engines roaring and floodlights glaring, a helicopter dropped out of the mist Monday night over Killenworth, the weekend residence here of the Soviet delegate to the United Nations.

title: CELEBRATING REGIONAL COOKING OF FRANCE
description: REGIONAL food has not done well in France's march toward modern uniformity. For many a contemporary Frenchman, cassoulet or choucroute is something that comes from a can, not grandmother's wood-burning stove. Enchanting country auberges that once served up regional specialties have given in to the greater marketability of nouvelle cuisine, while franchised creperies pop up in Brittany and fast-food brioche shops replace family boulangeries in communities large and small.

title: RODRIQUEZ TRADED TO TORONTO
description: As action in the free agent market lagged, the Yankees made a trade yesterday that on the surface was somewhat surprising. They sent Aurelio Rodriguez, their backup third baseman, to the Toronto Blue Jays for a player to be named.

title: ATLANTA GAS LIGHT CO reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
CBS PRESSES AFFILIATES TO ACCEPT ONE-HOUR NEWS
description: TV executives met with representatives of the network's affiliates yesterday in Hawaii in an effort to convince the affiliates' board to accept a proposal to expand ''The CBS Evening News'' from 30 minutes to an hour next year.

title: News Analysis
description: In the last eight weeks the Grumman Corporation has discovered just how expensive fighting an unwanted takeover bid can be. In its successful campaign to defeat the LTV Corporation's $450 million tender offer, Grumman spent more than $1.5 million in legal fees and $600,000 on newspaper advertising. The bills from its financial advisers are also expected to be steep.

title: BIO LOGICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JOFFREY BALLET: 'MOMENTUM' AND 'MOVES'
description: THE Joffrey Ballet's reputation for eclecticism got a boost on Saturday when two very different ballets re-entered the season's repertory at City Center.

title: DISCOVERY OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Closing in Canada
description: The Hudson's Bay Company, parent of Canada's biggest department store retailer, said it would close its unprofitable Shop-Rite catalogue store division on Jan. 30 because it saw no prospect for an early turnaround. Shop-Rite has been losing about $3 million a year, said C.W. Evans, president of the Bay, the retail division of the Hudson's Bay Company that runs Shop-Rite. Mr. Evans said the cost of closing Shop-Rite would amount to more than $8 million and would be written off as an extraordinary item by Hudson's Bay in the current year. The division is not affiliated with the Shop Rite food chain in the United States.

title: SIMPLICITY REJECTS BID FOR SHARES
description: The Simplicity Pattern Company, the world's leading producer of sewing patterns, turned down an offer from yet another suitor yesterday, apparently because it considered the bid inadequate.

title: MARGIOTTA RETRIAL OPENS IN U.S. COURT IN NASSAU
description: A prosecutor told the jury at the retrial of Joseph M. Margiotta today that the Nassau Republican leader had carried out ''a corrupt agreement'' to obtain insurancecommission kickbacks for his political supporters.

title: BISHOP SEEKING PERMISSION TO ORDAIN MARRIED EX-PASTOR
description: A Roman Catholic Bishop has asked the Vatican for permission to ordain to the priesthood a former Lutheran pastor who is married and has two children.

title: COAL-SLURRY PIPELINE BILL IS SET BACK
description: The Reagan Administration declared its opposition today to legislation that would give builders of proposed coal-slurry pipelines the power of eminent domain to acquire rights of way for their systems.

title: RAYMOND F. GRANLUND
description: Raymond F. Granlund, a Texas consultant sentenced to three years in Federal prison for his role in a Florida Power Corporation oil scandal, died Sunday in a hospital in Houston, Tex., at the age of 76.

title: JUDGE OVERTURNS AT-LARGE SYSTEM FOR CITY COUNCIL
description: New York City's system of electing two City Council members at large from each borough was declared unconstitutional yesterday by a Federal judge. He ruled that it violated the one-person, one-vote principle.

title: ULSTER PASSIONS HIGH AS M.P. IS BURIED
description: The Rev. Robert Bradford, the member of the British Parliament killed last Saturday by the Irish Republican Army, was buried here today after ceremonies that entwined religion and politics.

title: U.S. JUDGE RULES HINCKLEY'S RIGHTS WERE VIOLATED
description: Federal officials who interrogated John W. Hinckley Jr. after he was arrested for shooting President Reagan and three other men March 30 violated his constitutional rights, Federal District Judge Barrington D. Parker ruled this afternoon.

title: Fuqua Settles Shareholder Suit
description: Fuqua Industries said it had settled a shareholders' lawsuit challenging its plan to buy back its stock at $20 a share. The settlement, which must still have court approval in Delaware, stipulates that the company pay an additional 25 cents a share tendered.

description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that James F. Capalino, Commissioner of the Department of General Services, was resigning at the end of the year.

title: A New President Named by Nu-West
description: H. Earl Joudrie, 47 years old, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Nu-West Group Ltd., a real estate development and energy company based in Calgary, Alberta. He succeeds Ralph T. Scurfield, 52, who was elected chairman and continues as chief executive officer.

description: Net losses are after tax credits

title: Padres Bid for Williams
description: The San Diego Padres offered Dick Williams the job as manager yesterday and Williams said he would give them his reply today. ''We made what I consider a very substantial proposal,'' Ballard Smith, the Padres' president, said by telephone from San Diego.

title: HOUSE PANEL STUDIES A BAN ON OIL LEASES IN WILDERNESS AREAS
description: The House Interior Committee, under the initiative of its ranking Republican member, moved today to consider a proposal to bar oil and gas leasing and mining for minerals in Federal wilderness areas.

title: LUCKY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
SPECIAL HOLIDAY TOUCH BY SPECIAL PEOPLE
description: MOORHEAD C. KENNEDY Jr. will mark the first Thanksgiving at which he has ''ever felt the need to be thankful.'' Isaac Bashevis Singer will not have turkey on Thanksgiving Day. A vegetarian, he will eat the same way he does every other day. Arthur Miller and his wife, Inge Morath, will not have turkey either, but they will have a piece montee of colorful vegetables to look like the bird. Mary McFadden's dinner, prepared nouvelle cuisine style, will include glazed ham, pomegranates and raspberry sherbet.

title: News Analysis
description: Nine years ago this month, President Nixon demanded and received the resignation of the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh as chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights after the panel accused the Administration of reducing the enforcement of school desegregation.

title: BEST BUYS
description: SOME fruit and vegetable prices have gone up in the last week, but fresh turkeys have decreased in price compared to those of a year ago.

title: PERKIN-ELMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
G & K SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
Peplinski Gets 4 Goals
description: Jim Peplinski scored four goals for Calgary. Peplinski, who has nine goals for the season, scored twice in the first period.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: THE Talking Heads have been the most adventurous and consistently compelling of all the rock bands that emerged from the lower Manhattan ''punk'' scene of the mid-70's. Their backgrounds -Harvard and the Rhode Island School of Design - and their look - clean-cut bordering on preppie - were anything but punk, and their music, which was lean, almost skeletal in the beginning but has grown increasingly richer, started trends rather than following them.

title: HOP-IN FOOD STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jets' Linebackers Playing a Key Role
description: In the Jets' rise to only a game out of first place, the linebackers have been overshadowed by the extraordinary play of the club's front four.

title: JOHNSON PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
VOLUME FALLS
description: The stock market registered a moderate advance yesterday that analysts attributed to bargain-hunting and the continuing decline in interest rates.

title: Colin Winter, Bishop Expelled From South-West Africa, Dies
description: Colin Winter, the former Anglican Bishop of Damaraland in South-West Africa, who was expelled by South Africa nine years ago, died at his home in London today after suffering his fourth heart attack, his family said. He was 53 years old.

title: WELLS FARGO TRADING
description: Wells Fargo & Company disclosed today that its Wells Fargo Bank unit stated futures trading for the first time in the third quarter and had $175 million of Treasury bill futures outstanding at the end of the period. The bank began using the futures contracts to hedge that portion of its net liability position at the six-month maturity that funds shorter-term assets, the company said. It said that gains or losses on the trading will initially affect the income statement during the current fourth quarter.

title: HOLLY: THE TALK OF PRINCETON
description: The 104th Princeton-Yale football game will probably be remembered as Holly's Game, the one in which Bob Holly, Princeton's quarterback, scored the winning touchdown with four seconds to go. He passed for 501 yards and brought his team from a 21-0 deficit to a 35-31 victory, the Tigers' first over the Elis in 15 years.

title: AWARD-WINNING SCIENTIST ON L.I. PRIZES PRIVACY
description: Receiving not one, but two prestigious science prizes almost simultaneously, with a third in the offing, is unsettling, said Dr. Barbara McClintock, a geneticist who worries that the unsought awards could disturb the privacy she has guarded for more than half a century.

title: Coroner Terms Death Of Holden an Accident
description: The Los Angeles Coroner said today that the death of the actor William Holden sometime last week was probably accidental, the result of a fall. An assistant coroner said the actor had been ''heavily intoxicated'' when he fell.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, Nov. 9, to Sunday, Nov. 15), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets. KNICKS SUBDUED BY KINGS
description: The Knicks again showed poor execution on offense and little effectiveness on defense, and lost their third consecutive game, a 124-110 decision to Kansas City Kings last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: LEAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Aluminum Prices Drop
description: The price of aluminum fell to a record low today, in part a result of continuing weakness in the United States automobile and construction industries.

title: STANDARD BRANDS PAINT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STUFFING THE TURKEY: RECIPES FROM THE BASIC TO THE ESOTERIC

title: Schmidt Named M.V.P.  For 2d Straight Year
description: Mike Schmidt of the Philadelphia Phillies, who led the league in seven categories during the strike-interrupted season, was voted most valuable player in the National League yesterday. He became only the third player in the league to win the award in successive seasons.

title: ORBIT INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The shr earnings are fully diluted

title: FRESH CHESTNUTS DROP IN PRICE
description: There is good news for chestnut eaters this fall: fresh chestnuts from Italy are down to less than $1 a pound in some stores. Last year they were in short supply because of a summer drought; those who bought them roasted from chestnut vendors were paying as much as $1 for seven.

title: NATIONAL PARAGON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $6,500 for the qr and $57,400 for the 6 mos...C-Including extraordinary tax credits of $40,475 for the qr and $46,725 for the 6 mos

title: EXPERT ON YOUNG
description: Herschel Alt, a specialist in mental health and child welfare, author and former executive director of the Jewish Board of Guardians, died Monday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: No Headline
description: SPAIN DENIES MILITARY UNREST

title: NEW YORK TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PERKIN-ELMER OFF
description: The Unilever Group, the huge Dutch-British conglomerate, reported yesterday that earnings in the third quarter increased 13.2 percent, while sales increased 16 percent.

title: GROWTH REALTY COS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Flxible Buses In Use in Jersey
description: The first 61 of 271 Grumman Flxible buses have been put into service in New Jersey.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amcon Group Inc., a unit of Consolidated Gold Fields Ltd., said it had increased its share in Newmont Mining Corp. to 17.6 percent of the common shares outstanding, or a total of 4,578,300 shares.

title: Florida Savings Merger Studied
description: The officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank board will meet in Washington, D.C., tomorrow with officials of Miami-based Amerifirst Federal Savings in an effort to arrange a merger of that savings and loan with the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Broward County.

title: King Hussein in London
description: King Hussein of Jordan visited Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher for 35 minutes today, and they discussed the Middle East. Diplomatic officials said he also told her about his recent talks with President Reagan.

title: GRETZKY CLICKS ON INTERVIEWS
description: The greatest one-man show in ice hockey, the center of centers, the one and only Wayne Gretzky sat in the visitors dressing room at Madison Square Garden, beginning his second performance of the night.

title: Torres Dance Theater Honoring Chita Rivera
description: Julio Torres's Latin American Dance Theater will honor Chita Rivera with its 11th Anniversary Award in a private ceremony at Lincoln Center today. The citation reads: ''To a lady, who with her talent and artistry has helped raise the image of the Puerto Rican and Hispanic people everywhere.''

title: NOBEL SCIENCE PANEL'S METICULOUS ANNUAL SEARCH FOR EXCELLENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Mark for Weanling
description: A weanling bay filly by Vaguely Noble sold for a North American-record of $525,000 during the third session of the Keeneland November Breeding Stock Sale today. The British Bloodstock Agency of Ireland purchased the filly. The top price paid during today's session was $925,000 for Table of Contents, a 10-yearold mare reported to be in foal to Spectacular Bid.

title: Fumes Overcome 14 in Italy
description: Fourteen motorists were overcome by poisonous chlorine fumes today after a tanker truck overturned on the freeway near this southern Italian city. The police said that 4 people were hospitalized in serious condition and that 10 had been released after treatment. The motorists were overcome after they stopped to help the truck driver, who was trapped in his cab and died of his injuries.

title: MODERATE LEADER IN WEST BANK SHOT
description: A moderate Palestinian leader on the occupied West Bank, a key figure in Israel's latest efforts to curb the influence of the Palestine Liberation Organization, was critically wounded by terrorists today. His 23-year-old son was killed.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday on the Audelco Recognition Awards for black achievement off Broadway and off Off Broadway incorrectly listed the winner for best director of a musical production. He was Charles Turner, who directed ''Bessie Smith, Empress of the Blues.''

title: KOCH TO BOYCOTT MEETING ON WAY CITY IS MANAGED
description: Mayor Koch, reportedly still smarting from criticism he received a year ago, has told his commissioners to boycott an annual conference that will be held in early December to examine how New York City is run.

title: Taking the Cake
description: Representative Raymond J. McGrath, Republican of Nassau, in The McGrath Report, a newsletter, Nov. 12: We frequently think of the Federal budget as a large pie, each of us fighting for a larger slice. But I would like you to think of our entire Federal system of government as a cake.

title: President of Bangladesh Takes 66% of Vote
description: President Abdus Sattar won nearly 66 percent of the vote in the presidential election Sunday, official returns showed today.

title: President Appoints 2 Aides
description: President Reagan today named Aram Bakshian Jr., an author, as director of the Presidential speech writing office. Anthony R. Dolan, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter, was named chief White House speech writer. Mr. Bakshian, 37 years old, has been in the President's Office of Public Liaison. Mr. Dolan, 33, of Norwalk, Conn., has been acting director of speech writing.

title: POLISH GOVERNMENT AND UNION RESUME TALKS
description: The first substantive talks in almost three months between the Polish Government and the Solidarity trade union began today with an appeal for cooperation from the Government negotiator.

title: Henry Fonda Back in the Hospital
description: A day before the Hollywood premiere of his latest movie, Henry Fonda was readmitted yesterday to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, suffering from chronic heart disease.

title: ETZ LAVUD LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from affiliated companies of $409,000 for the qr and $1,301,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including income from affiliated companies of $155,000 forthe qr and $260,000 for the 6 mos; results were translated at the rates of 11.31 per $1 for the latest periods and 6.38 per $1 for the yr-ago periods

title: S.E.C. IS CHIDED IN ST. JOE CASE
description: The president of a Swiss investment house yesterday accused the Securities and Exchange Commission of ''leaking partial information'' about his role in the purchase of securities last March in the St. Joe Minerals Corporation before a takeover bid by the Seagram Company.

title: WEIDENBAUM SEES LOW GROWTH IN '82
description: President Reagan's chief economic adviser, Murray L. Weidenbaum, in an implicit acknowledgment that the recession will be neither mild nor brief, scaled back his forecast today for economic growth in 1982.

title: CITIZENS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Per Series A common stock...C-Per Series B common stock

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHENEVER I am asked how I go about ''creating'' recipes, I say that my approach is twofold. If it is a classic recipe along the lines, say, of a tournedos Rossini or a fillet of sole Duglere, I work mostly from memory. Yet I am also guided by the precepts laid down by Escoffier, who wrote the culinary bible more than 50 years ago. More often than not the foods that I cook at home or elsewhere are improvisations. And the latter are the types of dishes that give me the greatest pleasure.

title: DROUGHT THREATENS FLORIDA SUGAR CROP IN 1982-83 HARVEST
description: Less than a year after Florida surpassed Hawaii as the largest producer of raw sugar in the nation, sugar cane growers here are facing a severe water shortage that may cost them their 1982-83 crop.

title: STUFFING THE TURKEY: FROM BASIC TO ESOTERIC
description: IF there ever was a season for stuffed foods, it is now upon us. In fact, if I were to nominate a Stuffed Foods Day to be celebrated throughout America, Thanksgiving Day, a week from tomorrow, would be it. There is little doubt that cooks will spend more time, imagination and enthusiasm in stuffing holiday turkeys than they will in any other 24-hour period. And, of course, the season for stuffings and dressings will continue from now until New Year's Day, its focus ranging from turkeys and capons to all manner of game birds.

title: FOUNDATION PICKS GENETICIST AS ITS FIRST FELLOW LAUREATE
description: A 79-year old geneticist regarded widely as having laid the basis in 1951 of the modern chromosome theory of heredity was selected yesterday by a Chicago foundation as the winner of its Prize Fellow Laureate Award. The award, presented for the first time, gives her a guaranteed income of $60,000 a year for life.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have heard that basil leaves can be preserved in oil throughout the winter. I can find no instructions for this. Do you agree that the leaves can be kept in oil?

title: 1. Slinky Sashes
description: Fashion's focus keeps shifting to different parts of the figure. One season, designers are emphasizing shoulders, then they move to waistlines and everything gets cinched in. Now, the fashion prophets see an emphasis on hips, which means sashes wrapped and tied low, rather than at the waistline. Some of the most interesting of the hip sashes are made of leather by Douglas Ferguson, who hand paints abstract designs on soft kidskin, which drapes nicely. The Ferguson patterns are abstracts, using gold and pewter metallic paint, and sometimes an additional color such as magenta or turquoise. No two are alike and all are signed by the artist. You'll find them, priced at $90, at the Madeleine boutique, 237 East 60th Street.

title: Bear Ruffled
description: Talk of a pro football franchise for Birmingham has ruffled Bear Bryant, who says he believes that it would hurt the college game. ''If you want to see a pro football game, all you have to do is turn on your tube,'' said Bryant, the Alabama coach, who Saturday tied Amos Alonzo Stagg's record of 314 victories.

title: SECURITY COUNCIL AGAIN FAILS TO NAME A SECRETARY GENERAL
description: The Security Council went through eight more inconclusive rounds of balloting today in its attempt to choose a new Secretary General, and its members for the first time began considering how to bring other nominees into the race.

title: HUDSON GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CAST OF THOUSANDS
description: Believe me, friend, it's no lark shooting a film in Washington, especially a multibillion-dollar opus like ''The Trojan Horse.'' The phone goes from dawn to midnight. Hold it a minute. It's ringing now.

title: GEORGE KENNAN CALLS ON U.S. TO VIEW SOVIET MORE SOBERLY
description: George F. Kennan, the historian and former diplomat, feels that the view of the Soviet Union in ''our governmental and journalistic establishments'' is so distorted and exaggerated that it imperils the chances for ''a more hopeful world.''

title: CENTRAL SERVICE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss...C-Net income

title: The Therapy Maze
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Your generally fine discussion about major kinds of psychotherapy (''Guide Through the Maze of Psychotherapies,'' Oct. 28) contains two unfortunate errors. One is the stipulation of the Academy of Certified Social Workers (A.C.S.W.) as the qualifying professional organization for social work therapists.

title: BRIEFING
description: GOADED by motives ranging from moral outrage to bureaucratic animus, 250 Americans on the average call up their Government secretly every week over a single ''hot line'' and make charges of mismanagement, waste and fraud against individuals and programs. This accusatory buzz has become a steady feature of democracy in the age of the toll-free call since the General Accounting Office instituted its ''800'' number 30 months and 32,000 phone calls ago. The ineptitude and conniving uncovered so far range from a tip on purloined Navy refrigerators, to a $200,000-a-year loss in rent paid by the Government on New York office space that a caller disclosed to be vacant, to million-dollar boons extended to wealthy farmers supposedly ineligible for Government subsidies.

title: STAGE: 'FIRST,' BASEBALL MUSICAL
description: IF you're going to do a musical about how Jackie Robinson broke the color barrier in major-league baseball, there are two very difficult tasks that must be done right: you must find a singing actor who can impersonate the charismatic Robinson of legend, and you must find a method for simulating baseball games on stage. The paradox of ''The First,'' which opened at the Martin Beck last night, is that both these tough demands have been met well -and that the more routine tasks of creating a musical haven't been met at all. While this show offers about five minutes of good baseball and a promising star in David Alan Grier, its back is broken by music, lyrics, book and direction that are the last word in dull.

title: Street-Wise Sneakers
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: How timely Michaele Weissman's article (''Footloose in Manhattan (in Sneakers),'' Nov. 4) was for me. It appeared on the day I had purchased my first pair.

title: SOME NEW FLAVORS AS COUNTERPOINTS
description: Carrots, Ginger and Cumin 1 pound young carrots 2 teaspoons cumin seed 5 tablespoons butter 1 tablespoon chopped fresh ginger 2 cloves garlic, chopped 2 tablespoons lemon juice 1/2 cup regular or low-fat milk Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste.

title: THE RACE TO AUTOMATE OFFICES
description: The office automation business, William S. Anderson, chairman of the NCR Corporation, says, ''has become so crowded that it's difficult to keep track of all the players without a scorecard.''

title: BLACK DESIGNERS AND STUDENTS HONORED
description: ''REMEMBER the name Stephen Cutting, Seventh Avenue!'' the young design student shouted triumphantly into the microphone. Marvin Feldman, president of the Fashion Institute of Technology, had just presented a plaque to Mr. Cutting proclaiming his selection as the most promising student of the year for the Fourth Annual Harveys Bristol Cream Tribute to the Black Designer.

title: Teaching of Evolution And Bible View Favored
description: By The Associated Press Three of four Americans believe that both the scientific theory of evolution and the biblical view of the Creation should be taught in public schools, according to the latest Associated Press-NBC News Poll.

title: Teen-Agers Deny Role In Drowning Deaths
description: Five teen-agers accused of beating and then causing the drowning of two youths from a neighboring town said in statements to the police that they were involved in a brawl, but denied pushing the victims' car into a lake.

title: THE SEASON FOR GIVING HAS ARRIVED
description: THIS is the season for heaping encomiums, distributing awards, voting championships and bestowing immortality. A single mail delivery this week brought literature about a running back, a race horse, a first baseman and a brood mare. All called attention to exceptional qualities possessed by some athletic figure.

title: CHEYENNE RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income including extraordinary items...C-Including extraordinary items

description: Following are excerpts from the decision by Federal Judge Edward R. Neaher that the present apportionment of at-large seats in the New York City Council is unconstitutional:

title: Transactions
description: AUTO RACING

title: SAVORY VARIATIONS ON OLD THEMES
description: A FRIEND who had tired of watching her children pick at the turkey each Thanksgiving decided to teach them a lesson. Last year she served a Thanksgiving brisket of beef. She will never do that again.

title: VENEZUELA WARNS U.S. ON NICARAGUA
description: The President of Venezuela has cautioned the United States against any military action aimed at Nicaragua and says he is opposed to any outside intervention in Central America.

title: GROUPS TRYING TO SWAY LATIN AMERICA POLICY
description: As passions on the issue of United States policy toward El Salvador, Nicaragua and the rest of Central America rise, so does the visibility of ''alternative'' policy groups, who oppose that policy. Watching them at work in Washington these days is a laboratory lesson in the forming of public opinion.

title: HMG PROPERTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
House Bus Bill
description: The House Public Works and Transportation Committee today approved compromise legislation to loosen the Government's reins on the intercity bus industry. The legislation, which generally resembles the course taken in earlier years when Congress deregulated the airline and trucking industries, would ease requirements imposed by the Interstate Commerce Commission for bus companies to enter and leave a service route, obtain operating certificates and adjust fares.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE LANGUAGE OF CLOTHES. By Ali- son Lurie. 272 pages. Illustrated. Ran- dom House. $20. THE FASHIONABLE MIND. Reflections on Fashion 1970-81. By Kennedy Fraser. 270 pages. Knopf. $14.50.

title: PENNEY PLANS SALE OF INSURANCE UNIT
description: The J.C. Penney Company said yesterday that it was seeking a buyer for one of its insurance units, the Great American Reserve Insurance Company, in a bid to strengthen the name identification of its other two insurers. Penney, the nation's third largest retailer, did not disclose an asking price.

title: HAZELTON LABORATORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXCERPTS FROM THE ADDRESS BY ARCHBISHOP ROACH
description: Following are excerpts from an address today by Archbishop John Roach of Minneapolis, president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, at the group's meeting here:

title: Nick-Pack Strikes Home
description: Yesterday several New York radio stations started broadcasting commercials attacking Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. The attacks are from the right: they scorn him as the Senate's most liberal member. Yet the ads are not paid for by Bruce Caputo, the former Congressman who wants the Republican Senate nomination. The sponsor is NCPAC, raising a problem of fair play.

title: FUROR LOOMS AT HERBICIDE HEARING
description: A scientist chosen by the Veterans Administration to design a study of the effects of the herbicide Agent Orange on humans will be the focus of a hearing in Washington today by the Senate Veterans Affairs Committee.

title: NORDIQUES TRIUMPH, 7-2, OVER SLUMPING ISLANDERS
description: Unable to hold onto big leads in their last two games, the Islanders were forced to attempt something different tonight and play catch-up hockey against the Quebec Nordiques.

title: HIGBEE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CINDY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: FREDERICK C. SHIPLEY
description: Frederick C. Shipley, former professor of English at City College and dean of its summer session for many years, died last Wednesday at a hospital in Portland, Me.

title: Hyatt Holders In Share Bid
description: The Hyatt International Corporation said that its major stockholders, consisting primarily of Pritzker family interests, would offer minority shareholders $25 a share in cash to acquire full control of the company.

title: New Hope for the Ghost Hospital
description: Woodhull, the ultramodern new 610-bed hospital in Brooklyn, has seemed jinxed from the start. First labor strife and cost overruns imperiled construction. Then the prospect of staggering operating costs prevented its opening. Mayor Koch even tried to turn it into a Federal prison. The only people to use Woodhull as a hospital have been film makers who needed a set for medical sequences.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Caterpillar Tractor Company said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed offering of $150 million of notes due in 1991, to be sold through a Goldman, Sachs group.

title: STAR WITH DORSEY BIG BANDS
description: Bob Eberly, a popular Swing Era singer who performed with the Dorsey brothers and helped make famous such songs as ''Tangerine'' and ''Green Eyes,'' died Tuesday at his daughter's home in Glen Burnie. He was 65 years old.

title: COACH TESTIFIES IN TRIAL
description: Tom Davis, coach of the Boston College basketball team, testified as a witness for one of his former players yesterday that he detected no ''intentional'' errors by anyone on the team during the 1978-1979 season. However, under cross-examination by a Government prosecutor, Mr. Davis agreed that a coach would have little way of distinguishing between misplays that were intentional and those that were not.

title: ROHR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: B-Includes $98,000 gain from discontinued operations

title: SAGE ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $4,865,000 gain

title: Rear Adm. William O. Gallery; A Navy Veteran of Two Wars
description: Rear Adm. William O. Gallery, an aide to Adm. William Halsey in World War II and commander of the aircraft carrier Princeton in the Korean war, died Friday at the age of 77.

title: REAGAN TO CHOOSE CALIFORNIAN TO RUN IMMIGRATION SERVICE
description: President Reagan announced today that he intended to nominate Alan C. Nelson, a lawyer from California, to be Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization.

title: MCO RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company began operations Apr 16, 1980 so therefore the yr-ago 9 mos figures are pro forma

title: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1981; The Economy
description: Projected economic growth in 1982 was scaled back to roughly 1 percent in a new forecast by President Reagan's chief economic adviser, Murray L. Weidenbaum. It was an implicit acknowledgement that the recession will be deeper and longer-lasting than expected. Mr. Weidenbaum's figure seemed compatible with estimates of an $80 billion deficit in the 1982 fiscal year. (Page A1.)

title: NUTMEG GRINDERS
description: THERE is one spice the mere thought of which evokes for me the greatest triumphs of France's haute cuisine. It is nutmeg, a sweet, aromatic spice that comes mostly from the Caribbean or the Moluccas. It lends bouquet to a cream sauce and subtlety to a pate. It is nutmeg that elevates a puree of spinach or a mornay sauce.

title: GEO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for pooling of interests

title: Big Plus for Virginia
description: The news for the University of Virginia's basketball team, which opens Saturday against Brigham Young in the Hall of Fame Game at Springfield, Mass., is good and bad. Ralph Sampson, the Cavaliers' 7-foot-4-inch center, tested his injured hip in a scrimmage and is expected to be ready.

title: HAWAIIAN AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: A firehouse is a peculiar little world all its own, a welter of black Mackinaws, narrow bunks, pinups, wisecracks, camaraderie, soot, the smell of smoke and fear pushed far to the back of the mind. The fact is that things burn in New York City, and rarely more so than in the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick, where Engine Company 214 and Ladder Company 111 fight fire.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 16.00-16.50** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.+ Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Senate Panel Backs Abrams For Post on Human Rights
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved the nomination of Elliott Abrams today as Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights in a hearing that contrasted with the controversy over an earlier nominee, Ernest Lefever.

title: ATWOOD OCEANICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $1.9 million extraordinary credits...C-Including extraordinary tax credit and gain on partial extinguishment of debt

title: Key Oppenheimer Aide
description: Oppenheimer & Company, the Wall Street partnership, owns and operates a brokerage firm and two money-management companies as well as a variety of companies in other industries. Now the investment house has named Lester Pollack, 48, as a partner to direct a key aspect of the organization's investment banking activities.

title: BRIEFING
description: S ENATOR Arlen Specter was sitting in his office on Monday afternoon, listening to his ''squawk box'' and the floor debate on the school prayer issue. Suddenly Mr. Specter, a Republican from Pennsylvania, heard Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, provoke an uproar by referring to Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, who is Jewish, as ''the Senator from B'nai B'rith.''

title: Notes on People; Soviet Youth Seeks Adoption in Chicago
description: Since he ran away from his Chicago home 16 months ago rather than return with his parents to the Soviet Union, 14-year-old Walter Polovchak has been living in a foster home and the question of his custody has been entangled in lawsuits in Federal and Illinois courts.

title: WALDHEIM'S PERSISTENCE STIRS CONCERN
description: Some senior diplomats from countries supporting Secretary General Kurt Waldheim fear that his pursuit of a third five-year term has damaged his prestige and that of his office.

title: Helpful Hardware; UNDER LOCK AND KEY
description: FINDING a pick-proof padlock is a challenge, but we have found two whose manufacturers assert that the locks are practically ''unpickable.'' They are easy to use, whether locking a wine cabinet, gate, storage room or bubble-gum machine.

title: Change in Career
description: Calling it ''a career change,'' Jim Young, Purdue University head football coach, announced he would resign at the end of the season to devote full time to his position as the university's associate athletic director.

title: INCOME UP 0,6% IN U.S. IN OCTOBER
description: Americans' personal income rose sixtenths of 1 percent in October, the smallest increase since May, and their spending declined for the first time since April, the Commerce Department reported today in a new sign that the economy is in recession.

title: THE THRIFTS' SELF-INFLICTED WOUNDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Submarine Tanker Plans
description: The General Dynamics Corporation disclosed that it was discussing with several West German shipbuilders plans to build 28 submarine tankers to carry liquefied natural gas from the Arctic to North America and Europe.

title: AVANT-GARDE: PERCUSSION
description: PERHAPS it's just a coincidence, but the lower Manhattan musical scene all of a sudden seems awash in solo percussionists, from Zev to Glenn Velez to Gerry Hemingway, who appeared last Thursday evening for a recital of music by himself and others at the Kitchen.

title: A HALF DOZEN CRAFTS FAIRS IN CONNECTICUT
description: THIS holiday season in Connecticut brings a cornucopia of quality craft fairs and sales. And for New Yorkers with wheels, it is possible to cover several in a day, as they are closely clustered: four in the Hartford area; one in New Haven; another in New Canaan. The exhibitions include:

title: WEINBERGER ASSAILS STOCKMAN'S CHARGE
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger took issue today with Budget Director David A. Stockman's contention that the Pentagon was a ''swamp'' of waste and inefficiency. He said the assertion ''just isn't correct.''

title: Todd Still in Pain, Unsure of Playing
description: After a dozen warmup tosses at the Jets' camp today, Richard Todd had to stop because of pain from his broken rib. His availability to start at quarterback Sunday against the Miami Dolphins in the battle for first place will not be determined until Friday.

title: TURKS TREAT PAPANDREOU WITH PATIENCE
description: The Turkish military junta has decided that the best policy toward Greece's new Prime Minister, Andreas Papandreou, is patience.

title: 600 BRITISH TROOPS FLYING TO ULSTER
description: Britain began flying 600 more soldiers into Northern Ireland today in response to an increase in tension and violence.

title: Shell Finds Tungsten
description: Shell South Africa Ltd., a unit of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, has discovered recoverable reserves of tungsten-bearing ore in South Africa, the company said today. South Africa currently imports about 800 tons of tungsten ore a year, mostly from Canada, and last produced tungsten domestically in 1969, when 61 metric tons were recovered.

title: 'Specimen Days' Opens At the Public on Dec. 2
description: ''Specimen Days,'' a new musical theater piece conceived and directed by Meredith Monk, will begin performances Dec. 2 at the Public Theater-LuEsther Hall.

title: CITY PANEL NARROWS 4-BOROUGH CONTESTS FOR CABLE TV PACTS
description: A city panel yesterday narrowed from 13 to seven the number of companies competing for the most sought-after cable franchises in the nation - contracts in Brooklyn, Staten Island, the Bronx and Queens.

title: Critic's Notebook; THE HAZARD IN OCCUPATIONAL DRAMAS
description: TAKING a cue from Britain's David Storey, dramatists have increasingly been writing plays about shared work activities. The method is not as easy as it seems. The result can simply be a slice of life rather than a microcosm rising into metaphor. In the words of a character in a recent example of the genre, ''What you see is what you get.'' Plays have taken place in a second-hand resale shop, an all-night diner, bars, a gourmet restaurant, an art gallery and a shoeshine parlor. In each case, one can learn something new and occasionally useful. By that, I do not mean moral or philosophical truths, but simple, everyday lessons, such as how to steam a bass, spit-shine shoes or mix colors in a dye factory.

title: PIANIST: ROBERT SILVERMAN
description: ROBERT SILVERMAN, a Canadian pianist who has played in New York, gave a recital Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y in a series sponsored by the Center for Inter-American Relations. His program was made up of Beethoven's ''Moonlight'' Sonata, Rachmaninoff's Sonata No. 1, Brahms's Rhapsody in B minor, Copland's Variations and Jacques Hetu's Prelude et Danse.

title: Mobil Track Grand Prix Expands to 14 Meets
description: The USA/Mobil indoor track and field Grand Prix, backed by a $100,000 contribution in prize money, announced an expanded format yesterday.

title: MACY GAINS 6.1%
description: Three of the country's four largest department store chains yesterday reported sharply lower earnings for the most recent quarter, ended Oct. 31, while the fourth, R.H. Macy & Company, said its earnings were up 6.1 percent from last year for the quarter.

title: POP: NATALIE COLE SINGS ROCK AND SOUL
description: WHEN Natalie Cole burst onto the pop-music scene six years ago with her first hit, ''This Will Be,'' she impressed many observers as one of the most promising young pop-soul singers of her generation. Though her voice wasn't as large as Aretha Franklin's, she had skillfully assimilated many of Miss Franklin's mannerisms, such as unexpectedly bursting out of a pop mode into pure gospel.

title: THEATER: 'JOSEPH AND THE DREAMCOAT'
description: ''JOSEPH and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat'' was the first Andrew Lloyd Webber-Tim Rice musical to be produced - at St. Paul's Junior School in London in 1968 in a version that lasted 25 minutes. Since then, the show has been expanded, recorded, taped for television and staged in various cities of the world, including an engagement at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: WE NEED THE TAX WEAPON TO FIGHT HIGH INTEREST
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes on People; The Busy but Sometimes Lonely Cabaret Circuit
description: With Margaret Whiting and Rosemary Clooney opening at one Manhattan cabaret, Mel Torme holding forth at another, and Diahann Carroll opening on Long Island, Jonathan Schwartz wasn't expecting a sellout at his own New York opening Tuesday night.

title: KISSINGER RESCUED IN PROTEST AT BRAZIL COLLEGE
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger was trapped in a lecture hall for two hours today by 400 students protesting his visit to the University of Brasilia. He was finally rescued by the police and left in a paddy wagon.

title: Article 098605 -- No Title
description: A $225-a-week electrical maintenance worker in a Manhattan office building was announced yesterday as the sole winner of the $5 million prize in the New York State Nov. 14 Lotto drawing, the largest known lottery payoff in history.

title: U.N. ASSEMBLY, FOR 3D TIME, BIDS 'FOREIGN TROOPS' QUIT AFGHANISTAN
description: The General Assembly renewed its demand today that ''foreign troops'' leave Afghanistan. This was the third time since Moscow's military intervention in that country in December 1979 that the Assembly issued such a call, and the vote was again lopsided. Today, 116 nations supported the resolution, 23 were opposed and 12 abstained.

title: DEATH VALLEY FISH DECLARED EXTINCT
description: The Interior Department's Fish and Wildlife Service today pronounced the Tecopa pupfish extinct. It is the first creature to be removed from the endangered species list for that reason, and the cause, according to the service, was a bathhouse.

title: THE FINANCIAL ARM OF NATIONAL STEEL
description: When Pete Love, chairman of National Steel, is not busy streamlining his steel operations, he likes to talk about making National the financial services company for the working class.

title: FEMINIST MAYOR FOR HOUSTON
description: She beat them all: the Mayor, who in the voters' minds had apparently allowed the quality of public services in explosively growing Houston to slip badly; the sheriff, who called his 5-foot opponent ''that little lady,'' and the bankers and lawyers and developers and big-money people who once largely decided who was elected to public office in Houston.

title: No Headline
description: Harry Connick, the New Orleans district attorney, said today that he will disclose to the Louisiana Racing Commission tomorrow the details of a seven-month investigation into reports of race-fixing at Fair Grounds race track.

title: Chrysler Canada
description: About 9,000 unionized employees of Chrysler Canada Ltd. voted by a 79-to-21 percent margin to negotiate a separate contract with the auto maker beginning next year, a move that ends a 12-year practice of operating under a joint United Automobile Workers union contract with Chrysler workers in the United States.

title: FLAWS IN CENTRALIZING FUNDING OF RESEARCH
description: To the Editor:

title: World Textile Talks Begin
description: Major producing and consuming nations began a last round of negotiations here today on a new agreement to regulate the world's $100 billion-a-year trade in textiles and clothing.

title: Ogilvy & Mather Gets An S.& P. Account
description: Ogilvy & Mather's Direct Response Group has become the agency for the Standard & Poor's Corporation's financial services and publications and will start the assignment by doing newspaper and magazine advertising for The Outlook, a weekly investment advisory service, and for Stock Guide, which is published monthly and contains common-stock information.

title: RATES DROP SHARPLY ON FED MOVE
description: A surprising move by the Federal Reserve adding credit to the banking system led to a steep drop in interest rates yesterday, but by late in the day rates climbed above their lowest levels as some analysts began to doubt the significance of the Fed's action.

title: Veterinarian Publications
description: Medical Economics of Oradell, N.J., a subsidiary of International Thomson Business Press, has acquired the Veterinary Medicine Publishing Company of Edwardsville, Kan., and will merge into it Veterinary Economics, a publication it acquired Nov. 12 from the United Publishing Corporation in Cleveland.

title: Notes on People; Come Again?
description: Until a 22-year-old Cambridge University student qualified to run for Parliament in Liverpool, his name was John Desmond Lewis. But, for a 96-cent fee, he had his name legally changed.

title: Gambian Calls Union With Senegal Premature
description: The President of Gambia, Sir Dawda Jawara, was quoted today as saying that an announced confederation with Senegal would not become final until he had signed a treaty and had it approved by Parliament. He told Le Soleil, the Government-run daily, that he would sign the document within a few weeks.

title: 'ABSURD AND SUICIDAL'
description: President Reagan has set out the U.S. position for his Administration's first arms control negotiation with the Soviet Union, due to start Nov. 30 in Geneva. The subject is theater nuclear forces, as they are called: weapons systems based in, and designed for use against, Western Europe and European Russia.

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS PRESIDENT GOT 'ORAL F.B.I. REPORT' CLEARING ALLEN
description: The White House said today that President Reagan had received an initial report from the Federal Bureau of Investigation saying there was no call for administrative action against Richard V. Allen, the national security adviser, for receiving a $1,000 cash payment from a Japanese journalist.

title: RANGERS WIN FROM FLYERS, 5-2
description: The Rangers defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 5-2, at Madison Square Garden last night, with the clinching goals scored by the oldest Ranger and the newest one.

title: MIGRANT SLAVERY PERSISTS ON SOUTHEAST'S FARMS
description: The recent Federal indictment of four men on charges of enslaving eight migrant farm workers in North Carolina has drawn attention to what appears to be a broader problem of involuntary servitude in the fields of the Southeast.

title: MOON SECT FACES ORDER ON RECRUIT
description: Judge Ira Brown of Superior Court ordered today that officials of the Unification Church produce Mary Lee Hall in his courtroom next Wednesday so that he could determine whether she was being held by the church against her will.

title: NAME-DROPPING POLITICS
description: When he first came to the Senate in 1969, he was listed in the Congressional Directory and in Who's Who as Robert William Packwood. Today he goes by the name of Bob Packwood.

title: Faye Dunaway Signs For 'Aching Heart' Role
description: Faye Dunaway, who was believed to have dropped out of the play two weeks ago, signed yesterday to return to Broadway in William Alfred's new drama ''The Curse of an Aching Heart.'' The production will open in mid-January at the Little Theater.

title: U.S. FILES IRAN CLAIMS FOR 3,000
description: The United States today filed more than $180 million in claims against Iran on behalf of 3,000 American citizens and corporations seeking compensation for losses suffered in the Iranian revolution.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1981
description: International An American arms control plan was presented by President Reagan. Urging that both Washington and Moscow act to avoid ''the dread threat of nuclear war,'' he announced he had proposed to the Kremlin cancellation of plans for new American intermediate-range missiles in Europe in return for the dismantling of comparable Soviet nuclear forces. (Page A1, Column 6.) Moscow dismissed the arms proposals offered by President Reagan as a ploy designed to scuttle the Geneva talks on controls and to blunt the antinuclear movement in Western Europe. A dispatch by Tass questioned Mr. Reagan's assertion that Moscow was superior in mediumrange weapons and called his figures ''fantastic.'' (A1:5.)

title: CON ED WINS WALL ST. PRAISE
description: Throughout much of the 1970's the Consolidated Edison Company of New York was viewed as one of the nation's most troubled electric utilities. It committed the blasphemy of omitting a dividend payment in 1974. Its credit was deemed so risky that it had no credit rating at all. And stock market analysts did not even want to discuss the company, let alone recommend that their clients buy some of its depressed shares.

title: AN INVESTMENT BANKER
description: Kurt H. Grunebaum, an investment banker and co-founder of the New York Hanseatic Corporation, a bond trading company, died Monday at White Plains Hospital after suffering a heart attack. Mr. Grunebaum, a resident of Harrison, N.Y., was 76 years old.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The family room in our 13-year-old house has a floor of asphalt tile over concrete. We plan to put down new flooring over this, but in one small section there are bumps under the tile, perhaps from rough spots in the concrete. Will we have trouble putting the new flooring over these bumps, and if so, are we better off with sheet flooring or tile? - B.F., Spring Valley, N.Y.

title: 36% CUT IN BUDGET REPORTEDLY URGED FOR ECOLOGY
description: The Office of Management and Budget has proposed cutting the operating budget of the Environmental Protection Agency by 36 percent in the fiscal year 1983, Reagan Administration officials disclosed today.

title: Joffrey Ballet to Embark On 12-City Tour in '82
description: The Joffrey Ballet has announced that Philip Morris Inc. will sponsor the company's 25th anniversary national tour, which will cover 12 cities over 17 weeks, starting in March.

title: Warsaw and Union Fail To Resolve Key Points
description: Government and labor leaders agreed today on an agenda for talks but failed to resolve differences over free local elections, a national unity front and other issues.

title: News of Music; A MAN WHO SEES WHAT OTHERS HEAR
description: SOME talents elevate humankind. Others are sublime in their very pointlessness. An example of the latter is Dr. Arthur B. Lintgen and his astonishing ability to ''read'' musical recordings.

title: News Analysis
description: The big winners yesterday in the recommendation of candidates for cable franchises in Queens, Brooklyn, Staten Island and the Bronx were several of the nation's largest cable operators.

title: Costa Rica Loan Default
description: Costa Rica, which has been trying to reschedule about $2.6 billion of foreign debt, is technically in default for paying only part of the interest due last Friday on a $20 million floating rate note, the Bank of Japan said here today. The bank's London branch, as fiscal agent distributing payments to investors, said only $500,000 had been received of the $2 million due. This default means that in the last 30 days partial interest has been paid on only three of the country's four floating rate notes when due.

title: FUR WALKOUT ENDS 30 YEARS OF PEACE
description: The billion-dollar fur industry, which has seen a rare upsurge in manufacturing in New York City in recent years, has been hit by a general strike for the first time in 30 years.

title: Pitt to Join Big East, Shuns New League
description: The University of Pittsburgh will join the Big East Conference next September, becoming the ninth member of that basketball-oriented league. The move is likely to end the chances of forming an Eastern major-college football conference proposed by Joe Paterno, Penn State's coach and athletic director. He has been trying for months to create such a league, with the idea of including Pittsburgh, now the nation's top-ranked team.

title: PERIODONIST AND EX-TEACHER
description: Dr. Nathan Wachtel, a periodontist and former associate professor of periodontics at the New York University College of Dentistry, was killed Tuesday in an accident while driving to his office in Stamford, Conn. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan, where he also practiced.

title: JERSEY ELECTION RECOUNT STARTS IN ALL 21 COUNTIES
description: The first statewide recount of a governor's race in New Jersey began today at sites in the state's 21 counties.

title: Yugoslav Avalanche Kills 11
description: An avalanche in the village of Kosutani in Kosovo Province destroyed two houses and apparently killed 11 people, the Tanyug press agency said today.

title: MRS. REAGAN GOT JAPANESE GIFT
description: The Japanese magazine that interviewed Nancy Reagan in January said today that it received a letter from her on May 7 expressing thanks for a hand-painted box presented in gratitude for the interview.

title: Shave Trial Nears Close
description: Summations began yesterday in the trial of five men charged with conspiring to shave points in Boston College basketball games in the 1978-79 season. The prosecution was summed up in a three-hour presentation by Edward A. McDonald of the Justice Department's Organized Crime Strike Force, and the attorney for two of the defendants completed his case in the afternoon, clearing the way for summations by the other defense lawyers today.

title: JAZZ: KNEPPER-ALBANY FOUR
description: JIMMY KNEPPER, the trombonist, and Joe Albany, the pianist, have such contrasting musical personalities that the jazz quartet they led at the West End Cafe, Broadway at 113th Street through last Sunday night, has more variety, even within a narrow range, than one usually finds in such groups.

title: 'MAJORITY' VS. GAYS
description: Even a quick look at events in Washington and around the country shows that the Christian right's attack on gay civil rights is taking on new life and intensity. The outcome is uncertain, but two things are clear: The Moral Majority will stop at nothing to make scapegoats of gay people, and the gay community is becoming more united as a result. In this climate, nothing less than extending civil rights laws to cover gays will end the political and moral outrages coming into view.

title: SENATE PANEL PASSES BILL TO OVERHAUL CRIME LAWS
description: The 15-year-old effort to overhaul the Federal Criminal Code once again cleared the Senate Judiciary Committee today, in the form of a 425-page ''consensus'' bill with seemingly inexhaustible potential for sowing disagreement.

title: 'Annie,' at Last, Finds a Home at Uris; 'Annie' Finds A Home at Uris
description: ''Annie,'' which has been something of a homeless musical the last three months, has found a permanent home on Broadway - the Uris Theater. The show will give its last performance at the Eugene O'Neill Theater on Dec. 6 and begin performances Dec. 12 at the Uris.

title: 5TH 'SMOKEOUT' WILL BE OBSERVED TODAY
description: Today's fifth annual Great American Smokeout, promoted by the American Cancer Society, will encourage smokers to give up cigarettes for 24 hours - if only to prove to themselves that they can.

title: Helicopter Damaged by Sub In Swedish Naval Exercises
description: A Swedish helicopter was damaged today when one of its sounding devices struck an unidentified submarine in international waters off the Swedish island of Gotland, a military staff spokesman said.

title: Tape Recording Barred At Plot Trial in Colorado
description: Eugene Tafoya, accused of trying to kill a Libyan dissident, won a legal victory today when a judge refused to let prosecutors introduce a tape recording that they said would show the defendant had sought work as a hired killer.

title: Index; International
description: In China's garden, Protestantism blossoms, too A2 Turkey adopts patient attitude toward Papandreou A3 U.N. General Assembly urges troop pullout from Afghanistan A4 Reagan aide says Philippines needs more progress on rights A5 Israeli Cabinet's Secretary faces disciplinary hearing A6 Khomeini gives up further powers to expected successor A8 Henry Kissinger trapped in lecture hall in Brazil protest A9 Moroccan policy: crackdown at home, turn to U.S. abroad A11 Christian Lebanese militia keeps up siege of U.N. base A12 Japanese magazine presented gift box to Mrs. Reagan A14 Bulgarian collective farm is proud of its wine A15 Government/Politics Crime reform bill clears Senate Judiciary Committee A22 Illinois Democrats endorse Stevenson for Governor B8 Connecticut legislative session to provide test for Governor B2 Washington Talk Briefing B6 Henry Kissinger keeps distance from Reagan White House B6 Nicknames are in vogue on Capitol Hill B6 General Around the Nation A20 Geneticist and brain researcher get Lasker awards B2 Witness at Margiotta retrial details insurance fee splitting B3 How a young lawyer got his big chance B3 Industry/Labor A look at the efforts of organizers for the United Mine Workers A20 Silk gets 2 as Rangers defeat Flyers, 5-2 B11 Todd still in pain and his playing status remains uncertain B11 Dick Williams accepts job as manager of Padres B11 Rockets beat Celtics, 108-106 B14 Dave Anderson on the N.F.L.'s painful reality B14 Features/Notes Woman in the News: Kathy Whitmire, Mayor-elect of Houston A24 Notes on People C27 Sports People B14 News Analysis Hedrick Smith assesses Reagan's arms proposal A16 Martin Tolchin on reason for the delay on a money bill A21 Tony Schwartz on the cable telvision franchise candidates B4 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials A30

title: EPHRAIM KISHON WINS THE NOBLE (NOT NOBEL)
description: Ephraim Kishon, a Hungarian-born Israeli humorist, declared today that ''I merely write the naked truth, and it is very, very funny.'' Recognizing this, the Association for the Promotion of Humor in International Affairs, a sometime light-hearted group of writers and businessmen based in Paris, awarded its Noble (not Nobel) prize to him today.

title: Devine to Join Expos
description: Bing Devine, who as general manager of the Mets built the foundation that brought the club victory in the 1969 World Series, is returning to baseball after three years as vice president of the St. Louis Cardinals football team. Devine announced yesterday that he was resigning from the Cards, effective the end of the season, to become a vice president of the Montreal Expos, with whom he will be involved in player development.

title: No Headline
description: WARRIORS TOP NETS, 121-107

title: Selling Diamonds In Reader's Digest
description: You may have an image of Reader's Digest readers as nice, unsophisticated, down-home, middle American types. That obviously is not the way De Beers Conslidated Mines, the major supplier of the world's diamonds, and its agency-for-ages, N.W. Ayer, see them, or they certainly would not be running a 10-page advertising insert in the December issue promoting diamonds to a stagnant market badly hurt by the recession.

title: DANCE: CITY BALLET OFFERS TRIO OF CHOREOGRAPHERS
description: THE New York City Ballet gave us one of its subdued opening nights Tuesday at the New York State Theater, which is not necessarily a complaint. A little calm can be refreshing.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Chi Chi's Inc. is offering 600,000 common shares at $18.125 a share, to be sold through a Shearson/American Express Inc. group.

title: Anti-Apartheid Backing
description: Opponents of South Africa's apartheid system who sent death threats that forced Jimmy Connors out of that nation's tennis championships have been backed by the Supreme Council for Sport in Africa. Abraham Ordia, Nigerian head of the council, said: ''I agree with the antiapartheid people in this. If you play in South Africa, you support the system we are fighting.''

title: Account
description: * Botany 500, a unit of Rapid American, to Harold M. Mitchell Inc.

title: DEMOCRATS IN ILLINOIS ENDORSE STEVENSON FOR GOVERNOR IN '82
description: The Democratic Central Committee of Illinois today unanimously endorsed the candidacy of former Senator Adlai E. Stevenson for Governor in next year's election.

title: POLL DETECTS 'MYTHS' ABOUT PROBLEMS OF AGED
description: The widely held view that people over the age of 65 have serious problems with poverty, loneliness and fear of crime is ''a myth,'' according to a national survey conducted by Louis Harris.

title: MUSIC: NEW TIPPETT CONCERTO
description: THE British have always been a little self-conscious about their place in the musical scheme of things, and as a result they often let enthusiasm for native composers cloud their otherwise clear vision and famous common sense. No one can blame them for that; enthusiasm, no matter how misplaced, is probably healthier than the suspicion with which we Yankees view our homegrown product. But some perspective ought to be kept by us and them. After all, it is easier to make a composer famous than it is to make foreigners love his music.

title: Bausch & Lomb To End Eyeglasses
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc., for generations a well-known name in precision lenses, said today that it planned to discontinue its eyeglass business worldwide to emphasize its retail contact lens and growing scientific instrument operations.

title: Home Beat; DESIGNING FOR THE ELDERLY
description: ALTHOUGH he's been working for years as a designer for health care facilities, it is only recently that Louis Tregre decided he would concentrate on making available on a wider basis some special and reasonably priced furnishings designed especially for the elderly. His company, SOLA, stands for ''Selected Objects for Living Actively'' and includes more than 30 items - seating, bedding and accessories - that are meant to make everyday chores easier for the elderly and physically handicapped; they have been adapted from standard models.

title: QUESTIONS RAISED ABOUT LICENSING PLAYBOY CASINO
description: The State Division of Gaming Enforcement reported today that a two-year investigation had raised ''substantial questions'' about the suitability of Playboy Enterprises as a casino operator in Atlantic City.

title: GIANTS GET A QUARTERBACK AND A RUSHER
description: The Giants added two players and dropped two today. They signed Cliff Olander, a quarterback, and Ike Forte, a running back; placed the quarterback Phil Simms on injured reserve, and waived Alvin Garrett, who had played mostly on the special teams.

title: Gay Men's Chorus In Carnegie Hall Dec. 8
description: The 150-member New York City Gay Men's Chorus, under the direction of Gary Miller, will make its Carnegie Hall debut Dec. 8 at 8 P.M. The program will include a commissioned world premiere by Conrad Susa and works by Handel, Bach, Palestrina, Gabrieli and contemporary composers, Randall Thompson, Ron Nelson and P.D.Q. Bach.

title: Scarborough Surveys Black Readership
description: Yesterday at a luncheon in the Sheraton Centre in New York, Amalgamated Publishers, ad reps for 88 black newspapers, released an audience study of the publications done by Scarborough Research.

title: A GROWING PASSION FOR PLATE COLLECTING
description: ''IT'S part of a cultural explosion,'' said Emil S. Polk, president of the Collector Platemaker's Guild. ''Since 1968 the American middle class has been finding itself with more and more money, and suddenly they can afford to buy a piece of culture to hang on their wall.''

title: Market Place; Retail Stocks: Price Bargain?
description: SLIDING prices for retail shares in the last several trading sessions may have put the group in a buying range once again. The prevailing attitude has been that earnings growth will be slowing sharply for such leading companies as R.H. Macy; Federated Department Stores, which operates both Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus; J.C. Penney; Dayton-Hudson, and Allied Stores.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT REAGAN'S ADDRESS ON ARMS REDUCTION
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's address to the National Press Club in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Sports of The Times; The N.F.L.'s Painful Reality
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I. AT the Jets' training complex yesterday, Walt Michaels was discussing the status of his wounded, particularly Richard Todd, the quarterback whose fractured rib only hurts when he breathes.

title: MOYNIHAN, AT CITY COLLEGE DINNER, CITES RISING WELFARE DEPENDENCY
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan warned last night that 50 to 60 percent of the children born this year in New York City were likely to receive public assistance before they reach the age of 18.

title: WHEN A WORKER CHANGES COLLARS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NEW BOHEMIANS: DESIGN AS SELF-EXPRESSION
description: WHEN Maurizio Benadon, a real estate developer from Lugano, Switzerland, and Benedicte Siroux, a former Paris model, came to New York a year ago, they moved into an empty 72-by-35-foot loft in Chelsea.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS IN NEW YORK AREA
description: National Home Entertainment Show, New York Coliseum, Columbus Cir- cle.

title: EXXON MAY SHIFT PRODUCTS
description: THE marketing management of the Exxon Company, U.S.A., is in the process of deciding whether McCaffrey & McCall will be doing its product ads as well as its corporate advertising.

title: Japan Against End to Tariffs
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki today virtually turned down a United States request for removal of tariffs to cut Japan's huge surplus in trade with the United States.

title: I.B.M.'S PATENT PACT WITH NIPPON PHONE
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Public Corporation announced today that on Thursday it will sign a far-reaching agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation to exchange patents and share information on advanced technology.

title: Nuclear Agency Delays Action on Diablo Canyon
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission failed to reach a decision today on possible action against the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, owner of the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant in California.

title: Marathon Oil Is a Bargain
description: Should Big Oil be allowed to get bigger? The issue confronts the Federal Government, which must decide whether Mobil's proposed acquisition of Marathon Oil violates the antitrust laws.

title: KING HASSAN MOVES AGAINST HIS FOES
description: Challenged by war, drought and an embittered opposition, King Hassan II has opened a campaign against his domestic foes while turning to the Reagan Administration for support abroad.

title: Woman Sentenced In Parents' Deaths
description: A 23-year-old woman convicted of murder for plotting a robbery that resulted in the slaying of her parents was sentenced yesterday to 25 years to life in prison.

title: M.I.T. Faculty Approves Gift of Research Center
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology faculty voted overwhelmingly today to accept a proposal to build a $120 million independent research institute financed by a Connecticut industrialist.

title: Bennett Is Nominated; Humanities Fight Seen
description: President Reagan today formally nominated William J. Bennett to be chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, succeeding Joseph D. Duffey.

title: French Socialists Seek Power to Act by Decree
description: The Government, citing public pressure for rapid social change, said today that it would seek the power to put urgent social measures into effect by decree.

title: DANIEL LANG, 66, CORRESPONDENT AND AUTHOR FOR NEW YORKER, DIES
description: Daniel Lang, a prize-winning author, wartime correspondent in North Africa, Italy and France and a veteran writer for The New Yorker on moral, social and scientific issues, died in New York City Tuesday evening. He was 66 years old.

title: Turks Reporting 319 Cases Of Typhoid Fever in Ankara
description: Typhoid fever has reached epidemic proportions in this city, with 319 cases reported. The announcement was made by Turkey's Ministry of Health. There have been no deaths, the Turkish press agency Akajans said, quoting Ministry of Health sources.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What kind of a nut am I? Who walks around screwing in light bulbs that's a millionaire?'' - Louis Eisenberg, janitor, winner of $5 million lottery. (B9:2.)

title: A Sober Custodian, Not a Cowboy
description: At long last, President Reagan has made a sound and shrewd foreign policy speech. Its primary purpose, of course, was not the catchy proposal to clear Europe of nuclear weapons but rather to brace the West's faith in nuclear deterrence.

title: Notes on People; Badillo Moves On
description: Herman Badillo, a former New York City Deputy Mayor, Bronx Borough President, and United States Representative, has changed law firms.

title: Pianist: Salwen Plays Beethoven
description: AYOUNG pianist who programs Beethoven's Sonata in A-flat (Op. 110) is either very courageous or very cavalier. Barry Salwen at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night was neither.

title: POPULARITY OF REAGAN SLIPPING
description: President Reagan's popularity has again slipped a little, according to the Gallup Poll, but stands almost exactly where President Carter's stood four years ago.

title: RACING FIX REPORT SUBMITTED
description: A report that may result in the suspension of leading jockeys for failure to report knowledge of activities related to race-fixing was submitted yesterday to the State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: LEFTISTS ELECTED IN MANITOBA AFTER 4 YEARS OF RIGHTIST RULE
description: The western province of Manitoba has rejoined neighboring Saskatchewan in choosing to live under socialist government after four years of conservative rule.

title: RITZ THEATER TO RETURN AS A BROADWAY HOUSE
description: The Ritz will be reclaimed for Broadway's legitimate theater today with a ceremony beginning its renovation by the Jujamcyn Theaters Corporation.

title: Administration Opens Talks on Aid for Chad
description: The Reagan Administration began consultations with Congress today over United States assistance for peacekeeping efforts in Chad by the Organization of African Unity.

title: News Analysis
