description: However slim its chances for success in negotiations with the Soviet Union, the arms reduction proposal put forward by President Reagan today culminates a deliberate shift in both tone and policy toward Moscow from the bristling polemics of last spring to a new push for peacemaking.

title: Union Upset By G.M. Plea
description: The United Automobile Workers union reacted angrily yesterday to a campaign by the General Motors Corporation, made public earlier this week, that is aimed at convincing G.M.'s workers to ''reduce or eliminate unrealistic expectations about economic gains'' in the 1982 contract negotiations.

title: DR. MARGARET MCLANAHAN, 85, FORMERLY ON LENOX HILL STAFF
description: Dr. Margaret Janeway McLanahan, a physician on the staff of Lenox Hill Hospital until her retirement in 1973, died Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 85 years old.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 16.00-16.50.** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.+ Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Technology; A New 'Rifle' For Marketers
description: SINCE the 1950's, one of the buzzwords in marketing has been segmentation, the identification of specific groups of potential consumers. But the means of defining those groups have varied with advances - or fads - in market research, from geographics (ZIP codes, states or other areas defined by physical boundaries) to demographics (age, income, sex) and psychographics (life styles, value systems). And eventually, each technique has been found to be too broad or imprecise in defining its targets.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; U.N. Reports No Gains On Rights for Chileans

title: CHRISTIAN MILITIA IN SOUTH LEBANON CONTINUING TO BESIEGE U.N. BASE
description: The Lebanese Christian militia led by Maj. Saad Haddad kept up its siege around United Nations headquarters in southern Lebanon for the third day today as fresh water at the base began to run low.

title: S.& P. Refines Top Category
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday that about 500 companies that issue commercial paper would qualify for its highest rating, A-1+.

title: TV: H.B.O. OFFERS 'SHERLOCK HOLMES'
description: ''SHERLOCK HOLMES,'' starring Frank Langella, offers a neat illustration of what is happening in the crucial area of entertainment distribution. A few years ago, this production probably would have been seen on public television, perhaps as part of a WNET-TV, Channel 13 package on regional theater. Today, specifically tonight at 8:30, it will be carried on Home Box Office, a pay-cable outlet that in New York City is carried on Manhattan Cable's Channel H.

title: LASKER AWARDS GO TO GENETICIST AND A LAB HEAD
description: A geneticist whose work went largely unappreciated by the scientific community for many years and a National Institutes of Health investigator whose studies on the brain have facilitated modern biological research were named winners of the 36th Lasker awards yesterday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;
description: The Detroit Tigers have reportedly offered Steve Kemp a contract that would pay him $750,000 for each of the next five years and make him the highest-salaried player in Tiger history. But Kemp, a 27-year-old outfielder who will be eligible for free agency after next season, is asking for $1 million a year. Kemp, who went to arbitration last spring to win his current salary of $600,000, batted .277 this season, with nine home runs and 49 runs batted in. ... In a survey of players, Tim Raines of the Montreal Expos was chosen rookie of the year by The Sporting News in the National League, and Rich Gedman of the Boston Red Sox was selected in the American.

title: AMERASIAN BOY PLEADS FOR EASED IMMIGRATION
description: A teen-age boy who lived on the streets of Korea for much of his childhood has pleaded with Congress to help other children left by American servicemen in Asia become American citizens.

title: MUSIC: AMERICAS QUINTET
description: THE Quintet of the Americas presented a rather cosmopolitan picture in Monday night's concert of ''Music of North and South America'' at the Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Williams Spurned On New Evidence
description: WASHINGTON (UPI) - Senate leaders rejected the request of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. to introduce new evidence when the Senate begins considering whether to expel him for his Abscam involvement.

title: LIBYA IS SAID TO CUT OIL PRICE
description: Libya has offered to reduce the price of some of the crude oil it sells to a consortium of American oil companies by about $1 dollar a barrel, a senior oil industry official said yesterday.

title: SOVIET ACCUSES PRESIDENT OF 'PLOY'
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain enthusiastically welcomed President Reagan's statement on arms control today, with Mr. Schmidt calling it ''the American peace strategy.''

title: Wilfried Platzer Is Dead at 72; Was Austria's Envoy to U.S.
description: Wilfried Platzer, Austria's Ambassador to the United States from 1958 to 1965, died last Thursday in Vienna. He was 72 years old.

title: SCOTT PAPER GIVES PRESIDENT A 2D TITLE
description: Philip E. Lippincott, the 45-year-old president of the Scott Paper Company, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer, effective Feb.1. He will succeed Charles D. Dickey Jr., 63, who will continue as chairman of the Philadelphia-based concern until the end of 1982, when he will be 65.

title: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1981; The Economy
description: Housing starts fell 6.9 percent in October, to a 15-year low, depressed by the lowest rate for single-family houses on record, the Commerce Department reported. In addition, building permits for future construction sank for the sixth consecutive month. (Page D1.)

title: Grand Jury to Hear Case Of Doctor Held for Rape
description: A Federal District Court judge decided today there was sufficient evidence to forward to a grand jury charges of rape and assault brought by two hospital patients against an anesthesiologist.

title: U.S. Volkswagen Sets Diesel Rebate
description: In an attempt to sell its leftover 1981 Rabbit diesel cars and pickup trucks, Volkswagen of America Inc. said that it would offer rebate checks to customers through Dec.31.

title: An Off-Duty Policeman Kills Robbery Suspect, Police Say
description: An off-duty police officer shot and killed an 18-year-old youth who threatened him with a golf club during an attempted robbery last night in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, the police reported.

title: 2 Swiss Jet Fighters Collide
description: Two Swiss Air Force jet fighters, one an American-made F5 Tiger and the other a French-built Mirage, collided in midair and crashed today during an exercise over the Jura Mountains, military officials said. The fate of the pilots was not immediately known.

title: IN CHINA'S GARDEN, PROTESTANTISM BLOSSOMS, TOO
description: The seminarians seated around the polished tables of the small library bend studiously over their theological textbooks, while down the hall their professors prepare tomorrow's lessons.

title: Dow off 6.09 as Volume Rises
description: The stock market ended moderately lower yesterday in more active trading, with some of the technology issues posting the biggest losses.

title: Williams Is Named Manager of Padres
description: Dick Williams, who had been a candidate for the possible vacancy in the Yankees' managing job, became manager of the San Diego Padres yesterday. That left George Steinbrenner with one fewer candidate for the Yankee job, which he said may or may not be available.

title: NET CLIMBS AT HEWLETT
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1981, ended Oct. 31, climbed 17.5 percent, while sales advanced 14.8 percent.

title: Concerto Soloists To Make Local Debut
description: The Concerto Soloists of Philadelphia, which counts as that city's only full-time chamber orchestra, will make its New York debut Dec. 14 at 8 P.M. in Carnegie Hall. The orchestra will be led by its founder, Marc Mostovoy, and Hermann Baumann, the French-horn player, will be the soloist.

title: ORGANIZERS GO PROSPECTING FOR MINERS
description: They were a rough-cut, pleasant-appearing bunch of fellows, sitting or standing in a large, chilly union hall. Many had beards that, with the work coats and hats the men wore, made them appear as though they had stepped out of photographs of coal miners a century ago.

title: SECRETARY OF CABINET IN ISRAEL FACES A DISCIPLINARY HEARING
description: The Secretary of the Israeli Cabinet has been charged with improperly divulging information about a reported conversation between President Jimmy Carter and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amax Inc. said that it would receive about $23.5 million in cash from the sale of tax benefits on about $85 million worth of equipment to be leased in accordance with provisions of the Economic Recovery Act of 1981.

title: 5 Conrail Workers Charged in Thefts
description: Five Conrail employees were arrested on charges of stealing ''thousands'' of dollars since 1977. According to Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, the employees - all ticket sellers at Grand Central Terminal - would sell monthly tickets to commuters but record them as less-expensive one-way fares.

title: HOUSE VOTES FUNDS FOR THE B-1 AND MX AND BACKS REAGAN
description: In a strong endorsement of President Reagan's military strategy, the House of Representatives tonight passed a $197.4 billion military appropriation bill that included funds to continue development of the B-1 manned bomber and the MX missile.

title: JOLT FOR PEKING: A U.S. CHAMBER OPENS
description: A move by American businessmen working in China to facilitate bilateral trade by setting up an American Chamber of Commerce here has met with apprehension and evasiveness from the Chinese Government.

title: Korean Keeps Title
description: Kim Chul Ho of South Korea retained his World Boxing Council super flyweight championship in Seoul with a ninth-round knockout of Ryotetsu Maruyama of Japan. ... Eddie Mustafa Muhammad, former light-heavyweight champion of the World Boxing Association, is set to fight Mike Hardin of Dayton, Ohio, in a preliminary to the Muhammad Ali-Trevor Berbick bout in the Bahamas next month.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Airco Inc., Montvale, N.J., has elected Stephen A. Barre a group vice president in charge of Airco's training schools and superconductor manufacturing operations.

title: FOR A YOUNG LAWYER, THE GENESIS OF A SIGNAL VICTORY
description: In his 30th-floor law office in lower Manhattan yesterday, Kim Sperduto recalled easily the beginning of his work on the case that he won Tuesday in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

title: Cavaliers Lose Wedman
description: Scott Wedman is in the hospital, suffering from back spasms, and will be out of the Cleveland Cavaliers' lineup indefinitely. Wedman, a 6-foot-7-inch forward, was signed as a free agent by Cleveland in the offseason after averaging 19 points a game for Kansas City in 1980-1981. ... Jim Fitzgerald, owner of the Milwaukee Bucks, is also in the hospital, suffering from chest pains.

title: A New Account For a New Agency
description: Steven Penchina, who used to write those engaging monk commercials for the Xerox Corporation while at Needham, Harper & Steers, six months ago, left Wells, Rich, Greene, where he was a senior vice president and creative group head, to open Steve Penchina Inc., up to now a struggling, one-man agency.

title: Notes on People; Honoring Donors
description: ''I feel like a tenant, for the landlord is here today,'' said Nancy Reagan as she welcomed some 200 contributors to the White House last night.

title: Hers
description: MY mother wrote me one letter in her life. She was in California then, seeking treatment for the disease whose name she was never allowed to utter, as if in some magical way, speaking the illness would confirm it. I found the letter in a dresser drawer the other day, written in the round hand of Americanization school on tissuethin paper banded at the top with the narrow red edge of gum rubber where it was once attached to a tablet.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT BY CABLE TV WORKING GROUP
description: Following is the text of a statement by Rabert A. Kandel, chairman of the Cable Television Working Group: Today, the Cable Television Working Group (CWG) will make recommendations to the Board of Estimate regarding the applicants in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island initially to be targeted for negotiation of franchise agreements. In addition, we will recommend general guidelines to govern these negotiations.

title: Thomson-Brandt To Buy RCA Unit
description: The RCA Corporation said that the Thomson-Brandt electronics group of France had agreed to buy RCA's 42 percent stake in Videocolor, Europe's second-biggest producer of color television tubes.

title: WHY NORTH DAKOTANS CAN TAKE A JOKE
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: ''We tend not to resolve very thorny political problems until we absolutely have to, or everything comes to a halt,'' Senator Joseph R. Biden, Democrat of Delaware, said as Congress went down to the wire on yet another money bill.

title: Soviet Airline Explains 2 Unauthorized Flights
description: The Soviet airline Aeroflot said today that air traffic controllers were responsible for two of its flights taking an unauthorized route over southern New England on Nov. 8. The incidents prompted a State Department request for a weeklong suspension of Aeroflot flights.

title: TEXACO BID SOUGHT AS COUNTER TO MOBIL
description: Investment bankers and major shareholders in the Marathon Oil Company have approached Texaco Inc. suggesting a Texaco bid for Marathon to counter the Mobil Oil Corporation's $5.1 billion takeover offer, Texaco announced today.

title: Coast Death Ruled Homicide
description: One of a series of mysterious hospital deaths under investigation here has been ruled a homicide, Assistant County Coroner Leo Reyes says. He said an amended death certificate was issued last Friday for Estel Lee Jones, 67 years old, of Pomona, showing she died March 25, 1981, at Chino Community Hospital ''at the hands of another.''

title: PROMISING YOUNG ARTISTS RECEIVE VISUAL ARTS AWARDS
description: Ten artists each received $15,000 today as the first winners in an innovative program designed to identify promising American artists and promote their work.

title: Change at Videofashion
description: Nicholas H. Charney, founder of Psychology Today and currently chairman and editor of Videofashion Monthly, will announce today that his video magazine will go next month from a program distributed as a tape or a disk to a 28-minute feature with the potential to reach 8 million cable TV subscribers via the Modern Satellite Network and the Satellite Programming Network.

title: SOME TIPS FOR COLLECTORS ON HOW TO GET INTO THE MARKET
description: IF newspapers and magazines report that ''Pup and Dogs,'' the 1969 Bing & Grondahl Mother's Day plate, is worth $500, then there must be a way to sell it for that price or at least to sell it for something, right?

title: CHAMBER: MARLBORO GROUP PLAYS SCHOENBERG STRING TRIO
description: MUSIC From Marlboro, an offshoot of the Vermont Marlboro Festival and a touring showcase for chamber musicians, has become an institution not just in New York but also in the country at large. This year there are Marlboro series at the Metropolitan Museum and Alice Tully Hall, each offering the same three touring ensembles.

title: Gardening; INDOOR PLANTS THAT THRIVE IN LITTLE LIGHT
description: DOES a dark room with little natural light mean a life without house plants? Not necessarily. A number of plants will thrive indoors in low levels of light.

title: ELECTRIC BOAT RECEIVES NEW GENERAL MANAGER
description: Fritz G. Tovar, a 58-year-old German-born executive, has been appointed general manager of the Electric Boat division of the General Dynamics Corporation in Groton, Conn. He succeeds P. Takis Veliotis, 55, the controversial head of Electric Boat, which builds United States Navy submarines. General Dynamics had said last month that Mr. Veliotis, who has been at the division since 1977, would move to another post.

title: New Federal Inquiry Set In Town Bully's Death
description: The Justice Department has ordered a new inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation into the slaying of Ken Rex McElroy, shot four months ago outside a Skidmore, Mo., tavern.

title: I.B.M. Cuts Prices, Offers New Units
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced several new models, and price reductions in its 4300 line of computers. The announcements include a new low end of the line, the 4321, priced at $85,000, and additions in the larger 4331 and 4341 models, as well as a new set of operating programs that would make the computers easier to use, either standing alone or linked to other computers in a network.

title: BULGARIAN VILLAGE PROUD OF ITS WINE
description: Atanas Krustanov, chairman of the local collective farm, compares the Bulgarian grape industry to that of California ''in scientific production and efficiency.''

title: Public Radio to Explore Jazz in Los Angeles
description: The diverse jazz movements that have developed in and around Los Angeles since the 1920's will be explored in a ''Jazz Alive!'' special on National Public Radio over the Thanksgiving weekend called ''Central Avenue Breakdown: A Portrait of a Jazz City ... Los Angeles.''

title: REAGAN OFFERS 4-POINT PLAN FOR U.S.-SOVIET MISSILE CURBS AND FORCE LIMITS IN EUROPE
description: President Reagan, urging that the United States and the Soviet Union take steps to avoid ''the dread threat of nuclear war,'' today proposed canceling plans to deploy new American intermediate-range missiles in Europe in return for the dismantling of comparable Soviet forces.

title: Audience for Speech Is Put at 200 Million
description: Two hundred million people in 40 countries may have seen President Reagan's televised speech today on arms reduction, a Government agency said.

title: Going Out Guide
description: GRACIE GOES WEST

title: Iraq-Brazil Arms Deal
description: The Brazilian arms manufacturer Engenheiros Especializados was awarded a $250 million military equipment contract by Iraq during a visit to Baghdad this week by a Brazilian trade mission, a company official said today.

title: REAGAN GETS STARTED
description: Provoked by the success of the wave of pacifism in Europe, Ronald Reagan finally tackled a speech about one part of foreign affairs.

title: APPEAL OF RULING INDICATED BY COUNCIL
description: Despite disagreements among its members, the leadership of New York's City Council indicated yesterday that it would appeal a Federal court ruling that declared unconstitutional the Council's system of electing two members at large from each borough.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Nov. 2 incorrectly explained the causes cited by the International Business Ma- chines Corporation for its third-quar- ter earnings decline. I.B.M. cited pri- marily the adverse effects of a strong dollar abroad.

title: Severance Sought In Vandalism Case
description: A prosecutor in the case of four teen-agers charged with the $2.5 million in vandalism to the Newark water system is seeking to get one of the defendants tried separately so he can testify against the remaining three.

title: RATING ON G.M.'S BONDS IS CUT TO AA BY MOODY'S
description: The credit rating of the General Motors Corporation, long the symbol of America's industrial strength, was lowered yesterday by Moody's Investors Service.

title: Auto Imports Down in U.S.
description: Auto imports to the United States fell 31 percent in September compared with September 1980, the Commerce Department said today.

title: CASES DROPPED FOR 46 IN RAID ON DISCOTHEQUE
description: Forty-six cases involving the controversial arrests of hundreds of patrons -mostly teen-agers - accused of loitering to use drugs at an East Side discotheque have been dismissed, the Manhattan District Attorney's office disclosed yesterday.

title: Home Improvement; SOME TIPS ON BUILDING YOUR OWN BOOKSHELVES
description: MOST do-it-yourselfers who tackle repair projects still think that building furniture or cabinets is a task best left to those with well-equipped woodworking shops and considerable experience.

title: INS AND OUTS OF KISSINGER AND POWER
description: In the early days of the Reagan Presidency, Henry A. Kissinger, symbol of a foreign policy the Reagan forces once loved to hate, watched the new Administration edge closer to his views even as it moved away from him.

title: DOWN'S SYNDROME AND SIBLING LOVE
description: ''WELL, I wiggle her all around, see,'' said 7-year-old Sean Cohan, as he attempted to describe, as precisely as possible, exactly what it was like to have a 3 1/2-year-old sister who has Down's syndrome. ''Then she wiggles me all around,'' he said, ''and she jumps on me. Then she jumps on my dad. And that makes me laugh a little, and it makes my dad laugh a lot!''

title: The U.N.Today; Nov. 19, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CHAPTER 11 FOR SACHS
description: Sachs New York, operator of 11 furniture stores in New York City and Huntington, L.I., filed yesterday for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy law.

title: HOUSING SLUMP INTENSIFIES
description: Housing starts sank to a 15-year low in October, depressed by the lowest rate for single-family houses on record, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: CHAMBER: BOWERY SIX
description: THE Tuesday evening concert of the Bowery Ensemble in Cooper Union's acoustically and architecturally eccentric Great Hall turned out to be an 81st-birthday celebration for Aaron Copland. Mr. Copland's evocative Sonata for violin and piano (1943) opened the evening and his Twelve Poems of Emily Dickinson for soprano and piano (1950) closed it, and with those two pieces Mr. Copland - who was present for the occasion - handily dominated the program.

title: STUDY SEES RISK IN SALE OF SANTA FE
description: A Congressional research group has concluded that the prospective purchase by Kuwait of the Santa Fe International Corporation, which has a subsidiary that specializes in nuclear technology, could complicate efforts by the United States to stop the spread of atomic weapons.

title: REAGAN, THATCHER AND LIBERALISM
description: Will Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher destroy liberalism, or cure it of an old malady that might be called its economic sydrome?

title: KENNEDY CRITICIZES REAGAN IN SPEECH AT LABOR MEETING
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, sounding as if he might again seek the Presidency, assailed the Reagan Administration yesterday for what he said was its attempts to destroy vital social programs, and he assured a cheering audience of union members that he would fight with them to restore ''compassion and concern'' to Government.

title: Eberly Service Tomorrow
description: A service for Bob Eberly, the big-band singer, will be held at noon tomorrow at Pine Lawn Memorial Park, Farmingdale, L.I. Mr. Eberly, who made many popular songs with the Jimmy Dorsey Orchestra, died Tuesday at the age of 65.

title: DECISION ON CABLE RESULT OF YEAR'S WORK
description: The group that made recommendations yesterday to the Board of Estimate about cable television franchises did so after a year of research, during which it became intimately involved with the cable issue.

title: SCREEN: 'ABSENCE OF MALICE'
description: SYDNEY POLLACK'S recent movies have had a lot in common. In ''The Way We Were,'' in ''Three Days of the Condor,'' in ''The Electric Horseman'' and now in ''Absence of Malice,'' Mr. Pollack has presented his own contemplative brand of lonely love story. These films may look like romances, but they're about people who never quite fall in love. The characters invariably come from two different worlds. As they meet and make their earnest but futile efforts to reach one another, the action remains cautious, thoughtful and slow.

title: Synagogue Group Elects
description: Marshall Wolke, a Chicago businessman, was elected yesterday as president of the United Synagogue of America, a 1.5-million-member organization of Conservative Judaism, at the group's biennial meeting in Kiamesha Lake, N.Y. He is a member of West Suburban Temple Har Zion in River Forest, Ill., and has been national president of the United Synagogue of America.

title: Bridge: Charity Game on Monday To Be Played in 450 Clubs
description: For the next 10 days, San Francisco will be the capital of the American bridge scene, with thousands of players competing in the Fall National Championships.

title: Ford Seeks Concessions
description: Hourly workers at the Ford Motor Company's Brook Park plant complex near Cleveland have joined the list of union employees being asked to accept contract concessions, a Ford spokesman said yesterday.

title: Durocher: Plenty of Lip Left
description: The Lip was unsealed. ''If you really want to know,'' he said, slyly, ''I'd love to work for George Steinbrenner.'' Leo Durocher chuckled. ''Maybe I'm crazy,'' he said, sitting back in the easy chair in his room at the Waldorf Towers yesterday morning. ''All the time I was a young man,playing with the Yankees, with Cincinnati, with the Cardinals, I always wished I had played for John McGraw. He was the, what do you call it, the creme de cacao. It never happened. Maybe I'm crazy, but I'd love to work for Steinbrenner. Mister Steinbrenner.''

title: 54 CASES OF BRIBERY ABROAD
description: Justice Department officials told a House panel today that they were investigating 54 cases of possible bribery of foreign officials by American companies. Five of the cases, they said, involve the heads of foreign governments.

title: WHY NORTH DAKOTANS CAN TAKE A JOKE
description: To the Editor:

title: Passive Solar Homes
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: The article by Andree Brooks reporting on the two-year survey of passive solar homes by the New England Solar Energy Center in Boston (''Problems Turn Up With Passive Solar Houses,'' Nov. 5) was headlined in a way that is becoming increasingly typical when reporting on solar buildings.

title: G.T.E. in Venture With Ferranti Ltd.
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, a diversified electronics manufacturer based in Stamford, Conn., said that it had formed a joint venture company with Ferranti Ltd. in Britain to make and market telecommunications equipment.

title: Earvin Johnson Seeks a Trade
description: The Los Angeles Lakers' guard Earvin (Magic) Johnson, citing differences with Coach Paul Westhead, said tonight that he wanted to be traded. Johnson said that he planned to talk with the team's owner, Jerry Buss, tomorrow.

title: ON THE RIGHT TRACK DOWN IN THE VILLAGE
description: DOWN in Greenwich Village, where residents are inclined to greet anything new and unusual in their neighborhood with a combination of cynical humor and skepticism, they're calling it the most impressive train they've seen since the one on the wedding dress of Diana, Princess of Wales.

title: Western Electric Postpones Plant
description: The Western Electric Company said that it had decided to postpone, for at least a year, construction and production plans for a new $400 million integrated circuit plant here.

title: MONTICELLO REGAINS 18TH-CENTURY LOOK
description: lawyer, linguist, diplomat, astronomer, naturalist, political philosopher, educator, architect, statesman and President - liked to call himself a farmer.

title: No Headline
description: Capitals 7, Rockies 1

title: MARGIOTTA TRIAL TOLD OF SPLITTING OF COMMISSIONS
description: A key Government witness testified here today that his insurance agency had shared substantial commissions with individuals selected by Joseph M. Margiotta, the Republican chairman of Nassau County.

title: Books of the Times
description: By John Leonard THE LITERARY LIFE AND OTHER CURIOSITIES. By Robert Hendrickson. Illustrated. 406 pages. Viking. $25.

title: Ann Gordon, Ex-Press Aide For Metropolitan Opera, 65
description: Ann Gordon, retired press representative of the Metropolitan Opera Company, died of cancer Tuesday in Medical Arts Center Hospital.

title: Topics Stop, Look and Listen; Weiss Way
description: Representative Ted Weiss, from Manhattan's West Side, has sent a letter to members of the Senate, calling attention to a bill that would commit the Federal Government to paying its share of peripheral improvements to the Westway highway project - things like bicycle lanes and landscaping previously accepted by Washington. Mr. Weiss charges that the action would add more than $400 million to the cost of Westway, and that senators should scrutinize the measure cautiously before approving it.

title: U.S. Steel Coal Cut
description: The U.S. Steel Corporation said that it has cut back the work schedules of five mines in western Pennsylvania because of decreased orders for coal.

title: G.S.A Rejects Bids for Silver
description: The General Services Administration today rejected all bids for silver for the second consecutive week at its sixth auction of silver from the National Strategic Defense stockpile.

title: Pastorini to Start
description: Dan Pastorini, who was shaken up near the end of the Cincinnati game last weekend, will start Sunday for the Los Angeles Rams when they face San Francisco.

title: O'NEILL'S TAX PROPOSALS FACE TEST IN CONNECTICUT
description: When last January's session of the General Assembly began, Gov. William A. O'Neill had been in office for a week, and whatever he presented was clearly derived from the plans of his predecessor, Ella T. Grasso.

title: WOMEN'S VOTES ARE A REAGAN WOE
description: President Reagan has a women problem, and it seems to be spreading to other Republicans. That's the message Republicans are taking from recent poll findings. Mr. Reagan's difficulties in getting through politically to women threaten the party's goals of gaining seats in the House next year and of becoming the dominant political party in the country for the long term, political professionals say.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON INCREASES IN WHEAT AND CORN SUBSIDIES
description: Senate and House conferees today reached a compromise on higher subsidies and loans on wheat and corn that could add at least $730 million to the cost of supporting these basic grains.

title: MANILA'S PROGRESS ON RIGHTS STUDIED
description: The Reagan Administration said today that the Philippine Government had taken some welcome steps toward political liberalization, but that ''further progress'' was needed.

title: A FEDERAL EFFORT TO HINDER STATE AID FOR THE
description: POORTo the Editor:

title: Beethoven Marathon For 12 Hours Sunday
description: Symphony Space will be host to a ''Wall-to-Wall Beethoven'' marathon on Sunday from 11 A.M. to 11 P.M. The free chamber-music event will be broadcast by National Public Radio stations across the country.

title: RCA Satellite Going Up
description: RCA Satcom III-R, a commercial communications satellite that will take the place of a similar spacecraft that disappeared in space nearly two years ago, is set for launching here at 8:30 P.M. Thursday, aboard a Delta rocket. The ''R'' is used in the designation because the satellite will replace SATCOM III, which vanished following a spacecraft launching in December 1979.

title: MEASURE TO HASTEN GAS DECONTROL SEEN
description: The Reagan Administration appeared today to be moving toward sponsorship of 1982 legislation to hasten the decontrol of natural gas prices. That would mean higher heating and energy costs for households and industry.

title: BISMARCK'S LIMIT
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: KHOMEINI GIVES UP MORE POWERS TO CLERIC EXPECTED TO SUCCEED HIM

title: BISHOPS SUPPORT PLAN BY HATCH TO CURB ABORTIONS
description: The Roman Catholic bishops of the United States closed ranks today and affirmed support for a constitutional amendment proposed by Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah that would authorize Congress and individual states to regulate abortion.

title: NEW PROTESTS MADE ON CANADIAN CONSTITUTION
description: Both opposition parties in Parliament raised new obstacles today to Government efforts to give Canada a new Constitution.

title: WHOM THE GOVERNMENT PICKS TO LECTURE ABROAD
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANS-WESTERN EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFS
description: * Automatic Data Processing Inc. said it had acquired a majority interest in Rechenzentrum Frankfurt, a West German computer services concern, for cash and contingent payments based upon growth.

title: THE GREATEST OF BUGS BUNNY
description: ''THE LOONEY Looney Looney Bugs Bunny Movie,'' which opens today at the Criterion Center, Gemini and other theaters, is a sort of ''Bugs' Greatest Hits,'' because it strings together several of the redoubtable rabbit's better cartoons. Or, rather, it's Fritz Freleng's Greatest Hits, because Mr. Freleng is responsible not only for Bugs, but also for his co-stars here -Tweety, Sylvester, Porky Pig, Yosemite Sam and Daffy Duck. Daffy is ill-treated, because he is subjected to even more indignities than any of the others, and because he deserves a full-length movie of his own.

title: SRC LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corning Glass To Buy Metpath
description: Corning Glass Works said that it had agreed to acquire Metpath Inc., an operator of clinical laboratory services for physicians, for $150 million in stock.

title: Lawyer Suspended In Bribery Case
description: TRENTON (AP) - A lawyer who was accused of arranging a bribe for a Camden County Superior Court judge two weeks ago was suspended from practicing law by the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: Chicago Bank Sets 16% Prime
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, the nation's seventh-largest bank, said today that it was reducing its prime lending rate a half-point, to 16 percent, matching a level established earlier in the week.

title: Boeing and Japan Talks 'Productive'
description: Two days of talks with representatives of the Japanese aircraft industry centering on development of a new 150-seat airliner ''have been productive,'' the Boeing Company said.

title: Rebels in Chad Claim Control of Key Town
description: Forces loyal to Hissen Habre, the Chadian rebel leader, have taken control of the strategic eastern town of Abeche, near the Sudanese border, a spokesman for Mr. Habre said today.

title: The U.N.Today; Nov. 20, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Dillingham Elects A New Top Officer
description: J. Joseph Casey, 60 years old, has been elected president of the Dillingham Corporation, a diversified Honolulu-based energy, maritime and construction company.

title: U.S. ALTERS POLICY ON DESEGREGATION
description: The Justice Department, in a major change of civil rights policy, said today that it would no longer seek to desegregate an entire school district on the basis of segregation shown to exist in only a portion of the district.

title: FINNISH ROOKIE AIDS RANGERS
description: By National Hockey League physical standards, Reijo Ruotsalainen is an elf. Ruotsalainen, the Rangers' rookie defenseman from Finland, stands 5 feet 7 inches, without skates, and weighs about 165 pounds. But his stature among the Rangers has grown in the first quarter of the season. Virtually unknown as a player when he arrived at the Rangers' training camp in Vierumaki, Finland, in early September, and able to speak only a few words of English, Ruotsalainen, 21 years old, has not only made the team, but also has become one of its key players.

title: MASTERS ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Addenda
description: * Publication Management Inc., Glenview, Ill., has purchased National Racquetball magazine.

title: Correcting the Council, Cont.
description: The other shoe has dropped on New York's City Council. Not only has the Justice Department found that its 1981 redistricting plan violated the Voting Rights Act. Now Federal District Judge Edward Neaher holds that the Council's apportionment violates the Constitution as well. Its deviation from one person, one vote is ''simply too extreme.'' The city and the Council will recover from this legal double whammy, but it may take time to work out a careful and sensible plan.

title: MAYOR DEFENDS CITY'S HANDLING OF ITS HOMELESS
description: Mayor Koch yesterday disputed figures indicating there are 36,000 homeless men and women in New York City and strongly attacked the state, asserting that it had failed to live up to its obligations to these people.

title: No Headline
description: ADVERSE REACTIONS REPORTED FOR SOME TAKING FLU SHOTS

title: Airline Withdraws Stock Offering
description: Columbia Airline, a new carrier based at Baltimore-Washington International Airport, has withdrawn its public stock offering, company officials said.

title: Pistons 122, Bullets 97
description: Kelly Tripucka scored 22 points, and John Long had 20 for Detroit, which trailed only once, 3-2, in the opening minute.

title: Early-Music Concerts
description: Early Italian music can be heard in two concerts this weekend. Tonight at 8, the Waverly Consort will play works from the 14th and 15th centuries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82d Street.

title: Continental To Sell Unit
description: The Continental Group, a diversified international concern with interests in packaging, forest products, insurance and energy, said it had agreed to sell its Teepak Inc. meat casings subsidiary for about $110 million in cash to Hillside Capital Inc.

title: ART: JIM DINE REVISITS 'HEART' MOTIF WITH TOOLS
description: IT is always a mistake to expect painters - or artists generally - to develop their work along a straight and narrow path. Even when a painter abandons a certain way of working, or even a favorite motif, and turns to something that appears to be very different, it does not necessarily signify that he has finished with his original material. He may simply be holding certain aspects of it in reserve - waiting, as it were, for them to ''ripen.'' Then, too, certain motifs have a way of haunting an artist's imagination in ways that may sometimes surprise even the artist himself.

title: ICL Cutbacks Set
description: Britain's biggest computer concern, ICL Ltd., said it was eliminating another 1,500 jobs and closing a factory in Manchester.

title: Advertising; Bringing a Magazine To Market
description: year-old former general manager of Science 81 magazine, went down to Wall Street with an idea and proof that it was good, and came away with $4.95 million to start American Health magazine.

title: O'NEILL PRESENTS CONNECTICUT TAX PLAN
description: A $121 million program of layoffs and tax increases designed to balance the current state budget was presented today by Gov. William A. O'Neill to a special session of the General Assembly.

title: Knicks Lose 4th Straight
description: Despite three changes in the starting lineup, the Knicks were beaten, 89-84, by the Atlanta Hawks last night amid constant booing from a crowd of 9,614 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Woman Surrenders to Police After She Fires Several Shots
description: An armed woman surrendered today to the police after firing several shots from her apartment where she barricaded herself with her infant son for five hours, the police said.

title: Baseball Panel Tonight
description: Baseball is the subject tonight at 7:30 at the New School for Social Research, 66 West 12th Street.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD UP 4.8 MILLION SHARES
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose by 4.8 million shares, to 78.9 million, in the month ended Nov. 13.

title: PINEHURST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. MAIL DELIVERY HAS COME A LONG WAY
description: To the Editor:

title: ALMY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HIGH-TECH RIVALRY
description: Will Japan or the United States dominate world markets in high-tech products by the end of the decade? The odds favor Japan, but not because its high-tech firms get Government subsidies while American firms must fend for themselves, as commonly believed. Research and development is richly subsidized in both nations. But only America systematically discourages marketing of ''high technology'' - the term covers, loosely, commercial products that incorporate advanced electronics.

title: Bridge: Top-Ranked Stars Gather At Fall Nationals on Coast
description: Nearly all the top-ranked players in North America, and a few from other continents, are gathering here today for 10 days of play beginning tomorrow in the Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League at the Sheraton Palace Hotel. Among them will be the six players who won the world open team title for the United States a month ago, and the six American women who finished second in their world championship.

title: At The Movies
description: KENNETH McMILLAN, who plays Willie Conklin, the bigoted, beerbellied fire chief in ''Ragtime,'' has to be the busiest character actor since the days when E.G. Marshall was all over our television screens. Besides ''Ragtime,'' which opens today, Mr. McMillan has three other pictures coming out soon. In ''Whose Life Is It Anyway?'' he plays a judge, in ''Heartbeeps'' (about robots in love), he works for General Motors, and in ''Partners,'' he's head of the Los Angeles Police Department. (''Partners'' also stars John Hurt and Ryan O'Neal as policemen who pose as lovers in order to infiltrate the homosexual community and solve a plague of murders.)

title: U.S. MAIL DELIVERY HAS COME A LONG WAY
description: To the Editor:

title: DETAILS OF OPPOSING BIDS TO PURCHASE MARATHON
description: U.S. Steel's $6.3 billion offer for Marathon Oil consists of a combination of cash and notes that would be offered for the 60 million outstanding shares of Marathon stock.

title: SOVIET BROADENS ATTACK ON REAGAN'S MISSILE PLAN
description: The Soviet press broadened its attack today on President Reagan's proposal for eliminating medium-range nuclear missiles from Europe, but a senior information official said Moscow hoped the President's proposal was not his ''final say on the issue.''

title: FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $241,041 gain on the sale of the Southern division; 1981 shr earnings have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock div paid in Aug 10, 1981

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about where to buy a take- home turkey dinner gave an incorrect telephone number for the Market Din- ing Rooms at the World Trade Center. The number is 775-0582.

title: WHITE HOUSE OPENS A REVIEW ON ALLEN
description: Senior White House aides, concerned that they do not have full information about the activities of Richard V. Allen, have ordered Mr. Allen to review his office records on his contacts with Japanese businessmen while serving as President Reagan's national security adviser, according to an Administration official.

title: QUAKE RISKS CITED
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted today to suspend the license for the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant near San Luis Obispo, Calif.

title: REAGAN'S MISSILE OFFER IS SAID TO REFLECT WEINBERGER'S STAND
description: President Reagan's proposal to have both the Soviet Union and the United States do without intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe reflects a basic position advocated by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and Defense Department aides, senior Administration officials disclosed today.

title: PLAYWRIGHTS SPOTLIGHTED
description: It was a time for pleasantry and a time for generosity at the Shubert Theater yesterday, when Tennessee Williams and Harold Pinter accepted the third annual Common Wealth Awards for distinguished service in the dramatic arts.

title: Truck Dumps Chemical And Thousands Get Sick
description: Thousands of people were made dizzy and nauseated today as a truck leaking chemicals traveled 25 miles of freeway before dumping its load in a concrete pit.

title: TWO POP STARS AT THE NEW BALLROOM
description: When pop singers are looking for ideas for an act, one subject that constantly comes up is tributes to other singers. But Rosemary Clooney and Margaret Whiting, who are making their debut as a singing team at the new Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, found people closer to home to pay tribute to in their new act.

title: News Analysis
description: Behind the public displays of affection between labor and the Democrats at the A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention that ended yesterday are two critical realities: one financial and one political.

title: Funds' Assets Keep Rising
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $3.72 billion in the period ended Wednesday, to $176.42 billion, the 26th consecutive weekly increase and the third largest ever, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The average weekly increase since the beginning of the year has been $2.2 billion.

title: ROSSMOOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: the sale of properties in the fourth qr added $8.4 million to both revs and net income for the yr

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are not going to compel children who don't choose to have an integrated education to have one.'' - William Bradford Reynolds, Assistant Attorney General for civil rights. (A14:1.)

title: Agnew Hopes to Upset Order to Pay $248,735
description: Spiro T. Agnew, the former Vice President, will contend in an appeal that the state of Maryland failed to prove he accepted nearly $250,000 in bribes while as Governor, his attorney said today.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; CHRISTMAS AT MUSIC HALL
description: Santa Claus will fly over the stage in his sleigh at Radio City Music Hall tonight - just one of many spectacles in that traditional season opener, ''The Magnificent Christmas Spectacular.'' Other events will include the arrival of Scrooge in a horse-drawn carriage; ''The Parade of the Wooden Soldiers,'' danced by the Rockettes; part of ''The Nutcracker'' ballet, and a ''living nativity'' scene, complete with donkeys, sheep, llamas and Henry the camel. The show gets under way at 7:30 and runs through Jan. 3. Tickets are $14.75 for reserved seats, and $11.75 for general admission. Information: 757-3100. Ticketron: 977-9020. Chargit: 944-9300. JOFFREY SILVER JUBILEE

title: SHELL OIL COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-For Royal Dutch Petroleum Co...C-For Shell Transport & Trading Co

title: The Stepchild Of Apartheid
description: SYDNEY MAREE is one of the best mile runners in the world, one of the most personable young men in sports and an expectant father. Parenthood is scheduled to descend May 21, a Friday, which may or may not cause a date conflict with a track meet. But the former Lisa Rhoden is an 800-meter runner who will strive to accommodate her husband's schedule.

title: NORTHERN IRELAND'S JOB BLIGHT
description: Patrick Kelly, a 28-year-old electrician, was laid off a few months ago when the houses he was working on were completed. Now his days consist of visits to the corner of Davis and Conway Streets, in a Roman Catholic part of Belfast, where the unemployment office is protected from terrorists by an assemblage of wire mesh.

title: HUGHES SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $109,000 gain from the settlement of litigation; 1981 results include operations of Marbut Co from May 29, the date of acquisition

title: CAMPBELL SOUP CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
CBS WILL EXPAND NIGHTLY NEWS TO ONE HOUR
description: CBS will increase its national evening newscast from 30 minutes to at least 45 minutes and more likely a full hour by March 1983, top CBS executives said yesterday.

title: Summations Completed In Point-Shaving Trial
description: A spirited argument for the immunity given Henry Hill, a Government informant who was the chief prosecution witness in the Boston College point-shaving trial, was offered to the jury yesterday by Edward A. McDonald, the special prosecutor. He emphasized that the case would never have surfaced had it not been for information obtained from Mr. Hill, a convicted felon who has confessed to a wide range of criminal activity.

title: POSSIBLE CHIEF FOR LAW UNIT STIRS CONCERN
description: The Reagan Administration's plan to name Ronald A. Zumbrun of Sacramento, the president of the conservative Pacific Legal Foundation, as chairman of the board of the Federal Legal Services Corporation has created apprehension among public service law agencies here.

title: WHITE HOUSE SOUGHT F.D.A. DATA TO HELP IN-LAW OF PRESIDENT
description: The White House made inquiries to the Food and Drug Administration on behalf of Nancy Reagan's stepfather, a medical Administration on behalf of Nancy Reagan's stepfather, a medical equipment consultant, about a new surgical suture awaiting agency approval, a Presidential spokesman said today.

title: THE ZAMBIAN PEOPLE STAND UNITED BEHIND PRESIDENT KAUNDA
description: To the Editor:

title: BIOFUEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
description: LEBANON BLOCKADE IS SAID TO END

title: 200 CONTRIBUTORS TOUR A REFURBISHED WHITE HOUSE
description: Nancy Reagan, who sought $200,000 in donations to refurbish the White House, spent $730,000, most of it on the Reagans' private living quarters, according to the White House Historical Association.

title: Canada Denies Misdirecting Soviet Craft Over Eastern U.S.
description: The Canadian Government denied today that its air traffic controllers were partly to blame for misdirected Soviet airline flights over the eastern United States in early November.

title: Shower of Praise
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, speech on the Senate floor, congratulating the junior Senator from New York, Alfonse M. D'Amato, on his daughter's record-setting stunt for charity, Nov. 16:

title: REDKEN LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Yr-ago qr results restated to reflect 10 percent stock divd in Oct 81 and LIFO method of accounting adopted for substantially all inventory at fiscal yr ended July 31, 1981

title: Market Place; Picking Stocks That May Rise
description: MITCHELL & COMPANY'S stock picks for 1980 posted gains averaging 172 percent in a year, and the Cambridge, Mass., firm was deluged with requests for new selections.

title: Restaurants; Palace revisited; new in midtown.
description: EVER since it opened in 1975, the Palace on East 59th Street, across from the Queensboro Bridge, has been known as the city's most expensive restaurant. Renamed Michel Fitoussi's Palace last month, when the chef of the last five years also became the proprietor, the restaurant now has several rivals in its reduced price range. But four meals eaten there since Mr. Fitoussi took over the management several months ago indicate that it is still a one-star value.

title: Hinckley's Father Says His Son Needs Therapy
description: John Hinckley Jr. is in a state of ''total despair'' after his latest suicide attempt and urgently needs psychiatric therapy, his father said.
To the Editor:

title: INTERCONTINENTAL LIFE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Journalist Is Apparent Victim Of Wife, Who Shoots Herself
description: Neil McNeil, director of the Medill News Service, was shot and killed, apparently by his estranged wife, Doris, who then killed herself at their home in Northwest Washington, the police said today.

title: ARAB'S BANK BID THWARTED
description: With success almost in their hands, three wealthy Arab investors were spurned once again yesterday in their four-year quest to obtain control of Financial General Bankshares Inc., a multistate bank holding company.

title: LONELY COMEBACK OF AN EX-CHAMPION
description: On one wall of the clean, well-lighted gym, the exposed brick is covered with blown-up photographs of Joe Frazier's memorable career. On the opposite wall hangs a series of mirrors, in front of which the boxers skip rope and shadow box and see what they want to see.

title: ATLANTIC OIL CORP (DENVER, COLO) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BUFFALO BILL RETURNS TO THE WILDS OF BROOKLYN
description: BUFFALO BILL has returned to Brooklyn, that maverick borough where, some may be surprised to learn, he's ridden several times before. The legendary frontiersman and his traveling ''Wild West'' troupe visited Brooklyn around the turn of the century, setting up camp at, among other sites, Ambrose Park (now the Brooklyn Navy Terminal), where they performed their remarkable feats of horsemanship to capacity crowds. And tomorrow (and through Jan. 17), ''Buffalo Bill and the Wild West,'' a big show of memorabilia, posters, paintings and sculpture relating to Col. William F. Cody - as he was formally known - will open at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: A SPOOK'S BUCK IS A BUCK
description: A well-cast gunman, dark, handsome, neatly bearded and wearing a black leather jacket, emptied his Biretta at the U.S. Charge d'Affaires, Christian Chapman, as he was going to work here last week.

title: No Headline
description: The New York Times/Jack Manning Record Lottery Winning Spurs 'New Plateau' in Lotto Ticket Sales Sales of $1 Lotto tickets were brisk yesterday at this booth in the Port Authority Bus Terminal on Eighth Avenue, as they were at outlets throughout the state. Wednesday's announcement that Louis Eisenberg of Brooklyn won last week's accumulated record jackpot of $5 million resulted in what New York State Lottery officials called ''a new plateau'' of $1,204,322 in Lotto ticket sales yesterday. The drawing tomorrow will be for a top prize of $3,051,683.

title: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 20, 1981; Companies
description: An agreement for U.S. Steel to acquire Marathon Oil for about $6.3 billion was announced by the two companies. The dramatic new step in Marathon's effort to fend off a takeover by Mobil would, if consumated, create the nation's 13th-largest industrial concern. The takeover would be the second-largest ever, surpassed only by Du Pont's $7.3 billion purchase of Conoco. More than 1.5 million Marathon shares changed hands on the New York Stock Exchange. The company's stock soared $27.25, closing at $104.25. (Page A1.)

title: INJURIES FORCE CHANGES AT QUARTERBACK
description: Two - perhaps three - teams will not start their regular quarterbacks Sunday because of injuries. Late-season switches like this for teams with playoff possibilities are troublesome but unavoidable in these cases.

title: UNITED MERCHANTS & MANUFACTURERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $620,000 tax credit...C-Net loss including $916,000 tax credit

title: G.N.P. UP BY 0.6% IN 3D QUARTER
description: The Government, revising a preliminary estimate, reported today that the American economy went up slightly, not down, in the summer months.

title: Pakistan's Charge Is Denied
description: Afghanistan denied today that its aircraft had attacked Afghan refugee camps in northwest Pakistan on Monday and Tuesday and charged that Pakistan fabricated the incidents to get more aid from the United States. Pakistan said one refugee was killed and fourteen were injured in the attacks.

title: SEANTE G.O.P. SEEKS PLAN ON SPENDING AS DEADLINE NEARS
description: Republican leaders in the Senate struggled early today to find a compromise that would prune back a stopgap spending bill for the Federal Government and forestall a Presidential veto.

title: ASSOCIATED DRY GOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Books
description: Grand Romantic By John Leonard BOCCACCIO. By Thomas G. Bergin. 392 pages. Viking. $25.

title: HUSKY OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After extraordinary book loss of $17.4 million from the disposal of Gate City Steel Corp

title: Stuntman Warned
description: A follow-up: A judge in Chicago yesterday put Daniel Goodwin on probation for a year and ordered him not to climb any more buildings in Cook County.

title: POLAND WITHDRAWING TROOPS
description: The Polish Army announced tonight that it was withdrawing the hundreds of small military units sent to the countryside four weeks ago to help curb unrest.

title: UNITRODE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Includes $87,000 extraordinary gain

title: CIRCLE K CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $1,771,000 gain on sale of the company's investment in National Convenience Stores Inc in Sept 1981; yr-ago results have been restated for a change to LIFO accounting

title: 'HUNGARIANS,' TALE OF MIGRANTS IN GERMANY
description: ZOLTAN FABRI'S ''Hungarians'' is as stolid as its characters, a group of peasants who leave Hungary to work in Germany during World War II. The most knowledgable of them has never heard of Hitler. Yet signs of the war are unmistakable, as bands of refugees and wounded soldiers pass through the farm where the Hungarians have signed on as field hands. Mr. Fabri's film details their growing understanding of what is going on around them, as well as the fierce and renewed patriotism they begin to feel during their sojourn abroad.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day Nov. 10 about Supreme Court rulings incorrectly described the status of the Court of Claims. Congress now regards it, along with the Court of Customs and Patent Appeals, as having been established under Article III of the Constitution, thus guaranteeing its judges life tenure and protection against salary decreases.

title: DISPUTE THREATENS A REVIVAL OF MINIMUM PENSION BENEFIT
description: The attempt by Congress to restore the minimum Social Security benefit of $122 a month, which was ordered eliminated as part of the Reagan Administration's budget legislation last summer, appears to be approaching a political impasse.

title: Pop Jazz; ALL-BEETHOVEN, FROM MORNING TO NIGHT AT SYMPHONY SPACE
description: THE all-Beethoven program is a fixture of most orchestra seasons, just as it is of many pianists' repertories. The string quartet that hasn't played an all-Beethoven program doesn't deserve the name; in fact, a few, like the Guarneri and Juilliard, think nothing of putting six all-Beethoven programs together for a cycle of all the Beethoven quartets.

title: WASHINGTON HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
The Editorial Notebook;  A Beacon in the Bronx
description: Motorists whisking past on the Cross Bronx Expressway aren't likely to notice it, and few people would brave the rubble-strewn streets to find it, but there's a public school in the Crotona section of the Bronx that shines like a beacon. It's P.S. 44, whose nearly graffiti-free exterior and glistening halls and classrooms stand out as notably as its academic record.

title: Privacy in Public
description: A recent Miami Beach plan to install television monitors on streets to watch for crime led to official worries about invasion of privacy. Florida's Attorney General settled the qualms with an opinion: Cameras on the street, he said, don't invade privacy because they see only what the public sees; in effect, there is no privacy in a public place.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Guatemala to Draft Peasants to Fight Rebels

title: PEOPLES DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
PONDEROSA SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 5
Polish Union Asks Workers for Restraint
description: The Solidarity trade union appealed for restraint by its 10 million members today as Parliament again held out a threat of emergency measures to halt strikes and social unrest.

title: ALLY AND FOE ADMIRE BENCH NOMINEE
description: Seven years ago, a reviewer said that Richard A. Posner's ''The Economic Analysis of Law'' was more like a picaresque novel than a serious study of legal doctrines and institutions. Mr. Posner, the critic said, used the marketplace the way Huckleberry Finn used his cynical innocence or Tom Jones his sensuality: to make a complicated world seem neat and simple. The book, he wrote, was ''400 pages of tunnel vision.''

title: Penn Central Vote Review
description: The Penn Central Corporation said yesterday that independent election judges have yet to complete a review of a shareholders' vote that apparently rejected a proposed $1.4 billion acquisition of Colt Industries Inc.

title: District Attorney Tells Of Corruption in Racing
description: Harry Connick, district attorney of New Orleans, told the State Racing Commission today that tampering, illicit gambling and narcotics deals are commonplace at Louisiana race tracks. Mr. Connick, who made his comments after a seven-month investigation, urged the commission to take steps to clean up the sport.

title: NATIONWIDE LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Nationwide Life is the principal subsidiary of the Nationwide Corporation which is listed over-the-counter

title: NU-WEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hamilton Papers Show
description: Alexander Hamilton's handwritten record of all the law cases he handled from 1795 to his death in 1804 is among the rare papers on view through Dec. 4 at the Low Memorial Library at Columbia University, Broadway and 116th Street. Among the 40 exhibits are law briefs, trial reports and a bill of cost paid by Aaron Burr to Hamilton in 1789, 15 years before Burr killed him in a duel.

title: U.S. STEEL'S BID CRITICIZED IN WASHINGTON
description: The United States Steel Corporation's bid to acquire the Marathon Oil Company ''calls into question the seriousness of the steel industry's efforts to modernize its steelmaking facilities,'' Lionel H. Olmer, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade Administration, said today.

title: PRODUCTS RESEARCH & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Canada Loan Guarantee
description: The British Export Credits Guarantee Department said today that it would guarantee a $82.52 million (Canadian) loan to the Transalta Utilities Corporation of Alberta, its first such Canadian loan guarantee. The five-year loan, to help finance two turbine generators from GEC Turbine Generators Ltd. and GEC Canada Ltd., will carry a subsidized interest rate of 8.5 percent.

title: BLOOD DONERS, TOO, DESERVE A TAX BREAK
description: To the Editor:

title: SHARON CRITICIZED BY S.E.C.
description: The Sharon Steel Corporation should have disclosed more quickly its holdings in the Reliance Electric Company after the Exxon Corporation made a $1.2 billion offer to buy Reliance in May 1979, the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday.

title: SOUTHERN BIOTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $1,137,546 nonrecurring charge for both periods from the excess purchase of price paid in Aug for interest of a co- venturer in an interferons joint venture over the co-venturer's capital contribution to the venturer...C-Net income

title: AN EXPLORER ON MUSIC'S BORDERLANDS
description: CATEGORIES are useful only so long as they mean something, and at the moment the categorical separation of pop music from the avantgarde is in need of some revision. Consider Jon Hassell, who is giving concerts tonight and tomorrow night at 10 o'clock at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: First Chicago Official Is on Familiar Ground
description: A. Ray Einsel, a 41-year old senior vice president of the First National Bank of Chicago, who will preside over the proposed purchase of the Visa credit card operation of the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, expects an easy transition.

title: OLYMPIC SOLAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $5,408 for the qr and $37,558 for the 9 mos and $7,090 gain for the 9 mos from discontinued operations...C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $43,256 for the qr and $240,752 for the 9 mos, $10,585 extraordinary loss for the qr and $58,349 extraordinary gain for the 9 mos

title: AMERICAN PACEMAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Brazil Coffee Crop
description: The United States Department of Agriculture said today that its latest estimate puts Brazil's 1982-83 coffee crop at 16 million bags, a sharp decline as a result of the July frost. The preliminary United States estimate of the Brazilian crop following the frost had predicted the crop to be between 15 million and 18 million bags, the department said.

title: U.S. TO OFFER ATOM SECRETS TO AUSTRALIA
description: Department of Energy officials said today that President Reagan had decided to offer Australia access to highly classified centrifuge technology to enrich uranium, technology that until now has not been shared with foreign governments.

title: Fannie Mae Expansion
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, a Government-chartered, stockholder-owned company that ranks as the nation's largest supplier of residential mortgage money, said today that it would begin buying second mortgages on Nov. 30.

title: U.S. Moves to Seal L.I. Abscam Tapes
description: The Justice Department yesterday moved to seal for 60 days tape recordings of conversations in which a Long Island businessman convicted of Abscam conspiracy charges asserted that various political figures had engaged in corruption.

title: VENDO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $925,000 gain for both periods from the sale of machinery and factory equipment and $725,000 for the 9 mos on the sale of a warehouse and $870,000 gain on proceeds from the company's lawsuit against Stoner Investments Inc

title: A NECESSARY HUNT IN HARRIMAN STATE PARK
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Upholds Ending U.F.T. Dues Checkoff
description: A Federal judge yesterday upheld the right of New York City to stop deducting union dues from teachers' paychecks as a penalty against the United Federation of Teachers for its nine-day strike in September 1975.

title: Auctions; A major sale of rare works.
description: SOME exceptional European works of art will be auctioned next week in what Sotheby Parke Bernet calls the largest sale of Gothic and Renaissance bronzes, ivories, enamels, wood carvings, gilded metalwork and exotic materials ever held in New York. In all, 700 items will be offered.

title: MRS. JAMES A. DAVIDSON
description: Ann V. Davidson, the widow of James A. Davidson, a manager of concert and operatic singers in the 1940's and 50's, died yesterday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home in Manhattan. She was 80 years old.

title: DOW UP A BIT ON MERGER NEWS
description: Merger developments produced strong gains for many energy issues yesterday while the general stock market advanced slightly. At the final bell the Dow Jones industrial average was up 0.67 point, to 844.75. Advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered losses by a margin of 772 to 721.

title: NORRIS OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $4,444 extraordinary tax charge...C-Net income including extraordinary tax credits of $5,000 for the qr and $19,000 for the 9 mos; the company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange

title: U.S. STEEL AGREES TO PAY $6.3 BILLION FOR MARATHON OIL
description: The United States Steel Corporation and the Marathon Oil Company announced an agreement yesterday for U.S. Steel to acquire the Middle Western oil company for about $6.3 billion. The announcement came as a dramatic development in Marathon's efforts to fend off a takeover by the Mobil Corporation.

title: Dodgers Sign Johnstone
description: Jay Johnstone, who played an important role for Los Angeles in its World Series victory over the Yankees, signed a one-year contract with the Dodgers today.

title: LAKERS DROP WESTHEAD AS COACH
description: The Los Angeles Lakers today dismissed Paul Westhead as head coach, less than 24 hours after the team's star guard, Earvin (Magic) Johnson, asked to be traded because of differences with Westhead over the team's new offensive system.

title: WAVETEK CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-After $737,000 loss from discontinued operations and $515,000 gain on disposal

title: COUNCIL TO APPEAL RULING ON AT-LARGE SYSTEM
description: The City Council will appeal a Federal court ruling that declared unconstitutional the system of electing two at-large members from each borough, the Corporation Counsel said yesterday.

title: energywatch
description: NOV. 13, 1981 Despite a decline in crude oil imports and unchanged refinery output, crude oil stocks surged to 378.8 million barrels, up 5.3 million.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. DELEGATES URGE CONTROLLERS' RETURN
description: Delegates to the convention of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations in New York City called on President Reagan yesterday to return air traffic controllers to their jobs.

title: HELEN LOSKIN, 66, DIRECTOR OF HOSPITAL SOCIAL SERVICES
description: Helen Lokshin, director of social work services for Mount Sinai Services at the City Hospital Center in Elmhurst, Queens, died of cardiac arrest on Wednesday at Bellevue Hospital. She was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: PORCH OF STOICS IS FOUND IN DIG AT ATHENS AGORA
description: A major archeological discovery in Athens - the foundation of one of the most prominent buildings of the Classical period in Greece - will be announced in New York today by the American School of Classical Studies at Athens. The building, which dates from 470 to 460 B.C., is known as the Painted Stoa, from the works by important artists of the period that hung on its wall.

title: ASBESTOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income...C-Net loss; the company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Notable No-Show
description: Nadia Comaneci, who won the hearts of millions at the 1976 Olympics in Montreal, failed to appear with the Rumanian gymnastics team when it arrived in Moscow for the world championships, which start Monday.

title: Art at the Garden
description: Hundreds of works by 250 American and European artists will be on view this weekend at Madison Square Garden in ''New Artists at Madison Square Garden.''

title: G.E. Plant Closing
description: The General Electric Company said it would close a lightbulb manufacturing plant in this Orlando suburb because of a decline in business.

title: ROCKWOOD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $232,000 reversal of a tax credit...C-Net income including gains from discontinued operations of $7,999,000 for the qr and $8,419,000 for the 6 mos and $239,000 reversal of tax credit for the qr

title: A Castro Reappears After Long Silence
description: Little has been heard about him since he was a 9-year-old schoolboy, but now, it turns out, Felix Fidel Castro Diaz, the only son of Cuba's President Fidel Castro, is the director of Cuba's Atomic Energy Commission.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * A.B. Fortia is offering 2.8 million American depository shares at $18.20 a share. Each American depository share represents on nonrestricted B share of the company. Morgan Stanley is the lead underwriter.

title: CDX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: The company was formerly Cyber Diagnostics

title: EATING OUT: THEIR WAY OF LIFE
description: Eating out is half the fun. Or all of it. Or it is all business. Or half of that. It is, certainly, the preoccupation of many New Yorkers who dine out often in this city of restaurants, some to mark special occasions, others because dining out is a satisfying adjunct to their social and business lives, still others to whom eating out is a pleasure to be savored even as often as five times each week.

title: GAS PIPELINE CLEARED BY HOUSE PANEL
description: A House committee, in a decision that effectively removes the final big legislative hurdle to building a natural gas pipeline from Alaska's Prudhoe Bay, today approved a resolution easing the way for sponsors to raise the money.

title: ALLEN'S JAPANESE FRIEND: ROLE OF GO-BETWEEN
description: Tamotsu Takase, a business consultant who is a friend of Richard V. Allen, President Reagan's national security adviser, has played a role behind the scenes in trade negotiations between the United States and Japan for more than a decade, according to Japanese Government officials.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: T HE mob of autograph seekers outside Luchow's restaurant late Wednesday night appeared to be mainly young - too young, at any rate, to remember most of James Cagney's movies. Yet they screamed and yelled and otherwise went crazy when he left with his wife, Billie, after attending the opening-night party for his latest film, ''Ragtime.''

title: HARVARD TO NAME PANEL TO ADVISE DEPARTMENT ACCUSED OF SEX BIAS
description: The dean of Harvard's faculty of arts and sciences said today that he would appoint a committee of scholars to aid the university's sociology department in identifying candidates for tenure.

title: MARGIOTTA WITNESS DETAILS PAYMENTS
description: The prosecution's main witness testified today that his insurance agency had made payments to Nassau County politicians selected by Joseph M. Margiotta because he wanted to keep the county's insurance business.

title: NCK Gains a Position In Siboney of Caracas
description: The NCK Organization, parent of the Norman, Craig & Kummel agencies with worldwide billings of $447 million coming from operations in 20 countries, has entered into a working arrangement with Publicidad Siboney, the Caracas, Venezuela, agency that has $45 million in billings and offices in 12 countries. NCK will have a minority equity position in Siboney, which is owned by the Cubas family, formerly of Cuba.

title: WHITE HOUSE CLARIFIES POLICY ON JERUSALEM AFTER REAGAN STATEMENT
description: The White House was forced tonight to issue a clarification of American policy toward Jerusalem in an effort to head off possible misunderstandings over a statement by President Reagan to a group of prominent Jews.

title: Tower at St. Bart's Opposed by Board
description: Community Board 5, after a three-hour public meeting on a proposal to build a 59-story office tower on the site of the community house of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, unanimously opposed any development on the landmark site.

title: Games Magazine Doubling Its Frequency
description: Four-year-old Games magazine, acquired by Playboy Enterprises in 1978, will double its frequency to 12 issues a year, starting in 1982. The publication, which Playboy credits with being the fastestgrowing newsstand magazine, started with a circulation rate base of 200,000 and now has 600,000.

title: CHILDREN'S PLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
What Taiwan Wants - and Needs
description: There is a reasonable way for the Reagan Administration to extricate itself from a Chinese knot of its own making. Taiwan wants an advanced American fighter to replace the F-5E's it has been coproducing for six years. Law and good faith require Washington to help Taiwan defend itself. But that requirement can be sensibly met by supplying an improved version of the F-5E. It does not argue for the more formidable weapons that Taipei's American champions insist it needs - even at the risk of enraging Peking.

title: JETS' OFFENSIVE LINE RECOGNIZES ITS TASK
description: Amid the confusion caused by the injuries to the Jets' top two quarterbacks, the offensive line remains a stabilizing force, the unit that will have to protect the quarterback, whoever he is, Sunday against the Miami Dolphins.

title: U.S. STUDYING FOILED BID TO EXPORT A KEY REACTOR METAL TO PAKISTAN
description: Federal authorities are investigating a shipment of a key metal used in the construction of nuclear reactors that was seized as it was about to be loaded on a passenger flight from Kennedy International Airport to Pakistan.

title: News Analysis
description: A bill Mayor Koch signed into law represents the city's latest effort to halt the decline in the number of single-room-occupancy hotels. The provision offers owners on the Upper West Side, where many of the hotels are situated, greater tax benefits for upgrading them than for converting them to so-called luxury housing.

title: Bess Myerson to Join WCBS-TV in January
description: New York City's former Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, Bess Myerson, will join WCBS-TV in January when the station expands its evening news program, which now begins at 6 P.M., with ''The 5 O'- Clock Report.''

title: Mystery on 55th St.
description: The Negro Ensemble Company opens its season at Theater Four, 424 West 55th Street, tonight at 8 with a new play by Charles Fuller, whose ''Zooman and the Sign'' won an Obie award last season.

title: Swastikas Painted In Fair Lawn
description: Swastikas and anti-Semitic epithets have been spray-painted on two synagogues, Shomrei Torah and Temple Beth Sholom; the Fair Lawn Jewish Center; the community's water tower and the door of an auto shop at the high school, the police said.

title: VAIL ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Magic at the Garden
description: All may not be what it appears to be at Madison Square Garden for the next two weeks, when a show called ''The Amazing Masters of Magic and Illusion'' will be there.

title: KARPOV NEAR VICTORY
description: Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, the world chess champion, is within a hair-breadth of winning his title match with Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland. He adjourned the 18th game a pawn ahead in a rook-and-knight ending that he is expected to win when play is resumed tomorrow.

title: PEOPLE
description: * Michael Shalette has been elected a senior vice president at SSC&B Inc.

title: TIMES SEES RECORD NET
description: The New York Times Company expects record income for 1981, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman of the company, told security analysts yesterday.

title: WATT TIGHTENS UP OIL LEASING RULES
description: Under pressure from a New Mexico Congressman, Interior Secretary James G. Watt pledged today that no future oil and gas leases in Federal wilderness areas would be granted without a full environmental assessment, public notification well beforehand and consultation with Congress.

title: MCGRAW-HILL RYERSON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PUBLISHING: BABAR AT 50, A TRUNKFUL OF MEMORIES
description: WHEN the publishing company founded by Harrison Smith and Robert K. Haas merged with Random House in 1936, the Smith and Haas roster included William Faulkner, Isak Dinesen, Robert Graves and Andre Malraux. But another of its authors was Jean de Brunhoff, whose internationally famous creation, Babar the Elephant, is now celebrating its 50th anniversary.

title: DARWIN'S ISLANDS ADAPT TO A NEW SPECIES: TOURISTS
description: When Herman Melville visited these rude, mist-shrouded volcanic islands, he remarked on their ''emphatic uninhabitableness.''
