The first impression recorded in the notebooks of Charles Darwin, whose evolutionary convictions took root here, was, ''Nothing could be less inviting.'' And the captain of the survey ship H.M.S. Beagle that brought the English naturalist to the Galapagos found the craggy black coastline ''a fit shore for pandemonium.''

title: REAGAN PRESSED ON SALVADOR
description: A House committee urged President Reagan today to press opposing political factions in El Salvador, including the United States-backed junta, to hold ''unconditional discussions'' to guarantee that next year's national elections will be free and open.

title: Gerulaitis to Play
description: Vitas Gerulaitis, who had said that he would not play in the South African tennis championships because of death threats that caused Jimmy Connors to withdraw, has changed his mind. Gerulaitis now says he will take part, and he replaces Connors as the top-seeded entry.

title: LOUVRE SAYS PAINTING SOLD WITHOUT LICENSE
description: The Louvre has accused the Cleveland Museum and its director, Sherman Lee, of buying a painting that had been smuggled out of France. The picture is Nicolas Poussin's ''Madonna of the Steps,'' painted in 1648.

title: WOMEN IN MOON CASE FEARS PARENTS
description: A woman ordered by a California judge to return to San Francisco so that he could determine whether she was being held against her will by the Unification Church said yesterday that she had fled the West Coast because she feared her parents had hired ''deprogrammers'' to kidnap her.

title: Marcos Bans Video Games
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos banned video game machines today because of complaints from parents and teachers that the games were creating ''havoc'' with the morality of the nation's youth. President Marcos ordered the police to strictly enforce the provisions of a presidential decree prohibiting the video games as well as pinball machines, slot machines and other similar devices. Violators face a fine of $600 or six months to 12 years in jail.

title: Ard Will Start Again
description: Coach Ray Perkins of the Giants said Thursday that Bill Ard would start again at left guard against the Eagles in Philadelphia Sunday.

title: LACLEDE GAS CO reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
CONFERENCES ARE SITE OF LEGISLATIVE SHOWDOWNS
description: The conference committee on the farm bill was not meeting again until 2:30 P.M., but Horace Godfrey was on lineby 1 o'clock. So were the other lobbyists, the shrewd professionals representing rice and sugar, wheat and cotton.

title: CONFESSIONS OF SADAT ASSASSINS REPORTED BY EGYPTIAN PAPER
description: Confessions published today and attributed to the four men indicted for the murder of President Anwar el-Sadat said that he had been their only target.

title: Kissinger Asks Allies to Back Reagan's Nuclear Arms Plan
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger called on America's allies today to support President Reagan's proposal for a reduction in East-West nuclear arsenals in Europe.

title: BIG STEEL'S MOVES TO DIVERSIFY
description: The United States Steel Corporation's $6.3 billion offer for the Marathon Oil Company is more evidence of the steel industry's intensifying quest for growth outside its traditional business, analysts say.

title: SILICON SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
7 ARE INDICTED IN ROCKLAND FOR ROBBERY OF BRINK'S CAR
description: Seven persons, most of whom have been identified by law-enforcement officials as members of radical groups, were indicted today on murder and robbery charges stemming from the armored-car robbery and shootout in Rockland County on Oct. 20.

title: Behn Wilson Suspended
description: Behn Wilson, the Philadelphia Flyers defenseman, was assessed a four-game suspension by the National Hockey League yesterday for slashing Reijo Ruotsalainen of the Rangers in the face during a game at the Spectrum two weeks ago.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 16.00-16.50.** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.+ Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FIRST AMERICAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Didn't Take the Hint
description: About 50 students at Eastern Michigan University in Ypsilanti, Mich., gathered outside the school's administration office and chanted slogans protesting the rehiring of the football coach, Mike Stock. The rally came two days after student government leaders had sent Stock a letter asking him to resign. The Eastern Michigan team's 18-game losing streak is the second longest in the nation, exceeded only by Northwestern's 30-game streak, but Eastern Michigan administrators Monday rehired Stock for 1982.

title: AMERICAN SHIPBUILDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LABOR UNIT FAULTS CONTROLLERS
description: The governing body of the 146-nation International Labor Organization, a United Nations specialized agency, today faulted air traffic controllers on strike in the United States for their walkout but urged the Reagan Administration to reopen talks with the union to end the dispute.

title: Todd's Status Doubtful; He Says He Can Play
description: On his 28th birthday, Richard Todd threw gingerly on the sidelines today, a fractured rib preventing him from scrimmaging with the Jets and keeping his playing status doubtful for Sunday's game against the Miami Dolphins.

title: TV Weekend; ARNESS, 'NOVA' AND MUSIC
description: ''McCLAIN'S LAW,'' the new weekly series starring James Arness, gets under way tonight at 9 on NBC with a special two-hour premiere. Mr. Arness was Matt Dillon on ''Gunsmoke'' for 20 years. Now he is a former police detective who wants to come out of retirement and, for starters, to avenge the murder of a friend.

title: 7 MASSACHUSETTS YOUTHS GUILTY IN DROWNINGS
description: A jury tonight found seven teenagers guilty of involuntary manslaughter in the drownings of two youths from another high school after a graduation party.

title: Books of the Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt POEMS AND SKETCHES OF E.B. WHITE. 217 pages. Harper & Row. $13.50.

title: SCIENCE MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes tax credits of $21,000 for the qr and $88,000 for the 9 mos

title: POWER OF COURTS TESTED IN 2 SUITS
description: Pennsylvania legislators will not appear in court Friday, but they will be engaged, nevertheless, in a war of wills with Federal District Judge Louis C. Bechtle when he opens a session here.

title: Lukens Steel Plans Diversification
description: The Lukens Steel Company, a specialty steelmaker, intends to diversify outside the steel industry as part of a long-range strategic plan, its president and chief executive officer said.

title: Foreign Steel Investigation
description: The Reagan Administration today added Canada and Spain to its list of foreign steel producers under investigation for unfair trade practices.

title: U.S. 'REGRETS' SOVIET PRESS ATTACKS ON REAGAN'S PLAN TO CURB MISSILES
description: The United States said today that it regretted the ''hasty'' first reaction by Soviet information outlets to President Reagan's arms control proposals. It said that it hoped for a more constructive response in the future.

title: CELLO RECITAL: STEPHEN KATES
description: IN Stephen Kates's recital at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night, his skills as a cellist were employed so subtly at times that they passed virtually unnoticed. Rachmaninoff's Sonata in G minor and Schumann's ''Fantasiestucke,'' for example, call for nuanced playing that may not raise the rafters but does demand instrumental mastery of a high degree. Mr. Kates provided it, but did not flaunt it.

title: BRIEFING
description: A N unusual lawsuit by President Reagan's election campaign committee to block the release of a critical audit by the Federal Election Commission is failing in court. But, ironically, the lawsuit has heightened interest in what might otherwise have been a quiet, routine accounting, primarily because the Reagan-Bush Committee has said in its complaint that the audit would cause reputations to be damaged, would demand $1.5 million in repayment of public funds, and would allege ''apparent violations'' of the campaign law.

title: PIPER JAFFRAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: The company is listed on the Montreal Stock Exchange

title: LEISURE CONCEPTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VISTA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses of $132,505 for the qr and $236,736 for the 9 mos from equity in 50 percent owned company and $1,465,128 loss for the qr and $600,544 gain for the 9 mos from discontinu operations and gain on dispositions of $2,356,653 for the qr and 9 mos...C-After $264,279 loss for the 9 mos from equity in 50 percent owned company

title: 'Ragtime' Evokes Real and Fictional Pasts
description: Milos Forman's ''Ragtime,'' adapted by Michael Weller from E.L. Doctorow's rambunctious, kaleidescopic novel, begins and ends with a dreamlike image - a pair of ballroom dancers, caught in a spotlight, surrounded by darkness, performing, not very gracefully, to an unfamiliar melody, before an unseen audience.

title: MEASURES TO CONTROL COYOTES ARE SOUGHT BY U.S. OFFICIALS
description: The Interior Department's Fish and Wildlife Service today announced new measures to control coyotes that prey on livestock, including use of a poison that had been banned. It also eased restrictions on killing coyote cubs in their dens.

title: GENERAL DEFENSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
No Headline
description: E.C. HAYHOW

title: Shotgun 'Bump' Is Fatal
description: A man was accidentally shot to death today when he bumped his head on a policeman's shotgun while he was being searched, a police spokesman said. Rosendo Saavedra of Miami was killed at a Miami intersection when he ''suddenly jerked backwards and hit his head on the end of the officer's shotgun,'' said the spokesman, Angelo Bitsis. Officer John Sprague was carrying the weapon with one hand while he searched Mr. Saavedra with his other hand, Mr. Bitsis said.

title: 'Donation' to School
description: A judge has said that Manny Goldstein, a former assistant coach at the University of New Mexico who was involved in the basketball scandal there, can have a felony fraud conviction erased from his record by making a donation to the college. District Judge W. John Brennan, who presided at Goldstein's trial, said that he agreed to give Goldstein a deferred 18-month sentence if the former coach made restitution of $684 to the school and paid a $1,368 fine, which would go to the school as a ''voluntary donation.'' Although Goldstein and the former head coach, Norm Ellenberger, both were convicted on charges involving fraud and false travel vouchers, earlier this year, they will remain without criminal records when the time period of their deferred sentences runs out.

title: SEISCOM DELTA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STUDY FINDS LARGE OVERPAYMENTS IN AID FOR NEEDY COLLEGE STUDENTS
description: Secretary of Education T.H. Bell said today that a new study indicated overpayments of as much as $452 million were being made to needy college students receiving Federal grants.

title: YATES FIELD IN TEXAS IS KEY TO DEAL
description: In Texas they simply call it the Yates oilfield, but at the Marathon Oil Company's headquarters in Findlay, Ohio, it is spoken of more reverently as The Crown Jewel.

title: Turkish Gunboats Seize Greek Fishing Trawlers
description: Two Greek fishing vessels were seized by Turkish gunboats today in what Turkey said were its territorial waters.

title: ADVERTISING
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation early next year will end a three-and-ahalf year silence as a corporate advertiser on commercial television by sponsoring a one-hour, syndicated special based on material approved by editors of Discover, the relatively new science magazine from Time Inc. It will be called ''Discover: The World of Science.''

title: BRIDGEPORT'S NEW MAYOR FINDS SOME BARE FILE CUPBOARDS
description: When he left office Nov. 9 after six years as Mayor of Connecticut's largest city, John C. Mandanici carted off thousands of official documents relating to a score of city agencies, including some that have been the subject of Federal investigations.

title: American Fletcher Plans Dual Presidency
description: At the American Fletcher Corporation, the largest bank holding company in Indiana, two presidents will take office on Jan.1, 1982. Larry J. Hannah, 39, will become president of the $2.8 billion corporation and Joseph D. Barnette Jr., 42, will become president of the 60-plus branch Indianapolis bank.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alexander & Alexander Inc. has named Tinsley H. Irvin president and chief executive officer.

title: Moody's Upgrades City Bond Rating
description: Moody's Investors Service gave New York City's bonds a higher rating, but said they were below what is called an ''investment grade.''

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 20, 1981
description: International Washington said it regretted ''the hasty'' initial reaction by Soviet information outlets to President Reagan's arms control proposals and expressed the hope for a more positive response in the future. Moscow has derided the President's offer to cancel plans to deploy 572 new American medium-range missiles in Europe if the Kremlin dismantled 1,100 Soviet warheads now deployed. (Page A1, Columns 3-4.) Moscow broadened its attacks on President Reagan's arms control proposals, but a Kremlin spokesman said the Soviet Union hoped that the plan was not Washington's ''final say on the issue.'' (A9:1-3.)

title: EX-AGENT INDICTED IN WEAPONS SALES
description: Frank E. Terpil, a fugitive former intelligence agent who has been accused of selling arms to various authoritarian governments and terrorists, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges that he conspired to sell guns, ammunition and coding devices in 1979 to the now-defunct regime of President Idi Amin in Uganda.

title: CAREY INTRODUCES NEW PLAN FOR ASSESSMENT OF PROPERTY
description: Governor Carey introduced a new plan yesterday to revise New York State's system of property tax assessment, dropping his longstanding insistence that all localities reassess property at full market value by a definite date.

title: JERSEY LICENSES HARRAH'S CASINO AFTER THE INQUIRY
description: The state's Casino Control Commission licensed Harrah's Marina casino today and gave a temporary permit to Ramada Inns' Tropicana casino.
To the Editor:

title: CHICAGO SUES ON FLXIBLE BUSES
description: The Regional Transportation Authority today sued the Grumman Flxible Corporation for $9.5 million in damages the authority said it incurred because it had to take 205 Grumman buses out of service this year.

title: SAUDI ENVOY AND WIFE MAKE MARK
description: Television cameras and photographers focused on a green-eyed woman recently as she made her way across the lobby of the Fairfax Hotel here toward a cluster of people awaiting her at the head of the marble staircase.

title: 'RAGTIME' EVOKES REAL AND FICTIONAL PASTS
description: MILOS FORMAN'S ''Ragtime,'' adapted by Michael Weller from E.L. Doctorow's rambunctious, kaleidescopic novel, begins and ends with a dreamlike image - a pair of ballroom dancers, caught in a spotlight, surrounded by darkness, performing, not very gracefully, to an unfamiliar melody, before an unseen audience.

title: Economic Scene; Urgent Search For a New Mix
description: THE onset of a recession, which the Reagan Administration now expects to be severe, has focused national attention on the need for a new mix of economic policies that will check and reverse the slump without causing inflation and interest rates to soar again once the current recession ends. The American economy has been on a roller coaster. This is the second recession in two years, and if interest rates go shooting up again when the current slump ends, there could be a third recession close behind.

title: MYSTERIOUS 'MOZARTIANA' RETURNS
description: The New York City Ballet will perform a little Tchaikovsky festival at the New York State Theater this weekend, but the focus of all the attention will likely be on George Balanchine's new ''Mozartiana.'' The ballet returns to the repertory tonight at 8, but only briefly (tickets are $3 to $25; information: 870-5570). It will be gone again until January, adding, no doubt, to its mystique.

title: METPATH INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
FOOD STAMP RULE CHANGED IN FARM BILL CONFERENCE
description: House-Senate conferees on a new farm bill decided today to adjust food stamp benefits for inflation at an earlier date next year. The Agriculture Department said the step could save $700 million in the fiscal year 1982 because the rate of inflation was expected to be lower at that time.

title: CARSON PIRIE SCOTT & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
One Killed in India As Police Fire on Crowd
description: One person was killed and several injured when the police fired on a rock-throwing crowd as a 36-hour general strike began today in the state of Assam in northeastern India, the Press Trust of India, a news agency, reported.

title: ITI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A START ON START?
description: It remains to be seen whether President Reagan has made a real beginning toward his laudable goal of shifting from strategic arms limitation to what he called START - strategic arms reduction talks. But he's finally in a sound position for negotiations on removing or limiting theater nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: SEPARATE SUBWAY AND RAIL AUTHORITIES ARE URGED
description: Saying that New York City's regional transportation system has become ''too big and too unwieldy,'' a state legislative leader called yesterday for the creation of three separate authorities to run the subways and commuter railroads on a day-to-day basis.

title: Retailer's Profit Falls
description: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation said yesterday that net income for the third quarter, ended Oct. 31, fell 4.2 percent, to $10.1 million, or 56 cents a share, from $10.6 million, or 79 cents, in the similar 1980 period. Net sales, including those of the newly acquired Caldor subsidiary, rose 48 percent, to $710 million from $479.8 million. The retailer attributed the decline in earnings to significantly higher interest charges stemming from the Caldor acquisition.

title: ISLAMIC TREASURES ON VIEW AT THE MET
description: ''THE Art of the Mamluks'' at the Metropolitan Museum is that rare thing in our day - a wonderful exhibition that comes to us without benefit of hyperbole. What a happy surprise! No rubbishy pseudobooks, no selling of tickets in advance, no attempts at a factitious excitement. Nothing, in fact, but the orderly and lucid presentation of some of the most beautiful objects of art produced anywhere in the world at the time in question, the period 1250-1517.

title: BLACKOUT AWARD AGAINST CON ED UPHELD IN COURT
description: New York State's highest court yesterday upheld a jury verdict that the 1977 blackout of New York City and Westchester County was caused by the Consolidated Edison Company's ''gross negligence.''

title: CITY HOUSING CHALLENGES: A DEVELOPER'S EXPERTISE
description: Abram Shnay is a 33-year-old developer who grew up in the Rego Park section of Queens, graduated from Queens College and now has an office on Queens Boulevard. But he is immersed at present in housing challenges in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Staten Island. The family construction company, Shnay & Sons, founded by his father, seems to specialize in taking over subsidized projects from which larger organizations have withdrawn.

title: Cards Get Lonnie Smith
description: Baseball's busy trader, Whitey Herzog of the St. Louis Cardinals, came up with another major deal yesterday, this one involving three teams and resulting in the Cards' acquisition of the fleet outfielder Lonnie Smith.

title: Emlyn Williams Is Alive and, Well, Distressed
description: The actor and playwright Emlyn Williams, appearing in San Francisco in his touring one-man show, ''Emlyn Williams as Charles Dickens,'' was moderately shocked, he said yesterday, when he read the current edition of Contemporary Authors, a respected, standard reference work. The entry under his name began: ''Obituary Notice - Born Nov 26, 1905, in Mostyn, Wales; died in 1974.

title: 'THEY ALL LAUGHED'
description: THE title is ''They All Laughed.'' Would that anybody could laugh. The film, which is meant to be a witty, liberated sex comedy, was directed by Peter Bogdanovich from his own, apparently still unfinished screenplay. It's about some bumbling Manhattan private detectives, some extremely good-looking women they follow on behalf of jealous husbands, plus a pert, amorous country-and-western singer named Christy, a beautiful cabdriver nicknamed Sam, and other assorted characters who are never so colorful as the screenplay pretends they are.

title: No Major Swings In Jersey Recount
description: The recount in the New Jersey gubernatorial election continued for the second day yesterday without serious dispute and with no major vote swings reported for either Thomas H. Kean, the Republican candidate, or James J. Florio, his Democratic opponent.

title: OUTLET CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After extraordinary gains of $672,000 in the qr and $855,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $33,664,000 in the qr and $37,084,00 for the 9 mos which was from the sale of department stores and the company's men's wear store division

title: PAKISTAN JET DEAL BACKED BY PANEL
description: The Reagan Administration won another Congressional victory today on the issue of foreign military sales when the House Foreign Affairs Committee rejected a resolution opposing the sale of 40 F-16 aircraft to Pakistan.

title: BAKER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MADISON FUND SELLS MOST OF AM SHARES
description: The Madison Fund Inc. said yesterday that it had sold the majority of its 16 percent stake in ailing AM International Inc., the moneylosing maker of engineering graphics and information processing systems.

title: STAGE: MISS HEPBURN SAVES US A 'WALTZ'
description: ERNEST THOMPSON has written a tired play in ''The West Side Waltz,'' which opened at the Barrymore last night, but be assured that his star goes ahead and puts on her own vital show without him. Katharine Hepburn is at hand here, and Katharine Hepburn, in all her wonder, is what you'll get.

title: CITIBANK AND CHASE REDUCE MORTGAGE RATES
description: Citibank and Chase Manhattan, the two biggest banks in New York, lowered their mortgage rates yesterday. For Citibank, the No.1 bank in the area, the move marked the first reduction since August 1980. Chase, the No.2 bank, had cut home loan rates last Thursday as well.

title: Regular Times Dividend
description: The New York Times Company declared a regular quarterly dividend of 27 1/2 cents a share yesterday on its class A and class B common stock, payable Jan. 4 to shareholders of record on Dec. 4. A regular quarterly dividend of $1.375 a share on the 5 1/2 percent cumulative prior preference stock was also declared, with the same effective dates.

title: FED ADDS TO BANK RESERVES
description: The Federal Reserve was active yesterday adding reserves to the banking system on two occasions, but many analysts concluded that the nation's central bank was acting for technical reasons and was not trying to significantly increase the supply of credit in the banking system.

title: CITY BALLET: AN ALL-ROBBINS EVENING
description: THE New York City Ballet's second night of its State Theater season was devoted to works by Jerome Robbins on Wednesday, and the span was more complete than it would have been until recently.

title: CATHOLIC BISHOPS CRITICIZE AID TO EL SALVADOR
description: Calling for political, instead of military, solutions in troubled Central American nations, the National Conference of Catholic Bishops today renewed its appeal for an end to all United States military assistance to El Salvador and urged the Reagan Administration to maintain economic aid to Nicaragua.

title: RUN STOCKMAN OUT OF TOWN ON A RAIL
description: David Stockman has performed an amazing public relations feat by rallying to his support conservative spokesmen and publications throughout the country. Instead of being given their support, he deserves to be run out of town on a rail.

title: Ainge, Celtics Can Talk
description: The tale of two cities and sports involving Danny Ainge took another twist yesterday when the Toronto Blue Jays announced they had given permission, until the end of the month, to Ainge to negotiate a basketball contract with the Boston Celtics. Cliff Lax, the Blue Jays' lawyer, said that Toronto believed Ainge would have so much trouble reaching an agreement with the Celtics that he might consider giving baseball another chance.

title: Shell Group's Earnings Up 8.4% in Period
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said today that its net income rose 8.4 percent in the third quarter, mainly because of improved earnings by the Shell Oil Company, its American affiliate.

title: Broadway; A musical-fable with Michael York coming in January.
description: THESE are not the best of times for Broadway musicals. In the last 10 days alone, four of them opened to mostly disappointing notices, and one, ''Oh, Brother,'' has already folded. Nevertheless, there is no dearth of hopefuls waiting to go on. On Monday, ''The Little Prince,'' starring Michael York, will go into rehearsal for a Jan. 20 opening on Broadway.

title: MET MUSEUM PUBLICITY HEAD
description: Jack Frizzelle, manager of public relations at the Metropolitan Museum of Art since 1969 and a prominent figure in New York musical life, died of lung cancer in New York Hospital yesterday. He was 56 years old.

title: No Headline
description: North Stars Tie Oilers, 2-2

title: EIP MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THORATEC LABORATORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes tax credits of $3,680 for the qr and $11,900 for the 9 mos...C-Includes tax credits of $3,624 for the qr and $5,700 for the 9 mos

title: MALLORY RANDALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $10,000 for the qr and $125,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss including $7,000 extraordinary tax credit...D-Including $43,000 extraordinary tax credit

title: EXPLORING THE MANY FACES OF RIVERDALE
description: THE years since World War II have brought vast amounts of development to Riverdale, so much so that travelers passing through on the Henry Hudson Parkway could well mistake this northwest corner of the Bronx for a community containing nothing but high-rise apartment blocks. But concealed behind those towers on both sides of the parkway are two of the city's most prized enclaves, with not only single-family houses but also great mansions, sprawling lawns, twisting lanes and dense woodlands. While there are some plans for new construction, most sites on which large-scale development can take place are already built up - so the rustic illusion that the hidden Riverdale offers is not likely to disappear and that alone makes this part of New York special.

title: Marathon Suit Against Mobil
description: Lawyers for the Marathon Oil Company said today that they would pursue the company's antitrust case against the Mobil Corporation's $5.1 billion takeover bid despite Marathon's merger accord with the United States Steel Corporation.

title: K Mart Offers New Security
description: The K Mart Corporation and Merrill Lynch yesterday introduced a new kind of debt security that would allow the retailer to raise funds by selling its leases to 25 stores in 12 states.

title: Ex-Census Bureau Employee Is Indicted for Divulging Data
description: For the first time in the Census Bureau's history, a former employee is being prosecuted on charges of disclosing confidential census information, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Connecticut Faces the Tax Music
description: Connecticut's legislators, hardly in a Thanksgiving mood, are trying to figure out how to finance an $83 million deficit for the current fiscal year. The budget approved last May anticipated a gap, but lawmakers and Gov. William O'Neill marked time on tax increases and spending cuts pending final word on Federal aid.

title: REGAN SUSPECTS GOLDIN CRIBS OFF STATE REPORTS
description: The New York State Comptroller was unhappy with the New York City Comptroller. Early this week, the State Comptroller's staff sent the City Comptroller's staff a draft of a report on the outlook for municipal finances. Later in the week, the City Comptroller issued his own observations on the outlook.

title: American Airlines To Cut 454 Jobs
description: American Airlines said that it had sent layoff notices to 320 management and 134 clerical employees whose jobs were being eliminated in its continuing effort to cut costs to cope with fare competition, a decline in air travel and flight reductions resulting from the air controllers' strike.

title: NORTH CAROLINA NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Skalbania Grants Option
description: Nelson Skalbania, owner of the Montreal Alouettes, announced today that he had given Patrick Dennis Bowlen, a Canadian real estate developer, an option to buy the Canadian Football League team. ''Bowlen has until Feb. 28, 1982, to purchase 51 percent of the Alouettes and until Dec. 30, 1982, to purchase the remaining 49 percent,'' Skalbania said in a news release.

title: INVESTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings and shrs outstndg have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in Jan 1981

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Display of Japan Flag Starts Protest at Plant
description: Protesting workers at the Teledyne Wisconsin Motor Company tore down a Japanese flag on display at the plant, tossed it in a sewer and ran up an American Flag while singing ''The Star-Spangled Banner.''

title: U.S. Warning To Japanese
description: The United States is threatening to take Japan before the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world trade regulatory agency, if it goes ahead with plans to protect its aluminum industry, American and Japanese officials here said today.

title: 'LOVERS' EXILE'
description: ''The Lovers' Exile,'' which opens today at the Public Theater, is a charming film but it is less a cinematic than a theatrical event, one that no student of the theater can afford to miss. It's a straightforward film recording of a performance by the Bunraku Ensemble of Osaka, Japan's justly acclaimed doll theater that played limited engagements at the New York City Center in 1966 and 1973.

title: Bonn Economic Gloom
description: A panel of independent advisers today forecast near stagnation and increased inflation for West Germany's economy next year, in a report that was gloomier than recent Government predictions.

title: Around the World; Brazilian Labor Leader Is Sentenced to 3 1/2 Years
description: A military court Thursday sentenced the nation's top labor leader to three and a half years in prison for inciting workers to strike illegally.

title: AMERICAN GUARANTY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including net realized investment gains of $64,000 or 2 cents a shr for the qr and $203,000 or 6 cents a shr for the 9 mos...C-Including net realized investment gains of $7,000 for the qr and $92,000 or 2 cents a shr for the 9 mos

title: MUSIC: 'CHILD ALICE'
description: Since 1968, when he composed his first piece based on ''Alice in Wonderland,'' David Del Tredici has been obsessively concerned with making music out of Lewis Carroll's most famous fantasy. In 1976 he completed a massive work called ''Final Alice,'' which was recorded with a few pieces missing by the Chicago Symphony and has become a classical best-seller. However, ''Final Alice'' proved to be something less than Mr. Del Tredici's farewell to Wonderland. For the last five years he has been working on a fullevening work called ''Child Alice,'' three of whose four parts have been given premieres by leading orchestras with much success - the opening piece, ''In Memory of a Summer Day,'' won the 1980 Pulitzer Prize.

title: Your Money; Pensioners And Inflation
description: IT is commonly thought that retirees living on fixed incomes have shouldered a disproportionate share of inflation's burden. While inflation has eroded their purchasing power, many retirees have received pension increases to compensate. And those improvements along with Social Security increases mean that they are often no worse off - and sometimes better off - than active workers whose real incomes have also shrunk because of inflation. In general, retirees with modest pensions have suffered the least loss of purchasing power, partly because companies tend to give them larger increases than their more affluent peers.

title: Notes on People; A 'Basic Model Citizen' Gets a Break
description: A defendant the judge called ''a basic model citizen'' was given a conditional discharge yesterday after being convicted of stealing $2.28 worth of nuts and chocolate-covered raisins by eating them while his wife shopped in a Waldbaum's supermarket on Long Island.

title: Going Out Guide
description: HAPPY BIRTHDAY

title: News Analysis
description: As Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo labors to form a new cabinet - and others celebrate the sixth anniversary of Francisco Franco's death - rumblings of discontent from the Spanish armed forces are troubling the country's fragile democracy.

title: KAPOK TREE INNS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
GAF HEAD STEPS DOWN AFTER 10 MONTHS IN POST
description: The GAF Corporation announced yesterday that Jay R. Olson, president, chief executive officer and a director, had resigned those posts ''to pursue other interests.''

title: Sports People; Kenty Seeks Comeback
description: Hilmer Kenty says he wants to resume his career and win back the World Boxing Association's lightweight championship, but with a different manager. And so the 26-year-old former titleholder, insisting that he has recovered from the detached retina that forced an interruption in that career, is planning to announce the end of his relationship with Emanuel Steward, the current manager, and the famed Kronk boxing team of Detroit.

title: A VELVETEEN DA VINCI: MADE IN CHINA
description: Chi Zhongguo, the manager of the Yaxin Silk Weaving Factory, proudly showed off a copy of ''a very famous oil painting'' that his plant had started mass-producing for the American market.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1981
description: International A Soviet aide saw a welcome change change in President Reagan's proposal for a mutual renunciation of medium-range missiles in Europe. However, the official implied that Moscow would nevertheless react cooly to the idea when the negotiations on the missiles start in Geneva on Nov. 30. Vadim V. Zagladin, a member of the Central Committee of the Communist Party, said the President's proposal was a change from his ''bellicose'' pronouncements in recent months. (Page 1, Column 1.) Leonid I. Brezhnev disagreed with President Reagan's portrayal of Soviet-American global competition in a letter to Mr. Reagan released by the Soviet Embassy in Washington. The Soviet leader urged that Mr. Reagan's correspondence with him be augmentd with a personal meeting because ''private conversation is better.'' (25:1-6.)

title: PERJURY INDICTMENT FOCUSES ON QUESTIONS ABOUT EXPERT IN CRIMINAL
description: HYPNOSIS By MARCIA CHAMBERS

title: VELCRO INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALLIED STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results include operations of Garfinckel, Brooks Bros, Miller, Rhoads Inc since its acquisition in Sept

title: LET'S DO AWAY WITH CENTRAL PARK ZOO
description: I recently made the mistake of taking a stroll through the oldest zoo in the United States, the one in Central Park, which was opened to the public back in 1864, a year before the Civil War ended.

title: Israeli Official Asks to Resign From Post in Occupied Lands
description: The senior Israeli officer in charge of occupied Arab territories has asked to leave his post at the end of this year apparently because of liberalizing policy shifts, Israeli officials confirmed today.

title: ARROWS TRIUMPH
description: With Steve Zungul scoring four goals and Louis Alberto three, the New York Arrows defeated the New Jersey Rockets, 9-2, at Nassau Coliseum tonight. The Arrows' Major Indoor Soccer League home opener drew 12,118 fans, 112 fewer than last year's opener.

title: FUTURES MARKETS: BATTLE IN CHICAGO
description: For years the Chicago Mercantile Exchange has been overshadowed by the visibility and prestige of the Chicago Board of Trade, its more glamorous neighbor.

title: Notes on People; Brady to Be Discharged From Hospital Monday
description: The best news that James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, has had in months came from his doctors yesterday. He will be discharged ''for good'' from George Washington University Medical Center and be able to go home Monday.

title: SOVIET IN ACCORD ON SENDING GAS TO WEST EUROPE
description: An agreement was signed today that is expected to remove the last obstacle to the construction of a multibillion-dollar pipeline to bring gas from Siberia to Western Europe.

title: TURKISH EX-PREMIER TO BE JAILED
description: Ankara's martial law commander has confirmed a four-month prison sentence against former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit for defying a ban on political statements, it was announced today.

title: Penguins and Maple Leafs Tie, 3-3
description: Rick Kehoe of the Penguins falling as he defended against John Gibson of Toronto last night in Pittsburgh.

title: Matriarch Draws 9
description: Nine fillies and mares were entered today for Sunday's $221,600 Matriarch Stakes at Hollywood Park, a mile-and-an-eighth race over the turf course. Those entered, in post position order, were: Sajama, Bersid, Cool Moon, Just a Game II, Berry Bush, Queen to Conquer, Ack's Secret, Kilijaro and Rainbow Connection. The Matriarch will be run under weight-for age conditions with all but Sajama and Bersid carrying 123 pounds each.

title: Letter: On Protectionism Is Big Steel 'Pampered'?
description: To the Editor: The message of your Nov. 14 editorial, ''Big Steel Tries Again,'' appears to be that protecting the European steel industry and European steelworker jobs is more important than enforcing existing U.S. trade laws. It also misstates the function of the Trigger Price Mechanism, which is designed to expedite that enforcement, not to put ''an artificial floor under import prices.''

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1981; International
description: Construction of a 3,500-mile natural gas pipeline from the Soviet Union to Western Europe was expected to clear its final obstacle with the signing of price and delivery agreements in Essen. Ruhrgas, a West German gas company, contracted for 360.4 billion cubic feet of gas over 25 years. Washington has voiced objections to the project, fearing its allies will become dependent on Soviet gas. (Page 1.)

title: Around the World; Senate Confirms Abrams In Rights Position
description: The Senate today confirmed President Reagan's choice of Elliott Abrams as Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights.

title: MERCANTILE STORES CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 16.00-16.50** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. + Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Leonard C. Rennie, 78, Dies; Retired Graphics Consultant
description: Leonard C. Rennie, a graphics consultant and founder and former president of Design and Production Inc., of Alexandria, Va., died Wednesday at Sibley Hospital in Washington, D.C. A resident of Washington, he was 78 years old.

title: Jets' Ryan Ready to Start; Todd Status Is Uncertain
description: The Jets' quarterback situation brightened today when Pat Ryan, Richard Todd's backup, was able to direct the team in practice for the first time this week. Ryan's return indicated that even if the injured Todd cannot play in Sunday's battle for first place against Miami, the Jets would not be forced to start the untested Kyle Grossart.

title: 2 RESCUED FROM HUDSON AFTER A HELICOPTER CRASH
description: A private helicopter crashed into the Hudson River yesterday morning, and three New Jersey men rushed to a boat they had never before boarded, sailed to the middle of the river and rescued the two occupants of the overturned aircraft.

title: Sports of The Times; A Power Play, Off the Court
description: PAUL WESTHEAD has been bussed, and now he has been busted. Somewhere between the kiss on the cheek and the kick in the pants, he should have lost his innocence.

title: KARPOV WINNER IN CHESS TITLE MATCH
description: Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union retained his world chess championship here this afternoon by defeating the challenger, Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland, in the 18th game of their title match.

title: Soviet Lodges a Protest In Attack at Residence
description: In a note made public today, the Soviet Union lodged a strong protest with the United States over an incident last Saturday in which shots were fired into a Soviet residence at Glen Cove, L.I.

title: 98,000 Baby Cribs Recalled Over Weak Plastic Brackets
description: About 98,000 baby cribs are being recalled because of weak plastic brackets that could cause the springs to drop slightly, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said today.

title: THE PLEASURABLE RIDES ON THE M.T.A.'S X18
description: To the Editor:

title: Mobil Defends Its Merger Bid
description: A university professor, testifying for the Mobil Corporation, said in Federal District Court today that a takeover by Mobil of the Marathon Oil Company would not reduce competition in the sale of oil products.

title: CHILD REARING IS NOT A ONE-PARENT JOB
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGANOMICS, YES
description: After just 10 months as steward of the American economy, Ronald Reagan has come under sharp attack for the bold budgetary and tax policies that he has designed to correct decades of economic mismanagement in Washington.

title: G.M. and Ford Delay Steel Orders
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company have told steel producers to postpone deliveries to some auto plants through December, according to a trade publication.

title: SAB HARMON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After net from discontinued railroad braking equipment operations of $86,429 or 4 cents a shr...C-After net from discontinued operations of $20,801 or 1 cent a shr for the latest yr and $183,311 for the yr-ago period

title: ANTHONY S. O'CONNELL
description: Anthony S. O'Connell, an assistant chief inspector who had been commander of the Manhattan South uniformed police force until his retirement in 1965, died yesterday at his home in Daytona Beach, Fla. He was 78 years old.

title: MEYERS PARKING SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Zenith Closing
description: The Zenith Radio Corporation said it would close its plant here at the end of March, laying off about 750 workers. Zenith originally planned to close the plant in 1977.

title: Consumer Saturday; WOMEN WITHOUT PENSIONS
description: ''L OW pensions or lack of them are the main cause of women's poverty. Women have a very real reason to be concerned.'' With that statement Karen W. Ferguson, a lawyer and director of the Pension Rights Center, a nonprofit organization in Washington largely funded by private groups, gave a talk this week on the need for women to determine what pension money they can expect when they or their husbands retire or in the event of divorce or a spouse's death. She addressed a luncheon forum of the New York County Lawyers Association attended by 100 lawyers, mostly women.

title: INFORMATION DISPLAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes extraordinary tax loss credits of $75,000 in the qr and $122,500 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss

title: FLUKE, JOHN, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Yr to Sept 25
description: B-Restated to reflect a 5 percent stock divd in Feb 1981; yr-ago sales restated to reflect reclassification of certain items affecting net sales

title: News Analysis
description: Five vacant executive council seats had to be filled at the convention of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, and a group of 30 black unionists put forth the names of five blacks.

title: Texaco Unit Seeks Shares
description: Texaco Inc. said that a subsidiary would make a $3.96 million (Canadian) offer to buy 11,000 first preferred shares, series A, of Texaco Canada Inc., at $360 each.

title: Sports People; Owners' Orders
description: Robert Irsay, owner of the Baltimore Colts, confirmed reports from some of his players that, headset in place, he dictated strategy to Coach Mike McCormack from the stands during last Sunday's 38-13 loss to Philadelphia. But, he said, other than telling McCormack to replace Bert Jones, the starting quarterback, with Greg Landry late in the game, ''I did it just for a minute or two; then, after the touchdown, I shut up.''

title: Around the World; Shcharansky Reported To Be Back in Prison
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the Jewish dissident, has been transferred from a labor camp to the strictregime prison where he began his 13-year sentence on a conviction of spying for the United States and of anti-Soviet activities, sources close to his family said today.

title: Westchester Medical Center Absolves Doctors in a Death
description: Psychiatrists at the Westchester County Medical Center properly refused admittance to a Yonkers man with a history of mental illness who moments later threw himself in front of cars and was killed, according to a hospital report.

title: Bridge: Fall National Tournament Is Begun in San Francisco
description: Five major championships will be played during the 10 days of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall National Championships, which began here this afternoon. Among the titles at stake are the life master men's pairs, the life master women's pairs, the blue ribbon pairs and the Reisinger teams.

title: COMPO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: B-Net loss...C-Including $1 million gain from disposition of Settef and Mastic operations

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am glad to inform you that your wish has been fulfilled.'' - Anatoly Karpov to Leonid I. Brezhnev. (1:2.)

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; Homecoming Day
description: For Coach Bum Phillips, it will be a homecoming of sorts.

title: INDIA AND CHINA TO OPEN BORDER TALKS ON DEC. 10
description: A high-level Indian delegation will go to Peking next month for four days of talks that are to include discussion of the disputed Himalayan border between India and China.

title: BRIEFS
description: * First Financial of Virginia Corp. said it had signed a letter of intent to be acquired by the Perpetual American Federal Savings and Loan Association in Washington, D.C.

title: SUNAIR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $167,685 from settlement of tax dispute

title: No Headline
description: Turkish Consulate Bombed

title: G.M. BOND RATING CUT BY S.&P.
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation, citing depressed auto sales and predictions of a slow recovery in demand, yesterday lowered its credit ratings for the General Motors Corporation.

title: EXCERPTS FROM A SOVIET BOOLKET ON NUCLEAR WAR
description: Following are excerpts from ''The Threat to Europe,'' a booklet written in the form of questions and answers, that was issued today in English by the Soviet Committee for European Security and Cooperation:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article by United Press Interna- tional in Metropolitan Report yester- day incorrectly described a Federal judge's action on New York City pay- roll deductions of teachers' union dues. The ruling upholding the city's refusal to continue deducting the dues was made last March 18. The union has appealed, and legal briefs were filed Nov. 13.

title: Santa Fe Gives Data to the U.S.
description: The Santa Fe International Corporation, an American oil-drilling company under investigation in connection with a proposed merger with a Kuwait Government-owned oil company, has begun turning over documents for a Justice Department review of the merger's effect on national security.

title: PLAYBOY SELLING 2 RESORT HOTELS FOR $42 MILLION
description: In an effort to shed unprofitable operations and raise much-needed cash, Playboy Enterprises Inc. announced today that it had agreed to sell its two resort hotels for $42 million to a joint venture involving Americana Hotel Inc. and Eugene Golub, the real estate investor.

title: WALESA APPEALS TO THE WEST FOR FOOD AID
description: Lech Walesa, Solidarity's leader, addressed an unusual appeal to ''the working people and trade unions of Western Europe'' today, asking them to pressure their governments to provide food aid to get Poland through a difficult winter.

title: LEE STRASBERG DREAMS OF A NATIONAL THEATER
description: ''The theater is no different than the word,'' Lee Strasberg was saying. ''As O'Casey would say, it's in a state of chassis - very chaotic, not so much despondent as hopeless.'' At 80, which is what he became this week, Mr. Strasberg is rather that way, too. He has done virtually everything a man can do in theater; as a teacher, especially, he is known wherever there is a proscenium arch. Mr. Strasberg, however, still has an unrealized dream: He wants to see a national theater.

title: Patents; A Turbogenerator For Thermal Power
description: Sea Solar Power Inc., York, Pa., a pioneer in ocean thermal energy conversion, received a patent this week for a turbogenerator to be used in a thermal power plant. The equipment is regarded as important because of its compactness.

title: ssp434Westhead Defends Coaching Record
description: Paul Westhead, dismissed Thursday as head coach of the Los Angeles Lakers, said today that he thought he had been a success in his chosen career - ''to produce winning basketball'' - and that he had no inkling that his job had been in jeopardy.

title: Prescription for Dr. Koop
description: Dr. C. Everett Koop is a pediatric surgeon of fine reputation, and a man of many opinions. An opponent of abortion, he has characterized amniocentesis as a ''search-and-destroy mission'' and chided mainline Protestant denominations that support abortion for their ''superficial theology ... lack of morality ... and depravity.''

title: THEATER: 'MRS. WARREN'S PROFESSION' AT YALE REP
description: In 1905, ''Mrs. Warren's Profession'' had its American premiere in this city and was pre-emptorily banned by the Mayor. Its subsequent New York engagement ended with the actors being arrested for disorderly conduct. This formerly controversial comedy is the first play by Shaw to be presented at the Yale Repertory Theater, and in revival, it is not merely, as Shaw acknowledged, a ''comparatively prudish play,'' it is positively pussyfooting. When Mrs. Warren's daughter, Vivie, finally gets up enough nerve to tell her friends the source of her mother's income, she writes two words and then quickly crumples the paper. Shaw never discloses the two words, but clearly they refer to the business that dare not speak its name.

title: Rookie Guard Is a Jolly Giant
description: When the Giants play the Eagles Sunday at Philadelphia, Bill Ard, a 22-year-old rookie from Watchung, N.J., will be their left offensive guard for the second straight week.

title: Sports People; Something Off Base?
description: Ted Williams made $91,000 in four months through the purchase and sale of condominium property in Miami, but he is now suing the owners of the complex because he had to pay $7,500 for a recreation-club membership he didn't want. According to court records, the former Boston Red Sox slugger and Hall of Famer bought a condominium apartment for $154,000 in Miami's Grove Isle complex in April 1980 and sold it four months later for $245,000 to a Panamanian firm.

title: 8.18 RISE LIFTS DOW TO 852.93
description: The stock market registered a broad advance yesterday in accelerated trading with some energy, blue-chip and transportation stocks making the best gains.

title: Around the Nation; Two Priests Convicted For Ferrying Cubans
description: Two Episcopal priests from New Orleans were convicted today of violating the Trading with the Enemy Act by ferrying 402 Cubans to Florida last year.

title: GREENMAN BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NATIONAL STANDARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cray's Speed Being Raised
description: Cray Research Inc., which sells a computer designed for scientific calculations that is widely considered to be the fastest and most powerful in the world, said yesterday that it had overcome a major hurdle in its attempt to build a machine that would be 6 to 12 times faster than its current model.

title: AGENTS OF F.B.I. TOLD TO RESUME INQUIRY ON ALLEN
description: The Justice Department has ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation back into the field in its investigation of Richard V. Allen, the national security adviser, department officials said today.

title: COASTAL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $2.2 million tax credit for the qr and yr from writeoff last yr of the company's motor carrier operating rights...C-Net loss after $5.1 million writeoff for the qr and yr of operating rights

title: Soviet A-Test Recorded
description: The Swedish Defense Agency said today that it recorded a Soviet underground nuclear explosion in eastern Kazakhstan, in central Asia. It was believed to be the 12th such Soviet blast in the area this year.

title: ENQUIRER CHARGED ON ALIEN LAWS
description: Federal prosecutors today charged The National Enquirer with fraudulently obtaining United States resident status for more than 50 foreign reporters and other employees.

title: Editor Quitting Newspaper For 'Entertainment Tonight'
description: James Bellows, the editor of The Los Angeles Herald-Examiner, is leaving the paper to become an executive of a television program.

title: U.S. ACCUSED OF FAVORING CURBS ON FREE PRESS
description: The chairman of the International Press Institute charged today that the United States, while publicly criticizing a United Nations-backed campaign for a so-called ''new world information order,'' was moving toward support of projects contrary to the aims of a free press.

title: Sports People; McEnroe Appeal Heard
description: John McEnroe, the world's top-ranked tennis player, took his appeal of a $5,000 fine levied against him at Wimbledon last summer before a three-member panel yesterday, but a decision was not expected until next month.

title: Top Aides to the Mayor To Get Salary Increases
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that the city's Deputy Mayors and heads of mayoral agencies would receive salary increases. The raises will total just under $300,000 a year.

title: Bache Assumes Stix Accounts
description: Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. has agreed to take over the 5,000 accounts and 10 offices of the defunct Stix & Company, Harry O. Moline Jr., Stix trustee, said.

title: Jazz 105, Bulls 103
description: CHICAGO (AP) - Rickey Green sank a 25-foot jump shot as the buzzer sounded to lift Utah past Chicago.

title: Circumnavigation Complete
description: The nuclear-powered guided missile cruiser U.S.S. California ended a round-the-world cruise today to become the first nuclear surface ship to circumnavigate the globe in 17 years. The California returned here, completing a seven-month deployment highlighted by the rescue of 39 crewmen from a burning Greek tanker in the Arabian Sea.

title: Sonics 90, Mavericks 89
description: DALLAS (UPI) - Gus Williams scored on a 25-foot jump shot with 13 seconds left for Seattle's victory.

title: NO CAP ON I.R.A. INTEREST
description: Federal financial regulators have refused to reverse themselves and put an interest ceiling on new retirement savings accounts scheduled to go into effect on Dec. 1, an official said today.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 52. 1. According to the White House, it was (James A. Baker 3d/Michael K. Deaver/Edwin Meese 3d) who asked the Justice Department to investigate the receipt by President Reagan's national security adviser, Richard V. Allen, of a $1,000 cash payment from a Japanese magazine in exchange for arranging an interview with Nancy Reagan.

title: BREZHNEV REBUTS REAGAN VIEW OF U.S.-SOVIET RIVALRY
description: The Soviet Embassy released a letter today from Leonid I. Brezhnev to President Reagan, challenging Mr. Reagan's picture of Soviet-American global competition but urging that the two leaders augment their correspondence with a personal meeting because ''private conversation is better.''

title: News Analysis
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission's suspension of the license for the nuclear power plant at Diablo Canyon until an independent study can be made signals a setback for the nuclear industry as well as a painful reassessment for the Federal agency.

title: CUSHMAN ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
George B. Higgins, Ex-Head Of Boy Scouts' Council, 717
description: George B. Higgins, a former president of the Manhattan Council of the Boy Scouts of America, and president and chairman of Higgins Fire Protection Inc. of Manhasset, L.I., and Hillside, N.J., died Wednesday night at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I., after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhasset.

title: Pay Cut Backed At Republic Air
description: Nearly 7,000 ground employees of Republic Airlines have agreed to take a 10 percent pay cut, effective Dec. 1, to help the company offset $35.8 million in losses.

title: TYSON FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
Notes on People; Right Theater, Wrong Play
description: When Mayor Koch was delayed getting to a ceremony Wednesday, the city's Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, was more than happy to fill in.

title: GENERAL DATACOMM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income...C-Including investment tax credit carryback against prior yr's taxes

title: GRANDMA LEE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FEDERAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
POLES OFFER DEAL FOR FREEING U.N. AIDE
description: The Polish authorities have offered conditionally to free Alicja Wesolowska, a United Nations secretary who was jailed in August 1979 on charges of spying, officials here said today. They said the condition was that the United Nations dismiss her and thereby strip her of diplomatic privilege.

title: PROGROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
News Analysis
description: The United States Steel Corporation has startled the business world with its $6.3 billion offer for the Marathon Oil Company, but it has by no means carried the day. Though U.S. Steel's offer easily topped the Mobil Corporation's

title: 76ers 99, Cavaliers 94
description: Julius Erving scored 28 points and the Philadelphia defense held Cleveland to only one field goal in the final six minutes.

title: About New York; DEJA VU IN A CLUTTERED BOOKSHOP
description: In New York City, as in life, the more things change, the more they stay the same. It seems that the people of Manhattan were accused of being immoral and godless in 1650. It turns out that there were terrible traffic jams and people nearly run over in the streets by cabs in 1855. The Police Department was being publicly criticized in 1894. Wild gangs roamed the avenues at the turn of the century.

title: KLEINERT'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: B-Net loss...C-After $2,180,000 estimated extraordinary loss on disposal of footwear business

title: Corning Venture
description: Corning Glass Works said it had formed a joint venture company in France with Compagnie de Saint-Gobain-Pont-a-Mousson and Thomson-CSF, a unit of Thomson-Brandt, to produce optical fibers. The company, to be called Fibres Optiques Industries, will be 40 percent owned by Corning and 60 percent by the two French companies, Corning said.

title: Around the Nation; Woman Killed by Sniper On Highway in Alabama
description: A sniper fired dozens of shots at passing vehicles on an Alabama highway today, killing one woman and injuring another, the State Police said.

title: MURPHY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes special gains of $600,000 for the latest qr and $1,748,000 for the 1980 qr...C-Includes special gains of $600,000 for the latest 9 mos and $3,610,000 for earlier period

title: New Sohio Unit
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said it had formed the Sohio Industrial Products Company to direct the operations of the manufacturing businesses acquired in Sohio's takeover of the Kennecott Corporation. Sohio Industrial Products will begin operations Jan. 1 and will have its headquarters in Cleveland, Sohio said. Glenn P. Bakken, now president of Kennecott, will become president of the new unit.

title: SENIOR SOVIET AIDE CALLS REAGAN PLAN A WELCOME CHANGE
description: A senior Soviet official said today that President Reagan's proposal for a mutual renunciation of mediumrange missiles in Europe was a welcome change from Mr. Reagan's ''bellicose'' pronouncements in recent months.

title: EX-MAYOR'S FILES ARE RETURNED TO BRIDGEPORT CITY HALL
description: The official records of the six-year administration of John C. Mandanici were returned to City Hall today after members of his family had examined them for 11 days and removed what they said were personal items.

title: WHY TAIWAN NEEDS AMERICAN FX INTERCEPTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: Slumping Islanders Will Play Rangers
description: Lorne Henning, the Islanders' assistant coach, says that the ''best antidote for our club's slump'' is having to play the Rangers. ''All the intensity and concentration we've been lacking recently should come right back with the first drop of the puck,'' Henning said of tonight's game between the Islanders and the Rangers at Nassau Coliseum.

title: News Analysis
description: The extraordinarily close vote tallies for Governor of New Jersey and for New York State's prison bond issue are a reminder that the strength of the electoral system rests heavily on the weakness of the vote-counting abilities of a handful of inexpert officials.

title: De Gustibus; WHOSE DISH IS THIS ANYWAY?
description: How far a restaurant owner should go to accommodate customers is a question more difficult to answer than it would first seem. Let a Chinese chef adapt his native dishes to what he perceives to be the average American palate, and negative criticism will be heaped upon him by those who insist on authenticity and who would accuse him of pandering. But if another chef refuses to cook food any way other than the way he thinks it should be, he is also faulted. Request on Squab Rejected

title: Senators Urge Swift Action To Block Naming of Agents
description: The Select Committee on Intelligence has urged the Senate leadership to act soon on legislation that would make it a criminal offense to disclose the identities of undercover intelligence agents.

title: Jury Gets Point-Shaving Case
description: The Boston College point-shaving case was sent to the 12 jurors yesterday, but the deliberations were delayed when, soon afterward, those jurors requested a re-reading of large parts of the record. The re-reading took up an hour and a half of yesterday's proceedings and is expected to last four hours more beginning at 10 A.M. today.

title: Around the World; Ailing Argentine Chief Steps Down Temporarily
description: President Roberto Eduardo Viola is temporarily stepping down from his duties because of heart trouble, the Government announced today.

title: No Headline
description: In some copies yesterday, an article in Weekend about Riverdale incorrectly listed the owner of the Greyston mansion. It is owned by the New York Zen Community.

title: THE CATHOLIC HIERARCHY'S DEVISIVE NEW ACTIVISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Sales Top $125 Million At Keeneland Auction
description: The first segment of the November breeding stock sales ended today at Keeneland with more than $125 million in sales recorded.

title: CANADA SOUTHERN PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $16,000 tax credit...C-Net loss

title: Congress; LOBBYING: BUSINESS BY NUANCE, FEINT AND GAMBLE
description: More than a century ago, when lobbying was done in the card halls and bawdy houses along Pennsylvania Avenue, one of the most important power brokers in Washington was Samuel Ward.

title: Dorothy Rothschild, Violinist With the American Symphony
description: Dorothy Pixley Rothschild, a violinist who was a founding member of the American Symphony Orchestra and its first president, died of cancer Thursday night at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital. She was 44 years old.

title: The Coming Cry for Help on Housing
description: The housing industry is suffering its worst slump since World War II. Builders are starting new homes at a yearly rate that has just dropped below 900,000; in 1978, they started nearly two million. The slump hurts builders, but the pain soon radiates. If the slump lasts long enough, it will affect everyone who needs or wants a new home.

title: ARA SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: B-Including $8 million extraordinary credit for the qr and yr and $2 million approximate gain for the qr primarily from the sale of public vending operations and certain other businesses which was offset by the revaluation of certain asset C-Net loss after $20,774,000 extraordinary charge and $1.6 mill net gain from the sale of Sigma Marketing subsidiary and the sa of certain public vending operations...D-After $20,664,000 extr ordinary charge

title: ARTHUR HANNA
description: Arthur Hanna, a director in the theater, and for radio and television for 30 years, died Tuesday at his home near Paoli, Pa.

title: Patents; Conserving Energy In the Shower
description: A Maine inventor offers a means of conserving energy in the shower. Charles A. Berg of Buckfield, once chief engineer of the Federal Power Commission, got patent 4,300,247 this week for a bathing apparatus that uses water drained from the shower to pre-heat the incoming cold water. The result, it is explained, is that less hot water is needed to produce a comfortable shower temperature, cutting the heat expense.

title: Lakers Win; Johson Excels
description: The Los Angeles Lakers ran and won tonight, and Earvin (Magic) Johnson had fun. ''I didn't feel any more emotional for this game,'' Johnson said after sparking the Lakers with 20 points and 16 assists in a 136-116 victory over the San Antonio Spurs.

title: RSI CORP reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: B-Including $956,712 income from discontinued operations and $868,000 tax credit...C-After $455,156 loss from discontinued operations and $1.1 million tax credit; 1980 results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations

title: Sports People; Batter Beware
description: Flying bats - the wooden variety -are fair targets for lawsuits if they should strike people in the stands, a Pittsburgh judge ruled. The Pennsylvania law that bars legal action where baseballs are involved does not apply to bats, according to Judge I. Martin Wekselman.

title: Blazers Trounce Nets, 106-86
description: The New Jersey Nets got off to a 14-2 lead, but the Portland Trail Blazers recovered quickly and scored a 106-86 victory tonight.

title: FRANK J. SHEED, 84, A LAY THEOLOGIAN
description: Frank J. Sheed, a leading Catholic lay theologian and founder of the New York publishing house of Sheed & Ward, died yesterday at St. Francis Hospital in Jersey City. He was 84 years old.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. Edwin Meese 3d. 2. His six-numbered ticket won a $5 million prize in the New York State lottery. 3. President Reagan named him as chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights to replace Arthur S. Flemming, who he had dismissed, reportedly for his strong advocacy of civil rights.

title: Article 101647 -- No Title
description: A compromise public works bill that includes funds for the long-disputed Clinch River breeder nuclear reactor and the Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway was approved by the House today.

title: PLAYOFF SPOT IS BONUS FOR MONTCLAIR STATE
description: Bill Dioguardi peered over the little gold nameplate on his desk that identifies him as the director of athletics at Montclair State College and through a picture window at a handful of varsity football players loosening up on the artificial turf of the college stadium.

title: THE VIDEOGAMES: HOW THEY RATE
description: The following article was compiled by Bill Kunkel and Arnie Katz, who are, respectively, executive editor and co-publisher/editor of Electronic Games magazine and write the ''Arcade Alley'' column for Video magazine.

title: GRANT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 10 percent stock divd to be paid Dec 1981

title: Columbia Falls In Finale, 4-3
description: Columbia, which had been the nation's only unbeaten major college soccer team, lost its final game of the regular season to Brown tonight, 4-3.

title: Carter Hawley Net Off
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., a Los Angeles-based retail chain, said yesterday that earnings in its fiscal third quarter, ended Oct. 31, fell 34.6 percent, to $6.8 million, or 23 cents a share, from $10.4 million, or 37 cents a share, a year before. Sales rose 8.4 percent, to $683 million, from $630.3 million.

title: RADICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $10,000 tax credit and $9,000 extraordinary gain

title: Envoy to Sweden Nominated
description: President Reagan announced today that he would nominate Franklin S. Forsberg to replace Rodney O'Gliosain Kennedy-Minott as Ambassador to Sweden. Mr. Forsberg is president of Forsberg Associates and was formerly with Holt, Rinehart and Winston in New York City.

title: MICHAEL REAGAN CLEARED OF STOCK FRAUD CHARGE
description: The Los Angeles District Attorney's office said today that it had cleared Michael Reagan, President Reagan's eldest son, of complicity in a stock fraud scheme that it has been investigating for the last 18 months.

title: CARTER HAWLEY HALE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Sports People; Hero Without Hoopla
description: With none of the glare of national publicity that characterized his freshman and sophomore seasons, Joe Morris, the little Syracuse tailback, ends his college career today in a home game against West Virginia.

title: A DAUGHTER OF BYRNE IS ASSAULTED ON UPPER EAST SIDE OF MANHATTAN
description: The 25-year-old daughter of Governor Byrne of New Jersey said she was assaulted and robbed early yesterday on Manhattan's Upper East Side, according to a spokesman for Mr. Byrne.

title: Oil Find Off Brazil
description: Brazil has struck oil in an exploratory well offshore that could be part of a major oilfield, the Government oil company, Petrobras, announced today.

title: TEXT OF BREZHNEV'S LETTER IN MAY IN ANSWER TO ONE SENT TO HIM BY REAGAN
description: Following is the text of a letter from Leonid I. Brezhnev to President Reagan dated May 25, 1981, and made public today by the Soviet Embassy here: Dear Mr. President, I gave careful thought to your personal letter to me and want to respond to it in the same personal and frank manner. Just as you do, I recall our brief conversation at the reception given by President Richard Nixon at Casa Pacifica in June 1973. Today, as we did at that time, everyone in the Soviet leadership and I commit our hearts and minds to realizing the hopes and aspirations of all the peoples of the world for peace, a quiet life and confidence in their future.

title: Polish Debt Talks Gain
description: Financial experts from 16 countries have made progress toward resolving the problems that Poland faces in repaying debts due next year, the group said in a statement issued today at the end of two days of talks.

title: BL Ltd. to Cut 4,100 Jobs
description: BL Ltd., Britain's troubled state-owned auto maker, said that it was eliminating 4,100 more jobs from its bus and truck division.

title: Celtics 112, Bucks 89
description: BOSTON (AP) - Larry Bird scored 20 points and Cedric Maxwell 17 as Boston routed Milwaukee. A field goal by Bob Lanier with 4 minutes 59 seconds gone in the game gave the Bucks their last lead, at 15-14.

title: Books of The Times
description: Fashions in Madness By ANATOLE BROYARD FREEDOM AND DESTINY. By Rollo May. 275 pages. Norton. $14.95.

title: WOODHEAD, DANIEL, INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 3
MUSIC: ST. PAUL CHAMBER
description: Pinchas Zukerman has received considerable attention - not all the kind he might desire - as he has added conducting to his already notable violin-playing career. But at Wednesday's concert in Avery Fisher Hall of his Saint Paul Chamber Orchestra, Mr. Zukerman's conducting was more convincing than his violin playing. The concert was the first of four devoted to the complete Mozart works for violin and orchestra and co-produced by Lincoln Center and Carnegie Hall.

title: Washington State, Doormat of Coast, Now Close to Best
description: Long before the wheat farmers started to sow the fertile hills outside this tiny town years ago, the most influential founding fathers in Walla Walla, which is several miles to the southwest, were asked if they would rather have the state penitentiary or the land grant university in their town. They chose the prison.

title: BILL ON HOMOSEXUAL RIGHTS SPARKS EMOTIONAL DEBATES
description: A proposal to ban discrimination against homosexuals turned a City Council committee hearing into a long, loud display of emotions yesterday as supporters and opponents showed up in large numbers.

title: ELECTION PLEA SET ON CONSERVATIVES
description: Three national Democratic committees will ask the Federal Election Commission and the courts, if necessary, to rule that the National Conservative Political Action Committee has forfeited its right to make large ''independent'' expenditures because of collusion with Republicans, the head of one committee said today.

title: SURVEY FINDS TAX INCENTIVES DOING LITTLE TO LURE BUSINESS
description: The proliferation of tax reductions enacted by states in recent years to lure industrial development has had very little effect on where the companies decide to put their plants, according to a national survey by an advisory group to the National Governors Association.

title: CHARGES MADE IN EXPORT CASE
description: The Commerce Department has ruled that a Manhattan exporter and a Pakistani trading company cannot engage in the export business until charges that they violated Federal regulations are resolved.

title: BOWL SCRAMBLE IS SETTLED AND UNSETTLED
description: The annual rush for key bowl invitations was, as always, mostly over before it was supposed to begin when teams began falling into slots last Sunday, starting with the matchup of Pittsburgh against Georgia in the Sugar Bowl.

title: Patents; A Computer to Help Motorists Navigate
description: A computer patented this week is designed to guide a motorist without the need of maps or travel instructions. Daniel J. Turco, owner of several retail stores in Billerica, Mass., was granted patent 4,301,506 for the ''router.''

title: Rockets 95, Bullets 94
description: Elvin Hayes scored a season-high 23 points to help Houston rally to its victory.

title: CITY SEEKING TO STEM EXODUS OF 'BACK OFFICE' JOBS
description: Business and public leaders are warning that New York City may be losing its ''back office'' jobs as soaring office rents in Manhattan, together with advancing technology and the use of computers, lessen the need for office workers to be in the same place as their executives.

title: DONALDSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
New York; CAREY AND COSELL
description: Heaven knows the Democratic Party needs new blood. Hugh Carey clearly knows it. But he likes to play things close to the vest. Now the secret is out.

title: 'U-FER! U-FER!'
description: We are, out here in the Middle West, halfway down a dreary seven-week slide from autumn's gaudy days, which weren't all that gaudy this year, to winter. The disappointing color display is being raked up and burned, and we are left in a season of clammy melancholy, waiting for snow.

title: INDIANS FINDING GAS STRIKE IS BONANZA
description: Lavera Mae Reeder, a Wichita Indian who lives just north of the dusty little town of Gracemont, Okla., recalls that until recently she expected no more from life than the satisfactions and tribulations of rearing her 10 children. Only an oblique promise by her father, now deceased for 15 years, gave a hint of hope.

title: CITY BANS PAYROLL DEDUCTIONS FOR UNITED WAY
description: For the first time in 12 years, New York City is not permitting the United Way, the largest charity in the nation, to solicit funds from city employees through automatic payroll deductions.

title: Around the Nation; Air Traffic Declines 1.5% Despite Schedule Cuts
description: Domestic air traffic in October was down just 1.5 percent from October 1980, despite a cutback in schedules because of the air traffic controllers' walkout, the Air Transport Association said today.

title: Observer; HANDLING THINGS NICE
description: ''We're a very happy group.'' - President Reagan at his Nov. 10 news conference.

title: MARCELLUS B. M'DAVITT
description: Marcellus B. McDavitt, a former vice president of Bell Laboratories, died Tuesday in Guadalajara, Mexico. Mr. McDavitt, who retired from the company in 1968, had been a longtime resident of Rumson, N.J. He was 78 years old.

title: CONFEREES AGREE TO LOWER PEANUT SUPPORTS
description: Southern Congressmen defending the peanut farmer fell back a few yards today and agreed to lower price supports on next year's crop and to allow new peanut growers a larger share of the market.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Atlantic Richfield filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer $400 million of 7 percent original issue discount notes due in 1991, to be sold through a Salomon Brothers group.

title: DESIGNATRONICS INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
SEMICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 4
U.S. HELPS FORM GIANT THRIFT UNIT
description: The Government today authorized a California savings and loan association to acquire a financially troubled savings and loan association in Florida. The merger will create the third-largest savings and loan unit in the nation.
