title: Patents; A Method for Treating Malignancies in the Eye
description: A method of treating malignancies in the eye by inserting a capsule filled with an effective drug was patented this week for the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: TORO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-After loss from discontinued operations of $23,000; the 1980 results restated to reflect the divestiture of Barefoot Grass Lawn Service Inc as a discontinued operations

title: MONEY UP BY MODEST $2.3 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve Board announced yesterday that the nation's basic money supply rose by $2.3 billion in the latest reporting week - a relatively modest increase that economists said prompts the Fed to continue easing its monetary policy.

title: DONOVAN COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MISSISSIPPI ATTORNEY GENERAL
description: A.@F. Summer, a former State Attorney General who was Mississippi's top lawyer in legal battles over desegregation and prison conditions, died Thursday after suffering a heart attack. He was 60 years old.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL BUILDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Artists Donate Works For Lobbying Effort
description: To raise money for lobbying efforts in behalf of the proposed equal-rights amendment, more than 40 New York artists have donated works for a sale at the Zabriskie Gallery, 521 West 57th Street, through today.

title: Allied Stores Net Off 36.3%
description: The Allied Stores Corporation, one of the nation's largest department store chains, said yesterday that earnings in the third quarter, ended Oct. 31, declined 36.3 percent, to $10 million, or 50 cents a share, from $15.8 million, or 77 cents, in 1980.

title: IC Industries Offer
description: IC Industries Inc. said it would begin an offer for up to three million of its common shares at $36 a share on or about next Tuesday. As of Oct. 31, there were 17.29 million common shares outstanding, together with 3.65 million in $3.50 second-preferred stock, each convertible to 1 1/2 shares of common. The offer is scheduled to expire Dec. 15 unless extended.

title: Around the Nation; Judge Refuses to Bar Evidence in Atlanta Case
description: A judge ruled today that prosecutors in the murder trial of Wayne B. Williams could use evidence seized by the police in a 10-and-a-half-hour search of his home.

title: DATAPOINT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to include operations of Flex Inc which became a wholly owned subsidiary of Datapoint on Nov 2; shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in Feb 1981

title: NATIONAL GAS & OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After an accounting adjustment of $57,159; the 1980 net figures restated for the accounting change

title: TAKE A BUS (INSTEAD OF THE SUBWAY) AND SAVE
description: To the Editor:

title: EDWARDS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RELAXATION TANKS: A MARKET DEVELOPS
description: Four years ago Gary Higgins, then president of a small carpet-cleaning service in Denver, took his first ''float'' in a relaxation tank.

title: Ex-General Is Hurt in Bolivia As Gunmen Shoot at His Car
description: Gunmen fired 60 bullets into the car of a former high-ranking army general, hitting him in the hands and legs, the Government said today.

title: REAGAN CUTS IN WELFARE VOIDED IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that the Reagan Administration's regulations reducing welfare benefits under the program of Aid to Families with Dependent Children were invalid.

title: Briefing
description: I T is one of those gnawing problems that Congress has persistently avoided in the last decade: a problem that deepens year by year. ''It's a question of political courage,'' said Representative Butler Derrick, Democrat of South Carolina. ''We can't put off a decision any longer. We've got to act.''

title: BIOFUEL INC reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
SCURRY-RAINBOW OIL LTD reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-After tax credit of $2.9 million; the 1980 figures restated to reflect a change in the fiscal yr-end

title: UNIMAX CORP reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: B-After income of $23,800 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $749,200...C-After a loss of $577,500 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $1,386,600; the 1981 earnings include provisions $250,000 for moving its metal products manufacturing operation in 1982 to another facility

title: Layoffs by G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation will eliminate the second shift of van production at its Lordstown, Ohio, plant beginning Dec. 7, resulting in the indefinite layoff of 1,100 workers, the auto maker said. Meanwhile, officials at G.M.'s Delco-Remy and Guide division plants in Anderson, Ind., said that 837 hourly workers would be placed on indefinite layoff beginning Monday.

title: INTERFERON TESTED ON SCLEROSIS
description: year study by researchers in Buffalo has shown that interferon may be effective in treating multiple sclerosis, and doctors in New Orleans said today that they would test the antiviral substance against a highly contagious form of pinkeye.

title: LEGISLATORS MISS MIDNIGHT DEADLINE ON SPENDING BILL
description: Congress gave up Friday night on efforts to meet a midnight deadline on a stopgap spending bill, but House and Senate conferees narrowed their differences on the scope of further reductions in Federal funds for the current fiscal year.

title: SOVIET WARNS FINNS TO SELECT PRESIDENT WITH CARE
description: The Soviet Union cautioned Finland yesterday against ''any miscalculation'' in the choice of a President to succeed 81-year-old Urho Kekkonen, who resigned last month for reasons of ill health.

title: PANEL ACTS TO BAR WILDERNESS LEASES
description: The House Interior Committee approved a resolution today seeking to bar all oil and gas leasing in Federal wilderness areas until next June 1 to give Congress time to study ways to protect those areas.

title: U.S. STEEL GIVES LOAN DETAILS
description: The United States Steel Corporation said today that it had more than $5.61 billion available for its proposed acquisition of the Marathon Oil Company, consisting of $3.01 billion in commitments from various American and foreign banks and $2.6 billion on hand in cash or its equivalent.

title: Prize for Ansel Adams
description: King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden presented the Hasselblad gold medal and $20,000 to Ansel Adams, the photographer and conservationist, in ceremonies held Thursday at the Museum of Modern Art. The prizes were awarded by the Erna and Victor Hasselblad Foundation, founded in 1978 by Mr. Hasselblad, the Swedish camera manufacturer, to further teaching and research in the natural sciences and photography.

title: Carl Badenhausen, 87; Ex-head of Ballantine's
description: Carl W. Badenhausen, retired president of P. Ballantine & Sons, the brewers, died Thursday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 87 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange

title: IMM ENERGY SERVICES & TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $1,077,000 nonrecurring charge from costs incurred in connection with the acquisition of International Moorings & Marine Inc on a pooling of interests basis...C-Net income; Yr-ago results include operations of Uthe Technology Inc acquir in Sept 1980

title: 2 ASSAIL BYRNE ON PLANS TO ALTER PARK
description: The outgoing Byrne administration has touched off a controversy over its nationwide appeal last month for proposals for major commercial development on portions of Liberty State Park here. The proposals would affect large areas of the state-owned park originally designated as open space.

title: GRAND AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: Results for the latest yr include an estimated LIFO adjustment based on current prices and inventory levels

title: COLLEGE SPEAKS THEIR LANGUAGE
description: ''It's not an isolated ivory tower,'' said Flora Mancuso Edwards, president of Eugenio Maria de Hostos Community College in the South Bronx. She was commenting on both the college's academic ambiance and its location.

title: Notes on People; Wagnerian Ring Cycle Is Once Again Complete
description: Karl Bohm, the renowned Austrian conductor who died last Aug. 14, often called Zubin Mehta ''the bearer of the Wagner tradition,'' and how very much he meant what he said will be apparent tomorrow.

title: Patents; Patent Treaty Updated
description: WASHINGTON THE Patent Cooperation Treaty, under which a single application can be filed for patent coverage in many countries, is being updated, it was announced this week.

title: MODERN MERCHANDISING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Children's Books
description: FLIGHT A Panorama of Aviation. By Melvin B. Zisfein. Illustrated by Robert Andrew Parker. Pantheon Books. Paper, $11.95. (Ages 9 to 12) By ERNEST K.GANN

title: ON BOTH SIDES, PASSIONS IN ULSTER ARE AT A FLASH
description: POINT By WILLLIAM BORDERS

title: Reading and Writing; BEING A CHARACTER
description: In reading Matthew J. Bruccoli's current biography of F. Scott Fitzgerald, I was struck by the number of people Fitzgerald drew on in creating characters for ''Tender Is the Night.'' Some of the models for the characters seem to have been generally recognized, and this raised for me the question of how people feel about finding themselves portrayed in fiction.

title: U.S. EXPECTS SOVIET RELATIONS TO ENTER A PRODUCTIVE PERIOD
description: The Reagan Administration has told allied governments in recent days that it expects Soviet-American relations to enter a new phase, marked less by polemics and more by concrete discussions of arms control and other issues.

title: L.I. ECONOMY GAINS DESPITE RECESSION, BANK'S STUDY FINDS
description: Despite a general economic downturn, particularly in the Northeast, Long Island continues to enjoy growth in jobs, a modest but improving real-estate market and an expanding defense industry, according to a report prepared for Chemical Bank, the largest on the Island.

title: LURED BY 'SATAN,' HE ATTACKS THE CULTS
description: When Ralph Thomas was a boy growing up in the jungles of Brazil, where his missionary parents had founded a seminary, he was taught that movies were the work of Satan. Since there were no movie theaters in the neighborhood, however, temptation did not present itself until later. But then Ralph's father got beriberi and the Thomas family moved back home to Canada.

title: SOCCER UPSETS PARK'S BALANCE
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE IT'S somehow fitting that Ben Pearlman is moving to Florida next week - now that his beloved Mill River Park has been turned into a soccer field.

title: The Question of Sex Bias At Harvard
description: Dr. Skocpol may or may not have been the victim of antifeminism at Harvard, but Miss Schumer hardly proves it with a catalogue of department rivalries and the admission that junior faculty rarely achieve tenure there. But what, then, is the fuss? Is one supposed to feel sorry for Dr. Skocpol? She came away with a national reputation and job offers from several of the most prestigious universities in the country. Surely, life doesn't cease outside Harvard? LAILA Z. GROSS, BARRY R. GROSS, New York City

title: BUSINESS TAX REMAINS THE MAIN EVENT
description: HARTFORD THE most durable issue at the State Capitol this year has been the unincorporated business tax. Just when it appeared that the General Assembly was on the verge of repealing the tax that it had enacted at the regular legislative session last spring, Governor O'Neill called for changes in the levy to bring in more money to help close a deficit in the current fiscal year ending June 30.

title: The Nature Center And Volunteers
description: Aware of your interest in fair play and proper recognition of participants, I noticed several important omissions in Lynn Ames's delightful About Westchester article on Nov. 1, about the Greenburgh Nature Center's annual Halloween Night Walk. No mention was made of the enormous contribution made by volunteers in running this nonprofit educational institution - particularly for this special night.

title: Sports of The Times; Another Coach Is an Undercut Victim
description: ONCE the coach was one of America's authority figures. Do it the coach's way, or don't do it. If the coach was correct, the won-lost record showed it. If the coach was wrong, the won-lost record showed that, too. The good coaches endured, the bad coaches didn't. But in the money market that rules sports now, even the good coaches are stabbed too often by club owners and players, few of whom truly appreciate the coach's role.

title: New Jersey Housing; LEARNING TO RUN A CONDOMINIUM
description: ''ACONDOMINIUM is only as good as the people you get to lead it,'' said Ralph West, who serves on the Maintenance and Finance Committees of the condominium association at Bristol House, a 140-unit apartment house on Prospect Avenue in Hackensack.

title: BUSINESS WOOS SCIENTISTS AT COLD SPRING HARBOR LAB
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR FROM the four-lane section of Route 25A here, opposite the children gawking into the tanks of the state fish hatchery, there is little to reveal the presence of the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory except a very small sign and a curiously large number of parked cars.

title: CONQUES
description: To the Editor:

title: Numismatics; MODEL FOR THE SILVER DOLLAR NOW HAS SILVER HAIR
description: An 80-year-old New Yorker named Teresa de Francisci has a claim to fame that no one else alive today can make: Her portrait appears on one of our United States coins. Sixty years ago she posed for her sculptor husband, Anthony de Francisci, when he fashioned a depiction of Miss Liberty for the new silver dollar of 1921 -a coin now known to hobbyists as the Peace dollar.

title: Politics; SCHWENK LIFTS LID ON PARTY PATRONAGE
description: or at least a lot - about G.O.P. patronage, much of it hidden, in a political column he has started in local advertising giveaways.

title: Television Week
description: Music Reigns Several music programs have been scheduled this holiday week. On Sunday at 10 P.M., Channel 13 will broadcast ''In Performance at the White House,'' which marks the beginning of a four-part series. This latest in a long line of recitals at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue - there have been concerts there at least since Jenny Lind's in 1830, during the Andrew Jackson Administration - will feature Rudolf Serkin, Beverly Sills, Merle Haggard and Gene Kelly. And each of these veterans will appear with young artists whom they hold in high regard. Peter Weinberger, the producer, says that he selected the senior artists and each of them in turn selected ''the junior artists whom they will introduce to the President, Mrs. Reagan and the nation.''

title: ISRAELI ARABS LAG IN SCHOOL, A STUDY SAYS
description: Arab schoolchildren in Israel lag behind their Jewish peers in arithmetic and reading, according to a report recently published by the Hebrew University of Jerusalem in conjunction with the Education Ministry.

title: New Hampshire Deer Hunt
description: WENTWORTH LOCATION, N.H. KNEELING in an aluminum johnboat, breaking ice with a paddle to permit our crossing of the Dead Diamond River shortly after dawn, I could not refrain from thinking of more salubrious endeavors in warmer climes.

title: Business Forum; BUSINESS IS ASKING FOR TROUBLE AGAIN
description: O NCE each generation, American business has an opportunity to exert public leadership rather than defend itself against the public. It has that opportunity now. Will it use it? If the past is any guide, the answer is probably ''no.''

title: Paperback Talk
description: Paper dolls. The two old friends got the idea for their book - a paperback that may long be remembered for its evocation of the Presidential style at the dawn of the Age of Reagan - last February, while they were having drinks after a meeting in Manhattan of collectors of old postcards.

title: Ralph W. Brown, 88; A Retired Phone Aide
description: Ralph W. Brown, a vice president and the general counsel of the New York Telephone Company from 1943 until he retired in 1958, died Thursday at his home in North Brooklin, Me. He was 88 years old.

title: Dance; MEDLEY OF INDIA ART COMES TO ELMSFORD
description: AN unusual blend of art, music and dance from North India will be presented, free of charge, from 3 to 5 P.M. today at the Greenburgh Town Hall in Elmsford. Sponsored by the Greenburgh Arts and Culture Committee, the event will combine the showing of ''The Sword and the Flute,'' a film illustrating 16th-century Mogul and Rajput painting, with a live performance of dance by Carolyn Kay, Janaki Patrik, with rhythm provided by Paul A. Leake.

title: Dr. Laszlo Auer, 80, Is Dead ; An Expert in Paint Chemistry
description: Dr. Laszlo Auer, founder of the Aula Chemicals Company and holder of 300 patents for polymer and paint chemistry, died Thursday at his home in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 80 years old.

title: HARRISON BEATS RYE
description: Harrison finished an unbeaten season yesterday with a 13-0 victory over Rye, its traditional rival. The victory gave the Huskies of Coach Mike Belmont a 9-0 record in his first season.

title: 'Joseph' Will Double Capacity at Entermedia
description: At a time when a number of musicals have been faring badly on Broadway, ''Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat,'' which opened Wednesday at the Entermedia Theater on Second Avenue and 12th Street, has been doing so well that the balcony will be opened Tuesday. The action will increase the theater's seating capacity from 499 to 1,096.

title: THE NOW AND FUTURE ILLS OF THE NUCLEAR GIANT
description: In the last few months, the Diablo Canyon nuclear plant has become a paradigm of nuclear power troubles. The plant, close to an offshore geological fault near San Luis Obispo, Calif., has endured design errors, charges of inadequate safety and massive antinuclear protests. Last week, adding further to the mounting costs of opening it, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted to suspend the plant's license until it passes a series of seismic tests.

title: HERO OF A LOST CAUSE
description: LEE The Last Years. By Charles Bracelen Flood. Illustrated. 308 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $14.95.

title: Susan N. Eckstein Engaged to Wed
description: Mrs. H. Philipp Eckstein of Massapequa, L.I., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Susan Nina Eckstein, to Robert Nathan Perelman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Perelman of Union, N.J. Miss Eckstein is a daughter also of the late Mr. Eckstein.

title: THE TIME TO STUDY ELECTION REFORM
description: ALTHOUGH the 1981 General Assembly enacted important reforms in Connecticut's election laws last spring, events in Hartford, West Haven and other towns during the September primaries demonstrate that the job is far from complete.

title: WAGNER'S 'RING' RESOUNDS ANEW
description: When London Records released Georg Solti's recording of Wagner's ''Das Rheingold'' in 1959 as the initial installment of the first complete ''Der Ring des Nibelungen,'' it was a milestone in recording history. Part of the album's epochal nature had to do with its vibrant sound and the late John Culshaw's aggressive notions of sound effects as aural theater. But the real news was that Wagner's ''Ring,'' one of the undisputed masterpieces of Western culture, was at last to be available to anyone with a record player.

title: Glowing Account
description: To the Editor:

title: LOUISIANA SEEKING U.S. AID TO SAVE WETLAND
description: Gov. David C. Treen set out today to lead Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt through the largest hardwood swamp in the nation in an attempt to convince Mr. Watt that the Federal Government should help Louisiana buy a large piece of it.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; HOWARD FAST
description: Howard Fast and Bette, his wife of 44 years, moved back to Connecticut from California last year because - as he puts it - ''my wife wanted to and because I'm very fond of her.'' He still misses California, though, and it is easy to understand why. It is the setting for his hugely successful multivolume saga of the Lavette family, the fourth volume of which, ''The Legacy,'' is No. 5 on this week's fiction best-seller list.

title: YOU COULD SAY SHE HAD A CALLING FOR DEATH
description: THE COLLECTED POEMS By Sylvia Plath. Edited by Ted Hughes. 351 pp. New York: Harper & Row. Cloth, $17.50. Paper, $7.95.

title: COULD OIL DRILLS APPEAR CLOSE TO SHORE?
description: ALTHOUGH Government and industry analysts say it is doubtful that any gas or oil would be found within 50 miles of the shores of Long Island, James G. Watt, the Secretary of the Interior, has raised the possibility that drilling rigs could appear offshore anywhere from Rockaway Beach to Montauk Point.

title: REGAN OFFICE WARNS CITY TO CUT BACK ON SPENDING
description: Warning that New York City faces a budget gap of as much as $1.25 billion in fiscal 1983, the State Comptroller's office has recommended that the city move immediately to scale down its spending plans.

title: Food; CHICKEN COOKED TO MANY TASTES
description: ''I WANT to stay with simple, good, old-fashioned cooking,'' said Jay Post, co-owner with his father of the Happy Hostess, which has been serving such fare to the Island's South Shore for more than 35 years.

title: CONQUES
description: To the editor: Although the easiest way to reach Conques is to drive, there is another way to get there.

title: Westchester Guide; CAMPUS MONEY-RAISER
description: While Eunice Shriver Kennedy attends the Special Olympics Danceathon in Manhattan, Frank Gifford, Howard Cosell, Don Meredith and Pete Roselle will be doing the honors at a similar function to be held from 1 to 5 P.M. today at the State University of New York College at Purchase.

title: PRINCETON LOSES HOLLY BUT ROUTS CORNELL
description: Princeton lost Bob Holly, its star quarterback, early in the game today but put together a determined team effort and crushed Cornell, 37-14. But the outside shot the Tigers had of getting a share of the Ivy League championship was dissipated when Yale and Dartmouth won. So Princeton finished at 5-1-1 in the league and 5-4-1 over all.

title: NORTH CAROLINA GETS TOP BILLING, BUT NOT BY MUCH
description: DURING a recent trip to New York, Dean Smith was told his North Carolina team had been selected as the nation's best in several preseason polls.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Gracie Solar Plan
description: It was Sun Day in New York City, May 3, 1979.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is ridiculous to have this big a squabble over this small an amount.'' - Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, as conferees struggled over a crucial spending bill. (1:6.)

title: GEORGE YAMAOKA, LAWYER NAMED TO POST BY MACARTHUR, DIES AT 78
description: George Yamaoka, a Japanese-American lawyer who was apppointed by the Allies to defend accused Japanese war criminals after World War II, died Thursday of a heart attack while riding in a taxicab in Manhattan.

title: AMERICAN SETTINGS
description: WARLOCK By Jim Harrison. 262 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/ Seymour Lawrence. $13.95.

title: Bridging America's Drug Gap
description: John Kelly will undoubtedly strike a sympathetic chord among those who have experienced similar frustrations in obtaining new drugs, as described in his article, ''Bridging America's Drug Gap'' (Sept.13). Obstacles abound in the introduction of new treatments.

title: Nun Held Up on Bronx Street
description: A nun was held up Friday night in the Parkchester section of the Bronx, the police said yesterday. Officer Gilbert Starkey said the nun, who identified herself as Sister Peter Brigid of the convent adjoining St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church in the Mott Haven section, was accosted shortly after 9 P.M. at 40 Metropolitan Oval by a teenager armed with a pistol. The youth took about $12 from the nun, who was not injured, the officer said.

title: MARK DUGAN TO MARRY MARIA CRISTINA VALES
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Vales of Sewickley, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maria Cristina Vales, to Mark Peter Dugan, son of Peter Dugan of Fishkill, N.Y., and the late Mary Dugan.

title: CONSERVATIVES OPEN AN ANTI-MOYNIHAN DRIVE
description: A national conservative group has opened a campaign against Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, labeling the New York Democrat in radio advertisements as ''the most liberal United States Senator.''

title: FANCY STEPPING
description: Do you always have to pay a fortune for those superb little shoes offered by Madison Avenue's tony boutiques? You do. And you don't. It all depends on where you look and what you're looking for. Currently, there are three stores on Madison Avenue in the 60's where the shopper for the fashionable shoe can find it at prices that range from the reasonable to the stratospheric.

title: LIFE IN LAKE BENTON: AFTER HARVEST, PRAIRIE TOWN SETTLES IN FOR LONG WINTER
description: The traffic jam is over for the year. It went on for more than two weeks, as late as midnight, a line of farmers' trucks loaded with corn that started beyond the railroad tracks and curved around in front of the grain elevator.

title: EXCERPTS FROM PRESIDENT'S INTERVIEW
description: Following are excerpts from a White House transcript of questions and answers from President Reagan's interview Thursday in the Oval Office with representatives from the Gannett News Service, The National Journal, The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post:

title: THE VOCAL ODYSSEY OF JOSE CARRERAS
description: When Jose Carreras, the young Spanish tenor, sang in Franco Zeffirelli's ''La Boheme'' with the La Scala opera company in Washington five years ago, he was Rodolfo. He had the soft, sensitive, boyish-looking face one always felt Puccini's young poet should have. He moved with hesitance at times, as if he were unsure of what to do next. He held Mimi's hand as if he were truly afraid he might crush it, and when he sang ''Che gelida manina'' to her, he seemed to be expressing the sudden discovery of a fragile truth. His singing was natural, unaffected, disarmingly lyrical. His voice had a lustrous sheen in the upper register, with flashes of fire that set it somehow, indefinably, apart. One sensed immediately what a rarity he was.

title: OPENING GAMBIT BREZHNEV TRIP TO BONN SETS THE STAGE FOR MISSILE TALKS
description: BONN NOW the ''peace war'' begins in earnest. After President Reagan moved his ''program for preserving peace in Europe'' into place last week, Leonid I. Brezhnev arrives in Bonn tonight and is expected to fire a return salvo of the new soft and conciliatory vocabulary (for the Reagan team, at least) in a battle that will run at least into 1984.

title: GOVERNMENT, ITS SPENDING UNAUTHORIZED, GRINDS ON AND ON
description: The United States Government began to spend money today without technical authority to do so, but hardly anyone noticed.

title: LAVISH LONDON ARTS CENTER WILL OPEN SOON
description: It is described as ''the greatest arts complex in Western Europe.'' It is vast. It took 11 years to build, cost a fortune, and is either a glittering new jewel in London's crown or the biggest white elephant imaginable.

title: POP: THE BLENDS OF ALABAMA
description: Alabama, the country-pop quartet that appeared Thursday at the Bottom Line, may be the best-selling country group in America right now, rivaled only by the Oak Ridge Boys.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Surgical Stamina
description: Michael Bates entered Massachusetts General Hospital last Sept. 4 with one thumb intact on each hand and eight severed fingers packed in ice in a plastic bag. When he awakened after 46 1/2 hours of surgery, all eight fingers were reattached.

title: A Communicator Is Remembered
description: A few words about communication and redheads. The great thing about today's communication is that it brings all of us all-too-comfortable suburbanites into instant contact with outer space, South American summit meetings, and royal weddings.

title: Wine; NOTES FROM THE UNDERGROUND
description: e was infatuated with wine, and he had established an enormous collection in his cellar, wines from France, Italy, Germany and California, wines that steadily increased in value with the passage of time. He loved nothing better than to unlock his cellar door an hour or so before dinner and browse among the bottles, deciding which wine to drink with his wife or guests that night, whether it would be two bottles, a white with the first course and a red with the meat, or perhaps three, including a sweet dessert wine or possibly a vintage Port with the cheese course.

title: Pistons 95, Jazz 86
description: Isiah Thomas and John Long combined for 49 points to spark the Pistons. Thomas, the rookie from Indiana, scored 18 of his 28 points in the first half as Detroit took a 47-39 lead.

title: BUSINESS LOBBY TO WIDEN AIM
description: HARTFORD FROM his 12th-floor office in a shiny tower, Kenneth O. Decko, president of the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, can look down at the entire downtown area, a distinction that perhaps has added to the association's image among commmunity groups of being ''above and beyond'' the community.

title: A FRANCOPHILE'S GUADELOUPEZ
description: FRANK J. PRIAL is a correspondent in the Paris bureau of The Times. By FRANK J.PRIAL

title: Follow-Up on the News; At Loggerheads
description: It was an odd choice that Danville, Va., faced in December 1979 for polluting the air from its coal-burning power plant: pay a stiff fine or sponsor a $10,000 study of the sex life of loggerhead turtles.

title: St. John the BaptistCaptures Catholic Title
description: If the Holy Cross football team and its fans experienced a familiar feeling today at the Catholic High Schools Football League championship game, it was understandable.

title: LEAF-BURNING RITUAL EVOKES MANY CONSTRAINTS ACROSS U.S.
description: The burning of raked leaves in the autumn conjures up images of children jumping on leaf piles, neighbors leaning on rakes to chat and smoke wafting through the air on a clear autumn day.

title: STATE INQUIRY SET ON LIBERTY PARK
description: JERSEY CITY ASPECIAL State Assembly committee is expected to begin an investigation soon into the propriety of plans for the commercial development of 600 of Liberty State Park's 800 acres.

title: DOWNED PLANE IS SEARCHED FOR DRUGS
description: Rescue workers removing the body of one of seven people killed in the crash of a twin-engined plane near Edwards, Colo. The Drug Enforcement Administration in Denver said that the plane had been under investigation as a suspected carrier of cocaine from South America, but sheriff's deputies did not find any evidence of drugs in the wreckage. The plane disappeared Wednesday after the pilot radioed to a nearby airport that he was running short of fuel.

title: Leslie Anne Berdolt Married
description: Leslie Anne Berdolt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Berdolt of West Islip, L.I., was married yesterday at the Southward Ho Country Club in Bay Shore, L.I., to John Woodson Baker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Dill Baker of Frederick, Md. The Rev. Jack E. Savage, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: KNICKS END LOSS STREAK AT 4
description: In the alcove leading to their dressing room in Madison Square Garden last night, the Knicks acted more like a bunch of college kids than professionals after they defeated the Milwaukee Bucks, 118-112, and ended a four-game losing streak.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART One of the great charms of folk art is its affirmative view of the world. The green fields and white farmhouses limned by Grandma Moses radiate peace and harmony; peasants flourish in works by the Yugoslav painters Ivan Generalic and Stjepan Stolnik; Horace Pippin's cotton pickers make the sparseness of life in the rural South seem like pleasure incarnate.

title: Katya Laric Engaged To James J. Brennan
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Laric of New York and Mill River, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Katya Laric, to James J. Brennan, son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Brennan of Trenton. The wedding is planned for Feb. 6.

title: HOW THE SYSTEM PROCESSES JUVENILES
description: UNDER the state's Juvenile Code, if a complaint is filed against a person under the age of 18, he or she may be taken into custody by the police and processed through a county Juvenile and Domestic Relations Court. (In practice, children under 8 are rarely treated through any formal procedure.)

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Scanlon Triumphs
description: Bill Scanlon of Texas defeated unseeded Anders Jarryd of Sweden, 6-2, 6-1, in the semifinals of the $85,000 Bangkok international indoor tennis tournament tonight. Mats Wilander of Sweden beat Ramesh Krishnan of India, 6-1, 6-4.

title: YALE TO OFFER B.A. IN WOMEN'S STUDIES
description: Twelve years after admitting its first female undergraduates, Yale University will offer a Bachelor of Arts degree in women's studies beginning in the spring of 1982, making it the second Ivy League school to approve such a major.

title: Topics; CONSCIOUSNESS RAISED; Open Door
description: The rear doors on both the new Flxible and General Motors buses are designed for arm wrestlers and weight lifters.

title: FICTION BRIEFS
description: TRADITIONS By Alan Ebert. With Janice Rotchstein. 597 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $14.95.

title: Laura Friedland Is Fiancee of Leonard Rosenblatt
description: The engagement of Laura Susan Friedland to Leonard Reed Rosenblatt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Rosenblatt of Howard Beach, Queens, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Abner M. Friedland of South Orange, N.J., parents of the future bride. A January wedding is planned.

title: REAGAN BUDGET CUTS TERMED THREAT TO GREAT LAKES CLEANUP EFFORT
description: Proposed reductions in Federal spending for water pollution research and enforcement could endanger efforts to clean up the Great Lakes, a panel of American and Canadian scientists said today in a report presented to a conference here.

title: HERITAGE FOUNDATION DISAPPOINTED BY REAGAN
description: The Heritage Foundation said today that the first year of the Reagan Administration, while heading the country in the ''proper direction,'' had not lived up to the expectations of conservatives.

title: SEVERE CUTS IN RAIL SERVICE ANGER CANADIANS
description: By Government decree, Canada lost almost 20 percent of its passenger rail service this week, prompting a nationwide storm of protest, many lawsuits and a two-day physical blockade of at least one train.

title: SOVIET PRESS HAILS KARPOV VICTORY
description: The Soviet Union today toasted Anatoly Karpov's successful defense of his world chess title in gushing press tributes that all but disregarded his opponent.

title: WASHINGTON GETS ROSE BERTH
description: There was more than one game going on here this afternoon before a sellout crowd of 60,234 at Husky Stadium. One was on the field, where Washington was on its way to defeating its crossstate rival, Washington State, 23-10, and earning a second consecutive trip to the Rose Bowl.

title: PAPANDREOU TO REVEAL POLICIES TODAY
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou will present his Socialist Government's program to Parliament on Sunday in a speech that could clarify Greece's position on key foreign policy issues such as a possible withdrawal from NATO and the European Common Market and the future of American bases here.

title: Around the Nation; Coast Officials Find First Fruit Fly in 3 Weeks
description: The discovery of a Mediterranean fruit fly in San Mateo was confirmed today.

title: CAN A BOARD OF ETHICS HAVE A REAL EFFECT?
description: ARE you ethical? Are you ethical enough to serve on an Ethics Board? Are you ethical enough to face the board when charged with a conflict of interest?

title: Antiques View; A BLOCKBUSTER SALE OF EUROPEAN ART
description: Ahalf century ago private collections of European works of art were almost commonplace among the wealthy in this country. It was then that the taste peaked for Gothic and Renaissance sculptures, utensils and objects which are devised of bronze, wood, glass, ceramic, ivory or semi-precious stone. And the number of people with collections of such decorative pieces - sculptures, enameled plaques, polychrome platters, amber bowls, rock crystal ewers, agate cups, bronze mortars and pestles and steel boxes - increased in this country shortly before World War II with the influx of refugees from Nazi Germany.

title: The World; Guns and Butter In the Kremlin
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev last week played down one rationalization for Soviet belt-tightening - bad weather. But he was ready with another - the red, white and blue menace.

title: Playing Games With Pollution
description: Is Ronald Reagan ready to leave air and water quality to the mercies of the free market? A few months ago the question would have sounded silly -how could any responsible American want to roll back the progress of the last decade?

title: U.S. SCIENTISTS APPEAL TO BREZHNEV OVER SAKHAROV
description: American scientists have sent messages to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, and to President Reagan to try to avert a hunger strike by Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident physicist, which he has said he will begin Sunday to press for the emigration of his stepson's fiancee.

title: 'Inevitable Question' Gets More Answers
description: Thank you, Claire Waldman, for writing ''How to Parry the Thrust of the Inevitable Question'' (Opinion Page, Oct. 25.). You wrote the article I've been meaning to write for a long time. For years, ''the question'' was a source of agony and self-doubt for me also. Though I worked (in the commercial sense) for many years before I was married and had children, I have not had a full-time job since then.

title: Theater in Review; POETIC POWER SUSTAINS 'IGUANA'
description: EAST FARMINGDALE UNSEEN on the Island's stages for several seasons, plays by Tennessee Williams are suddenly back in style. As if in anticipation of a belated but nonetheless gala birthday tribute to the playwright coming up on Dec. 2 at Avery Fisher Hall, the Arena Players Repertory Company is presenting ''The Night of the Iguana'' (through next Sunday), and the Nassau Repertory Theater begins performances of ''Eccentricities of a Nightingale'' on Thursday.

title: CONSCIENCE TO HIS AGE, PLAGUE TO HIMSELF
description: JOHN RUSKIN The Passionate Moralist. By Joan Abse. Illustrated. 363 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.50. By RICHARD ELLMANN

title: Prospects
description: Buying Oil Companies

title: DANCE: BALLET TODAY PRESENTS A SHOWCASE
description: What's the point of a showcase without treasures to show? That question was prompted by the Choreographers' Showcase offered Wednesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church by the Ballet Today Company, a Connecticut troupe that plans to be the resident company of the new Stamford Center for the Arts.

title: Turnpike Deaths Up in 1981
description: The National Safety Council says that traffic deaths on the nation's turnpikes are up 15 percent in the first six months of this year over 1980. The council said Wednesday that 176 persons died in traffic accidents on toll roads this year, as against 153 in the same period last year.

title: Dining Out; NORTHERN ITALIAN FARE WITH STYLE
description: LA PRIMAVERA in East Hills has weathered the test of time extremely well. Shortly after it opened a couple of years ago, there was every indication that it would be among the best northern Italian restaurants on the Island. It still is, even though the rating has now been revised from three stars to two. Although the food can be astonishingly good, recent dining experiences have proved less consistently excellent than in the past.

title: Economic Affairs; DAVID STOCKMAN'S STORY
description: I T has only taken six months for the Reagan economic program to fail in its promise of full employment and low inflation for 1982. Now, beset by inflationary fiscal deficits and the highest interest rates since F.D.R., the program instead has given the economy the current recession. How and why this happened is the subject of the fascinating article in the December issue of The Atlantic Monthly, entitled, ''The Education of David Stockman,'' by William Greider.

title: VOLUNTEER WORK BY THE EMPLOYED INCREASES ON L.I.
description: ''IT's not that I have this grand mission to help others, but I know I have something to give,'' said Kay M. Herbert of Port Washington, a 44-year-old bookkeeper for a real-estate management firm. ''In my lifetime a lot of things have happened to me that can benefit other people, and I think the best thing you can do is share this experience and knowledge with others.''

title: HEALTH PRECAUTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: * Rates restricted by state usury laws

title: The Region; Old Frying Pan And a New Fire For City Council
description: For a body charged with making law, the New York City Council has recently displayed a discouraging propensity for running afoul of it. Last week, as Council members struggled to correct district lines that violated the Voting Rights Act, a Federal court ruled that the system of electing at-large members violated the Constitution.

title: Antiques; ELUSIVE PAINTER BEGAN 1796 MUSEUM
description: HARTFORD SIXTY portraits by an early Hartford artist who never signed his work have been identified, gathered together and today form a special exhibit at the Connecticut Historical Society, 1 Elizabeth Street.

title: PREPPIES FROM ABROAD
description: Andree Brooks is a frequent contributor to The New York Times. By Andree Brooks Joseph R. Curry, a tall, heavyset man with twinkling blue eyes, receding white hair and a fondness for referring to himself as ''the old schoolmaster,'' stood at the top of a hill overlooking the Nashua River Valley in Ashburnham, Mass. Below him spread the rolling green lawns of the 42-acre campus of Cushing Academy.

title: Brown Beats Columbia, 23-20
description: The fullback Bill Barrett ran a yard off left tackle with 27 seconds left today as Brown rallied for a 23-20 victory over Columbia. Brown finished the season 3-7 over all and 2-5 in the Ivy League; Columbia finished 1-9 and 1-6.

title: THEATER: 2 STRIKINGLY VISUAL SHOWS
description: Two shows, each strikingly visual and each drawing on traditional performance skills, are playing at two small New York theaters - the Talking Band's production of ''Giaconda and Si-Ya-U'' at the Dance Theater Workshop and Eric Bass's one-man puppet show ''Autumn Portraits,'' at the Theater for the New City.

title: ARTHUR GERSHWIN, 81, COMPOSER AND PRODUCER
description: Arthur Gershwin, a composer and the younger brother of George and Ira Gershwin, died at his home Friday after a long illness. He was 81 years old and lived at 25 Central Park South.

title: Around the Nation; Snowstorm Moves East Into Ohio and Maryland
description: By The Associated Press A snowstorm that wreaked havoc on the Middle West, killing 21 persons, piling up traffic in huge snarls and sending football fans to the hospital for exposure, blasted into the East yesterday.

title: Comment; THE 100 M.P.G. CAR
description: I T is not only possible, it is practical to build a car that gets 100 miles per gallon. At Battelle Memorial Institute, we have just completed a study of what could be done using today's technology to yield a highly fuel-efficient, lower-cost automobile that meets all current and anticipated United States legal, safety and environmental requirements.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Panocha String Quartet, Formed in Prague in '68
description: There is something about the Bohemian temperament that finds perfect expression in the string quartet. Perhaps it is the sense for order that binds individuals to a common purpose in this most democratic of chamber-music idioms; whatever it is, the national genius is inclined toward the quartet, and has produced some good ones, and some good music for them to play, over the years.

title: IOWA WINS TRIP TO ROSE BOWL
description: Phil Blatcher rushed for a career high of 247 yards and scored two touchdowns today as Iowa defeated Michigan State, 36-7, to tie for the Big Ten Conference title and earn its first trip to the Rose Bowl in 23 years. The Hawkeyes will face Washington on New Year's Day.

title: The Careful Shopper; Tasty Holiday Gifts: Cheeses and Nuts
description: The English send ''tuck boxes'' of sweets to allay loneliness as well as hunger at boarding schools; devoted families here depend more often on home-baked cookies or cakes, aware that apple pie may not survive the journey to students staying away for the holidays. For additional choices, and to save time in the kitchen, try a visit to Cheese 'n' Such in the Heathcote section of Scarsdale at the border with New Rochelle. There, free wooden lids, or fancier baskets at various prices, can be custom-filled, gift-wrapped, packed free and shipped postpaid.

title: Connecticut Housing; HOME PRICES DOWN; SALES STILL LAG
description: PLAGUED by a prolonged spell of high mortgage interest rates, home sales around the state are continuing to decline. Prices have barely increased all year and in some places they are actually lower than they were some months ago.

title: NEW ZEALAND ELECTION A TEST FOR MAORIS' PARTY
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand National elections being held next Saturday will provide the first test for the new political party of New Zealand's Maoris, one that has taken more than 40 years to form.

title: Nederlander Announces Executive Changes
description: The Nederlander Organization Inc., the concern that owns or controls 10 Broadway theaters, has announced executive changes.

title: Pete Johnson of Bengals Barrels Along
description: The image has been reinforced so often by both his physique and his performance that Pete Johnson has stopped trying to escape. First in Columbus as a record-breaking fullback at Ohio State, and now here with the Cincinnati Bengals, anytime Johnson has gone into a three-point stance when the situation called for a few very important yards, it was no secret where the ball would wind up.

title: Washington; HOPE IN HAMBURG
description: This old German seafaring city has been watching the political winds since the 13th century and observes the present East-West storm with a very canny eye.

title: Arguello Stops Foe in 7th
description: Alexis Arguello knocked out Roberto Elizondo, the No. 3 contender, in the seventh round today and retained his World Boxing Council lightweight title.

title: CANARSIE TOPS MIDWOOD, WINS 'B' TITLE
description: Canarsie captured the B Division championship of the Public Schools Athletic League yesterday with a 24-0 victory over Midwood, the titleholders the last two seasons.

title: Ideas and Trends; Bishops Deplore Arms Spending at Expense of Needy
description: After a period of relative quiescence, the Roman Catholic Church received a prod to political activism last week - and an agenda that cuts both ways.

title: MAKING BIKES FASTER WON'T MAKE THEM PLAY IN PEORIA
description: A diverse group of men and women was called to this suburb of Los Angeles yesterday, in the shadow of Disneyland, to discuss rolling resistance, linear motion drives, skin friction drag and other exotic aspects of aerodynamics. In fact, the subject of their discussions was the bicycle, and from the jargon of technical papers sprang dreams of creating a cheap, gasoline-free, nonpolluting commuter vehicle for the future.

title: Cx for Rx Is Offered By Two Pharmacists
description: ''Where Are the Nostrums of Yesteryear?'' (Nov. 1) was a delightful tidbit of nostalgia.

title: RICHARD TODD IS BASKING IN NEW JET AGE
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I. H E debated whether he could play, but Richard Todd finally decided: ''I want to be in there. I feel like I've gotten us this far.'' And so, dramatically on Saturday, he donned an outfit with a flak jacket and a microphone, suited up, and led the New York Jets through their final workout before Sunday's showdown for first place against the Miami Dolphins.

title: DOMESTIC NOVELS
description: AT PARADISE GATE By Jane Smiley. 224 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $12.95.

title: IN HARTSDALE, 3 STARS FOR FRENCH CUISINE
description: FEW restaurants in the county offer fine classic French cuisine, and even the best of these occasionally falter in a world where all is flux. Reputations of restaurants follow paths that swoop and soar according to changes in ownership, kitchen personnel, dining room staff and, not insignificantly, the economy. It is gratifying then to see Auberge Argenteuil in Hartsdale thrive under the new sole ownership of Henri and M'el Eudes. The menu streamlined, dining room staff efficient, dining rooms refurbished, thoroughly professional kitchen orchestrated by its longtime chef de cuisine, Francois Kerohas, together with Mrs. Eudes's gracious warmth and Mr. Eudes's felicitous attentiveness as he suggests special dishes and appropriate wines from his cellar - that old magic is there again. Right now Auberge Argenteuil is one of our favorite dining places this side of the Atlantic.

title: The Region; Seven Indicted In Brink's Case
description: Barely had the bullets stopped flying in last month's bloody Brink's robbery when speculation began over how many persons may have helped to plan and execute it. Last week, a Rockland County grand jury seemed to put the questions to rest, at least for the time being.

title: Dining Out; GIVING IT THE OLD SCHOOLHOUSE TRY
description: JUST over two years ago, a large old schoolhouse on Oakland Street in Red Bank was converted into a restaurant appropriately named the Oakland Street Schoolhouse. Five months ago, RKRA Enterprises acquired the property and renamed it Gables.

title: NIGHTCLUB TESTS A PRESS ISSUE
description: THE publishers of The Babylon Beacon, a weekly newspaper in Babylon, said they would continue to defy a court order requiring that they disclose the name of the person who wrote a letter to the editor criticizing the owner of a local nightclub.

title: A LA RECHERCHE DE PROUST
description: WHEN I went to Paris to find Proust this past summer, I had to begin in the Bibliotheque Nationale. But it wasn't as easy as I had thought. I came with a letter from my university attesting to my serious scholarly purpose, an identification card, a passport, a sheaf of papers and a list of manuscript numbers. What I didn't have was a current photo of myself, and a kind, but insistent, civil servant explained that the gallery of any large Metro station would be the best place to have one made. Seeing, however, that my hours in the library were to be limited, she allowed me a temporary card on the condition that I would have my picture within three days. With my papers under my arm, I started up the austere marble staircase to the manuscript room, the mecca for a certain elite of scholars. The ceilings are two stories high with ancient leather-bound volumes lining one long side and French windows on the other. Curved boiseries with intricate flowers, leaves and the crests of nobles from the times of Richelieu and Voltaire separate atlases from dictionaries, scriptures from myths, ancient histories from psalters. A squeaky ladder that rolls along a railing allows the blue-coated functionaries to climb up and fetch down books. The long tables are covered with red leather, bordered in light-colored wood worn smooth by centuries of leaning elbows, and the caned seats of the carved armchairs sag from years of scholarly bottoms.

title: Marci Arons Engaged To Harvey Weinberg
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jerrold A. Arons of Oradell, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marci Ellen Arons, to Harvey Bruce Weinberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Weinberg of Hackensack, N.J.

title: OHIO ST. BEATS MICHIGAN, BUT IOWA IS IN ROSE BOWL
description: With Woody Hayes watching from on high, Art Schlichter, the quarterback who had brought the pass back to Ohio State football, beat Michigan with a run today.

title: NON-CATHOLICS RALLY TO AID DIOCESAN SCHOOLS
description: Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish business leaders here have formed what they call the first independent, nonsectarian committee to raise funds for a Catholic school system. Their goal is a contribution of $77 million in three years.

title: FUND SET UP TO HELP HAITIANS
description: Several Haitian-American businessmen in New York City have established a fund to provide emergency food, clothing, medical supplies and legal assistance to Haitians, with an eye toward discouraging the influx of illegal refugees.

title: Art View; BEGUILING TOOLS OF THE WRITER'S CRAFT
description: Some years ago the English poet Robert Graves came to New York to give a reading of his poetry. Graves commanded a considerable following in those days. His copious volumes of poetry and prose seemed to pour from the presses in an unabated profusion, and for many readers ''The White Goddess,'' in which he professed to reveal the secret springs of poetry itself, had become a sacred book. His appearance in New York was therefore something of an event - and all the more so, of course, because Graves then had the reputation of a man who had more or less withdrawn from the exigencies of modern civilization.

title: Leslie Smith Is Engaged to Dale Florio
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Smith of Bethlehem, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Susan Smith to Dale Joseph Florio, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph N. Florio of Somerville, N.J.

title: EASED RULES ON ENERGY-USE SURVEYS OPPOSED
description: Spokesmen for two utilities predict that there will be no immediate savings, only confusion, if the Department of Energy eases its requirements for surveys of residential energy use that are provided by utilities.

title: HOW 3 YOUNG MEN GOT INTO TROUBLE
description: AMONG the young people incarcerated in Yardville is 18-year-old Jack, who was involved in a fatal holdup. Jack (not his real name) is one of 10 children of parents who were divorced when he was a baby. His mother is on welfare and he dropped out of school in the ninth grade, when he was 17.

title: Long Island Guide; FLYING HIGH
description: If kites fascinate you, either as art or craft, there are two opportunities today to indulge your fancy. At the Nassau County Center for the Fine Arts off Northern Boulevard in Roslyn Harbor at 1:30 P.M., William Tyrrell Jr., winner of the world's record for weight-lifting with a kite - he once sent a tow truck soaring via one of his creations - will tell how it's done and, just incidentally, lecture on other award winners and the dynamics of this craft. Then, in East Islip, at the Islip Town Art Center and Gallery at 50 Irish Lane at 2:30 P.M. - to round out its current exhibition, ''Art on a String,'' which closes Friday - the gallery will give Creighton Wirick, one of the exhibitors, the chance to discuss the artistic and artistic aspects of kite design. Each session is free, and, perhaps, if you pick up enough pointers from Mr. Tyrrell - and the winds are right - you can catch both.

title: NARCISO YEPES AND HIS 10-STRING GUITAR
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians. By ALLAN KOZINN

title: SAVING LIVES BY BEING THERE
description: IN A large Union County town, a 50-year-old man lies motionless on the floor of a tobacco shop, his skin ashen, his lips blue. A clerk from the store kneels beside the fallen customer, rhythmically compressing his chest. In the distance, an ambulance siren wails.

title: SOLVENT SYRACUSE AN ENVY TO SOME CITIES
description: This aging canal city between the Great Lakes and the Hudson River has problems with slums, crime and unemployment, but one issue that did not arise in this month's mayoral election was municipal bankruptcy.

title: Marian Levin Is Married
description: Marian Levin, widow of Dr. Cyril N. Levin, was married yesterday to Jerome S. Tally, president of the Stahlwood Toy Manufacturing Company in New York. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg of Temple Rodelph Sholem performed the ceremony at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel. The bride, director of occupational therapy at the Morningside House Nursing Home in the Bronx, has three children. Mr. Tally's first wife died and he has two daughters.

title: BEDFORD WEIGHS ARMED PRIVATE GUARDS
description: BEDFORD SOME residents of this northern Westchester town, evidently concerned about crime, are exploring the idea of hiring armed private guards to patrol their local roads, supplementing the town police.

title: Syracuse 27, W. Va. 24
description: SYRACUSE (AP) - Gary Anderson kicked two fourth-quarter field goals, and Joe Morris rushed for 168 yards and two touchdowns in the last game of his record-setting career as Syracuse upset Peach Bowlbound West Virginia.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 22, 1981
description: International A new phase in U.S.-Soviet relations that will be marked less by polemics and more by concrete discussions of arms control and other issues is expected by the Reagan Administration, and it has told the allied governments of the prospective change. In briefings for diplomats and journalists, the Administration has stressed that it believes there are good chances for progress in Soviet-American relations in specific areas. (Page 1, Cols. 4-5.) A huge iron cage in a Cairo courtroom held 23 of the 24 Moslem fundamentialists on the opening day of their military trial on charges of murder and conspiracy in the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat on Oct. 6. One of the defendants is in a hospital. Four are charged specifically with murdering Mr. Sadat. (17:1.)

title: Ideas and Trends; 'Mad' Scientist Gets Her Due
description: In a field of many bright new winners, it was a long-ignored contender who got the laurel crown. Dr. Barbara McClintock, a 79-year-old geneticist whose research waited 30 years for recognition, last week became both the first Prize Fellow Laureate of Chicago's MacArthur Foundation and the recipient of the Albert Lasker Basic Medical Research Award.

title: Hilary Neal Cole To Marry Feb. 20
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Hamilton Cole of Chappaqua and Lake Placid, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hilary Neal Cole, to Patrick Richard McDonald, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Taillon McDonald of Seven Hills, Ohio.

title: Tourist With Gun Arrested
description: White House guards arrested a 41-year-old Texan today when he tried to check a .22-caliber pistol at the gate before taking a tour, Mark Weinberg, an assistant White House press secretary, said. The man was identified as Lawrence Sheldon Chess of Houston.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Boston University 38 Northeastern 0
description: Boston University, led by the sophomore linebacker Tom Krasco, held Northeastern to 5 yards rushing and 26 yards passing.

title: Topics; CONSCIOUSNESS RAISED; The $134,000 Baby
description: You can buy a car without a tape deck, a television set without remote control and a bathtub without a Jacuzzi. But no-frills children are not possible.

title: STATE'S DISPUTE WITH TENANT STALLS ATOMIC DUMP CLEANUP
description: A bitter landlord-tenant dispute has delayed the start of the estimated $300 million cleanup of the West Valley, N.Y., nuclear waste storage site.

title: PITT IN SUGAR BOWL AFTER ROMPING, 35-0
description: Pittsburgh, undefeated and ranked No. 1 in the nation, today accepted a bid to meet Georgia in the Sugar Bowl Jan. 1, after Dan Marino had thrown four touchdown passes and led the Panthers to a 35-0 victory over Temple at Veterans Stadium.

title: CULINARY WAY TO SAVE AFRICAN WILDLIFE OFFERED
description: Some of the exotic wild animals that have drawn tourists to Africa for generations may soon be slaughtered and served up on hotel dinner plates under a proposal that a veteran African researcher believes will help save some species from extinction.

title: A FEAST AT THE FIRESIDE
description: MYSTIC SCENTS of nutmeg, cinnamon and apple have been wafting through the November air the last two Monday mornings near the Buckingham House at Mystic Seaport Museum.

title: PENN STATE OVERTAKES NOTRE DAME, 24-21
description: Penn State rallied in the final minutes to defeat Notre Dame, 24-21, today, and afterward accepted a bid to meet Southern California New Year's Day in the Fiesta Bowl.

title: 'BODY AND SOUL,' REMAKE OF RING SAGA
description: ''Body and Soul,'' which opened Friday at the Loew's State and other theaters, is only a passable remake of the old John Garfield boxing saga. But at least it's one of the few reasonably entertaining movies to be directed toward black audiences lately. Leon Isaac Kennedy (who also wrote the screenplay) and Jayne Kennedy star as a fast-rising young boxer and the very nice woman who believes in him, with a supporting cast that includes Peter Lawford as a high roller who tries to fix Mr. Kennedy's big fight, and Muhammad Ali as, well, Muhammad Ali.

title: WRITERS ORGANIZING ON ISSUES, WORRIES
description: LAST Columbus Day, while sensible people were either marching up Fifth Avenue, watching others do so or running off to New England to enjoy exquisite color, I was in Manhattan attending the best professional meeting of my life, the American Writers Congress.

title: REPORT TELLS OF MALNUTRITION IN 27 DEER SLAIN IN HARRIMAN
description: A report by two state wildlife biologists on the physical condition of the deer killed this week in Harriman State Park - before a court temporarily stopped the hunting - said all showed signs of ''an extremely malnourished population.''

title: STATE GROUP MOVES TO COMBAT RACISM
description: HARTFORD RECENT membership drives by the Ku Klux Klan, cross burnings and other seemingly racist acts have prompted a campaign by state and local officials to combat what Lieut. Gov. Joseph Fauliso has called a ''rebirth of racism and discrimination.''

title: HOW TWO ENGLISH ACTORS DISPLAY THEIR ART OF INTERACTION
description: It is not necessary that actors like one another when they work together. Fear and loathing are tolerable in small amounts. Friendship, however, is better, and trust is even better than that. In trust, there is no upstaging; there is no stepping on another actor's lines. One reason ''The Dresser'' works so well is that Tom Courtenay and Paul Rogers are friends. They exchange valentines. They turn the play by Ronald Harwood at the Brooks Atkinson Theater into an actors' celebration, or even a kind of sport. You may think of what they do, in fact, as something of a game.

title: 2-1 Viva Sec Takes Sprint
description: In a race that was not decided until the final strides, Viva Sec won by a head from the favored Sweet Revenge in the $56,000 Dark Mirage Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. The two 3-year-old fillies dueled the length of the stretch.

title: SLOW BURN IN CENTRALIA, PA.
description: Sally Kalson is a freelance writer who lives in Pittsburgh. By Sally Kalson t was late October and, in the tiny Appalachian coal town of Centralia, Pa., a fitting day for a demolition - cold, wet and penetrating in its dreariness. The Chapman house, a two-story frame building that had stood overlooking the town for more than a century, now pitched heavily to one side and hung there, poised to topple. For the town residents who straggled by, it was a grim scene, made even grimmer by the surrounding bare trees that had recently gone out in a blaze of autumnal glory. To these miners and descendants of miners, the once-sturdy structure, suspended at the point of collapse, was an all too vivid symbol of Centralia's predicament.

title: SALVADOR LIMPS ON WITH AID FROM U.S.
description: Hoping to bolster the Salvadoran Government, the United States doubled its economic aid to El Salvador during the last two years and is considering another substantial increase in 1982.

title: ALLEN INQUIRY STRIPS WHITE HOUSE GEARS
description: Confronting reporters on his front lawn Friday morning, Richard V. Allen, the White House national security adviser, denied that the President's top aides had ordered him to review his office records and report to them on his contacts with Japanese businessmen. By mid-day White House officials were confirming the accuracy of The New York Times's report.

title: GROUP SEEKS TO BUY NEIGHBOR'S LAND
description: SOUTHAMPTON IN an attempt to maintain the character of the neighboring property, a group of Southampton homeowners are seeking to buy a tract of adjoining vacant land and donate it to an organization created to preserve farmland.

title: U.N. Vote Supports P.L.O.
description: The General Assembly's Economic Committee passed a resolution Friday calling for continued United Nations aid to the Palestinian people in cooperation with the Palestine Liberation Organization. The vote was 112 to 2, with 21 abstentions. The United States and Israel voted against it.

title: Dayton 19, Augustana 7
description: The fullback Chris Papas opened Dayton's three-touchdown performance with a 50-yard run in the first period.

title: LONG RUN WINS FOR MONTCLAIR
description: Montclair State advanced to the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III football championship today by defeating Alfred, 13-12, before 3,224 fans at Merrill Field.

title: WITNESS TESTIFIES IN JERSEY BRIBERY
description: The Federal trial of Mayor William V. Musto of Union City, N.J., and seven co-defendants on racketeering and extortion charges has opened with the Government's key witness testifying that he had paid them more than $400,000 in bribes and kickbacks on construction projects in Union City.

title: Bulls 117, Bullets 105
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Artis Gilmore scored 23 points and Ricky Sobers 21 as Chicago broke a four-game losing streak and Washington lost its fourth straight game.

title: A RUSH TO BATTEN DOWN THE HATCHES
description: ALONG about now begins the annual event called Getting Ready for Winter. Ideally, it comes after the last leaves have shivered off the trees, but before the first snowflakes fall; usually it is a lastminute, panicked rush to ''batten down the hatches'' before they come down on our heads.

title: AMERICA'S DEBUT IN OFFSHORE BANKING
description: LESS than two weeks from now, on Dec. 3, the banks of New York City will be allowed to establish special accounts through which they may do a great deal more business with foreign customers. The opening of New York as a free banking zone will not be an event that will involve laying cornerstones or stringing up bunting. It may mean no more than a few thousand new jobs, and consumers and most American companies will feel no effects of it. The banks, for the most part, will only change some signs on office doors to read, ''International Banking Facility.''

title: DALI UNTANGLES HIS LIFE
description: James M. Markham is chief of the Madrid bureau of The Times. By James M. Markham s in the old days, Salvador Dali raised the glass of pink champagne in a toast to his wife. His guests on the high terrace joined him, lifting their glasses in unison. An autumn moon bathed the tranquil Mediterranean setting. ''To Gala,'' intoned the aging Surrealist, shuffling across the flat stones to the woman he has exalted in oils, drawings and countless aphorisms. The aging couple pecked at each other's lips. Dali's right hand, trembling violently, betrayed him. The champagne sloshed over his gold-embroidered silk robe. He surrendered his glass to a friend.

title: Topics Consciousness Raised Rights and Wrongs
description: Just as Arthur Flemming, chairman of the Civil Rights Commission held a news conference the other day to discuss a commission study criticizing the nation's failure to achieve school integration, the White House abruptly issued some bad news for Mr. Flemming. He is to be replaced by Clarence Pendleton, a black who heads the San Diego Urban League and who shares Mr. Reagan's negative views of affirmative action and busing.

title: ST. JOSEPH'S TRIUMPHS, 7-6
description: St. Joseph's won its second Metropolitan Bridgeport Interscholastic Athletic Conference championship by posting a 7-6 victory over Fairfield Prep at Bridgeport's Kennedy Stadium yesterday.

title: SHEPKO OF LAFAYETTE HELPS UPSET LEHIGH
description: An 8-yard run by the halfback Rodger Shepko in the fourth quarter produced the only touchdown today as Lafayette upset Lehigh, 10-3, before 19,414 fans in Taylor Stadium.

title: 'THE BLESSINGS THAT HAVE BEEN OUR COMMON LOT'
description: GUBERNATORIAL proclamations, as a rule, can claim only a short life and a modest readership. But in Connecticut the approach of Thanksgiving Day brings to mind for many residents the moving Thanksgiving Day proclamation issued in 1936 by the state's scholarly Governor, the late Wilbur L. Cross.

title: Britain's New Look at The Irish Question
description: According to William Borders's excellent article, ''Britain's New Look at the Irish Question'' (Oct. 11), the English find it ''un-British'' to have people starving themselves to death in protest of British occupation of their land. How unfortunate that more than 10 years of this occupation and of suspended civil rights and trial without jury were not also found to be un-British. Do these conditions have some basis in Magna Carta? PATRICIA DOWNEY, Hampton Bays, L.I.

title: 2 Killed in Bus-Car Collision
description: A bus returning from Atlantic City collided with a car on a steep hill Friday night, killing the two teen-agers in the car and injuring three persons on the bus, the authorities said. The victims were identified as Joseph A. Bail, 18 years old, of Brookhaven, and Laura L. Watts, 17, of Media.

title: COS COB SPELLS TROUBLE FOR 40,000 COMMUTERS
description: When trouble rides the rails of the New Haven commuter line, it tends to get on at Cos Cob. For 40,000 daily Conrail commuters in Connecticut and Westchester, the two little words, designating the line's power source, stand for missed meetings, burned dinners and angry spouses.

title: TV View; CONGRESS- A WHALE OF A SHOW
description: When it comes to television access, Congress cannot compete with the clout of the Presidency. Although the two governmental branches, along with the Judiciary, are equal in carefully spelled out Constitutional terms, the President is the superstar, the dominating public image, who can get national exposure on all three networks, not to mention cable, virtually whenever he decides to call a press conference or deliver an address. No member of Congress wields that kind of power. In addition, television's coverage of Capitol Hill tends to be sketchy, often reduced to brief reports summarizing the day's developments. Occasionally, a House or Senate committee will be taped for broadcast if the subject under review is generating headlines in the print press, and then viewers will get a glimpse of a legislator - the telegenic Senator Edward Kennedy, whenever possible - in confrontation with an expert witness.

title: Headliners Hinckley's Second Attempt
description: Having failed in May to relieve the pain of his existence with an overdose of Tylenol, John W. Hinckley Jr. tried again last week, this time by hanging himself in his prison cell. Mr. Hinckley, who has pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity to charges of shooting President Reagan and three other men March 30, was said to be ''alert, awake and functioning well mentally'' after guards cut him down. Meanwhile, a Federal District Court judge ruled that Federal investigators had violated his rights when they questioned him after his arrest. 10 Million Twinkies, Please

title: Lakers Are Gearing Up to Play 'Showtime' Basketball Again
description: Earvin (Magic) Johnson was not looking forward to the inevitable unmagical moment. It was Friday night, party night in Los Angeles, and it was an hour before the Lakers were to face the San Antonio Spurs before a capacity crowd here at the Forum.

title: Indiana 20, Purdue 17
description: Doug Smith's 39-yard field goal with 8:30 remaining snapped a 17-17 tie, then Indiana's defense stopped two Purdue drives with interceptions in the Old Oaken Bucket game. The Boilermakers came from a 17-7 halftime deficit to tie the score on a 34-yard field goal by Tim Clark in the third quarter and a 5-yard touchdown run by Bruce King in the fourth.

title: WRITING ROMANCES IS A FAMILY EFFORT
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE THE first writing project on which Lillian Koppel and her daughter Shelley collaborated was a book report on ''Heidi'' in the third grade. Mrs. Koppel made her daughter rewrite the essay four times, until the prose was razor sharp. ''I still haven't forgiven her,'' said Shelley Koppel, who is now 30 years old and teaches writing at New York City Technical College in Brooklyn.

title: Travel Advisory; HOLIDAY LIGHTS, FREE STOPOVERS; Niagara Falls Lights Up For Christmas
description: The people of Niagara Falls are turning their city into a kind of gigantic light show for the holidays. Twenty-five thousand lights on trees, buildings and huge cutout displays will turn the downtown section - two blocks from the falls - into a winter wonderland when the city's five-week Festival of Lights begins on Saturday.

title: Joint Governorship Proposed for the State
description: With the gubernatorial election so close, it is a shame to deny either candidate the fruits of victory. Why not have a joint administration?

title: THE UNFRIENDLY SKIES OF UNITED
description: JO ANN ALLEN-WADE, a flight attendant, struggled against the sea of passengers getting off the United Airlines flight at New York's La Guardia Airport from Cleveland. Boarding the plane, a Boeing 737, she threw her bags into one of the luggage compartments, quickly removed two plastic bags of garbage from the galley, checked it for supplies, and then looked down the aisle. ''There's no time do anything about that,'' she said, gesturing at some dirt on the carpet. The first of 91 new passengers were beginning to board. Mrs. Allen-Wade braced herself, then took each ticket with a ''thank you'' and tried to keep the line moving steadily.

title: Widener 10, West Georgia 3
description: Bobby Cole connected on a 35-yard scoring pass to Tom Kincade on Widener's first possession and, despite seven turnovers, the Pioneers held on.

title: Miami 14, N.C. State 6
description: Jim Kelly hit Mark Rush with two touchdown passes in the first four and a half minutes, and Miami held on to win.

title: HEARINGS END ON WESTCHESTER SHERIFF'S OUSTER
description: The five-month-long administrative hearings on Westchester County's top police official, who was suspended last February on charges of misconduct, ended Fiday, but it may take nearly as long for him to learn his fate.

title: The Nation; Panels Endorse Jets for Pakistan
description: Although a $3.2 billion package of aid for Pakistan is stalled on Capitol Hill, the Administration, barring a last-minute hitch, will sell Islamabad 40 advanced fighter planes. In separate votes last week, the House and Senate foreign relations committees rejected resolutions opposing the proposed sale of F-16 aircraft.

title: DISCUSSION PLANNED ON REGENTS ORDER
description: IN an effort to reduce the growing number of students who leave high school before graduating, the New York State Board of Regents has established a ''dropout limit'' of 10 percent, which became effective on Sept. 27.

title: The World; Poland Gets Down to Business
description: Winter's looming chill - and the prospect of Poles going hungry as well as cold - turned on the heat under Government-Solidarity negotiations last week. Two days of talks, the first on key economic and political questions since Aug. 29, produced agreement on an agenda for further discussions this week.

title: The Route Traveled To Greet Eisenhower
description: Irene and Lester David, authors of ''Ike & Mamie'' (''Matrimonial Ties in Peace and War,'' Long Islanders, Oct. 18), are to be encouraged in their joint writing efforts and their ''equally divided'' research work. However, they should take nothing for granted. Mr. David ought to have checked out his wife's personal recollection of rushing by taxi all the way out to Idlewild to cover the return of General Eisenhower.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: JUDGE AS STATESMAN, JUDGE AS POL
description: JUDGING JUDGES The Investigation of Rose Bird and the California Supreme Court. By Preble Stolz. Illustrated. 453 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Gibson. (Atheneum, $30.) The first part of a projected two-volume biography of the American playwright.

title: THEATER: 'SHOP' AT THE FOLKSBIENE
description: That splendid and durable company, the Folksbiene Playhouse, is offering in its 67th season, on East 55th Street, a play that should ring bells of reminiscence for New York's Jewish community. This Yiddish production of ''Shop'' is by H. Leivick, a poet and playwright whose feeling of social concern for the exploited and for the individual in a cruel society makes him a sort of forebear of Clifford Odets.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Laura Hamilton Plays Mozart Violin Sonata
description: If raw passion counts for anything, Laura Hamilton's afternoon of violin music at Carnegie Recital Hall Nov. 14 scored quite a few points. From the Mozart F major Sonata which began her program to Sarasate's ''Zigeunerweisen'' at its end, Miss Hamilton threw herself into her work.

title: Hawks 107, Pacers 100
description: ATLANTA (UPI) - Dan Roundfield scored 27 points, grabbed 11 rebounds and blocked four shots for Atlanta, which won its third straight game.

title: The Nation; Labor Tries Out Themes for '84
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O held what it called American labor's centennial last week, in the form of its biennial convention - the first such in New York City in 18 years and to which, in a break with tradition, the President of the United States was not invited.

title: 6 CIVIL SERVANTS WIN THE CITY'S 'NOBEL PRIZE'
description: Eight years ago Anthony Alvarado, a 30-year-old assistant principal at an elementary school in the Bronx, was chosen to become superintendant of District 4 in East Harlem, where all 21 schools were doing poorly by most measures of educational effectiveness.

title: Dance View; SCHAUFUSS'S BOURNONVILLE IN CANADA
description: TORONTO 'Tis the season to do ''Napoli.'' Denmark's favorite ballet by its favorite 19th-century choreographer, August Bournonville, is suddenly being staged by companies in Scotland, Sweden and even the Soviet Union, where Elsa Marianne von Rosen has supervised the first Russian production of ''Napoli,'' at the Kirov. Just this month, the National Ballet of Canada has presented a version in Toronto by Peter Schaufuss, the first full-length production of this 1842 ballet by a North American company.

title: JOFFREY: MASSINE 'PARADE'
