description: By placing Leonide Massine's ''Parade'' on its Tuesday-night program at the City Center-55th Street Theater, along with repetitions of ''Momentum,'' ''Deuce Coupe II'' and ''La Vivandiere,'' the Joffrey Ballet revealed much about its artistic policy.

title: Food; FISH: A TIMESAVER AND CHANGE FROM THE RICH FALL DISHES
description: FISH is one of the best dishes for small autumn dinners and a pleasant change from rich fall stews and game dishes. Endless experiment and discovery is possible - there is much on the market besides sole and flounder. The appealing thing about many fish dishes is their simplicity. They can be made at the last minute and don't require much in the way of preparation.

title: Crime
description: Call Eric Bercovici's SO LITTLE CAUSE FOR CAROLINE (Atheneum, $10.95) a private-eye novel, even though the hero is not a private eye. He is an ex-cop who drinks too much in order to forget the tragedy of his private life. But the owner of a casino in Nevada needs help fast, and Harold Shilling is called in to find a missing wife. It seems that old friends in the San Diego Police Department still remember him as a good, tough, incorruptible cop.

title: LONDON
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Conditions; FOREIGN INVESTMENT UP
description: Rising political uncertainty abroad has intensified direct foreign investment in the United States. And, according to a new study of foreign investment in manufacturing companies, West Germany now has interests in more American manufacturing plants than any other foreign country.

title: LEARNING HOW TO BUILD A HOME
description: MANY people have engaged in such ''family projects'' as building a dog house or a bird feeder, but it is not often that one encounters a family with as big a project as the Michells of Lewisboro. They built their own three-bedroom house, with the aid of a few experts and some friends.

title: Mr. Reagan's Other Cheek
description: Until last week, the Reagan Administration's foreign policy was little more than a booming weapons business. Outproducing the Russians was going to make them more docile, or broke. Selling the Arabs more arms would win security for Israel. Replacing Soviet arms with ours in Central America would pacify revolutions. Selling arms to Pakistan would keep it non-nuclear. Even the nostalgia for a ''two-Chinas'' policy would be served by sending weapons - to both.

title: Around the World; Gains Against Insurgents Reported in Afghanistan
description: A report from the Afghan capital, Kabul, said today that Soviet and Afghan troops had seized rebel strongholds in the Paghman mountains northwest of the city, killing or wounding more than 100 insurgents.

title: Illinois 49, Northwestern 12
description: Tony Eason threw three touchdown passes to give him a Big Ten season mark of 20 and lead Illinois over Northwestern, which extended its record losing streak to 31 games. Eason completed 27 of 48 passes for 409 yards, setting season Big Ten records in completions with 211 and in passing yardage with 3,360 yards to break the mark of 3,212 set by Mark Herrmann of Purdue. Northwestern lost its 35th straight Big Ten game.

title: A CLASS FOCUSES ON THE HYPERACTIVE
description: STONY BROOK EIGHT children in the second and third grades, all of whom have been diagnosed as hyperactive, applied themselves diligently to their work in the small classroom in the Point of Woods Laboratory School, which occupies a ranch house at the State University here. As work progressed smoothly, the teacher, Glen Conway, praised the students individually and collectively at frequent intervals. He complimented the class repeatedly, saying:

title: Best Sellers
description: Jx FICTION 1 1 5 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 2 2 10 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with an eccentric family. 3 3 15 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 4 4 29 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A British-Chinese struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 5 5 7 THE LEGACY, by Howard Fast. (Houghton Mifflin, $14.95.) The Lavette family of ''The Immigrants'' and ''The Establishment'' reaches the turbulent 60's. 6 6 5 RABBIT IS RICH, by John Updike. (Knopf, $13.95.) Harry Angstrom of ''Rabbit, Run'' returns in the chips but unfulfilled. 7 7 22 THE CARDINAL SINS, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner/Bernard Geis, $12.95.) The triumphs and tragedies of two Chicago boys as priests in the Catholic Church.

title: Susanne Lilly, Bank Trainee, Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. David M. Lilly of St. Paul and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susanne Brown Lilly, to Zenas Willard Hutcheson 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Hutcheson Jr. of Andrews, Tex.

title: Behind the Best Sellers: Howard Fast
description: Howard Fast and Bette, his wife of 44 years, moved back to Connecticut from California last year because - as he puts it - ''my wife wanted to and because I'm very fond of her.'' He still misses California, though, and it is easy to understand why. It is the setting for his hugely successful multivolume saga of the Lavette family, the fourth volume of which, ''The Legacy,'' is No. 5 on this week's fiction best-seller list.

title: FOLKSY CHARACTERS
description: TRAILERPARK By Russell Banks. 242 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $11.95. By IVAN GOLD

title: S.M.U. 32, Arkansas 18
description: Southern Methodist's defense scored a touchdown and set up another by intercepting two passes as the Mustangs rallied to beat Arkansas and win their first Southwest Conference championship in 15 years. Craig James's 10-yard run with 6:30 left put the Mustangs on top by 25-18.

title: STOCKMAN APPEARS ON CAPITOL HILL
description: For the first time since being rebuked by President Reagan for expressing doubts about the Administration's fiscal program, David A. Stockman returned to Capitol Hill today to help Congress devise a stopgap spending bill acceptable to the President.

title: No Headline
description: Because of a cancellation by the pianist Ilana Vered, a picture caption in the Arts and Leisure section and a classical-music listing in The Guide are incorrect today. The pianist performing with the cellist Simca Heled on Tuesday at 2 P.M. at Goodman House will be Daniel Blumenthal.

title: Miss Welch Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. G. Harold Welch Jr. of Hamden, Conn., and Ludlow, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Kimberly Welch, to Robert Frank Taugner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Taugner of Grosse Pointe, Mich.

title: LONDON
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: The Question of Sex Bias At Harvard
description: Fran Schumer's article inspires several thoughts: The injustice and arrogance of some entrenched, tenured members of faculties is exceeded only by their hypocrisy. Second, the sooner lifetime tenure, a relic of medievalism, is rooted out of American universities, the better they will be.

title: The Nation; In Congress, More Bucks For the Bang
description: Capitol Hill seems dead set on making it an early Christmas for the Pentagon. Any attempt to balance the budget on the back of the military -talked of by Democrats and some Republicans just a few weeks ago -evaporated last week.

title: Drs. Lori Jalens and William Sternheim Affianced
description: Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Jalens of Hollis Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Lori June Jalens, to Dr. William Leavitt Sternheim, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald E. Sternheim of Baldwin, L. I.

title: WHY INVESTORS IN BROADWAY HITS ARE OFTEN LOSERS
description: From the box office, Broadway has never looked better. Receipts for the 1980-81 season soared to a record $194 million - a figure that reflects swollen ticket prices, admittedly, but also the throngs of people who are willing to pay them; attendance also climbed, to a record 11 million. So surely Broadway's backers are enjoying record windfalls, right?

title: Kansas 19, Missouri 11
description: Roger Foote, who intercepted two passes, returned one 27 yards for a touchdown and helped Kansas stop Missouri. Kansas ended the season with an 8-3 record. Missouri, headed for the Tangerine Bowl against Southern Mississippi Dec. 19, dropped to 7-4.

title: KHEEL DROPPING THE LIBEL SUIT ABAINST MURDOCH
description: Rupert Murdoch, the owner of New York magazine, has moved to settle a libel suit against him by acknowledging that the publication's 1979 article questioning the business dealings of Theodore W. Kheel, the labor lawyer, had been ''inappropriate.''

title: Coghlan Is Winner in Cross-Country
description: Running on his 29th birthday, Eamonn Coghlan passed Henry Rono of Kenya in the final 75 yards yesterday to win the second New York Road Runners Club International invitation cross-country meet at Belmont Park.

title: WARHOL HAS PLANS FOR SUBSTATION
description: Andy Warhol has bought an old Consolidated Edison substation on Madison Avenue, and will move his ''factory'' there from a rented loft in Union Square.

title: Capitals 10, Flyers 4
description: Tim Tookey and Dennis Maruk scored three goals each as Washington scored its third straight triumph. Greg Theberge scored two goals to help Washington to its highest scoring game ever.

title: Many Participated
description: To the Editor:

title: UCONN BEHIND PRIVATE SCHOOLS IN ATTRACTING MINORITIES
description: MORE than a decade after the launching of programs to enroll minority students, many of the state's private institutions have considerably higher percentages of black and Hispanic students than does the University of Connecticut.

title: CUBANS ALTER HUDSON POLITICS
description: UNION CITY IN Flamen Gonzalez's liquor store on Bergenline Avenue in the heart of the shopping district here, a picture of Ronald Reagan is displayed prominently behind the cash register.

title: Sabbaticals
description: To the Business Editor: I would like to clarify something you said in ''Capital Sabbatical'' (Oct. 25), about the President's Commission on Executive Exchange. I refer to the statement that ''private sector employers, however, often make up the difference'' when a business executive, participating in the program, takes a loss in salary.

title: Q&A
description: Question:Can you give me information about rail service and the highway between San Jose, Costa Rica and Panama City, Panama? - D.A., Hendersonville, N.C. Answer:There is no rail line between San Jose and Panama City. The Pan American Highway (Carretera Interamericana) between San Jose and Panama City is two lanes, with the exception of ''super-highway'' strips around the capital cities and in the beach resort region near Rio Hato and San Carlos in Panama.

title: ISLANDERS WIN, 4-3, ON POTVIN'S 2D GOAL
description: Denis Potvin found some unusual ways to score tonight, and his two goals helped the Islanders defeat the Rangers, 4-3, at Nassau Coliseum.

title: The World; Concern Rises Over Situation in Central America
description: Washington sent a variety of signals to Central America last week, but they shared a single wave length of concern about the explosive potential in the region.

title: YALE WINS, TIES FOR IVY TITLE
description: The Yale football team, whose reach for an undefeated season was thwarted by Princeton a week ago, came down hard on Harvard today at Yale Bowl. The Elis trounced the Crimson, 28-0, and won a share of the Ivy League championship with Dartmouth.

title: GOVERNOR O'NEILL PUT IN HOSPITAL AFTER SUFFERING MILD HEART ATTACK
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill suffered a mild heart attack Thursday or Friday and was admitted to St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center at about 9:30 P.M. Friday for tests, his doctor said today.

title: Around the World; Pope Bids Bishops Help Italy's Earthquake Zone
description: Pope John Paul II urged 35 bishops from southern Italy today to lead the way in the reconstruction of their region, which was devastated by a a major earthquake a year ago.

title: MOSCOW SAYS U.S. DECEIVES ON ARMS
description: The Soviet Union, in a new attack on President Reagan's arms reduction plan, said today that his purpose was to hoodwink Western European opinion into accepting new American missiles.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: PERSON AMERICA, edited by Ann Banks. (Vintage, $5.95.) From the thousands of personal interviews that the Federal Writers' Project conducted with older Americans between 1938 and 1942, Ann Banks has collected 80 that describe what life was like in this country early in this century. The interviewees range from a North Carolina patent-medicine pitchman to Chicago musicians. Our reviewer Stanley Kauffmann observed that ''almost all are vivid and almost all cause astonishment.''

title: Catherine Hull to Be Bride Of John M. Lizzul, Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Hull of Bayside, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Anne Hull, to John Matthew Lizzul, son of Mr. and Mrs. Matteo Lizzul of Beechhurst, Queens.

title: Ankara Assembly Asks For Increase in Power
description: Turkey's 160-member consultative assembly, set up by the military junta to lay the legislative groundwork for an eventual return to democracy, has surprised the Government with demands that it be given more power.

title: Olivia Larisch Wed to Warren Hogue
description: Olivia Larisch, daughter of Count Johann Larisch of Marbella, Spain, and the late Countess Wilhelmine Larisch, was married yesterday to Warren M. Hoge, bureau chief of The New York Times in Rio de Janeiro. The Rev. William DeWitt Mosely of the International Baptist Church performed the ceremony in the home of Mr. and Mrs. Olavo Monteiro de Carvalho in Rio de Janeiro. Mr. de Carvalho is a stepbrother of the bride.

title: A VOICE FOR DESIGN WIDENS RANGE
description: She's one of the new bi-coastal people; her salary is in six figures and her presence at fashionable dinner parties across the country is considered a plus for any hostess. She's bouncy, verges on being cuddly looking, and the blue-gray eyes behind the tinted glasses blaze with enthusiasm. At 48, the woman who has been called the archduchess of decorating is supremely self-confident, knows exactly where she's going, enjoys her newly minted celebrity but looks at it with an amused eye. Paige Rense, despite the currently unfashionable high heels she favors, has her feet firmly planted on the ground.

title: JUVENILE JUSTICE SYSTEM: CRITICS SAY IT IS A FAILURE
description: NEW JERSEY'S juvenile justice system, long criticized by state and county corrections officials, prosecutors and the police, may undergo extensive changes if a package of five bills becomes law.

title: Maryland 48, Virginia 7
description: The tailback Charlie Wysocki, playing his final college game, ran for 153 yards and four touchdowns, and John Nash ran for 103 yards to pace the Terrapins. Maryland (4-6-1) finished its first losing season in 10 years.

title: JERSEY'S RISE IN VIOLENT CRIME EXCEEDED NATIONAL RISE IN '80
description: Reports of violent crime rose 21 percent in New Jersey in 1980, compared with 1979, much higher than the national increase of 13 percent, according to the state's Uniform Crime Report.

title: Around the Nation; 3 Convicted in Nashville In Plot Against Temple
description: A Federal jury today convicted two Ku Klux Klan members and a neo-Nazi of plotting to blow up a Jewish temple in what prosecutors called a ''bizarre'' scheme motivated by hatred and bigotry.

title: WOMEN'S NETWORKS COME OF AGE
description: Anna Quindlen writes the ''About New York'' column for The Times. By Anna Quindlen

title: PUBLIC LIBRARY SEEKS TO BUY APARTMENT FOR ITS PRESIDENT
description: The New York Public Library is looking for a cooperative apartment for its president. Until this year, the library let its presidents fend for themselves in finding living quarters. But earlier this year, after Vartan Gregorian was hired as president, the library began a search for a cooperative apartment that would go with the job.

title: QUAKE-PREDICTING WORRIES SCIENTISTS
description: A recurring fear is haunting some of the scientists who monitor the heaving and slipping of the faults that marble the earth's crust in California: Someday, they say, they will look down at a set of measurements and their experience and intuition will tell them that a major earthquake may be imminent. But they will not sound a warning that could save thousands of lives.

title: TRANSPORTATION: IT'S DECISION TIME
description: LESS than one full day after the State Senate confirmed Anne P. Canby as the new Commissioner of the state's Department of Transportation, she was officially introducing 61 long-awaited Grumman Flxible buses that would be put into service in the Newark area.

title: THE SEEDS OF TERROR
description: Lucinda Franks, a freelance writer and former Times reporter, covered the antiwar movement and won the l971 Pulitzer Prize for national reporting for a series written with Thomas Powers for United Press International. By Lucinda Franks

title: ARAFAT'S CHALLENGE, AS USUAL, IS TO PICK THE NEXT
description: WINNER By JOHN KIFNER

title: Investing; YOU JUST WON $5 MILLION. NOW WHAT?
description: L OUIS EISENBERG has a problem that a lot of people would like to have - how to invest a fortune. He was earning $225 a week as a lightbulb changer in a Manhattan office building when he learned he had won $5 million in the Nov. 14 New York State Lotto drawing, the largest recorded lottery payoff of all time. ''I don't have to wait for Reagan's 'trickle-down' now,'' Mr. Eisenberg said after the announcement.

title: Article 102290 -- No Title
description: Forty-eight nations have pledged more than $122 million to the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to continue its programs in 1982. The organization, which won the Nobel Peace Prize this year, has set a goal of $338 million.

title: HISTORICAL TOMB TO BE SPARED RAVAGES OF TIME
description: WALLINGFORD LYMAN HALL, a native of Connecticut who moved to Georgia and was a signer of the Declaration of Independence in 1776, is memorialized here with a tomb that is crumbling.

title: VENICE
description: To the Editor:

title: MINIMUSICAL VARIES THE CHAPIN'S SEASON
description: HUNTINGTON STATION THEATRICAL fads are often rooted in financial facts, and the bookless mini-musical has become one of them. With both levity and economic reality in mind, the Harry Chapin Theater Center's producer, Bill Thompson, looked around for a song-and-dance entertainment to balance a season of classical and dramatic plays, and to help diminish the deficit of a theater in bankruptcy.

title: NUCLEAR ARMS, BY THE NUMBERS
description: WASHINGTON WITH the Soviet-American talks on medium-range nuclear forces in Europe set to begin a week from tomorrow, the two sides find themselves far apart on what the present balance is and what forces should be counted in any agreement. Officials from East and West acknowledge there is no realistic prospect of accord until these basic issues are resolved.

title: ENVIRONMENTALISTS SEEK NEW FUNDS
description: EXPERTS in fund-raising and corporate gift-giving say it is doubtful that private foundations will take up the slack in Federal money coming to New Jersey for environmental and related matters, at least in the near future.

title: THE PRESIDENT AND MR. STOCKMAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Officials in Jersey Take Break in Vote Recount
description: Officials today took their first break in the massive task of recounting New Jersey's gubernatorial election vote, but will resume work Sunday in some counties, an official said.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an error in computer cod- ing, an incorrect entry appears today in the No. 9 position of the hardcover fiction best seller list in The Times Book Review. The books listed as No. 10 to No. 15 should each appear one position higher. The 15th book should be ''Spring Moon,'' by Bette Bao Lord (Harper & Row, $14.95).

title: Photography View; CINDY SHERMAN: A PLAYFUL AND POLITICAL POST-MODERNIST
description: When photography entered the discourse and marketplace of the art world in the 1970's it did so largely on the basis of its modernist momentum. Photographers took pains to stress their interest in the formal properties of their medium, investigating ''problems'' of time, tone, space and framing in the Bauhaus spirit of Moholy-Nagy. At about the same time, paradoxically, artists outside the photographic tradition were taking up the camera for radically different reasons. It was used to furnish visual documentation of relatively inaccessible or ephemeral art works, such as Robert Smithson's ''Spiral Jetty'' or Christo's ''Valley Curtain,'' or as a source of predigested imagery for certain representational painters, such as Chuck Close, or as a kind of shorthand notebook for Conceptual artists on the order of John Baldessari, Robert Cumming and William Wegman. In short, while photographers were involved with photographic form, artists in revolt against abstract and Minimalist art became enamored of photography for its content.

title: Bridge; ENTER BIG BROTHER
description: If the shade of George Orwell returns in 1984 to assess the accuracy of his predictions, he will have some cause for gloomy satisfaction: Most of the world is indeed ruled by ruthless and arbitrary dictatorships. Even in the Western democracies there has been some erosion of individual privacy.

title: TEXAS IN COTTON BOWL
description: Darryl Clark scored one touchdown and set up another to lead Texas to a 34-12 victory over Baylor today and a berth in the Cotton Bowl on New Year's Day against Alabama.

title: SOUTHERN STORIES
description: CAKEWALK By Lee Smith. 256 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam. $12.95.

title: TV Stereotypes
description: To the Business Editor: In Jan R. Van Meter's article, ''A Message for the Medium'' (Oct. 25), he offered some free advice on how to deal with special interest groups who threaten boycotts because they do not like television programs that companies sponsor.

title: A Correction
description: In the recipe for apple-walnut stuffing that appeared last week, the first line of Step 3 was inadvertently omitted. Step 3 is: Add remaining ingredients and mix well.

title: A SCHOLAR OF VISIONS
description: AUTOBIOGRAPHY Volume I: 1907-1937. Journey East, Journey West. By Mircea Eliade. Translated by Mac Linscott Ricketts. 335 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: WAR IS A VERY PRIVATE AGONY
description: To the Editor:

title: Nordiques 7, Whalers 3
description: QUEBEC (UPI) - Miroslav Frycer scored two goals and made one assist for Quebec, which extended its winning streak to four games.

title: CITY TO ADD 600 POLICE OFFICERS AS LOSSES OUTSPACE ESTIMATES
description: The New York City Police Department is planning to add an extra 600 officers to the force in January to offset personnel losses that exceeded earlier expectations.

title: NAPA VALLEY HIGH
description: From any vantage point at any season, there are few places more beautiful than northern California's wine country, the vine-covered Napa Valley. But seen from the gondola of a hot-air balloon floating over it like thistledown on the wind, in the bright promise of an autumn morning at harvest time, the valley is little short of supernal.

title: SCIENTISTS SAY A MILLION SPECIES ARE IN DANGER
description: The accelerating disappearance of the earth's species and the resulting shrinkage of its biological richness and diversity may be the crucial environmental issue for the rest of this century.

title: REAGAN REAFFIRMS DETERMINATION TO CUT FEDERAL AID EVEN FURTHER
description: President Reagan says he is concerned about the cries of economic hardship from state and local officials. But he remains determined to slash Federal aid programs even more in an effort to halt inflation and bring about a ''new federalism.''

title: Camera; TAKING FAMILY PICTURES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Fred Rosen and George Schaub and freelance writers and photographers. Pictures taken at a family gathering during the holiday season are an ideal method for preserving family history and making a permanent record of who we are and where we come from. Some may feel reluctant to bring their cameras, feeling they are imposing on people by asking them to pose, but it is important to take pictures of these unique moments for who knows if all the members of this year's gathering will be together again next year?

title: New York Political Notes
description: Governor Carey still has not announced his intentions for next year, but he has started fund-raising as if he will be a candidate for a third term.

title: New York Times Magazine November 22, 1981
description: William Safire 18 On Language Heavy Weather Russell Baker 30 Sunday Observer Cheap Heating Sources Lucinda Franks 34 The Seeds of Terror James M. Markham 60 Dali Untangles His Life Alan Riding 78 Panama: Troubled Passage for a U.S. Ally Anna Quindlen 82 Women's Networks Come of Age Andree Brooks 104 Preppies From Abroad Paul Hofmann 130 The Italian Art of Survival Harold C. Schonberg 142 Acoustics: Still Playing It by Ear Sally Kalson 155 Slow Burn in Centralia, Pa. Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: PROPOSED BUDGET IS UNDERGOING HEATED REVIEW
description: IT did not take very long last week for County Executive Alfred B. DelBello's proposed 1982 budget, with its 17 percent increase in the county portion of real estate taxes, to come under fire, from inside his government as well as from those affected outside. The clamor is expected to rise in coming weeks.

title: DO WE SUFFER FROM A FEMINIST MYSTIQUE?
description: THE SECOND STAGE By Betty Friedan. 344 pp. New York: Summit Books. $14.95.

title: BUILDERS WIDEN PURCHASE INCENTIVES IN SLOW MARKET
description: Jerry and Anne Mahl, until recently owners of a home in Rockland County, decided to try apartment living for a while. They sold their home and moved into a high-rise condominium in Secaucus, N.J., called Harmon Cove Towers where they are renting a two-bedroom duplex at $1,400 a month with an option to buy.

title: Art; CREATING BEAUTIFUL SHAPES THAT DANCE IN THE SKY
description: EAST ISLIP THE kite, mainly a child's toy, has had many practical uses over the centuries. In addition to serving as an airborne lightning rod for Benjamin Franklin, it has been pressed into service by the military for bombing and aerial surveillance and even for carrying archers into battle. Kites have been used by meteorologists in forecasting, and they provided prototypes for gliders and the earliest successful experiments in powered flight.

title: 76ERS WIN, 135-106, FOR 7TH IN A ROW
description: Julius Erving scored 21 of his gamehigh 32 points in the third quarter and the 76ers went on to defeat the Houston Rockets, 135-106, tonight for their seventh straight victory.

title: Painting by Noland Sets Record at Auction
description: Kenneth Noland's ''Empyrean'' sold on Thursday night at Sotheby Parke Bernet's Madison Avenue galleries for $300,000, the highest price ever paid at auction for the work of a living American artist. It was also a record for the artist and for a color-field painting.

title: WESLEYAN STUDENT A WHIZ AT JAI ALAI
description: BRIDGEPORT EMILIO SOTIL is a 21-year-old senior at Wesleyan University who is earning his tuition money, and then some, as a jai alai player at the Bridgeport fronton.

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE This is a week for quirks and special resonances. First of all, there's Harry, the modern dance company that serves as the instrument for Senta Driver's odd but intriguing choreographic ideas.

title: ACTIVISTS SWITCH TACTICS
description: THE Hartford headquarters of the Connecticut Citizen Action Group at 130 Washington Street appear at first glance to be part of an earlier era of protest and activism.

title: HUNTINGTON SEWERS DEBATED
description: WHILE Suffolk County is still trying to clean up the political pollution generated by the Southwest Sewer District scandal, the Town of Huntington is considering extensions to the sewer district in the northern part of the town. Elected officials are disassociating themselves from the proposal, but residents are registering concern.

title: REHIRING RETIREES
description: CHICAGO W HEN Deere & Company found itself with a sudden shortage of skilled engineers this summer, it called in Emil L. Gustafson, who had spent more than 30 years at its Harvester Works in Moline, Ill., before retiring three years ago.

title: About Westchester
description: AMONG his co-workers, John Maltzie is sometimes affectionately referred to as the Birdman. A slender, blond young man with a soft speaking voice and an engaging smile, he earned the nickname because of his interest in the behavior and habits of the chickens at Muscoot Park, a working, demonstration farm located in Somers and run by the County Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation.

title: Mailbox; Don't Stereotype
description: To the Sports Editor Much of the article, ''Soccer for Girls a Popular Game'' (The New York Times, Nov. 8, 1981), contained positive information about the growth of girls' soccer. The article ended on a negative note, though.

title: Business Conditions; THE LURE OF COGNAC
description: Cognac, the brandy distilled from wine in the Cognac region of France, is becoming increasingly popular in the United States. For the year ending Aug. 31, 23.5 million bottles of cognac were sold in the United States, up 48 percent from a year earlier, the French Bureau National du Cognac reports.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: THE COSMO REPORT By Linda Wolfe. 416 pp. New York: Arbor House. $14.75.

title: Elizabeth Defeats Barringer by 36-0
description: Elizabeth, led by Rodney Carter, scored a 36-0 victory over Barringer yesterday in a North Jersey, Section 2, Group 4 semifinal game at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford.

title: COLLEGE BOWL SCHEDULE
description: College Bowl Schedule INDEPENDENCE BOWL Okla. State (7-3) vs. Texas A & M (6-4) Shreveport, La. 8 P.M., Dec. 12 GARDEN STATE BOWL Wisconsin (7-4) vs.

title: Jets 1, Blues 1
description: ST. LOUIS (UPI) - Lucien DeBlois scored late in the third period to give Winnipeg the tie.

title: Chess; WISHFUL THINKING?
description: ''I see the pattern developing,'' said Bent Larsen, the Danish grandmaster. ''Kasparov always claims that he has a winning attack in post-game analysis sessions, but he is not willing to prove it with concrete variations.'' Larsen considers a lack of objectivity to be the prominent weak point in the play of Gari Kasparov, the brilliant 18-year-old Soviet grandmaster.

title: RUNNING AWAY FROM FANTASIES, AND TO REALITY
description: THE alarm rings out at 5:30 A.M. as I slowly crawl out of bed. In 15 minutes I'm ready and out the door to another dark and chilly morning. I'm cold and stiff as I round out of the apartment building I live in and out on the road to campus. It's pretty quiet out here as I run along the side roads that are nestled amongst the farms of the university. There aren't usually many cars out this way as one passes me. We go on past each other unnoticed as both my breath and steps are choppy as I run along into the darkness.

title: A Fire in Bedford-Stuyvesant Kills 2 Children in Brownstone
description: Two young sisters were killed and three other persons were seriously injured last night during a fire in a brownstone building in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Adding Up the 'Zero Option' Will Take Time
description: President Reagan last week made the offer to Moscow that Bonn, London and other European capitals had been waiting to hear. In a speech timed and beamed by satellite to catch Europe's evening news, Mr. Reagan said the United States was prepared to cancel plans to deploy new intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe if the Russians would dismantle comparable weapons trained on West European targets.

title: The Costakis Question
description: As a footnote to Hilton Kramer's article, in 1977, I attended the triennial congress of the International Council of Museums, in Leningrad and Moscow. One of the activities offered the 1,400 delegates was a reception at Moscow's Tretiakov Gallery.

title: Jodi Lee Perlmuth Is Wed
description: The marriage of Jodi Lee Perlmuth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Perlmuth of Penn Valley, Pa., to Garry Bruce Popofsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Popofsky of Merrick, L.I., took place yesterday. Rabbi Norman Kahan performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai in Roslyn, L.I.

title: DRUNKEN DRIVING FACES A NEMESIS
description: THE swerving traces of taillights, the squawking of police-band radios, the eerie reflections of flashing lights, the twisted wreckage, the innocent victim - these are some of the sights and sounds of Paul Cicarelli's Saturday-night world. For the last two years Mr. Cicarelli, a photojournalist, has risked his life and perhaps financial ruin to find out more about the Long Island drunken driver.

title: 'The Second Stage'
description: It is a commonplace that in most societies throughout history the division of household labor has corresponded to gender. Any society that attempts to change this pattern must be prepared to experience the turmoil that accompanies basic social reorganization. If significant groups within the society oppose this fundamental alteration of traditional sex roles, as they now do in the United States, the turmoil is likely to be exacerbated. Thus, it is not surprising that those who are trying to break the old pattern in their own lives should feel the tension most keenly. They are, after all, accurately perceived as threats to established ways, as agents provocateurs. But the strain extends as well to those whose comfortable habits are disturbed in the process.

title: Jamie G. Kantrowitz Wed To Mark B. Lorberbaum
description: Jamie G. Kantrowitz and Mark Bruce Lorberbaum were married yesterday at the Montammy Country Club in Alpine, N.J. Rabbi Gilbert Rosenthal performed the ceremony.

title: Britain's New Look At The Irish Question
description: A new look should have been the order of the day back in 1960 when it all began. The British should have learned from the colonies, Israel, etc. that outside rule and oppression always end in a revolution, and then people can rule themselves. EDWARD J. CLARKE, New York City

title: The World; Making Too Much Of Saudi Plan
description: Explaining what the boss really meant can be risky, Gaafar M. Allagany learned last week. Mr. Allagany, a veteran Saudi delegate to the United Nations, ventured that Crown Prince Fahd's Middle East proposals amounted to recognition of Israel. An unauthorized interpretation, the Government promptly said in Riyadh; whereupon Mr. Allagany stopped answering his phone.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; New Divertimento For Piano Four Hands
description: It is all too easy for pianists to begin sounding like students again when they sit down to the four-hand repertory. It needn't be that way, but playing in real unison is difficult and, like any other musical discipline, takes time to master. Listening to the debut performance of Walter Hilse and Constance Cooper as a four-hand duo Friday night in Carnegie Recital Hall, one sensed that the pair had not yet devoted quite enough time to it. It was also apparent they have yet to find the repertory to keep a recital from sounding thin and unexceptional.

title: Chicano Literature
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE MODERNIST GRAIN
description: WILLIAM CARLOS WILLIAMS A New World Naked. By Paul Mariani. Illustrated. 874 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Co. $24.95.

title: Miss Goldenberg To Wed in Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ira Goldenberg of Mamaroneck, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Beth Goldenberg, to Robert Elliot Fuller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Fuller of Orange, Conn. A spring wedding is planned.

title: HOW THE LENAPES CELEBRATED
description: EVERY fall beginning hundreds of years ago, the Lenape Indians would hold a long harvest festival to say wanishi -thank you - to their Creator and lesser gods.

title: CHAPIN'S MUSIC CARRIES ON
description: HARRY CHAPIN'S last work-in-progress, the score for a satirical one-man show - a musical paraphrasing of the Gospel according to the style of country-western music - has made its Off Broadway debut and may be settling in for an extended run.

title: Art; EARTH SCULPTURE INSPIRED BY INDIAN CEREMONIES
description: MORRISTOWN AT THE Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences through January, and perhaps until next April or May, is the last of a series of three outdoor environmental sculpture installations. This one, by Carolee Thea and Penny Kaplan, is entitled ''Earth Maze/Earth Mounds.''

title: Stage View; WHEN ACTORS TRIUMPH
description: What is most remarkable about the production of Ronald Harwood's ''The Dresser'' is that we are able to watch Paul Rogers, as a nearsenile and surely dying provincial actor, reach into his makeup kit and slowly, painfully put together something more than a recognizable King Lear. He puts a man together as well - himself. Out of eye-liner and greasepaint and spirit gum, he creates just enough faith and will and energy to get himself through one more storm on the heath. Which leaves us with a curious reflection. When an actor lives long enough, all the life he has left - perhaps all the life he now needs - can be carried about in a small tin box.

title: Index; International
description: Papandreou to present Govern- ment program to Parliament 3 Spain's Premier takes over as head of his splintered party 5 Sharp cut in Canadian rail service arouses storm of protests 6 London political leaders locked in dispute over transit fares 7 Advance of civilization threatens a million species in the world 8 London's lavish new arts center nearly ready to open 10 For Chinese, exhibition of Indian artifacts may have ancient link 12 New Zealand elections a test for new Maori political party 13 Soviet says Reagan seeks to hood- wink Europe on arms 22 Government/Politics Kentucky Governor's style seen as puzzling but effective 24 Budget cuts termed threat to Great Lakes cleanup effort 28 Government, its spending unau- thorized, grinds on 31 Secretary Watt to tour Louisiana swampland 37 Indicted Jersey judge faces a sec- ond bribery charge 43 Solvent Syracuse an envy to some cities 53 Conservatives open an anti- Moynihan Drive 57 General Around the Nation 28 Life in a Minnesota prairie town is marked by stability 28 Companies in race for TV fran- chises in 4 boroughs 50 Kheel dropping libel suit against Murdoch 51 Jersey's rise in violent crime ex- ceeds national rate 62 Dispute delays cleanup of atomic waste storage site 65 Education/Welfare Non-Catholics aid diocese schools in Philadelphia 29 Yale to offer degree in women's studies 57 Health/Science Scientists fearful of making earthquake predictions 25 Arts/Entertainment Dance Theater of Harlem in financial straits 69 Music debuts in review 70 ''Shop'' revived at the Folksbiene Playhouse 70 Ballet Today offers works of 6 choreographers 72 ''Body and Soul,'' remake of a film classic 72 The Joffrey dances Massine's ''Parade'' 72 Style A voice for design widens her range 74 Obituaries Arthur Gershwin, composer and brother of George and Ira 44

title: SKITCH HENDERSON EMPHASIZES MUSICAL LIFE AGAIN
description: HE'S back again, as charming and friendly as ever, pleasant and dapper, and, at 63, is planning a major role for himself in music and in Connecticut.

title: Ellen Jean Ackerman, Aide of I.B.M., Engaged to William Hudson Eyre Jr.
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Daniel H. Ridder of Long Beach and Pebble Beach, Calif., and Jack R. Ackerman of New York and Pound Ridge, N.Y., of the the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Jean Ackerman to William Hudson Eyre Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Eyre of New York and Sharon, Conn.

title: ACCESS TO CABLE TELEVISION OPENS NEW LINES OF COMMUNICATIONS
description: WHITE PLAINS TONY COASH, who runs a television workshop on Mamaroneck Avenue here, was talking about ''color locks,'' ''tracking'' and ''white balance.'' Andy Wasserman, who is in the ninth grade at Rye High School, was listening. He seemed familiar with the terms.

title: VENICE
description: To the Editor:

title: CUBA AIDED DOOMED HAITIANS
description: The 33 Haitians who drowned off the coast of Florida last month had spent nearly four weeks in Cuba, where they received food supplies and other assistance permitting them to continue their journey to the United States, Federal investigators said today.

title: OFFICER ASKS TO KEEP YOUTH HE RESCUED
description: A POLICE officer who dissuaded a homeless 17-year-old youth from jumping to his death will go to court Friday in an effort to win permanent custody of the young man.

title: Kentucky 21, Tennessee 10
description: Randy Jenkins passed for two touchdowns and Lawrence Lee dived 1 yard for a third as Kentucky (3-8) beat Tennessee (6-4).

title: CHARGES DISMISSED IN BRIBERY CASES
description: A judge in Brooklyn has dismissed bribery indictments against Waldbaum's Inc. and 15 employees of that supermarket chain and of the A.& P. because of ''undue delay'' in prosecuting the cases. The judge castigated the office of District Attorney Eugene Gold for ''unprofessional if not contemptuous'' conduct in the matter.

title: UConn Captures Title In New England Soccer
description: Led by Pedro DeBrito's two goals, Connecticut captured the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I New England soccer crown today with a 6-2 victory over Vermont. Connecticut advances to the Eastern regional championship, facing the victor of Sunday's match between Columbia and Long Island University.

title: Correction
description: An editing error changed the meaning of the last sentence of Benjamin R. Civiletti's article, ''Antitrust Travesty'' (Nov. 15). It should have read, ''Congress should end such abuses by promptly limiting liability of a defendent, including those whose cases are now pending, to treble the damages caused by its own sales.''

title: Paper Company Lays Off 50
description: A paper company has laid off 50 employees at its Brattleboro plant because fewer people are dining out. ''The whole economy is slowing down,'' said Leo Roiko of the Erving Paper Company in Erving, Mass., which makes paper napkins and towels. ''Fewer people are going out to dinner, so there is less consumption on the part of our customers.''

title: ROSALIND RIVIN TO BE WED IN APRIL TO CARL CHERNOFF
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Rivin of Portsmouth and Virginia Beach, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rosalind Rivin, to Carl Chernoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Chernoff of New York. The wedding is planned for April.

title: Miss McDonnell Will Be the Bride Of John A. Otoshi
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence E. McDonnell of Orlando, Fla., formerly of New York and Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Coralie Barry McDonnell, to John A. Otoshi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. Otoshi of Walnut Creek, Calif. A January wedding in New York in planned.

title: 'HEARTLAND'- A TRIUMPH OF TRUE GRIT
description: ''It really began, deeply, in Missoula in 1976,'' says Annick Smith. It was then that two women of Montana - Beth Ferris, who lives up along Rattlesnake Creek just outside of Missoula, and Miss Smith, whose ranch sprawls over 160 acres in nearby Blackfoot Valley, found themselves bound together by a passionate attachment to the wild outdoors and a desire to put that passion on film.

title: The Region; A Big Food Bill For Con Edison
description: New Yorkers may have no recourse when Consolidated Edison indulges in ''ordinary negligence,'' but when the neglect gets gross, the neglected can get even. So said New York State's highest court last week in ruling that Con Ed was indeed liable for certain damage related to the 1977 blackout.

title: The Question of Sex Bias At Harvard
description: To me, the most frightening thing about the Skocpol case is the review committee's apparent assumption that, unlike sex bias, personal dislike would be a perfectly good ground for not promoting an otherwise qualified candidate. Isn't it obvious the grounds are equally corrupt? DIANA F. ACKERMAN, Associate Professor Department of Philosophy Brown University, Providence

title: Topics; CONSCIOUSNESS RAISED; What Women Want
description: Houston is the nation's fifth largest city, pays its mayors a Texas-size salary ($81,000) and has just welcomed the newest occupant of City Hall with a winning margin of nearly 63 percent of the vote. Kathryn Whitmire, the first woman to hold the job, drew her support from every important ethnic and socio-economic group.

title: BUCKLEY ABOARD THE ORIENT EXPRESS
description: WILLIAM F. BUCKLEY Jr. is a sailor, writer, television host and editor of National Review. By WILLIAM F.BUCKLEY Jr.

title: JERSEY CITY HOUSE AUCTIONS LURE BUYERS
description: The search for housing bargains that has stimulated interest in tax-foreclosure auctions throughout the metropolitan area is lifting the prices for such properties in Jersey City.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Galina Heifetz Performs Program for Violin
description: One of the curiosities of musical life these days is the prevalence of violinists named Heifetz. The most recognized is, of course, Jascha Heifetz.

title: PULITZER PRIZE BOARD ADOPTS NEW PROCEDURES
description: The board that decides on journalism's most coveted awards, the Pulitzer Prizes, has adopted new procedures to deal with some of the problems raised last spring when a prize-winning article about an 8-year-old drug addict was exposed as a fraud.

title: Critics' Choices
description: THEATER If you've been despairing about the future of the musical theater, there's at least one surefire antidote - ''March of the Falsettos,'' the brief, totally fresh musical that has just moved from its original home at Playwrights Horizons to the slightly larger environs of the Westside Arts Theater. In this show, one hears 20 songs by a new young composer-lyricist, William Finn, whose work boils over with passion, witty invention and melody.

title: Ideas and Trends; Can the Shuttle Earn Its Keep?
description: To space program buffs and critics alike, the space shuttle may look better in the air than on the ground. In the air, it metamorphoses from rocket to spacecraft to 102-ton glider; on the ground, it is a reminder of $10 billion spent on a project that has yet to prove itself economically feasible or technologically practical.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: IN THE last two weeks, dozens of raccoons have abandoned the woodlands and wandered into yards, streets and garages in Bergen County, all the time hissing, foaming at the mouth, biting at themselves and walking in circles.

title: A PLAN TO END HASTY BOXING DECISIONS
description: THE site is Pittsburgh's Civic Center and the event is a heavyweight championship fight. That Larry Holmes only holds half the title and this bout with Renaldo Snipes is being looked upon as a mere tune-up is immaterial. What is important is that part of the heavyweight crown is being put on the line, and that only happens a few times a year. The last time it happened in Pittsburgh, a popular underdog, Jersey Joe Walcott finally won the crown in his fifth try by knocking out Ezzard Charles. That was 30 years ago.

title: Somerville Beats Wall
description: Tom Gray ran for a touchdown and returned a fumble recovery for another to lead Somerville to a 21-6 victory yesterday over Wall in the first round of the Central Jersey, Group 3 playoffs.

title: Chamber Music Society Postpones 'Wilderness'
description: The premiere of Lucia Dlugoszewski's ''Wilderness Elegant Tilt,'' scheduled for the next trio of concerts by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, has been postponed to next season because the score is unfinished.

title: The World; Argentine Chief Takes Sick Leave
description: Illness last week forced Roberto Eduardo Viola to temporarily give up his duties as Argentine President. His health could give his fellow military rulers a graceful reason to replace him permanently at a time of political and economic malaise.

title: Ruth Snowdon Hoopes Wed
description: Ruth Snowdon Hoopes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Coudon Hoopes of Greenville, Del., was married in New York yesterday to Zissimos Antonios Frangopoulos of London. The Rev. William Clarkson 4th performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: Crafts; WEAVER'S TEXTILES A FRAMEWORK
description: GAIL J. RESEN speaks deliberately yet poetically of her fiber art and her feelings about her work. ''I am always reaching for an emotional reaction and association within myself and the viewer - a tugging at some hidden, secret cord,'' she says. ''My work is a response to my love of the visually tactile. It is also the result of a fascination for the play between light and shadow.''

title: THE ITALIAN ART OF SURVIVAL
description: Paul Hofmann, a former Times correspondent who lives in Italy, is author of the forthcoming ''Rome: The Sweet Tempestuous Life.'' By Paul Hofmann

title: A Near Miss
description: William Safire attacks the use of the phrase ''near miss'' to indicate ''a moment of danger to two aircraft'' (''Winged Words,'' On Language, Oct. 4). He favors the new term of the striking air-traffic controllers - ''near collision.''

title: GET-TOGETHERS AID ADOPTIVE PARENTS
description: TWO years ago, five adoptive parents of preschoolers gathered in the White Plains offices of Family Service of Westchester to share ideas and discuss problems they had in common. The group, led by a family counselor, Shirley Zaret, was scheduled to meet one hour a week for six consecutive weeks.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN MONTREAL
description: HENRY GINIGER is chief of the Ottawa bureau of The Times. By HENRY GINIGER

title: Red Wings 4, Flames 4
description: The defenseman Jim Korn came out of the penalty box and deflected a 25-foot wrist shot from Paul Woods at 15:04 of the third period to give Detroit a tie.

title: The Week in Business; THE WHITE HOUSE TRIMS ITS GROWTH PROJECTIONS
description: The economy grew at a rate of six-tenths of a percent in the third quarter, the Commerce Department said in revising its earlier report of a decline by the same amount. Economic growth projected for 1982 was scaled back from 3.4 percent to about 1 percent in a new White House forecast.

title: CHAMBER: I SOLISTI DI ZAGREB
description: Some friendly and familiar faces from the chamber-ensemble world paid a visit Friday evening to Carnegie Hall. They were I Solisti di Zagreb, founded in 1953 and one of the first orchestras of the postwar era to turn our attention toward the vast literature of the Baroque.

title: Westchester Journal
description: THE three water systems serving New York City and the county reached 61.4 percent of their total capacity last week, the closest they have been to normal levels since last November, when the reservoirs fell to 39 percent of total capacity.

title: SOUNDS AND MUSHROOMS
description: FOR THE BIRDS By John Cage. In Conversation with Daniel Charles. 239 pp. Boston: Marion Boyars. $20.

title: On Language; Heavy Weather
description: Just about every newspaper in the country carried the etymology of ''Weather Underground'': A line in a Bob Dylan song, ''You don't need a weatherman to know which way the wind blows,'' became the basis for ''Weatherman''; then some women members objected to the male-sounding ending, and the name was changed to ''Weatherpeople''; when some members stormed about that, ''Weather Underground'' was adopted, with its immediate overtones of World War II resistance fighters and a deeper etymology from Dostoyevsky's ''Notes From the Underground.''

title: SOME BOOKS ABOUT THE STATE
description: FOR those interested in learning more about New Jersey, a cornucopia of books about the state's land, population, economy and housing is available this holiday season. Following is a sampling.

title: POINT MAN FOR THE RIGHT
description: Take many of the controversial ''social issues'' that have been simmering all year on Capitol Hill and the odds are that Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a Republican from Utah who's nearing the end of his first term, is somehow involved.

title: SHERYL ELLIS IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard Ellis of Pennsauken, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Sheryl Susan Ellis, to Richard Jay Bindelglass, son of Dr. and Mrs. Irving L. Bindelglass of Elizabeth, N.J. Miss Ellis, a senior at the University of Delaware, is a professional dance instructor. Her fiance is an associate with the law firm of Wilentz, Goldman & Spitzer in Woodbridge, N.J.

title: DECISIONS OF REGENTS: OTHER INPUT IS NEEDED
description: THE state's Board of Regents, those masters at tinkering, are at it again. The trustees who regulate all education in New York voted this fall to require high schools in the state to meet a new standard of school quality, maintenance of a retention rate of 90 percent.

title: Scott Leads 13-2 Triumph
description: Joe Scott threw two touchdown passes to lead Toms River East to a 13-2 victory yesterday over Southern Regional in the South Jersey, Group 4 playoffs.

title: A BEACHCOMBER'S BAEDEKER
description: S ome are large, lively by day and night and accessible by direct flights. Others are small, quiet, secluded and often require a flight on a small inter-island plane or perhaps a short boat ride from a neighboring island. What most have in common is a blessed climate that makes summer a year-round season. They are the scores of Caribbean islands that sweep in a giant arc from Cuba, just south of Florida, to Trinidad, nestled against the Venezuelan coast

title: THE DANCE: JOFFREY IN 2 BY ARPINO
description: As the Joffrey Ballet's resident choreographer, Gerald Arpino has turned out ballets for all times, moods and seasons. Should the repertory require a certain kind of work, Mr. Arpino provides it. But this capacity to produce has also caused many of his ballets to be facile, and care must be taken so that similar works are not programmed together.

title: IF YOU GET ILL IN BRITAIN
description: For many years, foreign visitors to Britain have been covered by that country's National Health Service, which provides free medical care. Now, however, because of shifts in health policies, the status of foreigners requiring medical care is uncertain. In some cases, they may be eligible for free treatment; in others, they may not and so will have to choose between public medicine or private medicine.

title: MEALS ON WHEELS SCRIMPS TO FEED AGED
description: For 215 elderly homebound people living between 59th Street and 106th Street, an area that is said to have the highest geriatric population in the country, the federally subsidized Meals on Wheels program is a lifeline, providing them with one hot meal Monday through Friday in their homes.

title: Williams Stars In Final Game
description: Bryan Williams of Bay Shore, a tailback, ended his scholastic football career by scoring four touchdowns and rushing for 317 yards to lead the Marauders to a 42-0 victory over Islip yesterday in a nonleague game.

title: Texas A & M 37, T.C.U. 7
description: Earnest Jackson ran for 219 yards and scored three touchdowns for Texas A & M. The Cadets, 6-4 and 4-3 in the Southwest Conference, close the regular season Thanksgiving Day against Texas and then face Oklahoma State in the Independence Bowl. T.C.U. finished with a 2-7-2 record.

title: Music; PHILIP GLASS'S MUSIC COMES TO HARTFORD
description: ''WE seem to have done something right,'' Philip Glass said recently, referring to the fact that ''Satyagraha,'' his opera based on elements in Mohandas K. Gandhi's early life and named for Gandhi's philosophy of nonviolent resistance was sold out for all five performances of its New York premiere run.

title: HEALTH REPORT
description: WOODROW WILSON A Medical and Psychological Biography. By Edwin A. Weinstein. Illustrated. 399 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $18.50.

title: LEGISLATIVE CALLS FOR BOATING SAFETY
description: THE fatal wreck of the cruiser Karen E. last August has some state legislators stirring about new proposals to require boat operators to take water safety courses before they are allowed to navigate on Long Island Sound and in state rivers.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Cho-Liang Lin, Violinist, Plays the 'Kreutzer'
description: The only hitch in the New York recital debut of Cho-Liang Lin, violinist, at Alice Tully Hall last Sunday afternoon (he has already appeared as a soloist with the Mostly Mozart Festival, and his New York Philharmonic debut will occur next month) came when a string broke less than a page from the end of Prokofiev's Sonata No. 2 in D, the final piece on the program. Up to that point Mr. Lin, who was born in Taiwan not quite 21 years ago, had sailed through the challenges of Stravinsky's ''Suite Italienne'' and Beethoven's ''Kreutzer'' Sonata, as well as all but the final minute of the Prokofiev, with no mishaps worse than an occasional raw tone and one or two dropped notes.

title: First of two articles.
description: Although it has been delayed time and again by the collapse of railroad empires, budget crises and inertia, the long-promised upgrading of commuter rail service in the New York metropolitan area is once more picking up speed, according to transit officials.

title: Gardening; THE SWEET SIDE OF THE TART CRANBERRY
description: POTATOES, corn, tomatoes, squash and several beans are native to America. They provided sustenance for the Indians long before the New World was discovered by Europeans. Descriptions of the first Thanksgiving indicate that corn and squash were on the menu, but no mention is made whether they had cranberry sauce with their turkey.

title: JAPAN MUST NOT LOSE ITS 'NUCLEAR ALLERGY'
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUTHERN CAL STOPS U.C.L.A.
description: Marcus Allen rushed for 219 yards and two touchdowns today, the last one with 2 minutes 14 seconds remaining, to give Southern California a 22-21 victory over U.C.L.A.

title: WANTED: TENANT FOR EMPTY SUBWAYS
description: Mayor Koch decided last spring that revenue might be produced and waste prevented by renting incomplete subway tunnels and unused subway stations. For one thing, the Mayor suggested, the overload of documents generated by the city could find secure keeping there.

title: HOW TO LOSE CHESS- AND A WAR OF NERVES
description: At its highest levels, the game of chess is always a drama involving wit, skill and psychological strategy. But even by the high theatrical standards established by recent tournaments, the world chess championship that reached its denouement last week was quite a spectacle. Its conflict was mostly provided by Viktor Korchnoi, the 50-year-old challenger who defected from the Soviet Union in 1976 and now lives in Switzerland. After hanging on precariously in the 800,000 Swiss francs purse title match, Korchnoi was defeated by the 30-year-old champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, by 6 wins to 2 in 18 games, including 10 draws. But that was not the challenger's only defeat. Mr. Korchnoi, a man known for his pugilistic proclivities, insisted on fighting three conflicts simultaneously. He lost them all.

title: NJ TRANSIT TRYING NEW WAYS TO CURB CRIME ON BUSES
description: SHORTLY after 9 P.M. on Nov. 5, three teen-agers pulled a knife on the driver of Transport of New Jersey's No. 49 bus as he stopped in front of the Prudential Insurance Company building in Newark.

title: Canadiens Put End To Penguin Streak
description: Keith Acton scored three goals and Steve Shutt two, helping the Montreal Canadiens to defeat Pittsburgh, 9-5, tonight and end the Penguins' seven-game undefeated streak.

title: GIFTS BIG AND SMALL TO U.S. OFFICIALS
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Bowl Rematch
description: The fourth annual Metro Bowl championship game between the best of the Public Schools Athletic League and the Catholic High Schools Football League is a rematch in the A division, with Bayside, 10-0, the loser last season, going against the 9-1 defending champion St. John the Baptist.

title: THE U.S. SHOULDN'T AID REPRESSION IN HAITI
description: The news that the Reagan Administration plans to strengthen its investment and trade relationship with Haiti came only days after its announcement that a firm, fearless human rights policy was brewing at the State Department. If our new liaison with Haiti is to serve as a model for this evenhanded policy, then regimes that take a purely adversarial view of their own citizens will have nothing to fear from the United States.

title: TRIAL OF 24 IN SADAT ASSASSINATION OPENS IN CAIRO
description: The trial of 24 Moslem fundamentalists charged in connection with the assassination of Anwar el-Sadat opened here today with the 23 defendants who were present in the heavily guarded courtroom appearing in an iron cage before three military judges.

title: Other Business; AS DETROIT GOES, SO GO MODEL CARS
description: Detroit's financial difficulties have been well documented but not, perhaps, the full impact of the ripple effect. Children, for example, are purchasing fewer toy plastic model cars than they did in the mid-1970's.

title: Queens and Manhattan In Tournament Final
description: Queens College, led by Marcia Blount, a freshman guard who scored 21 points, defeated Fordham, 82-72, yesterday at Manhattan College's Draddy Gym.

title: 62 FIGHT TO KEEP 'STATUS' ADDRESS
description: RESIDENTS of a neighborhood of $250,000 homes that dot the Stamford side of the Greenwich border near the Mianus River are furious over a decision by the Postal Service to change their Cos Cob mailing address and ZIP code to a Stamford designation.

title: Thousands of Canadians Rally To Protest High Interest Rate
description: Thousands of workers from across Canada gathered outside Parliament today to protest high interest rates. Dennis McDermott, head of the Canadian Labor Congress, said at the rally that ''an insane economic policy is robbing us of our jobs and our homes.''

title: Delaware 31 West Chester State 14
description: The Fullback Rick Titus ran 44 yards for a touchdown and Delaware gained 402 yards rushing. Delaware (8-2) also scored on touchdown runs of 30 yards by Bob Dougherty, 1 yard by John Davies and 5 by Rick Scully. K.C. Knobloch got a 37-yard field goal.

title: ACTION ON LOST CHILDREN URGED
description: The father of a 6-year-old boy who disappeared in a department store and was later found murdered has complained to Congress that ''once a child is taken from the jurisdiction of the local police force, virtually no one looks for him.''

title: CITY BALLET: BALANCHINE AND ROBBINS WORKS
description: On Thursday night at the New York State Theater, the New York City Ballet did the sort of thing it usually does best. It offered abstractions by George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins. But - and this is part of what the company does best - these works in no way seemed remote from human concerns.

title: Amy Jo Rosenblum Wed
description: Amy Jo Rosenblum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Rosenblum of New York, was married yesterday to Frank Greenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Greenberg of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Ezra Gellman at the Park Lane Hotel.

title: NEW TWIST IN A HAIR-FASHION
description: WHAT takes four yards of ribbon, comes in every color of the rainbow, plus a few, and can be seen on the heads of preschoolers and high school students alike? Ribbon barrettes - the newest fashion fad in the county.

title: The Region; The Worst Things In Life Aren't Free
description: New York's transit system may have more than its share of trouble but, a study of municipal services seemed to indicate last week, it isn't necessarily because it has had less than its share of money.

title: HOLLYWOOD CORRESPONDENT
description: THE LETTERS OF NUNNALLY JOHNSON Selected and Edited by Dorris Johnson and Ellen Leventhal. Foreword by Alistair Cooke. 281 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.50.

title: Essay; THREE INSIDE PHRASES
description: Because you have been an attentive readership and the holiday season is approaching, I am going to vouchsafe three phrases with which to stud your Thanksgiving Dinner conversation - a trio with brio that will identify you as a certified, or certifiable, Washington Insider.

title: Mailbox; Tearing Up Baseball Rules
description: To the Sports Editor: I have always been somewhat of a traditionalist when it comes to major league baseball. Perhaps my attitude stems from my formative years as a rabid Brooklyn Dodger fan. Maybe it is a residual allegiance to the National League that has prevented me from accepting the American League's designated hitter rule. In any case, the recent World Series has caused me to re-think the subject. After all, there have been innovative changes in other sports that have added to their interest. The 3-point field goal in professional basketball, the 2-point conversion in college football and the advent of the Major Indoor Soccer League are a few that come to mind.

title: Design; FASHION FLOWERS
description: couple of years ago, a customer telephoned one of the city's more exclusive flower boutiques and asked for some salmon-colored roses. The response was so chilly it could have withered an entire conservatory: ''I don't really think you would be happy with roses. Won't you let us cut some amaryllis instead?''

title: Nebraska 37, Oklahoma 14
description: Mark Mauer threw for 148 yards and one touchdown, and Roger Craig rushed for 102 yards as Nebraska finished with a 7-0 record in the Big Eight Conference, 9-2 over all and a trip to the Orange Bowl against Clemson. Craig surpassed 1,000 yards for the season on a 19-yard first-quarter touchdown run that put Nebraska in the lead to stay. Oklahoma (5-4-1 and 3-2-1), which faces Oklahoma State next week and then goes to the Sun Bowl, was led by Stanley Wilson, who gained 164 yards on 21 carries.

title: No Headline
description: 350,000 IN AMSTERDAM PROTEST A-ARMS

title: Houston 15, Texas Tech 7
description: HOUSTON (AP) - The quarterback Lionel Wilson turned a daring fourth-down play into a 5-yard touchdown pass to Lonell Phea in the third quarter to rally Houston.

title: A DEBATE- DOES NATO REALLY NEED THOSE MISSILES?
description: PRESIDENT Reagan's offer last week to scrap deployment of new medium-range American missiles in Europe if the Russians would remove theirs was timed for arms control talks beginning in Geneva next week. It was mainly prompted by rising opposition to the American missiles in Europe, where the deployment idea orginated. On the continent, only Italy and West Germany are still pledged to go through with the 1979 NATO agreement. Holland said last week it would be unable to reach a decision on the missiles by next month, as it had promised in 1979. Several hundred thousand demonstrators marched through central Amsterdam yesterday to show opposition to the deployment.

title: Fashion; A CRITICAL LOOK AT SPRING '82
description: The ready-to-wear clothes for spring 1982 will begin to arrive in American stores in January, and while the new season will offer some nuances in style, the real fashion story today involves the changes in the very nature of the industry: The acceptance of New York as the equal of Paris and Milan, and the phenomenon of the fashion show as spectacle.

title: Fire Delays Subway Travel
description: A fire on the tracks at Lexington Avenue and 77th Street yesterday afternoon interrupted the travel of about 500 subway riders when their trains were either stopped short of their destinations or routed to avoid the area, said William Hayes, a Transit Authority train dispatcher. There were no injuries and after a half hour, travel resumed. The blaze, whose cause was unknown, affected service between 86th Street and Grand Central Terminal.

title: CANADIAN RAIL RUNS IN MAINE COME TO END AFTER CENTURY
description: For nearly 100 years, Canada provided a link to the outside world for six backwoods towns in Maine. But the high cost of running a modern railroad has brought the only foreignrun passenger trains in the United States to an end.

title: 3-Alarm Fire Destroys Central Hoboken Hotel
description: A three-alarm fire last night destroyed the American Hotel in central Hoboken, N.J., injuring six of its residents and leaving dozens homeless, the city's Fire Department reported.

title: Speaking Personally; MUST EVERY DINNER PARTY BRING THANKS-GIVING?
description: WITH Thanksgiving dinner preparations no doubt already under way in households throughout the land, and with the season of dinner parties about to reach full flower, I am driven to wonder about thanks of a different nature.

title: THE AMAZON: A NEW SEARCH FOR EL DORADO
description: Edwin McDowell, publishing correspondent for The Times, has visited the Amazon regularly during the past decade. By Edwin McDowell One recent day in Manaus, the hands on the stately clock in the middle of Avenida Eduardo Riebero, overlooking the floating docks that rise and fall with the surging 30-foot tides of the Rio Negro, wound to a halt at precisely 7 A.M. In times past, few residents of this 321-year-old Brazilian city in the heart of the Amazon jungle would have noticed - or even cared. On this day, however, the clock was fixed before the morning traffic jam ended and well before many ships had headed downriver, weighted down by cargoes of everything from melons to electronic calculators.

title: INDICTED JERSEY JUDGE FACES A 2D BRIBE CHARGE
description: A grand jury has accused a Camden County Superior Court judge of not only taking a $15,000 bribe he has been arrested for accepting, but also soliciting a second bribe for $35,000 in an unrelated case.

title: Around the World; Walesa Food Plea Gives Warsaw Mixed Feelings
description: The Polish Government's press agency expressed ''mixed feelings'' today about Lech Walesa's appeal for food aid from Western Europe. The appeal by the union leader came amid shortages of nearly every type of food.

title: Business Conditions; A DEEPER TAX BITE
description: Despite calls for lower state taxes, 30 states have raised taxes by a total of $2.5 billion during the last 12 months, mainly through higher sales, excise and oil-severance taxes, according to economists at Morgan Guaranty Trust.

title: Long Islanders; PAINTINGS AND FILMS ARE ALL ONE TO HER
description: WHEN Faith Chestman and John Hubley wed in the mid-1950's, she said, ''We had two marriage vows. One was to eat with the children. The other was to make one independent film a year.''

title: Two Brothers Are Convicted Of Defrauding Jobs Program
description: A Federal jury has convicted two West Hartford brothers of defrauding the CETA job-training program of more than $200,000.

title: Thelma Petrie Bride of Alfred O'Hara
description: Thelma DeVries Petrie of New York and Alfred Peck O'Hara of Patterson, N.Y., were married yesterday at Christ Church on Quaker Hill in Pawling, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Bernard Brunsting performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Mail Carriers Allowed to Take Shortcut Over Private Lawns
description: A Federal appellate court has ruled that mail carriers may take shortcuts across residential lawns without permission of the homeowners.

title: LET'S HEAR IT FOR TODAY'S STUDENTS
description: IN HIS article, ''What Does 'Nontraditional' Really Mean?'' (Opinion Page, Aug. 30), Prof. Jackson Toby painted a rather unfavorable picture of today's students, or at least a significant fraction of them. He wrote:

title: Sarah Cosby Married To Theodore H. Yoh
description: Sarah Hovey Cosby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Finton Gerard David Cosby, of Stockbridge, Mass., was married there yesterday to Theodore Harold Yoh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Yoh of Palm Beach, Fla. Canon Robert S.S. Whitman and the Rev. Theodore H. Evans performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: REGENTS SEEK INCREASE OF 13% IN EDUCATION AID
description: The Board of Regents has proposed that New York State increase financing for education by 13 percent and start to equalize the amount of money available to richer and poorer districts.

title: Miss Braga, J. A. Figg 3d To Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Atkinson Braga of Alpine, N.J., and Fishers Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Allegra Beatrice Maud Braga, to James Alfred Figg 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Alfred Figg Jr. of Inverness, Ill.

title: THE HOUSTON THAT WAS LOSES ITS HOLD
description: Only yesterday, it seems, this city was a brash adolescent in jeans and cowboy hat, careering down the highway of urban growth and development in a pickup truck. But adolescents grow up, and Houston today seems more like an adult, with a more complex personality that displays new facets, shadings and sensitivities.

title: Children's Books
description: ARLENE ALDA'S ABC Illustrated. Unpaged. Millbrae, Calif.: Celestial Arts/Dawn-Leigh. Paper, $8.95. (Ages 3 to 5) By GEORGE A.WOODS

title: INMATE SUES ON WEDDING BID
description: DESPITE the frustrated wedding plans of one prisoner at the Ossining Correctional Facility, two other prisoners at the facility are now trying to marry behind bars.

title: BAYSIDE TAKES THIRD P.S.A.L. CROWN IN ROW
description: Bayside defeated Abraham Lincoln, 48-31, yesterday, to capture its third Public Schools Athletic League championship in a row. For the Commodores, now 10-0, it was the sixth P.S.A.L. title in the 11 years since the playoff system began. Bayside, which lost to St. John the Baptist in the Metro Bowl last season, will meet the Catholic school again in the citywide title game on Dec. 5. Called by Darkness

title: MUSINGS OF AN ARKANSAS TRAVELER
description: ROY REED, formerly a reporter for The New York Times, teaches at the University of Arkansas in Fayetteville and is an Arkansas farmer. By ROY REED

title: Around the World; Tin Workers in Bolivia Gain Support in Strike
description: Farmers and factory workers declared their support today for 50,000 tin miners, who are in the 10th day of a strike. The Government repeated its refusal to bargain and jailed more leaders of the strike, union sources said.

title: MAASTRICHT
description: To the Editor:

title: The Costakis Collection
description: Hilton Kramer's article on the Costakis collection of Russian art whets one's appetite to see these pieces that have been so long immured behind Soviet disapproval (''Russia's Lost Revolution in Modern Art,'' Oct. 11).

title: Sound; THE RECORD SHOP OF THE FUTURE MAY BE IN YOUR PARLOR
description: Ever since music divorced itself from noble or churchly patronage in the aftermath of the French Revolution, it has had to earn its own keep. Halls had to be hired and tickets sold, and in that sense, music became a commodity. The marketing of music has taken many forms, and it is now facing new changes geared to the space age. At present, these changes are still in the planning stage and not yet altogether certain of realization, and the record companies have been extremely cautious, at best. But the principles these plans embody and the challenges they raise may prove crucial to music in the future.

title: North Carolina 31, Duke 10
description: Kelvin Bryant rushed for a career-high 247 yards and two touchdowns to lead the Tar Heels to victory and a trip to the Gator Bowl.

title: 2 L.I. Schools Capture Titles
description: Doug O'Brien scored the goal as Southold, L.I., defeated Harrisville, 1-0, today at Union College to win the State Class D scholastic soccer championship.

title: Film View; FREE SPIRITS VERSUS GENERALIZERS
description: The controversy over Sidney Pollack's ''Absence of Malice,'' in which a reputable newspaper's supposedly savvy investigative reporter (Sally Field) and editors are snookered into defaming an innocent man (Paul Newman) by a tricky Federal investigator, has to do with something more than the public's faith in or skepticism of journalists. It has to do with our perception of narrative movies and the way in which, when watching almost any film, we tend automatically to transform the specific instance in a single narrative into a generalization.

title: CHAPLAINS ASSAIL RUTGERS CUTBACK
description: NEW BRUNSWICK CAMPUS chaplains and religious leaders throughout the state are trying to get the Rutgers University administration to reverse a decision abolishing the Office of the Coordinator of Religious Affairs.

title: Miss Heilmann, David Wilkinson Will Be Married
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John E. Heilmann of Greenwich, Conn., and Norwood, Va., of the engagement of their daughter, Marianne Christine Heilmann, to David Anthony Wilkinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. C.A. Wilkinson of London and Badingham, England.

title: Oregon 47, Oregon State 17
description: Oregon scored the first three times it had the ball in the 85th renewal of the West Coast's longest rivalry. Vince Williams, the fullback, scored the first two Oregon touchdowns on short runs. Oregon went ahead by 21-0 early in the second period on a 1-yard run by the tailback Harry Billups, the first of his two touchdowns.

title: JEWS ACT TO STOP YOUNG FROM DEFECTING TO CULTS
description: It was almost 10 years ago, Rabbi Rubin Dobin says, that he began to hear that young Jews were deserting their faith for membership in cults. First irregularly, then in a steady trickle, letters from distraught parents began to flow into his Long Island home from the congregation he had established by mail after World War II, consisting of Jewish families in towns too small and too isolated to support their own synagogues.

title: Wisconsin 26, Minnesota 21
description: MINNEAPOLIS (AP) - Wisconsin's reserve quarterback, Randy Wright, came in with less than two minutes remaining to complete four of five passes for 82 yards and the decisive touchdown.

title: New Jersey Guide; CENTER TO CELEBRATE
description: The Jewish Community Center on the Palisades, for many years a fixture in Englewood, is celebrating the opening of its new building in Tenafly with a lecture by Elie Wiesel and a concert by Marvin Hamlisch.

title: RAISE TAXES? O'NEILL HAS BOLL WEEVILS IN HARTFORD
description: Returning to the Capitol last week for a special session to close the state's $121 million budget gap, members of the General Assembly listened as Governor William A. O'Neill tried to be humorous about the state's fiscal predicament. ''The trouble with our times,'' said Mr. O'Neill, quoting an old saw, ''is that the future isn't what it used to be.''

title: Oklahoma State 27 Iowa State 7
description: The sophomore quarterback Rusty Hilger passed for two touchdowns and ran for another for Oklahoma State.
