title: 'CRUEL ART' BRINGS OUT THE BEST IN NUTMEG DANCERS
description: TORRINGTON ''CHINS!'' she yelled. ''I want faces. Expression. Details, everyone!'' Suddenly Sharon E. Dante, the petite, dark-haired artistic director of the Nutmeg Ballet Company, sprang from her canvas chair at one end of the studio and walked briskly to the side of 15-year-old Victoria Mazzarelli.

title: JAMAICA HIGH, WITH PRIDE, AWAITING MACCHIAROLA
description: Framed art work - scores of pieces by students and reproductions of old masters - line the walls of the corridors on all three floors of Jamaica High School in Queens. Some pieces have been there more than 20 years. None are vandalized or disturbed.

title: THE J. GEILS BAND'S FRESH NEW ALBUM
description: Peter Wolf, the lead vocalist with the J. Geils Band, sat on the edge of the bed in his Manhattan hotel room, leafing carefully through a portfolio of Expressionist drawings he had purchased earlier in the day. The J. Geils Band, a Boston-based rock group that has weathered a dozen years in the spotlight without a single personnel change, made its reputation as a full-tilt boogie band, a kind of American Rolling Stones, but Mr. Wolf was listening to a tape of the jazz singer Betty Carter. And he was talking about Expressionism and punk rock.

title: EMBRACING DEMOCRACY, ASIA TENDS TO CRUSH IT
description: As vote-counting in Bangladesh's second direct presidential election was nearing completion last week, Abdus Sattar, the 75-year-old jurist who was clearly winning, declared that the poll had reaffirmed the country's faith in democracy and that the election was ''the fairest ever held in this part of the world.'' But Kamal Hossein, a former Oxford University law professor, who ended up a distant second in the 26-candidate race, contended that the results were fraudulent. He said intimidation had kept his supporters from the polls, that ballot boxes had been stuffed and electionrigging had been widespread.

title: Children's Books
description: TRAITOR The Case of Benedict Arnold. By Jean Fritz. Illustrated With Original Sketches by John Andre. 192 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons.

title: Food; THANKS BE TO CROQUETTES
description: It long has been our notion that the French terms for kitchen and table items are more ''apt'' than those of any other nation. Thus there is mousse, which actually means foam, the desired texture when making one; or fondue, which simply means melted.

title: BEETHOVEN IS BIG BEAT ON W. SIDE
description: The Upper West Side of Manhattan shared one of its more unusual cultural resources with the rest of the nation yesterday as a 12-hour program of Beethoven's chamber music was transmitted live from Broadway and 95th Street to some 100 public radio stations around the country.

title: No Headline
description: This Week:

title: Art; MARTHA RYTHER RETROSPECTIVE TO PROVIDE AID TO FUND
description: THE Rockland Center for the Arts is showing, through Saturday, a retrospective exhibition of the work of Martha Ryther, a talented artist, a gifted teacher and a figure of note in the New York City area's art world for almost 70 years. Miss Ryther, who died last January, was the widow of Morris Kantor, himself a well-known painter and for many years a much-revered teacher at the Art Students League in New York City.

title: Politics; CRITICAL ISSUES FACE LEGISLATURE AS IT NEARS END
description: TRENTON WITH only a few ticks of the clock remaining in its two-year session, the State Legislature still has controversial and farreaching measures on its agenda.

title: ABRAMS REPLACES DEPUTY IN REAL ESTATE BUREAU
description: Robert S. Robbin has left his post as assistant state attorney general in charge of the Bureau of Real Estate Finance, and R. Scott Greathead has succeeded him.

title: Other Business; FOR PIPE SMOKERS, SOMETHING TO CHEW ON
description: A lone cowboy comes riding out of the mountains, puts a wad of tobacco to his gums, and lets a cool smile spread across his face. ''Gold Star,'' he says knowingly, ''What a chew!''

title: Ideas and Trends; Soon, Money Will Prevent Hepatitis
description: At $25 to $40 a shot, and three shots needed for five years of protection, Heptavax-B will be a relatively expensive vaccine against hepatitis B virus when marketed next year. Thanks to Food and Drug Administration approval last week, it will also be the first effective protection against the disease legally available in the United States.

title: Music View; 'ADVENTURER' IN CRITICISM
description: The other day I found myself thinking about Anton Bruckner when I should have been concentrating on writing a review of Philip Glass's opera, ''Satyagraha,'' which I had heard at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. I banished the Austrian symphonist from my head and got on with my work, but later it occurred to me why Bruckner and ''Satyagraha'' had been rubbing elbows in my mind. I had been enjoying myself earlier in the day with ''A Virgil Thomson Reader,'' a collection of the composer/critic's prose that has been brought out by Houghton Mifflin in conjunction with his 85th birthday on Wednesday. In it I had underlined these typically Virgilian lines:

title: Lakers 119, Clippers 117
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 12 of his game-high 33 points in the fourth quarter and grabbed 12 rebounds as Los Angeles won its seventh straight game.

title: Oilers 8, Canucks 3
description: The Oilers gained a 4-0 lead in the first period en route to their victory. Grant Fuhr, Edmonton's rookie goaltender, turned back 41 shots and Matti Hagman, Dave Lumley and Wayne Gretzky scored two goals each. Darcy Rota, Curt Fraser and Ivan Hlinka scored for Vancouver.

title: Black Hawks 6 North Stars 4
description: Tim Higgins scored the go-ahead goal and assisted on two others to lead Chicago to a comeback.

title: Money, Competition And the Colleges
description: In a letter in the Long Island Weekly on Oct. 25, Samuel J. Fanning praises Long Island's private colleges for ''holding their own despite strong competition'' from the State University of New York. Moreover, he proudly notes that the private colleges are making it without financial help from the state or Federal governments.

title: ENTERING ANOTHER AGE
description: HE had been running steadily for almost an hour, and now, even on this cool morning, his clothes were streaked with perspiration. His legs ached and his lungs burned, but the pain felt good.

title: Long Island Journal
description: THE five members of a state siting board are to meet soon to consider the Long Island Lighting Company's request for a one-year delay in deciding whether to build an 800-megawatt, coal-fired electrical generating station at Jamesport.

title: Dining Out; QUALITY AND OLD-TIME VERITIES
description: PUTNAM WELCOME to the pre-additive 1930's or 40's. Welcome to My Kitchen, a tiny restaurant in the northeastern tip of Connecticut. My Kitchen has a homey name and an attractive mix of down-home accouterments, such as an arrangement of black skillets hung along the brick fireplace wall and big black kettles of soup being kept warm on top of the old-fashioned stove. Fresh flowers on each table rest in oldfashioned pint milk bottles. Framed Norman Rockwell Saturday Evening Post covers hang along the walls, and in the bathrooms you'll find 1938, 1941 and 1948 copies of Life, Look and the Post.

title: 55 Dispensers of Food Cited on Health Code
description: The New York City Health Department released the names last week of 55 food establishments that it said had violated the health code. The department also named six that reopened after correcting earlier violations, and two that were closed for failing to do so. VIOLATIONS P & G Bar & Grill, 279 Amsterdam Ave. El Ocaso, 941 Amsterdam Ave. La Embajada, 953 Amsterdam Ave. Ricky's, 962 Amsterdam Ave. Punjab Indian, 175 Bleecker St. Mike's Pizza, 2038 Amsterdam Ave. China Chalet, 47 Broadway. John's Coffee Shop, 1966 Broadway. Premium Doughnut Shop, 2607 Broadway. Donuts Delight Two, 2696 Broadway. Santo Domingo, 3438 Broadway. Bueno Coffee Deli Shop, 3645 Broadway. Chino's, 4329 Broadway. John Serevetas, 293 Church St. Empire Szechuan, 193 Columbus Ave. Natural Source Foods, 258 Columbus Ave. Bocusse, 625 Columbus Ave. East End Deli, 52 East End Ave. Peter Parpas, 277 Greenwich St. Mimi's Pizzeria, 1248 Lexington Ave. Cafe Orlin, 41 St. Marks Place. Carolei Pizza, 1422 St. Nicholas Ave.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Paul Cox, John Myers In Bill for 2 Guitars
description: Monday evening's concert by Paul Cox and John Myers demonstrated how limited and uneven the literature for two guitars really is. Happily, these two players took the matter into their own hands and brought to this program at Carnegie Recital Hall some of their own transcriptions.

title: 50 YEARS OF MEMORIES IN A STEAMER TRUNK
description: IT was Thanksgiving Day 1978, a few weeks after my mother's death, but instead of roasting turkey and baking our favorite yam-and-apple casserole, I was busy cleaning out her apartment, discarding some things, saving as many as I thought I could keep, reliving her life as I leafed through books, gingerly skimmed letters, even tried on coats and jackets and dresses to see if any would fit me.

title: Connecticut Guide; LIVE TURKEY OLYMPICS
description: A Live Turkey Olympics are to be held at 1 P.M. today on the grounds of The Inn at Lake Waramaug, New Preston. An organizer of the event indicated that it was not known whether winners of the 50-foot race, the feed-eating contest, loudest gobble and largest turkey contest, and other competitions would receive Thanksgiving clemency as well as a victory wreath of Indian corn.

title: A RUTGERS TROUPE PACKS THE CHILDREN IN
description: NEW BRUNSWICK EVERY Sunday morning, eight Rutgers students go to the Jan Hus Theater on Manhattan's Upper East Side, where they turn into choreographers, stage managers, makeup artists and actors.

title: TRANSIT FARE CUTS DIVIDING LONDON'S LEADERS
description: The people who govern London are locked in a bitter legal dispute about a very basic subject - bus and subway fares.

title: November 22, 1981
description: NONFICTION AUTOBIOGRAPHY. Volume 1: 1907-1937. Journey East, Journey West. By Mircea Eliade. 12 THE COSMO REPORT. By Linda Wolfe. 16 FOR THE BIRDS. By John Cage. 12 THE GERM OF LAZINESS: Rockefeller Philanthropy and Public Health in the New South. By John Ettling. 16

title: MOROSCO GAINS AS LANDMARK
description: The Morosco Theater, threatened by demolition to make way for the long-delayed Portman Hotel near Times Square, was declared eligible last week for Federal landmark status. But its future as a theater remained in doubt.

title: Gail Shapiro, Teacher, Bride of Steven Goldman
description: Gail Helene Shapiro, a teacher of Spanish at John F. Kennedy High School in the Bronx, was married yesterday to Steven Paul Goldman, dean of students at the school. Dr. Israel Miller, senior vice president of Yeshiva University, performed the ceremony at the Bay Terrace Jewish Center in Bayside, Queens.

title: Other Hospitals Share Perinatal Designation
description: ''Shepherding Newborns Through Critical First Days'' (Oct. 25) failed to mention that the Level III regional designation in this area is shared by the Jersey Shore Medical Center, Neptune, and Monmouth Medical Center, Long Branch. The two hospitals combined are a Joint Regional Perinatal and Neonatal Center. BOBBE NICOLETTI Community Relations Director, Jersey Shore Medical Center

title: LET PILOTS ASSUME A GREATER SHARE OF AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: Westchester Housing; GREETINS WITH A PERSONAL TOUCH
description: ALOT of Christmas cards say ''Merry Christmas from our house to your house'' - and this year, more well-wishers will show exactly what they mean by ''our house.''

title: SOLAR RIDDLE OF AN ANCIENT EARTHWORK
description: One evening in 1953, over drinks at a ramshackle motel in the hill country of northeastern Louisiana, William Haag stared in disbelief at an aerial photograph. Part of an agricultural survey, the photograph depicted territory that Dr. Haag, an anthropologist and archeologist, had recently walked. But ground level concealed what a bird's-eye view made clear. Jutting out of a cotton field clustered with sharecroppers' houses was an enormous earthwork - mounds of earth of astonishing size and pattern.

title: PRUDENCE IN PARADISE
description: JO THOMAS is the Caribbean bureau chief for The New York Times. By JO THOMAS

title: ISLAND HIDEAWAYS: A SAMPLER
description: T o many people, ''Caribbean'' is synonymous with ''escape.'' To a select few, it isn't enough to escape to just any warm isle offering a reasonably comfortable hotel, edible food, a beach, water sports, golf and tennis. They also demand the ultimate in luxury and, often, maximum privacy, and are willing to pay $300 or more per person a day, including meals, to get what they want.

title: The Question of Sex Bias at Harvard
description: Fran Schumer's article, ''A Question of Sex Bias at Harvard'' (Oct. 18), suggests a basic conflict between the civil rights of women employed by universities and the ''academic freedom'' long cherished by university faculties.

title: Sunday Observer By Russell Baker, Cheap Heating Sources Patrick McDonnell
description: The heating-oil interests are advertising to warn consumers against switching to gas heat. Oil is still a terrific buy, they say, and even if it isn't, it will be just as soon as deregulation sends gas prices zooming.

title: Ideas and Trends; Flank Attack On Prayer Ban
description: The barriers that keep organized religion out of public schools came under a fresh, if somewhat oblique assault last week on Capitol Hill.

title: Crafts
description: ''FIBER,'' the current exhibition at the Tweed Arts Gallery in Plainfield, presents not only a broad view of the medium but also a challenge to its limits.

title: FREDERICK SMITH POTTER TO WED KATALIN SZULE
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Kalman Szule of Huntington, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Katalin Elizabeth Szule, to Frederick Smith Potter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Potter of Ormond Beach, Fla.

title: ROOSEVELT ISLAND TO ADD NEW UNITS
description: The second phase of the development of Roosevelt Island in the East River will begin next year, according to the Starrett Housing Corporation. A firm date has not been set.

title: Brunner Is Ready To Test His Future
description: In his entire career at the University of Delaware, Scott Brunner started only 14 games, all in his senior year. In his two seasons with the Giants, he has started only four games, all because Phil Simms has been injured.

title: PUBLICITY RIGHTS OF STARS: THE LIVING, AND THE DEAD
description: T HIS has to do with Martin Luther King, the Marx Brothers and Count Dracula. It has to do with Elvis Presley, Pat Paulsen's run for the Presidency and the ''Human Cannonball.'' It has to do with a Laurel and Hardy wiper blade campaign, and, if carried all the way back to its legal roots, it has something to do with baseball trading cards.

title: QADDAFI IS REPORTED TO PREPARE GUNMEN TO KILL THE PRESIDENT
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, has equipped ''special assassination squads'' to kill President Reagan, Vice President Bush, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, Newsweek magazine reported yesterday.

title: Pamela W. Handy Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Parker Douglas Handy of Fairfield and Lyme, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Woodbury Handy, to Roger Draper Shepley, son of Mrs. William Fenn of Blue Hill, Me., and Robert C. Shepley of Salem, Mass. A March wedding is planned.

title: Gregory Nelson, Executive, Weds Tris States, Designer
description: Tris States, an interior designer in New York, was married there yesterday to Gregory T. Nelson.

title: MURPHY'S LAW MEETS REAGAN'S ECONOMY
description: The emergence of a full-blown recession has thrown the Administration into tension and indecision over economic policy. Plainly, events have not followed the President's script. Unemployment is rising, possibly to 9 percent by March, Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, says. Housing and autos, pillars of postwar prosperity, are stunned. Capital spending is anemic despite the Reagan proinvestment tax cut. Revised figures showed the gross national product in the September quarter slightly up instead of slightly down, but that meant only that inventories were up; to work them off business would be trimming orders, production and jobs. Declines into the spring and perhaps the summer are expected.

title: Louisville 13 Southern Mississippi 10
description: The quarterback Dean May passed for two second-half touchdowns as Louisville rallied and upset Southern Mississippi, spoiling the Golden Eagles' hopes for an undefeated season.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Carol Davidson, Pianist, Plays Early Beethoven
description: Carol Davidson showed two attractive sides last Sunday afternoon at her Carnegie Recital Hall concert - first, a youthful energy, and then enough technique at the piano to make it felt. Not all of this ardor went in the right direction, but the opening movement of Beethoven's Sonata in D (Op. 10, No.3) had a wonderful springlike drive.

title: Mailbox; Seaver Was Best
description: To the Sports Editor: One of baseball's oldest sayings is that the first time a pitcher faces a team, it is easier to get the hitters out than it is after they've seen him a few times and know what to expect. Fernando Valenzuela was too erratic to deserve this year's Cy Young Award.

title: March Bridal Set By Miss Glodstein
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Glodstein of Massapequa, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jacqueline Sara Glodstein, to Charles Michael Diamond, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Diamond of Pittsburgh.

title: GRUMMAN SIGHS RELIEF AND SO DOES L.I.
description: Every Christmas Eve for the last 51 years, the Grumman Corporation has passed out a holiday bonus - one fresh turkey for each employee. It is a tradition that began during the Depression when Grumman's entire staff numbered 30 people. Keeping up that tradition costs Grumman more than $400,000 a year, for the payroll now includes 20,467 workers.

title: Japanese Volcano Erupts
description: One of Japan's most active volcanoes, Minami-dake on Sakura-jima Island in southern Japan, erupted today, sending a plume of ash 8,000 feet into the air. The Kagoshima observation station reported no major damage or casualties from the eruption, the 192d by the volcano this year.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: WHEN Massachusetts passed its bottle law, some liquor retailers there predicted disaster, but their counterparts in Connecticut were delighted that their competitors would soon face the same burden.

title: Chicano Literature
description: To the Editor:

title: Steven Salop Fiance Of Judith R. Gelman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman I. Gelman of Potomac, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Rebecca Gelman, to Steven Charles Salop, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul H. Salop of Penn Wynne, Pa. A March wedding is planned.

title: THE PATRON-REGULATOR OF THE BELEAGUERED THRIFTS
description: WASHINGTON H E looks something like a fullback for the New York Jets, and so when he says he wants to ''level the playing field,'' you have to take him seriously - especially with the kind of guards he's got running interference.

title: Paper Reports Four Suicides Related to Controllers' Strike
description: Two air traffic controllers and two wives of controllers have committed suicide since the walkout by the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization began in August, The Chicago Sun-Times reported today.

title: Future Events Auctions, Parties, Disco
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated: Disco in Darien Nov. 22 - The American Cancer Society's Southern Fairfield County Unit will benefit from a holiday party that begins with cocktails and hors d'oeuvres, followed by a roast-beef buffet and disco dancing at Twin Faces East, 2748 Post Road in Darien. An auction of 60 art works will be held. Tickets are $25, from (203) 655-3968. Singing for His Supper Nov. 23 - Hugh Shannon, the singer, will reign at an Evening With Hugh Shannon at the Carlyle Hotel to aid Southampton Hospital. Robert Welsh's decor includes flowers, and trees. The party, which starts at 6 P.M., includes an open bar, buffets of country pate, hot chicken dishes and marinated crudites. Tickets are $50, from 535-4060.

title: SPAIN'S PREMIER TAKES OVER SPLINTERED PARTY
description: Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo took over today as head of the badly splintered governing party and pledged to lead it through what he called difficult times for Spain's democracy.

title: CONNECTICUT PLAYERS SET PACE IN MIXED PAIRS AT TITLE BRIDGE
description: The first major championship to be played at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals, the mixed pairs, will be determined here tonight at the Sheraton Palace Hotel, and a Connecticut partnership is making a strong bid for victory.

title: PANAMA: TROUBLED PASSAGE FOR A U.S. ALLY
description: Alan Riding is the chief of The Times's bureau in Mexico City. By Alan Riding It was a dark and rainy morning, and the mood on the Panama National Guard's asphalt parade ground was no less somber as the country's military and civilian leaders gathered for the first time since burying the man to whom they owed their position and power, Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera. The band struggled to add some cheer with a medley of marches. Speeches pledging loyalty to the memory of the Lider Maximo were applauded. The army chaplain offered prayers, and young schoolgirls pinned red carnations on the uniforms of senior guard officers.

title: What's Wrong With Baseball
description: AMERICAN intellectuals from Billy Martin to George Steinbrenner have studied the science of baseball with varying results. Perhaps they are too close to the subject, unable to see the forest for the trees. Consequently, it is a blessing to view the subject briefly from the detached standpoint of the distinguished British scientific journal, ''Nature.'' The following was written soon after the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the New York Yankees for the fourth consecutive time, thereby winning the baseball championship of North America, not counting Cincinnati and St. Louis:

title: Stuart F. Walker And Katie Grimm Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jay V. Grimm of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Grimm, to Stuart F. Walker, son of Mrs. Robert Walker of Sampford Peverell, Devon, England, and the late Mr. Walker.

title: NEW YORK VS. LONDON
description: LONDON Bankers in the City, London's equivalent of Wall Street and the world's foremost Eurocurrency center, doubt that New York's debut in offshore banking will jeopardize their own position anytime soon. But it could eventually.

title: Deliberations Continue
description: The jury in the Boston College point-shaving trial completed its second day of deliberation without a verdict yesterday in United States District Court, Brooklyn and will resume deliberations tomorrow morning. The case went to the jury of eight women and four men Friday afternoon.

title: About Long Island
description: SIXTEEN miles and something more than a generation separate James Montalbano and Vin Roddie when they are at their hard days' nights of playing piano, Mr. Montalbano in the Lincoln Inn in Rockville Centre and Mr. Roddie in the Club House in Port Washington.

title: VENICE
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW THE FIRST THANKSGIVING MIGHT HAVE BEEN
description: CROSS RIVER WAS the Pilgrims' first Thanksgiving Day festival a solemn observance? Was turkey a main course on the menu? Did that early holiday observance last only one day?

title: ANATOLIA'S MAGIC CARPETS
description: MARVINE HOWE is chief of the Times bureau in Ankara, Turkey By MARVINE HOWE

title: MORE WOMEN TAKE KEY CO-OP POSTS
description: More and more women are joining the boards of cooperative apartment buildings in the city, according to an informal survey of managing agents and board members.

title: A THREAT TO JOBS
description: President Reagan greeted the autumn increase in unemployment with grim resolve - "I will not be deterred by temporary economic changes or short-term political expediency" - and with an affirmation of historic mission.

title: 11-0 CLEMSON TOPS S. CAROLINA, 29-13
description: Rod McSwain blocked a punt for a first-period touchdown to spark a Clemson rally, and Chuck McSwain, his older brother, ran for two second-half touchdowns as the secondranked Tigers defeated South Carolina today, 29-13, and completed their first perfect regular season in 33 years.

title: BARTOK- A LIFE BARED ON DISKS
description: Bela Bartok and the phonograph were born a century ago and grew up side by side. Bartok understood the power of recordings to broaden his career as composer and pianist; but in his shy, proud and somewhat fatalistic way, he never pursued the medium with any real tenacity. The phonograph, in return, showed only sporadic interest in him.

title: E.P.A.'S CHANGES DEFENDED BY AIDE
description: THE administrative head of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency said last week that he believed the current talk of massive cutbacks in environmental protection was exaggerated.

title: Practical Traveler; GETTING MILEAGE FROM YOUR FARE
description: As the cost of transportation rises, some of the best bargains continue to be the programs that allow you to travel as much as you want on a particular carrier within a specified time.

title: Brigham Young 56, Utah 28
description: The quarterback Jim McMahon became major college football's career passing leader, throwing for 565 yards and four touchdowns to lead Brigham Young to the Western Athletic Conference title and an automatic berth in the Holiday Bowl against Washington State.

title: DARTMOUTH DOWNS PENN, 33-13
description: Dartmouth scored two fourth-quarter touchdowns today at Franklin Field to cap a 33-13 rout of Pennsylvania and a season that earned the Big Green a share of the Ivy League championship.

title: TORONTO MOVIE BAZAAR
description: ANDREW H. MALCOLM is chief of the Toronto bureau of The Times. By ANDREW H.MALCOLM

title: Ex-Im
description: To the Business Editor: ''In Defense of the Ex-Im'' (Nov. 1), offers arguments for expanded funding of this ananchronistic institution. All are either wrong or naivee.

title: Boston College 27 Rutgers 21
description: Boston College turned two third-quarter fumble recoveries into a 36-yard field goal by John Cooper and a 4-yard touchdown pass from Doug Flutie to Brian Krystoforski and held on to win.

title: The New York Times/Sara Krulwich WINTER ON THE HORIZON
description: Pedestrians providing their chapeaus with additional anchorage as they crossed Columbus Avenue near Lincoln Center. Yester-day's winds of more than 30 miles an hour and falling thermometer were signs of coming season. Today should be cool, the temperature in the low 40's, and windy.

title: Other Business; BUSINESS ON TRIAL: A TEXTBOOK VIEW
description: The 1960's and 1970's was a turbulent era for the American corporation. Scores of companies were diverted from the delivery of their usual products and services by great conflicts between them and the society. Case studies of many of those conflicts are collected in the fourth edition of ''Up Against the Corporate Wall,'' by S. Prakash Sethi and published by Prentice Hall. The author is a business professor at the University of Texas in Dallas. The table of contents, alone, offers as good a record as any of those times: Here are excerpts:

title: Seton Hall Crushes Delbarton, Gains Final
description: Seton Hall defeated Delbarton, 42-3, yesterday to advance to the final round of the North Jersey, Parochial A playoffs. The Seton Hall defense held Delbarton to 136 yards rushing.

title: A SPECIAL DAY, A SPECIAL GUEST
description: I ASKED the question once, a long time ago, and never again. It was Thanksgiving 1943, and I was a toothpick of a lad, eager to gnash my teeth on the oven-brown turkey that was permeating the apartment with an exquisite aroma. The drumstick was my sole quest. But, as I stared hungrily at it in the oven, I noticed how enormous the turkey was for the number of people invited.

title: Children's Books
description: NEED A HOUSE? CALL MS.MOUSE! By George Mendoza. Illustrated by Doris Susan Smith. New York: Grosset & Dunlap. Unpaged. $5.95. (Ages 3 to 6) By DORIS ORGEL

title: ACOUSTICS: STILL PLAYING IT BY EAR
description: Harold C. Schonberg, cultural correspondent of The Times, is the author of the recent book, ''Facing the Music.'' By Harold C. Schonberg ext year will see an anniversary that perhaps Lincoln Center would prefer to forget. It was in 1962 that an eager audience in dress clothes picked its way through puddles of damp concrete and patches of wet paint to be at the inaugural concert of Philharmonic Hall, the first structure to be opened in the Lincoln Center complex. Leonard Bernstein conducted the New York Philharmonic, and well before intermission listeners began to realize that all was not for the best in this hailed-in-advance best of all acoustic worlds. The hall lacked bass, the sound was muddy. Later, this opinion was reinforced when acoustics specialists and critics rendered their negative verdict.

title: Ann Brooks, Student, Wed
description: Ann Jolliffe Brooks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Benjamin Brooks Jr. of Cresskill, N.J., was married yesterday to Gareth David Keene, son of the late Mildred A. Keene of Oradell, N.J. The Rev. Roger Weir performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Englewood, N.J.

title: Long Island Housing; NEW LAW MAKES FIRST-TIME HOMEOWNERSHIP EASIER
description: AGAINST all odds, Richard and Catherine Tantillo, newlyweds and first-time home buyers, have found an affordable house. The home, which is new, is in a development of 44 single-family homes called Woodridge Meadows, now under construction in Mount Sinai, and will be ready for occupancy by next spring.

title: HISTORIAN LINKS FREUD AND WIFE'S SISTER AS LOVERS
description: Sigmund Freud and his wife's sister, Minna Bernays, were probably lovers, a historian has asserted after restudying some of Freud's writings and retracing a trip to Italy that the two made in 1900.

title: MUSIC: MCCABE VARIATIONS
description: Each of the programs in the British Festival of Andre Previn and his Pittsburgh Symphony have included one New York premiere. The novelty for the third and last of the concerts Friday -the first in Avery Fisher Hall - was the Variations on a Theme of Karl Amadeus Hartmann (1964) by John McCabe.

title: Home Clinic; SAFETY TIPS FOR OPERATING A SNOW THROWER
description: WHILE no one will argue that a snow thrower can save the homeowner many hours of backbreaking shoveling - and maybe even a potential heart attack - these machines can also cause serious injuries when an operator is careless or not familiar with safe operating practices.

title: Rita Sluka, Nurse, Is Wed
description: Rita Marie Sluka, a registered nurse at Glen Cove (L.I.) Hospital, was married yesterday to Antonio de la Caridad Diez, a supervisor of building services at the hospital. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John T. Mahoney at the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church in Flushing, Queens. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Sluka Jr. of Jamaica Estates, Queens. Mr. Diez is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Manuel Diez of Havana.

title: C.W. Post 45 Merchant Marine 36
description: Tom Ehrhardt completed 34 of 55 passes, six for touchdowns, for 432 yards to set three school records in leading C.W. Post to a 45-36 victory over the United States Merchant Marine Academy today at Hickox Field.

title: Lisa Dillon Plans May 8 Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold C. Dillon of Darien, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Dillon, to Robert Stanton Tullis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Tullis Jr. of Westfield, N.J., and Groton Long Point, Conn.

title: CONFEREES REACH TENTATIVE ACCORD ON SPENDING BILL
description: House and Senate negotiators reached a tentative agreement early this morning on the major elements of a compromise spending bill that would provide operating funds for the Federal Government when it opens for business Monday morning.

title: Environews
description: WILL the Lone Pine Landfill in Freehold Township, one of the most seriously contaminated dumps in New Jersey, be converted into the state's first secured chemical-waste dump?

title: BY PATRICIA H. PAINTON PARIS
description: Whatever the other consequences of the election of a Socialist Government, American companies are finding a warmer welcome in France than they have in two decades. ''The previous Government refused everything except what it had to approve,'' said a civil servant in the Government's foreign investment agency. ''This one approves everything except what it has to refuse.''

title: COMPANIES IN RACE FOR TV FRANCHISES
description: It is heralded as the ''cable revolution'' and the ''electronic age,'' a bit of George Orwell's fictional vision come to alter reality in living rooms across the country. Now, slowly but inexorably, cable television is entering the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.

title: Leisure; THE VEGETABLE GARDEN AS A MELTING POT
description: As a nation prepares to pause next Thursday in Thanksgiving, gardeners can reflect on the past season's harvest. For all who wield a trowel and hoe share one thing in common. Their crops are ancestors of wild plants that once grew all over the world. The modern vegetable patch is a geographical potpourri gathered from plants that were found on mountainsides and along river banks in many remote regions.

title: Jill N. Beasley Is Married to Charles S. Johnson 3d
description: Jill Nedenia Beasley, a press relations representative for the Exxon Corporation in New York, and Charles Sanderson Johnson 3d, director of management development for ITT Rayonier in Stamford, Conn., were married yesterday at the Riverside Church. The Rev. Robert L. Polk, executive director of the Council of Churches of the City of New York, performed the ceremony.

title: AIRLINES EXPECT NO UNUSUAL PROBLEM OVER HOLIDAY
description: Although the walkout of air traffic controllers has curtailed the number of flights, Thanksgiving weekend is not expected to be significantly more difficult for air travelers than usual.

title: CABARET: ORIGINALITY BY CATHERINE COX
description: Catharine Cox has a long face that can be comic, warmly vulnerable, sad or simply sincere. She also has a penetrating sense of humor, a voice that can handle comic material or very lyrical melodies and a programming imagination that loaded her late-evening performances at Freddy's, 308 East 49th Street, through last night, with unusual material.

title: Antiques; FUNCIONAL OR FANCIFUL, IT'S ALL GLASS IN MILLVILLE
description: MILLVILLE THE Wheaton Village Museum, which claims to have the country's largest collection of American glass, could not be more ideally situated, for it was in this Cumberland County area that the New Jersey glass industry had its beginnings before the Revolution.

title: The Nation; A Reagan Man On Civil Rights
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights doesn't have all that much power but the person who heads it, and the way he is treated by the White House, has acquired some symbolic significance. Thus the outcry from many civil rights organizations last week when President Reagan abruptly dismissed Arthur S. Flemming as chairman.

title: Copiague Stops West Islip, 8-0
description: West Islip was defeated by Copiague, 8-0, yesterday, in the Suffolk Class A semifinal playoffs. Copiague will meet Commack North for the Class A championship next Saturday at Central Islip. Commack North gained the final with an 8-6 victory over Brentwood.

title: Stamps; AMERICA'S DESERT PLANTS
description: In its final commemorative issue of the year, the United States is putting out on Dec. 11 in Tucson, Ariz. its long-awaited block of four devoted to eye-filling varieties of desert plants found in greatest abundance in the American Southwest.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Mystery at Yale
description: Somehow someone had made off with the ''President's Collar'' at Yale. This $100,000 neckpiece, which the university president wore on occasions of high ceremony, was made of enamel, gold, silver and precious stones.

title: Edward Davie Jr. to Wed Urling Iselin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Iselin have made known the engagement of their daughter, Urling Sibley Iselin, to Edward Thomas Bedford Davie Jr., son of Mrs. Charles Addams of New York and Water Mill, L.I., and of Mr. Davie of Palm Beach, Fla., and Scottsdale, Ariz. A June wedding is planned.

title: CABLE TV- THE TIME IS PRIME FOR REGULATION
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lewis J. Paper practices communications law in Washington, D.C. Until recently, he was associate general counsel and chief of the Administrative Law Division of the Federal Communications Commission. By LEWIS J. PAPER

title: DANCE: JAZZ AND SHOW
description: Jazz and show dance haven't fared too well on the concert stage. But the Danny Buraczeski Dance Company, the creation of a former Broadway gypsy, has lasted an impressive two years. And on Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church, the company presented a bright, quietly inventive and even thought-provoking evening of jazz dance that suggested the idiom might be less limited than it seems.

title: High Suicide Rate in Prisons
description: On an average day, at least one prison inmate in the United States kills himself, according to a newly released study by the National Center on Institutions and Alternatives. The suicide rate in the nation's prisons was found to be 16 times higher than that of the general population. The study, based on 1979 data, found that the majority of the inmates who killed themselves had been arrested on alcohol or drug-abuse charges.

title: CLUSTERING LOOMS IN 3 TOWNS
description: EAST HAMPTON IF three Suffolk towns have their way, the clustering, or grouping together of homes, in subdivisions to increase an area's open space will no longer be a decision left to developers. Instead, the planning and town boards of East Hampton, Southampton and Islip will have the final say on whether large stretches of farmland, wetlands or woods will be left intact while housing - either on smaller-thannormal lots or in attached units - is built in concentrated sections of the virgin tracts.

title: KENTUCKIANS LIKE GOVERNOR'S STYLE
description: At the Cave Hill mansion of Gov. John Y. Brown Jr., the midnight oil is burning. The Kentucky Governor and his close aides are reviewing strategies, as they have on many similar occasions, for running state government more like a private enterprise.

title: Military Analysis
description: Ariel Sharon, Israel's Defense Minister, is due in Washington later this month to discuss the fashioning of a strategic alliance that has become urgently important to the Israelis.

title: Personal Finance; CON GAMES AT THE CASH MACHINE
description: T HE preoccupied Citibank customer inserts his Citicard into an automatic teller machine and presses the buttons that enable him to withdraw $200. But a well-dressed man talking on the customer service telephone nearby tells him the machine isn't working properly and urges him to use another machine.

title: CHINA GETS A GLIMPSE OF AMERICAN INDIAN LIFE
description: A century-old Sioux tepee, Pomo tribal baskets and Haida carved wooden masks may be giving the Chinese a not-sounfamiliar glimpse of that faraway land called America.

title: Dr. Frederick Reiss, 90, Dies; Taught Dermatology in China
description: Dr. Frederick Reiss, retired chief of the dermatology service at Montefiore Hospital, died Friday at Beth Abraham Hospital. Dr. Reiss, a resident of Manhattan, was 90 years old.

title: LOOK TO THE ISLAND AND FIND AMERICA
description: ON Long Island there is a unique stretch of pine-barrens land. It is unique because of the combination of pines, oaks, plants and certain wildlife that is peculiar only to this area.

title: The Question of Sex Bias At Harvard
description: The Harvard sociology department's callous disregard of enthusiastic student endorsement of Professor Skocpol's excellence as a teacher, plus Miss Schumer's assertion that at Harvard ''teaching is low on the list of hiring criteria,'' makes me cry out: For Mark Hopkins's sake, what confers academic distinction on a college - 345 years of existence - or a faculty of gifted and valued teachers? (REV.) HENRY M. BARTLETT, Deerfield, Mass.

title: CONQUES
description: To the Editor:

title: Critics' Choices
description: JAZZ Jackie Cain and Roy Kral have been singing together for 33 years, since 1948 when they were both with Charlie Ventura's orchestra in which Mr. Kral was the pianist and Miss Cain was the ''girl'' singer. They have since married, raised a family, lived the suburban life and still carried on their joint professional careers very successfully.

title: Mississippi 21, Miss. St. 17
description: John Fourcade scored from the 1 with two seconds left to upset Mississippi's archrival only moments after it had appeared the Hall of Fame bowl-bound Bulldogs had rescued a victory.

title: Stanford 42, California 21
description: Darrin Nelson's two touchdowns in the second period made him Stanford's leading career scorer. The junior quarterback John Elway threw three touchdown passes, one to Nelson and two to Vincent White, and tied a Pacific-10 Conference record by increasing his career total to 53.

title: FOUR ISLANDS A LA CARTE
description: CRAIG CLAIBORNE is the food editor of The New York Times. By CRAIG CLAIBORNE

title: INQUIRY ON ALLEN IS SAID TO FOCUS ON WHETHER HE RECEIVED $10,000
description: The Justice Department's renewed investigation of Richard V. Allen, the national security adviser, has focused on evidence found in Mr. Allen's safe indicating that he might have received $10,000 from a Japanese journalist, not $1,000 as previously reported, an Administration official said today.

title: I'm With Munro
description: To the Business Editor: I applaud J. Richard Munro's courage and honesty in expressing his disapproval of President Reagan's actions in ''Against the Budget Cuts'' (Nov. 15).

title: DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM CUTS BACK
description: Although the 12-year-old Dance Theater of Harlem is internationally acclaimed for being on its toes behind the footlights, its financial footing is quite shaky these days. That is chiefly, according to executives, because it has lost private support.

title: Susan Wilkinson Is Bride of Banker
description: Susan Stansfield Wilkinson, manager of planning and analysis with the Dayton Hudson Corporation in Minneapolis, was married yesterday in Wayzata, Minn., to A. Rodney Boren Jr., vice president of moneymarket services for the Northwestern National Bank in Minneapolis.

title: ELAINE BONILLA ENGAGED TO MAJ. ARTHUR ALPHIN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Enrique Bonilla of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elaine Marie Bonilla, to Maj. Arthur Brent Alphin, U.S.A., son of Col. Horace Edward Alphin, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Alphin of Buchanan and Clifton, Va.

title: HERE COME THE - HELP! - MOPEDS
description: AS A motorist, I have trained myself to deal with drunken drivers, drugged drivers, demented drivers and drivers whose carelessness seems innocent in comparison.

title: Rebels Kill 6 Thai Officials
description: Communist insurgents ambushed and killed six provincial officials Friday in southern Thailand. The police said today that the guerrillas detonated a land mine under a pickup truck carrying the officials in Chumphon Province, 250 miles south of Bangkok. The rebels then opened fire with rockets and light weapons, the police said.

title: HOW ELF WORKS FOR FRANCE
description: PARIS I n 1980, Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, the huge French oil company that later paid $2.5 billion to take over Texasgulf Inc., hoped to make a far bigger, $5 billion acquisition of another American company, Kerr-McGee. It never happened, and the reason was that Elf's big and even more powerful brother, the French Government, took a look at the deal, didn't like it and quashed it.

title: Judy Ann Stutz to Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan Stutz of Allantown, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judy Ann Stutz, to Barry A. Nelson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Nelson of Plainview, L. I. The wedding is planned for June.

title: The Region; The Straits of Westchester
description: Westchester may be affluent by many standards, but the condition of its treasury apparently isn't one of them. That seemed evident last week as the County Executive, Alfred B. DelBello, proposed a budget calling for layoffs, service cuts and, after three consecutive years of county tax reductions, a tax increase.

title: Marla M. Roth Is the Fiancee of Morris Newman
description: Mrs. Herbert I. Sugarman of Great Neck, and Howard H. Roth of Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marla M. Roth, to Morris Newman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Beni Newman of Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: Bruins 5, Maple Leafs 3
description: TORONTO (AP) - The Crowder brothers, Bruce and Keith, broke a 3-3 tie in the third period for Boston.

title: Lawrence 21 Minnesota-Morris 14
description: The quarterback Dean Walsh threw two touchdown passes, and Scott Reppert added a 78-yard touchdown run as Lawrence University won the Division III first-round playoff game in overtime. Lawrence has won 18 straight games.

title: QADDAFI'S DREAM OF ISLAMIC EMPIRE IS STILL A MIRAGE
description: In the posters of him that adorn this capital, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi does not ordinarily share the limelight.

title: Congress Keeps Them Guessing
description: Senator William Proxmire is not generally known for his restrained expressions of sentiment. Last week, he was a master of understatement.

title: M.S. Dreux Fiance Of Joan H. Albert
description: Mr. and Mrs. John H. Albert of Stratford, Conn., formerly of Rye, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Joan H. Albert, to Mark S. Dreux, son of Mrs. Victor Dowling of West Simsbury, Conn., and the late Dirk C. Dreux. The wedding is planned for May in St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Washington.

title: SCHOLARS FACE A CHALLENGE BY FEMINISTS
description: Using scholarship developed in the feminist movement, women in colleges and universities are questioning the fundamental tenets of academic fields ranging from history and philosophy to the natural sciences.

title: TRANSIT AUTHORITY'S LAWYERS SAID TO DO OUTSIDE WORK
description: Some lawyers on the full-time staff of the New York City Transit Authority engage in private practice during working hours, according to a team of management analysts that has spent the last six months looking into the system's operations.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Is there any difference between the 3-point lines in the National Basketball Association and those in the now-defunct American Basketball Association?

title: Ed Asner Editorializes About the Press
description: He portrays a newspaper editor on television and heads a union in real life, but Ed Asner isn't happy with either field. ''Somewhere along the line I fell out of love with the press,'' said the actor, who described the turning point as the press's ''noncoverage'' of the recent strike by the Screen Actors Guild, which he now heads.

title: WORK RULES HINDER GAINS ON COMMUTER LINES
description: In a single week last July, an engineer operating Conrail commuter trains from Grand Central Terminal drew more than 19 days' pay - $1,912. Last year he made $67,225. Nine other engineers and conductors on the Conrail-operated Harlem and Hudson lines of the state's Metropolitan Transportation Authority made $55,870 to $68,646 - close to the $70,000 salary of the M.T.A.'s top rail executive.

title: WILIAM ROSENBLATT, COMPANY FOUNDER AND FINANCIER, 88
description: William Rosenblatt, a financier and a director and organizer of many companies, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88 years old.

title: Washington Watch; Bankers' Goal: More Leeway
description: WASHINGTON THE Treasury has finally submitted its long-awaited legislative proposals to let commercial banks offer a much broader range of financial services and compete with securities firms, travel companies and even retailers such as Sears, Roebuck & Company.

title: PROFILES OF TRANSIT LEADERS IN NEW YORK CITY AREA
description: The destiny of commuter rail service in the New York area and the fortunes of more than 500,000 daily riders depend largely on the leadership of the area's three top commuter rail officials.

title: Hinckley, in New Cell, Is Under Closer Guard
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., who is charged with trying to kill President Reagan, was released from an Army hospital today and moved to a different cell from the one in which he tried to hang himself a week earlier, the Justice Department announced.

title: EAST BLOC ARMIES THINK NUCLEAR WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Power System Bonds Delayed
description: A $150 million plan to suspend development of two nuclear powers plants ran into another snag when the Washington Public Power Supply System was forced to postpone preparations for a $200 million bond sale to build three other power plants.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Solid Gold Mini-Car
description: Big Auto is finally getting its technical act together. The new American cars - which cost some $40 billion to tool - are trim, fuelefficient and, by most reports, better built than previous generations of Detroit iron.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT RANGERS, 7-2
description: The Islanders seemed completely recovered from their recent slump last night as they defeated the Rangers, 7-2, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Dead or Alive?
description: Is the Women's Professional Basketball League dead? The league that began with high hopes in 1978 is showing only feeble flickers of life.

title: Bridge: Retiring President Shares Title in Mixed Pairs Event
description: The retiring president of the American Contract Bridge League won the National Mixed Pairs title Saturday night at the Fall National Championships. Jim Zimmerman of Cleveland, who ended his one-year term three days ago, was the first outgoing president to achieve such a triumph.

title: Faltering Nets Beaten by Sonics, 109-92
description: ''I don't know why,'' Larry Brown, the coach of the Nets, said tonight after his team lost, 109-92, to the Seattle SuperSonics, ''that all of a sudden we're becoming the New Jersey team of old. But it sure looks like that's where we're going.''

title: GROUP GOES FROM EXILE TO INFLUENCE
description: The Committee on the Present Danger, a little-known foreign policy group, found itself in an unusual position at its annual meeting here this month. More than a sixth of its members had been forced to take leaves of absence.

title: Sohio Unit
description: The Standard Oil Company of Ohio has announced the formation of the Sohio Industrial Products Company to direct the operations of the manufacturing businesses acquired in Sohio's takeover of the Kennecott Corporation. Sohio Industrial Products will begin operations Jan. 1 and will be based in Cleveland, Sohio said Friday. Kennecott's current president, Glenn P. Bakken, will become president of the new unit.

title: Defective Welds Suspected In Fatal Crash of Test Plane
description: Defective welds on a recently installed engine mount may have caused the crash of an experimental plane, investigators said Saturday.

title: Addenda
description: Emery Advertising Corp., Hunt Valley, Md., and Torrieri/Myers Advertising have agreed to merge.

title: Mary Behling Married to Dr. Jay Bock, Pathologist
description: Mary Katherine Behling, daughter of John L. Behling of Newtown, Conn., and Elizabeth F. Nicholson of Pompano Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. Jay Lawrence Bock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Bock of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and New York. Rabbi Jon Hadden performed the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel.

title: Indiana Wins, 5-1
description: In other Division I games, top-ranked Indiana defeated Wisconsin, 5-1, in Bloomington, Ind., to take the Great Lakes Region championship for the fourth consecutive year.

title: Egyptian Oil Output
description: Egypt is expected to produce a record 35.5 million tons of oil this year, Deputy Premier Fouad Mohieddin told Parliament, up from 32.9 million last year.

title: COLUMBIA TO DISTRIBUTE ATTENBOROUGH 'GANDHI'
description: ''Gandhi,'' Richard Attenborough's $22 million movie biography of the Indian leader who was assassinated in 1948, has been purchased for worldwide distribution by Columbia Pictures. After three months of negotiation, the final details were ironed out this weekend.

title: New Jersey to Open the Files On the Lindbergh Kidnapping
description: Fifty-year-old police files on the Lindbergh kidnap-murder case will be opened for limited public inspection, officials said.

title: Venezuela Oil Price Rises
description: Venezuela raised prices for some residual fuels with low sulfur content by up to 60 cents a barrel, Humberto Calderon Berti, the Energy and Mines Minister, announced.

title: Jon Hassell in Program Of New Jazz at Public
description: ''Jazz'' is an ever more amorphous term, and one proof of that could be found last weekend at the Public Theater, when Blue Gene Tyranny and Jon Hassell appeared Friday and Saturday nights in that facility's estimable new-jazz series. Neither Robert Sheff, which is Mr. Tyranny's original name, nor Mr. Hassell derives from any recognizable jazz tradition.

title: SPACE PROGRAM: ALL OUR EGGS IN FOUR BASKETS
description: To the Editor:

title: GIANTS UPSET EAGLES
description: How do you figure it? The Giants had lost their last three games this season and had lost 12 straight to the Philadelphia Eagles since opening day in 1975. The Eagles entered the game with a 9-2 record, the best in the National Football League, and they were 9 1/2-point favorites.

title: Man Seized in Holdup Is a Suspect in 2d Case
description: One of the three men arrested after an attempted holdup of a Queens supermarket and a shootout with plainclothes officers yesterday has been identified by the police as a suspect in the shooting of a police officer in early October.

title: HOW HOUSE MEMBERS VOTED
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 205 to 194 by which the House of Representatives today approved a $427.9 billion continuing appropriations bill. A ''yes'' vote was a vote in favor of the bill. A ''no'' vote was a vote against it.

title: GROWTH BRINGS PAIN TO DRESDNER BANK
description: Behind the aging squat sandstone building housing Dresdner Bank's executive offices stands a new 32-story glass-andaluminum office building, neatly reflecting the bank's recent explosive growth.

title: Color Tile at Doner
description: W.B. Doner & Company will be serving the broadcast advertising needs of Color Tile Inc., Baltimore, from its offices in that city, Detroit and Houston.

title: Israeli's Trial Starts
description: Aharon Abuhazira, an Israeli Cabinet minister accused of larceny, pleaded not guilty today as his trial opened in District Court. Mr. Abuhazira, Minister of Labor, Welfare and Immigration, announced that he would take a leave of absence from his Cabinet post for the duration of the trial. Mr. Abuhazira is charged with using $4,300 in public money for household expenses while he was Mayor of Ramleh from 1975 to 1978.

title: TV: 'SAMSON AND DEILAH'
description: PUBLIC TELEVISION'S relatively ample opera repertory is expanded further this evening, on Channel 13 at 8, with the 1980 San Francisco Opera production of ''Samson and Delilah'' composed by Camille Saint-Saens to a libretto by Ferdinand Lemaire, a young Creole Martinique poet who was the composer's cousin by marriage. This version of the work, conducted by Julius Rudel, stars Placido Domingo as Samson, Shirley Verrett as Delilah and Wolfgang Brendel as the High Priest.

title: RAISING GIFTED CHILDREN
description: ''K IDS are kids,'' says Gail Robinson of the American Association for Gifted Children in New York. ''They are children first. They may be brilliant, but they're not little old people - they still have the emotional needs of all children. The best approach for a parent who is confused or anxious about how to handle such a special child is to join one of the parents' support groups you can find in almost any state.''

title: Boston Hospital Curbs Experiments on Children
description: Massachusetts General Hospital, one of the nation's major medical research centers, issued new guidelines today ordering doctors to avoid experiments on children unless the risks are ''decisively outweighed'' by the potential benefits.

title: People
description: * Robert H. Wolf has joined Kenyon & Eckhardt Inc. as a senior vice president and general manager of the agency's Los Angeles office.

title: NEW CHIEF AT COWLES
description: Francis J. Barry, 58, has been elected chief executive officer and named to the newly created post of vice chairman of Cowles Communications Inc., effective Jan. 1. As chief executive, he succeeds Marvin C. Whatmore, 73, who will continue as chairman and become a consultant to Cowles, which is based in Daytona Beach, Fla.

title: CABARET: PATTI LABELLE, POP AND SOUL
description: AFTER 20 years in show business, Patti LaBelle, who opened a fournight stand at the Savoy on Thursday, remains a great but eccentric pop-soul talent. Part earth mother, part glitter queen, and a performer who can go from pure gospel to pure camp with just a sweep of the hand, Miss LaBelle has built up an especially devout cult over the years, and on her opening night she was greeted with tumultuous acclaim.

title: From Court to Court
description: Last week, two cases involving high school sports were taken all the way to the United States Federal Court. Milton I. Shadur, a Federal District judge in Chicago, ruled on Tuesday that the Illinois Athletic Association does not have the right to order Yeshiva high school boys to remove their skullcaps during athletic events.

title: Books Of The Times
description: THE LETTERS OF NUNNALLY JOHNSON. Selected and edited by Dorris Johnson and Ellen Leventhal. Foreword by Alistair Cooke. Illustrated. 281 pages. Knopf. $16.50.

title: OKLAHOMA VS. HOUSTON IN SUN
description: The last two bowl spots were filled yesterday as Houston agreed to meet Oklahoma in the Sun Bowl Dec. 26, and Kansas accepted an offer to play Mississippi State in the Hall of Fame Bowl Dec. 31. This accounts for all 32 teams in the 16 major-college postseason games, only two of which may be involved in determining the final No.1 team in the nation.

title: OPERA: JANACEK TWO-ACTOR
description: Leos Janacek may never replace Puccini, his junior by four years, in the affections of operagoers outside Czechoslovakia; still, the last two decades have seen a remarkable and widespread resurgence of interest in his stage works, which he viewed as his own most important achievements. Such operas as ''The Makropulos Affair,'' ''The Cunning Little Vixen'' and ''From the House of the Dead,'' once consigned to sit on the shelf in a few Czechoslovak theaters, have been appearing with increasing frequency in major houses in the United States and in Europe.

title: LIBYA PRESSSED TO REVISE TOUGH OIL-PRICE POLICY
description: This North African country, a hawk among OPEC members, is feeling increasing pressure to lower its oil prices to prevent an exodus of American oil companies, which control 70 percent of the oil-producing technology here.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1981
description: International Greece will set a timetable for the removal of American bases from the country. The timetable is the firm intention of the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, who said in his first major policy address that his Government will also proceed to unilateral nuclear disarmament and the renunciation of the 1980 agreement that returned Greece to the military wing of NATO. The Prime Minister made it clear that he intended to carry out the broad lines of his radical election platform on which his Panhellenic Socialist Movement won a sweeping victory last month. (Page A1, Column 3.) Soviet-West German talks on arms are due in Bonn with the arrival there of Leonid I. Brezhnev, who will discuss with Chancellor Helmut Schmidt possible nuclear arms reductions in Europe. The schedule of the three days of talks was spaced to allow the 74-year-old Soviet leader long periods of rest. The basic issues are the Soviet Union's buildup of its SS-20 nuclear missiles, NATO's intention to deploy new American-made weapons to counter them, and the American-Soviet arms talks in Geneva. (A1:1-2.)

title: EDMONTON RETAINS GREY CUP
description: Warren Moon scored on two quarterback sneaks in the second half, and Dave Cutler kicked the winning field goal with three seconds left today to lead Edmonton to a 26-23 victory over Ottawa in the Grey Cup game. It was a record fourth straight Canadian Football League championship for the Eskimos.

title: Ford Plant Closing
description: The Ford Motor Company says it has turned down an offer by workers to buy its Northville valve plant and has closed the 62-year-old facility, eliminating 75 jobs. It cited as the main reason for the closing a reduced requirement in valves for smaller four- and six-cyclinder engines. Norman E. Fultz, president of United Auto Workers union Local 896, had proposed the workers buy and operate the facility, selling to Ford the engine intake valves they produce.

title: ELECTION NIGHT FEVER RISES IN JERSEY AGAIN
description: Tom Downs likes to tell the story about the schoolboy who is asked to add a list of numbers and totals it 10 times to make sure he is right. But it comes out differently each time. Unsure where the error lies, he gives his teacher all 10 answers.

title: PHONE FORECASTS FOR TRAVELERS SET
description: The National Weather Service is beginning a new call-in forecasting service for travelers this week. Two-day forecasts for major cities will be available to direct-dial callers from around the country.

title: THE DANCE: LARRY HYMAN'S 'TIME PIECES'
description: STAGESTRUCK youngsters still have dreams of ''putting on a show,'' it seems. But Larry Hyman, a young Bejart-trained Broadway dancer and assistant choreographer whose ''Time Pieces'' was performed on Saturday at the Washington Square Church, didn't have the backing of a big movie studio's resources behind him.

title: Daughter Held In Doctor's Death
description: A 27-year-old woman was charged with stabbing to death her 73-year-old father, a doctor.

title: COLLEGE BOWL SCHEDULE
description: INDEPENDENCE BOWL Okla. State (7-3) vs. Texas A & M (6-4) Shreveport, La. 8 P.M., Dec. 12 GARDEN STATE BOWL Wisconsin (7-4) vs.

title: CITY CREDITORS IN NEED
description: To the Editor:

title: ANNIVERSARY OF SLAYING
description: At the grave of John F. Kennedy yesterday, the 18th anniversary of his death, Evelyn Lincoln, a secretary to the former President, placed flowers. In Dallas, about 200 people attended a memorial ceremony at the site of the assassination.

title: MAIL CALL AT THE OVAL OFFICE
description: A 10-year-old writes wanting to join the Army. A union man condemns the President's handling of the air controllers' strike. A woman in Virginia pleads for help in finding the son kidnapped by her estranged husband.

title: ON TOUR IN LOUISIANA SWAMP
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt leaping to shore from boat Saturday in Louisiana's Atchafalaya River Basin. Gov. David C. Treen led Mr. Watt on the tour of the wetlands, the nation's largest hardwood swamp, in an attempt to convince him that the Federal Government should help the state purchase part of the 593,000-acre basin.

title: CHIEFS ROUT SEAHWAKS, 40-13
description: Since Marv Levy took over as head coach of the Kansas City Chiefs in December 1977, the team that had won only two of 14 games the previous season has showed a slow, steady improvement. Levy turned in records of 4-12, 7-9 and 8-8 during his first three seasons, building a youthful team through the draft. Now he seems to have the Chiefs ready to challenge for a divisional championship and, perhaps, the club's first playoff appearance since 1971.

title: News Analysis
description: Many bishops and others present at last week's meeting of the Roman Catholic hierarchy of the United States say they believe it was a remarkable turning point in the American church's stance on a cluster of social issues. In the meeting, the bishops took a new and riskier course of action.

title: Syrian Killed in Spain
description: A Syrian refugee was killed Saturday by unidentified assailants who shot him twice in the head, the police said today. Nizar Sagab, 40 years old, belonged to the Moslem Brotherhood.

title: WAGE RISE MODERATION SEEN FOR '82
description: Collective bargaining settlements in industries that have historically set wage patterns are expected to be ''very moderate'' next year and are unlikely to exert the influence that they have in the past, according to an annual forecast by the Conference Board that was released yesterday.

title: Tokyo Record Set By Mairzy Doates
description: Mairzy Doates, a 5-year-old veteran American campaigner, won the $537,000 Japan Cup horse race in course-record time today, beating an international field of 14 other horses before a crowd of 90,000 at the Tokyo Race Course.

title: Bills 20, Patriots 17
description: Joe Ferguson's 36-yard touchdown pass to Roland Hooks with only five seconds left gave Buffalo (7-5) the victory. The Bills had gained possession on their 28 with no timeouts remaining and 35 seconds left.

title: OUTDOORS: TRAIL RIDING NEAR HOME
description: THREE teen-age couples are about to plunge, on horseback, into the November cold of Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx. One couple, apparently the instigators of the outing, are already mounted and looking quite comfortable. The others size up their horses nervously. Finally, one approaches the mounting block as though it were a gallows.

title: French Military Base Raided
description: Ten armed men raided a French military base today, tied up guards and other personnel and stole more than 100 automatic weapons, an army spokesman said.

title: ASSOCIATED NAMES PRESIDENT OF CALDOR
description: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation is moving one of its own executives into top management at Caldor, a discount store chain that it acquired about six months ago.

title: REISCHAUER'S MISLABELED REPLY TO AN INTERVIEW
description: To the Editor:

title: Zaccio Triumphs
description: Heavily-favored Zaccio, ridden by Gregg Morris, moved from next-to-last in the stretch today and surged into the lead with one fence remaining to win the 12th annual Colonial Cup steeplechase by 11 lengths.

title: L.I.U. Triumphs Over Columbia, 1-0
description: After 90 minutes of regulation play and 48 minutes of overtime, Long Island University's George Touros scored on a penalty kick to give the Blackbirds a 1-0 victory over Columbia yesterday at Baker Field in the second round of the N.C.A.A. soccer championships.

title: New England Is Rated Undesirable for Retirees
description: High fuel costs helped rank states in New England among the least suited for retirement in the continental United States in a study, says an article published by the American Association of Retired Persons.

title: MITTERRAND'S RULE IS TAXED BY A FRACTIOUS FRANCE
description: It is six months since Francois Mitterrand was sworn in as President of France, but the fractious politics of the day have quite displaced any mood of the commemoration.

title: Saints 27, Oilers 24
description: HOUSTON (UPI) - George Rogers, the tailback, ran for 142 yards and Jack Holmes, the fullback, scored two touchdowns to help New Orleans and Coach Bum Phillips to a victory over Phillips's former team. It was Phillips's first visit to Houston since he was dismissed by the Oilers last December.

title: Dissident Soviet Couple Believed to Begin Fast
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident Soviet scientist, and his wife, Yelena Bonner, are believed to have begun a hunger strike in Gorky today to protest the Soviet authorities' refusal to grant an exit visa to their daughter-in-law. Dr. Sakharov has accused the authorities of penalizing the young woman for his activities.

title: UNCERTAIN FUTURE FOR CURBS ON SEX BIAS
description: When Congress passed Title IX of the 1972 amendments to the Education Law, it set in motion a comprehensive effort to eradicate discrimination on the basis of sex from all educational institutions that receive Federal financial assistance. How that measure, considered by many to be a major factor in the advancement of women, will be enforced henceforth is uncertain for it is under review in the Department of Education, Congress and the United States Supreme Court.

title: Betty Newman Is Married to Steven L. Newman
description: Betty Newman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin H. Newman of New York, was married yesterday to Steven L. Newman, son of Lillian Newman of Massapequa, L.I., and the late Nathan W. Newman. The families are not related.

title: COMMUNITY BOARDS IN NEW YORK FILLING GAP IN SOCIAL SERVICES
description: Members of New York's 59 Community Boards exchanged tactical tips yesterday: How to put one local board member on pothole duty for each of the district's 50 police car sectors. How to circulate new rules on smoke detectors in Slavic and other languages not provided by the city. How to take residents by van or car pool to claim food stamps and other benefits when agencies refuse to locate representatives in the community.

title: Buddy Tate, at 66, Plays As Saxophonist of Yore
description: When Buddy Tate replaced Herschel Evans in Count Basie's Orchestra in 1939, he was an authentic, fully developed representative of a tenor saxophone style indigenous to Texas and the Southwest that even then was beginning to fade. Today, more than 40 years later, we don't hear young saxophonists with that urgent drive anymore. But Mr. Tate, at the age of 66, is still a vivid and vital performer in this style, a living musical historic landmark.

title: C.I.A.'S CASEY DEPARTS FROM PRACTICE IN KEEPING CONTROL OF HIS OWN STOCKS
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, one of a handful of men with broad access to secret Government data on international economic developments, has reversed the practice of two predecessors by keeping control of his stock holdings.

title: PIANO RECITAL: SIEGEL AT 92D ST Y
description: JEFFREY SIEGEL'S piano recital last night at the 92d Street Y held out a particularly tempting lure: the chance to look into Schumann's waste basket and find out how he originally intended to end his most enigmatic work, the stupendous Fantasy in C (Op. 17). Mr. Siegel, after giving a brief talk in which he explained with admirable lucidity the tangled history of the Fantasy itself and the 15 measures that the composer decided for unknown reasons not to publish, went on to perform the work in its original version and to make a powerful case for it.

title: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1981; The Economy
description: Despite the President's objections, the House and Senate passed a $428 billion stopgap financing resolution. Mr. Reagan again threatened to veto the bill because budget cuts are insufficient. (Page A1.)

title: Flea Markets Tied To Revenue Loss
description: New York State continues to lose revenue from unregistered and supposedly inactive flea-market vendors, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said yesterday.

title: Secret Service 'Aware' Of Libyan Plot Reports
description: The Secret Service said today that it was ''aware'' of reports that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya had plotted the assassination of President Reagan, Vice President Bush and two top Cabinet members, but it declined comment on what security precautions had been taken.

title: PROPAGANDA AND ARMS
description: President Ronald Reagan said the right things on war and peace last week, and just in time. Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev arrived here tonight facing a new pressure to respond, after nearly a year of posing as the peace champion while Washington sounded increasingly belligerent to European ears.

title: Miss D'Aleo Hurt At Meadowlands
description: Twenty-three-year-old Kathy d'Aleo of Forest Hills, Queens, suffered a broken collarbone in a spill at Meadowlands Race Track last night.

title: HAIG WARNS TIME IS GROWING SHORT IN NICARAGUA
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that ''the hours are growing rather short'' to prevent Nicaragua under the leftist Sandinist Government from becoming a totalitarian state like Cuba.

title: Advertising; Not Just Another Book
description: CONSIDERING how he loves and respects the English language and the craft of advertising, it is quite surprising that John O'Toole waited until his 52d year to write a book on the subject.

title: An Affluent Nobody
description: Who was that man who got off the bus from Philadelphia and went to the Springfield, N.J., tax office with John V. Mahalchik?

title: A $377,000 Family On Chicago's Payroll
description: A city Alderman has acknowledged that 16 members of his family are on the city payroll. However, when he was asked about nepotism, he replied, ''So what?''

title: Red Smith Heismans Get a Home
description: JOHN W. HEISMAN was born in Cleveland, played football at Brown and Pennsylvania and coached at Oberlin, Akron, Auburn, Clemson, Georgia Tech, Pennsylvania, Washington and Jefferson, and Rice. At Georgia Tech he set a record for coachly compassion when his team defeated Cumberland, 222-0. This display of selfless clemency won him such warm affection among his fellows that when an award was established for individual excellence in undergraduate ranks, the trophy was named for Heisman.

title: CONGRESS VOTES BUDGET BILL AS REAGAN WARNS OF A VETO: PRESIDENT SUMMONS CABINET
description: Congress today approved a $428 billion stopgap financing bill needed to avert a threatened disruption in Government services. But President Reagan said he would veto the measure, and the White House said it would begin to shut down nonessential services Monday.

title: SPACE PROGRAM: ALL OUR EGGS IN FOUR BASKETS
description: To the Editor:

title: Royal Couple Sends Out for a Chef, and Gets One
description: Threatened with unwanted additions to the royal waistline, Prince Charles complained last week that he might soon have to get a corset, ''because my wife thinks I'm too thin and is trying to fat me up.''

title: GREEKS ARE TOLD TIMETABLE IS DUE TO OUST U.S. BASES
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou today announced his Socialist Government's intention to set a timetable for the removal of the United States military bases in Greece.

title: Brooklyn Boy, 13, Is Accused In Postal Employee's Slaying
description: A 13-year-old Brooklyn boy has been charged with the fatal stabbing of a 45-year-old postal employee in a street mugging last spring, the police said yesterday. A second 13-year-old suspect was identified and was being sought.

title: PLEA BY 4 G.O.P. GOVERNORS WAS REJECTED BY PRESIDENT
description: Four Republican Governors from the Middle West told President Reagan Friday that their states could not take more Federal budget cuts soon and suggested that he trim the military budget instead.

title: High Chilean Official Reports That Terrorism Is Increasing
description: A high-ranking Government source said Saturday that ''an escalating program of terrorism'' had begun in Chile and that three recent attacks on Government officials appeared to be the work of the same group.

title: SENATE ROLL-CALL VOTE ON BILL
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today approved the $428 billion compromise appropriations bill: FOR THE BILL - 46 Democrats - 2 Jackson, Wash. Moynihan, N.Y. Republicans - 44 Abdnor, S.D. Andrews, N.D. Baker, Tenn.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday misidentified the organiza- tion responsible for the antismoking advertisements on television featuring the actress Brooke Shields. They are sponsored by the American Lung As- sociation.

title: News Analysis
description: Many of the people who follow the affairs of Northern Ireland regard the situation there now as one of the gravest crises it has seen in years.

title: DISARMING BUT NOT SERIOUS
description: In the tone and timing of his arms control speech President Reagan had one immediate purpose: to calm European fears about American policy. By doing so he would put the political onus back on the Russians and remove an obstacle to his planned nuclear weapons buildup. Thus the National Security Council discussions before the speech reportedly focused on how to mollify the Europeans, not on how to approach the Soviet Union in arms negotiations with any realistic chance of success.

title: THE STAGE: 'MY SISTER' BY WENDY KESSELMAN
description: WENDY KESSELMAN'S ''My Sister in This House'' begins as a cool, black satire of provincial bourgeois life, turns into a macabre tale of incestuous homosexual love and ends with an explosion of Grand Guignol violence. If this play sounds discomforting, it is - and it means to be. Miss Kesselman's subject is repression -social, sexual, religious and political - and the havoc it wreaks on its victims. The author's feelings run so strong that she'll burn down the theater if that's what it takes to get the audience to see her point of view.

title: Index; International
description: Mitterrand's rule in taxed by a fractious France A2 Neofascists in Spain honor Franco A4 Around the World A5 Sahara rebel official warns U.S. on aid to Morocco A6 Arabs urge Europe to support creation of Palestinian state A7 Notes on the U.N.: Assembly's agenda is familiar A8 Polish police break up meeting in leading dissident's home A12 Salvadoran refugees suffer as war spills into Honduras A14 Government/Politics Reagan and Congress toss around blame for budget delay A25 Schweiker announces rules for conference on aging this week B12 Washington Talk Briefing A20 Mail pours into Oval Office, but President sees little of it A20 Committee on Present Danger plays role in Administration A20 Calendar A20 General Unemployment dims hopes of families around the U.S. A16 Around the Nation A16 Union study faults TV networks in depicting workers A19 New regulations make New York wine makers optimistic B2 Landmarks Commission to rule on Jewish Museum B3 Education/Welfare Nassau College trustees name in- terim president B2 Ellen Futter inaugurated as president of Barnard College B3 News Analysis William Borders examines the situation in Northern Ireland A3 SportsMonday Basketball: Rebuilding the em- pire at Indiana C1
