title: Sports World Specials; Taxing Problem
description: Alan Eagleson, a Toronto agent for about 60 National Hockey League players, is advising his clients who work for the seven Canadian teams to play out their options and leave Canada for the United States. He is upset about a new proposal in the Canadian budget that would eliminate income-averaging annuity contracts.

title: Coca-Cola to be Placed In the Midwest by MZB
description: Marvin Herb, who earlier this year acquired the Coca-Cola Bottling operations that cover Chicago, Indianapolis, Fort Wayne and Milwaukee and most of the areas in between from the Coca-Cola Company, has just selected MZB Advertising in Indianapolis to handle the merchandising and media ad placement. The advertising itself will continue to come from McCann-Erickson, Coke's traditional national agency and the one that had previously done the local work in this case.

title: Marriott Offer for Host
description: The Marriott Corporation has announced an offer to buy Host International Inc. for $29 a share in cash. Host previously announced it had agreed in principle late last month to merge with DFS Group Ltd., a privately held Hong Kong firm, for a cash price of $24.25 per share. At the time, Host said the acquisition required approval of a definitive agreement by Host's directors and shareholders.

title: RERUNS AT GENERAL ASSEMBLY; Notes on the U.N.
description: A spokesman for Kurt Waldheim complained recently that the American press had devoted so much space to the race for Secretary General that it had virtually ignored the General Assembly.

title: Cardinals 35, Colts 24
description: BALTIMORE (AP) - Ottis Anderson of St. Louis surpassed 1,000 yards in rushing for the third straight season as a crowd of only 24,784 watched Baltimore take its 11th straight loss.

title: SERKIN PROTEGEE OPENS SERIES AT WHITE HOUSE
description: One of America's oldest virtuosos shared the stage with one of the youngest this evening at the first recital of a series of protege performances at the White House.

title: Tafelmusik Orchestra Plays Baroque Program
description: The Tafelmusik Baroque Orchestra, a Toronto-based group of performers on ''authentic'' Baroque instruments, takes its name from the collection of Telemann's ''Tafelmusik'' Suites. The name emphasizes one neglected aspect of much Baroque music - it was never meant to be heard in concert; Tafelmusik is music to eat a courtly dinner by.

title: VIRGIL'S WILL: NEW ACCOUNT
description: A near-tragedy to world literature that has intrigued and horrified humanists for 2,000 years may never have happened, according to a scholar at Princeton.

title: Ballet Theater Names Head of Media Projects
description: Rhoda Grauer, former director of the National Endowment for the Arts' dance program, has been appointed director of the new mediadevelopment department of the American Ballet Theater.

title: New Law Increases Penalties For Trading in Illegal Wildlife
description: People caught trafficking in contraband wildlife could face felony charges punishable by fines of up to $20,000 and five-year jail terms under a bill that has been signed into law by President Reagan.

title: Honors to Allison, Waltrip
description: Bobby Allison won a duel with Joe Ruttman and captured the Western 500 stock-car auto race today. But Allison lost to Darrell Waltrip in the competition for the Winston Cup driving championship.

title: BLAME FOR BUDGET DELAY TOSSED AROUND
description: ''The fact that this country has gone for a year without a budget and is two months into the second year and without a budget -that is no way to run a railroad and it's even less of a way to run a country,'' President Reagan told reporters today.

title: SAHARA REBEL OFFICIAL WARNS U.S. ON MILITARY AID TO MOROCCO
description: A leader of the Polisario Front, which has been fighting Morocco for nearly six years for control of Western Sahara, said in New York Saturday that the Front's remaining hopes for peace and a political settlement in the region rested with the United States.

title: VAST MEXICAN PAWNSHOP IS A FRIEND IN NEED
description: It began as a Catholic charity, then became a business and is now a national institution, but it is still just a pawnshop, albeit the oldest and largest in the Americas, that helps the poor and bails out the spendthrift.

title: FINNISH CANDIDATE FAVORED BY MOSCOW IS REJECTED BY PARTY
description: Former Prime Minister Ahti Karjalainen, who received Moscow's apparent endorsement as a candidate for the presidency, failed tonight to win his party's nomination. Instead, the Center Party's congress voted in a stormy session to nominate the Speaker of Parliament, Johannes Virolainen, another former Prime Minister.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SHOT

title: SALVADORAN REFUGEES SUFFER AS WAR SPILLS INTO HONDURAS
description: Most of the 3,000 Salvadoran peasants who fled to this narrow river gorge came to escape bombing raids and artillery attacks by the Salvadoran Army during their operations to dislodge guerrillas from mountain strongholds.

title: U.S.-PEKING RELATIONS CALLED DELICATE
description: The prospect of American military sales to Taiwan is producing a ''very delicate moment'' in relations between the United States and China, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale said today.

title: UNINVITED GUEST IN MANY WORKERS' HOMES: UNEMPLOYMENT
description: The end sometimes comes in a pay envelope with a slip of paper titled ''Notice of Reduction in Force,'' a euphemism for a layoff.

title: Plane Crashes Near Marines
description: A twin-engine airplane crashed today into a field where about 230 Marines were camped, killing the pilot and a passenger but injuring no one on the ground, a military spokesman said. The private plane knocked down several tents before crashing into a bulldozer, Lieut. Col. Gale Stienon said.

title: A 'Klan Country' Greeting for Benjamin Hooks
description: When Benjamin Hooks, the executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, arrived at a meeting hall in Anderson, Ind., to give a speech on Friday night, he found that someone had placed a burning cross in front of the hall.

title: FRUSTRATED HOUSE AT WORK
description: Some Congressmen napped. Others read. Still others chatted in small groups in the rear of the House chamber, emerging occasionally shaking their heads.

title: PHILARMONIC: NEWLAND ON POSIUM
description: ONE of the reasons Zubin Mehta is popular with the orchestras he conducts is that he promotes from within. An example is Larry Newland, who joined the New York Philharmonic as a violist in 1960, filled in as part-time assistant conductor starting in 1974, and was named by Mr. Mehta officially to the post last season. In 1979 and a couple of weeks ago, Mr. Newland filled in for ailing conductors on short notice. But the concerts Thursday through tomorrow at Avery Fisher Hall constitute his first, regularly scheduled, fully rehearsed programs with the orchestra.

title: Spinks's Manager In Gun Incident
description: Pleas from family members and the heavyweight boxer Leon Spinks were ignored today, but a neighborhood minister finally persuaded Spinks's manager, Jerry Sawyer, to put down a gun and end what the police called a family dispute.

title: The Jets' Moment
description: WHEN a Super Bowl contender comes of age, there is always a moment of maturity, a moment that, if not grasped then and there, might not return for weeks or months. Often that moment is never in focus except through retrospect. But for the Jets that moment is clear now, that moment when they all seemed to grow taller. That moment occurred yesterday at Shea Stadium with only 16 seconds remaining when Richard Todd found Jerome Barkum in the end zone for an 11-yard touchdown pass that, with Pat Leahy's extra point, conquered the Miami Dolphins, 16-15, in a National Football League game that was as primeval as it was pivotal. Cold, windy, darkness beyond the lights, first place in the American Conference East at stake.

title: The Reckless War on Health Costs
description: President Reagan has a throbbing fiscal headache - the rising costs of Medicaid and Medicare. Like his predecessor, he is right to try to contain their growth. But the hasty reforms his Administration proposes imperil the health of needy people with no other place to turn.

title: PICKING UP THE PIECES AT INDIANA U.
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind. AS the bus headed south on Highway 37 on that giddy Tuesday late last March, the basketball players from Indiana University squinted out windows with eyes that had seen more celebrating than sleep, and saw something that remains as vivid as the memory of the game they had won the night before. At nearly every crossroad from here to Indianapolis, a distance of more than 40 miles, the people of southern Indiana had gathered spontaneously. The morning after the Hoosiers defeated North Carolina in the national collegiate championship game at Philadelphia, schools emptied and children stood along the road and cheered; farm work was put aside, and farmers stepped down from their tractors for something more important, to say thanks.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think it would have a more harmful effect on the country if the country got the idea that we're going to continue down the road of lavish deficit spending.

title: Pamela Jarvis, Lawyer, Is Bride
description: The marriage of Pamela Jarvis, an associate with the New York law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Schriver & Jacobson, to Elliot Carlen, a commodities arbitrager with Salomon Brothers, took place at the Lotos Club yesterday. Rabbi Henry Glazer of the Town and Village Conservative Synagogue performed the ceremony.

title: ACTOR AND COMIC ANNOUNCER
description: Harry von Zell, the burly coast-to-coast radio announcer and actor best known as George Burns's foil on the ''Burns and Allen'' radio and television shows, died Saturday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Calabas, Calif. He was 75 years old.

title: Iranian Leftists Warned To Limit Activities
description: Iran's Prime Minister has declared that supporters of the pro-Soviet Tudeh Party and the majority branch of the Marxist People's Fedayeen had infiltrated the Revolutionary Guards and other fundamentalist organizations, and that they would be executed if they were found to have concealed their party affiliations.

title: KEARNEY ANNOUNCES JOB SHIFT
description: Fred G. Steingraber has been elected chief operating officer at A.T. Kearney Inc., a major management consulting firm. Because Kearney does not use the title of president, Mr. Steingraber will rank below Kenneth L. Block, 62, the chairman and chief executive officer, and above the firm's other partners in its Chicago headquarters and 20 offices in the United States and overseas.

title: PLAN PERMITS MANY AGENCIES TO RUN WITHOUT NEW FUNDS
description: Vital functions of the Federal Government, including national security, public health, borrowing, tax collection and air traffic control, were set to continue Monday regardless of the outcome of the Congressional efforts to pass a stopgap spending measure that would keep money flowing for Government services.

title: 29-1 Shot Captures Nashua Stakes
description: Our Escapade, sent off at odds of 29-1, scored an easy victory in the $58,800 Nashua Stakes for 2-year-olds at Aqueduct yesterday. Don MacBeth rode the winner, a long-striding colt who has won races on dirt and grass courses this season.

title: AUGUST LANOIX
description: August Lanoix, who played string bass with the Preservation Hall Jazz Band, died last Tuesday at the age of 79. Mr. Lanoix retired in the mid-1970's because of ill health.

title: Steelers 21, Browns 10
description: CLEVELAND (AP) - Donnie Shell and Anthony Washington intercepted five Cleveland passes and five players scored touchdowns on short yardage plays for Pittsburgh.

title: Libya Denies Cut in Prices
description: Libya tonight denied cutting its oil prices, saying it adhered to the resolutions of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC).

title: CITY SEEKS A FEDERAL WAIVER TO AID HEALTH PLAN FOR POOR
description: The Koch administration is seeking to require 17,000 Medicaid recipients in Harlem to relinquish the ''freedom of choice'' that allows them to receive free health care anywhere in the city.

title: Report Warns Nation Of a Loss of Cropland
description: About 39 square miles of cropland is being lost in the United States each day to soil erosion and competing land development, a study of the nation's food production and delivery system concludes.

title: Braniff Sets More Layoffs
description: The Braniff International Corporation will lay off 220 pilots and flight attendants on Jan. 1, the airline's president, Howard Putnam, has announced.

title: Vivian Lucienne Belmont Wed to Jason Rosenfield
description: At Temple Emanu-El yesterday, Vivian Lucienne Belmont, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis E. Belmont of New York and Paris, was married to Jason Rosenfield, son of Mrs. Mortimer Wiley of New York and Lauderhill, Fla., and the late Bernard Rosenfield. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony.

title: Blood, and Fear, in Ulster
description: The angry Protestants who threaten to make Northern Ireland ''ungovernable'' could do just that. Twice before, in 1914 and 1974, they have risen against British Governments and forced a fundamental change in British policy. By promoting today's protest strike, hardliner Ian Paisley is reminding Britain that the armed Protestant majority is capable of nullifying any concessions to the province's Catholic minority.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Corp., Morris Township, N.J., has elected to its board Robert D. Kilpatrick, president and chief executive officer of the Connecticut Generalcorp.

title: NASSAU COLLEGE TRUSTEES TO NAME INTERIM PRESIDENT
description: The trustees of Nassau County Community College are expected to recommend tonight the appointment of an interim president to assume the duties of Dr. Robert Gwydir.

title: U.S. Boy, 12, Arrives For Moscow Eye Aid
description: Todd Cantrell arrived in Moscow tonight, where he is to be treated for a rare eye disease that American doctors say they cannot cure.

title: Ex-Guard Held in Theft Of $1.85 Million in 1980
description: A former Brink's guard suspected of stealing $1.85 million from an armored car last year was arrested today at a San Francisco market, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: TV INSISTS AD OUTLOOK IS BRIGHT
description: Although the cost of advertising on successful television shows has soared to as much as $5,000 a second, many ad people say the TV ad market is turning sluggish as the nation's economy slows down.

title: Betsy L. Bliss Is Married To Rev. James Nicholls Jr.
description: Betsy L. Bliss, a vice president of Oppenheimer & Company Inc., was married yesterday to the Rev. James Phillip Nicholls Jr., an associate rector of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, where the ceremony took place.

title: STEEL: TO DIVERSIFY OR REBUILD
description: A few years ago, when supporters of free trade would disagree with steelmakers on the need for import restrictions, the steelmakers would make a blatant appeal to patriotism and ask: ''Don't you think America needs a steel industry?''

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: Gracie Mansion Subject Of Museum Exhibition
description: Gracie Mansion, home of New York mayors since Fiorello La Guardia, is the subject of an exhibition running through June at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West. Built in the early 1800's by the merchant Archibald Gracie, the building served as a residence, a restaurant, a museum and a office for the Parks Department before it became home to the Little Flower in 1942.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Turkish Leader Goes To Pakistan for Talks

title: Book Asserts Cardinal Cody Never Overstepped Authority
description: A book to be published next month by the University of Notre Dame Press says John Cardinal Cody of Chicago has never overstepped the authority granted him by the Roman Catholic Church.

title: PRESIDENT SUMMONS CABINET; News Analysis
description: Having already signaled his willingness to accept half a loaf on his budget reduction proposals, President Reagan was engaged in a deliberate showdown with

title: Cowboys 24 Redskins 10
description: IRVING, Tex. (AP) - Danny White threw two touchdown passes for Dallas, which moved into a first-place tie with Philadelphia in the National Conference East with a 9-3 record.

title: NEW DEBT ISSUE IN COMEBACK
description: After months of waiting, major corporations are jumping at the chance to sell new long-term debt issues, even though interest rates are at levels that would have seemed prohibitive a year ago.

title: Bolivia Government Restricts Supplies To Striking Miners
description: The Government suspended meat supplies to three of Bolivia's seven strike-bound tin mines Saturday and restricted general provisions to the major Huanuni Mine, miners' leaders said here today.

title: POP: AUDREY THOMAS SINGS
description: Audrey Thomas is a short, round woman with twinkling eyes and a long memory who sings and plays the piano in a nook next to the bar of the restaurant called Mildred Pierce, 345 West 46th Street, in a way that evokes the Hollywood image, from ''Casablanca'' on down, of what a bar singer should be.

title: EGYPT'S ECONOMY NEEDS MORE "FAT CATS'
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDY BY 3 UNIONS FAULTS TV AS UNFAIR TOWARD WORKERS
description: With the single exception of CBS Television's ''Lou Grant,'' the role of the worker in this country is not fairly represented in prime-time television entertainment programs on the three major networks, according to a study by three American unions based on monitoring by 2,000 union members.

title: BEGIN VS. BEGIN
description: There is little doubt that Israel, surrounded by Arab countries, only one of which has recognized its legitimacy after four wars, remains in danger. But even as Israel's staunchest friends in Congress discuss a compensatory package of military and economic aid to offset advantages the Saudis gain by the Awacs, F-15's, and AIM-9L air-to-air missiles, questions have arisen about Prime Minister Menachem Begin's ''hardball'' tactics in dealing with President Reagan.

title: Driver Held as Drunk In 6 Deaths in Virginia
description: Six persons, including five teen-agers, were killed Saturday when a suspected drunk driver being chased by the police crashed head-on into their Volkswagen at about 100 miles per hour, the state police said today.

title: PLANS FOR REVIVING DUBUQUE SINK WITH ECONOMY
description: Ten years ago this affluent manufacturing center of 62,342 population completed construction of Town Clock Plaza, an attractive, tree-lined pedestrian mall that was to stand as a symbol of a major redevelopment to come.

title: TODD'S PASS IN LAST 16 SECONDS BEATS DOLPHINS, 16-15
description: More than five years of frustration and a week of pain ended in one glorious moment for Richard Todd yesterday. Encumbered by a flak jacket that protected his cracked rib and hobbling on an ankle that his center stepped on two hours earlier, Todd rifled an 11-yard scoring pass to Jerome Barkum with 16 seconds remaining to give the Jets a 16-15 victory over Miami and a firstplace tie with the Dolphins.

title: CITY BALLET: BALANCHINE'S 'MOZARTIANA'
description: WHEN ''Mozartiana'' by George Balanchine opened the New York City Ballet's Tchaikovsky Festival last June, it appeared so underrehearsed and poorly danced that it was difficult to make out the ballet itself.

title: Arthur Ozolins, Pianist, Celebrates Latvian Day
description: Arthur Ozolins helped commemorate Latvian Independance Day at Avery Fisher Hall Saturday afternoon with a piano recital devoted to some of the world's less-traveled ethnic byways. There was Albeniz from Spain, Ginastera from Argentina (the ''Sonata para Piano'') and, of course, music with a Latvian accent - in this instance by Alfreds Kalnins, Arnolds Sturms and Janis Medins.

title: Commodities; The Weak Market In Platinum
description: PLATINUM prices have been flirting with new contract lows in the futures market, along with other members of the precious metal family, gold and silver.

title: MET OPERA: CARRERAS SINGS CAVARADOSSI
description: THE Metropolitan Opera offered a new set of principal singers for Puccini's ''Tosca'' on Saturday evening. Jose Carreras as Cavaradossi proved himself a rarity - a tenor who can reach the back of a large opera house with his sound and still retain a large measure of its quality.

title: Burtnett to Coach Purdue Football
description: Improving the defensive secondary is an immediate goal of Leon Burtnett, who today was named Purdue's 30th football coach.

title: Market Place; Fighting Raids Is Costly Task
description: IT is becoming increasingly clear that when one corporation offers cash for another in an unfriendly takeover bid, the forces unleashed nearly always result in eliminating the target as a separate company.

title: Chipwich Goes Indoors To Advertise on TV
description: Now that Chipwich has begun moving its expensive ice cream sandwich into New York area supermarkets through the Haagen Dazs distribution system, and its handsome carts are running into bad weather, it is time to stimulate consumers with advertising.

title: VIRGIL FANS FIND HIS PEDESTAL SECURE
description: In an auditorium at Princeton University they were talking about Virgil. Their language danced from Old French to Middle English, from Latin, of course, to Greek, and from Italian to German to English - an English heavy with such words as redactions, vernacularizations and texts.

title: LATE KICK BY 49ERS TOPS RAMS, 33-31
description: Ray Wersching's fourth field goal of the game, a 37-yarder as time expired, lifted the San Francisco 49ers to a 33-31 victory over the Los Angeles Rams at Anaheim Stadium today.

title: NEOFASCISTS PAY TRIBUTE TO FRANCO
description: Tens of thousands of people, singing patriotic songs and chanting for the freedom of a leader of last February's abortive military coup, rallied today to mark the sixth anniversary of the death of Francisco Franco.

title: MEESE DEFENDS ACTIONS OF ADMINISTRATION AIDES IN ALLEN CASE
description: Edwin Meese 3d, the White House counselor, said today that both White House and Justice Department officials had been ''scrupulously'' correct in their contacts during the investigation into a $1,000 payment to Richard V. Allen, the White House national security adviser, by a Japanese magazine.

title: Lions 23, Bears 7
description: CHICAGO (AP) - Eric Hipple, the Lions' quarterback, scored on a 5-yard touchdown run set up by his 46-yard pass to Fred Scott, and Ed Murray kicked three field goals. Detroit (6-6) limited Chicago (3-9) to 24 net yards for the game, the lowest in the club's history, and registered seven sacks.

title: FINANCING CALENDER IS STILL FULL
description: In this holiday-shortened week, underwriters have scheduled $1 billion of new corporate issues, but they said that the volume could be much larger if market conditions are good.

title: Resurgent Hall & Oates Play a Paladium Date
description: Two years ago, it looked as though Daryl Hall and John Oates, the New York-based duo who helped pioneer the style known as ''blue-eyed soul,'' were in trouble. Their record sales were declining, and they had reached a stylistic impasse.

title: Damage Is Put at $100,000 After Melee at Texas Prison
description: Fifty inmates who engaged in a rock-throwing, tent-burning melee over the weekend caused an estimated $100,000 in damages, a spokesman for the Texas Department of Corrections said today.

title: SANCHEZ WINNER IN SQUASH RACQUETS
description: Mario Sanchez of Mexico won his first major World Professional Squash Association tournament yesterday with a 3-1 victory over Mark Talbott in the final of $18,800 New York Boodles Gin Open. The scores were 13-15, 18-15, 15-5, 15-9.

title: Early Morning Fire Destroys Several Stores in Larchmont
description: A fire ripped through an empty shopping plaza here today and destroyed eight stores, officials said. Fire Chief James Sarafaty said there were no injuries in the blaze, which began about 5:45 A.M. and spread quickly through the stores on Palmer Avenue. A luncheonette, hair salon, tax office and an appliance store were among those destroyed, he said.

title: LURKERS UNDER LONDEN STREETS
description: Why do some people take care not to step on the cracks in the paving while others take no notice whatever of the cracks?

title: Pope Resumes Schedule With Pilgrimage in Italy
description: Pope John Paul II made his first pilgrimage today since he was shot May 13, traveling to this ancient hilltop town 76 miles north of Rome. Security was described by the Vatican as the heaviest ever for a papal visit.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 23, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: ONE JERUSALEM
description: To the Editor:

title: POLISH POLICE BREAK UP MEETING HELD IN LEADING DISSIDENT'S HOME
description: The police today raided the home of Jacek Kuron, a dissident leader, and broke up a meeting of political and union activists, the Government press agency P.A.P. said. There was no report of arrests.

title: 'STRESS' CENTERS USE DOCTORS TO PRESCRIBE DISPUTED DRUG
description: A growing network of self-described ''stress'' or ''insomnia'' centers is using licensed physicians in New York and other major cities to prescribe methaqualone, a depressant most often sold illegally in a vast underground market. The centers have become a target of investigations by law-enforcement agencies and of condemnation by medical authorities.

title: LANDMARKS COMMISSION TO VOTE ON STATUS OF THE JEWISH MUSEUM
description: The former Felix M. Warburg mansion, a turn-of-the-century building on upper Fifth Avenue that houses the Jewish Museum, will come up before the Landmarks Preservation Commission tomorrow for designation as a landmark, after more than a decade of controversy.

title: Broncos Trounced By Bengals, 38 to 21
description: Ken Anderson, the Bengals' quarterback who is experiencing his best season of 11 in pro football, executed an impeccable game plan today as the astonishing Cincinnati team trounced the Denver Broncos, 38-21, for its ninth victory of the season.

title: Test the Enterprise Zones
description: In the 1980 campaign, Ronald Reagan pledged to create urban enterprise zones - where lowered taxes and relaxed regulation would stimulate investment and create jobs. The prospect of Federal deficits and doubt about the effectiveness of the idea have since intervened.

title: A Parents' Hope
description: It was, according to a hospital spokesman, ''a fairly routine birth,'' but when Martin Short was born at England's North Devon Hospital yesterday, he became a footnote to medical history.

title: Two Killed in Fire In Hoboken Hotel
description: Two persons were killed and seven were injured when a fire swept through the upper floors of the landmark American Hotel, the police said.

title: Chargers 55, Raiders 21
description: Dan Fouts set a San Diego record by throwing six touchdown passes, four of them to Kellen Winslow.

title: FOR NEW YORK WINE MAKERS, OPTIMISM ON THE VINE
description: Bubbles of optimism are wafting through New York's white-wine industry as scores of vineyards and small wineries are cropping up from the eastern tip of Long Island to westernmost Chautauqua County.

title: No Headline
description: LENDL SETS BACK VILAS, 6-1, 6-2

title: DANCE: PILOBOLUS REACHES 10
description: PRINCETON PILOBOLUS is alive and well and as brilliantly mad and uncategorizable as ever. That was the message of a performance Wednesday at Princeton's McCarter Theater. Celebrating its 10th anniversary this year - near-dotage, one would have thought, for such a youthfully high-spirited group of experimenters - Pilobolus has added another work to its repertory. And if this new ''Day Two'' is slightly unfinished looking, it nevertheless suggests much about the group.

title: Bayonne Captures Schoolboy Playoff
description: Greg Francois scored his second touchdown at 2 minutes 30 seconds of overtime today to give Bayonne a 20-14 victory over Teaneck in the North Jersey, Section I, Group IV football championship playoff at Giants Stadium.

title: BARNARD PRESIDENT STRESSES SCHOOL'S INDEPENDENCE
description: Ellen V. Futter was inaugurated yesterday as president of Barnard College and asserted in her first address that ''we cannot and shall not abandon our role as an independent women's college.''

title: BRIEFING
description: F ORMER Representative John B. Anderson, the once and, perhaps, future candidate for President, returned from India last week and experienced the shock of deja vu as he caught up with the tale of David A. Stockman's confessional use of journalism. Amateur psychologists all through the capital are still speculating on just what sort of self-destructive or Machiavellian impulse might have driven Mr. Stockman, the President's budget director, to build a separate record of startling candor and doubt with a magazine interviewer, even as he publicly directed the Administration's budget program. Mr. Anderson, who gave Mr. Stockman his big start in politics, leans decidedly toward a Machiavellian theory.

title: BREZHNEV ARRIVES IN BONN TO TALK WITH SCHMIDT ON ATOM ARMS CUTS
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev arrived in Bonn tonight for three days of Soviet-West German talks centering on possible nuclear arms reductions in Europe.

title: ARAB AIDES URGE EUROPE TO BACK PALESTINIAN STATE
description: Arab League foreign ministers reiterated their insistence today on the formation of a Palestinian state and urged Western Europe to end its hesitancy and join in supporting them.

title: Buccaneers 37 Packers 3 TAMPA, Fla. (AP)
description: Cedric Brown, a safety, started a 24-point second quarter for Tampa Bay by returning an interception 81 yards for a touchdown.

title: BACKLOG GROWS ON ALIEN FILES
description: Bureaucratic problems have left the Immigration and Naturalization Service unable to keep track of 30 million forms filed by foreign visitors, and it may be 1983 before it is known who entered or left the country in the last two years.

title: EASING OF RULES PRESSED ON CONFERENCE ON AGING
description: With the White House Conference on Aging only a week away, many of the state delegations and major organizations in the field are pressing the Reagan Administration to insure free debate and minimize partisan political activity at the gathering.

title: ROYAL COUPLE: PRIVATE LIVES IN PUBLIC EYE
description: They couldn't have looked more royal. Sitting on the brocade sofa of their suite in the Hotel Pierre last Friday, King Carl XVI Gustaf and Queen Silvia of Sweden looked exactly like a postage stamp come to life and come to the United States to help celebrate the 75th Anniversary of the Swedish-American Chamber of Commerce. She wore a red dress, a chignon, black patent pumps. She had folded her hands into her lap. He wore a dark suit, his curly hair slicked back. It was a picture of monarchical timelessness reminiscent of other queens and kings and other postage stamps.

title: Destruction of Homes In West Bank Assailed
description: Mayor Hana el-Atrash of Beit Sahur, the suburb of Bethlehem where three Arab houses were demolished by the military government in retaliation for attacks on Israeli army patrols, demanded today that the Government allow the families to rebuild their homes at Government expense.

title: WITNESS SAYS MARGIOTTA RECEIVED A $5,000 INSURANCE COMMISSION
description: Testimony that Joseph M. Margiotta kept a politically arranged insurance payment of $5,000 was presented today at the Nassau County Republican leader's retrial in Federal District Court.

title: HOLIDAY DRESSING: EASY LOOKS
description: The festive season is upon us. From now through New Year's Day, only a recluse doesn't have a choice of evening entertainment, whether the informal ''drop-in-for-a-drink'' variety or the kind when everyone dresses.

title: SECURITY CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REPUBLIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AM International Completes Sale
description: AM International Inc., the financially ailing maker of engineering graphics and information processing systems, said that it had completed the sale of its Micrographics division to Consolidated Micrographics Inc., a privately held supplier of equipment and supplies to the micrographics market.

title: Dryer Seeks Redress
description: Fred Dryer, the former defensive end of the Rams, who was cut last month despite his ''no-cut'' contract, filed a $5 million suit against the Rams yesterday in Los Angeles.. Filed in Superior Court, the suit seeks $5 million in punitive damages and an additional sum, to be determined later, in actual damages. Dryer's attorney, Sanford Gage, said the 13-year player in the National Football League suffered ''severe emotional distress'' because of the way in which he was dismissed.

title: FABLED MOROCCAN CITY POLISHES UP FOR ARAB CHIEFS
description: The sons of Fez have dominated the politics, economics and culture of Morocco for so long that, even though many leaders were born elsewhere, their tradition is here.

title: No Headline
description: EXCERPTS FROM BREZHNEV AND SCHMIDT SPEECHES

title: NEW TISSUE WILL BE IMPLANTED IN BRAIN TO TREAT
description: PARKINSON'S By WALTER SULLIVAN

title: NAVY SECRETARY SAYS ALLEN VOICED RESOLVE TO HAND IN $1,000
description: The Secretary of the Navy said today that he had signed a statement supporting Richard V. Allen's contention that he had intended to surrender to the Government the $1,000 he received from a Japanese magazine.

title: Fire Kills 4 in Family
description: A woman and her three daughters died today in a fire that raced through their house, situated about 100 yards from a fire station. The victims were identified as Fannie Coppedge, and her daughters Linda, 15 years old, and Dee Dee, 9, and Destiny, 17 months old. The authorities said the children's father, James Coppedge, 28, and two other children fled the 3 A.M. blaze.

title: Highwire Magazine Set For High Schools
description: Vidar J. Jorgensen, 34 years old, says he has been in fund raising ever since his graduation from Harvard. He could also say he has been in magazine subscriptions since his Lowell, Mass., company, National Community Services, makes its money by getting elementary and high school students to sell subscriptions for about 320 titles, with a portion of the proceeds going toward a school project.

title: Valle Family Plans Steak Chain Sale
description: Valle's Steak House announced that members of the Valle family and their trusts had agreed in principle to sell the restaurant chain to a group of nonfamily executives and private investors for $17.5 million. The Valle family and its trusts control 66.7 percent of the company's 2.5 million common shares outstanding.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: EAST IS EAST

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1981
description: International A freeze on nuclear forces in Europe was suggested again by Leonid I. Brezhnev in a day of talks with Chancellor Helmut Schmidt in Bonn. The proposal has been rejected by NATO on the ground that it would freeze Soviet superiority in medium-range warheads. (Page A1, Column 3.) A mixed economy in China is in increasing prospect. Peking's two top policy-making bodies formally acknowledged a need for more private enterprise to alleviate chronic unemployment, and they proposed that new jobs be created increasingly by private businesses as well as by cooperative enterprises. (A1:1-2.)

title: MURPHY, G C, CO reports earnings for 13 weeks to Sept 29
FACET ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sealed With a Kiss
description: Representative Lynn Martin, Republican of Illinois, Congressional Record, Nov. 19: Occasionally my side of the aisle has been accused of perhaps not treating the Speaker as well as we should and not recognizing his many good qualities. As Republicans, we are more than willing to admit that others can show us the way.

title: Soviet Union Ahead In World Gymnastics
description: The Soviet Union, defending the crown in front of a partisan home crowd, put on a powerful display in the compulsory exercises at the opening of the world gymnastic championships today.

title: RATES UP, BUT FALL IS EXPECTED
description: Short-term and long-term interest rates increased yesterday, although most analysts were convinced that rates will resume their decline after the market has a chance to digest the heavy supply of new issues.

title: S.E.C. Is Busy On New Issues
description: Despite the Government's partial shutdown, the Securities and Exchange Commission will continue to process registration statements relating to new issues of corporate securities, an S.E.C. spokesman said yesterday.

title: Beatrice and China In Joint Venture
description: The Beatrice Foods Company said that it had signed a long-term agreement with China for the establishment of a jointly operated company to pack and market foods and beverages. The agreement was described by company officials as the first of its kind by a major United States manufacturing company in China.

title: MARATHON WARNS COURT ON TAKEOVER 'TRIGGER'
description: Attorneys for the Marathon Oil Company argued in Federal court today that a wave of oil-company takeovers could be set off if the Mobil Corporation were allowed to proceed with its proposed $5.1 billion acquisition of Marathon.

title: Curbs on Files Fought In the Lindbergh Case
description: New Jersey state police files in the 1932 kidnap-murder of Charles A. Lindbergh's baby became available for scrutiny by ''interested parties'' yesterday. But a lawyer for the widow of the man convicted of the crime challenged restrictions on their inspection.

title: Enough, Says Judge
description: ''I hope this will close the case'' said Judge Phillip Baiamonte in Albuquerque, N.M., after refusing in District Court to order Norm Ellenberger, the former basketball coach at the University of New Mexico, to repay $6,000 in connection with a fraud conviction. ''Let these coaches pick up the pieces of their lives, let the university tighten up its procedures and get on with the teaching of students.

title: Police Asked to Close Case on Susan Byrne
description: An attorney for the family of Governor Byrne asked the New York City Police Department today to close its investigation of a report by Susan Byrne, the Governor's 25-year-old daughter, that she was assaulted last Thursday on the Upper East Side.

title: THE RUSTIC JOYS OF 'PUSHING DEER'
description: Grace McGrath opened her restaurant at 4 A.M., and within minutes it was filled to overflowing with flannel-shirted, down-vested, bullet-belted, rifle-toting, pistol-packing, bladewielding, bewhiskered hunters trading all manner of stories, jibes, tales, yarns and bald-faced lies. ''This is the best part of huntin','' said one named Lem from over by Copake Falls.

title: COUNTIES RENEW PLEA TO ALBANY ON SOCIAL AID
description: County Executives from around the state renewed their plea to Albany today for relief from social-service costs that they said had gone out of control.

title: Broth and Macaroni Recalled for Botulism
description: Cans of chicken broth believed to contain botulism toxin are being recalled from national distribution, Federal officials said today.

title: Racing Board Sets Up New Rule for Refunds
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board yesterday ordered refunds in thoroughbred races in which one part of an entry or the field is scratched after the betting has begun.

title: KOCH IS POISED TO CURB HIRINGS IN NEW BUDGET
description: Mayor Koch strongly suggested last night that New York City would not hire some of the thousands of new employees included in his election-year budget adopted last June.

title: Tavern Crusade
description: It's not much to look at, but a small band of preservationists is still determined to save Rhodes Tavern, a 182-year-old downtown building that has witnessed every Presidential inaugural parade since Thomas Jefferson took office.

title: ITALIANS SADLY REMEMBER QUAKE
description: With a silent vigil, prayers and protests, Italy today marked the first anniversary of the earthquake that killed 2,735 people, injured 8,807 others and caused $8.5 billion in damages.

title: A TWO POLITICIAN FAMILY
description: When Marilyn Stoughton Lewis, wife of the Secretary of Transportation, Drew Lewis, was offered the post of deputy protocol officer in the early days of the Reagan Administration, she was unable to decide whether to take it.

title: BIRD'D OLD SCHOOL REBUILDS
description: Bill Hodges would like to return to the Final Four some day. Not just to be there, because he has already taken an Indiana State University team to the national basketball championship game. Not just to win, because everyone wants that. ''Just to see if it's real,'' Hodges said.

title: Witco Seeking Richardson
description: The Witco Chemical Corporation said that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Richardson Company for $27.50 a share, or an indicated total of $61.4 million.

title: A THREATENED HARVEST
description: WickerLEXINGTON, Ky. -Thanksgiving Day commemorates the first of hundreds of bountiful American harvests. But there may not be that many in the future unless timely steps are taken to save our rich earth from being washed and blown away.

title: 4 IN SHOW BUSINESS PLAN ENLARGED ASTORIA STUDIO
description: Johnny Carson, Alan King, James M. Nederlander and Neil Simon have joined George S. Kaufman, a developer, as investors in the forthcoming restoration and expansion of the Astoria Studios in Queens - a project estimated to cost $50 million. Construction on the film-making complex is expected to start in January and be completed in a year to 18 months.

title: OLD PROGRAMS, NEW PROBLEMS
description: When people think of computers, they often envision the latest in sophisticated technology. However, for many companies and government agencies that use computers, that is not always the case.

title: ACF INDUSTRIES ELECTION
description: Ivan A. Burns, 46, has been elected president and chief operating officer of ACF Industries, a diversified New York-based company, effective next Tuesday. He will succeed Henry A. Correa, 64, who will become vice chairman.

title: Self-Inflicted Questions
description: The professionals in the Reagan White House know that a two-day story is more than twice as bad as a one-day story. Then why have they let the Richard Allen case drag on into an 11-day story? What are the Reagan Administration's ethical standards for its most sensitively placed officers? What are Mr. Allen's standards for himself?

title: DEMOCRATS' DISTRICT PLAN FOR ILLINOIS IS ACCEPTED
description: A three-judge Federal panel today approved a Democratic-sponsored Congressional redistricting proposal that would eliminate the seats of two Republicans and preserve the seats of two Democrats, although the population shifts that made redistricting necessary had occurred in Democratic districts.

title: Market Place; Semiconductor Investments
description: THE shares of semiconductor companies have dropped to their lowest levels in years and could be selling at bargain prices. That, at least, is the theme of a major new report from Hambrecht & Quist, a San Francisco investment banking concern widely known for its sponsorship of high-technology companies.

title: William Potter, a Lawyer, 76; Delaware Democratic Official
description: William S. Potter, a lawyer and a longtime leader in the Democratic Party in Delaware, died Sunday at his home in Centreville, Del., a suburb of Wilmington, after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: SELECTIVE JUSTICE
description: To the Editor:

title: Cave-In Suit: $219 Million
description: The Diamond Crystal Salt Company said today that it was seeking $219 million from Texaco Inc. and the State of Louisiana for damages resulting from the spectacular collapse of its Jefferson Island salt mine a year ago.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Graphic Scanning Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission $50 million of convertible subordinated debentures due 2001, to be sold through an E.F. Hutton group.

title: Burger King Warns of Move
description: The Burger King Corporation said that it was considering moving its corporate headquarters from here, possibly to Dallas, because of the area's rising crime rate and pressure for a more central location.

title: 4 EUROPEAN NATIONS AGREE TO CONTRIBUTE TO SINAI PEACE FORCE
description: France, Britain, Italy and the Netherlands announced an agreement today to take part in a Sinai peacekeeping force after Israel completes its withdrawal next spring.

title: U.S. JOB EXAM TO BE CHANGED
description: A Federal district judge has given final approval to a job discrimination settlement that calls for replacing the Federal Government's basic job test in stages over the next three years.

title: MEXICANS CAUTION HAIG ON NICARAGUA
description: Senior Mexican officials cautioned Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today against any precipitate action by Washingon against Nicaragua and offered to seek ways of improving United States relations with the Sandinist regime.

title: ULSTER MILITANTS ROUSED BY PAISLEY
description: The Rev. Ian Paisley, the militant Protestant leader, marched 4,000 men in military formation through this little town tonight and told them they should be prepared to die fighting against Roman Catholic Republican guerrillas.

title: Parker Is Bitter
description: ''I'd like to go back and inflict the same kind of agony the fans caused me in Pittsburgh,'' said Dave Parker, the Pirates' star outfielder.

title: Company Will Rebury Toxic Chemical Drums
description: Toxic chemicals illegally dumped at an upstate New York farm will be dug up by the responsible company and properly reburied, under an agreement announced yesterday by the State Attorney General, Robert Abrams.

title: MANHATTAN DEMOCRATIC CHIEF CHALLENGED FOR BOLTING PARTY
description: A move began yesterday to remove the Democratic leader of Manhattan on the ground that he had bolted his party to support the Liberal candidate for Borough President.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL BUILDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $1,553,000 charge for expenses associated with the development and operation of an affiliate company

title: CUTS IN FOREIGN AID SUDDENLY WORRY REAGAN
description: Foreign aid, traditionally a low priority for Republicans, appears to be the only area in which the Reagan Administration believes too little rather than too much money was provided in the budget resolution that Mr. Reagan vetoed today.

title: BREZHNEV REVIVES MISSILE-FREEZE BID PENDING U.S. TALKS
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, refashioning an offer previously rejected by the West, today proposed a freeze on the deployment of new medium-range nuclear forces in Europe pending talks with the United States on force reductions.

title: CITY ASKS A JUDGE TO VALIDATE COUNCIL'S ACTS DESPITE RULING
description: Lawyers for New York City asked a Federal judge yesterday to declare the City Council legally able to legislate in the coming weeks despite the judge's recent ruling that the Council's 10 atlarge members had been elected in an unconstitutional manner.

title: SCHLITZ PRESIDENT RESIGNS HIS POST
description: Jerome E. Vielehr resigned yesterday as president of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company, and Frank J. Sellinger, vice chairman and chief executive officer, took over his duties.

title: Financing Oil Hunt by China
description: China will need $20 billion to finance offshore oil exploration and production by 1990, a prominent Hong Kong banker said here today.

title: G.O.P. CHIEFS PLAN SINGLE-MINDEDLY FOR '82
description: It is perfectly clear what sort of candidate should run next year against Governor Carey -just ask leading New York Republicans. It should be a legislative leader who knows state government, says James L. Emery. A businessman with a conservative philosophy, says Lewis E. Lehrman. An official experienced at statewide campaigning, says Edward V. Regan. A politician with strength upstate and in New York City, says Richard M. Rosenbaum. If one looks carefully, all of the prescriptions for removing Mr. Carey from Albany are identical. Each is the political self-image of the man doing the prescribing. And Each One Has High Hopes

title: Kilijaro Triumphs In Matriarch Stakes
description: Kilijaro, a 5-year-old mare, won her sixth stakes victory of the year Sunday, pulling away in the stretch to take the first running of the $221,600 Matriarch Stakes by 2 1/2 lengths at Hollywood Park.

title: COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for Yr-to Sept 30
ARE THE RUSSIANS USING 'YELLOW RAIN' IN ASIA? EXPERTS DEBATE THE DATA
description: THE United States has been trying since 1976 to verify reports that chemical weapons, known popularly as ''the yellow rain,'' are being used against remote villages in Laos, Cambodia and, more recently, Afghanistan. In September, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. announced the first ''physical evidence'' to buttress the charge. It was a sample of vegetation from Cambodia that contained three toxins produced by fungi.

title: BANKAMERICA REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Includes a gain on sales of investments of $38,000 and also $358,000 of past due income...C-Includes a gain on sales of investments of $464,000 and also $369,000 of past due income

title: DFS Group Ltd.  To Acquire Host
description: Host International Inc., a food services company, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the DFS Group Ltd., a privately held Hong Kong corporation, in a transaction valued at $140 million. Under the agreement, DFS will acquire all of Host's 4.8 million common shares at a price of $29.25 a share.

title: JACOBSON STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 24
No Headline
description: TEXT OF PRESIDENT'S ANNOUNCEMENT ON VETO OF SPENDING BILL

title: Italian Copter Crash Kills 2
description: An Italian Air Force helicopter crashed today during a training exercise in southern Sardinia, killing both pilots. The air force identified the pilots as Alessandro Albani, 24 years old, and Mauro Marchini, 23.

title: Traffic Survey Plane Is Ditched in Hudson
description: A single-engine plane reporting on traffic conditions was ditched in the Hudson River off 96th Street last night, but the pilot swam ashore safely.

title: Italian Prison Guards Strike
description: Italian prison wardens and female guards went on strike today, saying they will remain off the job for a week to demand better pay, more guards and a new prison. Officials said most male guards were working and prison security was not imperiled.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Do whales sleep?

title: Another Dismissal
description: The rumors had been circulating for weeks, and yesterday they became reality as Roger Theder was dismissed as head coach at the University of California after failing to turn around the Golden Bears' football program in the last four years. Although Theder led California to its first postseason game since the 1959 Rose Bowl when it went to the 1979 Garden State Bowl, he was able to win only five of 22 games since finishing with an 18-27 record. The 2-9 finish this season was its worst in 19 years.

title: Danish Politician Convicted of Tax Evasion
description: Mogens Glistrup, who built up a powerful political party in Denmark by advocating the abolition of taxes, was convicted today of tax evasion. He received the maxiumum sentence of four years in prison and a $1 million fine.

title: SUN TO SELL ASSETS OF SHIP UNIT
description: The Sun Company announced today that it would sell the assets of its 65-year-old shipbuilding subsidiary to Levingston Shipbuilding Company, a privately held company that operates two shipyards in Texas and a marine engineering facility in Annapolis, Md.

title: The Breaking Point
description: ''I couldn't believe the club would give it's approval to something like that,'' said Ken Griffey, a .300 career National League hitter, describing how his breaking point with the Cincinnati Reds came when they gave in to a demand by Johnny Bench to catch only twice a week.

title: AMERICAN FLETCHER MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Some Memories of the President's Father
description: Reminiscing recently about life with father, Ron and Patti Davis Reagan said that President Reagan often told them how it was to grow up the son of an alcoholic, John William Reagan.

title: PLAY: FAY WELDON'S 'AFTER THE PRIZE'
description: THE heroine of the new play at the Phoenix, ''After the Prize,'' is a particle physicist who has just won the Nobel Prize. Its author, the British novelist Fay Weldon (''Praxis,'' ''Puffball''), is no scientist, but she might as well be. ''After the Prize'' is so diagramatically written, in its characterizations, thematic strategies and dramatic structure, that it is less a living play than an open-and-shut equation. While some talented actors are playing the variables, the enterprise remains bloodless and inert.

title: JAMES RIVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: B-After charges of $1,325,000 for the qr and $2,901,000 for the 6 mos from the settlement of an antitrust suit; the shr earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid June 22

title: Bookkeeper, 63, Found Slain In Her Office on the East Side
description: A 63-year-old bookkeeper was found bludgeoned to death yesterday in her company's 17th-floor offices in the Decorative Arts Building at 305 East 63d Street.

title: Burell Advertising Wins 3 CEBA Awards
description: At the fourth annual Communications Excellence to Black Audiences awards ceremonies at the New York Hilton Hotel last night, Burell Advertising of Chicago took three of the 35 category awards, the only competitor to do that well. The other multiple winners, with two CEBA's each, were N.W. Ayer; Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, and Uniworld Inc.

title: Vermont Picks School Chief
description: Stephen Kaagan, provost of Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, was named Education Commissioner today. He is to assume the post Feb. 1. The appointment is subject to approval by Gov. Richard A. Snelling.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CINCINNATI (NL) - Hired Joe Amal- f itano, former manager of Cubs, as assist- a nt coach.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Best Propaganda
description: During World War II, I was marginally involved in what were called black news broadcasts into Germany. The term was used because the broadcasts were not by the BBC. Though actually run by the Allies from London, they were presented as coming from a German underground radio.

title: SFN COS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TOPLESS DANCING IN BARS UPHELD FOR 2D TIME BY HIGH STATE COURT
description: The New York State Court of Appeals ruled 4 to 3 today that the state could not use its @liquor-licensing authority to ban topless dancing in bars.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: '' I am returning to Congress without my signature House Joint Resolution 357, the continuing resolution providing appropriations for fiscal year 1982.'' - President Reagan (B15:4.)

title: TRUE PEACE VIA A STRONG NATO
description: To the Editor:

title: QUADREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in July 1981

title: 8.5% Jobless In E.E.C.
description: Unemployment in the nations of the European Economic Community reached 8.5 percent of the work force in October, the highest total since the economic bloc was formed in 1958, according to statistics released today.

title: DETROIT EDISON CO reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
MOBIL MERGER OPPOSED BY OFF-BRAND DEALERS
description: Companies that sell so-called off-brand gasoline at prices 2 to 8 cents a gallon lower than the major oil companies would be hurt by the Mobil Corporation's proposed takeover of the Marathon Oil Company, opponents of the merger told Congress today.

title: Asmussen Back in Time For Another Victory
description: Cash Asmussen, who rode the winner of Sunday's $537,000 Japan Cup in Tokyo, returned to Aqueduct yesterday and captured the $24,000 feature race.

title: CITY BALLET TO HONOR STRAVINSKY
description: The New York City Ballet loves to give parties, whatever the occasion. Last night several hundred friends, company members and assorted dance personalities gathered at the New York State Theater, purportedly to celebrate the company's 75th New York season and announce its next festival. The festival would be dedicated to Igor Stravinsky, the centennial of whose birth will occur next June, and would take place at the State Theater from June 10 through 20.

title: No Takers for Plimpton and F. Lee Bailey Gifts
description: Who would pay $1 million for a fireworks display ''personally commemorated'' by George Plimpton, or $15,000 to spend a day with F. Lee Bailey?

title: SPARKMAN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REGENTS FIND A 'MILLSTONE' FOR HIGH SCHOOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: Service for Samuel Rosen
description: A memorial service for Dr. Samuel Rosen, a New York ear surgeon who died in Peking on Nov. 5, will be held at 5 P.M. Monday at the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th Street.

title: HARNISCHFEGER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Includes gain of $15,740,000 on sale of patents and knowhow

title: SUAVE SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The yr-ago shr earnings reflect 10 percent stock divd paid Apr 1981

title: OAKWOOD HOMES reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: the 1980 shr earnings reflect 10 percent stock divd paid Oct 1981

title: NEW YORK TESTING LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HIRSCHFELD IS HONORED AS THEATER'S HISTORIAN
description: Al Hirschfeld was attended to by some of his admirers last night, with a party held in his name. ''He's the only true historian of the Broadway theater,'' said Morton Gottlieb, the producer.

title: MANHATTAN GUARD IS SHOT 3 TIMES IN ONE OF 5 BANK HOLDUPS IN CITY
description: An armed guard was shot three times yesterday by one of two men who held up the Israel Discount Bank branch at Broadway and 35th Street in one of five bank robberies in the city during the day.

title: CITY TO COLLECT U.S. TAX REFUNDS OF LAGGARDS IN CHILD SUPPORT
description: The names of approximately 13,800 New York City parents who are delinquent in child support payments have been given to the Internal Revenue Service under a new program that allows the I.R.S. to turn over to the city any Federal income tax refunds due these parents.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avon Products Inc. has named James E. Preston to the newly created position of president of the Avon division.

title: REAGAN PRESS AIDE OUT OF HOSPITAL
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary who was shot in the head in the assassination attempt on President Reagan, left George Washington University Hospital today.

title: ROLL-CALL VOTE IN HOUSE
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 221 to 176 by which the House of Representatives today rejected a Democratic move to continue Federal spending at the old level until Feb. 3. A subsequent voice vote to place the date at Dec. 15 succeeded. Voting ''yes,'' in favor of Dec. 15, were 43 Democrats and 178 Republicans. Voting ''no,'' in favor of Feb. 3, were 176 Democrats and no Republicans. An ''xxx'' means not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, no; Flippo, no; Nichols, no; Shelby, yes. Republicans - Dickinson, yes; Edwards, yes; Smith yes .

title: The Budget Circus
description: It's great political theater: Here is Congress, undisciplined and ill-informed, ever ready to waste money at the drop of a campaign contribution. And there is President Reagan, a tough man elected to do the tough job of curbing Big Government. In the last act, our hero vetoes a bloated spending bill and makes it stick, teaching Congress a lesson in the value of the taxpayer's buck.

title: ABC AND NBC PRESS FOR HOUR NEWS
description: THE hourlong television evening news program seems finally to be shifting from a distant hope to an imminent reality. Last week, CBS announced that it intended to expand its news to 45 minutes or an hour by late next year or March 1983. Next week, ABC will offer its proposal for a one-hour newscast to its board of affiliates at a meeting in Hawaii.

title: ILL-ADVISED OBJECTION TO A LOAN TO INDIA
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE LEADERS MEET TO SEEK AN ACCORD ON ASSESSMENT BILL
description: Aides to Governor Carey and state legislative leaders began discussions yesterday in an attempt to reach a compromise on how the state should assess real property, but both sides expressed pessimism that an agreement could be worked out.

title: Kennedy Book Awards Sets Dec. 31 Deadline
description: The deadline for the second annual Robert F. Kennedy Book Awards, covering fiction or nonfiction published in 1981, is Dec. 31.

title: News Analysis
description: In his drive to cut the Federal budget, President Reagan has switched from his long and careful courtship of Congress to the tactics of confrontation and won a short-run political victory that may have a longer-run political price.

title: DURO-TEST PREPARING NEW LIGHT BULB
description: Above Luke Thorington's desk at the Duro-Test Corporation is a dogeared calendar page from 1956. It bears this Woodrow Wilson quotation: ''The thing to do is to supply light and not heat.''

title: RELIANCE JOB TO BROTHER OF FOUNDER
description: Robert M. Steinberg, 39, has been named president and chief operating officer of Reliance Group Inc. and the Leasco Corporation, which owns about 24 percent of Reliance. He succeeds his brother, Saul P. Steinberg, 42, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the two companies.

title: Aid for Afghan Refugees
description: The United Nations World Food Program said today that it would send an additional $12.2 million in emergency food aid for the 1.7 million Afghan refugees in Pakistan. The agency said the aid consisted of 44,000 tons of wheat and 2,000 tons of dates. Since January 1980, the program has provided $109 million in aid for the refugees, who fled to Pakistan after the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan in December 1979.

title: Dow Off 1.14 as Volume Drops
description: Companies involved in takeover situations scored the best gains yesterday as stock prices over all registered a slight setback in the lowest trading volume of the last four sessions.

title: GAP STORES INC, THE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MEAT PROCESSOR GETS 7-YEAR PRISON TERM IN HIJACKING OF FOOD
description: William Masselli, a Bronx meat processor who pleaded guilty to Federal hijacking charges, was sentenced yesterday in United States District Court in Manhattan to seven years in prison and fined $7,500.

title: GUIDRY STANDS FIRM IN YANK BARGAINING
description: Ron Guidry's lawyer said yesterday that George Steinbrenner had told him he planned to pursue Guidry to the end of his free-agent run. But John Schneider, the lawyer, repeated that if Steinbrenner wanted to get the pitcher back, he would have to agree to their proposal.

title: FALCONS' RALLY IN 2D HALF THWARTS VIKINGS, 31-30
description: Steve Bartkowski threw two touchdown passes in the third quarter, and Buddy Curry returned his first interception of the season 35 yards for a score in the fourth quarter as the Atlanta Falcons rallied to beat the Minnesota Vikings, 31-30, tonight.

title: Convicted Spy Indicted In Coast Prison Escape
description: Christopher John Boyce, the convicted Soviet spy, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury here on charges of escaping from the Federal Correctional Institution at Lompoc, Calif., on Jan. 21, 1980.

title: THE LAST FLURRY
description: To the Editor:

title: MOBIL SHORT OF GOAL ON MARATHON
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it had been tendered only 38 percent of the Marathon Oil Company's stock - well short of its goal. In the absence of an increase in Mobil's $5.1 billion takeover proposal, Marathon shares slid in value on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Silver Refining Off
description: Production of refined silver in the United States fell to 9.953 million troy ounces in October from 10.5 million ounces in September, the Silver Institute reported yesterday.

title: ARMATRON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes tax credits of $442,000 for the qr and $1.5 million for the yr...C-Includes tax credits of $352,000 for the qr and $1.2 million for the yr

title: WEBCOR ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MUSIC: EDUARDO RAHN LEADS THE MARACAIBO SYMPHONY
description: MARACAIBO is the second city of Venezuela in size but not, apparently, in orchestral status. In fact, the Maracaibo Symphony, which made its New York debut Monday night at Carnegie Hall under the baton of its music director, Eduardo Rahn, gave evidence all evening to support the program book's assertion that it is ''the best orchestra in South America.'' We do not hear enough of that continent's orchestras to judge that claim fairly, but we do know a good orchestra when we hear one, and the Maracaibo is certainly one.

title: MICROS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: B-Net income; restated from Thursday, Nov 12 editions

title: Chippendale and Billy Beer
description: When Mrs. Ronald Reagan moves into a new house and finds it full of ''beautiful, irreplaceable antiques falling into decay,'' she knows what to do. She is not going to just stand there while a Sheraton whatever wobbles on its last legs.

title: CITY JUDGES ASSAILED BY COOKE ON BACKLOG HE TERMS 'SHOCKING'
description: The Chief Judge of the State Court of Appeals criticized New York City judges last night for permitting a ''shocking'' backlog of cases to exist in State Supreme Court and announced measures that he said would improve the situation.

title: STOP PROLIFERATING THE 'WEAPON OF THE COWARD'
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEO-PLASTICIST PAINTER
description: Ilya Bolotowsky, an early champion and important practitioner of nonobjective painting, was found dead Sunday afternoon in an elevator shaft in the Lower East Side building where he lived. He was 74 years old and had until recently had taught in the art departments of several universities.

title: Navy Reports Plane Crash
description: The United States Navy said today that a light attack bomber crashed Sunday as it was returning from a routine mission to the Mediterranean-based U.S.S. Nimitz and the pilot was reported missing. The pilot was identified as Lieut. Hal B. Hawkins Jr. of Wilkesboro, N.C.

title: MYRA KINCH, 77, CHOREOGRAPHER
description: Myra Kinch, a dancer, teacher and choreographer, died Friday at her home in Bonita Springs, Fla. She was 77 years old.

title: Budget Impasse At a Glance; History
description: Most Federal agencies technically ran out of money at midnight Friday when a stopgap appropriations bill expired. A 1980 Attorney General's ruling held that in such a case funds could be spent only ''to bring about the orderly termination of an agen- cy's functions.''

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 24, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Storm in the North Sea Endangers 3 Oil Rigs
description: A storm with hurricane-force winds caused two Norwegian oil rigs to break loose from their moorings early this morning and drift with their sea anchors dragging behind them, the Royal Air Force said.

title: Donny Osmond to Star In Broadway Musical
description: Donny Osmond, the singer who has teamed with his sister Marie, will make his Broadway debut early in February as the star of ''Little Johnny Jones,'' a 1904 musical with book, lyrics and music by George M. Cohan. The show will have an out-of-town engagement in Washington, then open at a Nederlander theater on a date not yet announced.

title: Sports of The Times
description: AFTER what has seemed like centuries but is only a decade, New York is back in the National Football League. Not since 1969, which was actually the last season of the American Football League before the merger realignment, have the Jets been in first place entering the final four weeks of the regular season. And the Giants, who haven't appeared in a postseason game since 1963, remain alive for a wild-card playoff berth.

title: Well-Known Theme, Little-Known Composer
description: He is a guitar virtuoso, but Narciso Yepes is also a composer, best known for a tune he wrote, performed and recorded but for which he will never receive a cent, though it has earned millions for others.

title: FLORIDA GULF REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BRIEFING
description: T ENSIONS between two ideological allies, Elliott Abrams and Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, provided the backdrop for Mr. Abrams's recent shift from Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs to Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights.

title: Nurse Held and Charged In Coast Hospital Deaths
description: Robert Diaz, 44 years old, who worked as a nurse at several hospitals where patients died of drug overdoses was arrested tonight and booked for investigation on 12 charges of murder, the authorities said.

title: A PANEL KILLS BILL THAT AIDS HOMOSEXUALS
description: After two days of tumultuous and emotional debate, a City Council committee defeated yesterday a proposal to ban discrimination against homosexuals. The vote was 6 to 3.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An incorrect byline appeared on he Commodities column in Business Day yesterday. It was by Elizabeth M. Fowler.

title: BOHEMIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net income; the 1980 shr earnings adjusted for 3 percent stock divd distributed Jan 12, 1981

title: THOUSANDS OF WORKERS IDLED BY ABRUPT BUDGET FURLOUGHS
description: Guides at the Statue of Liberty and inspectors for the Environmental Protection Agency were among thousands of Federal employees in the New York area suddenly out of work yesterday, as the budget dispute in Washington left the Federal Government without authority to spend money.

title: U.N. TEAM IN DOUBT ON 'YELLOW RAIN'
description: A group of United Nations experts says that it can neither verify nor refute charges that Communist forces have used poisonous chemicals in Southeast Asia.

title: W.R. Grace Sets Stock Repurchase
description: W.R. Grace & Company, a diversified producer of chemical, natural resource and consumer products, said that it plans to repurchase up to 2.5 million of its common shares in unsolicited open market and privately negotiated transactions.

title: A World to Feed 16th article of a series appearing periodically
description: The very name of the country, Bangladesh, stirs images of misery and, in the minds of most Westerners, the perennial poverty here is the result of some inexorable Asian fate.

title: TV: 'SMALL KILLING,' ROMANCE ON SKID ROW
description: ''A SMALL KILLING,'' a movie to be shown tonight at 9 o'clock on CBS-TV, begins with the unexpected sight of Edward Asner, dressed as a bum, spitting on a car's windshield in a misguided effort to clean it. But Mr. Asner's Simon Shaber isn't a derelict, he is an undercover cop who understands derelicts, and the movie follows his investigation of the murder of one of them. The dead woman, a bag lady played by Sylvia Sidney, has observed, ''We're very fortunate to be living in such a rich country - I bet we got the best trash in the world,'' just before her demise.

title: GREEK OPPOSITION DEFENDS LINKS TO WEST
description: Former Prime Minister George Rallis tonight urged his successor, Andreas Papandreou, to maintain traditional ties with the West, arguing that to do otherwise would be ''harmful'' to Greece's interests.

title: Zlotnick Gets 5 New Clients
description: Bernie Zlotnick, who started in the business as an art director with the Zlowe Company, opened his own agency in July called the Zlotnick Company, but he waited until yesterday, his 45th birthday, to announce it. He also waited until he had five clients with annualized billings, he said, of $3 million.

title: UNITED ILLUMINATING CO reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: The 1980 earnings were reduced by additional income taxes of 17 cents a shr resulting from taxable gain produced by a sale of a portion of the company's ownership in the Seabrook Nuclear Generating project in Oct 1980

title: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1981; Companies
description: Mobil said it had received 23 million shares of Marathon Oil, well short of its goal of 30 million shares, or 51 percent. On the New York Stock Exchange, Marathon's shares fell in heavy trading when Mobil did not seek to match U.S. Steel's offer of $6.3 billion. (D1.) A takeover of Marathon by Mobil could set off a wave of other oil company takeovers if it is allowed to proceed, lawyers for Marathon argued in the Federal court in Cleveland. (D23.)

title: 'Merrily We Roll Along' May Close on Saturday
description: Unless business improves, ''Merrily We Roll Along,'' the musical that opened Nov. 16 at the Alvin Theater, will close Saturday night.

title: CARPENTER: A MAVERICK IN SPENDTHRIFT FILMLAND
description: HOLLYWOOD JOHN CARPENTER'S $13.7 million science-horror movie, ''The Thing,'' is $50,870 under budget. Mr. Carpenter - who is called, with a certain amount of seriousness, ''J.C.'' by his cast and crew - savors even such a narrow victory over the system.

title: TWO U.S. NUNS MISSING IN GUATEMALA BATTLE AREA
description: Two American nuns have been missing for four days in a province where Guatemalan troops battled leftist guerrillas in a search-and-destroy operation, a United States Embassy spokesman said today.

title: Rangers Defiant of Islanders
description: Despite two weekend losses to the Islanders, Coach Herb Brooks still feels his Rangers can beat them. When he took over early in September, Brooks said his chief purpose was to make the Rangers contenders for the Stanley Cup, which they have not won since 1940. To be genuine contenders, he said, they have to gain supremacy over the Islanders.

title: ALBERTSON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: The 1980 figures were restated to reflect adoption of F.A.S.B. No 43 accounting change

title: Alcoa Continuing Production Cuts
description: The Aluminum Company of America said that it will shut down two more potlines on Dec.4.

title: FREDERICK & HERRUD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 18
New Mobil Well
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation said that it will begin drilling its first exploratory well in the Georges Bank area off the coast of Massachusetts within the next few days.

title: 15 Prominent Members Of Solidarity Resign
description: Fifteen prominent Solidarity members resigned today, including Andrzej Gwiazda, an ideologist in the independent labor movement, the official news agency P.A.P. reported.

title: NAVY UPGRADES FLORIDA FORCE
description: The Pentagon announced the formation today of a new United States military command for the Caribbean. Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger announced the upgrading of a small task force established by President Carter two years ago at Key West, Fla., in what was a largely symbolic response to the reported presence of a Soviet brigade in Cuba.

title: SARGENT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $1,023,000 for the qr and $2,036,000 for the 6 mos...C-Includes tax credits of $916,000 for the qr and $1,771,000 for the 6 mos

title: Turkey Jails 33 Kurds On Subversion Charges
description: Martial law authorities jailed 33 suspected Kurd separatists and seized weapons, explosives and leaflets, the military Government said today.

title: Cincinnati Is Cleared Of Recruiting Charge
description: The University of Cincinnati was notified today by the National Collegiate Athletic Association that it had been cleared of any infraction of recruiting rules in connection with a basketball tryout for walk-on prospects.

title: ALL 5 CONVICTED IN SHAVE CASE
description: All five defendants in the Boston College point-shaving case were convicted yesterday at Federal District Court in Brooklyn of conspiracy to engage in racketeering and sports bribery.

title: UNITOG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
THE U.N. SECRETARIAT NEEDS 'NEW LIFE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Broker Loan Rate Cut
description: The United States Trust Company of New York said yesterday that it had lowered its broker loan rate to 13 1/4 percent from 13 3/4 percent, effective immediately. Most other major banks are quoting a 14 1/2 percent broker loan rate. Changes in the rate, which is the charge on loans used to finance stock purchases, are considered an indicator of the future direction of the prime lending rate.

title: HALEY INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
Henry Aaron Hall Candidate
description: Henry Aaron, the career home run champion, and Frank Robinson, a most valuable player in two leagues, head the list of 14 first-time candidates, announced yesterday, whose names will be placed on the 1982 ballot for entry to baseball's Hall of Fame.

title: Talking Business with Cray of Cray Research; Board Room To Laboratory
description: Seymour R. Cray is a prime example of a technical innovator who built a large company around the product of his work. Cray Research Inc., founded in 1972, had revenues of $61 million in 1980 and has been the clear leader in the business of selling the extremely fast and expensive ''supercomputers'' that are used for gigantic scientific problems. But Mr. Cray is also an example of how a technical innovator might not fit in at the helm of a large business.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A roll-call vote listing by United Press International printed in some editions yesterday, on the stopgap Federal spending bill that was ap- proved Sunday night, incorrectly listed Representatives Henry S. Reuss and Les Aspin, Democrats of Wiscon- sin. They did not vote.

title: Advertising; 2-Page Ad Impact Studied
description: SINCE it has been conventional wisdom that a magazine advertising spread - two full-page ads side by side - has only one-third more impact than a single full-page ad, a client might well suggest to his agency that it try a campaign made up of single pages and therefore double the amount of time the audience sees an ad.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: A NYONE in doubt that New York City is the center of the fashion universe had only to keep one eye open last week and his pleated bib-front shirt clean.
