The city was awash with kings and queens, which, Diane Von Furstenberg said at her screening of ''Ragtime,'' are ''very chic again,'' and the elite of European fashion, including Givenchy, Guy Laroche - who gave a little party for himself at Studio 54 complete with snake charmers - Karl Lagerfeld and Andre Courreges.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: SAN FRANCISCO PUBLIC schools are enjoying a lull in racial and ethnic conflict. Open hostilities, which frequently erupted when desegregation introduced large new groups into formerly homogeneous schools, have given way to a precarious new show of civility. This is the conclusion of a survey of more than 20 junior high and high schools in San Francisco, its peninsular suburbs and Marin County to the north. The study, conducted by the Jewish Community Relations Council of that region, was based on extensive interviews with students, teachers and school administrators.

title: RAVEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The shr earnings reflect 5 percent stock divd paid in Dec 1981 and July 1981

title: HARPER & ROW PUBLISHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CONGRESS AGREES TO EXTEND OLD SPENDING LIMIT TO DEC. 15
description: President Reagan today vetoed as ''budget busting'' a bill to provide the Government with money to continue operations.

title: Ford Ends Effort to Get Employees to Buy Plant
description: An effort to keep a Ford Motor aluminum casting plant open failed today, as union representatives of the 1,100 workers rejected a plan for employee ownership.

title: CHINA, TO RELIEVE UNEMPLOYMENT, GIVES PRIVATE SECTOR MORE LEEWAY
description: China today moved closer to becoming a mixed economy by formally acknowledging a need for more private enterprise to alleviate its chronic unemployment problem.

title: Chicago Priest Plans a Second Adoption
description: When the Rev. George Clements, a priest in Chicago, announced plans last November to adopt a 13-year-old boy, there was much disapproval in his church. Officials maintained that a priest's vow of celibacy implied that he should not undertake child-rearing but should channel all his resources toward serving his parish.

title: KATHERINE BOUDIN ROOMMATE DISMISSED BY STAMFORD PAPER
description: Rita Jensen has been dismissed as a reporter for The Advocate of Stamford for allowing the newspaper to publish what it termed ''inaccurate information'' on her relationship with Katherine Boudin, the Weather Underground fugitive seized in the Rockland County Brink's holdup, the paper said yesterday.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: An Iranian student was shot and wounded by an Iranian Consulate guard today when a group of anti-Khomeini activists demonstrated over the loss of their passports, Iranian sources said.

title: URBAN LIBRARIANS SEEK WAYS TO DEAL WITH 'DISTURBED PATRONS'
description: The director of Miami's library system has asked for a meeting with the Dade County Attorney. He wants to know how far he can go in protecting the good and faithful library patron from the noisome indigent who wants nothing more than a place to sleep.

title: TV: SIMON & SIMON,' CBS SERIES
description: ''SIMON & SIMON,'' the new weekly ''action comedy'' on CBS-TV on Tuesdays at 8 o'clock, offers the contrived spectacle of two very different private detectives who happen to be brothers. A.J. Simon (Jameson Parker) is the younger one, his clean-cut ways as squeaky cute as his carefully coiffed blond hair. Rick (Gerald McRaney), whose hairline is in a receding pattern, is the spaced-out one, always grumbling because his job - ''I hate this kind of work'' - keeps getting in the way of his love life.

title: Judge Throws Out Case On Ex-Congressman
description: A Federal judge today threw out the Government's case against former Representative Charles J. Carney, who was accused of illegally accepting use of an oil company credit card while in Congress.

title: JANE'S ASSESSES WEAPON ROLES
description: Neutron warheads could play a significant role against naval as well as against land targets and even in future space warfare against enemy satellites, Jane's Weapons Systems said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aluminum Co. of America said that it would build a $16.5 million alumina chemicals plant in Vidalia, La.

title: SENATE EASES FOREIGN BRIBERY LAW
description: The Senate voted today to weaken the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, which prohibits United States companies from bribing foreign officials.

title: News Analysis
description: When his Welfare Commissioner suggested recently that it might be cheaper for New York City to endure Federal penalties than to try harder to root out inefficiency, Mayor Koch's reaction was swift.

title: BUDGET IMPASSE ORIGINS: WHY A CRISIS DEVELOPED
description: Representative Jamie L. Whitten, Democrat of Mississippi, reflected a common view on Capitol Hill when he said today, ''This is a poor way to legislate.''

title: Household to Sell Wien Air Alaska
description: Household International Inc., the former Household Finance Corporation, said that it had agreed to sell its Wien Air Alaska subsidiary to the Eagle International Corporation, a privately owned air cargo and oil exploration firm, for $50 million.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 16.00-16.50. ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.+ Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: EX-GUARD PLEADS NOT GUILTY IN ROBBERY OF BRINK'S
description: Twenty-six-year-old George Manuel Bosque, a former security guard accused of being the thoughtful thief who drove off with a Brink's truck carrying $1.85 million and left $50 for the chambermaid whose car he later hijacked, pleaded not guilty today before a Federal magistrate.

title: DNA RESEARCH RAISES STATURE OF BIG AGRICULTURAL SCHOOLS
description: IN the last 10 years, America's agricultural colleges, so long the butt of jokes about their boot-wearing undergraduates and courses in fertilizer management, have acquired new prestige, first as the nation's food exports became an ever greater diplomatic tool and balance-of-payments item, then again as genetic research began to offer unheard-of new possibilities of improving agricultural productivity.

title: ALTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
Dome Set To Sell Off Properties
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., burdened by nearly $6 billion (Canadian) in debt, is planning to raise about $890 million in cash through the sale of oil and gas properties held through the recently acquired Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company.

title: Futures Monitoring
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said today that it would continue to monitor commodity markets during the partial shutdown of Federal Government activity for lack of appropriated funds. In a statement, the commission said all but essential activities had been suspended. It defined essential activities as ''market surveillance, investigations and audits and litigation in which the commission is a party.''

title: ROLLER COASTER U.S.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: 9th Gambling Casino Open in Atlantic City
description: After three days of delay to satisfy fire inspectors, Ramada Inns' $330 million Tropicana casino hotel opened today on the Boardwalk as this city's ninth legal gambling hall and the world's most expensive.

title: Gain in Economy Seen
description: James Tobin, the Nobel Memorial laureate in economics, forecast that the sluggish American economy could improve slightly early next year because of the Reagan Administration's tax cuts.

title: South Africa Troops Report Killing 114 Namibian Rebels
description: West Africa, Nov. 23 (AP) - South African troops killed 114 black nationalist guerrillas in operations in the last two weeks, the Defense Force headquarters here announced today. It also said five black civilians were killed by land-mine explosions near a rural village.

title: Executive Pay Seen Up 12.3%
description: Salaries of executives rose a record 12.3 percent in 1981 following sharp increases in the previous two years, according to a study to be released by the consulting firm of Sibson & Company.

title: A Blood Test Succeeds
description: Blood tests routinely given to most newborn babies throughout the United States in recent years do in fact appear to be greatly diminishing the incidence of cretinism, or hypothyroidism, in infants, according to a study published in The Lancet.

title: Failure to Pass 12 Bills Led to Stopgap Action
description: Congress was forced today to act on a stopgap spending measure, called a continuing resolution, because it had failed to pass any of the 12 appropriations bills that finance Government operations.

title: TODD IS OPTIMISTIC ABOUT FACING COLTS
description: With a cigar in his left hand and a newly outfitted cane in his right one, Richard Todd returned from a visit to the doctor and limped into a jubilant Jets' camp today.

title: Nabisco Purchase
description: Nabisco Brands Inc. announced that it had purchased a minority interest in Gamesa, a major Mexican producer of crackers and cookies, for $45 million. Nabisco did not specify what percentage of Gamesa it has acquired. Nabisco Brands, formed by the merger earlier this year of Nabisco Inc. and Standard Brands, manufactures a diversified line of food products.

title: OPERA: FALSETTOS IN GOWNS
description: LA GRAN SCENA Opera Company at the Orpheum Theater on Second Avenue asks - and answers - the question: If there are no more great women to sing dramatic soprano roles, why not men?.

title: NATO AND A-ARMS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. recently said: ''There are contingency plans in the NATO doctrine to fire a nuclear weapon for demonstrative purposes to demonstrate to the other side that they are exceeding the limits of toleration in the conventional area.'' Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger replied that there ''is absolutely nothing in any plan that even remotely resembles that, nor should it.''

title: TWO, IN THE MONEY, WANT U.S. TO LET THEM OUT
description: In a city where getting more money out of the Government is a venerated profession, Hastings Keith and John W. Macy Jr. are rocking the gravy boat. For a half-dozen years now, they have been trying to get the Government to give them less money, and having mighty little success at it.

title: Bridge: Woolsey's Side Sets Pace In Life Master Men's Pairs
description: Two top-ranked partnerships led in two major events at the Fall Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League this afternoon at the Sheraton Palace Hotel.

title: Oilers Rout Wings, 8-4
description: Glenn Anderson scored three goals and had one assist tonight to help the Edmonton Oilers beat the Detroit Red Wings, 8-4.

title: AMERICAN PACIFIC INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Chess: A Press Box View Faults Play in Korchnoi Victories
description: Both of Viktor Korchnoi's victories in his unsuccessful world championship match with Anatoly Karpov contained double errors at critical stages.

title: Postgame Confusion
description: A lawsuit filed by the Los Angeles Herald Examiner to allow Diane K. Shah, a sports columnist, into the locker room and an order by Judge Robert M. Takasugi of the United States District Court caused confusion after the San Francisco 49ers' 33-31 victory over the Rams at Anaheim, Calif., Sunday.

title: Foster Wheeler Pact
description: The Foster Wheeler Energy Corporation said today that it had received a contract for design, engineering and procurement of a 50,000-barrel-a-day oil refinery in Mobile, Ala. The overall refinery project is valued at more than $320 million, but the Foster Wheeler Corporation unit did not disclose the value of its portion of the contract.

title: COURT PERMITS DEER HUNTING IN HARRIMAN PARK TO RESUME
description: Deer hunting was restored to Harriman State Park today. The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn lifted a ban it had imposed last Monday when the hunting season began.

title: Malaysia Cocoa Output
description: Cocoa production in Malaysia this year will rise to 36,000 tons from 32,900 tons in 1980, an official of the Industries Ministry said today. Malaysia, whose major agricultural exports are rubber and palm oil, accounts for 2 percent of the world cocoa production of 1.7 million tons, he said. Last year, Malaysia exported 30,336 tons of cocoa.

title: Jersey State Senator Removed From Panel
description: Senate Democrats today removed State Senator Walter N. Sheil from his assignments on the Judiciary Committee because he had supported Republican Thomas H. Kean for Governor.

title: Texas-El Paso Runners Take 4th Straight Title
description: Texas-El Paso, led by Matthews Motshwarateu, swept the top three places today and won the national collegiate cross-country team championship for the fourth straight year.

title: TYPHOON NEARS PHILIPPINES
description: The stongest typhoon in more than 10 years began pounding the Philippines today with winds of as much as 130 miles an hour. The typhoon, called Irma, was 265 miles east-southeast of Manila and was expected to cross the area on Tuesday. The last storm to exceed Irma in strength was a typhoon that killed 575 people in October 1970.

title: WHAT CAUSED THE RECESSION
description: Like the Cheshire cat, the recession seemed to materialize from out of nowhere. But now that its shape is clearly visible, it raises the same inevitable questions: How did it happen? How bad will it get? And when will it end?

title: FOR SOME PEOPLE, STUDIES FIND, 'ONE TRUE SELF' ISN'T ENOUGH
description: PEOPLE ask the question all the time: Who am I? Who am I really? They suspect that under the many roles they play in life lies one true self whose identity strangely eludes them. Some look for it in tortuous self-examinations from psychoanalysis to religious devotion, others in the pat answers of astrological signs or trends to be followed.

title: Anaconda in Alaska Tie
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said today that its Anaconda Copper Company subsidiary had reached an exclusive agreement to explore some 24 million acres in south-central Alaska. Arco said the agreement was with Cook Inlet Region Inc. The shareholders in the energy and mineral corporation are 6,500 Alaskan natives. Under the agreement, Anaconda and Cook Inlet would share jointly in the proceeds of any mineral discovery, Arco said.

title: TRANSIT INQUIRY IS CONFIRMED ON OUTSIDE WORK BY LAWYERS
description: John D. Simpson, the president of the New York City Transit Authority, confirmed yesterday that he was investigating whether full-time transit lawyers were engaged in private legal practice during working hours in violation of authority rules.

title: FEDERAL OFFICES SHUT DOWN AS WORKERS ARE SENT HOME
description: The Government shut down many of its operations today because of a budget impasse between Congress and the White House. But it was a temporary disruption, with Congress later providing funds to permit Government workers to return to their jobs Tuesday.

title: 'OVERLAP' IS FOUND IN OIL CONCERNS' TIE
description: The Department of Energy has identified 11 states in which there was ''potentially significant overlap'' in the operations of the Marathon Oil Company and one of its suitors, the Mobil Corporation.

title: A NEW NO. 1 FOR PERKINS
description: Ray Perkins remembers the 1966 Orange Bowl game well. He helped Alabama beat Nebraska, 39-28, by catching 10 passes in the first half, and until yesterday he considered it his most memorable victory.

title: BRITISH GOVERNMENT SEEKS TO CURB UNIONS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today announced a major package of proposed restrictions on the powers of British trade unions.

title: SALVADOR PARTIES BEGIN CAMPAIGNING
description: The spray-painted revolutionary slogans on the walls here have been scrubbed off and replaced with neatly lettered posters in the blue and white national colors telling Salvadorans: ''In 1982 your vote will make the difference. El Salvador needs your vote.''

title: MR. PLEASANT REGRETS...
description: SchanbergIt's hard to find a good apartment in New York City, and even harder if you're Armenian. That is what Vartan Gregorian, the superb new president of the New York Public Library System, found out recently when the Library went searching for a cooperative apartment it could buy for Dr. Gregorian and future presidents.

title: DESERT MANEUVERS CONTINUE IN EGYPT
description: An American and an Egyptian soldier greet each other atop a Soviet-made T-62 tank after completing the day's joint ground offensive exercises near Gabal Hanza. This is the second week of the Bright Star war games.

title: AFRICA'S SPECIAL FARMING PROBLEMS
description: If something as big and complex as the third world could be presented as a drawing, black Africa would have to be treated as something different, as something outside the picture.

title: Steel Production Falls
description: Steel production fell to 1.853 million tons in the week ending last Saturday, a decrease of 4.9 percent from the previous week's 1.949 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: BONN FROM time to time over the last six weeks, West German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's pacemaker has taken over the management of his damaged heart to keep him alive.

title: ROAN CONSOLIDATED MINES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Move to Mental Hospital Is Sought for Hinckley
description: Attorneys for John W. Hinckley Jr., the man accused of shooting and wounding President Reagan, asked a Federal district judge today to send him to a mental hospital because they said he continued to be a suicide risk.

title: CLOUDED IMAGE OF TOLERANCE IN OLD JERUSALEM
description: To the Editor:

title: World Gold Output
description: Worldwide gold production and sales this year should total about 1,120 tons, with more than half coming from South Africa, the Union Bank of Switzerland said today. The bank's gold department estimated South African production this year at 650 tons. Other nonCommunist countries are likely to produce 290 tons and the Soviet Union can be expected to market 150 tons, the report said.

title: Budget Device Enables U.S. to Pay Employees
description: The Federal Government plans to use a bookkeeping procedure usually reserved for snowstorms and family emergencies to pay a half million employees who were sent home Monday as a result of a budget dispute.

title: TV: FIRST OF 'THE GIULINI CONCERTS'
description: PUBLIC television has been adroit in packaging serious music; its glossy showcases include such names as Seiji Ozawa and the Boston Symphony Orchestra and Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra.

title: 3 Are Sentenced for Fronting For Gang Figures in a Casino
description: Three businessmen convicted of fronting for reputed New Jersey organized-crime figures in a Las Vegas, Nev., casino were sentenced today to three years in prison and fined $60,000.

title: IN JERSEY SCHOOL, U.S. AND SOVIET LIFE ENTWINE
description: Preaching peace among nations, Raisa Smirnova and Ludmila Kondrakhina met the eighth graders of Glenfield School today. By the end of the afternoon, the two middle-aged women from the Soviet Union had the abashed teen-agers clasping hands, swaying and singing American antiwar songs from the 1960's.

title: John Rague, a Leader Of World Federalism
description: John R. Rague, executive director of the American Movement for World Government, died last Wednesday at his apartment in the Benjamin Franklin Hotel in Manhattan at age 63. He also had a home in Massapequa Park, L.I.

title: Holography Anniversary
description: The Museum of Holography will observe its fifth anniversary on Dec. 10 with the opening of ''Light Years IV,'' featuring recent acquisitions to its collection. The three-dimensional images in the new show join other works in the permanent exhibits. The museum is at 11 Mercer Street, in SoHo.

title: News Analysis
description: For the second time in less than a year, health problems of a Governor have created political uncertainties in Connecticut and raised questions about how the state government can function without the active participation of its chief executive.

title: STRATEGY STUDIED FOR FISCAL IMPASSE
description: White House officials met today with Republican leaders from the House and Senate to try to map a strategy to break the fiscal stalemate between President Reagan and Congress.

title: MACY'S PLANS TO EXPAND IN SUN BELT
description: R.H. Macy & Company's New York division, which has added no new stores in almost a decade, will be entering the Sun Belt at a cost of $250 million over the next seven years, the company told shareholders yesterday.

title: BT MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $10,662,000 gain on the exchange of assets for debt and tax loss carryforward...C-Net loss

title: MCCARTHY PONDERS RETURN TO POLITICS
description: In an 18th-century farmhouse at the end of Holim Hollow, Eugene J. McCarthy is hearing the drums again. He has lived here for four years, working at an electric typewriter before a great stone fireplace. His neighbors beyond the next hill ride motorcycles or ride to the hounds. The other day a black bear stepped out of the pines and birches and stopped at the pond beside his house.

title: 29 Days Left
description: You may not care to be reminded, but it's a fact - there are only 29 days left for Chistmas shopping. That is assuming that your favorite stores are staying open Sundays; otherwise, subtract four shopping days. It's time to check your gift list and venture forth before the crowds get overwhelming.

title: Rep. Butler to Quit Politics
description: Representative M. Caldwell Butler, Republican of Virginia, said today that he would retire from politics and return to Roanoke to practice law instead of seeking re-election to a sixth term.

title: CRUISE MISSILE COMPLETED
description: The first full-production air-launchable cruise missile on display yesterday at ceremony at the Boeing plant in Kent, Wash. It is the first of 705 missiles scheduled to be delivered to the Air Force.

title: 18 DEMOCRATS ASK SPECIAL PROSECUTOR IN ALLEN CASE
description: Eighteen Democrats in the Senate said today that, to insure a credible investigation, Attorney General William French Smith should immediately seek a special prosecutor in the case involving Richard V. Allen, the President's national security adviser.

title: LEVITT PLANS VENEZUELAN HOUSING
description: William J. Levitt, the builder behind Levittown, L.I., and other housing developments, and a Venezuelan group have agreed to build a $700 million, low-income housing project in Venezuela, and are seeking $20 million or $25 million in preliminary financing from United States banks for it, an aide to Mr. Levitt said yesterday.

title: AS DEMAND GROWS, FOOD SHOPS EXPAND
description: More chocolate truffles and caviar. More croissants and duck pate. More copper pots and coffee makers. As the appetite for specialty foods and quality cookware continues to grow, retailers are redesigning and adding space to keep up with the demand. This fall, several important food shops in Manhattan have undergone major expansions.

title: Economic Scene; Budgetary Brouhaha
description: THE great Symbolic Battle of the Budget between the President and Congress has broken off for the moment, with Congressional passage of the Republican-sponsored bill extending the present financing level until Dec.@ 15.

title: Bulls 109, Clippers 102
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Reggie Theus scored 25 points and Artis Gilmore had 12 of his 20 points in the fourth quarter for Chicago. The Bulls (6-8) led by as many as 14 points in the third quarter before the Clippers (2-9), who have lost five straight games, outscored the Bulls, 26-6, in the last seven minutes of the period to take a 78-72 advantage entering the final 12 minutes.

title: WILLIAMS ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-the yr-ago qr net is pro forma because the company was spun-off from a parent company

title: Tea Men Get Backing For '82 Outdoor Soccer
description: The Jacksonville Tea Men of the North American Soccer League will be in business in 1982 if the coming indoor season is a success, officials connected with the team said today.

title: ANOTHER REVISION
description: I wish intellectuals and scientists would stop revising my mind for a few years. They revised it so completely during the last 10 years that I can't find my way around in all the new mental furniture. And still they won't stop.

title: COLUMBIA HEADS HOME
description: The space shuttle orbiter Columbia sitting atop a 747 transport plane as it took off from Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. The shuttle is on the way to Cape Canaveral, Fla., to be prepared for a third mission.

title: EUROPE ALLIES VEX U.S. ON SALVADOR
description: The United States and four of its Western European allies are at odds here over the role of the leftist opposition in El Salvador.

title: Coach's Lament
description: Coaches of professional basketball teams should be paid ''somewhere in the middle to the top'' of the salaries paid their players, said Lenny Wilkens, coach of the Seattle SuperSonics.

title: 'Snubbies' on the Streets
description: Gun enthusiasts typically argue that limiting guns in order to fight crime would also limit them for legitimate use - hunting, target shooting and self-defense. An article excerpted in The Washington Post suggests a compromise: don't restrict all guns, just those most often used in crime.

title: BANK BIDS $53 MILLION FOR BROKER
description: The BankAmerica Corporation announced yesterday that it intended to acquire Charles Schwab & Company Inc., America's largest discount brokerage firm, for about $53 million in common stock. The transaction could develop into a historic test case for Federal banking laws.

title: CYMATICOLOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Iraqi Head of U.N. Assembly Going to Arab League Parley
description: Ismat Kittani of Iraq, the President of the General Assembly, said today he would leave his post for three days to attend the Arab League conference in Fez, Morocco.

title: One Round for Ali
description: It's being called the ''drama in the the Bahamas,'' but reports of financial troubles have cast doubt on whether the Dec. 11 Muhammad Ali-Trevor Berbick bout will ever get past casting.

title: Classified Data Reported In New England Dump
description: Classified military documents litter a New Hampshire dump in a ''careless breach of American military security,'' former Gov. Meldrim Thomson said today.

title: SOME REPORTS DELAYED OR CANCELED
description: Budget cuts have caused the Census Bureau to delay or to cancel reports of important findings from the 1980 population count and to say it cannot afford to conduct a 1985 middecade census that Congress has mandated.

title: CASO DENIES KNOWLEDGE OF SPLIT INSURANCE FEES
description: Ralph G. Caso, a former Nassau County Executive, testified today that he had not known that the county's official insurance broker was sharing commissions with political supporters of Joseph M. Margiotta, the county's Republican chairman.

title: Man Is Convicted In Friend's Death
description: A jury convicted Arne Cheyenne Johnson of first-degree manslaughter here yesterday in the fatal stabbing of a friend.

title: LA PRENSA'S BURDEN IN ARGENTINE PERSECUTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Labor Party in Britain Takes Turn to the Left
description: The leader of Britain's opposition Labor Party, Michael Foot, shuffled his shadow cabinet today to give it a distinctly leftist stance on nuclear disarmament and the European Economic Community.

title: STAGE: SURREALIST 'BULLET HEADED BIRDS'
description: UP to now, the Pan Asian Repertory Theater has specialized in naturalistic plays. With Philip Kan Gotanda's ''Bullet Headed Birds'' (at the 28th Street Playhouse), the nomadic company takes a sidestep into surrealism and contemporary musical theater. The shift is venturesome but also somewhat reminiscent of early Sam Shepard. In this new play, first staged last spring at the Asian American Theater Company in San Francisco, Mr. Gotanda has written a kind of Japanese-American equivalent of ''Cowboy Mouth'' by Mr. Shepard and Patti Smith.

title: Quake Shakes North Japan
description: A mild earthquake rattled windows and toppled flowerpots today in the city of Morioka and surrounding areas, about 300 miles north of Tokyo, but there were no reports of damage or injuries. The Central Meteorogical Agency said the epicenter of the quake was about 25 miles under the sea off the east coast.

title: FLAWED ALTERNATIVE TO INSTITUTIONS FOR THE ELDERLY
description: To the Editor:

title: LATEST BRITISH INVASION: 'THE NEW TRIBALISM'
description: WAR paint, Mohawk haircuts, three-cornered admirals' hats, pirate garb and rhythms copied from a field recording of African tribal music are some of the unlikely components of Britain's latest contribution to pop music. This dizzy mixed metaphor has been dubbed ''the new tribalism,'' and the two bands that are its most popular purveyors are making a splash this week - Bow Wow Wow returns to the Ritz Friday and Saturday, and a new album from Adam and the Ants has just been released.

title: HE KNOWS THE NAMES THAT MATTER
description: Every capital should have a Stanford Busby. Mr. Busby knows how to pronounce the name of just about everybody in the world who matters. In his corner of the Voice of America, Mr. Busby (pronounced ''BUZZbee'') presides over 15,000 little cards that tell the announcers of the United States Government network that Sam Nujoma is really Sam Nu-YO-ma and that Reagan and Begin don't rhyme. (It is ''be'' as in Betty, not ''ba'' as in bay, Mr. Busby says.)

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 15.75-16.00. ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. + Maximum rate payable by savings institutions. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Rose Kennedy Enters Hospital Heart Unit
description: Rose Kennedy was admitted to St. Mary's Hospital here today after suffering chest pains while attending a morning mass in Palm Beach. She was reported to be in stable condition and resting comfortably.

title: IN EGYPT, ELEGANT TENTS, TEA AND B-52'S
description: Six B-52 bombers, after flying nonstop from a base in Minot, N.D., bombed designated targets today near this desert oasis in the final phase of a large Egyptian-American military exercise.

title: 2 American Nuns Found Unharmed in Guatemala
description: Two Roman Catholic nuns from the United States, a Guatemalan priest and a seminary student who disappeared five days ago were found unharmed today in western Guatemala, a church official said.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, Nov. 16 to Sunday, Nov. 22), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets. RATING PROGRAM NETWORK 1 29.4 Dallas CBS 2 28.8 60 Minutes CBS 3 26.2 Three's Company ABC 4 25.3 Too Close for Comfort ABC 5 24.3 "Moonraker" ABC 6 23.0 "Bob Hope" NBC 7 22.6 Happy Days ABC 8 22.7 Dynasty ABC 9 22.2 M*A*S*H CBS 10 22.1 Laverne & Shirley ABC 11 21.7 Hart to Hart ABC 12 21.2 Facts of Life NBC 13 20.5 "Loretta Lynn" NBC 14 20.4 "George Burns" NBC 15 20.2 "Mary Poppins" CBS

title: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE IN OCTOBER BY A SLIGHT 0.4%
description: With housing prices falling and food inflation slowing, the Consumer Price Index rose by only four-tenths of 1 percent in October, the smallest increase in six months.

title: Rangers Return Larose
description: The Rangers yesterday returned Claude Larose, a left wing, to the Springfield Indians of the American Hockey League and signed Craig Norwich, a free agent defenseman, and also assigned him to Springfield. Larose had not played a game with the Rangers since being called up from Springfield last week.

title: Self-Promotion
description: Atlantic City's Director of Public Safety, Willie B. Clayton Jr., has promoted five police inspectors to deputy chief, and stirred up a political furor. Mr. Clayton, who is on leave from the department while serving as a City Commissioner, was one of the inspectors he promoted.

title: COAST POLICE SAY 'CALLOUS' YOUTHS VIEWED GIRL'S BODY AND STONED IT
description: A teen-ager reportedly bragged about killing his 14-year-old former girlfriend and showed off her corpse to more than a dozen high school classmates, but none of them notified the authorities, officials said today.

title: Warts and All
description: Getting all decked out to give the kiddies pleasure in the annual Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade is not all beer and skittles, especially for Rosalind Elias. She will work her wicked, wicked ways as the witch in ''Hansel and Gretel'' on the float the Metropolitan Opera will use in the parade down Central Park West and Broadway tomorrow.

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT
description: THE leaves had been falling ostentatiously onto my back lawn, but as I trudged through them the other day, their insistent rustling meant almost nothing to me. I was preoccupied with the smokehouse I had built myself (with some help from a friend who knows about these things) in the summer. It has become a kind of laboratory for me as I try to learn its ways.

title: Careers; Advanced Study for Engineers
description: CLASSES begin at 7 A.M. at least once a week for 980 working engineers who are part of the Early Bird Engineering Program at the University of Santa Clara, in California's ''Silicon Valley.'' They are slowly working part time toward master's degrees at the university.

title: MJB Coffee Prices Up
description: The MJB Company said today that it had increased the retail list price on roasted ground coffee by 15 cents a pound, to $2.70 a pound, effective immediately. MJB also raised its 13-ounce size of Colombian flake ground coffee by 12 cents, to $2.29 for a 13-ounce unit, and raised its retail price on instant coffee by 2 1/2 cents an ounce on the two-ounce size and 1 1/2 cents an ounce on the six-ounce and 10-ounce sizes. MJB cited the higher cost of green coffee beans.

title: Index; International
description: Outlook bright for British alliance on eve of election A2 Saudi plan is apparently creating a sharp division in Arab world A3 B-52's hit targets in Egypt as part of war games display A3 Canada's constitution to recog- nize equal rights of women A4 Around the World A6 Haig winds up ''cordial'' talks with Mexicans A7 4 European allies vex U.S. on Sal- vador A10 Greek Parliament approves So- cialist program A12 Washington Talk Briefing A18 Public interest work loses appeal for law school graduates A18 Eugene McCarthy finds lure of politics growing again A18 Voice of America employee knows the names that matter A18 Living Section Food A chefs' day out at a quail farm C1

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: History tells us that the first Thanksgiving was a dinner given by the Pilgrims for the Indians to celebrate the harvest, the happy culmination of that unending cycle of seed and green shoot and flowering bush and fruit and bare tree that occurs in nature, and in life.

title: G.M. Sets Layoffs
description: The General Motors Corporation said that it would reduce production at its Arlington assembly plant to 45 cars an hour, from 58, and lay off 900 workers because of weak market conditions.

title: AMES DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PASSBOOK RATES: TOO LOW?
description: Federal banking regulators took a step a few weeks ago to liberalize the interest paid to the millions of Americans who have passbook savings accounts, but they backed down under intense protests from savings instititions.

title: Ford Closes Its Dutch Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company's Dutch subsidiary said it had closed its plant here, despite a fight by employees to keep the factory operating.

title: PARAHO DEVELOPMENT CORP (DENVER, COLO) reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
Military Talks Held in Poland
description: Marshal Viktor G. Kulikov of the Soviet Union, commander of Warsaw Pact forces, met here today with Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader. The Polish press agency said they had discussed the training and combat readiness of the Polish Army. Gen. Anatoly I. Gribkov of the Soviet Union, chief of staff of the Warsaw Pact forces, also took part in the talks.

title: 3 FOSTER-CARE AGENCIES LOSE CONTRACTS AFTER CITY INQUIRY
description: New York City announced yesterday that it would terminate contracts with three private foster-care agencies that it said had serious deficiencies and ordered changes in the programs of three other organizations.

title: BIG 3 CAR SALES PLUNGE
description: Providing stark evidence that an economic recession was taking hold last month, the Government reported today that new orders for durable goods plunged 8 percent in October, the biggest one-month drop in two and a half years.

title: OUTLOOK BRIGHT FOR BRITISH ALLIANCE ON EVE OF VOTE
description: The temperature had fallen below 35 degrees, and the cutting wind off the Irish Sea made it seem colder. But both the assembly halls at Freshfield primary school were full, and 50 or 60 people were huddled outside, straining to hear the sound of the candidate's voice if not to catch a glimpse of her face.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Regina Doyle, 22 years old, was killed and Kevin Ryan, 23, was critically burned yesterday trying to rescue her in a fire that destroyed a windowless, wood-and-tin shed used as a club by young adults in the Union Port section of the Bronx. The fire was extinguished at 2:52 A.M. Mr. Ryan was taken to the Jacobi Hospital Burn Center with burns over 85 percent of his body. ... Amando Rudis, 18, of Brooklyn, was arrested shortly after 1 P.M. by two Manhattan Criminal Court guards who said Mr. Rudis was chasing James Palmer, 18, also of Brooklyn, with a carpet knife through lunch-hour crowds near the Criminal Court building. ... Two cabdrivers were robbed of their cabs and a total of $150 in separate incidents in Long Island City, Queens.

title: PUBLIC INTEREST JOBS LURING FEWER LAW STUDENTS
description: Between the salmon mousse and the creme de caramel at the law firm recruiting lunches here, there is less talk of ''pro bono'' and public interest law these days than there used to be.

title: WATT PRESSES OFFSHORE LEASING DESPITE OPPOSITION
description: More than 200 miles offshore, on the rich but turbulent spawning ground of the Georges Bank, two huge rigs are already probing for oil and gas far beneath the surface of the shallow Outer Continental Shelf. Many more are expected to follow.

title: RICHARD FOREMAN'S 'STRONG MEDICINE'
description: RHODA, a slender, pale woman in a sensible dress and sensible shoes, is in a state. To describe her as being extremely upset would be an understatement, much like a psychiatrist's saying that someone who is in the process of committing suicide is suffering an anxiety attack. Slang is more accurate. Rhoda is very nearly out of her wig, though her hair is apparently her own.

title: COBB RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; yr-ago shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in Feb

title: Portrait of a Winner
description: THE phone call came from Laurel Race Course in Maryland: ''Did you ever hear of a jockey named Nick Shuk?'' The answer was easy. ''I remember his father. Wasn't he prominent in the Preakness one year, maybe Nashua's Preakness?'' ''Yes,'' Joe Kelly said, ''but that was Nick, not his father. Nick is 51 and still riding, and winning, and battling cancer.'' They celebrated Nick Shuk Day at Laurel last week, calling the feature the Nick Shuk Purse and naming the other races for horses that meant something special in his career -Pilaster, Little Harp, Sailor, Tuscany, Brazen Brat, Damascus, Saratoga and Sunglow. Little Harp, owned by the Pittsburgh Steelers' proprietor, Art Rooney, was Shuk's first winner, in 1948, when Nick was apprenticed to Rooney's Shamrock Farm. Rooney gave Nick a watch on that occasion and, assuming the boy was Irish, had it engraved ''Keep the faith.''

title: VOTER WELCOME, WITH GUNS AND ARMBANDS
description: To the Editor:

title: WEINBERGER CONTENDS STATES MUST DEFER TO MILITARY NEED
description: Caspar W. Weinberger, the Secretary of Defense, told the Republican Governors Association today that, notwithstanding complaints from members of the group, the nation's military budget could not be cut to find money to help the states cope with the recession.

title: WESTERN NATURAL GAS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Advertising; Hard Sell At Burger King
description: ADVERTISING probably works at its very best when it takes advantage of a basic drive. For Burger King in 1982 this will mean latching on to good old-fashioned hunger. Its television commercials will be built around particularly good photography of its offerings and the radio spots will remind listeners of what they saw on television. The theme line, set to catchy music, will be: ''Aren't you hungry - for Burger King now?''

title: Lakers 125, Mavericks 110
description: DALLAS (AP) - Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 25 points to lead Los Angeles to its eighth straight victory. The loss was the 11th in a row for the Mavericks (1-12).

title: THE STORMY SUMMIT
description: When leaders of East and West meet, as they have here in recent days, they talk of different things. Both, of course, talk of peace, but President Brezhnev talked here primarily about the immediate problem of missiles, while Chancellor Schmidt of West Germany talked about history and the destiny of the human family in the coming century.

title: Flemish Liberals Accept Bid to Form Government
description: Willy de Clerq, leader of the Flemish Liberals, accepted King Baudouin's request today to form a new Belgian cabinet and said he would try to set up a center-right coalition of Liberals and Social Christians.

title: Robert Philipp, 86, Portraitist And Instructor of Painting
description: Robert Philipp, a painter who had been an instructor at the Art Students League for 33 years, died Sunday in Roosevelt Hospital from complications after a heart attack.

title: MOYNIHAN BARS EXPANDED INQUIRY ON STOCK DEALINGS BY C.I.A. HEAD
description: The acting chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence refused today to expand the panel's investigation of William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, to include a review of his control over his personal stock portfolio.

title: CONCERT: MUSICAL ELEMENTS
description: THE first Musical Elements concert of the season Monday night at Cooper Union might have seemed a random potpourri, offering a nonjudgmental vista of compositional possibilites. But the six pieces could also be perceived as pairs, some of them overlapping. There were two Japanese works, from Toru Takemitsu and Akira Miyoshi; two concertos for soloist and, mostly, winds, by Colin McPhee and George Lewis; two works harking back to older forms, by Peter Maxwell Davies and, again, McPhee, and two world premieres, by Mr. Lewis and David Olan.

title: Bucks 103, Pistons 95
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Bob Lanier scored 14 of a season-high 24 points in the second half to lead Milwaukee (8-5).

title: The Bets Ride on Used Horses
description: Only the horses looked as if they belonged in the paddock at Belmont Park yesterday. The 50 or so people milling around them in the sunny chill appeared out of place, looking not at all like the dapperly dressed horse owners who linger beneath the leafy trees and watch their thoroughbreds being saddled on summer and fall racing afternoons.

title: WHEN SPOUSES PLAY SAME GAME
description: John and Shernaz Kennedy of Little Neck, Queens are both highranking tournament chess players. He is 24, she is 27. When they announced a year ago that they planned to marry, Mr. Kennedy's worried father took his son aside and said:

title: BEST BUYS
description: THIS year, New Yorkers shopping for Thanksgiving dinner can be thankful for lower prices. According to a special Thanksgiving food price survey of the Department of Consumer Affairs, the average price of a pound of turkey, fresh and frozen, was 86 cents, down 14 cents from last year's average price of $1 a pound. Cranberries are down to 68 cents a pound from $1.09 last year.

title: U.S. PRESSING ISRAEL TO ACCEPT EUROPEANS ON THE SINAI FORCE
description: The United States has privately urged Israel to accept the participation of four Western European countries in the Sinai peacekeeping force and to ignore their statements indicating support for the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: MONUMENTAL INSURANCE FILLS TOP POST
description: The Monumental National Life Insurance Company of New York, a newly acquired subsidiary of the Monumental Corporation, has appointed Martha M. McCaffrey, 49, president and chief executive officer. On Jan.1 she will succeed John G. Wick, 56, who will return to private law practice.

title: Farm Workers in Photos
description: ''Rural Farm Workers - West/ Southwest,'' a photographic exhibition featuring the work of Bill Ravanesi, will open Tuesday on the ground floor of the Ford Foundation Building, at 320 East 43d Street, and continue till Feb. 16. It can be seen between 9 A.M. and 5 P.M. The exhibition of 33 photographs depicts the life of Mexican-American and Filipino farm workers.

title: COCKBURN LOADS ROCK WITH ISSUES
description: WHEN Bruce Cockburn, the Canadian singer-songwriter who appeared for two shows at the Bottom Line on Monday, writes songs called ''Civilization and Its Discontents'' and ''Justice,'' he's not kidding. Anchored in Christian mysticism, Mr. Cockburn's songs address our modern malaise with fierce, painterly images and an unambiguous moral passion.

title: A PROGRAM HEALS FOREIGN CHILDREN
description: The children come from Guatemala, Korea and elsewhere, seeking medical help unavailable in their countries.

title: Girl, 14, Accused in Fire Fatal to Four in Family
description: A 14-year-old girl has been accused of setting a fire that killed her mother and three sisters, the authorities and published reports said today.

title: Cotton Acres May Decline
description: The Agriculture Department said yesterday that cotton acreage in the United States for the 1982-83 season may fall slightly from this year's 14.3 million acres.

title: LANDMARK STATUS VOTED FOR WARBURG MANSION
description: Landmark status was voted yesterday for the former Felix M. Warburg mansion at Fifth Avenue and 92d Street. The unanimous decision by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission will make it more difficult to put a proposed 25-story luxury tower next to the mansion. The building was once part of Fifth Avenue's famed ''millionaires' row'' and is now the home of the Jewish Museum.

title: U.S. STEEL'S BID HALTED BY MOBIL
description: The Mobil Corporation, in an attempt to gain the upper hand in the competition to acquire the Marathon Oil Company, obtained a temporary court restraining order yesterday preventing the the United States Steel Corporation from going ahead with its $6.3 billion takeover bid for Marathon.

title: U.S.C. BREAKS GROUND FOR A FILM-TV SCHOOL
description: The directors of the four most commercially successful movies ever made stood on top of a grassy knoll overlooking a parking lot at the University of Southern California this week as the site for U.S.C.'s new $14 million cinema-television school was dedicated.

title: BRIEFING
description: I T can be a pathetic experience to spot a defeated Congressman lingering in the capital city, still smiling and backslapping but wraith-like without a constituency. The other night, by contrast, John Brademas, who was voted out of the House of Representatives last year after 22 years, was serene as he sat in the fashionable shadows of the Hay-Adams Hotel lounge, sipping a Campari and soda, reflecting on his new role as president of New York University, and sounding not at all nostalgic for Washington. This was the Indiana Democrat's first visit back since he moved last summer, and while it did not allow time to visit Tip O'Neill and other beloved cronies at the House, it did provide a handy forum at Georgetown University for Mr. Brademas to speak and to ''blister,'' as he put it, the Reagan Administration's dismantling of higher education programs that Mr. Brademas helped write as Congressman. Except for his direct concern, education, Mr. Brademas said he was ''not popping off'' in the political field, although he had found ''it is not really quite so far from Washington D.C. to Washington Square as you might imagine.'' He agreed with Thorstein Veblen's observation that academic executives and politicians had much in common in being ''peculiarly open to the appeal of parade and ephemeral celebrity.'' Then he hurried to complete his business and get back to campus in New York.

title: Fred R. Conrad New Kit in Town
description: Sara, a Bengal tiger cub, seemed to enjoy the fuss made over her yesterday as she arrived at her new home in the Children's Zoo in Central Park. The cub, donated to the city by a television production company, should have no trouble adjusting to her new fame; her mother is a circus performer.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The decision to improve defenses cannot really be contingent on passing fluctuations in the economy.

title: Doctor Surrenders On Jersey Charge
description: Dr. James Morrison, accused in New Jersey of conspiring to kill his son and daughter-in-law, turned himself in to the Mercer County sheriff's office after he had been free on bond for a week, Sheriff Ronald Kessler said. Dr. Morrison, 54 years old, was arrested on a warrant signed by Gov. Allen Olson.

title: Rockies Recall Hughes
description: The Colorado Rockies have recalled Jack Hughes, a defenseman, from their Fort Worth farm team to replace Tapio Levo, an injured rookie.

title: The Ax Falls
description: Kentucky's season-ending victory Saturday over Tennessee was not enough to save the job of Coach Fran Curci, who was dismissed yesterday after nine years, including 3-8 seasons in 1980 and 1981. Curci had been under fire from many quarters, including the office of Gov. John Y. Brown. ... The University of California said it had received permission from San Jose State to confer with State's football coach, Jack Elway, as a possible successor to Roger Theder.

title: JWT Chief Optimistic Over New Business
description: Security analysts on Wall Street yesterday heard from Don Johnston, chief executive of the JWT Group and of J. Walter Thompson.

title: SCHMIDT REPORTS HE IS PERSUADED BREZHNEV WANTS EUROPE ARMS CUT
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany said today that Leonid I. Brezhnev had convinced him of Soviet interest in arms reduction but that the Soviet leader was unable to acknowledge that the Reagan Administration wanted peace.

title: BALLET: 'CONCERTO NO. 2' AND 'EIGHT EASY PIECES'
description: ALTHOUGH the New York City Ballet's Saturday night program at the New York State Theater began with a repetition of ''Scotch Symphony,'' to Mendelssohn, the rest of the evening was devoted to ballets to music by two composers particularly associated with the company, Tchaikovsky and Stravinsky. Not one of those scores was specifically written for dancing. Yet the fact that they were successfully put to balletic use suggested that, as the company's balletmasters have long contended, much of Tchaikovsky and Stravinsky may be inherently danceable.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Express Credit Corporation registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of $250 million of medium-term senior notes, to be sold through a Salomon Brothers group.

title: By Leoanrd Sloane; BUSINESS PEOPLE; The Seamen's Bank Elects a President
description: Steven H. Rice, 38 years old, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Seamen's Bank for Savings, the New York savings bank founded in 1829. Effective Dec.1, he will succeed E. Virgil Conway, 52, who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer of the bank, which has six offices and $1.8 billion in assets.

title: MOHAWK DATA SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $165,000 extraordinary credit

title: BOSSY SCORES TWO GOALS
description: For the third time in their last three games, an Islander shot that floated high in the air landed inside the opponent's net for a goal. Tonight at Nassau Coliseum, it was such a goal by Mike Bossy that started the Islanders off to a 3-1 victory over the Boston Bruins.

title: NEW YORK PRICES DROPPED BY 0.2%
description: Consumer prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey region declined in October, the first drop in the monthly rate in four years and the second in nearly 15 years.

title: LONGS DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Includes after tax gains of $786,000 for the qr and $1,317,000 for the 9 mos from the sale of land

title: 'Miami's for Me' Slogan Aims at a Better Image
description: City officials have kicked off a public relations drive modeled after the ''I Love New York'' campaign to counter Miami's reputation as the murder and drug capital of America.

title: A TRIBUTE TO A SPRY BREZHNEV BRINGS AN EDGY SOVIET REPLY
description: The state of Leonid I. Brezhnev's health created a heated dispute today between Soviet and West German spokesmen. In what seemed intended as a compliment, Kurt Becker of West Germany said at a news conference that Bonn leaders were ''impressed with the physical stability'' with which Mr. Brezhnev followed a long program on Monday without outward signs of fatigue.

title: A CHEFS' DAY OUT AT A QUAIL FARM
description: Leslie Revsin from Restaurant Leslie, Nicola Civetta from Primavera, Lawrence Forgione from the River Cafe and Mark Chayette from the Quilted Giraffe, as well as Dennis Foy from the Tarragon Tree in Chatham, N.J. - organized garnishes, chopped, stirred, basted, foraged in the garden for fresh herbs and tried not to trip over one another with pans of boiling sauce.

title: Bridge: U.S. Women's Team Stars Capture Life Master Event
description: One of the world's top women partnerships held on to win the life master women's pair championship in the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals Monday night at the Sheraton Palace Hotel here. The partnership -Edith Kemp of Miami Beach and Nancy Gruver of Ellicott City, Md., who were members of the American team that finished second in the world women's team championship last month - held a big lead into the final session and eventually won by 3 match points.

title: MEDIAN HOME VALUE FOUND HIGHEST IN HAWAII
description: The median value of a house last year was more than $200,000 in Aspen, Colo., and at least $100,000 in 11 other areas of the country, including seven California counties, a Census Bureau report on housing said today. But the report said that, at the same time, renters were paying $50 a month in 34 counties, most of them in the South.

title: Paine Webber Narrows Loss
description: Paine Webber Inc. reported yesterday that it had a loss of $3.4 million in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1981 ended Sept. 25, compared with a deficit of $7.6 million in the corresponding quarter of the preceding fiscal year.

title: U.S. MAY CUT POOR NATIONS' LOAN AID
description: The Reagan Administration, as part of the budget exercise for the fiscal year beginning next Oct. 1, is considering a further cutback to $750 million a year in its contributions in the mid-1980's to a World Bank agency that makes interest-free loans to poor countries, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: SAUDI PLAN IS DIVIDING ARABS AT FEZ
description: A strong current was running against Crown Prince Fahd's Middle East peace plan today as heads of state gathered here for an Arab League meeting to consider the Saudi Arabian initiative.

title: Fordham Triumphs
description: Dud Tongal, a senior center, scored 19 points and had 13 rebounds to lead Fordham to an 85-66 victory over the Zagreb team of Yugoslavia in an exhibition game last night.

title: Byrne Vetoes Measure Against Peeping Toms
description: Governor Byrne today vetoed legislation that would have made the actions of a Peeping Tom a criminal offense. The legislation would have made such actions a disorderly-persons offense, punishable by up to 30 days in jail and a $500 fine. Mr. Byrne, a former Superior Court judge, said that though it might appear that the legal system had not dealt seriously enough with the issue, it was often difficult to regulate some kinds of behavior.

title: GREEK PARLIAMENT APPROVES POLICY OUTLINED BY SOCIALISTS
description: The Greek Parliament approved the new Socialist Government's program tonight by a vote of 172 to 113. This opens the way for Greece to initiate negotiations soon for the phased withdrawal of the four American bases from the country and for more favorable terms of membership within the European Economic Community and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's military wing.

title: Cambodian Rebel Groups Weigh New Unity talks
description: Cambodia's rival guerrilla groups, deadlocked after three months of negotiations, are considering new talks to form a loose coalition government in exile, it was announced today.

title: ADVERTISING COUNCIL OFFICIAL
description: Allan M. Wilson, a former vice president of the Advertising Council in New York, died Friday in a nursing home in Arlington, Va.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 25, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: OPEC Price Policy Review
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries intends to adopt a pricing formula allowing oil price cuts under certain conditions, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, said here today.

title: STYLE ADVISORY
description: A stroll on Fifth Avenue makes it clear That down is decidedly up this year. FELICIA LAMPORT

title: DISPUTE BETWEEN EQUITY AND OFF BROADWAY IS RESOLVED OUT OF COURT
description: The conflict between playwrights and Actors Equity Association over the union's codes for showcase productions - a dispute that for two years jeopardized the continuation of Off Off Broadway as an arena for production of new plays - has been settled out of court. Six American playwrights -Michael Weller, David Mamet, Romulus Linney, Barbara S. Graham, John Olive and James Childs - had been allied in an antitrust suit against Equity. The six recently terminated their suit and signed an agreement along with representatives of Equity, the Dramatists Guild and the Society of Authors Representatives. The settlement stressed amicability, not victory for either side.

title: KOCH CONSIDERS TAX INCREASE AND HIRING FEWER WORKERS
description: The Koch administration, faced with a rapidly deteriorating financial picture, is considering increases in a number of taxes and fees and is almost certain to hire fewer new employees than it planned, officials said yesterday.

title: SANDERS ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
THANKSGIVING: WHEN CUISINES MEET, IT'S A CHANGEABLE FEAST
description: Thanksgiving, in our house, is a changeable feast. It is American to the extent that it is observed on the day set aside for it, occasionally Italian in flavor simply because that is the ancestry of my husband and old feasts die hard, and quite often Chinese in taste because that is what I know and what I cook.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE SPIRAL STAIRCASE

title: Transactions; BASEBALL NEW YORK METS (NL) - Sent Dave von Ohlen, pitcher, to Tidewater of Inter- national League.
description: TORONTO (AL) - Peter Bavasi, club p resident, resigned. BASKETBALL DETROIT (NBA) - Signed Kent Ben- son, center, to contract extension through 1988-89 season.

title: Aminoil Sale
description: Aminoil Marketing Inc., a subsidiary of Aminoil USA Inc., said it had sold its retail liquefied petroleum gas and diesel fuel operations to the Cal Gas Corporation, a subsidiary of the Dillingham Corporation, on undisclosed terms. Aminoil USA is a subsidiary of R.J. Reynolds Industries Inc. of Winston-Salem, N.C. Before the sale, Aminoil Marketing Inc. sold liquefied petroleum gas and diesel fuel in the retail and wholesale markets in the central and Southeastern United States.

title: G.S.A. Defers Tin Sales
description: The General Services Administration said today that it would not resume its daily sales of tin from the National Defense stockpile until next Monday. The agency also said that no weekly silver auction would be held this week, and that the next sale would be held on Dec. 2.

title: Elevator Workers Ratify 3-Year Pact
description: An 18-day strike by 1,500 elevator maintenance men in the metropolitan area ended with ratification of a new three-year contract that would raise wages by more than 37 percent.

title: CBS-TV CANCELS 'UP TO THE MINUTE'
description: TV, suffering from ratings difficulties in both its news and entertainment programming, yesterday announced the cancellation of ''Up to the Minute,'' a weekday afternoon news program that featured the four ''60 Minutes'' correspondents, and two of its hourlong prime-time dramas.

title: MISS BOUDIN AND MISS CLARK REFUSE TO PLEAD TO CHARGES
description: Katherine Boudin and Judith A. Clark, charged with murder and robbery in the Oct. 20 Rockland County armored-car shootings, refused to enter formal pleas at their arraignment today. They cited the judge's refusal to allow them to meet with Chokwe Lumumba, a black-nationalist lawyer.

title: Soviet Gymnasts Lead
description: A young, powerful Soviet squad moved into the lead ahead of China and East Germany today in the women's team competition at the World Gymnastic Championships.

title: TEXSCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
WILEY, JOHN, & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: 1980 net income and shr earnings restated for non-material accounting change

title: BIG 10 IS STRIVING FOR BALANCE
description: The Big Ten Conference will become a balanced football league once again, if it is not already, according to Elroy (Crazy Legs) Hirsch, the director of athletics at Wisconsin for the last 13 years.

title: Judge Orders Sale Of House to State
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that 18 Long Island residents must sell to the state a house they bought to prevent it from being established as a community residence for the retarded.

title: Jets' Defense Beset by Mounting Injuries
description: Along with the kind of acclaim that few of the current Jets have known in their pro careers, there is the ever-present reality of pro football injuries to put a damper on the good times. And the injuries have hit most heavily at the unit least able to afford them, the defense.

title: PACERS TROUNCE KNICKS
description: The Knicks fell short with two second-half rallies tonight and suffered their fifth defeat in the last six games, a 127-112 setback to the Indiana Pacers at Market Square Arena.

title: Man on the Move
description: Peter Bavasi, who made the Toronto Blue Jays a financial success despite their ineptitude on the field, resigned as president yesterday with the explanation that he was looking for new challenges. ''The thrill of building the Blue Jays from scratch is gone,'' he said of the job, which he had held since the team's inception in 1976.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1981
description: International Deep Soviet distrust of Washington was reported by Chancellor Helmut Schmidt. The West German leader said that Leonid I. Brezhnev had convinced him of Soviet interest in arms reduction, but that the Soviet leader was unable to acknowledge that the Reagan Administration wants peace. (Page A1, Column 1.) Hopes about the arms talks in Geneva next week were expressed by the Reagan Administration. It said it hoped that Leonid I. Brezhnev's professed willingness to consider reductions in medium-range nuclear forces in Europe was a sign that Moscow was ''beginning to see the advantages'' of seeking genuine arms cuts. (A1:2.)

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: It is a fact of life that no matter the degree of one's popularity, there are occasions when he eats alone. The solitary eating can be done watching television in a hotel bedroom, standing in front of the refrigerator in the kitchen, curled up in front of a fireplace or sitting at a perfectly appointed little table, with candlelight and a glass or two of wine. The latter procedure is widely suggested in articles on gracious living but is practically guaranteed to depress any normal person.

title: More Power to the N.R.C.
description: Fool me once, the old saying goes, shame on you. Fool me twice, shame on me. Obviously feeling misled about the quality of the workmanship at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant north of Los Angeles, an embarrassed Nuclear Regulatory Commission has suspended the license it only recently granted the Pacific Gas & Electric Company to load fissionable fuel into the reactor and begin low-power tests.

title: EUROPEANS TO LAUNCH GE UNIT SATELLITE
description: In the emerging competition between European and American satellite launching services, a private European company, Arianespace, won a major marketing victory yesterday by signing its first contract to launch a communications satellite for an American customer.

title: COAST NURSE IS ACCUSED IN 12 KILLINGS
description: Robert R. Diaz, a 44-year-old nurse who the authorities say was working on the night shift at three hospitals when elderly patients died mysteriously earlier this year, was arrested last night on 12 counts of murder.

title: Two Die After Plea Fails To Halt Showing of Film
description: Officials say that two male viewers shot themselves to death after a television station showed the film ''The Deer Hunter'' despite a psychiatrist's warning that its Russian roulette scenes might inspire real-life imitators.

title: WINE TALK
description: BEAUJOLAIS NOUVEAU, the first wine of the new vintage in France, is flooding the American market as never before, partly because its quality is high this year and partly because its arrival has become an eagerly awaited annual event, heavily promoted by importers and dealers.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THERE are times when it is virtually impossible to explain why a dish belongs to one nationality or another, particularly in the Western world. Switzerland is divided into three sections so far as language is concerned: French, German and Italian, and the cooking of the different areas has obvious borrowings from France, Germany and Italy.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: PROFESSIONAL pitchers warm up before stepping out to the mound, and on-deck batters can be seen swinging weighted bats. Hockey players skate up and down the rink passing and shooting the puck, and college football players may do a dozen different calisthenics.

title: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1981; The Economy
description: The Consumer Price Index rose just 0.4 percent in October, the smallest increase in six months, the Government reported. That would produce an annual inflation rate of 4.8 percent. A key factor was a drop of 0.7 percent in home sale prices. (Page A1.) New York area consumer prices fell 0.2 percent. (A1.)

title: Mutual Funds Up 33%
description: Sales of mutual funds other than shortterm securities rose 33 percent in October to $866.5 million from $650.6 million in September, the Investment Company Institute reported today. October's figures compared with sales of $980.8 million in October 1980, it said.

title: A New Set of Billings For Shaw & Koulermos
description: Shaw & Koulermos, which has been around for two years and seven months and is billing about $6.5 million, has announced a bundle of billings led by its first packaged goods assignment.

title: GETTING THE JOB DONE RIGHT
description: I have interviewed more than 14,000 recently graduated college students for jobs in my organization and in nuclear ships. In recent years, a surprising number of applicants, even graduates of engineering schools and the Naval Academy, have become enamored with the study of ''management'' - some even majoring in this subject.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Rates Register Broad Drop
description: Volatility is still a byword in the credit markets, and yesterday both short- and long-term rates dropped sharply to more than offset the steep increases of the previous day's trading.

title: Topics; Protecting the Neighborhood; Park Avenue
description: It takes more than a degree in library science to know whether the New York Public Library really needs to invest a half-million dollars in a co-op apartment for its well-salaried president. Officials explain that he spends many evenings raising money and can do this most successfully in his own living room; a big one, preferably, with a splendid view.

title: Series on Stress to Begin on Cable
description: A series of television programs on stress is being developed by the Teleprompter Corporation and Columbia University's Teachers College for the Teleprompter Cable network.

title: PUBLIC LIBRARY PUTS OFF PLAN FOR BUYING CO-OP
description: The New York Public Library has for the time being decided not to purchase a cooperative apartment in Manhattan for its president. Andrew Heiskell, the chairman of its board of trustees, said in a letter to The New York Times yesterday that the library had decided that ''in view of market conditions, high interest rates and protracted negotiations, as well as certain practices and attitudes of co-ops vis-a-vis nonprofit organizations, a co-op purchase at this time was inimical to the interests of the New York Public Library.''

title: F.B.I. AGENT SEIZED ON COCAINE-SALE CHARGES
description: An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was arrested yesterday at his office at 26 Federal Plaza on charges of having sold cocaine to an undercover New York City police officer.

title: EIP MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHRYSLER TANK SCRUTINIZED
description: Throughout its financial problems of the last two years, the Chrysler Corporation has been able to rely on its highly profitable defense subsidiary - the sole supplier of the new M-1 battle tank to the Army.

title: Air Service to Brazil
description: President Reagan has approved an order by the Civil Aeronautics Board awarding Eastern, American and Capitol Airlines routes between the United States and Brazil, the board said today.

title: THE EUROPEAN PROTESTS
description: If there is one conclusion that should be drawn from the ongoing series of peace demonstrations in Europe, it is that they do not express a new wave of anti-Americanism. Even the sweeping explanation of ''pacifism and neutralism'' seems too easy.

title: Surgery for Rocket
description: Craig Allen, a forward with the New Jersey Rockets of the Major Indoor Soccer League, will undergo exploratory surgery in his right knee today and is expected to be out for about three months. Fred Bachman, a spokesman for the Rockets, said Allen injured his knee Monday in a scrimmage against the Blast in Baltimore. He said the Rockets would replace Allen on the roster as early as today by signing Billy Bolevic, the most valuable player in the American Soccer League last summer, when he played for the New York Eagles.

title: No Headline
description: Columnist Subpoena Ended

title: ALBERT SHANKER'S TONIC FOR A RACIST SOCIETY
description: To the Editor:

title: Hijacker Draws Second Sentence
description: A man who was sentenced Monday to seven years in prison and fined $7,500 fine for involvement in a hijacking ring was sentenced again for a plot to manufacture synthetic cocaine.

title: MUSIC: NEW AMSTERDAM'S 'NEW MOON'
description: THOUGH the music of Sigmund Romberg has been out of fashion for 20 years, it is unlikely that the Hungarian-American composer's best scores will ever be totally forgotten, because of their sheer wealth of melody.

title: NETS ROUT ROCKETS, SNAP 3-GAME SLIDE
description: The Nets, displaying new-found confidence tonight, shot better than they had all season and played tenaciously on defense to snap a three-game losing streak.

title: FLAWED ALTERNATIVE TO INSTITUTIONS FOR THE ELDERLY
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPANESE WRITER SAYS ALLEN KNEW HE WAS GETTING MONEY
description: A Japanese journalist says that Richard V. Allen was told that he was receiving money when he was handed an envelope at the White House after an interview with Nancy Reagan last Jan. 21.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report on Friday gave an incorrect title for James A. Krauskopf. He is the Administrator of the city's Human Resources Administration.

title: Pakistan Expels Indians on Spy Charges
description: Pakistan today ordered the expulsion of four members of India's consulate staff on espionage charges.

title: MRS. ROOSEVELT LOVED DOCTOR, ARTICLE SAYS
description: Eleanor Roosevelt harbored a platonic love for her personal physician, Dr. A. David Gurewitsch, in the years before her death, according to an article by his widow published in American Heritage magazine yesterday.

title: 6 ACCUSED OF PLOTTING TO KILL 3 LINKED TO BONANNO GANG
description: Six reputed members of the Bonanno organized-crime group were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges of conspiring to murder three other members.

title: U.S. Buys Bauxite
description: On orders from President Reagan, the Government today began buying 1.6 million tons of Jamaican bauxite for use in making aluminum, a key defense material.

title: ISABEL O'NEIL,73, AN AUTHORITY ON DECORATIVE PAINTING, DEAD
description: Isabel MacDonald O'Neil, the founder of the Studio/Workshop for the Art of the Painted Finish, died last Thursday after a long illness. She was 73 years old.

title: Real Estate; SoHo Loft For Use as Galleries
description: EDUARD NAKHAMKIN came from Russia with more love than money six years ago. An important object of his love was contemporary Russian painting, a taste he cultivated during a five-month stopover in Rome. Rome is a center of expatriate artists from the Soviet Union.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Agency Rent-A-Car Inc. said it had increased its stake in the Spencer Companies to 728,255 shares, or 38.4 percent. Agency bought 27,300 shares on the American Stock Exchange at prices ranging from $13.50 a share to $16.50.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because a corrected version was inadvertently omitted, an Athens, Ala., dispatch by United Press Inter- national printed yesterday incorrectly cited the reason for a canned-food re- call in eight Middle Western and Southern states. In the later dispatch, U.P.I. said the food, Chef Boy-Ar-Dee Rollercoasters Wavy Macaroni with Meatballs, was recalled because metal shavings were found in some cans.

title: Rubbing It In
description: It doesn't happen often in public in the National Football League, but the New Orleans Saints' owner and the Houston Oilers' general manager are exchanging unpleasantries. After the Saints beat the Oilers Sunday, 27-24, John Mecom, the owner, rubbed it in, saying that since the Oilers dismissed Bum Phillips, whom Mecom later hired, Houston had lacked leadership.

title: Education Board Has A $3 Million Surplus
description: The Board of Education said yesterday that it had ended the last fiscal year with a $3 million surplus from city-supported operations.

title: Other Economic Trends Prime Rate
description: Chase dropped to 15 3/4 percent, the lowest in a year, as other banks went to 16 percent.

title: HAIG WINDS UP 'CORDIAL' TALKS WITH MEXICANS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. ended a 24-hour visit here today with the United States and Mexico still in disagreement over policy toward Cuba, Nicaragua and El Salvador.

title: PRICE NEWS, 15 3/4% PRIME SEND STOCKS UP BY 18.45
description: The Dow Jones industrial average surged 18.45 points yesterday, to 870.24, against a backdrop of falling interest rates and rising hopes for improvement on the inflation front next year.

title: CHASE CUTS PRIME RATE TO 15 3/4%
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, the nation's third largest, reduced its prime lending rate yesterday to 15 3/4 percent from 16 percent - the lowest level in more than a year - while a number of other major banks trimmed theirs to 16 percent from 16 1/2 percent as the economic downturn continued to dry up loan demand.

title: Karpov Honored
description: It is not every Soviet citizen who gets the Order of Lenin, but then it is not every Soviet citizen who successfully defends the world chess championship.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aileen Inc. has appointed Robert Siegelin vice president of sales and Judy Smith president of the Redi division for juniors.

title: MOOG INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes pretax foreign currency gain of $1,660,000... C-After pretax foreign currency loss of $143,000

title: Van Patten Joins Pullout
description: Pam Casale, Kathy Horvath and Kathy Rinaldi, American teen-age stars, won today in the first round of the $300,000 South African Open tennis championships.

title: Newspapers in Soviet Publish Glowing Accounts of the Trip
description: The Soviet press today published glowing accounts of Leonid I. Brezhnev's meetings in Bonn, glossing over differences that arose and censoring references to Soviet missiles, Afghanistan and other tricky subjects from published versions of a dinner speech by Chancellor Helmut Schmidt.

title: HOW AUTO DEALERS ARE COPING
description: Jerry Bielfield has been selling Ford cars and trucks on the blue-collar west side of this city for 32 years. Lately he has been selling a lot fewer than he did just a few years ago.

title: RESEARCH-COTTRELL HEAD
description: Research-Cottrell Inc., an environmental equipment and energy company with headquarters in Somerville, N.J., has appointed Peter J. Gianacakes, 58, to the vacant post of president and chief operating officer. John E. Schork, the 57-year-old chairman and chief executive officer, will continue in those positions until his retirement in December 1982, when Mr. Gianacakes will become chief executive officer. The chairmanship may then remain unfilled.

title: Marathon Unit In Loan Pact
description: The Marathon Oil Company said that its wholly owned British subsidiary had completed a $650 million loan agreement with 20 international banks to finance part of the development of a North Sea oilfield.

title: OF ALIENS' CHILDREN, EDUCATION AND HYPOCRISY
description: To the Editor:

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard IN THE GARDEN OF THE NORTH AMERICAN MARTYRS. By Tobias Wolff. 175 pages. The Ecco Press. $10.95.

title: THANKSGIVING PILGRAMS FIND FEW TRAVEL WOES
description: With some exceptions, airline passengers ran into only scattered problems yesterday as they began heading home for Thanksgiving, the biggest travel weekend since the air-traffic controllers struck last summer.

title: ACCORD ON RIGHTS FOR CANADA
