description: Canada's Minister of Justice has announced that the proposed new constitution will include recognition of equal rights for women and still-to-be-defined rights for the nation's Indian and Eskimo populations.

title: Georgia-Pacific Purchase Approval
description: The Federal Trade Commission said that it had approved the Georgia-Pacific Corporation's proposed acquisition of eight corrugated container plants in several states from the Johns-Manville Corporation.

title: HANDY & HARMAN SHUNS LIQUIDATION
description: Handy & Harman, a leading producer of silver and gold products, said yesterday that it had decided against liquidating. The company, which disclosed in May that it was considering liquidation for tax reasons, said yesterday that it now thought that the interests of the company's shareholders, customers and employees ''are best served by the continuation of the business of the company as it has been run for the last 114 years.''

title: The Right Stick for Nicaragua
description: Nicaragua's two-year-old revolution is going very wrong. By jailing political opponents and silencing press criticism, the Sandinist leaders make nonsense of their democratic promises. Their economy is chaotic and the people's needs are enormous. Yet the junta sinks millions into provocative hardware, including Soviet tanks.

title: No Headline
description: Flyers Defeat Leafs, 6-3

title: Businesses Facing Strike by Carters
description: Hotels, hospitals, restaurants and other commercial establishments in the city face a possible sanitation strike next week after the breakdown of contract negotiations with the private carters union, a union official said.

title: AGREEMENT ON USE OF NONUNION SHOPS ENDS STRIKE BY FURRIERS IN MANHATTAN
description: Bullhorn announcements instructed union members to go to work at once, and picket-line barricades disappeared as an agreement ended a furriers' strike yesterday after 20 consecutive hours of negotiations.

title: AUTO SALES BY BIG 3 FALL 29.8%
description: Automobile sales by the nation's Big Three manufacturers continued their autumn slump during the second 10 days of November, dropping 29.8 percent below the period a year earlier.

title: Pakistani Leader Welcomes Passing of Deadline on Jets
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq today welcomed the passing of a deadline for the United States Congress to act to block the sale of 40 F-16 jets to Pakistan.

title: Market Place; Westinghouse: Analysts Differ
description: ANALYSTS are divided over whether Westinghouse will share in the bright outlook for electrical equipment companies generally or will remain in the shadows of an industry dominated by General Electric.

title: Ashland Talks
description: The Ashland Oil Company said it was negotiating to acquire the Tresler Oil Company, a privately held fuel distributor based here. Ashland, with yearly sales of $7 billion, is a wholesale supplier for Tresler, which markets gasoline, heating oil and other petroleum products and owns a chain of service stations. The purchase could improve Ashland's gasoline sales by insuring that Ashland would be Tresler's only supplier.

title: MCMAHON: COLLEGE GAME'S MAGIC ARM
description: Jim McMahon, hardly noticed, stood on the fringe of the crowd surrounding Marcus Allen. Though both were chosen by the American Football Coaches Association as all-America backs, McMahon seemed a little less equal at a midtown reception yesterday.

title: PERIODICALS FROM CUBA HELD IN BOSTON ARE THE SUBJECT OF A SUIT
description: On the wind-blown gray expanse of an asphalt parking lot here, two Postal Service tractor trailers are parked and locked. Filled with unread mail, they stand in mute testimony to what has evolved as the Reagan Administration's blockade of Cuban periodicals.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Quite often you print recipes that call for pine nuts, but I have no clue as to their origin. Can you please explain to me what they are?

title: A NEW CATHOLIC DIOCESE FORMED IN CENTRAL JERSEY
description: In response to population shifts, a new Roman Catholic diocese - the first in the Northeast in more than 20 years -has been created by dividing the Trenton Diocese in half.

title: Notes on People; New Dean at Stanford
description: Following a nationwide search, John Hart Ely, a constitutional law scholar from Harvard, has been named dean of the Stanford University Law School. He replaces Charles J. Meyers, who resigned last summer to go into private practice.

title: LONDON MELEE NOT RACE RIOT, STUDY SAYS
description: A long-awaited report to the Government declared today that the disorders last April in the Brixton section of south London had a strong racial element but were not race riots.

title: CONTINENTAL PACT WITH TEXAS AIR
description: Continental Airlines and its majority shareholder, the Texas Air Corporation, agreed today to drop all legal actions pending in Texas Air's takeover attempt and to ''normalize'' relations between the companies.

title: WAS A LITTON INDUSTRIES FOUNDER
description: Charles B. Thornton, the leader of the so-called ''Whiz Kids'' who devised modern management systems and one of the founders of Litton Industries, the sprawling conglomerate, died Tuesday of cancer at his home in the Los Angeles suburb of Holmby Hills. He was 68 years old.

title: Phil Woolpert Still Shapes the Lives of the Young
description: It was 2:38 one recent Monday afternoon when Jason, who is six years old, proudly jumped aboard the yellow bus outside his schoolyard, eager to boast of his achievements of the day.

title: China Oil Center
description: China has established a center for exploration and development of oil in the South China Sea at the port of Zhanjiang, about 260 miles southwest of Hong Kong, the official New China News Agency reported today. Seismic surveys have been completed and China has begun drilling exploratory wells in the area, the agency said. The China National Petroleum Corporation has set up a joint petroleum corporation with the Total Oil Corporation of France to explore and develop oil in the Gulf of Tonkin, it added.

title: Bridge: Blue Ribbon Event Paced By '80 World Champions
description: Two women led the field of 168 pairs into the semifinal stage of the Blue Ribbon Pair Championship of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals at the Sheraton Palace Hotel today. Mary Jane Farell of Los Angeles and Marilyn Johnson of Houston, who have won three world titles in partnership, headed a powerful field at the conclusion of qualifying play.

title: 'FAILURE' OF PAPER ARGUED IN SEATTLE
description: The Seattle Post-Intelligencer has been described in court testimony here over the last three weeks as the victim of relentless economic forces beyond the control of management and, conversely, as the victim of inept management.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I couldn't let that punk get away with it and what counts is that he didn't.

title: No Headline
description: EXCERPTS FROM COMMUNIQUE ON SCHMIDT-BREZHNEV MEETING

title: Jazz Orchestra to Play Saturday on Long Island
description: The Widespread Jazz Orchestra will perform Saturday night at the John Drew Theater of Guild Hall, East Hampton, L.I. The concert is part of the annual Thanksgiving jazz presentation in the Music for Everybody series at Guild Hall.

title: CRANBERRIES FROM A POLITICAL BOG
description: In the tradition of Thanksgiving, President Reagan, proclaiming the holiday, exhorted us to count our national blessings and to extend a helping hand to the "less fortunate." He put it this way: "Long before there was a government welfare program, this spirit of voluntary giving was ingrained in the American character." At a time when national policy is committed to increasing the gap between rich and poor, his pronouncement rings hollow.

title: NOVEMBER CHRISTMAS TREES
description: It's still November, but Pat Septon is already running short on Christmas spirit. For weeks now, he and hundreds of other eastern Canadians have been spending 12- and 14-hour days chopping down Christmas trees to decorate the living rooms, dens and basements of millions of American homes in the coming weeks.

title: KOCH, IN A SHIFT, TO SELECT AIDES OF TOP OFFICIALS
description: Mayor Koch has abandoned the policy of letting New York City agency heads pick their own deputies and has ordered that all such appointments be made by City Hall.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: CAREY GIVES CLEMENCY TO 11 JAILED ON DRUGS
description: ALBANY Nov. 25 (AP) - In a Thanksgiving-season gesture, Governor Carey announced today that he had granted clemency to 11 men sentenced to lengthy prison terms under tough drug laws promulgated when Nelson A. Rockefeller was Governor.

title: BRITISH DRUG MAKER HOPES IT HAS FOUND ITS OWN TAGAMET
description: Glaxo Holdings Ltd. entered the business world with the slogan ''Glaxo builds bonnie babies,'' a reference to the company's dried milk infant formula. Now, 70 years later, the company hopes to build a bigger, more mature image by tackling the problems of adulthood.

title: No Headline
description: GRETZKY SCORES 4 IN OILER ROUT

title: WORKERS WAIT NUMBLY FOR PROBABLE OBLIVION
description: As various arms of Government started closing up shop Monday for temporary lack of funds, there was one place with no perceptible change of pace or mood: the Department of Energy.

title: Hinckley to Be Treated At a Military Prison
description: A Federal district judge said today that he would allow John W. Hinckley Jr., the assailant of President Reagan, to receive psychiatric counseling at the military jail where he tried to hang himself last week.

title: HALF OF BLACK HOUSEHOLDS USED SCHOOL LUNCH PROGRAM IN 1980
description: About half the black households around the country with children of school age got free or reduced-price school lunches last year, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Eldredge Will Head Smithsonian Museum
description: Dr. Charles C. Eldredge, director of the Spencer Museum of Art at the University of Kansas, in Lawrence, has been chosen director of the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American Art, it was announced today.

title: CITY BALLET: 'TCHAIKOVSKY SUITE NO. 2' IS BACK
description: JACQUES D'AMBOISE'S ''Tchaikovsky Suite No. 2,'' which re-entered New York City Ballet's seasonal repertory on Tuesday at the New York State Theater, is faithful to the letter of the score that gives the ballet its name.

title: Boy Accused of Failing To Report a Murder
description: A 16-year-old boy was arrested as an accessory after the fact because he saw the body of a strangled girl and did not report it, the police said.

title: UKRAINIAN BOY'S FREEDOM QUEST FACES LONG FIGHT
description: When a 12-year-old boy runs away from home, it usually is not a Federal case. Yet, almost from the moment in July 1980 when Walter Polovchak left his home in Chicago with his 17-year-old sister, Natalie, to live with a cousin rather than return with his parents to the Ukraine, the Federal Government has been involved in his life.

title: Philip Morris Stock Swap
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company and Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. yesterday announced a public offering of 339,316 shares of Philip Morris Inc. This stock was obtained in exchange for $25.9 million face amount of the cigarette company's 6 5/8 percent sinking fund debentures, due 1993, and owned by Goldman, Sachs and Lehman Brothers.

title: Truck Exhaust Regulations Strengthened by Senate Unit
description: The Senate Environment and Public Works Committee, drafting revisions to the Clean Air Act, voted Tuesday to strengthen rules requiring the reduction of exhaust emissions by heavy-@ and light-duty trucks.

title: Flights to Russia Sought by GenAir
description: GenAir International, a new airline being formed in New York City, asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for permission to begin the first scheduled service to Russia since Pan American World Airways dropped the route more than three years ago.

title: Dow Advances 7.90; Volume Is Heavy
description: Stock prices forged higher in heavy pre-Thanksgiving Day trading yesterday as investors continued to respond to declining interest rates.

title: THE HARRIED TRAVELER HERALDS THANKSGIVING
description: At 3:10 P.M. yesterday, Grand Central's Track 23 gate opened, 142 waiting men, women and children hurtled through and onto the 3:45 Amtrak train for Buffalo and way points.

title: U.S. PRODUCTIVITY DOWN IN 3D QUARTER
description: American corporate productivity declined at an annual rate of six-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter, the first decline since spring 1980, the Labor Department said today.

title: The Region; Jersey to Certify Kean the Winner
description: With the recount of the 2.3 million votes cast in the election for New Jersey Governor on Nov, 3 virtually over, a special three-judge panel has ruled that the State Board of Canvassers may meet as scheduled Tuesday to certify the winner, using the figures in the original vote count.

title: Sports People; Williams Wins Appeal
description: Paul Williams, the Arizona State swing man, regained his basketball eligibility yesterday in a reversal of an N.C.A.A. ruling of five days earlier. Williams had been ruled ineligible for the season because he had participated in a non-sanctioned church summer recreational league in Phoenix. Arizona State appealed the ruling, saying that the twice-a-week cherch program was not a league.

title: The New York Times/Jack Manning
description: Let there be light, said the skyscraper owners, and there was light, and it was good.

title: A Special Sister
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: In regard to your article (''Down's Syndrome and Sibling Love,'' Nov. 19), I am 21 years old and one of eight children.

title: Notes on People; College Head Appointed
description: The board of trustees of the State University of New York has unanimously approved the appointment of an interim president for Nassau County Community College, to assume the duties of its embattled president, Dr. Robert R. Gwydir.

title: BONN AND MOSCOW SET OWN CONTACTS ON ARMS CONTROL
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt today ended three days of talks during which they agreed to set up separate Soviet-West German contacts on arms control parallel to the Soviet-American talks starting Monday in Geneva.

title: JACK ALBERTSON, VERSATILE STAR OF STAGE, FILM AND TV SERIES
description: Jack Albertson, the comedian and veteran star of such hit plays as ''The Subject Was Roses'' and ''The Sunshine Boys'' and more recently the crotchety garage owner in the television series ''Chico and the Man,'' died of cancer yesterday at his home in Hollywood Hills, Calif. He was 74 years old.

title: THANKSGIVING DAY
description: Parade - Begins 9 A.M., Central Park West and 77th Street; moves south to Columbus Circle, then on Broadway to 34th Street; ends at noon.

title: INSURANCE INDUSTRY SUES U.S. TO OVERTURN AIR BAGS RULING
description: The property and casualty insurance industry filed a suit today in the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, seeking to overturn a decision by the Reagan Administration to drop requirements for air bags or automatic seat belts in automobiles.

title: IRAQI OFFERS TO HELP IRANIANS BRING DOWN KHOMEINI RULE
description: Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, has offered to begin ''unconditional cooperation'' with any Iranian opposition group in an attempt to bring down the Islamic regime of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: INTENSE RACE IS ON TO ATTRACT WORKERS' RETIREMENT SAVINGS
description: Soon virtually everyone who works will be eligible to invest in Individual Retirement Accounts, and soon these accounts will be free of interest-rate ceilings. This has touched off what could be one of the biggest battles for personal savings in memory.

title: 2 YOUTHS CHARGED WITH FIRING AT SOVIET GLEN COVE MANSION
description: Two Long Island teen-agers were arrested yesterday and charged with having fired 12 shots Nov. 14 at the Glen Cove, L.I., residence used occasionally by the Soviet chief delegate to the United Nations.

title: Bonanno Son Denies Charge
description: Salvatore (Bill) Bonanno pleaded not guilty in Superior Court today to charges of grand theft and of conspiracy to defraud related to a home remodeling enterprise. Mr. Bonanno, 48, of Campbell, Calif., the son of the reported crime figure, Joseph Bonanno Sr., was arrested Monday. Investigators said that the junior Mr. Bonanno used Los Gatos, Calif., remodeling companies to cheat elderly customers of $750,000.

title: MEXICANS WILL DISCUSS 'CONCERNS' WITH NICARAGUA
description: The State Department said today that Mexico intended to raise with the Nicaraguan Government the concerns it shared with the United States over Nicaraguan political developments.

title: Money Funds Up $3.57 Billion
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds climbed $3.57 billion for the week ended Tuesday, to $179.99 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. It was the 26th consecutive weekly increase.

title: ARAB MEETING ENDS IN SUDDEN BREAKUP OVER SAUDIS' PLAN
description: The Arab League meeting here broke up in disarray a few hours after it opened today amid Syrian opposition to the Saudi Arabian plan for peace in the Middle East. The meeting opened with the ritual calls for Arab unity, but the most important topic of discussion in this ancient foothill city was the absence of President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, who unexpectedly joined the other major hard-line Arab leaders, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya and President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, in not attending the meeting.

title: Sports People; Flames Keep Dealing
description: The Calgary Flames are rallying in the standings after a disappointing start, but they continue to clean house.

title: ON HOLIDAY BACK AT THE REAGANS' RANCH
description: When dawn breaks in the mountains here, the embers are barely smouldering in the two fireplaces in Ronald Reagan's five-room, 100-year-old adobe ranch house.

title: CONNORS PULLS OUT OF CUP
description: The absence of Jimmy Connors overshadowed the selection of John McEnroe and Roscoe Tanner yesterday as the United States players who will face Guillermo Vilas and Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina in singles in the Davis Cup final beginning Dec. 11 in Cincinnati.

title: The Region; Payments Listed At Margiotta Trial
description: Testimony at Joseph M. Margiotta's retrial focused on prosecution charts showing that a Nassau County insurance agency had received more than $2 million in municipal insurance commissions from 1969 to 1980.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption Wednesday incor- rectly identified a vehicle taking par- tin American-Egyptian military exer- cises. It was a Soviet-made armored personnel carrier.

title: POLITICS AND COMPETITION WORRY TOBACCO FORCES
description: They were not quite ready to draw the curing barns into a circle, but the tobacco growers among the 70,000 visitors to the recent Southern Flue-Cured Tobacco Festival and Tobacco Farmer Show here were clearly worried.

title: Welfare Ruling Stands
description: An appeals court has refused to halt a lower court order that blocked new Federal regulations cutting welfare payments to 41,790 families in Pennsylvania. The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit acted Monday. The lower court had issued a permanent injunction against regulations governing Aid to Families with Dependent Children imposed by the Reagan Administration

title: BUSINESS PANEL AIMS TO SPUR HARLEM
description: As president of a successful Harlem real-estate management concern and a member of a melange of boards and committees, George M. Brooker often found himself in discussions with whites about economic issues that affected the city's black communities. But the talks seemed a bit off-key to him. To better affect the area's destiny, he felt, group meetings were needed among major black entrepreneurs in Harlem.

title: U.S. Deficit In October
description: The Government's finances showed an $18.1 billion deficit in October, the first month of the 1982 fiscal year, the Government said today.

title: MUBARAK FREES 31 JAILED BY SADAT, MEETS WITH THEM AT CAIRO PALACE
description: President Hosni Mubarak today unconditionally released 31 political figures and journalists jailed in September and met with them at the suburban palace where he keeps an office.

title: LAWYER WAS HEAD OF MT. SINAI BOARD
description: Alfred L. Rose, a lawyer and a former president of the Mount Sinai Hospital and Medical Center, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 95 years old.

title: F.B.I. SHARES ITS TURF WITH WHITE HOUSE FELLOW
description: With the kind of aplomb that reflected familiarity with the topsecret territory, Merrie Spaeth walked through the empty conference room of the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and strode into the Director's office.

title: Bank Merger Suit Filed
description: A major stockholder of the Hartford National Corporation filed suit today in Federal District Court to block the merger of the corporation's subsidiary, the Hartford National Bank, with the Connecticut National Bank, a combination that would form the largest bank in the state.

title: Harvester Seeking Labor Concessions
description: The International Harvester Company, the big maker of farm equipment and trucks that has been wrestling with a major financial crisis, today asked the United Automobile Workers union to help trim employment costs by $100 million by next October.

title: Soviet Gymnasts Win
description: Soviet men, scoring two marks of 10 on the horizontal bars, retained their team title today at the world gymnastics championships, edging Japan by more than 3 points.

title: Charges of Harboring A Spy Are Dropped
description: The Federal authorities today dropped their charge that Gloria Ann White hid a convicted spy, Christopher Boyce, at her summer home. Mrs. White's lawyer accused the United States Attorney's office of ''malicious prosecution'' in the case.

title: Riot Breaks Out at Rally Of Students in San Juan
description: Dozens of students and six policemen were injured in a riot that occurred when police broke up a meeting of University of Puerto Rico students today.

title: RANGERS, LEAFS PLAY TO A 3-3 TIE
description: The Rangers tied the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3-3, at Madison Square Garden last night in a game neither team seemed to be trying to win most of the time.

title: DEFENDANT DESCRIBES SHOOTING OF LIBYAN
description: Eugene Tafoya testified today that he went to the apartment of a dissident Libyan student last year believing that he was delivering a message from the Central Intelligence Agency and shot the Libyan in self-defense.

title: HUMAN DEPRESSION IS LINKED TO GENES
description: Genes associated with a specific chromosome appear implicated in the development of mental depression, according to new research that analyzed blood samples from victims of depression and members of their families.

title: F.D.A. CLEARS DRUG FOR HEART ATTACK VICTIMS
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved a drug for heart attack victims that, in a Norwegian study published earlier this year, sharply reduced the death rate among patients who had already survived a heart attack.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bass Brothers Enterprises Inc. said it had acquired 6.4 percent of Western Airlines Inc. cumulative convertible preferred stock.

title: IC Shares Offer
description: The Union Pacific Corporation will not tender any of its 2.15 million shares of IC Industries in response to IC's offer to buy back its shares, a Union Pacific spokesman said yesterday in New York. IC, which has 17.1 million shares outstanding, is offering $36 a share for three million of its shares.

title: Women Artists to Open Exhibition on Dec. 8
description: The National Association of Women Artists and the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs will present an exhibition of paintings, graphics and sculpture at the City Gallery, 2 Columbus Circle, from Dec. 8 to Dec. 22.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Svensk Exportkredit, a Swedish export group, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed public offering of $100 million of 10-year notes.

title: MIDEAST: WHAT U.N. RESOLUTION 242 SAYS - AND DOESN'T SAY
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: President Reagan authorized the donation of $30 million worth of food staples to Poland today to help ease shortages. The grant brings total food aid over the last year to $820 million.

title: Sports of the Times; GERRY FAUST'S JOY AND PAIN
description: IN his first season as the Notre Dame coach, Gerry Faust woke up the echoes. The bad echoes. If the Irish lose to Miami tomorrow in a nationally televised game, it will be the first time since l963 that Notre Dame's football team has had a losing season. That year the Irish had a 2-7 record with Hugh Devore as coach. The next season Ara Parseghian was the coach.

title: Several Haitians Escape From Refugee Center
description: As many as 20 Haitians bolted from a detention center west of Miami tonight. The officials said that between 15 and 20 Haitians scaled three barbed wire fences about 6:30 P.M. and ran into an area of marsh and sawgrass surrounding the Krome North camp west of Miami.

title: JAZZ: KAI WINDING AND CURTIS FULLER
description: KAI WINDING, whose trombone duo with J.J. Johnson, ''Jay and Kai,'' broke up 25 years ago, has, after a quarter of a century, taken a new trombone-playing partner, Curtis Fuller. Their quintet, called ''Giant Bones,'' is making its first New York jazz-club appearance this week, through Sunday, at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street.

title: Net Off at Grand Union
description: The Grand Union Company, a major supermarket chain, said today that profits for the second quarter fell to $6.85 million from $7.47 million in the similar 1980 period.

title: Helpful Hardware; LOCKING CABINETS
description: WE were surprised to discover in a recent look around bathroom supply stores that a locking medicine cabinet is unusual, though particularly for families with young children, it is a must.

title: T. JAMES TUMULTY, EX-OFFICIAL
description: T. James Tumulty, a former United States Representative, State Assemblyman and judge from Jersey City who was known for his quick wit and polished oratory, died Monday at the Jewish Hospital and Rehabilitation Center in Jersey City after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 15.75-16.00. ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. + Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FIVE MEMBERS OF BOARD OF ESTIMATE SUE KOCH OVER WESTWAY
description: Five members of New York City's Board of Estimate charged yesterday that Mayor Koch had usurped their power in agreeing to build the Westway, and they went to State Supreme Court in Manhattan to try to prove it.

title: TIFTON, GA., TAKES ON BIG MANHATTAN
description: The Tift County High School band has been going through New York's tourist attractions like a jackknife through a pitted peach since its members stepped off the bus Sunday from Georgia.

title: Tremor Rocks Italian Towns
description: An earth tremor shook towns and villages today in the heart of the area devastated by an earthquake a year ago, the Vesuvius Observatory said.

title: Bonn Surplus First Since '79
description: West Germany today announced its first balance-of-payments surplus in more than two years, reflecting a surge in exports and a decline in imports, especially oil.

title: Auto, Truck Output Slows
description: United States auto makers planned to build 76,051 cars this week, down 32.5 percent from last week's 112,628 cars because of the Thanksgiving holiday, Automotive News, an industry journal, said today.

title: Libya Asks U.N. Inquiry Into Murder Charges
description: Libya has said that it would welcome an investigation by a United Nations committee into reports that it was plotting to kill President Reagan.

title: JUDGE DENIES PLEA TO BAR ACCESS TO ABSCAM TAPES
description: A Federal judge yesterday rejected a Justice Department attempt to halt for two months public access to Abscam tape recordings involving Long Island political figures.

title: Design Notebook
description: RESTORING THE ARTIFACTS OF A PERENNIAL FUTURE IN LOS ANGELES AREA By Joseph Giovannini Joseph Giovannini is an architectural critic living in Los Angeles.

title: Zaire Aluminum Study
description: An international consortium formed by the Zaire Government will make a feasibility study on building an aluminum mill with a maximum capacity of 600,000 tons a year, a spokesman for member of the consortium, Vereinigte Aluminium-Werke A.G., said here today. Cost of the project was put at $1 billion.

title: Notes on People; Jimmy Connors Sued
description: The owner of two apartments the tennis star Jimmy Connors rented last fall during the United States Open championships yesterday sued him for $5,000 in damages she said he did to her property.

title: 2 ALLEN AIDES SAY FIGURE WAS $1,000
description: The personal secretary and a longtime close associate of Richard V. Allen, the national security adviser, have told Federal investigators that there was only $1,000 in an envelope he received from a representative of a Japanese magazine that interviewed Nancy Reagan, according to people close to Mr. Allen.

title: F.A.O. Votes Record Budget Over Objections of 5 Nations
description: A record $366.6 million budget was overwhelmingly approved today by the Food and Agriculture Organization despite ''no'' votes by the United States and four other members who called it wasteful.

title: Gardening; GIFTS BY MAIL FOR GREEN THUMBS
description: MOST devoted gardeners are gadget prone. It doesn't matter if the ''garden'' consists only of a few pots on a windowsill, a tiny yard or terrace or an estate of many acres.

title: BEYOND THE TINSEL AND HOLLY
description: THEY are colorful and traditional and really rather nice. Who could say a word against holly and mistletoe and red felt stockings at Christmas? No one. No one is saying a word against them. There is also nothing wrong with tinsel and red velvet, but nowhere is it written that they are holiday musts. If truth be told, a goodly number of people are tired of the whole lot of them, maybe even bored, and would like to bridge the new and the old without changing the flavor and spirit of the season.

title: Home Beat; HOUSEWARES TO JEWELRY
description: IN Amsterdam, he has his own shop and is known as an avant-garde jewelry designer, but these days Hans Appenzeller is branching out into home accessories. ''My bracelets and vases all come from the same point of view,'' said Mr. Appenzeller, whose predilection is to explore the different uses of ordinary materials.

title: MOBIL INCREASES BID TO BUY MARATHON, TOPPING U.S. STEEL
description: With a temporary court victory over the United States Steel Corporation under its belt, the Mobil Corporation increased its bid yesterday for the Marathon Oil Company by $1.4 billion. But Mobil's new bid of $6.5 billion did not impress Wall Street, where Marathon stock fell $1.25, to $105.50, in heavy trading.

title: Prime at 15 1/2% At Small Bank
description: Southwest Bank of St. Louis, a small Missouri bank that frequently leads the industry in interest rate changes, cut its prime rate today to 15 1/2 percent.

title: GUITAR: YEPES'S CLASSICS, 19TH-CENTURY WORKS
description: NOW that Andres Segovia has attained the status of an icon, the two guitarists who probably claim the most extensive international audiences are Narciso Yepes and Julian Bream. They are very different: one Spanish and one English, for starters, but also in that Mr. Bream is equally well known as a lutist and Mr. Yepes is the sole prominent exponent of his own invention, the 10-string guitar. Mr. Yepes, who appeared for his annual Carnegie Hall recital Tuesday night, also plays the lute, but less frequently, in part because his 10-string guitar allows him to encompass lute music without transposition or alteration.

title: Technology; Computerized Filing Systems
description: COMPUTER systems can store vast amounts of data. But, as with records kept on paper, merely putting something into a file cabinet is not enough. There must be some way to retrieve the information again when it is needed.

title: ISRAELI OFFICIAL TO VISIT WASHINGTON OVER DISPUTE ON SINAI PEACE FORCE
description: The State Department said today that Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel had agreed to make a hurried trip to Washington in an effort to resolve Israeli-American differences over possible participation by four Western European nations in the Sinai peacekeeping force.

title: Sports People; Lasorda Re-signed
description: The customary one-year contract for returning Dodger managers was signed yesterday by Tom Lasorda, who led the 1981 team to the World Series title. Though the salary was not disclosed, Lasorda said it is ''alongside the highest-paid managers in baseball.''

title: The City; Robber Kills Boy Said to Be Lookout
description: A teen-age lookout in a robbery of a Lower East Side social club was accidentally killed by an accomplice when he walked in to report that ''all was clear'' outside, the police said.
To the Editor:

title: PITFALLS IN A BRIEF ON FEDERAL JUDICIAL RESTRAINT
description: To the Editor:

title: MOON AIDES SOUGHT AS WOMAN MISSES COURT DATE
description: Judge Ira Brown of Superior Court set in motion contempt proceedings against two leaders of the Unification Church today after they failed to bring to his courtroom a New Zealand woman whose relatives successfully petitioned last week for a writ of habeas corpus.

title: Wickes Posts Gain in Net
description: The Wickes Companies Inc. today reported gains for the third quarter in sales and profits, but the income advances came mainly from the sale of Wickes's common stock holdings in two companies, a spokesman said.

title: State Plans to Appeal School Funds Ruling
description: New York State will appeal the so-called Levittown decision, involving the financing of public school education, to its highest court, Attorney General Robert Abrams announced today.

title: MAYOR ASSESSES STATE GUN LAW AFTER FIRST YEAR
description: Seven of every 10 persons sentenced in New York City under the state's new gun law during its first year got at least a year in jail, the city's criminal-justice coordinator said yesterday.

title: Budd Co. Layoffs
description: The Budd Company said that 1,500 employees at its Red Lion plant in Philadelphia will be laid off from Dec. 4 through mid-January because of a shortage of brake system parts caused by a strike against a supplier. A Budd spokesman said that the workers will be called back in mid-January but no specific date has been set.

title: TELEVISION ADDS TWIST TO MORNING'S RITUAL
description: It is just after 10 o'clock on a Thursday morning in the somnolent chamber of the House of Representatives. The chaplain has prayed for all 14 lawmakers present, Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. has given his blessing to the previous day's journal and three messages from the Senate have been duly received.

title: LIBRARY MICROFILMING 6,000 BLITZ-DAMAGED BOOKS
description: ON the night of May 10, 1941, the Luftwaffe lit up the skies over London, dropping a cluster of incendiary bombs that struck the old Iron Library of the British Museum. The southwest quadrant of the institution on Great Russell Street in Bloomsbury was destroyed, with a loss of 250,000 volumes - including a large number of American titles.

title: The Region; Gas Supplier Gets New Cutoff Rights
description: NEWARK (AP) - The State Board of Public Utilities Commissioners has ruled that the Elizabethtown Gas Company may cut service to apartment buildings in which some of the tenants fail to pay their bills.

title: CHAMBER CONCERT: TASHI
description: TASHI played a lovely concert of chamber music at the Abraham Goodman House Monday night. Its members are Richard Stoltzman, clarinetist; Ida Kavafian, Theodore Arm and Ik-Hwan Bae, doubling as violinists and violists, and Fred Sherry, cellist; and their program began and ended with Mozart.

title: PATCO REQUESTS BANKRUPTCY AID
description: The Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization, facing $150 million in fines and stripped of its right to represent workers, applied today for reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: AN IRRITATED RAVITCH ASSAILS KOCH ON CUT IN CITY'S TRANSIT AID
description: Richard Ravitch, in a vigorous defense of his leadership of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, criticized Mayor Koch yesterday for reducing New York City's aid to mass transit.

title: LOAN RESTRUCTURING SOUGHT BY SAMBO'S
description: In an effort to stave off a bankruptcy filing, troubled Sambo's Restaurants announced yesterday that it had submitted a proposal to its lenders to restructure its main loan agreement.

title: Kennedy Reports His Mother Suffered 'Episode of Angina'
description: Rose Kennedy was reported in stable condition in a cornary care unit here today.

title: Concern Lifts Coffee Prices
description: Despite a worldwide glut of coffee supplies and a drop in demand among consuming nations, the Coca-Cola Company said today that its foods division had raised the wholesale prices of its three brands of coffee.

title: EAST BLOC QUEST FOR WESTERN TECHNOLOGY
description: Every day, large crowds gather outside the United States Embassy here to admire an exhibit on American space exploits. And senior Bulgarian officials, who willingly acknowledge their gratitude to the Soviet Union for helping to modernize their country's industry and agriculture, just as willingly express the strong desire for Western technology, particularly from the United States.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1981
description: International An Arab League meeting broke up in disarray a few hours after it opened in Fez, Morocco, amid Syrian opposition to Saudi Arabia's peace plan for the Middle East. The conference convened with the ritual calls for Arab unity, but the major topic of discussion was the absence of President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, who joined the hard-line leaders of Libya and Iraq in boycotting the meeting. (Page A1, Column 6.) In an act of clemency in Cairo, President Hosni Mubarak unconditionally released 31 political figures and journalists who were jailed two months ago and met with them in his office. Among those freed were five former Cabinet officials, including a prominent journalist. (A1:4-5.)

title: KOCH CONSIDERING NEW PAYROLL TAX
description: The Koch administration is thinking about seeking a new payroll tax or adding a surcharge to income taxes paid by New York City residents and suburban commuters to help close an impending budget deficit that state officials believe exceeds $1 billion.

title: Kaiser Aluminum Plans Layoffs
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Company said that increasing losses resulting from a drop in the worldwide demand for aluminum would force the layoffs of an unspecified but ''significant'' number of salaried employees at its Trentwood, Wash., rolling plant.

title: Books: War at Sea
description: A GLORIOUS WAY TO DIE. By Russell Spurr. 341 pages. Newmarket Press. $14.95.

title: Mead to Reduce Salaried Staff
description: The Mead Corporation, an international paper products company, said that it would reduce the salaried staff at its headquarters in Dayton because of bleak business forecasts for 1982.

title: British Steel Fears Curb
description: The British Steel Corporation could lose 10 percent of its business if the United States adopts measures it is considering to protect its steel industry against European imports, Ian MacGregor, the chairman of British Steel, said today.

title: KOCH HEDGES ON ALBANY RACE
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that his support in next year's gubernatorial race would go to the candidate - Republican or Democrat - who promised to do the most for New York City.

title: Lynching Richard Allen
description: When high White House aides conspire with Justice Department political appointees to subvert and discredit the findings of professional lawmen at Justice and the F.B.I., that's a scandal.

title: CONCERT: LEPPARD LEADS BRITTEN BILL
description: THERE are not many composers whose music can support an entire concert program without sagging somewhere along the way. Even among the unquestioned, time-tested masters, only a handful have enough variety of expression to keep the line of interest pulled taut. Raymond Leppard, who led the New York Philharmonic last night, obviously believes that Benjamin Britten is one of the mighty few. The British-born scholar and conductor, who lives in New York and is an American citizen, offered an all-Britten program that lived dangerously by steering clear for the most part of that composer's better-known works.

title: G.M. to Cut 1,800 Workers
description: In the face of a continuing sales slump, the General Motors Corporation said it will cut production at two assembly plants early in January, putting 1,800 more hourly workers on indefinite layoff.

title: Cartwright Injury Minor
description: Bill Cartwright, the Knicks' center, has a chip fracture in the ring finger of his right hand, but he is not expected to miss many games, if any.

title: What to Do With 'Acting Supremes'
description: In New York City, ''Acting Supremes'' are not pop vocalists. They are 97 judges, and they are currently in turmoil.

title: Norman Lear Seeks Avco Unit
description: Norman Lear Productions, which produces many of television's popular series, said that it and Perenchio, Inc., would purchase the assets of Avco Embassy, a movie production subsidiary of the Avco Corporation, for an undisclosed price.

title: Honda to Build Ohio Parts Plant
description: The Honda Motor Company said it would build a $3 million parts factory to employ 200 people next to its new $200 million auto assembly plant.

title: SMITHKLINE, BECKMAN PLAN MERGER
description: The SmithKline Corporation yesterday announced a preliminary agreement to acquire Beckman Instruments Inc. for stock worth more than $1 billion.

title: Fingers Adds 2d Award: M.V.P.
description: Rollie Fingers of the Milwaukee Brewers, who won the Cy Young Award as the best pitcher in the American League three weeks ago, was named the league's most valuable player yesterday. He became the first relief pitcher in the league to win the honor in its 51-year history.

title: Virgil Thomson Gala To Help N.Y.U. Center
description: A ''Grande Soiree de Gala'' in honor of Virgil Thomson on the occasion of his 85th birthday will be staged on Dec. 4.

title: Bolivian Tin Miners End Strike Under an Accord
description: A 13-day strike by workers at the Huanuni tin mine ended today, Government negotiators announced. The accord, which also ended sympathy strikers at six other tin centers, guaranteed job security to the miners who struck to demand the restoration of union rights suspended after the military took power last year.

title: STAGE: JENKIN'S 'DARK RIDE' INTO LIMBO
description: IN Len Jenkin's ''Dark Ride'' (at the SoHo Rep), the theatergoer is a tourist in an unknown city. At the center of the stage, a neon sign pinpoints our place: ''You Are Here.'' Where are we? One answer would be a labyrinth in limbo, a favorite habitat of the author. Mr. Jenkin, who is also his own director, leads us - and loses us - in an impossibly tangled journey to inner space. His principal metaphor is the ''dark ride'' of carnivals and amusement parks, the other, un-Disney side of the tunnel of love, the tunnel of fright - where at every turn travelers are surprised.

title: Poland's Sugar Output
description: Poland's sugar production this year will amount to 1.6 million tons, nearly restoring output to pre-1979 levels and matching the domestic market demand for sugar, the official press agency, P.A.P. said today.

title: Hers
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- The Hers column was designed as a forum for writing by women. For the next several weeks it will be written by K.C. Cole, who is a science writer and the author of the forthcoming book ''Between the Lines'' (Doubleday).

title: New Rules Demanded For Aging Conference
description: The head of a coalition of 24 groups for the aging said today that some advocates for the elderly might walk out of next week's White House Conference on Aging unless the Reagan Administration made changes in ground rules.

title: Going Out Guide
description: FOR THE TRADITION SCORNER

title: PAPER SOMOZA HATED NOW ENRAGES THE SANDINISTS
description: When the Sandinists' final offensive began in June 1979, one of the first actions of the National Guard was to turn its guns on La Prensa, the newspaper that had long symbolized opposition to the Somoza family dynasty.

title: A Shaker Source
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: GEORGE K.C. YEH, TAIWAN AIDE
description: George Kung-chao Yeh, former Foreign Minister of the Chinese Nationalist Government on the mainland and later in Taiwan, died of a heart attack last Friday in Taipei. He was 77 years old.

title: My Daughter, Architect
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: As an architect and a woman, I found it interesting to read Joan Kron's article (''My Son, the Architect,'' Nov. 12). What I want to know is, is that how Laurinda Spear's parents refer to her? SHIRA ROSEN The Bronx

title: FROM RECORDS TO CLASSICAL RADIO
description: TERESA STERNE, who in 14 years helped build the Nonesuch Record label into one of the most distinguished and innovative in the recording industry, will be named director of music programming at WNYC radio next month. This is a new post, according to Peter Low, radio manager of the New York classical-music station, and Miss Sterne is expected to begin new kinds of programming - including some innovative approaches to new music and a series of live music programs.

title: AN INKLING OF RECOVERY FOR THE BRITISH ECONOMY
description: Slowly, but with almost every passing day, signs are growing that Britain's two-year-long economic decline has ended. According to a melange of the statistics favored by economists, ranging from housing starts to engineering orders, the output of manufactured items began to recover six months ago and the economy as a whole started growing over the summer.

title: NUCLEAR WAR AND THE CATHOLIC BISHOPS
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Sets Steel Order
description: The Soviet Union has told four major Japanese steelmakers that it wants to import one million tons of large-diameter steel pipes in the fiscal year 1982, which begins in April, industry sources said here today. The four Japanese companies are the Nippon Steel Corporation, Nippon Kokan, Sumitomo Metal Industries and the Kawasaki Steel Corporation. In September, Moscow contracted to import 750,000 tons of large-diameter steel pipes between October and June after the Japanese concerns offered a fiveyear credit carrying an annual interest rate of 7.75 percent.

title: Home Improvement; COMPOUNDS FOR REPAIRING CEILING AND WALL CRACKS
description: PROBABLY no home repair problem is as frustrating as trying to patch a persistent wall or ceiling crack that keeps opening repeatedly, no matter how carefully it is filled and painted over each time.

title: Index; International
description: The paper Somoza hated now en- rages the Sandinists A2 Mexicans will discuss ''concerns'' with Nicaragua A3 Iraq offers to cooperate with Ira- nian foes of the Ayatollah A4 Around the World A6 Israeli aide to visit U.S. to discuss rift over Sinai peace force A14 Government/Politics 7 of 10 persons sentenced under new state gun law got jail term B3 F.D.A. approves drug for heart attack victims D20 Washington Talk Briefing B8 Phillips Collection begins first drive to raise money B8 Morning hour is a revered ritual of the House B8 White House fellow made mark in year at the F.B.I. B8 Energy Department workers con- front likely oblivion B8 Home Section Home Many objects in a small space: A collector's elegant solution C1 Beyond the tinsel and holly C1 Marble for beauty and practical- ity C3 In Germany, the demand for new houses: 'Small, but mine' C6 The 800-calorie Thanksgiving Day C1 Hers C2 Helpful Hardware C2 Home Beat C3 Home Improvement C4 Calendar of Events C7 Gardening: Mail-order gifts C9 Design Notebook: Southern Cali- fornia modernism C10 Paddling increases in Miami schools C11 General Around the Nation A16 Moon aides face charge for failing to bring woman to court A16 Harlem business group seeking to revitalize the area B6 Arts/Entertainment Hans Sahl's study of Germany, ''House Music,'' is staged C13 ''Taste of Honey'' exemplifies col- laborative theater efforts C13 Harry dances ''Reaches'' and ''Missing Persons'' C15 Len Jenkin's ''Dark Ride'' is staged at SoHo Rep C15 City Ballet restores ''Tchaikov- sky Suite No. '' to repertory C16 ''What's What,'' a visual glos- sary, is reviewed C17 Book, ''A Glorious Way to Die,'' is reviewed C17 Narciso Yepes gives guitar re- cital at Carnegie Hall C17 Library microfilming 6,000 books destroyed during the blitz C17 Stephen Dickson makes debut in ''Die Zauberfl'' C17 Chamber music ensemble Tashi plays at Goodman House C19 Sports Rangers and Maple Leafs tie, 3-3 D15 Fingers voted most valuable player in American League D15 Nets send Tolbert to Sonics for Bailey D15 Connors pulls out of Davis Cup final D15 Jets greet a wan Augustyniak, out of hospital D17 Dave Anderson on Gerry Faust's joy and pain D19 News Analysis David K. Shipler comments on three dilemmas facing Israel A15 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials A18

title: THE SPACE SHUTTLE GOES HOME
description: The Columbia, on the back of a specially built Boeing 747, landing yesterday at the Kennedy Space Center at Cape Canaveral, Fla. About 9,000 people gathered to watch the return of the orbiter from California, where it landed Nov. 14 after its second space flight.

title: BEGIN MAKES OFFER TO REOPEN ARAB UNIVERSITY IN WEST BANK
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that he would allow the Arab university of Bir Zeit to reopen if the school's president pledged to restrain students from throwing stones, incendiary bombs and hand grenades.

title: Schoolboys Said to Bet
description: An Orange County grand jury has opened an investigation into what may be a $150,000-a-week sports bookmaking operation involving lines of credit to high school students, The Los Angeles Times reported today.

title: Article 107604 -- No Title
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today proposed a fine of $200,000 against the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company for ''a widespread breakdown'' in quality assurance in construction of a $1.25 billion nuclear power plant.

title: RATES SLIDE AGAIN IN BOND RALLY
description: Prices of long-term bonds advanced sharply yesterday, with investor demand boosting by more than a point the bellwether Treasury issues due in 30 years. They have advanced about 17 points since late October - a $170 gain per $1,000 face value and easily the largest increase in bond prices in more than 18 months.

title: MARATHON OIL WINS CHEERS IN FINDLAY
description: No doubt about it, this quiet town of 36,000 is decorated for an unusually festive occasion. The red ribbons tied to trees, lamp posts, parking meters and doors make it appear that the town folk are early in decking out their rambling frame houses and their quiet commercial strip for Christmas. The blitz of placards and buttons, all adorned with red hearts, suggests an even earlier start on Valentine's Day.

title: TO OUR READERS
description: Because of a labor dispute in its pressroom on Tuesday night, The New York Times printed 165,000 fewer copies than it had scheduled. The Times regrets the inconvenience to readers.

title: MARBLE FOR BEAUTY AND PRACTICALITY
description: THE reasons for using marble in interiors have not changed over the centuries: It is beautiful, practical and frankly luxurious. Used in building construction since ancient times, it is a form of granular limestone or dolomite that is mined all over the world.

title: Modern British Library Donated to Alfred U.
description: A private library of modern British literature and social history has been donated to Alfred University by Mrs. Evelyn Tennyson Openhym, a longtime benefactor of the western New York institution.

title: SUDAN IS FACING HARD ECONOMIC CHOICES
description: At the urging of the International Monetary Fund and other major donors from the West and the Arab world, President Gaafar al-Nimeiry has undertaken a program of sweeping fiscal change meant to rehabilitate the Sudan's deteriorating economy. The program includes a devaluation of the Sudanese pound and an end to Government subsidies for cooking oil, wheat and sugar.

title: Critic's Notebook; 'A TASTE OF HONEY,' AUTHOR'S PLAY OR DIRECTOR'S?
description: NEVER mind how doth the busy bee? How doth the busy director? Now that the effective Roundabout revival of Shelagh Delaney's ''A Taste of Honey'' has finally stolen away from us, we might well pause and make a note. I've referred to ''A Taste of Honey'' as Shelagh Delaney's play, which it surely was -in the sense that Miss Delaney invented its characters and wrote most or all of its lines. In part, however, it was someone else's play: it was a director's play, Joan Littlewood's play.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Junior Bridgeman, the swing man who had been out a week because of a sprained knee, was activated from the injured-reserve list by the Milwaukee Bucks. To make room on the roster, the Bucks waived the forward Bobby Dandridge, a former all-star. ... Arturo Frias of Los Angeles, the No.9 lightweight in the World Boxing Association and the World Boxing Council, will replace injured Gonzalo Montellano in the Dec. 5 W.B.A. championship match with Claude Noel, the titleholder, in Las Vegas, Nev. ... Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina has become the fourth player to qualify for the $400,000 Volvo Masters Jan. 13-17 at Madison Square Garden. earlier qualifiers were Ivan Lendl, John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors.

title: JETS GREET WAN AUGUSTYNIAK
description: A week ago, his weight was falling, his temperature was rising, his white-blood count was dangerously low. Mike Augustyniak, the Jets' starting fullback, was in Massachusetts General Hospital, suffering complications from two broken ribs.

title: Transportation Chief Sworn
description: Anne P. Canby was sworn in today as New Jersey's Transportation Commissioner for the last two months of Governor Byrne's administration. She has already served three months as Acting Commissioner while awaiting Senate confirmation of her appointment.

title: IN GERMANY, THE DEMAND FOR NEW HOUSES: 'SMALL, BUT MINE'
description: Germans spend more per capita on tourism each year than anyone else - but rather a nearly sensual relationship with their four walls, whether in a Munich highrise, a Bonn town house or a one-family home on Cologne's outskirts.

title: The City; Two Are Indicted In Rape of Nun
description: Two Manhattan men were indicted yesterday on charges of raping a 30-year-old nun last month, and District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said he would seek stiff consecutive sentences if the men were convicted.

title: SOVIET SOFTENS STAND ON REAGAN
description: An influential Soviet magazine markedly softened Moscow's criticism of President Reagan's disarmament proposals today and said it was important that he was talking about peace.

title: WE GATHER TOGETHER
description: Thanksgiving Day, as history and symbol, throws some curious light on a myth of our day: that American greatness came from free enterprise, from individual rather than community effort, and that a return to individualism can solve our current problems. That myth informs Ronald Reagan's whole political program, and a lot of people believe it. But it is a myth.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ADDRESS BY RAVITCH ON TRANSIT SYSTEM'S PROGRESS AND PLANS
description: Following are excerpts from an address delivered yesterday by Richard Ravitch, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, before the New York City Partnership:

title: THE DANCE: 'REACHES' AND 'MISSING PERSONS'
description: HARRY is heavy. Harry, the modern-dance group directed by Senta Driver, has come to specialize in heavy-weighted movement, and Miss Driver's investigations of kinetic weights and measures continued Sunday night at the Harry Studio, 87 Fifth Avenue, with a program that included a revised version of ''Reaches'' from last season along with her new ''Missing Persons.''

title: Student Strikes Spread In Polish Universities
description: (UPI) - Student strikes continued to spread across Poland today, closing two-thirds of the universities and a dozen high schools.

title: Sakharovs' Kin in U.S.  Seeking to Visit Them
description: Alexey Semyonov and Tatyana Yankelevich, the children of Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist, and his wife, Yelena Bonner, applied today for Soviet visas to visit their parents, who have been on a hunger strike since Sunday.

title: KARATE TEACHER, IN LINE AT BANK, FOILS A ROBBERY
description: A 25-year-old part-time karate instructor in a Lower East Side youth program yesterday thwarted an attempt by a 16-year-old to rob a mid-Manhattan bank.

title: Sports People; New Bids for Ainge
description: Danny Ainge resembles a roulette ball bouncing from one slot to another. Ainge has said for some time that he is determined not to play baseball any longer, that he has learned that his true talent lies in basketball.

title: Briefing
description: T HE scene was a White House Cabinet meeting the other day, and one ranking official was telling President Reagan that Congress would probably work late into the night on the budget bill. Mr. Reagan leaned over to his counselor, Edwin Meese 3d, and said in a stage whisper: ''You will wake me, won't you?''

title: CALENDAR: BASKETS AND ARCHITECTURAL DRAWINGS
description: Woven Work American Baskets, the Museum of American Folk Art, 49 West 53d Street.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt WHAT'S WHAT. A Visual Glossary of the Physical World. By Reginald Bragonier Jr. and David Fisher. 565 pages. Illus- trated. Hammond. $30.

title: Notes on People; Opinion Poll
description: In a scholarly poll of the nation's leading diplomatic historians, Henry A. Kissinger, Dean Acheson and George C. Marshall were adjudged among the 10 best Secretaries of State and John Foster Dulles was one of the five worst.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. SAYS TIME HAS ARRIVED FOR A SERIOUS PARLEY ON ARMS
description: The United States said today that with negotiations on nuclear forces in Europe opening Monday it was now ''time for serious discussions and a cessation of public posturing.''
To the Editor:

title: STAGE: 'HOUSE MUSIC' STUDIES GERMAN ATTITUDES
description: THEY say a drowning person sees his life just before he dies, but what do you see when you are a survivor returning to the scene of your early life that drowned 30 years ago? This is what Hans Sahl, one of that most impressive of immigration waves to America, the German-speaking refugees, explores in a new play, ''House Music,'' done by the American Jewish Theater at the 92d Street Y.

title: The City; 4 Sentenced in Bid For Copter Escape
description: Four persons received prison sentences for their attempt to free one of them from the Federal correctional center in lower Manhattan last Jan. 25 by landing a hijacked helicopter on the roof.

title: THE 800-CALORIE THANKSGIVING DAY
description: THIS is the season of satiation, the time to eat oneself into a stupor in the company of family and friends. My Thanksgivings have all fit the formula - four-day feeding frenzies ending in benign bloat, except for one, a Thanksgiving that I spent at the nation's most expensive diet spa.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I am thinking of putting plastic storm windows on the inside to help conserve heat. However, the sun comes in the back of my house most of the afternoon, so my question is: will the storm windows keep out the extra warmth I get from the sun on sunny days? - K.B., Southampton, Pa.

title: Mutual Funds By Prudential
description: After acquiring a major brokerage firm earlier this year, the Prudential Insurance Company of America said that it would begin selling mutual funds through its insurance agents.

title: Auto Output Down in Japan
description: Japan's automobile production in October fell by 3.5 percent, to 970,497 units, from October 1980, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers' Association announced today.

title: Giants To Start Weston
description: For the third week in a row, the Giants changed their starting offensive line today. This time the reason was not an injury.

title: Holders Back Offer By Sunshine Mines
description: Stockholders of four small silver-mining companies have agreed to merge with the Sunshine Mining Company, which operates the nation's largest silver mine, Sunshine said.

title: 2D BANK IN PACT WITH A BROKER
description: The Security Pacific National Bank announced yesterday that its 600 branches throughout California would begin buying and selling securities for the bank's customers.

title: To Grandmother's House
description: Just 361 years after a ship named the Mayflower dropped anchor, its landing place has been declared no place in which to spend one's golden years. High taxes, high fuel bills, not enough shopping malls -Massachusetts came in last on the list of best states to retire to, prepared by Chase Econometrics, a subsidiary of Chase Manhattan.

title: 'PROUD TO BE GERMAN'
description: Nowhere is the cry for ''peace'' louder than in Bonn, the overgrown village that is West Germany's capital. On its face, this seems odd. Bonn is almost assertively tranquil - as placid as the Pastoral Symphony by Beethoven, who, as it happens, was born there.

title: Miss Farrell Dancing 'Cinderella' in Chicago
description: Suzanne Farrell, principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, will appear with Maria Tallchief's Chicago City Ballet through Sunday at Chicago's Auditorium Theater in the title role of a new full-length production of ''Cinderella.''

title: MET OPERA: STEPHEN DICKSON
description: FOLLOWING the Metropolitan Opera's sixth performance this season of ''Die Zauberflote'' Tuesday night, a nearly unanimous ovation halted the bows when Stephen Dickson, who had just made his Met debut as the evening's Papageno, stepped forward.

title: Eurodollar Study Is Set
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said today that it would consider three proposals to permit trading in Eurodollar certificate of deposit futures contracts at meetings on Dec. 8 and Dec. 15.

title: NETS TRADE TOLBERT TO SONICS FOR BAILEY
description: No doubt more quickly than originally expected, the Nets' youth movement is aging. Almost two weeks after they acquired Sam Lacey, an 11-year veteran, in a trade with Kansas City, the Nets obtained James Bailey, a thirdyear forward, from the Seattle SuperSonics for Ray Tolbert, a rookie from Indiana, and a second-round draft-choice in 1984. Both Bailey and Tolbert are 6 feet 9 inches.

title: CITIES FOUND HARD HIT BY BUDGET CUTS
description: Cities throughout the country are laying off workers, raising taxes, reducing services and deferring major spending plans to cope with the ''immense burdens'' imposed by President Reagan's budget cuts, the United States Conference of Mayors said in a report released today by the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.

title: No Headline
description: LAKERS CAPTURE NINTH IN ROW

title: BROOKLYN, IN THE 30's: 'BEGGING,' FEASTING
description: In Brooklyn, during the Great Depression, when our parents had trouble putting enough food on the table, on Thanksgiving they somehow managed to give their hungry kids a feast. But before we ate our fill, we kids went begging; it was a Thanksgiving tradition.

title: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1981; Companies
description: Mobil raised its offer for Marathon Oil to nearly $6.5 billion after persuading a court to hold up U.S. Steel's $6.3 billion bid. Analysts expect U.S. Steel to present a stronger bid early next week. The Mobil offer, which Marathon has not welcomed, depressed Marathon shares on the Big Board by $1.25 a share, to $105.50. (Page A1.)

title: PROSTITUTION PLAN UPSETS ATLANTIC CITY
description: This resort city, in turmoil because of mounting crime and prostitution, land-buying efforts by the gaming industry and bizarre political manueverings, was in another uproar today.

title: THE ART OF RAISING MONEY
description: Dinner with Henry A. Kissinger? Drinks with Michael K. Deaver 3d? Those are some of the attractions for big contributors to the Phillips Collection, a highly praised private art museum here that has fallen on hard times. Although raising money for museums is never easy, it seems to be a bit less difficult in the nation's capital, where out-of-town contributors might find themselves seated next to a former Cabinet member or a Presidential adviser at fund-raising dinners.

title: DESPAIR- COMPANION OF NEEDIEST
description: In the months after the sudden death of her husband on New Year's Eve in 1978, the task of caring for their two sons nearly overwhelmed Mrs. D. Her limited command of English and a leg injury that kept her from working contributed to the family's problems.

title: NO U.S. HELP FOR VIETNAMESE IMPERIALISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Nickel Output Is Reduced
description: A French mineral producer, Ste. Metallurgique le Nickel, said today that it was shutting two of its nickel smelting units in New Caledonia.

title: PRESIDENT RESIGNS AT FUQUA INDUSTRIES
description: Fuqua Industries announced yesterday that Kay W. Slayden had resigned as president and a director of the Atlanta-based conglomerate ''for personal reasons.''

title: MANY OBJECTS IN A SMALL SPACE: A COLLECTOR'S ELEGANT SOLUTION
description: ''ADESIGNER'S character is as apparent in his work as in his handwriting,'' said Stanley Barrows, chairman of the interior design department at the Fashion Institute of Technology. ''I have never seen a good room design that did not reflect this.''

title: FOR ISRAELIS, 3 DILEMMAS
description: Israel is currently juggling three dilemmas. It must decide whether or not to accept European participation in a Sinai peacekeeping force under terms it finds abhorrent. It must decide whether or not to accept American notions of ''strategic cooperation'' far more limited than those originally sought. And it must decide whether or not to accept American appeals for continued restraint in the face of a Palestinian arms buildup in southern Lebanon.

title: Article 107716 -- No Title
description: The 1981 Mitchell Prize of $10,000 for a work of art history has been awarded to ''Luca della Robbia.'' The book was cited as a ''masterly and pioneering'' study and catalogue of the works of the 15th-century Florentine sculptor.

title: The Thanksgiving Law
description: There has always been a Thanksgiving, ever since Governor Bradford's three-day celebration in the Massachusetts Bay Colony in 1621. But it was not until 242 years later that President Lincoln proclaimed it an official holiday, a delay that invites speculation. What if he had not? What if formalizing the celebration had been left up to the interest group politics of today's Washington? Could Thanksgiving survive K Street?

title: PADDLING INCREASES IN MIAMI SCHOOLS
description: Dade County schoolchildren in increasing numbers are making the acquaintance of Mr. Understanding and similar wooden paddles that translate school officials' new get-tough attitude into something the students can feel.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * MacLevy Products Corporation and its associated company, Steamist Inc., to the Frank Vos Company.

title: ROCK ACTION IN THE SUBURBS DRAWS EVEN MANHATTANITES
description: WHERE do you go if you live in New York City's suburbs and want to hear some rock-and-roll? Until fairly recently, you would have had two choices. If you were willing to settle for an average suburban rock band, you could probably find one at a nearby watering hole. But if you wanted to hear a band with a reputation - albums in the stores, write-ups in the rock press - you got in your car and drove into Manhattan.

title: Around the Nation; Killer Held After Escape From Prison in Nebraska
description: Two employees of the Nebraska State Penitentiary were attacked today by a convicted killer who then escaped and was later captured, prison officials said.

title: D'EMILIA HELPS PARK RIDGE TOP BOGOTA
description: Rick D'Emilia passed for three touchdowns and ran for another to lead Park Ridge (10-0) to a 35-0 victory over Bogota yesterday. Todd Sisti, who kicked 5 extra points, caught D'Emilia's 10-yard touchdown pass in the first quarter for a 6-0 lead. Ted Gunther and Bob Drake were the other receivers of D'Emilia scoring passes. The senior quarterback completed 10 of 14 passes for 182 yards for Park Ridge, which will be in the final of the North Jersey Section 1 Group 1 playoffs next week.

title: The Evening Hours
description: F EATHERS were what the man asked for and feathers were what he got. The man is Bill Boggs and he requested that the feathers be worn by the 400 or so guests invited to his fifth annual Thanksgiving Party, which was held Tuesday night at Sybils. Mr. Boggs, of course, is the host of Channel 5's Midday, a program that seems to tickle a lot of people's fancy.

title: Slang Dictionary Ban Ordered in Colorado
description: The Westminster Board of Education, brushing aside accusations of censorship, has banned The Dictionary of American Slang from 21 elementary and junior high schools.

title: THREATENED HARVEST (2)
description: More than 400 beef cattle grazed the 1,665 acres of Field Farms, near Owensboro, Ky., in the 1960's. Today the herd numbers less than 100, owing to the rows upon rows of corn and soybeans growing on much of the old pasturage.

title: PHONE COMPANY IS UPHELD ON USE OF FEDERAL TAXES
description: A State Supreme Court justice has rejected a suit by Attorney General Robert Abrams charging that New York Telephone Company billed customers for $1.3 billion in Federal taxes that it never paid.

title: The New York Times/John Sotomayor THANKSGIVING WITH FRIENDS
description: Lorry Russell sharing part of her day yesterday with the pigeons in Brooklyn Heights. Her family lives in Washington, and she was unable to join them for the holiday.

title: Letters From Fitzgerald to Be Sold at Auction
description: When he was only 11 years old, Horace Wade was described in many newspapers as ''America's youngest novelist,'' having published a popular book called ''In the Shadow of Great Peril.''

title: THANKSGIVING IN A CITY OF 7,000 JOBLESS
description: The Smith family was separated for Thanksgiving dinner today. Unable to afford the traditional family meal, James Smith and two of the children had dinner at his mother's house and Patricia Smith and the third child dined with Mrs. Smith's parents.

title: A NEW SOAP STAR
description: And now, in the seemingly endless saga of the soap operas that might be called ''Guess Who's Making a Guest Appearance on Her Favorite Daytime Drama?'' throw in the name of Carol Burnett.

title: REAGAN CALLS CAPITAL 'LEAKS' HIS BIGGEST DISAPPOINTMENT
description: President Reagan says his biggest disappointment in Washington has been his inability to stop unauthorized disclosures in the city of ''one giant ear.''

title: Israel Confirms Flight Over a Saudi Air Base
description: The Israeli Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Rafael Eytan, confirmed today that Israeli planes had flown over a Saudi base that he said was being built for potential operations against Israel.

title: 'BOATLIFT' PRIESTS AWAIT SENTENCING
description: By May 14, 1980, when President Carter ordered a halt to the boatlifts that had brought more than 100,000 Cubans to Florida's shores, the priests felt they had gone too far with their plans to turn back. So they did what they believed was morally right and knew was legally wrong. Last week in a Federal court here they became convicted felons.

title: SCHMIDT CAUTIOUS ON GENEVA ARMS TALKS
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt said today that he was ''completely convinced that both the Russians and the Americans want results'' in the new round of arms negotiations opening in Geneva on Monday, but that there is no guarantee that results will be achieved.

title: No Headline
description: BOY, 12, UNDERGOES HEART TRANSPLANT SURGERY

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our kids are too old to bring now so we borrow our friends' kids.

title: Around the Nation; New Storms From West Threaten Plains States
description: The Plains States were threatened yesterday with another snowy assault from the West, where storms created avalanche hazards and icy driving conditions.

title: The Region; G.M. Lays Off 1,000 in Jersey
description: As they were preparing to go home for their Thanksgiving holiday, 1,000 blue-collar workers at the General Motors Corporation production plant here were told that they were losing their jobs, temporarily at least.

title: Escaped Lions Tie Up Traffic
description: Two lions escaped and caused a rush-hour traffic jam this morning after their cage fell from a circus truck on a main artery here. The male lion, named Nero, was easily recaptured, but his mate, Helena, kept firemen and her handler at bay for three hours. Two circus employees were lightly scratched in the chase.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in yesterday's Times in- correctly stated the interest rate $200 million to be loaned by the Fed- eral Commodity Credit Corporation to finance tobacco purchases. The rate is 14 1/2 percent.

title: Energywatch
description: NOV. 20, 1981 As refining output rose, crude oil supplies declined to 372.3 million barrels.

title: Flames 7, Kings 1
description: Kevin Lavallee scored a goal and had two assists to help Calgary extend its unbeaten streak to five games - four victories and a tie.

title: Plague Death Is Confirmed
description: Tests have confirmed that a visitor here died of septicemic plague, a rare form of bubonic plague, health officials report. Masaru Yamase of Chiloquin, Ore., died Nov. 21. Test results received Wednesday showed that septicemic plague and plague pneumonia caused the death.

title: Advertising; Sony States Opinion In Videotape Case
description: Earlier this week, the Sony Corporation of America, the Japaneseowned company whose products include the Betamax home video recorder, took to advertising in an attempt to create an atmosphere that would favor Congressional legislation that would permit ''private, offthe-air recording for non-commercial purposes.''

title: 1,715 Luxury Autos Recalled To Correct Potential Hazard
description: The DeLorean Motor Company announced Wednesday that it was recalling all of the 1,715 luxury automobiles it had sold in the United States to correct a potential safety hazard.

title: KOCH WILL APPOINT MASS-TRANSIT AIDE
description: As part of an effort to become more directly involved in running the city's mass-transit system, Mayor Koch plans to name a special assistant for transportation.

title: Article 108727 -- No Title
description: On the way from New York City to Seoul, South Korea, $2 million was stolen from five money sacks being transferred to the Government-run Korea Exchange Bank.

title: No Headline
description: TEXAS SUBDUES AGGIES, 21-13

title: Tours at Seaport Set For This Weekend
description: A mixed bag of history, architecture and sea lore can be found this weekend at the old seaport of New York downtown on the East River in tours sponsored by the South Street Seaport Museum.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: Irish Sweep
description: Eamonn Coghlan of Ireland, now a resident of Rye, N.Y., won the five-mile Manchester, Conn., road race in 21 minutes 37 seconds yesterday. Three other Irish natives tied for second in 22:26: Ray Treacy, Michael O'Shea and Brendan Quinn. ... Alberto Salazar, the world-record holder in the marathon and a two-time New York City Marathon winner, is favored in tomorrow's United States cross-country championships at Burbank, Calif. ... John Tate, the former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, continues his comeback attempt tonight in Knoxville, Tenn., where he meets Chuck Gardner of Minneapolis in a scheduled 10-round main event.

title: DISAFFECTED EXECUTIVES TURN TO VERMONT BUSINESS BROKER
description: For 14 years, Michael Balser worked his way up the corporate ladder to vice president at the Shipley Company, a family-owned, Boston-based chemical company.

title: Ex-Promoter Freed on Bond
description: Harold Rossfields Smith, the former boxing promoter on trial in a $21 embezzlement at Wells Fargo bank branches, was released Wednesday night on a $200,000 bond posted in part by the widow of Joe Louis. Mr. Smith, jailed two weeks ago when his original bond was revoked, said Martha Louis and another friend had pledged $200,000 in personal property to obtain his release.

title: Around the World; Death Count Tops 200 In Philippine Typhoon
description: The death count from a typhoon that struck parts of the northern Philippine island of Luzon Tuesday, has risen to more than 200. In two of the coastal villages hit by tidal waves, the count rose to 136.

title: ELECTION VICTORY IN HOUSTON SHOWS GAINS OF NEW DEMOCRATIC 'PROGRESSIVES'
description: While the national Democratic Party tries to chart a new philosophical course in the wake of its disastrous defeat a year ago, a new generation of Democrats in Texas seems to have found one, and by running on it they are winning elections, frequently by wide margins.

title: STATE DEPT. IS ASKING COLLEGES TO CURB RESEARCH BY CHINESE
description: The State Department has begun asking academic officials to cooperate in imposing security-related restrictions on research done by Chinese scholars studying in the United States.

title: BANKS HAIL 2 PLANS FOR BROKER TIE
description: This week's move by two big California banks into the exclusive preserve of the securities industry - buying and selling stocks - has drawn a mixture of applause and raised eyebrows from bankers around the nation. Some praise its boldness, and some wonder about its legality.

title: Judge Moves von Bulow Trial
description: Judge Thomas H. Needham of Superior Court, citing publicity and the prospect of a long trial, has moved to Providence, R.I., the trial of Claus von Bulow, the society figure accused of trying twice to kill his wife, Martha. Judge Needham said the facilities in Providence would better accommodate reporters and spectators.

title: AUTUMN 1981 ON SEVENTH AVE.
