description: ''In 1934, I started my own company,'' recalled Eli Elias, a manufacturer of women's suits and sportswear. ''It was the depth of the Depression. They were selling apples in the streets.'' He paused to emphasize the hardship of those years. ''But December,'' he continued, ''always showed an increase.''

title: The Region; Water Supplies In Jersey Decline
description: TRENTON (UPI) - Although reservoirs in northern New Jersey are fuller this month than a year ago at this time, environmental officials said that the rainfall for November was below normal and that water supplies are beginning to decline.

title: LAST-MINUTE GIFTS RESCUE A DAY OF GIVING
description: When organizers of a new charity in New York were selecting a day to start distributing free food to centers that serve the elderly and the poor, Thanksgiving seemed most appropriate.

title: E.E.C. Textile Plan
description: The European Economic Community today proposed a new world textile agreement to restrain a surge in clothing imports from major third world producers. The draft for a new pact, to succeed the current multifiber arrangement when it expires at the end of the year, would drop provisions in the 1977 treaty allowing nations with threatened home industries to make ''reasonable departures'' from a guarantee of a 6 percent annual increase in textile imports from developing countries. Third world nations have attacked the ''departures'' clause as discriminatory.

title: Advertising; New Chief Is Chosen For A.B.P.
description: Thomas Holdridge King, the 47-year-old executive who has been named to take over the presidency of the American Business Press from retiring Charles S. Mill on Nov. 2, has seen it all in his 25 years in the field. He has worked for publishing companies big and small, moved through research and sales, which he learned at the feet of a master, and publishing, which included production, circulation and working with editors.

title: PUBLISHING: 'VALLEY OF DOLLS' RETURNS IN HARD COVER AT '66 PRICE
description: NEWMARKET PRESS has received considerable attention by publishing a hard-cover edition of Jacqueline Susann's ''Valley of the Dolls'' at the book's original 1966 price of $5.95. But how was Newmarket able to price the book so low at a time when most hard-cover novels sell for $10 or more?

title: TROTTIER SCORES 3 IN ISLANDER ROUT
description: The Islanders, who will play their next seven games on the road, left something for their Nassau Coliseum fans to remember tonight by trouncing the St. Louis Blues, 9-2.

title: A Plea to Stay in the United States
description: As a Haitian refugee struggles with immigration officials in the doorway of plane on runway in Miami, another pleads to leave aircraft, which was carrying 125 Haitian refugees to Fort Allen, P.R. Officials reported yesterday that up to 18 Haitians had escaped from the Krome Avenue detention center in the Miami Everglades.

title: CAREY TO NAME SPECIAL PANEL ON TOXIC WASTE
description: Governor Carey, who earlier this week announced that the state had abandoned plans to sponsor a $1 billion toxicwaste treatment facility on the shore of Lake Ontario, said today that he would appoint a special panel to seek ways to overcome community opposition to the construction of such plants.

title: STAGE: 'SIDE STREET SCENES,' AN AMIABLE MUSICAL
description: THE essence of creative contemplation is not Rodin's ''The Thinker,'' but the popular composer sitting at an old upright, holding his head in his hands and trying to write a new tune. Unlike such shows as ''Merrily We Roll Along'' and the Off Off Broadway ''Bullet Headed Birds,'' Sam Henry Kass's ''Side Street Scenes'' approaches this heroic subject with a cheerful smile rather than a furrowed brow. ''Side Street Scenes,'' at the Open Space, never takes itself too seriously, and in so doing arrives at some amiable home truths, such as the fact that one does not have to fly to Hollywood to fail. If you try hard enough, failure can be lurking just around the corner on Tin Pan Alley.

title: Bridge:; 2 U.S. World Champions Lead in Blue Ribbon Play
description: Two of the United States players who won the world team championship a month ago in Port Chester, N.Y., seemed headed for another success when play in the blue ribbon pair championship resumed here this afternoon at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: DR. JOHN POMFRET, PRESIDENT OF WILLIAM AND MARY IN 40'S
description: Dr. John Edwin Pomfret, a historian and former president of the College of William and Mary, died yesterday in Camden, S.C., after a brief illness. He was 83 years old.

title: SOVIET-GERMAN BRIDGE
description: LewisBONN, Nov. 25 - The most important result of Leonid Brezhnev's trip to Bonn was West Germany's full emergence on the world political scene. Now it is Bonn, not Paris, that receives special messages from Moscow and relays them to Washington.

title: DECORATIVE ARTS: MET ADDS TO AMERICAN WING
description: DISPLAYS of three aspects of 19th-century decorative arts in this country - painted Federal furniture, American folk art and the Shaker style -have just gone on permanent view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the latest galleries to be opened in the museum's recently completed American Wing. The austere simplicity of the Shaker designs and the wit and warmth of the painted furniture and folk art are in sharp contrast with the formal, more elegant furnishings found elsewhere in the wing.

title: AT LAMBS MISSION, MUSICAL DINNER FOR THE POOR
description: Irvin Hummel, a farm equipment supplier from George, Iowa, drove 1,400 miles in a pickup truck to serve Thanksgiving dinner to more than 200 poor New Yorkers at a church mission off Times Square.

title: U.S. IS URGED TO SELL PROPERTY IT DOESN'T USE
description: Two Congressmen want the Government to sell hundreds of unused Federal properties, including lighthouses, airports, dams, Army bases, ammunition dumps, prisons, factories and post offices, which the General Services Administration has valued on its books at $1.3 billion but which others insist are worth much more.

title: N.F.L. Games Closer?: Statistics Say No
description: Two pro football games were decided by 1 point last weekend, the Jets' 16-15 victory over Miami Sunday and Atlanta's 31-30 decision over Minnesota Monday night. Those were the 41st and 42d games decided by 3 points or fewer this season, or one-fourth of the total played to date.

title: POP JAZZ
description: KAI WINDING, who was half of the celebrated jazz trombone duo, ''Jay and Kai,'' with J.J. Johnson in the 1950's and, before that, the creator of the broad, braying style used by the trombones of the Stan Kenton orchestra, is back in town with a new trombone partner, Curtis Fuller. They call themselves ''Giant Bones'' and they are playing this weekend at the new club the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street.

title: MCINALLY FINDS HIS GROOVE
description: When Pat McInally stepped from Harvard Yard into the National Football League in 1975, he was a receiver, punter and graduate student in art history who brought a Mickey Mouse lunch box to practice with the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: THR PROPER PARENT FOR THE PEACE CORPS
description: To the Editor:

title: Libya Orders 10 Airbus Jets
description: Libya's state airline has signed a contract to buy 10 wide-bodied European Airbus jet planes, Airbus Industrie said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * ACF Industries has named J. Donald Brinkerhoff to executive vice president-operations, Herbert A. Borst executive vice presidentfinance and Charles L. Harper a vice president and general manager of the W-K-M division.

title: The Region; Mrs. Grasso Left $256,000 Estate
description: Ella T. Grasso, who died last Feb. 5 after resigning as Governor because of ill health an estate valued at $256,000, according to Probate Court records in her hometown.

title: Ahmed Zaki Saad, 81; Was Official of I.M.F.
description: Ahmed Zaki Saad, a former executive director of the International Monetary Fund, died last weekend in Geneva, the I.M.F. announced. He was 81 years old.

title: IN INDIA, PAKISTAN BREEDS CURIOSITY AND CONTEMPT
description: The complicated feelings of Indians toward Pakistan, ranging from brotherly love to fratricidal revulsion, are being expessed here daily at the Indian International Trade Fair, where for the first time Pakistan has an exhibit.

title: Rise in Supply Of Gasoline
description: Gasoline supplies rose slightly last week, reflecting a normal seasonal decline in motor travel, the American Petroleum Institute reported.

title: YES, DEMOCRATS, SERVE OLD BACKERS, BUT ALSO...
description: The Democratic Party neither can, nor should, abandon its constituency of the poor, the minorities, feminists, and the unemployed. But it risks becoming a special-interest party with limited appeal to a majority of the electorate if it makes the welfare of these groups its primary cause and fails to offer convincing programs for coping with the ''system problems'' of inflation, energy, and economic growth that affect everybody.

title: BEGIN FRACTURES THIGH IN A FALL AT HIS HOME
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin fractured the upper thigh bone of his left leg tonight in a fall in his home in Jerusalem and underwent surgery at a hospital there, officials disclosed.

title: ISRAELI VETO ON SINAI EXPECTED
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that he expected to tell Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. that Israel opposed plans by four West European countries to participate in the peacekeeping force that will patrol Sinai after the scheduled Israeli withdrawal in April.

title: William Spire, 70, of Florida; Land Development Promoter
description: William M. Spire, an advertising executive who led in the promotion of land development in Florida for nearly a quarter of a century, died last Saturday at Baptist Hospital in Miami. He was 70 years old and lived in Miami.

title: NICARAGUA OFFICIAL ARRIVES IN MEXICO CITY FOR TALKS
description: Nicaragua's Foreign Minister arrived here today for talks with Mexican officials. The visit came two days after Mexico offered to act as an intermediary in efforts to reduce tensions between the Reagan Administration and the Sandinist Government.

title: New York's Dog Deal
description: Nobody ever has to run for dogcatcher in New York City, for a very good reason: the city turns the job of catching and disposing of stray animals over to the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

title: VALLEY STREAM NORTH PLAYS A 0-0 TIE
description: John Miele has been head varsity football coach at Valley Stream North High School for 25 years, and yesterday he completed his first undefeated season on the frozen field at C.W. Post College in Brookville.

title: STAGE: NEGRO ENSEMBLE PRESENTS 'SOLDIER'S PLAY'
description: IN the first scene of Charles Fuller's ''A Soldier's Play,'' the opening production of the Negro Ensemble Company's new season, we see a middle-aged black Army officer stumbling about in shadows. The man, Tech. Sgt. Vernon Waters (Adolph Caesar), is drunk and raving and half-bent to the ground. ''They still hate you!'' he screams in a gravelly, barrel-chested voice. ''They still hate you!'' Then two shots ring out, and Waters collapses in a mortal heap.

title: A 'HOMELAND' SPURS PROTEST FROM BLACKS
description: Thozamile Gqweta, a 29-yearold leader of a black labor union who has become a symbol of resistance to South Africa's ''homeland'' politics, had another funeral to go to today.

title: MORE SACRED THAN THE RIGHTS OF PRAYER
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Oregon Girls Allowed Tryouts in Wrestling
description: Two freshman girls are training on the Alsea High School wrestling team after getting approval from the school board to compete against boys.

title: Advertising; Hamilton Account
description: Ogilvy & Mather Direct Response has been named agency for the Hamilton Watch Company's Collector's Classic Edition Society, which sells specialty timepieces and ''original collectibles.'' The account was formerly with Mel Richman of Bala Cynwyd, Pa. The agency's fee, if capitalized, would come to over $1 million.

title: 9 Named to Songwriters Hall of Fame
description: Nine new members will be added to the Songwriters Hall of Fame, it was announced in New York yesterday by Sammy Cahn, president of the National Academy of Popular Music.

title: E.P.A. WILL LOOK TO THE STATES
description: The Environmental Protection Agency should transfer responsibilities for transporting and storing hazardous waste to the states when they are ready, Anne M. Gorsuch, the agency's administrator, said Tuesday.

title: Briefing
description: T HE Supreme Court had some potentially embarrassing time on its hands near the end of its last session. Justices wound up working a few short weeks and half-days as it became clear that the Court had accepted too few cases to fill out its planned calendar.

title: Index; International
description: In India, Pakistan breeds curi- osity and contempt A2 Spanish senate backs NATO entry A3 Schmidt cautious on arms talks A3 Israeli opposition to European units in Sinai expected A4 Around the World A7 Seychelles Govenment reports repulsing a mercenary attack A9 For foes of South African ''home- lands,'' funerals and protests A11 U.S. study says Soviet living standard still lags A13 Government/Politics Richard Allen defends the sale of his consulting firm A10 Gov. Carey to name special panel on toxic wastes B9 Reagan cites 'trying times,' but urges thanks B12 ''Reaganville'' camp erected in park near White House B14 Washington Talk Briefing B10 Former diplomats: how much should they tell? B10 Iowa Congressman to become a critic of Reagan budget B10 Washington Follow-Up B10 General Around the Nation A16 Thanksgiving in an Indiana town of thousands of jobless A16 Two Chicago police officers sus- pended in rape case A19 Two priests await sentencing over Cuban boatlift A25 Traffic clogs roads in New York metropolitan area B3 Milk production rises despite price support freeze B19 Cargo ship with 24 aboard feared sinking off Bermuda B25 Industry/Labor Burning of PCB on ship off Texas tests disposal cost A23 Phone company upheld in suit over deferral of Federal taxes B6 Weekend Events: Weekender Guide C1 Theater: Broadway C2

title: Lafayette's Brown Stars
description: Larry Brown, a senior tailback, went 166 yards on 33 carries, scored touchdowns on runs of 6 and 2 yards and was named the most valuable player for leading Lafayette to a 30-22 victory over New Utrecht yesterday in the 11th annual Lasagna Bowl.

title: White Plains Routs Stepinac
description: White Plains, Iona Prep, and Yonkers were winners yesterday in traditional Thanksgiving Day games. Once-beaten White Plains routed Stepinac, 42-20, as Jim Donahoe, the quarterback, passed for two touchdowns in his final scholastic game.

title: Officer Wounded in Assassination Attempt Retires
description: The Washington, D.C., policeman shot in the March 30 attempt on President Reagan's life has taken disability retirement because of his wounds.

title: CALIFORNIA FIGHT A CURIOUS REGIONAL DISEASE
description: In December 1977, a sudden wind erupted in the parched San Joaquin Valley of central California and, in one of the rare fireworks of nature that families speak about for generations, it whipped up clouds of dust that rolled like enormous opaque waves for hundreds of miles.

title: News Analysis
description: A Federal District Court decision in Illinois that caught Republicans by surprise has all but eliminated the possibility that redistricting in that state will play a major role in the party's efforts to win the

title: Jersey Casino Profits
description: Buoyed by a highly profitable summer, eight Atlantic City casino hotels have reported aggregate earnings of $37.2 million for the first nine months of this year.

title: Soviet Women Capture Title
description: The Soviet Union, which took silver medals for second place two years ago, recaptured the women's team title at the 21st world gymnastics championships tonight and completed the first team double in 23 years.

title: EVADING OF TAX BY BOAT BUYERS CITED IN INQUIRY
description: Widespread evasion of state taxes by boat buyers has been uncovered in the New York City area, according to the State Commission of Investigation.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 27, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: WORRIED RETAILERS PLAN MAJOR PUSH FOR HOLIDAY SALES
description: The nation's retailers, seeking to prevail in what promises to be an unusually difficult holiday sales season, are planning a flurry of price reductions, catalogue promotions, changes in advertising and increased community tie-ins.

title: OPENNESS: PANEL GETS A LESSON
description: The state's Freedom of Information Commission, which is supposed to keep government agencies open to the public, kept itself a little more open than usual by accidentally taperecording an informal conversation among its staff members.

title: BRAVING THE COLD TO CHECK ON HEAT COMPLAINTS
description: At 10:32 A.M. on the day before Thanksgiving, a day when a pale sun shone as through a prism of ice and a brisk wind made the air brittle, two men were standing in front of 450 Audubon Avenue in the Inwood section of Manhattan and peering intently at the thermometers that are the crucial instruments of their occupation.

title: Around the Nation; 9-Hour Hostage Ordeal Ends With Man's Suicide
description: A man with guns and a homemade bomb took his former wife, her friend and four relatives hostage in a house trailer, then set them free and killed himself today after the authorities threatened to storm the dwelling.

title: U.S. RECOMMENDING CHICAGO FOR WORLD'S FAIR SITE IN 1992
description: The Federal Government's decision to recommend Chicago as the site for a world's fair in 1992 could mean nearly 60 million visitors for the event, according to officials of the group promoting the event.

title: Lumet Film Retrospective in Astoria
description: A retrospective of films spanning Sidney Lumet's 25 years as a director in New York ends this weekend in Astoria, Queens, with ''The Wiz'' the 1978 musical adaptation of Frank Baum's ''The Wizard of Oz.''

title: Advertising; People
description: * Clifford W. Gulbransen has been elected a senior vice president of Creamer Inc./New York.

title: JOHNNY.  MR. DIXIE.
description: Americans baffled by the rash of seemingly hostile antinuclear demonstrations in Europe might care to ponder a fragment of wartime autobiography. It centers on two people who figured large in my life in England when I was 9 years old, Johnny Smith and Mr. Dixie.

title: Greenwich Sets Back Trumbull
description: Ken Bell ran 16 yards for a touchdown with 4 minutes 22 seconds remaining, and Dan Fleishman added the decisive extra point as Greenwich rallied to defeat defending champion Trumbull, 7-6, for the Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference championship yesterday before 9,500 fans at Boyle Stadium in Stamford.

title: THE STAGE: SINGING 'SUSAN B!'
description: ''SUSAN B!'', a one-act musical that will be playing at the Martin Theater (108 East 89th Street) through Sunday, belongs in the same category with such recent family-entertainment fiascos as ''Copperfield,'' the Broadway flop that turned Charles Dickens's novel into a singing Classic Comics. Of course, ''Susan B!'' cost only a tiny fraction of what it cost to mount ''Copperfield,'' and it's only one-third as long. Except for Lillian Byrd, who plays Susan like an earnest young ingenue, the six cast members all take multiple roles, and the tinny background music for the singers is taped.

title: Milo Hopkins, 80, Dies; Former Bank Executive
description: Milo B. Hopkins, a former executive vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, died Monday at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 80 years old.

title: Business People; ALLIED LENGTHENS ITS CHIEF'S CONTRACT
description: Thomas M. Macioce, the 62-year old president and chief executive officer of the Allied Stores Corporation, one of the nation's largest retailers, will continue to run the company until at least Jan. 31, 1987, the Allied board has decided.

title: 1 CREW RESCUED OFF CANADA
description: Two military helicopters battled 60-mile gales tonight to rescue the 26 crew members of a grain freighter that split in two after running aground in heavy seas on the Sable Island sands off the east coast of Canada.

title: A THANKSGIVING GIFT
description: The Rev. George Clements of Chicago feeding an infant, named Jonathan, being held by his adopted son, Joey. Father Clements had planned to adopt the baby, but decided to allow a childless couple that he had met to adopt the child instead. ''They got a Thanksgiving gift,'' he said in explaining his decision.

title: FOOD FOLKS HELP FEED ELDERLY
description: This fall 85 food corporations were asked to contribute Christmas baskets for some of the city's elderly poor who would otherwise have no Christmas meal. All refused. But Manhattan's food establishment has stepped in to fill the void.

title: Africans Plan to Meet Today On the Peace Force for Chad
description: Leaders of the African nations that have pledged to send peacekeeping troops to Chad will meet here Friday, the official Kenyan news agency reported today.

title: INDIAN OCEAN ISLE REPULSES RAIDERS
description: The leftist Government of this island nation in the Indian Ocean announced today that its forces had repulsed an attack by more than 100 mercenaries, many of them said to be former South African soldiers. It said some of the attackers had fled by hijacking an Air India jet to the South African city of Durban.

title: OLIVER HOLMES, 79, HISTORIAN
description: Dr. Oliver W. Holmes, an archivist, historian and former executive director of the National Historical Publications Commission, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in Washington. He was 79 years old.

title: THANKSGIVING IN THE DESERT
description: American troops taking part in the joint U.S.-Egyptian military exercises helping themselves to Thanksgiving dinner at Cairo West Airbase at the end of the two-week maneuvers.

title: Mets and Collins Talk
description: The Mets, who selected negotiating rights to five players in the free agent draft two weeks ago, have made an offer to one, Dave Collins. Lou Gorman, vice president for baseball operations, said the Mets had made a concrete offer to the former Cincinnati outfielder.

title: ONE FINDS STOCKMAN REMARKS A PLUS
description: What do Republican members of Congress have to be thankful for on this day? A Senate majority? A conservative President who has won some big victories? The promise of Reaganomics?

title: Around the World; Athens Cracks Down On Industrial Polluters
description: Drastic measures went into effect here Wednesday to fight record pollution levels registered in the Greek capital, including a reduction of traffic volume by one half and of certain industrial plants' production by 30 percent, and a ban on heating in almost all public buildings.

title: CULTURAL LEADER HEADED ART FUND
description: Doris Chanin Freedman, chairman of the Public Art Fund Inc. and a cultural affairs and landmarks preservation activist in New York City, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. Mrs. Freedman, who was 53 years old, had been in a coma since August 1979 as a result of medical complications following surgery at Mount Sinai.

title: Deal Clippers Out
description: The San Diego Clippers have acceded to the wishes of Lawrence O'- Brien, the National Basketball Association commissioner, to not make any further promotional deals with Las Vegas, Nev., casinos. But not all bets are off; the Clippers will be allowed to live up to their arrangement with the Sands Hotel and Casino, which includes free trips there for fans. ... Any moment now, says a report in The Boston Globe, Danny Ainge will be signed to a long-term contract with the Boston Celtics. The newspaper reported a breakthrough in negotiations between the Celtics and the Toronto Blue Jays, with whom Ainge has signed a contract to play baseball.

title: The City; Diplomat's Son Involved in Death
description: A car driven by the 18-year-old son of an envoy to the United Nations struck and killed a pedestrian in midtown Manhattan yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: BOEING'S 'RE-ENGINING' WORRY
description: Commercial airlines' growing interest in putting new engines on aging aircraft is causing some anxious moments for the Boeing Company.

title: Talafous a Quiet Contributor
description: It was not what Dean Talafous, the Rangers' gangly right wing, is expected to do often in the course of the 80-game season. But there he was with the puck on his stick and no one between him and Michel Larocque, the Toronto goalie.

title: Promises, Promises
description: That's show business. Fran Curci, dismissed as head coach of the University of Kentucky football team last Tuesday, says he might sue the school for the money he figures to lose from his statewide radio and television shows.

title: Say It Isn't So
description: Duriel Harris didn't like the play selection of Coach Don Shula in the 16-15 loss to the Jets last Sunday and said so, and Shula didn't like the wide receiver saying so and told his entire squad. ''Now, more than ever, it is the time to pull together,'' said Shula, whose Dolphins have fallen into a first-place tie with the Jets and have a Monday night game coming up against the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Lucien Rodriguez Wins European Ring Title
description: Lucien Rodriguez of France won the European heavyweight boxing championship with a unanimous 12-round decision over Luis Felipe (Pantera) Rodriguez of Spain tonight.

title: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Bernard D. Kahn Associates now called Kahn/Larsen/Walsh Inc.

title: High Interest: Problem or Solution?
description: Before I pray for my wife and children at night, I pray for lower interest rates. - Senator Jake Garn. Someone up there may be listening; interest rates have fallen sharply in the weeks since the Utah Senator expressed those priorities. But the cost of borrowing has fallen only because loan demand is off, reflecting business's poor prospects during a recession. Once the economy picks up, interest rates are likely to soar again. And many businessmen who not long ago saw tight credit as the economic solution now regard it as part of the problem.

title: SAMBO'S HAS CLOSED 447 RESTAURANTS
description: Sambo's Restaurants Inc. has closed 447 restaurants, resulting in layoffs of up to 10,000 employees, an official said today.

title: A Rare Performance: 'Aida,' With a Difference
description: The audience at the Bavarian State Opera had the rare experience of seeing Giuseppe Verdi's ''Aida'' without a chorus, after the singers refused to perform.

title: O'Neill and His Wife Have Hospital Dinner
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill was served a low-salt turkey dinner today at St. Francis Hospital, where he is recovering from a mild heart attack.

title: FORMER DIPLOMATS: HOW MUCH SHOULD THEY TELL?
description: As William H. Sullivan recounts the tale, it was ''a complete surprise'' when he was asked in 1977 to become the American Ambassador to Iran. Mr. Sullivan, perhaps the leading Southeast Asian specialist in the Foreign Service, had never served in the Middle East and ''knew little about its culture or its ethos.''

title: No Headline
description: McEnroe, Lendl Gain In Round-Robin Event

title: Rose Kennedy Quits Hospital
description: Rose Kennedy, accompanied by her son, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, and her daughter, Patricia Kennedy Lawford, was released from St. Mary's Hospital today and taken to her home in Palm Beach, the hospital said. The 91-year-old Mrs. Kennedy, admitted two days ago after suffering chest pains that have disappeared, was ''in fine spirits and in good health,'' said a hospital spokesman, Ruth Hardy.

title: UNION HALTS LINDEN AS SMITH SETS PACE
description: Albert Smith, a senior running back, ran 19 times for 140 yards and three touchdowns to lift Union to a 27-0 victory over Linden yesterday in the teams' 50th Thanksgiving Day game.

title: The City; 3 Teen-Agers Held In Subway Thefts
description: Three Brooklyn teen-agers were arrested yesterday and charged with robbing five people at knifepoint on four Manhattan subway trains, the Transit Authority police reported.

title: 2 French choices, modern and funky.
description: ONE of the most original and inviting new restaurants to open in New York in quite a while is Delices La Cote Basque at Olympic Tower, the handsome black glass building on Fifth Avenue with a thoroughfare lobby running from 51st to 52d Street. A modern version of the covered-street concept that inspired Milan's Galleria, the Olympic Tower setting is enhanced by a monumental waterfall and tall boxed trees. On the street level, Delices operates a retail pastry shop, a convivial bar and Le Cafe, a terrace area with bright tablecloths and an attractive menu offering breakfast, light lunches and snacks.

title: ECONOMISTS ARE NOT THE VILLAINS
description: To the Editor:

title: The Region; Leg Reattached For Boy in Crash
description: An 18-month-old New Jersey boy who had his left leg reattached in by eight-hour microsurgery following a car accident was reported in serious but stable condition yesterday at Bellevue Hospital in New York City.

title: Economic Scene; The Budget's Many Facets
description: THE recent battle of the budget, with the White House and Congress hurling estimates of expenditures, revenues and deficits at each other as though they were custard pies, seemed like a farce, except that the Government was suddenly brought to a grinding halt. Although it is back in operation, the serious issue of how to use the Federal budget to serve the public interest still remains.

title: Dr. Edith B. Hand Dies at 51; Attending Physician for G.E.
description: Dr. Edith Bramwell Hand, who was known professionally as Dr. Edith B. Reilly in her position as an attending physician in the New York City office of the General Electric Company, died Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 51 years old.

title: A ZOO FEAST WITH ALL THE TRIMMINGS
description: What does a lesser long-tongued bat have for Thanksgiving dinner? What about a mandrill? Or a Siberian tiger? In the midst of talking turkey all week, did you stop for a moment to think what animals might eat?

title: The City; City Urged to List Tax Exemptions
description: The Koch administration should publish an annual accounting of the tax exemptions it grants to further policy objectives, the Citizens Budget Commission recommended.

title: CARNEGIE STUDY SAYS COLLEGES SUFFER FROM LOSS OF DIRECTION
description: Colleges are suffering from a loss of confidence and purpose and are in danger of becoming ''academic supermarkets,'' the Carnegie Foundation has warned.

title: Hot Rods at Coliseum
description: The 20th National Hot Rod and Custom Car Show begins at the New York Coliseum today at noon.

title: '72 DISPUTE GIVES JUDGE DIFFICULTY
description: A controversy concerning a 1972 testimonial dinner that raised $23,500 in contributions has come back to haunt a judge now under consideration to become United States Attorney here.

title: BURNING OF PCB ON SHIP PLANNED TO TEST COST
description: More than 17,000 tons of polychlorinated biphenyl, or PCB, is to be burned on a ship in the Gulf of Mexico next month in an experiment to see whether the cost of disposing of the hazardous chemical can be reduced.

title: HOLIDAY TRAFFIC CLOGS HIGHWAYS IN NEW YORK AREA
description: With home-cooked turkey dinners, traditional family reunions and the Thanksgiving Day parade luring them on, tens of thousands of travelers joined a rumba line of stop-and-go traffic on roads and rails across the New York metropolitan area yesterday.

title: PACE U., 75, LAYS GROWTH TO FLEXIBILITY, INNOVATION
description: In the fall of 1906, 10 men and three women gathered in a rented room in the former New York Tribune building on Nassau Street in lower Manhattan to learn how to be accountants.

title: Todd Throws on Sideline
description: Richard Todd threw a football today for the first time since the last-minute touchdown pass last Sunday that helped lift the Jets into a tie for first place in their division. But he was not throwing the ball in the Jets' practice, which was directed by Pat Ryan, Todd's backup.

title: St. John's, Fordham Lapchick Favorites
description: College basketball returns to the metropolitan area tonight with the seventh Joe Lapchick Memorial Tournament, which has been won each year by the host school, St. John's.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1981
description: International The sharing of Common Market costs was discussed again as the 10-nation bloc opened a two-day conference in London. Britain and West Germany reaffirmed the position that they contribute a disproportionate amount of the European Economic Community's $25-billion budget. But the government leaders of the eight other member countries, which generally receive more money from the community than they contribute, offered no new formula to solve the increasingly pressing problem. (Page A1, Column 6.) Britain's new centrist party won a stunning victory in a by-election at Crosby near Liverpool. The victory by Shirley Williams of the new Social Democratic Party in a constituency previously regarded as a Conservative stronghold gave her party its first Member of Parliament and enhanced its alliance with the Liberals. (A1:2-3.)

title: ALLEN DEFENDS THE SALE OF HIS CONSULTING COMPANY
description: Richard V. Allen, President Reagan's national security adviser, said today that he had sold his Washington consulting business on a three-year installment plan and stood to make only $39,000 from the sale, which he characterized as a ''perfectly ordinary commercial transaction.''

title: MUSIC AND THE VISUAL ARTS TEAM UP IN PURCHASE
description: Alvin Lucier is one of the most interesting composers of the post-John Cage era, and one of his most elusive, subtly evocative works is called ''Music on a Long Thin Wire.'' It consists of an 80-foot strand of piano wire strung tautly between two posts and attached to an oscillator, which is, in turn, attached to amplifiers and loudspeakers. Anything - footfalls, air currents, a passing earthquake - will agitate the wire, and when it twitches, which it is always doing to some extent, it sets up an eerie, dappled texture of sound.

title: TOM LEHRER RENAISSANCE IN 'VILLAGE'
description: Tom Lehrer was the balladeer for the 1950's, singing his wickedly iconoclastic ditties around the country during that decade of manicured lawns, psychoanalysis and beat poets. In Mr. Lehrer's songs the Wild West was first perceived as radioactive; a sweet old gentleman turns out to be the Old Dope Peddler; the South of ''whuppin' slaves and sellin' cotton'' is nostalgically recalled, and spring is a time for poisoning pigeons in the park.

title: 'Sholom Aleichem' returning with Jack Gilford.
description: ''THE WORLD OF SHOLOM ALEICHEM,'' with Jack Gilford, will open at the Rialto Theater on Feb. 4. Mr. Gilford was in the original production, in 1953, when he had but a single line: ''A hot roll and fresh butter.'' It was a wonderful line, a memorable line; it followed Mr. Gilford wherever he went. ''There's hardly been a day in our lives,'' says Madeline Gilford, Mr. Gilford's wife, ''in New York, Paris or London, when someone hasn't said, 'I know you don't remember, but ... ' As soon as they say that, we know it will be about 'Sholom Aleichem.' We've been in restaurants, where the waiter has come over and said that someone is sending something over to us. It's always a roll and butter.''

title: The Greatest Gives Thanks
description: ''A IN'T no other fighter in the world would have the power to do what I've done,'' Muhammad Ali said, ''what I'm about to do.'' This was Muhammad Ali, the thrice and possibly future heavyweight champion of a world, on the telephone from Nassau in the Bahamas where he is scheduled to fight Trevor Berbick in yet another comeback Dec. 11.

title: MILK OUTPUT RISES DESPITE A PRICE SUPPORT FREEZE
description: Last March, when President Reagan stared down the dairy lobby and got Congress to skip the twice-yearly increase in milk price supports, the Administration hoped that this would persuade American dairy farmers to begin cutting back and bringing supply closer to demand.

title: About Real Estate; MANAGEMENT OF CITY-HELD PROPERTIES
description: New York City's Department of Housing Preservation and Development is saddled with an immense stock of residential property that has fallen into its hands through tax foreclosure.

title: An actor turns into a director.  HOLLYWOOD
description: RICHARD BENJAMIN is a happy man. The actor is directing his first feature film, called ''My Favorite Year,'' and he's never had a better time. Richard Benjamin is also a man who is all keyed up. He says even sleep doesn't do him any good, ''because I dream about the picture.''

title: VANISHED CITY LIFE BY BERENICE ABBOTT ON VIEW
description: THE career of Berenice Abbott, who is now 83 years old, has long been one of the legends of American photography, and there has probably never been a better exhibition of her work that the one that William A. Ewing has organized at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street (through Jan. 10). Called ''Berenice Abbott: The 20's and the 30's,'' this exhibition brings together nearly 200 pictures from the two decades with which this photographer's achievements have been mainly identified. It includes a great many of her most famous pictures as well as a significant number of ''lost'' pictures that few people have ever seen before. It is a stunning exhibition that everyone with an interest in photography or the cultural life of the 1920's and 30's will want to see.

title: Prices of Tin Swing Widely
description: The price of tin fluctuated widely today on the London Metal Exchange as a unnamed buyer who has forced prices to record highs apparently changed tactics to maintain his grip on the market.

title: HOMESTEAD EXEMPTIONS TAKE MANY IN FLORIDA OFF TAX ROLLS
description: Most homeowners in rural Florida Panhandle counties have stopped paying property taxes. Since 1980, when Florida voters overwhelmingly approved a constitutional amendment to raise homestead exemptions, the majority of homeowners in 20 counties have been removed from the tax rolls.

title: French Cut a Winner at $46.20
description: French Cut, a horse with bad feet who had won only one of 24 races in the last two years, beat Bar Dexter in a long stretch drive to win the $58,400 Queens County Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: ON A DAZZLING DAY, MILLIONS DELIGHT IN 55TH ANNUAL THANKSGIVING PARADE
description: The adults were as excited as the children yesterday as a crushing hodgepodge of humanity gathered to watch Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade.

title: JAZZ: DOC CHEATHAM QUINTET
description: ONE of Duke Ellington's many attributes was the polish, the wit and the style with which he talked to his audiences. It was a minor but very effective part of his performance, something that has not been cultivated by many jazz musicians.

title: MINI-CITY AT MEADOWLANDS: A SOLUTION APPEARS AT HAND
description: A family dispute that has jeopardized construction of a proposed billion-dollar ''mini-city'' in the heart of the Hackensack Meadowlands now appears close to a settlement.

title: ART: ARCHAIC INDONESIA AT BROOKLYN MUSEUM
description: NEW YORKERS who think there are no surprises left in ''primitive'' art are in for -well, a surprise. On short notice, the Brooklyn Museum has brought from Switzerland a marvel of a show called ''Art of the Archaic Indonesians'' (through Jan. 31), the first major museum exhibition in the United States devoted to sculpture of the island peoples of Indonesia. Their work, mostly in stone and wood, but also in metal, expresses the myths and religious concepts of a ''primitive'' culture that goes back to the last millennium B.C. and that spreads over a vast equatorial area of more than 6,000 islands.

title: Business People; TRANSCO'S PRESIDENT GETS POSTS AT TRIANGL
description: Arthur M. Goldberg, the 39-year-old president of the Transco Group, has been elected president and chief executive officer of Triangle Industries. Transco acquired 26 percent of Triangle earlier this year.

title: Market Place; Mistakes At Sambo's
description: SAMBO'S RESTAURANTS INC., once a rapidly growing and highly regarded chain of coffee shops, is now in deep trouble, its survival threatened. On Wednesday, trading in the company's shares was halted for most of the day after a Federal grand jury indicted two former officials and three other executives on charges of fraud and reports began to circulate that the company could be on the verge of bankruptcy.

title: Miami's Leaders Join To Fight Crime Rate
description: Officials of the Chamber of Commerce, awaiting tourists fleeing winter's snow and slush, have designed a new plan to fight increasing crime in Miami.

title: VOTE ON WAIVERS TO AID ALASKA PIPELINE IS NEAR
description: The House of Representatives is expected to approve next week a request from President Reagan that critics say could require natural gas users to pay as much as $37 billion for the proposed Alaska gas pipeline even if they never receive any Alaskan gas from it.

title: Racing Board Changes Rule on Coupled Entries
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board has changed the rule regarding betting on coupled entries at New York thoroughbred tracks. Under the new rule, which took effect yesterday, if a horse that is part of a coupled entry or field is scratched after betting has begun, all bets on the entry or field will be refunded.

title: Friday; FISHER HALL JAZZ GREATS
description: Two jazz artists of legendary stature - the vocalist Ella Fitzgerald and the pianist Oscar Peterson - will share the stage of Avery Fisher Hall tonight at 7:30 and 10:30 P.M., along with a guest artist, the guitarist Joe Pass. Miss Fitzgerald will be backed by the Jimmy Rowles Trio and Mr. Peterson will appear with John Heard on bass. Tickets, $10 to $25, at the box office (874-2424) or through Ticketron (977-9020) or Centercharge: 874-6770. STAGE DESIGN ON 57TH ST.

title: The City; The Police Blotter
description: A person who called the 911 police emergency number about 11 A.M. yesterday said there was a body at Crescent Street and Stanley Avenue in the East New York section of Brooklyn, the police said. Officers found the body of a man about 30 years old wrapped in plastic trash bags.

title: Auctions; Sales with a Latin flavor.
description: WHAT Sotheby Parke Bernet describes as the most important work by the Mexican painter Rufino Tamayo ever to be auctioned will be offered in a sale of Latin American art next Wednesday at 7 P.M. and Thursday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at its Madison Avenue galleries, at 76th Street. The 1946 painting, titled ''The Smile,'' depicts a happy figure seated before a table full of watermelon slices, arms raised jubilantly. The oil on canvas, 4 feet long by 9 feet wide, was in a Tamayo show at the Phoenix Museum in 1968. It is expected to sell for more than $220,000, which would be a record price for a work by the artist or for any Latin American work sold at auction.

title: POPE RESUMES TRAVEL, NOT WITHOUT CRITICISM
description: Six months after he was shot, Pope John Paul II has regained his vigor and is signaling that he intends to remain what he was before the assassination attempt: a robust, traveling teacher-Pope asserting his moral authority around the world.

title: Aoki's 67 Leads by Shot; Trevino Is 2d in Japan
description: Two veteran golfers - a Japanese and an American - were in the two top spots today after the first round of the Casio World Open Golf tournament.

title: THE SWIFT, MAGICAL RISE OF ELIZABETH MCGOVERN
description: THE story line reads like the highly improbable plot of girlhood fantasy. Aspiring young actress graduates from high school and moves to New York. She has barely begun her first year at Juilliard when Robert Redford casts her in his movie and structures his whole shooting schedule around her weekend availability.

title: ART: 17 NEW PAINTINGS BY TAMAYO ON 57TH ST.
description: RUFINO TAMAYO'S 17 recent canvases at the Marlborough Gallery, 40 West 57th Street, mark his 19th appearance in New York - including his 1979 show at the Guggenheim Museum - in 55 years. A veteran of three international biennials, the artist, now 82, has been enormously successful, not only in the United States, but also in Europe, Asia, the art-buying countries of South America and, of course, in his native Mexico.

title: COMMON MARKET, IN LONDON PARLEY, DEBATES FINANCING
description: The 10 nations of the European Economic Community opened a two-day conference here today aimed at finding a more equitable formula for sharing the burden of paying the organization's bills. But by the end of the opening session, there was no indication that they were anywhere close to a solution.

title: Quake on Puget Sound
description: A minor earthquake occurred today beneath the Kitsap Peninsula on the west side of Puget Sound, scientists said. No damage or injuries were reported. The 4:30 A.M. temblor, measuring 3.4 on the Richter scale, was centered about five miles north of Bremerton, said Christina Boyko of the University of Washington.

title: A CITY SOCIAL TRADITION: SUPPORT FOR SERVICE CLUBS
description: ''The times are with us,'' said Ivan Obolensky the other day at the Soldiers', Sailors' and Airmen's Club, of which he is an executive vice president. ''The era is not antipatriotic, the time is more clement to servicemen and women.''

title: MRS. MARCOS'S SPEECH
description: To the Editor:

title: Christmas Rooms And Film in Newark
description: ''To Grandfather's House We Go,'' a film about Victorian-style architecture in the United States, will be shown at the Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street, on Sunday at 1:30 and 2 P.M. Also on view are five rooms modeled after the Ballantine Brewery family home, decked for the season with holly, evergreen garlands and poinsettias. China is out on the dining room table, which is covered in Battenberg lace, and Victorian-style ornaments hang on a tree surrounded by toys and games from the museum's collection.

title: GAINS IN SOVIET LIFE ARE CALLED 'MODEST' BY C.I.A. RESEARCH
description: A study commissioned by the Central Intelligence Agency has concluded that the Soviet Union has made only ''modest progress'' in its drive to equal consumer living standards in the United States and other Western countries.

title: Don Hogan Charles Empty Truck Found in the East River
description: A garment delivery truck partially submerged in the East River near the Bronx Whitestone Bridge.

title: 16 Nurses Robbed in Class At a College in Philadelphia
description: Sixteen nurses attending an evening class at La Salle College here were robbed of cash, jewelry and keys by three armed men who barged into the classroom and ordered them to lie on the floor, officials said.

title: Inquiry on Nimitz
description: Navy officials say that an internal investigation is still under way into the cause of a plane crash on the deck of the aircraft carrier Nimitz.

title: Chiefs Fall To Lions By 27-10
description: Eric Hipple threw two touchdown passes in the first half, and Detroit's defense held the Kansas City Chiefs to a field goal in the second as the Lions posted a 27-10 victory today.

title: Jersey Agency Seeking Bids on 300 New Buses
description: Governor Byrne has announced that the New Jersey Transit Corporation, the state's mass-transit agency, is seeking bids for at least 300 new commuter buses for long-distance runs.

title: OTTAWA REJECTS QUEBEC MOVE
description: The federal Government today rejected an attempt by predominantly French-speaking Quebec to veto a proposed new constitution, raising the prospect of a new court battle over the plan, which has the support of Canada's nine predominantly Englishspeaking provinces.

title: LOUISIANA ACTING TO SAVE COASTLINE
description: Gov. David C. Treen has signed into law a bill that gives Louisiana $35 million to fight the erosion of 47 square miles of its coast every year.

title: Around the World; Iran Says 13 Leftists Have Been Executed
description: Iranian officials said today that 13 leftist guerrillas fighting Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Moslem regime were executed by firing squads.

title: WARDEN IS ACQUITTED
description: A jury in Atlanta spent eight hours deciding to acquit Jack Hanberry on a charge of shoplifting a $1.10 hairbrush from a local supermarket.

title: News Analysis
description: Israel appears to be the biggest winner to emerge from the Arab League meeting that broke up in disarray here Wednesday night after only four acrimonious hours.

title: 'REAGANVILLE' CAMP ERECTED TO PROTEST PLIGHT OF THE POOR
description: Despite warnings from the police, a social action group today erected a ''Reaganville'' of tents for homeless people in Lafayette Park across Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House.

title: 'Beauty and Beast'
description: The Gingerbread Players and Jack will present ''Beauty and the Beast,'' a musical adaptation of the Perrault tale, for preschoolers to sixth graders at the Colden Center for the Performing Arts at Queens College today at 11 A.M. and 7 P.M. The production was directed by John Ahearn.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By John Leonard DAMBALLAH. By John Edgar Wideman. 205 pages. Avon/Bard. $2.95. HIDING PLACE. By John Edgar Wideman. 158 pages. Avon/Bard. $2.95.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Fair Weather and Friends
description: Now begins the time of year when weather prophets solemnly intone that although tomorrow's high will be about 42 degrees Fahrenheit, the wind chill factor will make it seem no more than 30. The wind chill factor is a praiseworthy effort to quantify the difference between the real and the apparent. But since, by its nature, mere semblance cannot be quantified, how can its distance from reality be established?

title: SOCIAL DEMOCRAT WINS BY-ELECTION IN CONSERVATIVE DISTRICT IN BRITAIN
description: Shirley Williams scored a strong victory Thursday in a by-election at Crosby, near Liverpool, capturing a constituency previously regarded as an unassailable Conservative fortress and giving the new Social Democratic Party its first elected member of Parliament.

title: TWO OPERATIC NOVELTIES WITH AN ANTIQUE FLAVOR
description: Tomorrow night, New York is offered two fascinating footnotes to operatic history. One is opera in its early adolescence, Georg Philipp Telemann's ''Pimpinone'' at the 92d Street Y. The other - the New York Renaissance Band's staging of ''Gargantua and Pantagruel'' at Alice Tully Hall -really isn't opera at all, but here 20th-century hands have brought together the elements of Renaissance music and drama from which the operatic art was soon to spring. A children's version, called simply ''Gargantua,'' will be given tomorrow morning at Symphony Space.

title: Business People; NEW CHAIRMAN NAMED AT HARWYN INDUSTRIES
description: Philip K. Koss, 65, who resigned early this month as executive vice president of Saxon Industries, has been named chairman of Harwyn Industries. He succeeds Harvey R. Siegel, 54, who continues as president and chief executive officer of the New York-based importer and distributor of computerized video games and other gambling equipment licensed for sale in Nevada and New Jersey.

title: Cowboys Win; White Is Hurt
description: Ron Springs, the Dallas fullback, circled left end on a 5-yard touchdown run with 5:09 remaining today and Rafael Septien added the vital extra point that gave the struggling Cowboys a 10-9 comeback victory over the Chicago Bears.

title: 'MICE AND MEN' AND 'DREAM HOUSE'
description: THE schedule has a promising new weekly series, ''Open All Night'' on ABC, and a fine new version of an American classic, ''Of Mice and Men,'' on NBC, but nothing is likely to top ''Dream House,'' on CBS tomorrow at 9, for the kind of artful exploitation that characterizes shamelessly pure television.

title: Around the World; Polish Union Activists Detained by Police
description: The Polish Government and the trade union Solidarity held apparently inconclusive talks here today as new trouble flared between local union activists and the authorities in two major industrial regions.

title: 'CLEAN AIR ACT REGULATIONS ARE A NATIONAL BARGAIN'
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 CHICAGO POLICEMEN SUSPENDED IN RAPE CASE
description: Police Superintendent Richard Brzeczek has suspended and says he wants to dismiss two officers who are said to have ignored the pleas of a badly beaten rape victim, joked with her attackers and then let them go.

title: SPANISH SENATE BACKS NATO ENTRY
description: Spain's Senate today approved the Government's proposal to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The action cleared the way for an official request for membership that is expected to be made early next week.

title: 2 French Priests Go on Trial In Brazil on Violence Charges
description: Two French priests went on trial in the northern Brazilian city of Belem Wednesday on charges of encouraging violence in land disputes, church officials said today.

title: The City; Authorities Seek Rikers Escapee
description: Rikers Island correction officers searched the grounds with state police dogs and helicopters for a 23-year-old inmate who escaped from the prison's Anna M. Kross Center, authorities said.

title: A MERGER-MAKER AND HIS INVESTORS
description: In two recent corporate takeover attempts on the West Coast, the name of one man has emerged: Stanley Hiller Jr. Mr. Hiller, a 57-year-old industrialist, has spent the past decade attempting to rescue troubled companies. In several cases, he has gained financial control and then stepped in to redirect the faltering concerns.

title: A Key Aide Is Named By Transit Authority
description: John D. Simpson, president of New York City's Transit Authority, has announced the appointment of John N. Centinich to take charge of programs to overhaul and maintain the system's 6,500-car subway fleet.

title: FORD FUND TRUSTEE
description: A former United States chief delegate to the United Nations, Donald F. McHenry, has been elected to the board of trustees of the Ford Foundation, it was announced yesterday in New York.

title: Keeping Track of Missing Kids
description: Most parents know what it is to lose a child in a department store or amusement park. They know, too, about the late afternoon nerves when a fourth-grader is not home from school, and the sleepless hours waiting for a teen-ager to come in from a date.

title: The Region; Turkey Dispute Ends in Stabbing
description: An argument between two rooming house boarders Thursday over preparing a turkey for Thanksgiving dinner resulted in the stabbing of one and the jailing of the other, the Nassau County police said.

title: L.I. Girl Gets Hockey Chance
description: Barbra Broidy has been battling since early this year to get on her high school's all-boy hockey team - now she's going to get her chance.

title: Dollar Mixed In Europe
description: The dollar was mixed in European financial centers today, with trading subdued by the American Thanksgiving Day holiday. Trading in gold bullion was quiet.

title: SCENARIO FOR A PEKING-TAIPEI RAPPROCHEMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1981; The Economy
description: The nation's retailers are planning more aggressive advertising and more price-cutting in the face of what promises to be an unusually difficult holiday sales season. Retailers say sales rose only slightly above inflation in October and that business has improved only slightly. (Page A1.)

title: Around the Nation; M.I.T. Chiefs to Suggest Acceptance of Institute
description: The president and the provost of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology say they will formally recommend next week that M.I.T. become affiliated with a proposed biomedical research institute to be financed by an industrialist.

title: ART: MATTA PAINTINGS AND DRAWINGS OF 1937-47
description: SEBASTIAN Matta Echaurren (best known simply as Matta) was always a quick study. From the moment in 1934 when he arrived in Paris from his native Chile, he looked fast, he learned fast, and he adapted fast. Ill suited to the long haul of architectural studies -even when the teacher was Le Corbusier - he was just the man to profit by the ebullition of European Surrealism. Like a sorcerer's apprentice, he tried his hand at this spell and that until he found the one that would wreak his own particular magic.

title: LAWYER, 37, FOUND SHOT TO DEATH IN A BURNING MIDTOWN APARTMENT
description: A 37-year-old lawyer was found shot to death yesterday morning on the kitchen floor of his burning apartment in midtown Manhattan, the police said.

title: Advertising; Fast-Food Spending
description: One reason, perhaps, that the relationships between fast-food clients and their agencies are so volatile is the intense competition, heavy advertising spending and attendant need for great creative work to break tdhrough the clutter.

title: U.S. Acts After Report Of Arab Killer Squads
description: United States security agencies have bolstered their bodyguard forces and have tightened border controls after being warned that Libyan or other Arab assassination squads are out to kill President Reagan and other top American officials, the authorities said today.

title: Sunshine Suspends Dividend
description: The Sunshine Mining Company, one of the nation's biggest silver producers, said yesterday that it would not pay its regular 10-cents-a-share dividend for the fourth quarter because of a continuing slump in the price of silver.

title: STRIKERS' CASE AT THE UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO
description: To the Editor:

title: Deposit Loss Cut at Banks
description: Aided by a $4 billion gain from the ''All Savers'' certificates, the nation's savings banks lost only $100 million in net deposits in October, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks said yesterday.

title: JOSEPH SMITH, LEGAL HISTORIAN
description: Prof. Joseph H. Smith of the Columbia University School of Law, a legal historian, died Wednesday at Norwalk (Conn) Hospital. Professor Smith, a resident of Floral Park, L.I., was 68 years old. He was the George Welwood Murray Professor of Legal History at the Law School, where he taught for 20 years.

title: Sports People
description: What's Next? Now there's a Penguin Bowl. It's in the Antarctic.

title: VARIABLE MORTGAGE RATE CUT ON COAST
description: The country's two largest savings and loan associations, both in California, said yesterday that they had lowered their mortgage rates to 16 percent.

title: ALLEN IS SAID TO GET 'BIG PRESENT' FROM A LONGTIME JAPANESE FRIEND
description: Tamotsu Takase, a longtime friend of Richard V. Allen, was quoted today as saying he had flown to Washington and given a ''big present'' to the national security adviser in an effort to set up an interview with Nancy Reagan for a Japanese magazine.

title: 14 UNIONISTS SEIZED BY SOUTH AFRICANS
description: In coordinated predawn raids in several cities, the security police arrested the leaders of some of the most politically outspoken black trade unions today under a law that allows detention without charge.

title: BODY AND SURVIVOR FROM SHIP ARE FOUND
description: The United States Coast Guard said one person was found dead today and another was rescued after clinging to an overturned lifeboat from a West German cargo ship with a 24-member crew that foundered in the ocean east of here.

title: CLIPPERS THWART LAKERS
description: Freeman Williams hit a 3-point play with 3:16 left tonight to help the San Diego Clippers end the Lakers' nine-game winning streak with a 138-129 victory over Los Angeles.

title: Iona 58, Ohio State 57
description: ANCHORAGE (AP) - Tony Hargraves sank a free throw with 13 seconds remaining and gave Iona College a victory over Ohio State today in the opening round of the Great Alaska Shootout tournament. In the opening game, Michael Wilson's 18 points led a well-balanced Marquette attack that overwhelmed McNeese State, 88-57.

title: AUDITING STAFF FACING NEW CHALLENGES
description: Employees of the General Accounting Office, who investigate the activities of other Federal agencies, are now trying to figure out in which direction their own agency is headed under its new leader.

title: Notes on People; A Daughter of Shah Auditing College Classes
description: A follow-up: Two weeks after representatives of her family made inquiries about her attending Bennington College in Vermont, Princess Farahnaz Pahlevi of Iran has begun auditing classes there without credit.

title: Around the Nation; Chicago Officials Order Safety Work at Hyatt
description: City inspectors said today that suspended areas of the Hyatt Regency-Chicago need reinforcement and that occupancy should be limited to avert a disaster like the one that killed 113 persons at the Hyatt in Kansas City, Mo., last summer.

title: About New York
description: ON THE FRIDAY AFTER THANKSGIVING, THE CITY BELONGS TO THE CHILDREN By Anna Quindlen

title: Girl Fatally Burned in Queens; Mother Charged With Murder
description: A 9-month-old girl was found burned to death last night in an apartment in Hollis, Queens, the police said.

title: Invalid Woman, 57, A Suicide in Brooklyn
description: A 57-year-old woman confined to a wheelchair committed suicide yesterday morning by throwing herself out of a 12th-floor window at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn Heights, according to the police.

title: Carolyn Ruth Schatz Wed to John C. LeMenager
description: The marriage of Carolyn Ruth Schatz, a television field producer for NBC News, to John Charles LeMenager, an account executive with A.B. Isacson Associates Inc., a New York public relations agency, took place at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Bryant H. Kirkland performed the ceremony.

title: MORE FAMILIES LOSING HOMES AS INFLATION AND JOBLESS RATE SOAR
description: Bill Richey, a Los Angeles plumber, was divorced four years ago, and all that he and his former wife salvaged from 25 years of marriage, he says, were memories and a condominium apartment in suburban Culver City. Now, bankruptcy, back taxes and other economic setbacks have swamped Mr. Richey and, on Dec. 12, he will see the condominium sold at auction.

title: Miami Sets Back Irish, 37-15
description: Jim Kelly connected on 17 of 26 passes for 264 yards and two touchdowns today as Miami of Florida defeated Notre Dame, 37-15, and gave the Irish their first losing season in 18 years.

title: NEW YORK EXPECTS TO EXPAND PRISONS DESPITE BOND VOTE
description: Despite the defeat of the $500 million prison bond issue on Nov. 3, New York State prison officials say they still expect to have about 2,600 new inmate beds available by midsummer.

title: Revised 'Little Me' Will Open Jan. 21
description: A new version of ''Little Me,'' a musical comedy by Neil Simon based on the novel by Patrick Dennis, will start previews Dec. 26 at the Eugene O'Neill Theater and open Jan. 21.

title: De Gustibus; TURKEY SOUP: A CHALLENGE AND AN OPPORTUNITY
description: Long ago I was accused of being the sort of person who appears to be doing one thing while really doing something else. If ever there is a time when I would have to plead guilty to that charge, it is at Thanksgiving. Anyone watching me in the kitchen Thursday would have thought that my primary concern was the big meal of the day. In reality, what I was looking forward to while stuffing, basting and carving is the Saturday after Thanksgiving, when I will be alone with the carcass.

title: The Talk of Clear Lake
description: About 30 yards from the lake shore, almost beneath the municipal water tower, the city has just finished drilling a 500-foot well. It is the object of more than a little controversy.

title: Columbia 70, Brooklyn 52
description: Darren Burnett's game-high 17 points paced Columbia to the victory at Levien Gym. Brooklyn took an early 6-0 lead, but the Lions responded with 14 straight points. Columbia coasted from there, building a 29-14 gap before taking a 36-24 halftime lead.

title: Video Shipments Up
description: Japan exported 309,600 video cassette recorders to the United States last month, up 177 percent from a year earlier, officials reported today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Thursday about human genetics and depression incorrectly identified the professional affiliation of the researchers involved. Dr. Low- ell R. Weitkamp and Sally Guttormsen are at the University of Rochester Medical School. Dr. Harvey C. Stanc- er, Emmanuel Persad and Christine Flood are affiliated with the Clarke In- stitute of Psychiatry at the University of Toronto.

title: Todd Is Set For Start Tomorrow
description: When Richard Todd was ready to return to practice this afternoon as the No.1 quarterback of the Jets, Pat Ryan, his backup, simply handed him the ball. ''I just took over while he was getting ready,'' Ryan said in his laconic Oklahoma drawl.

title: Dance and Music on L.I.
description: Edward Villella and Christopher Keene will give children insight into the composition of classical dance and music during the Philharmonic Young Persons Concert at Huntington High School tomorrow at 1:30 P.M. The former New York City Ballet star, who will not dance on this occasion, and the conductor will provide commentary while dancers of the Eglevsky Ballet, joined by the Long Island Philharmonic, perform selections from Tchaikovsky's ''Nutcracker Suite'' and Vaughn Williams's ''Fantasies.'' Admission, $5. For ticket and travel information, call (516) 224-5420.

title: Around the Nation; Michigan Rejects Plan To Ship Nuclear Waste
description: Michigan officials have rejected a request by an Atlanta company to ship nuclear wastes through the state from Sault Ste. Marie to the Ohio border, the Booth News Service reported this week.

title: 12 CONVICTED OF BRIBERY INCLUDE 4 AT ITT-AUSTRIA
description: Austria's biggest postwar bribery trial ended today with the conviction of all 12 defendants. They included four top executives of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's Austrian subsidiary.

title: WHITE SOX GET KEMP FOR LEMON
description: The Chicago White Sox acquired Steve Kemp from the Detroit Tigers for Chet Lemon yesterday in a trade of outfielders that gave each team the kind of hitter it sought, drastically reduced the Tiger payroll and most likely reduced the number of teams interested in Reggie Jackson.

title: Notes on People; Convicted Politician Seeks Undertaker's License
description: Having served a seven-month term for his role in a payroll kickback scheme involving $66,000, Charles C. Diggs Jr., who had to resign as a United States Representative from Michigan, is trying to go back to his old calling as an undertaker.

title: Stability in Short-Term Rates; Some Bills Rise Slightly
description: Short-term interest rates were unchanged to slightly higher in very quiet trading yesterday, while bond prices rose slightly. Federal Reserve money supply and banking data usually released on Friday afternoon will be published on Monday. Most analysts are predicting that the Fed will announce a modest decline of about $1 billion in the M-1B measure of the money supply.

title: Around the Nation; U.S. Reports 78% Decline In Measles Cases in 1981
description: Through the first 44 weeks of 1981, the number of measles cases reported in the United States was down 78 percent from the same period in 1980, the national Centers for Disease Control reported today.

title: Taming the Wolf at the City Door
description: Once again the State Comptroller and the Financial Control Board have sounded alarms about a budgetary wolf at the city's gates. Mayor Koch, an early scoffer, now recognizes that his promises of improved services may not survive. Can he tame 1982's fiscal wolf? Only if he changes tactics.

title: DEADLINE IS SET ON PLAN TO AID HOMELESS MEN
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday ordered New York City to provide on Tuesday a comprehensive plan detailing how it would meet increased demands for sheltering homeless men this winter while complying with a consent decree under which the city and state agreed to improve conditions in the shelters and set standards of capacity.

title: BLACKS IN SAN DIEGO DIVIDED OVER NOMINEE TO CIVIL RIGHTS POST
description: Clarence M. Pendleton, president of the San Diego chapter of the National Urban League, addressed the City Council recently on the hotly disputed subject of where the Navy should build a new military hospital in San Diego: on a graveyard in a black neighborhood where some blacks thought a hospital would bring jobs and businesses, or in Balboa Park, a choice favored by Edwin Meese 3d, who is President Reagan's counselor and is sometimes described as Mr. Pendleton's political mentor.

title: Around the Nation; Gas Fumes Kill Family Living in Converted Bus
description: Five members of a family living in a converted school bus suffocated when a space heater consumed all the oxygen in the vehicle, the authorities said today.

title: Sports People; Suit Against Cards
description: Eugenia Cain, widow of the pro football player J.V. Cain, has filed a wrongful-death suit against the St. Louis Cardinals, their physician and their trainer. Cain, a 28-year-old tight end, died of a heart attack in training camp two and a half years ago, and the suit charges that the Cardinals and their trainer, John Omohundro, allowed him to play knowing he had a damaged heart. Mrs. Cain said that the damage was revealed by tests administered by Dr. Bernard Garfinkle, the team physician, eight days before her husband's death. Despite these tests, she said, the team continued to tell Cain that he was in good health ...Ed Siminoni, who was formerly Baltimore's leading tackler but who has been beset by a collarbone injury while the Colts have lost 11 straight, was finally placed on the injured-reserve list.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 39. 1. In a budget impasse with Congress, President Reagan vetoed a spending bill to keep the Government operating and ordered that ''nonessential'' Federal employees be sent home and that many Government services be curtailed. The disruption was temporary because Congress agreed to the President's request for a three-week extension of current spending levels.

title: Around the Nation; Landlord in California Loses in Eviction Case
description: A tenant cannot be evicted for reporting a landlord's crime to the police, the California Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Poland Eyes the Real World
description: One day Poland will have to return to the real economic world and live more or less within its means. When that happens, today's haphazard hardships will be superseded by planned austerity. Sacrifices will have to be organized and some authority will have to apportion them. The Poles know this. So do their fretful neighbors in the Soviet Union. And so do their patrons in Western banks.

title: U.S. AIDE OPTIMISTIC ON WEAPONS TALKS
description: Paul H. Nitze, the chief United States arms negotiator, said today that there were ''prospects for reaching a fair, equitable and verifiable'' agreement with the Soviet Union in the talks that will open here Monday on the reduction of nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: No Headline
description: Around the World; Round-the-Clock Curfew In Effect in Seychelles

title: New York; TRASHING OLD PEOPLE (1)
description: Albert F. Arroyo worked for nearly 30 years in Bethlehem Steel's accounting department at 25 Broadway before retiring at age 62 in 1978 to live on his modest Social Security check and a small pension. His home for the last quarter-century has been Hutton Hall, a onceelegant eight-story apartment house that, like many others in the city, particularly on the Upper West Side, was converted into an S.R.O. (single-room occupancy) hotel.

title: Philippines Plant
description: United Coconut Oil Mills is likely to choose Lurgi of West Germany as its partner in a chemical project costing $500 million, sources close to the negotiations said.

title: More Chinese Cotton
description: China's 1981 cotton harvest will rise to three million tons, but imports are likely to hold steady, Western agricultural analysts said today.

title: Susan A. Snorf Bride Of James E. Lansbury
description: At the Carmel (Calif.) Presbyterian Church yesterday Susan Alice Snorf, daughter of Dr. Charles Snorf and Mrs. Milton Bialek, both of Carmel, was married to James Edgar Lansbury, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Lansbury of New York.

title: Patents; Elastic Writing Material Adds to Typing on Page
description: Elastic writing material will enable a typist to squeeze more typing onto a single page.

title: WHAT'S GOOD FOR G.M.
description: My father sold Chevrolets. My brother and I were trained to spit when we saw a Ford, and the arrival of each year's Chevrolet was an event that was second only to Christmas in our family. We had a new Chevy hidden in our garage and an ample supply of balloons and masks to pass out to friends. Down at car lot there would be entertainment.

title: Mrs. Lloyd 2-Set Victor Over Miss Goolagong
description: Chris Evert Lloyd defeated Evonne Goolagong Cawley of Australia, 6-2, 6-0, today in the quarterfinals of the $147,250 New South Wales women's open tennis tournament.

title: MISGUIDED FOES OF WARTIME MEDICAL READINESS
description: To the Editor:

title: First Black Is Selected As Little Rock Mayor
description: Charles Bussey, a former court investigator, has been selected as Little Rock's first black Mayor. The city's Board of Directors elected the 62-year-old Mr. Bussey in an unexpected move Wednesday night.

title: INTERNATIONAL HARVESTER SAYS ITS LOSS ROSE BY 70% IN 1981
description: The International Harvester Company, the No.1 maker of farm and construction equipment, reported yesterday that it lost $635.7 million on its regular business operations in the year ended Oct. 31, nearly 70 percent more than a year earlier.

title: MAX EUWE, EX-CHESS CHAMPION, LED THE GAME'S WORLD FEDERATION
description: Dr. Max Euwe, the world chess champion from 1935 to 1937 and former president of the Netherlands-based International Chess Federation, died of a heart attack Thursday at a hospital in Amsterdam where he had been recovering from major surgery. He was 80 years old.

title: ST. JOHN'S, FORDHAM GAIN LAPCHICK FINAL
description: A strong second half carried St. John's to a 75-55 victory over Xavier of Ohio in its basketball opener last night and into the final of the Joe Lapchick Memorial tournament for the seventh straight year.

title: Ainge Signs With the Celtics
description: Danny Ainge, saying that ''I'm a better basketball player than a baseball player,'' officially switched careers today and signed a multiyear contract with the Boston Celtics to play professional basketball.

title: Patents; A 3d Patent For Cancer Treatment
description: WASHINGTON A YOUNG heart surgeon will receive the third in his series of patents on cancer treatment next week. An organization named Gordon Laboratories is being formed to develop equipment and arrange for early general use of the treatment in hospitals.

title: Patents; Three New Patents Are Granted Xerox
description: The Xerox Corporation, Stamford, Conn., leader in the copying field, received three patents this week and published an offer to license several thousand others.

title: LOTTE LENYA, SINGER-ACTRESS IN U.S. AND GERMANY, IS DEAD
description: Lotte Lenya, a star of the German and American stage and films who championed the music of her husband, Kurt Weill, died in the Manhattan apartment of a friend last evening. She was 83 years old.

title: BUDGET ACCORD ELUDES COMMON MARKET
description: The leaders of the 10 Common Market nations adjourned their two-day conference here tonight without any agreement on a solution to their crucial budget problem.

title: Celanese Canada To Share Plant
description: An agreement has been reached between Celanese Canada Inc., the Celanese Corporation and PanCanadian Petroleum Ltd. to share interest in a $255 million methanol unit.

title: CITY IS INCREASING AID TO CULTURAL INSTITUTIONS
description: New York's support for cultural institutions increased by about 20 percent in fiscal 1981, and renewed efforts will be made to expand aid for the arts in the next budget, according to John C. Lankenau, chairman of the 21-member Commission for Cultural Affairs. In many cases, the money filled voids left by the Reagan Administration's cutbacks in jobs under the Comprehensive Employment Training Act.

title: SCHWEICKER FIRM ON TALKS ON AGING
description: The Reagan Administration ruled today that delegates to the White House Conference on Aging next week would not be allowed to vote separately on major proposals coming out of the meetings.

title: POLITBURO TELLS POLAND TO PASS ANTISTRIKE LAW
description: Poland's Prime Minister and Communist Party leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, said today that the Politburo had instructed the Government to seek legislation banning strikes. He told the party's policy-making Central Committee that the move was needed because of the mounting economic, political and social crisis.

title: Pitt vs. Penn State Brings Bad Feeling
description: Tacked high on the walls of the blue-carpeted Pitt locker room are three recent quotes from Penn State sources viewing the Panthers' perfect record this season as one achieved against mediocre opposition.

title: Hawks 114, Pistons 112
description: Dan Roundfield scored 27 points and grabbed 15 rebounds to lead Atlanta.

title: Your Money; A Tax Assist For Merit Gifts
description: THE new tax law has given the old custom of merit awards a lift, and many workers may receive unexpected holiday presents from their employers as a result.

title: 'DRAMATIC' REVIVAL OF PROTESTANTISM SEEN IN CHINA
description: The Protestant church in China is experiencing a revival after its suppression during the Cultural Revolution, according to a delegation of American Protestants that has been visiting here for two and a half weeks.

title: Nuggets 123, Kings 115
description: Denver's Alex English scored 34 points, including 14 in the third quarter.Denver rallied from a 22-point second-quarter deficit and did not overtake Kansas City until Dan Issel's basket with 2:51 left in the game.The Nuggets outscored the Kings, 9-1, in the last three minutes to seal the victory.

title: CHAPTER 11 PETITION IS FILED BY SAMBO'S
description: Sambo's Restaurants Inc., the financially ailing food chain, said yesterday that it had filed a voluntary petition under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in the United States District Court in Los Angeles.

title: Consumer Saturday; AD CLAIMS: HOW CAN YOU JUDGE?
description: WASHINGTON ''C ONSUMERS are not as gullible as many people, as many regulators tend to think they are,'' said James C. Miller 3d recently.
