Mr. Miller, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, was defending his suggestion that it may not be in the best financial interests of advertisers and, indirectly, consumers to require companies to prepare costly reports substantiating advertising claims before making them.

title: Portugal Cuts Expenditures
description: Portugal's Government clamped down today on spending in an effort to contain its budget deficit.

title: CITY MULLS TAKING OVER MADISON SQUARE GARDEN
description: The Koch administration is considering taking over Madison Square Garden or providing some form of major subsidy as a means of keeping the Knicks and Rangers in the city, officials reported yesterday.

title: McEnroe Routs Vilas, Will Face Lendl in Final
description: John McEnroe routed Guillermo Vilas of Argentina tonight, 6-2, 6-2, in a third-round match and qualified for the final of the $350,000 Master Brooklyn chewing gum indoor tennis tournament.

title: Around the World; One Killed and 4 Hurt In a Bombing in Belfast
description: A bomb exploded near the center of Belfast early today, killing a police officer and wounding three other officers and a civilian, the police said.

title: (BODY) BUILDING AN EMPIRE
description: When Joe Weider first discovered body building, he recalls being the skinny kid sick of having sand kicked in his face who sent away for the Charles Atlas development guide.

title: Patents; Determining the Danger Of Chemicals to Genes
description: A process to determine whether chemicals are dangerous to the genetic function of human cells was patented this week for the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Mass.

title: Steubenville Plant Laying Off 650
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation will lay off 650 workers at its Steubenville plant on Sunday for one week.

title: Going Out Guide
description: CHILDREN'S THEATER

title: KNICKS TROUNCE CAVALIERS AS RICHARDSON SCORES 33
description: The Knicks tonight routed a Cleveland Cavalier team that is still having problems despite an offseason face changing by Ted Stepien, the owner, who signed three free agents and traded for a point guard.

title: Briefing
description: W HATEVER else it settled, or didn't settle, about fiscal probity or political power, last Monday's semi-shutdown of the Federal Government answered a question that has been around since the founding of the Republic: The Vice President is essential.

title: BONN PANEL URGES MORE MILITARY CUTS
description: A West German parliamentary committee has proposed further cuts in the 1982 military budget, the second round of reductions within a month.

title: Money Data Delayed
description: Because of the Thanksgiving Day holiday, the Federal Reserve Board did not issue money supply figures yesterday. The figures will be released Monday.

title: IF THE CITY MUST HAVE MORE OFFICE BUILDINGS
description: To the Editor:

title: 76ers 124, Pacers 112
description: INDIANAPOLIS (AP) - Andrew Toney, a reserve guard, scored 33 points as Philadelphia defeated Indiana in overtime.he Pacers rallied after trailing by 10 points with 9:57 left.

title: HEADED FOR LIVING ROOMS IN CONNECTICUT
description: Thousands of Christmas trees are loaded onto a truck at a tree farm in Norridgewock, Me. The truck and its load were destined for Connecticut.

title: UTILITY ASKS RISE IN PRIVATE RATES FOR CONNECTICUT
description: Northeast Utilities today proposed to raise home electric rates 17 to 20 percent as part of a program of increases to raise its annual revenues by $186 million.

title: News Analysis
description: After half a century, the mold of British politics has been broken. That conclusion emerged inescapably today from the all but incredible by-election victory scored Thursday at Crosby, in the Liverpool suburbs, by the five-month-old alliance of the Social Democratic and Liberal Parties. Overturning a seemingly inv lnerable Conservative majority of 19,272 at the last general election, Shirley Williams won by 5,289 votes to become the first Social Democrat elected to the House of Commons under the party's own banner. An Awesome Demonstration

title: Around the World; Sakharov's Fast Is Said To Affect Heart Problem
description: The protest fast started by Andrei D. Sakharov is aggravating his chronic heart ailment, his daughter-inlaw, Yelizaveta Alekseyeva, said today.

title: AGENCY VOTES PLAN FOR AUTOMATIC TAX ABATEMENT
description: A New York City agency has voted to designate part of the Times Square area and economically stricken sections in all five boroughs for automatic real-estate tax abatements.

title: Agreement, in Truth, About Guns
description: Washington is preparing for another battle over gun control: antigun forces are shaping up behind several House and Senate proposals that would put more muscle in Federal gun laws, while the gun lobby is marshaling troops for a ''reform'' bill to weaken them. Before the contest begins in earnest, both sides would do well to look at an article earlier this year in the Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science.

title: PLEADING GUILTY
description: I am perplexed by the absence of public discussion about a constitutional amendment that is obviously needed to restore our national economy and that would have the additional virtues of simplicity and noncontroversiality. I, of course, refer to the importance of deleting the bizarre, archaic provision in Article I, Section 9, which reads: ''No title of nobility shall be granted by the United States.''

title: Chinese See A Record '81 Harvest
description: Despite flood and drought, China is on target for a record 1981 harvest that will probably cause a reduction in grain imports next year, Western agricultural analysts said today.

title: Hart Industries Seeks to Dissolve
description: Hart Industries, the troubled discount long-distance telephone service, has filed a petition with Federal Bankruptcy Court in Miami asking for permission to voluntarily dissolve.

title: U.S. AND LIBYA: ARE THE VIEWS IN BOTH DIRECTIONS DISTORTED?
description: There is a vision of America on the sidewalks here: A death's-head is cloaked in the Stars and Stripes, arms emerge from the flag, brandishing a scythe-like dagger and a bomb. Another wall poster displays a creature that is half-rodent, half-reptile, strangled by an Arab hand.

title: LEARNING HOW TO PLAY SANTA AT MACY'S
description: Macy's, like most other businesses, has a sharp eye on costs these days, but one would not know it from Santaland. According to its records, Macy's has had a Santa at Herald Square as far back as World War I and possibly since the store's opening in 1902. This year at least 140 people are staffing the department store's eighth-floor Santaland, and visions of 375,000 visitors a day dance in their heads.

title: Suns 11, Bulls 107
description: PHOENIX (AP) - Phoenix rallied late in the final quarter, led by Dennis Johnson and Alvin Adams, to gain its third straight victory.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 47. 1. A temporary disruption foiled the plans of these sightseers, who had hoped to visit the Statue of Liberty, and of Vice President Bush, who had expected to visit New York City. What was the disruption, and why was it only temporary?

title: New Bacteria May Be Used To Make Toxic Herbicide Safe
description: Scientists have developed bacteria that they say can clean up land contaminated by Agent Orange, the powerful weed killer used in the Vietnam War, and other herbicides.

title: BONN LETS BIG STEEL PRODUCERS TALK OF COMBINING OPERATIONS
description: In the West German steel industry, history seems to be trying to repeat itself. In 1926 several of Germany's biggest steelmakers, hard-pressed by the collapse of the German economy after World War I, banded together in a cartel. It survived until the Allies dismembered it after World War II.

title: UNCAPPING THE TOP
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: David Thompson of the Denver Nuggets, the star guard who has been troubled with back problems, was put on the injured list. ... Danny White, the Dallas quarterback whose ribs were badly bruised early in the 10-9 squeaker won by the Cowboys from Chicago Thursday night, underwent a physical examination and will be listed as ''questionable'' for the Cowboys' game against Baltimore a week from tomorrow... Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina withdrew from the roundrobin tennis tournament in Milan because of pain in his right foot. He plans to rest in Miami before resuming training for the Davis Cup final against the United States Dec. 11-13 in Cincinnati...In Brisbane, Australia, the American light-heavyweight Alvaro (Yacqui) Lopez moved closer to a chance for the world championship with a third-round knockout of Tony Mundine of Australia.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1981
description: International The makeup of the Sinai peace force may not be decided at a special meeting of the Israeli Cabinet tomorrow. Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir left open the possibility that a decision on participation by Britain, France, Italy and the Netherlands may be postponed. Prime Minister Menachem Begin has expressed opposition to their participation because of their support for positions that Israel views as pro-Palestinian. (Page 1, Col. 6) The perception of the Libyan regime of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi held by the Reagan Administration is deliberately oversimplified, in the view of some of America's West European allies. They say that the Qaddafi regime is more complex and probably less dangerous than Washington will acknowledge, and that the American position could damage Western economic interests in Libyan oil and propel Libya closer toward Moscow. (1:5-6.) A ban against strikes in Poland is being sought by the Communist Party leadership. Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Prime Minister and party leader, said that the economy and severe food shortages were worsening primarily because farmers were staging demonstrations and sit-ins and withholding agricultural products to protest low wholesale prices. (1:5.)

title: Robert Philipp, 86, Portraitist And Instructor of Painting
description: Robert Philipp, a painter who was an instructor at the Art Students League for 33 years, died from complications after a heart attack Sunday in Roosevelt Hospital .

title: Observer; BIG OIL, YOU'VE LOST ME
description: Do you remember when you used to go driving around the country, and you'd get lost, and all you had to do was pull over to the side and consult your road map? They used to give you those maps free at the filling station. They don't do that anymore, at least not anywhere along the 500 miles of Eastern highways where I've been lost all week.

title: ROCK: ROD STEWART AND NEW BAND
description: Rod Stewart, who was at Madison Square Garden on Thursday and Friday, is one of rock's more durable talents. He is both a gifted songwriter and a first-rate interpreter of other writers' material, a rarity in an age that places singer-songwriters on a pedestal and dismisses interpretive singers as second-rate. His most distinctive calling card is his plaintive, burr-edged and widely imitated voice, but he has also developed an original style for his band that revolves around a heavy bottom and a front-line of three guitarists and has remained constant despite changes in band personnel.

title: A Bus-Truck Collision in Chile Kills 32 and Injures 10 Others
description: A truck carrying newsprint collided with a passenger bus today, killing 32 people and injuring 10 others on the Pan American Highway.

title: Seton Hall 91 St. Anselm's 68
description: Mike Ingram scored 23 points, and Danny Callandrillo 17 in leading the Pirates over the New Hampshire college. The victory before 2,000 home-court fans in the Pirates' marked the debut of their new coach, Haddy Mahon. He replaced Bill Raftery, who resigned just before the season.

title: Around the World; 4 Bombings in Teheran Kill 2 and Wound 15
description: Four bombs exploded on Teheran's main shopping street today, killing at least 2 people and wounding 15. It was the second bomb attack this week in the Iranian capital.

title: WINTER OUTLOOK: COLDER IN THE EAST
description: The winter will be colder than normal east of the Mississippi River and warmer than normal west of the Rocky Mountains, the National Weather Service said today.

title: Tate Scores Knockout At 2:25 of First Round
description: John Tate, the former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, knocked out Chuck Gardner at 2:25 of the first round tonight.

title: Venezuelan Iron Ore
description: Iron ore production in Venezuela in the first nine months of this year totaled 11,488.673 metric tons, the Ministry of Energy and Mines reported today. Production over the final three months of the year has yet to be calculated to determine if 1981 output will equal the 1980 total of 16,112,564 metric tons. Production that year reached 24,771,750 metric tons but has slipped sharply since.

title: Books of The Times Poetry's Backdoor
description: WILLIAM CARLOS WILLIAMS: A NEW WORLD NAKED. By Paul Mariani. Il- lustrated. 874 pages. McGraw-Hill. $24.95.

title: EVIDENCE OF TAMPERING FOUND IN FRUIT FLY TRAPS
description: California's troubled war against the tenacious Mediterranean fruit fly now appears to be plagued by a perverse new enemy, a so-called ''Johnny Medfly,'' a person who clandestinely flips dead flies into detection traps as false evidence of infestation.

title: Sports of The Times; A Biship's View of Football
description: WHEN 14-year-old Terrence Robinson died of head injuries from football last September, Bishop Walter F. Sullivan was stunned to learn the boy had been playing for a parish team.

title: DEBTORS' HEAVEN
description: To the Editor:

title: Maryland 49, St. Peter's 42
description: Despite scoring 17 of the first 19 points, Maryland had to hang on to win. Led by Herman Veal's 13 points and 11 from Jeff Adkins, the Terps squandered a 37-25 halftime lead when they were outscored, 17-12, in the second half. William Brown led the Peacocks with 15 points.

title: Warriors 113, Bucks 96
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Lloyd Free scored 28 points and Joe Barry Carroll had 23 to lead Golden State. Junior Bridgeman, who had missed five games with a strained knee, and Sidney Moncrief scored 19 points apiece for Milwaukee, which lost for the first time at home in seven games.

title: FORT DRUM IS NOWHERE NEAR SIBERIA
description: To the Editor:

title: D'AMATO IS NAMED BY ABSCAM FIGURE
description: Government tape recordings were played yesterday in which a convicted businessman and his associate assert that in 1979 Alfonse M. D'Amato was prepared to influence grants for development rights on public land on Long Island in return for ''contributions.''

title: North Stars 5, Jets 5
description: WINNIPEG (AP) - Dino Ciccarelli's third goal of the game, at 15:24 of the final period, gave Minnesota the tie.

title: Notes on People; Rose Kennedy, Out of Hospital, Attends Mass
description: When the adjective ''indomitable'' is used in relation to Rose Kennedy, it measures up to its full meaning.

title: SOUNDS OF SUCCESS AT WYNY
description: As recently as four years ago, it was an embarrassment. It was then a fully automated radio station. The machinery, though, had some bugs. The station was known to play as many as six songs simultaneously. (''All the hits at the same time,'' as its current program director puts it.)

title: KOCH SEEKS RIGHT TO NAME TRANSIT UNIT CHIEF
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he was seeking legislation to give him the power to hire and to dismiss the head of the city's Transit Authority, as the dispute grew over who should manage New York City's mass-transit system.

title: GAIN 3D IN ROW
description: The stock market's ''interest-rate rally'' continued for a third straight session yesterday amid sharply curtailed trading after the Thanksgiving Day holiday. Among individual issues, Merck, Paine Webber and E.F. Hutton showed gains of 2 points or more.

title: U.C.L.A.  Is Upset; Iona Tops Buckeyes
description: Fred Roberts scored 23 points and Steve Trumbo added 22 to give Brigham Young a 79-75 victory over U.C.L.A. tonight.

title: Notes on People; Beatles on the Map
description: As of yesterday, the city of Liverpool, in northern England, had thoroughfares named for the four men who did the most to bring the city to worldwide attention - the Beatles.

title: Korolev Takes Gymnastic Title
description: Yuri Korolev of the Soviet Union, scoring 9.95 on the pommel horse, overtook his compatriot Bogdan Makuc on the final exercise tonight to capture the men's individual combined title at the 21st world gymnastics championships. The Soviet Union had already won the men's and women's team titles.

title: HOW PUBLIC INTEREST RESEARCH RAISES FUNDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Honduran Battle Kills Policeman and Leftist
description: A Honduran policeman and a suspected leftist guerrilla were killed today in a gun battle, two days before the country votes in its first general election in 10 years.

title: Sports People; New Problems for Bear
description: On the threshold of his record 315th career football victory, Coach Bear Bryant of Alabama continues to have disciplinary problems with his players. Now he has been led to dismiss Bob Cayavec, an all-Southeastern Conference offensive tackle, and Gary Bramblett, a guard, before the game today with the Crimson Tide's cross-state rival, Auburn.

title: Canucks 6, Rockies 3
description: DENVER (UPI) - Ron Delorme of Vancouver scored two goals against his former Colorado teammates. Delorme scored his first goal on a short rebound at 18 minutes 56 seconds of the first period to make the score 3-1.

title: SOCIAL WORK GROWTH IS REPORTED SLOWED BY CUTS IN SPENDING
description: The Columbia Graduate School of Social Work says that it plans to lower its enrollment from 600 students to 500 next year. The move is one of many signs that the social-work profession, if not declining, is at least beginning to stabilize after the growth years of the late 1960's and early 70's.

title: Meat Output Off in October
description: Commercial meat production last month totaled 3.43 million pounds, down 4 percent from October 1980, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: BEGIN IN 'SATISFACTORY' CONDITION
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin was described by his doctors today as being in ''very satisfactory'' condition after he slipped in the bathroom of his Jerusalem home Thursday and broke his upper left thigh near the hip joint. The 68-year-old Mr. Begin is expected to be hospitalized for two weeks.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Atco Ltd. and Canadian Utilities Ltd., of which Atco owns 58 percent, have approved a proposal under which Atco would sell its oil and gas assets to Canadian Utilities for about $50 million (Canadian) of the common shares of Canadian Utilities.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There will be approximately a trillion and a half dollars spent on defense in the next five years - a trillion and a half, can you imagine? Everybody over in Congress wants some increased emphasis and oversight by the G.A.O. in that area, including the people who are supporting defense.'' -Charles A. Bowsher, Comptroller General. (10:4.)

title: Around the World; Turkish Police Chief Jailed for Using Torture
description: A police chief was sentenced today to a 14-year prison term for his role in the death by torture of a leftist militant who had been caught putting up posters.

title: F.A.A. IS ACCUSED OF 'LACK OF CANDOR'
description: Representative Patricia Schroeder contends that the Federal Aviation Administration is not cooperating with an investigation into charges that trainees' test scores have been upgraded in a rush to replace the 11,500 air traffic controllers dismissed in August for an illegal strike.

title: Index; International
description: Begin, in good condition, to pre- side over Cabinet meeting 2 U.S. arms negotiator says there are 'prospects' for an accord 3 Bonn panel proposes more cuts in defense budget 3 Common Market meeting ends without budget solution 3 Around the World 4 China has plan to end deadlocked race for Secretary General 5 'Big present' to Allen is reported by Japanese newspaper 6 South African police arrest 14 black union leaders 7 Government/Politics Six protesters camped near the White House, are arrested 8 Separate voting ruled out for White House parley on aging 10 Blacks in San Diego divided on nominee to rights post 10 City board to create real estate tax abatement areas 27 Washington Talk General Accounting Office faces new challenges 10 Briefing 10 General Around the Nation 8 The Talk of Clear Lake, Iowa 8 One person rescued from found- ered cargo ship off Bermuda 9 Inflation and joblessness bring in- crease in foreclosures 16 City given deadline on plan for homeless men 25 Utility seeks increases in home rates in Connecticut 26 Planners predict a big switch to little houses 26 Head of G.O.P. 'security' force in Jersey had been deputized 27 City may take over Madison Square Garden 27 Arts/Entertainment New York's aid for the arts up 20 percent in fiscal '81 11 'Operation Midnight Climax' at the Off Center Theater 11 Rod Stewart in concert at Madi- son Square Garden 12 Alan Kogosowski plays an all- Liszt program 12 Book on William Carlos Williams reviewed 14 Style Consumer Saturday: Judging ad- vertising claims 48 Shopping the city's museums for gifts 48 De Gustibus: The challenge of turkey soup 48 Obituaries Dr. Max Euwe, former chess champion 21 Joseph H. Smith, legal historian at Columbia Law School 21 Features/Notes Going Out Guide 13 Sports People 20 About New York 25 Notes on People 39 Saturday News Quiz 39 Health/Science Popularity of science books is in- creasing 11 New survey estimates job in- juries this year 24 Sports Knicks rout Cavaliers, 116-95, as Richardson scores 33 17 San Antonio Spurs subdue New Jersey Nets, 114-86 17 Ainge signs multiyear contract with Celtics 17 Todd works out, set to start against Colts 20 Charlie Lau's skill raises some salary averages, too 17 Miami triumphs over Notre Dame Irish, 37-15 18 Pitt-Penn State rivalry especially heated this year 18 George Vecsey on a bishop's view of football 19 St. John's and Fordham gain Lap- chick tourney final 19 Tigers trade Kemp to White Sox for Lemon 20 News Analysis R.W. Apple Jr. comments on Britain's by-election 1 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22

title: Satellite Study Due From F.C.C.
description: The staff of the Federal Communications Commission is preparing a position paper on the sale of satellite transponder facilities, a commission official said yesterday, and the commissioners may use it as the basis for a new policy in that controversial field.

title: CHINA SUGGESTS COMPROMISE ON U.N. JOB
description: China has tentatively proposed a compromise to settle the deadlocked race for Secretary General, suggesting that the next five-year term be divided between the incumbent, Kurt Waldheim of Austria, and Foreign Minister Salim A. Salim of Tanzania.

title: Vacant Apartments Now Scarcer in City
description: New York City's apartment vacancy rate has dropped from 2.97 percent in 1978 to 2.13 percent now, according to preliminary results of a survey announced yesterday.

title: BOOKS ON SCIENCE RIDING WAVE OF POPULARITY
description: Fifty-three weeks ago, Carl Sagan's ''Cosmos,'' a book explaining the evolution of the universe, jumped onto The New York Times nonfiction best-seller list, and it has been there ever since. Mr. Sagan owes some of his success as an author to his eminence as a television personality, but the major attribute the astronomer and astrophysicist has going for him as a writer is that he can convey the mysteries of the scientific profession to a public that cannot seem to get enough books about science.

title: Pay Cut Set At Republic Air
description: Republic Airlines, the seventh-largest passenger carrier in the nation, announced that a majority of its union employees would take a 10 percent pay cut for six months as part of the carrier's costcutting program. The employees will also forgo any scheduled pay increases during that period.

title: SUBURBAN PLANNERS SEE SWITCH TO SMALL HOUSES
description: Planning experts say the stagnant housing market in the New York suburbs and the changing complexion of the family structure pose major, far-reaching changes for the types of homes needed in coming years.

title: 3.3 MILLION JOB INJURIES ARE PREDICTED FOR 1981
description: A survey by two Federal agencies indicates that this year workers in the United States will suffer about 3.3 million on-the-job injuries requiring hospital treatment.

title: HEAD OF G.O.P. TASK FORCE WAS MADE JERSEY DEPUTY SHERIFF
description: John A. Kelly, the organizer of the Republican National Ballot Security Task Force, was sworn in as an Essex County deputy sheriff a month before the New Jersey gubernatorial election, the Essex County Prosecutor said yesterday.

title: The Times's Houston Bureau Is Broken Into on Two Nights
description: The New York Times bureau in Houston's Old Cotton Exchange building was burglarized Wednesday and Thursday nights.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1981; Companies
description: International Harvester reported it lost $635.7 million on its regular business operations in the year ended Oct. 31, nearly 70 percent more than a year earlier. The company, the No. 1 maker of farm and construction equipment, cited depressed world markets, high interest costs and industry price discounting. The loss was larger than expected, analysts said, and points to more losses next year. (Page 1.)

title: Circus at Meadowlands
description: For the first time since the early 60's, the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus will go to New Jersey, with appearances through next Tuesday at the Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford.

title: CELTICS 113, BULLETS 100
description: Larry Bird had 24 points as the Boston Celtics scored a 113-100 victory tonight over the Washington Bullets.

title: 6 HELD AS TENTS NEAR WHITE HOUSE ARE TORN DOWN
description: The police dismantled several tents across from the White House today and arrested six persons, ending after one night a planned 100-day campout by protesters of President Reagan's economic policies.

title: Marshall 71, Army 53
description: Three players scored in double figures, and Marshall University shot 58 percent from the field to defeat Army. Marshall made 32 of 55 shots for 58 percent, and shot 62 percent in the second half. Army went 21 for 45 from the floor for 46.7 percent, but the Cadets had 25 turnovers.

title: Oilers 8, Black Hawks 1
description: Wayne Gretzky scored his 29th and 30th goals of the season and assisted on three others as Edmonton extended its unbeaten streak to eight games. In 25 games Gretzky has totaled 60 points, including 31 in his last 10 games.

title: CANADIENS FALL, 5-2, TO CAPITALS' RALLY
description: Chris Valentine and Gaetan Duchesne, two rookies, scored goals three minutes apart to break a 2-2 tie and help the Washington Capitals to a 5-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight.

title: Patents; New Antitumor Agent Derived From Sponges
description: In research financed by the Government, Francis J. Schmitz of Norman, Okla., and four co-inventors have found a new antitumor and antibiotic agent.

title: East German Spy Is Freed
description: An East German spy freed by Denmark has been returned to East Germany by the West Germans. A Bonn Government spokesman said the spy, Jorg Meyer, was returned to East Germany Thursday. Danish political sources said Bonn had asked for Mr. Meyer's release as part of a prisoner exchange involving an East German master spy, Gunter Guillaume.

title: Coutinho Is Drowned; Former Coach of Aztecs
description: Claudio Coutinho, former coach of the Los Angeles Aztecs and the Brazilian all-star soccer team, drowned today while he was fishing underwater near Ipanema Beach, the State Rescue and Salvage Agency said.

title: Salvador Fighting Reported
description: An army drive in northern El Salvador is meeting heavy guerrilla resistance, contradicting Government reports that the drive had wiped out rebel activity in the area, officials said today. The army said earlier this week that 1,000 soldiers backed by artillery had secured the embattled town of Cinquera, 44 miles northeast of the capital, but a local commander said troops were still fighting rebels entrenched only miles away.

title: STAGE: 'OPERATION MIDNIGHT CLIMAX'
description: In ''Operation Midnight Climax'' at the Off Center Theater, the Central Intelligence Agency, or ''the Company,'' as Neall Bell, the playwright, calls it, is up to dirty tricks - spying on citizens, combining sex with surveillance, spiking drinks with LSD and driving innocent people to suicide. Although the 90-minute play has its dry spots, Mr. Bell has worked some interesting variations on a familiar subject, and Thomas Babe has given the work a taut production.

title: LAU'S SKILL IS RAISING SOME SALARY AVERAGES, TOO
description: Back in the 1960's, when he was a reserve major league catcher, Charley Lau once answered a knock at his hotel room door and was greeted by the clamorous sound of a giant Chinese gong that his prankish teammate, Moe Drabowsky, had transferred there from the lobby.

title: Trevino and Aoki Lead
description: Lee Trevino of the United States shot a five-under-par 67 today to gain a share of the lead with Japan's Isao Aoki after the second round of a $277,777 international golf tournament.

title: NETS FALL TO SPURS BY 114-86
description: Coach San Albeck of the Spurs once advised George Gervin, the team's high scorer, that if he wanted to be remembered as a truly great player, he would have to become a complete player.

title: No Headline
description: Mobil, U.S. Steel Argue Over Marathon

title: NEW STUDY BEGUN ON DC-10 AIRLINER
description: Federal safety experts are conducting an intensive new study of the DC-10 airliner as a result of an engine breakup that caused dangerous damage to wing devices on an Air Florida jet in Miami. In that incident, the crew safely stopped the takeoff run.

title: Canada Plan: Gas for Japan
description: British Columbia officials are considering a $2.3 billion (Canadian) proposal from a consortium of three companies to export surplus natural gas to Japan.

title: MANKIND'S OLDEST SHRINE DISCOVERED IN SPAIN
description: American and Spanish scientists have reported finding the earliest intact religious sanctuary from the early Stone Age at El Juyo Cave, an archeological site in northern Spain near the seaport city of Santander.

title: PIANO: ALL-LISZT BY ALAN KOGOSOWSKI
description: The principal danger for the pianist contemplating an all-Liszt recital is not so much that he may expose his weaknesses; only the most foolhardly performer plunges into Liszt's music without having the technique and velocity to render it at least with tolerable efficacy. The risk is much more that not enough of Liszt will be exposed.

title: SHOPPING THE CITY'S MUSEUMS FOR GIFTS
description: The gift shops in museums around town are a rich mine of unusual holiday presents. Although some confine themselves to books, cards and posters, many of them are eclectic bazaars full of things one might never find elsewhere, or would have to shop all over town for.

title: S. C. Smith Dies at 87; Headed U.S. Bar Unit
description: Sylvester C. Smith Jr., a former president of the American Bar Association and retired general counsel for the Prudential Insurance Company, died Thursday at the Hospital Center in Orange, N. J. He was 87 years old and a resident of West Orange.

title: SAN JUAN AREA BLACKED OUT BY BLASTS AT POWER STATIONS
description: San Juan's main tourist area, El Condado, was left without electricity Friday night after two power installations exploded and burned in what was believed to be a terrorist attack.

title: Morgan State 64, City College 42
description: Morgan State scored the first 5 points and never trailed at the City College gym. After trailing by as many as 21 points, City College narrowed the deficit to 9 in the second half before Morgan State put the game out of reach. Michael Richardson led City College with 16 points.

title: TIN PRICE MOVES JOLT MARKET
description: The London Metal Exchange was jolted Thursday when agents acting on behalf of an unidentified buyer bought tin for immediate delivery and started selling contracts to deliver it in three months.

title: EAST AFRICA SEEKING INDIA'S TECHNOLOGY
description: Confronted with the escalating costs of importing Western technology and technicians, Kenya and other East African countries are increasingly turning to India for assistance.

title: California Edison Buys Wind Power
description: The first contract to purchase electric energy generated by wind power from an independent supplier was announced by the Southern California Edison Company.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 15.75-16.00.** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.+ Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Letter: On Housing Vouchers Why Give Up a Good Rent Aid Plan?
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes on People; Jersey Pupils to Brighten White House Holiday
description: Five years ago on a visit to Williamsburg, Va., Thomas Levin, a teacher at Cape May (N.J.) Elementary School, saw something that gave him an idea - Christmas wreaths fashioned from tiny seashells glued to cardboard backings.

title: Salmonellosis Linked With Precooked Beef
description: Five outbreaks of the intestinal disorder salmonellosis associated with precooked roast beef have been reported in the Northeastern United States since August, the national Centers for Disease Control reported today.

title: ISRAEL MAY DELAY DECIDING MAKEUP OF THE SINAI FORCE
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel left open the possibility today that his Government might postpone a decision on the participation by four European nations in the Sinai peacekeeping force.

title: Delaware 35, Connecticut 26
description: John Davis scored one touchdown and passed for two more, and Bob Dougherty rushed for 181 yards for Delaware.

title: Bridge: A Westchester Partnership Wins in Blue Ribbon Play
description: Top honors in the blue ribbon pair championship, which ended here last night Thursday at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals, went to a partnership from Westchester County, N.Y., that has burst into prominence this year.

title: Sports People; Walton Deposition
description: Bill Walton, the former center of the Portland Trail Blazers, spent several hours, apparently in a Portland law office, testifying about drug use yesterday, prompting Paul Melodia, his lawyer in a $5.6 million lawsuit, to ask that the deposition be sealed against public disclosure. Judge Charles Crookham of the Multnomah County Circuit Court, indicated reluctance to issue such an order but said he would be willing to consider one if Walton's lawyer offered a written proposal.

title: The Banister Balance
description: I loved the visual appeal of Joseph Paul D'Urso's design for a very small apartment, and have admired his work for years (''Drama on a Small Stage,'' by Suzanne Slesin, Nov. 1). But I hope the new occupants of that apartment don't take a ''night out on the town'' or celebrate New Year's Eve. I'd hate to think of what might happen with a drink or two under their belts if they tried to make it up those narrow, diagonal stairs that are lovely to look at - but have no banister. JOANNE CALLAHAN, Brewster, N.Y.

title: SURVIVOR OF SKYWALK COLLAPSE GOES HOME A DIFFERENT MAN
description: Chuck Hayes, the last hospitalized victim of a hotel skywalk collapse, was sent home to celebrate Thanksgiving there. He says he has been giving thanks ever since he was dug out from beneath tons of steel and concrete that collapsed July 17. killing 113 people.

title: WAS DERAIN A COLLABORATOR?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sluggish Indiana Wins Its Opener, 71-64
description: Ted Kitchel scored 24 points to help Indiana overcame a second-half slump today and defeat Miami of Ohio, 71-64, in the opening game for both teams.

title: DEPARTURE TAXES
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Rodger, S. G. Rooney Are Married
description: Susan Janet Rodger, a clinical nutritionist, and Stephen Gerard Rooney, law clerk to Federal Judge Kevin Thomas Duffy in Manhattan, were married yesterday at the United Church of Rockville Centre, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Gary C. Haase and the Rev. Robert P. Henry.

title: The World in Summary; The Sinai Force Remains in Doubt
description: Israel kept looking a gift horse in the mouth last week, suspecting that it was really a Trojan one. Only last-minute American pressure kept the Begin Government from rejecting an offer by Britain, France, the Netherlands and Italy to contribute to a force that is to patrol Sinai once Israel completes its withdrawal in April.

title: I returned from my sister's wedding to find The New York Times Magazine and Andrew Silk's article on coping with cancer.  Fifteen years ago, doctors at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital told my parents that my sister, then 9 years old, would not survive surgery for the removal of a cancerous tumor on her kidney.  Yesterday, she was a beautiful bride.
description: If my family had known about Andrew and Nancy before the wedding, we could have saved them a piece of cake. MARJORIE SEYMOUR Harrisburg, Pa.

title: S. Mississippi 45, Lamar 14
description: Reggie Collier, the quarterback, ran for two touchdowns for Southern Mississippi.

title: THE COST OF NEGLECTING PUBLIC FACILITIES
description: NOT long ago, I was driving my child to school and noticed two interesting activities taking place: first, the municipal public works crew was raising the manhole covers, which indicated that the street was to be resurfaced, and, second, the water company was fixing a broken watermain. The water had been bubbling up through the street for days.

title: SABOTEURS AND SPIES
description: NORMANDIE TRIANGLE By Justin Scott. 475 pp. New York: Arbor House. $13.95.

title: N.D. St. 24, Puget Sound 10
description: Jeff Willis scored on a 5-yard run and Mark Nellermoe on a 1-yard quarterback sneak in the final three minutes, as North Dakota State-Fargo broke open a 10-10 game. The winner will play Shippensburg.

title: REMEMBERING PEARL HARBOR
description: AT DAWN WE SLEPT The Untold Story of Pearl Harbor. By Gordon W. Prange. In Collaboration With Donald M. Goldstein and Katherine V. Dillon. Illustrated. 873 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Co. $22.95.

title: MANAGING A CREDIT UNION
description: SINCE Peter Seitz took over the management of the Bethpage Federal Credit Union in 1975, its assets have increased from $49 million to $131 million and its membership has almost doubled, despite a slight decrease in the Grumman Corporation's work force.

title: Katherine B. Simons Is Wed
description: Katherine Bailey Simons, daughter of Dr. Elwyn L. Simons of Durham, N.C., and Mrs. M. Fitch Simons of New Haven, was married yesterday to Sean Joseph Egan. The ceremony was performed in the Marquand Chapel of the Yale Divinity School in New Haven by the Rev. Randolph C. Miller, Horace Bushnell Professor Emeritus of the Yale Divinity School.

title: Kentucky 83, Akron 64
description: Derrick Hord of Kentucky scored 28 points, including four straight field goals in the final four minutes. Kentucky got a big lift from Bo Lanter, a reserve guard who entered the game in the second half and scored 8 points.

title: Correction
description: An article last week on chewing tobacco misidentified the company affiliation of Martin Solow. He is president of Durfee & Solow Advertising Inc. Mr. Solow's comments about trends in national sales of chewing tobacco vs. pipe tobacco were erroneously reported as those experienced by Lane Ltd., one of his firm's clients. Test marketing of Lane's Gold Star brand of chewing tobacco has been completed.

title: Wisconsin Starts Well In Hockey Title Defense
description: Wisconsin, the national collegiate hockey champion last season, has established itself as the team to beat this season. The Badgers had a 12-0-1 record going into this weekend's series with Western Michigan. John Newberry, a sophomore center, is the leading scorer with 18 goals, seven on the power play, which Western Michigan scores on 35 percent of the time.

title: The Region in Summary; An On-Again, Off-Again Case
description: In banning topless dancing, the New York Legislature was apparently more concerned with the laws of human nature than those of the state, the state's Court of Appeals decided last week. The court struck down the ban for the second time.

title: THE RIDDLE OF ARMAND HAMMER
description: Edward Jay Epstein is a freelance writer. His most recent book, ''The Diamond Invention,'' an examination of the international diamond cartel, will be published by Simon and Shuster this spring. By Edward Jay Epstein In Moscow, on May 27, l922, Vladimir Lenin, the ailing leader of the Russian Revolution, sent an urgent and secret message to Joseph Stalin, the newly appointed General Secretary of the Communist Party, instructing him and the Politburo to give their ''particular support'' to a young American and his trading venture. Lenin explained: ''This is a small path to the American 'business' world and this path should be made use of in every way.'' The American was a 24-year-old graduate of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University.

title: Manhattan 80, Dowling 68
description: Jim Ward, a reserve guard, scored 20 points to lead Manhattan at Draddy Gymnasium.

title: No Headline
description: McEnroe Is Beaten By Lendl

title: Andrew Silk's Battle With Cancer
description: Andrew Silk's story of his battle to survive cancer is more than a moving personal chronicle of an individual's courage; as he indicated, it is also the story of an increasing number of Americans who have lived through what all had thought of as a death sentence (''The Struggle of Andrew Silk: A Young Man Confronts Cancer,'' Oct. 18).

title: Penguins 5, Red Wings 3
description: PITTSBURGH (AP) - Paul Gardner scored two goals within a span of 41 seconds in the second period to spark the Penguins. With Pittsburgh ahead, 1-0, Gardner scored at 7:30, rebounding a Rick Kehoe shot.

title: PEOPLE NEAR REACTOR GET PILLS
description: DAISY, Tenn., Nov. 28 (UPI) - State officials have begun dispensing vials of potassium iodide pills to about 7,000 families near the Sequoyah nuclear power as a precaution to be used in the event of a nuclear accident.

title: ONE MAN'S FUGU IS ANOTHER'S POISON
description: STEVE LOHR is a correspondent in the Tokyo bureau of The Times. By STEVE LOHR

title: 'DANCE ON THE MUSIC'
description: THE Long Island Philharmonic and the Eglevsky Ballet will join forces this afternoon for the first time in a special children's program, ''We Dance on the Music,'' that is designed to introduce youngsters to the world of dance.

title: Music; SOUNDS THAT USHER IN THE HOLIDAYS
description: SOME of us may still be nibbling leftover Thanksgiving turkey, but Santa Claus and friends will soon be coming to towns all over the county. One can, in fact, begin the holiday listening this afternoon, when Musica Reservata presents a program ''to usher in the Christmas season in the spirit of Saint Francis of Assisi, and to note the 800th anniversary of the birth of the Patron Saint of Peace.''

title: Iowa 84, Northern Illinois 66
description: IOWA CITY (AP) - Steve Carfino and Kevin Boyle led a second-half rally for Iowa that broke open a close game. Iowa struggled early in the game and led by 38-34 at halftime, but outscored Northern Illinois, 12-2, in three and a half minutes early in the second half. Tod Berkenpas, a freshman guard, made eight of nine shots and led Iowa with 16 points,

title: Elizabeth Dugan Married Upstate
description: Elizabeth Dugan, associate director for education and training for the National Republican Congressional Committee in Washington, was married yesterday to John A. Kochevar, manager of public affairs for the Chamber of Commerce of the United States of America in Washington.

title: YELLOW RAIN OVER SOUTHEAST ASIA: 'THE EVIDENCE IS COMPELLING'
description: To the Editor:

title: Arkansas 83, Michigan 72
description: Darrell Walker scored a career-high 25 points, including 6 straight points in the second half to lead Arkansas (1-0).

title: Connecticut Housing; PETS: A DILEMMA FOR CONDOMINIUMS
description: ''No animals of any kind shall be raised, bred or kept in any unit or in the common or limited common areas except that household pets, approved by the board of directors, may be kept in units, provided they are not kept, bred or maintained for any commercial purpose. No pets shall be allowed to create unreasonable nuisance or disturbance. In no event shall any dog be permitted in any of the common areas unless on a leash. Owners must clean up after their pets on each occasion.''

title: PROKOFIEV'S MYSTERY REKINDLES FILM IMAGES
description: Though it has been quite a while since I saw Sergei Eisenstein's films ''Alexander Nevsky'' and ''Ivan the Terrible,'' it took only a few minutes of listening to Leonard Slatkin's recordings of Prokofiev's scores to the films to have their images rush back to me: the blazing eyes of those imposing leaders from the 13th and 16th centuries; the huge crowds - armies and churchgoers - sweeping through the film as if moved by the cunning forces of history itself; the nefarious plotters against the the Russian people - the bronzed warriors, the evil henchmen; the gargantuan shadows projected on castle walls by flaming torches; in ''Nevsky,'' the Teutonic Knights crashing through a sheet of ice that collapses under the weight of armor and lances.

title: New Jersey Guide; VIRTUOSO TO PERFORM
description: Nathan Milstein, the 77-year-old Russian violin virtuoso, will give a recital in Montclair Thursday at 8:30 P.M. The program will nearly duplicate the performance that Mr. Milstein gave at Carnegie Hall earlier this month and for which he received, as always, glowing reviews. As one critic put it:

title: DRUG LINK SUSPECTED
description: Six persons were found shot to death tonight in a fashionable house in southwest Miami that was strewn with automatic weapons, the police said.

title: LOON
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation; Figure in F.B.I. Inquiry Flees Prison With Two
description: Three prisoners, including a key figure in an inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation into the laundering of drug money, escaped from a Federal facility after cutting holes in two chain-link fences, the authorities said today.

title: Long Island Guide; AFRICAN VISITOR
description: Singing of South Africa's racial turmoil, Tony Bird, a singer and songwriter from Malawi in central Africa, will be at My Father's Place in Roslyn at 2 P.M. today. Mr. Bird is appearing in the Guitar Workshop's Sunday Afternoon Concert Series. Tickets are $3.50; for children under 12, $1.50, and the hall is at 19 Bryant Avenue. ALL THAT JAZZ

title: A Brilliant Rendition of a Bird Classic
description: ABBEVILLE Press's new Baby Elephant Folio edition of Audubon's epochal ''Birds of America'' is a brilliant achievement. One of Abbeville's announcements of the book observes that ''although many attempts have been made to recreate the magnificent illustrations of Audubon's Double Elephant Folio, none has ever achieved the level of fidelity or scale that this volume reaches,'' and the claim is utterly justified.

title: Odd Couples Protects the Pros
description: The flak jacket that Richard Todd of the New York Jets wore underneath his jersey to protect a broken rib in the game against Miami last Sunday was made in a drug-rehabilitation center in Houston under the supervision of Byron Donzis.

title: LEVITTOWN DOWNS HEMPSTEAD
description: The quarterback Mike Galvin scored from 3 yards out with 3 minutes 7 seconds left in the third quarter yesterday as Levittown Division defeated Hempstead, 6-0, for the Nassau County Conference III football title at C.W. Post College. In the Conference I championship game Friday night at Hofstra, Massapequa and Sewanhaka played to a scoreless tie.

title: 8 CANDIDATES VIE IN FINNISH VOTING
description: Eight Finnish political parties have nominated candidates for a presidential election in January that is not expected to be settled until political deals are made in the 301-member electoral college.

title: COSMIC GUMDROPS AND MUSICAL GENIUS
description: THE PLAYBOY INTERVIEWS WITH JOHN LENNON AND YOKO ONO Conducted by David Sheff. Edited by G. Barry Golson. Illustrated. 193 pp. New York: Playboy Press. $13.50. By JOE KLEIN

title: Schools in an Oregon District Are to Reopen Despite Blasts
description: Two explosions damaged the entrance to Estacada High School early today, but the officials said schools in the district would reopen Monday.

title: Stamps; A LOOK AT THIS YEAR'S BIGGEST OMNIBUS ISSUE
description: The year cannot draw to a close without acknowledging the biggest omnibus issue of 1981: the outpouring of stamps marking the International Year of Disabled Persons. It was observed with sensitivity and imagination by nations all over the world, with many showing the disabled doing something - not helpless.

title: HIGH SCHOOL SCIENCE NEEDS SPUTNIKING
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY HALL YEARS: A LOOK BACK
description: ONE popular mayoral anecdote on public behavior concerns residents of a poorly paved street. Being human they complained. Being responsive, the mayor paved. The road now being smooth, people speed. The residents, still human, complain. The mayor, still responsive, sends out the radar. The police apprehend the speeders who turn out to be mostly other neighborhood residents who in turn complain about being arrested for driving only slightly over the foolishly low speed limit. Then in the spring all residents together complain about the higher taxes that resulted from paving the road and paying for the radar units.

title: REGENTS SEEK FULLER PROGRAM FOR 4-YEAR-OLDS
description: Oblivious to the untied shoelace trailing from one sneaker, 4-year-old Joey Chaple was down on all fours pushing around a toy pickup truck. It was 2:30 in the afternoon, and Joey had already spent more than five hours at the Woodmere Early Childhood Center.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: POLES IN TORONTO START A PRO-SOLIDARITY PAPER
description: A small group of Polish-Canadians has begun a publishing venture to support the Solidarity labor movement in Poland and possibly give themselves new careers in Canada.

title: Music; BAROQUE MINI-OPERA TO BE STAGED FREE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK AREVIVAl of ''Venus and Adonis'' by John Blow, a rare Baroque masterpiece that is said to be the first English-language opera, will be professionally staged by the Mason Gross School of the Arts of Rutgers University Friday and Saturday.

title: No Headline
description: On behalf of the Anti-Defamation League on Long Island and the 14,000 members of B'nai B'rith, I wish to express disgust at the way in which The New York Times of Nov. 8 gave credence to the arrogant and empty-headed billboard comment of John Higgins of Rocky Point in his evaluation of the Senate vote on the Awacs issue.

title: Food; PREPARATIONS FOR THE LAZY, OR 'GIFTS THAT KEEP GIVING'
description: THE turkey remains are barely out of the refrigerator. As a matter of fact, the carcass probably is still sitting there. Nevertheless, Thanksgiving is over and Christmas will be here long before it should.

title: AFRICAN WILDLIFE
description: To the Editor:

title: I was surprised that Helen Markel did not mention the New York Public Library's picture collection, the largest free circulating picture archive in the world.
description: We have a stock of five million pictures, three million of which, annotated and classified, will be accessible when we move later this year to our new quarters in the Mid-Manhattan Library. The collection is arranged under 15,000 headings and permits the user to make his own selection with no fee. LENORE COWAN Curator The New York Public Library New York City

title: KEEPING AN EYE ON RUSSIA
description: Leslie H. Gelb is The Times's national security correspondent, based in the Washington bureau. By Leslie H. Gelb

title: Deborah Renton to Be Wed
description: Mrs. Harry F. Renton of Jupiter, Fla., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Deborah Anne Renton, to Leonard Thomas La Croce Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. La Croce of Paramus, N.J. Miss Renton is a daughter also of the late Mr. Renton. A February wedding is planned.

title: MOROCCO GIVES UP 2 BASES IN WESTERN SAHARA
description: The Moroccan Army has abandoned two key outposts to guerrillas in the Western Sahara in what appears to be a strategic withdrawal behind a special line of fixed defenses.

title: DECEPTION BY JOB APPLICANTS IS CALLED WIDESPREAD
description: The registrar's office at the Harvard Business School recently received a call from a man who said he was a graduate and asked for a copy of his academic transcript to send to a prospective employer. He said he was legally changing his name and wanted the records in his new name.

title: The Week in Business; INFLATION EASES; DURABLE GOODS ORDERS PLUNGE
description: Inflation eased in October, the Government said last week. The Consumer Price Index rose just four-tenths of a percent, or 4.8 percent on an annual basis, the smallest increase in six months, the Government reported. One key factor was a decline of seven-tenths of a percent in the selling price of houses.

title: HOUSING REVIVES OLD-TIME MALL
description: A closed shopping center built as an oldtime village with shops located in a grist mill, a tavern, a schoolhouse and other period buildings is being converted into condominium apartments in this community just west of Summit.

title: PULASKI TEAM WINS IN STORY BOOK FINISH
description: NEW BRITAIN AT the end of August, things looked grim for the Pulaski High School football team: the coach had resigned the day before preseason practice was to begin, only about a dozen boys had expressed an interest in playing, the team had lost its last 14 games straight, and the school itself was on the verge of closing.

title: THE L.I. PHILHARMONIC: BARTOK CELLO CONCERTO
description: A mere six weeks after opening its doors, the Concert Theater at C.W. Post College of the University of Long Island attained a measure of exclusivity tonight when the Long Island Philharmonic presented the American premiere of a Concerto for Cello by Bela Bartok. Janos Starker, the noted Hungarian-born cellist, was soloist in the work, which is a transcription by the late Tibor Serly of Bartok's Viola Concerto.

title: Tennessee 38, Vanderbilt 34
description: The cornerback Carlton Peoples broke up a last-second end zone pass by Whit Taylor to save Tennessee's lead.

title: EVEN COLLEGE CAN'T SEPARATE GIRL AND HER REINDEER FAWN
description: Eskimo schoolchildren at Kotzebue, Alaska, have revised the nursery rhyme, ''Mary had a little lamb.'' They sing, ''Susan has a little reindeer, with fleece as white as snow, and everywhere that Susan goes, the fawn is sure to go.''

title: No Headline
description: SOUTH AFRICA DENIES INVOLVEMENT IN RAID ON INDIAN OCEAN ISLE

title: Carruthers Duo Wins International Pairs Title
description: Peter and Caitlin Carruthers of the United States won the pairs title at the International Figure Skating Championships tonight, beating Brigit Lorenz and Kaut Schubert of East Germany.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Civic Illiteracy And Education
description: American colleges have been criticized for a number of specific ailments lately, but last week came a diagnosis of a more pervasive malaise.

title: AT 39, ALI HAS MORE POINTS TO PROVE
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas H IS religion prohibits magic. Muhammad Ali mentions this as he performs some sleight of hand in his hotel room while waiting for a fight some people say he shouldn't attempt, and others suspect may never come off.

title: Pro Bergman
description: To the Business Editor: Barbara R. Bergman, in her excellent article, ''Relax, Social Security Is Doing Its Job'' (Nov. 15), refutes alarmists who have given the impression that the Social Security System is on its way to extinction. There are some additional points which need to be made.

title: Q AND A QUERIES
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 DOCTORS TELL OF TREATMENTS JEHOVAH'S WITNESSES ACCEPT
description: Doctors are finding more ways to treat and perform surgery on members of Jehovah's Witnesses without the blood transfusions that most of the sect's followers reject, The Journal of the American Medical Association has reported.

title: Freight Derailed in Virginia
description: A Norfolk & Western Railway freight train left the rails in a here today, spilling diesel fuel from a locomotive knocked off the tracks, officials said.

title: Banker Weds Lee Montross
description: Lee Chamberlin Montross and David Perrin Wheeler were married yesterday at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Daniel F. Miner. He was assisted by the Rev. Arthur W. Hargate.

title: ERRORS CONCEDED IN CONTROLLER SCHOOL GRADES
description: A review of test grading at the national training school for air traffic controllers has revealed major inadequacies, but no grade-juggling to produce a higher passing rate, the school's director said today.

title: THE EMBATTLED INDEPENDENT FARMER
description: David Kline is a freelance journalist and director of Impact Features, a Chicago-based agency for writers. By David Kline Heads bowed, a hundred Georgia farmers sit stiffly on folding chairs beneath a striped tent. They listen in silence as the pastor begins his invocation: ''Our Lord, whose farm is all creation, please grant thy blessings to those here today, and especially to Charles and Frances Bodrey and their children. Amen.''

title: EXERCISE REDUCED TO A MATTER OF SCIENCE
description: BETHLEHEM IN 1968, Paul Lessack was a senior at Kennedy High School in Waterbury. He could play two dozen sports - everything from baseball and basketball to horseshoes and bowling - and excel at all of them, but he rarely exercised and found it difficult to run even one mile.

title: Camera; DARKROOM TECHNIQUES FOR MORE INTERESTING PRINTS
HAITIANS: WE'LL KILL OURSELVES
description: Following are excerpts from an open letter to the United States Immigration Service from 'The Unhappy Refugees of Enclave IV'-a group of Haitians held at Fort Allen, Puerto Rico. In it, they threaten suicide. The letter was handed to a New York Times reporter.

title: CONFEREES ON ELDERLY UNEASY
description: TWO delegates and 35 observers from New Jersey will be among the 2,200 delegates and 1,500 official observers expected to take part in the 1981 White House Conference on Aging.

title: Amy Bondon Married To Stuart E. Rickerson
description: Amy Diane Bondon and Stuart E. Rickerson were married yesterday at the Union Congregational Church in Upper Montclair, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. J. Yorke Peeler Jr.

title: Southwest Texas 38 Jacksonville State 22
description: Mike Miller rushed for 135 yards, passed for 109 and ran for one touchdown as Southwest Texas State reached the semifinals of the playoffs.

title: POLISH PARTY URGES SPECIAL ACTION
description: Poland's Communist Party leadership, responding to Friday's initiative by the nation's leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, demanded tonight that Parliament approve ''extraordinary measures'' to curb labor unrest. These were said to include a law that would permit the banning of strikes.

title: Future Events Charitable Offerings
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Appeal for Funds Dec. 2 - Meet Milo O'Shea and Michael O'Keefe, the two-man cast of ''Mass Appeal'' at a supper reception at the Cafe Ziegfeld after seeing their bravura performances at the Booth Theater. There'll be a chance also to greet Geraldine Fitzgerald, who directed the play. Proceeds from the evening will go to the Manhattan Theater Club, which produces provocative new works, many of which, like ''Mass Appeal,'' go on to fame and glory on Broadway. Tickets, $100.

title: HONDURAS TO PICK CIVILIAN CHIEF TODAY
description: Hondurans vote Sunday for their first civilian president in a decade, hopeful that a return to democracy will protect this country from the political violence convulsing the rest of Central America.

title: Gardening; GREENHOUSE A POOR SOLAR-HEAT RETAINER
description: GREENHOUSES are being heavily promoted these days as passive solar collectors for use in supplementing the home heating system. Some new greenhouse owners have been able to deduct a portion of the cost of construction from their Federal income tax if the structure was built for that purpose.

title: On a Rift In a Family
description: In reply to the mother whose article, ''To a Mother, Child-Rearing Is About Choice and Freedom'' (Opinion Page), was published recently, I looked, vainly, for ways this mother has devised for reestablishing communications with her daughter. I looked for a public admission of errors in upbringing.

title: No Headline
description: Around the World; U.S. Marine Is Accused Of Assault in Managua

title: REFORM GETS ROCKED ABOUT IN THE CRADLE OF BUREAUCRACY
description: When China's nominal Parliament, the National People's Congress, convenes for its annual session this week, at least three old delegates will be missing. Two Maoists who scrambled to prominence during the Cultural Revolution were ousted recently for unspecified ''serious mistakes'' and a party secretary from Hubei Province lost his seat because he built a big house with public funds and got caught. But they are not the only officials to incur the displeasure of Deng Xiaopeng's reformist leadership. The Chinese leader has complained that ''some of our party members are not qualified'' to cope with difficulties that ''pile up like mountains.'' Even some old-timers, Mr. Deng added, ''cannot set an example for the masses.''

title: DRIVING IN IRELAND
description: To the Editor:

title: Follow-Up on the News; Frugality in Office
description: After his election in 1978, Mayor Koch spurned the Cadillac limousine of officialdom and settled for a creaky Chrysler sedan. It broke down so much that he finally got a new 1979 Chrysler.

title: Meet in Discord, Adjourn in Haste
description: Saudi Arabia's fellow Arabs last week succeeded where Israel had failed. They derailed a Middle East peace plan that traded tacit recognition of Israel for a Palestinian state.

title: The Bizarre, $43,000 Polocar
description: THE publicity handouts say that the only way you can buy one of Bob Obercian's cars is if you already own at least a dozen other vehicles.

title: Practical Traveler; TIME, MILEAGE AND FINE PRINT
description: Nothing seems to irk auto renters more than the unexpected charges they often find added to the bill when they return a car. Business travelers who rent cars frequently have learned to expect and understand the gaps between prominently advertised rates and what they are ultimately asked to pay. But the delight with which a vacation traveler picks up a subcompact advertised, say, at $69 a week with unlimited mileage can turn to angry shock when the cost at the end of the week proves to be almost twice that.

title: Sarah Brosious Is Married
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in Boulder, Colo., yesterday Sarah Krick Brosious, daughter of Jo Fox Douglass of Westport, Conn., and H. Hamilton Brosious of Stamford, Conn., was married to Paul Vaivoda, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Vaivoda of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Gordon Huffaker and the Rev. Gary Seibert, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. The bride is a graduate student at the University of Denver. Mr. Vaivoda attends the University of Colorado.

title: The Margin Holds In New Jersey
description: That close gubernatorial election in New Jersey, it turned out last week, was not quite as close as it first seemed. With virtually all of the 2.3 million ballots cast on Nov. 3 recounted, Republican Thomas H. Kean picked up nearly 150 additional votes, increasing his margin to about 1,800 votes and leaving little doubt about who will occupy the Governor's Mansion come January.

title: Antiques; A FAMILY AFFAIR IN SOUTH ORANGE
description: SOUTH ORANGE THE Village Antiques Shop at 8 West South Orange Avenue is, without a doubt, a family affair. It is operated by Alexander Chiger; his brother, Sinclair, and their wives, Yvonne and Marion.

title: BUDGET CUTS CURBING U.S. EXCHANGE PROGRAMS
description: The United States, already lagging behind the Soviet Union, Britain, France, West Germany and Japan in the percentage of its national budget committed to international educational exchanges, is moving closer to abandoning its programs altogether.

title: Peru Is Searching for Thieves Who Took Museum Treasures
description: A nationwide search is under way for the thieves who raided the National Museum of Anthropology and Archeology and stole a solid gold ceremonial knife, possibly the most valuable of Peru's pre-Columbian treasures.

title: Games Arcade Ceiling Falls
description: Four men and three women were slightly injured yesterday in a game arcade in the Times Square area when a section of ceiling fell on them, the police said. All seven were treated at St. Clare's Hospital after the collapse, which occurred at the Fascination Game Arcade, 1587 Broadway, at about 1:30 P.M.

title: MEXICO HAS GOOD CAUSE TO OFFER ITS GOOD OFFICES
description: Like a marriage counselor struggling with a seemingly irreconcilable couple, Mexico has offered to act as a ''communicator'' between its friends in Washington and its friends in Cuba and Nicaragua. Its motive is to keep the entire regional family from paying the price of any further deterioration in United States-Central American relations.

title: ON 'MENTAL ILLNESS': TERM IS CHALLENGED
description: DR. THOMAS SZASZ, the main speaker at a conference on ''Law, Liberty and Psychiatry: The Politics of Mental Illness,'' surprised at least a few people last weekend when he suggested that the term ''mental illness'' did not suffice as a proper diagnosis.

title: I enjoyed Helen Markel's twinkling article very much. However, on behalf of Athanasius Kircher, I take exception to the mention and reproduction of his ''loudspeaker'' illustration without so much as a mention of his name. To identify Kircher merely as ''a Jesuit priest'' is almost like referring to Galileo's telescope as ''a 400-year-old instrument belonging to an Italian astronomer.''
description: Kircher is known in the history of medicine as virtually the first to promulgate the theory that disease was caused by microorganisms. He is credited in the history of motion pictures with the invention of the magic lantern, the predecessor of the projector. His collection of art objects, artifacts and natural-history specimens formed the Kircher Museum, which became the nucleus of the famed Vatican Museum. ELLA MAZEL New Rochelle, N.Y. ------

title: HAIG IS CONFIDENT SINAI PEACE FORCE WILL BE DEPLOYED
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that although there may be unresolved questions about the makeup of a Sinai peacekeeping force there was no doubt that a force would be put into place, and that Sinai would be returned to Egypt as planned.

title: COURTLY CHAMPION OF AMERICA'S ELDERLY
description: John Egerton is a Nashville-based journalist and author. By John Egerton f ever a constituency could be expected to belong to a public official, the 25 million Americans age 65 and over should belong to Ronald Reagan. At 70, he is one of them, the oldest person ever to be elected to the White House. Millions of senior citizens share the general tenets of his conservative Republican philosophy. He is an attractive and glamorous man, a personification of usefulness and productivity in later years, an inspiration to others his age.

title: A NEW WAY OF HANDLING CHILD CUSTODY
description: Charles Rothenberg, author of ''Matrimonial Allowances in New York,'' has specialized in the practice of family law for almost 40 years. By Charles Rothenberg The prize-winning motion picture ''Kramer vs. Kramer'' reminded us that perhaps no legal battles are fraught with more bitterness, controversy and heartbreak than are child-custody cases. Yet at a time when one out of three marriages is doomed to failure and court calendars seem clogged with such cases, no new method for dealing with this human tragedy has been put forth. The question remains: Who is best able to decide what is right for the beleaguered child in such cases? Under present law, the role of deciding between two contesting parents still falls entirely to a judge, and once the judge decides what is best for the child, nothing else matters - certainly not the child's wishes - as a relatively recent spate of court rulings shows: In a 1977 Illinois case, Imes v. Imes, a 16-year-old girl told the judge that she did not love her father, could not get along with him and wanted to live with her mother. She was awarded to the father. In the 1977 Pennsylvania case of Tomlinson v. Tomlinson, a court made an award of a 13-year-old girl to her mother despite the child's stated preference for her father. The decision was made without consideration of a court-ordered psychiatric evaluation. A year ago, in a Washington case, four children of the Hadeen family, ranging in age from 5 to 15 years, were awarded to their mother, a religious zealot whose sect permitted, as a means of gaining parental control, ''beatings, vile language and lying to nonbelievers'' as well as enforced isolation and fasting.

title: Article 111089 -- No Title
description: President Reagan's $2 billion misunderstanding with Congress, which led last week to a shutdown of government functions that ended as swiftly as it began, seems destined to become a footnote in the contentious history of Mr. Reagan's economic program. But for both sides, there was meaning in the budgetary madness.

title: MONTCLAIR TOPPLED BY WIDENER, 23-12
description: Widener College made the most of numerous mistakes by a younger and less experienced Montclair State College team today and scored a 23-12 victory at Memorial Stadium.

title: IN DIFFICULT TIMES, ATHENEUM THRIVES
description: THE Wadsworth Atheneum, Hartford's encyclopedic art museum and the oldest of its kind in the nation, is developing a reputation for swimming against the economic tide. At a time when many art institutions are threatened by cutbacks in financing, the Atheneum is in the middlle of a comprehensive renovation of its physical plant and enlarging the size and quality of its art collection.

title: The Nation in Summary; Allen Defends Actions After; New Disclosures
description: ''How can there be a conflict?'' Richard V. Allen asked last week. President Reagan's national security adviser proceeded to answer his own question. ''If one guy leaves a law firm is there a conflict if he meets with the lawyer who takes over those accounts or the former client, particularly if he excuses himself from matters pertaining to the client? The answer is clearly no.''

title: 200,000 JOIN PROTEST IN FLORENCE
description: Nearly 200,000 people marched through Florence's historic downtown area today demanding nuclear disarmament and concrete moves to preserve world peace, the demonstration's organizers said.

title: Miss Gernert Is Married In Mt. Kisco
description: Catherine Joy Gernert, an assistant to Representative Stephen Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Donald Alexander Ramsay Jr., a management consultant with American Management Systems. The Rev. Jack Silvey Miller performed the ceremony in the Mount Kisco (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church.

title: Reich's Right
description: To the Business Editor: It would be hard to envision a more concise indictment of industry's indifference to what's known as ''the general welfare,'' than is contained in Robert B. Reich's ''Business Is Asking for Trouble Again'' (Nov. 22). This brief summary of abuses brings to mind a frequently heard objection to the proliferation of Government-required reports.

title: Miss Brommer, Taylor Pace Qualifiers in Run
description: Louise Brommer of Mechanicsburg, Pa., and Steve Taylor of St. Mary's, W.Va., won races yesterday in the Kinney Northeast Regional Championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. They will lead a contingent of 16 boy and girl runners who will compete in the third national prep meet in Orlando, Fla., Dec. 12.

title: Researcher Weds Mariana Coleman
description: Mariana Gowen Coleman, daughter of Mrs. Elliot R. Detchon and the late Bertram D. Coleman of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married yesterday to Alan Thomas Sorenson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Sorenson of Norwalk, Conn., and London. The Episcopal ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert Etter in the nonsectarian Coleman Memorial Chapel in Brickerville, Pa.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Fragile Fame
description: After New York University sold its campus on University Heights in the Bronx to the City University in 1973, fiscal troubles wracked the Hall of Fame for Great Americans at the western edge of the campus.

title: Moira McNamara Will Be Married To Lance Fitzgerald James in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. McNamara Jr. of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Moira Patricia McNamara, to Lance Fitzgerald James, son of Richard E. James of San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, and Mrs. Marion Fitzgerald James of Tucson, Ariz.

title: Arizona State 24, Arizona 13
description: Mike Pagel threw three touchdown passes in the second quarter - two to the split end Bernard Henry - in leading a winning rally by Arizona State, 9-2 over all and 5-2 in the Pac-10 Conference. Arizona finished at 6-5 and 4-4.

title: IN THE LAND OF THE ZAPOTECS AND MIXTECS
description: ALAN RIDING is chief of the Mexico City bureau of The Times. By ALAN RIDING

title: No Headline
description: As one who belongs to the other world of cancer patients who are assuming some responsibility and direction and input for their treatments, I hope that Mr. Silk's article does not discourage those cancer patients who are beginning to be aware of the broad and solid benefits of alternative treatments. Even in the rigid confines of Sloan-Kettering, can nutrition still be regarded as radical therapy? PATRICIA B. HOCHFELDER, Roslyn Estates, N.Y.

title: ALL ABOUT WRITING, ACCORDING TO IRVING
description: ''BEING a novelist,'' said John Irving, who is currently among the nation's most successful, ''is never throwing anything away.'' And being a speaker, which he also seems to do well, is describing to a Westchester audience how to transform that material into prose.

title: Mailbox; Boxing 8-Count Won't Work
description: To the Sports Editor: I want to take issue with the article calling for the inclusion of a standing eight count within the rules of professional boxing (''A Plan to End Hasty Boxing Decisions, The New York Times,'' Nov. 22, 1981).

title: A REGULAR BAKER STREET SOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. APPROVES THE RELEASE OF 703 CUBAN REFUGEES
description: United States immigration officials, acting under the close scrutiny of a Federal judge, have approved the release of 703 Cuban refugees from prison here. In doing so, however, the Government has asserted its right to deport them later.

title: Investing; THE NEW RULES OF BUYING A HOME
description: I T wasn't very long ago - last year even - that buying a house was an almost surefire investment. With the easy availability of credit in general and inflation-beating appreciation, the risks were minimal, and just about everybody could count on a killing upon resale.

title: Best Sellers
description: Jx FICTION 1 1 6 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 2 2 11 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with an eccentric family. 3 15 3 NO TIME FOR TEARS, by Cynthia Freeman. (Arbor House, $14.95.) A dauntless woman leads her family from Czarist Russia to Palestine to New York's diamond center. 4 1 SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord. (Harper & Row, $14.95.) Tradition and revolution in modern China seen through the eyes of an upper-class family. 5 3 16 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 6 5 8 THE LEGACY, by Howard Fast. (Houghton Mifflin, $14.95.) The Lavette family of ''The Immigrants'' and ''The Establishment'' reaches the turbulent 60's. 7 4 30 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A British-Chinese struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses.

title: Adrienne King, Actress, Wed to Robert Tuckman
description: The marriage of Adrienne King to Robert William Tuckman took place yesterday at All Souls Unitarian Church. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony.

title: SOVIET DRAFT SEEN OVERCOMING MANPOWER DIP
description: The Soviet armed forces are facing the prospect of substantial declines in available manpower in this decade, but Western analysts say there is little reason to believe that Soviet military strength will suffer as a result.

title: Follow-Up in the News; Instant Spanish
description: When Robert E. Lee, a retired Navy captain, went to work for the Department of Environmental Protection in Montgomery County, Md., he noticed that employees with Hispanic surnames were among those entitled to preferential promotion. Mr. Lee went before a judge. After 56 years as Robert Edward Lee, he became Roberto Eduardo Leon.

title: Mary E. Belden Is Married to Charles R. Baker Jr.
description: Mary Elizabeth Belden and Charles Richard Baker Jr., were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest. The Rev. Stephen Rodgers performed the ceremony.

title: FIGHTERS' PHYSICALS LEAVE SOMETHING TO BE DESIRED
description: Why can a 47-year-old dentist pass a physical to fight in a professional fight in the State of Illinois? Why can't the state commissions prevent old over-the-hill fighters from fighting even when it is evident by their pathetic ring performances that they are not fit to fight? Why can an obviously punchy fighter pass a commission physical?

title: Reader Comment; SOCIAL SECURITY'S NOT DOING ITS JOB
description: S OMETHING has to be said in response to ''Relax, Social Security Is Doing Its Job'' (Nov. 15). Barbara R. Bergman maintains that the detractors of the system are ''barking up the wrong tree economically as well as politically.'' But her own analysis points to the contrary.

title: PORT AGENCY IN SHIFT
description: HOBOKEN THE Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is transferring 200 employees who now work in Manhattan to space that the authority recently renovated on its unused Pier A here.
