title: Home Clinic; HOW TO ATTACH SHELVES OR FIXTURES TO A MASONRY WALL
description: THERE are numerous occasions when a homeowner may want to fasten something to a solid masonry wall around the inside or outside of the house - to put up shelves or hang cabinets on a basement wall, for example, or to attach any type of hanging fixture to a brick wall or fireplace chimney - and the simplest way to do this is to use masonry anchors or expansion-type fasteners made for the purpose.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1981
description: International

title: EXPRESSLY ABOUT MAIL
description: To the Editor:

title: Wrong Chapter
description: To the Business Editor: We read your ''Bankruptcy Among Consumers'' (Nov. 15), with interest, but want to call your attention to the fact that the Wage Earner Plan is Chapter 13, not Chapter 12.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: Sadat.

title: NEW EDITIONS OF BIBLE PROVOKE CONTROVERSY
description: Several new editions of the Bible are scheduled for publication in 1982, and some are provoking controversy between publishers and conservative Christian groups even before their release.

title: CAR DEALERS HOPE FOR VETO OF RULE
description: Members of Congress who are trying to block a regulation governing used-car dealers received more than $500,000 in campaign contributions from a dealers' association, a public affairs group says.

title: Other Business; THE SEARCH FOR THE INDESTRUCTIBLE AD
description: Advertising has been around, in a sense, since man began writing on walls. So have the forces that deface the message, from vandals to stormy weather. So advertisers, and the people who sell space to them, continue their quest for the indestructible ad.

title: Well Decorated Finishes First
description: Well Decorated, who was one of the leading Kentucky Derby candidates last spring, won the $54,600 Sport Page Handicap by two and three-quarter lengths over Engine One yesterday at Aqueduct. Heavily favored Guilty Conscience, carrying top weight of 126 pounds and conceding his rivals 2 to 13 pounds, finished third, a halflength behind Engine One in the field of six. Well Decorated carried 117 and Engine One 116.

title: White's Injury A Cracked Rib
description: DALLAS (AP) - Danny White's status for the Cowboys' game against Baltimore next week has become even more uncertain with the discovery that the quarterback has a cracked rib.

title: DON'T RAIL AT STOCKMAN FOR TELLING IT PLAINLY
description: To the Editor:

title: OFFICIALS FEAR LAG IN FUEL-AID FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON By States News Service

title: UNILATERAL ARMS CUTS ANYWAY
description: Supporters of the Administration's nuclear-weapons build-up may have been surprised when President Reagan offered to cancel the $5 billion deployment of new intermediate-range nuclear missiles destined for Western Europe in return for drastic Soviet cuts in similar forces. If so, they will be even more shocked when the Administration - perhaps unwittingly - pursues what are in effect unilateral reductions in United Stated defense programs in 1982 and beyond.

title: Habib Stopping Over in Rome On His Way to the Middle East
description: Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's special envoy to the Mideast, arrived in Rome today for a short stopover on his way to the troubled region.

title: Antiques View; A PRE-COLUMBIAN ART FEAST
description: Art and antiques collectors, more often than not, are more capricious than judicious in their choices of what to buy. It is rare to encounter a superb collection where the connoisseurship of the owner and the consistent esthetic level of the material are immediately evident. And when the assemblage is of exotic material from an unconventional area of the decorative arts - as is the case of the collection of pre-Columbian jewelry and ceremonial pieces that will be sold Friday at Sotheby Parke Bernet - the accomplishment seems even more impressive.

title: Speaking Personally; CHANGING TIMES AT CHRISTMAS TREE FARM
description: COME Thanksgiving, there had been one tradition our family looked forward to as much as feasting on turkey. It began many Thanksgiving afternoons ago when, stuffed to the teeth and blissfully euphoric, we drove from Madison a few miles north to Killingworth to select our Christmas tree.

title: Warning: Manatees X-ing
description: The Army Corps of Engineers has awarded Coastal Marine Inc. of Tampa a contract to install warning signs aimed at protecting the manatee in the Intracoastal Waterway on Florida's east and west coasts. Col. Alfred B. Devereaux Jr. said the signs were an attempt to get boaters to slow down, thereby lessening the chances of collisions with the large, underwater mammals, an endangered species.

title: DRIVING IN IRELAND
description: To the Editor:

title: Chess; STEAN'S STYLE APPEALED TO KORCHNOI
description: The members of Victor Korchnoi's analysis team - Michael Stean, a 28-year-old British grandmaster, Yasser Seirawan, a 21-year-old Seattle grandmaster, and Lev Gutman, a 36-year-old Israeli international master - had varying functions.

title: CHANEL: FROM 'PETITE COCO' TO COUTURIER
description: It took her, she says, 16 years - of collecting photographs, of unearthing old letters, of searching out the aged and abandoned courtesans who flowered briefly in another era. And it probably helped lose her her job at French Vogue.

title: BANGKOK: SUBTLE SILKEN LUXURY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- HENRY KAMM has just completed a tour as chief Asian diplomatic correspondent of The Times. By HENRY KAMM

title: Speaking Personally; HOW ABOUT SUPPLY-SIDE METEROLOGY?
description: THEY'VE got a real pleasant bunch down at the Hackensack Water Company. Four times a year, they send this friendly fellow around to read the meter under the rags behind the washing machine in my basement. He never asks why otherwise-normal people throw rags behind the washing machine in the basement. He just smiles.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE SPECIAL SESSION
description: HARTFORD LIKE a lot of others, state legislators will be down to cold turkey this week as they come to grips with a variety of proposed tax increases to solve the state's fiscal problems.

title: DRIVING IN IRELAND
description: To the Editor:

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Piano Four Hands From Mozart to Milhaud
description: The American debut program of Hui-Ying Liu and Erik Tawastjerna, duo pianists, last Sunday at the Merkin Concert Hall ran the gamut from Mozart to Milhaud and included what was billed as the New York premiere of Ferruccio Busoni's ''Finnish Folk Songs'' (Op. 27) for piano four hands.

title: Other Business; A PENNY SAVED EARNS 20%
description: Forget C.D.'s, forget All Savers, forget money market funds. Here's a no-risk investment with an instant, 20 percent return, and it's as close as the local bank.

title: Politics; KEAN SET TO GET 'DIPLOMA' TUESDAY
description: THOMAS H. KEAN of Livingston, a former Assembly Speaker, is scheduled to get his diploma on Tuesday. That is when the state's Board of Canvassers meets in Trenton to certify the results of the Nov. 3 gubernatorial election.

title: Business Conditions; VIDEO RECORDER BOOM
description: Despite the onset of a recession, pessimism is an unknown emotion among merchants selling videotape recorders and videotapes. By any measure, sales are booming.

title: UCONN WASTE PLANT TERMED ESSENTIAL
description: STORRS ''THERE'S really no alternative,'' said Frank Vasington, assistant vice president of academic affairs at the University of Connecticut and supervisor of the school's effort to build a hazardous waste disposal facility on campus.

title: DANCE: THE FANCY DANCERS
description: The Fancy Dancers Company describes itself as jazz and ballet, modern-dance and tap-oriented. But what the group offered Friday at Theater of the Riverside Church was basically choreographed disco dance with the pizzazz of a nightclub act. The 19-member company, recently formed by John Medeiros and Gene Aguirre, is an odd mixture of tough Broadway gypsy types and well-scrubbed novices, with a few somewhat creaky veterans thrown in for good measure. At its best, Fancy Dancers offer dance with a sure theatrical touch.

title: Rhode Island Schools Seek Paper Donations
description: The Exeter-West Greenwich Regional School District is turning to the parents of elementary pupils to ease a shortage of facial tissue, toilet paper and paper towels.

title: AMBULANCE VOLUNTEERS TOO MUCH OF A SUCCESS
description: As an elderly woman peered down her shadowy hallway in Mitchell House, a South Bronx housing project for the aged, she saw a strange young man with waist-length hair. ''What do you want?,'' she called tensely.

title: FATHER OF BRUISED CHILD IS ARRESTED IN QUEENS
description: The long-missing father of a bruised, 19-month-old girl taken from a city hospital last summer was seized at a Queens courthouse Friday night and ordered held without bail yesterday for a Family Court hearing tomorrow on his fitness as a parent.

title: L.I.U. 118, Pratt 60
description: Earl Fuller scored 19 points and Bob Cole 18 as Long Island University opened its basketball season by defeating Pratt, 118-60, in Brooklyn Saturday night.

title: Saudi to Visit Pakistan
description: The Defense Minister, Prince Sultan, is to begin an official visit to Pakistan Tuesday at the invitation of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, the official Saudi Press Agency reported today.

title: Trials Ordered in Italy for 42 Charged as Leftist Terrorists
description: State prosecutors have ordered trials for 42 suspected terrorists from the left-wing Front Line group, which has links to the Red Brigades urban guerrilla organization, court officials said today.

title: COPS AND CRIMINALS
description: YEAR OF THE DRAGON By Robert Daley. 507 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: Temporary Secretary Finds Good Jobs Scarce
description: According to an article last week (''Many Offices But Too Few Secretaries,'' Nov. 15), secretarial jobs are going unfilled, even with the unemployment rate at over 8 percent. I have been doing temporary secretarial work since September and my observation is that the jobs are scarce. There is stiff competition for the good ones, and the pay is not great. It would appear, therefore, that there is a hiatus between what the executives want in office help and what the agencies can produce.

title: F.B.I.'S MAN ON BRINK'S CASE: AN ELEMENT OF VINDICATION
description: Classical music plays softly in the background, coffee is served in gold-rimmed china and an antique brass lamp casts a warm glow across Kenneth P. Walton's desk. The calm surroundings, though, belie the fact that Mr. Walton, an assistant deputy director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the No. 2 man in the New York office, heads what is arguably one of the agency's most sensitive cases in years - the investigation into last month's Brink's robbery in Rockland County and the radicals from the Weather Underground and the Black Liberation Army who are suspects in it.

title: WILLIAMS AND SENATE PEERS APPROACHING THE BITTER END
description: Everyone on Capitol Hill uses the same words to describe the situation - painful, sensitive, delicate. Thursday, the Senate is scheduled to consider a resolution to expel Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., the New Jersey Democrat convicted of bribery and conspiracy for his part in the Abscam scandal. If the expected happens, Mr. Williams will be the first Senator to be expelled since 1862, when three lawmakers were ousted for aiding the Confederacy in the Civil War.

title: TEEN-AGE 'SOUND OF MUSIC' MUSIC TO EARS
description: THEY swarmed to our house. Within fifteen minutes of the time I got home from the final performance of ''The Sound of Music'' at our local high school, the entire cast and stage crew began to arrive at our house. They came through the front door, giggling and laughing in high excitement after their very successful performance, greeted me politely and proceeded down to our basement playroom. Within 30 minutes there were 80 students in my house, ranging in age from 12 to 19.

title: Cannie Crysler Wed to Edwin Hampton Shafer Jr.
description: Cannie Godwin Crysler and Edwin Hampton Shafer Jr., teachers at the Episcopal Academy in Merion, Pa., were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. Timothy Pickering performed the ceremony.

title: Theater in Review; A MOST ELOQUENT 'NIGHTINGALE'
description: HERRICKS WHO else but Tennessee Williams could turn a flickering feeling into a whole play - a complete play - and wrap it up with a title like ''The Eccentricities of a Nightingale''?

title: AMISH HERBALIST 'CURES' ARE IN HIGH DEMAND
description: To the end of a dusty road, past miles of cornfields, they come. From California and Ohio and as far away as Central Europe, they bring their headaches, back pains and liver problems.

title: CRIMINAL-JUSTICE SYSTEM TAKES A LOOK AT ITSELF
description: Representatives of various arms of the city's criminal-justice system have begun holding monthly meetings to discuss ways of solving problems and making the system more efficient and economical.

title: MILITARY REBUTS ITS CRITICS ON PROBLEMS WITH ARMS
description: Managing the development, production and testing of billions of dollars worth of new weapons and equipment and the use and maintenance of highly sophisticated arms systems are serious concerns in the military, officials say.

title: TV View; BRINKLEY'S SHOW HAS YET TO FIND ITSELF
description: One day several months ago, David Brinkley abruptly walked out of NBC News, the organization that had made him a television star back in the 1950's as the dour half of the successful Huntley-Brinkley anchorman team. The departure was so swift that NBC's press people had to scurry to begin putting the move in the best possible, or least damaging, light. The inevitable rumors about Mr. Brinkley's motivations included everything from his health to his unhappiness about not being offered a prominent spot on the nightly news when John Chancellor is replaced by Roger Mudd and Tom Brokaw next spring. Mr. Brinkley and the network would say only that the parting was relatively amicable, reflecting his desire for a change, although he had been professing publicly that he thoroughly enjoyed his assignment as host of the weekly ''NBC Magazine.''

title: GRAVE CONCERNS
description: Yes, indeed, after half a century of drawing morbidly witty cartoons for The New Yorker, Charles Addams, like the fellow pictured at the right, has developed a band of admirers resembling a cult. His creepy new book, ''Creature Comforts'' (Simon and Schuster, $12.95), includes some of his familiar old witches (like the manic one zooming out of the woods at the wheel of a Gingerbread House van), as well as an assortment of graveyard scenes, one featuring headstones inscribed with the names of old cars, Packard, La Salle, Nash and Hudson; another showing a headstone with hatch doors beneath it instead of a conventional grave.

title: Yale 68, Holy Cross 62
description: NEW HAVEN (AP) - Butch Graves, a sophomore guard, scored 26 points to help Yale score an upset.

title: No Headline
description: Andrew Silk's approach of leaving the physical problems to the professionals has been the right way for me, too, once I was assured that the doctor I selected was the best in the field. The area I've learned to work on is my own mental state.

title: DOWN-TO-EARTH CREOLE COOKING
description: CRAIG CLAIBORNE is the food editor of The New York Times. By CRAIG CLAIBORNE

title: MILD WINTERS MAKE MODERATE BUDGETS
description: HARTFORD THE mild winters of the last three years have provided the state and several towns something of a windfall. Because the snowfall has been well below average, road maintenance and overtime accounts have either been sufficient or have shown a surplus.

title: NEW RESTRICTIONS WORRY TURKISH EDUCATORS
description: Turkish educators are deeply troubled over a new law that abolishes the autonomy of the universities and subjects teachers to compulsory rotation in underdeveloped regions of the country.

title: Numismatics; TIME TO RESTRUCTURE U.S. COINAGE?
description: Is it time to scrap our system of United States coinage and start again with something brand new? A California architect-numismatist named Kirk Hillman thinks it is. What's more, he has drafted a detailed plan that he believes would do the job.

title: BIRTH CONTROL ADS MAKE DEBUT ON FRENCH TV
description: French television has a new hit - a Governmentsponsored commercial advocating contraception. Appearing daily through Dec. 9, the commercial is part of the first public information campaign on contraception since birth control was legalized in France in 1967.

title: Around the Nation; 23 Arrested in Raid On Dogfighting Ring
description: Twenty-three persons were arrested today in a raid on one of the largest dogfighting rings in the Middle West, officials said.

title: CITY BALLET: TOMLINSON MAKES DEBUT IN 'AGON'
description: Things were jumping at the State Theater Friday night, and the cause of the happy commotion was very obviously Mel Tomlinson, who made an electrifying debut with the New York City Ballet.

title: CHRISTMAS FAIR
description: To the Editor:

title: IS THERE LIFE ELSEWHERE, AND DID IT COME HERE?
SYRIA, AN ANCIENT CROSSROADS, SEEKS TOURISTS
description: Syria, which has a 100-mile-long Mediterranean coastline, is planning to develop new beach resorts in an effort to attract foreign tourists.

title: Critics' Choices
description: NEW MUSIC New York is full of worthy organizations devoted to the cause of new music. Sometimes they are blinkered in their devotion to a certain style of composition.

title: Washington; EUROPE AND AMERICA
description: The United States and Soviet Governments are finally renewing their talks on the control of nuclear weapons, but this will be no private party. The people of Europe are demanding the right to be heard and insisting that this subject is too important to be left to secret negotiations between the two atomic giants in Geneva.

title: ATTACK ON REAGAN EASED BY MOSCOW
description: In the period leading up to the talks between the United States and the Soviet Union on intermediate-range nuclear weapons, which are scheduled to open Monday in Geneva, the two sides have staked out positions that look almost irreconcilable.

title: The Region in Summary; Fiscal Outlook Puts a Crimp in Koch's Hopes
description: Sometimes the glow of apparent health is really the flush of fever. So it appeared with New York City's condition last week as Mayor Koch, who had said in May that the city was well on its way to financial recovery, reluctantly acknowledged that it has suffered at least a mild relapse.

title: REDMEN LAPCHICK WINNERS
description: A pair of freshmen led St. John's to a 91-71 victory over Fordham last night as the Redmen won the Joe Lapchick Memorial Tournament, which they sponsor, for the seventh time in its seventh year.

title: CAPITALS' STREAK ENDS AT 7
description: Doug Sulliman scored twice, including once during a four-goal second period, and powered the Hartford Whalers to a 6-2 victory over Washington tonight, ending the Capitals' seven-game unbeaten streak.

title: No Headline
description: N. CAROLINA TOPS KANSAS, 74-67

title: Navy Recruit Gets Discharge As a Conscientious Objector
description: The Navy has granted an honorable discharge to Robert Byron Mills, a recruit who became a conscientious objector while undergoing Navy training in nuclear power.

title: PUERTO RICO TERRORIST GROUP TAKES RESPONSIBILITY FOR BLACKOUT
description: The Macheteros, a Puerto Rican terrorist group that said it bombed the Air National Guard Base at Isla Verde last January, took responsibility today for bomb blasts Friday night that knocked out electricity to 20,000 customers in San Juan's luxury hotel and residential districts.

title: Teller Is Dismissed From Job For Opposiing Charity Drive
description: A part-time bank teller was dismissed from her job because she refused to make a voluntary donation to United Way, the bank president confirmed Friday.

title: Court Backs Jobless Pay Suit On Parental Care of Children
description: California residents who left their jobs from 1968 to 1976 to care for their children might share up to $96 million in back unemployment benefits under a new court ruling.

title: Sports of The Times; Something Better Than A Sermon
description: ALL over the country, college basketball coaches are warning their players to beware of gamblers this season. The required sermon probably goes in one ear and out the other of most players, who assume it couldn't happen to them. Three years ago, Rick Kuhn may have assumed that, too. But last week the former Boston College forward heard a Federal jury in Brooklyn return a verdict that he and four gamblers were guilty of conspiracy to engage in racketeering and sports bribery.

title: JUVENILE JUSTICE EXPERTS SEE GOOD AND BAD IN REVISION BILLS
description: THE five-bill juvenile justice package that unanimously passed the Assembly last week is being hailed by some experts as a panacea for the system and being deplored by others as opening a Pandora's box of new troubles.

title: OREGON HOSPITAL SEEKS TO CURE SEX OFFENDERS
description: Ward 41B at the Oregon State Hospital does not look like a cell block. Its rooms are laid out in dormitory style are decorated with pictures, pottery and macrame. Activities of the day, which begin at 6:15 A.M. and ends at 11 P.M., are tightly structured, with classes ranging from assertiveness training to wok cooking and recreation periods filled with basketball, volleyball and card games.

title: GIVE THE MONEY TO THE REAL INNOVATORS
description: I N our opinion, a renaissance in innovation in America is possible, but a basic systemic change must first occur in governmental policies affecting small innovative businesses. -Presidential advisory committee on industrial innovation, the final report 1979.

title: DESPITE SETBACK, MANY SEE BOON FOR COLLECTIVE HEALTH PLANS
description: STAMFORD HEALTH maintenance organizations, because they can give patients better and less expensive care in a setting more professionally satisfying to doctors, are the medical system of the future, according to their proponents.

title: Nancy Jane LaPook Wed To Robert Bruce Diamond
description: Nancy Jane LaPook, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney LaPook of Great Neck, L.I., and Robert Bruce Diamond, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Diamond of Tamarac, Fla., were married last night.

title: THE POINT OF PHOTOGRAPHS
description: BEAUTY IN PHOTOGRAPHY Essays in Defense of Traditional Values. By Robert Adams. Illustrated. 108 pp. Millerton, N.Y.: Aperture. $12.50.

title: SEEKING NAMES FOR PEACE
description: COMMUTERS wait for a glimpse of the 7:38 from Westfield to Newark, standing out on the railroad tracks themselves as if daring it to come. They stand with their backs to the slanting sunlight, heads bent over their newspapers.

title: HEMINGWAY TOWN IS LITTLE CHANGED
description: ''Horton's Bay, the town, was only five houses on the main road between Boyne City and Charlevoix,'' Ernest Hemingway wrote in the story ''Up in Michigan.'' ''There was the general store and post office with a high false front and maybe a wagon hitched out in front.''

title: Anne Tolley Wed To J. H. Rotondo
description: Anne Elizabeth Tolley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. B. Stuart Tolley of Larchmont, N.Y., was married there yesterday to James Holmes Rotondo, son of Marcella H. Rotondo of Hamden, Conn., and the late Dr. Delio J. Rotondo. The Rev. Michael Drake performed the ceremony in the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: FOR WRITERS, A DISTURBING MAGNET
description: MICHIKO KAKUTANI is a culture news reporter for The New York Times. By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

title: LIST OF STATE'S RESIDENTS IN HIGHER FEDERAL POSTS
description: Following is a list of the leading Reagan Administration appointees from New York State, including some career officials who were promoted within their departments: Department of Housing and Urban Development Samuel R. Pierce Jr., Glen Cove, L.I., Secretary. John J. Knapp, Garden City, L.I., general counsel. Joseph Monticciolo, Woodbury, L.I., regional administrator. Stephen May, Rochester, assistant secretary. Laura Lee Over, Rochester, special assistant to deputy undersecretary for intergovernmental relations. Edmund Davis, Manhattan, area administrator. Lance Wilson, Manhattan, executive assistant to the Secretary. Peter J. Ferrara, Manhattan, special assistant to the assistant secretary for policy, development and research. E. S. Savas, Manhattan, assistant director for policy, development and research.

title: BAGGAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Purdue 82, Tennessee 68
description: Keith Edmonson scored a career-high 36 points to lead Purdue. Edmonson scored 11 points as Purdue opened a 14-point lead, 34-20, with five minutes left in the half.

title: 6 NEW YORKERS IN RACE FOR TITLE IN U.S. BRIDGE
description: New York metropolitan area experts were represented on four of the six teams vying for the lead when the Reisinger board-a-match team championship resumed today at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here.

title: Essay; KIRKLAND COMES TO CALL
description: On Wednesday of this week, a score of labor leaders will troop into the White House Cabinet Room at the invitation of the President.

title: Around the Garden
description: THIS WEEK: Last call to clean, drain and store the power mower . . . Clean and oil hand tools . . . To prevent freezing, move garden chemicals out of an unheated garage or tool shed indoors to safe storage . . . Where bulbs and new perennials were planted, cover with leaves or clean straw mulch. A WORD ON WATERING Some house plants are thirsty year-round and thrive on a regular watering schedule. Many are everyone's favorites - African violets, begonias, Swedish ivies, spider plants, philodendrons and most ferns.

title: Margaret C. Rogers Wed
description: Margaret Carroll Rogers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Brien Burdick Rogers of East Varick, N.Y., was married yesterday to Roderick Gareth Lewis, son of Norman Lewis of Essex, England, and Mrs. Lewis of Banchory, Scotland. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by the Rev. Virgil Cordano in Old Mission Santa Barbara in California. The couple will live in London, where the bridegroom is long-haul product manager for Thomas Cook Ltd.

title: ABUSED MOTHERS, MARRIED OR NOT, GET ASSISTANCE
description: THE New York State Legislature made fundamental changes this year in the Family Court Act to give all women, married and single, more protection against violence at the hands of the men they live with. The new amendments, which became effective last July 7, add important rights such as free legal representation for abused spouses who cannot afford lawyers and a requirement that a Family Court judge see the abused woman the same day she comes to court. In addition, the purpose of the act has been changed from ''keeping the family together'' to ''stopping the violence and helping the victim.'' This change in emphasis from conciliation to protection of the victim gives abused women for the first time a viable alternative to pressing criminal charges against the men who beat them.

title: Dining Out; CONTINENTAL FARE WITH PRETENSIONS
description: AT Encore, the dining room of the Sheraton Smithtown, no cliche of fancy dining has been overlooked. The garnishes on the plates and platters, the tableside preparations, the dessert cart, the wine service and the dining room hierarchy are characteristic of the abundant superficial gloss. But the evidence of quality ingredients prepared with care and good taste is frequently lacking.

title: The Nation in Summary; Players Dispute The House Rules
description: Procedural rules may turn out to be the hottest issue at this year's White House Conference on Aging, scheduled to begin tomorrow. The rules permit only a single yes-or-no vote on reports produced by 14 committees, with no minority reports allowed.

title: SUPERPOWER TACTICS CHANGE BUT POLICIES REMAIN IN CONFLICT
description: WASHINGTON LISTENING to the upbeat statements from the Kremlin and especially from the Reagan Administration last week, it was easy to forget that Soviet-American relations may be worse now than at any time since the height of the cold war in the early 1950's.

title: Sabres 4, Maple Leafs 4
description: TORONTO (UPI) - Terry Martin's second goal at 9:14 of the third period enabled Toronto to gain the tie. Martin's first goal and seventh of the season at 17:55 of the second period drew Toronto within a goal at 4-3.

title: Morgan Rawlins Weds Phyllis Digges La Touche
description: Phyllis Digges La Touche, daughter of Mr. and Everard Digges La Touche of Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday in Bridgehampton, L.I., to M. Morgan Rawlins of New York, Stamford, Conn., and Bridgehampton. The Rev. Frederick W. Rapp performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Episcopal Church.

title: GIANTS OF THE MARKET
description: THE SKYSCRAPER By Paul Goldberger. Illustrated. 178 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Researchers Find A Genetic Tilt To Depression
description: Depression, a disease affecting 1 to 2 percent of all Americans, is in part a family affair, scientists at the University of Rochester Medical School say. Their research, reported last week in the New England Journal of Medicine, suggests that the presence of particular genes may predispose some people to developing depression.

title: Zoo Releases 4 Seals Mistreated by Visitors
description: Four harbor seals at the Washington Park Zoo in Portland have been released in the Pacific Ocean because zoo visitors persisted in tossing coins, flash cubes and other objects into their tank.

title: Pauli Overdorff And Idan Sims, Executives, Wed
description: Pauli Overdorff and Idan Sims were married yesterday at the Union League Club by Algernon Black, leader emeritus of the New York Society for Ethical Culture.

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE The new and the old will have their day this week in concerts at opposite ends of the city. Works by six new choreographers will be presented in a showcase at at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater on Tuesday.

title: Liverpool Names Streets After the Beatles
description: The Beatles finally got an official memorial here Friday when four streets were named after the city's famous sons.

title: COURT THROWS OUT BLURTED ADMISSION
description: New York State's highest court has overturned a robbery conviction in the Albany area on the ground that the defendant's confession to the police was not spontaneous and should have been suppressed.

title: Drive to Halt Nuclear Arms Race
description: As Secretary of State Alexander Haig and Foreign Minister Andrei Gromyko resume contacts between the United States and the Soviet Union after a hiatus marking the opening of the Reagan Administration, attention to nuclear weapons is being revived around the world.

title: ISLAND SURPRISES ITS BUSINESSMEN WITH GROWTH OF EXPORT TRADE
description: WITHOUT fanfare, Long Island has become one of the nation's leading export regions, shipping its goods to all parts of the world. The Island also is playing host to an increasing number of foreign businesses in an economic expansion that is expected to continue through the 1980's.

title: BURGLARY PREVENTION IS CLASSROOM COURSE
description: THE setting may be unusual but the subject - burglary and how to prevent it - is drawing students from 20 to 70 years old to standingroom-only classes at the White Plains High School.

title: LIBYA PLANS NEW FORCE TO COUNTERACT THE U.S.
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, said today that he was forming a rapid deployment force to fight the United States rapid deployment force if it intervened in any Arab country.

title: Leisure; DO-IT-YOURSELF HOLIDAY TRIMMINGS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Holly K. Emmons is assistant professor in plant sciences, SUNY - Cobleskill, N.Y. By HOLLY K. EMMONS

title: The World in Summary; New Offensive Against Strikes
description: Poland's Communist leaders grabbed for the steering wheel again last week. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the party chief, said the Government -which he also heads as Prime Minister - would ask Parliament to outlaw strikes that are making a critical economic situation worse.

title: BAGGAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Film View; HOW RELIGION ELUDES THE MOVIE-MAKER
description: Intense religious experience isn't often represented on the screen. At the very least, it's a difficult thing to convey. The movies have long offered us ministers, miracles and the poignant sight of children kneeling sweetly in prayer, but the innermost religious spirit is more elusive. And in its more fanatical forms, religious thought is particularly hard to depict, since it's so likely to look foolish or frightening.

title: WAR ON POVERTY IS DIFFICULT TO CALL OFF
description: In postponing further cuts in Federal benefit programs until January, President Reagan has implicitly recognized the political difficulty of dismantling the welfare state. The growth in welfare, Medicaid, food stamps and other ''entitlement'' programs, under which people who meet the criteria are automatically entitled to benefits, compelled the Administration to seek major changes earlier this year. Without such revisions and without cuts in the defense budget, Mr. Reagan would have no hope of controlling Government spending.

title: Around the World; Rebels Said to Kill An Afghan Defense Aide
description: Anti-Government rebels in Kabul, Afghanistan, killed a senior Afghan Defense Ministry official and his wife and several party functionaries this week, according to a report from the Afghan capital today.

title: DRIVING IN IRELAND
description: To the Editor:

title: ARE THERE TWO PREMIER PARISIAN ORCHESTRAS?
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Judith Karp, who has lived in Paris, writes frequently about music. By JUDITH KARP

title: SOVIET NEGOTIATOR CALLS A MISSILE PACT FEASIBLE
description: The Soviet Union's chief negotiator in the missile talks with the United States that are to open here Monday said today that an accord on ''radical reductions'' of medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe was ''not only imperative but quite feasible.''

title: WHITE PLAINS SHOW IS CAT'S WHISKERS
description: ONE year ago, Sulltans Raja-Yoga weighed one-and-a-half pounds and had to be fed through an eyedropper every three hours. Today, despite predictions that he would not live, he is a healthy eight pounds and is winning ribbons at numerous competitions.

title: 'GIVE IT UP TO SIT IN THE SUN? NOT YET!'
description: IT was a gentle pressure at first. Now the throbbing seems more persistent. A sensation of being surrounded, enclosed ... enveloped in the cocoon of opinion.

title: Protesters March in Lisbon
description: Hundreds of students marched through Lisbon today demanding the abolition of nuclear arms by both East and West.

title: Children's Books
description: THUNDERBOLT & RAINBOW A Look at Greek Mythology. By Guy Billout. Illustrated. Unpaged. Englewood Cliffs, N.J.: Prentice-Hall. $9.95. (Ages 8 and Up) By JOHN RUSSELL

title: VENERABLE SAILING CRAFT RESTORED TO NEW LIFE
description: SEA CLIFF THE burly northerlies of the fall on Long Island Sound have sent boat people hurrying to complete the prewinter ritual - hauling out, covering and storing.

title: Dayton 38, Lawrence 0
description: Jon Vorpe threw for one touchdown and ran for two others to spark the N.C.A.A Division III semifinal playoff victory.

title: AILING GARMENT WORKERS UNION FACES MORE PROBLEMS
description: ''I don't think there is another industry in this country,'' said Sol C. Chaikin, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, ''that has had to confront such burdensome competitive pressures'' - except ''those that have been wiped out.''

title: Olympic Sail Event in Danger
description: The International Yacht Racing Union has become embroiled in a dispute that, unless resolved by Feb. 2, will prevent board sailing from making its debut as an Olympic sport in the 1984 Los Angeles Games.

title: Prospects
description: Equities Mark Time

title: Around the World; Cambodian Rebel Seeks To Form a Coalition
description: Son Sann, a leader of right-wing forces fighting the Vietnamese-backed Government in Cambodia, met here today with the Foreign Ministers of Thailand and Malaysia to discuss forming a coalition of rival resistance groups.

title: New Jerseyans
description: TO PREVENT bank security people (who knew him) from recognizing him, he grew a beard. He also changed the style of his eyeglasses, and he told his new associates that he was a gambler with big debts and big alimony payments to his former wife.

title: WILDLIFE REFUGES SHOW RISE IN HUMAN
description: SPECIES By ANDREA AURICHIO

title: On Language By William Safire Shall We Enhance? Kimble Mead
description: The rise of ''enhance'' began in the 1960's with the need to spruce up monaural recordings for playback in stereo equipment. Salesmen called the static-erasing, rerecording ''enhanced sound''; sound engineers winced and called that a ''quasi-technical term.''

title: DRIVING IN IRELAND
description: To the Editor:

title: ONE THING THAT'S A LOT EASIER TO GIVE THAN TO TAKE
description: ONE of the hardest unwritten commandments to keep is ''Thou shalt not give unasked for, unwanted advice.'' When I see another person, be it my son, mother or friend, heading for the same emotional radar trap I just emerged from, scarred but perhaps wiser, I seldom can resist administering a preventive sermon. I have a 100 percent failure rate simply because the people I know, like me, rarely learn from another's mistakes.

title: WHEN TENANTS INITIATE THE CO-OP
description: Many of the tenants at 1361 Madison Avenue were convinced that their building would eventually be converted to cooperative ownership. ''Given the choice, whether it was the landlord or us,'' said Dr. Barbara McGann, chairman of the tenants' co-op committee, ''most people preferred it was us.''

title: Cooking Oil Deaths at 203
description: The deaths of a man and a woman have brought to 203 the number of people who have died after consuming poisoned cooking oil since last May, the Health Ministry said Friday. Officials said 566 people remained hospitalized in Spain, mostly in Madrid, after consuming olive oil adulterated with industrial rapeseed oil.

title: CAN A PANEL SOLVE KOCH'S TROUBLE WITH MINORITIES
description: A month after the most impressive election victory in municipal memory, Mayor Koch is turning to the one discordant note in his landslide re-election - the evident disaffection among the Hispanic and black New Yorkers who usually produce the largest Democratic pluralities of any group, but who did not for Mr. Koch.

title: Oklahoma 27, Okla. State 3
description: Fred Sims, a freshman halfback making his first college start, scored three touchdowns as Oklahoma won the battle for second place in the Big Eight.

title: Meredyth Sloane Armitage Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Armitage of Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Meredyth Sloan Armitage, to Dexter Freeman, son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Freeman of Osterville, Mass. The wedding is planned for January.

title: POLICEMAN, FORCED TO RETIRE, FIGHTS TO REGAIN JOB
description: Charles Leahey says he lost his job as a New York City police officer because he made too many arrests and issued too few traffic tickets.

title: NEW DATA REOPEN BUSING ARGUMENTS
description: New attendance figures compiled by the Los Angeles Unified School District show that a long-term decline in white enrollment continued this year despite the end of court-ordered busing in September.

title: THE ROYAL FAMILY OF THE GUITAR
description: Paul Bernstein is a contributing editor to Los Angeles magazine. He has been studying the guitar with Celin Romero for the past two years. By Paul Bernstein our decades ago, under the crystal chandeliers of Madrid's elegant Real Conservatorio Superior de la Musica auditorium, a young guitarist of regal bearing began a program of classical compositions. During a pause between numbers, a small boy in the audience escaped from his mother's arms, climbed onto the platform, removed Celedonio Romero's footstool and, without a word, sat down on it. Undaunted, Romero simply crossed his legs to support his instrument and began his next number. When the concert was over, the boy joined in the audience's enthusiastic applause. The guitarist took the child's hand and the two of them walked off together.

title: A HINDU REVIVAL MOVEMENT IN INDIA IS HOPING TO ASSIMILATE UNTOUCHABLES
description: A well-financed Hindu revival movement, with strong political implications, was started here last month by religious and lay leaders whose efforts were spurred by the recent wave of conversions to Islam by communities of Hindu untouchables.

title: Columbia 46, Union 40
description: Carl Scholz, a reserve forward, scored 10 points, including the first 2 in overtime, as Columbia defeated Union, 46-40, Saturday night at Levien Gym.

title: EX-MORMON PUSHES E.R.A. IN UTAH
description: SOUTHINGTON THE letter that notifed Gail Brooks Freeman in 1978 that she had been excommunicated from the Mormon Church took her breath away. ''I was shocked.'' she said. ''I thought the only thing you could get excommunicated for was murder or adultery.''

title: About Westchester
description: TARRYTOWN THE General Foods Corporation Technical Center off Route 9 here is a contemporary building, the sort of brick-and-glass structure that one associates with big business in the suburbs. It is a surprise, then, to discover that anyone who veers left shortly after pulling into the driveway and noses the car down a twisting dirt trail will come upon the remnants of something very old - the stone cellar of a farmhouse that may have been built in the early 1700's and the collapsed wood of a frame cottage probably added more than 100 years later and the space between the two where another wing once stood.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; A Dispute Over Access
description: National security and academic freedom are frequently incompatible when it comes to research with sensitive technological or military applications. The latest chapter in the conflict involves Chinese scholars in the United States.

title: The World in Summary; Papandreou Puts On the Squeeze
description: The new Greek Government announced plans last week to revise its Western ties and accentuate its Balkan and Mediterranean connections. But in classic Levantine style, Socialist Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou said in his first major policy address that he was ready for ''step-by-step'' bargaining to extract concessions from Washington, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the European Common Market.

title: BRYANT SETS MARK; ALABAMA WINS, 28-17
description: Paul Bryant of the University of Alabama, who once wrestled a bear to earn his nickname and long ago achieved immortality in these parts, today coached his 315th victory, more than any other college football coach ever.

title: Undercover With the New F.B.I.
description: The indictment in Manhattan of six reputed members of an organized crime family raises a fascinating question: how does the F.B.I. infiltrate a tight gang of mobsters? According to the indictment and guarded statements by officials, the charge of conspiracy to murder three mob figures stems from undercover work by two Federal agents who gained the group's trust.

title: SCIENCE TEACHERS IN SHORT SUPPLY
description: ALTHOUGH some school districts in New Jersey have been terminating or consolidating classroom space because of declining enrollments in recent years - and teaching positions generally have been harder to come by - an emergency shortage of science teachers has developed in elementary and junior and senior high schools throughout much of the state.

title: AGE IS A BOXER'S NATURAL OPPONENT
description: THE apparently endless comebacks from retirement by Muhammad Ali has brought about a dreary succession of attempts to return to the ring wars by other aging fighters and has raised several questions.

title: CASINO CHIPS GIVEN TO DEALERS ARE FOCUS OF A TAX DISPUTE
description: The little round chips are called gaming tokens, or ''tokes'' for short. A gambler who gives them away is called a ''George.''

title: Air Canada Asks Higher Fares For Most Flights to the U.S.
description: Air Canada has applied for fare increases of 9.5 percent on Canadian routes and 10 percent on flights to points in the United States other than Florida, The Globe and Mail reported.

title: DECEPTION GIVEN NEW IMPORTANCE IN PLANNING MX MISSILE STRATEGY
description: Senior officials in the Defense Department said today that they had begun to devise a new approach to the deceptive deployment of both the MX nuclear missile and a missile defense system intended to make the MX invulnerable to Soviet attack.

title: Dining Out; A BOOKSTORE WITH EXCELLENT PATE
description: NEW HAVEN ''MEET me at the bookstore for lunch'' may sound like an odd suggestion - but not in New Haven. One of the city's newest and better places for a quick, but not fast-food, lunch, or morning, afternoon or late-night snack, is located in the middle of the Atticus Bookstore, on Chapel Street near the Yale Repertory Theater.

title: Music; HOLIDAY CONCERTS OFF TO EARLY START
description: SOME of us may still be thinking of ways to prepare leftover Thanksgiving turkey, but Santa Claus and friends will soon be coming to towns all over the state. On Tuesday, for instance, you can celebrate a hometown Christmas with the Jack Daniels Silver Coronet Band at the University of Connecticut's Jorgensen Auditorium, starting at 8:15 P.M. The following Tuesday, the superb Waverly Consort will perform its Renaissance version of the Christmas story. If you like to wine and dine your way through the Yuletide festivities, UConn has the answer for this, too: the 12th annual Elizabethan ''Christmas feaste,'' from wassail to plum pudding, with the accompaniment of singers, dancers and players in 16th-century costume. The celebrations have been sellouts in past years. For information, call 486-2284, from 10 A.M. to noon on weekdays.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: * Rates restricted by state usury laws

title: BRYANT SETS MARK; BLACKLEDGE LEADS LIONS
description: With Todd Blackledge upstaging Dan Marino at quarterback, Penn State today achieved its biggest upset since Joe Paterno became the head coach in 1966, a 48-14 victory over topranked Pittsburgh that ended the Panthers' 17-game winning streak.

title: HE'S THE AVIS OF THE THEATER WORLD
description: It is lunchtime on a raw, rainy fall day. Limousines are pulling up in front of 21, unloading a parade of elegantly tailored men. The chosen among them are swiftly led inside to the first room in the bar section, the enclave where former Presidents Nixon and Ford and movers and shakers of industry have their regular tables. The restaurant is getting crowded and noisy when a conspicuously halfdrenched man holding a broken and misshapen umbrella arrives by foot at the front door of 21. He, too, has a regular table in the front room of the bar section.

title: Re: ''Points of View From a Rooftop,''
description: I can readily comprehend why John Higgins's Ash Wednesday message, ''Today the Moral Majority have dirty foreheads,'' would evoke ''some irate calls and letters.''

title: The Region in Summary; M.T.A. Feeling Mayoral Pressure
description: Edward Koch's talents as a backseat driver may be needed in the mayoral limousine, but transit officials don't seem to want them applied to the subway system. Responding last week to yet another round of criticism from City Hall, Richard Ravitch, the head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, assailed the Mayor's ''counterproductive'' comments on upcoming labor talks.

title: The Nation in Summary; Democrats Keep Theirs in Illinois
description: The Illinois Legislature, required to draft new Congressional district lines on the basis of the 1980 census, drew a blank, and turned the decisions over to a Federal District Court. Last week, Chicago Republicans were sorry they had let their compasses go.

title: Two Men Are Shot to Death While Tending Brooklyn Store
description: One man was found shot to death and another critically wounded inside a store in the East New York section of Brooklyn early Friday afternoon, the police reported.

title: 'I'M STILL FRIGHTENED OVER EACH NEW BALLET'
description: Whatever the company, you're likely to bump into Choo San Goh when you go to the ballet these days. At 33, he's one of the hottest choreographic properties around. The Joffrey Ballet has a Goh or two. American Ballet Theater has just acquired ''Configurations,'' starring Mikhail Baryshnikov, which will be performed during the company's New York season at the Metropolitan Opera House in April. And the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will be dancing Mr. Goh's new ''Spectrum'' for the first time on Friday at City Center, where the company will be performing through Dec. 20.

title: SHIPPENSBURG TOPS VA. UNION IN PLAYOFF
description: The junior quarterback Tim Ebersol passed for 270 yards and two touchdowns and scored twice today and led Shippensburg State to a 40-27 victory over Virginia Union in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II quarterfinal playoffs.

title: Wisconsin-Stevens Point 57 Creighton 51
description: John Mack and Jeff Radtke combined for 27 points to lead the upset and spoil the coaching debut of Willis Reed. The loss was the first opening-game defeat for the Bluejays since 1967.

title: Anne Miller Is Married
description: Anne Judith Miller, a student at the Harvard Medical School, was married yesterday to Stuart Jeffrey Breslow, a lawyer in Boston. Rabbi Robert A. Rothman performed the ceremony at the Ridgeway Country Club in White Plains. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Sidney M. Miller of Rye, N.Y., and Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Breslow of Fresh Meadows, Queens.

title: Careful Shopper; Scarsdale Pastry Shop With European Flavor
description: Part of Denmark's homage to the French actress Sarah Bernhardt was the creation of a pastry in 1883 - elegant almond macaroons filled with kanuche, a soft filling of cream and chocolate, and then coated in semisweet chocolate. Her name remains on the confection today and 5,000 Sarahs hardly meet the weekly demand at Jespersen's Pastry Shop in Scarsdale, where everything is shaped, rolled and dipped by hand.

title: Gail Gillespie Becomes Bride
description: Gail Gillespie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Gillespie 3d of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael V. Garcia, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Joseph Garcia of Mount Vernon, Me. The Rev. Patrick Holtkamp performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Manhattanville College Chapel in Purchase, N.Y.

title: PICTURE-TAKING IN COLD WEATHER
description: Taking pictures outdoors in cold weather can lead to some unpleasant surprises for those who are not properly prepared, so here is a brief review of steps you can take to make winter photography more trouble-free.

title: Topics; Itchy on the Trigger
description: Eighteen senators, all Democrats, have jumped the gun in their demand for a special prosecutor in the Richard Allen case. The 1978 Ethics in Government Act has a hair trigger but the senators, eager to exploit the White House embarrassment, have itchy trigger fingers.

title: DELAY BY 24 STATES ON WELFARE CUTS TRIMS U.S. SAVINGS
description: At least 24 states have delayed the enforcement of a new Federal law reducing welfare benefits. This will make it impossible for the Reagan Administration to achieve the full savings it predicted for welfare and Medicaid in the current fiscal year.

title: Temple 65 West Chester State 53
description: PHLADELPHIA (AP) - Terence Stansbury and Granger Hall led a 17-8 second-half burst to lead the Owls, who had held only a 31-30 lead at halftime.

title: Spec Toporcer Writes
description: IT was a happy accident of timing that with James Cagney, the actor, again prominent in the news, a letter from George Toporcer broke a silence that had been allowed to endure too many years. Jim Cagney is famous for many talents, including the ability to do more with a grapefruit than Luther Burbank, but probably his proudest boast is that when he was growing up in Yorkville on the East Side of Manhattan, he played sandlot baseball with his neighbor, Specs Toporcer.

title: No Headline
description: Because my family and I are blessed with fine health, we tend too often to take this great fortune for granted. My priorities have once again been put in proper perspective, thanks to Andrew Silk's article. DIANE LEVENTHAL, Colts Neck, N.J.

title: LUCAS HELPS KNICKS DEFEAT CAVS, 101-90
description: With every game, Maurice Lucas is projecting himself more and more as the power forward and leader the Knicks have needed. After losing a 15-point first-half lead and floundering through the third quarter last night, the Knicks sent the ball inside to Lucas, and he led them to a 101-90 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers at Madison Square Garden.

title: MEXICO: A WORLD OF DIFFERENCES
description: There are a lot of Mexicos, all inseparable from one another - ancient Mexico, colonial Mexico, provincial Mexico, metropolitan Mexico, wild Mexico, poor Mexico and rich Mexico, illiterate Mexico and intellectual Mexico, gentle Mexico and, I suppose, violent Mexico, although I have never met it.

title: E. T. Thompson Weds Susan Jacobson
description: Susan L. Jacobson, a freelance editor, and Edward T. Thompson, editor in chief of Reader's Digest, were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom in Bedford, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Stephen M. Bolle, rector of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Katonah, N.Y.

title: AT CREDIT UNIONS, HIGH RATES CUT 2 WAYS
description: CREDIT unions on the Island are offering high-yielding money market certificates, interest-bearing checking accounts, tax-exempt certificates of deposit, individual retirement accounts and, in some instances, chances at winning gifts, in order to counteract the effects of inflation and attract savers.

title: HANDLING SEXUAL HARASSMENT
description: PRINCETON ALTHOUGH Federal guidelines issued last year spell out what constitutes sexual harassment, colleges and universities in New Jersey are finding that, even when the problem is identified, it is not an easy one to face.

title: Personal Finance; FAILED PROMISES IN BANK DEREGULATION
description: B ANK deregulation was a major goal of the Reagan Administration that was supposed to provide consumers with a cornucopia of safe and competitively priced savings deposits. Whatever happened to it?

title: COUNTIES' REVENUE GAP GROWS
description: Spending by the nation's county governments increased 10.8 percent in 1980, surpassing income, which grew 8.9 percent, according to the Census Bureau.

title: WHY A RISING STAR, NOW AT RUTGERS, GAVE UP TENNIS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK IT IS a bright, cold afternoon, and the attractive, dark-haired young woman stops for a moment to watch players on the Rutgers University tennis courts.

title: The World in Summary; Now Paisley Has An Army, Too
description: For nearly 20 years, the Rev. Ian Paisley's main weapon in the fight to maintain Protestant dominance over Ulster has been his tongue. He employed it again last week to whip up support for a ''day of action,'' protesting what many Protestants see as inadequate British Army protection against Irish Republican attacks.

title: Woman's Body Discovered
description: A trapper found the body of a woman Thursday about a mile and a half from a nursing home where she had been missing since July 21, the police said. Beatrice Dehner, 79 years old, had been the object of an intense search. She apparently died of exposure and dehydration and had been dead four months, according to the police, who said there were no signs of foul play.

title: Westchester Journal
description: JUSTICE James D. Hopkins of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, an Armonk resident, once served as Westchester County Executive, and it was during his term in office that the decision was made to build the County Courthouse in downtown White Plains.

title: COUPLE SHARE GUESTHOUSE TIPS
description: WEST HARTFORD SOME people collect stamps or antiques. Jon and Nancy Kugelman collect guesthouses. They like traveling through the countryside, staying in tourist houses, avoiding the ''sameness'' of hotels and motels. ''It's also cheaper,'' said Jon Kugelman, who has put his collection of 1,400 guesthouse names into a small guidebook called ''Sleep Cheap.'' The booklet lists the names, addresses and phone numbers of 1,400 tourist homes in the Eastern United States and Canada and has no qualifying or recommendational remarks about the facilities.

title: CUTBACKS ASSAILED IN WAR ON CIGARETTE-SMUGGLING
description: New York State's Commissioner of Taxation and Finance said yesterday that the Reagan Administration had sent him a letter filled with ''gobbledygook'' in response to his plea that the Treasury Department revive its enforcement efforts against cigarette smugglers.

title: REAGAN IS ASSAILED BY THE FIELD FUND
description: The Field Foundation, one of the country's leading liberal philanthropic organizations, has attacked the policies of President Reagan, contending that the Administration is denying assistance to the poor, threatening civil liberties and human rights, irresponsibly expanding military spending and increasing ''secret'' government.

title: CATALAN DINING
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-HEAD OF FEDERAL DISEASE CENTER NAMED CITY HEALTH COMMISSIONER
description: Dr. David J. Sencer, former director of the Federal Center for Disease Control, was appointed yesterday by Mayor Koch as New York City's Commissioner of Health.

title: SOPHIE GIMBEL, LEADING AMERICAN DESIGNER FOR 40 YEARS, DIES AT 83
description: Sophie Gimbel, a leading American designer for almost 40 years, died of a heart attack at Mount Sinai Hospital yesterday morning. She was 83 years old.

title: THREE TARDIF GOALS BEAT RANGERS, 7 TO 4
description: The Rangers and the Quebec Nordiques stayed close to each other for 50 minutes tonight, in a game of quick offensive thrusts and one in which the lead changed five times.

title: Dr. Jerry Singer, Surgeon, Weds Lauretta C. Harmon
description: Lauretta Caryn Harmon, a field projects designer with Merrill Lynch Pearce Fenner & Smith Inc. in New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Jerry H. Singer, a surgical resident at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L. I. The ceremony was performed in the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhust, L. I., by Rabbi Jerome Fishman.

title: ERRORS HURT ISLANDERS IN LOSS
description: Playing giveaway in the first period and catch-up the rest of the way, the Islanders lost to the Boston Bruins today, 5-4.

title: Tanker Spills Oil in Soviet
description: Thousands of local people helped in cleaning up an oil slick around the Soviet Baltic port of Klaipeda after a wrecked tanker spilled 16,000 tons of fuel oil, Soviet newspapers said today. The 20,000 ton Gibraltar-registered Globe Asimi ran aground and broke up a week ago as it tried to leave the Lithuanian port during a heavy storm.

title: A DOOMSDAY VIGIL WITH BIBLE AND GUN
description: HOREB, Ark., Nov. 28 (AP) - Bivouaced in an Ozark encampment that bears a name borrowed from the Bible, a band of Scripturequoting, gun-toting Christian survivalists has set its sights on doomsday.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: WINTER driving might be just a little bit easier in the coming years thanks to an invention by an employee of the State Department of Transportation. Michael Kasinskas of Cheshire, a transportation materials technician in the Bureau of Highways since 1966, has developed and patented a device that could eventually replace rock salt as a means of controlling ice and snow. The device, a highpressure nozzle, distributes a salt solution, or brine, directly onto roadways, dissolving the ice more quickly than rock salt can. Excessive amounts of rock salt have been blamed for corroding motor vehicles, degrading pavement surfaces and polluting water sources.

title: Antiques; BAZAAR TO AID HISTORICAL SOCIETY
description: GREENWICH NEXT weekend the main hall and entryway of the Civic Center will be decorated with lush holiday greens by members of the Greenwich Historical Society. The extra sparkle and glitter associated with the season will be supplied by objects on sale at the 15th annual Christmas Antiques Bazaar. The show, a benefit for the Historical Society, will open Friday and run through next Sunday evening. There will be booths set up by antiques dealers from throughout the Northeastern states, including, of course, Connecticut.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: SOMOZA And the Legacy of U.S. Involvement in Central America. By Bernard Diederich. Illustrated. 352 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $19.75.

title: PLAN TO BUILD NEAR WETLANDS DEBATED
description: CEDAR BEACH A DISPUTE between property owners in this picturesque community in Southold Town shows why building new homes on the North Fork shorefront is no longer a simple matter.

title: Headliners; Rose Kennedy Out of Hospital
description: America does not have royal families. Consequently it does not have queens.

title: BLAZE DESTROYS URBAN COMPLEX IN LYNN, MASS.
description: A fire set by an arsonist engulfed the center of Lynn's urban renewal area today, forcing more than 600 people, many of them from a housing project for the elderly, into the streets. Damage estimates ran as high as $40 million.

title: Art; BOLD GEOMETRIC PLANES-A TRIBUTE TO EINSTEIN
description: PRINCETON AFTER two husky men removed a fluttering plastic cover from a sculpture by Tony Smith at the Institute for Advanced Study, one of the world's foremost mathematicians - a fellow at the institute - walked up to the sculpture and began pounding its black steel surface rhythmically, as if releasing harmonies from it.

title: THE CONSOLATIONS OF CLOUT
description: Sunday ObserverBy Russell Baker Patrick McDonnell

title: New York Times Magazine November 29, 1981
description: William Safire 16 On Language Shall We Enhance? Russell Baker 29 Sunday Observer The Consolations of Clout Leslie H. Gelb 31 Keeping an Eye on Russia Phil Berger 34 Dundee: Champ of Corner Men Edward Jay Epstein 68 The Enigma of Armand Hammer Lester Trimble 74 The Unsung American Composer Paul Bernstein 98 The Royal Family of the Guitar John Egerton 125 Courtly Champion of America's Elderly Charles Rothenberg 132 A New Way of Handling Child Custody David Kline 138 The Embattled Independent Farmer 150 Style/Christmas Gifts The Pleasures of Giving 166 Puzzles Answers, Page 139 174 Letters Cover: Illustration by Eugene Mihaesco Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: DUNDEE: CHAMP OF CORNER MEN
description: Phil Berger is a freelance writer with a special interest in sports. By Phil Berger September 16, 1981: The 12th round has just ended in the fight to determine undisputed possession of the welterweight title held jointly by World Boxing Council champion Sugar Ray Leonard and World Boxing Association champion Thomas Hearns. Leonard retires to his corner with the flesh beneath his left eye discolored, swollen and threatening to obscure his vision.

title: WITH STEEL ON THE MEND, HE'S TURNING TO OIL
description: W HEN David M. Roderick took over as chairman of the United States Steel Corporation in 1979, he shelved his predecessor's plans to build a $3.5 billion steel mill that could compete with the Japanese, closed 14 plants that were losing money and started to build a cash reserve for an acquisition that would make his company less dependent on steel for its growth and profits.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Varda Shamban Plays Varied Piano Program
description: Varda Shamban, a young Israeli who has been studying in the United States for the last five years, made her debut last Sunday as a solo pianist at the Abraham Goodman House. Miss Shamban's program was a long and difficult one, and she maintained throughout an impressive technical hold over such virtuoso pieces as the Schumann F-sharp minor Sonata (Op. 11), two of Messiaen's ''Vingts Regards sur L'Enfant Jesus'' and the Ravel ''Alborada de Gracioso.''

title: Editors' Choice
description: Gibson. (Atheneum, $30.) The first part of a projected two-volume biography of the American playwright.

title: Pegasus Also Offers Riding for Handicapped
description: We welcome your attention to riding for the handicapped (''Horseback Riding Aid to Handicapped,'' Nov. 8). It is, indeed, a remarkable therapy, unique in that it offers such varied benefits in a single time frame.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Miss Futter Says What She Thinks
description: True minds or not, the alliance between Barnard College and Columbia University has lately admitted definite impediments. Last week, Barnard's new president, Ellen V. Futter, took the occasion of her inauguration to address some of them with surprising directness.

title: LONDON'S TRANSIT BATTLE ECHOING FAR AND WIDE
description: Who should pay the costs of urban mass transportation? The traditional answer has been, the people who ride on it. But when inflation raises the price of the two-mile trip from St. Paul's Cathedral to Trafalgar Square to nearly $1, as happened earlier this year, should there be a substantial public subsidy?

title: Correspondent's Choice; A SEA CHANGE FOR SCANDINAVIANS
description: JOHN VINOCUR is chief of The Times bureau in Bonn. By JOHN VINOCUR

title: Around the Nation; Survivor Unable to Tell About Sinking of Ship
description: By The Associated Press The sole known survivor of a sunken West German freighter was reported too disoriented yesterday to be interviewed about the cause of a disaster that left 22 crew members missing in rough seas about 215 miles east of Bermuda.

title: Blues 4, Rockies 2
description: ST. LOUIS (UPI) - St. Louis ended a six-game streak without a victory, with Ralph Klassen scoring in a short-handed situation during a three-goal flurry in the second period that sent Colorado to its 10th straight defeat.

title: EGYPT AND ISRAEL POSTPONE PALESTINE TALKS
description: Egypt has agreed to an Israeli request for postponement of the talks scheduled for next week on self-rule for Palestinians in Israeli-occupied lands, a senior Foreign Ministry official said today.

title: AMERICANS WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: AMERICAN CATHOLICS A History of the Roman Catholic Community in the United States. By James Hennesey, S.J. Foreword by John Tracy Ellis. 397 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95

title: Q&A
description: Question:I have heard that there is a danger of tropical storms in the Caribbean in the fall. How bad is the danger, and when does the season end? - M.K., Syosset, N.Y. Answer:John Hope, the senior hurricane forecaster at the National Hurricane Center in Miami, says: ''The hurricane season generally extends from the first of June through the end of November. Hurricanes are most likely to occur in most of the Caribbean during the months of August, September and early October. A tropical storm has a circulation center in which maximum winds exceed 39 miles per hour; the system becomes a hurricane when the winds exceed 74 mph. On the average there are nine tropical storms each year, six of which reach hurricane strength; about half of these storms directly affect the Caribbean.

title: Westchester Guide; WILD TURKEYS MULTIPLY
description: Two dozen wild turkeys released in Dutchess County by environmental protection agents in the 1960's have increased their population to more than 1,000. A year ago, another two dozen were released at Pound Ridge and West Point in a continuing repopulation program.

title: Suez Canal Tolls to Rise
description: The Suez Canal Authority has announced an average 5 percent increase in tolls for ships using the 101-mile-long waterway linking the Mediterranean and the Red Sea. The increases will go into effect Jan. 1, the authority said Friday.

title: EASTERN PAINTED TURTLE; Chrysemys picta
description: Size: To almost 10 inches. Color: Black or olive upper surface and yellow underside.

title: Wagner 63, Post 62
description: Craig McCollum made both shots in a one-and-one situation with 13 seconds left for what proved to be the winning points at the winner's Sutter Gymnasium on Staten Island.

title: Edward Hausner SYRACUSE RETAINS TITLE, 97-88
description: Robin Smith of Queens putting up a successful shot over Jill Friedman of Syracuse yesterday in the championship game of the Manufacturers Hanover Invitational women's tournament.

title: Bridge; DEALING IN BIONIC PLAYERS, WITHOUT CARDS
description: Achallenge match to be played in Taipei, Taiwan, later this week will have a good claim to be considered the most unusual in the history of the game: Unofficial teams representing New York and Taipei will compete entirely without playing cards. Each player will sit at a computer terminal and see his cards, the bidding and other essentials on the video screen in front of him. He will make his bids and plays by pushing the appropriate keys.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Centers Hooked On Methaqualone
description: The drug methaqualone, better known by the brand name Quaalude, has stepped out of an illicit underground bazaar into an above-ground and perhaps barely licit market. The prescribers are licensed physicians working at ''stress centers'' that also claim to treat insomnia.

title: Architecture View; THE LEGACY OF MUSEUM DESIGN OF THE 1960'S
description: There is a museum explosion in the 1980's that is beginning to make the museum building boom of the 60's look like a practice run. In some ways this new museum wave is producing much more interesting buildings; they are far more revealing about the arts, including architecture, than most of the earlier structures. Many of today's most prestigious commissions are going to the architects of what used to be called the avant-garde - a sure indication that new styles, and new ways of thinking about the arts, are being adopted by the establishment.

title: HOW TO GO TO A SHOW IN STYLE
description: is contemplating a new type of presentation with mannequins parading in front of a screen on which close-ups of fashion details will be projected. Nina Ricci, 39 Avenue Montaigne. (723-7888.)

title: Canadians Cancel a Project For Rural Assistance in Haiti
description: The Canadian Government said today that it had canceled a rural development project in Haiti because the Haitian Government would not allow Ottawa to control administration of the program.

title: A LOOK AT WHO RUNS THE TRAIN STATIONS
description: AS most commuters would assume, Conrail, as contractor for the M.T.A., is responsible for the maintenance of all train-boarding facilities - the stairways and platforms, the track overpasses and tunnels. But Westchester's commuter train stations are the responsibility of their owners - and in many cases the stations themselves are not run by Metropolitan Transportation Authority, but are in the care of villages, private concerns or individuals.

title: November 29, 1981 NONFICTION AMERICAN CATHOLICS
description: A History of the Roman Catholic Community in the United States. By James Hennesey, S.J. 9 ARE WE ALONE? The Possibility of Extraterrestrial Civilizations. By Robert T. Rood and James S. Trefil. 1 AT DAWN WE SLEPT: The Untold Story of Pearl Harbor. By Gordon W. Prange. 3 BEAUTY IN PHOTOGRAPHY: Essays in Defense of Traditional Values. By Robert Adams. 14 THE BIG EIGHT. By Mark Stevens. 15 CREATURE COMFORTS. By Charles Addams. 14 DISNEY ANIMATION: The Illusion of Life. By Frank Thomas and Ollie Johnston. 11 FROM THE YAROSLAVSKY STATION: Russia Perceived. By Elizabeth Pond. 15 GOD'S FIFTH COLUMN: A Biography of the Age: 1980-1940. By William Gerhardie. 9 IN AND OUT OF THE GARDEN. By Sara Midda. 39 LIFE BEYOND EARTH: The Intelligent Earthling's Guide to Life in the Universe. By Gerald Feinberg and Robert Shapiro. 1 LIFE IN THE UNIVERSE. Edited by John Billingham. 1 LIFE ITSELF: Its Origin and Nature. By Francis Crick. 1 THE PACIFIC WAR. By John Costello. 3 THE PAPACY IN THE MODERN WORLD. By J. Derek Holmes. 20 THE PLAYBOY INTERVIEWS WITH JOHN LENNON AND YOKO ONO. Conducted by David Sheff; edited by Barry Golson. 7 THE QUEST FOR EXTRATERRESTRIAL LIFE. By Donald Goldsmith. 1 THE SKYSCRAPER. By Paul Goldberger. 14 SOMOZA: And the Legacy of U.S. Involvement in Central America. By Bernard Diederich. 15 FICTION HEAT. By Ed McBain. 12 MALLOY'S SUBWAY.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't want to operate the subway system. I just want input.'' - Mayor Koch. (40:5.)

title: JAME WYMAN: 'I ALWAYS DID FOUR-HANDKERCHIEF ROLES. UNTIL NOW.'
description: HOLLYWOOD Over the years, as the public's memory of her faded and the popularity of her ex-husband grew, she became known in the media as the former Mrs. Ronald Reagan. And to many on the street who said they remembered her so well, she was invariably mistaken for another actress, Jane Wyatt.

title: Economic Affairs; THE KING AND HIS GILDED COUNSELORS
description: F OR many years, the kingdom had been smitten by drought and disease. Grain was scarce and lamp oil dear. The people had become restive. Thereupon, a new king came down to rule the land from his mountain estate. He went throughout the kingdom and saw its hardships. Then he issued a proclamation that any who knew why their land had been disfavored should come forth and be heard.

title: Environews
description: ANYONE contemplating filing a noise-pollution complaint with the state's Department of Environmental Protection has only a slim chance of ever being heard.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Tax Rebel
description: As the news writers were fond of saying, Frank McNulty was a man who put his mouth where his money was and who spent a little over four years in prison as a result.

title: RECOUNT: A SLOW, CONTENTIOUS TASK
description: NEWARK ''I'M going to challenge this one,'' the lawyer said, looking at an absentee ballot on which a voter had scribbled something along the margin. ''These could be initials.'' A second lawyer examined the ballot - one of millions being rechecked across the state in a recount of the results of the Nov. 3 gubernatorial election - and said: ''I move to accept it.''

title: PREPARING FOR DOOMSDAY
description: THERE was all the down-home atmosphere of a Norman Rockwell painting. My grandmother and grandfather beamed with pride as three generations of offspring paid tribute on their 50th wedding anniversary.

title: DUMP DISPUTE STIRS NORTH HEMPSTEAD
description: PORT WASHINGTON THE 57-acre pit where the Town of North Hempstead dumps most of its refuse is in many ways a typical municipal landfill. Its construction conforms to legal requirements, and it has passed official inspections.

title: Ideas & Trends; OF LITERATURE AND SHARED MYSTERIES
description: ALBERT Einstein once said, ''The most beautiful thing we can experience is the mysterious. It is the source of all true art and science.'' A symposium earlier this month at the Library of Congress, calling together men and women from the worlds of science and letters, gave proof of this common wellspring. Through poems, fiction, scientific observation and philosophical discussion, participants revealed the ineluctable effects of science on the literature of our technological civilization and, in turn, the lyrical expression of the scientific mind. Excerpts follow.

title: REAGAN RENT AID PLAN HELD 'DISASTER' FOR CITY
description: Regional officials have begun criticizing the Reagan Administration's proposed ''voucher'' system to subsidize the rents of the poor.

title: HISTORY WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: GOD'S FIFTH COLUMN A Biography of the Age: 1890-1940. By William Gerhardie. Edited and with an introduction by Michael Holroyd and Robert Skidelsky. 360 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: Anne Barnes Is Married
description: Anne Ball Gibbs Barnes of Charleston, S.C., widow of Read Simons Barnes, was married yesterday to John Girardeau Leland. Canon Samuel T. Cobb and the Rev. Charles M. Furlowe 3d performed the ceremony at St. Philip's Episcopal Church in Charleston. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Ernest Gibbs, is entertainment editor of The Post-Courier newspapers in Charleston, where Mr. Leland is a columnist for The Evening Post. He is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Horace Wells Leland of St. James Santee Parish, S.C.

title: Debra Dee Doncaster Is Married to Samuel Bruce
description: Debra Dee Doncaster was married yesterday to Samuel George Bruce at the Trinity Lutheran Church in Somerset, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. H. James Meyers.

title: THE TEEN-AGER AS SEX OBJECT- ART OR EXPLOITATION?
description: PARIS Half a dozen years ago, in the grubbier reaches of filmmaking, there was a feeble vogue for snuff movies. These showed their protagonists being shot, strangled or slowly separated with buzz saws; but that was not the real point. The real point was the claim that the films had been made in countries where, as one put it, ''life was cheap''; and that what was shown happening to the character was in fact happening to the actor as well.

title: Jan A. Murray Is Bride Of John Patrick Tullai
description: Jan Allison Murray, a legal assistant in the New York law firm of Kelley Drye & Warren, was married yesterday to John Patrick Tullai, a naval architect. The ceremony was performed at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L. I., by the Rev. Bruce Rodgers.

title: 50 JEWISH PROTESTERS ARE SEIZED IN WEST BANK
description: About 50 Israeli demonstrators in the occupied West Bank were arrested by the army today and ordered held for two days of interrogation after gathering to protest the closing of Bir Zeit University and the demolition of Arabs' houses.

title: Miss Holmes Wed To P.W. Haigh 3d
description: Frances Walker Holmes, daughter of Mrs. John E. Slater of Cove Neck, L.I., and Fayetteville, N.C., and the late Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr., was married yesterday to Philip Wiley Haigh 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Haig Jr. of Fayetteville. The Rev. Robert L. Ladehoff performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Fayetteville.

title: PROSECUTOR BARS SEEKING NEW TERM
description: WITH his leave-taking seemingly inevitable in any event, United States Attorney Edward R. Korman said last week that he would not be interested in reappointment as Federal prosecutor in the Eastern District, which covers Nassau, Suffolk, Kings and Queens Counties.

title: 20-YEAR CRAFTS CENTER BOASTS A DIFFERENCE
description: NEW HAVEN THE Creative Arts Workshop, celebrating its 20th anniversary with a juried Christmas Crafts Sale by 175 artists, through Dec. 23, may have an edge over such prestigious country cousins as Wesleyan Potters, Brookfield Craft Center, Guilford Craft Center and Farmington Valley Arts Center.

title: Q AND A QUERIES
