description: To the Editor:

title: THE SCHOOLS AND THE PRINCIPAL FACTOR
description: When Frank J. Macchiarola, chancellor of the New York City public schools, arrives at Jamaica High School in Queens to take over as acting interim principal on Wednesday, he will inherit in his new office a nine-foot-high corn plant that needs two quarts of water a week. Doris Reid, his new secretary, will take care of that.

title: Art; AIM UNREALIZED IN SUFFOLK SHOW
description: RIVERHEAD THE second in the series of monumental sculpture exhibitions, sponsored by Suffolk County in cooperation with local arts councils, is on view at the County Center through the end of December. Like its predecessor, which was seen at the Dennison Building in Hauppauge last summer and fall, the show has a lofty aim: ''To put public space to creative use, providing functional exhibition areas to celebrate the achievements of local artists.''

title: CIRCUS FINDS ARENA GOOD PLACE TO PLAY
description: EAST RUTHERFORD YOUNGSTERS squealed with laughter as the first contingent of clowns chased each other in mock fury to the accompaniment of the circus band. Minutes later, they sat in awe as the full circus cast took center stage.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Kathleen Supove Offers Modern Works
description: Kathleen Supove's piano debut Tuesday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall showed artistic and professional bravery. No ''Apassionatas,'' no Chopin, no Liszt for this debutant.

title: Miss Malkin Plans Bridal
description: The engagement of Cynthia Allison Malkin to Richard Blumenthal of Stamford, Conn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Peter L. Malkin of Greenwich, Conn., parents of the future bride. A June wedding is planned.

title: INJUSTICE PROMOTED BY COLLEGE POWERS
description: ON Thursday and Friday, the National Collegiate Athletic Association will hold a special convention in St. Louis to deal with the issue of reorganization of Division I-A football. The proposals to be voted on will, if passed, reduce the premier football division from 139 institutions to a number closer to 90. Three similar attempts have failed over the last five years, and the special convention must be viewed as testimony to the perseverance of the proponents of this change. But it should not be seen as indicative of any underlying justification of their position.

title: FRED DEAN IS A BIG PART OF 49ER SUCCESS
description: When the 49ers are in their conventional 3-4 defense, Fred Dean stands on the sidelines and watches the other defensive ends try to shut down the opposition. If they succeed, setting up a passing situation, the 49ers replace the 3-4 with a 4-3 or an under defense or a nickel, and Dean goes into action.

title: Music View; CELEBRATING THE 25TH ANNIVERSARY FOR BERGONZI
description: ''At his best, he is the most winning Italian tenor of his time.'' That is Harold Rosenthal, the esteemed editor of Opera magazine, summing up Carlo Bergonzi in the New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians. At first look, that statement might seem debatable if not actually inflammable, but after thinking it over for awhile I find it easy to agree. In all the flurry over the current crop of tenors - Luciano Pavarotti, Placido Domingo, Jose Carreras - it is possible that the older generation's accomplishments might be overlooked or undervalued. It is worth trumpeting, therefore, that Mr. Bergonzi and a houseful of his admirers will celebrate the 25th anniversary of the tenor's Metropolitan Opera debut on Friday evening, when the Met will present a gala concert in his honor.

title: AFTER THE TREMORS, SOCIAL CHASMS EMBITTER VICTIMS
description: For a few seconds the other evening, a rumbling sound, almost a roar, thundered across Balvano, a hamlet in the earthquake zone east of Naples. The walls of the two-story town hall shook in quick sharp jerks. The mayor's aide, who had been talking with two reporters, turned white and froze, then rushed toward the door. But before he reached it, the shaking and the rumbling stopped.

title: Business Conditions; OIL RESERVES HOLD FIRM
description: After four consecutive years of decline, the nation's oil reserves held steady in 1980, a recent report from the Energy Department shows.

title: BELFAST
description: To the Editor:

title: A PHOTOGRAPHIC AFFAIR WITH THE PINES
description: TRENTON ''ICAN'T get involved this deeply and forget about it,'' Robert A. Huss, a photographer, said. ''The Pine Barrens is an evolving thing, a living entity.''

title: Rutgers 74 Fairleigh Dickinson 72
description: Clarence Tillman scored a career-high 24 points for Rutgers. Tillman scored 18 points in the second half, making eight of nine shots from the floor and two of two foul shots.

title: SOVIET VISITORS DISCUSS PEACE
description: INSTEAD of attending discussions on social problems at home, Maria Poleschuk, a deputy to the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union, came to White Plains last weekend to discuss peaceful coexistence, disarmament and the United Nations.

title: PRODUCER STRESSES QUALITY
description: NOT too long ago some 20,000 theatergoers in Connecticut and Rhode Island received a mailer announcing a four-play season in New London of the Theater-by-the-Sea at the Garde Theater.

title: Children's Books
description: MEAN JAKE AND THE DEVILS By William H. Hooks. Illustrated by Dirk Zimmer. 64 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $8.95.

title: Theater in Review; MUSICAL TEAM HITS A DELIGHTFUL CHORD
description: HUNTINGTON STATION ISN'T it odd that so many musicals winding up as big-time Broadway productions have nondescript scores? The last thing one expects of new musicals, to the extent that they exist, is new music - or literate lyrics.

title: IN SELLING CONVENTIONS, IT'S BETTER TO BE NO.1
description: I N the hotly competitive convention center business, the object is to sell space that the tenant will use for only a week or so. The sales tools are superlatives - the biggest, the most convenient, the most adaptable, the newest. Ask Jerry Lowery, director of the New York Convention Center, now under construction along the Hudson River between 34th and 39th Streets.

title: FUND FOR NEEDIEST OPENS 70TH APPEAL
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund opens its 70th annual appeal today. The fund was established in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, the publisher of The Times, in response to reports of conditions of misery among New York City's destitute families. Since then, with a growing number of benefactors, the yearly appeal has brought comfort to thousands of unfortunate and impoverished people in the New York metropolitan area who might otherwise be neglected or overlooked.

title: The Region in Summary; Sterner Brand of Juvenile Justice
description: Youth, no doubt, will always be wasted on the young but, the New Jersey Assembly concluded last week, leniency should no longer be. It unanimously approved a package of bills to reform the state's juvenile justice system and impose stricter penalties for young criminals.

title: DUBLIN'S TIMELESS TRINITY
description: P.D. JAMES is the author of ''Innocent Blood'' and ''Death of an Expert Witness'' among other novels. By P. D. JAMES

title: THE MAN WHO DRILLS THE DEEPEST WELLS
description: OKLAHOMA CITY R OBERT A. HEFNER 3d, a handsome and graceful man, has all the markings of an American success story. He dedicated his life to a vision, fought the condemnations of experts, soothed the nervousness of creditors and today is a multimillionaire.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Tie-in time. Nervous. That's the word that Hollywood correspondents are using to describe the mood of the movie makers as they await the public's response to the score of films they're releasing for the holiday season, films in which they've invested sums as huge as $35.5 million.

title: 7 SEIZED IN CONNECTICUT AS POLICE FIND COCAINE
description: Six Connecticut residents and a California man were arrested today on drug charges as the police seized cocaine that they said was worth about $1 million.

title: Art; FIGURATIVE PAINTERS IN YALE SHOW
description: NEW HAVEN IT looks as if the current swell in representational art is here to stay for a while. And, to judge from ''Eight Figurative Painters,'' at the Yale Center for British Art, the situation is much the same on the other side of the Atlantic.

title: Dining Out; WHEN SERVICE IS
description: TOO ATTENTIVE By ANNE SEMMES

title: TRINIDAD'S NATIVE SOUP
description: JO THOMAS is the Caribbean bureau chief for The New York Times. By JO THOMAS

title: PHILHARMONIC OPENS ITS REHEARSALS
description: Orchestras keep their secrets and should. But the New York Philharmonic is opening the door a little on a few of them. The Philharmonic attempted a pilot program of Thursday morning open rehearsals a year ago. This season it has doubled the number of these public performances to 24, and listeners who are attentive, persistent and willing to pay the nominal three-dollar ticket price can now enter into this private world and share the mysterious process of persuasion and concensus by which musical performance comes together. They can also gain a sense of an orchestra's personality - the enthusiasms, the pride, the satisfactions, the frustrations and the resentments that pass between 106 virtuosos and their conductor.

title: KOCH NAMES LAWYER AS TRANSIT AIDE
description: Mayor Koch named a 42-year-old lawyer and transportation expert as his special transit adviser yesterday, saying that the new aide would strengthen the Mayor's ''working partnership'' with the city's Transit Authority.

title: Crafts
description: CRAFT sales designed to catch shoppers in their first round of holiday buying are becoming an established early-December tradition. Two events in northern New Jersey, as well as another across the George Washington Bridge, are scheduled for the coming weekend. Another show, whose repetition testifies to its previous success, will be held this week in Trenton.

title: REPORTER'S DISMISSAL IN BRINKS'S CASE DEFENDED
description: The editor of The Stamford (Conn.) Advocate says that an off-therecord conversation he had with a reporter he dismissed last week had ''confirmed for me that the information we had published'' about the reporter's relationship with a suspect in the Oct. 20 Brink's armored-car holdup ''was inaccurate.''

title: PRINCETON UNEASY IN WAKE OF RAPES
description: PRINCETON IN THE wake of several recent unsolved rapes and assaults near Princeton University, women at the university are beginning to question their safety on its quiet, well-manicured campus.

title: In Harsh Truth
description: Suddenly, holiday spirit is in the air. Festive lights pierce the early evening darkness. Children imagine and re-imagine what presents they will receive.

title: Article 110930 -- No Title
description: Political action committees and other organizations and individuals spent $10,601,864 urging President Reagan's election last fall through independent expenditures not subject to any contribution or spending limits, a report by the Federal Election Commission released today showed.

title: NEW TWIST IN FINANCING CHANGES BUILDERS' WORLD
description: Benjamin Lambert likes the drama. Mr. Lambert, president of Eastdil Realty, a successful middleman for multimillion-dollar commercial real-estate deals, has taken to using code names for clients to insure secrecy while a financial package is being put together.

title: PATCHED-UP JETS NOT COMPLAINING
description: It was Richard Todd's little joke, but it was edged with cynicism. ''How does it feel to be a hero in New York?'' a fan asked. ''Fine - for this week,'' Todd replied. Todd and his New York Jets' teammates find out today whether it lasts. A new week starts at Shea Stadium at 1 P.M. against the Baltimore Colts, and the Jets are in the unusual position of trying to hold first place after taking 12 years to get there.

title: FLORIDA TROUNCES FLA. STATE
description: Wayne Peace, the sophomore quarterback, threw for 275 yards and four touchdowns, and Brian Clark scored two field goals today as Florida routed archrival Florida State, 35-3, and earned a Peach Bowl berth.

title: NEW YORK REPUBLICAN PARTY GETS FEW TOP REAGAN POSTS
description: The New York Republican Party has received few major appointments in the Reagan Administration at either the national or local level. ''There has been no bonanza,'' said George L. Clark Jr., the new Republican state chairman. He won the post on the basis of his longtime support of Mr. Reagan, and with the expectation that he would have a better pipeline to the President than New Yorkers who were late to board the Reagan bandwagon.

title: Headliners Headliners Economic Intelligence
description: If knowledge is really power, Director of Central Intelligence William J. Casey, with his instant access to strategic economic data, is a powerful man indeed. According to the agency's deputy general counsel, Ernest Mayerfeld, Mr. Casey is also ''a very honorable person.''

title: Style; THE PLEASURES OF GIVING
description: he perfect gift is part of the enjoyment of the holiday season. But picking it out can be agonizing. On these and the following pages are suggestions that may assist in lessening that agony. onsider gifts of timeless appeal, some expensive and some not so dear: an Art Deco clock or a little girl's camisole, a crystal plate or a stocking stuffer, handknit sweaters or a chair made out of New York State twigs. oliday cheer need not end with the holidays. Arrange for delivery of fresh flowers several times during the year. Or enhance wintry memories with a strikingly handsome ice bucket. spread 4 ot everyone has everything, so don't discount the practical present. For a recalcitrant correspondent, why not an abundance of postcards ? Or wrap up a friend in a robe ? spread 5 inch a friendship with an eye-catching scupltured belt of handcrafted silver and lizard skin. And send mechanically-minded friends wheeling with this toy auto driven by picture-snapping tourists. spread 6 oyous gifts for one and all - a basket for the gardener, a teddy-bear chair for the children, a glass for the wine lover.

title: Northern Michigan 55 Elizabeth City 6
description: Tom Bertoldi connected on 22 of 42 passes for 443 yards and two touchdowns.

title: The Struggle of The Artist
description: In reference to Nina Darnton's article on the Polish film maker Andrzej Wajda, we are told: ''Like many liberal Polish intellectuals, Wajda has had to compromise at times in order to get past the censors while trying to retain his integrity and express, within limitations, a point of view'' (''Poland's Man of Films, Oct. 11).

title: New Jersey Housing; HOME-IMPROVEMENT LOANS THRIVE
description: WHEN the state's Mortgage Finance Agency, now 11 years old, began providing low-interest home-improvement loans in 1978, its assistant executive director, Constance B. Gibson, recalled that ''the skeptics thought we'd really be ripped off, that the 'suede shoe' guys would come in, take the money and run off to Bermuda.''

title: THE TRAVELING LIFE, AND THE TOLL IT TAKES
description: PHILADELPHIA S EVEN men, some sitting alone, are at the U-shaped bar in the Philadelphia Centre Hotel. A pianist plays ''Fly Me to the Moon,'' as the marketing manager for a multinational company based in Cleveland says that traveling 30 percent of his time is not only ''unglamorous'' but full of special problems.

title: Connecticut Guide; A CHRISTMAS VILLAGE
description: More than 3,000 people from Connecticut, or half the total attendance, visited the Center for the Arts in Westerly, R.I., last year for a 10-day atmospheric art and craft sale called ''Dickens' Christmas Eve,'' located less than a mile from the state line. ''Christkindlmarkt: A German Christmas Celebration'' opening Friday, is expected to draw even larger crowds from west of the border this year.

title: Nuclear Theater
description: The Soviet-American negotiations that begin in Geneva tomorrow concern ''theater'' nuclear forces. They cannot really be confined to weapons in the European military theater, but they will be played mostly to European galleries. For months, perhaps years, this conference will be a stage for the propaganda war that tests the NATO alliance.

title: STATE'S MURDER WITNESS SAYS SHE BOUGHT WEAPON
description: A 26-year-old woman whose tip to the police led to the arrest of four persons who were charged with the murder of three armored-car guards has testified that she bought one of the weapons supposedly used in the murders.

title: PROGRAM IN WILMINGTON, DEL., HELPS HOMEOWNERS
description: It was an unusual sight in these days of stratospheric mortgage rates, squeamish lenders and gloomy builders. Young buyers beamed at the progress on prospective homes as they picked their way across the bare earth where they could visualize their own grass growing, while all around them was the din of construction work.

title: Reading and Writing; CONCERNING LOVE
description: In ''Fish,'' a recent novel by Monroe Engel, I was struck by what seems to be a new emphasis or trend in our approach to love. It's only natural for innovations in love to appear first in fiction, for that's where most of us get our ideas about it. In fact, some authorities claim that romantic love was invented by writers in the Middle Ages.

title: THE UNSUNG AMERICAN COMPOSER
description: Lester Trimble, a composer and critic, is on the graduate faculty of the Juilliard School and is professor of advanced composition at the City College of the City University of New York. By Lester Trimble This is the time of year when I and 5,000 other professional American composers spend a good part of our Sundays poring over The New York Times, searching for announcements of American orchestral compositions scheduled for performance in the coming season - and the remainder of the day fighting off a profound sense of futility. At this point, of course, the full story of the 1981-82 season has not yet revealed itself, but there is no reason to expect that it will be any better, in terms of our native music, than the last two seasons have been.

title: PEKING TAKING AIM AGAINST SMUGGLERS
description: The Hong Kong fishing junk bobbing low in the waters off the Fujian coast prompted more than passing interest from a Chinese coast guard patrol boat.

title: LOCAL TEAMS BAND FOR GLORY
description: Once, most of the schools playing college basketball in the Metropolitan area were independent. No more. The expansion of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, automatic bids for many conference champions and large post-season paydays have everybody coming together in leagues. All 16 of the area schools listed below belong to a conference.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART Quite a lot has been heard lately about the new Italian painting. It has been talked about, written about, promoted and (finally) seen.

title: Puck-Throwing Brings Ban
description: Chris Nilan, a Montreal Canadien wing, was suspended for three games today by the National Hockey League for throwing a puck last weekend at Paul Baxter, a Pittsburgh Penguin defenseman.

title: Notre Dame 82 St. Joseph's 52
description: John Paxon and Cecil Rucker scored 22 points each to lead the Irish in their opener. Paxon, a junior guard, shot 10 for 14 from the floor and made a game-high five assists and three steals. Rucker, a sophomore center, was nine for 14 from the floor and hauled down 15 rebounds, high for the game. St. Joseph's (1-1) made 19 turnovers.

title: Long Island Journal
description: UNABLE to raise money to finance this season - or retire a $52,000 deficit from last year - the Long Island Symphony has canceled its 1981-82 schedule. Some 500 subscribers, who had contracted to attend the orchestra's five series of three concerts each, will have their money refunded, said Donald Gebhardt, the orchestra's vice president. The October premiere was postponed, and the season was to open the weekend of Dec. 11.

title: Andrea Gray Wed to Stanley Stillman
description: Andrea Gray, an art consultant, and Stanley Wells Stillman, founder and editor and publisher of the Access Publishing Company, a publisher of daily news summaries, were married yesterday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. David H. C. Read performed the ceremony.

title: Long Islanders; A BIG-BAND LEGACY PLACED IN HIS TRUST
description: IN Larry O'Brien's case, roots are a bit difficult to find. As best as can be determined, in the East, they're in Garden City, where his parents, Vincent and Lenore, live. And in the West, they're in Las Vegas, where Mr. O'Brien was just becoming accustomed to a settled life when opportunity beckoned.

title: I am grateful to Andrew Silk for his honest and thoughtful account of his illness. I am only sorry that I could not have read such an article before, not after, I had passed through the same fire. I have Hodgkin's disease and, like Mr. Silk, I can reasonably expect to survive beyond five years - the interval that signals the nearest thing to a cure.
description: It is, in a way, our gain to be shown our own death early in life, and to be allowed to draw back from it.

title: No Headline
description: Around the World; Scores of Bodies Found North of San Salvador

title: NEW ZEALAND PARTY LOSES EDGE IN VOTE
description: Prime Minister Robert D. Muldoon's National Party appeared to have lost its legislative majority in national elections today.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; TRACY KIDDER
description: When he was an undergraduate at Harvard back in the mid-60's, Tracy Kidder was so fearful that science and technology were beyond his comprehension that he studiously avoided taking any courses involving them. Ironically, any number of critics are now hailing the skill with which he has transformed technological complexity into highly accessible English in ''The Soul of a New Machine,'' which is now No. 12 on the nonfiction best-seller list.

title: PAPER MILL PLAYHOUSE ON THE ROAD TO REVIVAL
description: MILLBURN WHEN fire destroyed the stage and auditorium of the Paper Mill Playhouse here on Jan. 14, 1980, the British Broadcasting Corporation reported ''the loss of one of the finest regional theaters in the United States.''

title: Points of View Over a Sign
description: For the benefit of John Higgins, who placed the message atop his restaurant, ''AWAC Score: USA-52, Israel-48''(''Points of View From a Rooftop,'' Nov. 8) and others who think like him, may I point out that more than 300 members of the House of Representatives voted against the Awacs deal, including all the members of the Long Island delegation; our two Senators did likewise. Can these all be Israelis?

title: AFRICAN NATIONS TO SEND TROOPS TO CHAD BY DEC. 17
description: Five African nations formally agreed today to the the deployment of peacekeeping troops in Chad by Dec. 17, the first such force assembled by the Organization of African Unity.

title: Topics; TERRIBLE TIMING; Up the Down Index
description: The new monthly Consumer Price Index suggests that inflation may be slowing down, especially in the New York region - where it actually showed a decline, for only the second time in 15 years.

title: Enid Schildkrout Married to Editor
description: Dr. Enid Schildkrout, associate curator of the department of anthropology at the American Museum of Natural History, and Dr. John Anthony Van Couvering, editor in chief of the museum's Micropaleontology Press, were married yesterday. The Rev. Frank Church performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls.

title: WHY 'THE NUTCRACKER' IS AMERICA'S BREAD-AND-BUTTER BALLET
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jack Anderson is the author of ''The Nutcracker Ballet'' published by Mayflower Books. By JACK ANDERSON

title: Television Week
description: Of Blake and Steinbeck John Steinbeck's best-selling novel ''Of Mice and Men,'' the story of the relationship between two Southern ranch hands, was made into a play in 1937, starring Broderick Crawford and Wallace Ford and subsequently into a movie in 1940 with Burgess Meredith and Lon Chaney Jr. This time around, it's a television drama starring Robert Blake as George and Randy Quaid as Lenny, his strong but retarded companion. It will be broadcast on NBC Sunday night at 9.

title: No Headline
description: No matter how whimsical a sense of humor the owner of the outdoor advertising board may wish to display from time to time, choosing to publish a particular exhibit, ''AWAC Score: USA-52, Israel-48,'' to my mind is unconscionable at a time when anti-Semitic outbreaks on Long Island and worldwide have reached too high a number to be acceptable. SIEGMUND SPIEGEL, East Meadow

title: RESTITUTION IS FOUND TO WORK
description: CAMDEN THE crime: Smashing windows and breaking a fence at a municipal building. The punishment: Spending 10 hours working at the same city building and being held responsible for all repair costs not covered by insurance. The crime: Stealing a bicycle. The punishment: Earning half the cost of the bike and giving the money to the victim of the crime.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: San Francisco 92 Georgia 84
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Quintin Dailey of San Francisco scored 26 of his game-high 39 points in the second half.

title: The World in Summary; Shirley Williams Proves Appeal of Social Democrats
description: So much for Britain's two-party system. A third entry - the new Social Democratic Party, in alliance with the Liberal Party - last week inserted itself firmly into contention for national power by electing its first bona fide Member of Parliament in a district that had been ''safe'' for the Conservatives for 30 years.

title: MEDICAL COLLEGE POSES CHALLENGE FOR ITS PRESIDENT
description: VALHALLA AFORMER president of the Dutchess Community College in Poughkeepsie, Dr. John J. Connolly, recently assumed the presidency of the New York Medical College without the pomp and ceremony usually afforded such an academic achievement.

title: Headliners; Sakharov's Hunger
description: In exile for 22 months far from Moscow, Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident Soviet Nobelist in physics, is reported to be subjecting himself to another punishment, a fast, that his daughter-in-law says is aggravating his heart condition. It will continue, it is said, until his son's wife-by-proxy is permitted to emigrate. Dr. Sakharov says she should not be penalized for his activities; his son, meanwhile, has applied for a Soviet visa to return to the Soviet Union to formalize the marriage.

title: Critics' Choices
description: POP MUSIC The Holy Modal Rounders have been called the first psychedelic folk group, and if that sounds like a contradiction in terms, well, so are the Rounders. Peter Stampfel plays traditional mountain music on his banjo and fiddle and Steve Weber flatpicks his guitar like an urbanized Elizabeth Cotton, and they both sing, Mr. Stampfel in a high, rangy yowl, Mr. Weber with a bluesy, blown-out croak.

title: 72 FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS CITED FOR VIOLATIONS OF HEALTH CODE
description: The New York City Department of Health has cited 72 food establishments for violations of the Health Code. It also named 12 that were reopened after correcting violations and five that were closed for failing to do so. The establishments are: VIOLATIONS Long John Lounge, 2154 Amsterdam Ave. Pink Tea Cup, 310 Bleecker St. Szechuan West, 2656 Broadway. Bit of Bengal, 2667 Broadway. River View Bar, 3553 Broadway. Zois Pizza, 3780 Broadway. Mama Lila, 3790 Broadway. El Espanol, 3825 Broadway. Las Parados, 3880 Broadway. Kwik Time, 115 Church St. Raul's Cafe, 112 Dyckman St. Vorilas Babatsikos, 317 Greenwich St. Portofino, 551 Hudson St. Yan Yan Take Out, 281 Lenox Ave. Bosphorous East, 121 Lexington Ave. Longley's, 569 Lexington Ave. El Angel Negro, 1697 Lexington Ave. Dee Dee Pizza, 1548 Madison Ave. Gladys', 278 Nagle Ave. Noche de Ronde, 1256 St. Nicholas Ave. Pan Am Employees' Cafeteria, 200 Park Ave. El Buturro, 1490 St. Nicholas Ave. El Rey Del Bistel Y Caridad, 1618 St. Nicholas Ave. B & H Dairy, 127 2d Ave.

title: Silver Taken From Church
description: About $50,000 worth of silver was discovered missing from a landmark Philadelphia church Friday, the authorities said. The police said that six large and six small silver alms basins had been taken from the 125-year-old St. Paul's Episcopal Church. The church's communion silver was also missing, said the church rector, the Rev. James Moodey.

title: Charity's Kettles Banned
description: The Salvation Army began its Christmas kettle solicitation Friday, but not at Target discount stores.

title: QUEBEC TAKES A GAMBLE ON ASBESTOS
description: THETFORD MINES, Quebec T HE scene is obviously a ski resort. Snowflakes fall heavily out of the early evening darkness. All around, high above the town, the hulks of mountains loom slightly darker than the early winter sky, their immense outlines sparsely peppered by the wan, rowed lights of the lifts, no doubt.

title: MAJOR PROVISIONS
description: Following are the major provisions of the five-bill juvenile justice package: (1) - No child under 12 years old would be placed in locked detention unless he or she was charged with an offense that, if committed by an adult, would be a first- or second-degree crime or arson.

title: No Headline
description: As the husband of an incredibly courageous woman who has triumphed over cancer, not once, but three times, I must take issue with Andrew Silk when he '' . . . exempts himself from all responsibility for his recovery.'' The intimate involvement of psyche and soma during episodes of life-threatening illness is well documented. That my wife is still able to discharge her duties as a nurse and teacher is, I feel, eloquent testimony to her indomitable spirit as much as tribute to the skill of her oncologist. ARNOLD SOLIS COHEN, Philadelphia

title: Tulane 48, L.S.U. 7
description: NEW ORLEANS (AP) - The quarterback Mike McKay threw four touchdown passes to lead Tulane over L.S.U. in a 99-year-old rivalry. It was only Tulane's third victory over L.S.U. since 1948, the last time Tulane was both favored and victorious.

title: Theater; WHAT WAS COMEDY BECOMES A FARCE
description: level restaurant named The Scenario with a theater upstairs. The theater is a small one, with seating at tables where drinks may be ordered. At capacity, it holds 60 to 70 people. Because the floor is not raked, I would not guarantee great visibility from a rear table. Furthermore, table seating, which leads to informality among the audience, can also lead to conversation, not a help if you are trying to hear what is occurring on stage.

title: Crime
description: Lawrence Block, in his novels about the hapless crook Bernie Rhodenbarr, has demonstrated a fluffy touch. But there is nothing fluffy about A STAB IN THE DARK (Arbor House, $10.95), a grim novel set in New York. An alcoholic ex-cop is hired to look into a murder committed nine years ago. The victim was counted at the time as one in a series of ice-pick killings, but now it appears that somebody had copied the ice-pick psycho's style. The dead girl's father wants to know the whole story.

title: Gallery View; THREE FRENCH LANDSCAPISTS WITH A COMMON VISION; RICHMOND, Va.
description: There are times when small is beautiful, and one of them is right now at the Virginia Museum of Art in Richmond, where there can be seen (through Dec. 27) an exhibition called ''Three Masters of Landscape: Fragonard, Robert and Boucher.''

title: Business Conditions; INTEREST RATES AS A BAROMETER
description: Economists have long looked at the differences between long- and short-term interest rates as a barometer of current market conditions, but few have employed so-called yield curve models to forecast future movements in the economy.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: FIRST, there were the rumors. The Two Guys store at the corner of Broad Street and Raymond Boulevard in Newark, the rumors went, was in trouble. Then newspaper financial pages began to report that Vornado Inc., corporate parent of Two Guys, the discount varietystore chain, was in difficulty. In January 1980, 12 of the company's stores in the Camden-Philadelphia area were closed.

title: CANADA-U.S. IRRITANTS RUB BOTH WAYS
description: Late last month, Peter M. Towe, Canada's ambassador to the United States, began a speech on relations between the two countries in the traditional fashion. ''We are two nations sharing a continent,'' he said. ''We share prosperity, fears and many values. We also share a great deal of history.''

title: DEXTER AND HOCKNEY TEAM FOR STRAVINSKY TRIPLE BILL
description: Among opera's most successful renewers of ''classic'' 20th century works are two Englishmen who became associated with each other when they joined forces for ''Parade,'' a triple bill of short French pieces (a ballet by Satie, and operas by Ravel and Poulenc) that was the unexpected hit of the Metropolitan Opera's winter season last year.

title: COLORADO RESORT
description: To the Editor:

title: IT'S GETTING EASIER TO BUY A HOME
description: I N the rubble of the worst year in decades for residential real estate has sprung the hint of a better day: The price of a home mortgage is going down.

title: THE TIME, THE SPACE, THE QUIET
description: BY the year 2001, present trends holding, we will be a nation of poets and novelists. That is the American Dream, and failure to understand this has led to immense confusion about ''national purpose.'' By that millennial year, all Americans -and most resident aliens - from nursery school to graduate school will be enrolled in some writers' workshop. Out of this critical mass great art must mushroom, in unprecedented magnitudes.

title: MOBIL BATTLES IN COURT FOR MARATHON OILFIELD
description: The president of the Mobil Oil Corporation testified today that his company wanted to take over the Marathon Oil Company only if the deal included Marathon's rich Yates oilfield in Texas.

title: Shere Hite And Sex Research
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSFIXED BY MOONLIGHT AND ANOTHER SILVERY GLOW
description: IT was the first weekend in December. The changing seasons had swept away all traces of summer from the beach at Westhampton. The houses remained, to be sure, but they no longer dominated the scene, and somehow seemed unsure of their place, no longer buoyed by the crowds. The winter beach is somehow more elemental; the rhythm and flow of life seems close at hand.

title: PASSPORT TO PARIS FASHION
description: BERNADINE MORRIS covers fashion for The Times. By BERNADINE MORRIS

title: Deborah Connor Married to Myles Alan Coker Jr.
description: Deborah Connor, project editor of the college department at the Random House Publication Company, was married yesterday to Myles Alan Coker Jr., a partner in the Liberty Government Securities Group, a company designed to assist small businesses and small investors with their financial planning.

title: Hofstra 64, Southampton 58
description: Dan Rumpf scored 18 points and Charlie Minor 13 for Hofstra. Hofstra, which trailed by as many as 8 points earlier, led by 28-26 at halftime.

title: Stage View; MISS HEPBURN DANCES RINGS AROUND A CLUMSY 'WALTZ'
description: Although ''The West Side Waltz'' began its cross-country journeyings approximately one year ago, I'm not sure that author Ernest Thompson realizes even now what multiple small miracles Katharine Hepburn is bestowing upon his play. I say this because of a casual three-line dialogue exchange that takes place somewhere past the halfway mark during the piece at the Barrymore, an exchange that Mr. Thompson has of course written. But before we can examine its implications, I'll have to brush you in on the evening's plot. Or what passes for its plot. To wit:

title: MUSEUM'S GROWTH TIED TO HEMPSTEAD
description: HEMPSTEAD AFTER a year that sometimes saw it ''hanging on by its fingernails,'' according to the president of its board of trustees, the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island is marking its first anniversary in its storefront quarters here and hoping that the revitalization of the distressed downtown area will not only help it survive, but also transform it into the Island's major showcase for contemporary art.

title: LEASES MUST PROTECT OWNERS
description: In an article Nov. 15, Kenneth B. Laub, whose company provides real estate services to office tenants, wrote that escalation clauses in office leases were becoming ''profit centers'' for landlords and would in the long run drive tenants away. The following article is a reply by the president of the Sylvan Lawrence Company, one of the city's largest owners of office property. By CHARLES L. GOLDENBERG

title: WHAT PRICE A BUDGET VICTORY?
description: To the Editor:

title: Monica Harris Wed to C. W. Blume Jr.
description: Monica Linda Harris, assistant secretary for administration of the Dubai Bank Ltd. in New York, and Clinton Willis Blume Jr., vice president of Cushman & Wakefield Inc., were married yesterday at St. George's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Thomas A. Pike performed the ceremony.

description: Hondurans voting for first civil- ian president in 10 years 3 Around the World 4 South Africa denies involvement in attack on the Seychelles 5 Budget cuts are curbing U.S. educational exchanges 6 New law curbing universities troubles Turkish educators 7 Finland's presidential election could hinge on political deal 8 Israeli demonstrators arrested on West Bank 10 Poles in Toronto
