Post 81 City ballet performs ''Tempo di Valse'' 82 Fancy Dancers Company at Riverside Church 83 Debuts in review 83 Chamber music concert at the Brooklyn Academy 83

title: ADIRONDACK GROUP ACQUIRES 4 ISLANDS
description: The Adirondack Nature Conservancy has acquired four small islands in Lake Champlain that are said to be the nesting ground of 10,000 pairs of ring-billed gulls.

title: The Region in Summary; For O'Neill, an Impolitic Ailment
description: Doctors said last week that Gov. William A. O'Neill appeared to have suffered no permanent damage from his mild heart attack 10 days ago. But they were speaking medically; politically, it could be another matter.

title: The Nation in Summary; And That's That, Weinberger Says
description: There had not been much doubt about the Reagan Administration's priorities, but last week, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger let retary Caspar W. Weinberger let them be perfectly clear again.

title: 2 Hurt in Jersey Plane Crash
description: A light plane caught in a gust of wind as it approached a runway at Aeroflex Airport stalled and smashed into a hill Friday morning, critically injuring a student pilot and his instructor.

title: OHIO AUDIT FINDS THEFT OF $400,000
description: An inquiry into the loss of $1.3 million from the State Treasurer's office has found that more than $400,000 was embezzled and that at least $400,000 more may have been taken, an independent auditing concern has reported.

title: The Bettmann Behind the Archives What a marvel Otto Bettmann is (''The Bettmann Behind the Archives,'' by Helen Markel, Oct. 18).
description: A dozen years ago, I ordered a print from the archive, an insignificant $10 order.

title: Westchester Housing; CON EDISON ENERGY SAVER TO OPEN
description: A$250,000 house with a $400 annual heating bill has been built in Briarcliff Manor as a demonstration of energy-saving features by Con Edison and will be open to the public for about two years, beginning Dec. 16.

title: Miss Story Is Married
description: Kimberly Sue Story, a reporter for KTLA News in Los Angeles, and Peter Lukas Shaplen, a producer with ABC Network News in Los Angeles, were married yesterday at University United Methodist Temple in Seattle. The wedding was performed by the Rev. Melvin Finkbeiner.

title: AT PUBLIC HEARING, OUTRAGE ON BUDGET JUST BENEATH SURFACE
description: THE debate over Westchester's 1982 budget moved briefly but dramatically last week from the County Office Building, where commissioners and others have been presenting orderly rebuttals to cuts proposed by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello, to the first of three public hearings, where outrage and frustration were barely concealed.

title: HEROIN OFFENSIVE ASSAILED AS 'SHAM'
description: Ernie Handy stumbled along a dirty sidewalk in San Francisco'sSouth of Market district, his pants supported precariously by a piece of string. To the untrained eye, he looked like many of the unshaven men sipping wine nearby.

title: About Long Island
description: I SEE it all: the Elizabethans, or whichever fiendishly energetic people it was who thought up all the homilies, were inspired by a cold, rainy weekend following just such a long, warm autumn as we have had.

title: Brezhnev Plays To Europe's Arms Anxiety
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, on his first trip to the West since Soviet tanks rolled into Afghanistan, spent three days in West Germany last week trying to make the most of opposition there and elsewhere in Europe to NATO's weapons plans. He presented Chancellor Helmut Schmidt with a new communication line to nuclear missile negotiations, outside the channel that has reached Bonn via Washington and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The effect was to build up Mr. Schmidt as an apostle of detente and to raise West Germany's status as an East-West interlocutor, a position with a potential for reviving old animosities in Europe.

title: ROSEMARY FOR MEDITATION
description: There is no conventional category for Sara Midda's exquisite new book, ''In and Out of the Garden'' (Workman, $14.95). Miss Midda, a young English watercolor artist with a distinctive miniaturist style and a gift for jewel-like colors and whimsy, has compiled a fantasy volume of gardening lore set in a never-never land of prettiness.

title: CAROLINA COUNTY AND A UTILITY BATTLE OVER CHEAP ELECTICITY
description: Fifteen years ago several thousand residents of Greenwood County were placed in a price time-warp that has them paying 1966 prices for electricity in 1981.

title: ASSESSMENT FIGHT FOCUSES ON L.I.
description: THE skirmishes between the State Legislature and Governor Carey over the property tax have statewide implications. But in many ways, the property tax is a local issue - and particularly a Long Island issue.

title: PROPOSED RULE ON MILK DISTRIBUTION REJECTED
description: New York State's Agriculture Commissioner has rejected a new rule on milk distribution proposed by his department after it incurred widespread opposition. Opponents said the measure would interfere with competition.

title: Arrows Win 3d, 11-6
description: Steve Zungul scored five goals and led the New York Arrows to an 11-6 victory over the Cleveland Force tonight before 15,022 fans at Midwest Coliseum, the largest crowd to attend a Major Indoor Soccer League game here. Zungul's five goals raised his season total to 13 in three games, and his career total to 254. The Arrows, champions of the M.I.S.L., are 3-0; the Force is 2-2.

title: MAVERICKS TOP NETS, 111-107
description: The Nets were afraid it could happen, and it did. After outscoring the Dallas Mavericks, the team with the worst record in the National Basketball Association by 33-22 in the third quarter to maintain a 5-point lead, the Nets faltered and lost, 111-107, before 9,287 elated fans at Reunion Arena tonight.

title: Detroit Church Gets $405,000 As a Result of TV Broadcast
description: A minister says his church raised nearly $405,000 after it produced and broadcast an hourlong documentary about itself on local prime-time television.

title: MAKING DRAWINGS MOVE
description: DISNEY ANIMATION The Illusion of Life. By Frank Thomas and Ollie Johnston. Illustrated. 575 pp. New York: Abbeville Press. $49.95.

title: CHAMBER: BROOKLYN ACADEMY
description: Unusual configurations of instruments tend to generate unusual programs, and so it was at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Chamber Series Friday night. The basic components were violin, viola and cello, with Ronald Roseman adding his oboe to the Mozart Quartet in F (K. 370) and Britten's youthful Phantasy (Op. 2).

title: BLACK COUNCILMEN GIVE VIEWS
description: JERSEY CITY SINCE they took office last July 1, the political and legislative views of Bobby Jackson, president of the Jersey City Council, and Councilman Glenn Cunningham have been watched closely in this city, where progress by blacks has been a slow and predictable process.

title: Private Mortgages
description: To the Editor:

title: Sound; VALUES FOR CHRISTMAS SHOPPERS
description: In the weeks before Christmas, the bundles of mail arriving at this desk grow fat with letters asking for specific buying suggestions. Stereo apparently ranks high on many gift lists and, as in previous years, we will try to pinpoint some current standouts as an aid to Christmas shopping.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN BARCELONA
description: JAMES M. MARKHAM is chief of the Madrid bureau of The Times. By JAMES M.MARKHAM

title: DREAMS REVIVED BY A LOVE OF READING
description: WHEN I was growing up, many of life's doors closed in my face, but I didn't know it. I knew our family was poor but I never stopped to think that beyond the food and shelter that we were short on, I was also missing out on opportunities.

title: LENA HORNE AND MEL TORME- SINGERS AT THEIR PEAK
description: Lena Horne and Mel Torme have each currently reached a peak in their performing careers and both, during the past week, have put their peaks on exhibit in New York. Miss Horne's somewhat autobiographical concert, ''Lena Horne: The Lady and Her Music'' is continuing its tremendously successful run at the Nederlander theater, and Mr. Torme has just concluded a four week engagement at Marty's, the restaurant and cabaret at Third Avenue and 73d Street.

title: Marquette 67, Iona 54
description: ANCHORAGE (UPI) - Michael Wilson scored 20 points and Marquette played tight defense to gain the final of the Great Alaska Shootout.

title: Soviet Wins Gymnastics
description: Olga Bicherova, a 15-year-old, led the Soviet Union to a sweep of the medals in the women's all-round event at the world gymnastics championships today.

title: BYRNE'S CHOICE FOR CASINO UNIT TO FACE SENATE
description: Governor Byrne's nine-month struggle to put Joel R. Jacobson, his Commissioner of Energy, on the Casino Control Commission for the next five years is scheduled to culminate Thursday. The State Senate Judiciary Committee plans then to question the appointee and vote on whether to release the appointment for a confirmation vote by the full Senate.

title: Queens Youth Injured In Ice-Crushing Device
description: A 16-year-old boy was buried up to his neck in ice for more than an hour and his right leg was severely mangled yesterday before he was rescued from a huge ice-crushing machine at a Queens meat-packing plant.

title: Richmond 64 Wake Forest 61
description: RICHMOND (AP) - Tom Bethea and Kelvin Johnson scored baskets on breakaways to protect a slender lead for Richmond in the last 20 seconds.

title: Children's Books
description: THE NOSE TREE Retold and Illustrated By Warwick Hutton. Unpaged. New York: Atheneum/McElderry. $11.95. (Ages 4 to 8) By KARLA KUSKIN

title: Dining Out; INDIAN SPOT WORTH LOOKING INTO
description: WHILE not exactly the culinary melting pot that is Manhattan, Westchester supports and cherishes restaurants that offer good examples of diverse cuisines. Diners seeking the rich and strange take particular note when a new restaurant offering Indian cooking opens its door, and Abhilash in New Rochelle has now had its door open for four months.

title: THOROUGHBRED HORSE FARMS ON THE RISE IN COUNTY
description: BEDFORD HILLS DURING the American Revolution, mounted Colonial and British troops rode across the fields in the northern regions of Westchester. Today, horses are still a common sight here but many of them are thoroughbreds belonging to the growing number of horse farms that have located in this section of the county.

title: SMOKEHOUSES FIND RISE IN DEMAND
description: ON a calm autumn day, people passing Ronald Nodine's big, white Victorian farmhouse on North Street in Goshen can detect the delicious fragrance of burning hickory and maple. The aroma does not originate in Mr. Nodine's fireplace or wood stove, but in his smokehouse, where hundreds of pounds of meat, fish and fowl are being cured and smoked to create the distinctive color and flavor that is more in demand than ever by consumers, he says.

title: Travel Advisory; HAWAII BARGAIN, HOUSEBOATING; A Price That Actually Went Down
description: When you arrive you are greeted with a lei. You are driven to the Waikiki section of Honolulu. For seven nights you stay at a hotel where the whisper of the waves will lull you to sleep at night, and one evening you attend a cabaret show. That doesn't sound so unusual for a Hawaii tour package, but here is the difference: It is more than $200 cheaper than it was earlier this year.

title: Miss Loomis, R.B. Hubbell Are Married
description: Loren Worth Loomis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aubrey Kingsley Loomis of Windsor, Conn., and Robert Burr Hubbell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Hubbell of Kelly Corners, N.Y., were married yesterday. The Rev. Ray Lawrence Donahue, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. F. Van Gorder Parker, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Windsor.

title: BALANCING A CHILD'S FUTURE
description: IT'S Monday again, and a foster mother is waiting in the hall outside our conference room in the Essex County Courthouse in Newark. She has two of her five children with her. One is 3 years old and the other only 5 months.

title: Politics; CANDIDATES START MANEUVERS
description: HARTFORD THE immediate concerns of many state legislators at the General Assembly's special session these days may be as much political as fiscal as they struggle to balance Connecticut's current budget.

title: BUDGET DISKS LURE COLLECTORS
description: At a time of generally rising prices for records as well as most other commodities, it is comforting to realize that there are still budget-priced classical disks available, albeit at prices higher than they used to be. Furthermore, new ventures into the budget field continue to be made at a rapid rate. While some budget disks should be approached with caution, in general the performances and technical level are of high quality, and offer enticing bargains to beginning record collectors as well as owners of large collections seeking to experiment in new fields.

title: Art View; A PROBLEMATIC RIVIVAL OF A 'VICTORIAN PARAGON'; PHILADELPHIA
description: The large Landseer exhibition that has now been installed with a good deal of pomp and solemnity at the Philadelphia Museum of Art (through Jan. 3) is, without question, one of the most problematic events to be offered to the art public in a great many years. The revival of extinct reputations from the ranks of 19th-century Academic painting is no longer the novelty or scandal it once was, of course. Slowly but inexorably, these revivals have become an established datum of cultural life.

title: BROOKINGS SCHOLARS SAY CLEAN AIR ACT IS INEFFECTIVE
description: The Clean Air Act is having little effect in reducing air pollution and should be drastically revised, according to a study published today by two scholars at the Brookings Institution.

title: Mailbox; Why Can't Pros Have Fun, Too?
description: To the Sports Editor: The viewpoint expressed by Dave Anderson in ''Another Coach Is an Undercut Victim'' (The New York Times, Nov. 22, 1981) is a traditional one. Yes, coaches can be seen as authority figures being undermined by spoiled players, who are younger and less experienced but now the possessors of outrageous leverage reflected in their incredible salaries.

title: PANEL RECOMMENDS OUSTER OF UPSTATE JUDGE
description: The state's Commission on Judicial Conduct has recommended that one part-time Lockport City Court judge be removed from the bench and another be admonished.

title: San Jose State 28 North Texas State 16
description: The quarterback Steve Clarkson ran for two touchdowns and passed for a third to lead San Jose State. The Spartans (9-2) won the Pacific Coast Athletic Association title with a 5-0 mark.

title: HARD WORK PAYS OFF FOR ALLEN
description: ''I'm sore after a game, quite sore,'' says Marcus Allen, the University of Southern California tailback. ''All over - arms, back, everywhere. Just the entire body. I'm sore until Wednesday.''

title: Article 110918 -- No Title
description: More than six years after it was filed, a $490 million libel suit brought by the California resort La Costa against Penthouse magazine is to go to trial Monday in Superior Court here.

title: North Stars 5, Flyers 3
description: Dino Ciccarelli scored twice and added an assist in leading Minnesota in a violent and rough game that broke into a free-for-all after the final buzzer. Players dropped their sticks and picked out the nearest opponent during the melee.

title: The Dust Is All That's Settled
description: Even Robert H. Michel, the Administration's good soldier in the House, conceded that the spending bill Ronald Reagan vetoed was ''more a product of symbolism than substance.''

title: Headliners; Brady's Progress
description: When President Reagan says he is mindful of the risk he poses for others, he surely has in mind James S. Brady.

title: ADVICE TO NETS: ELIMINATE THE NEGATIVE
description: If Larry Brown, the coach of the Nets, is to succeed in bringing his team out of the doldrums, then he might do well to heed the advice of one who is familiar with losing, the Dallas Maverick coach, Dick Motta.

title: HEAD OF SECRET SERVICE SAYS ITS JOB IS NOW TOUGHER
description: H. Stuart Knight, who steps down Monday as director of the Secret Service, says that protecting Presidents has become tougher because of restrictions on intelligence gathering and the speed with which potential assassins can travel.

title: Advertising; Magazine Format For Books
description: AFTER toiling in the soft- and hard-cover book publishing business for the last 23 years, Norman Goldfind was well aware of the problems of paperback distribution and therefore was primed to act when Benjamin Sher stepped forward with his concept.

title: DEATH ENDS A 39-YEAR CAREER, STARTING WITH CHILD ROLES AT 4
description: In a Hollywood career that began when she was only 4 years old, Natalie Wood made scores of films, was nominated for the Academy Award three times, won numerous lesser acting awards, amassed a fortune and became a household name to moviegoers.

title: Retirement, Too, Is Better Late Than Never
description: Friends were always telling Matt Brooks that he looked pretty young for a 62-year-old man, but despite his youthful appearance, Mr. Brooks was beginning to feel the years. So he decided to put in for early retirement from his job at a stove factory in Warrington, England.

title: Researcher to Get Columbia Prize
description: A geophysicist whose research led to sweeping changes in the way oil and gas are produced has won Columbia University's Vetlesen Prize, ''the premier award for earth science,'' the school has announced.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Lotte Lenya on Satur- day said incorrectly that she had re- ceived an Oscar. She won an Oscar nomination for her supporting role in the film ''The Roman Spring of Mrs. Stone.''

title: IF POLICE PUT CROWDS ON CANDID CAMERA
description: To the Editor:

title: Iona Gets 3d Place By 71-58
description: Steve Burtt and Gary Springer, both sophomores, combined for 41 points and led Iona to third place in the Great Alaska Shootout tournament with a 71-58 victory over Washington State today.

title: Ilise D. Lipton Is Wed To Daniel J. Hulbert
description: Ilise D. Lipton and Daniel J. Hulbert were married yesterday at the Atrium West in West Orange, N.J., where Mayor Samuel Spina performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Lipton of West Orange and her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dan R. Hulbert of Floyd, Va.

title: OPERA: THE DARK DEEDS OF MACBETH IN CAPITAL
description: The Washington Opera's recent production of ''La Boheme'' made the most of the troupe's virtues and turned even its liabilities into assets. The result was the kind of theater rarely seen on the opera stage. Adequate rehearsal time plus an inspired use of limited physical space made it possible.

title: Sakharov Vows He Will Fast Until Couple Can Be United
description: Andrei D. Sakharov vowed to continue his week-old hunger strike until Soviet authorities allow his daughterin-law to join her husband by proxy in the United States, the human rights activist and nuclear physicist said in a letter to his family today.

title: DECLINE IN RATES MAY BE PROLONGED
description: The decline in long-term interest rates has been steep during the past month, and only the most extreme optimists expect that rates will fall by the same amount in the coming month.

title: MIDWAY AIRLINES ANGERS BIG CARRIERS
description: An aggressive advertising campaign by a small airline in Chicago has touched off a feud that could end the peaceful coexistence between the nation's large, established airlines and the smaller carriers that have proliferated since the industry was deregulated three years ago.

title: Question Box
description: S. Lee Kanner QUESTION: As a touchdown is scored on a 5-yard run, a referee in the N.F.L. calls a dead-ball foul - clipping -against the offense. Is the touchdown allowed? If so, what happens to the penalty?

title: THRIFTS, TOO, LIVE BY RATE COMPETITION
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Swim of Things
description: In 1979, a Louis Harris poll discovered that about 26 million Americans swim three or more times a week. Although the fad sport of the last decade has been jogging, along with road running, swimming seems to be the nation's top participant sport.

title: Medical Examiner Relieved of Duties
description: The deputy state medical examiner for Gloucester County has been relieved of his autopsy duties during an investigation into allegations he committed ''serious improprities'' in office, officials said.

title: HARD-DRIVEN ELECTRONICS FIRM
description: In California's Silicon Valley, many firms boast about an assortment of employee benefits such as flexible work hours, swimming pools and Friday afternoon social hours.

title: Lucille Roberts and B.P.  Moving to Geers Gross
description: Geers Gross Advertising, whose parent company is in London, has become agency for Lucille Roberts, the health spa chain, which is expected to spend $1.5 million for advertising next year. The account was previously at Calet Hirsch Kurnit & Spector.

title: CLEMSON IS ANTICIPATING NO. 1 RANKING
description: ''I was feeling kind of bad when Dan Marino threw those first two touchdown passes and Pitt was leading,'' said Homer Jordan, Clemson's quarterback. ''But when he threw that first interception, I became a Penn State cheerleader, a real cheerleader after that.''

title: Buccaneers 31, Saints 14
description: NEW ORLEANS (AP) - With his ground game sputtering, Doug Williams, the Buccaneers' quarterback, passed for two touchdowns and ran for one. All of the scoring for Tampa Bay (7-6) came after New Orleans (3-9) had built a 14-0 lead.

title: Israeli Protesters Released
description: All but six of 49 Israelis arrested on the occupied West Bank during a demonstration Saturday were released Saturday night and this morning, Israel Radio reported today. They had originally been told that they would be held for interrogation for two days. The demonstration, involving about 70 Israelis protesting the two-month closure of Bir Zeit University on the West Bank, was broken up by Israeli troops firing tear gas, several protesters said.

title: 3-1 Stalwart Takes Hollywood Futurity
description: Stalwart today won the secondrichest thoroughbred race in North American history, the inaugural of the Hollywood Futurity for 2-year-olds at Hollywood Park. He finished a half-length ahead of Cassaleria in the race, which carried a purse of $715,100.

title: EXCERPTS FROM 'SETTING MUNICIPAL PRIORITIES, 1982'
description: Following are excerpts from ''Setting Municipal Priorities, 1982,'' a report on New York City affairs compiled by Professors Charles Brecher of New York University and Raymond D. Horton of Columbia. The study seeks to put forth a possible agenda for the city in the coming year:

title: RIGHTIST PARTY IN HONDURAS TAKES BIG LEAD IN VOTE
description: The right-of-center Liberal Party appeared headed tonight for a clear victory in Honduras's first presidential elections since the army seized power in a coup in 1972.

title: College to Call Theater The Maureen Stapleton
description: Maureen Stapleton will be honored Dec. 15, when Hudson Valley Community College of Troy, N.Y., names its campus theater for the actress. Miss Stapleton, a native of Troy, will attend the dedication.

title: Why Treat the Elderly Like Children?
description: White House Conferences on Aging have a good track record. The first, bringing together experts and older adults from around the country in 1960, created the impetus for Medicare. The second, in 1971, was important in getting Congress to create the Administration on Aging within the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Bengals Rout Browns, 41 to 21
description: Last year Brian Sipe, the Cleveland quarterback, was the top-rated passer in the National Football League, leading his team to first place in the American Conference Central Division. Ken Anderson of Cincinnati was rated 24th as the Bengals finished last.

title: TWO MEN ARE KILLED IN A FIRE IN ULSTER COUNTY APARTMENT
description: Two men were killed early today in a fire in a three-story apartment building in this Ulster County village, the state police said.

title: MORE LONG-TERM ISSUES ARE COMING TO MARKET
description: Activity in the long-term capital markets remains brisk, and this week underwriters plan to sell more than $2 billion face amount of new issues. Of course, the amount actually brought to market could vary by several hundred million dollars, depending on market conditions.

title: SETBACK FOR MINORITY BUSINESS
description: Manuel Rodriguez worked for nine years as a union pipefitter in the Chicago area before deciding in 1977 to start his own business. When he won his family's support to use the three-bedroom stucco house that he built in his spare time as collateral for a $30,000 starter loan, he was on his way.

title: FORECLOSURES ON FAMILY HOMES RISING IN CITY
description: In a development that has surprised and disturbed New York City housing officials, a rapidly growing number of properties being taken through tax foreclosure are occupied one- and two-family homes.

title: Steelers 24, Rams 0
description: Franco Harris, breaking O.J. Simpson's record for most career carries, rushed for 114 yards and a touchdown, and the Rams suffered their fourth-straight loss, their longest losing streak since 1966. It was their first shutout since a 1978 playoff loss to Dallas.

title: Bit of Wagner Returns
description: When the package was delivered to the museum of the Conservatory of Music in Venice on Saturday, officials were miffed. It arrived with the equivalent of 45 cents' postage due.

title: WATERFOWLING NUANCES
description: a half-mile to the south - was moaning and we were hunting waterfowl on Shinnecock Bay. The surf has various voices, from its summer whisper on a gently sloping shore to its thundering mid-winter assault against storm-created escarpments of sand and jumbled glacial rocks.

title: FRANK ENTWISLE
description: Frank Entwisle, retired director of testing and guidance of the New Jersey Insititute of Technology, died Saturday in the Northfield Manor Nursing Home in West Orange, N.J. He was 91 years old.

title: ISRAELIS TAKE NO ACTION ON EUROPEANS
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin conferred today in his hospital room with key Cabinet members on the draft of a proposed American-Israeli statement designed to clear the way for European participation in a Sinai peacekeeping force.

title: WINFIELD LOOKS BACK ON SATISFYING SEASON
description: THERE was a song in Dave Winfield's heart and salami-and-eggs on his paper plate. This was in the Bagel Nosh near the Yankee outfielder's apartment in Fort Lee, N.J.; it was on the morning before his debut as a bass-baritone on a float in Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade.

title: CONFLICT SEEN IN REAGAN PLANS
description: Taking budget cuts ''out of the hide of the cities'' is contrary to President Reagan's desire to reduce the Federal Government's role, the president of the National League of Cities said today in protesting planned cuts in revenue-sharing funds.

title: Poetic Justice Comes Late for a Lawyer
description: ''O, Wind,/If Winter comes, can Spring be far behind?'' And if spring comes, can a Yale freshman really be expected to sit down and write an essay on Shelley's ''Ode to the West Wind''? Not right away. That, at least, was the assignment 30-year-old Maynard Mack gave 19-year-old Donald W. Hoagland in the spring of 1940.

title: ROCK: GENESIS AT THE SAVOY
description: BECAUSE Genesis is riding high on the charts with the album ''Abacab,'' one of the best-selling records of its career, the group's rare club appearance Saturday at the Savoy had the aura of a major rock event. But the music scarcely lived up to the ballyhoo.

title: Hartford Archbishop Faints
description: Archbishop John Whealon of Hartford, who collapsed Saturday outside a steam room at the Y.M.C.A., clebrated mass today and was reported in good health. The 60-year-old Archbishop collapsed about 4:30 P.M. Saturday and was taken by ambulance to St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center, where he was released from the emergency room 45 minutes later. Henry Stratton, assistant physical director of the Y.M.C.A., said the Archbishop apparently had stayed too long in the steam room and fainted as he left.

title: Stop Milking New York Consumers
description: Three years ago Derle Farms, a Brooklyn dairy distributor, offered to supply milk to Staten Island schools at a bargain rate. No sale, replied the New York Department of Agriculture and Markets; the city must pay a higher price. Why? The state had no gripe with Derle Farms, which was licensed to sell milk in Queens. But Staten Island was already ''adequately served'' by milk wholesalers.

title: CRASH KILLS 'HAPPIEST WOMAN'
description: Trisha Worby, a nurse who had been called the happiest woman in America in Gail Sheehy's new book, ''Pathfinders,'' has died in a traffic accident. She was 35 years old.

title: ALLEN TAKES LEAVE UNTIL F.B.I. INQUIRY ON $1,000 IS ENDED
description: Richard V. Allen, the White House national security adviser, announced today that with President Reagan's approval he was taking a leave of absence until the Justice Department completed its investigation of his receipt of $1,000 from a Japanese magazine that interviewed Nancy Reagan.

title: I.B.M. WINS FIGHT FOR BONN CONTRACT
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has won a hotly contested battle for a communications contract from the West German Government, it was announced today.

title: THE HORSE OF THE YEAR
description: THE Eclipse Award ballot arrived, inviting votes as to the best race horses in various categories in 1981. Some are easy. Best 2-year-old filly: Before Dawn; best 3-year-old colt: Pleasant Colony; best horse, colt or gelding 4 years old and up: John Henry; best turf horse, male: John Henry; horse of the year: John Henry.

title: BROADCASTER STARTS UP FINANCIAL TV NETWORK
description: Today is a red-letter day for Glen H. Taylor, a 56-year-old businessman with a variety of programming and television interests: His Financial News Network, a five-day-a-week, seven-hour-a-day television service, begins broadcasting on 13 stations around the country in an effort to expand the availability of business news to the public.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's time that this case be aired in a responsible forum, and that it not be made on the basis of innuendo and sly allegations.

title: Ringsiders
description: Sunnyside Gardens, the last of the neighborhood fight clubs in New York, has been gone for four years, replaced by a Wendy's hamburger restaurant. But tonight, in another section of Queens, a former movie theater and bingo parlor will hold the first professional boxing card in the borough since the demise of Sunnyside.

title: Browne and Zerbe Set For 'Broken Words'
description: Roscoe Lee Browne and Anthony Zerbe will appear in ''Behind the Broken Words,'' a ''celebration of language,'' opening Friday at the American Place Theater.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Burmah-Castrol Inc., Hackensack, N.J., has appointed John S. Gardella general sales manager.

title: CLARA C. FREEMAN
description: Clara C. Freeman, a teacher and counselor in the New York City school system for almost 40 years, died yesterday at North Central Bronx Hospital. Mrs. Freeman, a resident of the Riverdale section of the Bronx, was 59 years old.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE AND ALLEN'S LEAVE: NECESSARY STEP IN 'DAMAGE CONTROL' ; News Analysis
description: By permitting Richard V. Allen to take a leave of absence as national security adviser, President Reagan is in effect acknowledging that Mr. Allen has failed so far to clear up the questions raised about his behavior in office.

title: East Europe's Foreign Debt
description: Eastern Europe may owe more than $80 billion to Western countries and Japan by the end of 1981, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe said in a report today.

title: PRETORIA JAILS FAMED SOLDIER AFTER FAILED SEYCHELLES COUP
description: When a band of white mercenaries hijacked an Air India plane in the Seychelles Wednesday night after an attempted coup, a slightly built man in civilian clothes with a white goatee, calling himself Tom, stepped into the cockpit to give instructions to the pilot.

title: Protest at Tokyo Airport
description: About 4,000 riot policemen guarded the New Tokyo International Airport at Narita today during a rally by about 800 students protesting the planned construction of another runway there. There were no clashes reported between the demonstrators and policemen at the airport, 40 miles northeast of Tokyo. The Narita airport opened May 20, 1978, after a 12-year struggle by farmers and students opposed to the expropriation of farm land at the 2,600-acre site.

title: Virginia 76 George Mason 57 CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. (AP)
description: With Jimmy Mller leading the way, Virginia opened a 17-3 lead and went on to win the United Virginia Bank-Cavalier invitation tournament.

title: UNESCO SHIFTS APPROACH ON PRESS IN THIRD WORLD
description: After more than five years of talking about measures to let governments control reporting and reporters, Unesco says it is shifting its activities toward concrete projects that will improve communications equipment and technical training for journalists in underdeveloped countries.

title: PHILADELPHIA RAIL SYSTEM IMPERILED BY LACK OF FUNDS
description: Without an emergency transfusion of public funds, this area's commuter-train service could die before next July, transportation officials have warned.

title: BILLS SUBDUE REDSKINS, 21-14
description: Roland Hooks, the hero of Buffalo's victory last weekend, ran for two touchdowns today to lead the Buffalo Bills to a 21-14 victory over the Washington Redskins.

title: Raiders 32, Seahawks 31
description: SEATTLE (AP) - Marc Wilson threw three touchdown passes in the second half, including a 22-yarder to Art Whittington with 5:53 to go, to help Oakland rally to beat Seattle. Jim Zorn, Seattle's quarterback, suffered a broken left leg with 3:20 remaining.

title: KEEP RESEARCH AFLOAT
description: The good ships Vema, Atlantis II, Glomar Challenger, Melville and Eltanin deserve a prominent place in the history of United States science. They are some of the oceanographic research ships used, with extraordinary results, to explore the oceans during the past two decades.

title: WHITE HOUSE 'CRISIS': NO CASH FOR TABLECLOTHS
description: The White House has ''a terrible tablecloth crisis'' and has no money to purchase new ones, says Muffie Brandon, the social secretary.

title: No Headline
description: Bob Brumfield, 56, Columnist For Newspaper in Cincinnati

title: Lori Faith Glass Wed To Donald Lee Citak
description: The marriage of Lori Faith Glass, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Glass of Bay Shore, L.I., to Donald Lee Citak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Citak of Flushing, Queens, took place yesterday at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Ezra M. Finkelstein performed the ceremony.

title: FORECASTS TOO GLUM FOR REGAN
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan predicted today that the current recession would not be so steep as many private economists believe.

title: Chargers Gain Share of Lead
description: Chuck Muncie ran for four touchdowns in the first half today, and San Diego moved into a three-way tie for first place in the American Conference West with a 34-17 victory over the Denver Broncos.

title: WHEN MOTHERHOOD DOESN'T MEAN MARRIAGE
description: Even in the age of the so-called supermother, they are extreme examples of the breed: seemingly self-sufficient women in their 30's who are choosing to become unwed mothers, to combine careers with child rearing in a home where there is no father and no serious talk of marriage.

title: Leg Reattachment Believed a Success
description: A doctor at Bellevue Hospital said yesterday that he was optimistic that surgeons had been successful in re-attaching the right leg of a 16-year-old boy who was caught in an ice-making machine at a Queens meatpacking plant.

title: NATALIE WOOD IS FOUND DROWNED ON YACHT VISIT TO SANTA CATALINA
description: The body of Natalie Wood, the actress, was found today in a rocky cove off Santa Catalina Island, the Los Angeles County sheriff's department said. Investigators attributed her death to accidental drowning, pending further inquiry.

title: Spy to Face Escape Charges
description: Christopher L. Boyce, a convicted spy, was flown back to California Saturday for arraignment Monday on charges related to his escape from the Lompoc Federal prison in January 1980. Mr. Boyce, 28 years old, had been at the Medical Center for Federal Prisoners at Springfield, Mo. He was taken to a jail at an undisclosed location.

title: Leukemia Deaths Linked To Radioactive Waste
description: The national Centers for Disease Control have begun a new study of cancer deaths among Tennessee residents living near a plant where the Navy's nuclear fuel is produced, The Atlanta Journal and Constitution reported today.

title: Police Use 2 Trucks To Pick Up Loot
description: Officials said the Nassau County police needed two trucks to carry away the stolen merchandise they found in the apartment of a man sought on assault, burglary and other charges.

title: AIDE TO D.A. AND I.R.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: AT THE UNCHANGING TIMES OF LONDON, ALL IS CHANGE
description: It is 5 o'clock in the afternoon at the rather shabby building on Gray's Inn Road, a mile north of Fleet Street, that houses this country's most prestigious but most consistently unprofitable newspaper, The Times.

title: FRANCE SHORES UP ITS SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The Socialist Government here, like the conservative Reagan Administration in Washington, is trying to change what it sees as a runaway social security system.

title: Order on U.S. Steel Bid For Marathon Revised
description: A Federal District Court in Columbus, Ohio, modifying a temporary restraining order, has set a new proration date of Dec. 4 for the United States Steel Corporation's tender offer for the shares of the Marathon Oil Company. The modified order also permits resumption of solicitation for Marathon's shares.

title: JAPANESE PRIME MINISTER REORGANIZES CABINET
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki replaced his Foreign Minister and other Cabinet members today and announced other appointments to top posts in the governing party.

title: MCNEIL BEST SINCE BOOZER
description: AT the snap, the Jets' offensive linemen burst to their left and the Baltimore Colts' defense reacted that way. But suddenly the Jets' ball carrier, Freeman McNeil, cut to the right and hurried 30 yards into the end zone. That touchdown in the first quarter would be all the Jets needed in the wild wind at Shea Stadium yesterday for what turned out to be a 25-0 victory. But their rookie running back added a 1-yard touchdown while rushing for 93 yards on 24 carries. Quietly, slowly, the Jets are beginning to turn loose the club's most gifted running back since Emerson Boozer bounced through tacklers as if he were a billiard ball.

title: Sports World Specials; Winning Spirit
description: While a winning season in pro football is a new experience for every Jet except for Randy Rasmussen, three team members never played for winners anywhere - in high school, college or the pros.

title: Imperial Chemical Elects a Chairman
description: John Harvey-Jones, a 57-year-old former British naval officer, has been elected chairman of Imperial Chemical Industries, the diversified international concern, effective April 1. He will succeed Sir Maurice Hodgson, who is retiring from the London-based company at the age of 62.

title: ROBERT REHME, KING OF THE LOW-BUDGET SHOCKER
description: HOLLYWOOD HOW does a small distribution company compete with the major studios? When the big elephants of Hollywood - Columbia, Universal, Paramount, Warner Bros., 20th Century-Fox and M-G-M - are routinely the first to be offered every polished project and every gleam in a screenwriter's eye, how does a mouse like Avco-Embassy manage to survive?

title: WITH COSTS CLIMBING AND PROFITS FALLING, FARMING IN IOWA FACES HARD TIMES
description: The chemical fertilizer business was pretty good in Greene County last year, which was good news to Clarence Springer, a farm supply store operator here who had begun to worry because of the decline in the area's hog and cattle market.

title: U.S.-Caribbean Trade Plan
description: William E. Brock, the United States Trade Representative, said tonight that the Reagan Administration might ask Congress to approve one-way free trade for Caribbean Basin countries, which would give them badly-needed access to United States markets.

title: HARLEM CHOIR TURNS YOUTHFUL ENERGY TO ANGELIC SONG
description: Walter J. Turnbull strode commandingly into the cacophony. ''You should not have any gum in your mouths, and you should be ready to perform,'' he bellowed above the din generated by an assortment of boys in the church gymnasium.

title: Canadiens 6, Whalers 3
description: MONTREAL (AP) - Doug Risebrough scored his first three goals of the season to lead Montreal over Hartford.

title: Air Force Is Bowl Winner
description: The Air Force overcame a 16-0 halftime deficit with three touchdowns and upset San Diego State, 21-16, today in the Mirage Bowl.

title: YEAR-END BONUSES AID JAPAN ECONOMY
description: Every year at this time, a rising sense of anticipation grips Japan. During the next few weeks, a ritual occurs that is not only of central importance to Japanese households, but also, in the view of many executives and management specialists, helps explain why Japanese companies are doing so well in world markets.

title: DRUGS ARE AN ISSUE AT THE SOUTH POLE
description: McMURDO STATION, Antarctica, Nov. 27 - The traditionally close cooperation between the United States and New Zealand in the study of Antarctica has been undermined in recent weeks.

title: Lakers Trounce Rockets, 122-104
description: Norm Nixon and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 23 points each to lead the Lakers to a 122-104 victory over the Houston Rockets tonight.

title: THE SOVIET HOSTAGES
description: LewisBOSTON, Nov. 29 -Andrei Sakharov, the dissident Soviet physicist, got a letter to scientific friends in this country some time ago saying that he and his wife would go on a hunger strike starting Nov. 22: a week ago today. They ''despaired,'' he said, ''of breaking through the K.G.B.-built wall by any other means.''

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: F.A.O.'S STRATEGIES FOR WORLD FOOD SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkey Imprisons 25 As Suspected Terrorists
description: Martial law authorities announced today that they had jailed 25 suspected members of a left-wing terrorist group and seized 16 handguns, 128 dynamite sticks and other explosives.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 30, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: News Analysis
description: Within days of the Nicaraguan revolution in July 1979, it was apparent that the diverse groups that united against the Somoza regime had conflicting ideas of what kind of society should replace the 46-year-long family dynasty.

title: TIMES CO. IS ASSAILED
description: An advertisement in The New York Times yesterday accused The New York Times Company of anti-union tactics at a paper mill in Madison, Me., in which the company is a partner.

title: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH ALLEN AND HIS ANNOUNCEMENT TO TAKE LEAVE
description: Following are excerpts from the NBC News ''Meet the Press'' interview with Richard V. Allen, the national security adviser, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Florida 70 Miss. State 62 GAINESVILLE, Fla. (AP)
description: Vernon Delancy and Mike Moses scored 17 points each, and Ronnie Williams added 15 for Florida. Kalpatrick Wells of Mississippi State led all scorers with 19 points and dominated the inside game, pulling down a game-high 11 rebounds.

title: 7 SEIZED IN CONNECTICUT AS POLICE FIND COCAINE
description: Six Connecticut residents and a California man were arrested today on drug charges as the police seized cocaine that they said was worth about $1 million.

title: CONNECTICUT REACHES SOCCER SENIFINALS
description: The University of Connecticut advanced to the Final Four of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I soccer championships today with a 3-0 victory over Long Island University in the Eastern regional final.

title: IF POLICE PUT CROWDS ON CANDID CAMERA
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Will Get Gifts From Anti-Watt Unit
description: The organizers of a rally that was held here to protest a visit by Interior Secretary James G. Watt say they will give the police a share of the proceeds.

title: U.S. INQUIRY REPORTED ON SALE OF AIRCRAFT PARTS TO LIBYANS
description: A small company operated by a Turkish national is being investigated by a Federal grand jury for possible involvement in selling more than $10 million in military aircraft parts to Libya, according to The Chicago Tribune.

title: SURVIVOR OF SHIPWRECK CLUNG TO BOAT 26 HOURS
description: The sole person rescued after the sinking of a West German freighter said today that he hung onto an overturned lifeboat for 26 hours, with sharks circling a few feet away, and watched as his shipmates lost their grasp on floating debris and drowned.

title: LARRY FARMER: GOOD FIT FOR U.C.L.A. MOLD
description: LOS ANGELES ''SUPPORT Your Local Farmer'' says the button worn by a secretary in the athletic department at U.C.L.A. The slogan has nothing to do with avocados, figs, oranges or grapes, but rather with the latest crop of Bruin basketball players and their new coach, Larry Farmer.

title: POP: MANILOW IN NASSAU
description: ALTHOUGH Barry Manilow isn't quite the superstar today that he was five years ago in terms of record sales, the delirious audience response Friday to the first of two sold-out shows at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I., demonstrated that his career has plenty of steam left in it.

title: EAST GERMAN WINS 3 GOLDS
description: Maxi Gnauck, an East German student, accomplished a spectacular gold-medal triple, and China staged a protest of the scoring to divert some of the attention today from the Soviet Union's domination of the World Gymnastics Championships.

title: JETS ROUT COLTS, 25-0, FOR 5Th IN A ROW AS MCNEIL STARS
description: Easily and powerfully, the Jets scored their fifth straight victory, defeating the Baltimore Colts by 25-0 at Shea Stadium yesterday.

title: MEMBERS OF CONGRESS HAVE VARIED RESUMES
description: For many years, the legal profession dominated both houses of Congress. And while lawyers still outnumber all other professions in both the Senate and the House, they no longer are in the majority. Today's Congress reflects a broad range of occupations.

title: PCB's Are Found In Jersey Buildings
description: NEWARK (AP) - A chemical that emitted clouds of toxic residues during a fire in a New York State office building in January has been found in four transformers in two buildings in Trenton, officials said.

title: PETER BROOK STAGES AN AUSTERE 'CARMEN' IN PARIS
description: PARIS THE Parisian stage wears the sign of giantism this season -with Patrice Chereau's six-hour production of ''Peer Gynt''; Antoine Vitez emerging naked from a barrel to act in one part of Goethe's ''Faust'' and direct both parts, and a monstrous, vacant ''Carmen'' put on by the Paris Opera at the Palais des Sports.

title: Talks Aim to Avert Strike by Carters
description: A state mediator, James McCabe, brought representatives of the private carting industry and their workers back together yesterday in a final effort to avert a strike, which could halt refuse pickups at hotels, hospitals, restaurants and other commercial establishments at midnight.

title: AFRICAN PEACEKEEPERS ENTER CHAD
description: Senegalese soldiers arriving in Ndjamena to help control the civil war there. They have been asked by President Gou-kouni Oueddei to act as a buffer between his forces and those of his challenger, Hissen Habre. Four other African nations have agreed to provide additional troops.

title: HELPING THE SHORT CHILD COPE
description: M EDICAL specialists are giving new attention to the emotional problems of growing up short. While in the past, they say, attention focused mainly on finding appropriate methods of treatment for the child who is small because of a physical disorder, they now believe the traumas suffered by otherwise healthy children who are naturally of short stature merit far more careful monitoring because they have such a fundamental impact on developing personality.

title: Commodities; Oranges And The Weather
description: THE nip of winter in the air marks the beginning of the ''freeze scare'' season for Florida orange juice. It's also a time when owners of orange groves in Florida, producers of concentrated orange juice, supermarket buyers and store managers, commodity traders and some orange juice drinkers will be watching weather reports.

title: INTERMEDIATE SCHOOL PREPARES TO RECRUIT PUPILS COLLEGE-STYLE
description: During the next few weeks, Intermediate School 44 on Manhattan's Upper West Side will begin a student recruiting campaign of the sort usually expected of a college, not a neighborhood school serving sixth, seventh and eighth graders.

title: Bridge: 2 New York Teams Battle For Reisinger Event Title
description: Two New York teams were fighting for top honors in the final session of the Reisinger board-a-match team championship here tonight at the conclusion of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: SESSION ON AGING IS STARTING TODAY
description: The 1981 White House Conference on Aging, troubled by political controversy in its planning stages, is scheduled to open here Monday on an unscheduled note of protest.

title: PUBLIC WORKER UNIONS QUESTION PRIVATE CONTRACTS
description: Public employee unions, fearful of layoffs and lowered working conditions, are challenging moves by cities, counties and other jurisdictions to reduce costs by turning to private business for some services.

title: British Ex-Envoy Tells Of Love and Indiscretion
description: A former British diplomat said today that a love affair with an embassy maid led him into illegal links with Czechoslovak intelligence sources in Prague and London more than 20 years ago.

title: Swiss Tax Increase
description: Voters approved today a Government plan that would raise sales taxes to relieve chronic federal deficits and a debt burden that has reached about $11 billion.

title: Pact in Canadian Steel Strike
description: Officials of Stelco Inc. and the United Steelworkers of America said Sunday they had signed a tentative agreement that could end an 18-week strike at Canada's largest steelmaker.

title: Norwich Terrier Is Named Best
description: Ch. Thrumpton's Lord Brady, a 5-year-old imported Norwich Terrier owned by Ruth Cooper of Glenview, Ill., and handled by Peter Green of Bowmansville, Pa., defeated 2,272 rivals today in gaining his 81st all-breed best-in-show award at the 15th annual Boardwalk Kennel Club show held in Atlantic City's Convention Hall.

title: DANCE: 'NURSE'S SONG' AT THE KITCHEN
description: ''NURSE'S SONG,'' performed Saturday by Eiko and Koma at the Kitchen, is part of a full-evening work in progress choreographed to the ''Songs of Innocence'' and ''Songs of Experience'' of William Blake, set to music by Allen Ginsberg and inspired by poetry readings by Mr. Ginsberg and Peter Orlovsky. The chanted, lulling music was performed by Bob Carroll, an endearingly mad poet of a performance artist, and the Dirt Band -quite a mixture, even for the intrepid young Japanese experimentalists. And ''Nurse's Song'' is quite an experience.

title: Renee Weinreb Is Wed
description: Renee Weinreb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Weinreb, was married yesterday to Joseph J. Chester, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Chester. Both families live in Elmwood Park, N.J., where the bride's father is a councilman and police commissioner. Rabbi Alfred B. Landsberg performed the ceremony at the Landmark II in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Braswell D. Deen, 88, Ex-Congressman, Dies
description: Former Representative Braswell Drue Deen, who served in Congress from 1933 to 1939, died in an automobile accident Saturday.

title: No Headline
description: GERULAITIS DEFEATS BOROWIAK IN FINAL

title: DUPLICATE DEER HUNTING TAGS AID IN ILLEGAL TAKING OF GAME IN STATE
description: There is an easy, albeit illegal, way to skin more than one deer in New York State, and environmental officials are trying to figure out what to do about it.

title: ONCE AGAIN, LYNN, MASS., SEEKS TO REBUILD ON ASHES
description: Lynn today lay wreathed in smoke and gloom. Once again, fire had dwarfed the best efforts of its citizens to shape the future.

title: Karen J. Erlick Is Married
description: Karen J. Erlick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abram Erlick of Hewlett, L.I., was married yesterday at Monti's Town and Country in Hempstead, L.I., to Ira Alan Schaeffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Schaeffer of Brooklyn. Rabbi Jonah Javna performed the ceremony.

title: Cardinals 27, Patriots 20
description: Neil Lomax threw a 33-yard touchdown pass to Roy Green with 33 seconds left to give St. Louis (6-7) its third victory in a row and send New England (2-11) to its sixth consecutive defeat. The Patriots tied the score with 2:54 left on Vagas Ferguson's 3-yard run.

title: Fierce Fighting Erupts Between Iran and Iraq
description: Iran and Iraq reported fierce fighting today in Khuzistan Province, with Iran reporting that its forces killed more than 1,000 Iraqis and captured 1,300 in its ''greatest victory'' of the 14-month war.

title: CITY HAS FAILED TO USE THE RESOURCES OF ITS AGENCIES FULLY, A REPORT
description: SAYS By CLYDE HABERMAN

title: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1981; The Economy
description: A sustained decline of the dollar against major world currencies is not expected by economists in Europe. A year from now, they add, the dollar is likely to be lower than it is today, but it has not been as badly depressed by the fall of interest rates in the United States as they had feared. (Page D1.)

title: BRIEFING
description: T HE Reagan White House, which would have Americans do for others what they have come to expect the Government to do for them, has found a housing program for the poor that is a good example of the kind of voluntarism the President is promoting. The Administration has congratulated the people behind the program, and they, in turn, have invited President Reagan, or one of his representatives, to dedicate their newest housing project. The hitch is that the project is in Plains, Ga., about a mile down the road from the brick ranch house of former President Jimmy Carter.

title: Market Place
description: THE sale of the Harley Davidson motorcycle division by AMF last April was part of a larger plan - thus far successful - to achieve bigger returns on investment and cause AMF's shares to trade at a higher level.

title: Falcons 31, Oilers 27
description: HOUSTON (AP) - Steve Bartkowski riddled Houston's disorganized secondary with touchdown bombs of 43 yards to Alfred Jackson and 42 to Alfred Jenkins as Atlanta kept its playoff hopes alive.

title: HAROLD GABRILOVE
description: Harold Gabrilove, chairman of R.T.A. Distributors Inc. in Albany, a distributor of electronics products, died Thursday at his winter home in Boca Raton, Fla. Mr. Gabrilove, a resident of Albany, was 74 years old.

title: Typhoid Cases Traced To Food in Delicatessen
description: Federal inspectors found fecal bacteria in a Mexican specialty meat, ''barbacoa,'' at a delicatessen associated with what the authorities have called the worst typhoid epidemic related to restaurant food in the nation in this century, according to a report by the national Centers for Disease Control.

title: 3 Accused Americans Deported by Nicaragua
description: A Marine guard and two other American Embassy employees charged with assault and theft by Nicaraguan authorities were deported today to the United States.

title: LESS BANG FOR A BUCK
description: Francois de Rose, urbane former French Ambassador to NATO, is a linguist whose expertise includes all the arcane jargon of alliance plans and debates for decades. He was a vital link during the tense Gaullist years and never wavered in his conviction that Western security depends on NATO, in which France remains a disengaged member.

title: Permalens Account
description: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners has become agency for Permalens soft contact lenses from the Coopervision Optics division of Cooper Laboratories in Palo Alto, Calif. An additional part of the assignment is the promotion of the contact solutions and related products. The lens, which can be worn up to two weeks, was approved last January by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Packers 35, Vikings 23
description: Green Bay's Harlan Huckleby scored three touchdowns, and Lynn Dickey, making his first start in four weeks, threw three touchdown passes. The loss dropped Minnesota (7-6) into a tie with Detroit and Tampa Bay for first place in the National Football Conference's Central Division.

title: Return of the Turkey
description: Every year since 1963, the rookies on the Cleveland Browns have been sent into the northeastern Ohio countryside a few days before Thanksgiving to pick up turkeys for their veteran teammates. They are always told to drive to a farm near Garrettsville where free turkeys are waiting to be picked up.

title: Washington Watch; Reliability Of U.S. Data
description: WASHINGTON MORE and more questions are being asked about the reliability of Government statistics, those numbers flowing almost daily from such departments as Commerce, Labor, Treasury and others, that underlie just about all economic policy decisions.

title: Connie Rennick Bride Of Andrew Malcolm
description: Connie D'Amelio Rennick, widow of John Rennick, was married Saturday in St. Aidan's Anglican Church in Toronto to Andrew H. Malcolm. The Rev. Robert Mackie performed the ceremony.

title: Dancers to Explore The Federal Period
description: The Old Sturbridge Village Dancers and Musicians will appear Dec. 9 in ''A Flute, a Fiddle, a Federal Period Dance'' at the Abigail Adams Smith Museum, 421 East 61st Street.

title: GADFLY SAYS WHAT OTHERS WILL NOT
description: ''Leave the Constitution alone!'' The big man was on his feet, a prowling, growling gusher of Parisborn, Yale-educated indignation. The Senate was debating a proposal to endorse organized prayer in public schools, the sort of prayer outlawed by the Supreme Court 19 years ago, and Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut, Republican by tradition and iconoclast by instinct, was voicing his finely honed sense of outrage.

title: TEXAN TOP SPENDER ON '80 CANDIDATES
description: Cecil R. Haden, who donated almost $600,000, more than five times as much as any other individual to aid last year's Presidential candidates, says it was a ''once-in-alifetime gesture.''

title: 36 REGIONS ADDED TO U.S. CENSUS LIST
description: The Census Bureau has designated 35 regions in the United States and one in Puerto Rico as new metropolitan areas.

title: SAFETY DEFICIENT IN OFFICE TOWERS
description: Fire officials have found that five out of six high-rise office buildings in New York City failed to meet a September deadline for complying with the fire-safety law.

title: A STATE'S OPPORTUNITY TO IMPROVE THE CARE OF THE MENTALLY ILL
description: To the Editor:

title: SECURITY SET FOR REAGAN TRIP
description: Although security will be tight, safety measures for President Reagan's visit to Cincinnati Monday will not be affected by reports of Libyan assassination squads in the United States, a Secret Service agent says.

title: THREE CHILDREN SEVERELY BURNED IN BROOKLYN FIRE
description: Four children were burned, three of them critically, in a fire in a three-room apartment in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn shortly after midnight yesterday. Fire officials said they believed the blaze had been ignited by religious candles inside a closet.

title: Pope Entreats Leaders To Lift Specter of War
description: Pope John Paul II said today that he had sent personal messages to President Reagan and Leonid I. Brezhnev expressing hope that the Geneva disarmament talks would lift the ''specter of a possible nuclear conflict.''

title: Sly Williams Plays Key Role
description: Coach Red Holzman of the Knicks says he has ''great instincts, something that is difficult to coach.'' General Manager Eddie Donovan, sees him as being ''street-wise.'' Geoff Huston, the Cleveland Cavaliers' playmaker and a former Knick, says, ''He has the moves of the ultimate playground player.'' Maurice Lucas calls him ''the floating garbage man who knows how to get position and come up with the loose ball,'' adding, ''He has magnets that put the ball in his hands.''

title: News Summary; MONDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1981
description: International Soviet-American talks begin today in Geneva on reducing medium-range missiles in Europe. Leaders in other countries are watching to see if the superpowers are ready for serious negotiations. Diplomats expressed uncertainty over how these talks will fit with other arms control negotiations, and whether much progress can be made in the absence of overall improvement in relations between Washington and Moscow. (Page A1, Col. 1.) The subject of talks in Geneva are nuclear weapons classified as tactical, or theater, arms - weapons that would be used in tactical support of ground forces. The issue of exactly what kind of weapons can be so classified and thus included in the negotiations is expected by State and Defense Department officials to dominate the opening sessions. (A1:2.)

title: Oilers 10, Jets 2
description: Paul Coffey, a defenseman, scored two goals and had three assists, and Wayne Gretzky added a goal and three assists as the Oilers stretched their unbeaten streak to nine games. The goal was Gretzky's 31st and kept him on a record scoring pace.

title: NUCLEAR MISSILES ARE NOT JUST WEAPONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Snowfall Assures World Cup Skiing
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Nov. 29 (UPI) - The first World Cup skiing events of the season will take place here as scheduled starting Friday because heavy snow has fallen in the Savoy Alps over the last two days, organizers said today.

title: Making Trouble on Human Rights
description: The Reagan Administration is finally talking sense on human rights. A State Department memorandum asserts what should have been made plain months ago - that human rights is at the core of American foreign policy; that Washington should condemn violations even when the offending country is an ally; and that doing so necessarily ''means trouble.''

title: 30 Salvador Guerrillas Are Reported Killed
description: A combined force of 40 National Guardsmen and National Police killed 30 guerrillas in a clash five miles west of San Miguel, El Salvador's third largest city, the National Guard said over the weekend. There were no Government deaths, authorities said.

title: DRUG EXECUTIVE RUNS DISPUTED SLEEP PROGRAM
description: A New York insomnia program, assailed by state officials as a cover for the mass prescribing of the depressant methaqualone, is operated by a research director for one of the nation's largest pharmaceutical companies.

title: J.A. Stein, Port Analyst, Weds Brenna Freedman
description: Brenna Susan Freedman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Freedman of Hollywood, Calif., was married at the Harmonie Club in New York yesterday to Julian Allan Stein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Stein of Queens Village. Rabbi Jerome Davidson performed the ceremony.

title: TRAFFIC SLOWED TO A POST-TURKEY TROT
description: The Sunday after Thanksgiving, by tradition and billing the year's heaviest travel day, brought stand-up rides for many train passengers and traffic delays at bridges and tunnels yesterday as holiday travelers coped with getting back over the river and back through the trees - from Grandmother's house or elsewhere.

title: 13-Month-Old Missing In Miami Slayings
description: The police today investigated the slayings of six people at a town house in a guarded compound southwest of Miami.

title: Letter: On Selling Planes to Taiwan Stay Out of China's Civil War
description: To the Editor:

title: Hope for Villanova
description: The University of Villanova was never much of a football powerhouse, but for 87 years it fielded a team. Then last April, citing lack of money, the school outside Philadelphia announced that its football days were over.

title: Show Time Pay TV To Name New Agency
description: Show Time, jointly owned by Viacom International and Teleprompter, is leaving its agency, Scali, McCabe, Sloves, after a brief half-year stay.

title: City College Wins
description: Michael Richardson scored 23 points to lead City College over Lehman, 63-50, at the winner's gym yesterday. Leading by 22-18 at halftime, City College opened up a 13-point lead with seven minutes to go, and was never seriously threatened. Miles Reilly led Lehman with 17 points.

title: Leader of Panel on Nobel Peace Prize Is Resigning
description: After two years as chairman of the Norwegian committee that awards the Nobel Peace Prize, John Sanness has told Parliament that he plans to step down when his term expires at the end of the year.

title: Ina P. Sherman and Stanley Lane Wed; Stanley L. Lane, A Lawyer, Is Wed To Ina P. Sherman
description: At the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue yesterday Ina P. Sherman, daughter of Shirley Sherman of Roslyn, L.I., and the late Burt I. Sherman, was married to Stanley Lawrence Lane Jr., son of Dr. Lane of New York and the late Sylvia Lane. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Joseph P. Sternstein and Cantor Seymour Schwartzman, assisted by the bride's grandfather, Rabbi Yehudah Leib Silverberg.

title: Dollar Dips in Tokyo
description: The United States dollar opened at 215.50 yen today on the Tokyo foreign exchange market, down from Friday's close of 216.50 yen.

title: MUSIC: SEQUENTIA RETURNS TO THE 12TH CENTURY
description: century Saxon hermit, Saint Godric, and the lyrics of 13th-century German Spruchdichter, poets who dealt more with the world as it was than with the courtly conventions of the world as it should be.

title: U.S. ENVOY ARRIVES IN BEIRUT
description: President Reagan's special Middle East envoy, Philip C. Habib, arrived here today for another round of Middle East peace negotiations. Mr. Habib is expected to visit Syria, Israel, and possibly Saudi Arabia.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TIMER

title: RANGERS TIE ON ON PAVELICH GOAL
description: The consistent Rangers, who had won only one of their seven previous games, did not alter that trend last night. But third-period goals by Mike Rogers and Mark Pavelich gave them a 4-4 tie with the Quebec Nordiques at Madison Square Garden. The tie kept the weekend from being another gloomy one, but extended the Rangers nonwinning streak to five games.

title: Index; International
description: All is change at the unchanging Times of London A2 Habib in Beirut for more peace negotiations A4 Around the World A9 Famed South African mercenary jailed in hijacking A10 French government tackles so- cial security system A11 Unesco urges specific projects for journalists in third world A14 U.S. inquiry reported on sale of aircraft parts to Libya B10 Jaruzelski warns more strikes may lead to emergency state A13 Government/Politics Texan tops campaign contribu- tors with nearly $600,000 B9 Secret Service chief, H. Stuart Knight, is stepping down B11 Washington Talk Working profile: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. B8 Members of Congress come from diverse occupations B8 Calendar B8 Briefing B8 General Iowa's farming troubled by high costs and low profits A16 Around the Nation A16 The Region B2 Boys Choir of Harlem turns youthful energy to song B3 Three children are critically burned in Brooklyn fire B3 The City B3 Philadelphia transit system may die soon without funds B15 Census Bureau designates 36 new metropolitan areas B17 Shipwreck survivor clung to life- boat for 26 hours B17 Health/Science Drugs are an issue at the South Pole A7 SportsMonday Baseball: Dave Winfield reviews his first year as a Yankee C1 Basketball: Sly Williams plays a key role for the Knicks C9

title: Two Magazines Widen Interest in Exercise
description: Family Circle and Woman's Day magazines, the two major ''store books,'' seem to be in constant activity in their highly competitive arena.

title: CHINA'S CULTURAL DILEMMA
description: Like an animal that cannot make up its mind which direction to run in order to escape an oncoming vehicle, China's leaders appear unable to decide how to respond to the demands of their intelligentsia for greater freedom.

title: PLAYOFF HOPES FADE
description: For the San Francisco 49ers, it was a dream come true. For the Giants, it was a dream that all but ended. The 49ers, the surprise team of the season, beat the Giants, 17-10, today and became the first to win a divisional title in the National Football League. They have a 10-3 record, the National Conference's Western Division title and the first of the 10 berths in the playoffs.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt

title: Draft Bowl
description: Bad news for ''football widows'': add one more televised postseason bowl game to the January schedule. Through the courtesy and promotion of the Olympia Brewing Company, the Olympia Gold Bowl will debut at San Diego Stadium on Saturday, Jan. 16. Team National and Team American will each be made up of 33 of the nation's top senior football players, coached by Dick Vermeil of the Philadelphia Eagles and Don Coryell of the San Diego Chargers.

title: TRADERS FIND DOLLAR IS RESILIENT
description: Despite the dollar's fall on foreign-exchange markets in recent days, currency traders and economists here do not believe that the American currency is headed for a period of extreme weakness.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET OPEN TALKS TODAY ON NUCLEAR WEAPONRY IN EUROPE
description: The Geneva negotiations on theater nuclear forces in Western Europe are scheduled to deal with missiles, aircraft and eventually also with nuclear artillery.

title: THE INTERNATIONAL DRY CLEANER
description: People used to ring up Lady Henderson, wife of the British Ambassador, and ask, ''When is that Mr. Browne coming to town?''

title: SABRES RALLY TO SET BACK ISLANDERS, 5-2
description: The Islanders lost to the Buffalo Sabres, 5-2, tonight and that was a bit of an improvement. When the teams met three weeks ago, the Sabres won, 6-2.

title: SYMPHONY: Y ORCHESTRA GOES BAROQUE
description: LIKE Pergolesi's ''La Serva Padrona,'' which followed it by almost a decade, Georg Philipp Telemann's ''Pimpinone,'' a comic opera in three intermezzi written in 1725, establishes the classic opera buffa confrontation - an ambitious, physically well-endowed (and marriageable) young servant girl finds a lazy, financially well-endowed (and marriageable) old gentleman with a weakness for feminine beauty, and sets about turning his fortune into hers.

title: JARUZELSKI WARNS POLAND ON ENDING LABOR UNREST
description: Poland's official press agency, giving details of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's speech Saturday to the Communist Party Central Committee, said today that the Polish leader warned that strikes and anarchy must be halted or they would lead to a state of emergency.

title: Gas Price Drop Seen
description: Wholesale gasoline prices were dropped by some major oil companies in Western states last week and the declines should stimulate a decrease in prices to motorists, according to Dan Lundberg, an oil industry analyst. The price declines indicated a change in policy for some of the oil companies, which earlier had been relying on rebates to dealers. Retail gasoline prices move ''in virtual tandem with the wholesale drop,'' Mr. Lundberg said Saturday, because the price change is immediately reflected at pumps owned by the oil companies.
